title: U.S. Suppliers Get a Toyota Lecture
description: Two hundred executives of North American automobile parts makers fell into a stony silence here the other day when Osamu Obata, a Toyota Motor Company official with little use for traditional Japanese indirection, made it clear that what was good enough for Detroit would not cut it in Toyota City.

title: Fares to Rise 5.8% At United Airlines
description: United Airlines increased fares on most domestic flights by 5.8 percent, joining other leading carriers in a price increase prompted by a jump in fuel prices. A United spokeswoman, Sara Dornacker, said the carrier was raising its prices to match the fares of other airlines that announced increases earlier.

title: Home Improvement
description: WOODEN double-hung windows, named for the two sashes that slide up and down, are hard to seal against drafts. Even well-made ones eventually shrink and the wind blows air between sashes and frame.

title: U.S. Health Care Costs Soar, But Not as Much in New York
description: New York State has health care costs among the highest in the country, but the rate at which those costs are increasing is the slowest of all 50 states, according to new estimates of health care costs issued today.

title: Treasuries Gain in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates fell in light trading yesterday, as traders chose to concentrate on rumors rather than the reality of a record supply of new issues that will begin to flood the credit markets next week.

title: Layoffs by Bendix On Marines Work
description: The Bendix Field Engineering Corporation said it was laying off 300 workers because most of the equipment the company maintains locally for the United States Marines has been shipped to the Middle East. The company said the workers would be recalled as soon as the equipment is returned or replaced.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARUN SHOURIE, editor of The Indian Express, India's largest English-language newspaper, was dismissed on Monday, apparently because the newspaper's owner was unhappy with Mr. Shourie's criticism of Government policies.

title: 5 Die in 3 Traffic Accidents
description: Three teen-agers died today when their car collided with a tractor-trailer truck on Interstate 95, the first of three accidents in which five people were killed in Westchester County, the state police said. The first crash occurred at 12:05 A.M., when a car carrying four teen-agers collided with the truck near Exit 21, the police said. Forty minutes later, a car went off the Taconic State Parkway and struck a tree just south of the Campfire Road exit. At 1:45 A.M., a driver who had been stuck on I-95 in the first accident smashed into another tractor-trailer a mile from the first accident.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I like capitalism a lot. When I was in government I was never so rich and I never had the chance to play such a fascinating game as I do now." -- Jerzy Urban, former spokesman for the Communist Government of Poland. [ A4:3. ]

title: Harvard Economist To Join World Bank
description: Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard professor and Keynesian economist who specializes in tax, labor and financial issues and who served as Michael S. Dukakis's chief economic adviser during his 1988 Presidential bid, is joining the World Bank as vice president and chief economist.

title: Verdict Against Tyson
description: A jury decided yesterday that the former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson fondled a woman at a Manhattan dance club in 1988 and awarded the woman $100 in compensatory damages.

title: For Sale: A Century of Modern Design
description: A drawing of a futuristic car that doubled as a boat, a seven-foot-high cast-aluminum statue of a wrestler, a swivel-top chess table by Isamu Noguchi -- these are some of the objects visitors can expect to see at "Modernism: A Century of Style and Design, 1860-1960," which opens to the public today at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

title: New United Air Executive Plans to Build Brand Loyalty
description: UNITED AIR LINES, America's largest carrier, has big ambitions. So does Adam M. Aron, its new senior vice president for marketing, who starts work on Monday when he leaves his current earthbound employer, Hyatt Hotels.

title: U.S. Preparing U.N. Draft On Claims Against Baghdad
description: The Bush Administration is preparing a new United Nations Security Council resolution requiring governments to earmark frozen Iraqi assets to meet future compensation claims by victims of its invasion of Kuwait, American officials said today.

title: Banning the A-Word
description: There are three ways your average 16-year-old sexually active girl approaches gynecological care.

title: 3 Youths Stabbed, One Fatally, in Subways
description: Three teen-agers were stabbed yesterday, one fatally, in the subway system in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, the police said.

title: Bridge
description: After almost a year of play, the New Jersey Double Knockout Team Championship ended a week ago in a victory for Eileen Brenner and Michael Pickert, both of Livingston, N.J., and Barbara Tepper and Lester Sokolower, both of Verona, N.J. Playing in Clark, N.J., they won the final by defeating a group led by Abe Pineles of Yardley, Pa.

title: Currents; Rich Looks That Don't Take Riches
description: THE post-modernists promoted the addition of old-fashioned architectural details to naked 20th-century rooms. Charming as that was, it was also expensive.

title: Flights to Be Cut By America West
description: America West Airlines will freeze hiring and eliminate some flights after reporting a $22 million loss for the third quarter of 1990. The company is trying to cut costs, which have escalated becuase of the rise in the price of jet fuel, said Al Frei, the airline's chief financial officer.

title: How to Rattle Iraq
description: President Bush is clearly seeking ways to put new pressure on Saddam Hussein. But he's floundering. He warns Iraq that he's prepared to attack, and snarls at mistreatment of American hostages. In the next breath, he tells Congress that U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf are in no imminent danger of war. He can't have it both ways and still send a credible message.

title: Review/Dance; Many Moods Of a Company From Jamaica
description: The National Dance Theater Company of Jamaica is a troupe with a long and honorable history. Established by Rex Nettleford and Eddy Thomas in 1962, the company is notable for its vibrant performers and for the intelligence of its repertory. But Mr. Nettleford nearly undid all that with a program that was far too long, presented Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: Italy to Aid Hostages' Kin
description: Reacting to protests that it has not done enough to free Italians trapped in Iraq, the Government approved a draft law today to give financial help to the hostages' dependents.

title: Wesleyan-Williams: It's a Perfect Pairing
description: Wesleyan and Williams will play each other for the 96th time at Williamstown, Mass., on Saturday and the event this time is different. Why?

title: Currents; Cards to Shuffle And to Build With
description: CARDSHARPS beware. These days, not all decks stack up, at least not a new one by the artist Donald Sultan or a recently reissued 1952 design by Charles and Ray Eames.

title: Review/Music; Mendelssohn's 'Scottish' Symphony as He Heard It
description: With the growing popularity of original-instruments performances of 19th-century compositions, a backlash is brewing from jealous standard-instruments performers, polemicists from within the movement and plain old thoughtful listeners, dismayed at gushing hype. Even Roger Norrington and his London Classical Players, recently hailed as the best of the bunch, have received their share of brickbats.

title: Anti-Zionism Prevents Solution to the Palestinian Problem; No Linkage in Time
description: To the Editor:

title: ASK Computer Dissenter Fails
description: ASK Computer Systems Inc., a leading maker of software for automating manufacturing, said today that an attempt by a dissident stockholder to gain control of its board had failed.

title: Review/Fashion; Spring Mood: Simple to Grand
description: SPORTSWEAR and the rarer forms of style were both acknowledged as the spring fashion openings reached their midpoint in New York yesterday.

title: A West Coast Composer Looks to the Far East
description: The California composer Lou Harrison, whose "Last Symphony" will receive its first performance tomorrow night as part of a three-concert Brooklyn Philharmonic/Next Wave event at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, had his links at one time to New York. He lived here in the 1940's, composing and organizing concerts and even writing music criticism for The New York Herald-Tribune when Virgil Thomson was that paper's chief critic.

title: Burglar Ransacks Files at Nominee's Home
description: The campaign organization of Oregon's Democratic senatorial nominee said today that an office at his home near here had been burglarized by someone who stole computer disks containing campaign material and ransacked his files.

title: Cambridge Journal; As Saudi Prince Lingers, The Red Carpet Fades
description: Three months ago, when a wealthy Saudi prince and his entourage moved into the top two floors of the Charles Hotel here, this college town gave them a royal welcome.

title: WIC: It Saves Lives and Money
description: Congress knows the worth of WIC, the remarkable Federal food plan for poor pregnant nursing women and their children. It has just increased spending for the program to $2.3 billion, up $135 million from last year. But only 19 states and the District of Columbia contribute their own funds to the program, whose initials stand for Women-Infants-Children. The other states are making a mistake. What they're saving by not giving to WIC, they're more than losing in Medicaid outlays.

title: Market Place; Drought May Hurt Some California Bonds
description: The drought afflicting California is starting to send an uneasy rumble through the municipal bond market, as some analysts and investors question whether the long dry spell will make it harder for thousands of local government units to repay billions of dollars worth of bonds they sold to the public.

title: Berlin, the Capital, Fears for Future
description: Nearly a month after unification, this sprawling city of more than three million people is still struggling to become the united Germany's capital in more than name alone.

title: INSIDE
description: New Barriers for Refugees As legal obstacles to their exit from Eastern Europe fall, many hopeful emigrants are finding new barriers erected by the West. Page A13. Women and Exercise A study shows that women who exercise are no more likely to have menstrual problems than those who do not exercise. Sports Pages, B13. Venereal Disease and AIDS Chancroid, a little-known disease, has become a chief villain in the global AIDS epidemic. Health, page B12.

title: MOLDAVIA AVERTS ETHNIC VIOLENCE
description: Nationalist rivalries seethed again today in the Soviet republic of Moldavia as angry crowds of demonstrators gathered at border checkpoints, but violence was averted.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Lifetime Television, a venture of Hearst Corp., ABC and Viacom Inc., New York, appointed Kristin Dean FitzGerald senior vice president in charge of sales. * Moore Handley Inc., Birmingham, Ala., a maker of industrial supplies, named Gordon K. Johnston vice president of merchandising. James A. Tucker was named vice president, overseeing major and corporate accounts. * Paramount Communications Inc., New York, appointed Alan Cole-Ford vice president of corporate development. * RJR Nabisco Inc., New York, named Robert S. Roath vice president and corporate controller. * Sonoco Products Co., Hartsville, S.C., producers of cones and containers, appointed Alexander Watson senior vice president. * TRW Space and Technology Group, Redondo Beach, Calif., a unit of TRW Inc., Cleveland, appointed Dr. George Gleghorn vice president and chief engineer. * U S West Inc., Englewood, Colo., named Tracie A. Muesing vice president of quality.

title: Blues' Star Is Looking Like a Million
description: With his game-winning goal Tuesday night in Detroit, Brett Hull of St. Louis has scored 15 times in the first 12 games of the season. That pace over the 80-game schedule would give him 100; the record is 92, set by Wayne Gretzky in 1981-82.

title: Postal Service Starts Campaign on 'L.A. Law'
description: The United States Postal Service will appeal to the sentiments of viewers of the NBC program "L.A. Law" tonight when it screens its new network campaign for the first time.

title: Questions Arise on Whether the Publisher Is Truly in Charge
description: In a career studded with successes, James Hoge probably received his biggest professional compliment early in 1984, when his perennial adversary, the Tribune Company, asked him to return to his hometown to take over the company's most troubled asset, The Daily News.

title: Review/Television; Jennings on Abortion: Looking at Both Sides
description: The news from ABC tonight at 10 is that abortion is a hot election issue. Peter Jennings starts "The New Civil War" with the announcement that it is "the most explosive social and political issue in America." More socially explosive than race? More politically explosive than tax increases? Well, a little hype is apparently necessary to justify an hourlong report on the networks these days, and this one offers interesting insights and asides on how uncivilly the abortion war is being fought in this voting season.

title: Retailer's Units Post Declines
description: Marks & Spencer, the British retailer that owns Brooks Brothers and Kings Supermarkets in the United States, said yesterday in London that Brooks Brothers' operating profits had plunged to $1.5 million in the year that ended March 31, from $8.1 million the year before. There was no explanation for the delay in filing the report.

title: Events: Design Lectures And a Fall Flower Show
description: Design Talk, Architectural League of New York, the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 980-3767.

title: Corrections
description: An article this week on the "On Your Own" page of SportsMonday, about spectators' encouragement of runners in the New York City Marathon, misidentified Dr. Ira D. Glick. He is a psychiatrist, not a psychologist.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the race for the United States Senate from North Carolina referred incorrectly in some copies to blacks' history of service in the United States Senate. Harvey Gantt would be the second black elected to the Senate since Reconstruction; the first was Edward W. Brooke, who represented Massachusetts from 1967 to 1979.

title: And Now, A Bahamas Bailout
description: While everybody has been worrying that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits, will start down the rabbit hole that devoured the fund that insured savings and loans, the F.D.I.C. has been paying off uninsured deposits held by foreigners, some of them very sleazy foreigners, in an overseas branch of a minor-league and pretty sleazy insolvent American bank.

title: Silber Grabs Attention But Not All the Backing
description: At a backstreet diner here in downtown Boston, where hundreds of city workers, lawyers and bankers rub elbows daily, conversations usually revolve around the Celtics or the daily specials scribbled above the cash register.

title: In New Haven, 2 Opposites Wage Shrill Fight for Congress
description: To listen to the candidates in the Third Congressional District, the fiercely contested race either pits a moderate Republican state senator against a "radical ultra-liberal feminist" from Washington or a moderate Democratic fund-raiser against an "extremist ultra-conservative career politician."

title: Consumer Spending Jumps 1.1%
description: Consumer spending jumped 1.1 percent in September, the Government said today, outpacing a five-tenths of 1 percent growth in personal income and contributing to the lowest savings rate in three years.

title: Old Disease Emerges as a Factor in AIDS Spread
description: The man was a prototypical patron of Nairobi's crowded city clinic for sexually transmitted diseases. An unmarried worker 31 years old, he had had sexual relations with about 20 women in the last year, he said. No, he never used condoms. He said he believed a recent "pickup" gave him the painful genital infection that brought him in, an oozing sore the size of a dime.

title: Hawaii Race Tests Democratic Hold
description: Two former schoolteachers are in a tight but polite race to represent Hawaii in the United States Senate, and the results may teach something of a lesson about the future of the politically remote and inbred but fast-changing island state.

title: Fed Notes New Signs Of Distress
description: The economy continues to weaken, particularly in retailing, but apparently not to the point that would call for energetic relaxation of monetary policy, a Federal Reserve survey indicated today.

title: Rival Shiite Groups in Lebanon Agree to a Truce
description: Rival Shiite Muslim factions that have been battling for three years for control of southern Lebanon agreed today to a cease-fire and said they would allow army troops to be deployed in a region near Israel.

title: Wing Toy, 64, Dies; Engineer and Inventor
description: Wing N. Toy, an electrical engineer who was with A. T. & T. Bell Laboratories for 37 years and held 28 patents in communications applications, died on Sunday at Evanston Hospital in Illinois. He was 64 years old and lived in Glen Ellyn, Ill.

title: Review/Film; Choreographer's Vision Of Antigone's Tragedy
description: One wants to like Amy Greenfield's new "Antigone/Rites for the Dead." Ms. Greenfield, a dancer turned film and video maker, has labored long in the field. But the 85-minute color film, which opens at the Anthology Film Archives today , is a disappointment.

title: Life After Death for Luxury Luggage
description: WITH stacks of suitcases by Vuitton, Gucci and Mark Cross, Lou Jacob's upstairs workshop could be a luxury luggage store, if only the bags weren't so battered. Handles are missing, zippers are broken and leather corners are shredded. But by the time the bags leave the Fordham Repair Center, they should look almost like new, said Mr. Jacob, who started this luggage and handbag repair business in 1953.

title: Just Like Old Times At Georgia Tech
description: When Bobby Ross left Maryland in 1987 to became the eighth football coach in Georgia Tech's football history, at the time 95 years, there was every reason to believe that the rebuilding task facing Ross would last well into the 1990's.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: Net Income Percent July-Sept. Change 1990 From '89 Bethlehem Steel Corp. $ 10,100,000 - 78.5 Eastman Kodak Co. (206,000,000) -- General Motors Corp. (1,980,000,000) -- Golden Nugget Inc. 5,200,000 *-- Horsham Corp. 40,300,000 + 269.7 National Steel Corp. 11,400,000 - 9.5 NL Industries Inc. 16,400,000 - 75.1 Wendy's International Inc. 12,700,000 + 46.0 Wm. Wrigley Jr. Co. 31,000,000 + 2.6 See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Currents; Fillips and Frills, Detailed in Wood
description: FOR builders, contractors and amateur home decorators Building Details is the stuff of dreams.

title: Interpublic, Omnicom Gain
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies and the Omnicom Group have both reported higher profits in the third quarter.

title: New Chairman for Public Library
description: Marshall Rose will succeed Andrew Heiskell as chairman of the New York Public Library's board of trustees, pending his formal election by the board on Nov. 14, the library announced yesterday.

title: The Second Front
description: What European member of NATO has the largest standing army? What NATO nation borders on Iraq?

title: Personal Health
description: In my eighth month of pregnancy in 1969, my obstetrician ordered an abdominal X-ray to confirm his suspicion that I was having twins. Although I feared possible fetal harm from the radiation, I knew the information the X-ray would reveal could be very important to the way the rest of my pregnancy was managed to insure my babies' well-being.

title: Migrants From Eastern Europe Find Journey Ends Just Short of the West
description: The Soviet Army pulled out of the dilapidated barracks here a few months ago and went home, but now new invaders from the East -- some Russians among them -- have taken their places.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Canadiens Beat Whalers, 4-2 Russ Courtnall outskated two Hartford defensemen to score twice and help Montreal to the victory last night in Hartford. The loss was the Whalers' fifth in a row. Courtnall tied the score, 1-1, 14 minutes 25 seconds into the game, then put his team ahead to stay at 8:43 of the second period. (AP) Sabres 3, Bruins 3: Returning to Boston's lineup after a four-game absence with a shoulder injury, Ray Bourque set up Bob Carpenter's game-tying goal midway through the third period in Buffalo. Carpenter tied the game at 10:15 of the third period, beating Reggie Lemelin with a shot on which Bourque screened his goaltender. Rick Vaive had given the Sabres a 3-2 lead at 8:35. Craig Janney and Dave Christian and also scored for the Bruins. Aleksandr Mogilny and Mikko Makela were Buffalo's other goal scorers. Boston is 0-5-1 in its last six road games. (AP) Jets 1, Oilers 0: Pat Elynuik scored 23 seconds into overtime and Bob Essensa stopped 24 shots for his third career shutout as visiting Winnipeg handed Edmonton its second consecutive 1-0 loss. The two games marked the first time the Oilers have failed to score in consecutive games. They lost by 1-0 to Washington on Sunday night when Michal Pivonka scored 2:11 into the game on the Capitals' first shot. (AP)

title: D.E.A. to Review Claims of Role By Agent in the Pan Am Bombing
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration said today that it would review persistent claims that an American who died in the terrorist bombing of Pan American Flight 103 in 1988 was an agency informant who smuggled the bomb onto the aircraft in the mistaken belief that it was a shipment of heroin.

title: Douglas Edwards Memorial
description: CBS is to hold a memorial service for Douglas Edwards, the first network television news anchor, tomorrow at 11 A.M. at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. The scheduled speakers are Don Hewitt, the executive producer of "60 Minutes"; Dan Rather, the anchor of the "CBS Evening News"; the CBS News reporter Charles Osgood, and the president of the CBS Broadcast Group, Howard Stringer. Mr. Edwards, whose career with CBS News covered 46 years, died of cancer on Oct. 13 at the age of 73.

title: So Long, Faux: New Materials Woo Designers
description: WE are (thank you, Madonna) living in a material world -- materials like dichroic glass and hand-woven bauxite.

title: BLACK AIDE QUITS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: For more than a decade, Daveyton's Mayor, Tom Boya, was Pretoria's evidence of the legitimacy of the municipal councils running its segregated black townships.

title: TOLL IN INDIA CLASH AT MOSQUE RISES
description: Northern India was relatively quiet today, as Hindu militant organizations and the Government claimed victory in the confrontation Tuesday at a disputed mosque in the holy city of Ayodhya.

title: The Homeless Sue for Toilets in New York
description: The dearth of public lavatories -- like incivility and high rents -- has long been one of the unpleasant axioms of New York City life. A lawsuit filed yesterday by homeless people seeking clean and safe public toilets demands an official answer.

title: Yankees Seem Bearish on the Market
description: The Yankees of past winters -- free spending, big talking and open to risk-taking when it came to free agents -- are apparently gone forever. The new direction in the post-George Steinbrenner era is fiscal responsibility and wiser investing, which could mean the team may choose not to join the bidding for Darryl Strawberry, which will begin next week.

title: Talking Deals; Pathe's Troubles In MGM/UA Bid
description: IF all goes according to schedule, the Pathe Communications Corporation will complete its $1.3 billion acquisition of the MGM/UA Communications Corporation today. But judging by the troubled history of the deal, all may very well not go according to schedule.

title: Moving to Slow the Revolving Door
description: From the "Great Barbecue" scandals of the Ad ministration of Ulysses S. Grant to Teapot Dome to vicuna coats, the United States has swung from long spasms of concern about corruption to equally long periods of complacency.

title: Politics of Rage Dominate Contest in Massachusetts
description: In this state where voters seem implacably angry, John R. Silber is the prophet of the politics of rage.

title: 472 of the Rich Avoided Taxes
description: Some wealthy Americans are still able to scrape together enough deductions to avoid paying any Federal income tax, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

title: Runners Have No Fear Before Hitting the Streets
description: More than 25,000 runners, a record, are expected to start the 21st New York City Marathon on Sunday. Nearly 24,000 others wanted to but were rejected for logistical reasons. That's a record, too. If New York's crime, urban squalor, high prices and economic decay have made headlines around the world, marathon runners from beyond the metropolitan area do not seem overly concerned. Maybe they have been too busy training.

title: More Newsroom Workers Return To News, but Its Delivery Is Spotty
description: The Daily News, apparently digging in for a long war of attrition with its unions, won over more striking newsroom employees yesterday, including four writers for the paper's prestigious sports section who crossed picket lines as some colleagues stared in horror.

title: Wertheim Is Pulling Out Of Primary Dealer Business
description: Furthering a contraction in the Government securities business, Wertheim Schroeder & Company announced yesterday that it will cease operations as a primary dealer in Government securities, effective immediately.

title: Money Fund Yields Drop
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were narrowly down in the week ended yesterday.

title: Polish and German Officials Said to Agree on Border Pact
description: Polish and German negotiators were reported today to have agreed on a treaty confirming their present border on the Oder and Neisse rivers, a pact that would end uncertainty dating from World War II.

title: Accounts
description: * Carewell Industries, Fairfield, N.J., to Baron & Zaretsky Advertising, for its Dentax toothbrush account, with billings of $1.5 million. * The United States Mint's Mount Rushmore commemorative coin program, to Kobs & Draft, Chicago, for advertising, and Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, Chicago, for public relations. The budget is $2.5 million. * Colonial Penn Life Insurance, Philadelphia, to Wunderman Worldwide, New York, for direct response media, with undisclosed billings.

title: Nets Might Run, but They Can't Hide the Truth
description: There is no disguising the truth about the New Jersey Nets. No slick promotional campaign featuring Derrick Coleman is going to fool anyone.

title: Part of Alaska Pipeline to Be Unearthed for Tests
description: Nine underground sections of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline are to be unearthed and examined as a result of allegations that workers checking for rust and cracks lacked training, used drugs and alcohol on the job and filed inaccurate test results.

title: Profits Up 45% At Wendy's
description: The profits of Wendy's International Inc. increased by 45 percent for the third quarter, the fast-food company said today.

title: Intense Exercise Safe for Women, Study Says
description: Women who exercise, even those dedicated women who run marathons, are no more likely to have menstrual disturbances than women who do not exercise, a new study has found.

title: Advocates for Homeless Fault Housing Plan
description: Advocates for homeless families this week sharply criticized the city's new apartment-lottery program for welfare and working-poor families and said the city plan takes apartments that had been set aside for the homeless away from families who need them most.

title: Metro Matters; Mayoral Summit: Hoping to Shape Urban Agenda
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins is hoping to accomplish what none of his predecessors have been able to do for at least two decades: rally fellow mayors of major cities to help shape a realistic national urban agenda.

title: Will W.B.C. Strip Holyfield of Title?
description: Will the World Boxing Council strip Evander Holyfield of his newly won heavyweight championship?

title: School Board Outlines Plan For Deep Cuts
description: In bleak and ominous tones, the Board of Education warned yesterday that meeting City Hall's budget-cutting target of $94 million would mean layoffs of 4,400 teachers, a disruption of classrooms across the city and the virtual elimination of services ranging from guidance to sports.

title: Texaco Ads On Energy
description: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday that it was beginning a national advertising campaign to urge consumers to use less gasoline, natural gas, heating oil and electricity.

title: CHRONICLE
description: STEPHEN J. RICHARD, the managing director of the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, will move to Washington in February as the executive director of the Arena Stage, that theater company announced yesterday. The appointment of Mr. Richard, 39 years old, completes a new management team that includes DOUGLAS C. WAGER , who will become artistic director, and GUY BERQUIST , who will be general manager.

title: The Rocket: Caring, Shy, Compelling
description: Lou Holtz likes to joke, "I didn't realize how fast Rocket was until I saw him playing tennis by himself." But for all the speed and success of Raghib Ismail as Notre Dame's tailback, slotback, wide receiver, kickoff returner and punt returner, his coach is surprised not so much by what Rocket does in a game as by what he does in practice.

title: Police Study Death of Baby Unhooked From Vital Tube
description: The police are investigating the death of an 8-month-old boy at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx that occurred after a breathing tube keeping him alive was apparently pulled out.

title: Coming-Out Party for Blooms and Edibles
description: Flower and vegetable displays lined the banquet room at Tavern on the Green and spilled onto a sunny terrace last week, a feast for the eyes as well as the palate.

title: Filming in New York May Be Disrupted By a Labor Dispute
description: With the expiration last night of a contract between the major Hollywood film and television producers and a production crafts union, New York City is facing a slowdown in an industry that is a source not only of prestige but of badly needed jobs and revenue as well.

title: Tissue From Aborted Fetus Is Tested in Rape Case
description: Prosecutors in Corpus Christi are using DNA tests on tissue samples from the aborted fetus of a 13-year-old girl to try to prosecute her uncle, who is charged with raping her.

title: Door Reopens on Prairie School Heyday
description: A small, subdued house in Minneapolis here has won resounding applause from students of Prairie School architecture. The Purcell-Cutts House opened to the public this fall after four years of restoration by the Minneapolis Institute of Arts and the architectural firm of MacDonald & Mack.

title: A Room for 2 Aboard the Overnight Sleeper
description: SPENDING the night in a luxuriously appointed sleeping car on one of those trains that criss-crossed the country in the 40's is the stuff of old movies these days.

title: Carl Barus, 71, Dies; Engineering Professor
description: Carl Barus, professor emeritus of engineering at Swarthmore College, died Monday at Hahnemann University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 71 years old and lived in Swarthmore, Pa.

title: Seafood Is Safer per Serving Than Poultry
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lack of Ads Shuts Monthly
description: Just three years short of its centennial, Business Month magazine suspended publication yesterday. It called itself the oldest business magazine in the country.

title: Unified Albany Supports Spending Cuts to Close Budget Gap
description: In an uncharacteristic display of unity, legislative leaders said today that they concurred with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's dim assessment of the state's finances and approved of plans to close the budget gap through spending cuts alone.

title: No Time to Give Raises to City Workers
description: To the Editor: While I agree with "Mr. Dinkins Faces Fiscal Reality" (editorial, Oct. 18), it does not go far enough.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES SCHOOL BIAS SUIT
description: Sixteen years after the Justice Department accused the state of Louisiana of running a dual system of higher education, one for blacks and one for whites, a Federal judge has reluctantly dismissed the Government's case.

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column on Sept. 4, about a summer camp in New Jersey for children with AIDS, referred incorrectly to its rarity in the eastern United States. A reader has recently written to point out that there is at least one other, Camp Stepping Stones in Providence, R.I., sponsored by the Brown University Center for Public Service and the Family AIDS Center for Treatment and Support. The column also listed the New Jersey camp's sponsors incompletely.They include the Sunburst National AIDS Project of Petaluma, Calif.

title: Currents; Art to Capture Bright Young Eyes
description: WHEN she was in law school, Kimberly K. Wheeler drew up a business plan for a children's art gallery. After graduating,Ms. Wheeler was interviewed by 19 investment banks but decided to start her fantasy business instead.

title: Vestron Deal Is Negotiated
description: Live Entertainment Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire substantially all of the assets and liabilities of Vestron Inc. in exchange for a package of Live Entertainment equity securities.

title: Maxwell Joins Rockets
description: Vernon Maxwell, a guard with two years remaining on his contract and a base pay of $200,000 this season, yesterday ended a monthlong holdout and rejoined the Houston Rockets.(AP)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Dow Slides 5.69 on Poor Economic Reports
description: Stocks seesawed yesterday in quiet trading amid new signs that a recession could be on the way.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARUN SHOURIE, editor of The Indian Express, India's largest English-language newspaper, was dismissed on Monday, apparently because the newspaper's owner was unhappy with Mr. Shourie's criticism of Government policies.

title: Freer Gallery of Art Is Pledged $1.5 Million
description: The Freer Gallery of Art, a Smithsonian Institution museum that houses one of the finest collections of Asian art, has received a pledge of $1.5 million from a Japanese corsortium, gallery officials announced Monday.

title: Behind the Tribune Gamble
description: Tribune Company officials say they can emerge from the bitter Daily News strike with a revamped paper. Others are not so sure. Page B2.

title: Reuters Planning To Cut 300 Jobs
description: Reuters, the international news agency and financial-services company, said it would cut 300 jobs, 200 of them in Britain, because of "difficult and unsettled" market conditions. Reuters said the cuts would be in the central corporate departments covering finance, marketing and administration. A small number of editorial jobs also could be affected. The layoffs represent 6 percent of the British payroll and 3 percent of the worldwide work force.

title: More Prisons Using Iron Hand to Control Inmates
description: After the killing of a guard at Folsom Prison in 1987, the warden ordered all furniture removed from the cells in the violence control unit, the isolated "prison within a prison" that is reserved for unruly inmates. The beds in the cells were replaced with concrete slabs, and the electrical outlets were sealed with epoxy. Some inmates who had caused trouble were forced to wear leg irons and handcuffs while they exercised in the prison yard.

title: Bush Weighs a Veto of Sanctions For the Spread of Chemical Arms
description: The White House said today that President Bush may veto legislation imposing sanctions on companies and governments that contribute to the spread of chemical and biological weapons.

title: A Police Officer Is Wounded And a Man Is Found Dead
description: A New York City police officer was shot and wounded last night in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said, and a man they say might be a suspect in the shooting was dead at the scene.

title: Pele One More Time
description: Pele, the most famous player in soccer history, made an apppearance in an exhibition match at San Siro Stadium in Milan, Italy, last night to celebrate his 50th birthday.

title: Foreign Depositors
description: To the Editor:

title: Birth and Life of a Political Ad: A Negative Message With Common Themes
description: Bathed in the ochre hues of the City Council's chambers in this fading industrial city, a voter ambled to the microphone and attacked the Republican running for Congress as being "Ed DiPrete's handpicked candidate."

title: Leyland Is Selected N.L. Manager of Year
description: Jim Leyland, who turned the Pittsburgh Pirates into contenders and guided them through the pressure of a pennant race, was selected as the National League manager of the year yesterday.

title: Republican Makes List A Bit Too Democratic
description: Representative Bill Green of the East Side of Manhattan is spending about $500,000 to defeat a Democratic-Liberal opponent, Fran Reiter, who has less than $20,000 for her campaign.

title: Yonkers Sewage Plant Befouls a Community
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 New Jersey High School Students Are Accused of Raping Girl, 15
description: Five Monroe Township High School students were arrested today and accused of raping a 15-year-old girl in a wooded area of the township on Oct. 16.

title: Prominent Dissident Is Freed by Beijing
description: The Chinese authorities have released Wang Ruowang, a prominent writer and dissident, after 16 months of detention, but he remains subject to some restrictions, his wife says.

title: Currents; Daily Life Of Fine Old Eggs
description: "WHEN people think of Russian Imperial furniture and objects, they think of individual, very grandiose objects like Faberge eggs," said Peter Schaffer, an owner of A la Vieille Russie, a Manhattan gallery that specializes in Russian jewelry and artwork. "But few people really have any idea how these pieces were used."

title: Computer Study of Cuomo Donors Finds Correlation With Contracts
description: Wells, Rich, Greene, the advertising agency, has a $30 million state contract for the "I Love New York" campaign and hopes to renew the contract next March. The agency has contributed at least $42,000 to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's campaigns over the last eight years, including $20,000 this year.

title: 2 Homosexuals Say U.S. Agents Assaulted Them
description: Two gay men plan to file suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan today, charging that they were beaten by three Federal drug agents after a minor traffic incident in Manhattan two years ago.

title: Bergevin Traded
description: Marc Bergevin, a defenseman playing this season with the Capital District Islanders of the American Hockey League, was traded yesterday by the Islanders to the Hartford Whalers for future considerations. His contract was assigned to the Springfield Indians of the A.H.L., a Whaler affiliate. (AP)

title: Guessing Game as Giants' Defense Prepares for Colts
description: The Giants (7-0) started preparations today for Monday night's game against the Colts (2-5) in Indianapolis not knowing who would play quarterback for the Colts.

title: Key Rates
Aqueduct Opens on Reflective Note
description: It looked like a normal day at Aqueduct yesterday: the hurly-burly in the saddling enclosure before the first race; an official calling out, "Riders Up! God bless," and the murmur of the fans as the horses took the track while the trumpeter played "first call."

title: Gregory P. Sprissler, Educator, 83
description: Brother Gregory Paul Sprissler, president of LaSalle University from 1945 to 1952, died Saturday at Germantown Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: BUSH INTENSIFIES A WAR OF WORDS AGAINST THE IRAQIS
description: Early this morning, President Bush paused on his way to a political fund-raising breakfast in Virginia to declare that he had "had it" with Iraq's treatment of American hostages and diplomats.

title: Michelin's Revamping May Cut 900 Workers
description: Michelin, the venerable French company that became the world's largest tire maker through an acquisition earlier this year, said yesterday that it was establishing a orth American holding company and laying off as many as 900 salaried workers.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about turmoil at Random House reported the departure of Joni Evans as publisher and her replacement by Harold Evans. It cited speculation about dissatisfactions with her performance, but because of an editing error it omitted some comments by Miss Evans.

title: Looking Ahead at Fay's After a Top Resignation
description: Fay's Inc., a drug-store chain in New York and Pennsylvania, has said that its president and chief operating officer, Lawrence J. Rose, has resigned to pursue other interests.

title: Why Young Children Are So Vulnerable to Lead
description: Lead is a toxin that is particularly harmful to the developing brain and nervous system, causing serious and largely irreversible damage in children at relatively low levels of exposure.

title: School Officials Vent Anger on New Jersey Financing Law
description: The anger, resentment and problems generated by New Jersey's new school-financing law swirled here today at the opening of a three-day convention of the state's school superintendents and school board members.

title: Review/Cabaret; Sylvia Syms's Many Modes
description: Some of the finest popular singers are vocal virtuosos. Others are dramatic interpreters. Then there are the artists, like Sylvia Syms, who sing from where they live, with only a thin protective shield separating them from the raw emotions of their material.

title: Catholic High School to Close
description: St. Mary's High School, New Haven's only Roman Catholic high school, will close in June because of declining enrollment, financial problems and the difficulty of retaining nuns to staff the school, officials said. The sisters who run the girls school reached a consensus on Tuesday night to close it."

title: Paul Bercow, Executive, 63
description: Paul Bercow, a chemical company executive, died on Monday at his home in Scotch Plains, N.J. He was 63 years old.

title: MINIMUM-TAX PROVISIONS EXPECTED TO SNARE MANY
description: Many taxpayers who have not had to worry about the alternative minimum tax may find themselves trapped by it in future years as a result of the deficit-reduction package approved by Congress on Saturday, tax professionals warn.

title: News's Owners Speak Softly but Take a Hard Line
description: From the 65-year-old Gothic tower of the Tribune Company, a sober place that respects prudence, the message is quietly stated but clear: The owners of The Daily News plan to hold on to their tabloid, defy strikers, revamp the newspaper's production and so, in effect, transform the way the press works in New York City.

title: Judicial Choices, and Non-Choices
description: Of this year's 52 judicial races in New York City, only 2 are seriously competitive. That woeful statistic underscores the need to reform judicial selection.

title: Despite Law, Study Finds, Water In U.S. Schools May Contain Lead
description: Four years after the Government imposed tough rules to limit the amount of lead in drinking water, Federal auditors warn that hundreds of thousands of American children may still be drinking lead-contaminated water at school.

title: LOSES $1.98 BILLION
description: The General Motors Corporation, acknowledging that it would not soon recapture lost ground in a glutted market and wary of harder times in the industry, moved today to close up to nine factories that employ tens of thousands of workers. The closings, which will cost G.M. billions of dollars, resulted in its biggest quarterly loss ever.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in Business Day on Friday about the pre-sentence hearing of Michael R. Milken misstated the period during which an illegal securities trading scheme was said to have taken place between Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the Columbia Savings and Loan Association. A witness said it began before 1983 and ended shortly after the 1986 arrest of Dennis B. Levine, a former Drexel investment banker, on charges of insider trading.

title: Big Figure For Phils' .268 Hitter
description: If anyone thought this year's free-agent market would be less lucrative than last year's economic explosion, the contract that Darren Daulton and the Philadelphia Phillies agreed to yesterday should signal otherwise.

title: American Airlines
description: American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, is offering $161.4 million in equipment trust certificates in a multi-part sale. The certificates are backed by Boeing 757's and DC-9's airliners. The financing is through an underwriting group headed by Goldman, Sachs & Company, which priced the certificates at par. Maturities range from 11.02 years to 22.16 years, with yields ranging from 10.22 percent to 11 percent. Underwriters said the financing is rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

title: Nycor Acquires Stake in Zenith
description: Nycor Inc., a company controlled by the family that also controls the Fedders Corporation, said today that it had acquired an 8.2 percent stake in the Zenith Electronics Corporation and that it might seek control of the Glenview, Ill., consumer electronics concern.

title: Name-Calling on Crime
description: To get a crime bill acceptable to the entire Congress, House and Senate negotiators struck a last-minute deal that scrapped many high-profile provisions. Out went death penalty proposals dear to the Bush Administration. Out also went measures the Administration strongly opposed, notably the Racial Justice Act, a measure to combat race bias in capital punishment.

title: F.D.I.C. Rejects Continental Bid
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had turned down an offer made Tuesday by executives of the Continental Bank Corporation and other investors to buy the Government agency's holdings in the Chicago-based banking company.

title: Travelers Posts Loss of $499.3 Million
description: The Travelers Corporation formally began writing down the value of some of its troubled real estate loans yesterday, and set aside $650 million for losses on those loans. That caused Travelers to report a loss for the third quarter of $499.3 million, compared with income of $94.2 million, or 89 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1989.

title: Review/Dance; 'Dream Dates,' Jennifer Muller's Caricatures
description: This season, Jennifer Muller's troupe, the Works, is presenting new dances by its members as well as by its artistic director, Ms. Muller. Two were on the company's program Sunday afternoon at the Joyce Theater. Both could have been called "Dream Dates."

title: Anti-Zionism Prevents Solution to the Palestinian Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Kitchen Tools Both Fanciful And Handy
description: NOW faux has moved to the kitchen. New appliances and counter-top tools are playing tricks on the eye and turning the kitchen into Pee-wee's Playhouse. These gadgets are just as handy as their sleek chrome cousins, but a lot less serious. 1. A Majestic toaster that is wide enough for bagels or French bread is $60 at Dot Zero, 165 Fifth Avenue at 22d Street. 2. A tape-measure holder in the shape of a rock by Tampopo is $28 at Dandelions in San Francisco. 3. Onion and tomato kitchen timers, made in Italy by Talora, are $14 each at the Pottery Barn, 250 West 57th Street at Eighth Avenue. 4. A can opener by Majestic is $60 at Little Rickie, 49 1/2 First Avenue at Third Street.

title: Puissance: No Giant Leaps for Horsekind
description: Like a rocket, Henderson Didi has astounding upward mobility. But like a rocket, the 10-year-old Belgian-bred stallion can be tough to pilot, which is why his rider, Michael Whitaker of the British equestrian team, decided to test the horse's hankering for heights in Puissance stakes in the first place.

title: Fierce Fight for Illinois Seat Pits Old Against New
description: Walter Dudycz is a classic insurgent: an angry, underfinanced candidate, the son of immigrant parents, bursting with intermingled idealism and naivete, waging a door-to-door campaign backed by a volunteer organization.

title: Bethlehem Steel Profit Plunges 78%
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, stung by sharply lower steel prices and higher operating costs, said yesterday that its third-quarter net income dropped 78 percent. Bethlehem, the nation's second-largest steel company, also said the level of shipments dropped 6 percent for the quarter.

title: New Pact for Larmer
description: Steve Larmer has signed a four-year, $3.1 million contract with the Chicago Blackhawks, the largest contract the team has ever negotiated.

title: Pakistan: No Stamp of Approval
description: After the recent Pakistani elections, an international observer delegation organized by the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs issued a statement doubting that certain reported voting irregularities "significantly altered the outcome of the elections." However, as a member of that delegation who both spoke the language and had studied the country, I would like to counter the widespread impression that by making this statement we intended to certify the election results.

title: Harry R. Burns, Priest, 68
description: The Rev. Harry R. Burns, a Jesuit priest and professor emeritus of St. Peter's College in Jersey City, died on Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Jersey City. He was 68 years old and lived at the Jesuit Residence at St. Peter's College.

title: After a Blunder, Karpov Offers a Draw
description: Anatoly Karpov pressed the advantage last night in Game 9 of the World Championship Chess Match until he blundered at move 32 and lost a pawn. He was fortunate to be able to recover it two moves later, but his superiority was dissipated and he had to offer a draw, which the champion, Gary Kasparov, immediately accepted. The series is now tied at 4 1/2 all.

title: McDonald's Expected to Drop Plastic Burger Box
description: The plastic McDonald's hamburger box may be on its way out, a packaging dinosaur that could not survive in a less wasteful age.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Acustar Inc., a components subsidiary of Chrysler Corp., said it would invest $37.4 million in new construction and equipment at its Dayton, Ohio, Thermal Products plant. * Datronic Rental Corp., Schaumburg, Ill., a general equipment leasing and computer sales company, has acquired the lease portfolio of Capital Leasing Co. Terms were not disclosed. * E. I. Du Pont & Co., Wilmington, Del., and Teijin Ltd., Tokyo, will establish a 50-50 joint venture to make polyester film for audio and video applications in the United States, Europe and other regions, but not Japan. *First Brands Corp., Danbury, Conn., a consumer products company whose brands include Glad, Prestone and STP, said its major shareholders, Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. and First Boston Corp., had terminated discussions with prospective acquirers of First Brands. * General Cinema Corp.'s proposed $240 million buyout of shares of Neiman Marcus Group, Dallas, a specialty store, has been challenged in Delaware chancery court by a Neiman Marcus shareholder group. General Cinema is a Chestnut Hill, Mass., operator of movie theaters and concession stands. * M. A. Hanna Co., Cleveland, will acquire Synthecolor S.A., a producer of formulated colorants, from Perstorp A.B. of Sweden. Terms were not disclosed. * Harsco Corp., Camp Hill, Pa., a maker of building equipment, said its patent scaffolding division had bought the scaffolding, shoring and forming branches of Universal Builders Supply Inc., Mount Vernon, N.Y., a maker of building and maintenance equipment, for $14 million. * Inco Ltd., Toronto, said it would spend $248 million to develop a large new nickel mine and to expand an existing one in Thompson, Manitoba. The money will be spent between 1991 and 1997. * Japan Air Lines Co., Tokyo, said it would buy two turboprop planes from British Aerospace P.L.C., London, for a total of 1.6 billion yen. * Mark IV Industries Inc., Amherst, N.Y., a maker of technical, engineered and transportation products, said it would buy Klark-Teknik P.L.C., Kidderminster, England, a maker of audio signal processing systems, for about $22.4 million. * Primerica Corp. said shareholders of American Capital Management Research Inc. had approved its purchase of American Capital's publicly held common stock. American Capital shareholders will receive $11.50 or 0.32 of a Primerica share for each American Capital share. * Signal Apparel Co. Inc., Chattanooga, Tenn., an apparel maker, said it was negotiating the purchase of Shirt Shed Inc., Wabash, Ind., a maker of sportswear, for $4 a share, or about $30 million. * TRW Inc., Cleveland, a maker of automotive tools and products, signed a joint venture agreement with Fabryka Samochodow Mazolitrazowych, a Polish automotive company, to assemble seat belts in Poland. Terms were not disclosed. * UGI Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., a utilities company, said its Amerigas unit would buy Prudential Insurance Co. of America's stake in AP Propane Inc., a joint venture between Amerigas and Prudential, for $62 million. * Waste Management of North America, Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., a provider of solid waste services, has acquired Durbin Paper Stock Co., Inc., Miami, a reclaimer and processor of recyclable paper. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Settlement Backed In SmithKline Suit
description: A Federal judge has approved a $22 million settlement of a class action suit filed in 1988 by stockholders of what was then the SmithKline Beckman Company. The shareholders accused the pharmaceutical company of misleading investors and not disclosing information that would have hurt the price of its stock. The suit contends SmithKline knew that sales of its leading products were on their way down and the company would not meet its promised growth rate of 10 percent in 1988.

title: Parent & Child
description: PARENTS often wish their children would read Doctors Spock, Brazelton, Leach and Salk so they would know how they should behave. Children have an uncanny ability to frustrate parents and experts alike, leaving them with the feeling that they have tried everything and nothing seems to work.

title: Anti-Zionism Prevents Solution to the Palestinian Problem; Low Profile
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecution Brief Accuses Milken
description: Government prosecutors argued in a memorandum released yesterday that the pre-sentencing hearing of Michael R. Milken established that the former financier had "committed serious crimes" in addition to those he has admitted.

title: Miscellany
description: * Della Femina McNamee Inc. has reopened its Boston office as a seperate subsidiary, with its principals holding minority interests. The new agency, which will be known as Lawner Reingold Britton & Partners, has $80 million in billings.

title: Fed Seeks Rule On Appraisals
description: Banking regulators moved today toward greatly expanding the requirement that independent appraisers assess the value of homes before buyers receive mortgages.

title: Kwok Tak-seng, Executive 79
description: Kwok Tak-seng, the chairman of one of this colony's largest property groups, died Tuesday of heart failure. He was 79 years old.

title: Minister Accused of Stealing Supplies at New York Agency
description: A former official of the New York City Human Resources Administration who was dismissed after his credentials were questioned has been indicted on charges of stealing city furniture and supplies, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Gene Therapy May Help Correct a Rare Liver Disorder
description: In yet another victory for gene therapy, researchers have sharply reduced the cholesterol levels of laboratory rabbits afflicted with severe cholesterol disease by inserting healthy copies of a critical gene into the animals' livers.

title: 4 Jurors Biased in Barry's Favor, Judge Says
description: The Federal judge who last week sentenced Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. to six months in jail for one misdemeanor count of cocaine possession says he believes that four jurors were determined to acquit Mr. Barry from the start and that they misled the court during jury selection by claiming objectivity.

title: Review/Fashion; Amid the Scramble Of the Style Race, Individuality Lives
description: IS there a designer glut out there? Followers of fashion raced across town, then tummy-bumped in elevators to keep up with a heavy schedule of Tuesday shows -- perchance to see one more little liquid slip dress that was almost slipping off; or another simple shift in a very unsimple fabric: sequins, wood beads, even shells.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Apache Corp., Denver, is offering $150 million in 7 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2000 at par through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The securities are convertible into the company's common stock at $19.18 a share. * Arkansas Development Finance Authority is offering $21 million in tax-exempt correctional facility construction bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.268 percent for an issue due in 2010 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Other yields range from 6 percent in 1991 to 7.15 percent in 2005. The issue, rated AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corp. and Moody's Investors Service Inc., is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp. * Monroe, Mich., is offering $50.7 million in tax-exempt pollution control revenue bonds due in 2020 at par to yield 7.65 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The bond issue, rated AAA by S.& P. and Moody's, is for the Detroit Edison Co.'s Monroe and Fermi power plant project and is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Co. For certain investors the bonds are subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax.

title: People
description: * Amanda Hahn has been named senior vice president, and management supervisor of Ayer, New York, where Rachel Treitelman was named vice president. In the Detroit office, Robert Reuschle was appointed senior vice president. * Peter Studney has been named senior vice president at J. Walter Thompson, Chicago, and Marty Levin has been promoted to group creative director and senior vice president. * Paul Guayante and Jim Chahalis have been named vice presidents of DDB Needham Worldwide, New York. * Jerrold H. Gottlieb has been appointed executive vice president and general manager of Hal Riney & Partners, New York.

title: Review/Dance; Memorial Retrospective
description: A legendary choreographer was honored on Saturday night when a James Waring Dance Retrospective was presented at the Judson Memorial Church. No better site could have been chosen.

title: Eyes of Jets on 3 Texas Christian Men
description: The Texas Connection, particularly the Texas Christian University connection, is prevalent in a big way with the Jets these days.

title: Farm Expenses Increase At Fastest Pace in 8 Years
description: Higher oil prices resulting from the Mideast crisis are driving up farm operating expenses at the fastest pace in eight years, an Agriculture Department report said today.

title: Beijing Opera Is 200 and Facing a Crisis
description: When an American tourist in Beijing wanted to thank a Chinese friend for his hospitality, he decided to invite the host to an evening of traditional opera. Beijing opera is world renowned, and so the American assumed it would be a great treat for his Chinese host.

title: Telerate: A Burden for Dow Jones
description: When Dow Jones & Company bought a 32 percent share of Telerate Inc. in 1985, its flagship, The Wall Street Journal, its other business publications and its newer electronic news services were flourishing. Telerate was doing even better, as sizzling demand for its computerized price quotes on United States Government bonds and other financial instruments had allowed it to report annual earnings growth of more than 50 percent for five straight years.

title: Scoring Spree in 3d Sends Rangers to Rout
description: A goal at 1 minute 12 seconds of the third period. Another at 2:16. One more at 3:07. For the Rangers, it amounted to a restoration of order -- brutal in its efficiency, convincing because of its magnitude and wide-reaching in its effects.

title: For Nonwhite Dolls, A Growing Family
description: FOR generations, nonwhite children have played with dolls bearing little or no resemblance to them in looks and style. Theirs was a make-believe world, populated by blond, blue-eyed, button-nosed dolls. Dolls with kinky hair, full lips, almond-shaped or slanted eyes, sepia or butter-toned skin, they probably imagined, were waiting to be born.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HENRY KRAVIS, often called the king of leveraged buyouts, stopped off at City Hall yesterday with a check for $1.5 million. Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS was delighted.

title: Harold B. Smith, 81, A Former Chairman At Tool Works, Dies
description: Harold B. Smith, former chairman of the Illinois Tool Works, died on Tuesday at Good Shepherd Hospital in Barrington, Ill. He was 81 years old and lived in Barrington Hills, Ill.

title: A Warning On Taj Mahal
description: In another signal of the doubts surrounding Donald J. Trump's cash-strapped casino business, the American Stock Exchange said yesterday that bonds for the Taj Mahal casino would be added to the exchange's "flat list," warning investors that the company cannot assure the exchange that it will meet its next bond payment.

title: Books of The Times;   What Presidents Should Have Done
description: Presidential Power and the Modern Presidents

title: Warsaw Journal; Poland's Old Cheerleader, He Lands on His Feet
description: For years, during and after martial law, Jerzy Urban was the spokesman for the Communist Government, and was known for his cynical wit and acid tongue. Now he is Poland's newest capitalist success story.

title: Alfred Sauvy, Expert On Demographics, 92
description: Alfred Sauvy, a sociologist who studied the effects of population trends, from the crisis of developing countries to the baby boom in France, died Tuesday in a Paris hospital, the National Institute of Demographic Studies said. He was 92 years old.

title: Spy Satellite Problems Delay Shuttle Flight
description: The Air Force today postponed a classified flight of the space shuttle Atlantis because of problems with a spy satellite that the craft was to carry into orbit next week.

title: Britain Advises Its Citizens To Prepare to Leave Sudan
description: The British Government advised its citizens in the Sudan today to prepare to leave, citing food shortages and possible civil unrest.

title: Review/Dance; Reflections From Quebec on Adolescence and the 60's
description: "Le Dortoir" ("The Dormitory") is not a masterpiece, but within the genre of dance-theater it is extremely well done. As six men and six women spend considerable time levitating above rows of brass beds that symbolize a regimented adolescence in a French Canadian boarding school, Gilles Maheu's company, Carbone 14, evokes a familiar era from a highly specific point of view.

title: Revisions Adopted in College Entrance Tests
description: Substantial revisions of the college admissions tests taken each year by more than one million pencil-chewing students were approved today. The changes will put more emphasis on reading skills, move the exams away from multiple-choice answers and, for the first time, permit calculators to be used.

title: Craig Russell, 42; Did Impersonations Of Female Film Stars
description: Craig Russell, who delighted and sometimes shocked audiences with his impersonations of Mae West, Judy Garland and Peggy Lee, died Tuesday night at Toronto Western Hospital. He was 42 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editorial on Wednesday erred when it said that Congress had voted down a bill to prohibit aid to Yugoslavia. The bill was enacted.

title: Packaging and Public Image: McDonald's Fills a Big Order
description: As recently as a week ago, the McDonald's Corporation was preparing to respond to public pressure for a cleaner environment by announcing that it would extend its limited plastics-recycling program to all of its 8,500 restaurants nationwide.

title: Papp Rejects $323,000 in Federal Grants
description: Joseph Papp, the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, said yesterday that the new law extending the life of the National Endowment for the Arts is "unacceptable, reprehensible and insidious" and said he was rejecting endowment grants worth $323,000.

title: News Strike: A New Era for Other Papers
description: The first week of the strike at The Daily News was also the first week of a new era of newspapering in New York City.

title: Macy Plans To Sell Equity To Cut Debt
description: R. H. Macy & Company, seeking to repay its debt, said yesterday that it planned to sell up to $150 million of its equity to its outside investors.

title: MBNA's Offering To Yield 8.938%
description: The MBNA 90-B Trust, established by MBNA America, a unit of MNC Financial, is making a $600 million global offering of certificates backed by Mastercard credit card receivables through Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: H. E. Scott Jr., 90, Professor of Fine Arts
description: Henry Edwards Scott Jr., a retired professor of fine arts, died Oct. 24 at his home in Chilmark, Martha's Vineyard, Mass. He was 90 years old.

title: Pathe Finally Takes Over MGM/UA
description: After months of scrambling to find financing for one of the most complex deals in Hollywood's history, the Pathe Communications Corporation today completed its $1.3 billion acquisition of the MGM/UA Communications Corporation.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Others May Love Color, But Scaasi Likes Slinky
description: Runways are aswirl with vibrantly colored clothes for spring, and the neat navy suit seems a victim of the frenzy for fuchsia, gold, turquoise and orange, shown alone or mixed all together. All this color blending is supposed to induce women to buy clothes, but it may just push up sales of sunglasses as the colors grow so dazzling that they hurt the eyes.

title: U.S. Commander Urges Caution on Attacking Iraq
description: The commander of the American forces facing Iraq said today that his troops could obliterate Iraq, but cautioned that total destruction of that country might not be "in the interest of the long-term balance of power in this region."

title: Ukraine Introduces a Form of Currency
description: The Ukraine today became the first Soviet republic to introduce its own crude currency, official coupons that come in every resident's pay envelope and must be used with Soviet rubles to purchase most consumer goods.

title: Striking Out at Public Order
description: A newsstand dealer in Queens says that striking New York Daily News workers wearing hoods told him that something would happen to him if he continued to sell The News. A store owner in Brooklyn who insisted on continuing to sell the newspaper had his windows smashed. Another, near Bryant Park in Manhattan, was threatened with arson.

title: Devils Are Outmuscled by Canucks, 2-1
description: Brian Bradley scored an unassisted goal early in the third period to lift the Vancouver Canucks to a 2-1 victory over the Devils tonight.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the presiding judge's criticism of jurors in the drug trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. in Washington misstated part of thecomment in some copies. The judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, said that of the 13 charges on which the jury either voted for acquittal or deadlocked, he believed Mr. Barry was guilty of 11, not 12.

title: Bowie and Coleman Won't Start
description: Sam Bowie and Derrick Coleman, two frontcourt players who were projected as starters, will begin the season on the bench when the Nets play the Pacers in Indianapolis tonight.

title: Corrections Officers Charged In Racially Motivated Attack
description: Two New York City corrections officers were charged yesterday with using aluminum baseball bats in a racially motivated assault in Queens, the police said.

title: Ralston Purina Net Up 81.4%
description: The Ralston Purina Company reported today that its profit for its fourth quarter soared 81.4 percent over last year mainly because of lower advertising and administrative costs.

title: United Airlines Faulted in Iowa Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board placed primary blame on United Airlines today for an accident that killed 112 people on a DC-10 jetliner last year, saying the company had failed to detect a flaw in an engine when it was inspected.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A New Address on Avenue A For four years, Bernard Leroy has been wheeling his rattletrap bicycle through the Union Square Greenmarket. With his navy blue beret perched at a gravity-defying angle on his shock of dark hair, and a leather jacket slung over his kitchen whites, he's a caricature of a crazed French chef pacing the farm stands, sniffing, prodding and bargaining. Smart shoppers follow him. In his quest for organic produce, fish from pristine waters and meat from animals raised without antibiotics, Mr. Leroy is indefatigable. He used to tuck his prizes in his bicycle basket and steer it back to Bernard's Organic Restaurant, a down-at-the-heels spot on Avenue A. Several months ago, he began pedaling to Cafe News, his new and slightly more civilized setting a few blocks away.

title: H.U.D. Hired D'Amato Ally Under Pressure, Report Says
description: Former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. has told investigators that he was forced to hire a longtime neighbor of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato as the Reagan Administration's senior housing official in New York even though "she was not competent for the position," according to a Congressional report made public today.

title: Accounts
description: * British Knights, a New York-based footwear company, to Deutsch Inc., New York, with a budget between $12 million and $15 million.

title: A Crucial Lending Rate Is Raised by Germany
description: Germany lifted one of its two primary lending rates today, bucking the international trend toward lower interest rates. Economists said the move could rekindle a dormant dispute between Germany and its trading partners over its restrictive approach to monetary policy.

title: Trottier Out Indefinitely
description: Bryan Trottier, the Pittsburgh Penguins' center who has been sidelined for the last two weeks by a sore buttocks muscle, will be out of the lineup indefinitely until doctors find out what's wrong with him.

title: Ex-F.D.A. Aide Guilty in Generic Drug Case
description: A Federal jury here has found a former chief of the Food and Drug Adminstration's generic drug division guilty of lying to the agency's investigators and a Congressional subcommittee.

title: Rinfret Campaign Winding Up in Anger
description: As his quest to be New York's next governor draws to a close, Pierre A. Rinfret has not assumed the air of confidence that almost all candidates try to exude in the last days of a campaign, even when they are far behind in the polls.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BP America Inc., Cleveland, the American unit of British Petroleum P.L.C., said it had identified 85 jobs for elimination as part of its management and operations restructuring. * Grace Energy Corp., Dallas, said its onshore drilling unit, Grace Drilling Co., had acquired the operating assets of Basin Drilling Corp., a wholly owned unit of Texaco Producing Inc. Terms were not disclosed. * Ingersoll-Rand Co., Woodcliff Lakes, N.J., a maker of industrial machinery, has acquired ABG Strassenbaumaschinen, Hamelin, Germany, a maker of road machinery. Terms were not disclosed. * Kennedy-Wilson Inc., Santa Monica, Calif., a real estate company, said it had received Federal Bankruptcy Court permission to extend the deadline for bids on the Aladdin Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev. * Pennsylvania Enterprises, Wilkes-Barre, Pa., a water and gas company, has approved a merger with NUI Corp., Bedminster, N.J., a natural gas company, and also approved the sale of the water operations and related assets from its Pennsylvania Gas and Water subsidiary to United Water Resources Inc., Harrington Park, N.J., a water utility, for $220 million. * Raytheon Co., Lexington, Mass., a maker of industrial and military equipment and appliances, acquired Nautech Ltd. of Britain, a marine electronics company. Terms were not disclosed. * TI Group, London, a specialized engineering company, said three of its businesses have signed a series of five-year agreements, valued at $160 million, with General Electric Co. to supply engine ring components. * Triton Energy Corp., Dallas, an oil and gas company, has sold its Servion of Nevada Inc. unit, which does business as Hughes Aviation Services, to Page Avjet Airport Services Inc., Orlando, Fla., a maker of aviation equipment, for more than $26 million. * Zapata Corp., Houston, completed the sale of its offshore drilling rigs and related assets to Arethusa Offshore Ltd. of Bermuda for $298 million.

title: Among Lawyers, Do Litigators Have Some Kind Of Hormonal Edge? Science May Deliver The Answer.
description: In the past few weeks, 50 lawyers here have taken sticks of Extra sugarless gum, placed them in their mouths, worked up some saliva, and expectorated into a small plastic vial.

title: Bonuses Up in Japan
description: The average Japanese worker received a summer bonus of $3,859 this year, up 7.1 percent from a year earlier and the biggest year-to-year-increase in 13 years, the Labor Ministry said today. Japanese companies pay bonuses twice a year. Summer bonuses at companies employing 30 or more workers in 1989 averaged $3,663, up 6.9 percent from 1988, and winter bonuses averaged $4,331, up 6.5 percent. The average monthly wage at Japanese companies employing more than 30 workers was $2,034 in 1989, up 3.7 percent from a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: The caption on Tuesday on a picture by The Associated Press showing unrest in India misidentified the scene. Though the violence was caused by a Hindu plan to build a temple on the site of a mosque in Ayodhya, the police officers and mosque shown were in neighboring Fyzabad, not in Ayodhya.

title: Saudis Report Syria Plans to Send More Troops to Gulf Within Days
description: Saudi officials announced today that Syria plans to send more troops to Saudi Arabia this weekend.

title: A Fire Sale in South Africa
description: Driving across South Africa some months ago, I came upon a telltale sign of one sweeping, ominous change.

title: Telephone Translations
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company this week expanded its telephone interpretation service to the consumer market, giving customers 24-hour-a-day access to translators in virtually any language or dialect. The per-call service is similar to one available since last year to businesses, police departments and emergency agencies on a subscription-only basis, A.T.&T. said. The service costs $3.50 a minute for the time a translator is on the line.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Commander of American Forces in Gulf
description: Following are excerpts from an interview here today with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf region:

title: Jack Sterling, 75, Host on Radio For 18 Years in New York, Dies
description: Jack Sterling, whose wake-up radio program was on WCBS in New York for 18 years, died Wednesday at his home in Stuart, Fla. He was 75 years old.

title: Economic Scene; The Case Offered By the Optimists
description: THE Government's report that the American economy expanded at an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the third quarter startled economists who have been saying a recession has already started or soon will.

title: Federal Judge Is Given Reduced Prison Sentence in Corruption Case
description: A Federal judge departed from Federal sentencing guidelines today and gave a fellow judge a reduced sentence in a corruption case, saying impeachment and disbarment actions he now faced were "a substantial punishment" in themselves.

title: Auctions
description: Two weeks of sales, including Rauschenberg, Dubuffet and Warhol, should reveal the actual state of the market for postwar art.

title: Rightist Campus Paper Must Clean Up Its Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town
description: 2 for the Saxophone Chico Freeman and Craig Handy, Condon's, 117 East 15th Street (212-254-0960). Here's a good idea: bring together two of the best young tenor saxophonists on the scene and let them mix it up. Chico Freeman, who became prominent as a John Coltrane-influenced improviser in the late 1970's, will meet Craig Handy, one of the young hopes of the 80's and 90's, backed by a young, burning rhythm section. Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 10 P.M., midnight and 2 A.M.; there is a $12.50 cover and a two-drink minimum. Mekons at Tramps

title: The Curtain Goes Up Again at Sardi's
description: Among the glitzy marquees and crumbling sidewalks of the theater district recently, a hand-lettered sign was propped in the window of a darkened restaurant for more than a month. "Very soon I will reopen Sardi's The Longest Running Show on Broadway," it read, and it was signed "Vincent Sardi."

title: Xerox Revamping South Pacific Units
description: The Xerox Corporation said it would restructure its operations in the South Pacific. The Fuji Xerox Company will assume management responsibilities and ownership of Rank Xerox Ltd.'s operations in Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand and Singapore. Rank Xerox, based in Britain, is a joint venture of Xerox and the Rank Organization of Britain.

title: Layoffs Set At Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 50 investment banking jobs, or 6 percent of the 800-member division. It is expected that this round of cuts will be followed by investment banking layoffs at other Wall Street firms.

title: Giants Sign Leach
