description: The San Francisco Giants kept Rick Leach, a reserve outfielder, from becoming a free agent yesterday by signing him to a 1991 contract for $375,000, the same salary he earned this year.

title: Review/Film; The Way It Can Be On the Road in America
description: Early in "Route 1/U.S.A.," Robert Kramer's four and a quarter hour epic about nothing less than America today, a fictional character called Doc reads from Walt Whitman's "Song of the Open Road." After 10 years practicing medicine in Africa, he wants something to measure against the changed America he will surely find as he travels down Route 1 from Canada to Key West, Fla.

title: Purchasers Index Declines To Lowest Level in 8 Years
description: Steeper energy costs, declining production and higher unemployment helped to push the nation's manufacturing economy in October to its lowest level in eight years, the nation's purchasing managers report.

title: Sergej A. Lebedeff, 62, Atmospheric Scientist
description: Sergej A. Lebedeff, an atmospheric scientist and a member of the atmospheric research team at the Goddard Institute for Space Studies in Manhattan, died on Monday at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 62 years old.

title: Missouri Family Renews Battle Over Right to Die
description: Four months after the United States Supreme Court issued its first ruling in a right-to-die case, the family of the victim returned to their county courthouse today in a renewed legal battle to let their daughter die.

title: The Poison Gas Trade
description: Yes, it's hard to believe, but it's true. President Bush is threatening to veto Congressional legislation to impose penalties on foreign companies that sell poison gas to our enemies.

title: Upsala Files Appeal
description: Acccusing collegiate athletic authorities of hitting its small-college basketball program with a big-college stick, Upsala College filed a vigorous appeal yesterday against severe sanctions imposed in August after the school in East Orange, N.J., acknowledged a series of recruiting violations between 1984 and 1988.

title: Leo Gartenberg, 84, Catskills Hotel Owner
description: Leo Gartenberg, a hotelier and an author, died on Monday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Our Towns; Forgotten Homes For Mentally Ill: A Sister's Tale
description: In the spring of 1988, Katina Zachmanoglou, a New York City actress, was helping her schizophrenic sister, Faye, look for a place to live. Faye was well enough to be out of a state hospital and in a community residence. The State Mental Health Department placed the sister in a family-care home, a boarding house licensed for up to six mentally ill people.

title: No Punitive Damages In Tyson Case
description: Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, won a decision in court yesterday when a jury decided he should pay no punitive damages for fondling a woman in a Manhattan disco almost two years ago.

title: After Six Years of Silence, Ferron Expresses Herself
description: In "Phantom Center," the title song of Ferron's captivating new album, the Canadian singer and songwriter dreams of a shift in the balance between positive and negative forces in the world: "While human hearts and ozones shatter/Galactic juries intervene." The song ends with an image of spiritual grace as a gift concealed in a magician's robe: "Cities fall but minds don't follow/And goodness hides up someone's sleeve."

title: Report By U.N. On Arabs
description: Following are excerpts from the report submitted to the United Nations Security Council by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on the Palestianians in the Israeli-occupied territories:

title: Still Climbing the Mountain
description: When Nebraska plays host to Colorado tomorrow afternoon, a capacity crowd of 73,635 will be on hand to watch what will most likely turn out to be the most important game of the regular season for both teams. Memorial Stadium will be a sea of Cornhusker scarlet and cream, dotted ever so scantily by Colorado black and gold. The city of Lincoln, with a population of 192,600, will practically be deserted.

title: Israel Lags in Housing for Soviet Jews
description: The number of Soviet immigrants arriving in Israel last month topped 20,000 for the first time.

title: Coke and Mattel
description: Coca-Cola U.S.A. and Mattel Toys will join forces in a cross-media effort for the Christmas season. The "Toy Money" promotion, which will begin in mid-November, will feature coupons on Coke packages that will offer savings on Mattel toys. The total value of the coupons will be more than $700 million. A multimillion-dollar advertising campaign will promote the deal as well.

title: Review/Film; Coming of Age Amid Divorce, in 'C'est la Vie'
description: "C'est la Vie" is so precisely set that it could not have taken place at any time other than July 1958, at any place other than the sunny French beach resort of La Baule-les-Pins, or have been experienced in quite the same way by anyone other than Frederique, the 13-year-old heroine of Diane Kurys's latest autobiographical film. That summer Frederique gets a first romantic kiss from her cousin Daniel; she lies on the beach listening to Bobby Darin's "Dream Lover" on the radio, and she goads her younger sister, Sophie, into throwing their daily laxatives into the landlord's goldfish pond (by the end of the summer the fish turn white). And when her mother jumps on a motorcycle and races off to dance the cha-cha with a younger man, Frederique begins to realize what viewers have picked up long before: her parents are about to divorce.

title: A Warning to Taxpayers: Deductions Under Attack
description: Long accustomed to a tax code that helps them achieve their most cherished financial goals -- home ownership and a decent retirement, for example -- Americans are being treated rather rudely. And that raises questions of how to plan for the future.

title: Rightist Campus Paper Must Clean Up Its Act; False Charges
description: To the Editor:

title: Patience Is Strength
description: The escalation of President Bush's rhetoric about Iraq and American hostages has led some to believe that he will soon order military action.

title: Review/Film; On a Musical Journey of Discovery
description: The camera pans slowly across the flat, frozen desolation of the Finnish north to discover a small unheated barn where the world's worst polka band is playing an audition best described as relentless. They are 10, if you include the manager, Vladimir, and one musician who is laid out in a home-made coffin, frozen stiff and, it is assumed, dead.

title: Save Redwoods and Aid a Logger? An Effort to Save Redwoods
description: Charles Hurwitz, the Houston financier whom environmentalists have harshly criticized for accelerating the cutting of California's redwoods, could become the biggest beneficiary of an initiative by environmentalists to protect those forests.

title: After a Gaffe by Karpov, Game 9 Ends in a Draw
description: Anatoly Karpov pressed the advantage Wednesday night in Game 9 of the World Championship Chess Match until he blundered at move 32 and lost a pawn. He was able to recover it two moves later, but his superiority was dissipated and he had to offer a draw, which the champion, Gary Kasparov, immediately accepted. The series is now tied at 4 1/2 all.

title: A Less Melancholy Dane Than Usual
description: The considerable strengths of the recent New York Shakespeare Festival production of "Hamlet" are captured and even enhanced in tonight's offering on "Great Performances," at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Faxing Democracy
description: The fax machine became an instrument of democracy last year when Chinese students living abroad used it to flood their homeland with news of the massacre in Tiananmen Square. Now the Pentagon is using it for another democratic cause -- voting in next Tuesday's elections.

title: Congress Remembers the World
description: Congress acquitted itself well in adjournment-hour decisions on foreign policy. It took steps to honor America's obligations to the United Nations, as the Bush Administration requested. Yet it sensibly ignored Administration wishes by suspending or restricting U.S. aid to Pakistan, El Salvador and anti-Government rebels in Angola. If the State Department now makes a virtue of necessity, it has the chance to reap real diplomatic gains.

title: Democrats Accuse G.O.P. of Voter Intimidation in Two States
description: The Democratic Party charged today that Republican organizations in North Carolina and Texas were trying to intimidate black voters by mailing to residents of predominantly black districts postcards that bear fraudulent information for casting ballots in the elections next Tuesday.

title: Teatime? Oh, Any Time Is Divine
description: BEFORE I discovered high tea, I knew only low tea, the sad, sodden tea bag oozing its last in the base of a plain crockery cup. Or worse -- the ignominy of lowest tea, takeout tea from the deli, a tepid brew, metallic with saccharine, served in a plastic-foam cup. These inelegant experiences have now been abandoned to the sensuous delights of high tea.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Rookies Help Flyers End Slide Two rookies, Mike Ricci and Dale Kushner, scored their first National Hockey League goals last night and Keith Acton added three assists as the Philadelphia Flyers ended a four-game losing streak with a 6-3 victory over the Minnesota North Stars in Philadelphia. Ricci played in his first game since breaking his right index finger in the season opener at Boston on Oct. 6. He tapped a rebound of Tony Horacek's shot past Jon Casey to gave Philadelphia a 3-0 advantage 3 minutes 6 seconds into the second period. (AP) Bruins 3, Blues 2: Cam Neely scored an unassisted goal at 3:14 of overtime as Boston, playing at home, ended St. Louis's seven-game unbeaten streak. Neely, who gave Boston a 2-1 lead with his sixth goal in the second period, knocked a St. Louis skater off the puck in the Boston zone, setting up a 2-on-1 breakaway. Using Bob Carpenter as a decoy, Neely held the puck and then sent a 15-foot wrist shot past Curtis Joseph. The victory extended Boston's unbeaten streak to four games. Brett Hull scored his 16th goal of the season for St. Louis. (AP) Red Wings 5, Maple Leafs 4: Johan Garpenlov of Detroit scored two goals and Steve Yzerman added the 300th of his eight-year career last night in Detroit. After Garpenlov and the Maple Leafs' Vincent Damphousse traded first-period goals, the Red Wings broke the game open with three goals in a 2:11 span early in the second period. (AP) TENNIS No. 134 Upsets Sampras in Paris A bespectacled Frenchman ranked 134th in the world stunned fifth-ranked Pete Sampras of the United States yesterday with a 6-3, 3-6, 6-3 victory in the third round of the Paris Open. Guillaume Raoux, a 20-year-old qualifer, pounded Sampras for an hour and a half with second serves hit as hard as the first ones and kept the United States Open champion on the baseline. Also an upset victim yesterday was Ivan Lendl, who played with a blister on his servinbg hand in losing, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2, to Jonas Svensson of Sweden. ROWING An Era Ends in Single Sculls Vaclav Chalupa of Czechoslovakia effectively ended the Pertti Karppinen era in men's single sculls by winning their semifinal yesterday at the world championships on Lake Barrington, Australia. Karppinen, a 37-year-old Finn, eased up and finished sixth when it became obvious he could not qualify for the final. Yuri Yaanson of the Soviet Union won the other semifinal in 7:45.32. Six rowers will compete in the final. (AP) HORSE SHOW British Win Nations' Cup The British equestrian team of Nick Skelton riding Alan Paul Grand Slam, Joe Turi aboard Waysider and Nigel Coupe astride Invinsible Lad put in three faultless performances in the jump-off last night to win the Nations' Cup competition at the National Horse Show at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Jane Austen, of Course, Wrote of Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Wilson's Still Here Julie Wilson, Rainbow and Stars, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, 65th floor (212-632-5000). Julie Wilson has never seemed more in her element than at Rainbow and Stars, where she and her accompanist, William Roy, are performing a program that ranges from Cy Coleman to Peter Allen to Harold Arlen, with many of the songs strung together into thematic blocks. Some wonderful comic moments (old Joe E. Lewis nightclub material; Arlen and E. Y. Harburg's hilarious "Lydia the Tattooed Lady") add spice to a program that reaches a dramatic peak with the singer's definitive version of Stephen Sondheim's "I'm Still Here." Shows are at 9 and 11:15 tonight and tomorrow. There is a $35 cover charge and no minimum for the late show; dinner is required for the early show. Songs of Wartime

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I don't consider myself dovish. And, I certainly don't consider myself hawkish. Maybe I would describe myself as owlish -- that is, wise enough to understand that you want to do everything possible to avoid war -- that once you're committed to war, then ferocious enough to do whatever is necessary to get it over as quickly as possible in victory." -- Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the United States forces in Saudi Arabia. [ A8:4. ]

title: With Budget Wars Ended, Frantic Campaign Begins
description: What Representative Wayne Owens calls his "nervous factor" hit new heights today when a man named Milt phoned him on K-TALK radio here to register his complaint that Congress had dithered over the budget deficit.

title: Dinkins Faces The Painful: More Taxes
description: In a year in which New York State increased taxes by $1.3 billion, its largest rise ever, and New York City imposed $817 million in new taxes, its largest rise ever, economists and even politicians are worrying about how much more a faltering city economy can afford.

title: Market Place; The Action Dries Up For Smaller Stocks
description: If the market for big stocks is depressed, then the market for small stocks seems almost lifeless.

title: Review/Art; A Cornucopia of Furniture and Design
description: For an overview of 100 years of the latest thing -- at least where furniture and design are concerned -- the Seventh Regiment Armory is the place to be this weekend. There, through Sunday afternoon, the annual antiques show known as "Modernism, a Century of Style and Design: 1860 to 1960" is in full swing. As usual the objects on view seem nearly encyclopedic in scope, if not in orderliness, confronting the visitor with a stimulating bombardment of disparate artifacts, contrasting styles and opposing attitudes.

title: At the Movies
description: Fresh From Baltimore

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS TO CLARIFY STAND
description: President Bush stepped back today from his ultimatum about Iraq's treatment of American diplomats and hostages, and his advisers fanned out to try to clarify the Administration's stance on the Persian Gulf.

title: How to Turn Adversity Into an Advertisement
description: Technically, the letter from State Representative Ellis Levin seeking funds was correct. It noted that Mr. Levin's reputation had "earned him special recognition by Chicago Magazine."

title: Ethiopia Says All Jews Are Free to Leave for Israel
description: The Ethiopian Government said today that all Ethiopian Jews were free to leave the country for Israel, pledging that the emigration flow that was interrupted in July would be fully restored this month.

title: 2-Part Financing Is Priced by Arco
description: A $300 million two-part financing by the Arco Chemical Company was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Aetna Tries Straight Talk In Television Commercials
description: AETNA LIFE & CASUALTY has begun a campaign that delivers what most insurance advertising tries to avoid -- straight talk about some of the thornier problems facing the public and insurance companies.

title: Bo Knows How to Be Average
description: Bo likes to cook cabbage and prizes his recipes for cornbread, biscuits and catfish. He plays a mean game of hide-and-seek, hates to give autographs when he is with his family, and loves toy stores.

title: Municipal Employees Join Demonstration at The News
description: At least 13,000 municipal workers and others joined an angry rally outside The Daily News yesterday to show support for the paper's nine striking unions.

title: Longtime Thatcher Aide Resigns Amid Tory Dispute Over Europe
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's fierce opposition to a federal European Community openly split her Conservative Party today with the resignation of her deputy,Sir Geoffrey Howe, the last remaining member of the team she brought into the Government in 1979.

title: Amoco Begins the Sale of Cleaner Fuels
description: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that it had begun selling a cleaner gasoline in all three grades in Washington, Baltimore, Richmond and Roanoke, Va., and that together the fuels meet the 1992 standards of the Clean Air Act passed by Congress last month.

title: What's Wrong With This Story?
description: All right, I know that New York is going to hell, that we are all ditching in droves, and that life here is an insane maelstrom of misfired shots ricocheting into people's living rooms, drugs and malevolence. Still, here is a true event that happened to me in New York City, on Oct. 23, a Tuesday, in which every person is a good guy. Perhaps this marks a new trend of which we should all take note: Secret Unreported Rampant Benevolence.

title: ARKANSAS OFFICIAL IS GUILTY OF THEFT
description: Attorney General Steve Clark was found guilty of theft by deception today for misusing a credit card issued by the state. He was fined $10,000 but drew no prison time.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Vittadini Integrates The Season's Trends
description: You can always count on Adrienne Vittadini to synthesize the trends of the season, and so she did again on Wednesday. She came out strong for color, for shifts and trapeze shapes, for trench coats and balmacaans, for sheer fabrics and flower prints. As always, she did it all with verve.

title: New York Can Afford Corruption, Not Salaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Gang Kills Homeless Man in Halloween Rampage
description: A gang of young men wielding knives and bats went on a Halloween rampage Wednesday night, assaulting several homeless people on the footbridge from Manhattan to Wards Island and leaving one of them dead among the garbage-strewn weeds, his throat slashed, the police said.

title: Court Ruling On Polly Peck
description: Asil Nadir, the chairman of the troubled conglomerate Polly Peck International P.L.C., won a court hearing today on an investigation of his business affairs.

title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON Start    ; Long and Winding Road For 25,000 Runners
description: Sunday at 10:47 A.M. on Staten Island. Runners will start from three different approaches to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to accommodate the more than 25,000 competitors. Good Views

title: Traffic Alert
description: New York City Marathon: A number of streets will be closed for much of Sunday morning and afternoon, including, in Manhattan, First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge; Fifth Avenue from 136th Street to 100th Street, and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Columbus Circle. Fourth Avenue from 94th Street to Flatbush Avenue will also be closed. In addition, some traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge and the Madison Avenue Bridge will be closed for parts of the day. The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge will be closed in both directions from 12:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M, and the westbound lower level, from 9:45 A.M. to 11:40 A.M.

title: In Connecticut, a Hard-Nosed Candidate With a Soft Touch
description: Over the last six months, Representative John G. Rowland, the Republican candidate for governor of Connecticut, has become best known for his television commercials that portray him as a stern budget-cutter adamantly opposed to a state income tax.

title: N.B.A. Story: Green Parrot To Tokyo
description: Thank goodness. It's basketball season. What with football and hockey, the helmet sports, we haven't seen an athlete's face in weeks, unless you count Blubbery Buster and the chap who pummeled him, which I certainly don't.

title: Another Term Seen For U.S. Comptroller
description: The Treasury Department will recommend the reappointment of the Comptroller of the Currency, Robert L. Clarke, a senior Treasury official said yesterday.

title: Riding Circuit With Swamps and Yellow Fever
description: With portraits of long-ago Justices lining its corridors and volumes of precedents filling its shelves, the Supreme Court lives its history as do few other institutions of government.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Arrow Electronics Inc., Melville, L.I., appointed Steven W. Menefee president of its Arrow/Kierulff group. * Bernard Chaus Inc., New York, maker of women's sportswear, named Michael J. Brown to the newly created position of executive vice president of management and planning. * Delphi Information Systems Inc., Westlake Village, Calif., developers of automation systems for insurance agents, appointed Terance A. Kinninger vice president of finance and administrative and chief financial officer. * Intermark Inc., La Jolla, Calif., a holding company for automotive parts, named James V. Iaco Jr. senior vice president and chief financial officer. * Intermec Corp., Lynnwood, Wash., producers of bar-code-related products, appointed Joseph E. Beebe executive vice president and chief operating officer and Gregory L. Tannheimer senior vice president. * Kulicke & Soffa Industries Inc., Willow Grove, Pa., supplier of assembly equipment for the semiconductor industry, named Herbert D. Benjamin vice president in charge of sales. * Selas Corp. of America., Dresher, Pa., an international design and engineering company, appointed Robert W. Ross vice president and treasurer, replacing Kenneth T. Joyce, who resigned. * Sunkyong America Inc., New York, a unit of Sunkyong Group, Seoul, South Korea, named James M. Demitrieus executive vice president and chief financial officer. * Wiener Enterprises Inc., Harahan, La., a shoe and apparel manufacturer, appointed Lynn D. Malmstrom chief financial officer.

title: Immigration Pressure
description: Signals that immigration is swelling may force Israel to confront its housing crisis. New figures show that more than 20,000 Soviet citizens arrived last month, and Ethiopia said it would lift obstacles that have prevented Jews from leaving. Articles, page A11.

title: An Artist's Creativity and Impotence
description: Near the end of "Vincent and Theo," Robert Altman's biographical film about the van Gogh brothers, Mr. Altman positions Vincent (Tim Roth) before an agonizingly blank canvas. In the midst of a glorious wheatfield, a sight that aches to be painted, Vincent stands paralyzed and finally gives up in despair.

title: Review/Theater; David Merrick Presents 'Oh Kay!'
description: IF there is any serious doubt that David Merrick is one of the greatest showmen in Broadway history, it can be dispelled by the fact that his flops are as fabled as his hits. Nearly as much theatrical lore attends the ill-fated "Mata Hari," "Breakfast at Tiffany's," "Mack and Mabel" and "Subways Are for Sleeping" as it does "Hello, Dolly!," "Gypsy" and "42d Street." Mr. Merrick, like most other high-rolling, larger-than-life impresarios, was rarely one to mess with the in-between, which is why "Oh, Kay!," his new show at the Richard Rodgers Theater and his first since "42d Street" a decade ago, is an anomaly. This loose adaptation of the Gershwins' 1926 musical is a chintzy, innocuous slab of stock that is likely to leave more than a few theatergoers shrugging their shoulders and asking, "Didn't I doze through that a couple of summers ago in a barn?"

title: Rightist Campus Paper Must Clean Up Its Act; Damaging Image
description: To the Editor:

title: 31 More Dead in India Riots, Bringing Toll to at Least 210
description: At least 31 deaths were reported across the country today in religious riots linked to a campaign by Hindu fundamentalists to build a temple on the site of a Muslim mosque here.

title: Hugh McPhillips, 70, Actor on Daytime TV
description: Hugh McPhillips, a cast member of the CBS daytime television drama "The Young and the Restless," died yesterday at Sherman Oaks (Calif.) Community Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in North Hollywood.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Races to Watch
description: From a strong challenge to a six-term incumbent in Fresno, Calif., to an anti-tax campaign in New Jersey, some races for the House of Representatives may be a bellwether of larger political trends. Sketches of some two dozen hotly contested races appear on page A18.

title: Construction Outlays Fall 2.8 Percent
description: Construction spending fell 2.8 percent in September, its steepest drop since the last recession, the Government said today. Analysts said any recovery is at least months away.

title: Pratt & Whitney Planning Layoffs
description: Aircraft-engine maker Pratt & Whitney Canada Inc. announced plans to lay off as many as 1,200 workers, about 12 percent of its work force. The company cited a downturn in demand for small jets in the United States for the cuts. Pratt supplies engines for corporate jets, regional commuter aircraft and other markets.

title: Blazing Trenches May Be Iraqi Means of Defense
description: Fortifying its military positions in Kuwait, Iraq has dug trenches that might be set afire to defend against an American attack, Administration officials say.

title: Old Rivalry Seeking a New Flame
description: Len Dawson, the Hall of Fame quarterback, remembers in the late 1960's and in the early 1970's when a visit by the Oakland Raiders to Kansas City meant bruised egos and bloody noses and worse. Dawson recalled when the Raiders' Marv Hubbard guaranteed a victory before traveling to Kansas City. Hubbard received death threats from Chiefs fans and required police escorts in and out of the stadium.

title: A Symbol of the Fast-Food Culture
description: As a package, the plastic foam McDonald's hamburger container may not have the emotional resonance of some other American packaging classics -- the Coca-Cola bottle, say, or Welch's Flintstones jelly glasses. But the simple hinged square box, known in industry jargon as a "clamshell," was in its way a small symbol of an era.

title: Bond Prices Pushed Up By Job Data
description: An unexpectedly large rise in weekly unemployment claims reported yesterday helped to push up prices of Treasury securities and drive down interest rates as traders speculated that the ever-weakening economy would prompt the Federal Reserve Board to move quickly to ease credit again.

title: Transactions
description: Hockey BUFFALO (NHL) -- Recalled Brad Miller, defenseman, and Rob Ray, right wing, from Rochester of the American Hockey League. HARTFORD (NHL) -- Sent Mikael Andersson, left wing, to Springfield of the American Hockey League.

title: Injury Forces Samuelson To Drop Out of Marathon
description: The New York City Marathon lost a touch of its glamour yesterday when Joan Benoit Samuelson, the 1984 Olympic champion, notified organizers that she would be unable to compete. Four other elite runners also withdrew.

title: A Union: the Staunch, the Desperate, the Undecided
description: There are usually two kinds of people in a strike: pickets and strike-breakers. Within the 750-member Newspaper Guild at The Daily News, a smaller, but highly vocal group has formed, the "fence-sitters."

title: Beijing Journal; China's Schoolboy Hero: Lesson Is Lost on Many
description: Until he died and ascended into the Communist Party's pantheon of secular deities, Lai Ning seemed a rather ordinary 14-year-old boy, except perhaps for his desperate yearning to be a hero.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies McDonald's abrupt decision to drop its plastic foam box came largely as a result of an unusual alliance forged in August with the Environmental Defense Fund, people involved in the discussions said. [ Page A1. ] The simple hinged square box was in its way a small symbol of an era. [ D5. ]

title: Review/Film; 'Corman's Frankenstein Unbound'
description: Consider "No one can create a soul."

title: INSIDE
description: Ex-Official Blamed D'Amato

title: Gloomy Outlook for Global Talks on Farm Trade
description: The European Community's continued failure to agree on a common negotiating position on agriculture has deepened pessimism over whether four years of talks aimed at liberalizing world trade can conclude successfully early next month.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROY ROGERS , the singing cowboy who appeared in 90 films, including 35 with his wife, DALE EVANS , is hoping to get out of the St. Mary Desert Hospital in Apple Valley, Calif. for a joint family birthday this week. "As soon as Dad gets home, we'll have a big cake and do everything together," the couple's son, ROY (DUSTY) ROGERS JR. , said yesterday.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Homelessness One Day, And Stardom the Next
description: In the quiet of a weekend morning when the deserted downtown is theirs, a group of homeless men and women lolled in the shadow of a skyscraper, chatting and enjoying the day's handouts of cigarettes and coffee with extra cream.

title: A Resignation At Mazda U.S.
description: Osamu Nobuto resigned today as chairman of the Mazda Motor Manufacturing (U.S.A.) Corporation.

title: Peace Corps' Eastern Focus
description: A new campaign for the Peace Corps plugs Eastern Europe. The public service spot, created by Backer Spielvogel Bates, opens with newsreel footage of the Berlin wall being torn down and moves on to a Hungarian classroom where a volunteer talks about how amazed he is to be in Eastern Europe.

title: Review/Art; Works of Myron Stout, Standing on Their Own
description: In the early 1950's, when the Abstract Expressionists were changing the scale and character of American art with their big, expansive, "all over" paintings, Myron Stout was moving toward small, highly concentrated black-and-white abstractions in which all signs of spontaneity, heroism and personality seemed to have vanished. During this crucial moment of his career, he was painting both with the current and against it, charting a course that would make him one of postwar American art's more influential outsiders.

title: Sexism Is the Offense In 'Blackman's Guide'
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. Contract
description: The Air Force has awarded an additional $557 million contract to the General Electric Company for the Navstar Global Positioning System of navigation-data satellites, the Pentagon said. The work on 20 replacement satellites will be done at plants in Princeton and Nutley, N.J. Contracts totaling $99 million will expire at the end of the year, and the new contract is expected to be completed in 1999.

title: Restaurants
description: After opening to mediocre reviews a year and a half ago, Ca'Nova (for Casa Nova, or new house) had been forgotten, except by the ladies who lunch and the neighborhood residents, none of whom were put off by the priceyness of its undistinguished Italian menu.

title: Review/Film; It's Scary, Yes, and Death Has a Role
description: It's tempting to look skeptically at the hits that have made Adrian Lyne a director to be reckoned with, but there's no denying Mr. Lyne's acumen. With "Flashdance," "Fatal Attraction" and even "9 1/2 Weeks," this exceptionally talented commercial film maker has repeatedly touched the pulse of something vital in his audiences' imagination.

title: Step Is Seen Toward Altering Photosynthesis
description: In a development that could eventually enable molecular biologists to manipulate a process basic to the maintenance of life, scientists have successfully inserted genetic material into the minute structures in which photosynthesis takes place in the cells of higher plants.

title: Dow Gains 12.62 Points, To 2,454.95
description: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, helped by a strong bond market and continued gains in the New York Stock Exchange's financial index and in utility shares.

title: Once Teammates in Rome, Now N.B.A. Foes
description: A year ago Danny Ferry, unhappy about being drafted by the Los Angeles Clippers, and Brian Shaw, annoyed with the Boston Celtics' contract negotiations, wound up as teammates in Italy, the centerpieces of Il Messaggero in Rome.

title: Loophole to Be Used To Keep Bailout Afloat
description: The Bush Administration said this evening that it would use a loophole in the bailout law adopted last year to borrow money to keep the rescue of the nation's savings and loans from grinding to a halt. The new borrowing would enable the Administration to spend an additional $8 billion to $10 billion to continue the rescue, Treasury officials said.

title: Forstmann President Named Chief Executive
description: Forstmann & Company, a privately held maker of woolen and worsted fabrics that is seeking to revamp $160 million in debt, has named Christopher L. Schaller chief executive, succeeding James J. Ammeen.

title: The Big Lie About Kuwait
description: Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Germany's chief propagandist, cynically contended that a huge lie repeated often enough is accepted as truth. Thus Iraqi propaganda insistently invokes "history" to justify the gobbling up of Kuwait. And lacking information, Westerners ignorantly accept Baghdad's claims -- that Kuwait once belonged to Iraq under Ottoman rule and that Iraq was robbed of oil and territory solely by British imperialists.

title: Rangers See October as an Omen
description: They have won in different ways, taken games by the throat at different points, benefited from the contributions of different players on different nights.

title: Miscellany
description: * Earle Palmer Brown, Bethesda, Md., announced an agreement to acquire Lawler Ballard, an agency with $75 milllion in billings that has its headquarters in Norfolk, Va. Terms were not disclosed. * Ketchum Public Relations has purchased an equity interest in the Paris-based I. G. Conseil S.A., a public relations firm. * Kobs & Draft Advertising has opened an office in Amsterdam, their 11th European venture. It will be managed by Bart Leusink.

title: Subtly and Not, Race Bubbles Up As Issue in North Carolina Contest
description: In "the Amen Corner" at Perry's hardware store, Glenn Bridgers had just listened to an old-timer give his opinion, in angry language laced with racial slurs, of Harvey Gantt's chances of defeating Senator Jesse Helms and becoming the South's first black senator since Reconstruction.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Representative TED WEISS may finally win a Congressional election with the support of his colleagues. While the 63-year-old Manhattan Democrat wins re-election to his Congressional seat with predictable regularity -- he is trying to do it again on Tuesday for an eighth term -- he has been defeated four times for election to a post dear to his heart, the chairmanship of the Congressional Arts Caucus.

title: In Year of Volatile Vote, Polls Can Be Dynamite
description: In California, one newspaper poll says Senator Pete Wilson is pulling ahead of Dianne Feinstein in the race for governor. Another says the race is deadlocked.

title: Jets' Thomas and Cowboys' Smith in Rookie Showdown
description: Blair Thomas and Emmitt Smith, the first two running backs taken in the draft last spring, will be on display at Giants Stadium on Sunday. And the game will provide a chance to evaluate which team made the better choice: the Jets, who took Thomas, or the Cowboys, who took Smith.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The annual contemporary art fair in Paris ended yesterday on one bitter note for LEO CASTELLI , who said that the repairing of two paintings by ROY LICHTENSTEIN and JAMES ROSENQUIST that were slashed last weekend "will not be perfect." The Lichtenstein painting was valued at $750,000 and the Rosenquist work at $375,000, said SUSAN BRUNDAGE , the director of the Castelli Gallery, which was showing the paintings at the Grand Palais.

title: Suspect in Holdup Is Slain And an Officer Is Wounded
description: A suspect was shot dead and a policeman was wounded Wednesday night in Brooklyn when the officer and his partner interrupted what appeared to be an apartment robbery, the police said.

title: MEXICAN ADAMANT ON CONTROL OF OIL
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari today strongly defended his ground-breaking efforts to open the Mexican economy to the outside world.

title: Walter F. Sloan, Dentist, 66
description: Dr. Walter F. Sloan, a dentist in Ridgewood, N.J., for 40 years, died on Wednesday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood. He was 66 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: Books of The Times; Father and Daughter, Mother and Son
description: Sexual Intercourse By Rose Boyt 181 pages. Random HouseAdvance Publications+. $17.95.

title: People
description: * Rodger Groves has been appointed senior vice president and multinational account director at J. Walter Thompson, New York. * Rod Burton has joined DDB Needham, Detroit, as vice president and management supervisor. * Bill Freed and Michele White have been named vice presidents at BBDO, Detroit. * David B. Srere has been appointed senior vice president and management supervisor at Cliff, Freeman & Partners, New York. * Kevin Porter has joined Lotas Minard Patton McIver, New York, as a media director. * Betty Woodward has been named vice president and management supervisor at Brouillard Communications, New York. * Susan Jenkins and Patti Friedman have been named group advertising directors at the American Express Publishing Corporation's City Magazine Network.

title: Mortgage Bonds By Florida Power
description: The Florida Power and Light Company, one of the largest investor-owned electric utilities in the country, yesterday priced $125 million in first-mortgage bonds due 2000 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Japanese Fear of Militarism Fuels Opposition to Sending Troops to the Gulf
description: When asked about pressure from the United States to send Japanese troops to the Persian Gulf, Michiko Goto, a 62-year-old Socialist candidate for Parliament, declares her amazement that outsiders have not learned the hard lessons of history.

title: Critic's Choice
description: In this post-glasnostian era, all manner of Eastern Europeans are flocking in our direction. No one has caused greater excitement than the Siberian baritone Dmitri Khvorostovsky (pronounced khvuh-rah-STOF-skee), who will sing a recital of Italian songs and arias by Giordano, Verdi, Bellini, Donizetti and others at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night at 8. Although the recital is being presented by Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York, it will be piano-accompanied.

title: Ian Woodner, 87, Builder, Artist And Collector of Rare Drawings
description: Ian Woodner, a New York builder and developer who was an important collector of Old Master drawings and other works of art, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: The Ones to Watch: Snapshots of Some of the Hottest Contests for the House
description: California 17TH DISTRICT. Calvin Dooley, the Democratic candidate, appears to be benefiting greatly from the headlines in the Fresno area about the six-term incumbent, Charles (Chip) Pashayan Jr., a Republican, and his ties to the savings and loan industry and Charles H. Keating Jr. Mr. Pashayan is not the target of any inquiries, but he received $26,000 in contributions from Mr. Keating in 1986 and shortly after wrote letters and introduced legislation to help the S.& L. industry.

title: Millicom in Test
description: Millicom Inc., a small New York communications company, announced yesterday that Northern Telecom Ltd., the telecommunications equipment giant based in Toronto, would help it design and conduct tests of a new type of tiny cellular telephone in Houston and Orlando, Fla. The Federal Communications Commission awarded Millicom an experimental license on May 8, setting off a rush by many other companies, including five of the seven regional Bell companies, to obtain permission for similar tests. None of the companies has yet demonstrated a working two-way handset.

title:
NEW JERSEY CONVERSIONS;
Condo Is Helping Buyers to Meet the Down Payment
description: Despite a sluggish market and flat prices for all residential properties, first-time buyers still face a large obstacle to homeownership: Saving enough money for a down payment.

title: A Court Backs Forced Retirement Of Commercial Pilots at Age of 60
description: A Federal appeals court here has upheld a 30-year-old rule of the Federal Aviation Administration that forces commercial airline pilots to retire at the age of 60.

title: James M. Foster, 55, Gay Rights Advocate
description: James M. Foster, a member of the San Francisco Health Commission who was a prominent advocate of gay rights for more than 25 years, died Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 55 yers old.

title: Key Rates
Alzheimer's Disease Rate Up
description: The rate of Americans dying from Alzheimer's disease increased tenfold in the 1980's, but heightened awareness may have led doctors to diagnose it more often than in the past, Federal health officials said today.

title: Review/Film; Magic, the Missile Crisis And a Very Minor Miracle
description: Shirley MacLaine's new career as a foxy, crazily dressed, jewelry-clanking harridan continues apace with "Waiting for the Light," a good-natured effort to turn the Cuban missile crisis into an occasion for spiritual uplift. Ms. MacLaine plays Aunt Zena, whose magic act is best utilized at children's birthday parties until it somehow begins to spill out into other situations.

title: Claudia Stern, Writer, 46
description: Claudia Stern, a writer and editor, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Phil Niekro to Manage
description: Phil Niekro, winner of 318 games in the majors and a bullpen coach with the Atlanta Braves last season, was named manager of the Braves' top farm club, Richmond of the International League, yesterday.

title: Leon Rosenbluth, Executive, 65
description: Leon Rosenbluth, an advertising executive, died on Saturday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Gainesville, Fla. He was 65 years old and lived in Gainesville.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 525 money market mutual funds decreased by $140.4 million, to $415.39 billion, for the seven-day period that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 162 institutional funds fell $94.2 million, to $102.94 billion. And those of the 104 broker-dealer funds dropped $475.9 million, to $164.72 billion. But, the institute said, assets of the 259 general-purpose funds rose $429.7 million, to $147.73 billion.

title: Roseanne Barr to Produce for ABC
description: ABC announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the comedian Roseanne Barr and her husband, Tom Arnold, to produce a half-hour series, a special and a television movie. The series, which the network said was "not intended to star Ms. Barr," could go into production as early as next season.

title: Bass Group Cuts Stake in Longview
description: A group led by the Fort Worth investor Robert M. Bass has lowered its stake in the Longview Fibre Company to 4.9 percent, from 8.2 percent. The Bass group sold 2.03 million shares back to the Longview, Wash., paper products concern for $9.98 a share, or $20 million. The Bass group also sold 99,500 Longview shares on the open market.

title: Marion Barry and Deaver
description: Marion Barry, the Mayor of Washington, D.C., was recently sentenced by a Federal judge to six months in prison after conviction on a misdemeanor cocaine charge. Two years ago the same judge gave no prison time to Michael Deaver, President Reagan's former deputy chief of staff, even though Mr. Deaver had been convicted of five felony perjury charges for lying about his lobbying activities. Asked to explain the difference, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson now says Mr. Deaver "was not a high public official at the time he committed his crime."

title: L.I. Pins Its Environmental Hopes on Iffy Bond Act Vote
description: Long Island, needing to replace landfills, protect water supplies and preserve dwindling open spaces, is looking to the 21st Century Environmental Quality Bond Act with eagerness and desperation.

title: 15 Left Because of Inquiry, New York Telephone Says
description: The New York Telephone Company disclosed yesterday that 15 people had resigned, retired or been dismissed in the last year because of an internal investigation into purchasing practices in the company's construction division.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Monday about a Halloween and birthday party for Peter A. Lewis, a general partner in the investment banking firm of Lazard Freres & Company, misidentified the chairman of the Metropolitan Opera. He is James S. Marcus.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: No Bows for Bad Guys? Things are not as O.K. at David Merrick's "Oh, Kay!" as at least one cast member would like. Mark Kenneth Smaltz, who plays the role of Janson, a police officer, has been forbidden by Mr. Merrick to take his curtain call with the rest of the cast. Why? Mr. Smaltz isn't sure, but he's angry enough to have filed a complaint with Actors' Equity against the legendary producer.

title: Knicks Starting Off On Shaky Ground
description: The Knicks boarded a plane today, ready to begin a new season, and hoping to avoid any turbulence that could throw their 82-game journey off course.

title: Voter Revenge for TV Ad Nauseam
description: What sweet revenge it was!

title: Global-Lender Aid Is Seen For Debtors Hurt by Crisis
description: The International Monetary Fund is expected to move Friday toward getting more and faster financial aid to countries feeling the economic shock from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, American and other officials said today.

title: Colts Have Giants Guessing On Their Use of Dickerson
description: All summer and five weeks into this pro football season, Eric Dickerson did not play with the Indianapolis Colts because of disputes over money and a strained hamstring muscle.

title: 2 Ex-Merrill Officials and Vendor Are Charged in Scheme
description: Two former executives of Merrill Lynch & Company were accused yesterday of accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes and kickbacks from companies that helped develop the firm's international headquarters at the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan.

title: Buried Treasure a Zillion Years Old
description: PRIMITIVE shellfish, monster amphibians, flying reptiles and dinosaurs all lived in Gotham at one time or another, and countless species of these ancient New Yorkers left a rich trove of skeletons and footprints to lure weekend fossil hunters.

title: Clayton Banzhaf, 72, An Ex-Sears Executive
description: Clayton H. Banzhaf, retired vice president and treasurer of Sears Roebuck & Company, died yesterday at his home in Blowing Rock, N.C. He was 72 years old and also lived in Longboat Key, Fla.

title: Bush Missed Golden Opportunity on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqis Capture 3 French Soldiers And Return Them to Diplomats
description: Three French soldiers stationed in Saudi Arabia were captured by Iraqi forces earlier this week near the Saudi border with Iraq and have been turned over to the French Embassy in Baghdad, the French Government said today.

title: Japanese to Buy U.S. Ski Resort
description: A Japanese business group that bought Steamboat Ski Area in Colorado plans to buy Heavenly Valley Ski Resort in South Lake Tahoe, Calif., the resort's owner said. Heavenly would become the third ski resort under control of the Kamori Kanko Company of Sapporo City, Japan. It also owns Rusutsu Kogen ski resort near Sapporo City, site of the 1972 Winter Olympics, as well as a koala park in Australia and restaurants, golf courses, zoos and amusement parks in Japan.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CHRONICLE
description: PATRICIA O'DONNELL EWERS is to be installed today Sat. at 11 A.M. at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center as the fifth president of Pace University and the first woman to head the 84-year-old institution. Dr. Ewers, 55 years old, graduated from Mundelein College and received a master's degree and a doctorate in English from Loyola University in Chicago. She goes to Pace from De Paul University in Chicago, where she was a vice president and the dean of faculty. Pace has 23,000 students in seven undergraduate and graduate schools at campuses in Manhattan and in Westchester County at White Plains, Pleasantville and Briarcliff.

title: INSURERS TANGLED IN BITTER DEBATES OVER REGULATIONS
description: The insurance industry, long accustomed to operating out of the limelight, is being challenged on many fronts by consumer groups and government officials. Frustrated by sharp rate increases and by restrictions on coverage, they are seeking a greater say in what insurers charge, whom they cover, what they must pay for and how they invest their money.

title: AIDS Patients May Get U.S. Housing Funds
description: Congress has approved and President Bush is expected to sign the first bill to offer housing assistance to people with AIDS.

title: Bridge
description: In the three-team final of the Long Island Double Knockout Team Championship, played a week ago at the Grand Club in Franklin Square, L.I., the victory went to the defending champions. Peter Bisgeier and Rob Gordon, both of Northport, L.I., and Bob Sherman of Dix Hills, L.I., and Jim Beery of Huntington, L.I., defeated strong squads led by Mitchell Pollenz of Wantagh, L.I., and Aaron Silverstein of Manhattan.

title: Electronic Data Ends Continental Air Offer
description: Electronic Data Systems will not buy Continental Airlines' computer reservation system, System One, the companies said yesterday. The companies had been negotiating the sale of certain assets, including the reservation system, for $250 million.

title: Reviews/Music; Refuting a Handel Myth With an Opera Still in Italian
description: Because truth is too complex to serve as a guide to everyday human thinking, myth had to be invented. It is not true, as program notes sometimes suggest, that the appearance of "The Beggar's Opera" on a London stage in 1727 forced Handel to stop writing Italian operas and begin composing "Messiah" to cater to the public's sudden preference for works sung in English. In the wake of the popular triumph of the Gay-Pepusch "ballad opera," Handel actually went on to write more than 20 operas in Italian, including such important ones as "Orlando," "Ariodante" and "Alcina."

title: Time Warner Resolves Suit Over Cancellation of a Book
description: Two former senior journalists of Time Warner Inc. have settled a bitter dispute with the company over an abrupt decision by a subsidiary to cancel publication of a book they wrote.

title: Review/Music; Goldsby Quintet in a Tribute
description: The music of Oscar Pettiford, a jazz bassist who brought an innovative approach to the bass in a be-bop context with a group that he led jointly with Dizzy Gillespie in the early 1940's, was celebrated on Tuesday in a free concert at Greenwich House by the John Goldsby Quintet.

title: Consolidated Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Dance What's New in Brazil? A Troupe With the Answer
description: Grupo Corpo was founded by a group of young dancers and had a surprise hit with its first ballet. The Brazilian troupe, which made its New York debut on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, has in the intervening 15 years established itself internationally as one of Brazil's most innovative dance companies. But the freshness and simplicity of that beginning are still a good part of the winning charm of Grupo Corpo, which has already extended its season at the Joyce (175 Eighth Avenue) through Nov. 11.

title: Mortgage Rates Dip
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.13 percent this week, down from 10.17 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.15 percent, down from 8.17 percent last week.

title: Democratic Candidates Shying From Florio
description: Democratic candidates in New Jersey this fall have generally avoided appearing on the stump with Jim Florio, the Governor who a year ago was elected with 62 percent of the vote. The reason is his $2.8 billion in tax increases, a program that has helped drive his approval ratings in polls below 20 percent.

title: Another Race Catches the Capital's Eye
description: Voters in the nation's capital are mainly focusing on two local elections this fall -- the contest to find a successor to Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and Mr. Barry's effort to extend his political career as a member of the City Council. But out of the corner of one eye, voters are also watching a third race, with bemusement and concern.

title: Leonard Settles Divorce
description: One of Hearns's former opponents, Sugar Ray Leonard, agreed yesterday to an out-of-court divorce settlement and left the Montgomery County Courthouse in Rockville, Md., arm in arm with his former wife, Juanita. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed and the case record was sealed.(AP)

title: CMS Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included writedown of $ 87.8 million. The writedown included $ 70.3 million for an assumed delay to mid-1991 in the final regulatory approval of the company's recovery of its investment in the abandoned midland nuclear project. Another $ 17.5 million is related to a writeoff of the remaining plant assets in Plateau Resources Ltd., the company's uranium mining and milling subsidiary.c-Net income

title: 6 Killed in Ethnic Violence in Moldavia
description: Weeks of nationalist tensions in Soviet Moldavia turned to violence today as 6 people were reported killed and 30 wounded after Moldavian vigilantes entered a predominantly Russian-speaking town in the republic's separatist eastern region.

title: Westcoast Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1990 reflected the inclusion from Jan. 1, 1990 of the gas distribution business purchased from Inter-City Gas Corp, and earnings per share reflected the issue in March 1990 of 6.25 million common shares, the proceeds of which were used to finance in part the acquisition of the ICG Gas Distribution business and to repay debt relating to the previous purchase of an interest in Ranger Oil.

title: Lawyer Tries Grilling Jogger on Park Rape
description: The woman known as the Central Park jogger was subjected to a persistent cross-examination yesterday in which a defense lawyer tried to suggest that her boyfriend had attacked her in a jealous rage because she was seeing someone else.

title: Anti-Jewish Note Chills Neighborhood
description: It was just a single handwritten note, scrawled in broken English and found on the ground in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. But its ominous message -- a threat to kill Jewish children in retaliation for recent violence in Jerusalem -- sent tremors through the heavily Jewish neighborhoods of Flatbush and Borough Park.

title: Encephalitis Death Toll Rises to 5 in Florida
description: Two more elderly people have died of St. Louis encephalitis, bringing to five the number of those killed by the disease in the three months since the beginning of an outbreak that has spread to 23 counties throughout Florida.

title: Reviews/Fashions; A First Show With the Right Flare
description: Nicole Miller stepped into the fashion arena for the first time on Thursday and scored a technical knockout.

title: Review/ Circus; Circus Reciprocates Artists' Affection
description: With its portrait of a ballerina on point on the bare back of a white horse, Georges Seurat's final, unfinished painting, "Le Cirque," stands as an emblem of the celebrated one-ring European circus. And the Big Apple Circus, in its grand new show, "Ballerinas, Horses and Clowns: The Golden Age," pays tribute to Seurat and other period artists who immortalized the circus on canvas.

title: Eliot Porter, Photographer, Is Dead at 88
description: Eliot Porter, a photographer whose color landscapes have been reproduced on numerous Sierra Club posters and exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 88 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about prison violence referred incorrectly to the university with which Dr. Thomas A. Johnson is affiliated. He is chairman of the criminal justice department at California State University, Sacramento.

title: William Howard Beasley 3d, 44, of Lone Star Technologies, Dies
description: William Howard Beasley 3d, former chairman and chief executive officer of Lone Star Technologies, the steel and environment-equipment company based in Dallas, died Thursday at Baylor Hospital in Dallas. Mr. Beasley, a Dallas resident, was 44 years old.

title: Entergy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included an after-tax write-off of $ 840.2 million.

title: Tasty Baking Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included a third-quarter provision for a special early retirement program begun in February 1990, of $ 1,250,000. Total provision for the early retirement program in the 9 months is pre-tax $ 9,450,000.c-Net income

title: A New Gaffe by Candidate In the Texas Governor's Race
description: Clayton Williams, the Texas oil millionaire who is running for governor, is trying to recover from the latest in a series of gaffes.

title: Varco International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Fuel Gas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leading Indicators Drop Again
description: The Government index designed to forecast turning points in the economy skidded eight-tenths of 1 percent in September, its second straight monthly drop, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Hyosuke Niwa Is Dead; Ex-Tokyo Aide Was 79
description: Hyosuke Niwa, a former Japanese Labor Minister, died today of heart failure 12 days after he was stabbed by a mental patient, officials said. He was 79 years old.

title: Anthony F. Russo, Dean, 55
description: Anthony F. Russo, dean of students at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn, died on Thursday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: The Newsroom: Doubts And 14-Hour Workdays
description: For newsroom workers, putting out The Daily News these days is an exercise in endurance, loneliness, awkwardness and resourcefulness. Management employees work six- or seven-day weeks of 14-hour shifts. Those toiling as reporters say they expect to be snubbed by reporters from other newspapers while on assignment. They usually are. Others have been thrown into new roles without the normal training or supervision, and they admit to feeling somewhat lost.

title: Iron Mike Gets Tickled In Court
description: For the party of one of the parts, anyway, it seemed that Mike Tyson was in court to defend his democratic right to grab and squeeze anyone he wanted, whenever he wanted, and wherever he wanted. In other words, he was, to the plaintiff, Sandra Miller Reese, the living symbol of the maxim of the fight manager Lou Duva. "The heavyweight champion is the 800-pound gorilla," said Duva. "He sits where he wants to sit."

title: Key Rates
Donald A. Wollheim, Publisher, Dies at 76
description: Donald A. Wollheim, a writer, editor and publisher of science fiction, died yesterday at the Jewish Home and Hospital in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Rego Park, Queens.

title: Savin Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included nonrecurring charges of $ 23,500,000 primarily related to operational restructuring.

title: Naval Technology Not Welcome Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Caribbean Has Preserved Its Stability
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilding Youth And Homeless: A Blood Feud
description: The footbridge between Wards Island and Manhattan arches between two groups of people who dislike each other despite their shared struggle against poverty and drugs.

title: Avondale Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 31.5 million relating to increases in the estimated costs to complete two shipbuilding contracts with the U.S. Navy. The quarter also included a net ESOP contribution of $ 6.2 million.c-Net income

title: CHRONICLE
description: IVANA TRUMP is filing for divorce from DONALD TRUMP, her lawyer's office said yesterday.

title: Dow Up 35.89 as Gulf Tensions Ease
description: Stock prices advanced briskly yesterday in heavy trading amid a reduction of tensions in the Persian Gulf, a drop in crude oil prices and increasing evidence that the economy is now so weak that the Federal Reserve may soon cut interest rates again.

title: Let's Look at Tompkins Sq. From Inside Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Ream V. Miller
description: Accountant, 84 Ream V. Miller, a tax accountant and former general tax manager of the Shell Oil Corporation, died on Thursday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 84 years old and lived in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.

title: Religion Notes
description: Methodists Ponder Move

title: '91 Trial Seen In VCR Case
description: The case of an American videocassette recorder company that contends that Japanese companies conspired to sqeeze it out of the consumer electronics business will go to trial next year, a lawyer for the American company said today.

title: Standard Motor Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ira A. McCown, Surgeon, 92 1
description: Ira A. McCown, a surgeon who served for 24 years as medical director of the New York State Athletic Commission, died of heart failure associated with Parkinson's disease on Tuesday. He was 92 years old and died at the Althea Woodland Nursing Home in Silver Spring, Md.

title: A Predator Guards Endangered Species
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Fears Exodus of Jobs On Wall Street
description: Just when New York can least afford to lose them, several major financial institutions are considering leaving the city and taking thousands of jobs with them.

title: Blast in Ireland Kills Soldier
description: A bomb hidden in a car killed a part-time soldier today, and the police said they were looking for a woman who had driven it into the garage where the victim worked. The police said the slain man was 34-year-old Albert Cooper, a member of the Ulster Defense Regiment, a locally recruited army unit. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but Ulster Defense Regiment members have been frequent targets of the Irish Republican Army, which is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland.

title: Permits Planned for Long-Disputed Carolina Jetties
description: Federal permits will be issued in six to eight months for the construction of jetties at an inlet in the Outer Banks of North Carolina, a project that has aroused intense disagreement in the state.

title: Big-City Ambitions at Toys 'R' Us
description: The new Toys "R" Us store that will anchor the Herald Center in Manhattan will be the company's first multilevel store in the center of a major city and, if successful, will lead the nation's largest toy seller in an entirely new direction for expansion.

title: Hindus Militant Try Again to Storm Mosque
description: A mob of 5,000 to 10,000 militant Hindus tried again today to storm a disputed mosque in the holy city of Ayodhya on whose site they want to build a temple to their god Rama. The toll of dead and wounded in the assault varied from 12 to 100, depending on the source.

title: Patents; Bonding Superconductor To Ordinary Metals
description: Researchers at the Government's National Institute of Standards and Technology and at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation have patented a way to bond high-temperature superconductors to ordinary metals.

title: Review/ Jazz; Hard-Bop Solos of 1950's
description: The small-group hard-bop compositions of the 1950's and 60's are some of the least explored territories in jazz. The music's composers have been seen as improvisers who wrote pieces as vehicles for soloing; the tunes, difficult to play, dropped out of the standard repertory. The sold-out show at Weill Recital Hall on Monday night featured the music of the tenor saxophonist and composer Hank Mobley, who died in 1986. The concert was meant to prove a point about his music's brilliance, and did a good job of it.

title: Credit Markets Calm, Awaiting Auctions
description: After an early flurry of activity, trading in Treasury securities declined yesterday as most market participants moved to the sidelines to await the Government's record refunding auctions next week. Prices were minimally higher late in the day.

title: American Honda Is Raising Prices
description: The American Honda Motor Company is raising prices on its 1991 model cars by about 1.3 percent over comparably equipped 1990 models. Honda attributed the price increase, averaging $173 a vehicle, on fluctuations in the exchange rate between the dollar and the Japanese yen.

title: Virginia's No. 1 Ranking Will Be on the Line Today
description: As the latest generation of students at the University of Virginia struggled to maintain its proper social approach to a hot autumn weekend, representatives from nine bowl games navigated today toward a historic campus near the Blue Ridge Mountains that has never been known as a significant football setting.

title: National Sea Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ZANG TOI, Zang Toi a 29-year-old Malaysian-born fashion designer who works in New York, is the winner of the third Mouton-Cadet Young Designer Award, which was established by Baroness PHILIPPINE DE ROTHSCHILD to recognize new talent.

title: A Republican Goes Against Bradley and the Odds
description: Christine Whitman is perched on a tall stool in a dimly lighted, slightly down-at-the-heels sound studio here, making her latest campaign commercial. It requires only three takes, and the message is clear.

title: Fred V. Heinkel, Farm Leader, 93
description: Fred V. Heinkel, a spokesman for Midwestern farmers who headed the Missouri Farmers Association for almost 40 years, died Wednesday at Boone Hospital Center in Columbia. He was 93 years old and lived in Columbia.

title: Tokyo Police Posts Bombed as Emperor Rite Nears
description: Bomb explosions at two Tokyo police stations today killed a police officer and wounded six others and raised the specter of violence as hundreds of visiting dignitaries gather for the enthronement ceremony for Emperor Akihito.

title: Showboat Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected pretax gain of $ 4.9 million, or 28 cents a share, on sale of Showboat Country Club, Las Vegas, and $ 2.4 million litigation settlement.

title: AMC Entertainment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Included gain on disposition of assets of $ 1.6 million in the quarter, and $ 3.3 million in the 6 months.c-Included a gain on disposition of $ 3.3 million and $ 10.5 million in the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Molson Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 61,931,000, or $ 1.88 a share, which represented the net result of two extraordinary items resulting from the merger of its North American Brewing operations and Elders IXL Ltd.Figures are in Canadian funds.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Nortek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,600,000 and $ 1,700,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain from debt retirements of $ 2,450,000, or 19 cents a share, and $ 7,750,000, or 58 cents a share, for the same periods, respectively.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,050,000, or 15 cents a share, and $ 3,950,000, or 28 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain from debt retirements of $ 400,000, or 3 cents a share, and $ 7,100,000, or 52 cents a share, for the same periods, respectively.Year-ago periods ended Sept. 30.During the third quarter and 9 months of 1990, the company recorded after-tax charges of about $ 800,000 and $ 1,600,000, respectively, in connection with various litigation matters.

title: Convicted Law Official To Resign in Arkansas
description: State Attorney General Steve Clark, convicted earlier this week of felony theft, said today that he would resign his office on Monday.

title: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail; Group Links Pornography Support To Lawmaker's Vote on Art Funds
description: The Christian Coalition says it isn't telling people how to vote. It just wants them to know which candidates support pornography.

title: First Major Air-Bag Recall Widening
description: The first major air-bag recall is under way: the Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it expected to replace potentially defective air-bag inflators in about 3,000 late-model cars, rather than only 133 vehicles, as it had announced last week.

title: Officer Shot in Chest In Building in Bronx
description: A police officer wearing a bullet-proof vest was shot and wounded last night in a Bronx apartment building where he had gone in response to a call about an emotionally disturbed person, the police said.

title: Upper Peninsula Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Woman Is Acquitted in Trial For Using the Men's Room
description: A Houston woman was acquitted tonight in her trial for using a men's restroom in desperation at a country-western concert.

title: Hotel Investors
description: The Beverly Hills investor Leonard M. Ross has raised his stake in Hotel Investors Trust and the Hotel Investors Corporation, the Los Angeles real estate and hotel management company that trades as a paired entity, to 15.5 percent, from 14 percent. Mr. Ross is threatening a proxy fight to replace the company's board. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Ross said he had talked with management but no agreement had been reached. Mr. Ross also said he would support a sale of 27 hotel properties to a unit of the EIE International Corporation of Japan for $152 million.

title: Michel Katcharoff, Dancer, 82
description: Michel Katcharoff, a dancer and former regisseur of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, died Oct. 25 at Arlington Hospital in Virginia. He was 82 years old and lived in Arlington.

title: Nice Day for Anything but Marathon Is Forecast
description: With a forecast for the worst running weather for a New York City Marathon since what Fred Lebow recalls as the "disaster of 1984," race officials were scrambling yesterday to assure safe passage for the 25,000 runners who are expected to start the 26.2-mile race tomorrow morning.

title: Top Movie Of the Year A Sleeper: It's 'Ghost'
description: Sometime this weekend, the motion picture "Ghost" will pass the $179 million mark at the box office, making it the most successful movie of 1990 and one of the biggest sleeper hits in Hollywood history.

title: New Plan on Nuclear Licenses Is Barred
description: In a blow to the nuclear power industry's hopes for a new generation of reactors, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Government could not give permission for operation before a plant is built.

title: Pride Cos. L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: News Summary
description: International 3-7

title: Honecker Hints at Kremlin Scheme To Bring the Eastern Bloc's Collapse
description: In the first major public statement since he was toppled one year ago, Erich Honecker, the former East German Communist leader, suggested in an interview published today that the Soviet leadership had intrigued to bring about the collapse of governments in Eastern Europe.

title: Harcourt Hires Smith Barney
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. announced on Thursday that it had hired Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to offer advice on ways to deal with a debt of more than $1.7 billion.

title: Review/ Theater; Dark Visions of America In a Modern Depression
description: In Richard Caliban's "Famine Plays," the center of the country cannot hold. America's heartland has become a disaster area. Facing unemployment and poverty, people move from street to highway, looking for a resting zone. Some grasp a livelihood in crime. No one has enough to eat, and there is no solace on the horizon. The once-sedentary become eternal nomads, as the Okies did in the 1930's.

title: Knicks Win the Hard Way on Opening Night
description: If every victory is as difficult as the one tonight, the Knicks will all have high blood pressure by the end of the season.

title: Peruvian Rebels Kill Official In Ruling Party and 9 Others
description: Leftist guerrillas killed 10 people, including an official of President Alberto Fujimori's political movement, in a wave of attacks around the country that began on Thursday, the police said today.

title: Weicker Finds Mantle Of Outsider a Good Fit
description: When the 6:51 A.M. train from South Norwalk pulled into Grand Central Terminal yesterday, Steven J. Anastos, a garment salesman from Stamford, found an unlikely figure greeting him and hundreds of other commuters on the platform: Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the independent candidate for governor of Connecticut.

title: Philadelphia Journal; City Waits For Rescue Amid Cries Of Chaos
description: The city's law department ran out of fax paper this week. The city's mail room in the Municipal Services Building ran out of stamps last week. Home care for 32 AIDS patients may end on Monday. And, at the end of this month, the city will run out of money to pay for most of its employees and services.

title: D.E.A. Denies Pan Am Bomb Tie
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration denied today that it knew of any connection between a Federal drug operation and the 1988 bombing of a Pan American World Airways jet that left 270 people dead.

title: Kenya Upholds Law, Elections and Free Press
description: To the Editor:
