description: b-Included an investment gain of $ 16,000,000 and $ 21,000,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included an investment gain of $ 23,900,000 in the quarter and $ 139,600,000 in the 9 months.

title: Richfood Holdings Inc. reports earnings for 12wks Oct 13
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 186,000 and $ 680,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-Net lossYear-ago periods ended Oct. 14.

title: Robert B. Clarke, 62; Led Publishing House
description: Robert B. Clarke, retired chairman of Grolier Inc., which publishes encyclopedias and other educational material, died yesterday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: About New York; Out On Strike: Fight on the Line, And in His Heart
description: Paul La Rosa remembers his father reading him comics in The Daily News, an activity that helped him learn to read. "The letters in the balloons over people's heads sort of snapped together one day, and I learned to understand them," he said.

title: Paris Open May Spawn Battle for No. 1 Ranking
description: It can be argued that something must be askew when the Association of Tennis Professionals Tour's computer awards the top world ranking to a man -- Stefan Edberg, in this case -- who could not get past the first round of the French or United States Opens this year.

title: Power Corp. of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 1,323,000 and $ 7,083,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 7,375,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $ 428,027,000, or $ 3.37 a share, for the 9 months.The charge in the 1990 periods and the year-ago quarter included charges from Power Financial Corp.'s subsidiary, Great-West Life Assurance Co.The gain in the 1989 nine-month period included its share of a gain at Power Financial on the sale of its unit, Montreal Trustco Inc., as well as Power Corp.'s gain on the sale of its shares of Consolidated Bathurst Inc.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Four Children Slain By Man With Knife In Mississippi Home
description: A man who had reportedly been rebuffed in his demand for money to buy drugs stabbed four small children to death and badly wounded three other people at his mother's home near here Thursday night, the authorities said.

title: Adding Police Officers Is Only a First Step
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Patent Fees Go Up
description: The Federal budget measure approved by Congress last week imposes a 69 percent increase in the fees charged by the Patent and Trademark Office for processing patent applications. Large corporations will have to pay $370 for filing an application and $1,050 at the time the patent is issued. Individuals, small businesses and universities will pay $185 and $525, respectively. The increases are expected to generate an additional $100 million, which is intended to make the office essentially self-financing.

title: Your Money; Rare Opportunity In the 28% Bracket
description: STANLEY BREITBARD, national director of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse in Los Angeles, calculates that some taxpayers who are in the 28 percent bracket this year have a rare opportunity in the next few weeks to make investments that yield double-digit rates of return after taxes, with virtually no risk.

title: Pretoria Adopts Pact on Freeing Political Prisoners
description: The South African Government today adopted an agreement it had reached with the African National Congress on a phased release of political prisoners and the return of political exiles, though the two sides differed slightly over the details.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies Thursday about the arrest of five students from Monroe Township (N.J.) High School in the rape of a 15-year-old girl rendered a quotation from the Middlesex County Prosecutor incorrectly. He said: "They got her into the car on the pretext of stopping at a convenience store and then taking her home. Instead they enticed her to a wooded area, where the assault took place." He did not use the word "rape."

title: Weldwood of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said a two-week maintenance shutdown, combined with a B.C. rail strike, reduced pulp sales considerably at its joint-venture Cariboo Pulp & Paper operation.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: THORVALD STOLTENBERG, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, announced in Geneva yesterday that he was resigning to become Norway's Foreign Minister. Mr. Stoltenberg, a Norwegian career diplomat, will become Deputy Prime Minister as well as Foreign Minister in the Cabinet of GRO HARLEM BRUNDTLAND, a member of the Labor Party who is the Prime Minister-designate.

title: Help Iraqis Do It
description: The one, relatively painless way to end the confrontation with Iraq without war or appeasement has, amazingly, scarcely been broached. It is called "the internal solution," helping the Iraqi opposition get rid of Saddam Hussein's regime.

title: Grants for 2 Performers Win Support
description: The advisory council of the National Endowment for the Arts overwhelmingly recommended grants for two controversial performance artists today, less than a week after Congress voted to repeal strict anti-obscenity curbs on the agency.

title: Game in Ireland Is Moved to U.S.
description: A football game planned for Killarney, Ireland, between Ball State and Ohio University has been moved because the promoter asked for an additional $150,000, the Mid-American Conference said Thursday.

title: Antony Clavet Dies; Makeup Artist, 45
description: Antony Clavet, an internationally known makeup artist, died on Oct. 24 at a hospital in Biarritz, France. He was 45 years old and had homes in Manhattan and in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL U.S. All-Stars Lose to Japanese Five pitchers combined on a two-hitter and Takahiro Ikeyama of the Yakult Swallows hit a two-run double in the third inning yesterday as a Japanese all-star team beat an American major league all-star team, 4-1, in Tokyo in the opener of an eight-game series. Barry Bonds of the Pittsburgh Pirates hit a bases-loaded single in the first off Hideo Nomo of the Kintetsu Buffaloes. Nomo, the Japanese rookie of the year, had walked the bases loaded. Sandy Alomar Jr. of the Cleveland Indians got the other hit for the United States team. The Japanese went ahead with a three-run third against Dennis Boyd of Montreal. Cecil Fielder, who returned to Japan as a hero after becoming the first major leaguer in 13 years to hit 50 homers, went 0 for 3, including two strikeouts. Fielder played for Hanshin in 1989. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals Surprise Kings, 4-3 Michael Pivonka's goal early in the final period last night broke a tie and gave Washington its first victory over Los Angeles at the Capital Centre since 1987. Pivonka broke a 3-3 tie with 16 minutes 21 seconds to play when he skated into the Kings' zone, used the defenseman Marty McSorely as a screen and beat Kelly Hrudey with a 50-foot slap shot for his fourth goal of the season and second game-winner in three games. Washington won its third in a row and beat the Kings at home for the first time in four games since a 10-3 victory on Dec. 6, 1987. Los Angeles, which lost to the Rangers on Wednesday night, has lost consecutive games for the first time this season. (AP) GOLF Brown Leads in L.P.G.A. Event Nancy Brown shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take a two-shot lead after the first round of the Mazda Japan Classic in Hanno, Japan, the final L.P.G.A. Tour event of the season. Caroline Keggi had four birdies on the front nine on her way to a 68 and a second-place tie with Vicki Fergon and Rosie Jones. (AP) Long Island Pro Wins: Tom Joyce of Huntington, L.I., fired his fourth consecutive sub-par round, a two-under-par 70, to win the PGA Senior club professional championship yesterday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Joyce, with a 10-under-par 278, finished two strokes ahead of Jim Albus of Locust Valley, L.I. (AP) HORSE SHOW Goldstein Takes Gambler's Choice Margie Goldstein of the United States equestrian team and her mount, Ranly, won the International and Open Jumper Gambler's Choice competition at the National Horse Show at Byrne Meadowlands Arena last night. Goldstein and the gray Dutch-bred stallion cleared 11 fences for 1,050 points within the allotted 50 seconds to win the event in which the riders select their own courses and are awarded points based on the difficulty of each obstacle.

title: An Iff and a Butt
description: the Water Genie told Haroun about the Ocean of the Streams of Story, and even though he was full of a sense of hopelessness and failure the magic of the Ocean began to have an effect on Haroun. He looked into the water and saw that it was made up of a thousand thousand thousand and one different currents, each one a different color, weaving in and out of one another like a liquid tapestry of breathtaking complexity; and Iff explained that these were the Streams of Story, that each colored strand represented and contained a single tale. Different parts of the Ocean contained different sorts of stories, and as all the stories that had ever been told and many that were still in the process of being invented could be found here, the Ocean of the Streams of Story was in fact the biggest library in the universe. And because the stories were held here in fluid form, they retained the ability to change, to become new versions of themselves, to join up with other stories and so become yet other stories; so that unlike a library of books, the Ocean of the Streams of Story was much more than a storeroom of yarns. It was not dead but alive.

title: Atwater Tries to Make Peace With Former Political Foes
description: Lee Atwater, who was accused of negative campaigning as head of George Bush's Presidential campaign, says he has been making peace with former foes, Democrats and Republicans.

title: NBC Protests Candidate's Use of Videotape
description: NBC yesterday issued its second protest against the use of NBC News videotape in campaign material distributed by Jane Brady, a Republican running against Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware.

title: Food Relief Convoy Sets Off in Angola
description: A convoy carrying emergency food and medicine left today for famine-stricken areas of central Angola, the beginning of an operation that United Nations officials hope will help nearly two million people threatened with starvation.

title: Adding Police Officers Is Only a First Step

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: An Embattled Retailer Refocuses on Retailing
description: These days, Philip M. Hawley is talking less about Wall Street and more about his own business, finally.

title: Guidepost; Credit: What It Costs
description: It is especially important in difficult economic times to know exactly what your bank credit card costs you. The first thing to know is what your interest rate is. The average rate is 18.8 percent a year, but lower rates are available. Last year, total bank-card spending was about $216 billion, or alomost half of all credit-card spending. If you do not pay off the balance each month, it's wise to know some things about your credit agreement that bans tend not to publicize. Grace Period: Time between purchase and end of billing cycle when interest is not charged. If the previous balance is carried over, there is no grace period, and you will have to pay interest. Interest Rates: Fixed rates can be increased with little notice. Check every statement for the rate being charged. Rates often rise when credit-card accounts are sold to antoher bank, increasingly common these days. Cash Advance: There is no grace period, and interest is calculated immediately. There is a growing trend among banks to add a fee for each transaction as well.

title: Allen C. Holmes, 70, A Cleveland Lawyer
description: Allen C. Holmes, a lawyer and former managing partner of Jones Day Reavis & Pogue, one of the nation's largest law firms, died Thursday at his home in Bratenahl, Ohio. He was 70 years old.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Fund-Raising Overkill
description: It's hard to say which is more dismaying: the correlation between state contractors and contributions to Gov. Mario Cuomo's re-election campaign or the fact that it's no surprise. Mr. Cuomo can conquer the cynicism by returning the dubious money.

title: Matchup With the Colts Is Special for Cooks
description: In 1982, the Baltimore Colts made Johnie Cooks the second choice over all in the National Football League draft. He became one of the better outside linebackers in pro football.

title: Frazier Goes to Court And Wins by Decision
description: A Federal court jury in Philadelphia has awarded the former heavyweight champion Joe Frazier a $77,000 verdict against a company that exploited his name without permission in order to promote a cruise.

title: Washington Gas Light Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Look Doesn't Help Old Nets
description: Things looked bright and new for the Nets in their season opener tonight. They had new uniforms and four new starters, and they were playing on a new court at the Market Square Arena.

title: Satellite TV Battle Ends in Britain
description: After battling for several months, British Satellite Broadcasting and Rupert Murdoch's Sky Television said yesterday that they would merge. The archrivals had waged a bitter war for dominance over a new British television market and in the process had accumulated losses of more than $1.5 billion.

title: UPI Announces Salary Cuts As Part of an Economy Move
description: United Press International said today that it would cut salaries of employees not covered by union contracts by 35 percent for 90 days as part of an economy move intended to bring about a sale of the 83-year-old news agency.

title: Kenya Upholds Law, Elections and Free Press; Nothing New About It
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: On Latin America; Street Life in Guatemala City
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Fashion; Beene, Mizrahi and the Longer Hems
description: Hemlines are on the march.

title: Baker Seen as a Balance To Bush on Crisis in Gulf
description: Since the beginning of the Persian Gulf crisis, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has shared President Bush's instinct to confront Iraq, but senior Administration officials say he has been a brake on any immediate impulse to use military force.

title: After Noriega, Change Comes Slowly and Panama's President Is Frustrated
description: Despite encouraging signs of national recovery, President Guillermo Endara continues to face political and economic frustrations as his Government tries to rebuild Panama after two decades of military rule.

title: Paley's Artworks Bequeathed to the Modern
description: The collection of 19th- and 20th-century art assembled by William S. Paley, valued in the hundreds of millions of dollars, will go to the Museum of Modern Art. Among the masterpieces collected by the former chairman of CBS is "Boy Leading a Horse," from 1906, a large-scale painting from Picasso's rose period that was a centerpiece of the Picasso survey at the Modern in 1980.

title: Nuggets Run, Gun And Lose
description: The Denver Nuggets unveiled their new rapid-fire offense tonight and the result was a National Basketball Association record for points in a regulation game, although the Golden State Warriors won, 162-158, behind Tim Hardaway's 32 points and 18 assists.

title: United-Pan Am Route Transfer
description: United Airlines and Pan American World Airways have asked Federal regulators to approve by Dec. 31 United's proposed purchase of most of Pan Am's trans-Atlantic routes. Under a $400 million deal announced on Oct. 23, United, whose parent is UAL, would acquire all of Pan Am's United States-London routes except those landing in Miami and Detroit; a Washington-to-Paris route; all Pan Am sites at San Francisco International Airport, Dulles International in Washington and Heathrow airport in London; and two Boeing 747-200 passenger jets.

title: Coping; With Finding Your Way by Car
description: Drivers were getting lost when Henry Ford was still hunting for financial backers. But in those days, motorists could at least stop and ask for directions. Today, along most roads, there is no one to ask, even if you could stop. Luckily, there are plenty of high- and low-tech ways for drivers to find their way in unfamiliar territory.

title: Fischer & Porter Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Taylor Demands Apology After Comments by Cosell
description: Lawrence Taylor lashed out at Howard Cosell today. At a news conference at Giants Stadium, the All-Pro linebacker demanded a public apology from the veteran broadcaster over Cosell's insinuations that Taylor had cheated on mandatory drug tests.

title: Islanders Slam the Door on Rangers' Home Streak
description: Until the scoreboard clock flashed nothing but zeros last night, it had been a season of no distinction for the Islanders. At that moment, they achieved what no other team in the National Hockey League had before, a victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden. The Islanders didn't hold back in their spirited celebration at center ice, their laughs and screams the final insulting escort into the night for the Rangers and their fans.

title: Government by Cabal -- Again
description: Whatever anyone thinks of the new deficit-reduction package, the process that produced the 1991 budget was a frightening display of government-in-secret. Members who battled and bargained into the wee hours are only now discovering the full content of what they approved. There is a better way, called telling it like it is.

title: Central Newspapers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pan Am Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 18,443,000 and $ 115,600,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Net income

title: Review/Dance; Technology's Poet (and Prophet) Comes Into His Own
description: The world has finally caught up with Kenneth King, whose poetics of technology were always transmitted through dancing and speaking, often at the same time. Today, anyone using a word processor or computer can begin to understand the wordplay dances, once so mysterious, that Mr. King programmed with prescience as a model for how we would all live and talk one day.

title: Did Life Leave the Sea Earlier Than Thought?
description: New fossil discoveries are pushing back by millions of years the time of a major benchmark in evolution, the emergence of the first animals to make their home on land.

title: INSIDE
description: Tactical Shift by Bush

title: Setback for Hebert
description: A Superior Court judge in Los Angeles yesterday refused to exempt the former New Orleans quarterback, Bobby Hebert, from the National Football League's free-agent guidelines, thus virtually eliminating any chance Herbert has of playing this season. Hebert is suing the league and the Los Angeles Raiders for abiding by what he contends are illegal free-agent rules.

title: Jerusalem Arabs Hold Strike To Mark British Declaration
description: Palestinians staged a general strike today in a protest marking the anniversary of the Balfour Declaration, in which Britain lent conditional support in 1917 to the founding of a Jewish homeland in Palestine.

title: Sarandi Journal; Land Program: What's Yours Is Mine
description: As Juvino Rodrigues de Aquino cleared brush with a sickle, a straining ox team plowed long furrows, slowly opening black soil as rich as chocolate cake.

title: Crawford & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split on July 24.Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Reviews/Fashions; Leva: Sprightly and Saucy
description: Michael Leva may have lost the Mouton-Cadet Young Designer Award to Zang Toi on Thursday night, but his collection earlier in the day was a winner. It was young and sprightly, with a nice mixture of well-tailored jackets and insouciant baby doll dresses.

title: Schott and Davis Talk
description: Marge Schott, owner of the Cincinnati Reds, and Eric Davis, the team's star outfielder, who complained publicly that the team ignored him after his World Series injury in Oakland, Calif., emerged from a private meeting yesterday to say they had begun to settle the dispute. Davis, appearing with Schott in a news conference at his suburban Cincinnati home, told reporters: "It's something that is going to take time. This is a big step. It eased my mind a little bit."

title: Karpov's Defense Holds Fast, And Game 10 Ends in a Draw
description: Gary Kasparov made a delicate attempt to outmaneuver Anatoly Karpov last night in Game 10 of the World Championship Chess Match, but was stopped cold by the challenger's precision defense and took a draw in 18 moves. The players remain tied, now at 5-5.

title: Questions Are Intensifying About Insurance Safety Net
description: The faltering economy is casting a shadow over virtually all aspects of American life, and insurance is no exception. Many insurance companies have invested heavily in real estate or junk bonds whose market value has declined sharply, making them more vulnerable to insolvency.

title: Nebraska Governor in Fight To Save Her Political Career
description: With Nebraska's unemployment rate at 2.1 percent, the nation's lowest, and the state's farm economy as healthy as it has been in a decade, political logic would suggest that Gov. Kay A. Orr should have little trouble winning re-election next week.

title: Bush Will Visit the Troops In Desert on Thanksgiving
description: President Bush will spend Thanksgiving with American troops in Saudi Arabia during an eight-day trip to review the Persian Gulf crisis and other matters with European and Middle Eastern allies, the White House said today.

title: Atlanta Gas Light reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gaylord Container Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a net provision of $ 3.1 million for plant consolidation.c-Net income and the year included a net gain of $ 3.4 million on the sale of the Baltimore, Ohio mill.Year-ago periods were reclassified to conform to current year presentation.

title: In Switch of Campaign Tactics, the Kinder, Gentler Bush Emerges
description: With some advisers urging him to be Harry Truman and some pressing him to be Dwight Eisenhower, President Bush has finally come down on the side of Mr. Eisenhower.

title: Traffic Alert
description: New York City Marathon: A number of streets will be closed for much of tomorrow morning and afternoon, including, in Manhattan, First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge; Fifth Avenue from 136th Street to 100th Street, and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Columbus Circle. Parts of Fourth Avenue from 94th Street to Flatbush Avenue will also be closed. In addition, some traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge and the Madison Avenue Bridge will be closed for parts of the day. The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge will be closed in both directions from 12:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M, and the westbound lower level, from 9:45 A.M. to 11:40 A.M.

title: A Dog At Sunrise
description: Waxter is running again. He is against waste. I was amazed when I heard it on a radio commercial paid for by the Waxter For Congress Committee.

title: Cuomo Tries Hard Not to Take It Too Easy
description: It was billed as a "traditional Democratic campaign rally," and this being a Democratic town, several hundred of the party faithful showed up to cheer and applaud in the traditional way, while the traditional Dixieland band played a few dozen choruses of the traditional song -- "New York, New York" -- and almost nobody listened.

title: Wheeling Steel Reorganization
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation hopes to conclude a reorganization of its debts and emerge from bankruptcy court protection on Dec. 20. Parties to the reorganization, now in its sixth year, will soon receive ballots and documents related to the proposed settlement.

title: Canadian Tire reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Polly Peck Chief Named in Claim
description: Lehman Brothers Securities, the British arm of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., filed a claim of $:18.5 million, or about $36 million, against the chairman of Polly Peck P.L.C., Asil Nadir, contending he failed to pay for stock purchases. Lehman Brothers said in a brief statement it had submitted the claim to the High Court in London, joining an earlier petition filed last week by Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. seeking $:3.6 million in unpaid fees.

title: 43 Nations Agree to Ban Ocean Dumping
description: The world's largest industrial nations agreed on Thursday to a global ban on dumping industrial waste at sea and then set the stage today for restricting the far greater volume of marine pollution discharged on land.

title: Review/ Film; A Spiritual Prince in a Back-Lot Musical
description: This will sound unlikely when said about a man who dances in his new film wearing spike-heeled, glitter-trimmed, hip-high leggings, but Prince is showing off his spiritual side. This will sound even more unlikely: Prince is nearly ready for Broadway.

title: Data General reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 71.7 million.c-Included a restructuring charge of $ 80 million.

title: SHARP DROP FOUND IN NUMBER OF JOBS IN U.S. WORKPLACE
description: The number of jobs in the nation declined markedly in October, particularly in construction and manufacturing. The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.7 percent, but only because the number of Americans looking for work also shrank, the Government reported today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing two dozen Congressional races around the country misidentified a Republican incumbent in Minnesota. He is Arlan Stangeland.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the financial troubles of The Daily News misstated the year of The News'sfront-page headline "Ford to City: Drop Dead." It was 1975.

title: Annette Pfeiffer Wed in New York
description: Annette Rae Pfeiffer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray A. Pfeiffer of Tulsa, Okla., was married yesterday to John Edward de Bruycker, the son of Mrs. Stanley B. Duvall of New Canaan, Conn., and the late John G. de Bruycker.

title: Books of The Times; How Both Sides' Artists Saw World War II
description: Images of War The Artist's Vision of World War II Selected and edited by Ken McCormick and Hamilton Darby Perry Illustrated. 453 pages. Orion Books. $65.

title: Patents; An Alarm in Eyeglasses Alerts the Fatigued
description: To help weary workers remain alert on a hazardous job or keep drivers awake on the road, two Israeli inventors obtained a patent this week for eyeglasses that use signals to detect fatigue and sound an alarm if a person is falling asleep.

title: CIRCULATION HURT, NEWS GIVES AWAY MANY OF ITS COPIES
description: The publisher of The Daily News, James Hoge, said yesterday that harassment of news vendors by striking union members had cut so deeply into his paper's circulation that the company had begun giving away 200,000 copies a day.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN F. KENNEDY JR. has passed the Connecticut bar exam, but he will have to wait until next week to find out if he passed the New York State bar exam, which he has failed twice. Mr. Kennedy, a 29-year-old graduate of New York University Law School, and 1,488 other people took the Connecticut test, and 1,081 passed it.

title: Cabot Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossc-After income from discontinued operations of $ 24,566,000, or 99 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 24,566,000, or 95 cents a share, in the year.Year-ago losses from continuing operations of $ 67,891,000 and $ 6,509,000 in the quarter and year, respectively, included net restructuring charges of $ 63,800,000.

title: Satmars Win Approval Of Williamsburg Plan
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected an attempt by Hispanic groups to block plans by Hasidic Jews to build a 6,000-seat synagogue, a school and faculty housing in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: Home Beneficial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included unspecified net gains related primarily to the sale of Regency Square Regional shoppiing center and an unspecified charge against income for the cumulative effect of the adoption of Financial Accounting Standard 96.

title: Robert Half International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pretax gain of $ 276,000 and $ 336,000 from the repurchase of debentures for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included pretax gains of $ 440,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: Hearns Visits Troopers
description: Thomas Hearns, winner of five boxing championships in his career, won over American troops in Saudi Arabia yesterday at the start of an eight-day World U.S.O. tour. Hearns autographed helmet liners and shook hands to boost the morale of the troops. "They are true fighters," Hearns said of the soldiers. "I know what I'm facing when I step in that boxing ring. They don't have any idea what's in store for them."(AP)

title: Pier 1 Imports Inc. reports earnings for 13wks Sept 1
Berkley (W.R.) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects special charge of $ 10,560,000 on after-tax basis from arbitration proceeding involving a subsidiary and several of its former reinsurers. Also reflects estimated tax benefits from the Tax Reform Act of 1986 of $ 255,000 for the quarter and $ 765,000 for the 9 months of 1990.

title: Chrysler And Fiat: No Deal
description: After months of speculation that the Chrysler Corporation was about to form an alliance with the Fiat Group of Italy, the two companies said today that they had broken off talks.

title: Suit Says TRW Cheated Air Force
description: A whistleblower's lawsuit is accusing TRW Inc.'s space and military division of inflating bids and double-billing the Air Force on classified contracts. Frank M. Breene, a retired TRW acquisitions manager, said in a $20 million Federal lawsuit that TRW violated the False Claims Act by submitting false bids and falsely allocating costs from 1982 to 1990.

title: Patents; Talking Book Made With Bar Codes
description: BAR code labels, those familiar if inscrutable blocks of black and white stripes, have long been used to store prices on groceries as well as information for such things as shipping orders and even business forms. Now, Matsushita Electric Works Ltd. of Japan has received an American patent on a way to use bar codes to create talking books and labels.

title: Final Four Become Free Agents
description: While Darryl Strawberry prepared to field contract offers beginning Monday, the final four eligible players became free agents yesterday. Scott Sanderson of Oakland, Mickey Hatcher of Los Angeles, Mark Thurmond of San Francisco and Mike Pagliarulo of San Diego brought the total number of available free agents to 95.

title: Wider Corruption Found, New York Telephone Says
description: The president of New York Telephone yesterday described a broader problem of corruption in the company's buildings department than had been previously indicated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "This magnificent donation of masterpieces sets an extraordinary example of generosity and public spirit." -- Richard Oldenburg, director of the Museum of Modern Art, which is being given William S. Paley's art collection. [ 1:5. ]

title: The Endowment's New Lease on Life
description: A bureaucratic nightmare: That's what detractors think Congress created in the legislation reauthorizing the National Endowment for the Arts for three more years. There may also be a minefield in the fuzzily worded requirement that the agency's grants take into consideration "general standards of decency and respect for the diverse beliefs and values of the American public."

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Stores Co., Salt Lake City, Utah, said its Skaggs Alpha Beta Inc. supermarket chain had completed the previously announced sale of its Buttrey food and drug division to an investment group led by the Los Angeles-based merchant banking firm Freeman Spogli & Company for $184 million. * Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd., Hong Kong's flag carrier, said it was interested in buying all or part of Dan-Air Engineering Ltd., the aircraft servicing arm of Dan-Air, a British charter flight operator. * Delco Electronics Corp., Kokomo, Ind., a unit of GM Hughes Electronics Corp., and Saab-Scania A.B.'s Combitech unit of Linkoping, Sweden, announced the formation of Mecel A.B., a joint-development company for automotive electronics. * EECO Inc., Santa Ana, Calif., a manufacturer of switch and keyboard products, signed a definitive agreement to sell EECO Computer Inc., its hotel-systems unit, to a Hong Kong investor group. Terms were not disclosed. * Honeywell Inc., Minneapolis, said it had been selected as lead contractor by Boeing Co., the aviation company, to supply avionics systems for the new Boeing 777 widebody jet. * Kentucky Medical Insurance Co., Louisville, Ky., completed the acquisition of United Leaseshares Inc., effective yesterday. Terms were not disclosed. * Qintex Entertainment Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., said that it had sold more than $40 million of assets to RHI Entertainment. * Southdown Inc., Houston, an oil, gas and cement concern, and Lone Star Industries Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a cement company, said they had mutually agreed to terminate their previously announced agreement under which Southdown's Southwestern Portland Cement Co. unit was to buy Lone Star's Maryneal, Tex., cement plant and related facilities. * Ultimate Corp., East Hanover, N.J., a maker of minicomputer-based business systems, dismissed 175 of its employees, or 25 percent of its total work force, in a shift of its business toward software and services and away from direct sales of hardware.

title: Marion Barry's Toughest Campaign: A Bid for Respect as Well as Office
description: "I'm hot! I'm hot!" Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. exults, reaching for the hand of a prospective voter.

title: CALL OF THE WILDMEN
description: Gabriel gives the show away with his remark about the "presentable-looking guys" at the Wildman Gathering. "With only a few exceptions," he writes, "they didn't strike me as life's losers."

title: Staying with a Baron At a Scottish Castle
description: DAVID LESLIE remembers driving to Leslie, Scotland, years ago with his father. There were only half a dozen houses, clustered in a tiny village, and the scenery was -- as it still is -- spectacular: the Bennachie Mountains, a spur of the rugged Grampian chain, looming off to the west and, all around, the handsome, prosperous farms of Aberdeenshire. And, of course, there was the castle. Bearing his name.

title: For Russians, Firsthand Lessons In Capitalism
description: A GROUP of Soviet executives, including the chief accountant of a Siberian tire plant, a lawyer and a division chief for a machine-building plant, have arrived in the county to study firsthand the dynamics of America's market-driven economy.

title: Lightweight Pair Holds On for U.S.
description: Steve Peterson and Robert Dreher of the United States fought back from a near-disaster early in the race to win the men's lightweight double sculls title today at the world rowing championships.

title: Lifestyle; A Wood-Paneled Refuge Beckons The People Used to Being Left Out
description: It was lunchtime at the New Yorker Club in midtown Manhattan, with its wood-paneled walls, brass chandeliers, overstuffed chairs and grand old bar. This new club resembles many others in the neighborhood, but there is one big difference: its 500 members are mostly people who historically have been locked out of other private clubs: blacks, people of Hispanic descent, Asians and women.

title: Voters Facing a Question on Reapportionment
description: ON Tuesday's ballot, Connecticut voters will consider a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would give the state more time to restructure its Congressional and General Assembly districts as a result of revisions in the figures from 1990 Census.

title: War? Make the Case
description: President Bush strains to sound bellicose, implying that American troops defending Saudi Arabia might now go on the offense and thundering angrily against Saddam Hussein's cruel and provocative mistreatment of Western hostages. The anger is surely justified. But hot words are poor premises for war; indeed, Mr. Bush is starting to stumble over his own oratory, suggesting for instance that compared with Saddam Hussein, Hitler was better (because he, at least, respected "the legitimacy of embassies.")

title:
FILM;
Kevin Costner Journeys to a New Frontier
description: "IT WAS VERY MUCH LIKE THE Hardy Boys or something," says Kevin Costner of his new film. "It was like, 'Hey, let's do a show.' "

title: A Temper Tantrum in the Film Industry
description: DAVID MAMET is well known in the theater world as the author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning "Glengarry Glen Ross," as well as "American Buffalo" and "Sexual Perversity in Chicago."

title: Ghastly and Unnatural Ambitions
description: THE WITCHING HOUR By Anne Rice. 965 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Pro Hockey; Ranger Effort Is Unrewarded
description: There had been a lack of resolve, a scarcity of goals, a complete absence of luck. When it was over, though, and the Rangers dressed soberly, if not somberly in their locker room, there was an abundance of perspective.

title: RUSHDIE IN HIDING
description: SALMAN RUSHDIE IS carrying more weight -- that was my first thought, as I glimpsed him from the foyer through a partially opened door. It had gathered in his cheeks, beneath his chin, above his belt especially. And as I was ushered in to see him, and as we stood together in the small, sparely furnished room waiting for his bodyguards to close the door behind us, I detected signs of the weight we do not measure but sense, the heartfelt burdens of deep loneliness and fear. His skin had a grayish night-pallor. His thinning hair was unkempt, he needed a shave, and his heavily lidded eyes, behind large glasses, seemed dulled and focused inward. He looked like a man who had not known a decent night's sleep for longer than he cared to remember. He looked the kind of tired for which sleep does little good.

title: Dresden's Magnificent Museums
description: THE modern-day porcelain collector Baron Kaspar von Utz, in Bruce Chatwin's novel "Utz," observes, "The craving for porcelain is like the craving for oranges." As he is quick to point out, he is borrowing the phrase from August the Strong. The 18th-century Saxon king had a passion for porcelain that made him turn his court city of Dresden into an enormous porcelain museum and the nearby city of Meissen into the porcelain center of the Western world. It doesn't take a visitor to Dresden long to see the extent of his passion in the city's museums.

title: Aid Pared for Young Offenders
description: MIGUEL had the cards stacked against him since elementary school. He was a drug abuser with bouts of uncontrollable behavior and he was a runaway from a home where he had been neglected and a victim of incest. Miguel was also learning disabled.

title:
FORUM;
Time for the Ex-Im Bank to Fade Away
description: CONGRESS struggled mightily to cut the deficit, yet one very large sacred cow still lives: the Export-Import Bank. Created in 1934 to subsidize trade with the Soviet Union, the bank since then has grown to subsidize exports to countries around the world.

title: Medicare Orders an Inquiry Into Florida Health Insurers
description: The overseer of the nation's Medicare program ordered an investigation into the marketing and patient practices of Florida health maintenance organizations with Federal contracts.

title: THE GUIDE
description: LAW AND ART

title: Nostalgia
description: To the Editor: A bit of nostalgia in Eureka Springs, Ark. There was a brick wall with the paint peeling with the following sign: Uneeda Biscuits -- 5; currently, Uneeda Biscuits are $1.49. VICTOR SIEGEL Red Bank, N.J.

title: INSIDE
description: Collusion May Cost Baseball $280 Million The issue involving major league owners found guilty of collusion in stifling free agency for baseball players in 1985, 1986 and 1987 has reportedly been resolved. The agreement may result in a $280 million payment to the players. Sports, section 8. Rare, and Formidable, Allies In a development reflecting the value of coalition-building, business groups joined the health care industry and children's advocates in getting Congress to expand Medicaid. Page 24. African Congress Struggle The African National Congress, restored to legal status only nine months ago, faces difficulties in waging a political struggle. Page 20. Birders Flock to Rye A wood sandpiper, not seen in North America outside Alaska since 1907, turned up in Rye, N.Y. Page 46. News Summary, Page 2 Obituaries, Page 48 Weather, Page 49

title: Vest Protects Officer Shot in Chest in Bronx
description: A bulletproof vest protected a police officer from serious injury late Friday night in a Bronx apartment building where he had gone in response to a call about an emotionally disturbed person, the police said.

title: Sports of the Times; Telling It Like He Thinks It Is
description: FOR too many years Howard Cosell pompously proclaimed that he "told it like it is." What he really meant was that he told it like he thinks it is. As he did the other day in alleging that Lawrence Taylor is using "fresh vials of Bible Belt urine" to cheat on his National Football League drug tests.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Harassment And High School
description: NOTHING Ilene S. Levitt did in her first three and a half years as principal of Amherst Regional High School in Massachusetts caused as much controversy as the school's new sexual-harassment policy regarding student-to-student behavior.

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: Photographers who hike, bike, cross-country ski or otherwise enjoy the great outdoors know the virtues of traveling light. When you're essentially self-propelled, every extra ounce of gear adds a measureable burden. Compactness counts, too, because you don't want to wear an expedition pack for an afternoon jaunt.

title: UNDER MY SKIN
description: Oh, how you brought back memories of my teen-age years, when I fell in love with Frankie. I heard his "Songs for Swingin' Lovers" album at the house of a boy I was in love with some 35 years ago, at the age of 15, when I was growing up in a London suburb. I spent a good part of a paycheck on my first LP, "Come Fly With Me."

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BRIDGEWATER ROAD RALLY

title: Stop Arming the Third World
description: Now that the cold war has ended, we should try to end one of its most evil side effects: the reckless arming of third-world countries with modern weapons.

title: For C. S. Lewis, Does Love Conquer All?
description: YOU WOULD HARDLY HAVE expected it to turn into one of the great love stories. He was a 52-year-old Irishman, the author of the international best sellers "The Chronicles of Narnia" and "The Screwtape Letters," a Christian theorist who had become a national celebrity discussing religion on the radio during World War II, a longtime Oxford lecturer and Magdalen College fellow, a bachelor settled into a comfortable life with a congenial older brother. She was a 35-year-old American, a New York Jew, a prize-winning poet married to the scenarist of Tyrone Powers's eerie "Nightmare Alley," the mother of two young sons.

title: Case Testing Right to Die 'Aged Us All'
description: There is a comforting rhythm to Midwestern life on these autumn weekends. The Carthage Tigers closed out another mediocre season at home against the Neosho Wildcats. The turkey hunting was off a little this fall and the fishing is a little better, which is good news down at the Snak-Atak convenience store, where the bait-vending machine offers fresh night crawlers for $1.75 a dozen.

title: Ms. Perry to Wed Jordan Rubinson
description: Dr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Perry of New Haven, Conn., have announced January wedding plans for their daughter Rachel Eve Perry and Jordan Daniel Rubinson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Rubinson of Teaneck, N.J.

title: No Palace Like Home
description: PAVLOVSK The Life of a Russian Palace. By Suzanne Massie. Illustrated. 394 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $29.95.

title: All's Fair Love and Physics
description: BEGINNING THE WORLD AGAIN By Roberta Silman. 414 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Kremlin Cup, first professional men's tennis tournament in the Soviet Union, through Sunday. * Intel displays technology for integrating video and computer screens. * Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills. * October auto sales. TUESDAY: Third-quarter productivity. * Hearing in Tyler, Tex., on damage awards for 2,128 asbestos victims. WEDNESDAY: Consumer credit for September. * Treasury auctions 10-year notes. THURSDAY: Major retailers announce October sales. * Treasury auction of 30-year bonds. * Nordstrom's motion to dismiss the State of Washington's suit over the retailer's employee compensation practices goes before a judge in Seattle. FRIDAY: Producer prices for October.

title: Latest Draw Leaves a Few Chess Fans Bored
description: Although 8 of the first 10 games have ended in draws, the World Championship Chess Match has generally kept spectators absorbed in the excitement of daring attacks and extraordinary blunders, as the tide of battle has shifted back and forth at a dizzying pace.

title: The War Window
description: As the military standoff in the Persian Gulf continues, various journalistic generals are forecasting hostilities with some impressive-sounding precision. According to Newsweek, local conditions create a "window for war" in cooler months from November to February, the optimal time being Nov. 17, in the darkness of a new moon. That old standby -- an unnamed "Western diplomat" -- is quoted as remarking gloomily, "Either there's a real confrontation before the New Year, or Saddam wins."

title: At End, More Pressure on Feinstein
description: They were the kind of voters Dianne Feinstein had to motivate to win, elderly Mexican-Americans at the Casa Ramona Community Center here amid the vast suburbs east of Los Angeles. "I need your help -- we need to mobilize our vote," the Democratic candidate urged them on Friday, after a lunch of tamales, beans and rice.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WALTZING IN THE ATTIC. By P. B. Parris. (Doubleday, $18.95.) P. B. Parris's first novel spans 60 years in the life of Hannah Meier, a woman so oppressed she bears more resemblance to the mice skittering across the attic floor than she does to the young girl who once waltzed in front of its mirrors. Living under the iron thumb of her dogmatic father, then of her erratic brother and illegitimate sons, Hannah finally cracks. One senses a better novel lurking in this saga of a rural Nebraska family ruled by Bible-thumping patriarchs whose hypocrisy is topped only by their ignorance. But in the hands of a clumsy first-person narrator -- Hannah herself -- the material rarely rises above the level of bad television. There are certainly enough florid plot twists to fuel a mini-series: a car wreck that paralyzes the narrator's sister and kills her boyfriend, an incestuous rape and a baby born during a tornado, no less. What finally trips Hannah's wire is the sight of her brother and sons sitting glassy-eyed in front of a pornographic videotape. And her actions trigger the sort of blood bath we now find almost daily in the morning newspapers. In the final pages of "Waltzing in the Attic," spent in the crazy labyrinth of Hannah's mind, the novel loses its pedestrian quality and approaches art. But by now it's too late.

title: Gorbachev Steers Middle Course on Lithuania; Subsidy and Separatism
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wizard Who Spun Black Rock Into Gold; Power Source
description: William Paley was my maximum boss for half a century. We were never intimates, but after some tense ups and downs in our relationship we became good friends in the later years. I felt the attraction of his powerful personality, but I never quite figured him out. He could be warm, then cold; imaginative, then dogmatic; kindly, then ruthless, a money-loving man who could spend it lavishly and often with a true generosity toward others.

title: Scab Labor in a Union Town
description: For some decades now, New York City has been a union town. What does that mean? Not that unions are to be regarded as a band of angels, nor that they are always good and wise. It means that unions are acknowledged as a legitimate part of the city's life, a partner in the social contract that more or less shapes our society.

title: World Views
description: FOR MORE than two decades, educators, scholars and politicians alike have called for public schools and universities to restructure their curriculums to include the contributions of women, blacks, Hispanics, Asians and other groups historically overlooked.

title: Business Diary/October 28-November 2
description: COMPANIES General Motors Scales Down, Ford and Chrysler Fall Back Alfred P. Sloan Jr.'s credo for turning General Motors into the world's largest company was simple: "Growth," he said, "is essential to the good health of an enterprise. Deliberately to stop growing is to suffocate." But size can be stifling as well, and last week G.M. gave up hope of regaining the immense portion of the market it has lost. The auto maker plans to shut nine plants, leaving it with a record quarterly loss of $1.98 billion G.M. executives want a company at least as trim and fit as Ford became after closing plants and cutting costs proved his company's decision to change course. "Any rigidity by an automobile manufacturer, no matter how large or how well established, is severly penalized by the market," he wrote. G.M. said its write-offs cover all foreseeable costs, but many analysts wonder whether G.M. will continue to shrivel. As James P. Womack, who studies the auto industry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said, "The real question is whether four years from now we'll just be repeating the process."

title: A Bad 'Budget Deal' <
description: This week's alarming employment statistics -- 68,000 jobs lost in October, after 52,000 disappeared in September -- not only suggested further national slippage into recession but that the celebrated new "budget deal" was the wrong economic medicine.

title:
END PAPER;
Undermining Overteachers
description: COLLEGE professors range from the serious, scholarly sort who forgo cturing in favor of reading verbatim from their own books, to the hipper variety whose lectures sound more like Sally Jessy Raphael than Ralph Waldo Emerson. But one type of professor is familiar to all undergraduates, recent and retired, whether they are A+ library dwellers or the type who coordinate their notebooks with their belt and shoes: The Overteacher.

title: Mutual Funds; The Ultimate in Bears and Bulls
description: JAMES M. BENHAM, chairman of the Benham Capital Management Group, in Mountain View, Calif., remembers what it feels like to be poor. His father supported 10 children on a minister's salary, and at dinner, he said, the rule was, "Pass the potatos, no stops." That's because if each child took an extra scoop, the bowl would be empty before it made it around the table. By the time he went to college, on scholarship, he wanted "to major in money on the theory that some would rub off on me," he said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart last week with an article about investment in South Africa misidentified one of the 10 largest American companies to have left South Africa. The company, ranking seventh, was Allegheny International, not the Alleghany Corporation.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LOVER OF HISTORY. By Jonathan Dee. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) In his first novel, "The Lover of History," 28-year-old Jonathan Dee has much to say, as well as a story to tell. Conjuring up a vividly evoked Manhattan where "yellow taxis darted in and out of each other's company like fish," Mr. Dee constructs a cat's cradle of connections out of three characters' relationships to one other, to their personal histories and to events unfolding in the world around them. Diane Kendall and her roommate, Robert Warner (always referred to by their last names), live a cold existence where "eating alone seemed the norm." Although they've occupied a thinly partitioned bedroom for two years, they barely know each other. Kendall hates her job as an engineer at an all-news radio station and grows weary of her lover Julian's lack of ambition to move beyond singing advertising jingles. Then the American Secretary of State is assassinated in the tiny island nation of Colozan and the United States declares war -- and the murder and its formulaic reportage in the media become catalysts for varying degrees of growth in each character. Julian, the innocuous charmer who signs petitions without reading them, grows least. Kendall, however, sees links between her alienation from her personal history and her estrangement from the larger currents of life; she recognizes that "the source of things might be found outside herself" and starts edging beyond Julian's sphere. Most intriguing is the high-minded if sanctimonious Warner, the lover of history of the title, a teacher who urges his pampered prep-school students to see their role in and responsibility for the larger world, yet is himself adrift in time and place. Some of Mr. Dee's pre-Iraq political gambits now seem obsolete, but more often they prove prophetic. This gifted young author, acutely aware of how lives intersect with history, himself weds art to wisdom with admirable authority.

title: New York City Marathon; 25,000 Runners, 1.5 Million Cups
description: WITH uncomfortably warm weather conditions forecast, the 21st New York City Marathon will begin at 10:47 this morning with a record number of starters expected (more than 25,000), several dozen of the best distance runners in the world and a race director who has an entirely new perspective on his race, his life and the world around him.

title: Traffic Alert
description: New York City Marathon: Several streets will be closed for much of this morning and afternoon, including, in Manhattan, First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge; Fifth Avenue from 136th Street to 100th Street, and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Columbus Circle. In Brooklyn, parts of Fourth Avenue from 94th Street to Flatbush Avenue will be closed. In addition, some traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge and the Madison Avenue Bridge will be closed for parts of the day. The upper level of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge will be closed in both directions from 12:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M., and the westbound lower level from 9:45 A.M. to 11:45 A.M.

title: Curious, Yet Familiar
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Rootlessness
description: IN THE MANNER of her ancestors, the girl knelt in the midst of a circle of her peers, placed a bit of ceremonial tobacco in a basket and gave thanks for the goodness of the Creator. Each Monday at the Hannahville Indian Reservation School in Michigan, the children participate in this ancient ritual, in which they are purified by the smoke from a burning stalk of braided sweetgrass.

title: Germany's 'Miracle Machine' Is Left in the Blocks
description: FOUR days before its 41st anniversary, on Oct. 7, the German Democratic Republic -- East Germany -- disappeared from the map. Founded as an experiment to establish socialism on German soil and as a counterbalance to the Federal Republic of Germany -- West Germany -- East Germany failed for all kinds of reasons, political, economic, ecological and cultural. But to put it in one sentence: the capitalism of West Germany was stronger.

title:
MULLICA HILL JOURNAL;
A Bucolic Crossroads Ties Its Financial Future to the Past
description: THIS bucolic crossroads, one of the state's oldest settlements, decided a while back to tie its financial future to the past. So far, by most accounts, it's worked out rather well.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Medical Student Refresher
description: LAST year when most of her classmates at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School were fretting over residencies and final exams, Wendy Sternberg was worrying about polio and malaria.

title: Gorbachev Steers Middle Course on Lithuania; 'Your Excellency'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; A Brazilian's Version Of Haydn's 'Creation'
description: Rodrigo Pedeneiras is a better choreographer than Grupo Corpo, the company he co-founded in Belo Horizonte, Brazil, indicates at first glance.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: One consequence of opening up Eastern Europe is that the Soviet Union is now a part of the international bridge community. It became a member of the World Bridge Federation at the start of the world championships held recently in Geneva. A contingent of players took part mainly from Moscow and the Baltic States.

title: At Mrs. Gorbachev's School, Hardy a Communist in Sight
description: The question before the 10th-grade history class at Raisa M. Gorbachev's old school was: How many students would like some day to enter the ranks of the Communist Party?

title: Barbara Hawkins Wed to Frank Sci
description: Barbara Kathryn Hawkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Hawkins of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Frank Paul Sci, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carmello J. Sci of Searingtown, L.I. The Rev. Leslie C. Hughs performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, assisted by the Rev. Thomas F. DeVita, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Reputation by Citation
description: CARDOZO A Study in Reputation By Richard A. Posner. 156 pp. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. $18.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
Cuisine That's in Tune With the Seasons
description: THERE'S nothing more inviting on a crisp autumn day than to tuck into a satisfying meal at a cozy country inn, and Pennsylvania's Bucks County has more than its share of atmospheric eating places. Most of them are dotted along the Delaware River, but Sign of the Sorrel Horse is hidden down a back lane in the northwest corner of the county on the fringe of Lake Nockamixon State Park.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Danbury, Conn. 205,000 7 Hubbell Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; large stone fireplace in living room, whirlpool bath, 1.2 acres; taxes $2,153. East Haddam, Conn. 177,500 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; rear deck, pond, eat-in kitchen, 4.8 acres; taxes $1,695. Old Saybrook, Conn. 170,000 6 Church Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old ranch; enclosed porch w/skylight, h/w floors, 1-car garage, 0.40 acre; taxes $1,712. Larchmont, N.Y. 359,400 42 Maplewood Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 64-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, 2 decks, eat-in kitchen; taxes $8,900. Scarsdale, N.Y. 520,000 88 Spier Road 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; fireplace, screened porch, modern eat-in kitchen, 2 dens, playroom; taxes $9,775. Yonkers, N.Y. $275,000 46 Oriole Road 4-bedroom, 1 full-, 2 half-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fireplace, study, eat-in kitchen, 3,000 square feet, 1.5-car garage, deck; taxes $3,500. OTHER AREAS Randolph, N.J. 412,500 22 Indian Trail 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; lakefront property, deck, fireplace; taxes $6,312. Union, N.J. 180,000 782 Evergreen Parkway 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; finished basement, c/a, updated kitchen; taxes $3,067. Merrick, L.I. 184,000 1778 Elsie Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,200.

title: Sharpening Pencils
description: Whatever it looks like, that is not chaos at Random House. The haute literati may have been agog when Joni Evans was replaced last week by Harold Evans, no relation, as publisher at Random, but Miss Evans insisted it was simply a matter of finally getting what she wanted after three years. And that is to head a smaller unit within the company that will publish books under her own imprint. Mr. Evans, too, may be getting something special -- besides one of the premiere jobs in publishing. In 1982, he left The Times of London, where he had been a legendary editor for 14 years, after repeated conflicts with the paper's publisher, Rupert Murdoch. As Random House publisher one one of his first big projects will be Mr. Murdoch's memoirs, which the publisher recently acquired. He said he was already sending Mr. Murdoch a letter saying, in part, "The wheel of fortune makes me your publisher as you used to be mine. I think it will be a happier experience for you than it was for me. But please don't pull any punches."

title: Bulgarian Ralliers Urge Ex-Communist Government to Quit
description: With the country trapped by deepening economic crisis and political paralysis, thousands of Bulgarians rallied in central Sofia today to demand that their renamed Communist rulers admit their failures and resign.

title:
ART;
Sculpture by Novel Means
description: YOU can't say that "Diverse Representations 1990," the exhibition chosen by John Yau to inaugurate the Morris Museum's sparkling 20,000-square-foot gallery addition, fits the new space hand-in-glove. Mr. Yau has put together a sculpture show with the work of 12 artists who are not shy about putting materials -- both traditional and novel -- together in two combinations. The work rattles around and makes visual "noise."

title: An Early Tribute to Performers From Mamet
description: DAVID MAMET is the play wright king of the con. From "American Buffalo," his breakthrough full-length play in 1976, to "Speed-the-Plow" most recently seen on Broadway, Mr. Mamet has been the acknowledged, masterful voice of power-crazed, double deal-making and assorted chicanery.

title: Clemency Urged in Drug Case
description: A teen-ager once accused of selling the cocaine that President Bush later held up in a televised anti-drug speech has received a 10-year sentence in a separate drug-selling case from a Federal district judge who says the mandatory penalty is too harsh. In imposing the punishment on Wednesday, the judge, Stanley Sporkin, suggested to the defendant, Keith Jackson, that he ask the President to exercise clemency to reduce the sentence, which was mandated by Congress for those who sell drugs near a schoolyard.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house, which is 50 years old, has become so damp that even the carpeting on the second floor feels damp. A professional waterproofing contractor said it would cost us $9,500 to waterproof the house. He recommended "bleeding the walls" by knocking holes in each section of block, running a French drain across the floor, digging around the outside, waterproofing the foundation and then regrading the soil so that it slopes away from the house. The contractor also wants to apply a waterproof paint. We thought the price to be excessive and do not know what to do. What do you think?

title: Community Theater Tackles Sondheim
description: WHO'S afraid of Stephen Sondheim? Profit-minded theater owners and strictly entertainment-seeking audiences, that's who. But not the members of PMT Productions, a community theater group based in Yorktown that is to present its sixth Sondheim musical, "Into the Woods," this month.

title: News's Loyal Readers Are Split on Strike, Too
description: Mickey Heit walked out of his neighborhood candy store with a copy of The New York Post tucked under his arm, barely glancing at a stack of yesterday's Daily News that lay free for the taking on the corner. Although he is a regular News reader, he said that picking up a free copy had a higher hidden cost.

title: Data Bank/November 4, 1990

FEASTS & CELEBRATIONS;
Well-Equipped For Guests
description: These kitchen utensils, bar accessories and serving pieces are good-looking and perform like precision tools; plus, they're reasonably priced and designed for easy handling

title: College Football: South; Auburn Routed for First Loss
description: Florida took advantage of turnovers and Terence Barber's 73-yard punt return to explode for 27 second-quarter points tonight as the Gators took a share of first place in the Southeastern Conference with a 48-7 rout of Auburn.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Chappaqua on Oct. 21 and an accompanying map misidentified Pleasantville and Edgemont. Pleasantville is a village, not a town. Edgemont is a hamlet in the Town of Greenburgh, not a section of Scarsdale.

title: New S.A.T.'s, Old Criticisms
description: THERE was little disagreement in education circles that it was high time to revise "the S.A.T.'s ", on which college admissions and scholarship possibilities have hung for generations of high school students. The revised test finally approved by the College Board last week after three years of tinkering contained some significant changes, but the changes fell short of what many educators hoped for and were criticized by groups who said the new tests failed to eliminate ethnic and gender bias.

title: Scholarship That Frees Mozart's Piano Concertos
description: ALL OF MOZART'S 27 PIANO concertos performed on period instruments have now been recorded by the fortepianist Malcolm Bilson with the English Baroque Soloists conducted by John Eliot Gardiner. The concertos are available on individual compact disks, but Archiv, the early-music line of Deutsche Grammophon, has also collected the last eight concertos on a four-CD set (427846-2, compact disk only) that one more time begs us to consider just what is happening to the way we perform and hear Mozart as we approach celebrations of the Mozart bicentennial year with its promised glut of concerts, recordings and Mozartiana.

title: Rosemarie Schoeffer, A Chocolatier, 79; Founded 13 Stores
description: Rosemarie R. Schoeffer, founder of the Rosemarie de Paris chocolate shops, died yesterday in New York Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-22

title: 'A Mockery Of Elections?'
description: The question posed in "Agreement on Judicial Candidates" [ Oct. 14 ] ,about the three-year deal made last year (and relevant to the coming election) between the major parties for judicial cross-endorsements, is an important one: "Is it a step toward a nonpartisan judiciary, or a mockery of elections?"

title: Gorbachev Steers Middle Course on Lithuania; Leninism Not Obsolete
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Grossberg to Wed Robert Finkel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ewel Grossberg of Long Beach, Calif., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter, Linda Ann Grossberg, and Robert Alan Finkel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Finkel of New York and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Resettled Afghan Farmers Face Uphill Task
description: The 800 Afghans who returned to work at a state farm here a year ago under an experimental resettlement program have learned how great will be the task of rebuilding their shattered country.

title: College Football; Irish Sputter but Win Big
description: Lou Holtz may be the master of somber hyperbole, but Notre Dame's 52-31 victory over Navy at Giants Stadium today was spotty enough to have the coach's customarily extreme post-game assessment met with less eye-rolling than normal.

title: Why the Japanese Find It So Difficult To Unsheath Swords
description: FOR four decades Japan's leadership has gone to extraordinary lengths to keep one issue off the country's political agenda: the real meaning of the famous "peace clause" in Japan's American-imposed Constitution. Over the years, the Government has gained a kind of grudging public acceptance that Japan needs what it carefully terms the Self-Defense Forces, despite the Constitution's clear prohibition that "land, sea and air forces, as well as other war potential, will never be maintained." But that acceptance has hinged on an oft-repeated assurance -- aimed at Asian neighbors as much as Japan's own populace -- that the military would never again stray from Japan's shores.

title: Protesters on Opposite Sides Still Defying Pretoria
description: The language of defiance and frustration with the changes set in motion by President F. W. de Klerk resounded today in gatherings at opposite ends of South Africa's political spectrum.

title: Car Rentals
description: To the Editor: Regarding Nancy Sharkey's article "Cutting the Cost of Car Rentals" (Practical Traveler, Sept. 9): I recently rented a car for nine days. I had checked with all major car rental agencies and found the cost to range from $275 to over $500. Since I live in Queens, I was looking for a car locally and, specifically, to be obtained at La Guardia Airport. Budget, at La Guardia, requires two major credit cards (I only have one). Therefore, I called their outlet on Queens Boulevard (approximately three miles from La Guardia). One credit card would suffice there, but the price was $75 more than at the airport. Nevertheless, it was also less than Budget's competitors so I rented the car there.

title:
ART;
Sculptors' Drawings Produce a Special Dynamic
description: ALL artists use the drawing medium as a way to conveniently explore as many facets of an idea as possible. Drawings rendered by sculptors tend to warrant a somewhat special kind of attention, for they sometimes refer to pieces whose full-scale execution may not be immediately feasible.

title: Pears Are All Around, but Caution's the Word
description: FINDING lush, ripe autumn pears is a challenge, one that requires time and patience. They are usually not available in that condition in the supermarket.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Darien
description: DARIEN is the epitome of Connecticut's gold coast. Sumptuous homes shaded by huge old maples and oaks line the country lanes of this 14.9-square-mile town of elegance and wealth.

title: James River's About To Invent Itself Again
description: DON'T call the James River Corporation a paper company when Bob Williams is around. Never mind that its nearly $6 billion in sales derive almost exclusively from paper products. Never mind that only paper analysts cover the company. Never mind that for a long time Mr. Williams was awfully proud that James River, which he co-founded 21 years ago, has grown to be one of the world's largest paper companies.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: POWERSHIFT: Knowledge, Wealth, and Violence at the Edge of the 21st Century. By Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) In "PowerShift," as in his earlier books "Future Shock" and "The Third Wave," the provocative social thinker Alvin Toffler urges us to contemplate, anticipate and act upon the extraordinary economic, social and political changes we face at the end of the 20th century. Mr. Toffler sees wide-ranging connections among the many separate events taking place in all these spheres. Thus the breakup of the Communist bloc, Michael Milken's exploitation of junk bonds and the increasing influence and sophistication of computer networks are all only symptoms of a larger "powershift" throughout the world. Bit by bit, in nations and in giant corporations alike, Mr. Toffler argues, the vast stores of information generated and made widely available by computer technology and by the mass media have taken power away from the centralized few at the top and given more to consumers, voters, workers and small businessmen. This has coincided with the growth of what Mr. Toffler calls our "super-symbolic" economy, one that is primarily based not on the production of goods but on the creation and dissemination of information, images and ideas. "PowerShift" is dense with jargon and buzz words: "For the new fact is that, as nations make the transition toward the advanced, super-symbolic economy, they need more horizontal self-regulation and less top-down control." And as is almost inevitable with an attempt at so sweeping a synthesis, some readers may grow uncomfortable with Mr. Toffler's relentless barrage of generalizations. These flaws should not overshadow his larger contribution, however. By placing the accelerated changes of our current information age in the larger perspective of history, Mr. Toffler helps us to face the future with less wariness and more understanding.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a gallery's schedule change, an art listing in the Arts and Leisure guide today for an exhibition of works by David Wojnarowicz is outdated. It is to open on Nov. 17, not this Saturday.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. CHARLOTTE L. DOYLE;
What Makes a Children's Book Good?
description: EDUCATORS say the best thing parents can do to give children an intellectual head start is to read to them. But what is it that makes a children's book a good one? What themes are appropriate for a young child? What do young children want from their books?

title:
Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;
Buying Houses For Homeless
description: A GOVERNMENT-FINANCED program that requires homeless people to meet a set of obligations in exchange for subsidized rental housing is about to start spending $3 million to acquire rowhouses here.

title: Beauty; MINOR ALTERATIONS
description: "Oh my dear, it's not ALL bad," murmured my stylish friend, squinting at the damage. "But you do have the look of one those mail-order Dresden dolls, don't you think? The kind from the Franklin Mint?"

title: How Much of Your Story Is True?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dislodging Incumbents Is Growing Harder
description: THE elections for six House of Representative seats on Long Island are more a matter of incumbent versus non-incumbent than Democrat against Republican.

title: Bush Signs Bill to Expand Head Start Program Fivefold
description: President Bush today signed a bill to substantially expand the Head Start pre-school program.

title: For Music's Sake, Young Pianist Comes to Stay
description: IN her native Algeria, when she played a Beethoven piano sonata for her grandmother, Karima Benameur was told to "stop making that noise!"

title: From Old Groups, A New Ensemble
description: THE Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester and the Chappaqua Orchestra have been lost, but some of the musicians and Louis Simon are determined to fill the cultural gap with an ensemble called the Fine Arts Symphony. Mr. Simon is the music director of the new group.

title: CRIME
description: "I know every bayou and channel from Sabine Pass over to Barataria," boasts Dave Robicheaux, the Cajun detective who works this swampy Louisiana territory in James Lee Burke's lushly descriptive crime novels. In A MORNING FOR FLAMINGOS (Little, Brown, $18.95), the tough but principled hero loses heart (as well as face) when two convicts escape his charge on their way to the penitentiary for execution, forcing him to plead with one of them for his life. Partly in penance and partly for vengeance, Dave leaves his rural home on Bayou Teche to set up a sting operation for the Feds in New Orleans.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; Supper Clubs: Taking Guests On the Town
description: THE STEAMY INCANDESCENCE OF nightlife in the 1980's seems ready to mellow to the soft glow of candelabra in the 90's. The over-25 crowd has all but abandoned those warehouses with decibel ranges approximating Boeing-jet test laboratories. Instead, they seek venues offering more intimacy, more style and, above all, comfort. This new genre of club-restaurants -- updated versions of the supper clubs of the 30's and 40's -- is taking root in such citiesas New York City, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington.

title: Senators Urge Bush to Lift Vietnam Embargo
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and seven other Democratic and Republican Senators have written to President Bush requesting the lifting of the 15-year-old trade embargo on Vietnam.

title: From Iraq, a Warning And a Hostage Offer
description: As Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d began a trip to consult allies about possible joint military action, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said his troops would wage a long war against any American-led force that sought to force them out of Kuwait.

title: Film Patrons Dread 'The End'
description: LAST summer, "Cinema Paradiso," a sentimental film about a little movie theater in Sicily, was a big hit at a little movie theater in Bantam. So the Oscar-winning film is being brought back for a return engagement.

title: Campus Life; Asian Languages Gain A Growing Following
description: With the emergence of Japan and Korea as world economic powers, East Asian languages are getting more attention at universities across the nation.

title: Passports
description: To the Editor: I had an experience on a recent trip to Italy that I hope will help others avoid grief. In Fiesole I lost my passport. It was on a weekend; the bank where I think I lost it was closed, and the American Consulate in nearby Florence was closed. On Monday morning I began making calls: first to the embassy in Rome, to the bank and finally to the Florence consulate. I found the process surprisingly easy.

title: Over Piles of Yarn, 4 Lives Intertwine
description: Piles of vivid wool yarns lie scattered on a Teaneck dining table like daubs of pigment on an artist's palette. Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, four women meet to stitch these threads, share their lives and lunch, as they have done for 10 years.

title: REGULATORS SUING LAW FIRM THEY USE
description: Regulators combing through the savings and loan wreckage are increasingly filing lawsuits against lawyers who represented savings institutions, accusing them of negligence or malpractice. This week, in a twist, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation filed suit against a law firm that is representing it in suits against other lawyers.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; WELL-PRICED WINES
description: IT MAY SOUND HERETICAL, BUT THE WINE YOU serve is less important than how much you offer. This is based on the observation that your guests will probably drink more than you or they suspect -- almost a bottle each over the course of an event -- which is not excessive because they are also eating.

title: Pro Basketball; Knicks Stunned By Celtics
description: For the second consecutive night, Patrick Ewing found himself handcuffed by foul trouble. This time, the Knicks did not escape.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; New Wines From an Old Region
description: The Hudson River Valley, whose wines are slowly gaining acceptance, is the nation's oldest winegrowing region. Wines have been made in the area since French Huguenot refugees settled in New Paltz, N.Y., in 1677. But the region's modern revival began in 1971, when the promotion-minded Mark Miller established the Benmarl Wine Company in Marlboro.
