Eighteen active wineries now dot the river's east and west sides -- all within a two-and-a-half-hour drive from New York City. They range from the 250,000-case-a-year Royal Wine Corporation, which makes only kosher wines, to the tiny Amberleaf Vineyards, which turns out fewer than 400 cases.

title: The Answers
description: 1. The sewing machine. Howe invented it in 1846; Singer promoted it for consumers. 2. The Chinese. 3. The fountain pen, in 1884. 4. China, with inventions like paper, movable type and ships with compartments to protect against sinking. 5. (B) 1783, Louis-Sebastian Lenormand, a French physicist. 6. In the 1920's, Birdseye, an American, devised a quick- freezing method for preserving foods. 7. Electricity. The exception, Daguerre, who in 1839 perfected the production of Daguerrotype, an early form of photographic plate. 8. James Rumsey, a protege of George Washington and Benjamin Franklin, developed a boat that used the propulsion system Franklin had devised in 1785. 9.Thomas Jefferson, who was an inventor and a kind of national information center on advances in the arts and sciences. 10. False. Otto Lilienthal, a German, made the first of 2,000 flights in 1891. 11. George Washington Carver, born in 1864 to slaves, developed 325 peanut- based products. 12. A. Nicola Tesla, born in Croatia, now part of Yugoslavia, in the 1880's. 13. The Mayan, A.D. 300 to 800, and Incan, whose height was between 1450 to 1532. 14. The lightning rod. 15. On Pearl Street in New York City, in 1882. 16. Alexander Graham Bell (1847-1922). 17. Woods (1856-1910) was born in Columbus, Ohio; his father was a former slave. He quit school at age 10 and was mostly self-taught. About 16 of his more than 60 patents are related to electricity. His first, in 1884, was for an improved steam-boiler furnace. Others include: an apparatus for sending messages by Morse code or articulate speech; a safe, energy-saving stage-lighting electrical system; an overhead conducting system for electric railways; the subway "third rail," and devices that resulted in the automatic air brake. 18. The elevator protected by safety devices, invented by Elisha Graves Otis. 19. (D) microchips. 20. (B) 1885. 21. Garrett A. Morgan, who was born in Paris, Ky., in 1877. His father was a mulatto; his mother, a former slave who was part black and part American Indian. Finishing elementary school, he eventually taught himself the mechanics of sewing machines and set up shop selling and repairing them. He accidentally discovered an effective hair straightener. The cream (and his factory) still exists. In 1912, he invented the "safety hood," forerunner of the gas mask (patented 1914), and in 1923 the traffic signal system. He started a newspaper for the black community, The Cleveland Call, now The Call and Post. 22. False. He was a chemist. 23. John Dunlop, a Scottish veterinarian, in the 1880's. 24. Bakelite, invented by Leo Baekeland, a Belgian-born chemist who came to America in 1889, and used for insulators and radios. 25. Lady Ada Lovelace, the daughter of Lord Byron. 26. "Mary had a little lamb," spoken by Edison into his new invention, the phonograph recorder, in 1877; "Mr. Watson, come here, I want you," spoken into the telephone invented by Bell (patented 1876); "Eureka!," supposedly shouted by Archimedes (287 B.C.- 212 B.C., approximately) on discovering the principle of buoyancy.

title: All About/Exercise Machines; The Fitness Boom Ends Up at Home
description: THE Marines still do their pull-ups.Heavyweights jump rope. But these days more and more ordinary Americans are trying to get in shape with elaborate and expensive home exercise equipment. Last year, they spent $1.73 billion, triple what they spent in 1980.

title: DONORS AND TRANSPLANTS
description: Nine years ago, I was told that I had less than three weeks to live ("The Drug That Works in Pittsburgh," by Barry Werth, Sept. 30). Thanks to a successful pioneering liver transplant performed by Thomas Starzl on Feb. 27, 1982, I'm still here almost a decade later. Dr. Starzl doesn't have to walk around with a perpetual smile on his face -- I'm grinning enough for the two of us! JOYCE S. WILLIG Fairfield, Conn.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; Viewing City Water, at Its Source
description: Turn on your faucet in New York City and it is likely that the water flowing out originated here in and around the Catskill Mountains, about 100 miles to the northwest, where the city owns andoperates two vast reservoir systems.

title: Kids' Stuff
description: EVERYBODY in the educational field knows that parental involvement is really important, and everybody wants more of it," said Dr. Jerold P. Bauch, director of the Betty Phillips Center for Parenthood Education at Vanderbilt University's Peabody College in Nashville. "But everyone is so busy these days that it seems impossible. Teachers run out of time and parents are also really busy, so the first thing you do is look for a technological answer."

title: Roman Soap
description: THE FIRST MAN IN ROME By Colleen McCullough. Illustrated. 896 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: Stephanie Claire Epstein Wed to Peter Alan Reiner
description: Stephanie Claire Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Epstein of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Peter Alan Reiner, a son of Martha Reiner of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and the late Charles Reiner. Rabbi David S. Halpern oficiated at Temple Beth El of Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; Hudson Valley Harvest Weekend
description: Phyllis and Ben Feder were unreachable the night before they were expecting 100 or so guests for the weekend. They were not being antisocial. The phone had been dead for three days. There was no running water. And the aftermath of a major hurricane had brought floods and tornado warnings to the entire Hudson Valley.

title: Twins on Different Tracks Through the Years
description: SERENDIPITOUS IS THE WORD for Ildiko Enyedi's "My 20th Century," an effervescent Hungarian celebration of electricity, love, movies and the infinite possibilities of man, woman and the chimpanzee.

title: Postings: Cooper Union Conference; The Infrastructure Issue
description: "Everybody knows the city is falling apart -- the bridges are in disrepair, the roads are are in disrepair, water mains break -- the infrastructure is old and outmoded and right now we don't even have the money to do maintenance."

title: Study Critical of Lending in E. Harlem
description: East Harlem residents and businesses had more than $220 million on deposit in the seven banks with branches in the neighborhood last year, but the banks awarded a total of only 15 mortgages to owners of houses and apartment buildings in the area, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house, which is 50 years old, has become so damp that even the carpeting on the second floor feels damp. A professional waterproofing contractor said it would cost us $9,500 to waterproof the house. He recommended "bleeding the walls" by knocking holes in each section of block, running a French drain across the floor, digging around the outside, waterproofing the foundation and then regrading the soil so that it slopes away from the house. The contractor also wants to apply a waterproof paint. We thought the price to be excessive and do not know what to do. What do you think?

title: Looking at Pay Phone Charges
description: The article "State Looking at Pay Phone Charges" (Sept. 23) told just part of the story of how alternative-operator telephone companies are mulcting us -- and not only in New Jersey, but elsewhere in the country.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Paying Parents To Help
description: WHEN parent meetings for the Stay In School Program at Public School 85 in the South Bronx break up, parentsmingle, striking up conversations in their native Spanish. Some greet neighbors quickly and leave; others linger over coffee. All sign an attendance sheet and take home an envelope containing $15, payment for attending workshops at their children's schools.

title:
MUSIC;
In Four Hours, Stage Is Set for Opera
description: UNLOAD two buses, a 24-foot truck, a van and 60 people including singers, musicians and staff, and the Western Opera Theater from San Francisco is ready to perform Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" anywhere. It takes about four hours to transform any site, good or bad, into a setting for the dramatic story of feuding noble families and tragic love. With an additional two hours, the cast is ready, in costumes, wigs and makeup.

title: Student Is Shot at Manhattan High School
description: A 15-year-old student was shot in the stomach by another student inside Martin Luther King Jr. High School on the Upper West Side of Manhattan on Friday, the police said.

title: A Manager System Is Preferred
description: The article "New Rochelle Debates Its Charter" [ Oct. 7 ] attributes remarks to me that require some clarification. In a far-reaching discussion, I commented on many aspects regarding the structure of the executive branch of local government and the advantages and disadvantages of at-large voting and district voting, respectively, for council members.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: IN THE NIGHT CAFE, by Joyce Johnson. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $7.95.) In the early 1960's, as the Beat Generation fades into the counterculture, 26-year-old Joanna Gold falls for a New York City painter who does everything to excess. Last year our reviewer, Phillip Lopate, said this novel "sails on its first-person narration: a fiercely believable, testifying voice that is pungent, close to the bone, stinging with candor."

title: Design Study Is Set for Golden Gate Bridge
description: The Golden Gate Bridge made it through the 1989 earthquake without any apparent damage. But bridge directors, who say spending $100 million to strengthen it would be a wise investment, have authorized a design study.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: KEEPER OF THE GATE. By Selwa (Lucky) Roosevelt. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) To work in protocol is to be eternally vigilant. That's the message of "Keeper of the Gate," a behind-the-scenes saga written by Selwa Roosevelt, the Reagan Administration's chief of protocol. Wearing certain colors, serving certain foods or beverages, proffering certain gifts, sitting a certain way would be sufficient to set off an international incident, she tells us. To work in protocol also requires forbearance (in a fit of pique, England's Prince Phillip slammed the door of an armored car in Mrs. Roosevelt's face), diplomacy (Mrs. Roosevelt managed to charm the Moroccan protocol chief, who was insulted that the United States was offering only five limousines for a state visit) and an economy-sized sense of humor. The stories Mrs. Roosevelt tells are frequently funny and revealing. That's what's good about this book. The problem is that Mrs. Roosevelt comes across as self-righteous ("I believed in the shining City on the Hill -- and when [Ronald Reagan] asked me to join his administration, I was grateful and ready to do my small bit to illuminate the American dream"), patronizing ("My protocol officers preferred the black African visitors above all others. With only a few exceptions the Africans were the kindest, the most gentle and compassionate. They . . . looked to my staff for guidance about everything"), and overly hostile toward Israel ("Terrorism was introduced into the Middle East," she writes, "as an instrument of national liberation by none other than the Israelis themselves").

title: San Francisco Journal; An Aging Crew Recreates a Trip on the Wild Side
description: All over town, it has produced a giddy sense of deja vu: a wild-looking bus covered with paintings of doves and clouds and weird squiggles and filled with strangely dressed people playing kazoos.

title: East Africa's Hideaway Isles
description: THE notebooks of the Portuguese and British navigators of the early 16th and 17th centuries who pushed into the Indian Ocean off the coast of East Africa are crammed with descriptions of the Seychelles, a scattered group of 115 lofty granite and low coral islands uninhabited until the late 1700's.

title: Shaking Up Rankings
description: One of those dramatic, end-of-the-game field goals ended Virgina's unbeaten streak yesterday and gave Georgia Tech a 41-38 victory that will undoubtedly depose the Cavaliers (7-1) from their across-the-board No. 1 ranking.

title: Lynne Elizabeth Byrnes Is Wed to Gregory Romano
description: Lynne Elizabeth Byrnes and Gregory Romano, both Deputy Attorneys General of New Jersey, were married yesterday at the bride's home in Princeton. Judge Arnold M. Stein of the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division, officiated.

title: Editors' Note
description: The front page of The Times Book Review today is devoted to "In All His Glory," a biography of William S. Paley, by Sally Bedell Smith. The review notes Mr. Paley's concern with dying; his death was announced on Oct. 26, after the section had gone to press.

title: Sports People; Deciding at Marquette
description: THE president of Marquette University, the Rev. Albert J. DiUlio, said he would decide this week whether Marquette will leave the Midwestern Collegiate Conference and join a new league that is expected to include DePaul, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Memphis State and Alabama-Birmingham. . . . Evander Holyfield, the new heavyweight boxing champion, is going to get a hometown welcome tomorrow when Atlanta honors him with a parade along Peachtree Street.(AP)

title: CALL OF THE WILDMEN
description: I heartily applaud the men's movement; I believe it may correct some of the excesses wrought by the women's movement.

title: Ms. Wilson Plans January Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. John O. Wilson of Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Edith, to Anthony David John Fleming, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Fleming of Leeds, England. A January wedding is planned.

title: Newspapers Watch What People Watch in the TV Campaign
description: INSPIRED by Theodore H. White's "Making of the President" books, newspaper journalists for a generation have covered political races from the inside out, traveling with the campaigns and reporting on their intrigues. This year, against mounting criticism that they had not kept pace with the modern campaign of sound bites, satellites and consultants, more than a score of major newspapers determined to watch televised political advertisements as vigorously as they did the road show. The last few months have seen dailies across America scrutinize the commercials, assessing their veracity in regular columns that political professionals have dubbed "truth boxes."

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Video Disks to Read By
description: STUDENTS and teachers in Los Angeles who thought that lasers and Shakespeare don't mix were shocked in September when video-disks arrived in some classrooms.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; Fantasy for A Good Cause
description: ON A CHILLY AUTUMN AFTERNOON, Penny Drue Baird, a doctoral candidate in psychology and the mother of a 10-year-old, rushed back to her apartment with the children's book hero Babar on her mind. The bemused but regal French elephant was the theme of the dinner party for 18 she was giving that evening at her home as one of 49 private parties constituting the New York Public Library's "Tables of Content -- Chapter IV" fund-raiser.

title: Wall Street; Taking Account Of the Boom In Mutual Funds
description: TRADITIONALLY, technical analysts see the earliest signs of a rally when the level of uninvested cash in the hands of mutual fund managers rises strongly above 10 percent. So when cash levels were hovering around 12 percent at the beginning of this year, it caused little excitement.

title: World Unity Is Focus of Bahai Faith
description: DISCUSSING the Persian Gulf crisis recently, the people who had gathered at Hooshmand Taraz's apartment in Stamford were finding parallels between the events that have followed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and those foreseen by the prophet Bahaulla a century ago.

title: Giants' Task Appears Easy
description: On paper, it looks so simple. The Giants are heavy favorites over the Colts on Monday night in Indianapolis, and the game could be a runaway.

title:
DINING OUT;
Tastes of the Portuguese in Tarrytown
description: CARAVELA seems to have evened out the checkered performance of its kitchen and its waiting staff. For Caravela at its very best, however, go during the week. On weekends, when a line of enthusiastic diners can spill out the door and onto the street, the busy kitchen is as likely as not to cook its fresh fish longer than necessary, efficient service can turn to hectic and air quality in the small dining space could do with better ventilation.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Children's Art, Wall To Wall
description: WHEN it comes to creativity, there's a lot grown-ups can learn from kids -- even grown-ups who earn their living through their creative impulses," said Richard Levenson, chief creative director of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, the eighth-largest advertising and communications company in the world, with more than 5,000 employees in 29 countries.

title: Fit To Survive
description: Amid the upheavals of Eastern Europe, Jerzy Urban has emerged as an exemplar of political Darwinism. The former spokesman for the Communist Government in Poland has not only survived but flourished by adapting to the new freedoms, particularly that of the press. His book, "Urban's Alphabet," which pokes fun at some of the country's leading political figures, has earned him around $80,000 so far and the press run of his new satirical weekly recently doubled to 200,000. Gone is the dour apologist for an unyielding party. "I like capitalism a lot," Mr. Urban said in a recent interview. "When I was in the Government, I was never so rich and I never had a chance to play such a fascinating game." Part of the fun, he suggested, lies in pointing out to the new democratic Government that it has some of the old totalitarian regime's flaws. "They have a complete inability to justify themselves to the public," Mr. Urban said. "They have believed themselves so beautiful and so good that they didn't need politics."

title: Will Undecided Voters Make Up State's Mind?
description: THE gubernatorial election is only two days away, but the ultimate disposition of voters like Lois Maxwell remains maddeningly unknown to the strategists for the three major candidates.

title: Mainstream Porn
description: To the Editor: Ms. Maslin alludes several times to the threadbare image of the typical porno film patron as some kind of alienated perverse freak who slouches into the theater with the collar of his dirty raincoat hiding his face. This perception of people who watch dirty movies seems outdated. Raincoats are no longer de rigueur.

title: Bush, in California, Opposes 'Big Green'
description: President Bush, on a final pre-election campaign swing to help Republicans, reiterated today that he would sign the recently passed legislation strengthening the Clean Air Act but voiced opposition to a sweeping California ballot proposition, known as "Big Green," that would severely curb use of pesticides and chemicals.

title: Interior Motives
description: Miss Page RenseArchitectural DigestLos Angeles, Calif.Dear Miss Rense:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A NEUTRAL CORNER: Boxing Essays. By A. J. Lieb ling. Edited by Fred Warner and James Barbour. (North Point, $19.95.) "The problem for Liebling and The New Yorker ," Joyce Carol Oates wrote in "On Boxing," "must have been to sell a blood sport like boxing to a genteel, affluent audience. . . . It is a problem that, for all his verbal cleverness, Liebling never entirely solves." One is tempted to reply that, in fact, A. J. Liebling is the only boxing writer who ever worked his way around this contradiction. The reason -- as readers of "A Neutral Corner," a collection of Liebling's previously uncollected boxing essays edited by Fred Warner and James Barbour, who teach English at the University of New Mexico, are quick to discover -- is that he was a great journalist. Unlike the celebrated boxing writers of today, Liebling went to a prize fight to report it, not experience it. Ms. Oates, Norman Mailer and others who cover only an occasional heavyweight championship fight always seem to be groping for the meaning of boxing; Liebling found meaning in boxing. Of course Liebling, who died in 1963, was fortunate enough to have lived in the last era when there were enough good fighters around to sustain interest in boxing more than once every two or three years. Not that he was all that taken with the era that inspired his best boxing pieces: "Nineteen-fifty was no Golden Age of boxing, but, compared to 1960, it was at least gold-plated." (But then, as he himself cautioned, "the exact period at which it was better . . . varies in direct ratio with the age of the fellow talking about it.") Liebling managed to find just enough gold, and, like Pauline Kael writing about bad movies, when his subjects were dull he turned lead into gold.

title: It Had Fat Tires And Fenders You Could Polish
description: BALLOON-TIRE bicycles -- two-wheeled cruisers with lots of chrome, high-pitched horns and enviable heft -- are pursued these days by collectors seeking more than speed in the bikes they buy.

title: Clash Of Cultures
description: To the Editor: By saying that Francoise Gilot has total recall and by heading the continuation "Listening to Matisse and Picasso," The Times indicates that the "conversations" between Matisse, Picasso and Miss Gilot are actual, as if transcribed [ "The Maid Was Ugly, the Meals Were Bad . . ." Oct. 7 ] .

title: Their Vietnam
description: RUSSIAN ROULETTE Afghanistan Through Russian Eyes. By Gennady Bocharov. Translated by Alyona Kojevnikov. 187 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ HarperCollins. $18.95.

title: U.S.O.C. Speaks On Drug Testing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Democracy And Religion Clash Again In India
description: AS the saffron flag of Hinduism fluttered over a battered little mosque in the temple city of Ayodhya last week and a national government tottered, India came face to face with with some chilling political truths. A militant Hindu revival movement had demonstrated its power to challenge the foundations of modern India, dredging up from a half-imagined civilization of 600 years ago -- before Mogul and British conquests -- a compelling vision of a Hindu polity that many believe is certain to undermine four decades of secular democratic tradition.

title: Style Makers; Beatriz Canedo Patino, Coat Designer
description: Beatriz Canedo Patino is a designer with a mission. She wants to enlighten the world about the glories of alpaca, a warm yet lightweight fabric made from the sheared fleece of South American llamas. To do this, she formed Royal Alpaca Inc. in 1987 to produce a line of coats, suits and dresses made of alpaca.

title: Matched Sets, Ideal as Starters, Take a Step Up in Class
description: WHAT'S THE LOWEST price of admission to the pleasures of good sound? Asked in different ways, the question pops up time and again in these days of budgetary caution. Luckily, there are some good answers.

title: A Timely Auction, As It Turns Out, For Cystic Fibrosis
description: WHEN J. Robert and Barbara Burton decided to organize an art auction on behalf of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation last July, they could not have known how timely the event scheduled for next Saturday evening would turn out to be. The Burtons, parents of an 18-month-old son with cystic fibrosis as well as of a healthy 4-year-old daughter, were already overwhelmed at the generosity of contributing artists and galleries when the news hit the front pages in September:

title: SAUDI OIL EXPORTS RISE TO NEW HIGH, ERASING SHORTAGE
description: Saudi Arabia's oil production surpassed 8.2 million barrels a day this week and is expected to rise to 8.5 million barrels early next year, the highest level in nine years, the Saudi Oil Minister, Hisham Nazer, said in an interview today.

title: Pedaling Beside th Potomac
description: I PROMISED my 8-year-old son a trip through time as well as distance. Perhaps curiosity would help propel his diminutive one-speed bike, which he had never pedaled more than a dozen miles, as we cycled at least six times that far in three days.

title: UNDER MY SKIN
description: I discovered Frank in the 1970's, when I was 19. Two friends and I took a motor trip to Canada in the car of my friend's mother. The only eight-track tape in the car was "Frank at the Sands." We listened to it for a week straight, never turning off the tape deck. Later, I fell in love with my future wife listening to "Saturday Night With Sinatra" on WYNY-FM.

title: The Operatic Art Redefined, Ravel's Way
description: HOW CAN YOU NOT LOVE AN opera, taking place "two steps from the Estramadure, in the land of the Guadalquivir," in which we learn that an appropriately affectionate diminutive of the name Torquemada would be "Totor"? Or one in which Arithmetic, in the form of a nasty little old tenor accompanied by a chorus of savage numerals, appears to torment a homework-resistant child with arithmetical gibberish?

title: Poker and Nothingness
description: THE MUSIC OF CHANCE >By Paul Auster. 217 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Before Lolita
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Heartland Of Old Germany
description: TRAVELING today in what was until recently the German Democratic Republic is an experience at once depressing and fascinating. Depressing, because of the dereliction of the towns, the mood of dazed anxiety and the poor state of tourist services, bureaucratic and not very customer-friendly. Fascinating, because of the bizarre outward symptoms of current revolutionary change (and resistance to it), and the historic and cultural riches of the area from Dresden to Weimar and Eisenach that was the very heartland of the glorious pre-World War I German tradition, so closely linked with Bach, Luther, Goethe, Wagner and others.

title: Jenifer Spaulding Engaged to Wed
description: January wedding plans for Jenifer Joan Spaulding and Christopher Milton Goulard have been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Daurice Rush Spaulding of Scituate, Mass. Mr. Goulard is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Goulard of New Canaan, Conn.

title: U. S. Agency Is Selling Failed Savings Units
description: The Resolution Trust Corporation announced Friday that it was putting up for sale 18 failed savings institutions, including the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

title: Review/Music; Leningrad Ensemble's Tchaikovsky
description: The Leningrad Philharmonic's four programs at Carnegie Hall, Monday through Thursday nights, were divided between Yuri Temirkanov, the orchestra's music director, and Mariss Jansons, the associate conductor, who had also led the performance on Oct. 27 at the Tilles Center on Long Island with Van Cliburn as piano soloist.

title: Style Makers; Mari Aldin, Cosmetics Executive
description: The growing diversity of the United States has had an impact on fashion, art, music and food. For Mari Aldin, it has led to a new career as founder and president of Astarte, a cosmetics company for Hispanic, black, Asian, Mediterranean and Indian women.

title: Lost Manuscript?
description: To the Editor: Among the many contributions of Leonard Bernstein to America's musical heritage and to the treasured memories of countless individuals [ "A Prophet Ultimately Honored," Oct. 21 ] is one I have not yet seen mentioned in the current recounting of his life. It was perhaps the first musical score written and directed by him for public performance. It was for the production of Aristophanes' "Peace" in Sanders Theater of Harvard University in the spring of 1941. The performance won critical acclaim. As far as I know, however, the score has never been published.

title: New Routes to Westchester Preservation
description: THE desire to preserve open land in Westchester County has given rise to a new batch of conservation groups whose members are finding increasingly inventive ways to hold the line on development.

title: Campus Life: Earlham; Computer Trove For Small College: Free Data Bases
description: Give Earl ham College stu dents a computer and a modem to communicate with, and they can move the world, or at least 200 million computerized pieces of it.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter to the editor last Sunday about affordable housing in Madison misidentified a town official, Carolyn Stitt. She is a Selectman, not the First Selectman.

title: Notebook; Quietly, the D.H. May Be on the Way Out
description: As relatively new as the designated hitter is to baseball, it is nevertheless older than many baseball fans. From some recent talk, however, emerges a question: will the designated hitter stay around long enough to outgrow its teen-age status?

title: Pro Hockey; Devils' Success Grows
description: John MacLean scored twice as the Devils beat the Edmonton Oilers, 5-2, tonight, handing the defending Stanley Cup champions their team-record-tying sixth consecutive loss.

title: Miss Curran Wed To T. S. Susanin
description: Barbara Ann Curran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Curran of New York, was married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York to Lieut. Timothy Scott Susanin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Susanin of Philadelphia. Msgr. Edward M. Connors and the Rev. Frederick D. Hoesli performed the ceremony.

title: Judicial Screening: Bar's Response
description: The Oct. 14 article "Agreement on Judicial Candidates," on cross-endorsements of such candidates, made no reference to bar association response. The Westchester Women's Bar Association, which annually screens judicial candidates after their nominations, formed a special task force on judicial-nomination procedures following its 1989 screenings.

title: Who Is Faculty Protecting?
description: The faculty of the State University at Stony Brook is moving to block military recruiting on campus because the armed forces ban homosexuals. However faculty members, stressing the university's dedication to free exchange of ideas, emphasized that the military could still be invited to give presentations.

title: French Astir Over Czarist Bond Accord
description: Tattered and yellowing, stored away in boxes, attics and safe deposits, millions of unpaid Czarist Russian bonds have for decades kept alive the dreams of many French families that one day they would strike it rich.

title: Deficit or No Deficit, Unlikely Allies Bring About Expansion in Medicaid
description: The United States Chamber of Commerce does not normally lobby for poor children. Nor does the National Association of Manufacturers usually advocate expansion of government programs.

title: Art for the Ages, All of Them
description: SEVEN-year-old Matthew Rifkin is trying to help his parents understand art. "Can't you hear the fire crackling?" he said to them while standing in front of Winslow Homer's "Camp Fire" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. "I think it's all quiet in the woods except for the noisy snapping and crackling of the fire and an owl going hoot, hoot."

title: Predators Kill Maine's Caribou Restoration Effort
description: The organizer of a private effort to restore caribou to the wilds of Maine, where that deer species has been largely extinct for about 80 years, says the project has failed, a victim of predators.

title: Sports People; Police Offer Apology
description: FOLLOWING the lead of scores of Wellesley, Mass., citizens who wrote their own spontaneous letters of apology, the police and Selectmen of the town have apologized to Dee Brown, for an ugly incident on Sept. 21. Brown, the Boston Celtics' top draft choice who is buying a house in Wellesley, was seized at gunpoint and forced to lie on the ground after it was noticed that he he had the same skin color as a black man who had robbed a Wellesley bank a few days earlier.

title: Review/Music; Honoring Franck Centenary
description: Thursday will mark the 100th anniversary of the death of Cesar Franck. To celebrate that event, St. Thomas Church organized two concerts, the more ambitious being a program of Franck's music for chorus, organ and orchestra this past Tuesday, and the second a recital of Franck's organ music by Gerre Hancock, the St. Thomas organist and master of choristers, today at 5:15. P.M.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
A MAINE SUMMER'S NIGHT'S DREAM
description: I CANNOT GET YOU CLOSE ENOUGH: Three Novellas. By Ellen Gilchrist. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) There must be a family tree pinned up on the wall in Ellen Gilchrist's study. It's exceedingly leggy, outlining how all the characters she has been writing about for the last 10 years are related -- and it's covered with kudzu, of course, since Ms. Gilchrist (who won the National Book Award in 1984 for her short-story collection "Victory Over Japan") is an aged-in-the-oak Southerner, indeed a former poet laureate of Mississippi. In writing the three novellas that compose "I Cannot Get You Close Enough," she shook that tree and out fell various members of the Hand clan from Charlotte, N.C., like the writer Anna Hand and Daniel, her darling, drunken brother, both of whom appeared in "The Anna Papers." "I Cannot Get You Close Enough" updates that earlier novel and fills in its ellipses. Still, it's something more beguiling than yet another series of chapters in a family saga; it's an invention that's pure Gilchrist, a screwball fugue on the theme of love, loosely patterned after "A Midsummer Night's Dream." It has its own Helena and Hermia -- Daniel's two difficult teen-age daughters, the fair Jessie and the half-Cherokee Olivia -- and its amorous fairy queen, reincarnated as crazy cousin Crystal Manning from New Orleans. With other familiar Gilchrist characters, they venture out of Dixie to spend a summer in Maine (taking in a production of Shakespeare's comedy along the way). On New England's rocky coast the fairy love dust flies, while the rusticators also endure marriage wars, a missing-child scare, boyfriend poaching and a surprise pregnancy. Some of Ms. Gilchrist's characters seem at first a little stereotypical, but it is this writer's way to wrestle down cliches, giving them eccentric contours, spontaneity and pathos. And always she takes the long, comic view of her characters' frailties, for only through the chaos they create, she seems to suggest, do family trees writhe toward the light.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; Time vs. Money Three Plans for a Brunch
description: WHEN ENTERTAINING IS meant to be informal, affordable and on a large scale -- say 20 guests, some with children -- nothing beats brunch. Increasingly popular, a brunch offers many options, from doing it yourself to purchasing prepared dishes from a carryout shop or even hiring a caterer. These three approaches have been contrasted here with estimates from across the country -- New York City, suburban Connecticut, Seattle, Washington and Pittsburgh.

title: Sudanese Troops Burn Refugee Camp, Forcing Residents to a Desert Site
description: A wasteland of black embers smoldered near the banks of the Nile, the remains of thousands of burlap-lined shacks burned by soldiers who forced southern Sudanese to leave their makeshift refugee dwellings for the desert outside Khartoum.

title: Sports People; Woes for Ex-Bengal
description: EVER since he was banned from the National Football League after using cocaine the night before the 1989 Super Bowl, Stanley Wilson, the former Cincinnati Bengals running back, has had problems. Last January, for example, he was arrested in Gardena, Calif., and charged with scuffling with police officers and possessing drug paraphernalia.

title: Feasts & Celebrations;   Newfangled Steamed Puddings
description: IN WINTERTIME, THERE ARE FEW DISHES MORE inviting and cozy, evocative of the holiday season or rich in literary associations than the old-fashioned warm steamed pudding. This festive, flavorful dessert -- which once required hours of steaming over the stove -- can be cooked in minutes in a microwave oven.

title: Guide Dogs and Masters Practice on Familiar Turf
description: ELI walked briskly along Farmington Avenue, in West Hartford. He skirted the benches, trees and planters that dotted the sidewalk; he looked both ways before crossing the street. Kathryn Mobley held the strap to Eli's harness and followed him.

title: Peggy Koenig and David A. Graves Are Married
description: Peggy Jean Koenig, a vice president of the Sillerman Companies, a merchant bank in New York, was married last evening to David A. Graves, a vice president of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company in New York. Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated at the Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

title: G.O.P. Senate Hopefuls Aim at Cuomo
description: In the great paradox of Tuesday's statewide election, the truest measure of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's popularity may be less the size of his own victory than the results of a half-dozen State Senate races where Republicans are running aggressively against the Governor.

title: The Deadline Nears for Putting In Bulbs
description: THERE is still time to plant bulbs, but hurry. Election Day is considered by many to be the official bulb planting cutoff date. The reason is that the soil has to be warm enough for the bulbs to grow roots. When the soil starts to cool down, the growth rate slows.

title: North Haven Keeps Ban on Deer Kill
description: STATE wildlife officials are dismayed that the Village of North Haven on Noyack Bay has refused to lift a ban on hunting deer with bow and arrow.

title: C. W. Cunningham, a Doctoral Student, Is Married to Polly Edelson, an Editor
description: Paula Topal Edelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert S. Edelson of New York, was married yesterday at the Century Association in New York to Clifford Wilson Cunningham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Cunningham Jr. of Orlando, Fla. Judge Michael B. Mukasey of the Federal District Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title:
National Notebook: Chicago;
Housing For the Needy
description: ABOUT 100 low- and moderate-income families are expected to buy houses here within the next year through a program initiated this fall by the city and two national nonprofit housing development groups.

title: Diving
description: To the Editor: Since I am in the dive travel business, I am always interested in articles on diving. Usually they are interesting and informative. However, I was appalled at the contents of the article on Truk by Howard Tomb (Travel, Sept. 16).

title: IF A TREE FALLS IN THE FOREST, THEY HEAR IT
description: By day, the forest is the property of the Pacific Lumber Company, but by night it belongs to the radical environmentalists of Earth First.

title: Commercial Property: Theater Renovations; Juggling Preservation, Potential Profit and Sentiment
description: SHOLOM ALEICHEM'S widow, Olga Rabinowitz, laid the cornerstone in place 64 years ago. It was fitting that she should, for the new Moorish-style playhouse at Second Avenue and 12th Street was to stand as a monument to her husband and other pioneers of the Yiddish theater.

title: Mercy Not Strained
description: Here was a hard case. Judge Robert P. Aguilar of Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., convicted of unlawfully disclosing a Government wiretap and obstructing justice, faced 21 months in prison under Federal sentencing guidelines. But last week the sentencing judge, Louis C. Bechtle of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia, found the special circumstances that warrant an exception: impeachment and disbarment proceedings, Judge Bechtle said, would be "long, humiliating and burdensome" and "substantial punishment" in themselves. So he gave Judge Aguilar six months in prison, 1,000 hours of community service and $2,000 in fines. Defense lawyers, who plan to appeal the conviction, said Judge Aguilar was nonetheless "thrilled" with the sentence; they had argued for leniency on the ground that he did not received any money or other benefits. The target of the Government wiretap, whom Judge Aguilar was accused of tipping off, was an 84-year-old heroin trafficker who is distantly related to him by marriage.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; Warm Flavors At a Family Lunch
description: Constant parade of family, friends, neighbors and children passing through the rambling adobe house of Michael and Wanda Cooper, in Corrales, N.M., means that their entertaining style is lively, casual and often totally unplanned. And they like it that way.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL 'Songs of Hector Berlioz' Janice Taylor, mezzo-soprano; Dalton Baldwin, piano; Bernard Greenhouse, cello. Dorian DOR-90128; CD only. This attractive collection ranges from the familiar "Nuits d'ete," in Berlioz's own piano-voice arrangement, to seldom-heard ballads and early songs. Ms. Taylor lets her velvety voice float across the music rather than penetrate it. The approach brings out more rapture in the dreamy lyrical songs than in the dramatic ones. (She is also a more persuasive Juliet than Ophelia.) Still, the opulent tones are hard to resist. Mr. Dalton provides distinguished accompaniments, attentive to every nuance. Mr. Greenhouse's obbligatos enhance three selections. Fine recorded sound.

title: Time Out for an Old-Fashioned Tea
description: THE city dweller's fantasy of getting away from the rat race has several varieties: opening a country inn, a restaurant or, perhaps, a bookshop or a tea room in a remote, pastorally pretty Connecticut village. We were reminded of this as we entered Chaiwalla, a tiny two-room tea shop in a pink frame house on the main street of Salisbury.

title: DONORS AND TRANSPLANTS
description: Perhaps we should be questioning the efficacy not only of the immunosuppressant, FK-506, but of liver transplants as well. The fact that a single patient may require as many as six successive transplants suggests that this technique is not so much a cure for end-stage liver failure as it is an interim measure that must be repeated over and over to preserve a person's life. Is it any wonder that there is such a shortage of donor organs? ROBERT J. YAES , M.D. Lexington, Ky.

title: Baseball; Players Said to Hit Collusion Jackpot
description: Baseball's club owners will pay players $280 million in damages under a settlement that will bring to a close the aftermath of the owners' three-year conspiracy against free agents, a lawyer involved in the case said yesterday. It will be the largest owner-to-player payment ever made in sports.

title: Drug Trial Shows the Rich Rewards of Informing
description: On March 14, 1989, the Federal Government paid $300,000 to a former Chinatown gang member. He had turned informer against suspected drug dealers in New York City. The money was a reward.

title: Baseball; The Return of Cecil: An Event in Japan
description: When Cecil Fielder ended his playing career as a Hanshin Tiger after the 1989 season, the powerful first baseman became a rarity: an American player who successfully repatriated to the major leagues. Now, Fielder has returned to these shores as the main attraction in a galaxy of touring major league all-stars, an American import not only welcomed back but idolized as a hero.

title: Utility Seeks Surcharge For Conservation Effort
description: LAST year, Northeast Utilities fell $11 million short of its goal to provide $24 million worth of conservation services to its customers in Connecticut. The power company found that few people wanted to hear about energy efficiency.

title: Works in Progress; The Small Ships
description: There is praise, and then there is praise. According to J. Russell Jinishian, director of the Mystic Maritime Gallery in Mystic, Conn., the nation's largest gallery specializing in contemporary marine art, Lloyd McCaffery "is simply the finest miniature ship model maker in the world." His latest work, a three-and-a-half-inch replica of a 17th-century British warship, is "in a class far apart from anything ever done in the field."

title: Iraq Vows Long Fight if U.S.-Led Force Attacks
description: President Saddam Hussein responded today to increasing American pressure for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait by vowing that his troops would engage any American-led force that sought to recover the occupied territory in a protracted war.

title: Boo!
description: Pollsters at this time of year usually ask people how they feel about the candidates for election. The University of Connecticut's Institute for Social Inquiry, polling for The Hartford Courant, thought also to ask how they feel about Halloween.

title:
Your Own Account;
Sorting Through the Tax Changes
description: TAX increases are spread broadly across middle- and upper-income taxpayers by the new legislation just approved by Congress, and there are only a few strategies left in the accountants' bag of tricks that would make even a slight difference in the taxes you pay.

title: Way, Way Beyond the Frontiers of Science
description: PINTO AND SONS By Leslie Epstein. 419 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: Nancy Lepp Weds Brooks Robertson
description: Nancy Mary Lepp and James Brooks Ayres Robertson 4th were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Walter C. Orlowski, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Erik Kolbel, a Congregational minister.

title: Agents Fall Victim to Slumping Market
description: IF the stalled housing market in the New York region has been an exercise in frustration for home sellers, it has become a stunning reversal of fortunes for thousands of residential real estate brokers and their agents who prospered during the boom and now are dwindling in numbers and earnings.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on page 35 of the Travel section today misstates the admission charges for two galleries in the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris. Admission to the Galerie des Monnaies, Medailles et Antiques is $4, not 25 cents; for the Mazarine and Mansart galleries it is $7, not 40 cents.

title: Fading Warsaw Pact Agrees on Split-Up of Arms
description: In what may be one of their last joint efforts as partners in a vanishing alliance, the six members of the Warsaw Pact today agreed on a weapons distribution formula that lifts a significant hurdle in the path of a East-West conventional arms agreement.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; Recruiting Goal For Minorities Is Increased
description: After criticism from acoalition of minority student groups, officials at the University of Wisconsin-Madison have increased their goals for recruiting minority students.

title: Hector's Determination
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: CAPTAIN'S COVE IN BRIDGEPORT;
Entrepreneur Makes a Showplace From a Dump and a Dream
description: SURROUNDED by a sewage-treatment plant, a garbage recycling center, a city dump and a crime-plagued housing complex, Kaye Williams stood in the middle of Bridgeport's depressed city-owned marina on Black Rock Harbor in 1982, he said, and did the only sensible thing for a risk taker to do. With $200,000 of his own money, he secured a long-term lease from the city and opened Captain's Cove Seaport.

title: In Nicaragua's Police, Sandinistas Are Dug In
description: When Nicaragua's new Government was sworn in last April, it moved immediately to erase the visible legacy of the Ministry of Interior, the powerful security apparatus that helped define and sustain the Sandinistas.

title: Democratic Candidates Step Away From Florio
description: "Jim Florio?" asks Joel Berg with a studied lack of recognition. "Frank," says Mr. Berg, who is Representative Frank Pallone Jr.'s campaign manager in New Jersey's Third Congressional District, "has never met Jim Florio."

title: Susan M. Hall Is Married
description: Susan Marie Hall and Glenn Howard Brill were married yesterday at the Georgian Suite in New York by the Rev. Frederick W. Thayer, an Episcopal priest. The bride, a daughter of Patricia M. Kesling of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Robert L. Hall of Jersey City, is a freelance writer and editor. She is a graduate of Vassar College. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley S. Brill of Somers, N.Y. He is a marketing director at Rand Engineering in New York and a graduate of the State University of New York at New Paltz.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; Acquired Tastes
description: SOMETIMES, PLEASURE TAKES A little work. The south face of Everest, a diabolical crossword, the later Henry James -- their allure underscores a very human paradox, that the gratification won through struggle is doubly sweet. This truth has a special resonance in the world of drink, where virtually all tastes are acquired. No one is born with the hankering for a dry martini, shaken not stirred. It's only by experimenting, waging war on prejudice and bending the taste buds that we colonize exotic flavors.

title: Learning Science By Mail
description: YOUNG science students and professional scientists can now be long-distance lab partners in the pen-pal program "Science By Mail." The program, based at the Boston Museum of Science, "is designed to change children's perceptions of who scientists are and what science is," said Stephen Brand, the exchange's director.

title: Holier Than Thou
description: MAKING SAINTS How the Catholic Church Determines Who Becomes a Saint, Who Doesn't, and Why. By Kenneth L. Woodward. Illustrated. 461 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Winter Wedding For Miss Kingrea
description: December wedding plans for Cecile Kingrea and Richard J. Stark have been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Byron Giles Kingrea of Dallas. Mr. Stark is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Stark of Vero Beach, Fla.

title: The Big Foliage Flop
description: The rainy year we've had -- remember the deluges of August? -- gave us the greenest summer in memory. But it has also given us, disappointingly, the greenest fall. Nowhere around the city are trees putting on their usual display. Maples and sweet gums in the parks should be red. Ginkos and sycamores on the streets should be yellow. They aren't. They are stubbornly, boringly green.

title: 'The Academic Equivalent of a Rock Star'
description: GIANTS AND DWARFS Essays 1960-1990. By Allan Bloom. 395 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Dark Metal: Not Just Smash And Thrash
description: UPSIDE-DOWN CROSSES, skulls, war and destruction -- these images dominate dark metal, the variety of rock-and-roll guaranteed to upset parents and would-be censors. Even the band names -- Slayer, Megadeth -- are provocative. But despite the eagerness of detractors to single out heavy-metal rockers like Judas Priest for everything from Satanism to suicide, metal's content is hardly unique.

title: Computer in Buffalo Tracks Endangered Turtle in L. I. Sound
description: EACH day between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M., Dr. Edward A. Standora dials a satellite data-processing center in Maryland from his home computer in Buffalo to track the movements of a Kemp's ridley turtle, one of the world's 12 most-endangered species, as it swims in Long Island Sound, 300 miles away.

title: The House on Jan Hus Street
description: We are driving to roudnice nad Labem (Roudnice on the Elbe River), a small town 22 miles north of Prague. My father was born there in 1904, when Roudnice was a town in Bohemia, Bohemia was a province of the Austro-Hungarian Empire and Franz Josef was Emperor. The house my grandfather built in 1900 is still standing on the site where his father had built, in 1830 -- the first house owned by a Jew outside the Jewish quarter. Several generations of my ancestors are buried in the cemetery just a few minutes' walk from it. But I was carried out of Czechoslovakia as a baby, a few months after the Communist putsch of 1948, and like so many others in this century of flight from totalitarian regimes I have never been able to see where my father came from. Now both my parents are dead, Central Europe is reviving and I, at the age of 42, am going back.

title: College Football; Ephs Streak Grows
description: After Williams beat Wesleyan today, 30-3, Teddy Rogers took his last walk up Spring Street, this college town's main stem, to the St. Pierre Barber Shop. Sixty teammates, still in purple and white uniforms and some sweaty, some not, joined him.

title: How to Use a Hammer
description: CARPENTERS with a sense of humor often refer to striking a thumb or finger accidentally while hammering as "hitting the wrong nail."

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: IT had threatened to rain all morning, sprinkled off and on, then started raining in earnest shortly after noon. I wrapped things up at 2, advised the volunteer handling the phones that I was leaving, and walked (note

title: HERS: TRUE BLUE
description: After reading "True Blue," I feel compelled to write. My husband, Neil, died last June. Not long after his death, my daughter suggested that I get a puppy. Not only did I get a pup, but my son brought home a kitten who, like Blue, would probably not have found a home otherwise. My older cat is now the elegant, aloof matriarch of my menagerie.

title: Nurses Delivering Service To the Poor
description: GLENN BASILE, a visiting nurse, knocked at the door of his patient Lauraine Page in Stowe Village, a large housing complex in Hartford. She opened the door with a cheerful "Everything went great last night."

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: The Formula for Enlightenment

title: Broadway by Way Of Second Avenue
description: Moe Septee, who was a Yeshiva bocher (that is, a student at an Orthodox school) when he was a youngster, came to produce "Those Were the Days," a new musical revue in English and Yiddish, by way of a bolt of inter ethnic inspiration.

title: Decision-Making's True Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Native in Opera Spotlight
description: AT 31, which is just about the right age for an emerging operatic tenor, things are beginning to fall into place for Vincenzo Scuderi, who used to be just plain "Vincent" Scuderi.

title: Moldavia Rejects Army's Aid in Ethnic Unrest
description: The Moldavian republic rejected new Soviet help today in battling a wave of ethnic unrest that left at least three separatists dead. It issued its own demand that the militants disband.

title:
National Notebook: Chicago;

Housing For the Needy
description: ABOUT 100 low- and moderate-income families are expected to buy houses here within the next year through a program initiated this fall by the city and two national nonprofit housing development groups.

title: Correction
description: Because of a typographical error, an article on Oct. 21 about Aspen, Colo., misstated the annual membership fee of the Caribou Club. It is $1,000, not $11,000. The article also characterized the club's admission policy incorrectly. Only members and their guests are admitted, according to Harley Baldwin, the owner. The club is not semiprivate.

title: 2 Men Found Shot Dead in Car in Queens
description: Two unidentified men, paper bags over their heads, were found shot to death early yesterday morning in a car parked in front of a Queens store, the police said.

title: Bulgaria
description: To the Editor: In regard to the Black Sea resorts in Bulgaria, I should like to clarify the origins of the name Black Sea. In Turkish, the words for black, white, red and blue are the same words for the cardinal directions north, west, south and east, respectively. Thus, the "black" sea is that sea which lies north of Turkey; the Turks call the Mediterranean the "white" sea, and the Red Sea takes its name from the fact that it once formed the southern boundary of the Ottoman Empire.

title: Joi Lisa Katz and Peter David Baum Are Married
description: Joi Lisa Katz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Katz of Jersey City, was married last evening to Peter David Baum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner G. Baum of White Plains and Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi Mark Winer officiated at the Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains.

title: Postings: 39 Units in Harlem; Housing for the Handicapped
description: A nonprofit housing group in Harlem has begun construction of New York State's first apartment building in which every unit is designed for the blind, the deaf or people in wheelchairs. Formal groundbreaking for the building, Tweemill House, at the corner of 126th Street and Lexington Avenue, took place Monday.

title: New York Rates Banks on Serving the Poor
description: For the first time, New York City is ranking banks eligible to do business with the city on how responsive they are to the needs of low-income communities.

title: Review/Theater; The Hero as Victim
description: A bandit with a record of crimes longer than the years of his life is the hero of "El Abanderado" ("The Standard Bearer") by the Chilean playwright Alberto Hieremans. And in the production by the Repertorio Espanol at the Gramercy Arts Theater, under the direction of Guillermo Semler, he becomes not only a believable hero, but the victim of the society bent on bringing him to justice.

title: Never Has So Few Owned So Much
description: THE DECLINE AND FALL OF THE BRITISH ARISTOCRACY By David Cannadine. Illustrated. 813 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: Single Travelers
description: To the Editor: The question of the singles surcharge keeps coming up (Q & A, Sept. 2). One solution that has been a help to me is Caravan Tours, 401 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago, Ill. 60611; 312-321-9800 (or a travel agent). Caravan runs a full line of tours with the policy that if you request someone to share with and no one is available you go at the regular tour price -- no surcharge. Last year on their Ireland and England tour I had no share and no surcharge. This year on the Switzerland tour I had a wonderful roommate. JAY BERNARD SCHEUER Danbury, Conn.

title: In Croton Falls, Coyote Stages 'Speed-the-Plow'
description: IN "Speed-the-Plow," David Mamet spread the scorn. The playwright didn't use up all his derisiveness on ruthless deal-makers -- the rulers and the comers -- of the commodities business called Hollywood. Such is the mentality of moviegoers, it follows, that they deserve whatever it is decreed they want: last year's winners, warmed over.

title: Doing Nothing and Watching Television
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Welterweight Wanted
description: IF you are a man who weighs no more than 147 pounds, has Canadian citizenship and doesn't mind rough work, Donovan Boucher has a job for you.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: A. PHILIP FERZAN;
State's Guiding Hand for Export Trading
description: TO New the Jersey business community, A. Philip Ferzan is known as the Great Facilitator.

title: UNDER MY SKIN
description: Like William Kennedy, I have been a Frank Sinatra fan for exactly 48 years ("Under My Skin," Oct. 7). What makes the Irish admire Italian singers? Just kidding.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SUPREME FAITH: Someday We'll Be Together. By Mary Wilson and Patricia Romanowski. (Harper Collins, $19.95.) It was only the beginning of the difficult years for Mary Wilson of the Supremes. The year was 1970. Florence Ballard had been fired from the trio; Diana Ross, the lead singer, performed her final concert with the group before pursuing a solo career, and Ms. Wilson was soon to discover that only $100,000, not hundreds of thousands, had actually been placed in her account by her record company. In "Supreme Faith," Ms. Wilson's sequel to her memoir "Dreamgirl," she gives a broader behind-the-scenes look not only at the popular singing group but also at Berry Gordy's record empire, Motown, which in the 1960's recorded many of America's top black artists. The story she tells, with Patricia Romanowski, her collaborator on "Dreamgirl," is not a pretty one. Corruption, financial mismanagement and favoritism were commonplace under Mr. Gordy's reign, Ms. Wilson charges. Unfortunately, much of "Supreme Faith" reads like a vendetta against Berry Gordy, Motown and particularly Diana Ross. (Miss Ross is mentioned 20 times in the preface alone.) Devout Supremes fans will be more fascinated by the chapters devoted to Ms. Wilson's private life, her love affairs with Steve McQueen and Flip Wilson, her marriage to an abusive husband, her children and her solo career. These sections are a quick and entertaining read. But when it comes to settling old scores, perhaps Ms. Wilson should have taken the advice of that old Supremes hit and stopped in the name of love.

title: Who Will Monitor Recycled Ash Blocks?
description: I suggest that these blocks be used to build a number of offshore islands. Miami Beach contains a number of man-made islands. To construct these islands, a perimeter outline was first laid down, made water-tight with cement and then filled in with earth or rocks. Why can't we construct a number of islands several miles offshore using recycled ash construction blocks? We might even consider backing up these ash blocks with nonbiodegradable garbage. We could use the interiors as garbage landfills. After an island is filled in, it can be covered with several inches of top soil. Seeds can then be sown so that trees and plants will grow.

title: The Wizard Who Spun Black Rock Into Gold; The Super Producer
description: Bill Paley gave me the worst day of my life as well as the best years. When we quarreled over the network's coverage of the Vietnam hearings in 1966, I quit. I now find myself celebrating those 16 years when I worked for him in his news division.

title: America Still Shuns Americans
description: WHEN LEONARD BERNSTEIN WAS named music director of the New York Philharmonic in 1958, many optimistic observers saw the 40-year-old conductor's appointment as the dawn following a long night. At last, an American-born and American-trained musician stood at the head of one of the nation's five greatest orchestras. Here was a living, often leaping, testimonial to the worth of native conductors and to the growing sophistication of symphony trustees who in the past had looked exclusively to foreign shores for leaders.

title:
Focus: Shared Living;
2 Housing Experiments in Massachusetts
description: A 12-year-old experiment in communal living is expanding here at the same time that other groups in the area are preparing to set up cooperative communities based on the European model of co-housing.

title: Pro Football; N.F.L. at Midseason: Losers Run Wild
description: EIGHT teams have reached the halfway mark in the National Football League season and the rest will have arrived at that crossroad by Monday night. As the sprint toward Super Bowl XXV in Tampa on Jan. 27 approaches full stride, the Giants and the San Francisco 49ers lead the pack with unbeaten records through seven games. The remaining teams are cleaning their spikes and retooling their attacks, trying to learn from pro football's two superior teams.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: New Yorkers, perhaps more than the citizens of any other metropolis, have always had an "I love you -- but" relationship with their city. They admire it, they're impressed by it, they think of it with enormous affection, and they're generally mesmerized by its pace, vitality and creativity. They believe that it's the best in many different ways and that it's absolutely true that if you make it in New York, you can make it anywhere. But New York and critics -- especially resident critics -- are synonymous, and it's almost a cardinal principle that the positive should not go unqualified, that praise should be tempered with censure.

title: Indiana House Race Shows Incumbency Is Still of Value
description: Incumbency can be a mighty weapon, even in a year when politicians are about as popular as tax collectors.

title: The Economy: More Than the Sum of Its Parts
description: THE American economy did surprisingly well in the third quarter of 1990. And the businesses that make up the economy did surprisingly poorly.

title: Adventures of Jane Wayne
description: IN THE MEN'S HOUSE An Inside Account of Life in the Army by One of West Point's First Female Graduates. By Carol Barkalow with Andrea Raab. Illustrated. 283 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $19.95.

title: Celebrity Cook; A Snack With Elle Macpherson
description: Don't have time to spend in the kitchen," said Elle Macpherson, glaring at the wide-open spaces in her refrigerator. Taking stock, she found nothing but a bottle of champagne and, deep inside the meat keeper, a dozen rolls of unexposed film. Not a single thing from your four basic food groups.

title: College Football: West; Washington Going to Pasadena
description: Washington clinched its first Rose Bowl trip in nine years with a 54-10 victory over Arizona today as Mark Brunell passed for two touchdowns and ran for a third, and Greg Lewis ran for 100 yards for the ninth time this season.

title:
Northeast Notebook: East Greenwich, R.I.;
Scaled Down, Mall Opens
description: NEARLY three years after announcing its proposal, a development company has completed the first phase of a $15 million shopping center in this affluent community 12 miles south of Providence.

title: Touring Companies Rev Up Season
description: IT took a while to get rolling, but the music season in Connecticut has really moved into high gear. Among the events on the schedule this week are three touring Broadway musicals, visiting ensembles from Germany, Mexico, France and the Soviet Union as well as opera, dance and orchestral concerts.

title: BUSH WEIGHS BILL ON TRIBAL REMAINS
description: A sweeping new law awaiting President Bush's signature would allow Indian tribes and other native groups to make broad claims to religious and ceremonial artifacts that are sometimes among the most valued objects in the collections of museums around the country.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
The Joys of Moving to Manhattan
description: WHEN confronted by an empty nest, many of my friends move to Manhattan. The day they are settled, their children take a leave of absence, leave their jobs or drop out of college -- which is the

title: Peace Hopes Dim in Londonderry
description: Before last week's attacks in which the Irish Republican Army forced civilians to act as "human bombs," the people of the city had dared to hope that they might be allowed to pioneer what Northern Ireland longed for most: peace.

title: Ideas & Trends;   Accusations of Abuse Haunt the Legacy of Dr. Bruno Bettelheim
description: IN his last book, "Freud's Vienna and Other Essays," the legendary child psychologist Bruno Bettelheim recounts how, as a young analyst in training, he was deeply influenced by a severely disturbed child he used to see in his own analyst's waiting room. The child, he writes, taught him the importance of listening, of putting yourself in the mind of a patient so as to understand the deep reasons for abnormal behavior. It was a lesson that Dr. Bettelheim, the longtime head of Chicago's renowned Sonia Shankman Orthogenic School for emotionally disturbed children, used to create an environment known for being nurturing, supportive and full of love.

title: In Defense of Mossad
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Residency Law Voided
description: A state appeals court overturned on Friday a state law that barred a Princeton couple who moved here from another county less than a month ago from voting in Tuesday's election. The law was challenged by a lawyer, Bruce Afran and his wife, Joyce, who were told soon after moving to Princeton in mid-October from Somerset County that they would not be eligible to vote in either county. Mr. Afran had argued that the law violates the equal protection clause of the 14th Amendment.

title: College Folly?
description: PEOPLE may have learned all they really needed to know in kindergarten, but they pick up quite a few pointers in college too. While these later lessons may not be as universal as don't hit people, take a nap and flush, in the light of ever-rising tuition costs it is comforting to know that something is invariably gleaned from higher education.

title: A Reawakening in Mecklenburg
description: Otto Von Bismarck, the Iron Chancellor of the German Empire, once said that when the world came to end, he hoped he would be in Mecklenburg. For there, he said, everything happened about 200 years later than anywhere else.

title: Reversal of Forces in Gulf: Iraqis Now Set for Defense
description: Three months after Iraq invaded Kuwait, military forces numbering at least 900,000 are amassed in the Persian Gulf, with Iraqi troops positioned in a formidable "V" defense and Western and Arab adversaries building up their offensive capabilities.

title: Andrew Murstein Weds Miss Rudnick
description: Barbara Lynn Rudnick and Andrew Mead Murstein were married last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York by Rabbi Joseph Sternstein. Mrs. Murstein is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Rudnick of Greenwich, Conn. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin S. Murstein of Old Westbury, L.I.

title: CALL OF THE WILDMEN
description: With a fairly normal suburban boyhood behind me, I can think of many ways in which men of my generation were able to display the "wildman" in them. There was nothing like a good gang brawl at a church carnival for letting off steam, or hanging out at Micci's Confectionery as warlord of the Black Crows Social and Athletic Club (we weren't terribly social, but we were reasonably athletic). When I attended Columbia, the Friday night keg parties at Psi U were an ideal opportunity to display energy and assertiveness, and, in true wildman style, to beat on drumlike garbage cans and dance with abandon around the room every time the band played "Louie Louie." RICHARD ZATHMARY Atlantic Highlands, N.J.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; One-Dish Entertaining
description: WHEN ENTERTAINING, IT IS ACTUALLY EASIER TO prepare a hearty one-dish meal ahead of time than to cook a three-course dinner just before your guests arrive. The two ethnic casseroles suggested here are unusual and economical, can be doubled or tripled for crowds, and require only simple accompaniments, such as a pilaf, bread and salad.

title: College Football: East; Another Milestone For Mayweather
description: In the presence of two of Army's three legendary Heisman Trophy-winning backs, Mike Mayweather asserted his right to be mentioned in the same breath as Blanchard, Davis and Dawkins today by rushing for 134 yards to become the only Cadet to ever gain more than 1,000 yards in three consecutive seasons.

title: Review/Opera; 'Porgy' Is Back At the Met
description: George Gershwin's folk opera, "Porgy and Bess," which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday evening, is one of a kind, which is part of what makes it so treasurable -- and so problematic. Seeking, in its finest moments, a kind of homely intimacy beneath the trappings of grand opera, it defies the confines and conventions of any single stage, theatrical or operatic.

title: Patricia Blythe Craven Is Married To Glenn M. Feit Jr. in California
description: Patricia Blythe Craven, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Craven of New York, was married last evening to Glenn Martin Feit Jr., a son of Rona F. Feit of Washington and Mr. Feit of New York. Rabbi Jerry Fisher officiated at Beau Rivage in Malibu, Calif.

title: A Growing Start for School
description: AMERICAN public schools served more waffles, pancakes and cereal under the auspices of the Federal School Breakfast Program in the 1989-1990 school year than at any other time in the program's 24-year history, according to officials at the Food and Nutrition Service of the United States Department of Agriculture, which administers the program.

title: Six Senate Races to Watch
description: NORTH CAROLINA ---- In one of the most dramatic races of the year, Senator Jesse Helms, an 18-year incumbent and conservative firebrand, is battling a strong challenge from Harvey Gantt, a black Democrat and former mayor of Charlotte. Three independent polls were released at week's end: two showed Mr. Gantt with a slight edge, one showed Mr. Helms with a narrow lead. Mr. Helms has been assailing Mr. Gantt in these closing days as a supporter of racial quotas and "mandatory gay rights," including the forced hiring of gay school teachers. Mr. Gantt has dismissed those charges as a smear.

title: Postings: Building Violations; Et Tu, Park?
description: The address was Park Avenue. Conditions in the building seemed to be anything but.

title: Wall Street; Do the Wizards Need New Tools?
description: TIMES are tough for the technicians of Wall Street, those elves who study various mathematical relationships in the stock market to forecast its path. Indeed, some of the top technical portfolio managers were disappointing investors long before the current bear market arrived in August.

title: About Cars; Lotus Will Sell Racecar Replicas
description: Lotus, a manufacturer of much sought-after sports cars, has long been a magical name in automotive circles. In recent years, however, the British company has expanded into consultancy, providing engineering know-how to companies such as Hyundai and others with such frequency that its own manufacturing is sometimes forgotten.

title: We Don't Have to Like Rap Music, but We Need to Listen
description: To the Editor:

title: National Notebook: Honolulu; Spadework For a New City
description: CONSTRUCTION is about to begin on a shopping center as first project in the planned community of Kapolei, a city that will rise 19 miles west of downtown Honolulu in a region that is expected to at least triple its current population of nearly 40,000 over the next 20 years.

title: Susan Gail Trachtenberg Is Married To Richard Mark Werman on L.I.
description: Susan Gail Trachtenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Trachtenberg of East Rockaway, L.I., was married last evening at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., to Richard Mark Werman, the son of Mrs. Frank S. Greenberg of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Stanley Platek performed the ceremony.

title: Bond Issue For Airport Is A Top Contest On the Ballot
description: WESTCHESTER voters will have a chance on Tuesday, Election Day, to play the decisive role in a dispute that has long divided elected officials, neighborhood groups and business leaders: whether to construct a new passenger terminal at the Westchester County Airport.

title: Tech Notes; Backup for the Utility When the Digital Clock Goes Dead
description: DIGITAL clocks are giving electric utilities fits because even short interruptions of power cause the displays to fail, precipitating floods of calls from frustrated consumers unable to figure out how to reset them. The culprit, according to the Electric Power Research Institute, is cost cutting on the part of clock makers. Clocks made in the 1970's came equipped with a capacitor -- a power storage device -- big enough to keep the display lit through outages of up to 10 seconds. But newer ones fade in one second. The answer, as far as the utilities are concerned, is a backup battery to kick in during outages.

title: College Football; Scent of Roses for Hawkeyes
description: With a Big Ten Conference title and a Rose Bowl berth within view, Iowa and Illinois met eye-to-eye today in a battle of teams that were undefeated in the conference.

title: W. Gardner Barker, Ex-Food Executive, 77
description: W. Gardner Barker, a former chairman of Thomas J. Lipton, who presided over a significant expansion of the food and tea company, died Friday in his home at Marblehead, Mass. He was 77 years old.

title: Marianne Acito Is Married
description: Marianne Acito, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Remo J. Acito of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert P. Campolongo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Campolongo of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. James T. McGuire officiated at St. John and St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Chappaqua. Mrs. Campolongo graduated from Smith College and the Fordham University School of Law; her husband graduated from Vassar College and received a law degree from Northeastern University.

title: Ms. Shapiro Wed To P. M. Brunell
description: Dani Shapiro and Peter Mark Brunell were married last evening at the Lotos Club in New York by Rabbi Rolando Matalon.

title: Helping Hands for Adults Who Cannot Read
description: For Don Chiappetta of Dix Hills, the day of reckoning came on his 40th birthday. His wife had surprised him with a big party, and as friends gathered around he was handed a stack of birthday cards.

title: Uniforms Becoming The Style
description: PUBLIC-school students are keeping their designer jeans and basketball team jackets in the closet, and opting instead for uniforms, the newly popular classroom couture that comprises jumpers, pants, skirts and shirts.

title: Rookie's Career Path Leads Back Home
description: TATE GEORGE grew up in Newark, and, at least half-heartedly, became a New Jersey Nets fan.

title: Cadaverous Period in Art Schools
description: AS STUDENTS, Michelangelo and Leonardo da Vinci dissected cadavers to understand human anatomy. Today there is a second renaissance of sorts as some art students once again study the dead.

title: Fire Kills Union City Man
description: Officials say a faulty extension cord started a fire that destroyed three buildings, left 20 people homeless and killed a Union City man the day before he was to move and weeks before he was to be married. Hugo Rojo, 29 years old, died of smoke inhalation in the blaze that destroyed three homes before dawn on Friday. Mr. Rojo had planned to move out today, and also was preparing to be married before the end of the year, said a friend who spoke on behalf of his family.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Encephalitis Outbreak In Florida

title: College Football; Fordham's 1,000th Comes Up a Loss
description: Fordham University football reached a milestone yesterday when the Rams played their 1,000th game. But history proved no inducement for competence as Lafayette was an overwhelming winner, 59-14, at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

title: The M.B.A. Rate Race
description: LAST FALL the University of Chicago's business school began offering a new leadership program for students -- about a year before it was originally scheduled to begin. It wanted the course, for which students had been clamoring, to be up and running when Business Week magazine compiled its 1990 graduate business school rankings, says Harry L. Davis, deputy dean of M.B.A. programs. (It worked -- graduates "raved" about the new program, Business Week says, and Chicago moved from No. 11 in 1988 to No. 4 on the 1990 list, in the magazine's Oct. 29 issue.)

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
2 Hours Out in Suffolk, Cheaper Homes
description: EASTERN Suffolk's new one-family- house subdivisions are not unlike those that sprang up in more westerly communities in the 60's and 70's.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Law Course Not for Lawyers
