description: CONVINCED that igno rance of the law -- or, more precisely, of the legal system -- is no excuse for anyone, Syracuse University is experimenting with a legal studies program intended for every undergraduate who is not already studying law.

title: Gorbachev Steers Middle Course on Lithuania; Peace Mocked
description: To the Editor:

title: Higher Bond Costs Seen for New York
description: Even if Mayor David N. Dinkins can reassure investors that New York City's finances are well managed, the city will probably pay sharply higher interest costs the next time it tries to raise money in the bond market, financial experts say.

title: Marcia Ackerman Wed To Marc Stuart Cohen
description: Marcia Ackerman was married last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York to Marc Stuart Cohen. Rabbi Philmore Berger officiated.

title: Weeklong Sit-In Ends With Plan On Minority Center
description: Students at Smith College ended a weeklong sit-in late last week, after drafting an agreement with administrators calling for a multicultural center for minority and interntional undergraduates.

title: Greeks Squabbling Over U.S. Cold War Plan
description: Greece's political parties have been dredging up the cold war again this week, with leftists protesting over the discovered existence of "Red Sheepskin," a American-Greek contingency plan aimed at resisting Warsaw Pact occupation forces.

title: Sex, Silliness and Happy Endings
description: THE RUNAWAY BRIDE Hollywood Romantic Comedy of the 1930's. By Elizabeth Kendall. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Treasures of the Bibliotheque
description: A FEW blocks from the perennially long lines snaking through the Cour Napoleon to the Louvre, another of Paris's great public collections remains all but ignored by tourists. With its impressive display of antiquities and decorative arts, and its many changing exhibitions about French history and letters, not to mention one of the world's five largest collections of books and manuscripts, the Bibliotheque Nationale is hardly a minor presence in France's vast cultural universe.

title: Reprimand of Judge Is Factor in a Manhattan Race
description: What would normally be a routine Democratic judicial victory in Manhattan has become an Election Day contest as a result of criticism of the Democratic candidate by a disciplinary committee and the city's leading bar association.

title: Bond Proponents Look for L.I. Support
description: WITH signs that support for a $1.975 billion environmental bond act may be soft upstate, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and a network of environmental and civic groups campaigning for approval of the measure are looking to Long Island to provide the margin of victory on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Sunday about Elliott Roosevelt, a son of Franklin D. Roosevelt, misstated his order of birth in the family. He was the third child of Franklin and Eleanor; their daughter, Anna, was the first and James was the second.

title: Breaking Up Was Hard to Do
description: ROAD TO DIVORCE England, 1530-1987. By Lawrence Stone. Illustrated. 460 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.

title: College Football; Ga. Tech Wrecks Virginia's Dream
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 3 --

title:
National Notebook: East Greenwich, R.I.;
Scaled Down, Mall Opens
description: NEARLY three years after announcing its proposal, a development company has completed the first phase of a $15 million shopping center in this affluent community 12 miles south of Providence.

title: Managing; The Trickle-Down Effect in Perks
description: PEPSICO INC. is giving its hourly workers the same stock options that top management gets. "We tell our people to act like owners, so it seemed right to give them the rewards of ownership, too," said David E. Scherb, Pepsico's vice president of employee benefits.

title: The Scientists Wear Black Hats
description: GOOD INTENTIONS How Big Business and the Medical EstablishmentAre Corrupting the Fight Against AIDS.By Bruce Nussbaum.Illustrated. 352 pp. New York:The Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.95.

title: Unsealed Testimony Tells of Keating Bond Sales
description: Charles H. Keating Jr. sold high-yield junk bonds to the public for his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association even after he had told a Federal regulator that the institution was likely to lose $2 billion, the regulator testified in September, according to records released Friday.

title: Seasonal Discontents; In an Unsettled Time, Feelings of Unease
description: PRESIDENTIAL campaigns often speak to the voters' hopes, to their yearning for clarity, as when Jimmy Carter promised to never lie and Ronald Reagan offered his vision of America resurgent.

title: The Wizard Who Spun Black Rock Into Gold
description: William S. Paley, the founder of CBS Inc. who died just over a week ago at the age of 89, was not only a giant in the communications field, he was a larger-than-life figure in his private and social domains as well. In this excerpt from "In All His Glory: The Life of William S. Paley," to be published by Simon & Schuster later this month, Sally Bedell Smith sketches a portrait of a man advanced in years but as hungry as ever for the power and attention that had been his for so long.

title: About Cars; Hyundai's Scoupe Fills a Sensible Niche
description: THESE days, it is refreshing to find a car whose sticker doesn't drain the blood from your face.

title: Which Westchester Is This, Anyway?
description: Perhaps the Westchester Weekly on Oct. 14 coincidentally included Denise Apuzzo's essay on the Opinion Page ("Why One New Yorker Is Leaving Home") and quotes from a speech by Rosemary Scanlon ("Dispelling the Gloom Over the Economy"). Is it possible both women are talking about the same county?

title: Buster Keaton Inspires a Spooky German Film
description: REBECCA HORN is contemporary art's master of special effects. Her exhibition and film here at the Museum of Contemporary Art, both of them inspired by the wizardry and daredevilry of Buster Keaton, include mechanized contraptions that snap, crackle, gurgle and fizz. With all the disconnected sounds emanating from the floor and walls, you don't have to look at the exhibition to know you are in it. Here and throughout Horn's installations, film props, instruments of torture, scientific equipment and objects of play seem to take on an anarchic life of their own.

title: Fan Clubs - From Engelbert to Mr. Ed
description: WILLIAM F. GRIGGS'S most prized possession is a small overnight bag containing suntan oil, throat medicine, a hairbrush, comb and lint remover. It once belonged to Buddy Holly. In fact, it's the bag the 22-year-old rock star carried aboard the prop plane that crashed on Feb. 3, 1959, killing Holly and the singers J. P. (Big Bopper) Richardson and Ritchie Valens. Only once has Mr. Griggs taken the bag out of the officially marked plastic wrapper in which it was given to him by Mr. Holly's brother, and which he accepted, as he puts it, "with great humility."

title: Today's Sections
description: Special Today: Education Life Section 4A Special Today: Entertaining /Magazine Part 2

title: What's Doing In; Chicago
description: Chicago has inspired more than its share of metaphors, many of which persist as cliches. For better or worse, Chicago will always be the Windy City and the Second City and, thanks to Carl Sandburg, the City of the Big Shoulders. The novelist Nelson Algren marked it as the City on the Make. Less well known, but more cleverly, he also described Chicago as a city where "someone is always forgetting to touch second."

title: More Than Just the Dr. Feelgood of Architecture
description: CHARLES MOORE IS AN architect, but for most of his career he has been more like a cross between a scholar and a pied piper, moving from university to university, lecture platform to lecture platform, seminar to seminar, schmoozing his way through the last 30 years of American architecture.

title: A Stronger New Profile For the European 12
description: ONE year after the crumbling of the Berlin wall, as Washington struggles to maintain NATO's traditional importance and Moscow talks wistfully of a new pan-European security structure, the 12-nation European Community has quietly and confidently asserted itself as the central pillar of the new Europe. The emergence of a stronger community underlines how swiftly economic development has replaced military confrontation as the region's main concern. But it also reflects how Western Europe has turned post-cold war uncertainties into opportunities to speed its own moves toward closer economic and political unity.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house, which is 50 years old, has become so damp that even the carpeting on the second floor feels damp. A professional waterproofing contractor said it would cost us $9,500 to waterproof the house. He recommended "bleeding the walls" by knocking holes in each section of block, running a French drain across the floor, digging around the outside, waterproofing the foundation and then regrading the soil so that it slopes away from the house. The contractor also wants to apply a waterproof paint. We thought the price to be excessive and do not know what to do. What do you think?

title: Man Arrested as Police Find Stolen Painting
description: A painting by the French artist Maurice Utrillo that was stolen from a Madison Avenue gallery on Tuesday was recovered in a Brooklyn apartment on Friday, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Edberg and Becker Advance: Stefan Edberg and Boris Becker advanced to the championsip of the Paris indoor tournament yesterday and will meet in a final for the third time in a month. Edberg needed less than an hour to beat Sergi Bruguera of Spain, 6-3, 6-3, but Becker had trouble against Jonas Svensson of Sweden, winning 4-6, 7-6, 6-1 in a 2-hour-15-minute match. Becker beat Edberg in the Paris final last year and has beaten Edberg in straight sets at Sydney, Australia and at Stockholm, the past month. Becker holds a 17-9 lead against Edberg in tournament play. Svensson almost prevented another Edberg-Becker final by taking the first set against Becker and going up a break in the second. But Becker turned up his game and won 11 of the last 14 games.(AP)

title: World Markets; Bleak Days for British Banks
description: AS a group, British bank stocks have been among the world's best performers in the banking sector this year, far outstripping their counterparts in the United States. Five of the top 10 banks in S. G. Warburg Securities' index of world bank stocks are British. And five of the nine major banks in England have outperformed the British stock market.

title: Weld Hopes Personality (His Opponent's) Will Help Him in Massachusetts
description: William F. Weld, the Republican candidate for governor, stood in the African Meeting House, the oldest black church in the country, to receive endorsements on Friday from an array of well known local liberals, including feminists, union leaders, blacks and homosexuals.

title: Zoning Bonuses
description: I am a shareholder in the Lex Tenants Corporation, which owns a 25-story building with a bonus plaza at the corner of Lexington Avenue and 24th Street. The corporation maintains the plaza, providing gardening, cleaning, lighting and a security guard.

title: Pro Basketball; Celtics' Coach Adds Zeal
description: Hours before an anxious Chris Ford left for the Boston Garden Friday night for his first game as the Celtics' head coach, he was reminded of another special occasion in his basketball life.

title: Shake, Rattle And Growing Old With the Wilburys
description: JUST ABOUT EVERYBODY HAS ONE or knows one: a garrulous elder relative, maybe an uncle, with a gift for puncturing family decorum. He'll share a racy joke, grumble about the state of the world, make faces at solemn moments, gripe and snicker at signs that he's not getting any younger. For their second album, "Vol. 3" (Warner Brothers 26324; all three formats), the Traveling Wilburys have forged a collective persona a lot like that uncle. From the youngest Wilbury, 37-year-old Tom Petty, to the oldest, 49-year-old Bob Dylan, they're ready to lead rock into an unseemly middle age. "Wilbury Twist" is probably the first would-be dance craze to instruct "Fall on your ass/ Get back up/ Put your teeth in a glass."

title: Campus Life: SUNY, Buffalo; Vandals Set Back Research Projects Using Animals
description: Two long-term health-related research projects at the State University of New York at Buffalo must be scrapped and started again as a result of vandalism that led to the release of about 750 laboratory animals at the university's School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, university administrators say.

title: Take My Husband . . . Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctor Links U.S. and Soviet Medicine
description: WHO could have predicted how much good will would come of Dr. Kristaps Keggi's visit to the Goodwill Games in the Soviet Union? In 1988, he traveled there to watch his daughter Mara compete as a rower. And in the two years since, Dr. Keggi has fostered cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union through a unique medical exchange program that regularly brings Soviet orthopedic surgeons to Waterbury to learn about American medical innovations and sends American medical students to the Soviet Union to see how doctors there employ some remarkably simple techniques to solve complicated orthopedic problems.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Oct. 20 MANHATTAN East Midtown 360,000 400 East 56th Street (Plaza 400) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining room; maintenance $1,264, includes gas and electricity, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: David Day Realty) East Village 207,500 629 East 6th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. co-op in a renovated loft; 17-ft. ceilings, exposed-brick walls, roof deck; maintenance $200, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Herbert H. Kleigerman Associates) Greenwich Village 440,000 1 Fifth Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,350-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, beamed-ceilings, parquet floors, Washington Sq. Park view; maintenance $1,087, 38% tax-deductible (Broker: Anne Weintraub Realty) TriBeCa 300,000 145 Nassau Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. co-op in a loft; high-ceilings, 3 exposures, City Hall Park view; maintenance $1,350, 67% tax-deductible (Broker: Eychner Associates/Tabak Real Estate) Upper West Side 630,000 325 West End Avenue (75th St.) 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,100-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned-elevator, dining room, 2 maid's rooms; maintenance $1,550, 37% tax-deductible (Broker: William B. May) Upper West Side 486,000 300 Central Park West (90th St.) (El Dorado) 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, entry foyer, fireplace, Central Park view; maintenance $845, 30% tax-deductible (Broker: Greenthal West Residential Sales) BRONX Allerton 195,000 1335 Allerton Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, brick house; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,300 (Broker: Tryax Realty) Riverdale 45,000 6485 Broadway 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining area, high-ceilings, remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $388, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: Charles G. Brophy and Associates) BROOKLYN Clinton Hill 170,000 275 Clinton Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. co-op in a renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $490, 33% tax-deductible (Broker: John P. Barry Realty) Sheepshead Bay 240,000 2368 East 22d Street 2-family, semi-attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, eat-in kitchen in each; new windows and doors, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Jacob Gold Realty) QUEENS East Elmhurst 215,000 22-47 92d Street 2-family, semi-attached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, dining room in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other; eat-in kitchen in each; 1-car garage, 30- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,297 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) Jamaica Hills 207,000 87-09 169th Street 4-bedrooms, 3-baths, single-family, semi-attached colonial; dining room, finished attic, hospitality suite in basement, 25- by 126-ft. lot; taxes $1,300 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) STATEN ISLAND New Springville 146,500 78 Rivington Avenue 3-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, semiattached, frame house; dining area, finished basement, 24- by 106-ft. lot; taxes $1,400 (Broker: Schlott Realtors) West Brighton 200,000 367 Oakland Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, den, finished basement, 50- by 117-ft. lot; taxes $990 (Broker: Rand Properties)

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: Is the United States Postal Service guilty of showing disrespect to the flag?

title: Regina Termine To Wed in 1991
description: The engagement of Regina Anne Termine to Dr. John Anthony McPhilliamy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick McPhilliamy of Little Neck Hills, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Termine of Forest Hills, Queens, and Palm City, Fla. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: Review/Pop; Fleetwood Mac, on the Verge of a Change, Revisits Several Musical Eras
description: "Yesterday's gone, yesterday's gone!" Fleetwood Mac proclaimed in its hit "Don't Stop," but the band ignores its own words. Its concert on Thursday evening at Madison Square Garden showed a band tangled in several time warps. (After performing "Don't Stop," the singer Christine McVie wished the audience "a great Christmas.")

title: The Boys in Berlin: Auden's Secret Poems
description: W. H. AUDEN was 21 years old when he went to live in Berlin in the autumn of 1928. He had recently graduated from Oxford and he was engaged to be married. Despite his notoriety as an undergraduate poet, the Oxford years had been something of a failure for Auden. He had taken a disappointing third-class degree in English, his first collection of poems had been rejected by T. S. Eliot at Faber & Faber and his love for several undergraduate men had gone largely unrequited. He had attempted to develop heterosexual traits and to improve his inferiority complex through psychoanalysis, but neither this nor a year of self-imposed celibacy brought much satisfaction.

title: As Election Day Nears, Poll Finds Nation's Voters in a Gloomy Mood
description: As Election Day draws near, Americans are more pessimistic about the future than at any time in a decade, according to the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: A Partner Exits, a Solo Begins
description: THE SCOURGE OF AIDS HAS given new visibility -- and determination to be visible -- to gay men in America. Artists have dealt passionately with the disease, forcing their audiences to pay attention to its emotional and physical ravages. But few artists have incorporated their lives as homosexuals so early and so boldly into their work as Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane, who over a period of 17 years saw their personal relationship become the material of their art.

title: Gorbachev Steers Middle Course on Lithuania
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeals Court Finds Los Angeles Discriminated in Setting Districts
description: A three-judge Federal appeals panel has upheld a lower court's finding that Los Angeles County's governing body intentionally diluted Hispanic voting strength when it redrew the boundaries of county election districts after the 1980 census.

title: Exxon's Slick Trick
description: The Exxon Corporation recently gave the Alaska Visitors Association $7 million to finance a nationwide advertising campaign, according to one news story, to "win back potential tourists still scared away by last year's oil spill." Exxon's public relations genius has struck again.

title:
POP MUSIC;
The Men on Wilbury Mountain
description: After the first album by the Traveling Wilburys and the death of their band-mate Roy Orbison, "there wasn't really a thought we would do any others," George Harrison said in a recent interview in Los Angeles. "But then Bob asked me a while back, 'When are we going to do another Wilburys record?' I said, 'You mean you

title: John P. Gill Wed To Miss Grimm
description: Sharon Ann Grimm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Grimm of Chatham Township, N.J., was married yesterday to John Patrick Gill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Gill of Plano, Tex., and New Vernon, N.J., at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in New Vernon. The Revs. Paul Brown and James Mahoney performed the ceremony.

title: CALL OF THE WILDMEN
description: I was struck by the intimacy of certain moments in Trip Gabriel's article "Call of the Wildmen" (Oct. 14). The hoopla and ceremony of the retreat, however, did not seem necessary to those moments, seemed even to detract from them. To get together and talk is a very natural activity; it does not require regimentation of this sort.

title: Feasts & Celebrations; In Praise of Home Cooking
description: LESLIE NEWMAN, a writer whose credits include co-authorship of the screenplays for "Superman: The Movie" and the next two sequels, is well known for cooking up dinners for 200 people at a time. "Her style is mine," says Nora Ephron. "We both tend to overdo things just slightly." This conversation was occasioned by the publication of Ms. Newman's first cookbook. NE: As I read your cookbook, I realized how much my own feelings about entertaining had been picked up from dinners at your house 15 or 20 years ago, which were, truly, feasts -- but in the most casual and informal way. At the same time, I couldn't help thinking we were the last middle-aged cooks in America. Everyone else has stopped, and you and I are carrying on some arcane tradition. We both learned to cook in the 1960's.

title: Staying Alive
description: I love newspapers. I know that's like a butcher telling you steak is great, but the butcher is right and so am I.

title: Pro Basketball; Key Call Is Costly As Nets Lose
description: If a play like the one that decided tonight's game went against one team in the National Basketball Association, it would have to be the Nets. It is just the way things go or, in this case, do not go for the troubled franchise.

title: Jessica Sunshine to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Sunshine of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jessica Sunshine, to Jeremy Selengut, a son of Barbara Sorce of Mahwah, N.J., and Arnold Selengut of Landing, N.J. The prospective bride and groom, both 24 years old, are graduates of Brown University, where Ms. Sunshine is a candidate for a Ph.D. degree in planetary geology. Mr. Selengut is a Ph.D. candidate in biochemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. A January wedding is planned.

title: Daniel C. Fives, Priest, 85
description: The Rev. Daniel Christopher Fives, a religious educator and parish priest, died on Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at Our Lady of Victory Church in lower Manhattan.

title: Teacher-Parent Party Lines
description: FINDING good educational software is a daunting task; of all the programs released each year, only a handful are worth installing on the hard disk. Finding good software for young children is especially tricky, since it must combine strong educational content with exceptional ease of use.

title: It's Still Chess, Just Played on Fast Forward
description: There are those who believe that chess is strictly an engagement of European manners, the feints and counterfeints concealing an epic struggle of daring, intellect and endurance. That may be the way it's played inside the Hotel Macklowe. But just outside, in Times Square, it's a different game: blitz chess lasts no more than 10 minutes, the sidewalk is its stage and aggressiveness always carries the day.

title: Poll Called Irresponsible
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner; Flavor, Smell and Taste, All With a French Touch
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Dinners' Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some places to dine on French cuisine in Manhattan.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;
Some Plants Crown Others
description: Of the approximately 5,000 flowering plants that grow in the Northeast, about 20 per cent are aliens. This means that, as far as is known, these plants were not here when the European settlers arrived, but they had some help getting here.

title:
Focus: Shared Living;
2 Housing Experiments in Massachusetts
description: A 12-YEAR-OLD experiment in communal living is expanding here at the same time that other groups in the area are preparing to set up cooperative communities based on the European model of co-housing.

title: College Football: Southwest/Midwest; Houston Goes to 8-0 A
description: David Klingler threw seven touchdown passes, offsetting a National Collegiate Athletic Association record of 690 passing yards by the Texas Christian quarterback, Matt Vogler, to lead Houston to a 56-35 victory today.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: LOCAL LENDING

title: Youths Are Sought in Killing of a Homeless Man
description: Detectives searching for a gang of youths who killed a homeless man during a Halloween rampage on the Wards Island bridge were combing the streets of eastern Harlem yesterday, trying to find several young men they know only by their nicknames.

title: Back and Forth Between Poussin and Cezanne
description: THERE HAVE IN RECENT YEARS been bigger, more provocative and more obviously ambitious exhibitions than "Cezanne and Poussin," which opened at the National Gallery of Scotland in Edinburgh at the time of this year's Edinburgh International Festival in August.

title: Ms. Breslow Wed To R. L. Strong Jr.
description: Nancy Ellen Breslow and Roger Leon Strong Jr. were married last evening at the Rockrimmon Country Club in Stamford, Conn., by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel. Mrs. Strong is the daughter of Dale Claman of New York and Jules W. Breslow of West Bloomfield, Mich. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Strong of New York.

title: The Camera Does Lie
description: In February 1982, National Geographic published a cover photo of the Great Pyramids of Giza, one of which had been repositioned by means of a new computer graphics technology. The earth moved in the world of photography. Although photographs had been altered in various ways almost from the beginning, the degree of manipulation possible had increased dramatically. One could efficiently add, subtract or move parts of a photographic image without leaving any evidence. Fred Ritchin, in his illustrated book of essays, IN OUR OWN IMAGE. The Coming Revolution in Photography: How Computer Technology Is Changing Our View of the World (Aperture, Paper, $15.95), explains how this technology works and speculates on the ways it will evolve; its implications for photography and, in particular, for photojournalism concern him deeply. Mr. Ritchin, a former director of photography for The New York Times Magazine and the founding director of the photojournalism program at the International Center for Photography, makes it clear that the ethical and esthetic issues involved affect all of us. If we can no longer rely on photography as our witness of time and place, he writes, then what we perceive as reality is suddenly malleable. Mr. Ritchin sees potential harm -- an almost infinite capacity for deception -- in the use of these technologies, as well as a great opportunity for the renewal of a medium that he feels has lost much of its power in recent years. Mr. Ritchin brings to his discussion a passionate interest in the social role of photography -- which, he says, should challenge our easy assumptions about the world by reflecting its complexity and richness.

title: A Company Gives Up on New York
description: FOR more than 20 years, my brothers and I have run a small, family-owned business in Manhattan that installs and maintains telephone systems and offers consulting services. But now we are moving out. We have finally lost our appetite for the Big Apple.

title: Jo Ann Jawidzik to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Jawidzik of Hazlet, N.J., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter Jo Ann Dolores Jawidzik and Michael J. K. Schiumo, a son of Patricia Schiumo of South Beach, S.I., and the late Louis J. Schiumo. A graduate of the University of Delaware and the New York Law School, Miss Jawidzik, 25 years old, is an associate at the Philadelphia law firm of Duane, Morris & Heckscher. Mr. Schiumo, 28, graduated from Cornell University and the University of Virginia School of Law. He is an associate at the law firm of Dechert, Price & Rhoads in Philadelphia.

title: Sports of the Times; Put Down the Souffle: Watch the Runners
description: IT is not every day that one can find 25,000 persons to admire. Sometimes, and particularly at this electoral time of year, it is hard to find more than one or two.

title: Hopes for Casinos Buoyed by 'Savior'
description: DESPITE the widespread agreement that casino gambling has failed to revitalize Atlantic City and that time to do so is running out, government and casino officials say they are optimistic the effort will ultimately succeed.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FINAL APPROACH. By John J. Nance. (Crown, $19.95.) John J. Nance, a lawyer and a former airline pilot, has made something of a career cataloguing the flood of changes that airline deregulation has brought to the industry and the traveling public. His first book, "Splash of Colors," depicted the bankruptcy of Braniff Airlines. "Blind Trust," Mr. Nance's best-selling second book, argued that deregulation has led to an erosion of safety margins. Now, in his first novel, Mr. Nance offers a behind-the-scenes look at the political jockeying that follows the crash of an airliner on a rain-soaked runway in Kansas City, Mo. In particular, he dissects the workings of the National Transportation Safety Board, the independent Government agency that, he suggests, is not so independent after all. Politically hungry officials at the Federal Aviation Administration, the Air Force and the fictional North America Airlines all try to sway the board's investigation. "Final Approach" is at its best as a gripping aeronautical whodunit. But the book seems overly ambitious, with a cumbersome plot that includes the possible assassination of a Congressman (a diversion Mr. Nance never fully resolves), a military cover-up and no fewer than two intra-office love affairs. The result is a sometimes turbulent read. Mr. Nance has gone to considerable pains to be technically accurate, and the novel occasionally bogs down in the fine points of flight-control systems or Federal rules that govern flying. But for the most part, "Final Approach" goes down smoothly, leaving readers something to chew on next time they board an airplane.

title: Time to Get Serious About Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Board Again Defers a Pay Increase
description: FACING a projected budget shortfall, the County Board of Legislators has declined for a second time to decide if the county's management employees and elected officials -- including the legislators themselves -- should receive a salary increase.

title: A Hostage Returns from the Persian Gulf
description: FOR six weeks in August and September, Thomas Hart Benton Ewald, a 25-year-old from Greenwich, was held hostage in Kuwait and Iraq. He had gone to Kuwait on July 30 to work in a bank, but when Iraqi troops invaded the emirate on Aug. 2, Mr. Ewald and hundreds of other Westerners went into hiding.

title: Boating Group Seeks More Access to Hudson
description: IN the belief that the Hudson River is a national treasure and that recreational boaters are the "forgotten masses," a group of boating enthusiasts has formed a committee to promote and improve boat access to the river in Westchester.

title: Baker Off to Mideast to Put Muscle Behind Bush Threats
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today he would be consulting with Arab and European allies to lay the foundations for a possible joint military operation to force Iraq out of Kuwait if diplomacy does not work.

title: A Mom-and-Pop Delight in Hauppauge
description: THE look and location of Due Torri say elegant supper club. Its penthouse perch atop a Hauppauge office building boasts floor-to-ceiling windows, plush banquettes, lively piano music, striking floral arrangements and tuxedoed waiters.

title: Q and A
description: Withheld Down Payment Question: We recently tried to buy a cooperative apartment in Manhattan. Our offer was accepted by the seller, a down payment of 10 percent was put into escrow, we were approved for the mortgage and we were interviewed by the board.

title: Feasts and Celebrations; Skiing to a Robust Supper
description: WITH 15 PEOPLE EXPECTED for dinner, Fred Nowak did what anyone in his position would love to do: He took the day off. And he headed for the ski slopes with a clear conscience, confident that he could provide his guests with an evening of food and hospitality. He knew this from experience -- nearly 30 years of it.

title: Amy Boas Weds Richard Walken
description: Amy Boas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald N. Boas of Woodmere, L.I., was married last evening at the Plaza in New York to Richard Harvey Walken, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Walken of Highland Park, Ill. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal performed the ceremony.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Fair Lawn 236,000 8-10 Hooper Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; custom kitchen, new windows, alarm system; taxes $2,914. Jackson 119,000 10 Valley Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old expanded ranch; patio, family room, w/w carpeting, deck; taxes $2,703. Randolph 412,500 22 Indian Trail 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old lakefront colonial; deck, fireplace; taxes $6,312. Union 180,000 782 Evergreen Parkway 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; finished basement, c/a, updated kitchen; taxes $3,067. Upper Montclair 295,000 227 Inwood Avenue 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; professionally landscaped, fireplace, deck; taxes $5,502. Westfield 350,000 758 Knollwood Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old split level; pool, eat-in-kitchen, full basement; taxes $6,415. OTHER AREASW Yonkers, N.Y. $275,000 46 Oriole Road 4-bedroom, 1 full-, 2 half-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fireplace, study, 1.5-car garage, deck; taxes $3,500. Danbury, Conn. 205,000 7 Hubbell Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; stone fireplace, whirlpool bath, 1.2 acres; taxes $2,153. Merrick, L.I. 184,000 1778 Elsie Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,200.

title: Fashion; UP SCALE
description: This is about big business, the cost of almost everything on these pages is on the staggering side of the price scale. But like most of fashion, what starts at the top shoots down to the bottom in record time. This is also about size. In today's world of style, the idea is to make a statement, no matter what you wear. And the message these designs convey is an impressive one: There is no point in being timid. If you like, say, overscale earrings, bracelets, bags, jewels, billowy capes, whooshing skirts or even chain-mail mesh, go for it all the way. The same holds true for short or long skirts, tight or loose clothes. A caution: Once you get used to a bigger version of something, an average-size one seems puny and insignificant. Right now, bigger is definitely better.

title: Sallies Fly at a Bronx Gallery
description: HUNTS POINT may be to greater New York what Les Halles was to Paris, but picturesque it is not. Then again, there is something exhilarating about this large tract with its strung-out warehouses and auto-glass dealers and coveys of tractor-trailers.

title: Pro Football; Jets Emerge as Favorites, but Prefer to Ignore It
description: The only other time this season the Jets were favored in a game was against the San Diego Chargers at home and Coach Bruce Coslet ominously predicted that being favored could be the "kiss of death." It was, as the Jets were routed, 39-3, by the Chargers.

title: Shared Housing for One-Parent Families
description: We were happy to read the Sept. 30 article about our Shared Housing for One-Parent Families project. As stated, the project assists many single mothers in finding housemates, saving many of them from homelessness. Some of these arrangements are transitional; others are still going strong two and three years later.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the Limon Dance Company misstated the date for a performance at the State Theater in New Brunswick. It is Tuesday; it was not last week.

title: Strength, Not Brains
description: BRUTE FORCE Allied Strategy and Tactics in the Second World War. By John Ellis. Maps. 643 pp. New York: Viking. $29.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house, which is 50 years old, has become so damp that even the carpeting on the second floor feels damp. A professional waterproofing contractor said it would cost us $9,500 to waterproof the house. He recommended "bleeding the walls" by knocking holes in each section of block, running a French drain across the floor, digging around the outside, waterproofing the foundation and then regrading the soil so that it slopes away from the house. The contractor also wants to apply a waterproof paint. We thought the price to be excessive and do not know what to do. What do you think?

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: The German chess term "Fingerfehler" means a mistake of the finger in moving a piece. The Manhattan Chess Club cynics have long taken it to be a lame excuse for something the brain did wrong and the player did not want to admit. But in the 10th round of the 14th Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, there was apparently a genuine case of a fingerfehler, or so the Dutch journalist Jules Welling reports in the Sept. 28 issue of the Swiss magazine "Die Schachwoche."

title: A Lesson From the Series
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Protests End at Smith College
description: A week of round-the-clock sit-ins at Smith College ended Friday when administrators and students tentatively agreed to establish a permanent center for minority and foreign students. Up to 60 students had camped out in the halls of Smith's main administration building since Oct. 26 to demand creation of a multicultural center. Numerous marches were held at the private women's college during the week. About 17 percent of Smith's 2,200 students are nonwhite.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 4, 1990
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 DADDY by Danielle Steel. (Dell $5.95.) Unexpected crises wreck a man's safe world. 2 6 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 3 1 DAWN, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.95.) A series of horrors besets a Virginia schoolgirl. 4 5 CALIFORNIA GOLD, by John Jakes. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A young man from Pennsylvania makes his fortune in 19th-century California. 5 5 THE SECRET DIARY OF LAURA PALMER, as seen by Jennifer Lynch. (Pocket, $8.95.) The journal of a "Twin Peaks" television character. 6 5 THE MINOTAUR, by Stephen Coonts. (Dell, $5.95.) The hunt for a mole in the Pentagon. 7 6 POSTCARDS FROM THE EDGE, by Carrie Fisher. (Pocket, $4.95.) A starlet's encounters with drugs and her quest for the right man. 8 17 SO WORTHY MY LOVE, by Kathleen E. Woodiwiss. (Avon, $5.95.) The abduction of a woman leads to romance in Elizabethan England. 9 2 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) A former Federal prosecutor reluctantly defends his daughter-in-law, charged with murdering his son. 10 * 6 OLDEST LIVING CONFEDERATE WIDOW TELLS ALL, by Allan Gurganus. (Ivy, $6.95.) A 99-year-old woman reflects on her past. 11 * 49 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $5.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis. 12 2 THE CAPTIVE, by Victoria Holt. (Fawcett, $5.95.) A 19th-century woman's adventures while a hostage of North African pirates and as a governess in an English household. 13 4 COLD HARBOUR, by Jack Higgins. (Pocket, $5.95.) A perilous mission during World War II. 14 1 A SEASON OF SWANS, by Celeste De Blasis. (Bantam, $5.95.) The final volume of a trilogy takes the Falconer family from California's Sonoma Valley to Saratoga Springs, N.Y. 15 1 SORCERESS OF DARSHIVA, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $5.95.) The fourth volume in "The Malloreon," a fantasy series. 16 * 24 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Ivy, $5.95.) Chinese-American women and their mothers. Weeks This On Week List Non Fiction 1 50 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 6 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $8.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's.

title: Toni Jay Weds M. A. Asch
description: Toni Georgenne Jay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Jay of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Alan Asch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Asch of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg officiated at Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. Mrs. Asch, 24 years old and a graduate of Pace University, is an accountant at Spicer & Oppenheim, a public accounting firm in New York. The bridegroom, 24, graduated from Friends Academy in Locust Valley, L.I., and the University of Pennsylvania. He is an associate at the investment banking firm of Robert Fleming Inc. in New York.

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Rake. Compost. Finish all planting, especially bulbs. Mow the lawn short -- about one inch -- for the last time, clean cover and store the mower. Move Christmas cactus indoors, if the potted plants have not been taken inside; they should burst into bloom soon. Arborvitae

title: Deborah Learn Wed To Dikran Kadagian
description: Deborah Susan Learn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dale H. Learn of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday at St. Paul Lutheran Church to Dikran Janus Kadagian, a son of Florence Clark Kadagian of Westport and Richard T. Kadagian of Frankfurt, Germany. The Rev. Paul Teske performed the ceremony.

title: Postings: 1 Housing Lottery; 2-Families in Yonkers
description: Construction is to begin this week on 14 two-family houses at seven sites in Yonkers that are to be sold for $115,900. They are intended for buyers, picked by lottery, who earn from $28,000 to $42,000 a year. Each three-story house includes a rental apartment, providing income to help with mortgage payments.

title: Miss Schneider Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Katherine Schneider to Dr. Peter Christopher Henry Gottschalk, a son of Peter M. Gottschalk of Land O'Lakes, Fla., and Mrs. Allerton Cushman Jr. of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Schneider of Rye, N.Y. A December wedding is planned.

title: OBSTACLE REMOVED ON NUCLEAR WASTE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has removed a major obstacle to a plan to create the nation's first permanent nuclear waste repository in a vast underground cavern mined from ancient salt beds near Carlsbad, N.M.

title: Susan Fowler Is Married
description: Susan Olivia Fowler, a daughter of Jacquelyn Keller Suber of Greenville, S.C., and Dr. Wesley C. Fowler Jr. of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married yesterday to Joseph Bernard Credle Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Credle of Beaufort, S.C. The Rev. David Hugh Upton performed the ceremony at the University Presbyterian Church in Chapel Hill. Mrs. Credle, 27 years old and a graduate of the University of North Carolina, is a copywriter at BBDO in New York. Her husband, 28, graduated from Louisiana State University. He is an architect at Rafael Vinoly Architects in New York.

title: Getting Away From a Getaway
description: IT was only hours after we reached nature camp in Maine that my college roommate, Sandy, and I realized we were in trouble. On paper, the camp had read like the ideal vacation, the perfect antidote to a grueling year of memorizing dates in darkened lecture rooms. But only hours after stepping on the barren island, we realized our mistake.

title: N.R.C. Modifies Stand On Closing Shoreham
description: AS always with Shoreham, the legal decisions are slow and thick, but in a decision last month the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission appeared to be laying the groundwork for approving the decommissioning of the reactor.

title:
WINE;
Local Stores Discover The Vineyards of Alsace
description: ONLY 55,000 cases of Alsatian wine were shipped to the United States last year, compared with 19 million cases from Bordeaux and 12 1/2 million cases from Burgundy. But, surprisingly, shops in Westchester are well stocked with bottles from Alsace.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical SCHUBERT: SONGS -- Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's historic recordings of several song cycles, which altered how we listen to this material, is released on compact disks. (Thor Eckert Jr.) EMI/Angel CDMC 63559.

title: State Helping Laid-Off Workers
description: IN a drafty board room at Silgan Plastics in Stonington, staff members from the State Department of Labor were outlining employment and training options for 60 people who were about to lose their jobs. Some had worked for Silgan Plastics for more than 20 years, and most had not looked for a job since the mid-1980's. After five decades in Stonington, Silgan had announced that it would close its mold-manufacturing plant on Nov. 16 and lay off its work force.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; A Flavorful Marinade For Beef
description: It takes very little time for the spunky flavors of this marinade to penetrate the meat, so don't worry if you have only 10 minutes. If you do not have maple syrup you can use honey, but the flavor will be slightly different.

title: The Executive Computer; When a Company Promises Service, Does It Mean It?
description: VIRTUALLY every computer maker boasts, one way or another, that its No. 1 goal is to serve the customer. It is no secret, though, that some companies simply pay lip service to the idea, while others do an extraordinary job of keeping customers happy. Unfortunately for corporate customers, it is often difficult to discover which is which until after the equipment is purchased.

title: To Hiss or Kiss? Villainy Still Works Its Wiles
description: ONE OF THE MAIN CHARACTERS in "Reversal of Fortune" is a nice guy who loves basketball, is an inspiration to his students and excels at whipping up salad-and-spaghetti dinners for a crowd. The other is a cold, supercilious aristocrat with a distinctly unsavory side. Accused of having attempted to murder his wife, he seems to positively thrive on the attendant notoriety. "Now, after all this unpleasantness," Claus von Bulow (Jeremy Irons) explains to his lawyer, Alan Dershowitz, "I always get the best table."

title: Can't Fool the Raincoat Crowd
description: To the Editor: Janet Maslin has misinterpreted the X rating, the NC-17 rating, "Henry and June," and, most important, the profound difference of purpose between the "person in the raincoat" and the mainstream moviegoer [ "Is NC-17 an X in a Clean Raincoat?" Oct. 21 ] . Judging from any of the essentially mainstream films that have garnered potential X ratings ("Henry and June," "The Cook, the Thief, the Wife and Her Lover," "Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!," "Hardware," etc.) and notwithstanding the differences in tone and quality among these films, they could never be mistaken for porn films. Their whole economy of desire and arousal is opposed to that of a true porn film and would be instantly recognized as such by the spectator in the raincoat. They lack explicit moments of orgasm.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Everyone has to believe in something. In your country you believe in God. In ours we had some kind of faith in a bright future. Now we have lost this belief and found nothing to replace it." -- Gennadi I. Malofeyev, principal of Middle School No. 3 in Sterlitamak, U.S.S.R. [ 10:3. ]

title: Taking Travel Agents to Court for Bad Advice
description: Ticket agents, in the words of the song, have come a long way from St. Louis. Once there was a person in the neighborhood who could order a ticket and save you a trip to midtown or the airport. Now there is a travel agent who may be styled an adviser or even a counselor.

title: For Dinkins And Unions, Friendship Has Its Price
description: MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS, a friend of labor who won office with its overwhelming support, now finds himself the target of labor's scorn and disbelief. That's bad news for any politician in a city with more than 300,000 workers on the payroll, the equivalent of 1 in 10 registered voters.

title: Governing Towns: Voters Seek Changes
description: ON Tuesday, voters in at least nine New Jersey communities will decide whether they want to change the way their municipalities are governed.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Rent a Cart for 25

title: At Columbia Tutoring Center, Teaching Is a Two-Way Street
description: When Lyndon B. Johnson began his war on poverty, two Columbia College students decided to enlist. In 1965, they gathered some of their classmates and started a summer tutoring program for underprivileged high school students in New York City.

title: Raise Adopted for U.S. Workers
description: FEDERAL workers in northern New Jersey will be receiving some financial relief now that Congress has passed legislation that ties government employees' salaries to living costs.

title: Campus Crime 101
description: CRIME has come to America's campuses, and with a vengeance that belies the image of universities free of sordid social ills. The recent murder of five college students in Gainesville, Fla., was only the most recent breach in the ivory tower.

title: Sports People; Historical Hoops
description: AMERICAN sports sometimes undergo subtle cultural changes when they are transported overseas, but the basketball game that was played at the Tokyo Metropolitan Gymnasium yesterday was as American as any National Basketball Association game, and for a good reason. That's exactly what it was, a regular-season N.B.A. game between the Phoenix Suns and the Utah Jazz.

title: Books From The Times
description: THERE'S A COUNTRY IN MY CELLAR. By Russell Baker. (Morrow, $20.95.) Russell Baker wrote his first column for The New York Times on July 16, 1962. Now, 3,800 columns later, "give or take a hundred," the author says, he offers a selection of the best. Arranged under such headings as "Family Matters," "Places I've Been," "Serious Nonsense" and "The Old Cuisine" (don't miss "Francs and Beans"), these 10 dozen mini-essays provide a gifted humorist's perspective on a quarter-century of the ridiculous and the sublime.

title: The Quiz
description: NECESSITY has birthed many an invention and discovery, but then so has untrammeled imagination. And let's not forget inspiration mixed, on occasion, with derring-do. The results have ranged from rarified creations to objects now so commonplace that we rarely think about them, or about the individual minds and grea civilazations that gave rise to them. Here, then, is an opportunity to uncover overgrown trails to innovation. The answers appear on page 44. 1. Elias Howe and Isaac Singer are both associated with what invention? 2. What people first used paper money? 3. What did Lewis E. Waterman invent? 4. What country, from the time of Christ to about 1350 led the world in number of inventions? 5. The first parachute jump was made in: (A) 1640; (B) 1783; (C) 1850. 6. What did Clarence C. Birdseye invent? 7. The following are names of people who, with one exception, were responsible for inventions and discoveries in a particular field. What was the field, and who is the exception? (A) Volta; (B) Watt; (C) Daguerre; (D) Ampere; (E) Ohm. 8. Who invented the steamboat? 9. Who was the "godfather of American invention"? 10. Hang gliders are a recent innovation. True or False? 11. How many peanut-based products did George Washington Carver invent? 12. Which of the following statements is myth and which is fact? (A) The complete system for an alternating-current motor came to Nicola Tesla in a vision. (B) The concept of gravity as a natural force came to Sir Isaac Newton when an apple fell on his head. (C) Galileo conducted some of his experiments on falling bodies from the Tower of Pisa. 13. Which advanced civilizations saw no utilitarian value in the wheel, but used it only as a toy? 14. What invention sprang from Benjamin Franklin's experiment with a kite? 15. Where was the first commercial power station? 16. Who was the last famous "lone tinkerer," before inventions and discoveries became a team effort in the laboratory? 17. Who was Granville T. Woods and what are some of his better-known inventions? 18. What invention in 1852 made skyscrapers practical? 19. Which of the following inventions did not exist before 1945: (A) television; (B) radar; (C) solar- powered equipment; (D) microchips; (E) liquid propellant rockets. 20. Carl Benz invented the first gasoline-powered vehicle in: (A) 1850; (B) 1885; (C) 1910. 21. Who invented the gas mask and the traffic signal system? 22. Louis Pasteur was a medical doctor. True or False? 23. Who invented the pneumatic tire? 24. The first synthetic polymer was invented in 1907. What was it called? 25. The principles of computer programming were devised in the 1840's by the daughter of a famous Romantic poet. What was her name? 26. Link Archimedes, Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell with the following sentences or words: "Mary had a little lamb"; "Mr. Watson, come here, I want you"; "Eureka!"

title: Allison Bell and George Wood Marry
description: Allison Lilith Bell, the daughter of Mrs. William S. Torrance of Rancho Mirage, Calif., and William L. Bell Jr. of Washington, was married yesterday to George Wood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Wood of Newtown Square, Pa., and Mountain Lake, Fla. The Rev. Stephen K. Jacobson performed the ceremony at the St. David's (Pa.) Episcopal Church.

title: Campus Life: Princeton; Engineering Tries To Find a Place In the Liberal Arts
description: If David P. Billington had his way, engineering would be part of every liberal arts student's education.

title: A Narco-Military State
description: IN THE TIME OF THE TYRANTS. Panama: 1968-1990. By R. M. Koster and Guillermo Sanchez. (Norton, $22.95.) Latin American armies have earned an evil reputation in the 20th century by corrupting the soldier's traditional role of protector into that of oppressor. Panama, though never an exemplary democracy, came relatively late to this unhappy situation. In 1968, its colonels engineered a coup d'etat that placed one military leader or another in control for the next 21 years. R. M. Koster, an American who teaches English at Florida State University's Panama Canal branch, and Guillermo Sanchez, a Panamanian journalist and the premier columnist of the opposition newspaper La Prensa, have joined forces to write a scathing history of these two decades of humiliation and corruption that is full of enough scoundrels, fools and genuine heroes to stock an old-time melodrama -- Omar Torrijos, for example, whose blend of charisma and radical slogans charmed Fidel Castro, the domestic Communists and naive intellectuals like Graham Greene, while his moderate actions reassured the United States. The authors, however, see in Torrijos the roots of the disasters that followed his accidental death in 1981, disasters such as the ascent of Manuel Noriega, whose limitless greed resulted in Panama being turned into a narco-military state. Opponents like Hugo Spadafora, who threatened Noriega's control, were murdered, preferably through torture; nearly everyone else was bought off. Looming over this catastrophe was, of course, the Colossus of the North, the United States, whose fears of instability and subversion led to a policy marked by callous stupidity, the end result of which was last December's invasion. "In the Time of the Tyrants" must read much as Mr. Sanchez' columns did: sarcastic, angry, witty, erudite and full of rumor, innuendo, insights and genuine news. It is by turns entertaining and horrifying, but always provocative.

title: Hamburger Heaven
description: In its attempts to be seen as the fast-food restaurant with a heart, the McDonald's Corporation has long declared that it buys no cattle from ranches carved out of rainforest. But McDonald's 8,500 restaurants consume vast amounts of polystyrene as well as beef, and it has been difficult for the company to appear environmentally aware while gorging landfills with millions of plastic foam hamburger boxes. For months the restaurant chain tried to find a solution to the problem, forming an alliance with the Environmental Defense Fund and experimenting with a recycling program. But last week Edward H. Rensi, the president of McDonald's U.S.A., announced that by popular demand the company would return to wrapping its sandwiches with paper instead of putting them in the plastic foam containers called "clamshells." "Our customers just don't feel good about it," he said. Still to be worked out are such engineering details as how to repackage the McDLT, for which a two-part foam container is used to keep the hot hamburger separate from the cooler lettuce and tomato slices.

title: Hikers on the Trail to Romance
description: WITH fitness in, alcohol consumption down and the specter of AIDS haunting every chance encounter, the likelihood of finding companionship across a crowded bar seems to have dropped.

title: Design; ART TURNS THE TABLES
description: Table settings have been a popular still-life subject ever since Pompeii. But artists today are looking beyond the canvas, painting the actual objects that go on a table: the plates and cups, vases and bowls. "There's a decorative-arts renaissance in America right now," says Frank McIntosh, the owner of several home-furnishings shops at Henri Bendel and elsewhere. "Artists have begun creating their own tableware designs."

title: The Bonus Army Incident
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE MAX PAVEY CHESS CLUB;
Playing With the Intensity of Champions
description: THE room was silent except for the ticking of clocks, the clicking of game pieces and the occasional declaration of checkmate.

title: Harvard Looks for New President and New Ideas
description: Midway through its task, the search committee seeking a successor to Harvard University's president, Derek C. Bok, has produced many names, but so far no clear favorite has emerged for what is often considered the premier academic job in America.

title: The Search for A Birth Parent
description: I was deeply moved by "Could You Be My Mother?" by Alyce Mitchem Jenkins (Opinion page, Sept. 30).

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: YOUNG MUSICIANS

title: Ideas & Trends; Why Some Oil Prices Rise While Others Rise Faster
description: THE rising tide of oil prices is producing some puzzling swirls. Crude oil is up by about 53 percent since Iraq invaded Kuwait, but gasoline, which comes from crude, is up less than 28 percent. Heating oil is up about 45 percent. Jet fuel is up 78 percent.

title: The Cost of Divorce to Staten Island
description: "Shall a charter commission to provide for the separation of the borough of Staten Island from the City of New York and for the establishment of the City of Staten Island be created?"

title: The New Woman Finds Her Place on The Small Screen
description: LET'S PLAY FIND THE COMMON denominator. The category is made-for-TV movies. Tonight at 9 on ABC, Mary Tyler Moore and Bernadette Peters star in "The Last Best Year." A couple of Sundays ago, Angela Lansbury could be seen on NBC in "The Love She Sought." And next Sunday on ABC, Patty Duke plays herself in "Call Me Anna," based on her autobiography.

title: Suzanne Tassie Plans to Marry
description: December wedding plans for Suzanne Tassie and Earl M. Grossman have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, John M. Tassie and Brogan Tassie, both of Princeton, N.J. Mr. Grossman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Grossman of Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Campus Life: Carleton; Charge of Sexism Ends a Tradition By Football Team
description: Carleton College's football team has abandoned a tradition in which a team member selects the most attractive first-year female student and tries to date her.

title: On Language; Judge Crater Found, Vegged Out
description: "YOU ASK ABOUT Marlin," George Bush wrote, kidding around earlier this year about his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater. "He is a serious contender for the coveted Scowcroft Award. . . . He needs to improve his record on sleeping in important meetings. The Scowcroft Award gives extra points for he/she who totally craters, eyes tightly closed, in the midst of meetings."

title: Correction
description: An article last week about traditional music included an erroneous figure supplied by a spokesman at the National Endowment for the Arts for its folk-arts budget. The correct figure is $3.4 million.

title:
Feasts & Celebrations;
Collecting the Old and . . . the New
description: Whether it is a reproduction of a Chinese export porcelain plate that was used in an English castle in the 1800's, or a silver teapot that could have been your great-grandmother's, the look of the past is appearing more often on tabletops today. Antique dealers and flea markets sell a wide range of period designs, which are being collected to be used and not just displayed. And, increasingly, sources from burgeoning museum mail-order businesses to manufacturers such as Minton and Towle are offering reproductions and heirloom-inspired examples. Many of the new wares will cost less than their older counterparts, but not necessarily -- the vagaries of pricing at antiques and flea markets means that a dedicated collector can often find pieces for modest expense. In either case, the thing to remember is that collecting does not need to be done all at once; rather, it is an investment preferably enjoyed over a period of years.

title: County Takes First Steps on Its Housing Plan
description: SIX months ago, Westchester officials announced a plan to develop more permanent housing and to reduce what is believed to be the highest per capita concentration of homelessness in the state. Last week, several pieces of the plan began to fall into place.

title: Bonnie Geller Is to Marry Isaac Geld
description: The engagement of Bonnie Stephanie Geller, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Steven Geller of New York and Tarpon Springs, Fla., to Isaac Aaron Geld, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Tobias Geld of Brooklyn, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. A December wedding is planned.

title: Artisan's Golden Touch Makes Interiors Glister
description: NORA A. HUMPHREY says her work is more of a craft than an art. With painstaking precision, she applies gold leaf to picture frames, mirrors, furniture, moldings, walls and ceilings.

title: 'Desegregating the Altar'
description: To the Editor:

title: Admissions Ploys That Backfire
description: AN EAGER applicant to Harvard University once deluged the school with letters of recommendation from virtually everyone he knew, including his orthodontist, who described the work he did on the applicant's teeth and the brightness of the applicant's new smile.

title: 90's Teen-Agers Echo 60's Spirit
description: THEY may not be a second Woodstock generation, but high school students nationwide are proving they're not the quiescent group that many assume. In the past year, students in dozens of cities have staged demonstrations, walkouts or sit-ins to protest everything from changes in school emblems to school budget cuts.

title: Success Was Not Enough
description: IN ALL HIS GLORY The Life of William S. Paley: The Legendary Tycoon and His Brilliant Circle. By Sally Bedell Smith. Illustrated. 782 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $29.95.

title:
ART;
Examining the Sensitivities of the Political Realm
description: THE title, "Artist as Apolitical Sensor," the group exhibition now on view in the Hillwood Art Museum at Long Island University's C. W. Post Campus in Brookville, gives viewers a foretaste of the show's complexities.

title: It's Tough Slogging in the Japan Markets
description: THE startling news that Matsushita Electric was negotiating to buy MCA Inc., the movie-maker, hit American securities houses here recently like a thunderstorm after a drought. Deal-parched investment bankers focused not on the proposed buyout's meaning for an ailing America or a Hollywood starry-eyed for Japanese money, but on one detail: Matsushita had not yet hired a financial adviser.

title: Currency; Still More Pressure on the Dollar
description: A SENIOR Treasury official expressed concern about the decline in the dollar last week, indicating a worry that had not been apparent in recent public statements by the Treasury Secretary and others in the Bush Administration. But by the end of the week, the German Bundesbank had wiped out any slight benefit from that comment by raising a key short-term rate, the Lombard rate, to 8.5 percent from 8 percent. The increase seemed to be mostly a signal to the German Government that the central bank is unhappy with Bonn's insistence on borrowing to pay for the huge rebuilding of the old East Germany. But the rate increase also undermined the dollar, sending it to a new 42-year low on Friday of 1.4937 marks to the dollar.

title: Review/Music; Folk Singer's View of Love
description: June Tabor, an English folk singer with a sense of humor as dark as her nearly vibratoless alto, described her favorite subject to sing about as "L.G.W.," in the first of two shows at the Bottom Line on Monday evening. Those initials stand for "love gone wrong," the singer explained wryly. And in a concert that blended traditional ballads with modern folk-pop songs and popular standards, Miss Tabor, who was dressed in black, kept the mood pensive and torchy.

title: Rinfret's True Opponent Isn't Cuomo
description: In the angry depictions of many Republican leaders, Herbert London is a man bent on wounding, perhaps even destroying, the Republican Party in New York State. But Mr. London, a registered Republican who is running for governor as the nominee of the Conservative Party, insists that the opposite is true.

title: The Germans Called It War
description: THE HOLOCAUST The Fate of European Jewry, 1932-1945. By Leni Yahil. Translated by Ina Friedman and Haya Galai. 808 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $35.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 4, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe during the Ice Age. 2 2 5 LADY BOSS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) Lucky Santangelo schemes and maneuvers to get control of a major movie studio. 3 3 8 FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Four novellas about horror and terror in the late-night hours. 4 4 11 MEMORIES OF MIDNIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $21.95.) The destiny of an American woman is haunted by a vengeful Greek tycoon. 5 8 2 LONGSHOT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $19.95.) An author of survival guides finds his know-how taxed when he undertakes to write about the world of horse racing. 6 9 3 BUFFALO GIRLS, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The end of the old Wild West, seen through the lives of Calamity Jane and two mountain men. 7 7 3 THE FIRST MAN IN ROME, by Colleen McCullough. (Morrow, $22.95.) The rivalry of two men who want to become consul of the Roman Republic in 110 B.C. 8 10 4 RABBIT AT REST, by John Updike. (Knopf, $21.95.) The fourth and final novel about Harry (Rabbit) Angstrom. 9 5 21 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An attorney tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death. 10 15 3 UNDER SIEGE, by Stephen Coonts. (Pocket, $19.95.) Chaos in Washington when the kingpin of the Medellin drug cartel is brought there for trial. 11 6 7 THE GENERAL IN HIS LABYRINTH, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $19.95.) The last, sad retrospective days of Simon Bolivar. 12 11 37 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 13 12 7 HOCUS POCUS, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Putnam, $21.95.) Life in the near future as noted by a college professor and prison administrator in upstate New York. 14 14 26 THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 15 13 6 SURRENDER THE PINK, by Carrie Fisher. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The romantic misadventures of a woman soap opera writer. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 6 BY WAY OF DECEPTION, by Victor Ostrovsky and Claire Hoy. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) An account of the operations of Mossad, the Israeli spy service. 2 2 4 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 3 3 6 MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The White House dog's memoirs. 4 5 14 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The different languages men and women speak. 5 4 7 GET TO THE HEART, by Barbara Mandrell with George Vecsey. (Bantam, $19.95.) The autobiography of the country-music singer. 6 8 3 THE CAT AND THE CURMUDGEON, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) The continuing contentions of two curmudgeons. 7 9 5 FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS, by H. G. Bissinger. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) Football in Odessa, Tex. 8 7 8 BOOTLEGGER'S BOY, by Barry Switzer with Bud Shrake. (Morrow, $19.95.) The autobiography of the former college football coach. 9 6 9 DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Styron. (Random House, $15.95.) The novelist's memoir of a period of severe depression. 10 13 2 AVA, by Ava Gardner. (Bantam, $19.95.) The autobiography of the veteran film actress. 11 * 14 5 CLOSER TO THE LIGHT, by Melvin Morse with Paul Perry. (Villard, $17.95.) A doctor examines the experiences of young patients who almost died. 12 1 THE BOOK OF J, translated by David Rosenberg. Interpreted by Harold Bloom. (Grove Weidenfeld, $21.95.) A critique of the texts of Genesis, Exodus and Numbers as the work of a woman. 13 * 15 2 FLEETWOOD, by Mick Fleetwood with Stephen Davis. (Morrow, $17.95.) The memoirs of the drummer for the rock band Fleetwood Mac. 14 1 POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives. 15 10 4 LOOKING FOR A SHIP, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A voyage along the South American coast. 16 * 1 THE CONTENT OF OUR CHARACTER, by Shelby Steele. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) A look at recent racial conflicts and an appeal for an integrated society. 17 * 1 NAPA, by James Conaway. (Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) A social history of the valley. 1 1 16 HOMECOMING, by John Bradshaw. (Bantam, $18.95.) How to find the child you once were that lives within you and use it to deal with today's problems. 2 2 47 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrated games. 3 5 3 DR. DEAN ORNISH'S PROGRAM FOR REVERSING HEART DISEASE, by Dean Ornish. (Random House, $24.95.) A system designed to supplement conventional medical therapy. 4 3 90 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's financial advice. 5 4 5 WHERE'S WALDO? by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A new book of illustrations in which the game is to find a hitchhiker named Waldo. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Hispanics in Despair
description: WITH just two months to go before his high school graduation, Maccario Garcia had the lead role in his drama club's production of "Macbeth" and was looking forward to attending college. It should have been a happy time, but sitting in the living room of his family's small apartment in Houston's East End one afternoon in April he toyed with the idea of dropping out of school. 'Crisis in Hispanic Education'

title: For House Republicans, Analysts Change Forecast From Gains to Losses
description: As recently as this summer, Republicans thought they might gain seats in the House of Representatives this year, trimming the Democrats' 83-seat margin and perhaps paving the way for Republican control of Congress later in the 90's. But that optimism evaporated with the budget and tax melodrama of the last few weeks, and now analysts are asking how many seats the Republicans will lose.

title: Embroidered Linens a Good Buy in Hong Kong
description: Embroidered linens from China, which have been made in that country at least since the years before World War II, are in plentiful supply in Hong Kong. Indeed, there are linens of every sort, from bedcovers and tablecloths to napkins barely large enough to hold a triangle of toast piled high with caviar, to fanciful potholders in the shape of a cat with appliqued paws and embroidered whiskers.

title: The Challenge AIDS Presents in the Suburbs
description: THE AIDS epidemic has descended on Westchester and the greatest challenge will be to curtail apathy and denial, AIDS experts said recently.

title: It Seemed a Good Idea at the Time
description: BEING RED By Howard Fast. Illustrated. 370 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Moving Commercial Property by Auction
description: TAKING their cues from residential developers, owners of vacant commercial office and warehouse space are turning to auctions.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Albertson 110,000 116 Sigsbee Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 70-year-old cottage; eat-in kitchen, front porch; taxes $900. Hauppauge 210,000 16 Pinedale Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 23-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, dining room, pool, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,600. Mineola 190,000 34 Dow Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 58-year- old Tudor; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,700. Merrick 184,000 1778 Elsie Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,200. Patchogue 114,000 21 Highland Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,900. Uniondale 130,000 681 Hempstead Boulevard 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,400. OTHER AREAS Union, N.J. 180,000 782 Evergreen Parkway 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; finished basement, c/a, updated kitchen; taxes $3,067. Yonkers, N.Y. $275,000 46 Oriole Road 4-bedroom, 1 full-, 2 half-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fireplace, study, 1.5-car garage, deck; taxes $3,500. Danbury, Conn. 205,000 7 Hubbell Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; stone fireplace, whirlpool bath, 1.2 acres; taxes $2,153.

title: It's Special Effects That Make the Actor
description: BRYANT HOLT of Nesconset may not be a household name, but the movies he has worked on are: "Star Trek 5: The Final Frontier," "The Blob" and "The Abyss," to name a few.

title: Giving Marathoners A Psychological Edge
description: SOME marathon runners wear talismans, some say a little prayer before a race, and some in today's New York City Marathon will accept instant psychiatric help to give them that extra edge. A little known group of psychiatrists and psychologists, which calls itself the Psyching Team, will arrive at the starting line at 6 A.M. to wander among the growing crowd of runners, offering support and reassurance as well as hypnosis and instant cures for phobias and psychiatric woes. For the last few years the group has mostly consisted of local practitioners but this year it has expanded, with nearly half of the 80 members flying in from other parts of the country, at their own expense, to help with the 26.2-mile race.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IN THE EYE OF WAR By Margaret and Raymond Chang. 198 pp. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. SHANGHAI PASSAGE By Gregory Patent. Illustrated by Ted Lewin. 115 pp. New York: Clarion Books. $13.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Review/Jazz; (Most of) The Marsalis Family in Concert
description: There's no generation gap in the musical taste of the Marsalis family of New Orleans. From the 55-year-old patriarch and pianist, Ellis Marsalis, down to the 13-year-old drummer Jason, the hard-bop of the late 1950's and 60's is the pinnacle of jazz, and they have led a revival of the style among young musicians.

title: Self-Esteem: Hoax or Reality?
description: IN THE battle for the minds of American children, there may be no more highly touted weapon in the 1990's than the concept of self-esteem. From studies conducted by educational researchers, to pilot programs organized by teacher advocacy groups, to parents concerned about their children's future, the debate over whether children's feelings about themselves can make a difference in their academic achevement has found its way into every level of education.

title: Social Events
description: Depardieu as Cyrano

title: No Strings, No Corruption
description: To the Editor: In response to Richard Bernstein's article about the cutting edge [ "Why the Cutting Edge Has Lost Its Bite," Sept. 30 ] , money does not corrupt a serious artist -- although if you read the cultural sections of our major newspapers these days you might be convinced that it did. Money with strings corrupts.

title: African National Congress Is Facing A New Struggle: Politics in the Open
description: The African National Congress, which was restored to legal status only nine months ago, is experiencing difficulty fulfilling the hopes and needs of the black majority that it says it represents.

title: Daily News Strike Becomes a Battle for Advertisers
description: The battle over the future of The Daily News shifted to its advertisers yesterday as the paper's management struggled to print and, more importantly, distribute its Sunday edition.

title: Review/Theater; Fun and Games With Two Geniuses
description: Near the end of Dimitri Frenkel Frank's stimulating dramatic study of the life and times of Benedict Spinoza, the 17th-century Dutch philosopher and his friend Rembrandt van Rijn find themselves down and out in their home city of Amsterdam.
