Spinoza, the brilliant but rebellious free thinker, has been excommunicated by the local rabbinate for his heretical views. And Rembrandt, a high-living sensualist 27 years Spinoza's senior, is out of fashion as a painter, bankrupt and about to lose his house and possessions.

title: Mobile College Aid Money
description: A PLAN to generate scholarship money by piquing the interest of alumni in both athletics and automobiles has turned into a successful fund-raising technique for at least 45 American colleges and universities.

title: December Bridal For Melissa Reali
description: December wedding plans for Melissa Maria Reali and Frederick Robert Wengler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Wengler of Bohemia, L.I., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John P. Reali of Sea Cliff, L.I.

title: Humane Society Will Divest Where Labs Test on Animals
description: Faced with declining financial support because of its investment policies, the Connecticut Humane Society has decided to sell off securities in companies that use animals for research.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; A French Firm With a Nose for Bargains
description: IN contrast to the British, Japanese and Canadian real-estate concerns pouring millions into this country in the last decade, few French firms have moved in.

title: Karyn Kirkman To Wed in Winter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Kirkman of Riverside, Conn., have announced January wedding plans for their daughter Karyn Elizabeth Kirkman and Christopher Gerard Lanzano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl N. Lanzano of the Bronx.

title: Talking: Remodeling; Imaging To 'See' Results
description: ONE of the recurrent fears in any remodeling job is that it will not look right. Would it be a major error, for example, to take down a kitchen wall? Would a new bay window be too large for the dining room? Should the screened porch be put on the side instead of the rear? Should shingles be used rather than clapboard?

title: Style Makers; Genevieve Lethu, China and Housewares Designer
description: "When people want a change at home, they can't go out and buy a whole new sofa, but they can change the look of their dining table." says Genevieve Lethu, whose name graces stylish dinner tables throughout France.

title: Tighter Rules Sought on Nonpublic Education
description: In response to a broad school-choice initiative on the ballot on Tuesday, education officials in Oregon have scrambled to tighten state regulations for private schools and education in the home, which would benefit from the referendum if it passes.

title: Who's in Control?
description: To the Editor:

title: Zoning Bonuses
description: While your article on the zoning-bonus program ("Are Plazas Public Boons, or Nuisances?", Oct. 7) was both cogent and timely, there were a few significant inaccuracies in discussing Sheffield Plaza. Unfortunately, they permitted the Plaza's owner, Rose Associates, to be portrayed as part of the solution instead of as part of the problem.

title: Evening Hours; Spotlight on Fashion And a Week of Benefits
description: With New York fashion showings winding to a close, the Baroness Philippine de Rothschild arrived from France to present the Mouton-Cadet Young Designer Award Thursday night at The Fashion Institute of Technology. On Wednesday the designer Giorgio Armani was host of the opening of his exhibition "Images of Man" at F.I.T. Later he greeted guests at a screening of "Made in Milan," a film about his life. Radio City Music Hall was the setting for a benefit Tuesday for the Historic Hudson Valley, which supports programs at six historic properties. On Monday the Metropolitan Museum opened the Carol and Milton Petrie European Sculpture Court and the Council of Fashion Designers of America held a party at the Paramount Hotel for visiting fashion journalists. That same night the Friends of the Israeli Museum celebrated the museum's 25th anniversary at the World Financial Center. On Sunday at the Music for Life concert for the Gay Men's Health Crisis fund for AIDS, guests dined at Lincoln Center.

title: Rhonda Sullivan Engaged to Wed
description: Rhonda Lee Sullivan, an assistant vice president at J. P. Morgan Investment Management in New York, and David Loren Kershner, a research chemist at Akzo Chemicals in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., are planning a December wedding. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Sullivan of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the Rev. and Mrs. Nevin L. Kershner of Philadelphia.

title: College Football; Buffaloes Slam Door on Huskers
description: It's happened again. Just when it seemed as if the Nebraska Cornhuskers were prepared to walk through a wide-open door of opportunity -- this time to the Big Eight Conference championship and a possible top ranking -- the door has suddenly and rudely slammed in their face.

title: Alyssa Srulowitz and Daniel Zanger Are Engaged
description: Alyssa Srulowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Srulowitz of Monsey, N.Y., and Dr. Daniel Zanger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Zanger of Bayside, Queens, are planning a December wedding. Miss Srulowitz, 23 years old, graduated from Barnard College. She is a member of the special client services division at Sotheby's in New York. Dr. Zanger, 27, is a resident in internal medicine at Bronx Municipal Hospital. He graduated from Yeshiva University and received his M.D. from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: Washington Is Tiring of Supporting All Those Spies
description: THE Pentagon, it turns out, was not the only Federal behemoth rescued from Congressional budget-cutters by Saddam Hussein. When Congress adjourned last weekend it left behind a top-secret 1991 espionage budget that not only is said to approach $30 billion -- just a nick below current levels -- but also resists deeper cuts that the House and Senate armed services committees are looking for.

title:
The Executive Life;
When Politics and Profits Just Don't Mix
description: TIANANMEN Square. The mere mention of Beijing's biggest public plaza brings back horrific memories of the bloody student uprising that was staged there last year and then quashed by the Chinese Government. Relations between the United States and China have since chilled considerably, and Congress has sought to show its disapproval of the Communist Government's violent crackdown through various diplomatic sanctions.

title: HERS: TRUE BLUE
description: My Sascha, a Siberian husky who died last year at the age of 16, sustained and comforted me in the same way Blue did Eileen Drenick (Hers: "True Blue," Oct. 7). An alcoholic's experience of "hitting bottom" can be a turning point -- or it can be one more experience on the way to total self-destruction. My promises to Sascha and her unconditional loyalty and affection kept me, against all odds, bound to civilized life and finally able to save myself. At least Sascha had nine of the good years to make up for seven of the horrendous ones.

title: Fashion;   Fake Fur Takes Off In New Directions
description: This fall, some fake furs come disguised as Persian lamb, rabbit, fox, mink, mouton, beaver, leopard and tiger. Others are dyed in strange hues -- pale blue, red, purple, pumpkin, pomegranate, silvery grey, pinky beige -- as well as in black, brown and taupe.

title: Irate Voters Approach Ballot Box With Sharpened Axes
description: Leo W. Charland is so angry at politicians that he plans to march to his polling place in Punta Gorda, Fla., on Tuesday and help vote them all out, including one of Florida's Senators, Connie Mack.

title: Technology; Computerized Holography: A Gimmick Grows Up
description: THIS is the way a 21st century operating room might look: A neurosurgeon peers up from the delicate surgery that is underway and requests information from a technician at a nearby computer. The technician adjusts some dials and immediately a computer monitor comes alive with a bright, three-dimensional holographic image of the patient's brain, generated by the computer from data it receives from a magnetic-resonance imaging device. The surgeon can rotate the image through each of its axes to peer deep into the structure of the brain. In this way, the most delicate of procedures can be planned and even rehearsed before any cut is made.

title: For the Soviet Press, Gorbachev as Target
description: TRADITIONALLY the only way for a Soviet leader to get bad press in his own country was to die. Then the puppet press, enlisted in the ritual of Kremlin forerunner-bashing, would discover that the late ruler had not been the benign genius portrayed during his lifetime in Pravda. Mikhail S. Gorbachev is the first Soviet leader who has lived to read his critics.

title: The Coming Squeeze on Capital
description: IN every international political crisis since World War II, the dollar has strengthened -- until now. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the dollar has fallen sharply. It is no longer the most important safe-haven currency.

title: New Designs Bring New Independence for Disabled People
description: SLEEK racing vehicles, contemporary flatware and colorful plastic forms are among the 45 objects in the current exhibit at Artspace in New Haven, "Designs For Independent Living." The display shows that items intended to aid disabled and elderly people can be highly attractive.

title: Ideas & Trends; Science and the Courts Take a New Look at Motherhood
description: AS advances in technology bring into question basic assumptions about life and death, medical and legal scholars are suggesting that motherhood may in the future be defined less in terms of biology than in terms of intent.

title: Palestinian Killed as Clashes Erupt With Troops
description: A Palestinian was shot to death today and at least 61 others were wounded in clashes between Israeli soldiers and Arabs who were angered by rumors that a Palestinian prisoner had been tortured to death in a military jail in the occupied Gaza Strip.

title: Blacks Look to Basics
description: FOR GENERATIONS, black children have hobbled behind white children on the road to learning, impeded by racial discrimination, hard times at home, low expectations of teachers and testing procedures built on a culture that is in many ways outside their own.

title: Special School Rates 'A' With Dropouts
description: ON graduation night in September, members of the 1990 class of the Harriet Eisman Community School in Long Beach, an alternative program for high school dropouts, milled around the doorway waiting for the ceremony to begin.

title: 'The Music of Chance'
description: THERE may be some doubt as to whether Paul Auster really means to be a novelist at all. Like Julian Barnes, though with infinitely greater success, he has used the form of the novel as a shell for intellectual speculation of one kind or another. His most brilliant effects have been achieved by his reworkings of the mystery in "The New York Trilogy," where the formalism of the genre also does much to specify the plot. Mr. Auster's latest novel, "The Music of Chance," seems however to have taken a picaresque model, whose form is less distinctly defined.

title: Birders Flock as One Very Lost Bird Lands in Rye
description: A wood sandpiper in the marshes here coaxed Bill Tucker from bed at 5:30 A.M. today to drive all the way from Washington. Keep in mind that this is someone who has already seen 2,500 birds, including the wood sandpiper.

title: Schools Try Math Program Emphasizing Drills
description: JOHN SAXON is a textbook author and publisher with a mission. He wants to change how mathematics is taught.

title: Pro Basketball; Spurs Overcome Injuries and Win
description: Terry Cummings and David Robinson sparked a 22-4 second-half run and held off a late surge today to lead the San Antonio Spurs past the Los Angeles Lakers, 110-99.

title: To Manipulate the World, Mystify It
description: WILL Saddam Hussein fight a war to defend his seizure of Kuwait? Will he push matters to the brink before eventually pulling out? Or will he succeed in dividing the alliance arrayed against him and make a deal that leaves him control of at least part of the occupied territory, as well as the enhanced stature of having faced down the United States?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FAR AFIELD. By Susanna Kaysen. (Vintage Contemporaries, Paper, $9.95.) After losing his suitcase en route from Harvard, Jonathan Brand arrives in the Faroe Islands with little more than a thick sweater, a notebook and his romantic ideals. He has planned a yearlong anthropological study of this remote region of the North Atlantic and cheerfully expects a cultural adventure -- a notion that is soon punctured when he settles in a tiny fishing community where everyday life is "composed of hundreds of unpleasant tasks." Overwhelmed by the desolate and rain-swept landscape, suspicious inhabitants and terrible food, Jonathan sinks into sullenness and lethargy. But as the taciturn villagers begin to accept him and teach him their rituals, Jonathan begins to realize that he is the most curious social specimen in the place. Once he shelves sentimentality and sees humanity as something to participate in, not to examine, his initiation into real life begins. "Far Afield" thus comes to the none too remarkable conclusions that the simplest of cultures are often the most complex and that the line between observer and observed is sometimes blurred. Susanna Kaysen, the author of a previous novel, "Asa, as I Knew Him," deserves praise for her confident and polished prose. Her artistry, however, cannot compensate for a drab main character and a dull plot. For an anthropologist, Jonathan has scant curiosity about other peoples or cultures, and through his eyes the alien landscape in which this story is so intrinsically rooted fails to come fully to life. We are left feeling that the novel, like the sea gulls Jonathan sees bobbing over the ocean, travels "long distances to get precisely nowhere."

title: More From the Font
description: To the Editor:

title: Allison Feman Weds John Haltmaier
description: The marriage of Allison Sue Feman to John Philip Haltmaier took place last evening at the Equitable Tower in New York. Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg and the Rev. James Hession, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Sunday at the Dacha With Rooster
description: IF YOU WERE OF A MIND TO APPEND a subtitle to Viktor Slavkin's "Cerceau," it seems to me that "A Little Soviet Night Music" wouldn't be too far off the mark.

title: Who Will Monitor Recycled Ash Blocks?
description: Ask a simple question and you get a simple answer. Robert R. McMillan's essay [ "Environmentalists Are Being Myopic on Ash Problem," Oct. 14 ] on the so-called solid block solution to the bottom-ash problem produced by incinerators does not address the real issues regarding far-thinking opposition to solid blocks.

title: Correction
description: A picture with the New & Noteworthy column on Oct. 28 was printed in error. It showed the novelist Rafael Yglesias, not Thomas Sanchez.

title: Lee Anne Sylva To Wed This Year
description: December wedding plans for Lee Anne Sylva and Anthony Magnier Nugent have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Sylva of New Vernon, N.J. Mr. Nugent is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Nugent of Morristown, N.J.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: SOUNDINGS;
A Psychedelic Hero
description: Roky Erickson is one of the most enduring cult heroes of 60's rock. An acid casualty whose drug misadventures led to a four-year stay at a Texas mental hospital, Mr. Erickson is also a gifted singer-songwriter who, as a member of the Austin-based band 13th Floor Elevators, was instrumental in the creation of psychedelic rock. Singing in the tremulous, incantatory full-moon howl of a teen-age werewolf, he brought a naive, mystic zeal to the Elevators' surging blend of garage-rock spunk and hallucinogenic flash (their trademark was the spooky percolating of an electric jug). Mr. Erickson also wrote the Elevators' 1966 debut, "You're Gonna Miss Me," one of the first Top 40 psychedelic hits.

title: Bulgaria
description: To the Editor: Eight years ago I toured Bulgaria and spent a week on the Black Sea with an English tour group. As Brenda Fowler indicated (Travel, July 22), Bulgaria is a fascinating place for travelers with an interest in Greek, Roman, Byzantine and Slavic history and art. Since most Westerners are sadly uninformed on eastern European history, Frances Dvornik's "Slavs in European History and Civilization" is excellent background reading.

title: The Culture Question
description: Demographics alone make it impossible, if not downright foolish, to ignore the education of minority students in the United States. Soon after the year 2000, black, Hispanic, Asian and American Indian youngsters will constitute a third of the nation's students, on their way to being a powerful presence in the American work force. Leaders in government, education and business agree that the schooling of these students has become a matter of national security. Parents and students acknowledge that schooling has become a grave matter of personal concern. Improving the education of minority students, however, is a delicate issue as entire communities struggle to find methods and approaches that work.

title: For the G.O.P., The Race Is to Win Second Place
description: NORMALLY, when politicians are stuck with a loser at the top of their Election Day ticket, they abandon ship rather than go down with it. The provincial message in such cases is usually something like, we don't care who you want for governor, senator or president, just vote for our local candidates.

title: SENATE RACES POSE HURDLE FOR G.O.P.
description: The 1990 campaign for the Senate enters its final hours with some of the most senior senators battling hard for re-election, with public opinion polls showing intensely competitive races in a half-dozen states and with the potential for last-minute swings in several more.

title: J.A. Kouwenhoven Is Dead at 80; Professor and Author on the Arts
description: John Atlee Kouwenhoven, a former Barnard College English professor and author of many works about American arts and society, died on Saturday at Greenrange, a community-care center in Manchester, Vt. He was 80 years old.

title: She Didn't Hate Herself in the Morning
description: KING'S OAK By Anne Rivers Siddons.623 pp. New York:HarperCollins Publishers. $21.95.

title: Kathleen Keogh to Wed in December
description: A December wedding is planned by Kathleen Byrne Keogh and Geoffrey R. Snelling Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Snelling of Wilmington, Del. The announcement was made by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Keogh of Larchmont, N.Y.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Portland, Me.;
Harbor Condos Go at Auction
description: THIRTY-TWO condominiums and 22 boat slips built during southern Maine's mid-80's real estate boom were auctioned last month for 30 to 40 percent of their original prices.

title: Lauren Hargraves Planning to Marry
description: January wedding plans for Lauren Anne Hargraves and Emmanuel Arguelles have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Julian T. Hargraves of Hopkinton, Mass. Mr. Arguelles is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eulogio Arguelles of Port Monmouth, N.J., and Manila.

title: Judith Abel Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Abel of Riverdale, N.Y., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter, Judith Nancy Abel, and Michael I. Brill, a son of Paula Brill of Hackensack, N.J., and the late Gene S. Brill. Ms. Abel, 28 years old, is an associate editor at the Mill Hollow Corporation, trade publishers in New York. She is a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Brill, 28, is an associate at Lehman Brothers in New York. He graduated from the University of Virginia and received a master's degree in public and private management from Yale University.

title: Streetscapes: The Bleecker Street Cinema; The 'Lost' Frescoes Of an Artist-Soldier
description: THOUSANDS of avant-garde and foreign films were shown at the Bleecker Street Cinema at 144 Bleecker from its opening in 1962 to its closing last August. It is now a gay porno house, but what is surely its most interesting drama -- involving an artist-soldier, the Spanish Civil War, five supposedly lost frescoes and artistic integrity -- is only now about to have its last act.

title: Arlene Markowitz, a Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Arlene Helen Markowitz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Markowitz of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Stephen Paul Rappaport, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Rappaport of Valley Stream, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Arnold Turetsky and David Lincoln at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: Outdoors; a Special Auction of Bird Decoys
description: COLLECTORS of waterfowl decoys who have been specializing in birds of Chesapeake Bay origin will find much to please them at R. W. Oliver's auction on Wednesday and Thursday at the Louis B. Smith armory in Easton, Md.

title: Fashion: On the Street; The Real Story Is Legs
description: Having been to Milan and Paris, the international fashion caravan made its way to New York last week.

title: High Schoolers: TV's 'In' Crowd
description: THIS could easily be called the year of the high school on television. Five new series focusing chiefly on high school students or high school settings were added to the prime-time schedule this fall, joining at least three others that examined high school life.

title: Q and A
description: Panning for Gold

title: Fashion; Good Looks You Can Hang Your Hat On
description: Cover your head. That's what you were always told as a child. But while that caution may have been about warmth alone, style as well and warmth are the watchwords today.

title: A Day of Tension For Young Riders
description: It will still be dark on Sunday morning when Nicole Shahinian and nearly 100 rivals saddle up in the makeshift barns that have been installed in a Meadowlands parking lot for the duration of the National Horse Show. Then, facing a battery of tests to determine the 25 riders who will be asked back to the arena on Sunday afternoon to determine the 1990 Rolex-Maclay national championship, Shahinian will embark on a daylong ordeal that has left her nothing but dejected the last three times she attempted it.

title: A World in Flux Means Steady Work for Risk Analysts
description: JUDGING by the number of crises in the world lately, profits must be soaring in the political-risk business.

title: Medium and Message Blend in 'Language and Art' at Aldrich
description: THE two shows at the Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield are poles apart: one is about words as (or in) art, the other German photography. Yet, in retrospect, the two blur into one spectacle -- chic, chilly and more than a little forbidding.

title: U.S. Cuts Aid to Zaire, Setting Off a Policy Debate
description: Resisting persistent lobbying by the Bush Administration, Congress has cut all military and economic aid to President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, a longtime United States ally in Africa.

title: Elisa Marke Wed to Lawrence Smiley
description: Elisa Hope Marke, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Julius J. Marke of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Lawrence A. Smiley, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Allan Smiley of Manhasset, L.I. Rabbi Abner Bergman performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: College Football: Ivy League; Cornell Sub Sets Record
description: Cornell lost John McNiff, the Ivy League's best runner, on the first play against Yale today when he suffered a bruised knee after returning the kickoff 22 yards. But his backup, Scott Oliaro, scored four touchdowns and broke Ed Marinaro's single-game Ivy League rushing record to lead Cornell to a 41-31 victory.

title: Hers; Mothers With AIDS: A Love Story
description: WHEN MY DAUGHter was 4 months old, I stuck myself with a needle. Fortunately, it was a clean needle. I was starting an IV on a baby, and after several unsuccessful attempts I had finally threaded a tiny plastic catheter into a twisty little hand vein. I reached for a fresh syringe, full of sterile saline, trying to keep the catheter steady, and when I tried to unscrew the needle attached to the new syringe, I handled it clumsily and felt a small but real prick through the rubber glove I was wearing into my thumb.

title: Pamela Bahr Engaged To Marc A. Hambley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry T. Bahr Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter, Pamela Williston Bahr, and Marc Andrew Hambley, the son of Elisabeth de Bourmont Canaday of New York and Clarke C. Hambley of Bronxville.

title: Pro Hockey; Islanders Fail to Follow Up
description: By the time the Islanders decided to play defense tonight, they had already allowed four goals, posing a virtually impossible task for themselves.

title: A Winter Bridal For Susan Hunt
description: Mrs. William E. Hunt of Albany has announced January wedding plans for her daughter Susan Marie Hunt and Sean Campbell McDowell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay H. McDowell of New York.

title: Cold War Lives in Immigration Proposals
description: To the Editor:

title: Upsets Diminish Ranks of Unbeaten
description: One swing of the right leg of Scott Sisson, Georgia Tech's place-kicker, defeated No. 1-ranked Virginia. One fourth-quarter collapse at Lincoln, Neb., pushed Colorado past Nebraska. Add one Auburn nightmare at Gainesville, Fla., against the overpowering Florida Gators and one defeat of Wyoming by Colorado State. The perfect major-college football team suddenly became an endangered species and bowl-game representatives had to be grateful that they had not given up their day jobs.

title: Union of Fighters: The News Drivers
description: The drivers' union, locked in a crucial fight with The Daily News, has a history of strikes, slowdowns, violence and intimidation.

title: Alexa J. Gardner Weds J.G. Lesser
description: Alexa Jane Gardner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Gardner of New York, was married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El to James Gordon Lesser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Lesser of Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: Elderly Woman Dies in an Apartment Fire
description: An elderly woman died and two other women were injured early yesterday morning when a three-alarm fire of suspicious origin swept through their apartment building on the Lower East Side, Fire Department officials said.

title: With Ebullience Gone, Auctioneers Are Sober About the Coming Sales
description: The ebullient mood that characterized art sales throughout the 1980's and as recently as last spring has vanished from the auction rooms at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York. Now auctioneers, art dealers and collectors are taking a sober view of the two-week round of sales of postwar, modern and Impressionist art that begins tomorrow night at Sotheby's.

title: Former Broker Wins Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned the sentence of Walter F. Curran, a former Boston stockbroker who pleaded guilty in 1989 to mail and bank fraud charges in a scheme to bilk his golfing partners and other associates of more than $2.3 million.

title: AIRPORTS PLANNING FOR BIG WINDFALL
description: Airports around the country are laying plans to spend an enormous windfall provided by Congress, which a week ago passed a law to let them charge airline passengers a boarding fee to finance expansion and modernization.

title: Moscow to Get Trading Help
description: The Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the world's biggest commodities exchanges, said last week that they would help to develop a Soviet commodity market.

title: Pentagon Will Call Up Combat Reserve Units
description: The Defense Department has decided to call up major combat units from the reserves totaling thousands of troops to join the force in the Persian Gulf in the next few months, Administration officials said.

title: The Wages of Fear
description: Fifteen years ago this week the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution declaring that "Zionism is a form of racism." It was a propaganda victory for the Arab states, won with the help of the Soviet bloc and many third world countries.

title: Review/Theater; Getting to Like Some Havana Fugitives
description: Not exile, poverty, loneliness or age, not even death can defeat the indomitable women of Luis Santeiro's new comedy, "The Lady From Havana," at the Intar Theater.

title: Metro Matters; Looking Beyond Cuomo's 3d Term Via Rockefeller's
description: The last Governor of New York to seek a third term got it, which is one of few similarities between this year's campaign and the one nearly a quarter century ago.

title: Eurotunnel Share Offer
description: Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium that is digging a rail tunnel beneath the English Channel, said Friday that it hoped to raise $:532 million, or about $1.04 billion, through the sale of new shares to existing shareholders.

title: Japan Loans To China
description: Japan announced Friday that it was resuming a development loan program for China that has been frozen since the brutal suppression of pro-democracy protests in Beijing last year.

title: Yisrael Levy, 64, Dies; Zionist Fighter in 40's
description: Yisrael Levy, an underground fighter in Israel's struggle for independence who carried out the 1946 bombing of the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, in which 91 people were killed, has died. He was 64 years old.

title: HEROISM HONORED BY CARNEGIE FUND
description: A foreman who saved a co-worker from grinding machinery at a Massachusetts gravel plant and two Canadian women who confronted a knife-wielding intruder after he slashed their elderly neighbor are among 18 people who have been recognized by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.

title: New $5 Million Account To McElligott Wright
description: McElligott Wright Morrison White, an agency so new that the paint has barely dried on its Minneapolis office door, picked up its first big piece of business, a cellular-communications product that bills $5 million, increasing the agency's billings to about $10 million.

title: In Fiery, Debate, Low-Key Cuomo Let His 3 Opponents Slug It Out
description: In one of the most raucous debates in many years, three opponents of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- all Republicans -- spent as much or more time attacking each other as they did the Democratic incumbent and heavy favorite in tomorrow's election.

title:
ON YOUR OWN: THE MARATHON;
Aching Feet and Muscles Get Immediate Attention
description: SOME came under their own power, others needed help. Some could joke about their situations, while for others, it was anything but a laughing matter.

title: People
description: * Anne Adriance and Marty Gertler have been promoted to management directors and appointed to the operating committee of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York. * Martyn L. W. Straw has joined Geer, DuBois Inc., New York, as executive vice president and director of strategic services.

title: Low New York Voter Turnout Seen
description: Dominick F. Vasaturo is a Manhattan Democrat who likes Gov. Mario M. Cuomo but sees little reason to vote on Tuesday because he believes the Governor will coast to re-election.

title: Please, Not Another Failed Presidency
description: A political observer who suggested any similarity at all three months ago between the Presidencies of George Bush and Jimmy Carter would have been referred somewhere for examination -- but that was then.

title: Lisa Anne Eckstrom Is Married To Gideon Avram Rosen in Virginia
description: Lisa Anne Eckstrom, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton V. Eckstrom of Newport News, Va., was married there yesterday to Gideon Avram Rosen, a son of the late Dr. Ora M. Rosen and the late Dr. Samuel M. Rosen of New York. A ceremony at Trinity Lutheran Church, conducted by the Rev. Jesse Hangen, was followed by another at Temple Sinai at which Rabbi Mark Golub officiated.

title: 3 U.S. Sailors Injured in a Bombing in Chile
description: A bomb exploded at a German restaurant in this seaside resort, wounding three sailors from the United States aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln and five other people, the police and the United States Navy said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The economic slump may be deeper and last longer than previous recessions, some economists and bankers warn. Banking and real estate troubles will work against a recovery. [ Page D1. ]

title: 49ers Unbeaten, Not Unbelievable
description: NOT far from a homemade banner that announced, "Move Over Rice, We Have Something Sharper," the wide receiver Sterling Sharpe soared and stretched to snatch a 20-yard touchdown pass from Don Majkowski. With only 71 seconds remaining in the first half yesterday, the Green Bay Packers suddenly had a stunning 10-0 lead on the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Sharon Heller Is Married
description: Sharon Heller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Heller of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Mitchell Harris Chosak, the son of Doris C. Farber of Scottsdale, Ariz., and the late Philip P. Chosak. Rabbi David Bergstein officiated at the Lou G. Siegel restaurant in New York.

title: Washington Talk; When Second Thoughts In Case Come Too Late
description: The most interesting opinion to come from the Supreme Court since the new term began last month may well be the comments of a retired Justice, Lewis F. Powell Jr., on his second thoughts about a 1986 decision.

title: Yemenis Fear High Cost of Gulf Crisis
description: The grumbling began over qat. The tales of economic woe stemming from the Persian Gulf crisis raced through the capital as Yemenis gathered each afternoon to chew qat, the mildly narcotic leaf that is Yemen's major cash crop and whose consumption is this country's most firmly entrenched social tradition.

title: P. N. Fahn Wed To Ms. Sherman
description: Meredith Sherman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan M. Sherman of Bridgeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Neil Fahn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Fahn of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Edward Schecter performed the ceremony at the Faculty House at Columbia University.

title: Our Universal Civilization
description: I never formulated the idea of the universal civilization until 11 years ago, when I traveled for many months in a number of non-Arab Muslim countries -- Iran, Indonesia, Malaysia and Pakistan -- to try to understand what had driven them to their rage. That Muslim rage was just beginning to be apparent.

title: We Can't Ask Africa To See Sex as We Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * Ketchum International Inc., New York, acquired an interest in CIA, a Paris-based advertising agency with billings of about $25 million. The agency, which will be known as CIA Ketchum, will be headed by Gerard Commerot.

title: For a Night of Comedies, CBS Challenges NBC
description: It is a night of television with four straight comedies, anchored at 9 by a classy, Emmy-winning hit and finished off at 10 with a drama about the trials and lives of lawyers.

title: Refinancing Move at Saks
description: Investcorp International Inc., the owner of the Saks Fifth Avenue chain, is seeking to raise $500 million by selling or refinancing the retail company's real estate holdings, Crain's New York Business reported in this week's issue.

title: News Drivers: A Tainted, Tenacious Union
description: It was born as a union of horse-and-buggy newspaper deliverymen at the turn of the century, a stepchild of the fledgling labor movement and New York's yellow journalism wars. Its story is not a sentimental tract on human rights, but an often unsavory tale of rough, insular workers struggling for their own interests.

title: Guns Offer New York Teen-Agers A Commonplace, Deadly Allure
description: On the corner of Utica and Sterling in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, in the light of a bright fall afternoon, Trent D. met a man who helped him through a neighborhood rite. The man gave Trent his first gun.

title: More of Less From Local TV Stations
description: Texans seeking information about the elections Tuesday need look no farther than WFAA-Channel 8, the ABC affiliate here. The station has run uncompromising critiques of political advertising by a local professor, sent reporters as far as Mississippi to explore issues important to Texas and lured each candidate for governor to submit to a detailed, half-hour interrogation by a panel of reporters.

title: Fedders Chief Finds Use For Spinoff's Nest Egg
description: Salvatore Giordano Jr., vice chairman and chief executive of the Fedders Corporation, the well-known maker of room air-conditioners, also heads another company. Known as Nycor Inc., it does not make anything.

title: Golf Ball Specialist
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Economists Warn of Paralysis
description: A group of free-market economists, including two of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's top advisers, warned today that the Soviet leader's compromise economic program was pointing the country toward hyperinflation and political paralysis.

title: Mary Martin, 76, First Lady of Musicals, Dies
description: Mary Martin, America's favorite leading lady of musical comedy, as Ens. Nellie Forbush in "South Pacific," Maria von Trapp in "The Sound of Music" or the title role in "Peter Pan," died Saturday afternoon at her home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. She was 76 years old.

title: Frederick Cummings, 57, Dealer, Art Historian and Museum Chief
description: Frederick J. Cummings, an art historian, an art dealer and a former director of the Detroit Institute of Arts, died on Friday in Isleboro, Me. He was 57 years old and lived in New York City and Isleboro.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Corestates Financial Corp., Philadelphia, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $800 million in senior and subordinated debt to be issued from time to time by its Corestates Capital Corp. unit. * CSX Corp., Richmond, is offering $200 million in 9 1/2 percent notes, due in 1995, at 99.88 to yield 9.53 percent through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes are noncallable and rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Number of Ballot Initiatives Is the Greatest Since 1932
description: Frustrated with the pace of representative democracy, voters across the country have put at least 67 proposals on statewide ballots for Tuesday's elections, the largest number in more than five decades.

title: Support On Street Is Very Generous
description: Maybe it was Samuel Robinson, a 37-year-old homeless man, who best summed up the spectator appeal of yesterday's marathon. He watched it in Harlem, in front of the Handmaids of Mary Convent at 15 West 124th Street, standing in a soup-kitchen line with dozens of people clapping and screaming at the runners, "Pump it up, man!" and "You can do it!"

title: Several Issues in This Week's U.S. Sales
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week consists of a record supply of Government securities for sale, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. And for the remainder of the week the Treasury will be busy with its quarterly refunding, consisting of three- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.

title: GOVERNORS' RACES, CLOSE AND COSTLY, ARE RICHEST PRIZE
description: From New England to California, the fiercest battles of this 1990 election are being fought for governor, as voters pick the men, and perhaps women, who will shape policy on items as diverse as taxes and the political districts that House members will serve for the next decade.

title: How to Make U.N. Ready for the 21st Century; Add to Security Council
description: To the Editor: In "Bonn and Tokyo as Global Police" (editorial, Oct. 22), you say of Japan and Germany that "it's hard to imagine future collective security and peacekeeping operations without them," and "when will Bonn and Tokyo start carrying their fair share?"

title: Skeleton in Car Solves 32-Year-Old Mystery
description: The mystery of a woman who disappeared 32 years ago seems to be solved with the discovery of bones inside a Ford sedan hauled from the bottom of Lake Lanier, officials said Saturday.

title: A Great Race for the Idle
description: A REMARKABLE experience it must be to run a whole marathon, and the throngs of spectators (some race officials said there might have been a million of them, or 2 million or even more) who stood, sat, kneeled, leaned and reclined along the 26-mile-385-yard route through the five boroughs and observed the runners running yesterday must surely have thought so. As long as it was somebody else doing the running.

title: Racial Politics in South's Contests: Hot Wind of Hate or a Last Gasp?
description: Like a virus that defies eradication, the politics of race is back in full view in Southern election campaigns.

title: INSIDE
description: Protest Reaches Albania Anti-Communist protests have been rising in Albania in a pattern that recalls the events that led to the collapse of Communism elsewhere in Eastern Europe last year. Page A8. Fear Stalks Haiti Campaign With two sworn enemies competing for votes in the presidential race, Haiti is bracing for the possibility of new political violence. Page A3. More Economic Gloom The slump could be deeper and longer than recent downturns because of the fragile shape of banks and the real estate market, experts say. Page D1.

title: CUNY Students Have a Role in the Quality of Their Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Bus Collision Sidelines 5
description: Florence Roudolff was asleep, presumably dreaming of marathon glory, her head nestled against the window of a bus taking her to the strating line when she was awakened by what she later described as "the crush," a severe jolt that shattered her own marathon dreams and those of four other high-ranked runners, all of whom were knocked out of the marathon by a freakish accident.

title: Question Box
description: Post-Season Slump Q. An answer two weeks ago established the Philadelphia Phillies as the major league team that lost the most post-season games in a row, 11. But the Phillies ended that streak in 1977. Which team currently has the longest losing streak in post-season play?

title: Where Schoolchildren Died, Dissension Over a Memorial
description: Almost a year after a tornado blew in the wall of an elementary school here, killing nine youngsters and injuring 17 as they ate in the cafeteria, parents are divided by an emotional dispute over how best to remember those who died.

title: In Fund-Raising Race, Incumbents Are Ahead
description: Once the Democrats' great hope to capture the First District House seat here, Rebecca Vigil-Giron is unintentionally waging something of an invisible race: Her campaign has no photocopier, no fax machine, no television commercials and, until a few weeks ago, not even a campaign manager.

title: Atlantic City for Holyfield
description: Evander Holyfield's first heavyweight title defense, against George Foreman, is headed for the Convention Center in Atlantic City.

title: Alec Ellison Wed To Tamar Sadeh
description: Tamar Sadeh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dov I. Sadeh of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Alec Lindsay Ellison, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Haskell S. Ellison of Charleston, S.C. Rabbi Alex J. Goldman and Rabbi David J. Radinsky officiated at Temple Beth El.

title: A Small Giant Proves to Be Giant at Heart
description: WHEN Dave Meggett was 9 years old and started playing Pop Warner football, he quickly became the quarterback. Not because he could pass the ball -- his hands were so small he could hardly grip it -- but at least he could hand it off to others who could run better.

title: Budget Gap: Few Layoffs Are Expected
description: As the Dinkins administration worked yesterday to finish its proposals for keeping New York City's budget balanced, officials said they planned to trim services and lay off a small number of city workers this year, but are still struggling to squeeze the bureaucracy to avoid deeper cuts.

title: Cuts in Rates Called Vital For Economy
description: Credit market analysts say the Federal Reserve will need to be much more aggressive in lowering short-term interest rates to help prevent what looks like the start of a mild recession from turning into a much steeper, more prolonged downturn.

title: Lifelong 'Cheerleader' For McDonald's Way
description: Edward H. Rensi, the McDonald's executive who was a leader in the fast-food company's decision to switch from plastic foam packaging to paper, is a lifelong "cheerleader" for the McDonald's way.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Car Sales - Oct. Tuesday U.S. Productivity - 3rd Quarter Wednesday Consumer Credit - Sept. Thursday None Friday Producer Prices - Oct.

title: Chronicle
description: From 1951 to 1981, Dr. MARTIN CHERKASKY served as director of the Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx, guiding the institution from a regional hospital to a large medical complex and teaching center. A group of anonymous people , described only as friends and admirers of the 79-year old physician, have established a $1 million endowed chair, the first for the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University. The chair will be in the expanding area of health policy and management.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Waitz Is Satisfied With Performance
description: She had won the the New York City Marathon all nine times she had finished. But yesterday, for 37-year-old Grete Waitz, just finishing was enough.

title: Perrier Reports Jump in Profits
description: The bottler of Perrier mineral water reported last week that its profits more than doubled in the first half of 1990 despite a worldwide recall after dangerous chemicals turned up in some bottles of the water.

title: Officer Called to Dispute Kills Woman in Bronx
description: An officer shot and killed a woman inside her Bronx apartment Saturday night, after she went after him with his nightstick, which had fallen to the floor in a struggle, the police said.

title: 3 Frenchmen Freed by Iraq Go Home to a Cloudy Future
description: Three French soldiers who were captured by Iraq last week had a homecoming here today, but not a hero's welcome.

title: STATES CRITICIZED ON MEDICAL GOALS
description: The Federal Government says state health departments have been slow to adopt a two-year-old set of proposals for improving public medical care, even though they have embraced the recommendations in principle.

title: Object: Survival
description: In August of 1989, a terrifying explosion ripped apart the Al Qaqaa munitions plant in Iraq. Sound waves carried the fact of the non-nuclear disaster for hundreds of miles, but news of what had happened remained Saddam Hussein's most closely guarded secret.

title: Europe's Ban on U.S. Meat Is Threatening Trade Talks
description: A European ban on practically all imports of American meat has angered United States officials, brought threats of reprisal and caused a general scratching of heads here.

title: Head Injury Claims Too Many Young Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: India's Leader Faces Threat Of Ouster Over Temple Issue
description: Less than 12 months after taking office, Prime Minister V. P. Singh faces the most critical week of his political career, and the possibility that he will be out of a job and back on the campaign trail in a matter of days.

title: Business Scene; Chemical Industry Faces Oversupply
description: CHEMICAL manufacturers illustrate a troublesome shortcoming of free markets. For three years, they have been expanding operations, even as they worried that their new plants would produce much more than anyone wanted to buy. And, as these plants come on line, their fears are coming true. Chemicals used in the manufacture of hundreds of household items are once again in oversupply.

title: New Haven Paper's Chief
description: William J. Rush, the publisher and editor in chief of The Morning Journal in Lorain, Ohio, was named chief executive of The New Haven Register last week.

title: Publisher Blames Union Rift in Strike
description: The publisher of The Daily News asserted yesterday that the 12-day-old strike at the paper was precipitated by a dispute within the drivers' union and efforts by an "out-of-power faction" to undermine the union leadership.

title: Foreign Flavor for Publishing Leadership
description: Whatever else the 1990's bring for book publishing, they are already shaping up as the decade of the foreign-born executive. The appointment last week of Harold Evans, a native of Britain, as president and publisher of Random House is only the latest example.

title: Chiefs Tough It Out Over the Raiders, 9-7
description: The Raiders and the Chiefs were greeted today at Arrowhead Stadium by 37-degree temperatures, swirling winds of 14 to 23 miles per hour and a drizzling rain that turned to sleet. The rain and sleet finally subsided but not the cold. Neither did the fierce tackling and the dominating defenses that have long been a part of this rugged series.

title: Panfil Starts Fast, Holds Off Challenge
description: Wanda Panfil, the woman an ailing Grete Waitz said she had to beat to win the New York City Marathon for an unprecedented 10th time, proved the nine-time champion an accurate prophet of her own doom yesterday by doing just what Waitz had fearfully predicted: She started out strong in Staten Island, pulled away from the pack in Brooklyn and never looked back until she crossed the finish line in Central Park, five seconds ahead of her nearest challenger.

title: Warning on Phone Tactic
description: The Federal Communications Commission warned consumers last week that sales representatives for long-distance telephone companies may be switching customers' long-distance carriers without their authorization, an illegal practice known as slamming.

title: Chronicle
description: One of Wall Street's major law firms, long a supporter of the Legal Aid Society's efforts on behalf of the poor, added to that relationship yesterday with a $500,000 gift. NED B. STILES, the managing partner of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, said that the gift would establish the MELVIN C. STEEN Fellowship Fund in honor of the 83-year old founding partner of the firm.

title: Few Buffers To a Slump Are Seen
description: The nation's economic slump could be deeper and last longer than previous recessions, some bankers and economists are warning, because many of the conditions that normally soften a recession or lead to a recovery will be lacking this time.

title: Networks in Tight Race, With All 3 Losing
description: As the fall television campaign enters its third month, the three major networks are marching in unison, like the fabled Revolutionary fife and drum unit -- bloodied, bandaged and limping.

title: Man Is Facing Charges As a Bogus Ballplayer
description: A Southington man who has been accused of posing as a major-league ballplayer and leaving a trail of jilted women and unpaid bills across Connecticut and around the country has been arrested by the police here.

title: Dressing Up, Dressing Cool
description: IT was two hours before the start of the 21st New York City Marathon, and 29-year-old Diane Ward of Mount Kisco, N.Y., knew she would be taking a big risk. "I know it's against the rules, but I'm running in a new outfit," she said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Seles Tops Navratilova: Monica Seles defeated top-seeded Martina Navratilova, 6-3, 7-6, last night to win the Virginia Slims of California in Oakland. The 16-year-old Seles, who was seeded second, won for the third straight time over Navratilova, using blistering groundstrokes. "I think if there had been any paint on the lines the balls would have turned white," Navratilova said. "I was always playing catch-up. She hits the ball so hard, once you're on the defensive, you're dead."(AP) ROWING West German Eight Wins: The defending champion, West Germany, in its last event before a complete merger with former East German teams, held off a strong challenge from Canada yesterday to win the men's eights title at the world rowing championships on Lake Barrington, Australia. The winners covered the 2,000 meters in 5 minutes 26.62 seconds. The Canadians finished second in 5:27.57 and East Germany was third in 5:29.88. Carmine and Giuseppe Abbagnale, Italian brothers who are two-time Olympic champions, won the men's pair-with-coxswain title for the sixth time. An East German, Birgit Peter, overhauled Silken Laumann of Canada with 250 meters remaining to win the women's single sculls title. The Romanian women's eight won the gold medal in 5:59.26 with the United States second and East Germany third. East Germany earned its fifth gold medal of the championships when its women's quadruple sculls won that final. (AP) GOLF Massey First After Rainout: Debbie Massey was declared the winner of the L.P.G.A. Mazda Classic in Hanno, Japan, yesterday after rain forced cancellation of the final round of the tour's final event of the year. Massey, who shot a course record-tying 64 on Saturday to take a three-shot lead over Danielle Ammaccapane and Caroline Keggi, finished the tournament at 11-under-par 133 at the 6,376-yard, par-72 Musashigaoka Club course, outside Tokyo. In winning her first tour event since the 1979 Wheeling Classic, Massey earned $82,500 to push her career earnings to $1,004,280. Ammaccapane and Keggi shared second place at 136. Betsy King, the 1989 champion, Elaine Crosby, and Cathy Gerring were tied for fourth place at 137. By finishing tied for fourth, King became the third player on the L.P.G.A. tour to exceed $3 million in career earnings with $3,013,537. The others are Pat Bradley and Nancy Lopez. (AP) Hill Edges Player: Mike Hill had a final-round eight-under-par 63 yesterday as he came from four strokes behind to beat Gary Player by one stroke in the Senior Classic in Los Angeles. Hill finished at 201, 10-under par on the 6,307-yard 71 Rancho Park course. Player was the first round co-leader and the sole leader entering the final round. (AP) Horse Racing Santos Takes Finale: Jose Santos made his last ride as a regular New York jockey a winning one yesterday, guiding Sports View to a hard-fought victory in the 46th running of the $88,050 Discovery Handicap, a Grade III stake for 3-year-olds, at Aqueduct. The 29-year-old Santos was to leave last night to continue his riding career on the Southern California circuit, and was scheduled to ride at Santa Anita today. Sports View passed Chief Honcho, the 8-5 favorite and highweight at 117 pounds, in the final strides to win by a nose. Killer Diller and Out of Place were 2 1/2 lengths back in a dead heat for third. The winner, a Cox's Ridge colt out of the Tom Rolfe mare Trestle trained by D. Wayne Lukas, ran the nine furlongs in 1:48.74 and earned $52,830 for his owner, Edward A. Cox Jr. Sports View carried 113 pounds and paid $10.20 for $2 to win. SOCCER Big East Title to Boston College: Justin Ceccarelli scored both goals to lead the Boston College Eagles to a 2-1 overtime victory over Seton Hall in the Big East championship game in Storrs, Conn. Boston College improved to 14-4-2 and received an automatic bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association A.A. tournament. It was the school's first Big East title. Seton Hall fell to 11-7-2. AUTO RACING Earnhardt Moves Ahead: Dale Earnhardt overwhelmed the field in the Checker 500 Nascar stock-car race in Phoenix yesterday, winning his ninth race of the season and vaulting past Mark Martin in the $1 million Winston Cup championship battle with only one race remaining. Earnhardt leads Martin by 4,260 points to 4,254. The championship will be decided on Nov. 18 in the Atlanta Journal 500 at Atlanta International Raceway. (AP)

title: A Modest Proposal
description: The fact that I can't find any place to relieve myself in New York causes me lots of problems and pain. I have never been able to find bathrooms in the subways. They are always locked and unavailable. The bathrooms in the parks . . . are in terrible condition and dangerous. -- Homeless plaintiff Luther (Boo) Riley.

title: The 1990 CAMPAIGN; Whoever Wins, Weicker Race Means Change in Connecticut
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s bid to become Connecticut's first independent governor since the Civil War has fused the anti-incumbent rage that appears in many states with the purely local appeal of a curmudgeon-like politician who seems to have been enraged for years.

title: Wakiihuri and Panfil Win Marathon
description: On an unseasonably warm day, perfect for almost anything but a marathon, Douglas Wakiihuri of Kenya and Wanda Panfil of Poland showed only minor discomfort, breaking away from their strongest challengers long before the finish line in Central Park to win the 21st New York City Marathon.

title: Small Bag of Cocaine Found In a Hangar at Space Center
description: The space agency is trying to determine who is responsible for a small bag of cocaine discovered in a hangar where space shuttles are prepared for launching.

title: Market Will Be Well Stocked
description: The way the free-agent market is shaping up, if baseball teams don't like what they see in the first group, they can wait for the second wave to hit.

title: Drug Case Links Sicilian Mafia to Medellin Ring
description: By the extravagant standards of South Florida's cocaine culture, John Galotolo seemed like just another entrepreneur with a black Mercedes, a diamond ring and a small horse farm in rural Dade County. But Federal investigators and court records say the Sicilian-born pizzeria operator has emerged as a far more significant figure.

title: For Skilled Foreigners, Lower Hurdles to U.S.
description: Responding to warnings that the United States is running short of skilled professionals, a new immigration measure is about to open the nation's doors to people like Kap Pyo Kwon, master of a rare and specialized computer art that is vital to the airline and banking industries.

title: Taxes in Limelight on Eve Of Elections in New Jersey
description: Candidates for the United States Senate crisscrossed the state today as politicians here wondered how, if at all, the public would express its rage over taxes and uneasiness about the future.

title: Reviews/Music; First Folk Masters Concert, With Radio Format
description: Form and content made an uneasy truce at the first Folk Masters concert on Saturday night at Weill Recital Hall. The series, which continues through Dec. 15, is to bring leading folk performers to a major concert hall and is produced by Carnegie Hall itself; it is being taped for broadcast in the spring on American Public Radio. The concert was produced as if radio listeners could not handle segments longer than those in "A Prairie Home Companion," and on Saturday the radio format, with interviews during each set, intruded on the music.

title: Bush's Plea Falls on Wrong Ears
description: President Bush -- shunned by Republican candidates in Illinois, Oregon and other states -- ended up spending most of his weekend in Texas, making appearances with Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for Governor.

title: Governorship Would Give Silber a Bigger Voice
description: If John R. Silber can hold off a late surge by his Republican rival, William F. Weld, on Tuesday, he stands to win not only the governorship of Massachusetts but also a prominent role in national Democratic politics for himself and his unorthodox views on domestic problems.

title: Bainbridge Island Journal; Ready to Burn Bridges To Govern Themselves
description: To the people who live on Bainbridge Island, Puget Sound is more than a place to go fishing. It's a moat.

title: Editorial Notebook; Why So Hard on Rabbit?
description: Harry Angstrom is dead after three decades as the fidgety, flinching hero of John Updike's Rabbit novels. We met Harry in "Rabbit Run," in 1960, a beautiful, brainless guy in his 20's, mourning the loss of high school basketball stardom, already experiencing that loss as the hand of death itself.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 5: 1990: MONDAY Baldor Elec Lockheed Corp Jefferson Pilot Corp TUESDAY Cincinnati Milacron Goodyear Tire & Rubr Cooper Inds Kansas City Pwr & Lt Delta Woodside Inds Liberty Corp S.C. Diamond Shamrock Monarch Mach Tool Emerson Elec Source Cap General Housewares Xtra Corp WEDNESDAY Carlisle Cos Phelps Dodge Hanna M.A. Premark Intl IE Inds Thomas & Betts Corp Northwestern Pub Svc USF&G Corp Outboard Marine Utilicorp UTO THURSDAY Adams Express Humana Inc Alexander & Alexander Lincoln Natl Corp Allegheny Ludlum Mattel Inc Cooper Tire & Rubr Petroleum & Res Dow Chem Van Dorn First Miss Webb Del FRIDAY Cabot Corp Eastman Kodak Deluxe Corp Sysco Corp

title: More Politics
description: When all is done, money still decides many races. Page B10.

title: Taylor Selling van Gogh
description: Elizabeth Taylor is selling Vincent van Gogh's "View of the Asylum and Chapel at St. Remy " from 1889 on Dec. 3 in London, Christie's reports. The subdued autumn landscape, painted in shades of green, violet, blue and yellow, is the only study by the artist of the building where he stayed from May 1889 to May 1890, two months before he committed suicide.

title: Hill, Holliday Is Poised For Success in New York
description: ONE of the hardest things for an agency outside New York is to establish a successful office on Madison Avenue.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., Zurich, an environmental and industrial production unit of Asea A.B., Stockholm, appointed Craig S. Tedmon Jr. executive vice president of research and development. * Barnett Banks Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., named Allen L. Lastinger Jr. president and chief operating officer, replacing Albert D. Ernest Jr., who is retiring. * Canonie Environmental Services Corp., Porter, Ind., providers of remediation services for contaminated sites, appointed Curtis J. Jones vice president in charge of marketing operations. * Club Med Sales Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Club Mediterranee Paris, named Michael Kubin president, succeeding Jacques Ganin, who is retiring. * Del Monte Foods, San Francisco, appointed Susan S. Clark vice president of business development. * Gentner Electronics Corp., Salt Lake City, named William V. Trowbridge president, replacing Russell D. Gentner, who will continue as chairman and chief executive. * Integon Corp., Winston-Salem, N.C., an insurance and real estate company, appointed Walter B. Colvin senior vice president of administration and Mark W. Shartle senior vice president and chief financial officer. * Minorco U.S.A. Inc., Denver, a mining unit of Minorco S.A., Luxembourg, named Gerard E. Munera chief executive. * Software Toolworks Inc., Novato, Calif., a software distributor, appointed Robert Lloyd president and chief operating officer, succeeding Elizabeth Barker. * Synergen Inc., Boulder, Colo., a biotechnology company, named Gregory B. Abbott and Dr. Robert C. Thompson executive vice presidents.

title: Jets Beat Their Demons and the Cowboys
description: In a way it's almost a shame that the Jets can claim only one victory out of their 24-9 triumph today over the Dallas Cowboys. They overcame a lot of the demons that have plagued them all year in a contest that was full of milestones, firsts and career highlights, including a record-tying punt return.

title: Five Are Arrested In Halloween Attack On Homeless Men
description: Three men and two boys were arrested yesterday and charged in the Halloween rampage on Wards Island in which one homeless man was killed and nine were injured, the police said.

title: Chronicle
description: On a six-acre site surrounding Yad Vashem, the central memorial to the Holocaust in Jerusalem, are rough-hewn blocks of stone that, seen from the air, form an outline of a map of Europe. On the blocks are being engraved the names of more than 5,000 European Jewish communities destroyed by the Nazis.

title: Kirsten Aasen Is Married
description: Kirsten Kay Aasen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carson M. Aasen of Billings, Mont., was married yesterday in Oxon Hill, Md., to Steven Andrew Wolfe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Wolfe of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y. Rabbi William D. Rudolph officiated at the Oxon Hill Manor. The bride, 26 years old and a graduate of William Paterson College with a law degree from Georgetown University, is the law clerk to Magistrate Patrick J. Attridge of the Federal District Court in Washington. The bridegroom, 30, is a national securities affairs analyst. He graduated from Harvard University and has a master's in international affairs from Columbia University.

title: Ms. Plessner Wed To J. H. Fishman
description: Renee Marga-Ann Plessner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Plessner of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Harris Fishman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Fishman of Davie, Fla. Rabbi Jack Bemporad performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Onetime King Has a Vision For Rwanda
description: For 30 years, King Kigeri V, the former ruler of Rwanda, has been waiting to go back to his small nation in the center of Africa. So have hundreds of thousands of his countrymen, scattered over nearby countries.

title: Even Newer Spurs Doing Fine
description: The San Antonio Spurs, with nine new players, enjoyed the greatest single-season turnaround in National Basketball Association history last season. Their 56 victories, 35 more than the season before, and the Midwest Division title earned Bob Bass the executive-of-the-year honors.

title: Penelope Perryman and Richard Nalbone Marry
description: Penelope Bowne Perryman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Firth Perryman of Webster, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard John Nalbone, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John E. Nalbone of Brentwood, L.I. Justice Kenneth K. Rohl of State Supreme Court officiated in his chambers in Babylon, L.I.

title: Jennifer Adelson Weds R. D. Mitty
description: Jennifer Rachel Adelson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Adelson of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Roger Daniel Mitty, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold A. Mitty of New York. Rabbi Robert Miller performed the ceremony at the Ritz Carlton in Boston.

title: Kenan Erim, Leading Excavator Of Marble Roman City, Dies at 61
description: Dr. Kenan T. Erim, a noted archeologist and professor of classics at New York University, who for 30 years led excavations of the ancient Roman city of Aphrodisias in southwestern Turkey, died on Friday while visiting the British Embassy in Ankara. He was 61 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Elite Magazines Compete for a Place at Home
description: Home is where the heart is, to be sure. But home may also be where the money is these days, as Americans put away their dancing shoes and come back home again.

title: Woman Dies In Marine Run
description: A 19-year-old Boston University student collapsed today at the 20-mile mark of the United States Marines Corps Marathon and died, race officials said.

title: Review/Theater; In a Rock Star's Story, the Music Is the Thing
description: "Let's rock and roll!" is the inevitable battle cry of the sainted hero of "Buddy: The Buddy Holly Story." And who would go anywhere near the new musical at the Shubert for any reason other than rock-and-roll? The nostalgia-seeking audience at "Buddy" knows what it wants -- golden oldies pounded out the way they used to be -- and the people who have concocted this entertainment know how to give it to them. In its final 40 minutes or so, "Buddy" unveils a torrential simulation of a hard-driving yet senior-prom-sweet rock concert of the 1950's in which Buddy (Paul Hipp), the Big Bopper (David Mucci), Ritchie Valens (Philip Anthony), a hyperkinetic band and a fervent choir of backup singers turn back the clock by blasting out "Chantilly Lace," "Maybe Baby," "Peggy Sue Got Married," "La Bamba" and more.

title: Baker Visits the Troops and Finds Them Impatient
description: American troops stationed in the Saudi Arabian desert told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that while they were more than ready to fight Iraq, they wanted to get it over with and return home.

title: Books of The Times; How Ronald Reagan Overcame Doubts and Became President
description: An American Life The Autobiography By Ronald Reagan Illustrated. 748 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Number of Parolees Rose by 12% In 1989, Justice Department Says
description: The number of convicts paroled from prison increased by 12.1 percent in 1989, reflecting a similar growth in the number of people put behind bars, the Justice Department said in a study made public today.

title: Motivate, Don't Isolate, Black Students
description: What are public schools to do with young urban black males, who, as students, are often troubled and unsuccessful? Milwaukee is creating two special schools for black males. New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez considered the same idea -- and has wisely rejected it.

title: DAMASCUS SEEMS TO TOUGHEN STAND TOWARD BAGHDAD
description: Syria appeared today to be adopting a more belligerent attitude toward Iraq, affirming that its support remains strong for the United States-led alliance in the Persian Gulf.

title: Edberg Wins by Default
description: Stefan Edberg won the Paris Open by default today when Boris Becker's left thigh gave out with the score at 3-3 in the first set.

title: A Duvalier Ally and a Foe Seek Election in Haiti, Raising Fears of Violence
description: With the entry into a crowded field of presidential candidates of two sworn enemies representing opposite poles of their country's political spectrum, many Haitians are bracing for the prospect that their confrontation will degenerate into a new wave of politically inspired violence.

title: Review/Dance; On Rising Above Adversity And Then Tasting Its Fruits
description: The Salon Project got off to a rather dryly cerebral start on Thursday at the Dia Center for the Arts (155 Mercer Street), where the three-program series runs through Nov. 16. Devoted to providing rehearsal space and informal but professional performances to choreographers selected by Susan Osberg and Joan Duddy, curators for the event, the series also got off to a difficult start, though professionalism triumphed, when a dancer in one piece and the choreographer-performer of another were unable to appear at the last moment because of illness.

title: Audit Says Forest Mishandling Costs U.S. Millions
description: The office of the Interior Department's inspector general says that Federal mismanagement of some of the world's most productive timberland -- 2.4 million acres across 18 western Oregon counties -- has cost the Government at least $90 million since 1986.

title: Reviews/Music; Thinking of Immortality in a 2-Symphony Evening
description: One of the pitfalls of criticism of contemporary music -- or one of the excitements, if you prefer -- is the way judgments shift like quicksand. At any given moment, some composers command attention and others languish in obscurity. But posterity may have a very different view of today than we do. The consensus of the future may prize composers barely heard of today in our bustling musical capitals, while our hotly debated new music stars may have faded into footnotes.

title: Bills Crush Browns To Win 6th in Row
description: Thurman Thomas scored three touchdowns and Buffalo's defense overwhelmed Mike Pagel in his first start in two years as the Bills beat the Cleveland Browns, 42-0, today for their sixth consecutive victory.

title: Israel Is Spurning U.N. Report's Call For a Geneva Convention Meeting
description: Israel today spurned a United Nations report suggesting that nations that have signed the Geneva Convention meet to discuss protection for Palestinians in the occupied territories, calling it a "dangerous politicization" of the international pact.

title: The Painful Reckoning for Australia's Economy
description: This is a nation famed for its entrepreneurial titans, larger-than-life empire builders like Rupert Murdoch and Alan Bond, and the Government is now turning to its entrepreneurs for help in bailing out faltering state companies and banks.

title: Bridge
description: A modern trend among those who like to live dangerously is the either-or bid. It announces possession of one of two types of hand, but the two types are diametrically opposite. A popular defense to the strong-club opening provides a bid to show two suits of the same color, or two of the same rank, or two of the same shape -- clubs and hearts, or diamonds and spades.

title: Sao Paulo Journal; The Pollution Is Horror Enough. Now Alligators.
description: It could be the script for a Grade B movie -- "Reptile Revenge of the Rain Forest." Wild alligators rise from the polluted waters of Brazil's coastal cities and terrorize boaters, joggers and children's birthday parties.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Morrison is much too liberal, Rowland is much too conservative and Weicker is basically a windbag." -- John Gesmonde, a voter in North Branford, Conn. [ B8:3. ]

title: Font and Lego Are Victorious Again
description: With a little less pomp and circumstance than had been the norm for the past 106 years but with a vow to return here in finer fettle next year in its 108th edition, the National Horse Show closed tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The show had an inconsistent week at the box office, but its equestrian performances offered the same championship tone traditionally expected of it.

title: Sara M. Light and Matthew Waller Are Married
description: Sara Merle Light, a daughter of Dr. Jack Light and Dr. Luise Light of Rockville, Md., was married yesterday to Matthew James Waller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Waller of New York. Rabbi Reeve Robert Brenner performed the ceremony at Rockwood Manor Center in Potomac, Md.

title: Times Getting Tougher for Business Magazines
description: It has been a tough week for the business magazines. On Wednesday, the Goldhirsh Group announced that it was closing Business Month, which it had acquired just three years ago. A day earlier, Business Week said it would lay off 10 of its 250 staff members and close two news bureaus.

title: TRIBE WILL ALLOW A DIG TO RESUME
description: An archeologist will resume digging at a site used by some of the earliest humans in North America under an agreement with Indians concerned about what will be done with artifacts or human remains.

title: Judith Pincus and Conan Freud Wed
description: Judith Ellen Pincus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Pincus of Yonkers, was married there yesterday to Conan S. Freud, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Freud of New York. Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner officiated at Temple Emanu-El.

title: Irene M. Selznick Service
description: A memorial service for Irene Mayer Selznick is to be held on Thursday at 4 P.M. at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street. Mrs. Selznick, a theatrical producer, died on Oct. 10 at the age of 83. Among those scheduled to speak at the memorial, which is open to the public, are Kitty Carlisle Hart, the chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts; Jerome Robbins, the director and choreographer; Jean Kerr, the writer, and Robert Gottlieb, the editor of The New Yorker.

title: Ewing Isn't Able to Do It All
description: The Knicks took Sunday off to recuperate from an opening weekend that did not go as well as planned.

title: Youth Killed and 3 Are Wounded In Soccer Violence Near Leipzig
description: Fighting in and around a soccer match in Leipzig on Saturday night turned into a violent melee in which police officers shot one young person to death and seriously wounded three others.

title: Ads on Values By Burger King
description: After reaching an agreement with a religious group, the Burger King Corporation has begun to take out newspaper advertisements declaring its support for "traditional American values."

title: SCIENTISTS URGING GAS EMISSION CUTS
description: A group of scientists considered experts on world climate called Saturday on all nations to take immediate steps to control global warming, regardless of the many questions that still exist about man-made climate change.

title: Laurie Ellen Lindenbaum Is Married
description: Laurie Ellen Lindenbaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Lindenbaum of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Alan Horne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred M. Horne of Wheeling, W.Va. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Town Hall To Survey A Century In a Decade
description: Town Hall, a venerable institution devoted to music and the spoken word, is about to begin a 10-year, decade-by-decade look at the arts and social history of 20th-century New York.

title: Arizona Hotel Investors Sue Laventhol on Study
description: A group of investors has accused the Laventhol & Horwath accounting firm of failing to alert their partnership to potential problems in the purchase of the Arizona Biltmore Hotel in 1984. The Phoenix landmark resort went into foreclosure in June.

title: 2 Youths Killed in Car Crash
description: Two teen-agers were killed and two others injured when the car they were riding in veered off the road and struck a tree, sheriff's deputies said. The identities of the two 17-year-old youths killed in the crash Saturday were being withheld today pending notification of relatives.

title: Halloween Beating Is Fatal
description: A man was charged Saturday in the fatal beating of a youth after an egg hit his car Halloween night. Dennis Moriconi Jr., 19 years old, faces a manslaughter charge in the death of Timothy Doucette. The 18-year-old died Thursday, 24 hours after he was beaten while trying to protect a friend.

title: Auditors Adjust to Desperate Times
description: Crazy Price Waterhouse. Its prices are insane!

title: Hubble Telescope Observes Distant Quasar
description: The Hubble Space Telescope, troubled since its launch last April, has for the first time observed a faint quasar billions of light years from Earth, the space agency said today.

title: British Review Of TV Merger
description: The Independent Broadcasting Authority said it had not been consulted about the proposed merger of two Britih satellite television channels and called for a review of the plan.

title: American Lawyers in Soviet Thicket
description: At Baker & McKenzie's office just off Pushkin Square, the phones are modern. But as one of the four lawyers there put it, "They're hooked into the Soviet system, so we're at the mercy of that."

title: Market Place; Big Oil to Gain, Barring Gulf War
description: THE modest prosperity that big oil companies reported in the third quarter could swell significantly in the next few quarters under almost any series of events except war in the Middle East, many analysts say.

title: Deficit-Cutting Plan Would Mean $321 Tax Rise for Average Family
