description: A new analysis from a research group financed by labor unions says the deficit-reduction bill awaiting President Bush's signature would cost the average family of four $321 a year in additional taxes, with the increases spread almost evenly among the states.

title: Masterful Is Word For Campbell's Run
description: John Campbell, a 41-year-old marathoner who sees himself as a sort of Everyman in shorts, decided to turn back the clock yesterday.

title: In Albania, Communist Stronghold, The Grip Appears to Be Loosening
description: When one of the dozen or so foreign automobiles that are permitted to circulate in this country passes through this filthy industrial town, citizens walking along the main street make a V sign to the occupants with their fingers.

title: How to Make U.N. Ready for the 21st Century
description: To the Editor:

title: The Usual Suspect Sparks 49ers' Rally
description: Joe Montana rallied San Francisco from a 10-0 deficit with three touchdown passes, and the undefeated 49ers held on to beat the Green Bay Packers today, 24-20.

title: Town Turns Private Site Into Dump
description: Peter D. Gache of Ketchum, Idaho, owns 104 acres of pristine woods in the exclusive Purchase section of this Westchester suburb. Well, make that 98.5 unspoiled acres and 5.5 that Mr. Gache was surprised to discover a few months ago had become a town dump.

title: Libya Said to Expel Palestinian Guerrillas
description: Abul Abbas, who directed the Achille Lauro ship hijacking five years ago, said today that Libya had expelled 145 members of his group, a wing of the Palestine Liberation Front, and closed down four training camps.

title: Election Day Tomorrow
description: Here are schedules.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Goldstar Promoting 'User Friendlier' Image
description: MANY consumers have been pushed to the edge trying to figure out how to program their videocassette recorders, microwave ovens and other high-tech gadgetry. Now Goldstar Electronics has begun a campaign, estimated to cost $15 million, telling people it understands the frustration of not being able to get the VCR to stop flashing 12:00 o'clock.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy The world's airlines agreed to seek fare increases of up to 8 percent on international flights. The carriers said the higher fares, the second round of increases since the Persian Gulf crisis began, are needed to cope with higher fuel costs. [ Page D1. ]

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It's polluted and noisy. I haven't seen a blade of grass or eaten a vegetable since I got here. I watched the rats scurry across the subway tracks. And the urine smell gets to me. But I haven't encountered a single rude person." -- David Burch, an Orlando Sentinel editor working as a nonunion reporter at The Daily News. [ B4:3. ]

title: Pakistanis Imperil Falcons To Please the Sheiks of Prey
description: When fall comes to the fields and hills of northern Pakistan, chilling the air and clearing the sky of its leaden summer dust, boys and men of the northwest frontier go falcon hunting. Not hunting with falcons, but for them -- with nets, traps, decoy birds or almost anything else that will snare a bird of prey for sale at fabulous prices to Persian Gulf sheiks.

title: Careers; Helping Commuters Commute
description: THE Association for Commuter Transportation was formed 14 years ago in the aftermath of the mid-1970's energy crisis to aid executives newly assigned to efforts to reduce automobile traffic.

title: Our Towns; Dark Side of Life: Glimpse of Home For Mentally Ill
description: Today, when the recovering mentally ill leave a hospital, they can go to modern group homes financed by the state and supervised by trained social workers. Twenty years ago, when mental hospitals were being emptied on a large scale, few such humane places existed. About the only option here was family-care homes, small licensed boardinghouses run by people with little training.

title: Article 247390 -- No Title
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, which generally issues short-term floating rate notes each month, priced $650 million of the securities yesterday through various securities dealers.

title: Ruling May Block Prosecutors in Boston Slaying
description: In a decision that could leave some questions about one of the state's most bizarre murders forever unanswered, the highest court in Massachusetts ruled today that Charles Stuart's lawyer cannot be forced to testify before a grand jury investigating the slaying of Mr. Stuart's pregnant wife.

title: Q&A
description: Local Showers

title: Washington at Work; Antitrust Lawyer Rises to Stardom On Combination of Caution and Zeal
description: James F. Rill was expected to shake the Justice Department's antitrust division from its torpor in the Reagan Administration. But he was not expected to go right at it, turning up the heat in two areas dear to George Bush: the oil industry and Ivy League colleges.

title: U.S. Dietary Guide Sets Fat and Alcohol Limits
description: The Bush Administration released dietary guidelines for the nation today, for the first time setting a limit on the amount of fat Americans should eat and the amount of alcohol they should drink. The guidelines also recommended the number of servings they should eat each day from major food groups.

title: Road Runners Consider Changes for Marathon
description: Despite the popular success of the New York City Marathon on Sunday, with unusually large crowds lining the five-borough course and relatively strong overnight national television ratings, organizers of the race are considering several changes, perhaps by next year.

title: Vehicle Sales Up 8.6% in Late October
description: Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose 8.6 percent in late October, compared with soft sales in the period last year. But weak consumer confidence and recent moves by the Big Three to cut production suggest problems ahead, analysts said.

title: INSIDE
description: Envoy in Spy Case Is Out The United States dismissed Felix S. Bloch, the diplomat long under investigation for spying but, for lack of evidence, not charged. Page A3. Global Air Fares to Rise The world's airlines agreed to raise international fares as much as 8 percent in the second round of increases since the Kuwait invasion. Page D1. Loopholes in Gun Laws Despite some of the nation's strictest gun laws, New York City has not been able to stop the tide of weapons entering the city. Page B1. New Diet Recommendations The Government issued new dietary guidelines for Americans suggesting specific limits on fat and alcohol consumption. Page C9. News's New Man Learns A Florida editor, called on to fill in as a reporter for the strikebound Daily News is enduring $10 Cokes and other New York niceties. Page B4. Vying for the Kremlin Cup First-class men's professional tennis came to the Soviet Union for the first time with the opening of a $330,000 tournament in Moscow. Page D21.

title: He Taught Them To Read Medical Clues
description: To the Editor:

title: Prague Gets Visa Cards
description: Visa International said Friday that a Prague bank had issued the first internationally accepted Visa cards to Czechoslovak citizens. The company also said three Polish banks would issue internationally accepted Visa cards by next June. Zivnostenska Banka of Prague has issued credit cards to customers with convertible foreign currency deposits. Next year, cardholders will be able to use the cards to make payments in crowns inside the country.

title: One Way to Foster Understanding in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Managua Dons High Heels and Has a Fling
description: Bourgeois is back.

title: An Ambassador-in-Waiting Takes Office in Washington
description: A new Ambassador was sworn in today as America's representative to a country he is unlikely to set foot in soon: Lebanon.

title: Miscellany
description: * Bergman Group, New York, specialists in communications services, will join the Ross Roy group, Detroit, by assisting on the accounts of its advertising agency subsidiary Calet, Hirsch & Spector, New York.

title: Political Satire in Berlin Cabarets Re-emerges With a Vengeance
description: Cabaret in Berlin, its mordant political wit crushed by the Nazis and left for dead by the Communists, is coming back to life.

title: Coal Miners Strike in Poland
description: Miners held a two-hour warning strike at virtually all of Poland's deep coal mines today to demand pay increases and protest the effects of the country's economic reform program. The strike, called by the Solidarity miners' union, affected about 70 hard-coal mines. It was called after months of negotiations between the Solidarity-led Government and the miners' unions produced no agreement on pay raises, an Industry Ministry spokesman, Jan Golab, said. He said that workers nationwide earn an average $126 monthly, but miners earn $179.

title: KAHANE IS KILLED AFTER GIVING TALK IN NEW YORK HOTEL
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the founder of the Jewish Defense League and leader of a militant anti-Arab fringe movement in Israel, was assassinated last night by a gunman during a Zionist conference at a hotel in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: Union at Modern Museum To Meet Over Strike Vote
description: The professional employees' union at the Museum of Modern Art will meet tomorrow evening to seek a strike authorization vote against the museum. The three-year contract between the museum and the union, the Professional and Administrative Staff Association, known by its acronym of Pasta, expired Oct. 31.

title: Key Rates
Karpov Holds Ground in Game 11 Against Daring Kasparov Attack
description: A bold idea, a flight of fantasy, a brief flurry of excitement -- all it got Gary Kasparov last night was an entertaining draw in Game 11 of the World Championship Chess Match in Manhattan. The stolid Anatoly Karpov held his ground against all the champion's machinations and could neither be overwhelmed by force nor lured into error. In the end, Kasparov was obliged to bring about a draw by threatening perpetual check.

title: Vietnamese Accuse Czechs of Racism
description: Vietnamese contract workers and students, whom their Government sent to Czechoslovakia when it was still a "brotherly" Communist country, are protesting in letters to President Vaclav Havel, appeals sent to Czechoslovak news organizations and public statements about an increase in racial assaults and insults.

title: When Day Care Clashes With Zoning Laws
description: When Tracey DeLaura decided to stay home with her baby, she figured she might as well watch a few other children. She thought she could have fun and make some money. She never suspected she would be breaking the law.

title: General Cinema Ends Neiman Marcus Bid
description: The General Cinema Corporation said yesterday that its deal to acquire the shares of the Neiman Marcus Group it does not already own collapsed after part of the Neiman Marcus board withdrew its support.

title: Tax Breaks Challenged On Low-Income Condos
description: Reduced property taxes paid by owners of 5,000 housing units built for people with low and moderate incomes around the state unexpectedly came under challenge today in a hearing before the State Supreme Court on a case affecting two condominiums in Ridgefield Park.

title: Books of The Times; Drama Critic in Role of Enthusiast
description: Profiles By Kenneth Tynan Selected and edited by Kathleen Tynan and Ernie Eban. Preface by Simon Callow. 437 pages. Cornelia & Michael Bessie Books/HarperPerennial. $14.95.

title: Move to Settle Asbestos Cases
description: Eagle-Picher Inc. said today that it hoped to settle thousands of asbestos disease lawsuits and future claims within 30 days.

title: Brandt's Hostage Mission to Baghdad Drawing Criticism Outside Germany
description: Former Chancellor Willy Brandt flew to Baghdad today on a private mission endorsed by the Bonn Government to free Western hostages in Iraq, an effort other European nations have sharply criticized as a breach of international solidarity in the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Equitable Real Estate Unit Is Vulnerable but Confident
description: Cracks are starting to appear in the portfolio of the nation's largest investor of real estate assets for pension funds. Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc., a unit of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, is grappling with rising withdrawals of pension money from its managed funds and, like others in the industry, faces growing delinquency rates in its mortgage portfolio.

title: Dutch Insurer In Big Merger
description: The Netherlands' largest insurance company and its third- largest bank announced today that they would merge, forming a financial giant with combined assets worth $156 billion.

title: Holyfield Honored
description: Tens of thousands welcomed the world heavyweight champion back to his hometown of Atlanta yesterday, and Mayor Maynard Jackson proclaimed November "Evander Holyfield Month" in the city.

title: Review/Theater; Ping Chong Spoofs the Present and the Future
description: As a theatrical explorer, Ping Chong once again ventures into the future in his enticing, elliptical "Elephant Memories." The time is distant in this new performance piece at La Mama Annex. But it could be closer than one thinks as a race of humans -- or are they humanoids? -- obeys their daily rules and rituals while receiving Big Brotherly orders from a ubiquitous voiceover.

title: Carson Is Dismissed As Coach of Browns
description: Bud Carson became the first coaching casualty of the National Football League season yesterday when he was dismissed by the Cleveland Browns a day after the worst home loss in their history.

title: Raymond Oliver, Famed French Chef, Dies at 81
description: Raymond Oliver, one of the great chefs of postwar France who at the height of his popularity was famed as much for his theatrical style as his cuisine, died in France yesterday. He was 81 years old.

title: CAMPAIGN ENDING WITH VOTERS SEEN IN A RESTIVE MOOD
description: An election year that began with the nation at peace and feeling prosperous wound up today with restless voters looking for ways to lash out at politicians and worried about war in the Persian Gulf and recession here at home.

title: The Iraqi Nightmare
description: So often, the worst thing about a nightmare is waking up, remembering that you have had the same dreadful dream before, and knowing that you will have it again.

title: Suzuki in China Deal
description: A Japanese car maker said today that it was providing technical assistance in a venture with China. The Suzuki Motor Company, Japan's top mini-car maker, plans to assist in production of a version of its Alto model, a five-door hatchback, a Suzuki spokesman said. Production is to start Tuesday in China. The China Changan Machine Building plant now manufactures Suzuki's Carry model, a lightweight commercial vehicle, with technical assistance from Japan, he said.

title: Reviews/Music; Adding Melody to Noise, Mekons Remain a Force
description: The Mekons are anything but the dull, earnest band you'd expect from their history. Founded in 1977 in Leeds, the band is among the last survivors of the British punk-rock explosion, and has held on to the political and intellectual underpinnings of fellow Leeds bands like the Gang of Four. But in its 13-year ramble from one independent label and club to the next, the band has tempered noise with melody, assembled a solid rhythm section and added a countryish twang to its punk assault; better yet, it has never lost its sense of humor.

title: The Scene: A Smile, Two Shots
description: The assassin seemed to come out of nowhere, but some of those who noticed him at the last moment said he was smiling and had a strange look on his face as he fired the fatal shot.

title: Accounts
description: * UJB Financial Corp., Princeton, N.J., to Linett & Harrison, Springfield, N.J., with a budget of more than $5 million. * Wordstar International Inc., San Francisco, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, with billings of about $2 million.

title: Judge Assails G.O.P. Mailing in Carolina
description: A Federal judge said today in New Jersey that mailings by North Carolina's Republican Party in the final days of the racially tinged Senate contest appeared to violate a court order he issued eight years ago prohibiting the Republican National Committee from improperly singling out and intimidating minority voters.

title: An Uphill TV Battle For Jesse Jackson Show
description: The talk-show host, circling his upraised arm Arsenio Hall-style, enters to wild applause from the studio audience and introduces his panel for the day's topic: civil rights in 1990. The guests include a former member of the Ku Klux Klan turned state legislator and Senate hopeful, a firebrand liberal lawyer, a black Congressman and a strategist from the Republican Party. During a commercial break, the host makes small talk with the former Klansman.

title: Contel Acquisition May Be Delayed
description: The GTE Corporation announced that its $5 billion acquisition of the Contel Corporation might not be completed until the second quarter of next year because of objections from a state agency and consumer and industry groups in California. GTE said that while shareholders of both companies would meet on Dec. 11 to vote on the deal, the actual exchange of 1.27 shares of GTE stock for each share of Contel stock might not be possible in this quarter, as previously planned.

title: The 1990 Campaign; War Clouds, No Thunder; As Guns Are Silent, So Are the Candidates
description: Two years ago, a Presidential campaign took place at a time of radical change in the world order, with the Soviet Union rapidly ceasing to pose a threat to the West, and there was almost no debate about what the United States should do.

title: Ventures Test Rival Ways to Recreate the World in a Spacecraft
description: AS space enthusiasts in Arizona prepare to seal themselves inside an eight-story, $100 million greenhouse for two years, an event tourists can commemorate with T-shirts and other memorabilia purchased at the nearby gift shop, the scientific field that parallels ther endeavor has been making quiet progress beyond the limelight.

title: Singapore Journal; As Sons Take Power, Patriarch Looks On Sternly
description: The familial psychodrama that tinges politics in Singapore is about to enter an important passage: the transfer of authority to the second generation after 25 years of independence.

title: News Hopes to Lure Minority Journalists
description: The editor of The Daily News, struggling to fill crucial newsroom jobs in the midst of a bitter strike by 9 of its 10 unions, began contacting minority journalists' groups yesterday to ask for their help in recruiting permanent replacements for the strikers.

title: Laundry List for The Knicks
description: With a skip in the step and a little whistling on the lips in anticipation of a brand new season in the National Basketball Association, the correspondent entered Madison Square Garden Saturday evening for the Knicks' game against Boston.

title: A One-Time Change On 'NBC Nightly News'
description: NBC News will change the format of its network newscast Friday evening to present a special broadcast on a single theme: the state of America today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arkla Inc., Shreveport, La., appointed Penelope S. Ludwig director of Federal regulatory affairs of its pipeline group. * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, named Dr. Andrew Bodnar to senior vice president of strategic management of its pharmaceutical group in Princeton, N.J. * Commodore International Ltd., West Chester, Pa., producers of personal computer systems, named its vice president, Ronald B. Alexander, to the additional position of chief financial officer. * Corroon & Black Corp., New York, an insurance brokerage, promoted Diane Askwyth to vice president. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, named its vice president of personnel, Richard F. O'Brien, vice president of industrial relations. He replaces Alfred S. Warren Jr., who retires in April. * Gilead Sciences, Foster City, Calif., appointed Dr. John C. Martin vice president of research and development. * Howard Savings Bank, Livingston, N.J., named Joel A. Brotman senior vice president in charge of its consolidated residential mortgage operation. * New York Life Insurance Co., New York, appointed Jean E. Hoysradt vice president in its investment department. * Ogden Projects Inc., a unit of Ogden Corp., Fairfield, N.J., named Scott G. Mackin and Bruce W. Stone co-presidents and co-chief operating officers.

title: Japanese Challenge Will Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq Allows Some Hostages to Phone Families
description: The State Department said today that at least 21 American families had received telephone calls over the weekend from relatives detained in Iraq. It declared that instead of simply permitting the hostages to speak with their families, the Iraqis should free them.

title: For Families, Fresh Fears
description: The Bush Administration's tough talk on the Persian Gulf is renewing fears among some relatives of American troops in the region. Page A16.

title: Nissan Profit Rises 16.5%
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's No. 2 auto maker, today reported a 16.5 percent increase in net income and record domestic sales in the first half of the 1990 fiscal year.

title: Sir David Stirling, 74, the Founder Of Britain's Elite Commando Unit
description: Sir David Stirling, founder of Britain's elite Special Air Service and dubbed the "Phantom Major" by Hitler's troops in World War II, died after a long illness on Sunday. He was 74 years old.

title: Gay Soldier Wins Battle to Re-enlist
description: A former Army sergeant, drafted in 1967 despite his avowed homosexuality, won a Supreme Court victory today when the Justices let stand a lower court ruling that the Army must allow him to re-enlist.

title: A Wall in SoHo; Enter 2 Artists, Feuding
description: A 38-year-old French artist unveiled his latest painting in SoHo last week and promptly faced the critics. Le Pointre, as he calls himself, was at the top of a wobbly 20-foot ladder, trying to glue and nail his 11-foot-wide canvas to a brick wall, when they started questioning the motivation behind this work.

title: By Design; More on Hemlines
description: When it comes to hemlines, the votes are already in and tabulated. The short one wins.

title: Irish At Center Of Volatile Situation
description: The luck of the Irish may have extended to Charlottesville and Lincoln, where losses Saturday by Virginia and Nebraska enabled Notre Dame to reclaim the top spot in the news-agency polls. But giving up 31 points to lowly Navy dropped the Irish in The Times's computer ranking from No. 9 to No. 11.

title: Oil Drops More than $2, To $31.96
description: Crude oil dropped more than $2 yesterday as traders' fear of normal supplies began to overpower their fear of war.

title: MCI to Build Phone Cable In Atlantic
description: The MCI Communications Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. announced yesterday that they would build a high-capacity telephone cable under the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Duerson Gets Timely Touchdown
description: The football that Dave Duerson had carried across a goal line not long before was resting near the bottom of his locker in the Giants' dressing room at the Hoosier Dome. A coach from a long time ago, but not far away, approached the locker, and stopped in front of Duerson, and the two embraced.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the installation of a new steeple on theFifth Avenue Presbyterian Church incorrectly stated the cost of the steeple, the nature of the tower it replaced and the source of the funds for the project. The steeple cost $400,000, not $3.5 million, which is the cost of the entire church restoration project. The tower that was replaced was made of cast iron, not stone. The project is being financed with money from the sale of unused development funds, not donations.

title: Market Place; At Coast Savings, Is the Worst Over?
description: COAST SAVINGS FINANCIAL INC., the parent of the nation's 10th-largest savings and loan association, is at a crossroads.

title: Puerto Rico Bank Merger
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved the merger of Banco Popular de Puerto Rico and the BanPonce Corporation.

title: Japan's Gulf Commitment Seems Endangered
description: The governing Liberal Democratic Party claimed a narrow victory today in a Parliament election that was widely seen as a referendum on Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's effort to send Japanese troops to the Persian Gulf. But Government officials said this would not be sufficient to save the effort from near-certain defeat.

title: Advance in Computers
description: Scientists at Bellcore Inc. in Morristown, N.J., will announce today that they have made a significant advance in developing a computer memory based on laser holography techniques. The new memory is capable of storing 10 times more information and retrieving it in a thousandth of the time taken by today's desktop computers. Holograms are three-dimensional images created with lasers, and the Bellcore researchers said holographic memory had broad potential for storing images for multimedia computer applications. The new memory is made possible by recent advances in extremely small lasers fabricated in arrays on a semiconductor circuit.The researchers said they had not yet built a working prototype to test the design.

title: Review/Music; Blockbusters in 3 Piano Recitals
description: A trend in piano recitals, if three examples last week gave an accurate indication, is toward relatively brief programs consisting largely of blockbusters.

title: Cyrus Levinthal, 68, A Genetics Scientist And Professor, Dies
description: Cyrus Levinthal, a scientist who spent 33 years researching molecular genetics, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: Ellis Flyte Wed To Brian Henson
description: Ellis Ashley Flyte, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tom Duncan of Edinburgh, was married yesterday to Brian David Henson, a son of Jane Anne Henson of New York and the late Jim Henson, creator of the Muppets. Miss Antoinette McKain, a registrar, performed the civil ceremony on a beach of the island of Tortola in the British Virgin Islands.

title: Harry Weinberg, 82, Businessman In Transit and Real Estate, Is Dead
description: Harry Weinberg, an entrepreneur from Baltimore who became a billionnaire through investments in real estate, mass transit and other ventures, died Sunday in Honolulu, where he had lived since 1968. He was 82 years old.

title: Japan's Rich Cars Enrich Dealers
description: Dealers that bet on the Japanese push into the luxury-car market are winning big. At a time when many dealerships in the United States are hurting, those selling the Lexus from Toyota, the Infiniti from Nissan and the Acura from Honda are being viewed as models both for their profitability and the lengths to which they and their car companies will go to impress customers.

title: Dissidents Split Indian Prime Minister's Party
description: Prime Minister V. P. Singh was dealt a crippling blow today when dissidents split his party and named a rival leader less than 48 hours before Mr. Singh was due to face a confidence vote in Parliament.

title: Chronicle
description: They're divorced and he's engaged. SARAH BRIGHTMAN was granted a divorce from ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER yesterday in London after six years of marriage. Also yesterday, Mr. Lloyd Webber announced his engagement to MADELEINE GURDON , a clothing designer. They expect to marry in Britain in February.

title: New Chrysler Sales Executive
description: The Chrysler Corporation today named Theodor R. Cunningham to the new position of vice president for sales and marketing.

title: Doubts Rise On Children As Witnesses
description: AN article of faith among many authorities investigating sexual abuse of children, that "they do not make these things up," is coming under fire as some researchers find that young children can be readily influenced by those who question them.

title: Rally in Bond Prices Continues
description: Falling oil prices and a ratings downgrade of $22 billion worth of outstanding Citicorp debt by the Standard & Poor's Corporation helped yesterday to keep alive the rally in the credit markets, as prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell.

title: Seagate Offers New Products
description: Seagate Technology introduced new products today in an effort to regain lost ground in the disk drive industry. The products include the company's first 2.5- inch-diameter disk drive and a 3.5-inch drive for use in laptop and notebook computers.

title: Meir Kahane, 58, Israeli Militant and Founder of the Jewish Defense League
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the founder of the Jewish Defense League, who was shot to death in a Manhattan hotel last night, made a long journey from the streets of Brooklyn to a powerful position on the far-right fringes of Israeli politics.

title: The New Populism
description: As the election returns trickle in tonight, some analysts may announce that "soak the rich" populism has become the Democratic Party's road to power in the 1990's. But it is proving hard to find many troops willing to enlist in the newly declared class war.

title: Rangers' Caution Backfires As Bruins Win in Overtime
description: Clear the crease, clear the zone, watch the clock. As a style of play, it is less than high art. As a strategy, it is often extremely high-risk.

title: People
description: * Jeff Palmer, an executive vice president at Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York, is leaving the agency to form his own consulting company. * Andrew Penney and Wendy Kapnek have been named senior vice presidents and group managers at Ketchum Public Relations, Philadelphia.

title: Herbert Berghof, Actor, Director And Eminent Acting Teacher, 81
description: Herbert Berghof, an actor and director who was one of the nation's most respected acting teachers and coaches, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: U.S. Dismisses Envoy Suspected as Spy
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today dismissed Felix S. Bloch, the American diplomat who has been under investigation for almost two years on suspicion of being a Soviet agent but has not been charged because of lack of evidence.

title: Patterns
description: Fans and Family of Mizrahi

title: Clock Plays a Role In Squirrel Mating
description: AS natural resources go, sperm is fairly cheap, and male animals usually need a good reason for rejecting a partner and conserving semen. Among one species of ground squirrel, that reason seems to be the time since a female last copulated with another male.

title: Council of Europe Seeks Others' Assistance
description: The Council of Europe, marking the 40th anniversary of its human rights charter, declared today that it wants the United States, the Soviet Union and Canada to join in some of its functions.

title: The Brazenness of New York's Illegal Gun Dealers Grows
description: Although New York City's gun-control laws are among the strictest in the nation, tens of thousands of guns are filtering here through lax laws in other states and through the intricate schemes of gun merchants who take advantage of loopholes in Federal regulations and the sloppy enforcement of basic bureaucratic rules.

title: Faulty Gauge?
description: A method using fossils of small marine animals called brachiopods to determine the temperature of ancient oceans may be flawed, new research suggests.

title: The Voting Today
description: The power of incumbency and one-party dominance of local elections have stifled competition in New York State politics. Page B1.

title: Abortion Records Subpoenaed
description: The New York City Human Rights Commission has subpoenaed medical records from 11 clinics that have refused to perform abortions on women infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Anti-Abortion Bill Prompts Poles To Debate the Church's Influence
description: Under heavy pressure from the Catholic Church, including personal intervention by Pope John Paul II, the Polish legislature is moving toward banning abortion, a major means of birth control in this overwhelmingly Catholic country.

title: Dr. John Wingate, 91, Professor Of Retailing and Business Adviser
description: Dr. John W. Wingate, professor emeritus and former chairman of the retailing department at City College, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: Moscow Glimpsing Tennis's Riches
description: Tennis, for too long the hidden Soviet game of Communist apparatchiks, reached for a populist dimension here tonight as the Kremlin Cup tournament opened with an array of world-ranked men playing for hard-cash prizes, no rubles accepted.

title: New Graphics Capability For Sun's Work Stations
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. introduced a family of powerful computer work stations today with an improved ability to draw and move images around on the screen.

title: Bache Settlement Seen On Big Board Charges
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. has decided to settle charges stemming from a series of cases under investigation by the New York Stock Exchange, according to an internal memorandum from the firm.

title: Americans Vote and Vote and Vote
description: Who says Americans don't vote? As far as we can tell, they vote more than anybody else in the world -- and that's the main reason why voter turnout is declining.

title: Review/Television; State Lotteries and Why They Grow
description: Last year, Americans bought $20 billion worth of lottery tickets, and if state governments around the country have their way, the figure will keep going up. "For the players," says James Reston Jr., the reporter of "Betting on the Lottery," tonight's lively "Frontline" offering at 9 on Channel 13 and 10 on Channel 49, "it is a bad bet with impossible odds that are rarely advertised."

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions with the Evening Hours column on Sunday referred incorrectly to two partygoers. They were Toukie Smith, at the Giorgio Armani party, and Carroll Petrie, who greeted Ronald and Nancy Reagan at the Petrie Sculpture Garden party.

title: Insider Charge Settled In Business Week Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged a former broker with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company with illegal insider trading that was based on information he obtained from advance copies of Business Week magazine.

title: Businessland Posts a Loss As Computer Sales Weaken
description: The slowdown that has beset many personal computer makers is taking its toll on sellers as well. Businessland Inc., the largest nonfranchised chain of computer stores, reported yesterday that it lost $19.9 million in its first quarter of fiscal 1991, ended Sept. 30, on $308.9 million in sales. A year earlier the company earned $4.3 million, or 14 cents a share, on sales of $315.9 million.

title: United Merchants'
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., a textiles and apparel producer, has filed for voluntary bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, for itself and two subsidiaries: Jonathan Logan Inc. and United Merchants Trucking Inc. The company has been burdened by large long-term debt.

title: The Shining Stars in a Month a Fashion
description: As the four-week marathon of spring and summer openings ended on Friday, Geoffrey Beene Beene, Geoffrey reinforced his standing as one of the world's front-runners in fashion. In a powerful showing of breathtakingly beautiful and marvelously inventive clothes, he left the rest of the American design field far behind.

title: Field Settles Book Charges
description: Field Publications has settled charges that it mailed books to its subscribers that they had not asked for or agreed to receive and then billed them for payment, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BRIEFS * American Founders Life Insurance Co., Phoenix, a unit of American Continental Corp., has been sold to American Financial Acquisition Corp., a new company formed by individual and institutional investors, for undisclosed terms. * Bell Atlantic International, Philadelphia, a unit of Bell Atlantic, signed a cooperative agreement with the national telephone company of Taiwan to explore marketing opportunities, research programs and personnel and information exchanges. * Cable and Wireless P.L.C., London, a telecommunications company, will acquire Alba Data Technology, a provider of data networking services which operates under the name DataAmerica. Terms were not disclosed. * Delta Air Lines, Atlanta, plans to expand its service to Japan in 1991 with new flights to Tokyo through Los Angeles and to Nagoya from Portland, Ore. The flights will begin on Feb. 6 and Feb. 7, respectively. * Grumman Corp., Bethpage, L.I., the military contractor, has received a $523.1 million contract to supply the United States Air Force with a Joint Surveillance Target Radar System. * Norfolk Southern Corp., Norfolk, Va., an operator of railroads and moving van lines, said it was starting a separation program for some clerical workers and some of those employed by its Norfolk and Western Railway unit in Roanoke, Va. * Olympia Holding Corp. has been given another month by a Federal bankruptcy judge in Florida to turn around its financially troubled PIE International trucking subsidiary. Over strong objections from the company's largest secured creditor, the Fidelcor Business Credit Corporation, United States District Court Judge George Proctor said the truck line could continue to use money from its accounts receivable to operate until the next court hearing, set for Dec. 15. * Scot Paper Co., Philadelphia, announced it had formed a joint venture with Feldmuhle A.G. to own and operate the European company's sanitary tissue business. Scott acquired a 51 percent interest in the venture and is entitled to obtain ownership of the remaining 49 percent in three years, Scott said. Scott paid Feldmuhle about $130 million and is obligated to pay Feldmuhle about the same amount over the next three years, plus interest.

title: Critic's Notebook; Fighting Against Film Coloring With a Label as a Weapon
description: For $19.95 at your local video store, you can pick up a full-color copy of John Huston's black-and-white gangster classic "Key Largo." At the top of the package, bannered above the cartoon-colored images of Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall, is the crucial marketing word: "colorized." And at the lower right, in a conspicuous white square that looks quite a lot like the Surgeon General's warning on cigarette packs, is a legend: "This is a colorized version of a film originally marketed and distributed to the public in black and white. It has been altered without the participation of the principal director, screenwriter and other creators of the original film."

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * CSX Corp., a Richmond-based transportation holding company, is offering $200 million in 9 1/2 percent noncallable notes due 1995 at 99.88, to yield 9.53 percent, or about 140 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through the First Boston Corporation as lead manager. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P. * Norwest Financial Inc., Des Moines, Iowa, a subsidiary of the Norwest Corp., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $1 billion in debt securities. * Pennzoil Co., a Houston-based oil and gas exploration company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $500 million in debt securities consisting of debentures and notes. * Pioneer Standard Electronics Inc., Cleveland, has privately placed $20 million in senior notes with Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America. Ratings * Transco Energy Co.'s debt rating is under review by S.& P. with negative implications. The energy holding company is based in Houston.

title: Communist Street Signs in Moscow Go the Way of a Spurned Ideology
description: The insurgent City Council, feeling increasingly powerless amid the nation's political ennui, began sweeping Communist names from Moscow street signs with a vengeance today.

title: School for Deaf In New Jersey Gets New Chief
description: The New Jersey Board of Education named a deaf woman to be the top administrator of its oldest and most important school for the hearing impaired yesterday, ending months of pressure by the state's deaf community to choose one of their own.

title: Chronicle
description: CHEYENNE BRANDO has emerged from a coma after taking an overdose of tranquilizers and is being treated in the intensive-care unit of Mamao Hospital in Papeete, Tahiti, where she fled after the fatal shooting last May of her lover, Dag Drollet, by her half-brother, CHRISTIAN BRANDO.

title: Sit Up and Do Tricks
description: COMPLETELY unscientific research has determined that the Apple Macintosh is more fun to use than a standard PC, and it is going to get a lot more amusing with Stupid Mac Tricks, a new book and disk combination from Bob (Dr. Macintosh) Levitus.

title: Mixed Views On NEC Computer
description: The performance of the NEC Corporation's newest SX-3 supercomputer, far outstrips its nearest American and Japanese competitors for speeds attained by a single processor system, according to a leading American computer expert.

title: Fare Rise Is Cleared By Airlines
description: The world's airlines agreed yesterday to seek fare increases of up to 8 percent on international flights. The carriers said the higher fares, which mark the second round of increases since the Persian Gulf crisis began three months ago, are needed because of higher fuel costs.

title: Review/Violin; Not Taking the Easy Way
description: If the music business were able to special-order the prerequisite parts for a successful concert career, it could scarcely come up with something more satisfying than Anne Akiko Meyers. The American violinist, who played a violin-piano recital with Rohan De Silva at the 92d Street Y on Sunday afternoon, is a powerful player. The attacks are decisive, the notes in tune. What Ms. Meyers wants from her instrument she seems to get.

title: Correction
description: Because of a technical error, the authors of two articles on last Sunday's Op-Ed page were not identified. John Creed is an assistant professor of journalism at the Chukchi Campus of the University of Alaska; Irving Howe is a co-editor of Dissent and a member of the American Federation of Teachers.

title: Retrograde Feminism
description: To the Editor:

title: What? Me Worry?
description: Press and television keep telling us we are worried and angry. Press and television have a vested interest in having people worried and angry, so it's only natural they may have persuaded themselves that the situation is parlous.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a memorial to children in East Coldenham, N.Y., who died when a tornado blew in a school wall a year ago omitted part of a quotation from a parent. The parent, Peter J. Orsino, said: "It's not that we're asking too much. We lost our children."

title: Pallid Promises to Puerto Rico
description: Puerto Rico's three main political parties all favor allowing citizens of the island to vote in 1991 to decide whether it should seek statehood or independence, or continue as a commonwealth. Puerto Ricans could then decide whether to give permanent form to their present status -- meaning home rule, with exemption from Federal taxes but no vote in Federal elections -- or forgo these benefits for more power as a state or sovereign nation.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) -- Named Ron Schueler senior vice president; Larry Monroe director of minor leagues and scouting; Steve Noworyta director of minor league operations, and Duane Shaffer director of scouting. FOOTBALL CLEVELAND (AFC) -- Dismissed Bud Carson, head coach. Named Jim Shofner head coach. HOCKEY CHICAGO (NHL) -- Recalled Dominik Hasak, goaltender, from Indianapolis of the International Hockey League. HARTFORD (NHL) -- Recalled Mike Tomlak, center, from Springfield of the American Hockey League. PHILADELPHIA (NHL) -- Recalled Bruce Hoffort, goaltender, from Hershey of the American Hockey League. VANCOUVER (NHL) -- Recalled Gary Valk, left wing, from Milwaukee of the International Hockey League.

title: Seeking Bit of Revenge in Texas, Bush Stumps for a Hard-Pressed Williams
description: George Bush never forgets a slight.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Chronicle
description: BARRY LEVINSON and MARK JOHNSON , the director-producer team behind the current hit, "Avalon," and the Academy Award-winning "Rain Man," will turn their talents to "Paley." Based on the biography of the late William S. Paley by SALLY BEDELL SMITH , "In All His Glory," the two will create a mini-series for HBO PicturesTime Warner+. Production is to begin next year, and the program is to be aired shown in 1992. The book was published last month by Random HouseAdvance Publications+.

title: Mets Reopen Strawberry Negotiations
description: The bidding war for Darryl Strawberry opened officially yesterday when all 26 major league teams were allowed to talk contract with all 95 free agents entering the marketplace. And the Mets, apparently destined to compete with the Los Angeles Dodgers for their star right fielder, acknowledged that they had reopened talks with his agent.

title: Rig Count Climbs by 37
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States has climbed by 37, to 1,144, the highest count in nearly three years, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The count has not been this high since Dec. 28, 1987, when there were 1,145 working rigs. A year ago, the count was 1,042.

title: Jets Unlock the Secret Of Success on the Field
description: Two games ago, the Jets were doing everything by the book, concentrating on ball control, leading the conference in rushing yardage and the league in time of possession -- and they had a 2-5 record.

title: South African Clerics Meet; Tutu Raises Issue of Restitution
description: The largest assembly of black and white churches in the history of South Africa convened here today to determine ecumenical guidelines for a future beyond apartheid.

title: 2 U.S. Track Stars Face 2-Year Ban for Drug Use
description: Two American track and field stars, each a world record-holder and an Olympic silver medalist, were found to have traces of an anabolic steroid in drug testing and face a two-year suspension from competition. The ban would make them ineligible for the World Track and Field Championships next summer in Tokyo and the Barcelona Olympics in 1992.

title: Milwaukee School Plan Needs Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 29 about the arrest of an Indian politician in connection with a dispute about a mosque referred incorrectly to casualties in Bihar state and elsewhere a year ago in disturbances over the same issue. As many as 2,000 people were killed or wounded then.

title: Business and Health; Big Costs Imposed On Drug Makers
description: CHANGES that Congress has voted in the Federal-state Medicaid programs for the indigent are expected to cost pharmaceutical manufacturers at least $3.4 billion over five years in rebates on prescription drug prices.

title: Biologists Unravel Key Events of Cell Division
description: EACH day in a healthy human body, at least a trillion cells divide. White blood cells proliferate into fresh legions of T cells, B cells, macrophages and other gladiators of the immune system. The cells that line the stomach divide daily to keep a seamless seal around the belly's caustic juices. As the uppermost layer of the skin sloughs off, newborn dermal cells poke their way up from below. Hair grows; nails grow. Cell division is synonymous with life.

title: Success Comes to a Start-Up Charity
description: As a teen-ager, Sharon L. Monsky competed against Dorothy Hamill as a top amateur figure skater. In her mid-20's, she logged thousands of miles and hundreds of meetings as a management consultant with McKinsey & Company.

title: Mercer in Main Event
description: Ray Mercer, who won a gold medal in the heavyweight class at the 1988 Olympics, will challenge Francesco Damiani, the World Boxing Organization heavyweight champion, on Jan. 11 at Trump Taj Mahal in Atlantic City.

title: China's Leaders Try to Improve Image Abroad
description: Apparently concerned by China's poor image abroad, Chinese leaders are taking steps to try to spruce up their reputation with a new public relations effort aimed at foreigners.

title: Mount St. Helens Explosion Sends Steam and Ash 30,000 Feet High
description: An explosion at Mount St. Helens early this morning sent a plume of ash 30,000 feet into the air, scientists said.

title: New Reporter at The News Learns Fast
description: For nine days now, David Burch, assistant city editor of The Orlando Sentinel, has endured $10 Cokes, a hotel room he considers a dump and editors who urge him to make use of words virtually unknown in the Sunbelt. Like wilding.

title: Time's Deal for Magazine
description: In its third magazine acquisition on the West Coast within a year, the Time Inc. Magazine Company will acquire the remaining shares of In Health, a consumer health magazine formerly known as Hippocrates.

title: Ocean Loudspeakers To Sound Off for Data On Global Warming
description: BY sending pulses of underwater sound around the world through all five of its ocean basins, scientists hope to settle the question of whether the predicted "greenhouse" effect has begun to warm the planet.

title: How Boards of Election Can Gain Public Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Dispute With the Majors May Change Minor Leagues
description: What some minor league club owners see as a battle for control could lead to two separate minor league structures next year, one operated by major league clubs, the other by minor league owners.

title: More Preventive Care Sought for Older People
description: INCREASED efforts to promote health and prevent disease should be aimed at people 50 and older, the National Academy of Sciences said in a report yesterday.

title: Toss the Rascals Out; Just the Rascals
description: California, Colorado and Kansas City vote today on proposals to limit terms of elected officials. Indeed, Californians are voting on two such proposals, one stricter than the other, and both are expected to carry. The very idea is a bad omen.

title: For This Pounding, Volvo Had Help
description: Volvo, which has carefully built a wide reputation for credibility and safety, has acknowledged that some recent advertisements dramatizing the strength of its cars were phony.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Here is a summary of our recommendations for noteworthy races. Poll hours are 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York and 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. in Connecticut and New Jersey. NEW YORK G OVERNOR and L IEUTENANT G OVERNOR Mario Cuomo and Stanley Lundine (D-L) C OMPTROLLER Edward Regan (R-C) A TTORNEY G ENERAL Robert Abrams (D-L) U.S. H OUSE of R EPRESENTATIVES 15th District, Manhattan: Bill Green (R) S TATE S ENATE 26th District, Manhattan: Roy Goodman (R-L) S TATE A SSEMBLY 66th District, Manhattan: John Ravitz (R) C IVIL C OURT 1st District, Staten Island: Alexander Graves (R); 9th District, Manhattan: Marylin Diamond (R-C-L) Ballot Issues Yes to a $1.9 billion environmental bond issue. Among other purposes, the funds would be used to preserve open space, encourage recycling, close unsafe landfills, upgrade sewage treatment plants and improve municipal parks. CONNECTICUT G OVERNOR and L IEUTENANT G OVERNOR Bruce Morrison and Sandra Bender (D) U.S. H OUSE of R EPRESENTATIVES First District: Barbara Kennelly (D); Second District: Sam Gejdenson (D); Third District: Rosa DeLauro (D); Fourth District: Christopher Shays (R); Fifth District: Anthony Toby Moffett (D); Sixth District: Nancy Johnson (R) NEW JERSEY U.S. S ENATE Bill Bradley (D) U.S. H OUSE of R EPRESENTATIVES First District: Rob Andrews (D); 12th District: Dick Zimmer (R) Ballot Issues 1. Yes to a $135 million bond issue to help finance affordable housing.

title: Reviews/Music; Fado by Amalia Rodrigues
description: Her head thrown back, her face a mask of tragedy, Amalia Rodrigues sang Portuguese fado songs on Friday night at Town Hall. Miss Rodrigues, a contemporary of Edith Piaf, has brought fado to the world beyond Portugal since the 1940's. Her repertory has some international touches; Friday's concert included songs from Mexico, Italy and the United States. But it was the slower fado songs, in which Miss Rodrigues's voice grew fierce and tearful as it lingered over a painful word with a swelling vibrato, that showed why she commands an adoring audience, one that sang along with a minimum of encouragement. Her voice was once sweeter, but her range seems undiminished, and she makes graininess suggest anguish and resolve.

title: Heir Apparent Gets Kimberly-Clark Posts
description: The Kimberly-Clark Company, adhering to its succession plan, said yesterday that its new president and chief operating officer would be Wayne R. Sanders, who is the heir apparent to the chief executive.

title: Expressing Yourself
description: PEOPLE who publish long and complicated documents have to pay the price of a Ventura Publisher or Aldus PageMaker, the top-rated standards. But people with more modest requirements can get equally professional results with more affordable desktop -publishing programs.

title: Accounts Differ in Killing Of Bronx Woman by Officer
description: Police officials and the family of a Bronx woman who was shot to death in her apartment by a police officer on Saturday night have given conflicting versions of the tumultuous events leading up to her death.

title: Power Plants of the Cell Become Suspect in Baffling Diseases
description: Ancient, bacteria-like creatures that inhabit every human cell may hold the key to degenerative conditions of old age like heart failure and Parkinson's disease, a growing number of biologists, geneticists and physicians believe.

title: Election Day Tomorrow
description: Here are Election Day schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal, state open; New York City offices closed. Post office: Normal service. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pickups, no street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Open. Transportation: Regular schedules for buses, subways and commuter railroads. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal, state offices closed. Post offices: Normal service. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit regular schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal closed; State, municipal offices open. Post offices: Normal service. Banks: Open. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: Metro-North regular schedule.

title: Homeless a Product Of Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: For Dozens In New York, Run for Office Is a Waltz
description: Dozens of New York candidates have redefined the phrase "running for office" this year. They are confidently sauntering to re-election today, exerting less energy and generating less excitement than even the losers of the New York Marathon who were exhilarated merely by making the race.

title: With Detectives Hard Pressed, Family Joins in Hunt for Killer
description: Laurie Picco pressed against the iron gate barring the way to Mayor David N. Dinkins's executive office and listened wearily to a City Hall aide explain once again that the Mayor was tied up in budget talks.

title: Valerie French, 59, Actress Who Played English Characters
description: Valerie French, who began her career as a much-publicized starlet for Columbia Pictures and became a screen, stage and television actress who specialized in playing a diverse collection of English characters, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 59 years old.

title: New Vodka Campaign: Style Over Substance
description: Trying to break though the clutter of vodka advertising, Ted Chin & Company has created a print ad for its new client Attakiska that is essentially a Calvin Klein knockoff: sexually ambiguous and otherwise obscure.

title: Bridge
description: Among the handful of bridge players competing Sunday in the New York City Marathon was one of the world's leading bridge journalists. Phillip Alder, who is in great demand as a writer and editor and happens to live a quarter of a mile from the marathon finish line, completed the course in 3:46, quite possibly the best time among top bridge players. He was 26 minutes ahead of his wife, Judy.

title: Reviews/Music; Los Lobos' Latino Blues
description: Although the Mexican-American band Los Lobos has always stressed the fact that its music bridges two cultures, it actually involves more than just simply bringing Mexican folk and American rock-and-roll together in the same setting.

title: Saudis to Give Free Hand to U.S. If Attack on the Iraqis Is Approved
description: The United States and Saudi Arabia tightened their pressure on Iraq today by agreeing on new command arrangements they would follow if they mounted an offensive strike, senior American and Saudi officials said.

title: Review/Dance; Louis Armstrong's Associates Honor Him
description: Dancers and musicians honored Louis Armstrong on Sunday afternoon at Greenwich House with "Tribute to Pops," a program of jazz and pop songs. The performers were all associated with the great jazz artist, and they were shrewdly chosen to enable the little revue to have great choreographic variety.

title: CALIFORNIA GAINS IN MEDFLY BATTLE
description: Agriculture officials expect to declare victory this week in the 16-month, $52 million campaign to eradicate the Mediterranean fruit fly from Southern California.

title: Families of American Troops in Gulf Find Solace in Talking to Each Other
description: As the Bush Administration talked tough about Saddam Hussein last week, families of American troops in the Persian Gulf region wondered if the renewed bellicosity signaled danger for their loved ones, who so far have battled only sand, scorpions and restlessness.

title: Revamped Cooper Cos. Forms Health-Care Unit
description: The Cooper Companies, having executed the first two phases of a plan to

title: Younger Than Springtime
description: Little kids are lucky. They can see as well as hear her joyous "I'm Flying" in the videotape of "Peter Pan." But we older kids know what they don't, that Mary Martin had a life in the theater before she played the boy who never grew up.

title: Hearing on Newspapers
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh last week ordered an administrative hearing to determine whether two central California newspapers should be given an antitrust exemption to form a joint operating agreement. The joint operating application was filed in 1988 by The Manteca News, a semiweekly published by Raymus Development and Sales Inc., and The Manteca Bulletin, a daily owned by the Morris Newspaper Corporation.

title: President Signs Budget Bill
description: President Bush officially ended months of partisan brawling with Congress over taxes and the budget today by signing a bill to cut $492 billion from the deficit over the next five years.

title: Voters to Decide on Bond Act For Environmental Projects
description: With New York State virtually out of money to buy land, protect watersheds, promote recycling and initiate other environmental projects, voters must decide on Tuesday whether to authorize large-scale borrowing for such purposes.

title: Colts No Obstacle at All as Giants Reach 8-0
description: It was no contest. Tonight, as the Giants scored the first three times they had the ball and routed the Colts, 24-7. The Giants moved the ball almost as they pleased and usually bottled up what little offense the Colts mustered.

title: Franciszek Szlachcic, Polish Communist, 70
description: Maj. Gen. Franciszek Szlachcic, a former Interior Minister and former member of the Communist Party Politburo, has died, the official Polish press agency reported on Sunday. He was 70 years old.

title: Man Surrenders in Mississippi
description: A man wanted in the stabbing deaths of four young nieces and nephews and the wounding of three other relatives surrendered to the police today. The authorities had searched since Thursday for Henry Curtis Jackson Jr., 26 years old, who they say attacked his sister and six nieces and nephews in his mother's home. They said he had surrendered in West Point, in Clay County. The dead children ranged in age from 2 to 5 years old.

title: EFFORTS AT AMITY FALTER IN ULSTER
description: A two-and-a-half-year-old power-sharing arrangement between Protestant and Roman Catholic political leaders here has been held up as proof that the division between the two religious groups in Northern Ireland can be bridged.

title: Results Plus
description: HORSE RACING Easy Outing for Fourstars Allstar Fourstars Allstar defeated a field of 12 New York-bred 2-year- olds yesterday in the $94,500 Damon Runyon Stakes at Aqueduct. The Leo O'Brien-trained colt, ridden by Mike Smith, won by 2 3/4 lengths, covering the mile over a firm turf course in 1:37 1/5. Irish Linnet held on for second, 1 1/4 lengths in front of Quick Power. Fourstars Allstar earned $56,700 for his owner, Richard Bomze, and paid $2.60 for a $2 win wager. HIGH SCHOOL SOCCER Newark School Claims Boys Title St. Benedict's Academy of Newark, a boys' school with only 435 students, claimed the unofficial title of national schoolboy soccer champions. St. Benedict's had been ranked first, along with Columbia High School of Maplewood-South Orange, in the Gatorade national high school poll organized by the National Soccer Coaches Association. On Sunday, St. Benedict's captured the Essex County boys' high school soccer championship with a 3-2 overtime victory against Columbia.

title: Voters Complain Negative Campaigns Are Driving Them Away
description: At Aunt Millie's Restaurant, a diner in this industrial city 40 miles north of Chicago, Leonard Davis said political advertising had just about persuaded him to stay home on Election Day.

title: Stocks Advance Broadly; Dow Gains 11.39
description: Stocks rose yesterday for the third straight session but trading activity lagged as many investors marked time until after today's elections.

title: Ryder Cup Differences
description: A European golf official threatened yesterday to pull stars like Nick Faldo and Seve Ballesteros out of the Ryder Cup because of rifts between the event's organizing bodies, the Professional Golfers Association and the PGA European Tour.

title: (Class) War in the Gulf
description: The events of these last months in the Persian Gulf have brought to light a problem of the American democracy that all will, I cannot doubt, wish to see corrected once it is fully recognized. Deployed on the sands of Saudi Arabi and facing possible extinction, are young men and women drawn, in the main, from the poorer families of our republic.

title: A LOOK AT NAZI ERA IS URGED IN POLAND
description: In an effort to combat what he called growing anti-Semitic sentiment in Poland, a prominent Roman Catholic clergyman is trying to prompt a critical re-examination of Polish complicity in the Nazi horrors.

title: Saudi Tradition: Edicts From Koran Produce Curbs on Women
description: Saudi society's Government and its restrictions on women are not based on written laws, but on Sharia, the edicts of the 14-century-old Koran. The restrictions spring from interpretations of this Islamic code as offered by senior religious figures, known as the ulemas.

title: Sulaiman Faces Controversy Again
description: This past summer, Jose Sulaiman testified in Federal court that while he had said that he was withholding recognition of James (Buster) Douglas's knockout victory over Mike Tyson back in February, in his heart he really perceived Douglas as the bona fide champion.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Islanders Beat Leafs But Then Who Can't?
description: Two last place teams got together at Nassau Coliseum tonight, and one of them played well enough not to lose.

title: Sondheim's 'Night Music' Set for TV
description: The popularity of Stephen Sondheim has probably never been greater than it is now, with the composer and lyricist bringing out new musicals and theater and opera companies here and in London reviving and sometimes rethinking his older works.

title: Jacques Traubee, Developer, 77
description: Jacques Traubee, a real-estate developer who was also an investor in a number of Broadway productions, died last Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: The 1990 Elections: New York - Bond Acts; Voters Appear to Reject Environmental Measure
description: The proposed $2 billion environmental bond act in New York State appeared headed for defeat early this morning, when state election officials suspended counting returns.

title: Court Limits Awards to Seamen Killed on Job
description: A unanimous Supreme Court ruled today that families of American seamen killed on the job may not be awarded monetary damages for lost future earnings or loss of social ties.

title: The Push to Recycle Newsprint
description: With environmental concerns rising and a growing number of governments requiring publishers to use recycled paper, makers of newsprint in North America are rushing into recycling. After showing little interest for years, they are investing $1.5 billion to $2 billion in equipment that will allow them to use scrap paper as well as trees as raw material.

title: A Move to Define Teaching A Cut Above the Average
description: What does it take to make a great teacher? And once you have one, how do you know?

title: The 1990 Elections: Congress - Washington; Newcomer Elected to Replace Barry, Who Loses Council Bid
description: Voters gave the District of Columbia a political facelift today, handing a newcomer, Sharon Pratt Dixon, an easy victory in the mayor's race and denying Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. the City Council seat he had sought to salvage his tattered career.

title: F. J. Dunnigan, 75, A Retired Executive With Prentice-Hall
description: Frank Joseph Dunnigan, the retired chief executive of the Prentice-Hall book publishing company, died on Sunday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. he was 75 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: U.S. Unlikely to Use Force to Resupply Embassy
description: A United Nations effort to arrange for the resupply of the American and British Embassies in Kuwait has stalled, but Administration officials say they are not likely to use military force to restock the missions with food and other supplies.

title: Treasury Auction Starts Off Well
description: The largest auctions of Treasury debt ever started off well yesterday, as a wide spectrum of investors easily absorbed a record $12.5 billion in three-year notes.

title: In China, Censorship Takes a New Guise
description: To the Editor:

title: Hall Settles
description: Mel Hall, the Yankee outfielder charged with illegally bringing cougar cubs into Connecticut, where he lives, agreed yesterday to pay $2,000 to charity in exchange for having the misdemeanor charges dropped. He bought the cubs in Florida as pets

title: 2-Day Strike Ends at Navistar
description: Negotiators for the Navistar International Corporation reached a tentative agreement on Monday with the United Automobile Workers, ending a strike by 8,000 employees in six states. Details of the agreement were withheld. The employees walked out at midnight Friday after a contract extension expired.

title: Commodities Rise Sends Stocks Tumbling
description: An unexpected rise in commodities prices yesterday pushed bonds lower and sent stocks tumbling.

title: Upset by Beggars, Washington Is Arresting Them
description: Responding to complaints about panhandlers on the street, District of Columbia police officials said today that they had been using an almost-forgotten law to arrest beggars.

title: Lesotho Army Ruler Declares Exiled King to Be Dethroned
description: The military ruler of the southern African nation of Lesotho today declared the exiled King, Moshoeshoe II, dethroned and stripped him of his title of head of state.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Dear Diary:

title: City Jails, Flirting With Disaster
description: New York City's jails are so crowded that wardens are squeezing more beds into tense dormitories and forcing some inmates to sleep on floors. The crisis reflects shaky management that invites disaster.

title: Jacob Slavitt, 83, Dies; Lawyer in New Jersey
description: Jacob Slavitt, a lawyer in New Jersey for more than 50 years and a leader in Jewish charitable affairs, died on Monday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark. He was 83 years old and lived in Verona, N.J.

title: Book Notes
description: A Committed Independent

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Wingate Surrenders
description: David Wingate, a guard with the San Antonio Spurs the last four years, surrendered to Bexar County authorities in San Antonio yesterday on charges of sexually assaulting an unconscious woman at his apartment last June 24.

title: A Militant Leader, Fiery Politician And Founder of Anti-Arab Crusade
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the founder of the Jewish Defense League, who was shot to death in a Manhattan hotel on Monday night, made a long journey from the streets of Brooklyn to a powerful position on the far-right fringes of Israeli politics.

title: Louis Lichtman, Baker, 78
description: Louis Lichtman, a baker who ran a bread and pastry shop on the Upper West Side of Manhattan for 40 years, died on Monday at the Jewish Home and Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Young, Successful But Between Jobs
description: IT was the ideal pairing of young urban professionals: two careers on Wall Street, a wedding, a slice of cake, a short honeymoon and back to the office grind.

title: Richard Lindsay, 85, An Air Force General
description: Richard Clark Lindsay, a retired Air Force lieutenant general who commanded NATO air forces in southern Europe, died Saturday at a Glendale hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: Charles Smith Jr., 62, Boston Executive, Dies
description: Charles L. Smith Jr., a Boston financial executive, died Sunday at his home in Cohasset, Mass. He was 62 years old.

title: A Poor Environment For Republicans
description: To the Editor:

title: The Legacy of Hate
description: The lone gunman who killed Rabbi Meir Kahane in a midtown Manhattan hotel on Monday gave his victim the symbolic death he had long expected. "He knew that someone would shoot him," said Rabbi Kahane's lawyer, Barry Slotnick. But if the assassin hoped to eliminate Meir Kahane as a political force, experience attests that such deeds can backfire.

title: Appeals to Vincent
description: On Sept. 5 and Sept. 28, George Steinbrenner asked Commissioner Fay Vincent for permission to become involved in negotiations with free agents for the Yankees, Steinbrenner said yesterday. He was turned down flatly each time.

title: Patrick May Get $2 Million in New Ranger Contract
description: James Patrick, the Rangers' superb skating defenseman who is one of the team's critical components for long-term success, is on the verge of signing a new contract, one that is likely to keep him a member of the Rangers until 1993.

title: Henry Hoyt, 96, Dies; Headed Drug Company
description: Henry H. Hoyt, a retired chairman of Carter-Wallace, the pharmaceutical and toiletry company, died on Monday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 95 years old.

title: About New York; AIDS Children Get a Little Time As Just Children
description: As if life were kinder, the children devoured fried chicken, painted their faces, shot baskets, listened to African storytellers, danced to rap music, made short work of a homemade gingerbread house.

title: The Pop Life
description: Dance Music With a Zing

title: Baghdad Says It Will Free 78 of 305 Japanese Held
description: Stepping up its policy of using hostage releases to deter a war over Kuwait, Iraq announced today that it would reward the visit to Baghdad of Yasuhiro Nakasone, the former Japanese Prime Minister, by freeing 78 of the 305 Japanese citizens it has held since the Kuwait invasion.

title: Merrill Plans Consolidation
description: Continuing a reorganization of the firm begun last week, Merrill Lynch & Company is planning to consolidate the management of its retail operations, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: From Bitter Seeds, Carrot Cake Empire
description: RENEE ALLEN MANCINO, the proprietor of Carrot Top Pastries in the Bronx, may bake the best carrot cake in the world.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about revisions in the Scholastic Aptitude Test and the Scholastic Achievement Tests given by the College Board referred incorrectly to a proposal to rename them. The proposal, to call them both Scholastic Assessment Tests, has not yet been adopted.

title: The 1990 Elections: The Message - Vermont; Socialist Ex-Mayor Elected to House
description: Bernard Sanders declared victory tonight in his race for the House of Representatives and put "the millionaires and the multinational corporations" on notice that he would be going to Washington.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Rabbi Meir Kahane in some copies yesterday described his education incorrectly. He graduated from the Yeshiva University High School for Boys in 1947. He did not attend the university's college, nor was he ordained at its Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. In addition, the main front-page headline about Rabbi Kahane's death misstated the timing in some copies. He was shot after giving a speech, not during it.

title: Conference on Climate Singles Out U.S. as Wastrel of Energy
description: The United States was depicted as the great polluter among rich nations today at a gathering of about 80 environment ministers, environmental campaigners and industry specialists.

title: Minors Meet To Study Proposal
description: Members of two minor league committees are scheduled to meet in Cincinnati tomorrow to study the player-development proposal from the major leagues. Their assessment of the proposal could determine the immediate future of the minor leagues.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of American forces facing Iraq, referred incorrectly in some editions to the regular tour of duty for Americans in Vietnam. The tour for members of the Army, the Navy, the Air Force and the Coast Guard was 12 months; for the Marines, it was 13 months.

title: New Store On 5th Ave. Is Not Just Any Shop; It's Dior's
description: NEW YORK'S first Christian Dior boutique opened to the public yesterday at 703 Fifth Avenue, at 55th Street. But to the city's worlds of fashion and society, it was a bit anti-climactic. More than 400 people had been given a preview of the shop at a champagne reception Monday evening, and 250 privileged guests attended a black-tie dinner later at the Frick Collection on East 70th Street.

title: Mandatory Retirement Is Age Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: China Hints It Is Ready to Resume Professional Exchange With U.S.
description: In a sign of improving relations with the United States, China has indicated that it is ready to resume participation in a program in which 60 or more Chinese professionals travel to America each year for monthlong visits, an American diplomat said.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Export Development Corporation, created by the Canadian Government to develop trade with other countries, is offering in the United States bond market $200 million in notes, due in 1993, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Justice of Braves Receives Rookie Honor
description: Dave Justice of the Braves, who became a full-time outfielder after Atlanta traded Dale Murphy to the Philadelphia Phillies in early August, earned 23 of the 24 first-place votes and was named the National League rookie of the year yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Erik F. B. Fries, Professor, 91
description: Erik F. B. Fries, a former professor of biology at City College of New York, died last Wednesday at Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Burger King Ads Help End Boycott by Religious Group
description: It was a puzzling declaration with an even more puzzling provenance. The Burger King Corporation, without explanation, took out large advertisements in newspapers all over the country to say that the fast-food company "wishes to go on record as supporting traditional American values on television."

title: The 1990 Election: Nonvoters; Turned Off by Campaigns, Or Just Too Busy to Vote
description: Stephen Smith, a 22-year-old garbage collector in Utica, Mich., is tired of watching candidates "cutting each other down." He liked Ronald Reagan, but looks at the current crop of politicians and says, "You don't know who to believe."

title: America's Real Deficit
description: Are you one of those many Americans who regard driving your car as an inalienable right?

title: OTHER NEWS
description: Exchanges to Stay

title: The 1990 Elections: New York - The Legislature; G.O.P. Adds to Senate Majority While Democrats Keep Control of Assembly
description: The Republicans expanded their majority in the New York Senate yesterday, achieving their main political goal in a year in which they all but conceded the gubernatorial race to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Layoffs Continue at U.P.I.
description: United Press International laid off more employees today, a day after company officials said the news service faced liquidation unless remaining workers accepted a 90-day pay cut of 35 percent.

title: Europeans Reach Accord on Farm Aid; Tepid Reaction in U.S.
description: American trade officials said today the Brussels agreement should forestall an untimely collapse of the Uruguay Round, but they insisted it would have to be sweetened considerably to serve as a basis for future farm negotiations.

title: Trash Hauler In Settlement
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest trash hauler, has agreed to pay several customers $19.5 million to settle price-fixing accusations.

title: The 1990 Elections: Connecticut - Battle for Governor; Weicker Triumphs Narrowly As Loner in a 3-Way Race
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a renegade Republican who formed his own party this spring with a pledge to "deregulate" two-party politics in Connecticut, won a narrow victory yesterday to become the state's first independent governor since the Civil War.

title: Zale Jewelry Retailer Names Top Executive
