description: The Zale Corporation, a jewelry chain owned by Canadian and Swiss interests, yesterday named Dennis S. Bookshester, a former Chicago department store executive, to be president and chief executive.

title: Europeans Reach Accord On Farm Aid
description: After five weeks of wrangling about the future of small farmers, the members of the European Community agreed tonight that reductions in agricultural subsidies should be part of their negotiating position in the current round of worldwide talks aimed at freer trade.

title: G. Malcolm Trout, 94, A Food Scientist, Dies
description: G. Malcolm Trout, professor emeritus of food science and human nutrition at Michigan State University, died last Thursday at Sparrow Hospital in Lansing, Mich. He was 94 years old and lived in East Lansing.

title: Stake in Shawmut Acquired by Tisch
description: Laurence A. Tisch, the chief executive of CBS Inc. and the chairman of the Loews Corporation, has acquired a 5 percent stake in the Shawmut National Corporation, one of New England's largest banking companies, for $33.2 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Tisch said that he had acquired the Shawmut shares as an investment.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about a television mini- series based on the life of William S. Paley misidentified the publisher of "In All His Glory," the biography by Sally Bedell Smith on which it is to be based. It was published this month by Simon & Schuster, not Random House.

title: The 1990 Elections: Connecticut - Congressional Contests; Franks Wins House Seat, Spoiling Moffett's Comeback Effort
description: Connecticut's four incumbent United States Representatives won re-election easily yesterday, while close contests were being waged for the state's two open Congressional seats.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the drivers' union at The Daily News referred incorrectly in some copies to the drivers at Newsday. They are represented by the Graphic Communications International Union, not the Teamsters.

title: Chronicle
description: SAUL BELLOW has won three National Book Awards, more than any other writer. So this year, the National Book Foundation, which sponsors the awards, will give him its medal for distinguished contribution to American letters.

title: The 1990 Elections: State By State; South
description: ALABAMA

title: 5 Local Colleges in Soccer Tourney
description: Five colleges from the New York metropolitan area have been awarded bids to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament, which begins over the weekend.

title: California Says Laos Refugee Group Is a Victim of Leadership's Extortion
description: For years, some members of the most primitive refugee group in America, the Hmong, have complained, mostly in whispers, that the anti-Communist leader who fled here with them from the remote mountains of Laos has been extorting money from them.

title: Lyman Ogilby, 68, Ex-Diocese Leader Of Episcopal Faith
description: The Rev. Lyman Cunningham Ogilby, retired bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania, died on Saturday at Sacred Heart Hospital in Spokane, Wash., where he was attending a consecration. He was 68 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Kahane: More Than A Marginal Figure
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane's murder in a Manhattan hotel Monday night marks the end of a career that feasted on political turmoil, race hatred and violent confrontation. "The worse it gets for Israel, the better it gets for me," he told me in New York shortly after he was elected to the Knesset in 1984. The militant rabbi certainly did everything within his power to make Israel an angrier and more polarized society.

title: An Unlikely Pairing Gets Closer: Golfers and New York
description: In all the 14,870 acres of Manhattan, there is not a square foot of outdoor property set aside for the exclusive purpose of golf. As with most things in New York, opinion is divided as to whether or not this is a bad thing.

title: Columbia Savings Has A Big Loss
description: The financial slide of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association quickened today, as the troubled institution reported a $352 million loss for its third quarter after taking a large write-down in the value of its "junk bond" holdings.

title: Grief and Anger at Kahane's Funeral
description: In a white brick synagogue near his boyhood home in Brooklyn, Rabbi Meir Kahane was eulogized yesterday as a holy man who, like the prophets of old, was often shunned by his people.

title: Wal-Mart Set to Buy Discount Club Chain
description: Wal-Mart Stores, already the operater of the nation's largest chain of wholesale warehouse clubs, will acquire the Wholesale Club Inc., which operates 27 membership clubs, for $21 a share, or a total of $178 million.

title: The 1990 Elections: New Jersey - Congressional Races; Voters Angry, but Not at Incumbents
description: In New Jersey's 14 Congressional races, rendered volatile both by resentment over tax increases wrought by Gov. Jim Florio and general discontent over the performance of Congress, the state's 12 incumbents still fared well, winning all their races.

title: Study Finds Soldiers Healthier Than Civilians
description: The peacetime Army is a healthy alternative to civilian life, say military researchers, who found that soldiers died at half the rate of their civilian counterparts in 1986.

title: Parent of First Boston Plans To Buy Firm's Bridge Loans
description: CS Holdings, the parent of the First Boston Corporation, has decided to step up to the plate to help bail the investment banking firm out of one of its thorniest financial problems.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Savings and loans are trying to get state laws enacted to allow them to convert into savings banks. Regulators see an attempt to evade strict new Federal rules -- laws the S.& L.'s say are so onerous they can no longer do business under them. [ Page D1. ]

title: Kahane Suspect Is a Muslim With a Series of Addresses
description: The suspect in the slaying of the Jewish militant Rabbi Meir Kahane emerged yesterday as an elusive, Egyptian-born devout Muslim who kept to himself and worked for New York City repairing air conditioners in the Criminal Courts building.

title: The 1990 Elections: State By State; West
description: ALASKA

title: The 1990 Elections: Governor - Texas; Fierce Election for Governor Is Narrowly Won by Richards
description: Sounding the populist themes tonight that carried her to a fiercely fought victory in the Texas governor's race, Ann Richards, the Democratic candidate, invited her supporters to join her in a march to the State Capitol and proclaimed, "We're going to take back the Capitol for the people of Texas."

title: International Paper Sets an Acquisition
description: The International Paper Company agreed to buy the graphics business of Cookson Group P.L.C. of Britain for about $215 million. International Paper, based in Purchase, N.Y., said it was buying Cookson Graphics, a supplier of lithographic printing plates, press room chemicals and plate-processing equipment to the commercial printing industry.

title: Dollar Up on Mideast Worry; Election Hedging Also Cited
description: The dollar rose yesterday on worry about the Middle East and on technical buying by traders adjusting their positions in advance of the results of the day's elections.

title: About Education
description: When fear fills the halls of a school or the way to and from school, education is the victim.

title: In Trial on Slaying of Agent, Jurors Spoke of Other Things
description: Jurors who convicted four men this year in crimes linked to the slaying of the Federal drug agent Enrique Camarena Salazar have testified that during deliberations they discussed news accounts of the trial and facts not admitted as evidence.

title: EATING WELL
description: THE 1990 dietary guidelines, announced on Monday by the Federal Departments of Agriculture and Health and Human Services, represent a bold step for the two agencies.

title: A Risky Business for State Farm
description: In normal times, Edward B. Rust Jr., chairman and chief executive of State Farm, would be euphoric about taking policyholders away from rival insurance companies. But times are far from normal in the car insurance business.

title: BRITISH WARNINGS TO IRAQIS ON WAR
description: With expectation growing here that the United States is preparing for an attack against Iraqi forces in Kuwait as early as December, the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, warned President Saddam Hussein today, "Time is ticking on."

title: Chronicle
description: Arch enemies for much of their political careers, BELLA ABZUG and EDWARD I. KOCH are finally getting together. They are to read children's stories at a benefit for the Children's Museum of Manhattan on Nov. 23.

title: Ruby Estate's Executor Removed
description: A lawyer was removed today as executor of Jack Ruby's estate, whose major asset is the .38-caliber Colt Cobra revolver that the Dallas nightclub owner used to kill Lee Harvey Oswald, the Presidential assassin.

title: Moscow Journal; Soviet Students Study the Art of the Deal, Avidly
description: Night school has commenced at Moscow State University, and brilliant malcontents are plotting oligopoly and other coups de grace for Communism.

title: Bridge
description: Whether to defend actively or passively is an ever-recurring problem for the defenders. Each case must be considered on its merits, but there are some tendencies worth noting: No-trump contracts and unbalanced hands both hint at active defense; trump contracts and balanced hands both hint at passive defense.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Who am I voting in? I'm voting another bum in." -- Stephen Smith of Utica, Mich., who did not vote. [ B1:4. ]

title: OTHER HIGHLIGHTS
description: CONNECTICUT Weicker Beats 2 Rivals As an Independent

title: The 1990 Elections: New York - Secession;   Staten Island Votes a Resounding Yes on Taking Step Toward Separation
description: Staten Island voted overwhelmingly yesterday to begin a process that could lead the borough to secede from New York City.

title: ANOTHER SETBACK FOR INDIA'S LEADER
description: On the eve of a crucial vote of confidence, the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh suffered another setback today when the leader of the opposition, Rajiv Gandhi, gave a guarded pledge of support to forces expected to challenge Mr. Singh for leadership of the Government.

title: Southern Lebanon Shiite Militias Sign Peace Pact
description: Lebanon's two main Shiite Muslim militias signed a peace accord Monday night in Damascs, Syria, under the supervision of top Iranian and Syrian officials, security officials said today, apparently ending their three-year struggle for supremacy over a strategic southern Lebanese region adjacent to Israel.

title: Asbestos Plan Is Set Back
description: A group of seven lawyers who each represent thousands of asbestos victims voted unanimously yesterday to oppose a class action settlement proposed by Eagle-Picher Industries.

title: The 1990 Elections: Governors - Florida; CHILES TRIUMPHS ON LITTLE MONEY
description: In a race that was viewed by many as an experiment in American politics, former Senator Lawton Chiles was elected Governor of Florida today, easily defeating the Republican incumbent, Gov. Bob Martinez.

title: Fire Roars Across Lot at Universal Studios
description: A roaring fire fanned by gusty winds broke out tonight at Universal Studios, burning an unknown number of buildings at the 420-acre complex and forcing an evacuation of the studio lot and Universal's amusement park.

title: The 1990 Elections: New Jersey - Senate Race; Bradley, Heavily Favored, Narrowly Defeats Whitman
description: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, one of the national stars of the Democratic Party, won a slender victory last night over a little-known opponent, stunning political professionals and pollsters who had shown him heading toward re-election in a walk.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Congress; Helms and Other Incumbents Manage to Hold On
description: In a day of dramatic struggle and unexpected twists, Senator Jesse Helms prevailed over his Democratic opponent, Harvey Gantt in North Carolina yesterday, while Senator Bill Bradley beat back a surprisingly powerful challenge from Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican, in New Jersey.

title: Food Styling: The Art Of Making the Basil Blush
description: LIGHTS. Camera. Act . . .

title: Baker Gets Help From China on Gulf
description: China's Foreign Minister signaled to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that Beijing would not block the United Nations Security Council from authorizing force against Iraq if diplomacy proved futile, a senior Administration official said.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Cuomo Lags Behind '86 Showing; Regan Is the Victor Over Bellamy
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo easily won a third term against weak and divided opposition yesterday but fell short of his overwhelming victory of four years ago.

title: The 1990 Elections: The Message - The President; Bush, Absent From Ballot, Stands in Line to Cast One
description: Being President has its perks, but going to the head of a line at the polling center is not one of them.

title: In Israel, Kahane's Slaying Stirs No Wide Violence
description: The police were deployed across the city early today to deter an angry backlash within a few hours of Rabbi Meir Kahane's death, and in the West Bank, two elderly Palestinians were shot to death.

title: Bigger Note Issue By Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation is offering $150 million in subordinated notes through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Originally, the size of the issue by the Los Angeles-based bank holding company was $100 million, but because of good investor demand it was increased, underwriters said.

title: Continental Posts a Loss
description: Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. lost $88.3 million in the third quarter as higher fuel prices increased costs, the company said today.

title: Strong Quake Near Aleutians
description: A strong earthquake struck west of the Aleutian Islands today, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The quake, which hit at 11:14 A.M., measured 6.7 on the Richter scale, said Bob Hammond of the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer. It was centered about 150 miles west of Attu Island, 1,250 miles southwest of Anchorage.

title: Sale of FNN Is Expected
description: The Financial News Network, the troubled cable news service, is expected to be put up for sale, an executive familiar with the plan said yesterday.

title: Rich Japanese Beef's Here. Call It Wagyu.
description: To many Americans, the city of Kobe in Japan is synonymous with the most succulent and costly beef in the world, but now that the beef is available in the United States, the importers, Zen-Noh Unico America, want it properly identified.

title: The 1990 Elections: New York - House Races; Easy Victories For Incumbents In the Congress
description: New York's 34 incumbents in the House of Representatives were re-elected yesterday, many by overwhelming margins.

title: Quake Strikes Iran; At Least 20 Said to Die
description: A major earthquake struck a mountainous area in southern Iran tonight, the United States Geological Survey said. A preliminary report indicated that at least 20 people had been killed.

title: Don't Retreat Now on New York City Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Correction
description: Yesterday's list of Connecticut candidates endorsed by The Times misidentified the Democrat running for lieutenant governor. She is Sandra Bender.

title: Yields at 8.431% to 9.62% On Offering by Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday priced its $850 million two-part offering of callable debentures through various securities dealers.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Campbell Soup Co. is offering $100 million in 9 percent notes, due in 1997, at 99.74 to yield 9.05 percent, through Morgan Stanley & Co. The notes are noncallable and rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA by S.&P. * Fuji Bank's New York branch, acting as agent bank, has closed a $45 million syndication of financing to National Westminster Bank and Deutsche Bank for a new electric plant owned by Pure Air on the Lake Ltd., Allentown, Pa., an affiliate of Air Products and Chemicals Inc. and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries America Inc. * LDDS Communications Inc., Jackson, Miss., announced that because of market conditions it was withdrawing from a proposed offering of $50 million in convertible subordinated debentures and 1.4 million common shares. COMMON STOCK * Health Risk Management Inc., Minneapolis, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 1.2 million common shares, through Wessels, Arnold & Henderson. RATINGS * Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc.'s senior unsecured note rating has been lowered to CCC, from B-, and the subordinated debt rating to CCC-, from CCC+, by S.&P. The company is based in Orlando, Fla. * Pontiac, Mich.'s general obligation rating on unlimited tax bonds has been lowered to BB+, from BBB, by S.&P., which also reduced the rating of limited tax general obligation bonds to BB, from BBB-. * Tucson Electric Power Co.'s debt rating is under review with negative implications by Moody's.

title: Auction of Postwar Art Falls Short of Estimate
description: The November art auctions began last night with dealers and collectors watching, not bidding, at Sotheby's in New York in a sale of postwar art at which fewer than half of the works offered -- 34 out of 77 -- were sold. The total for the sale was $19.8 million -- only half of the low end of the house presale estimate. Sotheby's had expected the sale to bring $39.6 million to $52 million.

title: Cuts at Prudential-Bache Raise Questions on Chief
description: The most extensive and costly program undertaken by George L. Ball since he became chairman of Prudential-Bache Securities has ended in failure, renewing questions on Wall Street about Mr. Ball's future with the firm.

title: U.S. Investigates the Cost of Research at Stanford
description: Three Federal investigations are under way to determine whether Stanford University overcharged the Government tens of millions of dollars for research done on its campus in the last decade.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: BLACKS BOYCOTT SCHOOLS IN MIAMI
description: Black students, teachers and bus drivers boycotted Dade County schools today as a protest against what they said had been a succession of racist affronts.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Oct. 10 about Japanese corporate involvment in United States sports misidentifed the company that tried to buy the Dallas Cowboys. It was the Seibu Railway Group, not the Seibu Saison Group.

title: Topics of The Times; Greening of the Golden Arch
description: The McDonald's Corporation, which each day serves its global clientele more than 20 million Big Macs, Quarter Pounders, Egg McMuffins, Chicken McNuggets and McChicken Sandwiches, is the unquestioned king of the fast food business. Less happily, McDonald's is among the most visible and widely criticized symbols of America's throwaway society. Now, however, McDonald's is at last showing some McSense on the environment.

title: Karpov Holds Ground in Game 11 Against Daring Kasparov Attack
description: A bold idea, a flight of fantasy, a brief flurry of excitement -- all it got Gary Kasparov on Monday night was an entertaining draw in Game 11 of the World Championship Chess Match in Manhattan. The stolid Anatoly Karpov held his ground against all the champion's machinations and could neither be overwhelmed by force nor lured into error. In the end, Kasparov was obliged to bring about a draw by threatening perpetual check.

title: Emerson Profit Rises 3.3%
description: The Emerson Electric Company today reported a 3.3 percent rise in fourth-quarter profits and a record annual profit for the 33d consecutive year.

title: Fugitive German Spy Planning to Surrender After Elections
description: East Germany's former master spy, Markus Wolf, who is in hiding, said today that he intended to return to Germany and hand himself over to the justice authorities after the reunited country holds elections in December.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Dear Diary:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Penguins Rally to Top Flames

title: Soviet Rookie Seems Made for N.H.L.
description: Sergei Fedorov of the Detroit Red Wings speaks Russian better than English. The security guards at Montreal's Dorval Airport prefer French. But when Fedorov joked with a Swedish teammate about "a bomb" earlier this week, the guards understood.

title: Postal Service Gets a 'Low B' in Mail Delivery Test
description: The Postal Service delivered about four-fifths of overnight mail on time in its first test by an outside consultant, a performance that the Postmaster General said today earned the agency a "low B."

title: Waiting, Eagerly, for Disaster to Hit
description: Disasters are Richard Zane's business, and business has been booming since a blackout on Wall Street in August caused palpitations or total arrest in 300 computer centers whose whirring hum is the modern company's heartbeat.

title: Alvin Z. Halpern, Executive, 65
description: Alvin Z. Halpern, a retired textile company executive, died on Sunday at his home in Bay Harbor Island, Fla. He was 65 years old.

title: New Pakistani Premier Is Sworn In
description: Nawaz Sharif, who led a rightist coalition to a landslide victory in elections last month, was sworn in as Prime Minister today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Atlantis Group Inc., Miami, said it had received an offer from management of the companies in its furniture group to buy the unit for $25 million. * Flow International Corp., Kent, Wash., a manufacturer of water-jet and abrasive-jet cutting equipment, said it had ended its efforts to find a buyer for the company. * General Development Corp., Miami, a community development and real estate concern, said its shareholders were not likely to receive any distribution in its pending bankruptcy proceedings. * Harleysville Group Inc., Harleysville, Pa., a holding company, said it had ended talks on the acquisition of Hawkeye-Security Insurance Co., a unit of USLico Corp., and on the sale of its Harleysville Life Insurance Co. to USLico. * Maxwell Communication Corp., London, announced that its independent shareholders had approved the sale of its interests in Quebecor Printing Inc. and Donohue Inc., Quebec, a newsprint and lumber company, to Mirror Group P.L.C. * May Department Stores Co., St. Louis, said it had completed a spinoff of its wholly owned Venture Stores Inc. discount retail subsidiary by distributing more than 16 million shares of Venture common stock to May shareholders. * McCall Pattern Co., New York, said it had completed its reorganization under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code and had been acquired by an investment group organized by Dimeling, Schreiber & Park, a Philadelphia-based partnership. * Morgan Keegan Inc., Memphis, a brokerage, announced an agreement in principle under which it would acquire substantially all the operating assets of Scharff & Jones, a New Orleans-based brokerage. * Pitney Bowes Inc., Stamford, Conn., says 100 workers at its distribution center will lose their jobs by early December as a result of a decision to close an operation that refurbished used copier equipment. * San Jacinto Savings Association, Houston, a wholly owned subsidiary of Southmark Corp., said that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its 68.8 percent interest in Thousand Trails Inc., Bellevue, Wash., a resort campground concern, and certain assets of American National Corp., Omaha, a bank holding company, to Delta Campground Management Corp. * Union Carbide Corp., Danbury, Conn., formed a joint venture with three partners to build a new plant in Alberta for $350 million.

title: Dozier Signs
description: D.J. Dozier, who led Minnesota in rushing last year, signed a contract with the Vikings yesterday. He had been a conditional free agent after having requested a trade to another team. Dozier ended up playing baseball this summer with the Mets' team in the instructional league. (AP)

title: Bennett to Resign as Director Of U.S. Drug Control Effort
description: William J. Bennett has told President Bush that he intends to resign as the nation's leading anti-drug fighter, an Administration official said last night.

title: Play Proves Its Point in Obscurity
description: The playwright Sophie Treadwell died at the age of 85 in 1970, "but everywhere in her play, you keep discovering Sophie," the director Michael Greif was saying about her expressionist drama, "Machinal." "Whenever you're in doubt, Sophie makes it so very easy for you. She thought of everything."

title: Rams Waive Warner
description: Curt Warner, the running back who signed a $700,000 contract with the Los Angeles Rams during the off season, was waived by the team yesterday. Warner, 29, had signed with the Rams as a free agent after playing seven seasons with the Seattle Seahawks. Warner played in seven games this season, rushing 49 times for 139 yards and a touchdown. The Rams are expected to activate the former Oklahoma running back Marcus Dupree. (AP)

title: The 1990 Elections: Connecticut - Renegade's Victory Man in The News: Lowell Palmer Weicker Jr.; The Independence of a Maverick Republican
description: Even for Lowell P. Weicker Jr., tested by three stormy terms in the United States Senate, a prominent role in the Watergate hearings, and a brief run for President, the scene that unfolded in a packed conference room in the State Capitol on March 2 signaled the start of an unparalleled political adventure.

title: Day of Decision: What Decision?
description: What did yesterday's election prove? Nothing, except that when voters are not given choices to make, they cannot make them. And since there were so few truly contested races either in New York or elsewhere in the country, there's little point in consulting the sum of the parts.

title: Giants Become Believers in Themselves
description: The Giants are getting good news from all directions.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M.

title: 2 Girls Stabbed to Death in Bronx Robbery
description: Two teen-age girls were stabbed to death yesterday afternoon at an apartment complex in the Bronx in what was believed to have been a robbery, the police said.

title: In Mexico, Machismo Slows Family Planning
description: Nearly two decades after the authorities here embarked on a sweeping program of public-sponsored birth control, Mexico has become a model of effective third-world family planning.

title: Books of The Times; Grandeur and a Joan of Arc Complex
description: De Gaulle The Rebel, 1890-1944 By Jean Lacouture Translated by Patrick O'Brian. Illustrated. 615 pages. W. W. Norton . $29.95.

title: Wary Enthusiasm at GATT
description: The European Community's agreement on the terms of a proposal for cutting barriers to farm trade was greeted with cautious enthusiasm tonight at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 105-nation organization that is responsible for the Uruguay Round of world trade liberalization talks.

title: Dr. Edward F. Falsey, Psychiatrist, 80, Dies
description: Dr. Edward F. Falsey, a psychiatrist and educator, died on Saturday at the Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 80 years old and lived in Brooklyn. He died of a heart attack, his daughter, Elizabeth, said.

title: Oil Price, a New Blow to Central Americans
description: The crisis in the Middle East has set off a new round of inflation throughout Central America, wreaking havoc with ambitious economic development efforts and threatening to plunge the region into a full depression.

title: The 1990 Elections: State By State; Midwest
description: ILLINOIS

title: Nets on Brink of Record to Forget
description: The game was still a game with under five minutes remaining when Muggsy Bogues turned it into his own private show while the Nets played like rejects from a basketball clinic.

title: Mandatory Retirement Is Age Discrimination; Study and Reflection
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Simulating Competition
description: DO consumers still benefit from the regulation of long-distance phone rates? Not so long ago the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was almost universally regarded as a puma amidst newborn kittens -- a powerful beast, whose predatory instincts made it untrustworthy out of sight of its Government keepers.

title: Page By Page
description: Governors Democrats surprised Republicans in two important states, Florida, where Lawton Chiles defeated the incumbent Republican Bob Martinez, and Texas, where Ann Richards defeated Clayton Williams. An in New York Mario M. Cuomo won re-election easily [ Page A1. ] Incumbents lost in several other states, including Rhode Island where Bruce Sundlun defeated the Republican Edward Di Prete, and Kansas, where a Democrat, Joan Finney, ousted Mike Hayden. In Ohio, Republican George Voinovich, the former mayor of Cleveland, defeated a Democrat. [ B2. ] Congress In the bitter Senate race in North Carolina, Sen. Jesse Helms defeated his Democratic challenger, Harvey Gantt. No incumbent Senator lost a seat, and only a few Representatives did. Massachusetts Sen. John Kerry won re-election, as did Sen. Bill Bradley in New Jersey. [ A1. ] Other Democratic Senators who defeated challengers included Claiborn Pell in Rhode Islnd, Joseph R. Biden Jr., in Delaware and Paul Simon in Illinois. [ B3. ] State By State Marion S. Barry Jr., lost his bid for City Council seat in the District of Columbia, while Sharon Pratt Dixon, a Democrat, won Mr. Barry's former job as Mayor of the District. In a Vermont Congressional race, the Republican incumbent, Peter Smith, lost to Bernard Sanders, a self-proclaimed socialist running as an independent who will sit with the Democrats in Washington. [ B4-5. ] The Message Disenchanted with the American electoral process, many voters did not go to the polls. [ B1. ] President Bush's prestige suffered with Republican losses, although his advisers loudly suggested otherwise. [ A1,B6. ] New York Staten Island voters overwhelming cast ballots in favor of taking the first step toward secession from New York City. [ B7. ] Republicans retained control of the New York State Senate. [ B9. ] Connecticut Running as an independent, Lowell P. Weicker, Jr., defeated the Democratic and Republican nominees to become Governor. [ B9. ] New Jersey Overcoming a surprisingly stiff challenge from the Republican candidate, Christine Whitman, Sen. Bill Bradley won re-election. [ B10. ]

title:
Real Estate;
New Project At Site Near Co-op City
description: A MANHATTAN-BASED development company that has done extensive commercial and residential development in the Bronx intends to build retail and office space on a large stretch of city-owned land near Co-op City in the northeast Bronx.

title: 4 Exchanges Spurn Moving To New Jersey
description: Spurning an offer to cross the Hudson to New Jersey, leaders of New York's commodities exchanges said yesterday that they would recommend that their new headquarters be built in lower Manhattan, home to the exchanges for more than a century.

title: The 1990 Elections: Television; Networks Quietly Abandon Competition and United to Survey Voters
description: Most of the millions of television viewers probably did not know it, but the networks last night made a major shift in their election-night reporting by declaring a truce in their traditional competition to be the first to declare winners in close races.

title: Islamic Politics Drive Away Allies of the Sudan
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, came here not long ago for what was supposed to be a celebration of his Sudanese neighbors' decision to adopt, in part, his political system.

title: The 1990 Elections: Congress - North Carolina; Helms, Basking in Victory, Taunts 'Ultra-Liberal' Foes
description: In a bitter race that ended in a welter of racial discord, Senator Jesse Helms staved off a challenge tonight from his Democratic opponent, Harvey Gantt, to win a fourth term in the Senate.

title: Louisville Gas Bonds
description: A $100 million issue of tax-exempt bonds for Trimble, Ky., was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The pollution-control revenue bonds, due in 2020, were issued on behalf of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company and were given an interest rate of 7.625 percent to be offered at par. Underwriters said the bonds for some investors might be subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax.

title: Lehman Leads New York Issue
description: Lehman Brothers announced yesterday that it had been chosen by New York City to be the lead manager of the city's $1.3 billion offering of revenue anticipation notes on Nov. 19.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ajay Sports Inc., Delavan, Wis., appointed Michael S. Casazza president and chief executive of its leisure products unit. * Consolidated Rail Corp., Philadelphia, named Baxter D. Wellmon assistant vice president. R. Paul Carey was given the new position of general manager in charge of route optimization, and Paul T. Jones Jr. was appointed manager of Conrail's minority vendor program. * Foster Wheeler Energy Corp., Clinton, N.J., designers of steam-generating equipment for electric utilities, named Fred M. Talmud vice president for contract operations. * Giga-Tronics Inc., Pleasant Hill, Calif., a microwave signal generation and measurement instruments ccompany, named Robert Bertsch vice president of manaufacturing. * Irwin Toy Ltd., Toronto, appointed George MacDonald Irwin president, replacing Samuel MacDonald Irwin, who is becoming co-chairman.

title: Miscellany
description: * Gannett Co. formed a cross-media advertising network called Gannettwork, to allow advertisers to design special multimedia packages that could include advertising placed in Gannett's newspapers, billboards and radio and television stations. * Merchandising Corporation of America, a unit of MCA Inc., signed an agreement with New Age Pad and Paper, a division of Colad Group, that allows New Age to use the cartoon character Woody Woodpecker on a new line of environmentally safe school supplies.

title: For Support on Iraq, Syria Gets Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: The 1990 Elections: Connecticut; Panel Raises Questions For Connecticut Courts
description: A limited staff, outdated computer systems and a shortage of other resources may be influencing the quality of Connecticut's court system, a commission said in its initial findings.

title: Union Panel Sends Contract to Workers At Chrysler for Vote
description: The United Automobile Workers' bargaining council for the Chrysler Corporation has approved a new three-year contract that the union's negotiators reached with the auto maker last week.

title: Mexico Features Its Culture In New Tourism Campaign
description: MEXICO is trying to change its image, and to do so has enlisted the singer Linda Ronstadt in a campaign for the Ministry of Tourism estimated to cost $10 million.

title: A Music Lovers' Mecca Is Closing
description: What William Lerner set out to create, when he opened the Music Masters record store in 1956, was a place that would serve the music world the same way the nearby Algonquin Hotel served the literary crowd.

title: Europe Backs U.S. Solvent
description: The European Community's Executive Commission said today that it was satisfied that imports of an organic solvent from the United States would not threaten the trade bloc's chemical industry.

title: Review/Music; Claire Bloom in a Twist on Homer
description: From this distance in time, it is not easy to understand why Richard Strauss at the artistically mature age of 33 should have felt impelled to set Tennyson's narrative poem "Enoch Arden" as a melodrama for piano solo and speaking voice. Perhaps his understanding of the English language was less than firm in 1897, when this Opus 38 was committed. Just before taking up this breathtakingly mawkish example of Victorian sentimentality, the composer had certified his artistry with the tone poems "Till Eulenspiegel" and "Don Quixote.'

title: Critic's Notebook; Reagan, the Author, Tours TV Talk Shows
description: Ronald Reagan is observing the publication of his memoirs, "An American Life," in American style. He is appearing every day this week on ABC's "Good Morning America," where Charles Gibson propels him through his career in five-minute segments. Last Friday, he submitted to Barbara Walters on "20/20." And the next two Saturdays will find him on Channel 13 at 10 A.M., participating in "Two Friends Talk: Ronald Reagan and William F. Buckley Jr." These encounters, which are not so much interviews as ceremonial gestures, reveal as much about the performing styles of the hosts as about the condition of the guest.

title: Mandatory Retirements Is Age Discrimination; Pursuit of Happiness
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniel Sanchez Flores Political Cartoonist, 30
description: Daniel Sanchez Flores, a political cartoonist, known throughout Latin America by his penname, Roger, has died of cancer, the newspaper Barricada reported Monday. He was 30.

title: With Faint Blush, I.R.S. Sells a Brothel
description: When it comes to selling a brothel, the Internal Revenue Service is drawing a few lines.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: SHELL steak goes by several names, including New York steak and club steak. Whatever it is called, the meat should be very tender, since it comes from the short loin, one of the most succulent cuts of beef. I have a particular weakness for shell steak au poivre, which is quick and simple to prepare.

title: Chronicle
description: While perhaps not quite in the same league, BARBARA CARTLAND has just hammered out her 500th high romance, assuring her status as the world's top-selling author. The Guinness Book of World Records credits her with 500 million copies in 27 languages.

title: The 1990 Elections: State By State; Northeast
description: CONNECTICUT

title: Market Place; At Nortek, a Handsome Going-Away Gift
description: Ralph R. Papitto is leaving Nortek Inc., a company he built on debt and whose continued operations, some analysts say, are threatened by that debt. As a going-away present, Mr. Papitto is receiving $16 million, largely because he is being allowed to sell his shares for a price several times that available to public shareholders.

title: The 1990 Elections: New York - Comptroller Contest; Regan Edges Bellamy in Closest Race in 12 Years
description: The New York State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, claimed a cliffhanger re-election victory this morning, turning back the toughest challenge he has faced in his 12 years in office and preserving the Republicans' sole hold on a statewide office.

title: Once Again, Knicks Squander a Lead
description: In their three games this season, the Knicks have let leads slip away as easily as a wet bar of soap.

title: Boeing Cargo Jets Ordered by U.P.S.
description: United Parcel Service Inc. has ordered 25 Boeing 757 jet freighters, Boeing said. The total value of the order, including spare parts, is about $1.7 billion. Fifteen of the orders were converted from options U.P.S. held for the twin-engine midsized jets.

title: Celtics Beat Bulls At Buzzer
description: Brian Shaw's layup at the buzzer capped Boston's comeback from an 11-point fourth-quarter deficit and gave the Celtics a 110-108 victory tonight over the Chicago Bulls, who have yet to win a game this season.

title: Ousted General Gets a Break
description: Over the objection of the Senate, President Bush has extended the service of the former Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Michael J. Dugan, who was dismissed in September for publicly discussing contingency plans for waging war against Iraq.

title: Award for Buoniconti
description: Nick Buoniconti, a former all-American with Notre dame and All-Pro linebacker, with the Patriots and Dolphins, was named the 1990 Walter Camp Man of the Year yesterday. He was cited for his work with the Miami Project to Cure Paralysis and will receive the award at the 24th Annual Walter Camp All-America Banquet on Feb. 16 at Yale University. (AP)

title: The 1990 Elections: Connecticut; New Air Terminal Is Voted
description: Westchester County voters today narrowly approved a $21 million bond issue for a new passenger terminal at Westchester County Airport. The 41,000-square-foot structure is four times the size of a Quonset hut that has served as a temporary terminal since World War II.

title: Zenith Awarded Grant for HDTV
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation received a $1 million grant from Illinois to develop manufacturing processes for high-definition television monitors. The grant from the Illinois Technology Challenge Grant Program will augment Zenith's $50 million commitment to the emerging television technology.

title: Ex-Militia Chief to Fight Decision Barring Him From Haiti Election
description: The former leader of a feared militia that operated under the Duvalier dictatorship said today that he would appeal a decision by the country's election council to bar him from the presidential election next month.

title: Effort to Trim BellSouth Staff
description: The BellSouth Corporation said today that it would offer a special early retirement option to some managers in an attempt to cut its management staff by 3,000, or about 10 percent.

title: Interco May Sell Its Converse Unit
description: Interco Inc. reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might be forced to sell its Converse athletic footwear business to ease the debt burden it incurred to avoid a hostile takeover in 1988. The St. Louis-based footwear and furniture maker said it would put Converse up for sale if its plans to sell $140 million in other assets falls short of expectations and its earning and cash flow do not exceed current expectations.

title: Unusual and Tasty Gifts Can Have Tasteful Prices
description: AS the flamboyant 80's give way to the frugal 90's, flaunting it has been replaced by hiding it. And though there will always be people who can afford a special gift from Neiman Marcus -- perhaps an antique gypsy wagon for $85,000 -- and though Van Cleef & Arpels is in no danger of going out of business, many people are cutting back.

title: Wine Talk
description: JUST as every bird has its own individual song, there is also the unique call of the wine merchant. There are many variations, but basically it goes like this: "Better buy now. Wine of this quality comes along once in a lifetime. There is hardly any left and the price is going up next month."

title: Review/Film; The Human Comedy, as Observed By a Dog Who Takes It Seriously
description: Like "Lassie," "Baxter" is a movie about a dog, but, unlike the mannerly collie of the children's classic, Baxter is a rude, questing mind inhabiting the stocky, dirty-white body of a bull terrier.

title: The 1990 Elections: The Message; A Quiet Day For Quayle
description: After casting his vote in his hometown of Huntington, Ind., this morning, Vice President Dan Quayle spent a quiet morning before returning to Washington to catch up on paperwork, his press secretary, David Beckwith, said.

title: Mail-Order Eating, From Stew to Nuts
description: Mail-order items from these companies were sampled by Marian Burros. The ones here were selected from several dozen products bought in recent months. 1. JAMISON FARM , 171 Jamison Lane, Latrobe, Pa. 15650; (800) 237-LAMB.

title: Complaints, but More Power for China Leader
description: One of the puzzles of the Chinese political system is that Prime Minister Li Peng seems to gain power along with unpopularity. The more he is mocked and reviled, the more he seems able to consolidate his authority.

title: Saudi Women Take Driver's Seat in a Rare Protest for the Right to Travel
description: In daring defiance of the Saudi tradition against women driving, about 70 veiled Saudi women gathered on Tuesday in front of a supermarket in Riyadh, dismissed their drivers and drove in a convoy of cars before being stopped and and detained by the police a short time later.

title: Ford to Get Unit Of Marine Midland
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company will acquire a subsidiary of Marine Midland Banks Inc. to develop non-Ford business, the companies announced. The new business will continue for now as the Marine Midland Automotive Financial Corporation. Later, its name will be changed and headquarters will be established in Nashville. The acquisition price was not released.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: The Nation; DEMOCRATS RETAIN GRIP ON CONGRESS, TAKE TOP POSTS IN TEXAS AND FLORIDA; CUOMO RE-ELECTED, BRADLEY SURVIVES
description: Democrats captured the governorships of two Sun Belt states that will play key roles in the battle over reapportionment, while retaining their strong hold on the Congress yesterday in midterm elections.

title: Barnes Claims Testing For Steroids Was Flawed
description: In his defense against charges that he tested positive for an anabolic steroid after a track meet last August in Sweden, Randy Barnes contended that the urine sample containing the drug cannot be proved to have been his.

title: Automating the Lonely Photo Booth
description: The lonely cashier in the one-hour photo booth may become even lonelier after automated machines that handle film orders are installed in several shopping malls and supermarkets next year.

title: People
description: * Timothy J. Sickinger has been made an executive vice president at Bozell. * Jean de Yturbe has been named chief executive of Eurocom's worldwide advertising network, known as Eurocom WCRS Della Femina Ball. * Stew Sherling has been promoted to senior vice president at Leo Burnett Co., Chicago. * Cynthia Styx has been made a vice president at J. Walter Thompson in Chicago. * Jay MacDonald has been appointed associate publisher and director of marketing for Inc. magazine, a publication of Goldhirsh Group, Boston. Mr. McDonald had been publisher of Business Month, which ceased publishing recently.

title: Black Journalists Won't Assist News
description: Bowing to a torrent of criticism, the National Association of Black Journalists yesterday rescinded a decision to give The Daily News a list of its members, which the paper planned to use to find permanent replacements for striking newsroom employees.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: The Implications; Much Ventured, for Little
description: Like many a President before him, George Bush proved unable to move the political heavens on Tuesday.

title: S.& L.'s Seek State Charters
description: From New Jersey to Texas to California, savings and loan institutions are trying to get state laws enacted that would allow them to convert into savings banks. Federal regulators say this is an attempt to evade strict new Federal rules -- laws that the savings institutions say are so onerous they can no longer do business under them.

title: Productivity on the Increase But Hours Worked Decline
description: The productivity of American workers climbed at the fastest pace in two years during the July-September quarter, but hours worked fell, the Government said today, in a sign that the economic slowdown is forcing businesses to make do with fewer employees.

title: Tenneco Unit Plans Western Pipeline
description: Tenneco Inc. said a subsidiary had ordered pipe for a 904-mile, $940 million natural gas pipeline from Wyoming to California. The pipeline will deliver gas to the heavy oil fields of Kern County, Calif., where it will be burned to make steam for enhanced oil recovery.

title: Food Notes
description: Plump Loaves

title: The Pepper In the Giants' Defense
description: The soul of the Giants is their linebackers. Even with Carl Banks out with a damaged left wrist, no other National Football League team has a pride of linebackers quite like them. Lawrence Taylor still defines the outside linebacker. And now Pepper Johnson has emerged as a force.

title: Key Rates
The 1990 Elections: New York - Cuomo's Re-election Unchallenged Victor; A Mismatched Race Against Rinfret Left the Governor Largely Untested
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was re-elected last night after a campaign that offered little challenge to his political endurance, scant scrutiny of his record and almost no test of his stature as a potential presidential candidate.

title: Afrikaner Cleric Asks Blacks to Forgive
description: A prominent Afrikaner theologian surprised a multiracial church conference discussing South Africa's future today when he stood and begged black churchmen to forgive him and other Afrikaner communicants of the Dutch Reformed Church for having condoned apartheid.

title: College Said to Offer a Deal to Ex-Chief Ousted in a Scandal
description: American University's trustees were reported tonight to have offered a $1 million settlement to Richard Berendzen, who was forced to resign as the university's president last spring after it was discovered that he had used his office telephone to make obscene calls to women.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Carter Hawley Official Will Lead Stor Chain
description: Richard F. Clayton, vice chairman and chief operating officer of the Broadway, the largest department store chain in Southern California, is leaving to become chairman and chief executive of Stor Furnishings International Inc., a specialty home-furnishings chain based in Industry, Calif., south of Los Angeles.

title: Dealers Cite Warnings On Selling The News
description: Liz Willis, a newsstand operator who has been around long enough now to live through two major newspaper strikes, hasn't seen a copy of The Daily News near her stand for almost two weeks. And that's just fine with her.

title: Two Missing Landslides
description: Two of the Democratic Party's most promising candidates stumbled Tuesday on the road to the 1992 convention. In view of their overwhelming victories the last time each ran, landslides seemed certain for both Mario Cuomo and Bill Bradley. Both won; but, as Mr. Bradley might say about a sloppy basketball game, they "won ugly" -- and certainly not by landslides.

title: Reputed Crime Figure Is Found Slain in Car
description: A reputed captain of the Gambino organized crime family who was acquitted on narcotics trafficking charges recently was found shot to death on Tuesday in his car in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Poll of Voters In North Carolina
Bush May Meet Gorbachev
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 The White House said today that President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union would probably meet in Paris this month. The two will be in Paris to attend the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and to sign a treaty cutting nonnuclear forces in Europe. Mr. Bush also plans stops in Czechoslovakia, Germany, Saudi Arabia and Egypt during his trip, which is scheduled to begin Nov. 16. - EVOLUTION IN EUROPE

title: Amid Some Strong Play, Knicks Struggle on Defense
description: After their 1-2 start, the last thing the Knicks want to do is panic. There will be plenty of time for that if their play doesn't improve.

title: The 1990 Campaign: Moments to Remember, Moments Best Forgotten
description: Politicians take a binary view of their work -- it is either win or lose. After election day, winners, in particular, prefer to put the sordid business of campaigning behind them and get on with the sordid business of governing. The election of 1990, however, brought out so many odd notions, weird statements and inglorious actions that it seems a shame to just stow them away.

title: An Outcry From the Saudis' Liberal Minority
description: A day after 70 women openly challenged the ban on driving by women, it is still not clear whether their move was a giant stride for Saudi society.

title: Review/Dance; A Post-Modernist Revival
description: David Gordon was a major participant in the post-modernist dance experiments of the 1960's. But aside from its introduction of "real life" elements into the dance, his "Framework" is a far cry from the scruffy iconoclasm of that era. Polished, elegant and full of assured humanity, the piece has become a signature work for Mr. Gordon. And so his revival this year of "Framework" and "TV Reel," another classic from the early 1980's, was welcome news.

title: Smith Corona Says 2 Nations 'Dump' Word Processors
description: The Smith Corona Corporation said yesterday that it has filed an "anti-dumping" petition with the Commerce Department, claiming that producers from Singapore and Japan were selling personal word processors at unfairly low prices in the United States.

title: Abrams Bars Trump From Selling Condos On Upper East Side
description: The New York State Attorney General has told Donald J. Trump that he may not close on any sales contracts at his new East Side condominium building until he proves that he has enough money to pay the common charges, real-estate taxes and other obligations on the building.

title: High Blood Pressure: An Overtreated Condition?
description: Millions of Americans are being overtreated for the mildest form of high blood pressure, critics say. They blame a government health strategy that they call wasteful, expensive and possibly dangerous.

title: Old Missouri Friendship Turns Into a Pro Rivalry
description: Even though they were seniors together at the University of Missouri, you won't see Erik McMillan, the Jets' safety, and Jeff Cross, the Miami defensive end, saying much to each other when the Dolphins come to Giants Stadium to play the Jets on Sunday.

title: Jac Lessman, 85, Dies; Hotel-Resort Developer
description: Jac Lessman, a hotel and resort planner and developer, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: States Seek to Control Environmental Claims
description: In a bid to rein in mounting environmental marketing claims, attorneys general from 10 states will propose guidelines today aimed at limiting the types of "green" claims manufacturers make for products.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: What Went Wrong?; Bradley Says He Sensed Voter Fury But It Was Too Late to Do Anything
description: Senator Bill Bradley said today that a little over a week ago he had detected voters' anger over taxes, the economy and the failure of elected officials -- including possibly himself -- to address the issues, but that it was too late to do anything about it.

title: Europe Plan Is Criticized
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen tonight dismissed the European Community call for 30 percent cuts in farm supports as unacceptable.

title: New Bon Voyage Ahead For a Floating Antique?
description: ANTIQUES and old boats have long been his thing, but that only partly explains Jimmy Gallagher's latest adventure: restoring the Yankee, a steam ferry built in 1907 and used by the Immigration Department from 1925 to 1939. "On her route was Ellis Island," Mr. Gallagher said. "Her last job was as a Providence-to-Block-Island ferry."

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: State By State; Poll Of Voters in California
And Now, Meet Mr. and Mrs. Irony
description: JANE and Michael Stern live on a secluded wooded knoll in Connecticut, in a nice Colonial house painted yellow with black shutters. An American flag flutters over their front door; near the driveway, a stone hippopotamus nudges two plastic flamingos.

title: Times to Sell 3 Papers
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell three of its regional newspapers to the American Publishing Company, based in West Frankfort, Ill.

title: Gunman Fires Twice Close to Gorbachev At a Moscow Parade
description: A man carrying a sawed-off shotgun marched onto Red Square with the 73d Revolution Day parade today and fired two shots not far from where President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was presiding over an unusually discordant holiday.

title: Chess Game 12 Ends in Rocky Draw
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov played to a rocky draw after 37 moves in Game 12 of the World Championship Chess Match last night, thus finishing the New York portion of the contest tied at 6-6.

title: Blaze Destroys 4 Acres of Sets At Film Studio
description: A raging fire at Hollywood's biggest and busiest film studio on Tuesday night destroyed four acres of sets and decades of movie history. Today the police arrested a studio security guard and charged him with arson.

title: Dow Plunges 44.31 as Trading Picks Up
description: Strong war talk from Margaret Thatcher pushed oil prices sharply higher yesterday and sent stock prices sharply lower.

title: Patriot Inquiry Is Over
description: Philip Heymann, the law professor investigating allegations that members of the New England Patriots had sexually harassed a Boston Herald reporter, Lisa Olson, submitted a 60-page report to the National Football League commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, yesterday after conducting 91 interviews. There was no indication when Tagliabue would take action on the inquiry, which also looked into how the matter was treated by the club's owner, Victor Kiam, and other members of management. (AP)

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock * Columbia Gas System Inc., Wilmington, Del., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 2.6 million common shares through Morgan Stanley & Co. Ratings * Guardian Industries, Northville, Mich., had its senior debt rating increased to A, from BBB, by Standard & Poor's. * Universal Corp., Richmond, had its commercial paper rating lowered to Prime-2, from Prime-1, by Moody's Investors Service.

title: Review/Theater; Bragging of Patricide In Synge's 'Playboy'
description: Among comic protagonists of 20th-century drama, Christy Mahon, the title character of John Millington's Synge's satirical masterpiece "The Playboy of the Western World," is one of those most open to interpretation. At once loutish and poetic, cowardly and dashing, the young man who seduces the imagination of a poor Irish village with his story of having murdered his father can be played as everything from a dolt to a slippery con man to a flawed romantic hero. It depends on the actor playing him and on how harshly the director wishes to rub the audience's noses in Synge's satiric vision of the brutish life of the Irish peasantry in 1900.

title: Nynex Sells Unit Linked To Inquiry
description: The Nynex Corporation said late yesterday that it had sold the small computer software development subsidiary whose activities resulted in Nynex's indictment by a Federal grand jury on May 30.

title: Woodworkers Try to Save Rain Forests
description: Woodworkers have long lamented the demise of tropical rain forests from hydroelectric development, slash-and-burn agriculture and overharvesting. But Scott Landis, a craftsman in Newtown, Conn., believes woodworkers can play a decisive role in preserving these forests.

title: The Decline And Revival Of a Diner
description: IT sort of looks the way it always did and that is perfectly fine. But the Market Diner, at 43d Street and 11th Avenue in Manhattan, has been undergoing a major facelift. It will soon be the Big City Diner, with a round-the-clock restaurant, the Mercury Bar, a restaurant based on a World's Fair theme, and a disco.

title: Chairman of USF&G Sets Early Retirement
description: Jack Moseley, chairman, president and chief executive of the USF&G Corporation, said yesterday that he would take early retirement. At the same time, the insurance company slashed its dividend and announced plans to reduce costs through layoffs.

title: The 1990 Elections: Signals - The Outcome; VOTERS OUST GOVERNING PARTY IN 14 STATES; CONGRESS IS SHAKEN BUT FEW ARE UNSEATED
description: A divisive, tumultuous midterm election has ended with a striking new class of governors, a strengthened Democratic majority in Congress and some ominous signals for President Bush and other potential candidates in 1992.

title: Tom Clancy, a Singer and Actor; Founder of Irish Folk Band Was 67
description: Tom Clancy, a founder of the Clancy Brothers folk group and an actor, died yesterday at Mercy Hospital in Cork, Ireland. He was 67 years old.

title: Friction Amid Riches
description: Seven of the men's players ranked among the top 10 in the world have agreed to compete Dec. 11-16 in the International Tennis Federation's $6 million Grand Slam Cup in Munich, Germany. But Boris Becker and John McEnroe have turned down invitations to join the 16-man field for the inaugural event, according to an announcement yesterday by Axel Mayer-Woelden, the chief organizer.

title: Rubber Chickens in Potholes Fail to Attract Many Voters
description: Wavy Gravy, a clown with a red nose and tie-dyed clothes who promised voters "a rubber chicken in every pothole," lost his race for the Berkeley City Council on Tuesday.

title: Illini Penalized In Basketball
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today barred the Illinois men's basketball team from post-season play for the 1990-91 season because of recruiting violations.

title: Award for Agencies
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies has created a creativity award for its member agencies. The award, which will be called the "A+", is the first of its kind from the organization and will be presented in May at its annual meeting. The award is scheduled to be given annually based on an agency's total creative output, rather than a single campaign.

title: F.B.I. Arrests Members of Black Sect in 14 Slayings
description: The head of a religious group that says it is a lost black tribe of Israel was arrested today on Federal racketeering charges along with 12 of his followers.

title: The 1990 Elections: Signals - The Message; The Big Vote Is for 'No'
description: The nation's voters didn't much like the choices presented to them in Tuesday's midterm elections.

title: HUGE COMET LINKED TO LIFE ON EARTH
description: Studies combining astronomy, geology and biology have produced a new theory that links comets with the beginning of life on Earth and also some of the most devastating extinctions, including that of the dinosaurs.

title: Readings by 4 Authors To Benefit the Homeless
description: Tom Wolfe, Maya Angelou, Garrison Keillor and Laurie Colwin will read from their works at 8 P.M. on Monday in a benefit for the Goddard-Riverside Community Center, a nonprofit organization that feeds, houses and counsels the homeless in New York City. Calvin Trillin will be the master of ceremonies.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Governor Weicker, and Allies
description: Lowell Weicker's convincing 42 percent plurality victory as Connecticut's next governor came largely at the expense of the Democratic candidate, in a state the Democrats have controlled for years. They still control the legislature, and Mr. Weicker, who ran as an independent, has no party organization of his own; he and they must quickly build a working relationship.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Texas; RICHARDS PROMISES A NEW DIRECTION
description: Ann Richards's narrow victory in the race for Texas governor may be just the first surprise she delivers to the people of her state.

title: Bennett to Resign as Chief of U.S. Anti-Drug Effort
description: William J. Bennett is planning to resign as the nation's first drug policy director, White House officials announced today. The departure comes at a time of uncertainty over whether the Administration is making any progress on its efforts to combat illegal drugs.

title: Sol Chalek Dies at 93; Led a Grocers' Group
description: Sol Chalek, a former chairman of Associated Food Stores, a buying cooperative of grocery owners, died on Tuesday in Hollywood Memorial Hospital in Florida. He was 93 years old and had lived in Rego Park, Queens, and Danbury, Conn., before retiring to Florida in 1971.

title: Ban on Cigarette Ads Protects the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: Cynicism Clouds Nigerian Election Campaign
description: It has been seven years since Nigerians were given a chance to choose their leaders, a right that was abruptly taken away when a military coup ended this country's experiment with democracy.

title: The Bush Victory
description: The only time Richard Nixon quoted Walter Lippmann, not his favorite pundit, was the day after the midterm elections of 1970 in which the Republicans lost nine House seats.

title: Apache Helicopter Meeting Its Commitments
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOLAR PROPOSES 'BRAIN BIRTH' LAW
description: A model piece of legislation aimed at resolving the nation's abortion debate, proposed at an international conference here, would extend legal protection to fetuses at a point when integrated brain functioning begins to emerge -- about 70 days after conception.

title: 7-Eleven Opens Store in Brazil
description: The giant convenience store operator 7-Eleven opened its first store in South America. The store in Sao Paulo, South America's largest city, is a venture between the Southland Corporation, the Dallas-based owner of the 7-Eleven chain, and Esteve S.A. Exportadora, a Sao Paulo-based commodities exporting firm.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS Four Issues and How They Played at the Polls Before Uncertain Voters; Taxes: Voters Send Mixed Message
description: The message voters sent politicians on taxes and the economy was a muddled one, reflecting discontent with the way economic policy is being run but offering no clear signal on how they would like to see Federal or local budgetary problems solved.

title: Northeast
description: CONNECTICUT

title: Gunman Kidnaps Girl At a School Bus Stop
description: A gunman drove up to a school bus stop this morning and abducted an 8-year-old girl as her younger sister and another girl watched in horror, the police said. The victim was released unharmed about an hour later in another town.

title: De Kooning Landscape Sold For $8.8 Million at Christie's
description: Willem de Kooning's "July," an abstract urban landscape painting from 1956 in gritty blacks and summery colors, was sold last night at Christie's for $8.8 million, well above the auction house's estimate of $5 million to $7 million. The price, the second highest ever paid at auction for a work by the artist, exceeded all others at the sale, which dealers said was far more successful than the sale Tuesday night at Sotheby's .

title: Syracuse Starts Long Road Back From Environmental Blight
description: To the Editor:

title: Club Drops '93 P.G.A. Over Race Issue
description: Unable to meet the requirement that clubs must have nondiscriminatory membership policies to host tournaments, the Aronimink Golf Club has asked to be relieved of its agreement to be the site of the 1993 P.G.A. Championship, the Professional Golfers' Association of America said tonight.

title: The 1990 Elections: New Jersey - A Governor's Response New Math on Both Sides of the Hudson; Hearing Tax Outcry in New Jersey Vote, Florio Says He'll Consider New Course
description: Seemingly chastened, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey said yesterday that the near defeat of Senator Bill Bradley on Tuesday had sent a "humbling message" aimed at himself and his aggressive tax and social policies, and that he was opening his entire legislative program to revision.

title: For Bulgaria, a Soviet Day is a Day to Ignore
description: For the first time in decades, the anniversary of the Soviet Union's Bolshevik Revolution was almost totally ignored today in this Balkan land that used to walk in lock step with Moscow.

title: Talking Deals; Satellite TV's Appeal to Comsat
description: WHEN the Communications Satellite Corporation bought a majority stake in the Denver Nuggets basketball team, a lot of people wondered why. Now, as the company contemplates investing $100 million in a new satellite television venture, the answer seems clear.

title: Poll of Voters In Massachusetts
Humphrey Gibbs, 87, of Rhodesia And a Foe of White Rebels, Dies
description: Sir Humphrey Gibbs, who as British Governor of Rhodesia vigorously opposed the white Government's declaration of independence in 1965, died on Monday, his family said Tuesday. He was 87 years old.

title: Islanders Treat Devils The Same as Rangers
description: The Islanders are last in the Patrick Division, but first when it comes to ending unbeaten home streaks built by the two contenders who are their rivals in this area. They ended the Rangers' streak at Madison Square Garden last Friday night and did the same thing to the Devils tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: From Internal Exile, A Book of Fables By Salman
description: In Salman Rushdie's first book since "The Satanic Verses" -- the novel that enraged Muslim fundamentalists and prompted the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to issue a death sentence against the author in February 1989 -- a young hero and his loyal band of friends do battle against an evil sorcerer who has imposed "a Cult of Dumbness or Muteness" on an entire land. <TD WIDTH=2

title: Miscellany
description: * Neale-May & Partners, a marketing communications company in Los Altos, Calif., has signed a three-year agreement with the Gannett Company, Arlington, Va., to market USA Today's Future File and News Source Guide, which are editorial resources used by Gannett reporters.

title: Key Man at Banking's Crossroads
description: In this city where relationships mean power, a former Harvard Business School professor who has the ear of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who himself has the ear of President Bush, may well become the Administration's strongest voice in reshaping the nation's banking system.

title: De Klerk's Party Wins By-Election Decisively
description: South Africa's ruling National Party, with the support of many white suburban voters who rejected it 14 months ago, today obliterated a right-wing challenge and decisively won a Parliamentary seat that had been surrendered by the liberal Democratic Party.

title: Woman for All Editions?
description: THERE she is with a sweater loosely tied around her neck; there she is choosing a Christmas tree; there she is arranging flowers on the mantelpiece. Martha Stewart Living, a new magazine, is all about Ms. Stewart.

title: Books of The Times; From Internal Exile, A Book of Fables By Salman Rushdie
description: Haroun and the Sea of Stories By Salman Rushdie 219 pages. Granta Books/Viking. $18.95.

title: West
description: ALASKA

title: Race in North Carolina
description: The process by which North Carolina returned Jesse Helms to the Senate Tuesday has some hopeful implications for American politics -- and also some dismal implications. The race pitted Harvey Gantt, the first black Mayor of Charlotte, against a man who tends to appeal to the lowest human instincts in his quest for votes.

title: Review/Dance; This Season's 'New Stuff'
description: "New Stuff," a showcase for new dance and performance art, was more interesting for the stage presence of each of the three contributors to this season's program than for their contributions.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: The Challenger; Numbers Ease Defeat for Bradley Rival
description: After coming within 55,000 votes of defeating one of the stars of the Democratic Party, Christine Todd Whitman said that Senator Bill Bradley was hurt most by "his unwillingness to speak out" on the tax issue.

title: New Jerseyans Restore 'Messiah' Performances
description: The New Jersey Symphony announced yesterday that it was restoring two of four performances of Handel's "Messiah" canceled on Oct. 24. They will be on Dec. 7 at the New Brunswick State Theater and on Dec. 9 at the Newark Symphony Hall.

title: Ex-Eurocom Executive Heads TBWA in Paris
description: Pierre de Plas, the former chief executive of Eurocom's Paris-based advertising group EWDB, has been named chief executive of TBWA Advertising's Paris office, which will be known as TBWA de Plas.

title: Chronicle
description: Since its founding in 1981 by BEN SONNENBERG , Grand Street has been a small but respected literary quarterly. The magazine, which suspended publication briefly, has re-emerged, thicker and slicker, under a new editor and publisher, JEAN STEIN .

title: Review/Theater; Wife Is Dutiful Though Separated
description: In "The Wash" by Philip Kan Gotanda, a wife abruptly leaves her husband after more than 40 years of marriage, but she continues to do his laundry, visiting him regularly in what is now his seedy bachelor home. She has been totally subservient in marriage and remains dutiful during their separation. The laundry becomes the central symbol of a wife's self-subjugation and the hesitancy with which she assumes a life of independence. For the Matsumotos, the Japanese-American couple at the heart of the play, habit is indeed a great deadener.

title: 'Twin Peaks': Splash on Both Sides of Atlantic; Who Killed Laura Palmer? Stay Tuned!
description: Who killed Laura Palmer? Bob did.

Across the nation, environmental groups found themselves unable to translate the benevolent oratory of last spring's Earth Day into gains in the voting booth. From New York to California, open space, clean water and forestry measures that would have required taxing or bond indebtedness or made food and other agricultural products more expensive for consumers were defeated.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about children's reliability as witnesses misidentified a psychologist at the University of California at Los Angeles. She is Dr. Karen Saywitz, not Karen Smith.

title: Guilty Plea In Bank Fraud
description: The former controller of a failed New Jersey savings bank has pleaded guilty to bank and tax fraud, admitting he took an employee bonus after directors voted against them, United States Attorney Michael Chertoff said today.

title: A Test of Principles in India
description: In India, the politics of opportunism have triumphed over the politics of principle. Yesterday Parliament ended Prime Minister V. P. Singh's 11 months in office with a huge vote of no confidence. The vote came amid shabby political horse-trading that may not fairly reflect popular sentiment.

title: Treasury Says Limits on Foreign Bids Still Hold
description: The Treasury Department announced on Tuesday that it would regard as still in effect a statute that enables the President to block foreign acquisitions that threaten national security, even though the 101st Congress allowed the law to lapse last month in its rush to adjourn.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Secession; Staten Island Turns to Cost of Parting
description: Having gone to the polls on Tuesday to declare their willingness to consider seceding from New York City, Staten Islanders turned their attention yesterday to the question that will largely decide their next vote: How much will independence cost?

title: Georgia Man Is Charged In a Series of Bombings
description: After an 11-month investigation, the Government today charged a Georgia man with murder in a series of package bombings last winter that killed a Federal appeals judge in Alabama and a civil rights lawyer in Georgia.

title: Take Trash, Make Decor
description: FOR Howard Rosenthal, a sculptor in Manhattan, broken television sets are not junk. They are homes for fish or birds.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS Four Issues and How They Played at the Polls Before Uncertain Voters; Abortion: Both Sides See Some Victories
description: Although both sides in the abortion fight could point to individual races as victories, anti-abortion groups were left saying that the results were not as bad as they might have been.

title: 'Twin Peaks': Splash on Both Sides of Atlantic; In Britain, It's All Just Beginning
description: The British are fighting furiously against addiction to "Twin Peaks," which arrived on the BBC's second channel last month, but it may be a losing battle.

title: Bush Administration Is Split On Taiwan's Joining GATT
description: The Bush Administration is divided over a long-pending application by Taiwan to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 100-nation agency that oversees global trade.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS Four Issues and How They Played at the Polls Before Uncertain Voters; Ethics: Scandals Costly In Some Races
description: Lawmakers linked to the crisis in the savings-and-loan industry or whose ethical conduct came into question found themselves the targets of voters' wrath in Tuesday's elections, and analysts predicted that the sentiment would continue to build for the 1992 campaign.

title: Ogrodnick Snaps the Rangers Out of Slump
description: The knock against John Ogrodnick was blunt, even if it was only subtly and almost silently delivered by management throughout September's contract standoff.

title: Iranians Begin Search for Victims of Quake
description: Search teams and relief aid were dispatched to remote sections of southern Iran today after a powerful earthquake that killed at least 22 villagers and left more than 12,000 homeless, the Teheran radio reported.

title: Mandela Sees Western Bias In Outrage at Iraqi Invasion
description: Nelson Mandela accused the West today of hypocrisy and prejudice in responding to Kuwait's occupation, saying Iraq is being singled out because its people are "brown-skinned."

title: Advanced Chip Offered By Texas Instruments
description: Restoring a touch of pride for American makers of computer chips, Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it was delivering limited supplies of its model of the world's most advanced memory chip to some of its largest customers.

title: Citicorp To Redeem Some Stock
description: Citicorp, embarrassed by the high rates it has had to pay in recent weeks, announced plans yesterday to redeem some of its preferred stock.

title: Once Upon a Time in the Land of Bibliotherapy . . .
description: DANIEL is a little boy who adored his Uncle Tim. He remembers him as "more fun than any other grown-up I knew." They used to go for long walks in the woods, and tried to outwit each other in hard-fought battles of checkers. Then one winter Uncle Tim began to stay home and sleep a lot, and Daniel's mother told him the awful truth: Uncle Tim had AIDS.

title: Review/Dance; Siblings Who Stress Individuality
description: Christopher Gillis and Margie Gillis, brother and sister, are magnificent dancers, and although they are rarely together on the stage, they have joined forces this week for the kind of concert you will never see anywhere else.

title: EGYPT'S PRESIDENT CALLS FOR A DELAY IN ATTACKING IRAQ
