description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that the coalition allied against Iraq should wait "at least two to three more months" to determine whether the economic sanctions were able to force President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait. But he warned President Hussein that if he did not pull his troops out, war was inevitable with "the greatest concentration of military force I have ever seen in this area."

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Comptroller Race; Suburban and Upstate Voters Carry Regan to Narrow Victory
description: Several hours after claiming victory in his bid for a fourth four-year term as the state comptroller, Edward V. Regan returned to work yesterday morning as New York's chief fiscal watchdog.

title: THE 1990 ELECTION: A Dividend Party; After Rinfret, Republicans Face Even Deeper Disarray
description: The New York State Republican Party, weakened by the disastrous gubernatorial campaign of Pierre A. Rinfret and no longer able to disguise or patch up its deep splits, now faces an open and prolonged struggle for control among its various factions.

title: Personal Health
description: Not so very long ago the process of conception, pregnancy and childbirth was one big mysterious miracle. Beliefs spawned by biological ignorance held women responsible for the sex of a couple's offspring, and in some cultures wives were -- and in a few cases still are -- abandoned if they failed to produce a male heir.

title: Farm Chief's Foe Has the Last Laugh
description: The Texas Agriculture Commissioner with the Borscht Belt sense of humor is out. Jim Hightower, a two-term incumbent known as an advocate of enlightened farming as well as one of the funniest figures in American politics, was defeated Tuesday by Rick Perry, a 40-year-old rancher and farmer.

title: No, We Don't Have to Go to War With Iraq; Palestinian Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: The 1990 Elections: New York - Bond Act New Math on Both Sides of the Hudson; Defeat of the Environmental Bond Act May Mean Higher Taxes in New York
description: The defeat of the $2 billion environmental bond act on Tuesday leaves communities throughout New York State with few ways to pay for urgent and costly landfill and recycling programs, many of them required by law.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: North Carolina; Helms Kindled Anger in Campaign, And May Have Set Tone for Others
description: It began as a clash of visions and personalities that seemed startling and new, but when it ended Tuesday, the bitter North Carolina Senate race between the Republican incumbent, Jesse Helms, and the Democratic challenger, Harvey Gantt, gave off the inescapable air of deja vu.

title: Review/Theater; Laughing All the Way To the Sperm Bank
description: Desperation is at the root of Tom Mardirosian's comedy. In "Saved From Obscurity," he chronicled his life as an actor looking for work in the desert of New York theater. In his new play, "Subfertile," he graphically -- and amusingly -- describes the anguish of a husband with a low sperm count who will do almost anything in order to improve his chances of fatherhood. The would-be father is named Tom and he is played by the author, facts that move the play (at Playwrights Horizons) two steps closer to autobiography.

title: Paul B. Halstead, 104, Cotton Institute Official
description: Paul B. Halstead, a longtime official of the Cotton Textile Institute who was the oldest living graduate of Harvard College, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Clermont, Fla. He was 104 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn., before he moved to Florida in 1962.

title: Northrop Sets Revamping
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it would close a missile manufacturing plant in Newbury Park, Calif., next year and eliminate about 800 jobs in a restructuring that includes reorganizing its electronics businesses.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Governor's Race; Cuomo, Omnipotence Blunted, Gets Back to Budget
description: On the heels of a successful, but still disappointing, re-election bid, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo returned to Albany yesterday to confront one of the most severe challenges of his tenure: how to balance the state budget when the nation is slipping into a recession, New York City is edging toward a fiscal crisis and voters in New York State appear to be fed up with tax increases.

title: TV to Invade Greta Garbo's Last Refuge
description: Garbo. The Name. The Face. The Auction. The Video.

title: Rumor Inquiry in London
description: London's Stock Exchange said this week that it was investigating more than a dozen suspected "bear raids" in which stock manipulators illegally profit by spreading malicious rumors about companies.

title: No, We Don't Have to Go to War With Iraq; Another Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: Lebanon Announces a Timetable For All Militias to Leave Beirut
description: The Government today set Saturday as the day to begin disarming all militias in and around the capital and decided to build a new presidential headquarters on the ruins of the country's once-famous race track in central Beirut.

title: Next Shuttle Launching Is Set
description: NASA today set Nov. 15 as the launching date for the space shuttle Atlantis and its classified cargo, a spy satellite that needed last-minute repairs and delayed the flight for a week. Military experts said the satellite would spy on Iraqi forces. Atlantis was supposed to have carried the spacecraft into orbit in July, weeks before Iraq invaded Kuwait, but hydrogen leaks grounded the shuttle. During the delay, the satellite was reported to have been modified to focus on the Persian Gulf.

title: Custom-Made Dolls
description: To The Home Section:

title: Chronicle
description: JOHN F. KENNEDY JR. told his boss, ROBERT M. MORGENTHAU , yesterday that he had passed the New York State bar exam, thus insuring his job and a raise. Mr. Kennedy, who had failed to pass the test twice previously, will remain in the Manhattan District Attorney's office and receive a $3,000 raise, which is routine upon passing the exam. When he is formally admitted to the bar he will get $1,000 more, raising his salary to $34,000.

title: Poll of Voters In Illinois
Chinese Oilfield Policy
description: Prime Minister Li Peng today indicated a willingness to give foreign companies a role in developing China's most promising oilfield, which has been closed to foreign involvement. The official New China News Agency said Mr. Li made the statement at a meeting with the president of the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan, Shinroku Morohashi. Mr. Morohashi mentioned the Tarim Basin in northwestern China, saying his company "is ready to participate" in oil development there. Testing has indicated that the basin is rich in oil and natural gas deposits.

title: University Offering Ex-President $1 Million to Sever His Ties to It
description: The trustees of American University have agreed to pay more than $1 million as a settlement to Richard Berendzen, the university's former president who resigned six months ago after being accused of making obscene telephone calls from his campus office.

title: Why the Rush to War?
description: The continuing buildup of American forces in the Persian Gulf and the increasingly heated rhetoric emanating from the White House point to the likelihood that the U.S. will soon be waging all-out war against Iraq and Saddam Hussein.

title: Witness Says Defendant Said He Held Jogger
description: A surprise prosecution witness testified yesterday that a defendant in the second Central Park jogger trial called her from Rikers Island last year and confessed to holding the victim down while she was raped.

title: India's Cabinet Falls as Premier Loses Confidence Vote, by 142-346, and Quits
description: The 11-month-old Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh collapsed tonight after losing a confidence vote by a wide margin.

title: Pan Am Gets Shuttle Offer
description: Gordon A. Cain, a Houston investor who realized gains of hundreds of millions of dollars from the sale of companies he built, has said he would cooperate with the pilots' union from Pan American World Airways in a bid for the Pan Am shuttle.

title: Key Rates
THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Choice of Governor; Old Face Brings Change to 'Land of Steady Habits'
description: Contrary to long-established tradition, Connecticut's Governor-elect, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., did not come to the State Capitol today to stand before television cameras and thank the voters for supporting him or to ask for their continued good will.

title: Review/Music; Opera When Money Is Tight
description: Reduced circumstances place a burden of excellence on New York's smaller opera companies that is unforgiving and a little unfair. Money is short and facilities bare; and when extravagance and display are removed from opera's traditional roster of assets, something has to serve as compensation: repertory of striking originality, fresh young singing talent, the subtleties of ensemble that big opera houses can rarely offer but that in a college theater, a high-school assembly room or a converted loft become a possibility.

title: Siemens and GPT Plan Merger of U.S. Units
description: Siemens A.G. of Germany and GPT Ltd. of Britain said yesterday that they planned to merge their American units that produce call-switching and transmission equipment for telephone companies.

title: At a New SoHo Gallery, A First, From Paris
description: IF there is a common factor in the furniture collection by Elizabeth Garouste and Mattia Bonetti on view at Neotu, a new SoHo gallery, it is what Ms. Garouste called "their generous size and noble materials."

title: Review/Dance; Handel's 'Alcina' Adapted
description: "Lies Revealed," which was danced Friday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, was ambitious and unconventional. It was also a mess.

title: Mayor to Seek Cuts to Close Budget Gap
description: In an important test of his credibility in the financial world, Mayor David N. Dinkins is to present today his plan for service reductions and other cuts that could mean several hundred layoffs to help close a gap of about $400 million in New York City's budget.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Nuggets Lose Again David Robinson scored a career-high 43 points and Terry Cummings added 31 last night as the hot-shooting San Antonio Spurs beat the defenseless Denver Nuggets, 161-153, in San Antonio. Denver, which has lost all four of its games, set a National Basketball Association record with 90 points in the first half. The teams' total of 173 points in the half was also an N.B.A. record, and the final total of 314 was the fifth highest in league history. San Antonio shot 63 percent from the field and Denver shot 57 percent. (AP) Pistons 110, Clippers 83: Joe Dumars scored 25 points to lead six Pistons in double figures in Los Angeles. Using the same balanced scoring attack they employed in their first three games, the Pistons led from the opening basket and were never seriously threatened after a jumper by Vinnie Johnson and four free throws by Dumars widened their lead to 52-36 with 4:25 left in the first half. (AP) Mavericks 104, 76ers 101: In Philadelphia, Roy Tarpley scored 26 points and Herb Williams and Alex English, reserve forwards, combined for 18 in the fourth period for Dallas. Two free throws by Derek Harper gave Dallas a 104-99 lead with 12 seconds left, but Johnny Dawkins made a layup with 3 seconds remaining. Charles Barkley intercepted the inbound pass deep in the corner, but his 3-point shot at the buzzer bounced off the rim. (AP) Bulls 96, Timberwolves 91: Chicago avoided its first 0-4 start in 23 years, beating Minnesota as B. J. Armstrong came off the bench to score 10 of his 14 points during an 18-8 second-half surge in Minneapolis. (AP) N.H.L. Shutout for Moog Andy Moog stopped 23 shots for his 10th career shutout and Dave Christian broke a scoreless tie with a power-play goal one minute into the third period as the Boston Bruins beat the Montreal Canadiens, 2-0, last night in Montreal. (AP) TENNIS Ivanisevic a Winner Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia took a small step toward a place in next week's eight-player Association of Tennis Professionals championships in Germany by overpowering Thierry Champion, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday in the first round of the Wembley indoor tournament in England. Other winners were Guy Forget and Patrick McEnroe. (AP) Mayotte Advances in Moscow: Tim Mayotte beat Patrick Kuehnen, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday in the second round of the Kremlin Cup indoor tournament in Moscow. In other matches, unseeded Udo Riglewski upset Richey Reneberg, 1-6, 6-3, 6-2, and Andrei Cherkasov beat Gilad Bloom, 6-3, 6-3. (AP) GOLF Peoples Leads on a 63 David Peoples shot an eight-under par 63 yesterday for the first-round lead in the Kapalua International on the island of Maui. Peoples was one shot in front of Ben Crenshaw. (AP)

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Pre-election Polls; The Surveys Were Accurate, With Some Key Exceptions
description: More often than not, public polls before Tuesday's elections fairly accurately reflected the final outcome of the races. Yet there were dramatic exceptions in which the public was probably caught by surprise, while the candidates' advisers insisted they knew what was coming.

title: No, We Don't Have to Go to War With Iraq; Negotiate First
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudan's Famine Denials Take Anti-West Tone
description: Officials of the Islamic fundamentalist junta here continue to deny that the Sudan faces the possibility of a severe famine, with a strong anti-Western theme as their underlying message.

title: Allies Tell Baker Use of Force Needs U.N. Backing
description: Midway through Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's tour of Europe and the Middle East, it has become clear that Washington's partners in the coalition against Iraq will not consider using military force unless it is authorized by the United Nations, American officials said today.

title: Bronx Man Slain in Robbery
description: A 46-year-old Bronx man was shot to death in a robbery last night as he returned home from work, the police said. The victim, Stanley Luccas, who had worked at A.T.&.T. for 26 years, was assaulted at 9 P.M. in front of 911 East 230th Street, half a block from his home in the Woodlawn section, said Officer Scott Bloch, a police spokesman. He said Mr. Luccas was shot once in the head and robbed of his wallet.

title: Bridge
description: Successful maneuvers at the card table, as in the kitchen, frequently depend on careful planning and preparation. An example is the diagramed deal, which helped Seymour Reich, John Solodar and Michael Radin, all of Manhattan, and Michael Kopera and Gene Prosnitz, both of Brooklyn, to come from behind and capture the Regional Swiss Team title in Lancaster, Pa., on Sunday.

title: The 1990 Elections: The Future - Redistricting; Elections Strengthen Hand of Democrats In '91 Redistricting
description: The 1990 midterm elections left Democrats well positioned to protect their majority in the House of Representatives for the next decade, despite the shift in the nation's population to more Republican areas in the South and West.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Notebook; A Reserve Back Is Ivy's New Star
description: The Ivy League's surprising new star, Scott Oliaro of Cornell, will try for an unlikely encore against Columbia at Baker Field on Saturday.

title: U.N. Aide Fears Iraqis Can Militarize Medicine
description: A senior official in charge of enforcing economic sanctions against Iraq expressed concern today that Baghdad may be importing pharmaceuticals and other medical supplies that could be used in the manufacture of chemical or biological weapons.

title: Soldier Killed in Saudi Arabia
description: An American soldier died today in Saudi Arabia of injuries he incurred while trying to free a 20-ton truck that had become stuck in the sand, the Defense Department said. The soldier, whose identity was being withheld until his relatives could be notified, was a member of the First Cavalry Division from Fort Hood, Tex. A Pentagon spokesman said no details were immediately available on the circumstances of the accident or its location.

title: INSIDE
description: Indian Government Falls Prime Minister V. P. Singh resigned after a wide majority of the Indian Parliament voted no confidence in his 11-month-old Government. Page A3. Mail-Bombing Indictment The Government charged a Georgia man with mailing the package bombs that killed a Federal judge and a civil rights lawyer last winter. Page A26. Fire at Universal Studios A fire among sets at Hollywood's biggest film studio swept away much of movie history. A security guard was charged with arson. Page A26. Top Drug Fighter Resigning William J. Bennett is leaving his post as the nation's No. 1 anti-drug official because, a White House official said, he has become dispirited. Page A26.

title: Big East, Bigger Business
description: The Big East Conference held its annual media day in New York City yesterday: same format, different players, same coaching alibis. But this year, one major player was not on hand. Dave Gavitt, the founder and commissioner of the Big East, resigned earlier this year to become the general manager of the Boston Celtics.

title: South
description: ALABAMA

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: BEFORE covering uneven floors with either vinyl flooring, tile or carpeting, a layer of smooth material called underlayment must be installed. The underlayment will prevent irregularities in the old surface from showing through the new one.

title: Unions Draw Thousands to City Hall Rally
description: Several thousand municipal workers gathered in City Hall Park last night in a protest mounted by New York City's municipal unions over their deadlocked negotiations for new contracts and a pay increase.

title: Review/Recital; Unstampeded by Success
description: Outside of the wrestling arena, there are no more unreasonably passionate fans than those of the human voice. Bored by an emerging generation of competent singers, they long for some sensational new talent on which to deposit their adoration. Many think they have found it in Dmitri Khvorostovsky.

title: U.S. Fighter Planes to Leave Philippine Base in '91
description: The United States will withdraw fighter planes from a base in the Philippines and reduce its troop strength there starting next year, moving toward the Filipino position on the bases, an American official said here today.

title: Outpouring for Kahane: Pity or a New Respect?
description: At the funeral on Tuesday of Rabbi Meir Kahane, the militant Brooklyn-born rabbi got the honor and acceptance he never got in life. Among the thousands of mourners were the leaders of several establishment Jewish organizations that had once vilified him as a racist, a meglomaniac and "a fringe person."

title: Steelmaker Files For Chapter 11
description: The CF & I Steel Corporation and its nine subsidiaries filed petitions for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Frank J. Yaklich Jr., the president and chief executive, said the company would continue to operate during reorganization. The steelmaker, based in Pueblo, serves the energy, transportation and agricultural markets.

title: A Shift on Benson & Hedges Is Reported
description: UNHAPPY with the advertising that Wells Rich Greene created for Benson & Hedges cigarettes, Philip Morris U.S.A. has quietly reassigned the majority of the $40 million to $60 million account to Leo Burnett, said advertising executives who are familiar with the company's plans but who insisted on anonymity.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Ballot Proposals; Voters Spurn Array of Plans For Protecting Environment
description: Environmentalists said yesterday that they had suffered major setbacks as voters in California and several other states rejected ballot proposals to protect air, land and water against pollution and the effects of commercial development.

title: Kahane's Followers in Israel Bury Him and Vent Anger
description: As mourners wept or angrily shouted "Death to the Arabs!" and masses of policemen looked on, Rabbi Meir Kahane's coffin was carried today from the yeshiva he founded in an impoverished neighborhood to a hilltop cemetery on the edge of Jerusalem.

title: Calendar: Model Trains and Handicraft
description: Miniature Towns and Trains, Bay Ridge Model Railroad Club, 28 Marine Avenue off 93d Street, Brooklyn; (718) 745-1953.

title: Police Think Kahane Slaying Suspect Acted Alone
description: Police investigators remained baffled yesterday over why Rabbi Meir Kahane was shot to death, but they said the suspect, El Sayyid A. Nosair, appeared to have acted alone.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans for a driving range on Randalls Island referred incorrectly to its rarity. It would be the first public outdoor golfing facility in the borough of Manhattan. There is a golf course on Governors Island, but it is not open to the public.

title: Selma Mayor Has Heart Attack
description: Joe Smitherman, the seven-term Mayor of Selma, suffered a heart attack Tuesday afternoon and underwent successful treatment here today for a blocked coronary artery. The 60-year-old Mr. Smitherman was Mayor during the 1965 civil rights marches as well as during protests earlier this year over the firing of the city's first black Superintendent of Schools.

title: Market Place; Seeking Safety In Money Funds
description: THE risk-averse buyers of money market funds are turning increasingly to the safest of such funds, giving up slightly higher yields for the safety of funds that are invested only in United States Government securities.

title: China's Press Casts a Cold Eye on U.S. Vote
description: Eighteen months after Chinese students fought and in some cases died for their vision of democracy, the official Chinese press is taking a jaundiced look at American electoral politics, suggesting that if this is democracy then it isn't really worth fighting for after all.

title: Metro Matters; Election '90: A True Nobody Spoke Volumes
description: When New York Republicans were searching for a challenger to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last spring, they took a statewide poll to measure support for six potential candidates. Among them, Joe McCormack got an impressive 28 percent of the votes.

title: Alomar Is Named A.L. Rookie of Year
description: His father played in the major leagues for 15 seasons and has been a coach in San Diego the last six. His brother Roberto is the Padres' second baseman. He himself was twice voted minor league player of the year. So it was not that surprising yesterday when Sandy Alomar Jr., the 24-year-old catcher for the Cleveland Indians, became the third player unanimously voted the American League rookie of the year by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Massachusetts; Weld Reaffirms Pledge To Shrink Government
description: William F. Weld, the first Republican to win the governor's office in Massachusetts in two decades, today savored his narrow victory over John R. Silber and said his first priority would be to repeal a state sales tax on services passed only last summer.

title: Elizabeth Walker; Lawyer, 81
description: Elizabeth Walker, a tax lawyer, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. She was 81 years old and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: The 1990 Elections: Signals;   'Butterfly Town U.S.A.' Votes To Give Its Namesake a Home
description: The migratory haven of thousand of monarch butterflies has been saved at the ballot box as voters here approved bonds to buy a habitat for the insects.

title: Puny Chicken Mocks Lenin's Legacy
description: With the temperature freezing, their fortunes sagging and Lenin's portrait plastered in holiday red all over the city, Muscovites today entered their richest season for grim laughter.

title: Offers Being Sought for U.P.I. and FNN
description: The newly appointed co-chief executives of Infotechnology Inc. yesterday put the Financial News Network and United Press International, the company's major holdings, up for sale.

title: U.S. VIEW PREVAILS AT CLIMATE PARLEY
description: United States negotiators today turned aside an effort to set specific targets for wealthy countries to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, which is widely expected to cause a dangerous heating of the global atmosphere.

title: Good-Will Tour Is Producing Some Hard Feelings
description: The Japanese businessman kept talking baseball, which, during a week when East met West on the diamond, had become both a hot subject and a concern after the surprising showing by a Japanese all-star team against a visiting squad from the United States.

title: Smithsonian Stamps Get A New Home
description: The administrator of the Smithsonian Institution, Robert McC. Adams, and the Postmaster General, Anthony M. Frank, signed an agreement Tuesday to relocate the National Philatelic Collection, now at the Smithsonian, to a new museum in the capital.

title: Daily News and Police Vary on Degree of Violence
description: The Daily News and the New York City Police Department differ sharply on how much violence and harassment has occurred since the paper was struck by nine of its 10 unions two weeks ago, an analysis of the statistics indicates.

title: Pakistani Vows to Step Up Nuclear Program
description: The new Prime Minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, said today that he would accelerate the country's nuclear energy program, calling it "imperative" to reduce oil dependency and meet the growing needs of the industrial sector.

title: Accounts
description: * Palazzetti, a New York-based furniture designer, to Weiss, Whitten Inc., New York, with a budget of more than $1 million.

title: Congress Passes Plan To Protect Artworks
description: An amendment to a bill passed by Congress on Saturday in its closing session would, for the first time, protect the work of visual artists, sculptors, photographers and print-makers against unauthorized destruction, distortion, mutilation or modification.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Georgia; Gingrich Barely Escapes Going From G.O.P. Whip to Just Plain Whipped
description: Representative Newt Gingrich, the powerful House Republican who likes to regard himself as a kind of verbal bomb thrower, had a big one go off in his own home district on Election Day. Mr. Gingrich survived, but just barely.

title: Depressed Smokers Are Seen in Peril
description: Depression has long been suspected of reducing the body's immunities; now a study suggests that depressed smokers have a higher risk of cancer than nondepressed smokers.

title: New Demand Delays Quedlinburg Treasures Case
description: A demand for nearly $2.5 million in exchange for the return of the Quedlinburg treasures has stalled out-of-court negotiations between opposing parties in a case now before Federal District Court in Dallas, said a German cultural official close to the negotiations.

title: Dr. Erich Heller, Professor, 79; A Scholar of German Philosophy
description: Dr. Erich Heller, a noted scholar and writer on German philosophers and literary figures of the last three centuries and a professor emeritus of the humanities at Northwestern University, died on Monday at a retirement home in Evanston, Ill. He was 79 years old.

title: U.S. Declares Missions To Iraq Are 'Being Used'
description: The Bush Administration plans to send at least 100,000 additional troops to the Persian Gulf region by late December, bringing the total number of American forces in the region to about 350,000, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Another Writer Who Spoke for Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: Wally Redux
description: The one man Richard Nixon dismissed from his original Cabinet has managed to survive in politics longer than any of his colleagues. Walter J. Hickel -- he's just plain Wally these days -- was the little-known Governor of Alaska when President Nixon named him Interior Secretary in 1968. Mr. Hickel has tried ever since to get back to the governor's mansion. Yesterday, on his fourth long-shot attempt, he succeeded.

title: G.M. in Venture In Czechoslovakia
description: The General Motors Corporation announced a further expansion into Eastern Europe through a transmission and vehicle assembly agreement with Czechoslovakia. G.M. will work with Bratislavske Automobilove Zavody factories in Bratislava to make 250,000 transmissions for G.M.'s Opel A.G. factories in Europe. The partners also will assemble a small number of Opel cars to distribute in Czechoslovakia.

title: Howard Cady, a Book Editor, 76; Had 50-Year Career in Publishing
description: Howard Cady, who during a 50-year publishing career edited books by Rex Harrison, William Saroyan, Sophia Loren, Leon Uris, Barry Goldwater and Norman Vincent Peale, died Sunday at Porter Medical Center in Middlebury, Vt. He was 76 years old and had recently moved to Middlebury.

title: New Wave of Job Cutbacks Hits Wall St.
description: A new wave of dismissals is spreading throughout Wall Street, with cutbacks reported yesterday at both the First Boston Corporation and Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Water for Two-Wheelers
description: TRUST Philippe Starck, the French designer who put his imprimatur on New York's Royalton and Paramount Hotels (and who has been known to tool around the city on a motorcycle), to come up with a striking look for Glacier, bottled water from Canada.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: Legislative Contests; Most Incumbents Win In Races for Legislature
description: If New Yorkers suffered at all from anti-incumbency fever on Tuesday, they chose to direct their wrath at Gov. Mario M. Cuomo while virtually absolving the State Legislature.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I got the message; the results were really directed at me and the policies of my administration." -- Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey. [ A1:2. ]

title: Lemuel Ricketts Boulware, 95; Headed Labor Relations for G.E.
description: Lemuel Ricketts Boulware, a former vice president of the General Electric Company who formulated a new approach to union management contract negotiations in the 1950's, died yesterday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 95 years old.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Maxwell Plans to Publish Newspaper on Horse Racing
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, said yesterday that he would begin publishing a new daily newspaper in the United States next year devoted to thoroughbred horse racing.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: California; Wilson, the Election Won, Plans for His Toughest Job
description: Today, twenty-four years after he first got into politics as a young State Assemblyman from San Diego, Senator Pete Wilson returned to his hometown to prepare for what may be the toughest job of his life, governor of California.

title: Frito-Lay's Speedy Data Network
description: There is no danger that the new personal computer sitting on Mary Ellen Johnson's desk at Frito-Lay's office here in suburban Detroit will gather dust. It came with a new program that allows a delighted Mrs. Johnson, one of 32 divisional sales managers, to quickly determine what happened to every one of the snack-food giant's product lines in every type of store in her territory the previous week.

title: AIDS DRUG TRIALS MAY BE REVAMPED
description: A coalition of 22 of the world's leading statisticians has called for substantial changes in the way potential AIDS treatments are tested.

title: Review/Folk; French-American Flair
description: From Quebec down to the bayous of south Louisiana, French-speaking North Americans have held onto musical styles as well as language. "La Veillee," the Folk Masters program on Tuesday night at Weill Hall, traced connections in an amiable, well-researched concert that showed the music gathering syncopation as it moved southward and European marches mutated into Cajun two-steps. As it has for generations, the music continues to run in families.

title: To Gaze Deep Into the Teapot Of Time
description: "NOT enough time" is the modern lament. Work, family, not to mention the weight of an approaching millenium -- the minutes are ticking away, loudly. But time is standing ominously still on some bold new accessories with clock faces as a motif. The hands are often frozen at 10 minutes before the hour.

title: Panel's Boycott Report Called Biased
description: A City Council committee yesterday sharply criticized a mayoral committee's report on the boycott of two Korean-owned stores as biased and poorly researched.

title: Herbs as Beguiling as a Dulcimer
description: THE road to the Sandy Mush Herb Nursery , in a remote cove in the Newfound Range of the Blue Ridge Mountains 20 miles west of Asheville, N.C., is not an easy one, but it is beautiful. The narrow pavement wends through the Big Sandy Mush Valley past tidy farms on rolling terrain. In high autumn, the tobacco crop has just been harvested, using techniques unchanged since the 18th century. The golden-tan leaves have been cut by hand, gathered into sheaves on pointed wooden sticks and hauled to two-story barns to hang and cure.

title: Architect Picked for Newark Concert Hall
description: In appointing an architect today to design the first major new East Coast performance hall in three decades, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center took a firm step toward creating a $70 million multi-use concert hall in downtown Newark.

title: No, We Don't Have to Go to War With Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: An Anti-Theft Specialist Bolsters Its Top Ranks
description: The Knogo Corporation, which makes electronic devices to stop thieves and shoplifters, has beefed up its management with the goal of doubling sales volume within three years.

title: Customized Woven and Braided Rugs
description: SEVERAL years ago a curator at the Brooklyn Museum asked Elizabeth Eakins, a New York rug maker, to reproduce an old American woven rug for a historic house. The rug was what weavers call a warp-face rug, which means its pattern comes mainly from threads running lengthwise. Ms. Eakins's specialty had been hand-braided rugs, but she promptly abandoned them to make warp-face rugs woven in wool.

title: Yields Drop At Funds
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell in the week ended yesterday.

title: Out of the Trunk
description: It all began when someone heard a noise coming from the back of a car in the mall parking lot.

title: Two Records Stand
description: Randy Barnes, the world record-holder in the shot-put since May, and Butch Reynolds, who set the world mark in the 400-meter run two years ago, will be allowed to keep their records despite being suspended for steroid use by the world governing body for track and field. The marks will stand because both athletes passed drug tests after setting their marks, the International Amateur Athletic Federation said yesterday in London.

title: Missouri Awaits N.C.A.A. Verdict
description: Missouri will learn on Thursday its fate in a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation into its basketball program that lasted more than 18 months.

title: 36,000 Hours of Overtime
description: News dealers and their families are threatened, apples containing razors are thrown at drivers, a store carrying newspapers is set on fire, a bullet is fired into a truck and strong-arm squads are roaming the streets with baseball bats. Is this any way to decide the fate of The Daily News? More violence in a city already deeply corroded by violence?

title: Events: Gardens and Their Settings
description: Orchid Sale, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433.

title: War Talk Pushes Oil To $35.31
description: Spooked by tough talk from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the price of oil rose sharply yesterday. Traders also cited a variety of colorful rumors and further speculation about war.

title: THATCHER WIDENS CONTROL ON TORIES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher moved today to whip her Conservative Party back into line after the sudden resignation of her deputy and longtime political ally, Sir Geoffrey Howe, last week over the tone of her opposition to a federal Europe.

title: Ghosts of Disasters Haunting the Giants
description: Whom will the Giants play Sunday in Anaheim, Calif.?

title: Sakaigawa Journal; Faster Than a Speeding Bullet, It's Magnet-Train
description: For as long as Japanese have been riding trains, this country has harbored a dream: downtown Tokyo to downtown Osaka in an hour flat, a 325-mile journey in less time than most weary commuters spend getting to work each day.

title: Chronicle
description: Upon learning that American soldiers were pumping iron by hefting pails filled with sand, ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER , a former Mr. Universe, called his friend, Gen. COLIN L. POWELL , Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: KRIS MASON is still angry about how people responded when her 19-month-old daughter, Carley, started biting her playmates at day care. The child occasionally bit adults when she was excited and would sometimes bite other children when she was playing alone and they came too close. Although the bites did not break the skin, they were painful and left marks.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ABN-Amro Holding N.V., the Netherlands, said its merchant banking arm, Pierson Heldring and Pierson N.V., was negotiating to buy Elders Roach Asia Ltd., the Hong Kong brokerage unit of Elders IXL Ltd., Australia. * American Screen Co., New York, a motion picture and tape-production services company, has acquired 67 percent of TVC Image Technology Inc., a film-processing business. Terms were not disclosed. *Courier Dispatch Group Inc., Atlanta, said its board had rejected as inadequate an offer of $3.75 a share from John H. Harland Co. * Daewoo Corp., Seoul, South Korea, agreed to export $500 million in consumer products to the Soviet Union in return for Soviet natural resources. It will also build several factories there for $500 million. * Harley-Davidson Inc., Milwaukee, the motorcycle manufacturer, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to a million common shares, or about 5.6 percent of its common stock outstanding. * Kansas City Power and Light Co., Kansas City, Mo., said its hostile tender offer of $857 million for all shares of Kansas Gas and Electric Co. remained open despite Kansas Gas's agreement to be acquired by Kansas Power and Light Co. * Lotus Development Corp., Cambridge, Mass., the software maker, has begun an $18.84-a-share offer for all common shares outstanding of Samna Corp., Atlanta. * Moulinex S.A., Paris, which makes microwave products, said it was negotiating to buy Robert Krups G.m.b.H, a German appliance maker. * Oddo & Cie., a Paris brokerage, will sell 5 percent of its stock to Daiwa Securities Co., Tokyo. The deal would be through a capital increase to which Daiwa would be the sole subscriber. * Pier 1 Imports Inc., Fort Worth, a retailer of imported household items, has extended until Nov. 16 its $12-a-share offer for Sunbelt Nursery Group Inc., Fort Worth, which operates nurseries and garden supply stores. * Prakla-Seismos A.G., a German state-owned oil exploration company, will be sold to Schlumberger Ltd., New York, the oil-service company. No terms were disclosed. * Scott's Hospitality Inc., Toronto, a restaurant and hotel chain, said its Scott's Hospitality Ltd. unit had acquired 50 percent of Courtlands Leisure Ltd., a British operator of shopping-center restaurants. Courtlands' former owner was Scottish & Newcastle Breweries P.L.C., Scotland. Terms were not disclosed. * U. S. Long Distance Corp., Houston, a long-distance telephone services company, said its board had authorized the buyback of up to a million common shares.

title: Harold S. Coleman; Stockbroker, 81
description: Harold S. Coleman, a stockbroker for more than half a century, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: An English Manor Pays It With Flowers
description: AMANDA DOCKER was not to the manor born. But 13 years ago she and her husband, Fred, sank their savings into a crumbling Elizabethan pile called Armscote Manor near Stratford-Upon-Avon in the Cotswold Hills north of London. She was determined to find a way for the house and its 18 acres to support themselves, as manors were originally designed to do, and to pay for the restoration the 28-room house so badly needed.

title: War Talk Hurts Treasury Prices
description: Hawkish statements on the Middle East, a rise in oil prices and worrisome comments from a Federal Reserve Board governor combined to push down prices of Treasury securities and raise interest rates in rocky trading yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Asea Brown Boveri Inc., Stamford, Conn., a unit of ABB-Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., Zurich, a provider of steam, gas and hydro turbines, appointed Richard J. Slember president of its United States power plant businesses and executive vice president of ABB Inc. * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., an advanced technology company, named Donald J. Redlinger senior vice president of human resources. * DPL Inc., Dayton, Ohio, a gas and electric holding company, appointed Thomas M. Jenkins group vice president and treasurer. * Definicon International Corp., a unit of Helionetics Inc., Irvine, Calif., which makes computers, named Joseph Z. Perry president and chief executive. * First Interstate Bank of California, a subsidiary of First Interstate Bankcorp, Los Angeles, appointed Susan Whipple vice president and manager of its South Anaheim office. * General Public Utilities Corp., Parsippany, N.J., named Susan S. Schepman vice president in charge of communications. * Hansen Manufacturing Company,a subsidiary of IMC Magnetics Corp., Jericho, L.I., promoted William K. Poyner to president. * Kansas City Power and Light Co., Kansas City, Mo., said its president and chief executive, Drue Jennings, would take on the added post of chairman on Jan. 1, succeeding Arthur J. Doyle. * McDermott International Inc., New Orleans, a pipeline holding company, appointed M. E. Eagles vice president of marketing, engineering and its industrial groups. * Tultex Corp., Martinsville, Va., a clothing manufacturer, named Walter J. Caruba vice president of distribution and James M. Baker secretary and treasurer.

title: U.N. Honors Its Workers Held Against Will
description: The usual buzz of conversation and clatter of silverware in the staff cafeteria fell quiet at 12:30 P.M. today as the United Nations observed a minute of silence during its first day of solidarity for staff members detained or missing.

title: Message to Iraq: The Will and the Way
description: President Bush sought today to send an unmistakable message to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that the United States had the will to go to war, that it would soon have the means to go to war and that a war, if it came, would inevitably inflict terrible damage on Iraq.

title: PGA Director Agrees With Aronimink's Decision to Withdraw
description: The executive director of the PGA of America said yesterday that Aronimink Golf Club was right to withdraw as host of the 1993 P.G.A. Championship rather than risk a repeat of the furor that arose this year at Shoal Creek.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 10; Wild-Card Race Gives Redskins And Eagles Plenty of Motivation
description: The Washington Redskins' rematch against the Eagles on Monday night at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia probably won't affect the National Conference East title chase. The Redskins (5-3) have lost twice to the 8-0 Giants, and although Philadelphia (4-4) has a Nov. 25 home game with New York, it has already dropped a game to the Giants.

title: BRIEFS
description: COMMON STOCK * Oncotech Inc., Irvine, Calif., a clinical laboratory and drug development services company, is postponing its initial public offering because of poor market conditions. RATINGS * Federal-Mogul Corp.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to BBB, from A-, by S.& P. The corporation is based in Southfield, Mich. * Joy Technologies Inc.'s senior secured debt rating has been raised to BB-, from B, by S.& P. The company is based in Pittsburgh and is a leading producer of underground mining equipment.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on His Order to Enlarge U.S. Gulf Force
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference at the White House today, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company.

title: 2 Insurers To Cut Back
description: The ITT Hartford Insurance Group and the Aetna Life and Casualty Company said today that they planned to withdraw from various insurance markets in three states.

title: Reviews/Theater; 'Six Degrees' Reopens, Larger but Still Intimate
description: "How do we keep the experience?" asks an anguished Stockard Channing, fighting back anger and tears near the end of "Six Degrees of Separation," the John Guare play that reopened in a new and larger Lincoln Center theater, the Vivian Beaumont, with a new co-star, Courtney B. Vance, last night.

title: Laventhol Paying the Price For Accounting Ambitions
description: Laventhol & Howarth, the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm, tried to take on the giants of accounting, landing such diverse clients as Jim Bakker's P.T.L. and the film maker Woody Allen.

title: The Limits To Anger
description: The voters were angry. But they were not so carried away by anger that they would put their trust in a man of vindictive and tyrannical character, even though he promised real change.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: 'Kate' the Great

title: MOSCOW REFUSES TO RULE OUT FORCE
description: In its most explicit warning to Iraq yet, the Soviet Union said today that the use of force to end the Persian Gulf crisis could not be ruled out if diplomatic means fail.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Economic Stratagems

title: News Unions Said to Be Ready to Take Cuts
description: Striking workers at The Daily News are ready to make the same contract concessions to the financially shaky newspaper as their counterparts made to The New York Post two months ago, the leader of the paper's 10-union coalition said yesterday.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Sanchez Advances in Moscow Second-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain defeated unseeded Veli Paloheimo of Finland, 2-6, 7-5, 6-2, in the third round of the Kremlin Cup tournament in Moscow yesterday and advanced to the semifinals. Petr Korda of Czechoslovakia battled back to beat Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden, 1-6, 7-6, 6-2, in reaching the semifinals today. (AP) Graf Wins 17th in a Row: Steffi Graf needed just 36-minutes to beat Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, 6-0, 6-1, in the New England Virginia Slims at Worcester, Mass. Graf's 1990 record is 68-4, with 17 straight victories. In the other evening match, Mercedes Paz of Argentina became the only unseeded player to reach the quarterfinals with a 4-6, 7-5, 6-4 victory over Arantxa Sanchez Vicario of Spain. Earlier sixth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia struggled to eliminate Stephanie Rehe, 4-6, 6-2, 6-2, and eighth-seeded Amy Frazier of Rochester Hills, Mich., defeated Andrea Temesvari of Hungary, 6-3, 7-5. (AP) Krickstein Loses: Fifth-seeded Aaron Krickstein suffered a midmatch letdown and was beaten, 7-5, 6-4, by Peter Lundgren yesterday in the second round of an indoor tournament in Wembley, England, at which pigeons continually stopped play. No. 3 Michael Chang had more success than his American compatriot, advancing to the quarterfinals by defeating Jeremy Bates, 6-3, 6-3. (AP) Wilander Wins Easily: Mats Wilander of Sweden defeated Andrew Sznajder of Canada, 6-1, 6-0, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Citibank tournament, played in 100-degree temperature at Itaparica, Brazil. (AP) N.B.A. Bucks Overwhelm 76ers Ricky Pierce scored 28 points and Jay Humphries and Frank Brickowski sparked a third-quarter spurt to lift Milwaukee over Philadelphia, 141-111. The 76ers were forced to play most of the game without the starting guard Johnny Dawkins, who injured his right knee in the first quarter. The preliminary diagnosis was a torn anterior cruciate ligament. (AP) Rockets 103, Magic 99: Akeem Olajuwon had 25 points and 19 rebounds to power Houston. Olajuwon, who had fouled out of two of Houston's previous three games, scored 13 of his points in the final period. (AP) Jazz 103, Spurs 94: Karl Malone scored 9 of his 14 in the final 5 minutes 34 seconds as Utah handed San Antonio its 13th consecutive defeat at the Salt Palace. (AP) N.H.L. Flames Overwhelm Flyers Sergei Makarov and Joe Nieuwendyk each had a goal and three assists and Calgary scored five goals in the third period last night to defeat Philadelphia, 8-2, at the Spectrum. Stephane Matteau and Gary Roberts each had one goal and one assist for the Flames. (AP) Blues 3, Penguins 2: Michel Mongeau and Gino Cavallini scored power-play goals in the first five minutes of the third period to lead St. Louis. The Blues are 9-1-1 in their last 11 games and ended the Penguins' season-best streak of four consecutive victories. (AP) Canucks 5, Maple Leafs 3: Trevor Linden and Brian Bradley scored power-play goals to key a four-goal outburst as Vancouver handed Toronto its fifth consecutive defeat. (AP) North Stars 3, Nordiques 2: Gaeten Duchesne Shane Churla scored goals in the second period to lift Minnesota. (AP) Blackhawks 5, Oilers 3: The goaltender Ed Belfour became the league's first 10-game winner as Chicago extended Edmonton's all-time franchise losing streak to eight games. The Oilers, the defending Stanley Cup champions, are 1-10-0 in their last 11 games, 0-5-1 on the road and 2-10-2 over all. (AP)

title: Maurice Mann Dies; Stock Chief Was 60
description: Maurice Mann, an economist, banker and a former aide to President Richard M. Nixon, died Wednesday aboard an airplane returning to California from Florida. He was 60 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Stocks on Roller Coaster as Dow Rises 2.97
description: Stocks gyrated wildly yesterday, rising and falling with every rumor that raced through trading rooms.

title: Review/Pop; Peter Allen Becomes the Life of the Party
description: Peter Allen is not an outstanding singer, dancer or pianist, but when he gets going on the stage he becomes the life of the party, a saucy scamp who will go to almost any length to be entertaining.

title: Nixon Center Delays Access to Tapes
description: The newly opened Presidential library of Richard M. Nixon has postponed making two crucial Watergate tapes available to visitors. Instead, the director said, the museum is putting its money into acquiring 23 oil paintings by Dwight D. Eisenhower and expanding a display of gowns worn by Mr. Nixon's wife, Pat.

title: NASA Studying Ways to Redesign Space Station to Meet Budget Cut
description: At the urging of Congress, space agency officials say they have begun studying ways to redesign the space station Freedom that will probably result in a smaller orbiting station that will not be permanently occupied at first.

title: A Male Trait in Fish Has That Certain Something
description: The male swordtail fish has a long sword-like appendage extending from its rear fin that seems to serve no purpose other than to attract mates. Now a study has determined that the sword evolved to exploit a female taste for something entirely unrelated to courtship.

title: Review/Film; Sisters as Extremes of Civilization
description: "My 20th Century," a new Hungarian film written and directed by Ildiko Enyedi, is a number of wondrous things.

title: Washington Talk; Last Word on Taxes? Don't Hold Your Breath
description: The monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986, with its lower rates, fewer brackets and closed loopholes, was supposed to stay intact for many years, giving businesses, investors and ordinary families a stable tax system they could depend on to make financial plans.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The reclusive advertising agency founder and art collector CHARLES SAATCHI has bought 51 percent of Spy magazine for about $4 million. A spokesman for Mr. Saatchi in London would not comment on what Mr. Saatchi intends to do with the publication.

title: English Uber Alles
description: Unser Way of Life im Media Business ist hart, da muss man ein tougher Kerl sein. Morgens Warm-up und Stretching, dann ein Teller Corn Flakes und ein Soft Drink oder Darjeeling Tea, dann in das Office -- und schon Brunch mit den Top-Leuten, Meeting zum Thema: Sollen wir die Zeitung pushen mit Snob Appeal oder auf Low Profile achten?

title: FUSION RESEARCHER DISCUSSES FINDINGS
description: Two weeks after his absence set off an uproar, a top cold fusion researcher met privately with Utah officials today to discuss his work.

title: Hussein Ousts Chief of Staff Amid Signs of Army Dissent
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has dismissed his military Chief of Staff, an Iraqi newspaper reported today. Several Western officials said the move indicated dissension in the hierarchy of his armed forces.

title: A Year After the Wall, Some Nostalgia
description: Like all Berliners, Jan Faktor and his wife, Annette Simon, were dumbfounded when the Berlin wall opened a year ago on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about the Ohio elections misstated the result of the vote in the Seventh Congressional District and misstated the legislative position of a candidate. David L. Hobson, a Republican who is president pro tempore of the State Senate, defeated Jack Schira, a Democrat.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Bobby Short . . . Still

title: Trump Move Is Reported
description: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump, the New York developer and casino operator, are preparing bankruptcy papers for the Trump Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City in case such a filing is necessary, people close to the Trump Organization said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The latest odd couple: JOHN CLEESE and PRINCE CHARLES . The two are the stars of a new video, "Grime Goes Green: Your Business and the Environment."

title: Germans and Poles Agree to Pact on Oder Border
description: German leaders promised their Polish counterparts today that they would join them in signing a treaty this month that would formally establish the Oder and Neisse Rivers as the permanent border between the two countries.

title: New York Needs Its Practical Nurse Programs
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.&T. and NCR in Talks
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is negotiating a possible acquisition of the NCR Corporation or a combination of the companies' computer businesses, investment bankers and people involved in the discussions said yesterday.

title: Hartford? A Nice Place To Visit, Says Weicker
description: Governor-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. made his first public appearance today since his victory as a third-party candidate on Tuesday, but he gave little indication about the direction of his new administration.

title: Conference on Dance
description: George Balanchine's Ballets 1933 company and the dance career of Bronislava Nijinska will be discussed in a two-part conference today and tomorrow at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. Presented by the ibrary's ance ollection and the Dance Critics Associatin, the conferences -- which will include interviews, speeches and films -- are free and open to the public. They begin at 12:30 P.M. each day. Among the participants are Irina Nijinska, Igor Youskevitch, Frederic Franklin and Roman Jasinsky. The programs are presented in connection with two free exhibitions at the library. "Les Ballets 1933 and Beyond" will run through Jan. 19. "Bronislava Nijinska: Choreographer, Dancer, Teacher" opens on Dec. 7 and runs through April 6. Information: 870-1657.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ball Stalker Co., a contract office furniture unit of Arron Rents Inc., Atlanta, appointed Robert C. Loudermilk Jr. executive vice president. * John V. Carr & Son Inc., a subsidiary of Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit, promoted Richard E. Lowrie Jr. to chief executive and Stephen D. Marr to president and chief operating officer, replacing Richard A. Hazel, who is retiring. * Global America Inc., New York, an international investment banking firm, named Eugene J. Messenkopf chief operating officer. * Landes Organization, New York, a parent company for several entertainment ventures, appointed John J. Delucca president and chief financial officer of Landes and president and chief operating officer of its Lexington Group Ltd. financial evaluation corporate affiliate. * Leslie Fay Cos., New York, a clothing manufacturer, named Mitchell Lynn to the new position of vice president of its evenings division. * Oesterreichische Laenderbank, Vienna, appointed Gerhard Randa chairman and chief executive, succeeding Gerhard Wagner, who died in August. * Oneita Industries Inc., Andrews, S.C., producers of active wear and infants' wear, named Douglas E. Pease chief financial officer and vice president. * Pacific Stock Exchange, San Francisco, promoted Charles A. Rogers to executive vice president of trading floor operations; Stephen M. Pettibone to vice president of option trading services; Nancy A. Olmstead and Gary K. Staggs to vice presidents of equity floor operations; Erin E. Cosgrove to vice president and corporate secretary; Joseph F. Humphrey to vice president of finance, and Steven Schwartz to vice president of accounting. * Time-Life Video, a division of Time-Life Books Inc., Alexandria, Va., appointed Candice Carpenter president.

title: Citing Cancer of Prostate, Cranston Rules Out '92 Bid
description: Alan Cranston, a onetime Presidential candidate who is one of five United States Senators under investigation for ties to a savings and loan executive, announced today that he would not run for re-election in 1992 because of prostate cancer.

title: J. O. Zurhellen Jr., 70, A State Dept. Official
description: Joseph Owen Zurhellen Jr., a former Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs, died on Monday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 70 years old and lived in Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Review/Film; The Malicious Chucky Is Up to His Old Tricks
description: The opening shots of "Child's Play 2" show Chucky, the devilish doll incinerated at the end of "Child's Play," being scraped clean of charred crust and restored to full working order. This proves that movie ideas truly never die, not even when they ought to.

title: Missouri Gets Basketball Probation
description: Missouri's basketball team was put on two years' probation today, banned from the N.C.A.A. tournament in March and hit with severe restrictions on recruiting and scholarships. About an hour later, the school announced that the assistant coaches, Bob Sundvold and Rich Daly, had resigned, effective at the end of this season.

title: Eastern,Seeing Gain, Asks $30 Million More From Escrow
description: Martin R. Shugrue Jr., the trustee of Eastern Airlines, contending that Eastern's program of offering first-class seats to flyers who pay full coach fare has resulted in strong bookings and better cash flow, is asking the bankruptcy court to let the airline withdraw an additional $30 million from escrow funds to keep operating.

title: Greece Plans Privatizations
description: Greece has proposed legislation allowing the sale of 49 percent of state-controlled corporations to private interests.

title: Peace Corps Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloc Warns Europe on Plan
description: A 14-nation bloc of farm exporting countries said today that world trade talks might collapse unless the European Community changes its proposal on cutting agriculture subsidies.

title: Police Say Kahane Suspect Took Anti-Depression Drugs
description: Law-enforcement officials said yesterday that the man accused of killing Rabbi Meir Kahane was under psychiatric care and taking drugs for treatment of depression.

title: Giants' DeOssie Going at Full Speed
description: Steve DeOssie is 6 feet 2 inches tall and weighs 248 pounds. Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants calls him Beachball.

title: Demonstration in Bangladesh
description: Anti-Government demonstrators demanding the resignation of President H. M. Ershad fought with the police today, exploding homemade bombs in the center of Dhaka, the capital. Journalists at the scene said at least 20 people were injured. They said riot-equipped police officers fired rifles in the air and used tear gas and steel-tipped batons to disperse the protesters, numbering about 3,000, mostly students.

title: Johannes Eerdmans, Ex-Auto Importer, 85
description: Johannes Eerdmans, retired president of Jaguar Cars North America, died on Monday at the Eliot Center Hospital in Manchester, N.H. He was 85 years old and lived in Manchester.

title: Straw's $20 Million Burden
description: His father was George Sisler, a Hall of Fame first baseman for the St. Louis Browns who twice batted over .400. Dick Sisler was a first baseman whose three-run homer off Don Newcombe of the Brooklyn Dodgers on the final day of the 1950 season won the National League pennant for the Philadelphia Phillies. In that economy, his highest salary was $18,000.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILLIAM H. WEBSTER was given the Silver Buffalo Award of the Boy Scouts of America last week, "not because he's head of the C.I.A.," said Lee Sneath, a spokesman for the Boy Scouts, "but because of his contributions to young people." Mr. Webster is a former president of the Big Brothers program in St. Louis. He was also a Boy Scout, "a character-building experience for my life," Mr. Webster said. He said his three children had also been Scouts.

title: Eye on Voters, Bush Resurrects Anti-Tax Pledge
description: In a new twist to his political gyrations over taxes, President Bush promised today that he would never again break the no-new-taxes promise that he broke last summer in the Federal budget fight.

title: Mayor Dinkins, Finally on Track
description: The lurching, at least, is over even if the pain has just begun. Mayor David Dinkins yesterday did what he had to do to steer New York City out of fiscal calamity. After taking the city on a jolting ride of contradictory fiscal pronouncements a month ago, he now proffers a prudent and coherent plan for balancing the budget.

title: Black History Is Central to American History; Du Bois Deserves Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Twin Thugs With a Mother Complex
description: The white swan flying through the dream sequence that opens Peter Medak's spooky and transfixing new film, "The Krays," appears predatory and gray. And in a later scene, children in a schoolyard are made to resemble an insect swarm. By comparison, the twin gangsters who are the film's central characters could not look more innocent or pristine. A speck of someone else's blood on one of their clean, monogrammed white shirts is enough to cause them real dismay.

title: Citing Taped Talks, Lawyer for Noriega Wants Case Voided
description: The defense lawyer for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega said today that he would seek dismissal of the Federal drug trafficking charges against the deposed Panamanian dictator because, he said, conversations between him and his client had wrongly been tape-recorded.

title:
Affordable Housing;
Projects Being Priced to Sell in Queens
description: One of the casualties of the troubled New York housing market is the Embassy, a 27-story luxury condominium on Queens Boulevard at 75th Avenue in Forest Hills, where sales were suspended in May and construction halted.

title: Black History Is Central to American History
description: To the Editor:

title: Mars Introduces New M&M Candy
description: M&M-Mars has introduced a peanut butter M&M, but the newest version of the candy can only be bought on the West Coast because of limited production capacity, said Bill Deeter, a spokesman for M&M-Mars, a division of Mars Inc. He declined to predict when it would be widely available.

title: Review/Dance; Bill T. Jones In a Quest For Truth
description: Anyone who has mistakenly wandered onto a nudist beach will feel right at home in the audience at the Brooklyn Academy of Music when nearly 70 naked performers, diverse in size, race and age, end a sprawling three-hour discourse on freedom by the choreographer Bill T. Jones.

title: Economic Scene; Is the Deficit Cut A Serious Error?
description: AFTER failing time and again to work out a plan to eliminate the budget deficit during the years when the economy was climbing, the White House and Congress finally made a deal to cut the deficit by an estimated $40 billion in the next fiscal year and by $490 billion or so over the next five years -- just when most economists believe the economy is weak and falling into recession.

title: Topics of The Times; Governor Clean
description: There are many explanations for the victory of former Senator Lawton Chiles over Florida's Republican Governor, Bob Martinez. Polls indicate, for example, that Mr. Martinez was hurt by his strident anti-abortion stand and that Mr. Chiles triumphed in the only televised debate. But what stands out is the astonishing position Mr. Chiles took on campaign contributions.

title: Treasury Bond Auction Ends Well
description: The last, most speculative leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions went smoothly yesterday, as credit market participants bought $10.75 billion in 30-year bonds.

title: Disney Profits Increase 9%
description: The weakening economy slowed profit growth at Walt Disney Company to 9 percent in the quarter that ended on Sept. 30, the entertainment giant said today.

title: U.S.-Philippine Bases Talks Labeled 'Starting From Zero'
description: United States and Philippine officials negotiating the future of the American military bases here agreed today to disregard the existing security treaty and devise a new agreement.

title: Hong Kong Journal; From One Who Suffered, Dire Words on China
description: It was to be a private visit to Hong Kong, a rest after a grueling lecture tour of Japan. But once Nien Cheng agreed to sign copies of her book, "Life and Death in Shanghai," people here lined up by the hundreds in front of the little basement bookstore.

title: R. B. Okun Wed To Roni Dratler
description: Roni Susan Dratler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Dratler of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Robert Bruce Okun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Okun of Searingtown, L.I., were married last night. Rabbi Myron Fenster officiated at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Dr. Logan Wilson Is Dead at 83; Led University of Texas System
description: Dr. Logan Wilson, a former chancellor of the University of Texas system and past president of the American Council on Education, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Austin, Tex. He was 83 years old and lived in Austin.

title: Black History Is Central to American History; Great Books Fallacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Guitar Recital
description: Nicholas Goluses, a guitarist, is to give the New York premiere of Michael Blake Watkins's "Solus" at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow evening at 8. The program also includes Manuel de Falla's "Tombeau de Claude Debussy," Benjamin Britten's "Nocturnal," Bach's Sonata No. 2 in A minor (BWV 1003/964) and Manuel Ponce's Variations on "Folia de Espana." Tickets are $12 to $15. Information: 362-8719.

title: Books of The Times; In a School of Pain, Learning About Joy
description: Road Song By Natalie Kusz 258 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $18.95

title: Newswomen's Club Announces Winners of Its 1990 Awards
description: The Newswomen's Club of New York has announced its Front Page Awards for 1990, honoring work by female journalists in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Restaurants
description: The white double-stretch limo -- the "long enough to lie down in" kind -- was waiting for the blonde in the black-sequined jump suit with appliqued flowers and a clear plastic jacket. She emerged from dinner with her friend, also in black, the preferred dress of the hour at Luma in Chelsea. On one evening alone, there were 10 women in the uniform: black turtleneck; black leggings or tights; short blunt-cut hair. Straight from a tryout for another Obsession commercial.

title: Prior Restraints and Right to Counsel Entangle Noriega Legal Case
description: If criminal charges against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega are ultimately dismissed, as his lawyers say they will demand in light of today's developments, that determination will almost certainly be based not on the Cable News Network's broadcasting excerpts from jailhouse tape recordings, but the tapes' existence in the first place.

title: Margaret W. Poe, Dentist, 93
description: Dr. Margaret W. Poe, a retired dentist who also held a medical degree, died on Saturday at Humana Bennett Hospital in Plantation, Fla. She was 93 years old and lived in Plantation.

title: Cigarette Machine Ban Voted
description: The New York City Council yesterday passed a bill that would make New York the first large city in the United States to ban cigarette vending machines from most public places. The bill, which Mayor David N. Dinkins has indicated he will sign into law, would ban such machines from apartment buildings, gas stations, coin-operated laundries and theaters, as well as from restaurants where the sale of alcoholic beverages is incidental.

title: Review/Art; Evolution of French Landscape Painting
description: One of the most impressive gallery exhibitions to be mounted in New York in a long while has opened at Colnaghi, the Old Master dealer. "Claude to Corot: The Development of Landscape Painting in France," a display to benefit the Frick Art ReferenceLibrary, brings together 72 paintings and drawings, many of them from museum and private collections across the United States and Canada. With no fewer than seven works by Claude Lorrain, three by Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot, and paintings and drawings by the likes of Poussin, Watteau, Boucher, David, Philippe de Champaigne, Claude-Joseph Vernet and Fragonard, this show would do honor to any small museum. It is further illustration of the extent to which commercial galleries, buoyed by the skyrocketing art market of the 80's, have begun to stage shows of a scale and ambition previously reserved for museums.

title: U.S. Judge in Bias Case Sets January Vote in Los Angeles
description: A Federal district judge today set for January and February the special Los Angeles County elections that he ordered last summer, when he found that the county's governing board had intentionally diluted Hispanic voting strength in its drawing of election districts.

title: A lawyer's journey of discovery becomes a book on the horrors of the Treblinka death camp.
description: In 1986, Tom Teicholz, a New York lawyer, went on leave from his life as a real estate lawyer, a world of mortgages and points, contracts and certificates of occupancy.

title: Cash and Crud Are King
description: When I handed my ballot to the nice lady at my polling place, she gave me a stub that said "I have voted -- have you?" I suppose it was meant to make me feel virtuous. It should have said "Please shower after voting."

title: Toy-Based TV Shows Win Ruling
description: In a move that benefits advertisers and television broadcasters, the Federal Communications Commission proposed a rule today that would allow broadcasters to continue showing most shows based on popular children's toys like G.I. Joe, He-Man and ThunderCats.

title: Assault on Woman Of 46 Personalities Leads to Conviction
description: A man was convicted today of sexually assaulting a woman whom doctors described as having 46 personalities.

title: A Choral Premiere
description: John Daly Goodwin will conduct the New York Choral Society in the world premiere of Robert De Cormier's "Under the Greenwood Tree," a setting of the Sean O'Casey poem, at Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening at 8. Mr. De Cormier is the choir's music director emeritus. The program also includes Aaron Copland's "Old American Songs," Charles Ives's setting of Psalm 90, and George Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess" Concert Suite. The singers in the Gershwin will be Leavata Johnson, a soprano; Arthur Williams, a tenor, and Kevin Deas, a baritone. Tickets are $12 to $40. Information: 724-6633.

title: Hughes Danbury Is Cutting 90 Jobs
description: Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., citing Federal budget cuts, said it would eliminate about 90 jobs early next month, trimming its 920-person work force by about 10 percent. Layoffs of salaried workers will probably account for most of the cutback, a company spokesman, Tom Arconti, said.

title: Northern Telecom Is Under Review
description: The proposed acquisition by Northern Telecom Ltd. of the remaining 73 percent of the outstanding shares of STC P.L.C. for about $2.6 billion has prompted Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation to place the senior debt rating of Northern Telecom under review with negative implications.

title: Crowding of Rikers Inmates Is Ordered Eased
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ordered New York City yesterday to move scores of jail inmates from crowded holding pens that do not have working toilets and sinks. The judge also said that if the city did not ease overcrowding in all its jail receiving areas, he would hold it in contempt.

title: Iran to Get Japan Parts
description: The Japanese company Missho Iwai will sell $52 million in parts to Teheran for a petrochemical plant abandoned by another Japanese consortium, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported on Wednesday. The report, monitored in Nicosia, said the parts were for the trouble-ridden Bandar Khomeini petrochemical plant, the largest such project in the Persian Gulf region. It also said Missho Iwai and other Japanese companies would grant millions of dollars in credit to Iran in exchange for exports of liquefied natural gas. Missho Iwai will replace all components of the complex destroyed in the 1980-88 war with Iraq.

title: Veterans Day Monday
description: Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK

title: Licensing Fee Suit Against Microsoft
description: The Z-Nix Company, a personal computer supplier, filed a $4.5 million lawsuit against the Microsoft Corporation, the giant software company, charging restraint of trade and breach of contract. The suit, filed in United States District Court, says Microsoft agreed to license its popular Windows software to Z-Nix for $27.50 a copy. But Microsoft is said to have sought to double the fee when Z-Nix wanted to pair Windows with a device it produces that points out material on computer screens.

title: Teaneck Panel Sends Protest About 2d Jury
description: A majority of the jurors on a grand jury that exonerated a Teaneck police officer in the fatal shooting of a teen-ager has sharply criticized New Jersey's Attorney General for presenting the case to a second grand jury.

title: Peter H. Adler Memorial
description: A memorial service for Peter Herman Adler, former artistic director of the NBC Opera Company, is to be held on Tuesday at 5:30 P.M. in the C. Michael Paul Hall of the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street. Participants will include Kirk Browning, director of the "Live From Lincoln Center" television series. Mr. Adler died on Oct. 2 at the age of 91.

title: Kim and Eschenbach
description: The violinist Young-Uck Kim and the pianist Christoph Eschenbach will play Mozart's Sonatas in C (K. 296), E flat (K. 380), E minor (K. 304) and A (K. 526) at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: BUSH SENDS NEW UNITS TO GULF TO PROVIDE 'OFFENSIVE OPTION'; U.S. FORCE COULD REACH 380,000
description: President Bush today ordered more than 150,000 additional American ground, sea and air forces to the Persian Gulf area, saying they were needed to provide "an adequate offensive military option" to drive Iraqi troops from Kuwait.

title: Market Place; Sales Are Halted at 2 'Junk' Funds
description: Facing charges of fraud filed by New York and Massachusetts, the First Investors Corporation yesterday said it would halt sales of its two "junk bond" funds, including one it says was the first in the industry.

title: Critic's Choice
description: The London-based Hanover Band is well known to collectors of early-instrument recordings, having made its way through a good deal of the early-19th-century symphonic repertory in its growing series of disks for the Nimbus label. But its live appearances in the United States have been rare. This season, the group is celebrating its 10th anniversary, and is undertaking an American tour that takes it to Alice Tully Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HARRY REASONER is stepping down as a correspondent on "60 Minutes," the CBS News program. At the end of this season Mr. Reasoner, who is 67 years old and has appeared on the program since it began 23 years ago, will become an editor emeritus and will appear occasionally, the network announced yesterday. A successor has not been chosen.

title: Black History Is Central to American History;   Du Bois Deserves Better
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: New Prime Minister in India Chandra Shekhar, who helped to bring down India's coalition government on Monday, was named as the next prime minister. Page A3. Cranston Won't Run in '92 The Senate majority whip, Alan Cranston, under an inquiry for his savings- and-loan ties, said cancer would keep him from a re-election bid. Page A18. Grand Jury Protest Most of those on the grand jury that cleared a Teaneck officer in a teen- ager's death criticized New Jersey's Attorney General. Page B1. Offer by Daily News Unions Union leaders at The Daily News say they are ready to make the same contract concessions their counterparts gave The New York Post. Page B1. Lawrence Durrell Dies The author and poet who wrote the "Alexandria Quartet" novels died at home in France. He was 78. Page B7.

title: Two Punk-Rock Icons Adapt and Keep Going
description: Punk rock is slowly becoming a cultural myth, like the American Old West or 1950's greasers hanging out in front of a diner. Elements of the style have been absorbed into mainstream culture, from the prefabricated rips in the knees of Gap jeans to Sinead O'Connor's skinhead hairdo. But punk itself no longer exists as a distinct genre, and icons of the punk-rock movement, like Iggy Pop and the band Social Distortion, are having to adapt themselves in order to stay musically vital. Both Mr. Pop and Social Distortion will perform in Manhattan halls this weekend.

title: Elwood Ingledue, Founder of Hotel Guide, 91
description: Elwood Ingledue, founder of Hotel and Travel Index, a listing of hotel rates and services, died on Monday at his home in Glendale, Calif. He was 91 years old.
