title: High-Stakes Political Chess Begins in California
description: Senator Alan Cranston's decision not to run for re-election radically alters the chemistry of California politics, and Democrats and Republicans the length of the state began testing the political waters today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: BUSH WON'T SIGN DRUG-PROFIT BILL
description: President Bush will pocket veto a bill meant to stop companies from making huge profits under a law to stimulate production of drugs for rare diseases, White House officials said today. The bill was unanimously passed by Congress last month.

title: PROTEST IN FRANCE GAINING MOMENTUM
description: High school students demanding smaller classes, greater safety and vastly increased educational spending demonstrated in Paris and other French cities for the fourth straight day today, in a fast-growing movement that has thrown the Socialist Government on the defensive.

title: Search to Fill Bloomingdale Chairmanship
description: An informal search is under way to find a successor to Marvin S. Traub, longtime chairman of Bloomingdale's, sometime before 1993, officials of the department store chain and its corporate parent said yesterday.

title: Pact in Yonkers Ends New Delay In Housing Case
description: The developer selected to build court-ordered low-income housing in Yonkers agreed yesterday to the broad terms of a contract after a delay prompted by threats of boycotts and picketing against any bank that provided financing.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13

title: Vito Russo, 44; A Historian of Film and a Gay Advocate
description: Vito Russo, a film historian and critic and a prominent advocate of gay rights, died on Wednesday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 44 years old.

title: Key Rates
Political Consultants May Be Election's Big Losers
description: The big losers in Tuesday's elections may have been Washington insiders -- the major-league political consultants whose awkward advertisements and antics damaged their reputations and, in some cases, their candidates.

title: Runner Suffered Heart Defect
description: A 19-year-old Boston University student who collapsed and died during the Marine Corps Marathon in Washington on Sunday was buried today with military honors here.

title: Knicks Sweat One Out but Survive This Time
description: The Knicks did not lose any big leads last night, something they did in their three previous games. They never really had a big lead until the closing minutes of the game and then with an alert defense and a key 3-point basket by Kiki Vandeweghe they went on to beat the Washington Bullets, 114-103, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Rose Sells Off Property
description: Pete Rose appears to be breaking his ties with Cincinnati, where he grew up and spent most of his life.

title: Fed Urges Bank Rule Be Delayed
description: The Federal Reserve has urged the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay moves that would require banking companies to report market values for investment securities, a change the commission says would give invesors a better picture of a bank's financial condition.

title: The Halfway President
description: George Bush's Presidency approaches the two-year mark in disrepair. If Mr. Bush is interested in finding out why, he would do well to look not at Tuesday's election returns but at his own conduct before and during the midterm campaign. His problems, not entirely of his own making, include a faltering economy, the threat of war in the Persian Gulf and a restless Republican Party. But the greater difficulty is that he seems to have no governing style or strategy that could help him regain the initiative.

title: Lawrence Durrell, 78, Author, Is Dead
description: Lawrence Durrell, the British novelist and poet whose sensuous and exotic fiction, especially in the "Alexandria Quartet" novels, made him a sort of prophet of the sexual revolution of the 1960's, died Wednesday at his home in Sommieres, France. He was 78 years old.

title: TV Weekend; Once Again, It's Jeeves and Company
description: Sunday night, "a little late in the day," as Alistair Cooke confesses, "Masterpiece Theater" presents "Jeeves and Wooster," a five-parter adapted from the stories of P. G. Wodehouse. As Mr. Cooke notes in his capsule introductory biography, Wodehouse, who died in 1975, was not only one of the most popular writers of all time, but was also highly regarded by such worthies as Hilaire Belloc, Rudyard Kipling, Evelyn Waugh and George Orwell. Whether this new television series centered on his most famous creations, the unfailingly feckless Bertie Wooster and his valet, the formidably feckful Jeeves, will enhance that reputation is uncertain.

title: Review/Photography; When Pictorial and Purist Overlap
description: Pierre Dubreuil's work is the kind of historical curiosity that seems to pop up more often in photography than anywhere else. Dating from the early years of this century, it combines a wispy, Whistlerian estheticism with a modernist bent for machinery, overall pattern and abstraction. Needless to say, Dubreuil's pictures have long remained outside conventional photography histories.

title: Corrections
description: An anecdote yesterday in a roundup of vignettes about memorable moments in the 1990 political campaign misstated the outcome of the Michigan race for governor in some copies. John Engler, whose former wife, Colleen, wrote an autobiography but delayed publication, defeated James J. Blanchard and was elected governor, not re-elected.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I have today directed the Secretary of Defense to increase the size of U.S. forces committed to Desert Shield to insure that the coalition has an adequate offensive military option, should that be necessary to achieve our common goals." -- President Bush. [ A1:6. ]

title: Robert Jay Misch, 84, Food and Wine Writer
description: Robert Jay Misch, a writer on food and wine for more than four decades, died on Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Quitting, Bennett Blames Others for Work Undone
description: Formally stepping down as the first Director of National Drug Control Policy, William J. Bennett today assailed one of his Congressional critics and blamed Washington's Mayor for the failure to make good on a promise that the capital would be a showcase for the war on drugs.

title: Harold D. Klipstein, Lawyer, 82
description: Harold D. Klipstein, a lawyer in Manhattan, died on Tuesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Voters Showed A Loss of Trust, Cuomo Asserts
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo suggested yesterday that voters had sent him more of a message than a mandate, and he said the message was that New Yorkers no longer trust their government.

title: Campaign for Members Only Shifts Emphasis to Clothes
description: MEMBERS ONLY, the maker of casual men's clothing, made its reputation with an unorthodox marketing strategy that relied solely on a public service advertising campaign to fight drug abuse.

title: A Sudden Departure Leaves Fans Divided
description: Darryl Strawberry is gone, but life goes on. At least it seemed that way yesterday in Manhattan, where a sampling of baseball fans was clearly split on the sudden departure of the former Met right fielder.

title: What Did the Fire Destroy?
description: "Some wonderful moments in film history have been destroyed, just gone up in smoke," a Universal Studios executive said about the fire that consumed four acres of sets Tuesday night. She's right to be sad, but wrong about what was destroyed. All those buildings that went up in smoke were three-dimensional fantasies. Whereas what firemen struggled to save -- master prints of hundreds of films that had been kept in a vault -- are, in a sense, far more solid.

title: Taiwan Beckons Foreign Investors, but Its Stock Market Slips
description: At one time, the stock market here seemed to have no top, soaring ever higher and trading more shares than either the New York or Tokyo markets. Foreigners longed for a chance to join in the gains.

title: Ragged Chess Game 12 Ends in Draw
description: With a handshake on Wednesday night, Game 12 of the World Chess Match ended in a draw and its New York segment ended in a 6-to-6 tie. But both the champion, Gary Kasparov, and the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, have reason to be disappointed.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Caribbean Dance

title: Navistar International Names New Officers
description: The Navistar International Corporation, maker of heavy trucks and diesel engines, yesterday announced a new management lineup, with John R. Horne as president and chief operating officer.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Has 24% Quarterly Gain
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc. of Chicago reported yesterday that third-quarter net income rose 24 percent, to $3.1 million, or 30 cents a share, from $2.5 million, or 25 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenues rose 10.9 percent, to $86.3 million, from $77.8 million in 1989.

title: ANGOLAN LEADER GLOOMY ON TALKS
description: President Eduardo dos Santos of Angola says that the prospects for ending his country's 15-year-old civil war soon appear bleak. He accuses Jonas Savimbi, the American-backed rebel leader, of negotiating in "bad faith" and says he doubts that a new round of peace talks, scheduled for next week, will yield anything positive.

title: Budget Jockeying Is Fight for Survival
description: In tangling so publicly with the Dinkins administration over his budget, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez is fighting not only for the jobs of teachers but for his own credibility, and perhaps survival.

title: Net Jumps at B.P. and Shell
description: British Petroleum and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group today announced dramatically higher third-quarter profits, after riding a sharp rise in oil prices prompted by the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Betz Laboratories Inc., Trevose, Pa., a water treatment company, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 2 million more common shares. The company has bought back more than 1.7 million common shares under a 1989 share-buyback authorization. * British Steel P.L.C. London, said it would close a Scottish steelworks early next year, resulting in the loss of 1,200 jobs. British Steel said it had decided reluctantly it could no longer support the losses at the Clydesdale plant, which makes seamless steel tubes for the oil and gas industry. * Burger King Corp., Miami, has bought 27 Burger King restaurants in Massachusetts and New Hampshire for $48 million from Erin Food Systems Inc. * Canada Packers Inc., Toronto, a food processing company, said it would sell its edible oils division. * Cincinnati Milacron Inc., Cincinnati, a producer of machine tools, plastics machinery and other equipment, has completed the sale of its industrial robot business to ABB Robotics Inc., a unit of ABB Brown Boveri Group. Terms were not disclosed. * Huffy Corp., Miamisburg, Ohio, a maker of sporting goods equipment, has acquired Black & Decker Corp.'s United States and Canadian assets in True Temper Hardware as well as capital stock of True Temper Ltd. in Ireland for about $55 million. * JWP Inc., Purchase, N.Y., a technical services company, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to one million of the company's shares over the next 12 months. * Pratt & Whitney, a unit of United Technologies Corp., has received a $220 million order from Korean Air Lines for its Pratt & Whitney PW4000 jet engines to power up to 11 Airbus Industrie A300-600R airliners. * Rax Restaurants, Inc., Columbus, Ohio, an operator of fast food restaurants, said it would close and sell its 26 restaurants in Florida. * Teradata Corp., Los Angeles, a maker of computer systems, said it would cut its work force by 10 to 12 percent in an effort to return to profitability. Grand Metropolitan(Burger King)

title: Drexel Faces Claims by S.& L. Regulators
description: Federal savings regulators plan to file claims expected to reach billions of dollars against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., former employees and related entities, people with direct knowledge of the plans said yesterday.

title: Our Towns; A Man of His Age, And Still Driving In the Fast Lane
description: Eli Finn eased his '78 Cadillac onto I-95, heading for the history class he's taking at Fairfield University. "I still remember standing in front of my father's house in Russia, and the principal said, 'He's of college capability.' My father said, 'He will not go to college. I will educate him in the rabbinate.' Well that wasn't for me. So I came to America." That was 1907.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in The Living Section on Wednesday about young professionals worried about the economic downturn misidentified one. He is Richard Rottkov, not Mel Rottkov.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 525 money market mutual funds increased by $2.94 billion, to $418.33 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 162 institutional funds increased by $1.27 billion, to $104.22 billion. The assets of the 259 general-purpose funds were up by $1.06 billion, to $148.79 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds rose $608.5 million, to $165.33 billion, the institute said.

title: DINKINS ANNOUNCES JOB CUTS TO EASE BUDGET TROUBLES
description: Facing New York City's deepening fiscal problems, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would not hire workers to fill about 5,000 planned city jobs, would lay off at least 556 workers in schools, parks and hospital headquarters and make other cuts to keep the city budget balanced.

title: Review/Art; Audacity in Milton Avery's Paintings
description: For close on 20 years, the work of Milton Avery has been shown regularly at the Grace Borgenicht Gallery. To come across his pacific and lyrical art in the middle of a crowded and raucous season is a pleasure that renews itself without repetition. His current show there is no exception.

title: Sampras Withdraws From Indoor Tourney
description: Pete Sampras, the United States Open champion, withdrew from an indoor tournament in Wembley, England, yesterday with shin splints and said he may have to skip the Association of Tennis Professionals Finals in Germany next week.

title: Israeli and Intruder Killed in Jordan Border Clash
description: An Israeli soldier and an Arab gunman were killed in a firefight in the Israeli-occupied West Bank early this morning when troops battled armed infiltrators from Jordan, the army said.

title: Dispute and Deadlock
description: The dispute between the major leagues and the National Association, the umbrella organization for the minor leagues, reached a new low yesterday, with no apparent end in sight.

title: Trial Ordered in Suit Over Silver at Sotheby's
description: The State Supreme Court was ordered yesterday by the Apellate Division in Manhattan to proceed to trial on two conflicting claims of ownership on 14 pieces of ancient Roman silver that Sotheby's is trying to sell for the Marquess of Northampton.

title: Four Carless Ways to Slip a City's Bonds
description: NEW YORK is a city where people don't have to have a car to get around. But the wanderlusting know just how confining the last few weekends before winter can feel. If winter is a time to come into town -- to see the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center or the department-store windows -- this is a time when people who don't have cars wonder if they can squeeze in one last get-away-from-it-all weekend.

title: Absolut Focuses on Environment
description: Absolut Vodka's holiday campaign will be quite a departure from its usual funky, festive ad. It has the requisite gimmick, but the focus has switched from social drinking to social consciousness.

title: The Skipper Quits
description: The brand new sailing vessel had just about cleared land for the journey across the ocean when the skipper decided to get off.

title: Accounts
description: * Thompson Medical Co., West Palm Beach, Fla., to Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson, New York, for their Sleepinol sleeping aid and Encare contraceptive accounts, with a combined budget of more than $5 million. * Bahamas Ministry of Tourism to Caroline Jones Advertising, New York, for the United States-based black consumer campaign and on-shore tourism awareness campaign, with a budget of more than $1 million. * Nutri/System Inc., Willow Grove, Pa., to Earle Palmer Brown & Spiro, Philadelphia, for its national recruitment advertising, with a reported budget of $2 million. The account was previously handled by Cameron, Newell Advertising, Van Nuys, Calif. * L'Habitation, Paris, the account for a beach resort in St. Martin, French West Indies, to Kirshenbaum & Bond, with undisclosed billings.

title: Eastern Europe: An Update
description: BULGARIA Nov. 10, 1989: Todor Zhivkov, long-time party leader, is replaced by Petar T. Mladenov, who also becomes head of state on Nov. 17. Jan. 16, 1990: start of round-table talks between the Government and the opposition. Feb. 6, 1990: the opposition party U.D.K. rejects participation in the Government. June 10, 1990: free elections held, Communists (renamed Socialists) come out as the strongest party with 48 percent of the vote. A run-off election on June 17 gives the Communists a majority in Parliament. July 6, 1990: Mr. Mladenov resigns over charges that he had ordered use of force against demonstrators in December. Aug. 1, 1990: Parliament names Zhelyu Zhelev, leader of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, the country's first non-Communist President in four decades. Looking Ahead The Government rationed fuel in mid-October. Basic foods like cheese, sugar and oil are obtainable only with special tickets. The United States said in September it would supply 100,000 tons of corn until the end of the year.

title: Hearst to Buy 20% ESPN Stake From RJR
description: The Hearst Corporation said yesterday that it was buying RJR Nabisco Inc.'s 20 percent stake in ESPN, the nation's largest sports cable network.

title: Strawberry Greets L.A. and Welcomes Dream
description: Darryl Strawberry, Los Angeles Dodger and family man, introduced his new boss, Fred Claire, to his wife and children today at a Dodger Stadium news conference. Then he introduced himself to Dodger fans.

title: At the Movies
description: A Romantic Mixture

title: Chopin as Subject
description: Phyllis Billington, a pianist, will present a lecture and recital entitled "Chopin -- Poet and Patriot," tonight at 7 at the Kosciuszko Foundation House, 15 East 65th Street. Miss Billington's program includes the Nocturne in B and the Scherzo in C sharp minor. Tickets are $14. Information: 734-2130.

title: Tagliabue's Extra Point
description: Paul Tagliabue, commissioner of the National Football League, said last night he had not ruled out Phoenix as the site for the 1993 Super Bowl.

title: Bomb Suspect Says All U.S. Judges Are Biased
description: A man charged with killing a judge and a Georgia lawyer in a series of mail bombings last winter argued today that the Government's indictment essentially accuses him of waging war against the Federal judiciary and that all Federal judges should therefore be barred from hearing his case.

title: Curbing Sexual Harassment in the Legal World
description: As more women enter the legal profession, the law firms that hire them are increasingly confronting a problem they have long ignored: sexual harassment in their own offices.

title: Japan's Chief and Rivals Agree On Plan for Civilian Gulf Force
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, rebuffed by the political opposition on his proposal to send military forces to the Persian Gulf, reached agreement with key opposition groups this morning on a new proposal to send a civilian contingent of Japanese to operate in the region.

title: Carol Sobieski, 51, A Writer of Scripts For Films and TV
description: Carol Sobieski, a film and television writer who was widely praised for her sensitive characterizations in original or adapted works, died on Sunday at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 51 years old.

title: New Jet Knows The Drill
description: Although he's the newest member of the Jets, Ken Johnson, the safety acquired from the Vikings on Wednesday, is not a complete stranger in the Jets' locker room.

title: Sylvan Geismar, 97, Shirt Company Chief
description: Sylvan Geismar, retired chairman of the Manhattan Shirt Company, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 97 years old.

title: New Hoosier Hysteria: Freshman Is a Legend
description: The letter jacket from Bedford North-Lawrence High School, adorned with enough distinctions to qualify for display in the Basketball Hall of Fame, hangs in a bedroom closet 20 minutes removed from the new home of Damon Bailey, freshman history student at Indiana University.

title: Taking Dodgers' $20 Million, Strawberry Leaves the Mets
description: Darryl Strawberry completed his clamorous exit from New York's baseball stage yesterday when he left the Mets as a free agent and signed with the Los Angeles Dodgers for five years at $20.25 million. The contract is second only to the $23.5 million deal signed by Jose Canseco of the Oakland Athletics in the sport's spiraling financial market.

title: First Step of Florio's Tax Retreat: Repealing Assessment on Trucks
description: Bowing to pressure from business groups and legislators, Gov. Jim Florio agreed yesterday with legislative leaders to repeal a new sales tax on heavy trucks, his first retreat on a $2.8 billion tax package that has infuriated New Jerseyans.

title: Executive With Trump Joins Housing Company
description: Anthony B. Gliedman is leaving the big-city real estate aura of the Trump Organization to become chief executive-designate of the Amrep Corporation, which builds moderate-priced housing in New Mexico and Florida land developments.

title: John Fuller, 76, Playwright, Dies; Wrote Books on the Unexplained
description: John Fuller, a playwright, documentary film producer and author of many books about the unexplained, died Wednesday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The trial of a lawsuit against ELIZABETH TAYLOR filed by HENRY WYNBERG , once a close friend of the actress, will begin in Los Angeles on Dec. 5. Superior Court Judge COLEMAN SWART refused Wednesday to dismiss Mr. Wynberg's suit.

title: Wall Street Cutting Muscle Now
description: In the last three years, Wall Street has seen two stock market crashes, several investment houses go bankrupt or nearly collapse, some of its most profitable businesses evaporate and tens of thousands of employees lose their jobs.

title: Seeing New York With a Poet's Eye
description: "YOU cannot have any preconceived notions when you look at New York City," says Charles Simic, the winner of this year's Pulitzer Prize for poetry. "If you have preconceived notions about beauty, about culture, you're not going to see anything. But if you have an open mind, you're going to find interesting things in the most unlikely places. The model for this is Walt Whitman. More than a century ago he discovered the joys of walking around Manhattan and looking at things and delighting in their diversity.

title: Blaylock Powers Nets in Home Opener
description: It had been so long since the Nets won a regular-season game, seven months, that they were not going to worry about where or how it happened. They just wanted it to happen.

title: Review/Art; The Yangzhou Eccentrics, Rule-Breakers All
description: The "eccentric painters" of Yang zhou are a loosely defined group of 18th-century Chinese painters who lived for at least several years in Yangzhou, a Qing Dynasty center of commerce and pleasure. These sometimes wild and not always wonderful painters (their number varies from 8 to 11) saw themselves as heirs of the great Individualists of the 16th and 17th centuries, like Zhu Da and Shitao, who helped define an esthetic of audacity, self-expression and transformation.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Graf Looking to Clean Up at Garden
description: Although she captured only one Grand Slam event on this year's women's tennis tour, Steffi Graf may still be in a position to push her winnings for 1990 over the $2 million mark as the top-seeded player in the weeklong $3 million Virginia Slims championship, which begins Monday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Baby Death at Hospital Tied to Heart Problem
description: An 8-month-old boy who was found dead last week in his crib at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx died of a heart problem, not the removal of a breathing tube, the Chief Medical Examiner said yesterday.

title: Topics of The Times; What Housing Slump?
description: The real estate business is in its worst shape in years. But you'd never know that from the deals being done in Lotusland. Out in star-studded Malibu, according to The Los Angeles Times's weekly "Hot Property" column, the Frank Sinatras paid $3 million for "an ocean-front tear-down" -- realtor jargon for a house to be wiped away so the new owners can build something they like better. And Arsenio Hall has bought Rudy Vallee's old place in Hollywood Hills for a reported $3.5 million cash, without even setting foot in the place.

title: Plenty of Talent Out There For Mets to Try to Fill Gap
description: If the Mets had to pick a time to blunder into the loss of Darryl Strawberry, they could have done worse than now.

title: Albania Chief Urges Charter Be Changed to End Atheism
description: President Ramiz Alia of Albania said his hard-line Communist country should revise the Communist Party's leading role and end the policy of atheism in the Constitution, the state press agency said today.

title: Latvian Choir Came To Seek Brethren
description: To the Editor:

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
McDonnell's New Jet Is Ready for Delivery
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that the Federal Aviation Administration had certified its new MD-11 wide-body jet, giving the company permission to begin deliveries to the first of 32 customers by the end of the year.

title: How Best to Test for Criminal Obscenity
description: To the Editor:

title: Mandatory Minimum Lacking for Crack
description: To the Editor:

title: Bull to Cut 7 Plants and 5,000 Jobs in Europe and North America
description: In another sign of sagging fortunes for Europe's computer industry, Compagnie des Machines Bull of France announced today that it would close seven plants and cut 5,000 jobs in Europe and North America.

title: Jaguar Workers Accept Contract
description: Employees of Jaguar and the Rover Group have voted to accept new contracts that include double-digit pay increases in the first year, the companies said. Rover Group's 31,000 hourly workers approved their new contract by nearly 5 to 1. It gives them an 11 percent raise this year and a 7.5 percent raise in 1991.

title: Corrections
description: A crossword puzzle definition yesterday for 23 Across misidentified a Richard Gere movie. It is "Pretty Woman," not "Pretty Lady."

title: For Eastern Europe Now, a New Disillusion
description: A group of Czechoslovak students, veterans of the demonstrations a year ago that brought down the Communist Government, issued a statement recently urging that the anniversary not be marked this year, because "we don't want former Communist officials coming out cheering and laughing in our faces."

title: Car Loans Back Chrysler Offering
description: A $1.3 billion offering of certificates backed by Chrysler car loans was priced yesterday through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Review/Film; A Soldier at One With the Sioux
description: KEVIN COSTNER has come a long way after playing the man whose suicide was the peg for "The Big Chill" but whose role was left on the cutting-room floor.

title: Shots in Red Square Are Echo of a Thriving Market in Arms
description: The daily newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda recently sent reporters out shopping for guns to dramatize the flourishing Soviet black market in arms.

title: Auctions
description: November Sales, Round 2

title: Miscellany
description: * Sosa & Associates, a Hispanic advertising agency in San Antonio, has expanded into a full-fledged marketing communications firm, with the new name Sosa, Bromley, Aguilar & Associates. Its current billings are more than $60 million. * Sudler & Hennessey, a health-care advertising unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., has formed a worldwide board to oversee expansion efforts. The company will now also consolidate all of its reporting directly to Joe DeDeo, president and chief of Y.&R. * Robert Snyder has left his position as creative director at Barham & Partners, New York, to start his own agency, Snyder & Partners. Its first account is the Aris Isotoner gloves and slippers account, with $8 million billings.

title: Telecom Bid To Buy STC
description: Northern Telecom Ltd., the leading Canadian telecommunications company, made a takeover offer today of $:1.3 billion, the equivalent of about $2.6 billion, for the British electronics company STC.

title: Rodrigo Moynihan, 80, a Pioneer Of Abstract Painting in England
description: Rodrigo Moynihan, a painter and teacher and a co-editor of Art and Literature: An International Review, died Tuesday in London after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Patents; Auto Beams Shift With The Traffic
description: DRIVERS at night frequently fume when they are blinded by approaching cars with headlights on the high beam. Yet the need to continuously flick between high-beam and low-beam lights as traffic ebbs and flows can confuse even the most conscientious drivers.

title: Your Money; Some Strategies For Hard Times
description: A CROSS America, hard times are turning to granite for hundreds of thousands of people. And it is not just those caught in the layoffs sweeping manufacturing plants, Wall Street firms, banks and city hall, but also real estate investors and the self-employed. Financial survival depends on making the right decisions and avoiding panic responses.

title: Sentex Sensing Tech reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Not the Declaring Type
description: The Bush people want the United Nations to approve the use of force against Iraq. "Use of force" -- that means the same thing as "make war."

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "By the strictest definition of plagiarism -- that is, any appropriation of words or ideas -- there are instances of plagiarism in these papers." -- Clayborne Carson, the editor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s papers. [ 1:1. ]

title: Patents; An Advance Reported In Linking Lego Blocks
description: Rolf Myller, an architect with the Department of General Services in New York City, has patented what he said was an improvement in Lego blocks, the interlocking plastic blocks that have captivated children for decades.

title: Nobel Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossThe company said its third-quarter gain is due to an increase in investment income, a decrease in expenses and an improvement in its claim ratio. Results were affected by the increase of its stake in Epic Insurance Co. to 86 percent, allowing Nobel to book the unit's income with its own.

title: Bridge
description: When a declarer rejects an obvious finesse and drops a singleton king held on his left, the opponents sometimes suspect good eyesight.

title: Gorbachev Signs Treaty in Bonn And Is Hailed for His Unity Role
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was hailed in Germany today on the anniversary of the breach of the Berlin wall for helping make German unity possible. But the Soviet leader's reduced status was underscored when he appealed to the Germans to be tolerant of the Soviet troops still stationed on their soil.

title: Rating Cut On 4 Banks In Japan
description: Long-term bond ratings of four large Japanese banks were reduced yesterday by Moody's Investors Service because of weak earnings and troubles with declining real estate prices in Japan.

title: E.D.S. to Develop Systems for Saab
description: Electronic Data Systems, the computer services division of the General Motors Corporation, will develop computer systems and applications for the Swedish auto maker Saab in a 10-year deal worth an estimated $300 million. The contract is the first of its type for a Swedish company. It is also the first time E.D.S. has acknowledged working for another auto maker.

title: Dr. King And the Super Bowl
description: Five states in the United States combine Martin Luther King Day with Robert E. Lee Day. It is ironic that the man who fought for greater freedom for blacks in America is so paired with the man who commanded the Confederate army to, in effect, retain the slave system in this land.

title: Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 66,436, or 1 cent a share, from sale of real estate.

title: Knee Injury Sidelines Philadelphia's Dawkins
description: The Philadelphia 76ers are losing half of their high-powered backcourt for at least five games. Johnny Dawkins, the point guard who usually teams with Hersey Hawkins, was placed on the injured list yesterday after he was forced to leave Philadelphia's game Thursday night against the Bucks in Milwaukee with a knee injury.

title: Outdoor Wear: Sorting Out the Choices
description: Parkas, shells and other rugged outdoor wear are supposed to be part of the simple life. But increasingly, buying such clothing is anything but simple.

title: Lageman and Townsell Work Out
description: Jeff Lageman, the defensive end still bothered by a deep thigh bruise, and JoJo Townsell, the kick returner with turf toe, saw limited practice for the Jets today, but were still listed as questionable for the game Sunday against the Miami Dolphins in Giants Stadium.

title: U.S. SAYS ITS TROOPS WON'T BE ROTATED UNTIL CRISIS IS OVER
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the Pentagon was no longer planning to rotate troops through Saudi Arabia and that the American forces already in the Persian Gulf area or headed there would remain for the duration of the crisis.

title: Yes Clothing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Defying Judge, CNN Televises Tape of Noriega
description: In defiance of a Federal judge, Cable News Network tonight broadcast what it said was a tape-recorded conversation between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed Panamanian leader, and a member of his legal team.

title: Murree Journal; Hill Station Thrives, a Piece of Time Gone By
description: In the days of the British raj, when the white-hot sun of the subcontinent's summer drained colonial administrators of energy and patience, and stifling nights under mosquito nets robbed them of sleep, the empire was saved by the hill stations.

description: b-After income of $ 11,680,000, or 10 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net loss and after charges to income associated with the 1989 settlement with New York State concerning the Shoreham nuclear power station and a class settlement concerning Rico litigation.The earnings for the 9 months of 1990 reflected the positive effect of the Shoreham settlement for the entire 9 months, while the comparable period in 1989 reflected only 3 months of the settlement.

title: About New York; Stress Sufferers! Relief Is Here (Even if Comic)
description: Sometimes it takes an outsider to focus our thoughts. The other day we found ourselves at a fancy restaurant chatting with a Georgia onion farmer, Delbert Bland.

description: b-Net incomeThe company attributed the decrease in year-to-date earnings to various state-mandated assessments and associated expenses.The company said the state's recurring unsatisfied claim and judgment fund rate was increased to 7.3 percent in 1990 from 3.3 percent in 1989, causing an increase in third-quarter expenses of $ 773,000. The New Jersey Automobile Insurance Risk Exchange adjustment increased expenses by $ 769,000 in the quarter, while the New Jersey Fair Automobile Reform Act has required the accrual of $ 2,559,000 in recurring surtaxes and assessments, including $ 757,000 in the third quarter.

title: U.S. Cellular Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Interest-Rate Drop Pushes Dow Up 44.80
description: A strong decline in interest rates, plus the prospect of more to come, lifted the stock and bond markets sharply yesterday.

title: Transport Secretary Given A Dismal Report by Airlines
description: Samuel K. Skinner, the Secretary of Transportation, concluded two days of talks with top airline executives yesterday aimed at assessing the damage caused by higher fuel costs and is now considering ways to aid the faltering industry, said a senior agency official who spoke on the condition he not be identified.

title: Israel Raids Area North of Its Lebanese 'Zone'
description: Israeli troops attacked north of Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon today after Israeli officials guaranteed the safety of Christians living nearby.

title: Arrest in Robbery of a Nun
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday and charged with knocking down and dragging an 81-year-old nun as he tried to snatch her purse as he rode by on a bicyle Wednesday. Sister Joseph Concepta Farrell broke her hip and left wrist, said a police spokeswoman. She had been returning to St. Cecilia's Convent at 21 Monitor Street in the Greenpoint section at 5:10 P.M. when Edward Hernandez, of 417 Morgan Avenue, rode up and grabbed at her, the police said.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Stands Tall as Devils Fall Short
description: The Rangers tonight presented more of the inspired goaltending and effective defensive play that have helped them monopolize the Patrick Division so far this season.

title: The Things With Which She Was Alone
description: Two kinds of people turned out for the opening of a five-day exhibition of the Collection of Greta Garbo at Sotheby's auction house yesterday: People who appreciate paintings by Renoir and Bonnard and French antique furnishings with a classy provenance. And people who would have gone to an exhibition of Garbo's garbage.

title: Rexhall Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company said sales are lower due to the impact of the Gulf crisis.

title: Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Insta Cool Inc. of North America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vanguard Cellular Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company attributed its higher losses this quarter compared to last year primarily to increased interest expense related to outstanding borrowings under its line of credit.

title: Plagiarism Seen by Scholars In King's Ph.D. Dissertation
description: Torn between loyalty to his subject and to his discipline, the editor of the papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. reluctantly acknowledged yesterday that substantial parts of Dr. King's doctoral dissertation and other academic papers from his student years appeared to have been plagiarized.

title: North American National reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $ 34,350, or 1 cent a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.All share earnings for 1989 periods have been adjusted for a 6-percent stock dividend paid in July 1990.

title: Mayor Forced Out in 1984 Wins Election in Providence
description: A recount today by the State Board of Elections gave the race for mayor here to Vincent A. Cianci Jr., a Republican who was forced from the office in 1984 because of his conviction for assault.

title: Bobby Scott, 53, Dies; Composer and Singer
description: Bobby Scott, a musician, conductor and arranger who wrote the songs "A Taste of Honey" and "He Ain't Heavy, He's My Brother," died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 53 years old.

title: Belgium Seeks To Sell Sabena
description: The Belgian Government is seeking private investors for the national airline Sabena, the Communications Minister, Jean-Luc Dehaene, said today.

title: Anya Seton, Author of 'Foxfire' And Other Novels, Is Dead at 86
description: Anya Seton, the author of several popular historical and biographical novels, two of which were made into successful films, died on Thursday at her home in Old Greenwich, Conn. She was 86 years old.

title: In Berlin a Year Later, The Wall Still Lingers
description: One year after it was breached by throngs of jubilant and incredulous Germans, the Berlin wall is disappearing.

title: Ironstone Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charge of $ 1,225,000 in the quarter and 9 months related to settlement of litigation and a charge of $ 3,473,000 in the 9 months only related to restructuring.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The first Courage in Journalism awards, established by the International Women's Media Foundation, will be given to four journalists on Sunday in Washington at a foundation conference, headed by JUDY WOODRUFF of the MacNeil/Lehrer News Hour and SUSAN KING an anchorwoman at WJLA-TV, in the capital.

title: Peter Asch, Professor, 52
description: Dr. Peter Asch, a professor of economics at Rutgers University, died on Wednesday at his home in Belle Mead, N.J. He was 52 years old.

title: Edith Schaffer Phillips, Ex-ABC Executive, 82
description: Edith Schaffer Phillips, a former official of the American Broadcasting Company, died on Friday at her home in Lake Worth, Fla. She was 82 years old.

title: Woman With a Shovel Gets Ready to Govern
description: For months it's been shovels: shovel pins on her lapel, shovels in her hands, shovels in campaign speeches that said a mere broom wouldn't be enough to clean up City Hall. Now the question is whether Sharon Pratt Dixon, Washington's Mayor-elect, can turn her winning metaphor into a workable government.

title: U.S. Envoy to U.N. on Center Stage
description: America's United Nations representative, Thomas R. Pickering, celebrated his 59th birthday on Monday by taking the president's chair at a Security Council meeting for the first time since the Persian Gulf crisis broke.

title: Its Money Running Out, Philadelphia Offers Plan
description: Two months after Wall Street turned off Philadelphia's credit and three weeks before the city could run out of money for most services, Mayor W. Wilson Goode and other city and state officials today announced a plan to rescue the city.

title: Cheryl M. Pascoe Wed in Baltimore
description: Cheryl Marie Pascoe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Pascoe 3d of Baltimore, was married there yesterday to John William Highfield 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Highfield Jr. of Baltimore. The Rev. John B. Ward performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Mary Our Queen.

title: Piedmont Management Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Books of The Times; Finding Humor in Castro and His Cuba
description: Cuba A Journey By Jacobo Timerman. Translated by Toby Talbot. 125 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL Japan Clinches Series on a Tie Japan clinched its first series victory over a major-league all-star team when it played a 6-6 tie last night for a 4-1-1 lead in the eight-game series. Although a Japanese all-star team beat the San Francisco Giants, 6-3, in 1970, Japan had never won an all-star series. Major leaguers began making tours in 1951. Kelly Gruber of the Toronto Blue Jays and Jesse Barfield of the Yankees hit consecutive run-scoring singles in a three-run seventh inning as the major leaguers gained the tie. In Japan, tie games are frequently played during the regular season.(AP) TENNIS

title: Vintage Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rival of Singh Becomes India Premier
description: Nearly a week of political uncertainty ended today when Chandra Shekhar, the leader of a breakaway faction that helped topple the national coalition Government, was installed as Prime Minister.

title: Judge Calls 22 Keating Charges Too Vague
description: A state judge ruled today that more than half of the 42 fraud charges filed in September against Charles H. Keating Jr. and three other former executives of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association were too vague to be brought to trial.

title: Jews in Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Running Mate Says She Could Have Helped
description: Lieut. Gov. Martha Griffiths says Gov. James J. Blanchard lost his job on Election Day in part because he had removed her as a running mate.

title: Giants Sign Black
description: Bud Black, a 33-year-old left-hander with an 83-82 career record, yesterday agreed to a $10 million, four-year contract with the San Francisco Giants, the team announced.

title: Coping; With Leather Cleaning
description: Consumers pay a hefty price for clothes made of fine suede and leather, and proper care is essential to maintaining them.

title: To Stop the Killing Soon in El Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Lazy Violence Punctuates A Drug War in Disarray
description: "The Return of Superfly" is a sequel whose time has long since passed. The original "Superfly," directed by Gordon Parks Jr. and released in 1972, was one of the more successful of the so-called "blaxploitation" movies of the early 1970's.

title: The Two Faces of Southern Populism
description: George Wallace, that Southern ghost of elections past, still haunts us as we enter the 1990's.

title: Dangers Can Lurk In Luggage
description: You've packed for a week's vacation and the luggage you are entrusting to the airline contains some seemingly harmless items: matches, nail-polish remover, a cigarette lighter, a can of hair spray.

title: Lawrence Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Doctors Urge Public to Heed Dangers of Flu
description: Dismissing influenza as an inevitable risk of winter could be a fatal mistake, doctors say, warning that flu kills an average of 20,000 Americans a year.

title: Navratilova Withdraws From Slims Tourney
description: A dejected Martina Navratilova announced yesterday that she was withdrawing from the Virginia Slims Championships, the $3 million year-ending event that begins Monday at Madison Square Garden because of persistent pain in her right knee.

title: HOLIDAY ON MONDAY
description: Veterans Day is observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Fifth Avenue will be closed from 24th to 39th Streets from 8:30 A.M. until noon. Govermnet offices: Federal, state closed. Local closed in New York City, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam and Long Island. Post Office: No regular delivery except for Express Mail. Special delivery at certain locations. Emergency window open at main post office at 33d Street and Eight Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pickups and street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses and commuter railroads on regular schedules. NEW JERSEY Govermnet offices: Federal, state closed. Municipal have option to close. Post offices: Same as New York. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: Regular New Jersey Transit trains, buses and PATH on regular schedule. CONNECTICUT Govermnet offices: Federal, state closed. Municipal offices have option to close. Post offices: Same as New York. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Regular schedules.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MSTISLAV ROSTROPOVICH is remembering his friend, Leonard Bernstein, in the way many people are, through music. But Mr. Rostropovich is playing works that Mr. Bernstein wrote specifically for him.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column yesterday referred incorrectly to Bard College, in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. It is not part of Columbia University, although it was from 1928 through 1944. The column also omitted the title of Hyman P. Minsky, a Bard professor. He is a fellow at the college's Jerome Levy Economics Institute.

title: A Museum Chief Greets the Fray
description: When art collides with politics, museums shouldn't stay aloof. That's the view of Kathy Halbreich, who was recently named director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. "If museums and universities are not helping us to understand crucial issues concerning First Amendment rights, I don't know who will," she said in a recent interview.

title: F.D.A. Approves Medication For Treating Panic Disorder
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first medication for the treatment of panic disorder, a condition that will affect about three million Americans at some point in their lives.

title: Bush Signs Food-Labeling Bill
description: President Bush today signed legislation requiring food manufacturers to put more nutrition information on package labels. The bill, intended to help consumers choose a more healthful diet, sets specific standards for what information must be on food labels. It also prohibits manufacturers from making health claims on their packaging unless scientifically proved according to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER, 10, 1990
description: The Economy

title: CHRONICLE
description: The National Council for the Humanities recommended that KEN BURNS be given a grant for "The Civil War" from the National Endowment for the Humanities. Mr. Burns, who produced the acclaimed public television series, was honored yesterday by the council, which is giving him the 51 volumes published by the Library of America, a nonprofit publisher of works by the best American writers. The library is financed by the endowment organization.

title: James C. Harrison, Brooklyn Artist, 64
description: James C. Harrison, an artist who had his first one-man exhibition at age 58, died on Saturday at his home in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. He was 64 years old.

description: Baseball

title: Public Service of N.H.

title: Joffrey Ballet Extends Los Angeles Residency
description: The Joffrey Ballet announced Wednesday that it had signed a one-year extension of its residency contract with the Music Center of Los Angeles County. The New York-based troupe has had a second home at the Los Angeles theater complex since 1982. The company also announced that it had raised $2.6 million in the last six months, enabling it to pay off an $800,000 debt to the Internal Revenue Service for back payroll withholding taxes.

title: Ex-Leader of Bulgaria Reappears Unrepentant
description: For the last year he has been Bulgaria's invisible man, but Todor Zhivkov, the deposed Communist strongman, reappeared today, unrepentantly telling Bulgarians that under his rule they never had it so good.

title: Prices of Long-Term U.S. Issues Rise
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities advanced yesterday, buoyed by expectations of a further easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve, a sharp drop in oil prices and a report that the core rate of inflation at the producer level, which excludes energy and food, remained unchanged in October.

title: Law Seeks to Eliminate Abuses in Medigap Sales
description: As part of last month's deficit-reduction agreement Congress took strong action to reform the laws governing Medigap insurance. As a result, elderly consumers receiving Medicare benefits will be assured of tougher standards and simplified rules when they buy this type of insurance.

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Viking Place-Kicker Is Indicted on Heroin-Smuggling Charges
description: The Minnesota Vikings' place-kicker, Donald Igwebuike, was indicted today on charges that he and two other men had conspired to smuggle an estimated $1 million worth of heroin from his native Nigeria.

title: Brazil Under Pressure to Ease Stance on Debt
description: Brazil, the developing world's biggest debtor, is under increasing pressure from commercial bankers and American and other officials to take a less adamant stand in crucial debt talks. They are pressing Brazil to begin paying some back interest.

description: b-Net loss

description: The Energy Department has begun testing an $86 million plutonium processing center in South Carolina that is scheduled to begin operating in June and would be the first entirely new plant to produce nuclear weapons materials since 1960.

title: WMS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 332,000 on retirement of debt.

title: New U.S. Suit on Centrust New U.S. Suit On Centrust
description: The Resolution Trust Corporation today filed a lawsuit against David L. Paul, the former head of the Centrust Bank of Miami, and 15 other former directors and officers seeking more than $250 million.

Net income for 1990 included about $ 600,000 of expenses associated with the proposed sale of preferred stock to W.R. Berkley Corp. and resultant litigation. The company said the deal was never consummated and the litigation has been settled.

title: Bill on Windfall Profits From Drugs Is Vetoed
description: As expected, President Bush today pocket vetoed a bill to block drug companies from gaining windfall profits through the monopolistic marketing of drugs for rare diseases.

title: Daily News Uses Homeless to Sell Paper
description: Shortly after the strike at The Daily News began 16 days ago, The News started recruiting homeless people from shelters across New York City to work as street vendors, advocates for the homeless say.

title: Bank in Harlem Fails and U.S.  Takes Control
description: Freedom National Bank of New York, one of the largest black-owned banks in the country, was declared insolvent and closed yesterday by Federal regulators.

title: Lauren Bacall Receives George Eastman Award
description: Lauren Bacall has been named this year's winner of the George Eastman Award for Distinguished Contribution to the Art of Film, given by the George Eastman House in Rochester. The award, a glass sculpture, has been given to both actors and directors since its inception in 1955; past recipients have included Lillian Gish, Charlie Chaplin, Cecil B. DeMille, Gary Cooper, Frank Capra, Fred Astaire, George Cukor, James Stewart, Louise Brooks, Myrna Loy, Gregory Peck and Joan Bennett.

title: The National Ends Its Sunday Issue
description: Feeling the pressures of a sagging economy, The National, the fledgling sports daily, said yesterday that it would stop publishing a Sunday issue and that it was undergoing some management changes.

description: A Roman Catholic woman in Corpus Christi, Tex., has been excommunicated for refusing to quit as director of an abortion clinic.

title: Blazers Shoot Down Pistons, 113-101
description: Terry Porter had 29 points and 10 assists and Kevin Duckworth scored 27 points tonight to lead the Portland Trail Blazers to a 113-101 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a rematch of last season's finalists.

description: b-Net income

title: Hofstra Trounces St. John's to Go 10-0
description: Before his team's football game against St. John's began tonight, Joe Gardi, Hofstra's first-year head coach, said he wanted to see the Redmen give his 9-0 playoff-bound team a "little scare."

title: Qantas Will Cut Work Force by 500
description: Qantas Airways will reduce its work force by 500 by the end of February to help it survive an industrywide downturn prompted by higher jet fuel costs, the carrier's chief executive, John Ward, said. Mr. Ward also said five Boeing 747 planes would be sold earlier than planned and flying hours would be cut back, as part of a cost-cutting plan.

title: Fun's Over, So U.S. Grandmasters Return to Studying Job Openings
description: The party's over.

title: Vols Plan to Give Irish an Earful
description: If the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame are to avoid becoming top-ranked casualties for the second time this season, they will have to solve the severe, noisy problems posed by a once-beaten University of Tennessee team and its more than 90,000 fans at Neyland Stadium on Saturday afternoon.

title: Improving the Dreaded S.A.T.
description: The bane of college-bound students, the Scholastic Aptitude Test, is due for change. By 1994 it will focus more on reading and reasoning skills, have fewer multiple choice questions and allow the use of calculators. The changes are welcome, and may even alter public perceptions of the test. That could be the biggest change of all.

title: Division Rivals, Meanwhile, Are Delighted
description: Life without Darryl Strawberry may be a Mets fan's worst nightmare. But not surprisingly, the prospect has many a resident of the National League East delightedly dreaming of the possibilities.

title: Peachtree Center Foreclosure Begun
description: Foreclosure proceedings were started against John C. Portman Jr.'s holdings in downtown Atlanta's Peachtree Center, including six office towers, a retail shopping mall, two parking decks and an athletic center. Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc., which holds a $332.6 million mortgage, began the foreclosure process.

title: A.T.&T. to Expand Discount Program
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is expanding its program of offering deep discounts to the largest corporations and institutions despite a Federal appeals court ruling on Oct. 23 questioning the discounts' legality.

title: Copeland Plans Debt Revamping
description: Al Copeland Enterprises Inc., owner of the Popeye's fried chicken chain, is restructuring $391 million in debt from last year's takeover of Church's Fried Chicken Inc. The company said it would not make two scheduled payments totaling $7.5 million during negotiations on the restructuring and was in default under its loan agreements.

title: Patents; Shock Absorbers Adjust The Car to the Road
description: Nissan has also patented a new shock-absorbing system for cars that is designed to automatically adjust to bumpy or smooth roads.

title: Electronics Business Longing for a New Hit
description: For the second consecutive year, electronics retailers see little hope for a bright Christmas. With no new hit products to lure consumers and competition growing from Sears and Montgomery Ward, a fresh wave of store closings is expected by early next year, industry executives and analysts say.

title: Software Services of America reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CHRONICLE
description: They have the ring, but they won't be officially engaged until her birthday on Dec. 21. TED TURNER bought a large opal-and-diamond ring for JANE FONDA earlier this week. The couple, in their 50's, have not set a wedding date, said Pat Newcomb, a spokeswoman for Ms. Fonda. Ms. Fonda was divorced in June from her second husband, TOM HAYDEN Mr. Turner has also been married twice.

title: Reports of Wit and 'Laser Brain' At Irene Mayer Selznick Memorial
description: Admirers of Irene Mayer Selznick, the theatrical producer who died on Oct. 10 at the age of 83, gathered at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Thursday to remember what speakers called her "laser brain," her "ferocious courage," her honesty and wit and an uncommon sensitivity to friends.

title: Numac Oil reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said improved third-quarter results mainly reflected a 40-percent increase in crude oil selling prices and an 8-percent increase in crude output.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Quit Trashing Teachers
description: As a junior high school teacher in New York City, I have some advice for those who support Mayor Dinkins's proposed cuts in the education budget and criticize the recent 5.5 percent pay increase for teachers: Just try it for yourself.

description: To the Editor:

title: Standard Register Sets Plant Closings
description: Standard Register Inc. said it would close plants in New York, Colorado and Illinois and reduce its work force of about 6,100 people by 5 percent through attrition, early retirement and terminations, John K. Darragh, Standard Register president and chief executive, said in a prepared statement.

title: Foes of Florio's School Plan Are Hopeful About Changes
description: Some of the strongest foes of New Jersey's new school-financing law detected cracks in the Florio administration's resistance to changing it even before the Governor opened his entire legislative program to review on Wednesday.

title: The Storytellers Gather With Tales That Teach as Well as Delight
description: "In my village in Uganda," Samite said, "when the elders are trying to teach you not to do something, they don't tell you straight out. They tell you a story, followed by a song. That way you'll remember."

title: Producer Prices Post 1.1% Jump
description: Prices at the producer level, a prominent inflation gauge, jumped more than expected in October as oil prices continued to escalate, but economists generally took the numbers in stride.

title: Guidepost; Preparing Holiday Foods
description: It's not too soon to begin cooking for the holiday season. For serving or giving, many special foods can be prepared several days or weeks in advance. In fact, a number of preparations that are laced with brandy or other spirits, like fruitcake and plum pudding, should be made well in advance to allow the flavors to ripen and mellow. Be sure all foods are wrapped well for storage. Those that can be preserved should be put in sterilized canning jars, then sealed. Fruitcake, mincemeat, most cookies and other baked goods can be frozen for longer keeping. FOOD SHELF LIFE STORAGE Brandied fruit 2 weeks-1 year In canning jar in pantry or in refrigerator Cookies 2 days-2 weeks Pantry Cranberry relish 2 days-1 year In canning jars in pantry or in refrigerator Fruitcake 4 weeks-1 year Pantry or refrigerator Mincemeat 3 to 4 days Refrigerator Plum pudding 6 to 8 weeks Pantry or refrigerator Stollen 1 to 3 weeks Pantry

title: Spectrum Info Tech reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Harrelson Says Mets Must Enter The Marketplace
description: On the day after he lost Darryl Strawberry and the bat that produced 252 home runs in eight years, Bud Harrelson said it was "imperative" that the Mets go into the marketplace and "make a trade or sign a free agent to show we're a contending club." But the new priority will be speed rather than power.

title: INSIDE
description: New Indian Prime Minister

title: Why Keep Yugoslavia One Country?
description: Polat, a remote village in Yugoslavia's troubled Kosovo province, is too small to appear on our map. Until the ghastly events of Sept. 13, its name was virtually unknown. We went to Polat in early October to investigate reports of violence by the nationalist Serbian government against ethnic Albanians. We returned with serious doubts about whether the U.S. Government should continue to bolster the national unity of Yugoslavia.

title: A Mobile Hospital May End Its Rounds Because of Gunshots
description: Every Wednesday for the last three years, a mobile hospital co-founded by the singer Paul Simon has stopped at the St. John's Family Center in Brooklyn to serve homeless children. But perhaps not anymore.
