description: A Roman Catholic priest who was once accused of lying in the murder trial of Claus von Bulow has been indicted on charges of stealing about $200,000 from his church.

title: Hugh MacLennan Is Dead at 83; A Canadian Novelist and Teacher
description: Hugh MacLennan, one of Canada's best-known authors, died Wednesday night at his home in Montreal. He was 83 years old.

title: In-Store Advertising reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 3 about a merger between British Satellite Broadcasting and Rupert Murdoch's Sky Television misstated the ownership of the British Broadcasting Corporation. It is a public corporation supported by a television users' fee set by the Government; it is not state-owned.

title: New Deal for Kersey
description: Jerome Kersey has completed a four-year extension of his contract with the Portland Trail Blazers yesterday. The Trail Blazers declined to release terms of the deal when they announced it, but Kersey said after the announcement that he would earn about $11 million through the 1995-96 National Basketball Association season. (AP)

title: Modern Communications Muddy Rights of Criminal Defendants
description: While the sanctity of a defendant's relationship with his lawyer is well established, telephones and electronics have confused the issue in modern times.

title: Jersey City Complex Owners Default on Their Mortgage
description: In an indication of the New York region's weakening real-estate market, the owners of the huge Newport development in Jersey City have defaulted on a $150 million mortgage for four apartment towers, New Jersey state officials say.

title: Navy Considers Mothballing Its Battleships
description: The Navy is considering the idea of mothballing its last two active battleships, a leading officer told a House subcommittee hearing Thursday.

title: John Forsyth Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Public Service of N.C.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mott's Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,126,000 and $ 1,920,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 313,000 and $ 991,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Albany Leaders Tell Cuomo to Recommend Budget Cuts
description: With the campaign season over, a new round of political jockeying began today over who would take the lead in recommending painful cuts in the state budget. The state's legislative leaders quickly reached agreement -- to place the responsibility on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Key Rates
Landmark Land Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Landmark said its wholly owned subsidiary, Oak Tree Savings Bank, established about $ 52 million specific and general loan reserves for the third quarter, due in large part to a decline in value of real estate collateral securing loans.In addition, Oak Tree took a third quarter writedown on the carrying value of its real estate portfolio of about $ 15 million. Of the $ 67 million in charges, about $ 23 million are reflected in Landmark's third quarter results.

title: Metro Tel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeShare earnings are after preferred dividend requirements of $ 6,300 in both periods.

title: Buildup in Gulf Seen as a Signal On Use of Force
description: President Bush ordered more troops to the Persian Gulf because the threat of economic strangulation is not swaying President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and he did not want to wait a year or more for sanctions to cripple the Iraqi economy, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Hemlo Gold Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: More Girls Are Sexually Active, Study Finds
description: More American girls are having sex at younger and younger ages. Nearly 40 percent of 15- to 17-year-old girls were sexually active in 1988 as against fewer than a third in 1982, according to a new study by the Alan Guttmacher Institute.

title: Plan to Share Data on Drexel Is Reported
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to provide Federal savings regulators with information from its four-year investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., people directly involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Micron Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 28,000.Results for 1989 have been restated.

title: Ousted Senator Apologizes for Letter to Jews
description: Senator Rudy Boschwitz apologized today for a letter sent to some Minnesota Jews on behalf of his unsuccessful re-election campaign suggesting that his challenger was not a good Jew.

title: Sealed Air Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Music; Norwegian Program And Pianist
description: Just how far north can the North Norwegian Music Conservatory in Tromso be? The mind reels. Tori Stodle, a Norwegian pianist who teaches there, made her New York debut on Thursday evening at Weill Recital Hall with a program suggestively titled "Music From the Top of the World." Its first piece was Ketil Vea's attractive "Stallogargo" (1974), written for Ms. Stodle and named for a Norwegian village in the vicinity of Hammerfest, which the program booklet calls the northernmost town in the world.

title: Finding Fault With New Arts-Grant Law
description: The legislation adopted by Congress last month to extend the life of the National Endowment for the Arts may be as restrictive as the law it replaced, according to a majority of arts administrators, public officials and legal experts gathered here this weekend at a symposium sponsored by the American Assembly.

title: Elway's Unusual Return
description: The Denver Broncos' quarterback, John Elway, will be in the starting lineup tomorrow against the Chargers in San Diego but his dress may be a little unorthodox. Elway will play with a hole in his shoe to alleviate the pressure on the sprained left toe and strained left arch he suffered in the Broncos' game last Sunday against the Minnesota Vikings.

title: 3 Found Guilty in 20-Ton Cocaine Seizure
description: A Federal jury has convicted three men of drug charges in connection with the 20 tons of cocaine that were seized here last year, the largest seizure of the drug in the nation's history.

title: British Government Giving 11 Percent More to the Arts
description: The Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today announced an 11 percent increase in Government support for the arts next year and set up a new fund to which arts organizations can apply for additional money.

title: Jaclyn Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Russ Berrie & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected a one-time before tax restructuring charge of $ 9,500,000, which reduced net income by $ 6,200,000, or 41 cents a share.

title: Beliefs
description: The event in Iowa City last week was billed as the International Symposium on the Beginning of Human Life, but in the first session a speaker declared that the meeting was misnamed.

title: Review/Music; Two Chamber Orchestras And Their Idiosyncrasies
description: The Jupiter Symphony and Concordia are two chamber orchestras that present annual seasons in Alice Tully Hall. Each appeared there this week, the Jupiter on Monday night and Concordia on Thursday night. Each attracted a good-sized audience that appeared to enjoy itself, and each concert had its virtues. Both, however, fell victim to certain inherent limitations in their ambitions, financing or both.

title: Nordstrom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Marquest Medical Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 56,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 103,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from early extinguishment of debt.c-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 70,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 106,000, or 3 cents a share, from early extinguishment of debt.The company said earnings for the second quarter were impacted by about $ 400,000 of start-up costs.

title: In a Failed Hungarian Factory, Jeans Succeed
description: The tall brick wall that slices through the textile factory here is a dividing line between Eastern Europe's dreary economic past and what people here hope will be a brighter economic future.

title: Leftist Lawyer Is Elected President of Ireland
description: Mary Robinson, a leftist lawyer who had fought to legalize divorce and contraception, won Ireland's presidential runoff election today, defeating the candidate of the governing Fianna Fail party.

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column on Nov. 3 misstated the filing fees set in the new Federal budget. A large corporation, which now pays $370, will pay $630 when applying for a patent at the Patent and Trademark Office; individuals, small companies and universities, which now pay $185, will pay $315.

title: Jannock Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 1,487,000 charge related to the sale of a Quebec-based printed circuit board operation.Results are in Canadian funds.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Mid-American Waste Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
East Europe Finds Pain On Journey to Capitalism
description: The sudden collapse of Eastern Europe's Communist governments inspired dreams and expectations that living standards would improve quickly and substantially. But nowhere has the voyage from Marxist central planning to free markets gone smoothly and painlessly.

title: No Headline
description: International 2-7

title: Review/Music; An Evening of Contrast and Companionship
description: Stravinsky and Debussy made unlikely companions on the New York Philharmonic program Friday morning at Avery Fisher Hall. But companions they are. Stravinsky's "Symphonies of Wind Instruments" grew out of a posthumous tribute to the French composer. The Symphonic Fragments from "The Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian" that followed it on Friday are a world away in style and mood, but this did not keep Debussy from supporting his Russian colleague at the most controversial moments of his career.

title: Labor Party Wins 2 Elections A Week After Tory Aide Quits
description: The opposition Labor Party has easily won two special parliamentary elections, the first since the resignation last week of the top deputy of the Conservative Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher.

title: Roger B. Etherington,Ex-Bank Chairman, 66
description: Roger Bennett Etherington, a retired New Jersey banker and former chairman of Horizon Bancorp, now part of Chemical Bank of New York, died on Tuesday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Let's Take the Arms Treaty We Can Achieve
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * General Binding Corp., Northbrook, Ill., a maker of business machines, and Velo-Bind Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., a maker of binding equipment, have received requests from the Department of Justice for additional information in connection with their proposed $50 million merger. * Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio, a maker of tires, offered to acquire the remaining common stock of Brad Regan Inc., Charlotte, N.C., a maker of retreaded tires with 133 retail stores, for $22 in cash, or about $12.3 million. * H. H. Robertson Co., Pittsburgh, a building products company, said shareholders of Ceco Industries, Oak Brook Terrace, Ill., a manufacturer of construction materials, had approved merging the two companies. * LTV Corp., Dallas, a maker of steel and energy products, received a $126.3 million contract to produce 318 Army Tactile Missile Systems to be delivered by the end of 1992. * Mirror Group Newspapers, London, a publishing company, said Robert Maxwell had acquired 40 percent of Esti Hirlap, the evening paper in Budapest, through Mirror Holdings Ltd. Terms were not disclosed. * Recognition Equipment Inc., Dallas, an optical data and computer processing company, said its board had decided to cancel a tender offer for $15 million to $20 million of its common stock. * Scottish and Newcastle Breweries P.L.C. said it would cease brewing operations at two sites in Blackburn, in the northwest of England, in an attempt to increase efficiency. * Spelling Entertainment Inc., Los Angeles, a television production company, said its board had authorized the buyback of up to one million shares of its common stock. * Unifi Inc., Greensboro, N.C., said it planned a "Dutch auction" self-tender for up to two million common shares, or about 10.4 percent of its stock. Shareholders will be asked to tender their shares at prices of $15 to $18 each. Unifi will pick one price in that range and buy shares tendered at that price and below. * Waste Management Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., a waste collection company, said it had completed its previously announced agreement to combine certain customer services with Servicemaster L.P., Downers Grove, Ill., a management services company. * Wiggins Teape Appleton P.L.C., London, a paper company, announced its merger with Arjomari-Prioux S.A., Paris, another paper company, for an undisclosed amount. Wiggins is to issue 315.5 million ordinary shares to Arjomari in exchange for all of its assets.

title: Baker Portrays Soviets As Pessimistic on Iraq
description: Soviet leaders told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had firmly rebuffed every suggestion made by Moscow for a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis, despite some reports to the contrary, a senior American official said today.

title: Dinkins Is Criticized on School Cuts
description: Superintendents of New York City's community school districts said yesterday that the budget cuts proposed on Thursday by Mayor David N. Dinkins would wreak havoc with an already troubled educational system and that the greatest impact would be on the poorest districts.

title: P&F Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Eye Injuries Linked to Contaminated Drug
description: One woman has lost an eye after using eye drops that were contaminated by bacteria, and at least 10 other people are under treatment after using the same drops, which were made by a local pharmacy.

title: David Mizrahi Is Dead; Mideast Editor Was 64
description: David Mizrahi, a newsletter publisher who was an authority on oil and Middle East politics, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Hudson Bay Mining & Smelting Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is a unit of Inspiration Resources Corp.Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Memry Corp.
Senior Service Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a net foreign exchange loss of $ 125,584.

title: Heroux Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Pincay Hurt in Spill
description: Laffit Pincay Jr. knows all about riding injuries. He has had 10 in his 26-year riding career. The most recent, a broken collarbone, came Thursday at Hollywood Park when his horse, Dr. Damascus, a 3-year-old colt, broke a leg and fell. The mishap occurred 50 yards beyond the finish line in the ninth race.

title: Activated Dupree May Not See Action Tomorrow
description: In his prime, Marcus Dupree seemed to be a running back headed for greatness. The problem was he was in his prime when he was 19 years old. Now he is 26, supposedly sound after tearing up a knee, and he is struggling to find a job he can keep.

title: Taiwan: Too Big to Ignore
description: Taiwan is now one of Asia's most powerful industrial and trading economies. It is America's sixth-largest trading partner, doing more business with this country than France or Saudi Arabia and twice as much as mainland China. Taiwan has become a major global investor; its companies now buy out American businesses.

title: Hexagon Acquires 5.8% Hexcel Stake
description: Hexagon Partners, a limited partnership controlled by the New York investment firm Siegler, Collery & Company has acquired a 5.8 percent stake in the Hexcel Corporation, a San Francisco-based producer of alloys, plastics and specialty chemicals. Hexagon said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had bought the Hexcel shares because they "were undervalued."

title: Review/Theater; A Family in Which the Last Shall Be First
description: Jo Carson's "Daytrips" is a collage of events, memories and fantasies, as a granddaughter moves back and forth between her demanding, often abusive elders. She is the sole attendant for her mother, who is suffering from Alzheimer's disease, and for her grandmother, who is subject to her own delusions as well as to the infirmities of old age.

title: Scor U.S. Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1989 are restated to reflect the mid-year merger of Rockleigh Management Corp. into Scor U.S. as accounted for in a manner similar to a pooling of interests. Merger expenses reported in the current 3-month and 9-month periods ended Sept. 30 were $ 23,000 and $ 1,671,000, respectively.After-tax net realized investment gains for the 3-month and 9-month periods ended Sept. 30 were $ 178,000, or 1 cent a share, and $ 807,000, or 5 cents a share, respectively. After-tax net realized investment gains for the corresponding 3-month and 9-month periods of 1989 were $ 1,667,00, or 9 cents a share, and $ 2,479,000, or 14 cents a share, respectively.

title: Pe Ben Oilfield reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Petrominerals Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Piper Jaffray Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: The company said it is difficult to compare 1990 fourth quarter results with those of 1989 because the 1989 quarter was an unusually strong one, with a single, large bond fund offering and a single, large advisory fee, neither of which have been repeated in the same magnitude this year.The company also said certain costs began to rise in fiscal 1990, some associated with selective growth of capital markets efforts in Denver and Los Angeles and significant growth in the money management and trust areas.

title: Thomas C. Ragan, 86, Retired Navy Admiral
description: Thomas Cameron Ragan, who retired as a vice admiral in 1959 after a 39-year career in the Navy, died on Wednesday at St. Joseph's of the Pines Hospital in Southern Pines, N.C. He was 86 years old and lived in Pinehurst, N.C.

title: M.D.C. Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 9,444,000, or 50 cents a share, and $ 16,124,000, or 85 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the gain on the repurchase of notes.c-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 18,986,000, or $ 1.19 a share, and $ 36,454,000, or $ 2.29 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the gain on the repurchase of notes.The company said that the improvement for this year was due to lower interest expense as a result of the repurchase and restructuring of notes, reduction in selling, general and administrative expenses, increases in earnings from collateralized mortgage obligations and higher gross profit margins on home closings.The losses before extraordinary gains were primarily due to a $ 12 million provision recorded Sept. 30, 1990, to reduce the carrying value of the company's inventories to their net realizable value.

title: Are States All Equal?
description: Iraq's Saddam Hussein is doing his best to make nuclear weapons. If he survives the Persian Gulf crisis in power, he will certainly be more determined than ever to press his effort. Even if he doesn't, his successors may continue the attempt, as successive Governments in Pakistan have done.

title: Spectrum Control reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
In India, the Tyranny Of the Majority Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Apartheid a Sin, Clergy Conference Says
description: A watershed five-day conference of 80 black and white church denominations in South Africa ended today by formally condemning apartheid as a sin and supporting restitution for its victims.

title: Strober Organization reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Rexon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 116,000 and $ 350,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Israeli Police Move to Pre-empt Strife on Both Sides
description: The police in Jerusalem today intensified their efforts to separate Palestinians and Israelis and to deter both spontaneous violence and planned attacks between Arabs and Jews, fearing more trouble after a month of killing and disorder.

title: J.A.M. Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dinkins's Fiscal General For an Unpopular War
description: Philip R. Michael, the director of New York City's Office of Management and Budget, is the orchestrator of the city's campaign to slash and burn its way through agency budgets to close a budget gap of more than $1.6 billion for the coming fiscal year.

title: Moore Medical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: Latest quarter results were offset by a $ 453,000 pretax loss at West-Ward. The company said it is considering various alternatives, including the sale of the entire business.

title: Every Other 14-Year-Old, Armed
description: Teen-agers in New York City have never had so many guns with so much killing power. Informed estimates of the number of illegal guns on the street run into the hundreds of thousands. "If you're asking me if every 14-year-old has a gun," a police officer recently told The Times, "the answer is no. Does every other 14-year-old have a gun? The answer is yes."

title: Maxco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $ 650,000, or 13 cents a share.

title: KMS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Japan Shrugs Off Emperor's Big Day
description: Dozens of heads of state and dignitaries began arriving here this weekend for the formal enthronement of Emperor Akihito on Monday in an elaborate ceremony aimed at displaying Japan's ancient past and celebrating its current status as an economic superpower.

title: Headliners; Are We All Really Extraterrestrials?
description: ON the molecular level, the ancient ontological question about chickens and eggs comes down to this: Which came first, amino acids (the building blocks of proteins) or nucleic acids (the components of DNA)? Self-replicating molecules of DNA and its cousin RNA carry the genetic code for stringing together amino acids to make proteins. But DNA and RNA can't reproduce or direct protein synthesis without the proper chemical catalysts. And those catalysts are none other than proteins. Adding to the confusion, some scientists doubt that the Earth's early atmosphere had the proper composition to promote the spontaneous formation of either kind of molecule.

title: Headliners; Here's to Her
description: It is an irony of the Irish Presidency that those who win the office are expected to be above the sort of political activism that got them elected. But the republic's new President, Mary Robinson, has made a career of challenging her country's conservative laws on contraception, divorce and homosexuality and there seems a fair prospect that the largely ceremonial office could take a swing from the symbolic toward the activist after she is sworn in next month. A lawyer first elected to the senate at 25 years old in 1969, Mrs. Robinson used the courts and the legislature to advance women's rights. The first woman elected President of Ireland, Mrs. Robinson said she was mindful of the office's tradition of remaining above the fray. But, she added, given that her views are widely known, she expected to become a force for "more pluralism and more tolerance" simply by virtue of being elected.

title: Adoptees' Search for Birth Parents
description: "Could You Be My Mother?" by Alyce Mitchem Jenkins is an article about an issue that should not be an issue, but a truth about life.

title: The Bad Man of Baghdad
description: SADDAM HUSSEIN AND THE CRISIS IN THE GULF By Judith Miller and Laurie Mylroie. 268 pp. New York: Times Books/Random House. Paper, $5.95.

title: Stretching Dollars on the Slopes
description: NOW that the economy has turned chilly, ski resorts across the country are concentrating less on expansion and investment -- popular words in ski country in the 80's -- and more on attractive pricing to please skiers with tighter belts. A flurry of discounts, deals and packages indicates that budget conscious skiers can do well shopping around and bargain hunting in the coming season.

title: Patients Salute 'Old-Fashioned' Doctor
description: BAYARD COGGESHALL has been a pediatrician here for 41 years, caring for thousands of children from infancy through adolescence. For the last 40 years his office, cozy yet increasingly cramped, has been in a white Colonial house on Franklin Street, just around the corner from where he grew up.

title: Bite Back And Bargain
description: If the global embargo fails to liberate Kuwait, what military action should be taken to move the Iraqis?

title: Business Diary: November 4-9
description: THE ECONOMY From London to Cairo: A March Toward War? The week's events seemed as carefully orchestrated as a Sousa, or maybe a James A. Baker 3d, march: Tuesday, the British Foreign Minister warned that time was running out for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Wednesday, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said war was inevitable unless Iraq withdrew from Kuwait in two or three months. Thursday, President Bush ordered at least an additional 150,000 troops to the Persian Gulf. And, in Moscow, the Soviet Foreign Minister sounded a softer but still harmonious note by admitting the possible use of force. Traders, who sent the price of oil below $32 a barrel on Monday, raised it to $35.53 after President Bush spoke. On Friday, oil finished at $33.89, as market participants decided that armed conflict was unlikely for the rest of the year. William L. Randol, an analyst at First Boston, figures that oil supplies will be tight enough to keep prices at about $30 through the winter. He adds another $5 or so for rising fears of war. "It's workable if nothing goes wrong," he said. "But the history is that things do go wrong."

title: A Pen, Snug as a Gun
description: SELECTED POEMS, 1966-1987 By Seamus Heaney. 273 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $20.

title: The More Things Change . . .
description: The most remarkable consequence of the 1990 midterm elections was that they changed very little.

title: A Gentle Smile And the Art Of Ancient Greece
description: A MINOAN BRONZE HEAD of a gently smiling youth, wearing a pigtail on the top of his shaved head, exudes enormous charm out of all proportion to its inch-and-a-half height. The Lilliputian study is the centerpiece of "The Art of Prehistoric Greece," an exhibition at the gallery of Michael Ward, 9 East 93d Street in Manhattan, through Jan. 12.

title: Legend of the Playground
description: "POUND for pound, Joe Hammond was the greatest basketball player to ever come out of Harlem. There is a major difference between Joe and legendary schoolyard players like Earl Manigault and Helicopter Knowings. The rest of them had a chance to make it and didn't. But Joe, he was certain to make it, and just didn't want to." -- Don Adams, basketball coach, Taft High School, the Bronx.

title: Voters in Westchester Approve Air Terminal
description: ERIC LANGELOH, Westchester County's Commissioner of Transportation, has about two dozen architects' renderings in his office of proposed new terminals for the county's airport, right across the state line from Greenwich. The earliest drawing is "dated 1946, the year I was born," he said.

title: State Is Taking Action On Underground Tanks
description: THROUGH one of the strictest programs of its type in the country, the State Department of Environmental Protection has forced the replacement of 12,000 underground gasoline tanks that were leaking or were so old that they were in danger of leaking. Now the state is going after the 350 to 400 old tanks it estimates are still in use, including some of its own.

title: NEW EMISSION TEST FOR HEAVY TRUCKS
description: Roving teams of state inspectors will begin random roadside testing of diesel smoke from heavy trucks and buses next spring under a new program adopted by the State Air Resources Board.

title: Backstage Secrets
description: SHADOW PLAY By Paul Fleischman. Illustrated by Eric Beddows. 34 pp. New York: A Charlotte Zolotow Book/ HarperCollins Publishers. $14.95. (Ages 7 and up) HENRY IN SHADOWLAND Written and illustrated by Laszlo Varvasovszky. Unpaged. Boston: David R. Godine. $17.95. (Ages 7 to 12)

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: The Region; Trenton State Wins
description: Steve Mortallite, the Trenton State quarterback, combined with the tight end, Anthony Johnson, on a 24-yard fourth-quarter touchdown pass as the Lions shut out previously undefeated Ramapo, 9-0, yesterday at the Ramapo Sports Complex in Mahwah, N.J.

title: GUATEMALA BALLOT MARKS WATERSHED
description: Barring a collapse brought about by the wave of political violence now afflicting Guatemala, the general elections on Sunday and the inauguration of a President in January should mark a democratic watershed: the first transfer of power from one elected civilian to another in the country's history.

title: Day of the Dolphin Popular Jet Video
description: Even though dolphins are mammals, the National Football League team from Miami with that nickname is known as the Fish. This past week, before the Jets' second meeting of the season against Miami, they were often reminded about the big one that got away.

title:
The Executive Life;
Leaving the Office Behind - at 130 M.P.H.
description: TWICE a month a group of about 100 East Coast executives gather to spend the weekend together. With their families often in tow, they congregate at such scenic spots as Bridgehampton, L.I.; Watkins Glen, N.Y., and Lime Rock, Conn. By night the group is raucous, joining in tailgate parties and dinners at area restaurants that last late into the night.

title: Dracula's Passion May Have Lost Bite
description: DEVILISH Dracula, that fanged count from Transylvania, has provided creative artists with sundry versions of plots for novels, films and plays.

title: Nixon's The One
description: On Halloween night one of the neighborhood dads was dressed as Nixon. The mask was lifelike, down to the 5 o'clock shadow, and the costume was exact: dark suit, white shirt, quiet tie. As he shepherded his children down the street he flashed me the double V with his upraised hands, the Nixon digital signature that was so near to the peace sign and yet so far.

title: Divining the Mystique of Mark Morris
description: BEWARE OF THOSE WHO STIR the waters to suggest they are deep, as the Chinese saying goes. No other choreographer in the 1980's has acquired a large following as swiftly as Mark Morris or had so many extravagant claims attached to his ascendancy.

title:
Style Makers;
Howard Kamentsky, Metal Designer
description: Howard Kamentsky's Boston studio is stockpiled with old toasters, electric fan blades, stove burner coils, rusty roller skates, springs, rivets, screens and drains. From the scrap heap of the old and familiar, he creates hanging lamps, illuminated sculpture and mechanical banks.

title: Karen Foley Wed To E. B. Freeman
description: Karen Mary Foley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Foley of Jupiter, Fla., and Cinnaminson, N.J., was married yesterday to Eric Bradley Freeman, a son of Claire M. T. Halbardier of New York and Edward H. Freeman of Barneveld, N.Y. Msgr. John G. Woolsey, assisted by the Rev. Mark Wood, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: Give Horses Chance to Mature
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Enduring, Not Always Endearing 'Wall Street Week'
description: "NOW Lou should walk into the studio in 5 or 10 minutes," announced the technician. "As soon as Lou walks in, please stay in your seat and keep quiet. Try to keep all your laughter to yourself if he says something funny. And no eating or smoking."

title:
DINING OUT;
A Decent Meal by Choosing Carefully
description: A RESTAURANT'S appearance sets up certain expections. So when a meal in a elaborately decorated restaurant, with a fancy menu, extensive wine list and elegantly attired servers, comes up short, it is a greater disappointment than it would be in a more simple establishment.

title: Fragile Families Are Guided Past Crises
description: TRYING to shepherd her four boys out of a social worker's office at the Milford Mental Health Clinic, a 26-year-old mother asked one of her 4-year-old twins to put down the "Star Trek" doll that he had been grasping for more than an hour. The boy stubbornly refused to give up his toy, alternately waving it in the air and clutching it to his chest. Taking cues from their brother, the other three grabbed dolls and clamored to play.

title: Voter Turnout Still Poor, With 3 Exceptions
description: Despite record or near-record voter turnout in North Carolina, Louisiana and the District of Columbia, fewer than four in 10 people eligible to vote actually did in this year's midterm elections, according to a study made public this week by a nonpartisan organization that monitors voter turnout.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Midwest; Iowa Is Upset by Ohio State, 27-26
description: Greg Frey hit Bobby Olive with a 3-yard touchdown pass with 1 second to play today to give Ohio State a 27-26 victory over Iowa. The loss was the Hawkeyes' first in the Big Ten and slowed their drive toward the conference title and a Rose Bowl berth.

title: England
description: To the Editor: At the Shap Wells Hotel dining room (in Shap, in the Lake District of England) you must interpret the small print of the menu. If you order from the a la carte menu you will be surcharged $23 for the fixed-price dinner. Since my wife and I did not read the small print we were charged an extra $46. I made a vociferous protest but to no avail. Luckily I paid with my Visa card, and after three weeks of negotiating the charge was dropped. Ray Finkelstein Great Neck, L.I. S.W. Simpson of the Shap Wells Hotel replies: Mr. and Mrs. Finkelstein stayed with us for two nights. They had dinner in our restaruant one night and ordered alternative dishes from our a la carte menu. The charges on this menu are in addition to the fixed-price menu charge. Their extra charges were $20. The total charge for the dinner was $66. We make no attempt to hide the extra charge; it is clearly printed at the top of the a la carte menu. We have not made any reduction to their bill, so any refund that has been made must have come from the credit card company.

title: Ms. Edersheim Engaged to Wed
description: January wedding plans for Katherine Ann Edersheim and Bruce Aaron Tuckman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Tuckman of Great Neck, L.I., have been announced by Ms. Edersheim's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hans S. Edersheim of New York.

title: Shell Game?
description: To the Editor: A few weeks ago, in an effort to improve the national voluntary movie rating system, we made some modest changes. In her article "Is NC-17 an X in a Clean Raincoat?" [ Oct. 21 ] , Janet Maslin suggests that the new NC-17 rating is nothing more than a shell game.

title: The Executive Computer; The Latest Convert to Network Religion? Big Blue
description: IN what it described as its most significant announcement since the PS/2 family was rolled out in 1987, the International Business Machines Corporation last month introduced two machines at the high end of its personal computer line. Both are based on the powerful 486 microprocessor from the Intel Corporation and use a high-resolution display system designed to show to best advantage all the new graphic-based software. At the same time, I.B.M. came out with an updated version of its OS/2 operating system software.

title: Autumn Leaves? A Compost Pile Turns Them Into (Black) Gold
description: IT is not mandatory yet and county officials are still suggesting rather than insisting. But the days of voluntary recycling are waning, and there is no time like the present for Westchester homeowners to plan their own household waste strategies.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE PUSHCART PRIZE XV: Best of the Small Presses. Edited by Bill Henderson with the Pushcart Prize editors: William Heyen, Elizabeth Spires, Anthony Brandt. (Pushcart Press/Norton, $27.95)

title: A Hodgkin Original
description: IT WAS IN THE FIRST HALF OF the 1980's that very large claims began to be made in an international context for an English painter, born in 1932, whose name was Howard Hodgkin. His specialty was the human figure -- sometimes alone and sometimes not -- in well-observed and often voluptuous interiors. Lawrence Gowing -- painter, art historian, teacher and recently Kress Professor at the National Gallery in Washington and curatorial chairman at the Phillips Collection -- numbered Hodgkin among "the uncommon painters who have added to painting a part of life that the rest of us had supposed to be no part of it." And he went on to say that Hodgkin was a painter "more naturally and effortlessly original, more entirely himself, than anyone else alive."

title: A Touch of Christmas for Soldiers in the Desert
description: LATE one hot night in August, Ann Page was making flower arrangements for a wedding when her thoughts turned to Christmas and the American military personnel in Saudi Arabia.

title: 'Unmentionable' Art Through the Ages
description: The first thing one notices about the installation that the Conceptual artist Joseph Kosuth has orchestrated for the Brooklyn Museum's grand lobby is not the art but the people. There are lots of them and they are unusually intent on the displays, looking back and forth between the paintings and sculptures and their labels, and then up at the statements splayed out across the lobby's high walls in large (sometimes huge) white type.

title: For Suharto, His Heirs Are Key to Life After '93
description: In hierarchical, deferential Indonesia, the principal political question is whether President Suharto, now 69 years old and in power unchallenged for 25 years, will decide to step down in 1993 or stay in office for a sixth five-year term.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is 45 years old, and has a dry well that is no longer useful. Either the roots of some large trees nearby have taken over, or the dry well is so full of leaves that it can no longer hold water that pours into it from the gutters. What options do I have for dealing with this?

title: I Shot 10 Presidents
description: For just about a half century, George Tames behind the lens of a camera has been a fixture in Washington. That rarissima avis , a native Washingtonian, he was born to Greek immigrant parents and grew up in the shadow of the Capitol. Government and those who run it were an early and constant source of fascination. Franklin D. Roosevelt, a Tames household hero, was the first President to be a subject ("I didn't know whether to light a candle, kiss his ring, or chant the Kyrie Eleison," Mr. Tames writes). Mr. Tames had an easy way with his subjects, and was close enough so that he could catch asides and offhand remarks that the political leaders would not have made if reporters were within earshot. EYE ON WASHINGTON: The Presidents Who've Known Me (HarperCollins, $35) is a kaleidoscope of pictures made with cameras and with words, rich in detail and anecdote. In a time when Presidents enjoyed a closer rapport with the press than their present-day handlers will allow, Mr. Tames, who spent 40 years in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, could put them at their ease and make great photos. One, showing a solitary John F. Kennedy hunched over his desk during the Cuban missile crisis, says more about the burdens of office than thousands of photos of men in dark suits holding meetings. Another, depicting Richard M. Nixon in golf togs putting his socks on at Burning Tree Country Club, captures self-conscious informality to a fare-thee-well. "Eye on Washington" is an affectionate look at the corridors of power by one who has prowled them for five decades.

title: Exploring Communities Becomes Child's Play
description: A CHILD'S activity book is meant for quiet times, for long rides in cars or planes or for rainy days when there is nothing to do. Right? Wrong, say Janet Horowitz and Kathy Faggella, authors of two "Time Travel Activity Books," a concept of their own creation.

title: England
description: To the Editor:

title: Fit to Be Tied: The Shogun's New Clothes
description: IF YOU WANT TO KNOW HOW TO spend over a million dollars on the wardrobe for a Broadway show, just look at the "bible." This is not the neat black volume that the Gideons slip into other people's night table drawers. This is the costume designer Patricia Zipprodt's bible for the musical version of "Shogun." It's an overstuffed looseleaf notebook, thicker (in inches if not in pages) than the James Clavell novel upon which the new Broadway spectacular is based.

title: Wall Street; A Well-Informed Lucky Break
description: THE Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and some very astute investors do not see eye to eye on when to buy and sell banks.

title: A Question Unanswered: Where Is India Headed?
description: Just before he fell from power on Friday, Prime Minister V. P. Singh asked an essential question.

title: Elis Swamp Tigers in Rain
description: Yale punished Princeton in the rain today, routing the Tigers by 34-7 in the 113th game of one of college football's oldest series.

title: Celtics Cash In On Nets' Mistakes
description: All of the troubling plays that clouded and cluttered last season for the Nets came sweeping back in vivid shades of Celtic green in the fourth quarter tonight.

title: Cynthia Johnson Rutgers, a Teacher, To Marry Kurt Overhardt, a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Gouverneur Rutgers of Kamuela, Hawaii, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Johnson Rutgers, to Kurt Frederick Overhardt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Overhardt of Birmingham, Mich. A June wedding is planned.

title:
PRO FOOTBALL;
Edgy but Confident, Everett Faces Giants
description: JIM EVERETT understands there might be an edge to the meeting today between the 8-0 Giants and the 3-5 Los Angeles Rams in Anaheim Stadium.

title: Anorexia Stalks the Moors
description: A CHAINLESS SOUL A Life of Emily Bronte.By Katherine Frank.Illustrated. 303 pp. Boston:Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95.

title: Yale Repertory Stages Havel's 'Largo Desolato'
description: THE philosopher blocked, depressed and paranoid -- paces maniacally amid the clutter that overwhelms him. Instead of motivation, friends, fans and once and future lovers provide unwelcome distraction and intensified pressure. An avid audience awaits his words, and he is letting it down.

title: Bush to Rule on Raises At L.I. Federal Offices
description: A CONGRESSIONAL move to raise Federal pay on Long Island, where living costs are higher than many other regions, has been thrown into President Bush's lap.

title: Lynda M. Brahs Weds C. C. Allen
description: Lynda Marie Brahs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart J. Brahs of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to Christopher Charles Allen, a son of Col. and Mrs. Dan C. Allen of Baltimore. The Rev. William C. Farraday officiated at the Rockville United Methodist Church in Rockville, Md.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 11, 1990
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 DAWN, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.95.) A series of horrors besets a Virginia schoolgirl. 2 4 DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe, predictable world a man has built for himself and his family. 3 7 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 4 3 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) A former Federal prosecutor reluctantly defends his daughter-in-law, charged with murdering his son. 5 6 THE SECRET DIARY OF LAURA PALMER, as seen by Jennifer Lynch. (Pocket, $8.95.) The journal of a "Twin Peaks" television character. 6 2 SORCERESS OF DARSHIVA, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $5.95.) The fourth volume in "The Malloreon," a fantasy series. 7 3 THE CAPTIVE, by Victoria Holt. (Fawcett, $5.95.) A 19th-century woman's adventures while a hostage of North African pirates and as a governess in an English household. 8 * 6 THE MINOTAUR, by Stephen Coonts. (Dell, $5.95.) The hunt for a mole in the Pentagon. 9 1 EXILES, by Howard Weinstein. (Pocket, $4.50.) "Star Trek" 's Enterprise gets caught in a vicious conflict between two trouble-plagued planets. 10 * 1 DEFCON ONE, by Joe Weber. (Jove, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative is trapped in the Kremlin as glasnost fails and the Soviets plan a first strike against the United States. 11 50 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $5.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 12 * 7 POSTCARDS FROM THE EDGE, by Carrie Fisher. (Pocket, $4.95.) A starlet's encounters with drugs and her quest for the right man. 13 * 7 OLDEST LIVING CONFEDERATE WIDOW TELLS ALL, by Allan Gurganus. (Ivy, $6.95.) A 99-year-old woman reflects on her past. 14 6 CALIFORNIA GOLD, by John Jakes. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A young man from Pennsylvania makes his fortune in 19th-century California. 15 18 SO WORTHY MY LOVE, by Kathleen E. Woodiwiss. (Avon, $5.95.) The abduction of a woman leads to romance in Elizabethan England. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 51 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 7 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $8.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's, as witnessed by a young bond trader. 3 368 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 4 13 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict over the past decade. 5 * 23 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $9.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 6 * 9 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) A historian recalls her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. 7 * 9 AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN, by Tracy Kidder. (Avon, $9.95.) A year in the life of a fifth-grade teacher in Holyoke, Mass. 8 116 LOVE, MEDICINE, AND MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 9 * 2 HIGH TREASON, by Robert J. Groden and Harrison Edward Livingstone. (Berkley, $6.50.) Evidence to suggest that the assassination of John F. Kennedy resulted from a massive conspiracy. 10 5 EXIT THE RAINMAKER, by Jonathan Coleman. (Dell, $4.95.) The enigmatic case of a successful Maryland college president who disappeared and assumed another identity in Europe. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 7 THE AUTHORITATIVE CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons. 2 3 THE "LATE NIGHT WITH DAVID LETTERMAN" BOOK OF TOP TEN LISTS, by David Letterman, Steve O'Donnell, et al. (Pocket, $8.95.) Humor. 3 114 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperSanFrancisco, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people. 4 3 THE OLD FARMER'S ALMANAC 1991. (Yankee Publishing, $2.95.) The 199th annual edition. 5 1 WIENER DOG ART, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $7.95.) "Far Side" cartoons. 6 * 3 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Headliners; Reporting for Duty
description: There was a war on in 1967 when Perry J. Watkins was drafted, and the Army told him that it wanted him to take up arms for his country despite his avowed homosexuality. Fourteen years and three re-enlistments later, Mr. Watkins was a sergeant and the Army wanted him out. But Mr. Watkins, having compiled what the courts later recognized as an outstanding military career, didn't want to go, at least not before he put in the 20 years that would make him eligible for a pension. In 1984, the Army succeeded in denying him the right to re-enlist and Mr. Watkins has been fighting to get back in uniform since then. Last week the United States Supreme Court upheld a lower court ruling that since the Army had "affirmatively misrepresented" to Mr. Watkins that his homosexuality would not be a bar to re-enlistment, it had to take him back. Mr. Watkins, who in recent years has worked for the Social Security Administration in Tacoma, Wash., said he would be re-enlisting "without a doubt."

title: Christa J. Clarke To Marry in May
description: May wedding plans for Christa Joan Clarke and E. Brendan Magrab, a son of Dr. Phyllis R. Magrab and a stepson of Grant Peters of Cabin John, Md., have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John M. Clarke of Rye, N.Y.

title: 50 MILLION FRENCHMEN
description: In your article on Mickey Rourke, the author refers to the Deauville Film Festival, of which I am the United States director, saying it is a "forum for such great Hollywood artists as Jane Russell." Well, Miss Russell was given a tribute this year and proved to be immensely popular with the French. But we also have honored Gregory Peck, Elizabeth Taylor, Shirley MacLaine, Gene Hackman, Joseph Mankiewicz, Sydney Pollack and on and on. And along with Jane Russell this September, we gave tributes to Robert Duvall, Sidney Lumet, Jon Voight and Richard Chamberlain. (The latter is a succes fou in France; he required a police escort everywhere he went.)

title: 50 MILLION FRENCHMEN
description: The French have traditionally appreciated any number of American actors, writers and film makers ignored or forgotten in their homeland, and this appreciation has been more than vindicated over time. How the French must be amused by America's belated "discovery" of artists like Buster Keaton, Erich Von Stroheim, Orson Welles, Howard Hawks, Dashiell Hammett, Chester Himes, Samuel Fuller and Preston Sturges. And no, they don't like Steven Spielberg or Bruce Willis movies nearly as much as we do, bless them LEE SERVER Brooklyn

title: Eileen M. O'Hern Engaged to Wed
description: Justice and Mrs. Daniel J. O'Hern of Red Bank, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eileen Marie O'Hern, to William Kent Luby, the son of Carol Pope Luby of Warwick, R.I., and the late Frank W. Luby Jr. A March wedding is planned.

title: Data Bank/November 11, 1990
Transactions
description: Basketball

title: THE HARROWING PLUNGE
description: IN THE LAST FEW MONTHS I HAVE COME TO ACCEPT THE fact that AIDS is going to kill me.

title: Shari L. Littman Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Littman of Oceanside, L.I., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter Shari Lynn Littman and Daniel Louis Kramer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kramer of Margate, N.J. Miss Littman, 29 years old, is a graduate of Tufts University and has an M.B.A. received from the University of Rochester. She is a strategic planning analyst at Pfizer Pharmaceuticals in New York. The prospective bridegroom, 29, is a graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and earned an M.B.A. from Harvard University. He is an associate publisher and editor of American Retailer, a trade magazine, in Atlantic City, N.J.

title: 'Diplomat's Diplomat' to Lead National Human Rights Panel
description: A Commissioner in the Koch administration who became known as a "diplomat's diplomat" for her work at the United Nations has been named to a new position where diplomacy is of the essence: the presidency of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

title: Magellan Resumes Mission
description: Magellan resumed making radar readings of Venus today, two weeks after engineers suspended the mission because the sun was lined up between Venus and Earth, impairing communication with the spacecraft. The Oct. 26 suspension of the $744 million map-making mission was also meant to give engineers time to fix a programming glitch that was causing the craft's solar power panels to wobble. A new computer program will be broadcast to Magellan next week, officials said.

title: Review/Cabaret; A Liberated Karen Akers
description: Karen Akers, a performer who had seemed increasingly frozen in her ways in her last several New York club engagements, has suddenly blossomed.

title: Sacca Rewards Paterno's Faith
description: Last week at this time, Tony Sacca was convinced that his reign as Penn State's starting quarterback had ended. He had been yanked from a game by Coach Joe Paterno for the second straight week, this time in the second quarter against West Virginia after completing only one of four passes. And his replacement wound up leading the Nittany Lions to their sixth straight victory.

title: Fraud Charges Raised in Election in Mexico State
description: Elections scheduled for Sunday in Mexico's most populous state appeared likely only to deepen political conflicts here after opposition parties denounced what they called preparations for widespread fraud by the governing party of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari.

title: Dostoyevsky, With All the Music
description: THE BROTHERS KARAMAZOV A Novel in Four Parts With Epilogue. By Fyodor Dostoevsky. Translated by Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky. 796 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $29.95.

title: SETI, PHONE HOME
description: According to Howard Blum, scientists believe that if intelligent life exists on some other planet, the "development of technology, an attempt to control the environment, would then be inevitable" ("SETI, Phone Home," Oct. 21).

title: New & Noteworthy
description: EDEN CLOSE, by Anita Shreve. (Signet, $4.95.) When a New York City advertising man goes home to attend a funeral in the upstate farming community where he was raised, he falls back in love with Eden, the girl next door, who was raped and blinded when she was a teen-ager. Last year our reviewer, Carolyn Banks, called this an "evocative and moving novel. . . . Its insights are keen, its language measured and haunting."

title: Female Sailor Quits In Conflict on Crew
description: Larry Klein, a San Diego yachtsman who was to be a helmsman for William Koch's new America's Cup defense syndicate, resigned unexpectedly last week. His abrupt departure came in the wake of an incident last month in which Klein balked at having a woman assigned to his all-male crew during a regatta in Annapolis.

title: Love Is the Pot of Gold
description: THE TALE OF THE MANDARIN DUCKS By Katherine Paterson. Illustrated by Leo Dillon and Diane Dillon. Unpaged. New York: Lodestar Books. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is 45 years old, and has a dry well that is no longer useful. Either the roots of some large trees nearby have taken over, or the dry well is so full of leaves that it can no longer hold water that pours into it from the gutters. What options do I have for dealing with this?

title: America Is Still a Land of Opportunity
description: I OFTEN get the feeling that the United States has lost some of the confidence it once had. America's perception of its economic vulnerability is reflected in the success of such books as "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers" by Paul Kennedy, "The Reckoning" by David Halberstam, "Buying Into America" by Martin and Susan Tolchin, and numerous public opinion polls. But the United States is still the richest country in the world. The American people still enjoy the highest living standard of any people and the United States still plays a dominant role in the world economy.

title: Review/Music; Big Swing's West Coast Rhythms
description: In the middle of the first set played at the weekly "Hi-Steppin' Tuesdays" dance at the Aspen Club, 20 West 20th Street, on Tuesday evening, the band announced that it was changing its name. For more than two years the five-piece group had been playing as the Be-Hop Band. But, said its singer and co-leader Jenny Dee, it would now be known as the Big Swing.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: South; Ga. Tech Remains Unbeaten on Kicks
description: Scott Sisson's 38-yard field goal with eight seconds remaining gave unbeaten Georgia Tech a 6-3 victory today over Virginia Tech.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Oradell
description: ORADELL'S history can be read on the signposts of its tree-lined streets. The main street, Kinderkamack Road, got its name from the Leni Lenape Indians, who had several large burial sites in what is now this Bergen County borough. "Kinderkamack" means "place of ceremonial dance and worship."

title: Tami Bitter Engaged to Kevin Cook
description: Spring wedding plans for Tami Bitter and Kevin Cook, 1984 graduates of Cornell University, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Bitter of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Pain at a Remove
description: To the Editor: In our narcissistic society, people enjoy others' pain vicariously without having to actually participate physically in it. Frida Kahlo is the perfect woman for the 90's because people can feel about her without having to bother with entering into an actual relationship with someone who really needs their support. But romanticizing pain never helped anyone who needed support. KATE W. McKENZIE Riverside, Conn.

title: Chappaqua
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Upset By U.C.L.A., 25-22
description: Brad Daluiso kicked a 43-yard field goal with 10 seconds left to give U.C.L.A. a 25-22 victory over Rose Bowl-bound Washington today and put a damper on the Huskies' national title hopes.

title: Rentals Flourish as Home Sales Slow
description: IN the New York region's troubled home market, the rental alternative is becoming an increasingly attractive temporary haven for many would-be sellers and buyers. Among them are Samuel and Giedra Trocone, who see the should-we-sell-should-we-buy dilemma from both sides.

title: Pamela Flaum Marries
description: Pamela Flaum, the daughter of Susan Kastin of Fair Lawn, N.J., and Sander A. Flaum of New York, was married last evening in New York to Matthew Weinberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Weinberg of Smithtown, L.I. Rabbi David Rosenzweig officiated at the Lincoln Square Synagogue. The bride, 25 years old, and the bridegroom, 26, are Brandeis University graduates. She was until recently an account executive at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver Advertising in New York. The bridegroom is a mortgage-backed securities trader and a vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York.

title: Flood Tunnel Plan: A State-U.S. Split
description: A CONGRESSIONAL plan for a $1.2 billion tunnel to end flooding in New Jersey's Passaic River Basin has pitted Washington lawmakers against state legislators worried about costs and environmental impact.

title: Cats Watch Over Us
description: PUSS IN BOOTS Written and illustrated by John S. Goodall. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. $14.95. (All ages) PUSS IN BOOTS By Charles Perrault. Translated by Malcolm Arthur. Illustrated by Fred Marcellino. Unpaged. New York: Michael di Capua Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: National Notebook: Wilmington, Del.; Riverfront Plan Goes Awry
description: A HISTORIC rehabilitation project along the riverfront faces foreclosure because nearby renewal efforts failed to live up to expectations.

title: Food
description: IN THE THANKSGIVING TABLE OF MY CHILDHOOD, only one thing ever changed from year to year, and that was the green vegetable. Some Novembers it was canned peas; others, it was Del Monte green beans. No one would ever have known that my mother was Irish or that we lived in a Mexican neighborhood. The only deviations from Yankee tradition were the California ripe olives and the middle-American Jell-O with fruit cocktail.

title: A Jukebox on the Sand
description: BEACH BALL Written and illustrated by Peter Sis. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books.

title: The Nation: Measuring the Pain; Why It's Too Soon To Predict Another Great Depression
description: ONE big reason for the angry mood of many voters last week was pain in the pocketbook, actual or expected, from sinking incomes, lost jobs, failing businesses, higher fuel prices and rising taxes. Even more disturbing than the perceived pain was a gnawing anxiety that the American economy might be headed not just for another brief recession, the 10th of the post-World War II period, but for a real depression.

title: Harbaugh Emerges as Ideal Fit for Bears
description: HE snatched the snap and backpedaled, facing third-and-seven at the Chicago 23. The Bears trailed the Raiders, 10-7, 10 minutes were left before halftime and Jim Harbaugh was determined to make something big happen. Something really big.

title: Campus Life: William and Mary; A Lake Reopens, But Some Fear Jumping Back In
description: For the first time since Lake Matoaka on the campus of the College of William and Mary was closed because of bacterial contamination more than a year ago, students in Sylvia Shirley's class in adventure games have been allowed to cross it, guided by a line strung between trees on opposite shores.

title: Irish Hang On to Hopes for the Title
description: After a series of failures earlier in this football season had reduced them to spectators in gold helmets, Ricky Watters and Rod Smith led Notre Dame to a 34-29 victory over Tennessee this afternoon, and that preserved the Fighting Irish's chance to win an unofficial national championship for the second time in three years.

title: India
description: To the Editor: Ms. Hospital's lament concerning the unpredictable nature of Indian Airlines need not discourage tourists from taking a journey to that fabulous country.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 21 about southern India referred incorrectly to the founding of Yale University. It was begun in 1701 by a group of clergymen as the Collegiate School; in 1718, it was renamed for Elihu Yale, a benefactor.

title: Review/Music; Santana's Cultural Open-Mindedness
description: About halfway through the guitarist Carlos Santana's show at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night, his lead singer, Alex Lingertwood, walked off stage, only to return three or four songs later. His vanishing made no difference. Mr. Santana, whose three shows at the Beacon sold out, is, 21 years after his first hit, on the margins of pop music. Without radio airplay, he's managed to sustain a career out of his frequently brilliant, improvised and mostly instrumental live shows. The singer was just a vestige of Mr. Santana's career as a pop performer.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TRACY IS ON HIS WAY

title: New Yale Program Treats Breast Cancer
description: THE discovery of a lump in the breast can be an unsettling experience for women, who must often spend weeks waiting for appointments to see two or more specialists before receiving a final diagnosis. Besides the time missed from work or home, the fear associated with breast cancer can also create mental agony.

title: Coaxing the Stanford Elephant to Dance
description: NOURISHED over the years by affluent and well-insured patients, the Stanford Medical Center has expanded in the past decade from a single large building into a leading example of what some health-care experts call the medical-industrial complex. It now covers an area almost as large as the adjacent century-old central campus of Stanford University. And bulldozers and cranes are still roaring, at work on new laboratories and a new children's hospital.

title: Small Hellenistic Sculptures And a Painter's Rebellion
description: THE Art Museum at Princeton University is a major exhibition in itself, particularly now that it has been refurbished -- and enriched by new acquisitions. Custom dictates, however, that temporary installations get the ink, and the two currently on view are certainly worthy of attention.

title: Born to Win -- and to Lose
description: HUSTLE The Myth, Life, and Lies of Pete Rose. By Michael Y. Sokolove. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Q and A
description: Wine Tours in Chile

title: An Octogenarian Who Breeds Plants
description: Elwyn M. Meader, a man of gentle persuasion and boundless patience, speaks of time not as a series of yesterdays and tomorrows but as blocks of overlapping quarter centuries. Such a long view has been necessary to his work as a plant breeder. His specialty has been to develop fruits and vegetables for the home gardener that can withstand northern winters and produce bumper crops in a short season.

title: Shawn Reilly Is the Bride Of Thomas David Meyer
description: Shawn Reilly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald D. Reilly of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas David Meyer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John L. Meyer 2d of Woodstock, Conn. The Rev. James A. Birdsall officiated at Christ Episcopal Church in Pomfret, Conn.

title: In McCarthy Era, TV Networks Cowered; 'The White Case'
description: To the Editor:

title: Gigli Opens a New Playground for His Imagination
description: The new Romeo Gigli shop is not only a little off Madison Avenue at 69th Street, it's also a little bit off the wall. Will it suffice to say that very few clothing stores are remarkable for their ashtrays and garden furniture? That this one sells a scarf for about $2,500 -- and it actually seems to be worth it?

title: Memorial Service for Paley
description: A memorial service for William S. Paley, chairman and founder of CBS Inc., is to be held at 11 A.M. tomorrow at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street. The speakers will include Frank N. Stanton, David Rockefeller, Henry A. Kissinger, Walter Cronkite and Marietta Tree. Mr. Paley died in Manhattan on Oct. 26 at the age of 89.

title: Neighborly S.&L. Is Pinched by the Times
description: George Bailey lives.

title: Martha Kittredge and Brian Costello Are to Wed
description: Mrs. David Brayton Kittredge of Charlotte, Vt., has announced the engagement of her daughter Martha Louise Kittredge to Brian Costello, a son of Joseph V. Costello of East Brunswick, N.J., and the late Mrs. Costello. A February wedding is planned.

title: Patricia Linda Boas Marries
description: Patricia Linda Boas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert H. Boas of New York and Newtown, Conn., was married yesterday to Gary Edward Paladin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph K. Paladin of St. Louis. The Rev. Richard Leonard officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The bride, 30 years old, is keeping her name. She graduated from Hamilton College and received an M.B.A. from Columbia University. She is a product manager at the Warner-Lambert Company in Morris Plains, N.J., where her husband is a senior product manager. Mr. Paladin, 35 and a graduate of the University of Missouri, received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago.

title: Review/Theater; A Baroque Vision of Evil in One-Act Play Series
description: In the dramatic imagination of the late playwright Alan Bowne, hell on earth had a very specific location: Manhattan and its predatory nether world of addicts and male prostitutes where heroin and sex are all-consuming cravings and survival a daily dog-eat-dog struggle.

title: Responding on the Learning Disabled
description: The article is unfortunately typical of journalistic naivete (blindness?) in catering to the educational establishment party line about treatment of kids who aren't learning as fast as their peers. The entire focus of the article assumes that all problems reside in the child.

title: Campus Life: Curry; Dyslexics Learn To Believe First, Then to Overcome
description: The roster of winners at last month's Curry College alumni awards dinner was impressive: lawyer, clinical psychologist, commercial real-estate developer, interpreter, special-education teacher, film stunt coordinator, prep school alumni relations director, prison chief.

title: Style Makers; Judith Eloise Hooper, Tableware Designer
description: "You should dress your table like you dress yourself, with tone and an attitude," said Judith Eloise Hooper.

title: Congress Thwarts Plan To Move Plum I. Virus
description: A PROPOSAL to transport frozen crystals of the virus of foot-and-mouth disease from the Plum Island Animal Disease Center to the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton has been thwarted.

title: A Very Liverpudlian Spouse
description: To the Editor: Joe Queenan suggests in his review of Neil Gaiman and Terry Pratchett's novel, "Good Omens" (Oct. 7), that marriage to a British national will "disabuse any American of the notion that always and everywhere English people are witty and clever, imperturbable and sophisticated," particularly "if the spouse has relatives in Liverpool."

title: Obscenity Charges Dismissed
description: A Dallas County judge has dismissed eight misdemeanor obscenity charges againt a music store chain in an agreement with prosecutors under which the chain will stop selling an album by the rap group 2 Live Crew. Gerald H. Goldstein, a lawyer for the chain, Sound Warehouse Inc., said it would stop selling "As Nasty As They Wanna Be," an album deemed obscene by a Federal judge in Florida.

title: Outdoors; Predators in Boats Prey on the Shark
description: UNTIL fairly recently, sport fishing for shark was viewed as being slightly outre or perhaps a bit self-destructive, since the angler was pitting his skills and equipment against the nastiest fish in the sea for no obvious purpose. Since the fish was unpopular for eating at the time and no one wanted to buy them, sharks were nuisances wrapped in an aura of menace so why bother.

title: The Gershwins' 'Oh, Kay!' Dances to Harlem
description: "OH, KAY!" -- THE GERSHWIN brothers' 1926 opus, David Merrick's 88th Broadway production and the first big splash of the season -- is the one thing an escapist musical can't afford to be: hard-working.

title: SUNY Chief Weighs Spring Tuition Increase
description: Faced with the prospect of a new round of budget cuts, the Chancellor of the State University of New York is considering recommending an increase in tuition of $50 to $100 for the spring semester, university officials have said.

title: Need a 1937 Dodgers Cap? Here's the Place
description: It was the 1946 baseball season, Arthur Gottheim will tell you at the drop of a hat, that the Brookyn Dodgers wore blue satin caps for their night games. For fans who crave more such facts, he will go on to say that from 1902 to 1957 the beloved 'Bums' sported no fewer than 15 cap styles, including one of Kelly green wool with a block-letter B in white (1937), and one of white wool with blue pinstripes and a blue bill (1938).

ART;
Prizes From L.I. Collectors

title: Postings: Lawrence-Woodmere; Sites for Sale

That depends on who is interested. It is even conceivable that the school would sell all 22 acres on three sites and relocate somewhere else in the Five Towns area. "The strategy is to liquidate the right amount of acreage at the right price," said the headmaster, Richard E. Hanson Jr.

Either the roots of some large trees nearby have taken over, or the dry well is so full of leaves that it can no longer hold water that pours into it from the gutters. What options do I have for dealing with this?

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Animal Vegetable Mineral
description: Animal, vegetable, mineral? Ever heard of the old Victorian parlor pastime? In those pre-Nintendo days, this guessing game ranked right up there with charades as an after-dinner diversion. Nowadays, those same three categories operate in a different sort of diversionary way -- as neat little tools to get you through the holiday shopping maze. Think of them as sort of a psyche-specific gift guide. Your mother-in-law, for example, may have characteristics that you find, well, animal. It doesn't mean that she's a beast, rather that she's particularly animate, or has a thing for pets. If so, a faux-jaguar-print scarf or a pair of buggy earrings would do nicely for her. If your significant other is into plant life, then look in the vegetable designation for vials of frankincense and myrrh. The mineral category is the most tactile group, so if you've got a touchy-feely buddy, you might consider something as prosaic as a bit of pumice stone or as silken as a pair of gold satin gloves. The gift ideas on these pages offer a range of possibilities, with lots of room for thought. They're not such a bad way to play the Christmas guessing game, especially if you're on the receiving end.

title: You've Read the Book, Now Play With the Toy
description: WHEN is a book more than a book? The question sounds like a child's riddle, and most young readers probably know the answer: When it's a toy.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE COUNCIL FOR THE ARTS;
Making Culture a Priority

Its first grant, from the State Council for the Arts, was for $1,500. Now the council operates on a yearly budget of $2 million, with a staff of 14, and is the largest private nonprofit arts council in the state.

title: An X Is Bad For Business
description: To the Editor: Janet Maslin's statement that "for a little-known independent film, after all, an X isn't necessarily bad for business" is wildly inaccurate. Why, pray tell, have a number of respected American independent distributors like Miramax filed expensive lawsuits in the past year to have X ratings of high-quality films like Almodovar's "Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!" overturned? And why did the distributors of Wayne Wang's "Life Is Cheap . . . but Toilet Paper Is Expensive" advertise their film in The Times with their own A rating rather than the Motion Picture Association of America's X rating?

title: A WAR OF WORDS
description: My parents would have grown up to be garment workers, not English teachers, had there been a bilingual education program in Yiddish when they started public school. The very idea of a program aimed at identifying Jewish children by their last names and segregating them from the rest of the school in special classes with special teachers, also Jewish, to make them feel "comfortable" is preposterous. Should any such program have been attempted, cries of anti-Semitism and racism would have been heard.
