title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Recent mild weather has kept lawns green; if the grass is tall, be sure to mow again, so it winters at a height of about one inch. Rake leaves, too, and compost them. Also, pull up and compost frosted annuals. Last call to set out hardy bulbs; try scattering moth crystals on the ground after planting, if rodents. particularly squirrels and mice, are a problem.

title: They Know Bo
description: A basketball court, complete with bleacher seats, was installed early this year in the offices of Wieden & Kennedy, an advertising agency based in Portland, Ore. Another firm might have opted for a large conference room, but the way Dan Wieden -- the agency's 45-year-old founder and president -- sees it, a basketball court is more important. It offers not only recreational release to the pressure that seems to mount each day at the firm, but also a place where he can conduct staff meetings and hold his creativity seminars. At the seminars, noted local artists take center court and discuss the creative process, while Wieden and his staff sit on the sidelines.

title: Dormitory Offers Haven From Alcohol and Smoke
description: AT first, many of the residents on the top floor of Brock Hall at the University of Connecticut in Storrs were shy about admitting that they chose to live on a floor where no drinking or smoking is allowed.

title: The Spigot Strategy
description: By most accounts, it will probably be months before Saddam Hussein feels the pinch of international sanctions. Even if President Bush continues to send more troops to the gulf, our choices will hang between stalemate and military action. But the U.S.-led coalition arrayed against Saddam Hussein has a decisive third option short of all-out attack.

title: Seaneen A. Regan Engaged To John William Carton Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kennedy Regan of Chatham, N.J., have announced February wedding plans for their daughter Seaneen Anne and John William Carton Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carton of Chatham.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: IN THE GARDENS

title: African Films Build a New Audience
description: THE PAST FEW YEARS HAVE seen an emergence of African film in this country. Since the late 70's African cinema had more or less disappeared from American screens, but 1987 brought "Yeelen" ("Brightness") by the Malian director Souleymane Cisse, which was shown at Cannes and the New York Film Festival and later had a theatrical run in New York. Then last year "Yaaba," a movie by a film maker from Burkina Faso named Idrissa Ouedraogo, also played in New York and nearly two dozen other cities.

title: Social Events
description: Writers Read From Works

title: Hollywood Goes In Quest of Spiritual Reward
description: GOING TO THE MOVIES, NOT always necessarily a character-building experience, has been taking a dangerously instructive turn. Those seeking innocent escapism currently risk being alerted to the unjust treatment of American Indians, the power of miracles, the inevitability of death and the very scary possibility that a Messiah arriving among us could look, sound and act like Prince.

title: That Girl Is Everywhere
description: FOR a girl whose first appearance, in 1865, was promptly quashed, Alice has done pretty well. You can find her on film, on tape, in chess sets, as jewelry. Her story has been danced, mimed, acted, set to music, embodied by puppets. Alice and her world of Wonderland are a part of civilization's fabric. She has been parodied ("Alice in Blunderland"), adopted ("Alice's Adventures in Jurisprudencia"), analyzed ("Alice in Wonderland: A Masterpiece of Victorian Pornography?"), even twinned ("Alice's Adventure in Wonderland and Gravity's Rainbow: A Study in Duplex Fiction"). The current edition of Books in Print has 93 entries for "Alice" and books whose genesis is her dive down the rabbit hole -- compared with 32 entries for "Moby-Dick."

title: Suns Score 107 in First Half
description: The Phoenix Suns shattered the National Basketball Association scoring record for a first half when they took a 107-67 lead over the Denver Nuggets tonight.

title: Miss Rafter Wed To A. J. Newman
description: Susan Rafter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Rafter of West Islip, L.I., and Anthony Joseph Newcomb, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Newcomb of Massapequa Park, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. John Moore performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Babylon, L.I.

title: Observation of Grief
description: WIDOW'S JOURNEY A Return to the Loving Self By Xenia Rose. 205 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: America's Official Voice of Champions
description: IT TOOK ONLY FOUR HIT SINGLES TO establish Whitney Houston as one of the pop music world's official beautiful voices. "The Greatest Love of All," the 1985 ode to self-reliance that solidified her popularity, also defined her as a celebrity of discipline, stamina and remoteness. With her Miss America good looks and record-breaking album sales that were the pop-music equivalent of gold medals, Ms. Houston became an all-purpose national champion. It made almost too-perfect sense that she would score a top-five hit with "One Moment in Time," a clanking, impersonal television theme song for the 1988 summer Olympics.

title: The Case for a New Civil Rights Bill
description: LATE one afternoon a vice president at a Fortune 500 company who is African-American and has a doctorate received an unusual telephone call.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: East; Syracuse Upset by Tulane in Last 0:22
description: The wide receiver Steve Ballard grabbed a 12-yard scoring pass with 22 seconds to play as Tulane overcame a 21-point rally by heavily favored Syracuse for a 26-24 victory today that seriously damaged the Orangemen's bowl chances.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ELVIS DON'T LIKE FOOTBALL: The Life and Raucous Times of the NFL's Most Outspoken Coach. By Jerry Glanville and J. David Miller. (Macmillan, $18.95.) Jerry Glanville, formerly the head coach of the Houston Oilers and now with the Atlanta Falcons, has been over the course of his career a controversial figure who fancies himself something of a rebel. His book, "Elvis Don't Like Football," is dedicated to "Jerry Jeff Walker, Kris Kristofferson and John Cougar Mellencamp, the last true rebels of our time." Like many self-proclaimed rebels, Mr. Glanville, perhaps best known for his cloyingly precious habit of leaving tickets at the box office for deceased notables like Elvis Presley and James Dean, complains that he is misunderstood. For example, his football teams don't play dirty, they just play tough. With the help of J. David Miller, a contributing editor of Sport magazine, Mr. Glanville has produced what amounts to little more than an apologia for his professional life, as well as a comfortable perch from which he can snipe at his detractors; most notably, he settles scores against other coaches, including Chuck Noll of the Pittsburgh Steelers and Sam Wyche of the Cleveland Browns, who once proclaimed that Glanville's teams "are the dumbest, most stupid, undisciplined teams we've ever played." Others who come in for the Glanville chop block include sportswriters and broadcasters and assorted aides and players who were either disloyal to Mr. Granville or did not measure up to his code of ethics. On those rare occasions when he does stoop to discuss football philosophy, he often shoots himself in the foot. "Defenses get beat by mental errors. I don't believe you win a game with cerebral ideas. Your players have to know what they're doing. They have to react, not think." Say what? For the most part this is a rambling, sophomoric, self-indulgent book marked by feeble and tasteless attempts at humor, such as his description of one of his nonunion players during the strike of 1987 as "so fat he would've turned queer for a chocolate sundae." Curiously missing from this book is any mention of the Oiler quarterback Warren Moon, who most certainly had something to do with the success of the team while Mr. Glanville was at the helm. Or did he? In any case, it is hard to imagine who the audience for this book would be, other than Atlanta Falcon fans who might want a peek into the future of their team.

title: Clap Your Hands to the Joyous Beat
description: MOTHER GOOSE'S LITTLE MISFORTUNES Selected by Leonard S. Marcus and Amy Schwartz. Illustrated by Amy Schwartz. Unpaged. New York: Bradbury Press. $15.95. (All ages) THE ORCHARD BOOK OF NURSERY RHYMES Selected by Zena Sutherland. Illustrated by Faith Jaques. 88 pp. New York: Orchard Books. $21.95. (All ages)

title: Too Far Too Fast in the Gulf
description: President Bush has supplanted a defensive strategy in the Persian Gulf with what sounds like a unilateral declaration of offense. Pleading a need to provide an "adequate offensive military option" against Iraq, Mr. Bush has ordered 150,000 additional U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia. And now the Pentagon has decided not to rotate the troops already there until the crisis ends.

title: Miss Svikhart Weds Charles Garner 2d
description: Elizabeth Bynerd Svikhart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford M. Svikhart of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Everet Garner 2d, a son of Mrs. Alexander J. O'Reilly of Kensington, Md., and Richard A. Garner of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Joseph W. Hughes performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson.

title: Rutgers Worn Out By West Virginia
description: In a driving rainstorm that made both teams look worse than their mediocre records, West Virginia's superior strength wore down a futile Rutgers squad today on the drenched artificial turf of Giants Stadium.

title: Daily News Loses Columnist And Ads to New York Post
description: The New York Post continued to gain from the troubles of the strike-bound Daily News yesterday, as it announced the hiring of its rival's leading news columnist and published 13 pages of advertising from Alexander's, one of The News's biggest sources of revenue.

title: Nouveau Blood Is Welcome
description: To the Editor:

title: Life With the Real White Goddess
description: ROBERT GRAVES The Years With Laura, 1926-40. By Richard Perceval Graves. Illustrated. 380 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: The World; In Israel, Kahane's Ideas Have Taken On A Life of Their Own
description: IN death, Rabbi Meir Kahane may achieve a respectability that eluded him in life.

title: Laurie Ann Siegel Wed To Joseph R. Nosofsky
description: Laurie Ann Siegel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Siegel of Chicago, was married there last evening to Joseph Richard Nosofsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Nosofsky of New Hyde Park, L.I. Rabbi Victor Weissberg officated at the Four Seasons Hotel. The bride is a principal in Strategic Compensation Associates, management consultants in New York. She is a graduate of the University of Michigan with an M.B.A. and a master's in city planning from Harvard University. The bridegroom, a summa cum laude graduate of the State University at Albany and a member of Phi Beta Kappa, is a manager in the risk management group at A.T.&T. Capital Corporation in Morristown, N.J.

title: Angel Island Journal; Saving Voices of the Other Ellis Island
description: Paul Q. Chow re members that when he first learned in school of the great flow of immigrants from Europe to America through Ellis Island, he went home and asked his mother where their people arrived in this country.

title: A Lawn Needs Nutrients to Flourish
description: BECAUSE of abundant rainfall, most soil in the Northeast is acidic. That is why Northeastern gardeners and their counterparts in the Pacific Northwest are relatively successful growing rhododendrons, azaleas, heaths, heathers and other plants that thrive in acidic soil. The rainfall has a leaching effect, dissolving the soil's alkali nutrients and leaving acidic residue, which is essentially organic matter.

title: Winter in the Snow; Finding Alpine Value
description: DESPITE rumors to the contrary, skiing in the European Alps is far from finished.

title: Yes, Spalding Gray, This Is Your Life . . .
description: SPALDING GRAY WAKES UP AT 5:30 A.M.

title: Rare Find: A Steakhouse of Yesteryear
description: MULLANEY'S is meat and potato country. This year-old newcomer in Bohemia is a nostalgic throwback to days when juicy, platter-filling steaks were king and cholesterol unknown.

title: The Region; Worse Than Cuts And Layoffs? More Taxes
description: MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS warned that he had "some bad news and some worse news" last week as he outlined the cutbacks needed in New York City's budget to keep it balanced this year and next. He said it was too early even to talk about what new taxes might be required.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is 45 years old, and has a dry well that is no longer useful. Either the roots of some large trees nearby have taken over, or the dry well is so full of leaves that it can no longer hold water that pours into it from the gutters. What options do I have for dealing with this?

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: THE REV. DEFOREST L. RAPHAEL;
Defining the Mission of the Black Church
description: JESSE JACKSON and Al Sharpton and the late Martin Luther King, all flamboyant and controversial in different ways, are to some degree what white Americans know about the black church. How representative are they of black clergymen? And just why is there a black church -- one of the most segregated institutions in America? There was a time DeForest L. Raphael thought the black church was irrevelant. He changed his mind, was ordained in 1975 and today is pastor of the Institutional African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church in Yonkers, a position he has held since July. Before then he was pastor at the Park Street A.M.E. Zion Church in Peekskill.

title: Adoptees' Search For Birth Parents
description: In "Could You Be My Mother?" (Opinion page, Sept. 30), Alyce Mitchem Jenkins simplifies a very complex problem by comparing adoption to a children's fable in which everyone lives happily ever after.

title: The Way We Live Now
description: To the Editor: Last night I had the strangest dream. In an article about Frida Kahlo [ "Why Frida Kahlo Speaks to the 90's," Oct. 28 ] , one of this century's most powerfully talented artists, Madonna, the pop star and actress, and Isabella Rosselini, the model and actress, offered such critical gems as "I love the way she dressed. . . . Her clothes made her stand out."

title: In Japan, Hot Springs and Skis
description: SKIING has been taken up by the Japanese with the kind of enthusiasm they used to reserve for exporting video recorders. This mountainous land is filled with dozens of modern ski resorts, indistinguishable from their American counterparts, except for the language and the fact that the cafes serve bowls of noodles and green tea instead of chili and hot chocolate.

title: Special Effects Take on Special Meaning on TV
description: IF EARTHQUAKE-THEMED EPICS can be called a genre, "The Big One: The Great Los Angeles Earthquake," a $9.5 million, four-hour mini-series that NBC will broadcast tonight and tomorrow at 9, is bringing that genre to television. Like the 1936 feature film "San Francisco," starring Jeanette MacDonald and Clark Cable, and Irwin Allen's visceral 1974 "Earthquake," which won an Oscar for its special effects, "The Big One" relies on an assortment of time-tested special-effects techniques to foster the suspension of disbelief.

title: Foley's Law
description: TWO WEEKENDS AGO, SPEAKER OF the House Thomas S. Foley brought the gavel down on the 101st Congress, one of the most ragged and tumultuous in history. The first half of the 101st was largely consumed by twin struggles over Congressional pay raises and the ethical problems of Foley's predecessor, Jim Wright of Texas. The end of the second half, Foley's first full session as Speaker, was overwhelmed by the bitter struggle to forge a deficit reduction plan.

title: Review/Cabaret; Reams's Camptown Traces
description: Lee Roy Reams, who has appeared in "Applause," "Hello, Dolly!" and "42d Street," among other Broadway shows, may be a seasoned musical-theater veteran, but in his cabaret act at Rainbow and Stars he seemed as stage-struck as someone just off the bus.

title: Odd Couples in 'Daisy' and 'Sisters'
description: AFTER 15 years, a willful Jewish widow admits that her dutiful black chauffeur is her best friend.

title: Peter's Pesky Little Brother
description: FUDGE-A-MANIA By Judy Blume. 147 pp. New York: Dutton Children's Books. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Trouble in Murder City
description: THE BUCK STOPS HERE The Presidents of the United States.Written and illustrated byAlice Provensen.Unpaged. New York:HarperCollins Publishers.

title: Confronting Today: Jobs? Yes, but...
description: FOR the hundreds of Long Islanders gathered in the lobby of the H. Lee Dennison Building in Hauppauge, good fortune could be measured by which side of the table they were on.

title: INSIDE
description: New Poland, Evolving Anew

title: Who Knew How To Make The Nose New?
description: ONE HUNDRED FAKE NOSES were needed to make the latest and most lavish movie version of "Cyrano de Bergerac." It also took five years, 2,000 extras, 40 studio sets, $17 million and Gerard Depardieu.

title: World Markets; Lessons From the 20-Year Averages
description: IN this bear market, one place to look for guideposts is history. A sharp-eyed student of past market behavior just might find some clues to the time when stocks, whose long-term values have been enhanced by the sharp drop in prices, will be real bargains again.

title: Must Have Been Some Party
description: NOW LET'S TALK OF GRAVES By Sarah Shankman. 309 pp. New York: Pocket Books. $18.95.

title: Leila Whalen and P. G. Longo Jr. Wed
description: Leila Mary Whalen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Whalen of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Philip Gerald Longo Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Longo of Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Lawrence J. Carroll and Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Church in Greenwich.

title: Joking Aside, Maybe It's Just a Yuppie Recession
description: INVESTMENT bankers are being laid off.

title: In Beverly Hills, A Theme Park For Rich Adults
description: IF JUDITH KRANTZ HAD DESIGNED Disneyland, it would have turned out like Two Rodeo Drive. Whatever else can be said about this super-upscale shopping mall, whose first stores opened last month, it is surely the ultimate synthesis of the major Southern California fantasies: Disneyland crossed with Rodeo Drive. This place is not really a mall at all; it is more a kind of theme park for rich adults, a grown-ups' version of Disneyland's Main Street in which the attraction is not fake Victorian buildings filled with souvenir shops but architecturally ambitious stone and brick facades housing expensive and status-y boutiques.

title: Piercing Questions
description: EARRINGS! By Judith Viorst. Illustrated by Nola Langner Malone. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: A WAR OF WORDS
description: The benefits of bilingual education should be obvious to anyone familiar with the historical background of the new wave of Latino and Asian immigrants. Is it not enough that these children have been uprooted from all that was familiar to them? Must we also take away their language and culture? Must we isolate them and doom them to sink or swim?

title: Another Dangerous Story From Salman Rushdie
description: HAROUN AND THE SEA OF STORIES By Salman Rushdie. 219 pp. New York: Granta Books/Viking. $18.95.

title: Hockey Trade
description: THE Winnipeg Jets and the Toronto Maple Leafs traded top players yesterday in a four-player swap between teams off to poor starts. The Jets sent Dave Ellett, a defenseman, and Paul Fenton, a left wing, to Toronto for Ed Olczyk, a center, and Mark Osborne, a left wing. Ellett, 26 years old, was in his seventh season with Winnipeg and was 1 point short of 300 for his career. Olczyk, 24, had 88 points with the Leafs last season. Osborne had 23 goals and 50 assists for the Leafs last season, his 10th in the National Hockey League. Fenton, 30, had a career year last season with 32 goals and 18 assists. (AP)

title: Karpov, at Match's Midpoint, Says Even World's Best Err
description: The World Championship Chess Match is in recess, but the players are not.

title: Putting Prussia in Its Place
description: GERMAN HISTORY 1770-1866. By James J. Sheehan. 969 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $64.

title: 1990 Apple Crop Is Up 3 Percent in New York
description: With the harvest over, the 1990 apple crop in New York State is estimated at 990 million pounds, up 3 percent from 1989, according to a report from the State Agricultural Statistics Service.

title: Review/Dance; Choreographic Potpourri at Dia Center
description: Just as art salons bring various painters together, so the Salon Project at the Dia Center for the Arts in SoHo serves as a choreographic showcase. The second program in the series, coordinated by Susan Osberg and Joan Duddy, was offered on Thursday night. It was most striking when it was most peculiar.

title: What Wouldn't They Overdo for Art?
description: From the minute we see Camille Claudel clawing fresh clay from the ground in the middle of the night, we know this sculptor is destined for a tortured, romantic life -- the kind that marks the most delicious, least believable artists on screen. CAMILLE CLAUDEL (1989, Orion, $79.98), just released on video, is part of a hugely entertaining genre that is too often taken as seriously by critics as the films take themselves. Overlong movies about oversized lives, they are shamelessly romanticized, bursting with the sense that suffering for art is the most glamorous occupation in the world. Even scaled down for video, they are luxurious, light fictions to sink into.

title: SCRANTON MAY CUT WORK FORCE 50%
description: This city, hometown of Gov. Robert P. Casey, is facing a fiscal crisis, and the Mayor says it could reduce the municipal work force of 650 people by about half, with the layoffs starting as early as next week.

title: Greenwich Village Honors a Model Officer
description: For 19 years, James R. Fleming was the kind of policeman that the Police Commissioner now wants to be the model for New York City patrol officers.

title: The Nation; Now, to Find Out What the Reserves Can Really Do
description: THE Pentagon's decision last week to call up more than 12,000 Army reservists for combat duty poses the first important test of the military's largely unproven policy of integrating active-duty front-line forces with their part-time counterparts.

title: Goin' Primitive: Where Natives Aren't Restless
description: THE LITERARY CRITIC Marianna Torgovnick argues in her new book, "Gone Primitive," that Western culture's ideas about "the primitive" have had more to do with the West's fears and hopes than with reality. The West, she writes, "creates heightened versions of the primitive as nightmare or pleasant dream." If the West is seen as civilized and rational, Ms. Torgovnick observes, the primitive is portrayed as violent and instinctual; if the West is complex, the primitive is simple; if the West is repressed, the primitive is erotic; if the West is competitive and alienating, the primitive is nurturing and communal.

title: Miss Booth Engaged to Palmer Murray
description: The engagement of Stephanie Alice Booth to Palmer Neville Murray, a son of Robert N. Murray of Houston and Daphne Wood Murray of Washington, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Otis Booth Jr. of Bel Air, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: Pictorial Salute to the 19th Century
description: IN critical circles, the jury may still be out on the artistic merits of Edward Lange, the prolific artist from Elwood, who left behind a detailed record of life on Long Island from 1871 to 1889. His problems with perspective and scale, the experts say, make them question his contribution to "fine art."

title:
Northeast Notebook: Nashua, N.H.;
Development Vs. Wetlands
description: THE Tamposi Company of Nashua, which agreed to pay this city $18 million for public improvements in exchange for approval of a 656-acre housing and commercial development, is fighting an ordinance it contends would jeopardize the project.

title: Elizabeth Ellen Schriever Is Married To John Brandow, a Fellow Lawyer
description: Elizabeth Ellen Schriever, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred M. Schriever of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to John Michael Brandow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd E. Brandow Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson and the Rev. Melvin Hawthorne, the chaplain of the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Texas Hands Houston First Loss
description: Peter Gardere's passing set up six touchdowns tonight as Texas defeated previously unbeaten Houston, 45-24.

title: 'Tracy' Turns Two-Faced
description: FOR VIDEO SPECIALTY STORES THE FILM "Dick Tracy," to be released Dec. 19 by Touchstone, is a little like having a rental and sales title in one. Priced at $92.95, "Tracy" will begin its video life as a rental title, but when the first rush of renters thins, probably in about 30 days, retailers will offer the used rental cassettes for sale. To stoke that activity, Touchstone will provide a $3 rebate to the customer, which, according to estimates, will bring the sales price to anywhere from $9.95 to $19.95, depending on the store.

title: Commercial Property: Banking Chambers; Finding Tenants to Fill the Temple-of-Finance Voids
description: A TRIP to the bank once meant a journey into a Roman temple or a Florentine palazzo or -- at least -- a generously proportioned and luminous contemporary space with high ceilings and huge windows. Today, a trip to the bank usually means a moment or two at something not much larger than a telephone booth.

title: Pace of Concert Schedule Quickens
description: THE pre-Thanksgiving concert rush has begun, with a proliferation of enticing concerts.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Who ever would have thought that chairs and sofas would be looked on as anything other than useful seating and, occasionally, pleasant-to-look-at objects of decor? After all, chairs and sofas, without pedigree or distinction of any kind, aren't likely to arouse great interest, and in general, they still don't.

title: Robin Williams, More Than a Shtick Figure
description: In a movie set, Robin Williams wears two heads. When the camera rolls, he is an actor of great authority and accomplishment. Between takes, he is himself, or a stand-up version of himself, giving little performances for his fellow performers. These cameos, at the very least, are endearingly silly -- the sound of his mind at idle -- and occasionally so startling that his peers wonder, as audiences have been wondering for more than a decade, if he's working off his left brain, his right brain or instructions from outer space.

title: Businesses Confront Office Wastepaper
description: THE same week McDonald's announced it would do away with its plastic foam hamburger box because "our customers just don't feel good about it," a broad spectrum of county businesses sent 70 representatives to a conference here to learn about protecting the planet by improving the disposal of office waste.

title: Malaysia's Virgin Forests
description: JERANTUT, gateway to Malaysia's peninsular national park, is shabby and ramshackle, the gutted buildings lining the main road giving the place the air of a ghost town. Once, a decade or more ago when the forest resources of the Malay peninsula still seemed inexhaustible, this must have been a timber boom town. Now, rubber and oil palm plantations have replaced the rain forest in many areas around the town.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Assessment Reform Stirs Controversy
description: ALTHOUGH there is widespread agreement that New Jersey's property tax assessment system needs to be changed, the form of change is a matter of debate.

title: Indian Fare That's Seasoned With Zing
description: SO many restaurants open with a bang and decline with a whimper that it is a pleasure to write of one that has reversed the process: Bonani Indian Cuisine on Summer Street in Stamford.

title: Managing; Corporate Advocates for the Family
description: CHANGING work-force demographics being what they are, flexible hours, child care referral services and other family-oriented benefits are growing increasingly common in American corporations. But the fillip that the General Electric Company's Aerospace unit added in August rings a less commonly heard bell: It appointed 18 "work and family coordinators" to help employees use its new benefits and to make sure that managers do not stand in their way.

title: Katherine Tuttle, Appraiser, to Wed
description: Katherine Ann Tuttle and Dr. David Curry Shepperly plan to marry in February. Miss Tuttle is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Tuttle of Morristown, N.J. Dr. Shepperly is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester E. Shepperly of Cherry Hills Village, Colo.

title: Food Airlifts Called Insufficient in Ethiopia Region
description: Daily airlifts of food for the besieged town of Asmara, the Eritrean capital, and the immediate countryside are proving insufficient to keep the million people in the province under Ethiopian Government control from starving, relief officials say.

title: Elisabeth Hirsch, Teacher, to Wed
description: The engagement of Elisabeth Stewart Hirsch to Dr. Harry David Fischer, the son of Anne R. Fischer of Brooklyn and the late Joseph J. Fischer, has been announced by her parents, Mariellen E. Stewart of Westport, Conn., and John A. Hirsch of Greenwich, Conn., and New York. A February wedding is planned.

title: 2 Grenades Fired in Manila At U.S. Embassy Compound
description: Two grenades were fired at the United States Embassy compound today, but only one exploded and no injuries were reported, an embassy spokesman said.

title: Smiles and Songs Brighten Sisters' Cloistered Life
description: FOR more than 40 years, the Monastery of Our Lady of Grace has stood quietly on 100 rolling acres in North Guilford, little known to the world. Behind the walls, 50 cloistered Dominican sisters spend their lives praying, working and singing.

title: Review/Music; Sung Tales About Just Plain Folks
description: The Texas troubadour -- acoustic guitar in hand, world-weary parables in mind -- is a hearty species, one that has survived from the confessional early 1970's through the "outlaw country" vogue to the present resurgence of folkies. Two Texas patriarchs, Guy Clark and Townes Van Zandt, and a younger disciple, Robert Earl Keen Jr., shared a bill on Wednesday night at the Bottom Line, quietly fingerpicking and talk-singing. They share a penchant for what might be called small tales, quiet narratives about unheroic lives. But their songs displayed three distinct sensibilities -- kindly and nostalgic, gravely depressive and earnest but sly.

title: Leaders Forum Enhances School's Sports Program
description: WHEN Staples High School in Westport was searching for a new football coach last spring, many of the players dropped by the office of the school's athletic director, Robert Byiteck. "They wanted to know whether we were even going to have a football team," Mr. Byiteck recalled. "I really enjoyed meeting with them."

title: Vatican Bars Honor for Archbishop of Milwaukee
description: The Vatican has barred the theology faculty of the University of Fribourg in Switzerland from granting an honorary degree to the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Milwaukee, Rembert G. Weakland, this week, asserting that his statements on abortion had caused "a great deal of confusion among the faithful."

title:
Northeast Notebook: Baltimore;
Luxury Condos Rise on Harbor
description: BALTIMORE Harbor's most ambitious upscale-housing development is rising on what was once Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Key Highway Shipyard, on the southwest side of the port.

title: Running Off With the Tinkers
description: DESTINY OF DREAMS. By Michael Bowler. (Poolbeg/Dufour Editions, Paper, $14.95.) The richness of daily life in rural County Kerry in the 1950's is evoked in exquisite detail in this first novel by Michael Bowler, a Kerry native himself. Mr. Bowler captures well the acute sensitivities of his narrator, an adolescent whose failed attempt, at age 10, to run away with tinkers in a horse-drawn caravan does little to staunch his melancholy and his sense of longing for life beyond the emigration-bled village of Cahirciveen. Young Michael's best friend is Johnny Coffey, the tinker's son, a slow-witted child who suffers endless cruelties at the hands of the priest who teaches the boys' form in the local primary school. "A big country footballer who taught like he played football -- by fear and favour," the teacher "would murder the spirit of a child," notes Michael, who observes that, unlike himself, the teacher's pet student is called "by his first name along with any other boy whose father had clean hands." With rituals of dailiness, time passes, "slow as a wet week." Michael's Mam, who often sits by the window after second Mass on Sundays, "having a peep," is forever serving up meals of bread and eggs and potatoes; his father, with whom, after a violent episode, the son barely speaks, reads the paper after tea "under the bulb." The limited experience and the cautions that abound in rural village life are unfurled in large and small moments, as when Michael is called "an obliging boy" by a neighbor for whom he does errands and the family looks "obliging" up in a dictionary, "in case it had two meanings." Mr. Bowler is a dab hand when it comes to the turn of a phrase, rendering with precision what has been said, just so, while at the same time evoking all that goes without saying.

title: When Picasso Spooked the F.B.I.
description: ALTHOUGH PABLO PICASSO WAS born in Spain, lived most of his life in France and never visited the United States, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Department of State maintained a voluminous secret dossier on the titan of 20th-century art. These documents show that high officials spent a good deal of time and effort worrying about what effect Picasso, who joined the French Communist Party in 1944, might have on American opinion and how best to use him for propaganda purposes.

title: Socialist Is Installed as India's Eighth Prime Minister
description: Chandra Shekhar, a socialist politician who has never held Government office, was installed this morning as India's eighth Prime Minister and the head of a minority Government. He described one of his main tasks as the "removal of fear" following Hindu-Muslim riots in the past weeks.

title: Campus Life: Michigan; Frank Discussion Of Sex Problems Draws Hundreds
description: Sororities and fraternities at the University of Michigan held two Sexual Awareness Days last month that attracted more than 300 members who held frank discussions on a variety of subjects often avoided on college campuses.

title: The Mild-Mannered Revolutionary
description: To the Editor: One need not be a Leninist to take exception to the "uncompromising" treatment of Lenin attributed to Richard Pipes and heartily endorsed by Ronald Hingley in his review of "The Russian Revolution" (Oct. 7). I believe this treatment is a rather crude example of scholarship at the service of politics.

title: February Bridal For Miss Carroll
description: Elizabeth Holladay Carroll and James White Parmele plan to marry in February. Miss Carroll is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Mabon Carroll of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Parmele 3d of Skillman, N.J.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: DANBURY;
Amid the Malls, an Old Farm Sprouts Anew
description: IT seems an unlikely place for a farm, less than a mile and a half from the intersection of Route 6 and Federal Road, Danbury's busiest commercial strips. There, sitting among the parking lots and shopping malls, are fields of pumpkins, tomatoes and corn.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: True Gifts of the Spirit Modern designers have embraced Shaker theories of clarity and simplicity but ignored the spirit behind Shaker ideas. This is from "By Shaker Hands" by June Sprigg (University Press of New England, paper).

title: Review/Dance; 90's Inventory of Love, Joy and AIDS
description: Rachel Lampert's "Inventory 1990" is a dance about AIDS and its impact. But it is not about victims, victimization or brave survival. The full-evening piece, performed at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater on Thursday evening, tells the story of a close friendship between Toby, a gay dancer who has AIDS, and Rachel, a choreographer and company director with whom he has lived.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 11, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe during the Ice Age. 2 1 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) title: In McCarthy Era, TV Networks Cowered; McCarranism
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Back
description: To the Editor: The question "Should German Movies Look Back?" [ Oct. 21 ] confronts the general policy of disregard, denial and outright refusal to acknowledge the reality of Germany's past among Germans in all levels of society. Like Anna Elisabeth Rosmus, I grew up in postwar Germany, but as a child of Jewish Holocaust survivors. I think I became a writer out of the sheer frustration of living in silence and constantly being silenced.

title: Trouble in Murder City
description: DEVIL'S NIGHT And Other True Tales of Detroit. By Ze'ev Chafets. 240 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN Innsbruck
description: The capital of the Tyrol, in the very heart of the Alps, offers what few resort cities in Europe can: a full assurance that enough snow for skiing will be found within a radius of 16 miles from mid-December to early April.

title: Beethoven Programs
description: Joel Krosnick, the cellist of the Juilliard String Quartet, and the pianist Gilbert Kalish are to play Beethoven's complete works for cello and piano in two concerts today at Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street. The first program, at 3 P.M., includes the First, Third and Fourth Sonatas and the variations on a theme from Handel's "Judas Maccabaeus." The second program, at 7:30 P.M., includes the Second and Fifth Sonatas and the two sets of variations on themes from Mozart's "Magic Flute." Tickets are $12 for both performances. Information: 307-7171.

title: In North Salem, the Price for Rusticity Is on the Rise
description: IN this rural community, tranquillity is "the bottom line," the Town Supervisor once observed. But in the aftermath of a court ruling on its zoning law, the county's slowest-growing town has found that the price of peace and quiet has risen dramatically.

title: After Plane Crash, Injured Brothers Hike for 4 Days to Safety
description: Two brothers suffered broken bones in the crash of their small plane last weekend, then hiked for four days through the wet, cold Chiricahua Mountains before being rescued.

title: The World;   In El Salvador, Much Has Changed, and Little
description: HUMAN rights, President Jimmy Carter used to say, is "the soul" of American foreign policy. But Washington's policy here always was much less idealistic. Convinced that El Salvador was the front line in the battle against Communism, Congress overlooked thousands of human rights abuses and in the last decade poured $4 billion into this country, more than into any other nation in the hemisphere.

title: Disks Awake And Shine
description: LIKE RIP VAN WINKLE, THE videodisk lay dormant for 20 years, sleeping in the shade of the more popular videocassette. But now it has awakened to a technically changed world of home electronics. It has become the fastest-growing segment of the video market, with an estimated seven million disks to be sold this year.

title: Works in Progress; Totsy-Turvy
description: IT HAS BEEN POPULAR KNOWLEDGE for nearly two decades that women's gymnastics is the province of the impossibly young, a lesson imparted to the world at the Munich Olympic Games in 1972 by Olga Korbut, who won gold medals for the Soviet Union in the floor exercises and the balance beam. Korbut was 17 years old at the time, but weighing just 88 pounds, she looked maybe 14. In Montreal, four years later, Nadia Comaneci of Romania was 14 when her perfect scores on the beam and uneven parallel bars -- the first in Olympic history -- astounded millions of viewers and established forever the idea that exquisite athletic form is best achievable, perhaps, in adolescence.

title: Postings: 50 Miles From Midtown; 16 Duplex Condos With River Views
description: When Daniel Z. Nelson, a Manhattan developer, bought an abandoned lumberyard at the foot of Main Street in Cold Spring, N.Y., 50 miles from midtown Manhattan, in 1986, he envisioned a commercial project there. His idea was to capitalize on the village's growing appeal to weekend visitors seeking antiques shops, galleries and restaurants.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE BIG SPLASH: A Scientific Discovery That Revolutionizes the Way We View the Origin of Life, the Water We Drink, the Death of the Dinosaurs, the Creation of the Oceans, the Nature of the Cosmos, and the Very Future of the Earth Itself. By Louis A. Frank with Patrick Huyghe. (Birch Lane, $21.95.) "I live on the plains of Iowa, drive a pick-up truck, and build instruments for satellites that study the Earth," Louis A. Frank, a professor of physics at the University of Iowa, begins his story. "I am conservative in the way I dress, in the way I lead my life, in the people I vote for, and in the way I do science." "The Big Splash," written with Patrick Huyghe, the author of "Glowing Birds," tells how a respected physicist became a heretic and was pilloried by the establishment. In 1982 Mr. Frank discovered mysterious dark spots on satellite photographs of the atmosphere; he eventually concluded that the earth was being bombarded by small comets at the amazing rate of 20 times a minute, or 10 million times a year. (The spots were clouds of water vapor left as the comets, 100-ton house-sized blocks of ice, burned up in the atmosphere.) Among other things, that would be enough comets, over history, to account for all the water on earth. If Mr. Frank was right, grumbled one scientist, "we would have to burn half the contents of the libraries in the physical sciences." Mr. Frank's publication of his discovery led to three grueling years of warfare in the pages of the journal Geophysical Research Letters. His account has a wounded, ingenuous air; one famous scientist after another takes him on and, according to Mr. Frank, misses the point. When an astronomer finally photographs the supposed comets streaking across the sky, the evidence is disallowed. This is a savage tale of how science works, but lacking the other side of the story the reader has no way to decide whether Louis A. Frank is a martyr to truth or just bullheaded -- or both.

title: Pterrified by Pterodactyls
description: JURASSIC PARK By Michael Crichton.400 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Mr. Stanley, We Presume?
description: DARK SAFARI The Life Behind the Legend of Henry Morton Stanley.By John Bierman.Illustrated. 401 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95

title: Order Against CNN Broadcast Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court in Atlanta tonight upheld an order barring Cable News Network from broadcasting what it said were tape-recorded conversations between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his legal team.

title: A Marine General Speaks To Troops of an Offensive
description: A senior American military commander here told his troops today that it is now possible that they will launch an offensive against Iraq in the months ahead.

title: Gulf Crisis Produces Surge of Egyptian Confidence
description: Despite its ailing and heavily indebted economy and lingering Arab resentment of its decade-old peace treaty with Israel, Egypt is experiencing a surge of self-confidence with the Persian Gulf crisis and what Egyptians see as their pivotal role in Arab efforts to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.

title: Elderly Become the Gross National Product
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Prussia in Its Place; What Comes After the Wall?
description: THE GERMANS: A People at the Crossroads. By David Marsh. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) There is a hint of pretentiousness about books on whole nations that are titled with a "the" -- as in "The Germans" or "The Russians." But let us see -- does the author deliver? David Marsh, chief German correspondent of the London Financial Times, has updated the 1989 British edition of his book, "The Germans," with some cutting and pasting to bring us beyond the fall of the Berlin wall, the collapse of the Communist system in East Germany and the express-train rush toward unification of the two German states. His thesis is that "Germany's destiny will shape the future of Europe" either to the Continent's benefit or to its risk. So far, so good, although I think one could argue with equal force that Europe's destiny will shape the future of Germany, as it has increasingly in recent decades. But to propose to inform readers about the nation and then largely or completely ignore the women of Germany, the writers of Germany, the film makers of Germany and even some of the major postwar politicians like Herbert Wehner or Theodor Heuss who played central roles in shaping modern Germany is to leave yawning gaps. "The Germans" is further marred by sloppy and turgid writing, awkward usages like "ecumenicalism" -- to describe the role of a church in northern Germany -- and an excess of material taken over unrevised from the previous edition that is now obsolete or irrelevant. On the plus side, Mr. Marsh has dealt at some length with the still unresolved problem of German national identity, which is the core of understanding this strange people, and with demography -- the peculiarity of a declining birth rate for the Germans themselves and the burgeoning of foreign-born people in their midst, now exceeding 5 million in what was West Germany. The best material in this book may be the lengthy quotations the author has assembled in the course of numerous interviews with politicians, bankers and some less extraordinary Germans. They at least give a sense of how contemporary Germans think about themselves and their world. Mr. Marsh is far less eloquent than his subjects.

title: Why Were We in Vietnam, Daddy?
description: VIETNAM A War on Two Fronts. By Sidney Lens. Illustrated. 115 pp. New York: Lodestar Books. $15.95. (Ages 12 and up) VIETNAM Why We Fought: An Illustrated History. By Dorothy Hoobler and Thomas Hoobler. 196 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95. (Ages 12 and up) PORTRAIT OF A TRAGEDY America and the Vietnam War. By James A. Warren. Foreword by Harry G. Summers Jr. Illustrated. 206 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $17.95. (Ages 10 and up) THE WALL By Eve Bunting. Illustrated by Ronald Himler. Unpaged. New York: Clarion. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Lawyer Accused of Faking Personal-Injury Cases
description: A New York lawyer and six associates bribed witnesses and faked evidence in winning millions of dollars in personal-injury cases, a Federal prosecutor charged on Friday at the opening of a trial in Brooklyn.

title: Bradley Is Expected To Heed Voices at Home
description: AFTER surviving the toughest election challenge of his career on Tuesday, Senator Bill Bradley looked like a man who knew he had dodged a bullet as he thanked his supporters and told those who had voted against him that he was listening.

title: Perspectives: Low-Income Housing; New York's Push Into Rental Production
description: GIVE it a long and complicated title and slide it through the Legislature without much controversy and the general public may never know it's there.

title: WILDMAN GATHERING
description: Trip Gabriel may not have gained much from his experience at the Wildman Gathering, but I was enlightened by reading of his encounter ("Call of the Wildmen," Oct. 14). Our culture has produced an extraordinary number of emotionally starved men. The Wildman Gathering affords us a chance to unburden ourselves in ways we couldn't imagine outside of such a forum.

title: Chess
description: When you have a lead, say of a point, toward the end of a very strong competition, it makes sense to take draws and coast into first place. Of course, it is more exciting to press hard for more victories, but you are tired and don't want to gamble on the chance of a loss that could cancel the effect of your earlier labors.

title: The World; Among War's Problems: It Would Be A Hard Sell
description: IF Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's visit to the Saudi desert last week demonstrated anything about America's ability to go to war against Iraq, it is that the Bush Administration could still face a tough time justifying the costs to the American people.

title: Sharon R. Cohen, Lawyer, to Marry
description: February wedding plans for Sharon Ruvena Cohen and Michael Charles Liebman have been announced by Miss Cohen's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon S. Cohen of Chevy Chase, Md. Her fiance is the son of Edna Bauer of Susquehanna, Pa., and the late Arthur Liebman.

title: Campus Life: Illinois; Basketball Team Penalized After Recruiting Inquiry
description: The University of Illinois men's basketball team will enter the 1991 recruiting fray hobbled by National Collegiate Athletic Association penalties imposed last week.

title: Headliners; Education Pays
description: The cloud under which Richard Berendzen left the presidency of American University was fitted with a million-dollar lining last week. Dr. Berendzen resigned as head of the Washington institution six months ago, after he was accused of making obscene phone calls from his university office. He subsequently pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor charges, spent three months undergoing treatment at a clinic for sexual disorders at Johns Hopkins University, and has not returned to the campus. But the tenured physics professor has continued to draw his $140,000-a-year presidential salary. As word spread last week that the university's board of trustees had agreed to pay Dr. Berendzen a settlement of more than $1 million out of the school's $100 million budget for 1990, there was consternation on campus, but Dr. Berendzen declined to address the issue. "I can't make any comment," he said. "I wish I could but I can't."

title: JERSEYANA
description: THE modern Ku Klux Klan was founded 85 years ago this month in a Thanksgiving eve ceremony on a mountaintop in Georgia. The new Klan was a revival of the original hooded order, which had appeared briefly in the South right after the Civil War.

title: A WAR OF WORDS
description: Like many debates about what should be taught in our schools, the debate on bilingual education is cynical and does not really focus on what school kids need to learn ("A War of Words," by Richard Bernstein, Oct. 14). For those who favor starting out in the children's first language (because that's what we're talking about, not bilingual education), the agenda is jobs and perks for the bilingual teachers, and the formation of a political constituency that crystallizes around language and ethnicity.

title: At a Shepherd's Table
description: IT was the cloud of sheep, not their shepherd, that I focused on when the rustle of bells in the driveway woke me my first morning in the Tuscan cottage. The shepherd would become interesting later. And our rapport would ruffle the delicate social contract of the nearby hill town where a pair of ferocious angels stood guard over the entry gate.

title: Those Big Guys on the Ceiling
description: SAYONARA, MICHELANGELO The Sistine Chapel Restored and Repackaged. By Waldemar Januszczak. 207 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $16.95.

title: Responding on the Learning Disabled
description: Learning differences pose a double challenge: identification and then proper remediation.

title: Currency; Dollar's Gain Is Limited to Yen
January Wedding For Ms. Davidson
description: Cantor and Mrs. Louis E. Davidson of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gina V. Davidson, to Roman R. Rossell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rafael R. Rossell of Brooklyn. A January wedding is planned.

title: Caroline V. Clarke Weds J. C. Graves
description: Caroline Veronica Clarke, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Clarke of the Bronx, was married yesterday to John Clifford Graves, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl G. Graves of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr. and the Right Rev. Orris G. Walker Jr., the Bishop Coadjutor of the Episcopal diocese of Long Island, officiated at the Riverside Church in New York.

title: The Spinoff Stratagem
description: THOUGH analysts may be impressed with how rapidly the Thermo Electron Corporation has been growing, George N. Hatsopoulos has a more ambitious perspective. Thermo Electron's founder and chief executive believes his 36-year-old company would be a $7 billion business, roughly 10 times its current size, if he had been running it in Japan instead of here in suburban Boston.

title: Simplifying the ABC's of Science
description: FIVE minutes before his sixth-grade class was due to arrive, Wayne Mammina, a science teacher at the Joseph A. Edgar Intermediate School in Rocky Point, dashed outside to prepare for his lesson.

title: Islanders Crush Flames
description: The Calgary Flames, the team with the best power-play percentage in all of hockey, squandered all four of their power-play opportunities tonight at Nassau Coliseum and lost to the Islanders, 5-1.

title: Responding on the Learning Disabled
description: The article "The Learning Disabled: Challenge to Identify" [ Oct. 7 ] points out the need for independent, comprehensive evaluation of children who pose problems to the school. This is especially true in the Riverhead district, where the Superintendent's wishes are expected to be exactly affected by clinical as well as all other staff.

title: Winter in the Snow; Breckenridge's Wealth of Choices
description: IT takes most skiers at least a week to learn the subtle differences in slopes and landmarks that keep them on course in the 70 miles of trails at Breckenridge, Colo. Signs are scarce at major junctions of trails, transfer roads and broad slopes, and a few lifts are frustratingly slow. But any one of Breckenridge's three main peaks (imaginatively titled Peak 8, Peak 9 and Peak 10) could easily qualify as a mountain at almost any other ski resort.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
It's Not Perfect, but It Works
description: AMERICA'S MISUNDERSTOOD WELFARE STATE: Persistent Myths, Enduring Realities By Theodore R. Marmor, Jerry L. Mashaw and Philip L. Harvey. (Basic, $22.95.) The misunderstanding is simple, persistent and discouragingly familiar: this country's welfare system is a mess, an incoherent jumble of programs that are undesirable, unaffordable and ungovernable. But the reputation is unearned, and "America's Misunderstood Welfare State" explains why. The authors -- Theodore R. Marmor, a professor of public policy and management at Yale University; Jerry L. Mashaw, a law professor at Yale, and Philip L. Harvey, a New York lawyer -- blame what they call "undisciplined rhetoric" in part for the problem. For example, Americans expect a program extravagantly labeled a War on Poverty to end poverty. That the poor are still with us is taken as a failure not just of particular programs but of welfare itself. The authors point out that although Aid to Families With Dependent Children has become synonymous with welfare in public discourse,

title: BAKER TRIP SHOWS COALITION DISCORD ON WAR WITH IRAQ
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's weeklong talks with America's main partners in the coalition against Iraq has demonstrated that there are some very obvious differences over when, and even if, a military operation should be carried out against Iraq, senior Administration officials said today.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT: GOODBYE, DARRYL;
Yankee Retort: Now He's Irreplaceable
description: DARRYL, we heartily booed ye.

title: T. J. Wallace Wed To Delia Marshall
description: Mary-Delia Marshall, an associate editor at Conde Nast Traveler magazine in New York, and Thomas Joseph Wallace, the magazine's editor in chief, were married yesterday in Williamstown, Mass. The Rev. Gary O'Brien performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Campus Life: U.C., Irvine; Chemist Links Global Warming To Methane Leaks
description: Once called "the man who saw the end of the world" and "the man who knew too much," F. Sherwood Roland, a chemist from the University of California at Irvine, is again drawing attention with his most recent studies on methane and its contribution to global warming, or the greenhouse effect.

title: Ian Cosman, 80; Famed As 'Singing Policeman'
description: Ian Cosman, a former New York City police officer, public school teacher and operatic tenor who was known in the 1940's as the "singing policeman" died on Thursday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 80 years old.

title: Appeals Court Rebuffs CNN on Noriega Tapes
description: A Federal appeals court, finding that the Cable News Network had "shackled" a judge in Miami, ordered the network to surrender the disputed tapes to him.

title: Students Pay a Visit to Sing Sing
description: NEAR the stark prison walls of the Sing Sing Correctional Facility, the last of the marigolds planted by the prisoners swayed in a warm breeze. Here, high above the flowing Hudson River, two cultures bumped into each other one recent day.

title: Nepal's King Gives Way to Multiparty Democracy
description: Seven months after pro-democracy forces toppled Nepal's absolute monarchy and began a difficult process of change, King Birendra has put his official seal on a new Constitution that enshrines multiparty democracy and human rights as hallmarks of the political system.

title: Family Guards Its Forest for the Future
description: FROM the top of Crissey Mountain in Norfolk, the Great Mountain Forest sweeps west over the Canaan border and east toward Colebrook. Its 6,500 acres of hemlock, red oak, white pine, beech and cherry make it the largest privately owned forest in the state.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. 375,000 46 Windmill Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split-level; family room, fireplace, formal dining room, eat-in kitchen, deck, 2-car garage, 1.5 acres; taxes $5,129. title: Her Tennessee Background
description: To the Editor: An excerpt from Richard Lingeman's "Theodore Dreiser: An American Journey 1908-1945," printed in connection with your review of the book by Alfred Kazin (Sept. 30), states that Dreiser admired "Evelyn Scott, an English novelist published by Liveright." I quote from Evelyn Scott's autobiography, "Background in Tennessee" (1937): "From 1893, when I was born, until 1909, when I was sixteen, I was never absent from Tennessee for more than a few months together. . . . I was first in England in 1914."

title: A Lurk of Lions, A Leaking Urn
description: On Thursday 118 distinguished writers who have been designated Literary Lions by the New York Public Library in the past decade were honored again at a 10th anniversary benefit dinner at the library to raise $1 million for books.

title: Arizona Could Lose Fiesta Bowl Game
description: The Fiesta Bowl will be moved out of Arizona if Virginia or other high-ranking teams refuse to play in the state over the controversy surrounding a holiday for Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthdate, the chairman of the bowl's selection committee said today.

title: Adventures of Goethe Among the Republican Fund Raisers
description: To the Editor:

title: D. A. Jeffrey Wed To Marla Gusmer
description: Marla Ann Gusmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Gusmer of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to David Arthur Jeffrey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Jeffrey Jr. of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Charles W. Gusmer, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Church in Short Hills. He was assisted by Msgrs. William P. Devine and Harrold A. Murray.

title: Philadelphia Shuffle
description: ONE day after losing their starting point guard, possibly for the season, the Philadelphia 76ers made a trade yesterday. Only it wasn't for another point guard. Instead, General Manager Gene Shue sent Bob Thornton, his 6-foot-10-inch reserve forward, to the Timberwolves for Minnesota's second-round pick in the 1991 draft. The trade left the 76ers with 10 players for last night's game against the Cavaliers in Richfield, Ohio, and left Shue promising by telephone that "we do have another deal planned."

title: Forum; The Collaborative Organization
description: FASHIONABLE organizations today are flattening their hierarchies, streamlining operations and using the word "empower" a lot. The most adventurous increasingly rely on information technology to reshape themselves. They buy into the idea that network technologies will let them become lean and mean so they can do more work with fewer people.

title: Betsy King to Wed Samuel Militello
description: February wedding plans for Elizabeth Ann King and Samuel Bennett Militello, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Militello of Mesa, Ariz., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. King of New York.

title: Investigators Put Milken's Profit at Hundreds of Millions of Dollars
description: Partnerships in which Michael R. Milken and many other former employees of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. invested paid out more than $1 billion to investors in the 1980's, according to information collected by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress.

title: Kabul Rebels Reported to Kill 200 Soldiers
description: Muslim guerrillas fighting to topple the leadership of Afghanistan killed more than 200 Government soldiers who had agreed to surrender, diplomats and guerrillas said today.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: MARC GOLDMAN;
A Champion for Milk and Its Marketers
description: AS president of one of the few privately owned dairies in New Jersey, Farmland Dairies Inc., Marc Goldman has sought to improve the image of milk and increase its consumption while fighting to maintain the number of dairy farms in the region.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IF I EVER GET BACK TO GEORGIA, I'M GONNA NAIL MY FEET TO THE GROUND. By Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $17.95.) Surprise! When Lewis Grizzard drops the bra-snapping, chest-thumping good ol' boy routine, which he does after the first chapter, he's a good, entertaining storyteller. "If I Ever Get Back to Georgia, I'm Gonna Nail My Feet to the Ground" is an account of Mr. Grizzard's boyhood, how he got into the newspaper business and his career as a columnist. Being a newspaperman and being a columnist are two different things, and his explanation of the difference is clear and funny. Mr. Grizzard's passion for the newspaper business and his humor are at equal strength throughout. However, the author, whose numerous previous best sellers include "Chili Dawgs Always Bark at Night," acknowledges an inability to stick to the point; he begins a second anecdote in the middle of the first, and by the time he gets back to the first the reader has lost track of which one was which. And a good newspaperman always checks his facts; Mr. Grizzard should know, having spent three years as sports editor at The Chicago Sun-Times, that Lincoln Avenue is not the city's only slanted street, and he also should have checked and discovered that it was Gladys Knight, not Aretha Franklin, who sang "Midnight Train to Georgia." Over all, though, this book is good, entertaining reading.

title: Headliners; Just Say 'Bye'
description: Sounding a bit like politicians of another era boasting of "peace with honor" in Vietnam, Bush Administration officials last week praised Mr. Bush's drug czar, William J. Bennett, for orchestrating "a turnaround" in the nation's attitude toward drugs and putting America "on the road to victory" in the drug war. The occasion was Mr. Bennett's resignation as Director of National Drug Control Policy, a post in which his policies were frequently criticized by Congressional Democrats. Mr. Bennett denied reports that he was leaving because he was "bored, moping about lack of media attention, sulking about not being in the Cabinet, in a snit with John Sununu and being stampeded out of town." And to the end, he swapped jabs with his detractors. Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Manhattan Democrat who heads a panel on drug abuse, said Administration drug policy had been "a colossal failure." Mr. Bennett called Mr. Rangel "a gasbag."

title: Grandmother Had a Million of 'Em
description: MY GRANDMOTHER'S STORIES A Collection of Jewish Folk Tales. By Adele Geras. Illustrated by Jael Jordan. 96 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: 'I Woke Up When the Bomb Came Through the Roof'
description: WAR BOY A Country Childhood. Written and illustrated by Michael Foreman. 92 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $16.95. (Ages 8 and up)

title: VETERANS DAY TOMORROW
description: Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Fifth Avenue will be closed from 24th to 39th Streets from 8:30 A.M. until noon. Govermnet offices: Federal, state closed. Local closed in New York City, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam and Long Island. Post Office: No regular delivery except for Express Mail. Special delivery at certain locations. Emergency window open at main post office at 33d Street and Eight Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pickups and street cleanings. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses and commuter railroads on regular schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal, state closed. Municipal have option to close. Post offices: Same as New York. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: Regular New Jersey Transit trains, buses and PATH on regular schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state closed. Municipal offices have option to close. Post offices: Same as New York. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Regular schedules.

title: Joggers Favor Agassi's Style
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Suzanne Morris, A Buyer, Marries
description: Suzanne Carol Morris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Griffith R. Morris of Gillette, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven John LeFrancois, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. LeFrancois of Vienna, Va. The Rev. James C. Holmes officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: A Better Way to Reward Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants Look To Moderate Menus As Business Falls by 20%
description: FEELING the pinch of a sluggish economy, Long Island restaurant owners are adding moderately priced items to menus, increasing attention to lighter and healthier eating and promoting weekday specials.

title: What's Missing From This Wedding?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dawn Marie Lucas Marries
description: Dawn Marie Lucas and Richard Patrick Morrison were married yesterday in Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Donald E. Babinski officiated at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Morrison, 25 years old, is a daughter of William G. Lucas of West Hempstead, L.I., and the late Marie Lucas. The bridegroom is a son of Carol Avigliano of Massapequa, L.I. The bride is a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology. Her father is the chairman of the Command Credit Corporation, a credit card company, in Rockville Centre. The bridegroom, 26, is an Adelphi University graduate. He is the assistant to the president of Command Credit.

title: Review/Music; Lennon, McCartney and Harrison Songs
description: The New York Festival of Song, now in its third season, has ranged freely through the art-song literature, touching on everything from the milestones of 19th-century German lieder to contemporary American works and rarely heard corners of the repertory.

title: Campus Life: Mount Holyoke; Students Rally To Overcome Discrimination
description: Led by the As sociation of Pan-African Unity, the black student group on campus, several Mount Holyoke student organizations joined with college administrators in a rally on Friday calling for the college to acknowledge that discrimination exists on campus and to combat it.

title: Don Shula, Still the Best Coach
description: IN sports, the living monuments compete only against themselves, not against anyone else. Whatever these people sculpted in granite and marble accomplish or don't accomplish, it is measured against what they've done, not against what anybody else has done.

title: South Africa: A Communist Looks Ahead
description: Raymond Mhlaba was 23 years old and angry when he attended his first Communist Party meeting in the South African city of Port Elizabeth. He was surprised to hear a white speaker address a black man as comrade. He was startled to see blacks stand up and criticize whites for talking nonsense.

title: Review/Theater; The Stockbroker or the Painter? A Modern Dilemma
description: Mitchell Uscher's romantic comedy "Life on the Third Rail" is supposed to take place in several spots around Manhattan, but its actual setting might better be described as the land of the tired sitcom.

title: Jo-Ann M. Cox, Accountant, 45
description: Jo-Ann M. Cox, a partner in the New York accounting firm Ernst & Young, died at her home in Manhattan on Thursday. She was 45 years old and also lived in Sea Bright, N.J.

title: 'The Conquest of Paradise'
description: To the Editor: I grieve at the sight of a distinguished historian, at this late date, talking about the "New World." New to whom? Conservative estimates put human life in the Americas at about 15,000 B.C., and recent studies push it possibly back to 30,000 B.C.

title: Janina Valdez Engaged
description: Janina Valdez, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Valdez of San Antonio, and Walter B. Terry Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Terry of Peapack, N.J., are planning a January wedding. Miss Valdez, 25 years old, graduated from the University of Texas. She is an artist. Her father is an architect in San Antonio. Mr. Terry, 41, graduated from Lake Forest College. He is an associate at L. H. Friend, Weinress & Frankson, a Los Angeles investment firm. His father retired as a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York.

title: Responding on the Learning Disabled
description: Your report on the learning disabled was a disservice to both parent and professional.

title: Ideas & Trends; Fighting for Control of America's Hinterlands
description: A VAST wilderness preserve in Indiana may seem unlikely as corn fields in the northern tundra, but that is just what Representative Don Young of Alaska proposed -- seriously, he said -- in the waning days of the Congressional session.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We know a war is a war. Some of us won't make it back. But we say, 'let's do it so the rest of us can get home.' " -- Sgt. Frank Huerta of the Marines, in Saudi Arabia. [ 14:2. ]

title: About Men; How Sweet The Sound
description: I ride an old motorcycle. It breaks down regularly, and the guy who used to do the repair work went bankrupt and left town. I called around, and the only place willing to do the work now is about an hour away, a chopper shop where the local motorcycle gangs get their bikes fixed.

title: Minnesota Professor's 'Everyman' Appeal Wins a Senate Seat
description: When Paul Wellstone began his campaign for the Senate, hardly anyone knew his name. He had very little money, and no experience in government. Not surprisingly, the experts said Mr. Wellstone, a political science professor at Carleton College here, was tilting at windmills.
