title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Bird on a Wire 1990. MCA/Universal. $91.95. Laser disk, $34.98. 1 hour, 50 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Militias Begin to Withdraw From Beirut
description: Hundreds of militia fighters pulled out of the city this morning, allowing army soldiers to move in on the first day of a plan to extend the Government's authority over the capital after 15 years of civil war.

title: Tech Notes; Heating Radioactive Waste
description: A TEAM of scientists at Oak Ridge National Laboratory led by Terry White, an electrical engineer, is experimenting with using microwaves to concentrate and solidify highly radioactive liquid waste for safe disposal. The Oak Ridge group believes that using microwaves as a heat source is more efficient because it requires no heat exchanging devices or oven and involves no moving parts that require maintenance. Microwaves heat materials by vibrating the bonds between atoms, causing friction. In the project, radioactive sludge is concentrated and heated by steam inside a cylindrical tank. Blades spread the sludge into a fine slurry, which is fed into a drum and bombarded with high-frequency, high-power microwaves. This heats the slurry to 120 degrees centigrade for drying and then to 300 degrees. By keeping the molten slurry below 350 degrees, gasification does not take place. When the slurry cools, the waste assumes a crystalline-solid form that can be sealed inside the drum and taken to a waste disposal site.

title: Wall Street; The Post-Election Outlook for Municipals
description: AT least Lake Andes, S. D., can spend $110,000 to upgrade its sewer plant, and one of the fire-protection districts in Snohomish County, Wash., can buy $87,000 worth of new fire-fighting equipment. But voters elsewhere were far less willing to approve the ballot issues that generate new business for the tax-exempt bond market.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Cruise Ships Score Higher In Health Tests

title: What Will Become of the Baby?
description: IN A CHILD'S NAME The Legacy of a Mother's Murder. By Peter Maas. Illustrated. 378 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: California Politicians Reel After a Vote Limiting Terms
description: On the same day they returned most incumbent legislators to office, the people of California voted to throw them all out, approving a ballot measure on term limits that exploded like an antipersonnel bomb in the Capitol here.

title: Widow Says Writer Didn't Care That King Copied
description: The widow of a professor of religion whose doctoral dissertation was partly copied by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said yesterday that her husband knew of the plagiarism but dismissed it as unimportant.

title: Style Makers; Harriet Selling, Fashion Designer
description: Harriet Selling is model-tall and slender, with dark blond hair that brushes her shoulders. She dresses like a model, in jeans and cowboy boots, but doesn't model clothes; she designs them.

title: All About/Cruise Lines; A Deluge of Growth in the Floating Vacation Market
description: EVERY Sunday, newspaper travel advertisements bring a reminder that cruise ships have armed themselves for competitive battle. For example, seven-day cruises to the Caribbean that normally cost $1,800 are discounted to $1,000, airfare included. Those who shop around can pay as little as $700.

title: What Did Milken Earn?
description: To the Editor:

title: At Yale, Not-So-Grim Reapers Gather Cranberries
description: THE 14 Eastman Johnson paintings on view at Yale University Art Gallery are outweighed by the amount of information that comes with them, not an uncommon imbalance these days. The exhibition, an import from San Diego, celebrates the 25th anniversary of the Timken Art Gallery there, and its centerpiece is "Cranberry Harvest, the Island of Nantucket" (1880), a work that was bestowed on the gallery by the Putnam Foundation in 1972.

title: Bridge
description: The dramatic finale of the Spingold Knockout teams in Boston in July, when the Jimmy Cayne team rallied from a 32-imp deficit to defeat the Jim Mahaffey team by 24, was recently described by this department as "unprecedented in the 57-year history of the Spingold." Two players in the best position to know, Allan Stauber and Lee Hazen, pointed out that this statement was erroneous.

title: Judge Harold Stevens, 83, Dies; First Black on Court of Appeals
description: Harold A. Stevens, the first black to sit on New York State's highest court and a former State Assemblyman, died on Friday at his home in Harlem. He was 83 years old.

title: Suzanne Charbonneau Wed to S. S. Sullivan
description: Suzanne Marie Charbonneau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Charbonneau of Barrington, R.I., was married yesterday to Shawn Stephen Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sullivan of Upper Montclair, N.J. Msgr. Oscar Ferland performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Barrington.

title:
National Notebook: Waukegan, Ill.;
Bear Market Optimism
description: THE Chicago Bears have given a lift to a business park here by building a $750,000 temporary indoor practice field on three acres they leased for $1 a year for the first two years.

title: Murky Path to Capitalism For Solidarity's Shipyard
description: The giant cranes are mostly idle, the work force has shrunk by nearly half, and there isn't much exhilaration these days at the shipyard that gave birth a decade ago to the Solidarity trade union.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
The Sins of His Waking Hours
description: JUST A DREAM Written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg.Unpaged. Boston:Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95. (Ages 4 and up)

title:
WINTER IN THE SNOW;
Hut-to-Hut in the Colorado Wilderness
description: BACK-COUNTRY skiing doesn't get much better than on the ridge route of Colorado's Shrine Mountain, particularly when the long alpine traverse features untracked powder, no other people and a wraparound view of crisp, white peaks and valleys under an intensely blue high-altitude sky.

title: Panel Finds a Severe Overload in Appeals Court
description: A backlog that could reach 3,000 cases and delay some decisions by up to five years plagues the intermediate state appeals court that handles cases in much of New York City and its suburbs, a state task force found today.

title: Crystal Unclear; Will Tuesday's Disaffection Become Rejection At the 1992 Polls?
description: IT is a mistake to try too hard to project the results of midterm elections forward two years to the next Presidential election. Inevitably, the context changes. The issues come and go.

title: Cash Cards
description: To the Editor: From a piece in your Travel section (Practical Traveler, July 15), I was delighted to learn that Cirrus cards were acceptable in a number of banking machines abroad. I opened an account in a bank affiliated with the Cirrus network since I was going to France, which, according to your information, had over 200 Cirrus locations. I tried out the card successfully in my neighborhood machine, and my bank assured me that nothing special was needed to activate my card for use in Europe. With the greatest relief I pocketed this financial safety net.

title: In Small Shelters, Touch Of Home for Homeless
description: Four years ago, Sister Kathleen Toner opened Samaritan House. Her goal was to show that homeless mothers and children could be given a place to live that was more like a home and cost less than welfare hotels or the big, impersonal and sometimes dangerous shelters run by New York City.

title: ALL ABOUT A COCKEYED OPTIMIST
description: In the latter years of her life, Mary Martin liked to tell people that when her time came, she wanted to be flown out of this world on wires. Preferably from Madison Square Garden. Having looked into the possibility, she claimed that all it required was the installation of a window under the roof.

title: Talking: Relocation; Companies Limit Help For Moves
description: IN the old days, corporate transferees could remain blissfully remote from swings in the real-estate market because their employers covered most of the costs and contingencies occasioned by a move.

title: Japanese Labs in U.S. Luring America's Computer Experts
description: To the dismay and chagrin of many scientists, leading Japanese computer and electronics companies are opening laboratories in the United States to do basic research, luring some of the most creative American computer scientists to work for them.

title: SETI, PHONE HOME
description: Shouldn't the SETI program equally be concerned about sending our message out there as it is about listening for someone else's? Has it occurred to NASA that an extraterrestrial civilization also might have set up a listening post? After all, if we are both listening, there is no conversation -- someone has to be talking. BRIAN D. JAFFE Forest Hills, Queens

title: A Downtown for the Planned Community of Reston
description: Meant to look as if it had evolved over decades, a downtown has begun to emerge here with office buildings, stores and a first-class hotel that have gone up this year. The new center was created almost as fast as a movie set on four blocks in the center of one of the country's earliest privately developed planned communities.

title: Mavericks Hobbled
description: THE Dallas Mavericks' off-season renovation has been set back for several weeks. Friday night's 111-99 victory over the Orlando Magic ended with Lafayette (Fat) Lever scheduled for arthroscopic surgery later this week and Roy Tarpley facing recovery from a partly dislocated right kneecap, suffered during a fast break in the first quarter. Both are expected to be out for at least three weeks.

title: Half the Effect Can Be Better Than All
description: With fewer consumer dollars going to big-ticket fashion items, many designers are succeeding with garments that are half what they pretend to be -- dickeys, ascots, half-shirts and other "suit fillers."

title: Review/Music; A Spanish History of Medieval Repertory
description: Alia Musica, an early-music ensemble from Spain, offered a concise tour through the history of medieval music and a selection of works from the Sephardic Jewish literature, at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue on Wednesday evening.

title: Winter in the Snow; Tenting and Telemarking in the Tetons
description: LEANING wearily on our ski poles, the three of us stood at the crest of Beard Mountain, a smooth, rolling, 10,500-foot summit in Wyoming's Jedediah Smith Wilderness. My friend Ted Buhl, an accomplished back-country skier, grinned like a madman in anticipation of a dream run: vast expanses of feathery, untracked, knee-deep powder and a brilliant blue sky with the jagged peaks of the Grand Teton Range as a backdrop. Best of all, there was not another human being within miles -- a just reward for the grueling four-hour climb on skis from our camp in the valley below.

title: At Wineries on North Fork of L.I. Tasting Rooms Are Center Stage
description: Thomas Krumholz, an accountant from Smithtown, L.I., waited in line at the busy Hargrave Vineyard cash register. He had just driven over from Bidwell Vineyards, three minutes away, where he had sampled the 1988 merlot and cabernet sauvignon.

title: In McCarthy Era, TV Networks Cowered; Harry Hopkins No Spy
description: To the Editor:

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
In Long Beach, It's 'Let's Make a Deal'
description: AFTER almost a decade of intense development, major residential building in the city of Long Beach has come to a virtual standstill. "Developers are still putting up one- and two-family houses, but except for that, we're in a holding pattern right now," said City Manager Edwin L. Eaton.

title: JUST ANOTHER SOAP OPERA?
description: Penelope Green's article on shampoo (Beauty: "Just Another Soap Opera?" Oct. 21) and Alessandra Stanley's on Mickey Rourke complemented each other. Don't you get it? Americans are obsessed with clean hair and apparently will spare no expense to have it. Mickey Rourke has dirty hair. He obviously does not share our values. Let the French have him! JANE CARY Deerfield, Mass.

title: India
description: To the Editor: It is regrettable that Janette Turner Hospital, in using her pass ("India Air Pass: Waiting for Enlightenment," Travel, Sept. 2), was snarled in computers and haste. Having escorted groups to India over the past 25 years, I have seen the positive reaction of travelers to the trip; difficulties there have been, and airline problems have occurred, but these have been minimal in the total picture. The Discover India ticket is one of the world's great travel values, and with careful management the tourist map of India can be adequately covered.

title: The U.S. Exits the Plutonium Business And Wonders About Its Arms Business
description: FROM the high bluff east of the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington State, the only activity visible around the mammoth concrete reactor buildings and plutonium processing plants is the swirling of dust across empty parking lots and an occasional coyote slinking past the sagebrush. A thousand miles away, just north of Denver, the Rocky Flats plant is shut down, too; last January it stopped shipments of its only product, the plutonium components used as triggers for nuclear bombs.

title: Beyond the Rush of Traffic, an Oasis for Horses and Riders
description: JUST a half-mile east of the intersection of Route 80 and the New Jersey Turnpike lies an unlikely suburban oasis. On the eastern bank of Overpeck Creek, behind the high willows and thick green pin oaks, the persistent roar of rushing traffic quickly gives way to the gentle rhythm of neatly timed hoofs in an easy canter.

title: McCartney On Life In Fast Forward
description: The corporate symbol of MPL Communications -- the production company that oversees Paul McCartney's endeavors in music, film and video -- is a celestial harlequin tossing aloft several planets and moons. Whether or not the figure represents Mr. McCartney, his current agenda is surely a juggling act.

title: Selling a Free-Trade Pact With Mexico
description: ALTHOUGH the Bush Administration will only begin negotiating a proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico this spring, Safi Qureshey, the chief executive of AST Research Inc. in Irvine, Calif., is already anticipating the wider opening of a major market for his computers. "We see a tremendous potential there," Mr. Qureshey said.

title: Camera
description: Choosing what camera to take on a trip is always a problem for me, since I'm confronted with everything from an 8-by-10-inch view camera to a compact 35 millimeter. On my most recent jaunt I decided to compromise and take along two new models: the Olympus IS-1 and the Canon EOS Rebel.

title: Young Performers To the Fore
description: "A SONG for every season and a symphony that lasts a lifetime" is the motto of the Greater Bridgeport Symphony Youth Orchestras, which begin "a year of celebration" today to mark their 30th anniversary. In 1960, George Jacobson led the debut concert of what was then called the Connecticut Youth Orchestra. Soon taken under the wing of the Greater Bridgeport Symphony, the student ensemble became known as the Principal Orchestra, and in more recent times has flourished under the direction of Robert Genualdi.

title: Scholars and Descendants Uncover Hidden Legacy of Jews in Southwest
description: After several centuries, scholars are uncovering the history of Spanish Jews who converted to Catholicism under threat of expulsion by Spain's monarchs in 1492 and then found refuge and obscurity in the mountains of New Mexico.

title: Sunday Dinner; A Seafood House and Ethnic Fare
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: In the Judge's Chambers: Arguments Over the Tape
description: At a few minutes before 6 P.M. on Friday, Federal District Judge William M. Hoeveler sat down in his chambers and faced Frank A. Rubino and Jon May, lawyers for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, and Terry Bienstock, a lawyer for Cable News Network.

title: Responding on the Learning Disabled
description: I am a parent of a dyslexic child. If the New York State Department of Education had its way, he certainly would have been labeled as "learning disabled." Over the years I have grown to hate that term.

title: Ellen Tabor Wed to Terrence Bennett
description: Dr. Ellen Beth Tabor, a daughter of Mrs. William Jacobs of Yardley, Pa., and the late Robert Tabor, was married yesterday in Philadelphia to Terrence Michael Bennett, the son of Assemblyman and Mrs. Lawrence E. Bennett of Newburgh, N.Y. Senior Judge J. Sydney Hoffman of Pennsylvania State Superior Court performed the ceremony at the Hotel Atop the Bellevue.

title: 2 Burmese Hijack Jet and Give Up in Calcutta
description: Two Burmese students carrying a fake bomb made out of soap hijacked a Thai jetliner to Calcutta today to dramatize demands for an end to military rule in Myanmar, formerly Burma.

title: Renamed Communists Losing Control in Bulgaria
description: Bulgaria's Socialist leaders tried to inject fresh spirit into their troubled party today by summoning loyalists to the streets, but instead they accentuated the political crisis that has overtaken them.

title: Sentence in Officer Shooting
description: A Bronx man was sentenced to 9 to 18 years in prison on Thursday in the shooting of an off-duty New York City police officer last year during a robbery. The man, Robert Ferrer, 21 years old, of 2 West 169th Street in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, had been convicted of three felonies and was sentenced by Justice Robert Cohen in State Supreme Court. The robbery took place at the Schumacher Tobacco Company at 1216 Jerome Avenue where an off-duty police officer, David Scudder, 42, was visiting the owner. When Mr. Scudder resisted, he was shot, suffering permanent damage to his right arm forcing his retirement.

title: Visions of Gingerbread In Architectural Shapes
description: ELISE UPTON just finished building a Victorian on Prospect Street in Darien. Next week, she will begin work on a Colonial. Her chosen building material is gingerbread.

title:
Your Own Account;
Tackling the Dreaded W-Word
description: ED EMERMAN is not one to put off financial housekeeping chores, no matter how onerous. When his daughter, Sarah, was born two years ago, he spent several months researching life insurance before deciding how much coverage he needed and what type of policy to buy. He has even been known to look forward to the arrival of a dinner guest, one with a new financial planning software program.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BECOMING THE BUTLERS. By Pamela Brandt. (Bantam, $19.95)

title: After the Vote, Practicality May Temper Independence
description: AFTER Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s landmark victory last week, the political parties that he tore asunder began picking up the pieces. In just seven weeks, Mr. Weicker will become the state's first independent governor since Alexander H. Holly's election on the eve of the Civil War, and both Democrats and Republicans say they have little time to dwell on what might have been.

title: Sports Reveal Distorted Values
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Saddam Hussein and the Crisis in the Gulf': The Bad Man of Baghdad
description: THE most extraordinary story that runs throughout "Saddam Hussein and the Crisis in the Gulf," a book filled with extraordinary stories, is of the brutality of the Iraqi leader. He burst onto the Iraqi political scene in 1959, ordered by the Baath Party to assassinate the Iraqi leader Gen. Abdul Karim Kassim. The attempt failed and Mr. Hussein was wounded. (On the orders of the Baath, he had already murdered his brother-in-law, a Communist supporter of Kassim.) Mr. Hussein escaped across Iraq into Syria, to find refuge in Egypt.

title: Ways to Cut Household Din
description: NOISE, whether generated inside a building or coming from outside, is a complaint of many homeowners and apartment dwellers. Reducing noise to moderate levels is relatively easy, but complete soundproofing is difficult and usually requires costly remodeling.

title: Denouncing the China Hands
description: CHINA MISPERCEIVED American Illusions and Chinese Reality. By Steven W. Mosher. 260 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Report on Rose
description: A FRIEND who visited Pete Rose in prison last week says he fears for the well-being of the former Cincinnati Reds' player and manager if he fails to be elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Educators Welcome Sobol's Plan
description: WESTCHESTER educators and other community leaders are reacting favorably to a proposal by the State Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, for a far-reaching revamping of the state's educational system.

title: Data Update
From the Pit at the Met, the Sound of Success
description: THE CROWNING ACHIEVEMENT of James Levine's tenure at the Metropolitan Opera is the playing of the orchestra: its night-to-night standards, its steady and remarkable improvement over the last 20 years, its peak accomplishments of rare excellence. This is the one facet of the vast Met enterprise that supporters and detractors agree in finding positive, and it is crucial: the orchestra is the musical spine of the house. It is about to become more than that. At the threshold of the 1990's Mr. Levine stands poised to take the orchestra he has built to a new and unprecedented level of prominence in the international musical world.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Sunday about political risk analysis misidentified two companies. Business International is the London-based subsidiary of the Economist Group; Business Risk International Inc. is based in Nashville. They are not connected.

title: Havel's 'Largo Desolato' At Yale Repertory
description: THE philosopher -- blocked, depressed and paranoid -- paces maniacally amid the clutter that overwhelms him. Instead of motivation, friends, fans and once and future lovers provide unwelcome distraction and intensified pressure. An avid audience awaits his words, and he is letting it down.

title: Truant Student's Parents Are Threatened With Jail
description: Threatening to jail parents of chronic truants is one way to insure that students get a better education, some officials say.

title: Curiouser and Curiouser! The Endurance of Little Alice
description: ONE hundred twenty-five years ago "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" transformed Lewis Carroll's life by launching him as a writer for children. The book changed my life, too.

title: Bryn Mawr Bookstore Marks Its 15th Year
description: THE Bryn Mawr College Bookshop on 170 Grand Street here is "small, dusty, dark and cluttered -- and everyone loves it."

title: Earl Torgeson , Baseball Player, 66
description: Earl Torgeson, who played for five major league baseball teams in 18 years and served four years as a Snohomish County commissioner, died of leukemia at his home on Friday. He was 66 years old.

title: New Airline Terminal Is a Hard-Won Victory
description: ERIC LANGELOH, Westchester County's Commissioner of Transportation, has about two dozen architects' renderings in his office of proposed new terminals for the county's airport, right across the state line from Greenwich. The earliest drawing is "dated 1946, the year I was born," he said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-19

title: About Cars; Acura's NSX: All-Aluminum Exotica
description: WHAT is so amazing about Acura's new NSX is not its blinding speed or the ripping mountain-lion snarl of the engine when you put your foot into it. What is so amazing is not the complex suspension that makes the NSX handle as well as anything yet put on the road. Nor is it the fact that hungry customers are pushing and shoving to pay double the car's sticker price.

title: CRAFTS
description: EARPLUGS with bats' teeth from the Solomon Islands. A Sauk Indian chief's necklace strung with otter fur and grizzly bear claws, or beetle-wing earrings from Ecuador. This jewelry, now on display at the Newark Museum, was once worn to attract attention, establish status or fight off evil spirits.

title: Le Grand Charles
description: DE GAULLE The Rebel, 1890-1944. By Jean Lacouture. Translated by Patrick O'Brian. Illustrated. 615 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.

title: Cornell Trounces Columbia
description: Even though Scott Oliaro says he is content in his role as Cornell's second-string tailback, somewhere in the back of his mind, he must be wondering what he has to do to start in the Big Red backfield.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NO RETURN. By Alexander Kabakov. Translated by Thomas Whitney. (Morrow, $15.95.)

title: On Language; Isn't It Rich?
description: "DON'T TAX YOU, don't tax me," goes the doggerel that former Senator Russell Long used to enjoy quoting. "Tax that feller behind the tree."

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Don't Stress the Birds

title: All the Stage Is Two Cousins' World
description: JOEL MALINA and Joshua Malina are first cousins, close friends and professional colleagues. They look like brothers and in a way they are -- brothers in their devotion to acting. They also share a joint good fortune -- both have wound up in successful shows on the Manhattan stage while still in their 20's.

title: Helen Gayer, a Horse Trainer, Is Married on L.I.
description: Helen Hoffman Gayer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Gayer of Muttontown, L.I., and Unionville, Pa., was married yesterday to Dr. Norman Leslie Shettel, a son of Mrs. Ned M. Shettel of Princeton, Ill., and the late Mr. Shettel. The Rev. Allen Ramirez performed the ceremony at the Brookville (L.I.) Reformed Church.

title: Patterson Rises
description: HE may not yet be a chip off the old block, but Tracy Patterson, the adopted son of Floyd Patterson, the former heavyweight champion, will become the No. 1 contender for the the World Boxing Council's superbantamweight division, effective Nov. 20, according to Eduard Lamazon, the W.B.C.'s rankings' supervisor. Patterson, who had been ranked No. 2, moved up a notch when Pedro Decima of Argentina, the previous top-ranked challenger, defeated Paul Banke, the champion, on Monday. Patterson has a 38-2 record, which includes 27 knockouts. (AP)

title: Hearty Schnitzel, a Staple of Vienna's Kitchens
description: AUSTRIAN gastronomes like to make clear at the outset that Wiener schnitzel -- literally, Viennese cutlet -- did not originate in Vienna. Indeed, the Viennese seem as proud of their ability to adapt and perfect the foods of foreign invaders and the ethnic groups of the old Austro-Hungarian empire as Americans are of having made an original contribution like corn on the cob. The Viennese borrowed goulash (they spell it gulasch) and the delicate dessert pancakes known as palatschinken from the Hungarians, sausage from the Poles, dumplings from the Bohemians and thick black coffee from the Turks. As for Wiener schnitzel, they will cheerfully recount to you its non-Austrian origins at the same time as they prescribe the qualities it should have in order to be considered authentically Viennese.

title: Putting a Spotlight on Halibut
description: "ALL profile" Jean Cocteau once described the flatfish family. Their bodies are shaped like the sole of a shoe and both their eyes lie on the same side of the head. The halibut is the largest member of this family and can weigh as much as 600 pounds and measure six feet long. Such hefty specimens are unusual, however; most of the big ones weigh around 100 pounds. The smaller fish -- often known as chicken halibut -- can weigh as little as three pounds.

title: Snow-Condition Reports: How Accurate Are They?
description: SNOW-QUALITY reports from ski areas sometimes seem an exercise in semantics. In these recordings, there is no such thing as "ice," for example. Instead, it's "hardpack." And there's no "slush," although sometimes a report will admit to "frozen granular."

title: Ex-Police Officer and Firearms Dealer Is Linked to Kahane Suspect
description: Detectives investigating the killing of Rabbi Meir Kahane have searched the home of a former police officer in Waterbury, Conn., who sells guns and used to practice shooting with the man accused of the assassination, the police said.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SUNDAY NIGHTS AT SEVEN: The Jack Benny Story. By Jack Benny and Joan Benny. (Warner, $19.95.) "Had I known, as a young man, that someday I would want to write my autobiography, I assure you that I would have gone out of my way to have at least two or three great love affairs." Imagine those words delivered in Jack Benny's distinctively dry voice and you have some idea of the charm of "Sunday Nights at Seven." Unfortunately, this is not Jack Benny's autobiography, at least not entirely; it is an odd and rather disjointed literary hybrid in which the great comedian's own memories alternate with those of his daughter, Joan. Ms. Benny explains in her introduction that her father's words are excerpted from a manuscript of almost 400 pages that she discovered in 1984, a decade after his death. What she does not explain is why she has published only a fraction of that manuscript, fleshing out the book with her own reminiscences. Whenever the words are Jack Benny's, which is about half the time, "Sunday Nights at Seven" (the title refers to the time slot of his classic radio show) is a delightful book. His passages may be a bit short on depth and on details of his personal life, but they are long on warmth and wit, and they are full of perceptive -- and refreshingly immodest -- observations about the art and craft of comedy ("It has many times been written that I am a master of timing. I would agree to some extent. I am a master of my kind of timing"). His daughter, not being a brilliant comedian -- or, for that matter, much of a writer -- provides a far more prosaic and less insightful slant on things. She has a few good stories to tell, some of them funny and some of them touching. But she has very little to say about her father, or about growing up in Hollywood, that has not been said before.

title:
MUSIC;
A Strictly Classical Guitarist
description: THE guitarist William Anderson believes that the guitar has become of increasing interest to contemporary composers and that the instrument has finally gained full acceptance into the classical mainstream.

title: The Power of the Pigtail
description: SOULSTEALERS The Chinese Sorcery Scare of 1768.By Philip A. Kuhn.Illustrated. 299 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title: Cutbacks Delay Recycling in New York City
description: An austerity program announced by Mayor David N. Dinkins last week will mean dirtier streets and a delay of at least six months in expanding New York City's recycling program, the Sanitation Department says.

title:
National Notebook: Richmond, Calif.;
A Tech Center For a Revival
description: THIS once-flourishing shipbuilding city at the north end of San Francisco Bay has been given a boost in the form of Point Richmond Tech Center, a 23-acre office park.

title: Pulp and Passion
description: To the Editor: I like Lawrence Block's work, but his essay "A Tale of Pulp and Passion: The Jim Thompson Revival" (Oct. 14) contained some haughty implications I'd like to address.

title:
DINING OUT;
Pasta and Fish, Italian Style, in Yonkers
description: STELLA DI MARE is not just another Italian restaurant. This newcomer has already captured a clientele enthusiastic not only for nicely prepared pasta dishes but also for the many splendidly fresh fish offerings in which this dining spot specializes. Thus it is of little surprise that, in delicious compatibility, a partner in this new enterprise is also the owner of the fish shop next door. Our conservative rating reflects the kitchen's occasional tendency to oversalt; we recommend that when placing an order one reminds the kitchen to use a light hand with that seasoning.

title: Air Force Spoils Army's Home Spirit
description: An underdog Air Force Academy team spoiled Mike Mayweather's farewell at Michie Stadium and kept its Liberty Bowl hopes alive today when it beat Army, 15-3, in a driving rainstorm.

title: Laura Casillas and Robert Mele Wed
description: Laura Giovanna Casillas was married yesterday in Guadalajara, Mexico, to Robert Emidio Mele. Msgr. Maximiliano G. Macouzet performed the ceremony at the Templo de Nuestra Senora de Aranzazu.

title: Virginia Clay Corpening Is Wed to Henry W. Ijams
description: Virginia Clay Corpening and Henry Wigglesworth Ijams were married yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in High Point, N.C. The Rev. Glenn Busch and the Rev. Marvin C. Perry, a great-uncle of the bride, officiated. The bride is a daughter of Virginia T. Corpening and A. Glenn Corpening 3d, both of High Point. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seton Ijams of Bowdoinham, Me.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SCANDALOUS RISKS. By Susan Howatch. (Knopf, $21.95).

title: A Playwright's 'Three-Way Look at Time'
description: YES, the abstract is real -- and romantic. And isn't it time for time to be redefined?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Percentage Losers table for the New York Stock Exchange in the Money pages of Oct. 28 referred incorrectly to the change in the value of American Brands Inc. shares for the week ended Oct. 26. The stock, adjusted for a 2-for-1 split effective Oct. 26, rose 2 percent in the week. The table, from the Associated Press, should not have compared the pre-split price with the post-split price.

title: Reliving the War Not Fought in the Living Room
description: OF ALL THE SORRY STORIES OF the Korean War, one of the saddest is its legacy -- that of a war whose cease-fire is remembered in America perhaps less for the end of the carnage than as the inspiration for the final episode of "M*A*S*H."

title: Campus Life: Kansas State; Protests Prompt Officials to Drop Proposal for Cuts
description: Demonstrations forced Kansas State University administrators last week to rescind a proposal intended to cut $3 million from the Colleges of Human Ecology and Architecture and Design.

title: With Yugoslavia in Turmoil, Macedonia Holds First Free Election
description: In an election laced with anxiety over this country's possible breakup, voters in Yugoslavia's southern republic of Macedonia will go to the polls on Sunday in the first free multiparty parliamentary elections in the republic's 45-year history.

title: Days and Nights in Baghdad.
description: Sept. 27. My first appointment in Baghdad is at the Ministry of Information and Culture, a blocklike building in the steel and concrete heart of the Iraqi capital. While I wait in a deserted lobby under heavy-lidded portraits of Saddam Hussein, groups of uniformed officials hurry by. Some carry AK-47 rifles, others .45-caliber pistols. They are volunteers for the Popular Army, the militia assigned to bolster front-line forces in Kuwait.

title: Q and A
description: Selling During a Suit Question: Recently my co-op board and several individual shareholders including myself sued our sponsor and managing agent for mismanagement and fraud. Our lawyer has told me that since the suit has been filed with the Attorney General's office, I will not be able to sell until the suit is settled or the trial finished. Is this true? . . . Rachel Sapers, Manhattan Answer: Probably. According to Paul E. Roberts, a lawyerwith the firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius who specializes in real estate matters, the Attorney General has the authority to halt the sale of both sponsor-controlled apartments and those owned by resident shareholders until the matter is resolved.

title: Mets Wisdom: Majestic, But Not a Winner
description: Fans from other towns never got it. "What'd you guys want?" they were always asking. "What are you looking for from the guy, 50 dingers? One hundred and 50 ribbies?"

title: Cecile Mattocks Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. B. Mattocks of New Bern, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cecile Dione Mattocks to Andrew DeRoy Shenkan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack A. W. Shenkan of Yardley, Pa., and Pittsburgh. The wedding is to be in February.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold 226,900 31 Fern Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old split level; fireplace, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,260. Hamilton 255,000 Nalbone Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; deck, whirlpool tub, fireplace; taxes $4,700. Millburn 312,000 52 Mountain Avenue 6-bedroom, 2.5-bath, 45-year-old Tudor; den, porch, three fireplaces, 2-car garage; taxes $3,724. Springfield 136,000 323 Hillside Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old split level; w/w carpeting, family, full basement; taxes $2,994. Wanaque 185,000 29 Fourth Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; skylight, cathedral ceilings, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,800. West Orange 225,000 3 Wedgewood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 42-year-old split level; 2-car garage, c/a, deck, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $5,607. OTHER AREAS Kings Park, L.I. 197,500 7 Ivy Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, family room, fireplace, 2- car garage; taxes $4,800. Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. 292,500 93 Cochrane Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; cathedral ceiling, wood-burning stove, deck, breakfast area, den; taxes $5,500. New Britain, Conn. 82,000 32 Jubilee Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 90-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, eat-in kitchen, dining room; taxes $1,678.

title: Editorial Notebook; Dirty Political Ads, Reconsidered
description: Filthy campaigning can be fatal to politicians who practice it. This notion has been more a prayer than an axiom. Then came Minnesota.

title: Rams Dangerous Despite Their Record
description: In many ways, the unbeaten Giants will play a typical Los Angeles Rams team today in Anaheim, Calif. These Rams have great firepower on offense, and creativity often makes up for shortcomings on defense.

title: Governors Facinga Fiscal Squeeze and Tough Choices
description: Governors elected this week on a wave of popular discontent over rising taxes will soon be squeezed by fiscal pressures even more severe than those that forced their predecessors to increase taxes.

title: The 'Tree Doc,' of Course, Still Makes House Calls
description: AS trees shed their seasonal foliage, the falling leaves can reveal more than a better view of your next-door neighbor's new deck. The bare trees that remain can look unsightly, with misshapen branches, discolored bark or mysterious growths.

title: Suiting Up
description: THE Jets have provided a helping hand for Frank Mickens, the Boys and Girls High School principal, who is seeking to instill pride in his students through a campaign for shirts and ties to become part of the Brooklyn school's daily dress code. Aware that many of the students are unable to comply with his request because they don't have enough money, Mickens has written to several organizations, the Jets among them, asking for donations.

title: Don't Belittle Steroid Dangers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On the Street; Red, White, Blue and Hot
description: The Stars and Stripes have shown up in a lot of places. In a bit of warmly received patriotic fervor, Geoffrey Beene recently sported them on the front of his sweater as he strode down the runway after his spring collections were shown. It was a proud moment for Mom, apple pie and designer clothes.

title: China Gains in Mideast Crisis But Loses Cold War Benefits
description: Less than a year and a half after China's leaders sent tanks and machine guns to crush the Tiananmen democracy movement, Western sanctions are being dismantled and China is regaining status in the international community.

title: A 30-Year Veteran in the Many Efforts to Combat Drugs
description: AFTER more than 30 years in the drug wars, Harold E. Adams, Commissioner of the Nassau County Department of Drug and Alcohol Addiction, says the efforts are largely imagery.

title: The Drug Czar's Coherent Legacy
description: It's not clear how much praise William Bennett, the nation's first drug czar, deserves for glimmers of hope that the nation's crack epidemic may have peaked. But there is no denying the intelligence he brought to a tormenting struggle marked by ignorance and confusion.

title: Splicing Dante and Homer
description: To the Editor: It is perhaps not merely pedantry to point out that Derek Walcott's "Omeros" is written not in blank verse, as your reviewer supposed (Oct. 7), but in loose terza rima, splicing a Dantesque ambition with a Homeric one. ROSANNA WARREN Needham, Mass.

title: Harold Caccia, at 84, in Britain; Envoy to U.S. After the Suez Crisis
description: Harold Anthony Caccia, a respected British diplomat who served as Ambassador to Washington from 1956 to 1961, died Oct. 31 in Builth Wells, in Wales. A resident of that mid-Wales town, he was 84 years old.

title: Family's Book Gives Life to Dinosaurs
description: HAVING a long and heated discussion about fossils does not happen too often in most homes. But for Niles Eldrege and his sons, Douglas and Gregory, discussing prehistoric animals around the kitchen table is commonplace. In fact, the Eldreges have published a popular children's activity book on the subject, and the book, out 11 months, is going into its second printing.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers 104, 76ers 88: Larry Nance scored 23 points and inspired his teammates by blocking Manute Bol's shot during an 18-4 Cleveland run in the second quarter last night in Richfield, Ohio. Cleveland, which won for the third time in its last four games, trailed by 29-24 early in the second quarter after Charles Barkley completed a 3-point play. The Cavaliers ran off the next 11 points and were fired up when the 6-foot-10-inch Nance jumped high near the basket and stuffed a layup attempt by the 7-7 Bol. Craig Ehlo hit two 3-point shots during the 18-4 spurt, which put Cleveland ahead by 42-33. Philadelphia got no closer than 4 points after that. The 76ers were short-handed because Johnny Dawkins is out with a knee injury and Bob Thornton was traded to Minnesota earlier in the day. (AP) Heat 120, Pacers 105: Kevin Edwards scored 13 of his 30 points and Sherman Douglas contributed 7 of his 14 assists in the third quarter for Miami, which was playing at home. Leading by 58-56 at halftime, the Heat scored the first 11 points of the second half, 5 by Edwards, and took a 69-56 advantage 4:10 into the third period. Indiana cut the gap to 6 points early in the fourth quarter, but a 14-4 Miami surge made it 104-88. (AP) N.H.L. Sabres 4, Capitals 2: Clint Malarchuk, making his first start against his former teammates, stopped 27 shots as Buffalo ended Washington's five-game winning streak. Malarchuk, undefeated in his last five appearances, was traded by the Capitals in March 1989. Buffalo, 6-1-1 in its last eight games, took a 1-0 lead in the first period at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., when Benoit Hogue scored his sixth goal of the season. Mike Ridley tied the score for the Capitals, who at 10-8 are off to the best start in their 17-year history, on a power-play goal against the league's best penalty-killing unit. The Sabres made it 2-1 less than five minutes later on Uwe Krupp's goal on the rebound of a shot by Mikko Makela. Pierre Turgeon scored his 11th goal for a 3-1 lead with 1:17 remaining in the period. (AP) Penguins 3, Bruins 3: John Cullen steered Zarley Zalapski's pass into the net with 5:20 remaining in the third period last night to give Pittsburgh the tie in Boston. Ken Hodge set up three goals for Boston, including Cam Neely's ninth, as the Bruins improved their record to 5-2-1 over the last eight games. Both Hodge and Neely had a hand in first-period goals by Bob Carpenter that gave the Bruins a 2-0 lead. Andy Moog had 30 saves for Boston, including a stop on Mark Recchi's breakaway in overtime. Tom Barrasso faced 38 shots in the Pittsburgh goal. (AP) Tennis Chang Rallies to Gain Final: Michael Chang, the defending champion, scored another great escape yesterday by rallying from a four-game deficit in the last set to reach the final of the Wembley indoor tournament in England. Chang defeated Christian Bergstrom, 6-3, 3-6, 7-6, and will face Jakob Hlasek in the final. Hlasek, the 1988 Wembley champion, scored a 7-6, 6-2 semifinal victory over Diego Nargiso, who pulled a stomach muscle in the second set. (AP) Graf Struggles to Advance: Steffi Graf beat Manuela Maleeva-Fragniere, 7-6, 6-7, 6-3, yesterday to advance to the final of the New England Virginia Slims in Worcester, Mass. She will play Gabriela Sabatini, who beat Mary Joe Fernandez, 6-2, 6-4. (AP) Mayotte and Cherkasov in Final: Tim Mayotte of the United States and Andrei Cherkasov of the Soviet Union won semifinal matches yesterday in the Kremlin Cup in Moscow, the first professional men's tennis tournament in the Soviet Union. Mayotte beat Petr Korda of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 3-6, 6-3. Cherkasov defeated Udo Riglewski of Germany, 6-1, 7-6. (AP) Baseball Wild Pitch Gives U.S. Victory: Ken Griffey Jr. of the Seattle Mariners scored the tie-breaking run on a wild pitch in the eighth inning as a major league all-star team defeated Japan, 3-2, yesterday in the seventh game of an eight-game series in Tokyo. The victory was only the second for the major leaguers, who lost the first four games and played a 6-6 tie with the Japanese on Friday. (AP) Golf First Victory for Peoples: David Peoples, who led every round, collected his first victory as a professional yesterday in the Kapalua International tournament in Hawaii. Closing with a round of five-under-par 66, Peoples finished at 264, 20 under par and five shots better than Davis Love 3d. (AP) Horse Racing Scan Takes the Remsen: Under weather conditions that made any determination of raw ability suspect, Scan showed the professionalism, if not the overwhelming talent, of a horse at the top of his class yesterday in the Grade II $177,600 Remsen Stakes at Aqueduct. The 2-year-old took a slight lead in the stretch, was overtaken but rallied in the final strides to pass Subordinated Debt and win by a nose. Scan ran the mile and an eighth through gusty winds over an inundated track listed as sloppy in 1:52.55 to earn $106,560 for his owner, William Haggin Perry. He paid $3.80 for $2 to win. Scan broke well under Jerry Bailey and settled three wide between Kyle's Our Man and Subordinated Debt round the clubhouse turn and down the backstretch. Those three stayed a length off the moderate pace set by Fire in Ice before the front-runner yielded around the far turn. Scan held a narrow lead in midstretch before Subordinated Debt stuck his head in front at the sixteenth pole. But Scan came back to regain the lead yards from the finish.

title:
ART;
Black Artists Record Jazz Scene in a Lively Show of Paintings
description: A PERENNIALLY tantalizing question is what do artists listen to while creating. This writer's random surveys show classical music to be the most preferred, with talk radio ranking surprisingly high and, in the warm months, many painters listening to a baseball game while working. But a large number listen to jazz, and the fact that jazz stimulates artists doesn't need explanation.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THE DEEP BLUE SEA

title: Lora A. Amoroso Married to Richard A. Haws
description: Lora Alexis Amoroso, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl F. Amoroso of Mercerville, N.J., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Richard Andrew Haws, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Haws of Mercerville. The Rev. Edward J. Dougherty officiated at Our Lady of Princeton Roman Catholic Chapel. The bride, 26 years old, graduated from Villa Victoria Academy and Rosemont College. She was until recently a director in Princeton with Clancy-Paul/Valcom Inc., a computer distributorship based in Omaha. The bridegroom, 26, is an associate in the law firm of DeMaria, Ellis, Hunt and Salisburg in Newark. He is a graduate of the Hun School of Princeton and Drew University and has a law degree from Temple University.

title: Northeast Notebook: Wilmington, Del.; Riverfront Plan Goes Awry
description: A HISTORIC rehabilitation project along the riverfront faces foreclosure because nearby renewal efforts failed to live up to expectations.

title: India
description: To the Editor: Even with confirmed seats, the waits on Indian Airlines are one to eight hours, as we found out recently. Missed Khajraho altogether (same wait-list fiasco) and can almost swear that a herd of elephants sat on our pancake-flat, water-soaked luggage. BETSY JAFFE New York, N.Y.

title: An Air War Of Attrition
description: When political and military leaders contemplate the use of military force, the only thing more dangerous than an unquestioned assumption is a false analogy. Unfortunately, both are present in the Administration's current thinking on the gulf.

title: Giving Iraq Time

title: Chronicle
description: Five months after an appeals court reversed his conviction in the Wedtech scandal, former REPRESENTATIVE ROBERT GARCIA has joined Prison Fellowship Ministries, the organization founded by CHARLES COLSON of Watergate notoriety. Mr. Garcia, who represented the South Bronx, where Wedtech's offices were, said his faith sustained him when he and his wife, JANE, were accused of demanding payoffs from Wedtech in return for Mr. Garcia's influence in Washington.

title: Review/Pop; Josie Esteban's Propulsive Merengue Style
description: Halfway through its first tune at S.O.B.'s on Thursday night, the merengue group Josie Esteban y la Patrulla 15 shook off the cobwebs and began to play. Starting at 11 P.M., the band was practically playing at its breakfast time; it often doesn't go on until 2 or 3 in the morning. But once it started, it seemed as if it could go on all night. The group, based in Puerto Rico but playing music from the Dominican Republic, is one of those road-hardened bands that play virtually every night and can pull off spectacular, effortless performances any time they hit a stage.

title: Showing Gun, Shoots Himself
description: A man accidentally shot himself in the head today as he showed off an illegal semiautomatic handgun in the men's room of a tavern, the police said. The man, Anthony Spradley, 28 years old, of Westbury, was showing a 9-millimeter handgun to his cousin at 12:45 A.M. in the men's room at Donald's Bar here, when the cousin asked Mr. Spradley if the safety was on. Mr. Spradley pointed it at himself and fired, hitting himself in the right temple.

description: The cold war may be over in Europe, but the political frost is still on Korea. How that nation came to be divided, why it remains so and its prospects for reunification after almost a half century are among the matters addressed in "Korea: The Unknown War." Most of its six hours, however, are given to an eventful account of the war itself.

title: INSIDE
description: Big Airline Deal Proposed Trans World Airlines has offered to buy Pan Am for as much as $450 million. The takeover is contingent upon Pan Am's breaking its agreement to sell important overseas routes to United Airlines. Page D1.1 Israel's Offer to U.N. The Israeli Government said it might allow a United Nations envoy to study Arab-Israeli tensions in general, but ruled out an outside inquiry on killings at Al Aksa mosque. Page A3. Economic Blow to Harlem The closing of Freedom National, one of America's largest black-owned banks, was a blow to "the empowerment of black people" and the end of an idealistic venture. Page B1.

title: A Giant That Takes No Giant Steps
description: Over the last five years, the Tribune Company of Chicago has faced a persistent question from some investment bankers: With the powerful base of its six television stations, why not emulate Fox Broadcasting and develop a new network?

title: Scouting Schools For 'Farm' Talent
description: Dave Gagnon was a key player for Colgate last season as the Red Raiders reached the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Associatin tournament, losing the championship to Wisconsin.

title: Scoring Marks Fall In Rout by Suns
description: A television channel at a Queens restaurant flashed a bulletin Saturday night that the Denver Nuggets had given up 107 points to the Phoenix Suns -- in the first half.

title: CBS News to Lay Off 30 to 40 Employees
description: CBS News will lay off 30 to 40 employees in the next few weeks as part of a "general scaling down" of the staff, a CBS News executive said yesterday.

title: Perceptronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 42,800, or 1 cent a share, and $ 104,300, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-Included a tax credit of $ 164,900, or 5 cents a share, and $ 205,400, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves; Public Sector: Government Help, At Least for Now
description: Even in bad times, New York can count on prodigious public spending to help prop up its economy -- at least for a while.

title: CNN IS TO APPEAL RULING ON TAPES
description: Cable News Network said today that it was preparing an emergency appeal of Saturday's Federal appellate court order barring it from broadcasting taped conversations between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his lawyers.

title: DVI Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Holyfield Plan Up for Vote
description: On the morning of Oct. 26, the day after Evander Holyfield knocked out James (Buster) Douglas for the heavyweight title, Jimmy Binns, legal counsel for the World Boxing Association, said it would not insist that Holyfield fight Mike Tyson next, and would allow him to request permission to face George Foreman instead.

title: 3 Papers' Unions Set Deadline
description: In an effort to shift contract talks to economic concerns, unions representing workers have set a deadline of 5 P.M. Friday for strikes against The San Francisco Chronicle, The San Francisco Examiner and The San Jose Mercury News. The Conference of Newspaper Unions, representing 10 unions and 4,500 employees, took the action last week. Employees have been working without a contract since Feb. 2.

title: Witness in Barry Trial Jailed on Drug Charge
description: Charles Lewis, a former Virgin Islands official who was a main witness in the drug trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington, was arrested Saturday and held on charges of possessing crack, the police said.

title: Monitek Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Great Northern Iron Ore Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves; Retailing: Big-Name Stores Strive to Survive
description: Sweeping changes in New York City's retailing and apparel industries seem inevitable, because of changing consumer tastes, in creasing competition and ever-growing finan cial pressures. Some big retailers may change ownership, and many are expected to close some larger stores, open smaller ones and, in general, have a tough time surviving.

title: Georgia Bonded Fibers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First of Long Island reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Business and the Law; New Adversaries In Asbestos Battle
description: FOUR months ago, Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein stepped into the quagmire of costly litigation surrounding asbestos, promising from his Brooklyn courtroom to take bold steps to consolidate thousands of cases from around the nation and achieve strong results for countless victims and their survivors whose compensation has been delayed for decades.

title: Crimean Tatars Return as Squatters, Taking Advantage of Current Chaos
description: Rooted in memories dark as the earth itself, the Crimean Tatars have been returning home as squatters 100,000 strong from Stalin's brutal exile, building stone huts all over the Yalta hills and beyond in a measure of the creative space that can be clawed paradoxically from the current Soviet chaos.

title: Making a Virtue of Moscow's Necessity
description: One wouldn't normally speak of the world trade negotiations and Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika in the same breath. Yet, by a strange conjunction of circumstance, the problems that are threatening to undo both undertakings fit like pieces in a jigsaw puzzle: the solution to one is the mirror image of the solution to the other. This raises the prospect of a unique policy initiative.

title: Hyde Athletic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Restated to reflect a change in inventory accounting.c-Net lossb-Net income

title: Giants Brush Rams Aside
description: It doesn't seem to matter whom the Giants play anymore. Today, against a team that beat them three times in the last two years, they outpassed, outran and outplayed the Los Angeles Rams in every way and won impressively, 31-7.

title: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves; Banking: Many Questions About the Future
description: With their profits and stature at a low ebb, New York's largest banks are realizing that their size and traditions do not guarantee them a place at the top of the financial-services indus try in 10 years.

title: New Hampshire Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge
description: One of the major weaknesses of standard methods lies in the bidding of very strong balanced hands. The auction arrives quickly in three no-trump, in one or two rounds of bidding, and the problems of locating a good suit fit are almost insuperable.

title: Green Forest Lumber reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Microsoft's Bold New Game Plan
description: Is William H. Gates the most powerful man in the computer industry? Many people describe the chairman and chief executive of the Microsoft Corporation that way, often with as much fear as admiration.

title: Uncertainty At Computer Exposition
description: Amid a mixture of glitz and uncertainty, Comdex/Fall, the world's largest annual exposition of computer products, opens here Monday for a weeklong trade show expected to attract 100,000 buyers and sellers, nearly a fifth from overseas.

title: SUNY Campus in Cornfields Cultivates an Ivy Reputation
description: In the Genesee River Valley, the ivy-covered buildings of the State University of New York's College of Arts and Sciences at Geneseo soar startlingly out of the surrounding cornfields.

title: From China's Provinces, Rare Voice of Dissent
description: While China's students and workers seem too intimidated to mount any new protests, the hard-liners who run the country are now facing a challenge from an unexpected quarter: the leaders of the nation's provinces.

title: Telephone Sale By Argentina
description: The Government of Argentina has returned the national telephone company to private ownership.

title: R.E. Flower Wed To Claire Palermo
description: Claire Palermo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice R. Palermo of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Eugene Flower, the son of Mrs. Jacob Flower of Peekskill, N.Y., and the late Mr. Flower. The ceremony was performed at the Westchester Country Club in Rye by Justice Samuel G. Fredman of State Supreme Court in White Plains.

title: Dolphins' Defense Smothers Jets
description: Last Sunday, Terance Mathis was a hero after running a punt back 98 yards for a touchdown. Today, he was by his own admission, the goat in the Jets' 17-3 loss to the Miami Dolphins at Giants Stadium. Both plays were the results of rookie mistakes.

title: G.O.P. Chief Will Run Again Despite an Inoperable Tumor
description: Lee Atwter intends to seek election in January to a second two-year term as Republican national chairman but would likely maintain a reduced role as he continues treatment for an inoperable brain tumor, party officials said Saturday.

title: Things Best Left Unsaid in Saudi Arabia
description: To the Editor:

title: New Rate Cut By Fed Panel Is Predicted
description: Credit market analysts say they expect the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee to approve another cut in a key short-term interest rate when the policy-making group meets in Washington tomorrow.

title: 'Lost' S.& L. Money Is Still Out There
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Japan's Hakuhodo Expands In U.S. and Eastern Europe
description: HAKUHODO, the oldest agency in Japan, is now opening offices in Eastern Europe and expanding its operations in the United States.

title: Euro-Nevada Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 8 Years Later, 2 G.O.P. Losers Win Their Case
description: Two candidates for the United States Senate in 1982 learned this weekend that the wheels of justice had turned slowly in their cases, but had finally turned.

title: Connecticut Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Freedom Bank's Failure Hits Harlem Like a Death in the Family
description: The failure of the Freedom National Bank of New York last week was more than just the demise of another shaky financial institution. It was also a symbolic blow to Harlem, where the bank was based, and marked the end of an idealistic venture begun during the height of the civil-rights movement.

title: Review/Theater; 'Shadowlands,' C.S. Lewis and His Life's Love
description: Jack is a crusty, remote middle-aged Oxford don, a devout Anglican who is more comfortable chatting to God than to the opposite sex. Joy is a 40-ish New Yorker, a Jewish convert to Christianity with a big mouth and a failing marriage. Jack and Joy strike up an unlikely epistolary friendship, rendezvous in Oxford and, overcoming all obstacles, fall in love. No sooner do these opposites attract, however, than tragedy, in the form of terminal illness, tears them asunder.

title: Barge Closings Reduce Sludge Disposal Ability
description: Officials in Westchester County and Northern New Jersey say it may be impossible for them to dispose of millions of gallons of sewage sludge at an offshore dump site if sludge barges owned by a company New York State wants to shut down are taken out of service.

title: Finally, a Little Courage on Trade
description: After years of intransigence, and only weeks before the Uruguay Round of international trade talks is scheduled to end, the European Community offered last week to trim its protectionist farm policies. The European leaders did not offer much in the way of concessions. But the proposal will at least keep the trade talks alive.

title: A Pudding Test for Martha Stewart
description: Time Publishing Ventures, the entrepreneurial arm of the Time Inc. Magazine Company, is trying something that its media parent has not attempted since starting People magazine 16 years ago. It is testing out a magazine by putting it on the newsstands and waiting to see who buys it.

title: Caryn Gail Heyman Weds Craig C. Rose
description: Caryn Gail Heyman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Heyman of Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday to Craig Charles Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Rose of Baldwin Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Lawrence Colton performed the ceremony at Dix Hills Jewish Center in Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Altus Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Logic of War
description: If Saddam Hussein does not withdraw from Kuwait by early in the new year, President Bush intends to use military force against him. That is the inescapable logic ofJU Mr. Bush's decision to send massive additional U.S. forces to the Persian Gulf.

title: First Savings Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Egypt Angry at Former Arab Allies
description: In a reflection of the bitterness that Egypt holds toward former Arab allies over the Iraqi seizing of Kuwait, senior Government officials here have traced the Iraqi invasion to what they call a conspiracy more than a year old involving Jordan and Yemen as well as Baghdad.

title: Chronicle
description: CICELY TYSON is getting an award today from Inwood House for her portrayals of valiant women in films and on television. Inwood House operates a home for unwed mothers and provides social services, family planning and child care to young parents. The organization is also giving a posthumous award to Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, who served on its board for many years. SUSAN DRYFOOS SELZNICK, Mrs. Sulzberger's granddaughter, will accept the award at a reception at the Cosmopolitan Club.

title: Japan Enthrones Emperor Today in Old Rite With New Twist
description: In an atmosphere of solemn celebration, Japan installed Emperor Akihito today as the 125th occupant of the Chrysanthemum Throne, using ancient rituals and customs but for the first time vesting national sovereignty in the people.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: ECONOMY

title: Foothill Independent Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Accounts
description: * Choice Hotels International Inc., Silver Spring, Md., to Gray Kirk & Evans, Baltimore, with a budget of $6 million. * Sky Pix, Seattle, a direct broadcast satellite company, to McCann-Erickson, Seattle, for a special project, with undisclosed billings.

title: Chronicle
description: JEREMY TREGLOWN, editor of The Times Literary Supplement, the British literary journal, has resigned in an argument with the new chief executive, MICHAEL HOY, the former managing editor of The Times of London. Mr. Hoy objected to a headline on the cover of an issue last month and told Mr. Treglown to change it.

title: Enviroq Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Columbia Gains in Soccer
description: Columbia scored two goals in little over a minute near the end of the first half yesterday to defeat Seton Hall, 2-0, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's soccer tournament. The Lions (11-2-3) move on to play the winner of the Vermont-Dartmouth game today in Hanover, N.H.

title: Artist Outwits Inquisition
description: The clash between official taste and artistic vision is nothing new. The recent brouhaha involving Congress, the National Endowment for the Arts, Jesse Helms, Robert Mapplethorpe, Andres Serrano, the City of Cincinnati et al. only echoes a case that came before the Tribunal of the Holy Office -- popularly known as the Inquisition, 417 years ago, in Venice. There is evidence to suggest that the Inquisition was more understanding than one might have imagined.

title: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves; The Media: Growing Trouble For the Networks
description: Network television is in a steep downturn that has led to forecasts of reduced profits and possible layoffs. Cable television, on the other hand, is doing fine.

description: Once the bedrock of New York City's economy, the manufacturing industries that historically provided many blue-collar jobs have been leaving the city for years. Even during the prosperity of the 1980's, the city lost about 150,000 factory jobs.

title: National Micronetics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Irish Look to Colorado in Orange Bowl
description: Thirteen days before the hour when bowl games may officially extend invitations to college football teams, Notre Dame has unofficially chosen to spend New Year's Night at the Orange Bowl in Miami with a game against Colorado that could match the two highest ranked teams in the news-agency polls.

title: Gunfire From a Passing Car Kills a Teen-Ager in Brooklyn
description: One teen-ager was shot and killed and another was wounded as the two walked down a street in Brooklyn Saturday night, the police said.

Silverstone of Baltimore. Rabbis Herman Savitz and Irving Koslowe performed the ceremony at the Hanover Marriott Hotel in Whippany, N.J.

Ian Cosman, 80; Famed As 'Singing Policeman'
description: Ian Cosman, a former New York City police officer, public school teacher and operatic tenor who was known in the 1940's as the "singing policeman" died on Thursday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 80 years old.

title: Pillars Under Stress: New York's Economy - A Special Report; New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves
description: Every so often, New Yorkers find themselves whistling past the graveyard. A recession sets in. Longstanding economic ills, masked during good times, recapture attention. And the city seems to be fading, perhaps irreversibly, as a great financial headquarters and as the center of creative industries.

title: Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK Parade: Fifth Avenue will be closed from 24th to 39th Streets from 8:30 A.M. until noon.

title: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves; Entertainment: Still a World Stage, But With Problems
description: Broadway, the arts and tourism still command a world spotlight, and in the last 10 years they have nearly doubled the number of people they employ -- to more than 50,000. But economic problems have led to worries about the future.

title: Dr. Michelle H. Schiffer and Dr. David Merer Wed
description: Dr. Michelle Helene Schiffer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Schiffer of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. David Mitchell Merer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Merer of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Edward Schecter performed the ceremony at the Fountainhead in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Knicks Set Back Lakers by 109-103
description: The Knicks went into the Great Western Forum tonight and stole the spotlight from the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Biathlon Winner Overcomes the Cold
description: Frigid winds and a long, hilly course were obstacles for many of the 350 participants in the United States Biathlon Federation national championship yesterday at Central Park. But for Rick Trainer, who won the event in a time of 1 hour 17 minutes 59 seconds, the conditions were not particularly challenging.

title: Joy A. Weber Wed To F. C. Tortorici
description: Joy Ann Weber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Weber of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Frank Charles Tortorici, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Tortorici of Brooklyn. Msgr. Joseph K. Parks performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

description: Like it or not, the advertising industry is stuck in New York City. As long as the city remains a mecca for the arts and the media, advertising will stay close by.

description: * American Software Inc., Atlanta, a developer of computer software, appointed Neal L. Miller vice president of finance and chief financial officer, replacing M. E. Renner to the new post of vice president of corporate development. * Reuter Inc., Hopkins, Minn., manufacturer of machined items, appointed Joseph E. Blankenship vice president and general manager of its waste processing division. * Storage Technology Corp., Louisville, Colo., named Geoffrey De Belloy senior vice president. * Tandy Corp., Forth Worth, producer of consumer electronic products, appointed William C. Short president and chief operating officer. * Westinghouse Electric Corp., Pittsburgh, named Nathaniel D. Woodson vice president and general manager of its energy systems business unit.

Market Place; Real Estate Unit Heads for Risk
description: THE Catellus Development Corporation is about to do something that terrifies most real estate companies: trade publicly.

title: A 'Tit for Tat' Cathedral Gift to Jewish Museum
description: The building blocks of interfaith fraternity are literally being cut, chiseled and carved into shape at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where a team of young stonecarvers are crafting an intricate, Gothic-style pinnacle to be donated for the new building of the Jewish Museum.

title: Socialist Vows to Be Capitol Outsider
description: Twenty years ago, many Vermont residents saw Bernard Sanders as little more than a political hippie.

description: Trans World Airlines Inc. has proposed buying the Pan Am Corporation for as much as $450 million in cash and securities, Pan Am said yesterday.

Nunn, Citing 'Rush' to War, Assails Decision to Drop Troop Rotation Plan
description: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee today criticized the Bush Administration's decision to drop its plan to rotate troops in Saudi Arabia, saying that it puts the United States on too fast a track toward war.

title: Guatemalans Vote, but Seem Disenchanted
description: Josefa Coronado left home shortly before dawn today and, carrying a small bundle on her head, walked for an hour with her daughter and two young nieces to vote in this small town. This time she cast her ballot against the Christian Democrats, whom she voted for in 1985 and who won.

description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 200,000, or 7 cents a share, from loss carryforwards.

title: Senate Is Quick to Approve Judgeship for Former Aide
description: In the final rush before Congress adjourned, the Senate rapidly approved a Federal judgeship in South Carolina for a former Congressional aide with limited courtroom experience.

title: SEVERAL WON BIG BY SPENDING LESS
description: Although most of the wealthiest candidates in Tuesday's elections used their financial advantage to overwhelm rivals, an unusually large number of low-budget Davids succeeded in toppling financial Goliaths.

description: b-After extraordinary benefits from tax loss carryforwards of $ 1,170,000 for the quarter and $ 2 million for the 9 months.

title: Head of Carnation Gets New U.S. Nestle Post
description: Nestle S.A., the Swiss-based food company, plans to reorganize its United States business effective Jan. 1, with Timm F. Crull as president and chief executive of a newly formed Nestle USA Inc.

title: Arizona Instrument Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Included net gain of $ 100,000 on sale of a product line.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with tomorrow's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, rescheduled from today because of the Veterans Day holiday. On Thursday the Government will auction a record $11.75 billion of one-year bills.

title: Second Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Intellicorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: All-Sports Radio Format Arrives on the West Coast
description: Thirty years after major league baseball reached the West Coast, all-sports radio has made the journey, with a powerful San Diego-based radio station adopting the format pioneered by New York's WFAN-AM.

title: 49ers' Top Combination Clicks
description: Joe Montana completed 12 passes to Jerry Rice for 147 yards and a touchdown tonight, keeping alive the San Francisco 49ers hopes for a perfect season with a 24-6 victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Comfed Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Yvonne Caravaglia Is Wed
description: Yvonne Maria Caravaglia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Caravaglia of New York, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Grant Moss, a son of Susan P. Moss of Brooklyn and Joel W. Moss of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Dr. Howard Irwin of the Ethical Culture Society of Suffolk, L.I., performed the ceremony at Westbury Manor in Westbury, L.I.

title: Matter of Time For Runners
description: A new electronic timing system that allows officials to keep track of thousands of competitors at a time was used at the New York City Marathon as a backup to the laborious manual process of tracking runners' bibs. Individual runners can also time themselves at clubs that make use of the system. The computerized Time Tag Identification System, introduced by American Sports Timing Systems of Topsfield, Mass., three months ago, is scheduled to replace traditional timing systems for upcoming marathons, triathlons and sailboarding events.

title: Choice of U.N. Refugee Chief Angers the U.S.
description: An attempt by the Secretary General of the United Nations to put his closest personal aide in charge of helping the world's 15 million refugees is drawing sharp protests and accusations of cronyism from the Bush Administration and many other countries, diplomats say.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Graf Beats Sabatini: Steffi Graf used aggressive play at the net to beat Gabriela Sabatini, 7-6, 6-3, yesterday in the championship match of the New England Virginia Slims tournament in Worcester, Mass. The 84-minute match was Graf's 20th victory over Sabatini in 24 meetings since 1985.(AP) Victory for Hlasek: Jakob Hlasek served 13 aces and used his power to overcome the quickness of Michael Chang for a 7-6, 6-3 victory yesterday in the final of the indoor tournament in Wembley, England. (AP) Lendl Wins Again: Ivan Lendl, dethroned earlier this year by Stefan Edberg as No. 1 player in the world, proved to be the king of exhibitions yesterday by taking his second big-money event in two nights. Lendl won the first Milan shootout, featuring tie breakers instead of standard sets, by defeating a surprise finalist, Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 7-5, 5-7, 7-4, at the Assago Forum. (AP) Soccer UConn Advances to Semifinals: A senior forward, Angela Gibbons, scored from 7 yards out after a corner kick to lift Connecticut to a 1-0 victory over Virginia in the quarterfinals of the N.C.A.A. women's tournament yesterday in Charlottesville, Va. Connecticut (13-7-1) will face Santa Clara. (AP) N.H.L. Bruins 5, Capitals 3: Craig Janney scored the tie-breaking goal early in the third period last night in Landover, Md., as the Boston Bruins beat the Washington Capitals to remain unbeaten at the Capital Centre since 1987. (AP) Canadiens 5, Nordiques 4: Sylvain Lefebvre scored with 53 seconds remaining in overtime last night to give the Montreal Canadiens a victory over Quebec, handing the Nordiques their 10th consecutive defeat. Lefebvre drilled a slap shot from the point shot through heavy traffic past Ron Tugnutt for his first goal of the season. (AP) Flyers 2, Canucks 0: Pete Peeters stopped 31 shots to record his 21st career shutout as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated Vancouver last night in Philadelphia, snapping a four-game home losing streak against the Canucks.(AP) Baseball No-Hitter for U.S. Pitchers: Chuck Finley and Randy Johnson combined to hold a Japanese all-star team hitless as the United States major leaguers wrapped up a losing tour with a 5-0 victory. There were a record nine no-hitters in the big leagues this year. Johnson was the first to pitch a complete-game no-hitter, leading Seattle over Detroit on June 2. Despite the efforts of Finley and Johnson, the Japanese won the overall series 4-3-1. Only once before had an American team lost in a tour of Japan, in 1970 when the San Francisco Giants went 3-6. Finley, of the California Angels, struck out five and walked three. Johnson relieved and struck out four and walked two. (AP) N.B.A. Blazers 138, Clippers 107: Clyde Drexler scored 17 of his 23 points in the first half and Kevin Duckworth added 22 as Portland remained the league's only undefeated team (5-0) with a victory over the Los Angeles Clippers last night.
