Duckworth scored 14 points in the third period, hitting six of eight shots from the field, as Portland extended its lead to 105-76.(AP) Rockets 110, Jazz 90: Akeem Olajuwon had 31 points and 21 rebounds and scored 7 points during a 21-2 run that carried the Houston Rockets to a victory over the Utah Jazz last night. Utah took advantage of a 2-for-16 shooting slump by Houston to take a 79-78 lead with 8:27 remaining in the game. But the Rockets regained the lead for good on their next possession with a 3-point play by Otis Thorpe that touched off the 21-2 spurt.(AP)

title: Elizabeth Laurel Miller Married to Glenn Golden
description: Elizabeth Laurel Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Miller of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Glenn Golden, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Golden of Deerfield Beach, Fla. Rabbi Michael L. Abraham performed the ceremony at the Radisson Tara Hotel.

title: Hofstra Will Face Cortland State
description: The unbeaten Hofstra team, one that has outscored its 10 opponents this season by 472-90, will be host to Cortland State in Hempstead, L.I., on Saturday in a first-round game of the 16-team National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III tournament.

title: Lexie Thomas Wed to Peter Demirali
description: Alexandra Webster Thomas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Thomas of Lancaster, Pa., was married there yesterday to Peter M. Demirali, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myfit Demirali of Richmond Hill, Queens. The Rev. Ross S. McClintock performed the ceremony at Highland Presbyterian Church.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 12, 1990: MONDAY FPL Group Inc Stone Container Group Meredith Corp Waste Mgmt Group Minn Mining & Mfg Co TUESDAY Gallagher Arthur J & Co Reynolds & Reynolds Co Guardsman Prods Inc Smith Corona Corp Longs Drug Stores Corp Suntrust Bks Inc WEDNESDAY Atmos Energy Group Kansas Pwr & Lt Co CSX Corp Nacco Inds Inc Eldon Inds Quaker Oats Co Foote Cone & Bldg Comm Sears Roebuck & Co Fund Amern Cos Southwest Airls Co Gabelli Equity Tr Inc Storage Equities Inc Gerber Prods Co Unionfed Finl Corp IBP Inc Wallace Computer Svcs Inc Johnson Ctls Inc THURSDAY Air Prods & Chems Inc Millipore Corp Alco Std Corp NS Group Inc Automatic Data Proc Inc Pepsico Inc Beneficial Corp Plains Pete Co Champion Intl Corp PNC Finl Corp Continental Corp Realty Refund Tr Dresser Inds Sterling Bancorp Florida Progress Corp Talley Inds Greyhound Dial Corp Tiffany & Co New Halliburton Co Time Warner Inc Laclede Gas Co Wal Mart Stores Inc McDermott Intl Inc Weirton Stl Corp FRIDAY Barnes Group Inc Louisiana Gen Svcs Inc Chem Waste Mgmt Inc Reynolds Metals Co Donaldson Inc South Jersey Inds Edwards A G Inc Texas Utils Co Freeport McMoran Inc Varian Assoc Inc Home Depot Inc Williams Cos SATURDAY Dillard Dept Stores

title: Newspaper to Cut Staff
description: The Daily News in Los Angeles will lay off 4 percent of its workers in a cost-cutting move, its publisher, David J. Auger, said last week. The newspaper, based in the San Fernando Valley, employs about 1,200, indicating that about 48 employees will be let go. The Daily News has offered a voluntary early retirement plan to some employees, Mr. Auger said. He attributed the layoffs to the economic downturn that has hurt newspapers across the country.

title: For Graf, A Year To Forget
description: GRANTED a wish, Steffi Graf would have probably asked for the impossible, to have been able to erase this version of 1990 altogether, to have reached her 21st birthday and got on with the business of retaining her title as the world's top female tennis player. Instead, she had to endure a family scandal that debilitated her mind and survive a stream of illnesses that had a similar impact on her body, forcing her to re-evaluate everything from tennis to filial loyalties.

title: Plymouth Five Cents Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company said that during the latest quarter, it charged off $ 10.5 million in loans and wrote down $ 884,000 of real estate, part of which was acquired through foreclosure.

title: Trade Pact With Czechs
description: President Bush signed legislation on Friday to extend most-favored-nation trade benefits to Czechoslovakia. Under the agreement, the United States and Czechoslovakia will grant each other the lowest possible tariffs on goods. The Bush Administration earlier awarded the preferential trade status to Poland and Hungary in the aftermath of the upheaval in Eastern Europe.

title: European Push by Haagen-Dazs
description: Now that the Haagen-Dazs Company has won over many American taste buds, it is taking on the land of napoleons, creme caramels and eclairs.

title: People
description: * Flavio Correa, president of Ogilvy & Mather, Latin America, has given up his role as head of the Brazil sector to Ronald Assumpcao. Newton Guerra has been named new vice president of Ogilvy & Mather, Latin America. * Marjorie R. Porter has been named vice president and account director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York. * Appointed as account management representatives at Ogilvy & Mather, New York were: Bill Gray, Neve Savage, Michael Vaughn, David Warden and Jack Reed. * Virginia Kraus has joined Wells, Rich, Greene, New York, as senior vice president and director of local broadcast. * Robert Cook has been named senior vice president of marketing for Columbia Pictures Television.

title: Allison M. Hayes and Chuck Palsho Are Married
description: Allison Mary Hayes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Hayes of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Ernest Charles Palsho Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Palsho of Robbinsville, N.J. The Rev. Francis V. Boyle performed the ceremony at St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Thomas of Chiefs Gets 7 Sacks
description: Derrick Thomas set a National Football League record today with seven quarterback sacks, but could only agonize over the one that got away.

title: New Breed of Hawkers Peddling News in Strike
description: Like a flashback from a bygone era, newspaper hawkers with their rapid-fire sales pitches have returned to the streets, weaving through traffic trying to nab the attention of motorists and pedestrians scurrying through New York City.

title: Many Are Caught but Few Suffer For U.S. Military Contract Fraud
description: Twenty-five of the 100 largest Pentagon contractors have been found guilty of procurement fraud in the last seven years, some more than once. Yet not one has been barred from Government contracting, and the renewed debate over how to discourage such fraud has produced no easy solutions.

title: At Long Last, Autumn
description: It's beginning to look a lot like Thanksgiving. The leaves are finally starting to drop, the impatiens have gone limp and leggy, and weatherstripping suddenly seems a fine idea. But before the endless summer of 1990 drops into the void there are a few things worth remembering.

title: Hungary's Germans Reasserting Identity
description: A monument to the war dead of this southern Hungarian village was erected in September and consecrated by a local priest.

title: Cynthia C. Davidson, Editor, Marries
description: Cynthia C. Davidson, the editor in chief of Inland Architect magazine in Chicago, was married at the Racquet Club there yesterday to Peter D. Eisenman, the principal of Eisenman Architects in New York. The ceremony was performed by Judge Lester D. Foreman, an associate judge of the law division of Cook County Circuit Court.

title: Giants' Pressure Foils Everett
description: The Los Angeles Rams were efficient and quiet this afternoon as they went about their business of cleaning up after their 31-7 loss to the Giants. The Rams' quarterback, Jim Everett, said his team kept believing until the very end.

title: GNI Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Lean' in Label Only
description: Federal dietary guidelines issued last week urge Americans to "eat less fat and fatty foods." But the effect of the guidelines will be blunted by the Bush Administration's failure to halt the use of misleading meat labels. The perverse result could be to encourage consumption of fatty cuts of beef. Indeed, an individual who tries to follow the new guidelines could well find that a single serving of supposedly "lean" ground beef is enough to exceed recommended allowances of fat for the meat portion of the diet.

title: An Outcast With Super Bowl Rings
description: AT the next locker, Tim McKyer overheard one of his Miami Dolphin teammates, the linebacker David Griggs, talking about the Super Bowl potential of this 8-1 team that leads the National Football League in defense.

title: Hibernia Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Maury Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Bad Year for Out-cumbents
description: Despite all the talk about the electorate being in an anti-incumbent mood, 96 percent of the Representatives who ran for re-election last Tuesday were returned for another term, and all but one Senator. For 10 ex- incumbents, it was a different story.

title: Miscellany
description: * Reebok will be the exclusive athletic footwear and apparel advertiser on CBS network broadcasts of the United States Open Tennis Championships, under a three-year, multimillion-dollar deal.

title: Army Wives Try to Cheer Each Other
description: For Magalis Goebel, the stalemate in the Persian Gulf has become unbearable.

title: Gramm Strategy Faces Senate Test
description: Measuring the length of Senator Phil Gramm's coattails is becoming a new political art form because his ability to help others win election may determine whether the Texan eventually makes a run for the White House.

title: Strong Start In Slims for Sanchez Vicario
description: Buoyant even when confined to the baseline, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario is slowly learning how to be explosive from all sectors of the tennis court. She is as short and stocky as ever, but her bolder serve and cagey dashes netward have made her a bigger player, and with a combination of those new ingredients and her old, reliable groundstrokes, she snubbed Natalya Zvereva, 6-2, 7-5, last night as the $3 million Virginia Slims Championships opened at Madison Square Garden.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., a manufacturer of auto-exhaust and ride-control products, appointed V. William Hunt and Byron O. Pond executive vice presidents. * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, promoted Peter R. Dolan to senior vice president of marketing and sales in its products division. * Cushman & Wakefield Inc., a business real estate firm that is a subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group, New York, named Philip C. Iglehart senior vice president and Eastern regional director in its financial services group. * Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, Mich., appointed Murray L. Reichenstein vice president and controller. * Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, New York, a subsidiary of Seagram Company Ltd., Montreal, named Ronald C. Simpson vice president of quality assurance and scientific affairs. * Yellow Freight System Inc., Overland Park, Kan., a motor carrier unit of Yellow Freight System Inc. of Delaware, named Michael F. Bruns vice president of insurance and claims.

title: Survey Sees Recession
description: The majority of top economists in a monthly survey believe a recession will begin before the end of the year, but most predict it will be brief and relatively mild, a prominent economic newsletter reports.

title: Our Towns; Dear Grown-Ups: It's Our World. Take Care of It!
description: In September, Annette Berson told her third graders at Kennedy Elementary School about a recycling program run by Kroger, a supermarket chain in the Middle West. If you bring back your paper bags and use them for your next load of groceries, you get a 3-cent refund for each re-used bag.

title: HONG KONG CLASH OVER VIETNAMESE
description: A Supreme Court judge reprimanded the Hong Kong Government today for treating a group of Vietnamese refugees "as unwelcome nuisances and not human beings" as he ruled that they had been illegally detained for more than a year and ordered their release.

title: Rio Slum Children Find Death in 'City of God'
description: The sounds of children happily chasing a soccer ball came in an open window, but Maria Teresinha Justo's mind was on the street children who never made it to her drop-in center.

title: Chase Cutting Back Business in Spain
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation is cutting back its Spanish operations and discussions are under way with foreign and local banks to sell its retail and leasing operations, a spokesman for the New York-based banking company said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "A few years ago, the dollar was worth 10 francs, and now it's five, so things don't seem so expensive." -- Sylvain Macrez, a tourist visiting New York from Lille, France. [ A1:1. ]

title: Cellular Offer By U S West
description: U S West Inc. yesterday offered to buy the 19 percent of its cellular telephone subsidiary that the regional Bell company does not already own.

title: MGM-Pathe In French Deal
description: The MGM-Pathe Communications Company said Friday that it had agreed to sell the French-language rights to the MGM film library to United Communication S.A., a European television-programming distributor. A spokeswoman for United said the price would be nearly $100 million.

title: New York City Faulted for Use Of River Water
description: A Federal judge has found that New York City violated the Federal Clean Water Act when it pumped Hudson River water through the Chelsea pumping station during the 1985 drought and discharged pollutants into a nearby reservoir without obtaining permits.

title: Goldman Lifts Bonuses For Staff Below Partner
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company told its work force yesterday that the firm was slightly increasing annual percentage bonuses for 1990 for all employees below the partner level, but cautioned that future compensation might not be as generous.

title: U.S. Treasury Securities Up Abroad
description: Prospects of a further easing in monetary policy by the Federal Reserve Board pushed prices of Treasury securities higher yesterday in Europe.

title: Fire Contained at Tire Dump
description: Using bulldozers and loads of sand, more than 300 firefighters battled a blaze at a tire dump for 10 hours before containing it early today. The blaze, which began among more than 25,000 tires on Sunday near the Pinelands, was contained about 3 A.M. today. The cause was still being investigated. Small mounds of tires continued to smolder late today as crews buried piles of tires under soft sand. Scores of nearby trees were scorched by the fire, the second at the site in recent years.

title: Lincoln Foodservice Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter reflected one-time costs associated with the special committee study of alternatives to enhance Lincoln's stock value. Those costs amounted to 2 cents a share after taxes. Earnings for the year-to-date reflected costs of the study and a writeoff taken during the second quarter of Lincoln's investment in Bay-Lea Industries Ltd., which amounted to 10 cents a share after taxes.

title: Orange Bowl Will Decide Who Gets No. 1 Rating
description: The Associated Press poll of writers and broadcasters and the United Press International poll of coaches agreed yesterday that the New Year's night game in the Orange Bowl between Notre Dame and Colorado would be between the No. 1 and No. 2 teams.

title: Nynex Unit's Proposal Loses
description: The New York State Public Service Commission has rejected the New York Telephone Company's proposal for a new system of incentive-based regulation and ended its formal review of the subject.

title: No Sponsor for Event
description: Furniture City Classic, sponsors of a Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament in High Point, N.C., for the last 10 years, announced yesterday that it could not find a sponsor for the 1991 tournament.

title: Teachers and Principal Begin Sharing Power, but Gingerly
description: At Public School 192 on Harlem's western edge, there are moments when the teachers and the principal are not sure who is in charge.

title: Healy Gets Honor
description: The Islander goaltender Glenn Healy, who had a 2.33 goals-against average and three victories in three games, was named the National Hockey League player of the week yesterday. (AP)

title: Teachers Relish New Lessons at Prague School
description: The same teachers who were there before last year's revolution are still teaching at Ludvik Svoboda Basic School on Freedom Square, and only the former principal and deputy principal have been demoted back into the classroom, with the administration turned over to new people.

title: You'll Never Have to Reset a Clock Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Figures Add Up Right for Rangers
description: Roger Neilson sat at his office desk yesterday and pored over the computer printout of National Hockey League statistics, digesting each of its 28 pages of production reports and defensive evaluations and quietly computing the significance of every impressive number and each tiny decimal point.

title: Normans Plans to Play
description: Greg Norman suffers pain during every tournament because of an incurable wrist injury but he has no intention of giving up the game, his agent said yesterday. Norman tore ligaments and cartilage in his left wrist several years ago playing Australian Rules Football and aggravated the injury during the 1988 United States Open at Brookline, Mass., when he hit a rock with his club. He had to take a two-month break to recuperate.

title: Plant Lovers' Ambitious Goal Is No More Extinctions
description: THE Malheur wire lettuce, an unprepossessing but rare plant that grows only in hot, dry central Oregon, appeared to have lost its struggle for survival.

title: Dillard Department Stores Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 3
Banner Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 10,141,000 which reflects a provision for loss on the disposal of discontinued operations, and an extraordinary credit of $ 1,025,000, or 6 cents a share.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 460,000.Latest income from continuing operations of $ 29,270,000, or $ 1.71 a share, included a nonrecurring, pretax gain of $ 54,550,000 from the public offering of 52.8 percent of Banner's holdings in Banner aerospace.

title: Wife, Tracking Her Husband, Is Slain at the Wrong House
description: A wife who tracked her husband to what she thought was a rendezvous with another woman was slain when she broke into the wrong house, officials said today.

title: Letter From North Pole Arrives 32 Years Later
description: A letter sent by a sailor on the first submarine to pass under the North Pole arrived at his brother's home last week, 32 years after the voyage.

title: Good Guys Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Paying Attention to Pelvic Infection in Women; Breast Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL WASHINGTON (NBA) -- Signed Ledell Eackles, guard, to a two-year contract. FOOTBALL NEW ENGLAND (AFC) -- Released David Douglas, offensive lineman, from injured reserve.

title: Clayton Out for a Month With an Injured Knee
description: Mark Clayton's injury-plagued season took another painful turn yesterday with the announcement that the Miami receiver would be sidelined at least a month because of a bad knee. Clayton tore the medial collateral ligament of his right knee in a victory Sunday over the Jets.

title: Earl A. Verpillot, 90, Engineering Executive
description: Earl A. Verpillot, a former executive vice president of the Wigton-Abbott Corporation, an architectural, engineering and construction concern. died on Saturday at his home in the Rossmoor retirement community in Jamesburg, N.J. He was 90 years old.

title: Eagles Defense Finally Enters Picture
description: In recent years, the Philadelphia Eagles made their mark under Coach Buddy Ryan with a robust, free-wheeling and ball-hawking defense that scored touchdowns as easily and as frequently as some of pro football's fanciest offenses. But after struggling to a 1-3 start and a 4-4 record this fall, the Eagles entered their game with the Washington Redskins tonight with no touchdowns produced by their defense and none by their special teams.

title: Stress Forces Whistleblower To Retire From the Schools
description: Colman Genn, a hero last year for exposing corruption in New York City schools, is prematurely ending his 30-year career with the school system because of exhaustion, stress and fear -- the repercussions of being a whistleblower.

title: Christo's Intercontinental Umbrella Project
description: The artist Christo is sometimes asked nowadays whether the Japanese or the Americans are better at comprehending his latest project: he intends to plant a forest of 1,340 blue umbrellas in the rice paddies near Tokyo and 1,760 yellow ones along the tawny open hillsides of California.

title: Kentucky Central Life Insurance Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article on the Consumer's World page on Saturday about outdoor wear misidentified the maker of Ultrex, a treated fabric. It is Burlington Industries, not the Du Pont Company.

title: Accounts
description: * Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Inc., Lyndhurst, N.J., to Mullen of Wenham, Mass., with a budget of $5 million. * Budget Rent a Car Corp., Chicago, to W. B. Doner, Baltimore, with undisclosed billings.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Victory for King's Swan

title: March Of the Engineers
description: The company is putting in a new phone system. It's so complicated everybody has to take lessons in how to use it. Nobody knows what happens to people who flunk. This is why I've been putting it off. It would be humiliating, having to go to summer school to make up a failure in Telephone.

title: Thoughts Of 16-0 On Giants' Minds
description: Finally, the "U" word has become part of Bill Parcells's vocabulary.

title: Paying Attention to Pelvic Infection in Women; Obstetrics Liability
description: To the Editor:

title: Lotas Minard Swaps Work for Equity Stake
description: A New York agency has decided to swap its marketing expertise for a minority share of a company that could afford to pay little. Lotas Minard Patton McIver, a New York agency, has taken on Brooklyn Brewery, a small company with roots in a Brooklyn brownstone, for an interest in the company.

title: Eli Louis Rousso, 70, Chairman of Russ Togs
description: Eli Louis Rousso, a leader in the apparel industry for more than 40 years, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and had homes in Manhattan, Hewlett, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Jets' Lack of Offense Has Become a Collective Effort
description: When the new Jets' regime hired away the Cincinnati Bengals' offensive coordinator in February and put him in charge of rebuilding the entire team, the expectation was that Bruce Coslet would at least make the Jets' offense lively, exciting and productive.

title: Bow Valley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Topics of The Times; The First Day of What?
description: Yesterday, just a week after the end of summer and fully six weeks before The Day, a New Yorker in search of shampoo entered a discount variety store and found -- Christmas. Counters full of Christmas.

title: Workers vs. The Daily News: The Issues and the Prospects
description: Nineteen days after a bitter strike began at The Daily News, the struggle between management and the newspaper's nine striking unions remains centered in the streets, not at the bargaining table.

title: New Publishing Star, Sonny Mehta, Talks Profits as Well as Art
description: Through all the considerable upheaval at Random House over the last year, one man's star has continued to rise, to the point where some say he has now become the power behind the throne at America's largest trade publishing company.

title: Texas School Panel Approves Textbooks Teaching Evolution
description: The State Board of Education has approved science textbooks that teach evolution, despite objections from those who say alternative views get short shrift.

title: Nets Unable To Contain Bullets' King
description: Too much Bernard King, too many missed shots and what their coach saw as a shoddy attitude were the elements that buried the Nets tonight in a 97-92 loss to the Washington Bullets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Article 522090 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Steelmakers Try To Defend Prices
description: WHEN the Bethlehem Steel Corporation said last week that it had decided to cut its 8 percent price increase for steel shipments by half after Dec. 30, the nation's second-largest steelmaker sought to put the best face on a troubling matter. The company noted that the move still offers a price increase that it says it desperately needs. But industry analysts, who say the the steel industry needs somewhat higher prices, contend that by cutting the price increase to 4 percent, Bethlehem's retreat underscores the underlying weakness in the steel business that companies will have to contend with for some time.

title: F.B.I. Investigates Groups of Zealots Who Praise Kahane Slaying
description: The Federal Bureu of Investigation is scrambling to investigate the Muslim groups associated with the Masjid al-Salam mosque in Jersey City, where El Sayyid A. Nosair, the man accused of killing Rabbi Meir Kahane, worshiped, according to high-level law-enforcement officials.

title: Review/Television; Even 'Smart Weapons' Need a Human Touch
description: "Killing Machines," tonight's report on "Nova," targets some of the weapons that American troops in the Middle East will rely on if they are ordered into battle. Known in the trade as "smart weapons," they use electronic sensors and computer brains to do the job of destruction faster and more accurately than conventional guns and bombs. Most have never been tried on the battlefield.

title: Topics of The Times; Wanted: Zeus at the Plate
description: "Moody." "Sulking." "Streaky." "Not a money player." These arrows bristle from Darryl Strawberry's back as he leaves the New York Mets for Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles. But only one word fully explains why so many New Yorkers felt aggrieved by him while he was here. That word is "mortal."

title: Needham Fills Post
description: Women have been regularly gaining power in advertising, and DDB Needham provides the latest example. Susan Gillette has been named president of the Chicago office, replacing Joel Hochberg, who is leaving to become president of marketing at 20th Century Fox. "Susan Gillette is one of our industry's most dynamic and talented leaders," said Keith Reinhard, chairman and chief executive of DDB Needham Worldwide. "Her appointment reflects our commitment to carry on the traditions of growth and excellence."

title: Efficiency of Snakes
description: Until recently many zoologists believed that snakes were more efficient in their use of locomotive energy than other animals. But by putting snakes through their paces on a laboratory treadmill, investigators at the University of California at Irvine have disproved that assumption.

title: Delivery of Oil Products Off
description: Deliveries of oil products dropped 4.9 percent in October, the American Petroleum Institute said today, although deliveries of kerosene jet fuel rose 9.5 percent.

title: Donohue Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Medusa Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hold Your Breath, It's France's Scariest Job
description: The light-fingered man in the blue flannel jumpsuit hopped astride the rusting American-made bomb, poked at the hot-wired fuse and said with a grin, "Well, we'll just have to blow it up here."

title: Pan Am's Fight to Survive on Its Own
description: The Pan Am Corporation has sold off its Park Avenue headquarters building, its Inter-Continental Hotel chain, its routes across the Pacific and now, in a deal on which final agreement could be reached tomorrow, its routes between New York and London. But despite years of trying, the company that used to symbolize the prestige of aviation has never succeeded in selling off itself.

title: Chess
description: The late Paul Keres used to scoff at grandmasters who denied that they were professionals. He did not care what other profession they might also be pursuing. He simply stamped the man, "chessplayer." He especially did not like his defeated opponents to give the excuse that they could have played better, had it not been for the demands of their "real" profession.

title: East Europe's Cultural Life, Once a Refuge, Now Eclipsed
description: In Prague, theaters reported a sharp drop in attendance. In Budapest, no new feature films went into production for the first half of this year. Here in the Romanian capital, fewer books were published this year than in any year of the Communist dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: Illness Leads to Switch At Panhandle Eastern
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation, which operates one of the nation's largest natural gas pipeline systems, said yesterday that its chairman, president and chief executive, Philip J. Burguieres, had resigned for health reasons and been succeeded by Dennis R. Hendrix.

title: Chronicle
description: A new entertainment complex where the people of Hollywood can work, eat and play has been conceived by KEITH BARISH, who directed "Ironweed" and "Sophie's Choice," among other movies. The complex is to open next summer -- in Manhattan.

title: Girl Killed by Tractor-Trailer
description: A 15-year-old girl was killed today by a tractor-trailer in Carle Place, the Nassau County police said. Jennifer Manivesa of Mineola was walking north on Cherry Lane across Westbury Avenue at 4:45 P.M. when she was hit by the truck, Officer Andy DeSimone said. She was taken to Nassau County Medical Center where she died shortly before 6 P.M., Officer DeSimone said. The driver of the truck, Thomas Cavaluzzi, 29, of Bay Shore, was not injured. No charges were filed.

title: No Japanese Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Press Is Clouded By Dread of the '97 Takeover
description: These days journalists here have a special kind of deadline in mind that affects their work: July 1, 1997, when this British territory is returned to China.

title: Israel Promotes the Police Official In Charge of Operation at Al Aksa
description: The Israeli police announced tonight that the officer in charge of the Jerusalem police district, who was severely criticized by the Government commission that investigated the killings at Al Aksa Mosque a month ago, would be promoted.

title: A Cosmos Reunion
description: Eddie Firmani, the former coach of the Cosmos, arrived in Rome yesterday after his release by the Iraqis on Sunday and will have a Cosmos reunion of sorts and a job offer in the next day or two.

title: Wallace Son to Quit Politics
description: State Treasurer George Wallace Jr., whose father served four terms as Governor of Alabama and twice sought the Presidency, announced Monday that he would retire from politics when his second term as Treasurer ends in four years.

title: Applied Biosystems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Net incomeThe company said the latest quarter loss included a charge of $ 5 million related to the relocation of its Ramsey, N.J., operations to San Jose, Calif.

title: United Gaming reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeResults for 1990 included a pretax, non-recurring charge of $ 12,816,000 which substantially completes a financial reorganization begun in September.

title: Prison Nurse Charged In Death by Morphine
description: A nurse who worked at the Somers state prison has been charged with criminally negligent homicide after being accused of injecting a dying inmate with a fatal dose of morphine, the state police said.

title: Woman, 69, May Face Execution in 5 Killings
description: A 69-year-old woman convicted of killing five transients, should be sentenced to death, a prosecutor argued in court today, but her lawyer said she was a battered wife who deserved a new trial.

title: Tyson Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Sale by P.&G.
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said William B. Reilly & Company had bought Caliente Chili Inc., an Austin, Tex., subsidiary that P.& G. obtained in its merger with the Noxell Corporation last year. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. P.& G. said Caliente, which makes chili and Mexican food products, does not fit into its food businesses.

title: What Cinderella Might Wear to a 90's Ball
description: Many evening clothes have changed less in the past century than almost any article of apparel except perhaps men's cravats. A woman who would have been appropriately dressed for a turn-of-the-century salon would probably not cause heads to turn at a major charity ball today. While the rigidity and the number of the underpinnings have been reduced over the years, the outward effect has remained pretty much the same.

title: Lebanese Split on Potential for Peace
description: This country long riven by factional and sectarian strife is now torn between hope and pessimism as militia fighters withdraw from the capital and the Government moves ahead with a plan to restore peace.

title: Chronicle
description: SARGENT SHRIVER celebrated his 75th birthday on Saturday with his family, friends and about 1,500 others at a charity ball in Washington for Best Buddies of America, founded in 1987 by ANTHONY K. SHRIVER, his son. Shriver pere is the chairman of the organization, which gets college students together with mentally disabled people in 66 cities.

title: Books of The Times;   Proust's Life and Art, A Truly Proustian Mix
description: Proust

title: What Dr. King Wrote, and What He Did
description: To millions of admirers around the world, the disclosures about Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his doctoral dissertation cast a shadow on his memory; a shadow should not, however, be confused with a cloud.

title: Advest Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Knicks Finding Unity On Visit Out West
description: When the Knicks left practice at Loyola Marymount University today, their attitude was as sunny as the Southern California weather.

title: F.C.C. Cites Phone Violation
description: The Federal Communications Commission said last Friday that four telephone companies had engaged in "manipulative and erroneous" accounting practices during 1988 and that it intended to fine them a total of $1 million.

title: Syphilis Fools a New Generation
description: SYPHILIS, which is known as the great imitator because it mimics so many other diseases, is making its strongest comeback in 40 years in the United States. And it is fooling a generation of doctors who have rarely, if ever, seen a case.

title: France Yields to a Huge Student Protest
description: Bending to pressure from a student protest movement that put more than 100,000 demonstrators onto the streets of Paris today, the French Government announced an "emergency plan" to improve conditions in the country's 4,700 senior high schools.

title: Eve Arden, Actress, Is Dead at 83; Starred in TV's 'Our Miss Brooks'
description: Eve Arden, the caustic comedienne featured in dozens of films as a heroine's wry and wisecracking best friend, a warmhearted but sassy schoolteacher or secretary, died yesterday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: After the Cold War: Frozen Chaos?
description: Food. Fuel for heat. Pharmaceuticals. Boots. Winter winds have just started blowing across the steppes but some necessities are already in short supply in Soviet cities. Unless the Soviet people get help from abroad, they could take to the streets of Moscow, Leningrad and Sverdlovsk in protest.

title: Creating Scholarly Book Lists In a Hurry
description: FOR students and others who must keep track of printed material and make bibliographies, RefBase could be a godsend. It is a database manager for the Apple Macintosh, running under HyperCard, the program that comes with all Macs.

title: MIDEAST TENSIONS: Washington Talk; War, Class Divisions And Burden of Service
description: "What Did You Do in the Class War, Daddy?" asked the headline of a 1975 article in The Washington Monthly.

title: Murder Case In Community Of Families
description: A Brooklyn woman with a history of violence against her children was arrested and charged yesterday with the murder of her 8-year-old son in a case that revealed what one public official called a little-known problem: child abuse in the family-oriented, tightly knit Orthodox Jewish community.

title: Encinitas Journal; Accident of Geography Prompts Local Protest
description: The bill to the Fed eral Government, for $225,356.20, covers items like the policing of migrants' campsites and the establishment of a hiring hall for day laborers. But as much as anything it is a cry of protest over an undeniable fact of geography.

title: Rig Count Dips in Week
description: The number of working rigs in the United States dropped by 20 last week, to a total of 1,124, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The decline, attributed partly to bad weather, followed several weeks of increases that had taken the total to its highest level since Dec. 28, 1987. The count a year ago was 1,045, the Houston-based tool maker said. The count represents the number of rigs exploring for oil.

title: Weiss, Whitten Is Putting A Sense of Humor to Work
description: WEISS, WHITTEN's letterhead says it all: Instead of the typical corporate logo, it has a picture of a bagel and a slice of white bread.

title: Review/Music; An Evening of Arias At Richard Tucker Gala
description: Since Richard Tucker's death in 1975, the great American tenor's memory has been kept alive not only by his many recordings, but also by the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, which supports the careers of young singers through a series of awards and career grants. Every year the foundation presents its winners, along with some of their more firmly established colleagues, in a gala concert.

title: Prosecution Seen As Unlikely In 228 Rape Cases in Oakland
description: Prosecution of 228 rape cases that were reopened for investigation is unlikely because the women who said they were assaulted have been difficult to find or are unwilling to cooperate, the police say.

title: Big-City Mayors Focus On Problems and Goals
description: Joined by his counterparts from nearly three dozen big cities around the nation, Mayor David N. Dinkins played host yesterday to an "urban summit" in which they conferred, conversed and otherwise hobnobbed on how best to make their cities' case to Washington and the world.

title: After Years at the Top, Jordan Is No. 5 Scorer
description: In the 39 years since the introduction of the 24-second clock, only one team has won the National Basketball Association championship when one of its players was the league's scoring leader. That was in 1971, when Kareem Abdul-Jabbar averaged 31.7 points a game and the Milwaukee Bucks won the title.

title: Pregnancy Problems Linked to Hormone
description: ABNORMALLY high amounts of a hormone in the first phase of the menstrual cycle have been linked to infertility and miscarriages in a British study of nearly 200 women.

title: ABC Cancels 'Cop Rock'
description: "Cop Rock," the new television series that dropped pop songs into a gritty police drama, has been canceled, Robert A. Iger, the president of ABC 's entertainment division, announced yesterday. The show, which had its premiere on Sept. 26, failed to generate an audience despite the tempered enthusiasm of critics.

title: Apple Shifts President's Title
description: Michael H. Spindler, Apple Computer Inc.'s chief operating officer, has been named president. The appointment does not involve any changes in responsibilities but endorses Mr. Spindler's leadership role,

title: Bertelsmann Wins MCA
description: MCA Inc. said today that its music unit would shift its $100 million overseas distribution business from Time Warner Inc. to the Bertelsmann Music Group of Germany.

title: Amid Talk of Layoffs and Cuts, Sanitation Workers Stage Unauthorized Slowdown
description: New York City's unionized sanitation workers are engaged in a job slowdown in sections of Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn, the Sanitation Department said yesterday.

title: On Quake Fear, Business Bonanza in the Midwest
description: The Middle West is thinking about earthquakes. Survival kits are turning up on store shelves and companies are selling anti-shatter window film, portable chemical toilets and other emergency gear.

title: Exxon to Trim Alaska Cleanup
description: The president of the Exxon Company U.S.A., the domestic operating unit of the Exxon Corporation, said today that his company would go back to Alaska next spring to inspect the oil remaining on beaches from the spill from the tanker Exxon Valdez in March 1989, but that the cleanup effort in 1991 would be very small.

title: Titan Rocket, With Secret Cargo, Lifts Off
description: A Titan 4 rocket, the nation's most powerful unmanned rocket, roared into space with a secret military cargo today after a delay of nearly two months.

title: Holnam Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe 1989 results do not reflect the acquisition of Northwestern States Portland Cement Co. on Jan. 19, the March 8, acquisition of the minority interests of Ideal Basic Industries, nor the acquisition of United Cement Co. on Aug. 28. The effect of these transactions is reflected in 1990 beginning at their respective dates of acquisition.

title: Ex-Mayor of Chicago Says She'll Run Again
description: Former Mayor Jane Byrne, who has lost in her last two attempts to regain thepost, said Monday that she would run again next year, becoming the first announced candidate for mayor.

title: Connecticut Officials Question Bridge Study
description: State transportation officials are questioning a new report that says almost two-thirds of the state's bridges are deficient.

title: An Empty Patch in Right Field
description: Outside, just beyond Frank Cashen's office on the field level of Shea Stadium, at around 10 A.M. yesterday, the ball field, still looking green and ready in case a game broke out later in the day, was bathed in sunlight, except for right field. Right field was in shadows. The old Strawberry patch. A section of turf where Darryl Eugene Strawberry, the longtime proprietor, the Straw Man, would no longer roam, or at least linger, for the Mets.

title: Too Early for Bush to Dial 911
description: President Bush keeps saying he is "running out of patience" with Saddam Hussein, who is, he insists, "worse than Hitler." In the process, he is helping create a feeling in the country that war is inevitable. It's easy to understand his frustration, but history hasn't been very kind to impatient warriors.

title: Paying Attention to Pelvic Infection in Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Moon Rings

title: Madison Gas & Electric Co. reports earnings for 12mos to Sept 30
FREE-TRADE TALKS IMPERILED BY FIGHT ON FARM SUBSIDIES
description: Talks to liberalize world trade were threatened with collapse today in an impasse over the subsidies that the European Community gives its farmers.

title: Europeans Ask North Africa Aid on Hostages
description: The foreign ministers of the European Community asked their counterparts in the Muslim countries of North Africa today to help win the release of the thousands of hostages held by Iraq.

title: By Design; Colors That Flash and Flatter
description: Color is one fashion message that has certainly got through to women this fall. Everywhere you look, the eye catches a flash of some strong shade like orange, apricot, acid green, deep blue, hot pink, yellow, lacquer red or deep purple.

title: Man in The News;   India's Freewheeling Leader: Chandra Shekhar
description: Chandra Shekhar, the perennial outsider who made a career of bucking the system until he became India's eighth Prime Minister on Saturday, spent the weekend learning to part with his life of restless informality, a friend of 30 years said today.

title: Talking Business with Ricke of Deutsche Bundespost; German Defense On Phone Fees
description: Helmut F. Ricke is chairman of Deutsche Bundespost Telekom, the state-owned company that provides all local, long-distance, international and cellular telephone service in Germany, and subsidizes postal service. The company has been a target of a four-month-old plan by Alfred C. Sikes, the chairman of the United States Federal Communications Commission, to drive down the fees that foreign monopolies charge to American phone companies for completing calls placed from the United States. Deutsche Bundespost announced on Oct. 29 that it would cut these fees, known as accounting rates, by 17 percent on April 1. Mr. Ricke discussed the company's position during a recent visit to New York.

title: APPLE SCARE OF '89 DIDN'T KILL MARKET
description: Almost two years ago, publicity about health risks from the chemical Alar caused a sharp drop in apple sales and growers feared that many Americans would drop apples from their daily diet. But consumers are now eating as many apples as before and the industry is just as profitable.

title: Coalition Struggles to Raise Funds to Save Freedom Bank
description: A coalition of community leaders scrambled yesterday to raise $6 million to save Freedom National Bank in Harlem, which was closed on Friday by Federal regulators.

title: Debate on Persian Gulf Enlivens Bishops' Meeting
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, gathered here for their fall meeting, strongly backed an appeal today for American restraint in the Persian Gulf.

title: New York City Gains As Low Dollar Lures The Foreign Tourist
description: Guests at the Ritz-Carlton, one of New York City's more traditional hotels, can have bacon and eggs for breakfast in the Jockey Club restaurant for $14.50. Or they can have miso soup, grilled fish and rice for $18.

title: Chip Indicator Is Unchanged
description: Orders for computer chips rose slightly in the United States while shipments declined in October, but the semiconductor industry's leading indicator remained unchanged from September, a trade group reported today.

title: Icahn Expects Pan Am To Falter in Route Sale
description: Carl C. Icahn is betting that the Pan Am Corporation's agreement to sell its New York-to-London routes to United Airlines will not go through.

title: Alexis Minotis Dies; A Greek Actor, 90, Who Staged Classics
description: Alexis Minotis, the dean of Greek tragic actors, who was a longtime pillar and director of the Greek National Theater, died Sunday in the Red Cross Hospital in Athens. He was 90 years old and lived in Athens.

title: Visitors for Enthronement Press Japan for Support
description: After a day of celebration for the enthronement of Emperor Akihito, diplomats and representatives from 158 countries plunged into another round of parties and diplomatic activities today, including discussions with Japan seeking economic aid for their countries.

title: Beijing Journal; Little Whispers, the Big Lie and China's Future
description: For Americans, the campaigning and the mud-slinging are over for a while. For Chinese, they never end.

title: Fairfax Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said gains on the sale of portfolio securities in the third quarter were $ 5.2 million, compared with $ 4.7 million, in year-ago period.Share earnings are fully diluted.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Some Advice To the Jobless On Wall St.
description: AS waves of dismissals continue on Wall Street, out-of-work analysts, brokers and investment bankers should expect keener competition as they seek new jobs, says Jan A. Cris of the Cris Group, a management recruiting firm.

title: Near-Polar Finds Offer New Look at Dinosaurs
description: DISCOVERIES of dinosaur and plant remains in near-polar latitudes are revolutionizing concepts of how dinosaurs lived toward the end of their reign, 65 million to 100 million years ago.

title: Rally's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRETORIA RETREATS ON PRIVATIZATION
description: Under pressure from anti-apartheid organizations, the South African Government has in recent months all but suspended two-year-old plans to sell state corporations and other public enterprises.

title: Southern Indiana G&E reports earnings for 12mos to Sept 30
Son's Killing Leaves Family An Angry, Painful Legacy
description: On Thursday, Kimson Russell was supposed to celebrate his 17th birthday. His unemployed mother had even scratched together enough money to buy him a much wanted new coat with the Los Angeles Raiders football team logo stitched across the back.

title: On 4th Try, a Victory for Ex-Governor of Alaska
description: Former Gov. Walter J. Hickel succeeded in winning back the governorship in a way few but himself thought he would.

title: ILC Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 325,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 393,000, or 17 cents a share, for the year.c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $ 1,172,000 for the quarter and $ 3,039,000 for the year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Helping Women Abroad Get Started in Business
description: Women's World Banking, an unusual global group that helps women get started in business, has a new president, Nancy Barry.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-17

title: Review/Blues; Ray Charles and B.B. King at the Apollo
description: The high point of Saturday night's show at the Apollo Theater, featuring B. B. King and Ray Charles, came at a predictable point: Mr. Charles crept through a set of his standards, whispering and moaning and caressing the words, imbuing them with a sense of loss and longing that had the hall stone quiet.

title: When to Threaten Iraq?
description: To critics who ask why the United States should not wait a year or more to see if economic sanctions force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, Administration officials say they have valid reasons for threatening a war this winter.

title: Paley Recalled as the Man Who Made a Network
description: William S. Paley, the chairman of CBS Inc. who died Oct. 26, was praised yesterday as the man who had more impact on the delivery of news and entertainment than any other person in this century.

title: At the Brink of Death
description: PEOPLE who nearly die and people who merely think they are about to die experience strikingly similar sensations, including a feeling of well-being and clarity of mind, researchers have found.

title: Bridge
description: An exact tie in a major pairs event scored by imps is very rare. It happened on Sunday in the Ogust-Schenken Pairs at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan. A strong field of 28 pairs included many with international reputations.

title: Patterns
description: But Is It a Business?

title: Correction
description: The Social Events column on Sunday gave an incorrect address for the annual benefit of the junior committee of the Alzheimer's Association, to be held tomorrow at 7 P.M. It will be at the Grolier Club, 29 East 32d Street. Information: (212) 983-0700.

title: Antibodies May Set Off Clogging Of Arteries
description: The body's defenses against disease can go awry and attack proteins that carry cholesterol through the body, triggering a buildup of the artery-clogging deposits that lead to heart attacks, researchers said today.

title: Monkey Fossils Reveal a Species
description: IN the first large-scale research conducted by Americans in Cuba in nearly 40 years, paleontologists have found fossils of a previously unknown extinct species of monkey.

title: People
description: * Laurie Irwin and Jan Johnson have been named vice presidents of J. Walter Thompson, Chicago. * Gary Andrews has joined Grey Advertising, New York, as senior vice president and management representative, and Karen Harris has become senior vice president and media director. Alan Braunstein has joined as vice president and associate creative director. * Stephanie George has been appointed advertising director of W Magazine, a Fairchild publication.

title: Bazaar of Technology
description: Smaller, faster, more powerful, less expensive and more overwhelming: these are the words that best describe the products on display here at the annual personal computer trade exposition called Comdex, a high-tech bazaar where an estimated 120,000 computer buyers and sellers are meeting this week. It is a veritable wonderland of whirring, beeping technology.

title: London Betting on Itself And on Canary Wharf
description: When Olympia & York Developments Ltd. decided in 1987 to undertake Canary Wharf, the biggest real estate development project in Europe, Paul Reichmann, the president of the family-owned company, said he was prepared to live through at least two downturns in the real estate market here.

title: Brascan Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New Boeing Order
description: Egypt Air has ordered five Boeing 737-500's worth about $150 million, the Boeing Company said. Egypt Air said it would use the planes on domestic and European flights. The twin-engine jets seat 108 to 132 passengers and have a range of 3,340 miles.

title: Shadow of Terror, Hope for Peace
description: "I understand why 'they' do it," a friend wrote me from Jerusalem, "and I suppose I understand why 'we' do it. And there is nothing left for me to do." An American by birth, she and her Israeli husband have been active in the peace movement for 20 years. She had spent a Saturday afternoon protesting the killing of 19 Palestinians by Israeli police on the Temple Mount. That Sunday morning an Arab youth knifed three Israelis to death blocks from her home. She confessed, "I feel a terror such as I've never known before."

title: At Surgery's Frontier: Suspended Animation
description: THE operating room at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center was alive with the sounds and lights of high-technology medical equipment.

title: FAVORITISM FOUND IN SAVINGS CASES
description: Senior officials in Washington knew as long ago as 1988 that preferential treatment was being given to some troubled savings and loans whose senior executives also served on Government regulatory boards, newly disclosed documents show.

title: Yeltsin Wants Economic Pact Before Union Treaty
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, negotiating anew with his chief adversary, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, said today that he was rebuffing Kremlin attempts to engineer a new union treaty before settling such critical issues as control over petroleum, diamonds, banking and other economic resources.

title: Job Fair Is Bleak Portrait of Economic Mood
description: Armed with resumes, years of experience and tenuous hopes for employment, thousands of people stood for three hours or more yesterday, waiting to enter a job fair and gain the attention of receptive industry recruiters.

title: Undersea Robots Open a New Age Of Exploration
description: A NUMBER of small technical advances in devising undersea robots have combined to make vast reaches of the ocean floor accessible to exploration for the first time. The gains have enabled salvagers to locate and recover a fascinating array of material and treasure from sunken ships, planes, missiles, submarines and other artifacts lost at sea over the ages.

title: Northwest Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Miscellany
description: * FCB/Telecom, the television programming division of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., and Channel America, are establishing a programming collaborative for designing new projects and overseeing programming activities. Terms were undisclosed.

title: Angola Says Rebels Can Help Write Constitution
description: In perhaps his most ambitious attempt to end the war against his Soviet-backed Government, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos has offered guerrilla leaders a chance to help draft a new constitution for Angola.

title: Oil Industry Shows Caution In Spending Sudden Profits
description: The American oil industry's response to the surge in oil prices in recent months is to sit tight and hope prices do not crash after the crisis in the Persian Gulf ends.

title: Saudi Women Disciplined
description: At least 6 of the 50 Saudi women who took to the road to protest Saudi Arabia's enforcement of customs that prohibit women from driving have been suspended from their jobs, Saudi academics said today.

title: Culbro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Reflects a $ 1 million gain from the sale of excess warehouse facilities recorded in the third quarter of 1990.c-Net lossd-Reflects $ 4 million restructuring charges recorded in the third quarter of 1989.

title: Dow Soars; Cut by Fed Is Expected
description: A relaxation of war nerves coupled with expectations that a reduction in interest rates could come as quickly as today or tomorrow helped push stock prices sharply higher yesterday for the second straight session.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arkla Inc., Shreveport, La., a natural gas company, and Diversified Energies Inc., Minneapolis, said the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission would reconsider last Friday's vote against the proposed merger of Minnegasco, Diversified's natural gas distribution company, into Arkla. * BET Industries, London, an industrial services, transportation and leisure company, said it was trying to sell its 20 percent stake in Thames Television P.L.C. by the end of the year. * Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, and Amersham International, a British health-care company, have formed a jointly owned clinical diagnostics company to be called Amerlite Diagnostics Ltd. * Freeport-McMoran Oil and Gas Co. said holders of about 90 percent of its common stock approved the proposed merger of the company into Freeport-McMoran Inc., New Orleans, a minerals and energy company. * Genex Corp., Gaithersburg, Md., a biochemical, engineering and pharmaceuticals company, will cut its staff to about 28 employees from 65 beginning this week and continuing over the next several months. * Newmont Australia Ltd., a mining company, will acquire 54.9 percent of BHP Gold Ltd. of Australia in a stock swap that will form Australia's largest gold producer. * Trustco Bank Corp. N.Y., Schenectady, N.Y., and the National Savings Bank of Albany have terminated discussions of a possible business combination. * Volvo A.B., the Swedish auto maker, said it would investigate its television advertisement that erroneously showed a Volvo withstanding the attempts of a "monster truck" to crush it.

title: Article 271090 -- No Title
description: Renoir's "Cup of Chocolate," from 1878, was sold last night for $18.2 million -- the highest price in Sotheby's auction of artworks from the family and the estate of Henry Ford 2d. The sale brought many disappointments for the auction house: of the 36 works offered, 23 were sold for a total of $48.6 million, well below Sotheby's presale estimate of $66 million to $85.8 million.

title: Key Rates
Advanced Micro's Bid to Break Monopoly
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. raised the stakes today in its attempt to break the Intel Corporation's monopoly on one of the most popular microprocessors used in personal computers, showig off a chip that appears to match the functions of Intel's 80386DX microprocessor.

title: Chronicle
description: The tenor Richard Tucker, who died in 1975, is being remembered in an exhibition at La Scala in Milan, Italy, and RENATA TEBALDI , who frequently starred with him, will inaugurate it in April. Last month GIANPIERO TINTORI , La Scala's museum director, spent two weeks at the Metropolitan Opera, combing through Tucker memorabilia.

title: New Offer for Lockheed
description: Harold C. Simmons, the financier, renewed his interest in the Lockheed Corporation today by proposing that the company join him in offering investors $40 a share to take the company private.

title: No Wonder Fewer and Fewer Want to Accept Public Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Guatemalans Face a Divisive Runoff Election
description: A newspaper publisher and an evangelical Christian who caught the rising tide of national discontent appeared today to be headed into a runoff election that threatens to aggravate religious factionalism here, according to returns from the presidential election held Sunday.

title: The President's Mistake
description: President Bush made one profound mistake immediately after Iraq conquered Kuwait. Every day it becomes more important that he correct it before United States ground forces go into action against Saddam Hussein.

title: Hostage's Son Dies
description: Joseph Cicippio Jr., son of an American held hostage in Lebanon, died of a heart attack on Sunday, hospital officials said today. He was 35 years old. Joseph Cicippio Sr., a 60-year-old former resident of Norristown, was taken hostage in Beirut more than four years ago. His son became the third member of his family to die since he was taken into captivity. A sister, Rose Abell, 73, died of cancer months after his kidnapping. Her husband, Bill, 80, died of a heart attack last year.

title: Senate Democrats Expected to Elect Kentucky Lawmaker for No. 2 Post
description: Senate Democrats say they will elect Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky to replace Alan Cranston as Senate majority whip on Tuesday in leadership elections, as lesser-known lawmakers from both parties seek a bigger say over party policies and agenda.

title: Two Security Guards Found Slain in Queens
description: Two security guards for the Rochdale Village housing development in Queens were fatally shot last night in a hail of gunfire in the rear of a Chinese restaurant, the police said.

title: Chevron Turned Down On Tankers
description: County officials in Santa Barbara, Calif., voted today to deny permission to a consortium led by the Chevron Corporation to use tankers to ship oil from a large field off the Southern California coast to three Los Angeles area refineries.

title: Consortium To Buy Intel Computer
description: A consortium of 14 United States research institutions led by the California Institute of Technology is scheduled to announce today that it will purchase a custom-designed supercomputer from the Intel Corporation to help solve a series of scientific "grand challenges."

title: Ramsey Clark, on Iraq Visit, Meets With Saddam Hussein
description: Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark met here today with President Saddam Hussein, who told Mr. Clark that he hoped there would be no showdown with the United States, the official Iraqi News Agency said.

title: Lisa Kirk, Cabaret Performer, 62; Featured in Broadway Musicals
description: Lisa Kirk, a cabaret performer who won Broadway acclaim in the late 1940's singing "The Gentleman Is a Dope" in the musical "Allegro" and "Always True to You (In My Fashion)" in "Kiss Me, Kate," died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 62 years old and had homes in New York City and Malibu, Calif.

title: Pubco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings for the year-ago quarter are adjusted for the 1-for-20 reverse split of common and class B stock which occurred Aug. 14, 1990.

title: Review/Television; The Familiar Seasonal Glitter at Radio City
description: If you ever doubted that life in New York was on the fast track consider this: less than a week ago we were in the midst of Election Day and today we are already in full celebration of Christmas. Not all of us, of course, but certainly the people up at the Radio City Music Hall, where the venerable "Christmas Spectacular" has opened, just moments, it feels, after the mercury learned how to spell Jack Frost.

title: Jockeying Completed, Panel to begin Hearing on Senators Tied to S.&.L.
description: Five Senators are preparing to go before the Senate Ethics Committee for hearings beginning Thursday in which they will defend their reputations while offering the most detailed public glimpse of the political machinations behind the savings and loan debacle.

title: Northwest Air Net Falls 47%
description: Northwest Airlines said today that higher fuel costs associated with the Middle East crisis had caused a 47 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings and would result in a fourth-quarter loss.

title: INSIDE
description: Aligning Leadership For 102d Congress Much will be decided about the tone and temperament of the new Congress as members begin electing leaders today. Senate Democrats say they will elect Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky to replace Alan Cranston as majority whip. Page A18. Woman Held in Son's Death A Brooklyn woman was charged with killing her child, and her Orthodox Jewish community is confronting the issue of child abuse. Page B1. At Surgery's Frontier In a risky brain operation, surgeons put a man's body in suspended animation to work on a ballooned blood vessel. Science Times, page C1. India's New Leader Chandra Shekhar, a perennial outsider, made a career of bucking the system until he became India's Prime Minister. Man in the News, page A3.

title: Rash Censors in the Noriega Case
description: Manuel Noriega, the deposed Panama dictator who awaits a Federal trial on drug and money-laundering charges, has been overheard and tape-recorded talking with his legal advisers. That's cause for alarm, since the United States is pledged to try him fairly. But that's not what's bothering the courts. Oddly, Federal judges aren't so concerned with probing the potential invasion of the defendant's rights. Hastily, they assail Cable News Network for its reports that brought the problem to light in the first place. It's a textbook case of shooting the messenger.

title: S.& L. Shifts to Be Eased
description: The director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, Timothy Ryan, told industry executives today that his agency would make it easier to convert their institutions into commercial banks. The move could hasten the end of savings and loan associations as a separate financial industry. Mr. Ryan also said at the 98th annual convention of the United States League of Savings Institutions that he remained deeply troubled by savings and loan associations becoming state savings banks.

title: Interstate General L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: Air Force Base Is Firebombed
description: Investigators today ruled out terrorism in the firebombing early Sunday of two Government-owned cars and a building housing an Air Force investigation office. There was little damage, and no one was injured on the Air Force base adjoining the Army's Fort Lewis near Tacoma. The authorities said terrorism was not suspected because no note was left.

title: Judge in Eastern Case to Face Difficult Choices
description: Efforts by the judge overseeing the Eastern Airlines bankruptcy case to keep the carrier flying will be severely tested tomorrow. The airline's unsecured creditors, including airplane and engine makers, banks and unions, are losing patience and are resisting attempts by Eastern to tap anew into its cash reserves.

title: Oak Hill Sportswear Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net inome

title: CNN Won't Play Noriega Tapes Until Ruling
description: Cable News Network agreed today to play no more taped conversations between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and members of his defense team until the Supreme Court decides whether to hear the network's appeal of an order barring the televising.

title: Chronicle
description: The Sarasota French Film Festival will pay tribute to CATHERINE DENEUVE on Saturday by giving her a statue and a screening of "Frequence Meurtre," a movie she made two years ago that has not been seen in the United States. Coincidentally, it is based on a novel by STUART KAMINSKY, who heads the Asolo Film Conservatory at Florida State University in Sarasota.

title: Viatech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 53,000, or 4 cents a share.The company attributed its higher sales and earnings to its Ferembal unit, which it acquired in the fourth quarter of 1989.

title: Devils Rally Past Canadiens
description: When the officials allowed what appeared to have been an illegal goal by the opposition to stand and deadlock the game early in the last period, the Devils could have become unglued. Instead, they kept their composure and scored the next three goals for a 6-3 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena that ended a three-game losing streak.

title: INSIDE
description: Move on Antarctic Mining The United States will seek a legally binding moratorium on mineral development in Antarctica, and other nations are likely to agree, Bush Administration officials said. Page A10. Harsh Words for Thatcher The former Deputy Prime Minister of Britain, Sir Geoffrey Howe, defended his decision to leave Margaret Thatcher's Government and invited others to follow suit. Page A3. East Europe's Dark Winter As Moscow's most faithful ally, Bulgaria had always expected to be taken care of. Now, with its neighbors, it finds Soviet largess drying up. Sixth article of a series, page A12. New Life on Death Row The Supreme Court ordered Louisiana courts to reconsider whether a psychotic inmate on death row can be forced to take medication. Page A30. Accident Disrupts 'Shogun' The lead actor of the Broadway musical was injured by falling scenery, halting a preview and putting the official opening in doubt. Page C24.

title: Textbook Out, Videodisk In
description: Clearing the way for the wider use of high-technology teaching aids in public schools, the Texas State Board of Education on Saturday approved a videodisk- based science curriculum for elementary schools, allowing schools to choose it instead of textbooks.

title: Freedom Bank Is Paying Off Its Depositors
description: A group of business, political and religious leaders failed yesterday to raise the $6 million needed to save the Freedom National Bank in Harlem, and Federal regulators began paying off its depositors and settling its accounts.

title: Central Park Restaurant Plans Betray Olmsted's Vision; Volunteer Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry in South Africa Inconclusive
description: A judicial commission that spent six months investigating clandestine operations by special units of the army and police said today that it could not prove that they had systematically murdered and terrorized opponents of apartheid.

title: Suit Challenges Gulf Buildup
description: A sergeant in a National Guard unit today challenged as unconstitutional an order that he be transferred with his unit to the Persian Gulf.

title: People
description: * A. L. Powell has been promoted to executive vice president for corporate development at Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Minneapolis. * Raymond L. Marquis has joined Ketchum Public Relations as vice president of operations and planning.

title: Empire District Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TBS Profit Off Sharply
description: The Turner Broadcasting System said today that it had net income of $1.3 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, down from $35.2 million in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about a former New York City engineering executive rendered his first name incorrectly. He was Emil A. Verpillot, not Earl.

title: Kollmorgen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 908,000 from discontinued operations.c-After income from discontinued operations of $ 14,748,000, or $ 1.39 a share, which included a gain on the sale of Kollmorgen's 50 percent interest in the Additive Products Co. joint venture and the graphics part of its PCK Technology division of $ 23.7 million, or $ 18.8 million, net of tax, or $ 1.75 a share.d-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $ 3,182,000 for the quarter and $ 11,348,000 for the 9 months.The latest 9 months' income from continuing operations included after-tax, non-recurring charge from proxy contest and related costs of $ 1.8 million, settlement costs with Vernitron Corp. of $ 2 million and $ 1.4 million, or $ 1.1 million after tax, for a plant closing and related consolidation from operations.

title: Books of The Times; Instinct: A Tough Bird to Change
description: Soviet Civilization A Cultural History By Andrei Sinyavsky Translated by Joanne Turnbull with the help of Nikolai Formozov. 291 pages. Arcade/Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: Nike Hires an Agency With Minority Interest
description: Nike has hired Muse Cordero Chen Inc., a Los Angeles agency, to work with its current agency of record, Wieden & Kennedy, on advertising for its corporate programs. Terms are not yet decided.

title: 28 Held in Filing of Fake Car-Theft Reports for the Insurance
description: An elementary school principal and an antiques dealer were among 28 people arrested yesterday and charged with falsely reporting their cars stolen for insurance money, the police said.

title: The Wrong Strategy
description: President Bush has adopted exactly the wrong strategy in his decision to send heavy reinforcements to American troops in the Middle East, at the same time canceling plans to rotate home some of the forces already there.

title: With Millions Frozen in Banks, Noriega Might Be Tried as Pauper
description: A Federal judge said today that he would order Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to be tried as a pauper, entitled to only two defense lawyers, unless his lawyers and the Government succeed by Friday in obtaining access to the millions of dollars in the deposed Panamanaian dictator's frozen overseas bank accounts.

title: T.W.A.'s Narrower Loss
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. yesterday reported a net loss of $14.7 million for the third quarter, compared with a loss of $29.9 million the year before. The airline's revenues were $1.34 billion, up 5.5 percent from $1.27 billion in the corresponding quarter last year. The privately held company attributed the loss to higher fuel and labor costs. The carrier has been hit especially hard by higher fuel costs because its fleet consists mainly of older, less-fuel-efficient jets. T.W.A.'s fuel costs are $99 million higher so far this year. The depth of the loss was reduced in part to gains of $166.8 million from asset sales. T.W.A., based in Mount Kisco, N.Y., reported an operating profit of $58.8 million, compared with $60.7 million in the 1989 period.

title: Little Need for Warm Socks, But a Bear Might Be Welcome
description: QUESTION: How do you cheer up the holidays for servicemen and women stationed in the Middle East?

title: CHRONICLE
description: The 25th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act will be marked by honoring three black women who challenged the seating of the Mississippi delegation to the 1964 Democratic National Convention and, the following year, the state's all-white Congressional delegation.

title: Stop Copying Ballots, You Parties
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The capital has disappeared." -- William H. Roelle, of the Resolution Trust Corporation, on the difficulty of selling failed savings institutons to private investors. [ A1:4. ]

title: Giants Get a Lift Out of Landeta
description: Sean Landeta had punted indoors and out for the Giants, in September heat and January winds, he has boomed 70-yarders and touched the sky, but he had never punted like he did last Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday misidentified the company that has named Gary Andrews and Karen Harris senior vice presidents. It is Grey Direct, a marketing subsidiary of Grey Advertising, not the parent company.

title: Angelica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Running Scared
description: Every country in the East has its own post-Communist problems. But they all share the discovery that things had gotten much worse than anyone realized.

title: Bulgaria and Neighbors In East Bloc Are Reeling After Cuts in Soviet Oil
description: At Gasoline Station 31 in northern Sofia, Georgi Georgiev finally neared the pumps after four hours of waiting in a line that was 90 cars long behind him.

title: YELTSIN PROPOSES MOSCOW COALITION
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic said today that he had urged President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to share power in a "coalition government of national unity" and that Mr. Gorbachev agreed "in principle" to consider the idea.

title: The Pop Life
description: Holcomb's Crosscurrents

title: Japanese Banks Plan Merger
description: Under pressure from rising interest rates and the prospect of more deregulation, two of Japan's mid-size banks, the Kyowa Bank and the Saitama Bank, said tonight that they would merge next year.

title: Limited Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
Jailed Vietnamese Refugees Are Released in Hong Kong
description: The Hong Kong Government today released on bail 111 Vietnamese refugees it had arrested Monday just after a Supreme Court judge freed them from more than a year of detention.

title: Morocco's Call for Arab Meeting On the Gulf Has Diplomats Astir
description: The call by King Hassan II of Morocco for an emergency Arab summit meeting to avert a war in the Persian Gulf has set off a flurry of diplomatic contacts, including the dispatch of an Iraqi envoy to the Moroccan capital, but Arab reaction to the appeal has been extremely cautious.

title: Citizens Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A New Hearing for the Gershwins' Rhythms
description: On Oct. 14, 1930, a new musical by George and Ira Gershwin opened at the Alvin Theater in New York City. It starred Ginger Rogers, Willie Howard, Allen Kearns and a young actress named Ethel Merman, who made her Broadway debut and wowed audiences with her renditions of "Sam and Delilah" and "I Got Rhythm."

title: Accounts
description: * Olympus Corp., Woodbury, N.Y., to DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, for its consumer products group. The $12.5 million account was previously handled by Lowe & Partners. * Sterling Motor Cars, Miami, a subsidiary of of the Rover Group, London, to Grace & Rothchild Advertising, New York, with billings of $10 million to $20 million. The incumbent agency was AC&R, New York.
