title: Bolar Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeLastest quarter and 9 months sales were reported as negative figures; $ 10,324,751 for the quarer, which included reserve of $ 15 million for recalled products and $ 1,733,592 for the 9 months, which included reserve of $ 17.2 million for recalled products.

title: Florio Facing Revolt by 4 On Tax Plan
description: Four Democratic Assemblymen called today for the repeal of a major aspect of Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax package, in the latest indication of legislators seeking to distance themselves from the Governor's plan.

title: Key Rates
Book Notes
description: For Sale, but Still Hot

title: Atari Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from repurchase of debentures of $ 6,858,000.c-Net loss

title: Fan Dies After Fight at a Meadowlands Concert
description: A rock concert fan at the Meadowlands Sports Complex suffered fatal head injuries Sunday night after a New Jersey State trooper tried to break up a fight in a parking lot.

title: On Infant Formula
description: To The Living Section:

title: Bonds Rally on Weak Output Data
description: The rally in the Government bond market continued yesterday, as traders pushed up prices of some Treasury securities as much as a point and long-term interest rates fell to their lowest levels since the Persian Gulf crisis began.

title: A Raise for Met's Curators
description: A gift of $20 million, contributed by 14 donors over the last year and a half, will help raise curators' salaries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Although the funds are specifically earmarked for 13 existing curatorships, in fields ranging from Egyptian art to 20th-century painting, they will also make it possible to raise the general level of curatorial salaries, Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan, said yesterday.

title: J.C. Penney Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: Year-ago 9-month results included a charge of $ 20 million for discontinuance of an interactive television shopping service.Pre-tax LIFO charges in the quarter increased to $ 20 million from $ 5 million in the year-ago period. Such charges in the 9-month period increased to $ 35 million from $ 15 million in year-ago period.

title: 2 Charged in Slaying of Gay Man
description: In a case that homosexual groups say typifies the increasing violence against gay people, two men were charged on Monday with murdering a man in Queens last summer.

title: Alliance Capital Mgmt L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: A Welcome Defeat for Death
description: Amid all the complexities and confusions of last week's New York election, one clear, welcome result now stands out: Capital punishment lost.

title: Vincent James Aufiero, Restaurateur, 75
description: Vincent James Aufiero, the retired owner of Monsignore, an Italian restaurant on the East Side of Manhattan, died on Friday at New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Now, Vidalia Onions To Sweeten Winter
description: DELBERT BLAND didn't have to go to college to learn the law of supply and demand.

title: Biocraft Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Donegal Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S., Despite Dispute, Will Go to Trade Talks
description: As the first of a series of high-level meetings leading up to global trade talks was being held today, the Bush Administration sought to quash speculation that it planned to walk out of negotiations on liberalizing trade because of sharp differences with the European Community over agricultural protection.

title: Businessland Names Chief Operating Officer
description: Businessland Inc., a leading retailer of personal computers that has been struggling to cut costs and return to profitability, yesterday named Edward R. Simon Jr. president and chief operating officer.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Pic 'N' Save Chief Has Retailing Expertise
description: The Pic 'N' Save Corporation, a close-out merchandiser based in Dominguez, Calif., near Los Angeles, said yesterday that it had found the retailing expert it was seeking to serve as president and chief executive. He is Len Williams, a retailing consultant who is a former president of the Caldor and Gold Circle chains.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A GREEN-THUMBED friend writes:

title: William M. Walsh, 54, Clearinghouse Official
description: William M. Walsh, a banker and executive vice president of the world's largest electronic funds transfer company, died on Saturday at his home in Pleasantville, N.Y. He was 54 years old.

title: More on the Thymus
description: To The Living Section:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. CHAUNCEY STARR , the founder of the Electric Power Research Institute, which helps electric utilities with a technology program to improve power production, got the National Medal of Technology from PRESIDENT BUSH yesterday. Dr. Starr, 78, was cited for his contributions to energy policy and to development of nuclear energy and for creation of risk-management concepts, as well as for his role as an educator.

title: Caribe Seeks Seats On Ambase Board
description: The Caribe Investments Corporation, a group of investors led by two former managing directors of Dillon, Read & Company, has requested four seats on the board of the Ambase Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Caribe, which holds a 10.8 percent stake in Ambase, said it had made the request for board seats in meetings and telephone calls with George T. Scharffenberger, president and chief executive of Ambase, a New York-based financial services company.

title: The No. 2 Man for the Democrats in the Senate
description: Two years ago, Senator Wendell H. Ford stood up to face his Democratic colleagues and acknowledged that he had lost in his attempt to unseat Senator Alan Cranston as Democratic whip.

title: Motta Is Suspended
description: Dick Motta, the coach of the Sacramento Kings, has been suspended for one game and fined $500 for bumping an official during a game against the Knicks last Saturday night. Motta's suspension will be in effect for the Kings' game tomorrow night at home against San Antonio.

title: Milken Letter Tells Judge Of Remorse
description: In an emotional letter, Michael R. Milken wrote the Federal judge who will sentence him that he was sorry for the crimes he committed and asked for an opportunity to rebuild his life.

title: Good Day Off the Field
description: On a day off for the Jets yesterday, their cornerback James Hasty was busy going to school.

title: Richard Hummler Services
description: A memorial service for Richard J. Hummler, the theater editor and critic of Variety, will be held tomorrow at 2 P.M. at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street. Mr. Hummler died of a heart attack on Oct. 16 at the age of 47.

title: A Turnabout for Agassi As He Dominates Sampras
description: Andre Agassi beat Pete Sampras here on the opening evening of round-robin play in the Association of Tennis Professionals championship, but he objected when someone spoke about revenge.

title: About New York; Hearing Voices From Long Ago: Benny, Cantor . . .
description: Last March we visited the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged at 120 West 106th Street to listen to residents, average age 86, debate what college courses they would invite professors to come and teach. A spirited discussion.

title: 'Shogun' Lead Is Injured By Scenery in Performance
description: A large piece of scenery fell on Philip Casnoff, the lead actor in the Broadway musical "Shogun," at last night's performance at the Marquis Theater. Mr. Casnoff, who was struck on the head, was taken by ambulance to St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, where he was reported to be conscious and undergoing tests early this morning.

title: Immunex Plans Job Shift At Crucial Time for Drug
description: Michael L. Kranda will be named president of the Immunex Corporation today, the Seattle-based biotechnology company said yesterday. Immunex is on the threshold of manufacturing and selling its first major drug product.

title: Trump Ends Talks on Debt
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, said yesterday that he had broken off debt-restructuring negotiations with representatives of some of the Trump Taj Mahal bondholders.

title: Stinging Attack on Thatcher by Ex-Aide
description: In his first speech in Parliament since resigning as Deputy Prime Minister, Sir Geoffrey Howe added to the pressure today for a leadership challenge to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher by delivering a stinging attack on her opposition to the greater economic and political integration of Europe.

title: Desert Sword: Time for Answers
description: Suddenly, in the wake of President Bush's declaration of possible war against Iraq, members of Congress clamor to be heard. They're acting not merely within their rights but within their responsibilities.

title: Impressionists and Moderns Auctioned for $84.4 Million
description: The auction world continued its roller-coaster performance last night in Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art. Some of the offerings brought less than the estimated prices, with exceptions including three paintings from the Greta Garbo estate.

title: Paul Clay Baldwin, 76,Chemist and Executive
description: Paul Clay Baldwin, a chemist and a retired paper industry executive, died on Sunday at his home in Rose Valley, Pa. He was 76 years old.

title: Fabri-Centers of America reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Handy & Harman reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Sales for the first quarter of 1990 and for the 1989 periods were restated to reflect the transfer on June 1, 1990 of the automotive replacement segment to a 50-50 joint venture partnership named Go-Dan Industries.

title: Stocks Ease, With Dow Off by 4.95 Points
description: Yesterday was a choppy one on Wall Street with stock prices dropping slightly. Trading was brisk and oil prices edged $1.25 a barrel higher, to $33.12. Program trading was heavy and small stocks picked up a bit.

title: News Strikers Ask Abrams to Step In
description: The leaders of striking Daily News unions said yesterday that they would ask the New York State Attorney General to look into a series of actions by the newspaper that they claim may be violations of state law.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $ 3.9 million for the quarter and $ 10.2 million for the 9 months.c-Included tax credits of $ 7,013,000 and $ 15,713,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.d-Net incomeShare earnings are after accretion of preferred stock dividends of $ 11.9 million and $ 35.4 million for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively, and $ 11.6 million and $ 34.6 million for the comparable year-ago periods, respectively, and adjusted retroactively for the share dividend declared on July 23.Results for the year-ago quarter included a $ 38.8-million nonrecurring gain from settlement of a tax matter.Results included the company's equity in earnings (loss) of Atlanta Hawks Ltd. and Sportsouth Network Ltd.Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform to the 1990 presentation.

title: Wine Talk
description: THERE is a new wine newsletter from France, La Cote Gault Millau des Vins. It may even be France's first effort in this line. Wine has been a way of life in France for a couple of millenniums, but it's been a hobby for only a decade or so. Thus, the appurtenances of wine as a pastime -- the myriad wine books and newsletters -- are relatively new.

title: Defense Puts Eagles Into Playoff Picture
description: After the Eagles finished 11-5 and reached the playoffs last season, they were projected this season as a Super Bowl contender or at least a major force in the National Conference championship race. Randall Cunningham figured prominently into the Eagles' equation, but their big-bang defense was front and center in the Eagles' promise.

title: Death Penalty Recommended In Slaying of Five Transients
description: A jury today recommended the death sentence for a 69-year-old woman who was convicted in the slaying of five transients in a cattle-rustling scheme.

title: U.S. Owes Payment for Panama Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Trans World Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $ 9,267,000 for the quarter and $ 29,037,000 for the 9 months, from repurchase of long-term debt.The company said that the latest 9 months' results included $ 166.8 million of net gains from sales of assets including $ 83 million from the sale of certain airport facilities at Chicago; $ 47 million from the sale of aircraft; and $ 37 million from sales of a portion of TWA's interest in Worldspan, the passenger reservation system owned principally by TWA, Delta and Northwest.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Rise in Oil Production Fails to Blunt Price Increase
description: Global oil production is running 200,000 barrels a day higher now than it was before the Kuwaiti crisis began, but even so, prices will not fall until there is an easing of tension in the Middle East, W. Henson Moore, the Deputy Secretary of Energy, said at the American Petoleum Institute's annual convention here this morning.

title: Type of Vitamin A Found to Cut Heart Disease
description: A form of vitamin A common in carrots and many other vegetables and fruits appears to reduce substantially the risk of heart trouble in people who have coronary artery disease, researchers said today.

title: C.D. and Fund Rates Down
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mostly lower in the week ended yesterday and the outlook is for further declines if the Federal Reserve Board lowers rates again, as most analysts expect.

title: Miscellany
description: * Burson-Marsteller has opened an office in Taipei, Taiwan, its 59th international post, which will be headed by Kathleen DesRosiers.

title: Recycling of Plastic Bottles Inaugurated in Minneapolis
description: City officials on Monday began what is being called the nation's most comprehensive plastic bottle recycling program.

title: Shrinking the Laptop
description: The Toshiba Corporation is planning to sell a laptop computer that includes a lighter, more efficient power source than conventional laptop batteries.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: PRESERVING is usually thought of as a summer and fall activity and as one that requires huge pots, enormous labor and lots of steam. With a microwave oven it becomes so easy that we can coolly turn out reasonably sized batches of at least one kind of preserve: delicious chutneys.

title: Doskocil Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a non-cash charge of $ 750,000 for loss on the sale of Golden Harbor Seafoods Inc. in the third quarter. The third quarter and 9 months included special charges of $ 3,444,000 and $ 8,195,000, respectively, related to the firm's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.c-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 8,170,000 for the quarter and $ 6,089,000 for the 9 months.

title: Swiss Deal For 60% of First Boston
description: Following nearly a year of chaos, a large Swiss investor in CS First Boston Inc., the parent of the First Boston Corporation, agreed yesterday to bail out the firm by purchasing $300 million in new equity.

title: Mavericks Lose Tarpley For Regular Season
description: Roy Tarpley, the Mavericks' star forward, will miss the rest of the National Basketball Association regular season as the result of ligament damage discovered yesterday in his right knee during surgery in Dallas. He could return for the playoffs in May.

title: Virginia's Bowl-Game Victory
description: As the airplane approached Charlottesville, Va., last Saturday, on the way home from the eighth victory in the most memorable football season in the history of their school, the University of Virginia Cavaliers listened to what they thought would be routine announcements. This weekend would not be anywhere near routine, a reality that could be found in the news that their Sunday meeting, usually at 1:30 P.M., would be held instead at 8 o'clock in the morning.

title: DINKINS CRIME PLAN STALLED BY DELAY ON FUNDS PACKAGE
description: Six weeks and one election after Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed an ambitious anti-crime package, state officials say the Mayor's delays in devising an acceptable means of financing the plan has jeopardized its chances for passage this year.

title: CONSERVATIVES WIN G.O.P. LEADERSHIP
description: A group of conservative Republicans won major posts in the Senate today as Democratic and Republican senators elected leaders for the 102d Congress.

title: Bridge
description: A quick look at the deal shown in the diagram suggests that South will fail in six diamonds after a heart lead. A "disappearing trick" trick was required when it was played in a Swiss Team event in Westchester a month ago. North and South were Linda and Harold Rasmussen of New Providence, N.J.

title: Olivetti Is Said to Plan 7,000 Layoffs in Slump
description: Faced with slumping profits and intense foreign competition, Olivetti, the Italian computer and office equipment giant, is planning to eliminate 7,000 jobs worldwide, or more than 12 percent of its work force, a Government official said today.

title: Canadian Bank To Open U.S. Unit
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, which has assets of more than $85 billion (United States) and is one of the 10 largest banks in North America, yesterday announced the formation of a group specializing in public finance to be based in New York.

title: Fiesta Wants Louisville
description: John Junker, the executive director of the Fiesta Bowl, said yesterday that it would extend bids to Louisville and the Southeastern Conference runner-up for its New Year's Day game, and would also have ceremonies honoring Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Junker said the bowl also planned to provide $100,000 for a minority scholarship fund or to endow a chair for minority-group students at each competing university.

title: U.S. Jobs at Stake in Gulf, Baker Says
description: With the domestic consensus for the Administration's policy on the Persian Gulf beginning to fracture, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d declared today that a primary reason the United States must confront Iraq is to save American jobs.

title: New Hearing on Forced Medication of Inmate
description: The Supreme Court today ordered the Louisiana courts to reconsider a ruling that a psychotic inmate on death row could be forced to take medication to make him mentally competent to be executed.

title: Democracy Fails in Guatemala
description: Guatemala's presidential election Sunday was no victory for this hemisphere's growing democracy movement. The problem wasn't in the conduct of the election, but in its outcome. The two candidates voted into the runoff, Jorge Carpio Nicolle and Jorge Antonio Serrano Elias, both promise more authoritarian government and downplay desperately needed reforms.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Friday about Spy magazine misstated the status of negotiations for the sale of a 51-percent interest to Charles Saatchi, founder of the British advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi. A sale is under discussion, but no agreement has been signed.

title: U.S. Withholding Boeing Payments
description: The Air Force is withholding $240 million in payments from the Boeing Company, saying the concern failed to make satisfactory progress on an air defense network for Saudi Arabia. A spokesman for the Air Force's electronic systems division, said the Air Force's primary complaint was Boeing's failure to meet a Sept. 30 deadline for software testing.

title: State Plan For Choice Of Schools Is Voided
description: Citing a violation of state legislative rules, the Wisconsin State Court of Appeals yesterday ruled unconstitutional a plan to use public money to pay for private education in Milwaukee, the first such system in the nation.

title: Labor Relations Regress to Robber Baron Era; To Continue Business
description: To the Editor:

title: John M. Zwach Sr., Former Congressman, 83
description: John M. Zwach Sr., a Republican member of the House of Representatives from 1967 to 1975, died of lung cancer on Sunday at Redwood Falls Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Redwood Falls.

title: Maurice H. Berins, Executive, 82
description: Maurice H. Berins, a retired department store executive who worked in behalf of Hartford's senior citizens and other charitable causes, died on Friday at Hartford Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: Ailing Graf Shakes Off a Persistent Capriati
description: Steffi Graf, the reigning monarch of women's tennis, and Jennifer Capriati, who appears to be less and less inclined to be a teen-ager in waiting, dueled in bravura fashion for almost two hours last night in the Virginia Slims Championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: Labor Relations Regress to Robber Baron Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Creditors Urge Liquidation
description: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines yesterday urged the judge handling the carrier's bankruptcy case to begin "a prompt and orderly liquidation" of the airline.

title: Cuomo Names Aponte As State Housing Chief
description: Angelo J. Aponte, a former New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner, was named State Housing Commissioner yesterday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Vic Upshaw, Jazz Choreographer, 50
description: Vic Upshaw, an American choreographer who brought modern jazz styles to France in the mid-1960's, died on Nov. 5. He was 50 years old.

title: Yannis Ritsos, a Greek Poet, 81; Wrote Verse Inspired by Politics
description: Yannis Ritsos, Greece's most popular poet, died in his sleep on Monday. He was 81 years old.

title: Col. Ezra Kotcher, 87, Air Force Technologist
description: Col. Ezra Kotcher, the first director of the United States Air Force Institute of Technology, died Thursday at the United States Naval Hospital in Oakland, Calif. He was 87 years old and lived in Oakland.

title: As Paris Mends, Students Plan More Protests
description: With Paris nursing its wounds after looting and violence disrupted a huge demonstration here on Monday, French high school students announced plans today to continue their campaign of protests against overcrowded classrooms, inadequate security and too few teachers.

title: Review/Pop; Kiss Still Offers a Kick In a Ritual of Rebellion
description: As soon as the group Kiss came huffing out of the head of a giant Sphinx at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, it was clear that the band didn't share an artistic sensibility with the previous group, Winger. Whereas Winger had been acrobatic and almost balletic in its moves, the members of Kiss lumbered around and fell into splits from which they looked as if they might not recover. Running around seemed to pain them; the rails along the risers of the stage were padded, as if to protect the band. Occasionally, as a sign of rebellion, the band's guitarist, Paul Stanley, flung a leg over the padding and looked stuck. The vultures were flying overhead.

title: Editorial Notebook; The New Old South
description: The woman leaned from her own place setting toward mine. "Do you work here?" she asked. "I need some help with this menu." The restaurant was in a fashionable section of Durham, N.C., well within Duke University's cosmopolitan shadow. My tools were scattered around me: newspapers, my reporter's notebook, a long printout telling where the Senate candidates would be over the next few days. Despite these clues, the woman had only one category for me: the help. I was the cook or dishwasher, out among the white folks on his dinner break.

title: Ex-Official Concedes Lapses in Savings Collapse
description: A former senior official responsible for overseeing savings and loans as the industry was collapsing in the late 1980's conceded today that the Government had failed to respond adequately to auditors' concerns about pervasive regulatory problems.

title: Downey Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Knicks Win 3d in Row on Western Trip
description: The Knicks are having so much success on their West Coast trip, they may not want to return home.

title: Sulaiman's Corner Is Feeling Pressure
description: That may have been Don King in Caracas, Venezuela, last week, asking the World Boxing Association to enforce its previous decree that made Mike Tyson the mandatory opponent for Evander Holyfield. But many saw the shadow of Jose Sulaiman behind King's effort to forestall a Holyfield-George Foreman match now scheduled for April 19 in Atlantic City.

title: Singapore to Allow Greater U.S. Military Presence
description: In a modest but symbolic expansion of the American military presence in Southeast Asia, the United States and Singapore agreed today for Singapore to serve as a base for increased American training missions, visiting warships and Air Force and Navy personnel.

title: News of AIDS Therapy Gain Delayed 5 Months by Agency
description: Treatment with steroid hormones can halve the death rate from the pneumonia that is the leading killer of people with AIDS, a panel of experts has concluded. But it was five months before the Government agency that had convened the panel notified AIDS doctors of the finding, in part because the experts were concerned that notification might jeopardize the publication of their conclusions in a leading medical journal.

title: Live Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures included income of $ 8 million related to proceeds from certain life insurance policies.Latest quarter figures included results of Navarre Corp. and Waxie Maxie Quality Music Co., both acquired in the first quarter.

title: Our Allies, the Slave Holders
description: The principle that "my enemy's enemy is my friend" is obviously a dangerous one. Nevertheless, any power contemplating military action against another finds itself obliged to court the antagonist's other enemies, however repellent they might be. Once our enemy's enemy is our ally he acquires immunity from criticism. Then our representatives are photographed clutching the hands of tyrants, laughing with them in dishonorable camaraderie.

title: Sea Urchins in the Village
description: To The Living Section:

title: Balcomb Greene, 86, Painter Who Bucked Trends in Art World
description: Balcomb Greene, a painter known for his iconoclastic attitude toward the art world, died Monday at his home at Montauk Point, L.I. He was 86 years old.

title: Ernest Lowy, Manufacturer, 80
description: Ernest Lowy, a lighting manufacturer, died on Saturday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 80 years old.

title: Modern Pilgrims Who Tote Their Own Trimmings
description: AN archetypal Thanksgiving dinner stretches like an early American oil painting across the national conscience.

title: Journal to Close Philadelphia News Bureau
description: The Wall Street Journal announced yesterday that it would close its bureau in Philadelphia at the end of the year as an economy move and that some of the 10 reporters and editors there would be dismissed.

title: Richard Lewis, Tenor, Dies at 76; Sang Baroque and Modern Works
description: Richard Lewis, a tenor who excelled in Handel and who also sang in the first performances of several contemporary operas, died yesterday at his home in Eastbourne, England. He was 76 years old.

title: Home Depot Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Highest Bond Yield Is 7.40% In New York State Offering
description: The State of New York, which is facing a midyear budget gap of $894 million, most of it caused by a revenue shortfall, sold $303.3 million in general obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding won by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Economic Scene; And Then There Were 3
description: A WHO'S WHO of airline executives offered a warning last week to Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner: The first casualties in America's war of nerves with Saddam Hussein may be right here at home. Several United States carriers, already enfeebled by heavy debt and slumping passenger demand, could be forced into liquidation or merger by another six months of oil inflation.

title: PRESIDENT HONORS 30 FOR RESEARCH
description: President Bush today awarded the National Medal of Science and the National Medal of Technology to 30 scientists, engineers and mathematicians, calling them "real life pioneers who press the very limits of their fields."

title: Providence Journal; The Election Was Only Round One
description: Sisto Sperdgiti says there is no doubt in his mind that politics, Rhode Island style, is alive and well.

title: Eugene J. Wyser-Pratte, Investment Banker, 89
description: Eugene J. Wyser-Pratte, a retired investment banker, died on Sunday at his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 89 years old.

title: Stock Exchange in Moscow
description: The Soviet Union has created a Moscow Stock Exchange, the first in the country since the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. The official Tass press agency said today that the exchange was founded on Monday by 187 Soviet enterprises and banks. It did not say when trading would begin.

title: CHRONICLE
description: United States Senator BILL BRADLEY and YEVGENY PRIMAKOV will receive the Citizen Exchange Council's George F. Kennan Award tomorrow at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat, has been active in United States-Soviet exchange programs. Mr. Primakov is the Soviet Union's specialist on the Middle East and President MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV'S personal envoy.

title: Gulf Actions Expose Foreign Policy Limits
description: President Bush is learning that limitations on Presidential power apply in foreign policy as well as domestic affairs.

title: U.S. Output Fell 0.8% In October
description: The output of American factories, mines and utilities dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, prompting many analysts to declare that the economy as a whole has now conclusively slipped into recession.

title: Ousted Indian Leader Plans Fight for Change
description: V. P. Singh, whose Government collapsed last week over age-old issues of religion and caste, says he is ready to "fight the system" by touring India to convince its people that the country needs a social revolution.

title: British Plan New Phone Decontrol
description: The British Government said yesterday that it would pursue wide-ranging deregulation of the nation's telecommunications industry, including erasing most of the legal restrictions separating the telephone and cable television industries.

title: Central Park Restaurant Plans Betray Olmsted's Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Get Ferraro
description: The Islanders, looking for an experienced center to provide some offense, and the Hartford Whalers, seeking a defenseman to provide the same, completed a trade yesterday that sent Doug Crossman to Hartford and Ray Ferraro to New York.

title: Review/Music; Choral Group And Ives's Radicalism
description: John Daly Goodwin led the New York Choral Society in a program of American works on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall, and of the four works the choir sang, the most harmonically radical was the oldest.

title: Rikers Suspect Held In September Killing Of Homeless Helper
description: A 36-year-old man being held on a robbery charge at Rikers Island was charged yesterday with the September murder of a former recluse who helped the homeless, the police said.

title: Review/Music; A Trio With a Difference
description: Some instrumental combinations are called into being by the composer's ear -- Mozart's sonorous matching of clarinet to viola in his famous trio is one example. Others arrive by way of circumstance, like the "Quartet for the End of Time," which Messiaen wrote for himself and fellow concentration camp inmates.

title: Credit Agency Urges Mayor To Ready More Budget Cuts
description: A major Wall Street credit rating agency warned yesterday that New York City may have to make deeper service cuts than envisioned in even the worst scenario Mayor David N. Dinkins outlined last week to keep its current budget balanced in the face of a soft economy.

title: F.D.A. Approves Radical Gene Therapy for Advanced Cancer
description: After a lengthy review that proved far more rigorous than researchers had expected, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a highly experimental treatment for advanced cancer.

title: CRANSTON TO MISS SESSIONS ON ETHICS
description: Senator Alan Cranston announced today that he would not appear at most of the Senate Ethics Committee's hearings that open on Thursday into his and four other Senators' ties to a savings and loan executive, because he is beginning a seven-week program of radiation therapy for prostate cancer.

title: Memories of Ithaca
description: To The Living Section:

title: Review/Television; 'WIOU' Lashes Out At Its Own Medium, But With a Soft Touch
description: In the new CBS series "WIOU" (Wednesdays at 10), Liz McVay, the executive producer for news at a dumpy television station, has this to say about her product: "Television news is like sausage. People who love it shouldn't see it being made." Not so incidentally, Liz is played by Mariette Hartley, herself one of the many anchors felled over past decades by the CBS News tinkering machine.

title: 'Speak Low'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Cuarteto Latinoamericano in a Program From Mexico
description: The Cuarteto Latinoamericano continued this season's series called "Mexico: A Work of Art" with an evening at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday. The program -- five pieces in all -- formed a compact survey of how Mexican composers in the last 100 years have reacted to the string quartet as a medium.

title: Lockheed Shares Rise But Far From $40 Bid
description: Shares of the Lockheed Corporation increased $2 today, to $31.75, on the New York Stock Exchange after the investor Harold C. Simmons expressed interest on Monday in acquiring the company for $40 a share.

title: Dravo Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 1,754,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 3,587,000, or 24 cents a share, for the 9 months.c-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 1,387,000, or 9 cents a share, and $ 2,651,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: An Impish Coloratura Who Takes Risks
description: In the role of Oscar, the impish page in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Verdi's "Ballo in Maschera," Harolyn Blackwell risks perils beyond the coloratura demands of her vocal line, because her character is so active.

title: Aspirin and Liquor Can Be a Bad Mix, Study Says
description: Aspirin, a longtime antidote for the side effects of drinking, may actually enhance alcohol's effect, researchers at the Bronx Veterans Affairs Medical Center say.

title: Computers Without Keyboards
description: A number of computer makers are betting that the pen is mightier than the keyboard.

title: Spotlight Fades on AIDS in Town, But the Disease and Stigma Remain
description: Five years ago, as much of the nation groped to understand the mysteries of AIDS, this isolated sugar cane town became the center of AIDS hysteria after researchers discovered a rate of the disease here comparable to that in San Francisco and Manhattan.

title: Scali Quits Volvo Account, Citing Faked Commercial
description: Rocked by a highly publicized scandal involving a misleading Volvo commercial, Scali, McCabe, Sloves resigned the $40 million account yesterday.

title: Market Place; Kay Deal Hurts Shares of Ratners
description: GERALD RATNER has wrought a revolution in the British retail jewelry market, and now he is trying to prosper in the American market with a company that was on the verge of financial failure before he took it over. Share buyers in both London and New York are dubious.

title:
Real Estate;
Market Slow For Offices In Boston
description: NEWLY built office buildings in downtown Boston are struggling to find tenants amid a general downturn in development activity, which is related to the slowing New England economy.

title: An Ancient Skill, Sewing, Is Revived
description: LONG before it was possible to buy ready-to-wear clothes, generations of women learned to sew, usually at their mother's knee. Long after that era, home-economics teachers and organizations like 4-H clubs helped to spread the practice of sewing at home, mainly to economize on things like curtains or prom dresses.

title: 2 ARAB LEADERS JAILED BY ISRAEL
description: Israeli military authorities sentenced two of the occupied West Bank's most prominent community leaders today to six months in jail for "subversive activities" that the authorities said helped to induce the current cycle of violent attacks between Arabs and Jews.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FOR the past few years, I have been experimenting with turkey breasts in Thanksgiving recipes. They are widely available fresh in supermarkets and are fairly economical, especially for small families or couples who have no need to buy a whole bird for a holiday. Turkey breast is also an excellent low-fat source of protein.

title: The Chips Are Down: Will Island Get a Casino?
description: In the small towns and deep-water harbors of this seductively beautiful Caribbean island, it has long been said that large white ships deserve a special welcome.

title: Debate on School Choice Continues
description: The debate over school choice is rather like a Ping-Pong match that so far, no one has won.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Orlando Terminates Long Losing Streak The Orlando Magic snapped a National Basketball Association record 16-game home losing streak last night as Terry Catledge scored 30 points and Sam Vincent hit a jumper and two free throws in the final minute of a 109-103 victory over the Dallas Mavericks. The victory was the first of the season for the second-year Magic (1-6), which also got 18 points from Nick Anderson and 16 from Vincent, whose jumper gave Orlando a 105-101 lead with 43 seconds to go.(AP) Trail Blazers 155, Nuggets 129: Clyde Drexler had 39 points, 11 rebounds and 12 assists as Portland, the only unbeaten team left in the league beat Denver, one of two teams without a victory. Orlando Woolridge had 30 points for the Nuggets (0-7), who gave up close to their average for points allowed (152.7). Drexler scored 18 points as Portland jumped to an 81-59 halftime lead. The Blazers (6-0) connected on a team-record 38 of 56 field goals (68 percent) in the first half.(AP) Suns 112, Lakers 111: Phoenix overcame 36 points by James Worthy and took advantage of his missed free throw with one second remaining to defeat the struggling Lakers at the Forum. It was the Suns' first regular-season victory there in 18 attempts. Magic Johnson finished with 20 points for the Lakers, who dropped to 1-4, their worst start since 1978-79, the season before Johnson's arrival.(AP) Hornets 120, Bullets 105: Armon Gilliam scored 39 points -- one short of the franchise record -- as the Charlotte Hornets coasted past Washington in Charlotte, N.C. Gilliam was pulled by the Charlotte coach, Gene Littles, with 49 secthe third quarter. Alvin Robertson onds left and the Hornets ahead, 116-105. Kelly Tripucka holds the club record for points in a game with 40.(AP) Pistons 118, Heat 93: Isiah Thomas scored 23 points, and the Detroit Pistons used a 19-1 first-quarter run to rout Miami in Auburn Hills, Mich. The reserve forwards, Mark Aguirre and John Salley, added 20 and 15 points, respectively, for Detroit. Thomas scored 8 points in the third quarter, including a layup off a steal with 1.3 seconds remaining to give the Pistons an 86-66 lead.(AP) Bucks 119, Celtics 91: Jack Sikma scored 21 points in Milwuakee as the Bucks held Larry Bird to 5 points and routed the Boston Celtics 119-91 for their fifth straight victory. The Bucks (5-1) jumped ahead by 15-2 in the opening minutes behind 7 points from Sikma and kept rolling, building the lead to 84-50 with 38 seconds left in the third quarter. Milwaukee held the Celtics to 26 percent shooting (12 of 46) in the first half. Bird had only 2 points in the first half and Robert Parish didn't score.(AP) 76ers 108, Pacers 100: Charles Barkley scored 19 of his 23 points in the second half, lifting Philadelphia to a victory over Indiana. Barkley, 0 for 4 from the field in the first half, scored 11 points in the third quarter, but Indiana still held an 88-87 lead midway through the final period. Then Philadelphia broke away to a 100-90 lead. The 13-2 run was concluded with a 3-pointer by Hersey Hawkins with 2:26 remaining.(AP) Bulls 84, Jazz 82: Michael Jordan's jumper as time ran out gave Chicago the victory over Utah in Salt Lake City. A basket by Mark Eaton gave the Jazz an 82-80 edge with 2:52 remaining, but the Jazz never scored again, and John Paxson's jumper tied it with 1:35 left. Karl Malone, who scored 28 points for Utah, missed shots on Utah's last two possessions, and the Bulls rebounded the second with 16 seconds remaining and called timeout.(AP) Rockets 90, Timberwolves 88: David Wood tipped in a pass from Otis Thorpe with 24 seconds left, completing a Houston rally from an 11-point halftime deficit against Minnesota. Thorpe, who finished with 20 points and 13 rebounds, started in place of Akeem Olajuwon, who missed his first start in 184 games after he sprained his left ankle on Sunday against Utah.(AP)

title: Anthony Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit from early extinguishment of debt of $ 988,000.

title: Corn, the Omnipresent Staple
description: FRESH corn on the cob is on my table from the middle of July through late October. Now that the season is over, I will not serve corn on the cob again until next summer.

title: McReynolds Plans to Stay a Met
description: After six days of sniping and backbiting, triggered by the loss of Darryl Strawberry, the Mets finally got some comfort and some answers yesterday from an unlikely source: Kevin McReynolds, the silent left fielder, who has been widely portrayed as the next likely candidate to defect.

title: Alexander's Store To Close in 1991
description: Alexander's Inc. said yesterday that it would close its two-level, 260,000-square-foot store in the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center in Garden City, L.I., after selling the lease to Corporate Property Investors, owner of the mall, for $25 million in cash.

title: Backlash On Schools Unrealized
description: Predictions of a national backlash against higher taxes to pay for education failed to materialize fully on Election Day last week. In Oregon and Nebraska, voters defeated two ballot issues that had been attacked as anti-education moves.

title: Guerrilla Network Uncovered in West Europe
description: Stockpiles of arms and explosives for hundreds of resistance fighters trained to counter a Soviet invasion were hidden in Western European countries from the 1950's until recently, officials said today.

title: U.S. Lawmakers Visit China; First Time Since Crackdown
description: The first group of lawmakers from the United States to visit since the June 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators were greeted today by Prime Minister Li Peng, who urged them to help improve relations with the United States.

title: Douglas A. Anello, Communications Lawyer, 78
description: Douglas A. Anello, a communications lawyer, died Thursday at Melbourne Regional Medical Center in Melbourne, Fla. He was 78 years old.

title: TRW Cuts 1,600 Jobs
description: TRW Inc. acknowledged today that it had eliminated 1,600 jobs at its space and defense division. About 1,000 jobs were in California. TRW kept its cuts secret until they were reported in The Los Angeles Times today. Officials said the cuts were not disclosed because they occurred gradually, and mostly through attrition with only about 500 actual layoffs. Lawrence Harris, an analyst at the Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards brokerage, said he was somewhat surprised by the size of the job eliminations. Profits at TRW were $231 million in 1989, up from $209 million in 1988.

title: Messinger Urges Cutting Jobs From Central Education Staff
description: Wading into the roiling waters of the school budget debate, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan said yesterday that the Board of Education could eliminate 639 additional jobs from its headquarters staff instead of laying off teachers.

title: INVESTORS DECLINE GOVERNMENT DEALS FOR FAILED S.& L.'S
description: When Congress passed the savings industry bailout legislation more than a year ago, it had high hopes that new money from private investors would pour in to strengthen the beleaguered industry. But today, even though Wall Street pledged nearly $2 billion for the effort, only a trickle of private money has been invested.

title: Frank D. Rich Sr., 96,Developer in Stamford
description: Frank D. Rich Sr., a retired construction company official who helped redevelop the city of Stamford, Conn., died on Saturday at his home in Stamford. He was 96 years old.

title: Review/Theater; A Musical Cavalcade In Yiddish and English
description: Like a glass of cold seltzer, "Those Were the Days," the new revue at the Edison Theater, brings sparkle to the eye and a tickle to the throat. It's in Yiddish and English, practically a self-translating effusion of song and dance. Yiddish, a dead language? At the Edison, it bounces like a baby.

title: U.S. ARMY ADVISERS TRAINING KUWAITIS
description: In a particularly desolate stretch of desert here, a team of American special warfare advisers is helping the remnants of the Kuwaiti Army regroup, rearm and prepare to fight Iraq.

title: Perilous Moments In Ranger Tie
description: The scoreboard read 1-1. The clock read :005 and counting. John Vanbiesbrouck, having had Rick Tocchet's shot from 10 feet snag under his right arm, felt the puck slip slightly as he simultaneously felt himself losing his feet.

title: Police Officer Shot in Face During Drug Raid in Bronx
description: A 31-year-old New York City police officer was shot and wounded in the face last night while raiding a Bronx apartment for narcotics. Two men and a woman were arrested and 120 packages of heroin were recovered, the police said.

title: As L.I.'s Garbage Mounts, Its Taxes Do, Too
description: On Long Island, the simple act of putting out the trash and then forgetting about it is no longer simple. With no place left for their garbage to go, residents are confronting the fact that trash disposal has become one of their municipalities' top expenses, and the cost is likely to rise even more.

title: Iran-Qatar Gas Field
description: Iran and Qatar will invest $3 billion to tap the offshore Pars gas field, one of the biggest in the world, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported today. The Iran agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted a deputy oil minister identified as M. Naimi as saying the joint project would be running by the end of 1994. The gas reserves lie beneath Iranian and Qatari waters in the Persian Gulf. Mr. Naimi said Iran intended to pump the gas through a pipeline it will build through Turkey.

title: Prosecutors Said To Be Preparing To Charge Gotti
description: After a five-year investigation, Federal law-enforcement officials say they are close to seeking a new racketeering indictment against John Gotti, whom the F.B.I. has described as the nation's premier Mafia boss.

title: BRIEFS
description: * H. F. Ahmanson & Co., Los Angeles, a savings and loan holding company, said it would complete the acquisition of Home Savings Bank, Brooklyn, on Monday. * General Mills Inc., Minneapolis, expects its restaurant business to be a big growth area, chairman, Bruce Atwater, said in an interview. He said revenues from General Mills' Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurants were good, despite a generally poor economy. "Our restaurants continue to act just as they did in the first quarter," when sales grew 18 percent, he said. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, has cut ties to six health maintenance organizations and has frozen membership in 20 others in an annual review aimed at reducing its $3 billion annual bill for health care. The cuts have not been opposed by the United Automobile Workers union. * Leaf Inc., Bannockburn, Ill. the maker of the Clark candy bar, announced it would close the Pittsburgh plant where the bars are made and put the 104-year-old Clark name up for sale. Prospective buyers are looking at the plant. Leaf, owned by Huhtamaeki Oy of Finland, operates 11 candy and gum plants in the United States and Canada. * Norfolk Southern Corp., Norfolk, Va., a railroad operator, has acquired the assets of an Ohio River terminal near Wheelersburg, Ohio, from an affiliate of Island Creek Corp., Lexington, Ky., a coal company. Terms were not disclosed. * Rank Organization P.L.C., London, a communications and entertainment concern, said it had decided not to sell its Clermont Casino to Bally Manufacturing Corp., Chicago, a gaming company. * Reading Co., Philadelphia, a real estate and emergency services company, completed the sale of several properties in Philadelphia for $18.4 million. * Textron Inc., Providence, R.I., an aerospace and technology company, said it would integrate its Bell Aerospace unit into its Textron Defense Systems division.

title: U.S. Seeks Moratorium on Antarctic Minerals
description: The United States will seek a legally binding moratorium on mineral development in Antarctica when it meets with other nations next week to consider the continent's future, Bush Administration officials say.

title: Editors Wanted; English Helpful
description: "Enclosed is my resume in response to Sunday's New York Times."

title: U.N. Secretary General's Man For Refugee Post Withdraws
description: A senior Indian official at the United Nations today withdrew his bid to take command of the agency protecting the world's 15 million refugees after encountering stiff opposition from the United States and other Western aid-giving countries.

title: Great American Management & Investment Inc. reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 11.5 million, and an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $ 6.9 million.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 500,000.Year-ago period was restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Noriega Tape Case Reviving Clash Over First Amendment
description: In the Noriega tapes case, broadcasters and the press find themselves fighting a battle they thought they had won long ago: their right not to be stopped in advance from printing or televising the news.

title: Review/Recital; A Violinist From Canada Makes Debut
description: In both programming and performance, the formal New York debut of Victor Schultz, a Canadian violinist, on Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall was easier to admire on some abstract level than to love. The program ranged adventurously and showed a strong interest in 20th-century music, with works or movements by Edvard Grieg, Eugene Ysaye, Ernest Bloch, George Antheil, Ilhan Mimaroglu, Josef Suk and John Corigliano and an encore by Bedrich Smetana. But no particular logic emerged from this string as a whole or from any individual juxtapositions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Food Notes
description: Beyond Everyday Turkey

title: New Flock for Moon Church: The Changing Soviet Student
description: The Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon has extended its proselytizing efforts to the Soviet Union. Hundreds of Soviet college and graduate students have been brought to America for an all-expenses-paid immersion in the ways and beliefs of the church, which suggest that Mr. Moon may be the new messiah.

title: Eating Well
description: A RELATIONSHIP is developing between two most unlikely bedfellows, haute cuisine followers and hard-line nutritionists. From Boston to San Francisco, chefs, nutrition experts, physicians and dietitians are putting their heads together to find innovative ways to prepare food that is tasty and healthful at the same time. The consensus so far is that the two don't have to be mutually exclusive.

title: Dropout Fight Is Retooled for Grade Schools
description: The boy seemed a loose tangle of arms and legs as he spoke of spending many of his school days last year at home watching cartoons or outside riding his bicycle. Whenever he rode, graffiti and urban decay whisked by as he pedaled along in his New York City neighborhood, flattening spent crack vials with as little alarm as if they were fallen leaves.

title: Atkinson (Guy F.) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 312,000, or 3 cents a share.c-Net loss

title: Manning on Injured List
description: Danny Manning, the forward who has played in only two games this season, was placed on the injured list yesterday by the Los Angeles Clippers and will miss at least five more games. Manning, who has tendinitis in his right knee, has averaged 11.5 points and three rebounds. (AP)

title: School Feared Borough Park Boy Was Victim of Abuse
description: The public school attended by an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy whose mother is accused of killing him alerted welfare officials at least three times over the last year because teachers suspected the boy was a victim of child abuse, the school's principal said yesterday.

title: Taboos and Sexuality
description: To The Living Section:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bank of America, a division of BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, appointed Barbara L. Rambo executive vice president. * Emerson Electric Co., St. Louis, named Robert M. Cox Jr. senior vice president of development. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, named Thomas M. Culligan vice president of program development and marketing and Ronald L. Kerber vice president of technology and strategic business development. * Raychem Corp., Menlo Park, Calif., a producer of electronic hookup wire and cables, named Charles J. Abbe, Stephen A. Balogh, Michael B. Sullivan, Eric Van Zele and John A. Webb vice presidents. Deidra D. Barsotti was appointed corporate controller. * Saks Fifth Avenue, New York, a subsidiary of Investcorp International, Manama, Bahrain, named Suzanne McMillan senior vice president in charge of sales promotion, marketing and public affairs. * Sasson Licensing Corp., New York, a holding company for various clothing companies, appointed Linda Elton executive vice president.

title: Senators Asking President To Call Session Over Gulf
description: Influential lawmakers from both parties urged President Bush today to convene a special session of Congress on the Persian Gulf crisis, as the White House confronted increasing concern about the possibility of war in the Middle East.

title: Notes by Conagra Total $100 Million
description: Conagra Inc., the Omaha-based food products company, is offering $100 million in notes due 2005 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: More Encephalitis in Florida
description: Seven new cases of St. Louis encephalitis have brought the number of confirmed cases in Florida to 101. Six deaths have been attributed to the mosquito-borne illness. But David Adams, a spokesman for the State Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services, said Tuesday that counts were down in mosquito traps in many counties and that colder weather should reduce the numbers further.

title: Publisher Is Stabbed In a Sudden Attack In a Movie Theater
description: A publisher of the Zagat New York City Restaurant Survey was stabbed in a Manhattan movie theater Tuesday night by an apparently deranged man who had been muttering obscenities at other moviegoers, the police said.

title: The Police Disconnect 1-800-WANT-POT
description: A Greenwich Village man who calls himself "The Pope of Pot" was arrested yesterday on charges that he ran a marijuana delivery service using a toll-free number and bicycle messengers, the police said.

title: Swarovski Head's Goal: Lift U.S. Jewelry Sales
description: Sherry Baker's first career was as a high school history teacher. "It seems like another person who lived that life," she said yesterday. Some years after teaching, Ms. Baker zigged to the fragrance and cosmetics business; this week she zagged to the jewelry industry, where she was named president and chief operating officer of Swarovski Jewelry Ltd. U.S.

title: Community National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeYear-ago per share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for 5 percent stock dividend paid July 3, 1990, and a 1-for-10 reverse stock split on July 29, 1989.

title: GTS Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Florida First Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Panel Says White House Delayed Effort to Curb Food Health Claims
description: White House interference delayed for at least three years the Food and Drug Administration's attempt to curb misleading claims on food, a House panel said in a report today.

title: Fast Food and Bookstores Top List for Openings in '80's
description: In the last decade, Americans' love for fast food, reading, home electronics and sporting goods helped to cause a boom in specialty stores. But other changes in shopping habits and the population mix have led to only a slight overall gain in the number of retail establishments around the country, according to a new study.

title: How to Characterize Black Conservatives
description: To the Editor:

title: Wacky Collectibles Trivia For Every Day of the Year
description: TO the insatiable collector, every new day brings a new excuse for shopping. Based on this premise, Kovels' , which packages collecting guides, has introduced the Kovels' Collectibles Calendar, published by Workman ($8.95).

title: Orbit Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 161,000.

title: Edberg In A.T.P. Semifinals
description: Stefan Edberg became the first semifinalist at the Association of Tennis Professionals championships when he outlasted Andre Agassi, 7-6, 4-6, 7-6, tonight.

title: I.R.A. Suspect Is Extradited To London for Bombing Trial
description: The Supreme Court of Ireland today ordered the extradition to Britain of an accused I.R.A. bomber who is in his 36th day of a hunger strike to fight extradition.

title: May Department Stores Co. reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 3
description: b-Included a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $ 23 million for the both periods, and the 9 months also included income of $ 6 million, or 5 cents a share, from discontinued operations.Year-ago periods ended Oct. 28.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Duke Wins in N.I.T. Christian Laettner scored 24 points and had 12 rebounds last night in Durham, N.C., to lead Duke to a 87-74 victory over Marquette in the opening round of the Big Apple National Invitation Tournament. The Blue Devils, who lost to the University of Nevada-Las Vegas in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game last season, will play host to Boston College tomorrow night. Boston College beat Memphis State, 82-78, in a first-round game in Boston. The Eagles overcame a 16-point halftime deficit. (AP) Oklahoma 95, New Orleans 65: In another Big Apple N.I.T. game in Norman, Okla., Oklahoma used a 16-0 run early in the first half to take control against New Orleans. Terrence Mullins started the spurt with a 3-pointer and four other players scored during the four-minute streak, which gave the Sooners a 21-4 lead. Mullins finished with 16 points, one of six Sooners in double figures. Oklahoma has no full-time starters back from a year ago, when it finished the regular season ranked No. 1. The Sooners will travel to Fayetteville, Ark., for a second-round game against Arkansas. The Razorbacks defeated Vanderbilt, 107-70. Vanderbilt won the post-season N.I.T. last season. (AP) Arizona 122, Austin Peay 80: Chris Mills led Arizona's balanced scoring with 17 points as the Wildcats overwhelmed Austin Peay with a 59-point first half and cruised to a 122-80 first-round N.I.T. victory in Tucson. Arizona, which won its 48th straight home game, will play host to East Tennessee State tomorrow night in a second-round game. East Tennessee State beat Brigham Young, 83-80. (AP) N.B.A. Bird Scores 45 One night after his lowest point total in four years, Larry Bird scored 45 points at Boston Garden last night and the Celtics survived a late Charlotte comeback for a 135-126 victory. A 116-101 lead with 7 minutes 35 seconds remaining dropped to 122-117 with 4:21 to play on Rex Chapman's driving layup. Boston's Kevin Gamble then made two free throws and the Hornets came no closer than 5 points the rest of the way. Bird, who had 5 points in a 119-91 loss at Milwaukee on Tuesday night, added 8 assists, 8 rebounds and 5 blocks last night against the Hornets. While the Celtics were coming off their worst game of the season, the Hornets had their best game Tuesday night, a 120-105 victory over Washington. But they remained without a victory in nine games against Boston in their three-year history. On Nov. 12, 1986, Bird had 2 points in nine minutes against Milwaukee before being ejected. His 5 points Tuesday night were the fewest in a game in which he was available the entire 48 minutes since he was scoreless against Golden State on Jan. 3, 1981. (AP) 76ers 112, Hawks 104: Charles Barkley scored 34 points and grabbed 13 rebounds as Philadelphia turned back a late rally at the Spectrum. Philadelphia took its biggest lead of the game, 98-89, on a layup by Rick Mahorn with 5:56 to play. The Hawks then went on a 9-2 spurt, closing to 100-98 on a driving layup by Dominique Wilkins at the 3:24 mark. But Barkley made a 3-point play, and after John Battle connected on a jumper, Barkley added a turnaround shot with 1:47 remaining. Atlanta's Moses Malone hit a jumper 18 seconds later but one free throw by Mahorn and two by Barkley gave the 76ers a 108-102 lead with 32 seconds left. The Hawks played without Glenn Rivers, a starting guard who has a groin injury. The 76ers again dressed only 10 players. Johnny Dawkins is out for the season with a knee injury and Bob Thornton was traded over the weekend. (AP) Cavaliers 113, Pacers 95: Danny Ferry hit two quick baskets and passed to Craig Ehlo for a third during a 24-5 run in the second quarter as Cleveland built a 22-point first-half lead and coasted to the victory. The Cavaliers, who had seven players score in double figures, won their third straight game and their fifth in the last six, improving their home record to 3-0. Indiana lost its third straight and has lost 14 of its last 15 in Richfield, Ohio. Vern Fleming, an Indiana guard bothered by a virus, ended his team-record streak of 133 consecutive starts but came off the bench to score 15 points. (AP) Heat 105, Mavericks 93: Miami, playing at home, gained its first victory ever over Dallas after eight losses. Rony Seikaly had 30 points and 21 rebounds and Bimbo Coles sparked a decisive fourth-quarter spurt. (AP) N.H.L. Leafs Beat Capitals, 5-3 Dave Reid score a short-handed goal in the first period last night and added the clincher in the third as Toronto, playing at home, hung on to hand Washington its third straight loss. Toronto won a second straight game for the first time this season. (AP) Penguins 6, Jets 4: Phil Bourque scored a pair of goals to lead Pittsburgh in Winnipeg, Manitoba. Winnipeg lost despite outshooting the Penguins by 46-20. (AP) Whalers 3, Boston 1: In Hartford, Yvon Corriveau, Ron Francis and Dean Evason scored within 1:48 of the third period for the Whalers. Doug Crossman, a defenseman the Whalers acquired Tuesday from the Islanders, had an assist on Evason's goal. (AP) Blackhawks 3, Red Wings 2: In Detroit, power-play goals by Michel Goulet and Frantisek Kucera lifted Chicago past St. Louis into first place in the Norris Division. The Blackhawks, with 28 points, are tied with the Rangers for the most in the National Hockey League. The Rangers and the Blues did not play last night. (AP)

title: Icahn Group to Urge USX Sale of Steel Unit
description: The New York corporate raider Carl C. Icahn disclosed today that he had formed a new shareholder committee to press for the rapid sale or spinoff of the USX Corporation's steel business.

description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday priced at par a two-part $730 million bond offering through its regular selling group of securities dealers.

title: Title Fight Sanctioned
description: The World Boxing Association said yesterday that it was sanctioning the title defense of the undisputed heavyweight champion, Evander Holyfield, against George Foreman. At a news conference at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan, Jimmy Binns, counsel to the W.B.A., said the winner of the Holyfield-Foreman bout would be required to fight the leading available contender by June 11.

description: Two young brothers playing with matches in bed were rescued yesterday from a fire they set while their father was out placing a $10 bet on a horse, the housing police said.

Corcoran Gallery Awaits New Director And New Start
description: After 18 months of upheaval, the Corcoran Gallery of Art is slowly regaining its equilibrium and is about to announce that its new director will be David C. Levy, chancellor of the New School for Social Research in New York City. Mr. Levy is expected to be named to the post after a final vote of the museum's board on Monday.

title: Houston Journal; Lesson for Drivers: The Train Wins
description: The train rumbles along Houston's West Side, on tracks that parallel a seemingly endless strip of shopping centers, restaurants and apartment complexes. The locomotive, its horn blaring, is a quarter of a mile from the next grade crossing, at Fox Vale Lane, where bells now sound and the gates come down beside flashing lights. Suddenly a maroon sedan zigzags past the gates and beats the train by seconds.

title: Lions Undecided on Quarterback
description: When the Giants started preparing today for Sunday's game here against the Detroit Lions, they had one overriding question.

title: Fed Stance on Rates Still Unclear
description: A big drop in commodity prices yesterday helped to lift Treasury securities and lower long-term interest rates a bit more.

title: Accounting Move Weighed
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board agreed yesterday to consider whether companies, particularly financial institutions, should account for securities held for investment purposes at their market value.

title: Ban on Driving by Women Reaffirmed by Saudis
description: On the advice of its conservative religious leadership, the Saudi Government has declared firmly that it remained impermissible for women to drive cars in this Arab kingdom.

Browning Is Listening To Two Other Teams
description: Tom Browning, the Cincinnati Reds' left-handed pitcher who won 15 regular-season decisions and the third game in the Reds' four-game sweep of the Oakland Athletics in the World Series, may have pitched his last game for Cincinnati, his agent said. Jim Bronner said yesterday that his free-agent client has received five-year contract offers from two teams whose identities he would not disclose. Bronner said if the Reds did not agree to discuss a five-year deal, Browning would go elsewhere. The Reds say they have a policy against granting any contract longer than three years.(AP)

title: Dinkins Stands By Troubled Tax Proposal for Police
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he had not abandoned his proposal for a payroll tax to finance his ambitious anti-crime plan, even though there was virtually no support for it among state legislative leaders whose approval would be needed.

title: New World at War
description: When the police arrived they found the three children alone. They were wearing dirty clothes because they hadn't figured out how to do the laundry, and their father had tacked a note to the wall, telling them how to get cash with his automatic teller card. They were 8, 12 and 13, and they were hungry. There was no food in the house. Their father had been gone a week.

title: University to Establish Center For Black-Jewish Relations
description: As a young graduate student in 1949, Dr. Samuel DuBois Cook, now president of the predominantly black Dillard University here, was puzzled by a remark by a professor who had taken him under his wing at Ohio State University.

title: 14 Are Charged In 7 Burglaries By Skilled Ring
description: Fourteen men were charged yesterday with operating a burglary ring that used skilled specialists to steal cash and jewelry from banks and stores in New York and New Jersey.

title: Bensonhurst Witness Blocked From Recanting, Lawyer Says
description: A defense lawyer in the Bensonhurst case asserted yesterday that prosecutors had concealed the information that a main witness wanted to recant her testimony against one of the young men charged with the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins.

title: Franchise Report For World League
description: The World League of American Football announced today that it would begin its first season as scheduled in March 1991 with 10 teams in three divisions, comprising seven North American cities and three European sites.

description: Gasoline prices continued their climb this week, with the average price of self-serve regular unleaded up almost a penny a gallon since last week, the American Automobile Association reported on Tuesday. The average price of self-serve regular unleaded was $1.385 a gallon, up eight-tenths of a cent in the last week and 11.1 cents since Labor Day weekend.

title: Joseph Pacter Zone, Lawyer, 87
description: Joseph Pacter Zone, a lawyer and a former municipal judge in Stamford, Conn., died on Tuesday at Cortland Gardens Health Center in Stamford. He was 87 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Review/Rock; Syllables and Music
description: Good lyrics can make a standard rock song great; bad ones can wreck perfectly good music. Yet without a central voice a song becomes an instrumental, on its way to background music. The Cocteau Twins, the English band that performed Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, have adroitly hedged their bets on lyrics. In their ethereal, majestic songs, the singer, Liz Fraser, sends melodies floating in her angelic voice, while what she's saying is largely obscured by billowing guitar chords and her own liquid enunciation.

Guest, who has just introduced a line of hand-thrown clay garden accessories, from $92 to $334, sold at the Chestnut Hill store in Wilton, Conn.

Should he forthwith be brought before a tribunal for acts detrimental to the world of sports? title: Review/Dance; Garth Fagan Is Beginning 20th Season
description: Garth Fagan Dance opened its two-week season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with a triumphant declaration of achievement, growth and fidelity to its origins. In the 20 years since it was founded by Mr. Fagan in Rochester, the troupe has moved far from its rough beginnings but has not lost its early quality of idealism and commitment. It is a company in the tradition of the founding American modern dance troupes -- an instrument of a choreographer's earliest and developing ideas. And Mr. Fagan has used it well.

title: Impressive Turnaround For Nets
description: This could not have been the same New Jersey Nets that opponents have come to know, love and beat very often. Stroll into Byrne Meadowlands Arena, put any five players on the court and waltz out with the victory. The Nets have been that pathetic.

title: Rockwell Picks An Italian Partner

Rockwell said the international market for upgrading aircraft avionics -- a plane's communications, navigation, flight controls and displays -- was potentially a multibillion-dollar business.

title: Bush Has the Cards, So Why Bluff?
description: All at once, President Bush has lost key allies in the international coalition he assembled so skillfully to deter Saddam Hussein's aggression in the Persian Gulf. His approach to the crisis has lost the support of nearly half the American people, polls show.

title: Bridge
description: Competitors in a team event occasionally observe when it is over: "It didn't matter what we did." This is usually said gloomily, meaning that the other half of the team has played so badly that heavy defeat was inevitable irrespective of the performance of the speaker and his partner.

title: Review/Music; Pianist Continues Liszt Cycle

On the evidence of her second installment, which she played on Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall, Miss Kiss has the technique, the temperament and the stamina that the project requires.

There are jeweled rings by Maryse Boxer, a British designer known for simple ceramic dinnerware; gold-tone heart-shaped lockets to personalize place settings; rings of coconut shell encrusted with faux jewels, and tassels used to hold drawer keys.

Replacing Broken Spindles of a Chair
description: The spindle-back chair is usually associated with the Windsor style, its slender uprights usually made of hickory, a springy wood that forms a back with a slight give to it and thus adds to the comfort of the sitter. The Windsor spindle was of simple form and did not require turning, carving or shaping with a fret saw, but merely shaving down to shape.

description: To the Editor:

title: Extensive Chrysler Deal Set With Time Warner
description: Chrysler has signed an extensive multimedia marketing deal, one of the largest of its kind, with Time Warner.

description: The company said all per share earnings give effect to 3-for-2 stock split in October 1989.

Too Much Credit to Campus Trotskyites

title: Burroughs Wellcome Co. Criticized for AIDS Effort
description: BURROUGHS WELLCOME, maker of the AIDS-fighting drug AZT, has come under fire for sponsoring a new national public service campaign that urges people to be tested for the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Times Co. Magazines Introducing an Option
description: The Magazine Group of The New York Times Company is introducing an option for advertisers to make tailor-made ad purchases in the various publications of its women's magazine division.
