description: b-Net income

title: Mission Resource Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Shedding a Demon, Sabatini Flourishes
description: As obsessions go, Gabriela Sabatini's seemed credible enough: over and over again, she told not only herself but also everyone who cared about tennis that she wanted to be the world's No. 1 female player. But if there's anything more draining than an obsession, it's an unwanted obsession.

title: Franklin National Bank of Wash., D.C.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: How About Paying Czarist Debt to U.S.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Federal Corp. (Md.) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Bally Reports $84.7 Million Loss in Period
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, squeezed by debt and a downturn in its businesses, yesterday reported a third-quarter loss of $84.7 million after writing off $69 million of the value of its two Nevada casino-hotels.

title: American Financial Enterp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Farm Credit System reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from repurchase of debt of $ 39,000,000.

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST people are familiar with deadbolts, door locks that consist of a sliding metal bar mounted horizontally in a door's edge and that are operated by a key or small knob called a thumbturn. Because deadbolts lack spring-loaded parts, which can be jimmied, they are more effective against burglars than many other types of locks.

title: Reynolds Goes to Japan
description: R. J. Reynolds, the outfielder who became a free agent after playing last season with the Pittsburgh Pirates, has signed a one-year contract worth an estimated $1.3 million with the Yokohama Taiyo Whales of the Japanese League. He recently played in Japan with a major league all-star team. He had rejected a proposed two-year, $1.5 million offer from the Pirates.(AP)

title: Nord Pacific Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kenwin Shops Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Sept 30
A Harbor's Tough Matriarch, Under Fire
description: For at least 25 years, Evelyn Berman Frank has been calling the shots for her family business in the close-knit, male-dominated world of the waterfront. Around New York Harbor, men called Mrs. Frank "Dragon Lady" for her toughness in running the family's barge company and ship tank-cleaning business. Mrs. Frank is proud of the nickname.

title: Hispanic Officer Says Police In Brooklyn Defer to Hasidim
description: A Hispanic police officer in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn asserted yesterday that officers in his precinct are encouraged to give special, kid-glove treatment to members of a Hasidic sect at the expense of black and Hispanic people.

title: McDonald's Tries Seaweed
description: The McDonald's Corporation said today that it had started testing a low-fat hamburger that contains a seaweed derivitive.

title: Grants to Arts Colonies
description: A special series of grants to artists' colonies, totaling $2.5 million, is being awarded by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation of Chicago, it was announced today.

title: Making a Radiator More Comely
description: THE first cast-iron radiators, throbbing with steam heat, were invented during the Industrial Revolution. Almost immediately, radiator owners devised ways of covering them.

title: Topics of The Times; Keeping Up With the World
description: The "Political Handbook of the World" is a massive compendium published annually by the State University of New York. The 1990 edition, just out, has 956 pages of fact about 175 countries and a raft of international organizations. Keeping up with new governments and, indeed, new nations is no small undertaking. When the 1990 book was being prepared there were still two Germanys, and there are full descriptions of both. But with unification on the way, alert editors managed to squeeze in a few last-minute paragraphs about developments through early July.

title: Intercontinental Life reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Granges Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian funds.

title: The Elliptical Presidency
description: George Bush is unique among modern Presidents in his inability to articulate his policies passionately and persuasively, and in memorable phrases. Until the Persian Gulf crisis, that shortcoming did not seem to matter. But now, Mr. Bush's tin ear and his rambling, sometimes incoherent style -- long apparent when he has deviated from his ghostwriters' scripts -- could cripple his Presidency.

title: Van Gogh Drawing Sets a Record at $8.4 Million
description: The ups and downs in art auctions continued last night at Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern works that saw a painting by Vincent van Gogh go unsold and a drawing soar to record levels.

title: Anger in Youth Linked To Future Heart Attack
description: Hostile teen-agers are likely to grow up to be adults who have high cholesterol levels, according to a study that finds new links between anger and heart trouble.

title: Guards Say Daily News Hired Them as 'Bait'
description: The Daily News has hired unemployed veterans and other jobless men through a Kentucky security company to drive delivery trucks and collect money from news dealers. But two men who say they quit the job in disgust say the real object was to videotape them and other security personnel being beaten by strikers as evidence to use in court against the drivers' union.

title: Money-Fund Yields Drop
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell in the week ended yesterday.

title: American Israeli Paper Mills reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ohio Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Poland and Germany Sign Border Guarantee Pact
description: Poland signed a treaty guaranteeing its border with Germany today, ending months of anxiety among Poles about the intentions of their neighbor to the west.

title: Oil Surge Disrupts Southeast Asia Economies
description: The increase in oil prices since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has taken some of the heat out of Southeast Asia's booming economies, while significantly adding to political stresses in the Philippines, which has no indigenous energy sources and a faltering economy.

title: Canada Malting reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains of $ 1,150,000 from foreign exchange and $ 6,183,000 from sale of real-estate assets.The company said the sales growth in the latest quarter mainly reflects the contribution of Hugh Baird & Sons Ltd., acquired in November 1989.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Topics of The Times; Congress Cavorts
description: "The idea that the press thinks these trips are junkets is absolutely ridiculous," says Representative Martin Russo of Illinois. But tell that to the millions of television viewers who saw a recent "Prime Time Live" report showing Mr. Russo and eight House colleagues cavorting at the beach during a four-day, taxpayer-funded stay on Barbados this spring. The embarrassing episode was vividly captured on videotape by ABC producers posing as camcorder-wielding tourists.

title: Trump Shifts And Talks To Creditors
description: Only a few hours after declaring on Tuesday that he had broken off negotiations with holders of the "junk bonds" of his Taj Mahal casino, Donald J. Trump reopened the talks yesterday to try to avoid an involuntary bankruptcy filing on the Atlantic City property.

title: First American Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected a pre-tax gain of $ 4 million from the sale in the third quarter of First American Bank of Ashland, Ky.c-Net income

title: RWANDAN PLEDGES DEMOCRATIZATION
description: In a major break with past policies, the President of the strife-torn Central African country of Rwanda said Tuesday that he would permit a multiparty political system next year.

title: Review/Recital; Eschenbach And Kim Play Mozart
description: Eighteenth-century music emerges for the modern listener out of a historical fog. Not only have the individual instruments changed drastically, but the balances between them as well. So when Young Uck Kim and Christoph Eschenbach played four Mozart violin and piano sonatas at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night -- and used today's instruments to do it -- they were perhaps speaking in metaphor rather than reciting history.

title: Another Night, Another Knick Star
description: During the Knicks' current four-game winning streak, several players have stepped forward in crucial situations.

title: Advanced TV Testing Set Amid Tumult on Technology
description: The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it would begin to test six rival high-definition television systems in April, but the competition has been thrown into turmoil.

title: Washington at Work; Taking On 5 Senators, Ethics Panel's Counsel Insists He's Not Political
description: As a high-powered, $400-an-hour Washington lawyer, Bob Bennett is well acquainted with the ways of Government but does not count a single politician among his friends.

title: Parent & Child
description: A FEW years ago one of Ann Lonstein's children was having trouble with a 10th-grade social studies course. Even though he did well on the examinations, the boy refused to do the weekly worksheets because he found them boring and meaningless. The teacher failed him and insisted that he attend summer school.

title: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Year-ago share earnings were restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split effected on June 29, 1990.

title: Logic Devices reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $ 665,000, or 14 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: CHRONICLE
description: People all over the country are fasting today -- except in New York, where they did it yesterday -- to raise awareness of world hunger. Last night about 100 people went to the Manhattan apartment of the folk singer PETER YARROW to break the fast. The 17th annual national fast is organized by Oxfam America, a nonprofit agency that supports development and disaster relief in poor countries.

title: Cambridge Biotech reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said all figures represent the combined results of predecessor companies Cambridge Bioscience Corp. and Biotech Research Laboratories Inc., which merged effective Sept. 7 to form Cambridge Biotech.

title: Colts' Coach Says Jets Can't Be Taken Lightly
description: When Joe Namath guaranteed a Jets' victory over the Baltimore Colts in Super Bowl III in 1969, he was quoted as saying afterwards that he was afraid of the Jets watching too much film of their opponents because they might get overconfident.

title: 'Shogun' Postpones Opening After Star Is Injured
description: "Shogun," the new Broadway musical based on James Clavell's best-selling novel, will resume performances tonight, and the official opening has been rescheduled for Tuesday, the show's press representative said yesterday. Philip Casnoff, the show's leading actor, was injured on Tuesday evening when a large piece of scenery fell and struck him on the head.

title: Energy Commission Gives Final Approval to Gas Pipeline
description: A Federal agency today gave final approval to the construction of a pipeline that will carry natural gas from western Canada to six Northeastern states, eventually replacing 100,000 barrels of imported oil a day.

title: Review/Theater; Scenes From Family Life: Always More of the Same
description: In David Storey's novel "Pasmore," the title character is troubled by a recurrent dream. Running in a race, he finds himself overtaken by everyone, even the "idlers and dullards." Suddenly awakening, he feels an "undiminished sense of terror."

title: Fit to Kill?
description: Short of incurable insanity, is there any disability the Supreme Court will recognize as severe enough to justify sparing a killer from the electric chair? The justices have allowed states to execute the mentally retarded and murderers who were juveniles at the time of their crimes. And only by the barest, 5-to-4 margin, the Court held four years ago that a condemned inmate could not be executed if he was so insane that he did not know he was being put to death or why.

title: Geodynamics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mahine Banou Qajar, Iranian Princess, 90
description: Princess Mahine Banou Qajar, a member of the ruling family of Iran in the mid-1920's, died on Saturday at D'Huys Hospital in Paris. She was 90 years old and lived in Paris.

title: Gensia Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Gensia is a development stage company and had no revenue for all periods.

title: Memorial Service
description: About 500 people gathered last night in Huntington, W. Va., to remember the 75 players, coaches, administrators and fans who died 20 years ago when a plane carrying the Marshall University football team crashed into a hillside. "All of us here this evening honor them by remembering them," said Courtney Proctor Cross, a 1986 Marshall graduate who along with her brother and three sisters were orphaned when their parents died in the crash.(AP)

The company was created in July by the combination of Rhone-Poulenc's Human Pharmaceutical businesses and Rorer Group Inc.Year-ago quarter results included a pretax gain of $ 23 million from the sale of assets.

description: Census Falling Short The 1990 population count is likely to fall two million people short of an early estimate of 250.2 million, a Congressional panel says. Page A22. Advance on Hyperactivity Researchers have found a specific brain abnormality that could explain why some children and adults are hyperactive. Health, page B18. Malcolm Muggeridge Dies The British journalist, social critic, lecturer and television personality with a lethal wit was 87. Page B19.

title: Eastern Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest third quarter included a gain of $ 212.3 million on the sale of assets and a special charge of $ 284.8 million as a result of a settlement with the pension benefit Guaranty Corporation with respect to the company's fixed benefit pension plans. Before these two non-recurring items the loss amounted to $ 180.3 million. The year-earlier loss included a gain of $ 100.3 million.Eastern said 1990 figures are not directly comparable with year-earlier results due to the March 1989 strike.

title: Reproductions: Today's Craftsmen Are Using Lasers
description: THE brown wood chest with a shiny bullet-proof finish and a generic Colonial shape is no longer the standard-bearer of furniture described as traditional. A new generation of reproductions with all the eccentricities of antiques -- sometimes even loving dents and a finish that seems faded by a hundred years of sunlight -- is the handiwork of a new team,the computer programmer and artisans skilled in old finishing techniques.

Crop Genetics International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leave Kuwait First, Saudis Say of Iraq Talks
description: Efforts to convene an Arab summit meeting to avert war in the Persian Gulf appeared to collapse today when Saudi Arabia said it would not attend such a meeting unless Iraq agreed to withdraw from Kuwait.

title: Lund International Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Former Grants Panel Protests to Endowment
description: Nine of the 11 members of last year's Literary Publishing Panel of the National Endowment for the Arts have sent the endowment's chairman a letter protesting a restriction imposed by Congress last month.

description: * Leo Burnett International has formed a non-equity affiliation with the Finnish agency Turkami & Co. The Helsinki-based company will represent Burnett's key multinational clients in the Finnish market.

description: As the Bush Administration prepares to sign a landmark treaty next week cutting conventional forces in Europe, the United States is trying to insure that Moscow will destroy many of the weapons it has removed from Europe over the last two years.

title: 5 Senators in S.& L. Case Plan to Challenge Ethics Panel's Legal Authority
description: A strong challenge to the Senate Ethics Committee's authority to discipline five Senators for what they feel are nebulous accusations will be a central legal argument when the five appear before the panel beginning Thursday.

description: A memorial for Marya Mannes, the critic, author and journalist, will be held on Sunday at 1 P.M. at the Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street in Manhattan. Ms. Mannes died in San Francisco on Sept. 13 at the age of 85.

description: A needle-exchange program intended to curb the spread of AIDS began in New Haven this week, and city health officials said they were pleased with the initial response.

description: "WHEN the children see it, oh, they like it," Darwish Ali Salamah, a 55-year-old retired Saudi Air Force colonel, says of the colorful cement and iron "Saudi-scape" he has built in his front yard in Jidda, Saudi Arabia.

description: Ginette Laurin, perhaps the most interesting of Montreal's experimental choreographers, creates movement and images that are original and startling -- yes, something different from what others do.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Personal Health
description: Strep throat is a bacterial infection that few American children escape. Most parents know that even though a strep throat will nearly always get better by itself, antibiotics are necessary to prevent its most serious complication, rheumatic fever, which can permanently damage the heart.

title: PRESIDENT SEEMS TO BLUNT CALLS FOR GULF SESSION
description: President Bush appeared to turn back the movement for a special session of Congress on the Persian Gulf crisis today by assuring lawmakers that he would consult with the before using force.

2 Teams Use Different Methods to End Slumps
description: Different teams respond to similar circumstances in different ways. Consider the respective plights of the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Edmonton Oilers, who have the lowest point totals in the National Hockey League.

First Federal Savings Bank of Montana reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Theater; Spalding Gray's Unfounded Worries
description: To hear him tell it -- and we do, for 90 delicious minutes -- Spalding Gray was starting to worry that he might be pandering to the audience with his autobiographical monologues. "Swimming to Cambodia," his soliloquy about his adventures as an actor in the movie "The Killing Fields," was so successful on stage that Jonathan Demme adapted it into a hit film. Mr. Gray's answering machine was soon clogged with show-biz offers, with everyone from the Mark Taper Forum to HBO to Creative Artists Agency ("the Mafia of talent agencies") on the prowl. Maybe it was time to escape. Should he get away from his "self-deprecating, ironic voice" and look for a Jimmy Stewart role "with heart"? Should he stop performing altogether and write a book?

title: No Talk of Glory, but of Blood on Sand
description: Richard Weese, a beefy man chewing on a tiny stub of a cigar, insists he is no liberal. "I don't believe in the do-gooders who say we should go home and stick our heads in the sand," he said the other day, settling into a seat at the Sadler Cafe.

title: Germania Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Germania Bank said that in the latest quarter it sold its Springfield, Ill. branch for a gain of $ 6,050,000, which was largely offset by a $ 5.7 million provision for losses on real estate owned.

title: In Yugoslavia, the Old European Order Passes; Hands Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Israeli efforts to control violence after the killing of Rabbi Meir Kahane included an erroneous identification, supplied by Israeli officials, for a man detained as a suspect in the killings of two Palestinians. The man, David Axelrod, is not related to Leon Trotsky. A man with the same name, who is a descendant of Trotsky, was questioned briefly by the police in a case of mistaken identity.

title: Review/Music; Classical Briskness
description: The Hanover Band, an English orchestra devoted to the sound and style of the 18th and early 19th centuries, played Hummel, Mozart and Haydn at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. The customary elements were there: period instruments, quick tempos, the emphasis on short, articulated phrases rather than long unbroken ones.

title: Adelphia Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alarmed Soviet Legislators Insist Gorbachev Give an Accounting
description: Alarmed by the nation's deepening economic crisis, the Soviet Parliament unexpectedly bolted from its prescribed agenda today and demanded an emergency address on the state of the union from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Turkey Wary of Being a 'Second Front' in a War
description: The idea is still more an abstraction than a real plan, but Turkey's leaders nonetheless are making it clear that their army will not be used as a "second front" in a war against neighboring Iraq.

title: Werner Jarowinsky, German Communist, 63
description: Werner Jarowinsky, a former economics official in East Germany and member of the Politburo at the time of the Communist Party's fall from power there, died Oct. 22. He was 63 years old.

title: Give Squatters Title, and You Will See Neighborhoods Bloom
description: To the Editor:

title: Gold Posts Heavy Losses As Inflation Worries Ease
description: Weak oil prices and a strong stock market combined to send gold prices reeling yesterday. Platinum and silver prices, which have been depressed for some time, posted smaller losses.

title: BMA Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain from disposal of discontinued television operations of $ 1,137,000 and $ 6,262,000, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and from disposal of insurance operations of $ 32,220,000, for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9-month also included income from discontinued operations of $ 11,872,000, or $ 1.23 a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 5,596,000, or 58 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 11,768,000, or $ 3.13 a share, for the 9 months.Latest quarter's loss from continuing operations is after a net loss of $ 27.9 million on the carrying value of real estate assets.

title: Review/Music; Taking a Season's Theme From Space
description: The Goliard Concerts opened a modest three-program season at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday evening organized around a grandiose theme, "New Orbits." A Goliard brochure, citing the spacecraft Magellan's entry into orbit around Venus and other recent space exploration, says the group has taken it upon itself to celebrate "three giant musical explorers: Debussy, Schoenberg and Stravinsky."

title: Mesa Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $ 455,000, or 26 cents a share.

title: Vehicle Sales Up 3.2% as Low Demand Continues
description: Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose by 3.2 percent in early November, suggesting that sluggish retail demand for vehicles was continuing.

title: Mutual of New York Appoints a President
description: The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York named Michael I. Roth president and chief operating officer. Mr. Roth, who is 44 years old, succeeds James B. Farley, 60, who continues as chairman and chief executive.

title: Mets' Plans and Elster's Shoulder in Doubt
description: The Mets' talent search to replace Darryl Strawberry took an unexpected turn yesterday when Howard Johnson, widely cast as the replacement in right field, said: "I'd be totally shocked if they told me to play the outfield, because right now I'm the shortstop. And it looks as though I'll stay there because Kevin Elster's shoulder isn't coming along as expected."

title: Reviews/Rock; A Band With a Purpose, AC/DC Has Volume
description: For a while during AC/DC's show on Sunday night at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., the audience sent objects whizzing past the musicians' heads. Caps, posters and other junk went flying. The members of the group didn't seem to notice. Like boxers who don't hear the bell at the end of a round, the band was engaged in the pursuit of a purpose.

title: Drabek Wins Cy Young Award
description: Doug Drabek, who pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to the National League East championship, came within one vote today of unanimous selection as the league's Cy Young Award winner.

title: Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included equity in net income of subsidiaries of $ 2,535,000 and $ 6,280,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included equity in net income of subsidiaries of $ 2,258,000 for the quarter and $ 6,577,000 for the 9 months.Revenue represents net premiums earned.The net income represented income from operations.

title: Home Office Reference Lab reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 7 about The Dartmouth Review misattributed the quotation "The question is not whether women should be educated at Dartmouth but whether theyshould be educated at all." Dinesh D'Souza, a former editor of The Review, was not the author; the remark first appeared in The Review in 1980 as part of a compilation of provocative quotations. It was attributed then to Keeney Jones, who was not further identified. Mr. D'Souza referred to the comment in a 1986 Review article as an example of the paper's "outrageous streak" in its efforts to stir debate on campus. The misattribution was called to The Times's attention by Mr. D'Souza in mid-October; publication of this correction was delayed pending research by The Times.

title: Perkin-Elmer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for the year-ago quarter included about $ 7 million in sales and $ 10 million in orders of Semiconductor Equipment Service, a unit that was subsequently divested.

title: New Orleans, Where Rot Is Noble
description: LIKE most New Orleanians, Peter Yokum is not a keen follower of the latest interior design trends. Rather, the 41-year-old artist belongs to what might be called the Tennessee Williams school of decorating.

title: Leonard Bernstein Is Remembered With Music, Words and Laughter
description: Friends, family and colleagues of Leonard Bernstein, who died on Oct. 14 at the age of 72, gathered yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall for a concert in the composer and conductor's honor.

title: A Global Push by Credit Suisse
description: With their decision to purchase control of CS First Boston, executives at Credit Suisse, the giant Swiss bank that is a corporate cousin of the international investment bank, plunged decisively into the competition to be one of the dominant global forces in the securities business.

title: A Windshield Wiper Inventor Settles Suit Against Ford
description: The inventor of the intermittent windshield wiper ended a 12-year-old patent-infringement lawsuit against the Ford Motor Company today by accepting $10.2 million from the auto maker.

title: Malcolm Muggeridge, Writer, Dies at 87
description: Malcolm Muggeridge, a prolific British journalist and caustic social critic, died yesterday in a nursing home in Sussex, England. He was 87 years old.

title: Horn & Hardart reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on early retirement of debt of $ 2,146,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months.The latest periods' losses before item included $ 4.7 million charge related to the settlement of an employment contract with a former chief executive.

title: Black Hills Corp. reports earnings for 12mo to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 826,000 which included net charges from th disposal of discontinued operations of $ 378,000.

title: Olympic Star Has Baby
description: Florence Griffith Joyner, who won three golds and a silver medal at the Seoul Olympics, gave birth to a 6-pound-4-ounce girl at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, her agent said yesterday. Mary Ruth Griffith Joyner was born at approximately 1:30 P.M. Tuesday, said the agent, Gordon Baskin.(AP)

description: "INVENT, invent!" exhorted Modern Mechanix magazine in 1935. As Eric Baker, a New York designer, demonstrates in his new book, "Great Inventions, Good Intentions: An Illustrated History of American Design Patents," invent Americans certainly did.

title: Retail Sales Up Only 0.1% In October
description: Retail sales growth slowed to a barely perceptible one-tenth of 1 percent in October, the Government said today, prompting analysts to predict a big cutback in holiday gift-buying.

title: NASA IS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT LAUNCHING
description: Improving weather raised hopes today that the space shuttle Atlantis and its secret military cargo could be launched on schedule Thursday evening.

title: Schmidt to Drop Plan for Demise Of Yale Review
description: A campaign to save The Yale Review has forced Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the school's president, to reverse his decision to cancel the 79-year-old literary quarterly, review editors and supporters said yesterday.

title: Apogee Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Talking Deals; Chairman's Ambitions For United
description: IT is as if all of the stress of repeated buyout offers, incessant criticism from union leaders and a much-publicized plan to oust him as chairman and chief executive of the UAL Corporation has had no effect on Stephen M. Wolf.

title: Fernandez Asserts He'll Resist State Cuts
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, already embroiled in a dispute with Mayor David N. Dinkins over cuts in city funds, angered the Legislature's top Democrat today by publicly declaring that he would resist cuts in state aid as well.

title: PROTESTERS DELAY TEST OF ATOM BOMB
description: An underground test of a British nuclear weapon was delayed today when four members of the environmental group Greenpeace were sighted near the detonation site minutes before the bomb was to go off.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BILLY JOEL will receive a humanitarian award from the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Episcopal cathedral in Manhattan. Mr. Joel, who has given concerts for the benefit of environmental groups and is active in local causes on Long Island, where he lives, plans to accept the award in person, said Jane Arginteanu , his spokeswoman.

title: Trustcompany Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago quarter's per share earnings was adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split effective August 1990.

title: The Right Response to Recession
description: The pertinent economic question for America is not whether a recession has arrived but what to do about it.

title: Bishop Issues Warning on Birth Control
description: A Roman Catholic Bishop told colleagues today that their refusal to openly discuss objections to the papal ban on contraception was seriously damaging the credibility of the church.

title: Benjamin Clapp, Television Pioneer, 96
description: Benjamin Clapp, an engineer who helped develop television in the mid-1920's, died Monday at his home in Warlingham, England. He was 96 years old.

title: Western Union Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue for the year-ago quarter and 9 months included $ 4,335,000 and $ 12,265,000, respectively, in revenue from services formerly provided, which are not included in 1990 revenue.The year-to-year increase in common shares was due mainly to conversions of Western Union Class B convertible preferred shares into common shares during the past 12 months.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ansett Worldwide Aviation Services, Melbourne, Australia, a leasing company, has ordered five more Boeing 737-500 airliners, worth about $150 million, Boeing announced, for a total order of 86 planes. * Avon Products, New York, the world's largest cosmetics company, began a door-to-door campaign in Guangdong province in southern China. Representatives schooled in a Chinese translation of the "Avon calling" slogan are hoping to carve out a market among mainly urban workers aged 20 to 35. * Bridgestone Corp., Akron, Ohio, a tire manufacturer, said it would acquire the foreign operations of Banner Industries Inc.'s Thompson Aircraft Tire Corp. for about $28 million. * Christiana Cos., San Diego, a property manager and manufacturer of drill bits, and Interstate Drop Forge Co., Milwaukee, a foundry company, have terminated negotiations about Christiana's proposed acquisition of Interstate. * Conquest Exploration Co., Houston, an oil and gas company, said the unsolicited takeover offer from Forest Oil Corp., Bradford, Pa., had expired. * DeSoto Inc., Des Plaines, Ill, said its board had declared a special cash dividend of $11.50 a share, payable Dec. 21 to shareholders of record at the close of business on Dec. 12. * Freeport-McMoRan Inc., New Orleans, an energy company, said it had received court approval of the settlement filed in connection with its proposed acquisition of the shares of Freeport-McMoRan Oil and Gas Co. * FPL Group, Inc., a holding company for Florida Power & Light Co., is exploring the possible sale of its Turner Foods Corp. citrus subsidiary. * Penn Central Corp., Cincinnati, an industrial manufacturing company, has raised its stake in Buckeye Partners L.P., Emmaus, Pa., a maker of petroleum products pipelines, to 17.4 percent from 16.3 percent of its limited partnership units.

title: Review/Television; A Detective Who Is Himself a Puzzle
description: Year in, year out, one of public television's most popular series is "Mystery." Vincent Price may go and Diana Rigg may take over as weekly host, but the core of this project remains the collection of sleuths, done to an ever-so-knowing turn by various British production entities. This writer is an unabashed pushover for a good mystery romp, finding it the equivalent of a gentle massage on what M. Poirot likes to call the "old gray cells." Miss Marple, Sherlock Holmes, Inspector Marsh, Adam Dalgliesh, Peter Wimsey -- they're all marvelous companions for an hour or so on a chilly evening.

title: COSTA RICAN URGES CUBA TO LIBERALIZE
description: Unless President Fidel Castro of Cuba allows opposition parties to organize, he may face a violent revolution, former President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica said here today.

title: S.& L. Woes Creep Into California
description: California has had more than its share of savings and loan fraud and mismanagement. But a robust real estate market has largely spared savings institutions here from the crippling losses suffered by their counterparts in depressed housing markets in Texas, Colorado, Arizona and the Northeast -- at least until now.

title: P.&G. to Invest $1 Billion for Medical Care
description: The Procter & Gamble Company announced today that it would invest $1 billion in its stock as a way to pay health-care expenses for its retirees in the future.

description: The General Electric Company and Thorn EMI P.L.C. are forming a new lighting company in Britain. G.E. will hold a 51 percent interest and take management control of the new company, G.E.-Thorn Lamps Ltd. The two organizations will collaborate on lamp marketing and distribution, and after three years Thorn EMI's minority interest will transfer to G.E.

Sabatini Receives a Scare but Stays Tough at the Finish
description: Monica Seles and Mary Joe Fernandez practically skipped into the quarterfinal round of the $3 million Virginia Slims Championips. But for third-seeded Gabriela Sabatini, Madison Square Garden metamorphosed from a showcase to a torture chamber in midmatch against Jana Novotna last night and she didn't breathe easily again until her dominance in the third-set tie breaker delivered her a 6-1, 5-7, 7-6 victory.

title: '90 Population Count Is Likely to Fall 2 Million Short of the Early Estimate
description: The 1990 population count is likely to fall about two million people short of the Census Bureau's earlier estimate of 250.2 million, the chairman of the House committee that oversees the census predicted today.

title: Key Rates
Eastern Is Given More Time
description: A bankruptcy judge late last night gave Eastern Airlines more money and time to demonstrate that it is on the road to recovery, but not as much money as Eastern had sought.

title: Another Perry Inquiry
description: Gerald Perry, offensive tackle for the Denver Broncos, is under investigation on charges of third-degree sexual assault, according to a spokeswoman for the Aurora (Colo.) Police Department. The investigation marks the fifth time in two years the 6-foot-6-inch, 305-pound lineman has been named in a criminal case.

title: First Executive Profit
description: The First Executive Corporation said today that it earned a third-quarter profit of $24 million, or 5 cents a share, despite adding $75 million to its reserves for possible losses on its "junk bond" portfolio and a drop in the value of its stock portfolio. A year earlier, the insurance company's earnings were almost 55 percent higher, with profits at $53.2 million, or 47 cents a share. First Executive said customers were redeeming policies at a much lower rate. The company also said its capital ratios were healthy.

description: Stocks rallied yesterday in the heaviest trading in nearly a month, but analysts differed sharply on whether more big gains or additional setbacks would follow.

title: Report Raises Questions on Osprey Aircraft
description: Congressional investigators said today that the tilt-rotor V-22 Osprey, which takes off like a helicopter but flies like a plane, was too heavy and vibrated excessively in early tests.

description: The Brooklyn woman who is accused of killing her 8-year-old son was removed from probation last March, even though the city's welfare agency was already investigating new child-abuse complaints against her.

title: Help for Grand Central's Homeless
description: Statues atop Grand Central Terminal's south facade depict Mercury, god of commerce, flanked by Hercules, symbol of moral strength, and Minerva, who signifies intellect. But the scene inside the building below falls far short of those ideals: it has become an unofficial shelter for the homeless.

title: Pan Am in Agreement To Sell Routes to United
description: Pan American World Airways reached a definitive agreement with United Airlines late last night for the sale of its London routes, said Jeffrey Kriendler, a Pan Am spokesman. Lawyers for both airlines worked late into the night to meet a midnight deadline for the $400 million transaction, he said, adding that further details would be announced today.

title: Needed Now: Radio Free Iraq
description: Americans are supposed to be hotshots at the techniques of mass persuasion. In the war against Hitler, we nearly perfected "psychological warfare," a combination of propaganda, rumor-mongering and mental intimidation that helps erode an enemy's power.

Rose Hall-of-Fame Fate Is Studied
description: Is there a movement under way to keep Pete Rose out of the Hall of Fame?

title: British to Prosecute 3 Detectives in I.R.A. Case
description: Three police detectives involved in the investigation of the Irish Republican Army bombing of an English bar in 1974 in which 5 people were killed and 65 were wounded were charged today with conspiracy to pervert the course of justice.

title: Depression Hidden in Deadly Disease
description: People with incurable conditions like Alzheimer's disease and terminal cancer are frequently depressed or suicidal, but their doctors often do not recognize the warning signs or they disregard them, a growing number of researchers say.

title: A Gardener In Your Life? Ideas for Gifts
description: AS autumn colors fade, it is time to ponder holiday gifts for gardeners. Whether the landscape tilled is a windowsill, greenhouse, city backyard or country estate, there is no need to worry about color, style or fit. The possibilities range from botanical prints to voracious but beneficial insect predators that safely eliminate plant pests. Here is a sampling of what is to be found in shops and mail-order catalogues this season. (Prices listed do not include shipping.)

title: Suspected of Poisoning Her Mates, Woman Is Guilty in Friend's Death
description: A woman accused of poisoning her first husband and trying to kill her current spouse was convicted today of murdering a former boyfriend with arsenic.

title: Z-Nix Settles Suit Against Microsoft
description: The Z-Nix Company, a small personal computer accessory maker, has settled its lawsuit accusing the software giant Microsoft of restraint of trade and breach of contract. Under terms of the settlement, Microsoft will license Z-Nix to use Microsoft's Windows software through 1991. It will then negotiate a renewal with Z-Nix. Neither company disclosed details.

title: Leo Gross Dies at 87; Taught Law at Tufts
description: Leo Gross, a scholar in international law who taught at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University for four decades, died last Thursday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 87 years old and lived in Belmont, Mass.

title: Kel Journal; In Torn Kashmir, Frontier Is Aflame Once More
description: In the treacherous mountain terrain along the disputed border between Pakistani and Indian Kashmir, life would be tough enough without war. On precipitous slopes and pocket-sized meadows, rural families raise their crops and animals in isolation at altitudes that demand a mountain climber's skills.

title: Bishops Prefer Problems on Outside
description: As the fall meeting of America's Roman Catholic bishops drew to a close today, the leaders of the nation's largest church were showing signs of a split personality.

title: Gericault's Views of the Times of Day
description: Last year, when the Metropolitan Museum of Art bought Theodore Gericault's "Evening: Landscape With an Aqueduct," from 1818, a few eyebrows went up around the art world. The museum was conspicuously short on French Romantic paintings, and that meant short on works by Gericault. But the painter of "The Raft of the Medusa" and "The Wounded Cuirassier," those towering landmarks at the Louvre, has always been considered principally a figure painter, and this was one of his rare landscapes, and an odd one at that -- unusually large for a landscape from that era, and depicting an ambiguous scene, cast in slanting light, of swimmers bathing near a hill town.

title: L.S.U. Coach to Resign
description: The Louisiana State coach, Mike Archer, said yesterday in Baton Rouge that he would resign at the end of the season.

title: Upbeat European View
description: Trade ministers from the European Community's 13 nations tried today to put a positive cast on the continuing negotiations to break the impasse on farm subsidies.

title: Premier Warns Yugoslavia It Faces Disintegration
description: The Yugoslav Prime Minister warned today that continued moves by this country's restive republics to block economic and political change might lead to disintegration of the country.

title: Staying Warm In Chicago
description: On a busy corner in Chicago, a fiberglass replica of a Crown Royal bottle that is 16 feet high and weighs 2,000 pounds has been attached to a billboard. The copy reads, "Ready for another Chicago winter?"

title: Article 317390 -- No Title
description: The Province of Newfoundland yesterday priced $150 million in 30-year debentures for offering through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: The Man in the Middle of the Noreiga Mess
description: When Federal District Judge William M. Hoeveler was assigned the case of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, he said it seemed like a routine narcotics matter.

title: Home Insurance Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net realized losses on investments of $ 69 million for the quarter and $ 155 million for the 9 months.c-Net income and included net realized gains on investments of $ 9 million for the quarter and $ 24 million for the 9 months.The company attributed the decline principally to the sale of its Canadian subsidiary, the Commonwealth Insurance Co., which resulted in a loss under generally accepted accounting principles of $ 21 million, and to realized losses due to the restructuring of its investment portfolio.Home Insurance is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Ambase Corp.

title: Stephen King's Mad Clown Returns
description: Stephen King steadfastly maintains his blockbuster status on best-seller lists, but his tales of the supernatural have not fared particularly well as films. His clever forays into Paranoia Alley, that ominous terrain where your worst dreams threaten to come true, seem to resist the condensation required for screenplays. That hasn't stopped ABC from proceeding with a four-hour version of the novel "It," which will be broadcast this Sunday and Tuesday, at 9 each night. The result, featuring a strong cast, is far better than any adaptation so far of a King book.

title: Satellite Information Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mr. Dinkins's Orphan Crime Program
description: Mayor Dinkins deserved the praise showered on him last month for his strong, sophisticated crime control plan. Now he deserves criticism for his inept, indifferent political handling of this urgent issue.

title: Band With a Different Ethic
description: On the back cover of an early album by the German industrialist group Einsturzende Neubauten , in tiny print, is the motto "Destruction ist not negative, you must destroy to build." Pretensions and broken English aside, this aphorism does justice to a group that has rethought and redefined the process of building music. Neubauten's first New York City concert since 1986 will take place tomorrow night at the Sound Factory in Chelsea.

title: Arizona Struggles Anew to Erase Its Negative Image
description: Once again Arizona has been plunged into political and racial turmoil, its leaders forced to protest that the state is not as narrow-minded and backward as it might seem to some outsiders.

title: News Chief Assails 'Bait' Report
description: The publisher of The Daily News, James Hoge, yesterday criticized a report in The New York Times about his paper's use of out-of-state security guards, calling it "distorted and unfair."

title: Christina Ellis Gruber, Editor, 43
description: Christina Ellis Gruber, editor and associate publisher of Earnshaw's Publications Inc., a group of trade publications for children's products, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 43 years old and lived in Greenvale, L.I.

title: Inventories Rose 0.5% In September
description: Business inventories grew five-tenths of 1 percent in September while sales suffered their biggest decline in five months, the Government said today, leading some analysts to express concern that the situation could lead to further production cuts and job losses.

title: Carolco Pictures reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Notes by Merrill
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is offering $150 million in notes with a maturity date of Nov. 23, 1992, with Merrill Lynch serving as sole manager of the offering. The securities have a 9 percent coupon and are priced at 100, to yield about 143 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Merrill said the short-term notes are not callable before maturity and are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

description: About 100 union members of the staff of the Museum of Modern Art staged a two-hour walkout yesterday afternoon.

Quake Hits Central Oklahoma
description: A minor earthquake shook pictures off walls and knocked objects off tables in two central Oklahoma communities early today. The Oklahoma Geological Survey said the quake registered 3.6 on the Richter scale of ground motion. The tremor occurred about 5:45 A.M. and was felt in Rush Springs, 40 miles southwest of Oklahoma City, and Lindsay, 28 miles south of Oklahoma City.

title: Advanced Micro To Lay Off 200
description: Reeling from a $17.8 million loss in the third quarter, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. is laying off about 200 employees to cut costs, the company said. The layoffs are in the sales, general and administrative departments in the United States and overseas, a spokesman, John Greenagel, said. The company employs more than 12,000 people.

title: Bush Signs Major Revision of Anti-Pollution Law
description: Saying every American "deserves to breathe clean air," President Bush today signed an extensive overhaul of the nation's anti-pollution law to curb acid rain, urban smog and toxic chemicals.

title: Parcells Feeling Pressures Of the Job
description: If Bill Parcells had to do it over again, he said today, he probably would not have become a professional football coach.

title: How to Save the Trade Talks
description: There is new hope that the Uruguay Round of international trade talks, currently stalled by protectionist bickering, will finally pick up speed toward resolution. The White House announced this week that President Bush and his European counterparts had agreed to take charge of the negotiations. The elements of a deal are clear. All that's missing is leadership.

title: Kohl Pledges Help in Soviet Food Crisis
description: Germany will increase food shipments to the Soviet Union if an acute supply crisis develops this winter, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today. He called on other Western nations to give more support to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic changes.

title: Alpha 1 Biomedicals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Critic's Choice
description: The French Ballet of Nancy, which makes its New York debut this weekend at the Tilles Center of Long Island University and the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, is probably unfamiliar to most American balletomanes. Mention the name of the company's director, however, and there is likely to be instant recognition.

title: You Can Tell A Mad Killer By His Eyes
description: The most lucid idea to emerge from "Mr. Frost" is that being a psychopathic killer is contagious. That is not quite what this thriller means to suggest. When Jeff Goldblum, as a mass murderer with no other name or identity than Frost, tries to persuade his psychiatrist (Kathy Baker) to kill him, he wants to prove that science is a joke next to the forces of evil. The audience is meant to wonder about the power of suggestion if not demonic influence. But the film displays so little eeriness that when people around Frost start killing, it might as well be caused by some nasty germ he's spreading around the psychiatric hospital.

title: Daily News Plan for Strike: A Fundamental Miscalculation
description: For the management of The Daily News, the newspaper's three-week-old strike has been like a complex military campaign in which surprising initial success could not be turned into quick and complete victory, in part because the battle plan had a fundamental miscalculation that seems stunning in retrospect.

title: Valenzuela Is Given Indefinite Suspension
description: Patrick Valenzuela, who rode Sunday Silence to victories in the 1989 Kentucky Derby and Preakness, was suspended indefinitely yesterday by the board of stewards at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif.

title: New Sponsor for Tour
description: The Du Pont Company announced yesterday that it had taken over sponsorship of the former Tour de Trump and said the United States' premier cycling race would be sanctioned internationally as a professional event. Du Pont stepped in to create the Tour Du Pont after Donald Trump ended his multimillion-dollar involvement in the two-year-old race over the summer because of his real-estate organization's financial troubles. (AP)

title: Dow Drops 14.60 Points, To 2,545.05

description: The United States is ready to seek a United Nations resolution this month authorizing offensive military action against Iraq, provided that final consultations with other members of the Security Council go as anticipated, a senior American official said today.

title: Corrections
description: A table on Nov. 8 reporting a New York Times/CBS News Poll of voters leaving polling places around the country carried incorrect figures for two groups. The poll indicated that male college graduates voted 45 percent for Democrats and 55 percent for Republicans in the 1990 elections for the House of Representatives. Female college graduates in the poll voted 56 percent for Democrats and 44 percent for Republicans for the House. As printed, the table was off 13 points, in favor of Democratic candidates, for the male graduates, and off 2 points, also in favor of the Democrats, for the female graduates.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced a plan to build the first fiber-optic link between the United States and Germany. A.T.&T. and a German telecommunications company, Deutsche Bundespost Telekom G.m.b.H., are scheduled to complete the project in late 1992 or early 1993, an A.T.&T. spokesman, David Bikle, said. The system would allow A.T.&T. to meet a growing demand for overseas calls to Europe, he said.

description: The British unemployment rate rose to 6 percent in October, according to figures released today by the Department of Employment. The figures show a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent, or 32,200 workers, to 1.7 million, from the previous month.

description: Mildred Riorden Blake, a former New York advertising writer who was a founder of the World Federalists, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Williamstown, Mass. She was 93 years old and lived in Williamstown.

description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher made a spirited rejection of Michael Heseltine's challenge to her leadership of the Conservative Party in the House of Commons today.

RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Becker, Lendl Reach Semifinals Boris Becker and Ivan Lendl eased into the semifinals of the Association of Tennis Professionals championships yesterday in Frankfurt with straight-set victories. Becker, the German who is ranked No. 2 in the world, defeated Thomas Muster of Austria, 7-5, 6-4. Lendl, who lives in the United States and is ranked third, swept past Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 6-4, 6-1. Andre Agassi, the American who is ranked fourth in the world, kept alive his chances of advancing by routing Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-0, 6-3. Agassi's 53-minute victory gave him a 2-1 record in the round-robin portion of the eight-man tournament. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Irish Top Rams in N.I.T. Opener Elmer Bennett, a starting guard, scored 13 of his 16 points in the second half and a freshman reserve guard, Carl Cozen, added 12 points, all on 3-pointers to lead Notre Dame over Fordham, 56-46, last night in South Bend, Ind., in the opening round of the Dodge National Invitation Tournament. LaPhonso Ellis, who led the Irish in scoring last season with a 14-point average, was held to 6 points by the Rams' collapsing defense. Jean Prioleau led Fordham with 18 points. (AP) Iowa 73, Temple 71: Acie Earl scored with six seconds to play to lift the Hawkeyes at Iowa City in another first-round game of the Dodge National Invitation Tournament. Mark Macon gave the Owls a 71-68 lead with 56 seconds to play, but Val Barnes's 3-pointer from the top of the key tied the score with 43 seconds left. Temple took a timeout but Iowa stole the ball with 19 seconds remaining. Kevin Smith drove into the paint and passed to Earl for the decisive basket. (AP) N.H.L. Flyers Topple Canadiens Rick Tocchet and Murray Craven each had a goal and an assist as Philadelphia defeated visiting Montreal, 4-1, last night at the Spectrum. Keith Acton and Tocchet scored goals 1 minute 52 seconds apart in the opening period to give Philadelphia a 2-0 lead. In the second period, the Flyers' goaltender, Pete Peeters, turned back 13 of 14 shots, including three on a power play. (AP) Bruins 6, Nordiques 0: Dave Christian scored twice in a three-goal first period and Reggie Lemelin recored his 12th career shutout as Boston handed Quebec a club-record 12th consecutive defeat. The Bruins took command from the start and extended their home unbeaten streak against Quebec to 13 games. The Nordiques haven't won a game since Oct. 20, when they beat Detroit at home. (AP) N.B.A. Nuggets Win First Game The Denver Nuggets, whose fast-break style had produced seven previous losses, were reduced to a more normal game by the ball-control Minnesota Timberwolves last night and won their first game of the season, 121-108, at Denver. The Nuggets, who averaged 137 points in their 0-7 start and yielded 153 a game, wanted to run but the Timberwolves' slow-down style did not permit it. It turned out to be a help as the Nuggets hit 54.5 percent to 41.1 percent for Minnesota. Orlando Woolridge hit 11 of 16 shots and led the Nuggets with 25 points. (AP) Lakers 108, Rockets 103: Magic Johnson scored 4 of his 24 points in the final minute as the Lakers avoided the worst six-game start in the history of the franchise in Los Angeles. Sam Perkins led the Lakers (2-4) with 29 points. Kenny Smith led Houston with 24 points, Vernon Maxwell had 23 and Akeem Olajuwon had 21 points and 12 rebounds. James Worthy, who scored 24 points, did not appear on the court until the 10:03 mark of the second quarter. He was arrested earlier in the day for allegedly soliciting prostitutes and was released from Houston police custody shortly before game time. (AP)

title: Mickey Plays the Palace, and Rescuers Go Walkabout

Mickey can easily play ordinary souls, but obviously this role as the future King of England demands something of a stretch. Happily, plummy tones and regal condescension are well within his dramatic range.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bausch & Lomb Inc., Rochester, a maker of contact lenses and other products, said it put its plans for a new corporate headquarters on hold. * Boeing Co., Seattle, said Garuda Indonesia, an Indonesian carrier, had ordered 25 jets worth $1.8 billion. * British Gas P.L.C., London, said it would make a $34-a-share (Canadian) offer for Consumers Gas Co., Toronto. * Enzon Inc., South Plainfield, N.J., a biopharmaceutical company, and Schering Corp., a unit of Schering-Plough Corp., Madison, N.J., will develop a longer-acting form of Schering's Intron A. The genetically engineered drug is an anticancer and antiviral agent. * Hadson Energy Resources Corp., Oklahoma City, said it would acquire Baruch-Foster Corp., a Dallas energy company, for $6.24 a share, or $16.9 million. * Joy Technologies Inc., Pittsburgh, a manufacturing company, and Morrison Knudsen Corp., Boise, Idaho, a construction company, said their joint venture had received a $155 million contract from Ontario Hydro, a utility company. The contract covers installation of a flue-gas scrubbing system at a power plant. * Tambrands Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a maker of health-care products, has completed the sale of its Lake Success offices to Astoria Federal Savings, Jackson Heights, Queens. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Memorial for Artist

Participants in the event, at 111 Amsterdam Avenue, between 63d and 64th Streets, will include Barbara Cook and Lorin Hollander. Ms. Gurka, the wife of Michael Gurka and daughter of George Lang and Doe Lang of Manhattan, was 37 years old.

title: Christmas Fair
description: Items will be up for auction, trade or sale this weekend at the annual Christmas fair at the St. Luke School, 487 Hudson Street. The offerings will include new and used books, as well as toys, jewelry, crafts and sporting goods. Used Nintendo and Game Boy video cassettes can be traded, and among the items up for auction will be theater tickets and dinners-for-two. A Chinese dinner will also be offered tonight. Fair hours are 5 to 10 P.M. today and noon to 5 P.M. tomorrow. Admission is $2.50 ($1 for children). The dinner is $9 ($6 for children). Information: 924-5960.

Yankees Move Softly And Carry Small Wallet
description: The Yankees, who used to turn the off-season marketplace into a frenzied dash for free agents, have begun their bidding this year with all the enthusiasm of a cold war.

title: Gap Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: Share earnings for all periods are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split to shareholders of record Sept. 17, 1990.

title: Cletus O. Oakley, 91, Mathematics Professor
description: Cletus Odia Oakley, a retired professor of mathematics at Haverford College who wrote several textbooks, died Monday at a retirement home in Chelsea, Mich. He was 91 years old.

title: Barrister Information Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: Year-ago results are restated to include a $ 318,000 loss on the subleasing of excess office space.

title: Hal Holbrook in a 'Lear' Of Druids and Wimps
description: In the title role of "King Lear," Hal Holbrook has a magisterial grace and the agility of a mountain climber, capturing the sudden, mercurial turns in his character. Dividing his kingdom and activating his wrath against Cordelia, he becomes mean-spirited and abusive. At home and in court, he is a monarch who insists on having his own way. His bitter humor, one of the strongest elements in the actor's performance, eventually turns inward into self-mockery as he falls into despair. In the course of the play (at the Roundabout Theater), Mr. Holbrook's characterization grows and deepens.

title: Parkway Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company said it continues to suffer from the operating losses of its equity method investee, Rockwood National Corp., and from the consolidated operations of One Jackson Place. The losses from the direct and indirect ownership of Rockwood were $ 209,000 for the 1990 quarter; the losses from One Jackson Place for the quarter were $ 136,000, of which $ 80,000 reflects depreciation and amortization.

title: Boxing Needs a New Kefauver
description: Near the end of "Rocky V," the old champ, broke and brain-damaged, finally flattens the new champ in a savage street brawl, then turns to the promoter who would be Don King.

title: R. P. Saunders Dies; Founder of Colleges And Groups Was 89
description: Richard P. Saunders, an educator and sociologist who headed two colleges and three welfare organizatons, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Chittenango, N.Y. He was 89 years old and lived in Fayetteville, N.Y.

description: Richard O. Covey Mission Commander

description: b-Net income

Rangers Manage to Bumble Past Woeful North Stars
description: The Rangers didn't play well enough to beat any team in the National Hockey League tonight, but their effort was sufficient to prevail over the woebegone Minnesota North Stars at the Met Center.

title: Court Move Reassures Eastern Travelers
description: Eastern Airlines appeared yesterday to be weathering any damage done to its advance bookings by a request from its unsecured creditors that the carrier be shut down and liquidated. Travel agents reported bookings were holding up now that a Federal bankruptcy judge has given the airline more time and money to make its recovery program work.

title: Saztec International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Knicks Finish a Distant 2d In High-Speed Road Race
description: The Knicks knew that beating the Trail Blazers would be difficult. Portland made it look impossible tonight.

title: T. William Brockbank, Psychiatrist, Dies at 97
description: Dr. T. William Brockbank, a psychiatrist who was medical director of the Guidance Institute of Catholic Charities of New York City for 35 years, died on Tuesday in Watervliet, N.Y., where he was visiting. He was 97 years old and lived in Del Ray Beach, Fla., and for many years had been a resident of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: New Coach Hopes to Save Browns
description: When Bud Carson sought out Jim Shofner in February to revive the Cleveland Browns' erratic and lethargic offense, he could not have envisioned that Shofner would eventually preside over more than just the offense.

Tax Rise Sought In Budget Plan For Westchester
description: The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, proposed a $1.09 billion budget today that would include a 9.63 percent property-tax increase and a sales-tax increase in much of the county.

description: Share earnings represent units.

title: Sizeler Property Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: "I don't care if they're using me as a propaganda ploy. I don't care if I'm going against my Government. I just want to go to Baghdad and see my husband." -- Donnita Cole. [ A1:4. ]

title: Islanders Top Flames in Overtime
description: Brent Sutter's power-play goal with 42 seconds remaining in overtime tonight gave the Islanders a 4-3 victory over the Calgary Flames and their first victory ever in the Olympic Saddledome. The Islanders were 0-8-2 at the Saddledome since it opened in 1983 and had not won in Calgary since October 1982.

title: A Troubled Agency Gets a New Director
description: The head of Youth Services in the District of Columbia, a brother of Malcolm X, has been named the director of New York City's Child Welfare Administration, a position that has been open for nearly eight months.

title: Coach and His Devils Go Quietly Into Night
description: The gloomy expression on Coach John Cunniff's face after the game more than adequately described the listless performance of his Devils tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Prairie Oil Royalties reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Westmin Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomePreferred-share dividends were not immediately available.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: High-Ranking Official Of H.U.D. Is Demoted
description: A high-ranking official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development has been demoted and transferred from the agency's regional office in Manhattan to a field office in Newark, an agency spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: Judge Revokes Order on Liability of Abortion Foes
description: A Federal District Court judge today rescinded an order that made contributors to a militant anti-abortion organization potentially liable for fines against the group. Lawyers for the group, Operation Rescue, had argued that the order put unconstitutional restraints on the supporters' rights of free speech and free association.

title: Olympic Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures were restated to reflect a change in accounting.

title: United Backed On Tokyo
description: Federal transportation officials have given approval to United Airlines' planned new routes between Chicago and Tokyo. The Transportation Department approved the routes over the objections of American Airlines, which had sought to offer the service. United applied two years ago for permission to offer nonstop service between the cities. United plans to begin the flights on Jan. 8, using new 747-400 aircraft and offering service on the same plane to Dulles International Airport outside Washington.

title: Rohr Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net lossYear-ago period ended Oct. 29.

title: Hijack in Washington
description: Early on the morning of Oct. 26, a handful of members of the House of Representatives, working with the Bush Administration, hijacked direct relief for the people of the Soviet Union. Americans little noted, but should long remember.

title: Panel Sees Lower Prices
description: Changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe will drive down prices for food and energy worldwide, an international panel of experts predicted today.

title: C'est le Bronx? Ou Sont les Maisons Abandonnes?
description: It didn't rate three abandoned cars in the Guide Michelin, but a new chapter in Bronx tourism history may have been opened yesterday, when a busload of French architects rolled up the Grand Concourse to survey monuments to the borough's rebirth.

description: The company said year-ago net income reflected a change in the accounting for incremental nuclear outage maintenance costs.

title: Ciprico Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Victory for Genetic Fingerprinting
description: After the most exhaustive judicial review to date of the reliability and scientific validity of DNA fingerprinting, a Federal magistrate in Ohio has ruled that the technique is admissible as evidence in a criminal trial.

title: Brock Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Nycor Is Seeking More of Zenith
description: Nycor Inc. said it had filed for Federal antitrust clearance to buy more shares of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, the consumer electronics concern in Glenview, Ill., that is the only remaining American manufacturer of television tubes. Nycor, a company based in Basking Ridge, N.J., that is controlled by Salvatore Giordano and members of his family, owns 8.2 percent of Zenith's shares.

title: Cable Concern Shows a Loss
description: The giant cable television company Tele-Communications Inc. this week reported a loss of $44 million in the third quarter, as improved operating results were offset by higher interest expenses and other costs.

title: Abortion Link Helps to Kill Research
description: Federal scientists have decided to halt years-long experiments on the use of the French abortion pill, RU 486, for treating a serious medical condition because of uncertainty about getting supplies from the manufacturer, an official of the National Institutes of Health said today.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Former Apple Executive Is Named Chief at Covia
description: Allan Z. Loren, a data processing expert who tried his hand unsuccessfully in a top sales and marketing post at Apple Computer, has been named president and chief executive of Covia, which operates the Apollo travel reservation system for a number of airlines.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * DLJ Mortgage Acceptance Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $1 billion in mortgage pass-through certificates through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. * General Motors Corp. has filed for a shelf offering of $2 billion in debt securities. * Maxus Energy Corp., Dallas, has filed a shelf registration for a proposed public offering of up to $150 million in medium-term notes through Lehman Brothers. Common Stock * Cabletron Systems Inc., Rochester, a manufacturer of data communications equipment, has filed for 3.5 million common shares. * In Focus Systems Inc., Tualatin, Ore., has filed for an initial public offering of 2.1 million common shares. Ratings * Dime Savings Bank of New York's long-term deposit and medium-term deposit rating has been lowered to Ba-3, from Ba-1, by Moody's. * University Medical Center Corp.'s outstanding series 1986 and 1987 bond rating has been increased to A, from A-, by S.& P. The corporation is based in Tucson, Ariz.

title: G.M. to Export Cars to Yugoslavia
description: The General Motors Corporation will begin exporting a small number of Chevrolet, Pontiac and Cadillac cars to Yugoslavia beginning early next year, the auto maker said. The initial order is for 450 1991 Chevrolet Corsica, Cadillac Sedan DeVille and Pontiac Grand Prix and Bonneville cars. The order was to be signed on Friday in a ceremony at G.M. headquarters here.

title: Sit Down and Talk With Hussein
description: The United States should talk directly with Saddam Hussein.

title: Despite CNN's Folly
description: The most basic premise of American freedom of the press is that editors do not have to persuade a judge to let them print or broadcast a story. Freedom from prior restraint -- from judicial orders against publication -- is a crucial difference from a country as generally free as Britain, where court orders often silence the press.

title: Bush Says Recession Is Possible
description: President Bush conceded for the first time tonight that the country might face a recession, but he said his economic advisers did not believe a long and severe one was in the offing.

title: Atomic Agency Invited by Iraqis For Inspections
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency disclosed yesterday that Iraq had invited a team of inspectors from the agency to verify that Iraq's small stock of highly enriched uranium has not been made into a nuclear weapon. The report is expected to ease fears that Iraq might be rushing to complete an atomic bomb for use in the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LINDA ELLERBEE , an acerbic critic of how television treats its own, may return to the network that canceled her show seven years ago. NBC has a project in development, "Women's Diaries," with Ms. Ellerbee as host.

title: Leo's Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 2,635,000 from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net income

title: Stepping Into the 1800's on Broadway in NoHo
description: From the 1840's to the early 1900's, the mile-long stretch of Broadway between Houston Street and Union Square blossomed as a bastion of New York aristocracy, thrived as a fancy shopping district and then hardened into an overcrowded garment district.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Birtcher Corp., Irvine, Calif., designers and manufacturers of electronic medical instruments, appointed J. Michael Brown vice president of sales and marketing. * Conrail Mercury Inc., a door-to-door intermodal service subsidiary of Consolidated Rail Corp., Philadelphia, named Kevin M. Donohue vice president of operations. * K Mart Corp., Troy, Mich., appointed George R. Mrkonic Jr. executive vice president of specialty retailing. * Sysdata International Inc., New York, providers of software utility packages, named Pamela J. Baron vice president in charge of sales and marketing. * USX Corp., Pittsburgh, manufacturers of metal and gas products, appointed Terrence D. Straub vice president of public affairs, succeeding Earl W. Mallick, who is retiring.

title: J & J Snack Foods Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included charges of $ 287,000 for the quarter and $ 609,000 for the 9 months for streamlining manufacturing operations and discontinued incentory adjustments.The latest periods comprised of 13 weeks for the quarter and 52 weeks for the year, compared with 14 weeks and 53 weeks for same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Hope and Fear as Wife Plans Trip to Iraq
description: Her trip to Iraq has not even begun and already Donnita Cole is trying to block the images of how it will probably end.

title: Top Gillette Managers Prepare for Succession
description: The Gillette Company, the world's largest maker of razors and blades, said yesterday that Colman M. Mockler, its chairman and chief executive officer since the mid-1970's, will retire at the end of next year as part of a plan to set up an orderly line of succession for senior management.

title: Italy Discloses Its Web Of Cold War Guerrillas
description: In Europe's new order, they are the spies who never quite came in from the cold, foot soldiers in an underground guerrilla network with one stated mission: To fight an enemy that most Europeans believe no longer exists.

title: Andrew P. Solt, 74, Screenwriter, Is Dead
description: Andrew P. Solt, a screenwriter who was the co-author with Maxwell Anderson of the 1948 film "Joan of Arc," starring Ingrid Bergman, died on Nov. 4 at his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: Diane Bernstein Marries R. I. Steiner
description: Diane Bernstein and Robert I. Steiner were married yesterday at the Box Tree in New York. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: The Gulf Crisis: Its Effect on U.S.
description: WHAT will be the impact on the American economy of the Persian Gulf crisis? The first problem economists face in trying to answer that is what assumptions to make about how the conflict with Iraq will play out, and what effect different results will have on the price of oil.

title: News Corp. Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: In U.S. dollars the company reported first quarter operating profit after tax but before abnormal items of $ 20.9 million, compared with $ 28.7 million in the year-ago first quarter.Earnings summary in U.S. dollars included revenues and income of U.S. operations in actual U.S. dollars. Revenues and income of Australian and United Kingdom operations have been converted at the average exchange rates for each period. The U.S. operations in 1990 accounted for 56 percent and 79 percent of consolidated revenues and operating profit, respectively. Revenues and operating profit of the United Kingdom represented 22 percent and (6) percent, respectively, and the Australian and Pacific Basin operations represented 22 percent and 27 percent, respectively.

HUSSEIN OFFERING TO TALK WITH U.S.
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today that he was ready for negotiations with the United States, although he again refused to accept a withdrawal of his troops from Kuwait as a condition for talks to avert war in the Persian Gulf.

title: U.S. Legislators Warn Kenya Rights Record Endangers Aid
description: Three United States Senators have told the Kenyan Government, once one of Washington's favorite aid recipients in Africa, that because of its poor human rights record it would not receive its usual military aid next year.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a rally in support of the strike at The Daily News misidentified the president ofthe New York City Central Labor Council in some copies. He is Thomas Van Arsdale, not Harry Van Arsdale Jr.

description: b-Included a charge of $ 316,000 in 1990 and a gain of $ 214,000 in 1989 related to settlement of litigation.c-Net income
