description: b-Included $ 290,000,000 pretax gain on sale of container, ferry, and containership assets.

title: Cuomo Asks Forced Furloughs for State Workers
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, struggling to close a nearly $900 million gap in this year's state budget, will propose that tens of thousands of New York State workers be placed on mandatory furloughs, Cuomo administration officials said today.

title: Paramount And 2 Moguls Agree to Part
description: In a surprise announcement, Paramount Pictures and the film producers Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer, two of Hollywood's most flamboyant and successful movie moguls, said today that they had "mutually agreed to terminate their exclusive production agreement."

title: UAL to Back Tickets Sold By Pan Am
description: The Pan Am Corporation yesterday disclosed details of its agreement to sell United Airlines its London routes for $400 million. As part of the agreement, reached late Wednesday night, United will guarantee $100 million worth of Pan Am tickets if Pan Am stops flying.

title: Japanese Back New Barneys Store
description: With backing from a major Japanese partner, Barneys New York said yesterday that it planned to open in 1992 the largest specialty clothing store in Manhattan in many years.

title: Depardieu as the Blustery Yet Wistful Cyrano de Bergerac
description: It is one measure of Gerard Depardieu's mysterious grace as a film actor that he can play the manic, love-possessed homosexual lover in "Menage," the bewildered bourgeois husband in "Too Beautiful for You" and now the title role in "Cyrano de Bergerac" without missing a beat, or appearing to change his suit or even his nose.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Southeast Asian

title: Will Kuluva, 73, A Character Actor
description: Will Kuluva, a character actor for more than 50 years, died on Nov. 6 while scuba diving in Bequia, in the British West Indies. He was 73 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Sonora Gold reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Lower Rating for 2 Banks
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered its ratings yesterday for the Dime Savings Bank and the Apple Bank for Savings, both of which have been suffering losses on real estate loans.

title: New York's Transit Facing Grim Steps in Budget Crisis
description: Officials of the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that to close a $272 million deficit for 1991, they could be forced to take such drastic steps as raising the fare again, eliminating all subway and bus service in early-morning hours or closing some stations and token booths.

title: Ah, to Be 20 With Cash in NoHo
description: THEY are young. They are snarly. They think they discovered the color black.

title: Sanchez Vicario Falls In Slugfest With Seles
description: Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, the plugger, and Monica Seles, the pummeler, toiled for almost three hours last night in their quarterfinal match at the Virginia Slims Championships before Seles managed to sneak out of Madison Square Garden with a 5-7, 7-6, 6-4 victory.

title: Cranston and DeConcini Focus of Ethics Hearing
description: Opening hearings into the ethical conduct of five Senators, the Ethics Committee's special counsel asserted today that Senators Alan Cranston and Dennis DeConcini were "by far the most active" in pressing regulators to go easy on the owner of a collapsing savings-and-loan institution.

title: Lands' End Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2

title: Selling Sacrifice: Gulf Rationale Still Eludes Bush
description: More than three months after the Persian Gulf crisis began, the Bush Administration still seems to be seeking a rationale to convince the American public of the need to commit hundreds of thousands of troops for a possible war to free Kuwait from Iraq.

title: Texas Speech by Greenspan
description: A crowd of nearly 300 Texans who had hoped to hear Alan Greenspan say something about interest rates instead heard the chairman of the Federal Reserve expound today on what he described as the great and fundamental problems of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

title: States Are Pressed to Suspend Driver Licenses of Drug Users
description: States must suspend the driver's licenses of all convicted drug offenders or risk losing part of their Federal highway funds under newly approved legislation signed by President Bush.

title: Which Films And When
description: "Camera on the Couch," a film and lecture series, continues through Dec. 9 at the Anthology Film Archives, 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street. Each program runs from 2 to 5 P.M. Tickets are $5. Information: 505-5181. SUNDAY "THE THREE FACES OF EVE" (1957), directed by Nunnally Johnson. The lecturer is Hariette Podhoretz, an analyst and member of the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis. DEC. 2 "WHIRLPOOL" (1947), directed by Otto Preminger. The lecturer is Krin Gabbard, an author and associate professor of literature at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I. DEC. 9 "VERTIGO" (1958), directed by Alfred Hitchcock. The lecturer is Sandy Flitterman-Lewis, an author and associate professor of English and cinema studies at Rutgers.

title: Taking One Giant Step Toward Seriousness With Neckties
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Hearst Magazines, the publisher of Harper's Bazaar and Cosmopolitan, will pay for the annual awards dinner of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, which has been without a corporate sponsor since the Wool Bureau pulled out last year. D. CLAEYS BAHRENBURG, the president of the Hearst Magazines Division, has stepped into the breach and will pay the bill, about $500,000, for the evening. The awards will be presented on Feb. 25 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Kiki Smith's Comments On Human Physiology
description: In her "Projects" exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, Kiki Smith weaves a compelling narrative about life's most tangible element, the human body, and our understanding of it. She does this with nine artworks -- most of which are sculpture -- almost never using the same material twice.

title: George A. Alford, Banker, 63
description: George A. Alford, a banker and civic leader, died on Tuesday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 63 years old and lived in Saddle River, N.J.

description: A group of prominent intellectuals called on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to resign if he is unwilling to dissolve his Government and form a coalition with non-Communists.

title: Bensonhurst Motion Denied
description: A defense motion to throw out the charges against James Patino, a defendant in the Bensonhurst murder case, on the ground that prosecutors had not told him and his lawyer about material favorable to him, was rejected yesterday by Justice Thaddeus Owens of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. Mr. Patino's lawyer, Benjamin Brafman, had contended that the prosecution had hidden information that Gina Feliciano, who lived in the neighborhood, wanted to recant her grand jury testimony. Mr. Patino, 25 years old, is accused in the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins in August 1989.

title: The Stench of Bangkok
description: When I returned to New York City after living for two years in Bangkok, Thailand, I was amazed at how clean the air was, even at Broadway and 42d Street.

title: Baruch-Foster reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Denies Any Delay in Announcing Treatment for AIDS Patients
description: Responding to criticism that it had delayed announcing a lifesaving treatment for people with AIDS, the Federal Government yesterday issued a defense in the form of an elaborate chronology of the events that occurred over a five-month period before letters were sent to doctors informing them of the treatment.

title: Capital Housing & Mortgage Partners Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Education Certainly Is a Propaganda System; Erosion of Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOSETTE SIMON , who played Maggie in the National Theater's production of "After the Fall" in London this season, won the London Evening Standard Drama Award for best actress on Wednesday. Ms. Simon was the first black actress to play the role, based on the life of Marilyn Monroe, in the play by ARTHUR MILLER .

title: Another Facet of Mexico's Artistic Achievement
description: Judging from the evidence now on view in Manhattan, Mexican photographers are currently of two minds. They remain indebted to the country's leading practitioner, Manuel Alvarez Bravo, who for nearly 70 years has taken pictures that combine modernist clarity, Surrealist mystery and Mexico's own cultural heritage. At the same time, they have reached beyond Mr. Alvarez Bravo's influential synthesis to adopt postwar European and American styles -- notably those descended from Henri Cartier-Bresson.

title: WARMING IN NORTH DISRUPTS ECOLOGY
description: In what is described as a preview of some of the effects of global warming, Canadian researchers have documented a profound and pervasive disruption of ecosystems that they attribute to a rise in the temperature of northwestern Ontario in the last two decades.

title: Reading Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 637,000.c-Net lossd-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 18,798,000.

title: Accounts
description: * Labatt Breweries of Canada to J. Walter Thompson, Toronto, with billings between $15 million and $20 million. * Minolta Corp., Ramsey, N.J., to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, for its business equipment dealers account, with a reported $4.5 million in billings. * El Conquistador Resort & Cuntry Club, Fajardo, P.R., a unit of Williams Hospitality Management Corp., San Juan, to AC&R Advertising, with a budget of $2 million. * H. P. Hood Inc., Boston, distributors of dairy, citrus and cheese products, has consolidated all its advertising for its dairy and ice cream accounts in Ketchum Advertising, New York. Part of the account, which has a budget of $5 million, was previously handled by Leonard Monahan Lubars & Partners, Providence, R.I.

title: Western Resonances In an African Tragedy
description: "I violated tradition by not killing Saga," a man says of his own brother, an adulterer whose punishment by death fell to his sibling. "My conscience bothers me." His aged mother tries to soothe him to sleep, saying, "That is the way of the world."

title: Raycomm Transworld Indus reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Biospherics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOVIET AIDE URGES DELAY OF U.N. MOVE ON FORCE IN GULF
description: The Soviet Union's chief Middle East negotiator called today for a delay in introduction of a Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq to give time for a final negotiating effort that would give President Saddam Hussein a "face-saving" reason to give up Kuwait peacefully.

title: Advertisers Hired By Law Firms Gather to Honor One Another (Discreetly, of Course).
description: In the beginning they were pioneers, visionaries, the vanguard of a great movement. There were only a few of them -- some accounts say 40, others 50 -- and they faced hostility, persecution, ridicule. But defying the odds, they grew in numbers, acceptance and respectability, until they became a formidable force.

title: Slater Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 840,000 from the downsizing of its corporate office and other restructuring costs.c-Net income and for the 9 months included an after-tax gain of $ 3,970,000 on the sale of an investment.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Key Rates
Agassi Spurns Rich Cup
description: Andre Agassi has joined Boris Becker and John McEnroe in passing up the $6 million Grand Slam Cup, the richest tournament in tennis history. The Grand Slam Cup, scheduled for Dec. 11-16 in Munich, Germany, has raised controversy by offering record prize money. The winner in the 16-man field will earn $2 million.

title: An Oil Dealer's Niche: The Man in the Middle
description: Fred Allegretti, the head of a large New York heating oil delivery company, follows daily oil trading on the computer screen behind his desk. The ever-changing numbers directly influence the wholesale price he pays for oil and, in turn, what he ends up charging his customers. He doesn't like what he sees on his screen and his customers don't like what they see on their bills.

title: U.P.I. Employees Vote to Take 35% Pay Cut
description: Union employees of United Press International today accepted a 35 percent pay cut for 90 days in what company and union officials said was an effort to keep the news service going while its owners sought a buyer.

title: On the Left, Voices Amid Confusion
description: For months, the Persian Gulf crisis has invited this surprising question: What if they gave a war and no protest movement came?

title: CHRONICLE
description: RON REAGAN will enter the late-night talk show arena with a new syndicated program, "Reagan: On the Edge." The show, a production of MCA-TV and Fox Television Stations, is being developed for next fall.

title: A Crucial Legislator Is Leaving
description: IN the annals of Congressional politics, it may amount to little more than a footnote. But for inventors and their patents, it is hard to overstate the significance of the upset election defeat of Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier.

title: Chrysler Halts Plans To Make a Mini-Jeep
description: Amid a worsening economic climate and pressure on automotive producers worldwide, the Chrysler Corporation scrubbed plans today to produce a mini-Jeep for lack of a joint-venture partner.

title: Separate Tables for the Keating Five
description: There are five separate defense tables in the Senate Ethics Committee's hearing room, one for each Senator called to answer charges of improper ethical behavior during the savings and loan scandal. Each of the "Keating Five," accused of favoritism toward the failed financier Charles Keating, has taken care to sit alone with his lawyer. It's a reasonable precaution. Each Senator wants and deserves an individual judgment.

title: Darman Says Bush Is Exploring Shift in Benefits
description: Richard G. Darman, the budget director, said today that the Bush Administration was exploring ways to shift Government benefits from the wealthy and middle class and concentrate them more on the poor.

title: Law Firms That Assist Services for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: For his song "Don't Drive Drunk," STEVIE WONDER received the Honorary Global Founder's Award from the Recording Artists Against Drunk Driving on Thursday in Los Angeles. The song inspired MORT WEINSTEIN and KEN ANTHONY to found the organization.

title: Shares in MCI Tumble $7.375
description: Shares in the MCI Communications Corporation plummeted $7.375 yesterday, to $22.625, on extraordinarily heavy over-the-counter trading of 24.6 million shares.

title: ACCORDS REACHED BY IRAN AND IRAQ
description: In another sign that Iran and Iraq are drawing closer even as an international alliance tries to isolate President Saddam Hussein, the two nations said today that they had reached agreement on a series of steps to end major disputes lingering from their eight-year war.

title: A Storm in Williamsburg as Two Ethnic Groups Clash
description: In the more than 20 years since New York City began razing dilapidated tenements nestled in the shadow of the Wiliamsburg Bridge and building high-rise subsidized housing, the area's growing Satmar Hasidic population has clashed with longtime Hispanic residents like urban Hatfields and McCoys.

title: Two Phone Aides Retire
description: The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that a former head and a current senior manager of its buildings department had retired after disclosures of widespread wrongdoing by junior managers in the construction and maintenance unit.

title: 15,000 Reservists Are Called to Active Duty
description: The Army and Marine Corps today ordered more than 15,000 reservists to report for active duty to support the gulf force opposing Iraq.

title: The Thin Bottom Line; Dinkins's Failure to Plan Acceptable Taxes Or Woo Albany Hurts Police Plan's Chances
description: The prospects for financing Mayor David N. Dinkins's sweeping anti-crime plan have been damaged by his administration's difficulties in focusing on more than one problem at a time, and on his lack of personal diplomacy with the politicians whose support is needed to make the plan a reality.

title: Budget Gap Grows Larger In New Jersey
description: Less than five months after pushing through the largest tax increase in New Jersey's history, the Florio administration announced today that the state now faces a budget shortfall of more than $600 million, and that it expects the situation to grow even worse.

title: Poverty and Privacy: Home, Sweet Niche?
description: For a brief time three summers ago, home for David Mooney was a small niche beneath Interstate 91 in New Haven. The girders overhead served as shelves, some boxes on the ground as a chest of drawers. Slabs of the concrete roadway were his bedroom walls. From one of them he hung a Playboy calendar.

title: Drumming up Tourism Is Aim of 'the Safe Peru'
description: Voiced in the two-mile-high air of this ancient mountain city, Carlos Milla Vidal's command sounded like an ancient Inca rallying cry: Forget Peru.

title: Rangers Toil for Victory
description: It wasn't a memorable night for body checking or sharp goaltending, but the Rangers-Jets game here tonight did feature swift skating, precision passing and numerous scoring chances.

title: Religion Notes
description: Bible Week

title: A Long Shot Pays Off
description: The Detroit Lions, who play the Giants here Sunday, have eight wide receivers and use four at a time in their run-and-shoot offense. The Giants have four wide receivers, and in shotgun situations they often use all four at a time, as they did last Sunday against the Los Angeles Rams.

title: In France, They Do Public Toilets With Style
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cloud Over Reform in Mexico
description: The Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has dominated Mexico since the 1920's, won every contested seat this week in legislative elections for Mexico state, the heartland region surrounding Mexico City. That could be taken as a popular endorsement for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's reform policies. But the huge pluralities, 90 percent in many cases, suggest systematic electoral fraud.

title: Key Rates
IRT Lines on West Side To Be Closed for Work
description: Subway riders on the West Side IRT lines will be inconvenienced again this weekend as the Transit Authority continues work on replacing an outdated track switch just north of 96th Street.

title: Bush Said to Question Soviets On Supplying Missiles to Iraq
description: The Bush Administration has asked Moscow if the Soviet Union has supplied medium-range SS-12 missiles to Iraq recently, Administration officials said today.

title: Review/Dance; 'Nutcracker' And Joffrey: Both Fine
description: The Joffrey Ballet made an exuberant return to New York on Thursday with the opening performance of "The Nutcracker," which runs through Dec. 2 at City Center Theater. The company, which survived an administrative and financial crisis in the spring that threatened to destroy it, is in top shape. And so its presentation of the holiday classic, in a production conceived and directed by Robert Joffrey with some new choreography by Gerald Arpino, is an even happier occasion this year.

title: Mr. Tarkanian, in Triple Overtime
description: Jerry (Tark the Shark) Tarkanian gnaws on towels while he coaches basketball games. Thirteen years of gnawing have slipped by since the N.C.A.A. first sought to bring him and the University of Las Vegas at Nevada to account for improprieties in its basketball program. It is time for the N.C.A.A. to administer appropriate medicine.

title: William S. Borden, Airline Executive, 65
description: William S. Borden, a retired vice president of Trans World Airlines, died on Tuesday at St. Peter's Medical Center in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 65 years old and lived in Somerset, N.J.

title: New Obscenity Trial Is Denied
description: A music store owner convicted of obscenity for selling an album with sexually explicit lyrics by the rap group The 2 Live Crew lost his bid for a new trial today. A jury convicted the owner, Charles Freeman, on Oct. 3 for selling the album "As Nasty as They Wanna Be." Mr. Freeman's lawyer, Bruce Rogow, argued today that his client should be granted another trial because the judge gave the jury instructions that both defense lawyers and prosecutors had not agreed to. Mr. Rogow said his client would appeal.

title: Coping; With the Sudden Loss of a Job
description: In scenes that are becoming increasingly common among companies hard hit by the sagging economy, employees are being called in, usually by an immediate superior, and being told they have lost their jobs.

title: Law Firms That Assist Services for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: First High-Temperature Superconducting Transistor Is Announced
description: Government and university scientists have built the world's first superconducting transistor able to operate at relatively high temperatures, they announced yesterday. The achievement might eventually lead to significant improvements in computers and other electronic devices, the scientists said.

title: Millions in Unclaimed Funds Wait to Find Owners
description: For most consumers, abandoned funds are nothing more than spare change lost in the cushions of a car seat or the corner of a desk drawer.

title: Fed Panel Favored Easing At Meeting in Early October
description: Federal Reserve policy makers agreed in early October to ease interest rates if a Federal budget-cutting agreement was reached and to permit further easing if economic conditions warranted, records released today showed.

title: Review/Dance; Affirmation And Nuances Of Politics
description: The Hungarian composer Zoltan Kodaly wrote "Missa Brevis in Tempore Belli" or "Short Mass in Time of War" at the end of World War II in Budapest. In 1958 Jose Limon, one of American modern dance's major choreographers, stirred by this music and the wartime ruins he had witnessed in Poland, conceived a danced affirmation of the human spirit: secular choreography to a 20th-century modernist mass.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN OCTOBER AT A SLOWER RATE
description: In a reassuring report on inflation that appeared to lead to another interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve, the Labor Department said today that consumer prices had climbed less in October than in the preceding two months. The bond market rallied in response.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It is painfully obvious that the United States Government does not wish me to be able to defend myself and have done everything possible to deprive me of a fair trial and due process. They have taken my money, deprived me of my lawyers, videotaped me in my cell, wiretapped my telephone calls with my lawyers and even given them to the Endara Government and to the press." -- Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. [ 8:5. ]

title: UConn Awards Calhoun A Four-Year Deal
description: Jim Calhoun, coming off one of the best seasons in the University of Connecticut's history, has agreed to a new four-year contract as head coach that will guarantee him $255,000 a year, the school said yesterday.

title: No Bowl For the Mount
description: While numerous other college football coaches are working like dogs to get their teams into one of the overflow of bowls -- from the Rose Bowl and the Sugar Bowl to the Blockbuster Bowl and the California Raisin Bowl -- John Pont's season is over. And he is pleased, more or less, with a 1-9 record -- not doing cartwheels from goal post to goal post, to be sure, but able to keep his head erect.

title: Jogger Jury Sees Videotaped Confession
description: The jury in the second Central Park jogger trial watched a chilling police videotape yesterday in which one of the teen-age defendants admitted taking part in the attack, saying "It was my first rape."

title: CHRONICLE
description: FERDINAND MOUNT will be the next editor of The Times Literary Supplement, the British literary journal. He replaces JEREMY TREGLOWN, who resigned in a dispute over a headline with MICHAEL HOY, the journal's new chief executive. Mr. Hoy had objected to the headline "Syphilis and Us" on a review.

title: Kuwait Asks U.N. to Preserve Pre-Invasion Population List
description: Kuwait's Government in exile is seeking United Nations help in preserving records listing the nation's population before it was invaded by Iraq, Kuwaiti diplomats say.

title: Chase Says Its Losses Will Rise
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation expects increased losses on consumer and business loans in coming months, assuming that the economy continues to weaken, the banking company said in a document filed early this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Performing Groups To Share $3 Million
description: The Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund has announced $3.2 million in grants to several dance, theater, music and visual arts organizations in the New York metropolitan area and around the country. The grants are part of the fund's continuing contributions to cultural orgranizations.

title: Holtz Hopes the Irish Defense Isn't Charitable
description: By this time, with a defensive unit that presents more problems for the coaches at Notre Dame than for their opponents, the length and intensity of practices were going to be reduced as the Fighting Irish completed their schedule in the unfamiliar position of watching others compete for a championship.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about the growth of interest in sewing misstated the amount of money spent on fabrics, patterns, notions, laces and trims in 1987. It was $2.5 billion, not $2.5 million.

title: AIDS and Halloween
description: To the Editor:

title: Factory Pact By Compucom
description: In a move that would create the nation's second-largest personal computer dealer, after Businessland, Compucom Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Computer Factory Inc., a financially troubled chain of computer retailers with headquarters in Elmsford, N.Y., for $4.50 a share, or $39 million over all.

title: Coniston in Shift On Stake in UAL
description: Coniston Partners, which for months allied itself with the efforts to sell the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, has sold a small portion of its UAL shares on the open market and distributed the remaining 2.3 million shares to its investors.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Applied Materials Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of products for the semiconductor industry, said it would reduce its work force by 250 to 300 people, or about 7 to 9 percent, and cut the salaries of executives by 10 percent. * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., a food products company, acquired B.E. Verduijn B.V., Breda, the Netherlands, a maker of confectionery items. Terms were not disclosed. * General Housewares Corp., Stamford, Conn., a maker of cookware products, said it would close its Minneapolis plant that houses some manufacturing processes and a distribution activity for the company's Chicago Cutlery line. * Home Insurance Co., a property and casualty company and unit of Ambase Corp., said it had completed the sale of Commonwealth Insurance Co., for $49 million to Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. of Canada. * Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc., Anaheim, Calif., a restaurant operator, said it plans to franchise 57 company-owned Carl's Jr. restaurants in Northern California in the next two years. * Midial, Cleveland, said it intends to sell its Gorrant Candies Inc., Boardman, Ohio, a local candy maker. Gorrant employs 100 full-time and 30 seasonal employees. * Scana Corp., Columbia, N.C., a diversified holding company, said it had an agreement with Tri-C Resources, Houston, an oil and gas company, to buy natural gas producing properties in Texas for $29 million. * Schering-Plough Corp, Madison, N.J., a pharmaeutical company, said Biogen Inc., Cambridge, Mass., had received complete European Patent Office approval for its genetiacally engineered alpha interferons. Schering markets Biogen's recombinant alpha-2 interferon under the brand name Intron A. Terms were not disclosed. * Steel Partners L.P. said it had made an offer to buy all of the common stock of Kinark Corp., Tulsa, Okla., a chemical storage concern, that it does not own for $6 a share. It requested a response from Kinark by Tuesday. * UGI Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., a utilities company, said its Amerigas unit had bought the Prudential Insurance Company of America's 49 percent equity interest in AP Propane Inc., a joint venture between Amerigas and Prudential, for $62 million.

title: Familiar End Despite Late Drama
description: The game between the Nets and the Detroit Pistons tonight was like a mystery novel in which the reader discovers who the murderer is in the opening chapter. There was certainly no suspense in the first half.

title: From Japan With Love
description: My friend the tube inspector thinks he has spotted a trend. While stationed at his tube the other morning checking the health of the Republic, he was startled to hear America being offered "a new and meaningful personal relationship" of an unusual kind.

title: A Case for No New Tummies: The Tax on Cosmetic Surgery
description: If nature did not provide you with a flat stomach, a wisp of a nose or big breasts, you may want to take note: there are only 45 shopping days left before the price goes up.

title: Charles J. Scanlon, 75, Retired G.M. Executive
description: Charles J. Scanlon, a former banking executive and financial officer for General Motors, died on Thursday at his home in Essex, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: Noriega Tells Judge He's at Mercy Of an 'Unfair and Unjust System'
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega lashed out at his accusers today, charging in a court hearing that he is a political prisoner "at the mercy of a totally unfair and unjust system."

title: Washington Talk; The Sniping Begins and All Is Normal
description: In the Reagan White House, arias of treachery echoed through the halls. Peggy Noonan, President Ronald Reagan's speechwriter, recalls walking down the West Wing corridors and hearing people shouting at one another behind closed doors. Officials fought about their tables in the White House mess, their seats on Air Force One, their access to free Presidential cuff links, the order of their cars in motorcades. No concern was too petty.

title: On Venus, Pancakes for Volcano Domes
description: New radar images from the Magellan spacecraft have given scientists more surprising views of the planet Venus, notably a huge plateau that appears to be collapsing of its own weight, dunes of dark windblown sand in the shape of giant horseshoes and an extensive row of volcanic domes as round and flat as pancakes.

title: Knicks Hope Success Rubs Off at Home
description: Had the Knicks beaten the Trail Blazers in Portland on Thursday night, their West Coast trip would have been perfect. As it was, the trip was productive.

title: KILLER OF 7 GETS PENALTY OF DEATH
description: A jury today sentenced a winery worker to die in the San Quentin gas chamber for the 1989 slayings of his wife, two of their children, three in-laws and his boss.

title: John J. Bauer, Football Coach, 67
description: John J. Bauer, a high school football coach whose teams set a state record for consecutive victories, died of heart failure on Wednesday. He was 67 years old.

title: Excerpts From Ethics Committee's Session on Five Senators
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of today's session of the Senate Ethics Committee's hearings into the conduct of five Senators in the Lincoln Savings and Loan affair. The Federal News Service, a transcription company, recorded the session.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about plans for budget cuts in New Jersey referred imprecisely in some copies to Gov. Jim Florio's position on layoffs of state workers. He said some of the state's more than 80,000 employees might be laid off.

title: Gideon Hausner, 75, Dies in Israel; Headed Prosecution of Eichmann
description: Gideon Hausner, who as Attorney General of Israel prosecuted the Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann nearly three decades ago, died on Thursday in Jerusalem. He was 75 years old.

title: Adolf Rudnicki Author, 78
description: Adolf Rudnicki, a leading Polish writer and essayist known for his complex characters and his depictions of Jews during the Holocaust, died on Wednesday in Warsaw, the Polish press agency reported. He was 78 years old.

title: 3 Men Are Shot At Reggae Club, Site of Slayings
description: Three men were shot early yesterday morning in Manhattan as they left a reggae nightclub, just 12 hours after the state moved to shut it down because three people had been killed there in the last two years, the authorities said.

title: Fruit of the Loom
description: A group of former employees and associates of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the defunct investment firm, have filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to complete the already-announced acquisition of 3.75 million class A shares of Fruit of the Loom Inc. from the company's chairman, William Farley. The group, Land Free Investment Ltd., includes Leon Black, the former co-head of mergers and acquisitions at Drexel. Land Free has agreed to acquire the shares, representing 7.5 percent of Fruit of the Loom's class A shares outstanding, for $43.1 million.

title: Urban Gift: Wilderness Regained
description: With a $6.3 million gift from a charitable foundation, New York City is opening up for recreation thousands of acres of urban wilderness in 21 locations around the city, many of them just a subway ride away from Times Square.

title: Novelist Savors Link to Broadway
description: "I was passing by the Booth Theater," Rosa Guy said the other day, "and 'Once on This Island' is up there on the marquee. I said, 'My God!' and then I thought, 'I deserve it.' " Ms. Guy, whose name rhymes with "key," is clearly enjoying the limelight that comes with being associated with a Broadway musical. But, she said, as a grandmother of five who confesses to being "well past 50" and who has written 15 novels and one play, she feels the recognition is long overdue.

title: Legislators Seek Laws to Aid Environment
description: Legislators from the United States, Europe and Japan announced plans today to introduce parallel legislation to deal with climate change, deforestation and other threats to the environment.

title: Trump, $47 Million Short, Gives Investors 50% of His Prize Casino
description: Donald J. Trump, whose sudden financial problems this year seemed a symbolic bookend for the free-spending 1980's, agreed yesterday to turn over half ownership of his crown jewel casino to its bondholders. On top of that, the flamboyant financier must take thecasino on a brief detour to bankruptcy court, and could eventually even lose control of it.

title: About New York; Recall Brando? The Wild One? Bet They Do, Too
description: Members of the Gotham City Riders motorcycle gang weren't pleased to see Ivana Trump on television saying she was the recipient of New York's first case of Beaujolais nouveau.

title: William Finch, 93; Held Many Patents In Radio Technology
description: William G. H. Finch, a radio engineer who in the late 1930's pioneered the development of facsimile transmission of printed matter and photographs, died on Monday at Martin Memorial Hospital in Stuart, Fla. He was 93 years old and lived in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: Sabatini Struggles; Graf Cruises
description: Perennial rivals and former doubles partners Steffi Graf and Gabriela Sabatini successfully negotiated the quarterfinal round of the $3 million Virginia Slims Championships last night, earning the familiar privilege of dueling each other at a critical point in a pivotal tournament.

title: Manley Decision Due
description: The National Football League commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, met with Dexter Manley, the Washington Redskins' defensive end, yesterday in New York and said he would announce Monday whether Manley would be reinstated from a drug suspension. Manley was banned for life last Nov. 18 as a three-time offender, but can appeal for reinstatement after one year.

title: Guidepost; Wines for the Holidays
description: Wine is the drink of moderation, and holiday time is the season to drink moderately. The wines here will carry you through the most elegant or the most informal holiday dinner. And as the approximate prices here show, most can be bought for no more than $12. Note also that two of the three main-course wines are reds. If turkey is your fare, consider serving a red: turkey is stronger-flavored than many red meats. APERITIFS CHAMPAGNE: Pol Roger Brut Reserve: medium-bodied, it won't be lost among strong-flavored delicacies; $21. FINO SHERRY: La Ina: pale as a chardonnay but with the lively assertiveness and rich, nutty flavor of a sherry; $12. WITH THE MAIN COURSE ZINFANDEL: Storybook Mountain, 1987: rich, lush, concentrated; $12. BEAUJOLAIS: Chateau de la Chaize, Brouilly, 1989: the greatest vintage since World War II; $8. RIESLING: Trimbach, Cuvee Frederic Emile, 1986: an Alsatian surprise for white-wine die-hards; $12. WITH DESSERT VINTAGE PORT: Dow's, 1983: a tradition, with cheese or sweets; $35. SAUTERNES: Chateau Rayne-Vigneau, 1979: perfect with ripe fresh fruit; $11.

title: A Bitter Pill for Trump and Maybe Another
description: For the first time, Donald Trump is being forced to hand over a share of his real estate empire to creditors. It could happen again next month.

title: Girl's Death Linked to Transplant Rejection
description: Stormie Jones, who was the first person to receive heart and liver transplants in a single operation, died of an unusual rejection of her transplanted heart, doctors said today.

title: Review/Theater; Uncertain Hero Who Juggles Three Women, Musically
description: Barbara Schottenfeld's previous musicals, "I Can't Keep Running in Place" and "Sit Down and Eat Before Our Love Gets Cold," were collage-style shows dealing principally with questions of feminism. Her new musical, "Catch Me if I Fall," continues the composer's fondness for conversational titles. But this time she has both a central story line and a male protagonist. Unfortunately, "Catch Me if I Fall" is decidedly lacking in character.

title: SURVEY SUGGESTS HESELTINE VICTORY
description: A survey of voter intentions published in The Times of London today, taken with a grain of salt by many politicians, predicts that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party would win the next national election if Michael Heseltine headed it.

title: 3 Bids for Mexico Phone Company
description: The Mexican Government said today that two multinational consortiums and one Mexican group had made formal bids to buy a controlling share in the national telephone company, Telefonos de Mexico. The bids set the stage for what promises to be one of the largest and most complex sales of a government-held enterprise attempted by any nation.

title: CONCEDING A CRISIS, GORBACHEV VOWS TO SHIFT LEADERS
description: Conceding that his country was paralyzed by political stalemate and sinking deeper into economic crisis, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today promised a shake-up of Government and military leaders to win back diminishing public support.

title: Northern Dancer, One of Racing's Great Sires, Is Dead
description: Northern Dancer, the thoroughbred who won the 1964 Kentucky Derby and Preakness and then became the dominant progenitor of his breed, was put to death yesterday at in Chesapeake City, Md., a day after his younger half first cousin, Alydar, was destroyed in Lexington, Ky.

title: Bridge
description: When Ely Culbertson was in his heyday in the 30's, he could call on a stable of talented bridge writers. In his office he could ambiguously shout "Al," and expect a response from Albert Morehead, Alphonse Moyse Jr., Alexander Sobel or Alfred Sheinwold. Since then, talented young American writers on the game have been few and far between.

title: The Peace Dividend, Unredeemed
description: For all their talk about saving money, President Bush and Congress are throwing away billions on defense. By shrinking from the task of canceling wasteful new weapons, they're canceling the entire peace dividend.

title: Hints on Carving Turkey
description: Doing a competent job of carving the Thanksgiving turkey takes the right kind of knife with a keen edge. You also need some notion of the bird's anatomy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER, 17, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Oil Prices Drop Below $30 a Barrel
description: A barrel of oil cost less than $30 yesterday for the first time in more than three weeks, as traders reacted to conciliatory talk from Saddam Hussein and to the beginning of President Bush's trip to Saudi Arabia.

title: Vintage Buys Violent Book Dropped by Simon & Schuster
description: Vintage Books yesterday acquired Bret Easton Ellis's "American Psycho," a novel that Simon & Schuster canceled this week, citing its brutality and violence.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the actress Eve Arden misstated the date of her film debut. It was in 1929, when she appeared under her original name, Eunice Quedens, in "The Song of Love"; it was not in 1937.

title: Bond Prices Climb After Fed Move
description: A belief that the Federal Reserve had begun to cut interest rates swept the credit markets yesterday and prices of long-term Treasury bonds moved sharply higher. But short-term Treasury issues, usually the first to reflect a significant change in interest rates, were essentially unchanged.

title: On Priestly Marriage in Eastern Rite Churches
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Bishop Volunteer, 82
description: Ruth Bishop, past president and a board member of the New York chapter of the United Nations Association, which promotes the United Nations, died on Wednesday at the home of her son Arthur Lipper 3d in White Plains. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dow Up 5.20, to 2,550.25, in Seesaw Session
description: The stock market seesawed in jagged fashion yesterday and finished higher despite a selloff of long-distance telephone issues and weakness in autos. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 5.20 points, at 2,550.25, for a gain of 61.64 points on the week.

title: Jewish Federations Endorse Bush's Policy in Gulf
description: A meeting of executives of American Jewish organizations backed the Bush Administration's policy in the Persian Gulf today but they put the President on notice that they would fight his plan to sell sophisticated arms to Saudi Arabia.

title: America's Youngest Professionals
description: Something is unraveling in our country.

title: Manville Trust Is Planning Executive Severance Pacts
description: The trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos poisoning is about to give its senior executives sizable severance packages, officials at the trust said today. The packages, they said, would include lump-sum payments of one and a half times the executives' annual salaries.

title: 'Salinastroika,' Si; Democracy, No
description: As evidence mounts of widespread fraud last Sunday in a key regional election in Mexico, new questions arise about the persistence of authoritarianism and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's commitment to democratization. It appears that, instead, he is committed to a police state.

title:
PALO ALTO JOURNAL;
Band's Marching Orders Are No More Encores
description: Given its checkered history of outrageous performances at college football games, it is difficult to pinpoint the most embarrassing moment of Stanford University's marching band.

title: Text of Noriega's Statement At Federal Court in Miami
description: Following is the text of a statement prepared for delivery yesterday by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in Federal District Court in Miami, as provided by his lawyers. A full transcript of his remarks as delivered, made in Spanish, was not available.

title: Yellowstone Rangers to Shoot Bison Leaving Park
description: Yellowstone National Park rangers, charged with protecting the park's animals, plan to begin shooting bison that leave the park this winter in search of food in Montana. Many bison carry brucellosis, a disease that causes cattle to abort their calves.

title: Don't Forget the East
description: The taxi driver who came to Berlin from West Germany in 1977 and hadn't known it before the wall was ecstatic. "Every day I'm more delighted at what a big, beautiful city it is," he said. "Lovely countryside all around, so much water. The Russians took the best part."

title: Review/Opera; Timeless Depravity in Met's New 'Salome'
description: In "Salome," Richard Strauss's music and Oscar Wilde's setting make promises to the listener that few performers are able to fulfill. One looks to the stage for life-threatening beauty, dancing feet, a soprano voice of Brunnhildean proportions and a level of psychosexual madness unprecedented in opera.

title: Four Senators Deny Doing Favors For Keating in Exchange for Cash
description: Four United States Senators forcefully defended their political integrity today, insisting to their peers on the Senate Ethics Committee that they had done no special favors for Charles H. Keating Jr., a savings and loan executive, in exchange for large campaign donations.

title: Pakistan Has Differences of Clans, Not Castes
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; A Serious New Look at a Dying Swan, Etc.
description: There was a pleasing warmth and informality to the Choreographers Showcase, presented by Evolving Arts last Sunday night and being repeated today and tomorrow at the handsome Dance Space studios (622 Broadway, at Houston Street).

title: Harry Nadler, Painter and Teacher, 60
description: Harry Nadler, a painter and the chairman of the art department at the University of New Mexico, died Wednesday at his home in Albuquerque. He was 60 years old and also had a home in Amagansett, L.I.

title: Stray Shot Kills Bronx Man As His Convalescence Ends
description: A 28-year-old Bronx man who spent the last year fighting to regain the use of his legs after a bout with meningitis was shot in the head and killed late Thursday night by a bullet meant for someone else, the police said.

title: Jacqueline Schwartzman, Community Leader, 71
description: Jacqueline Schwartzman, a community leader in the Chelsea section of Manhattan for many years, died on Thursday at her home in Chelsea. She was 71 years old.

title: Bonilla Frustrated
description: Bobby Bonilla said he won't sign another contract if the Pittsburgh Pirates let more free agents get away the way they allowed R. J. Reynolds to sign with a Japanese team.

title: In France, They Do Public Toilets With Style; Hang On Until '92
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Using the Tools of Logic In the Cause of Utopia
description: Selected Writings 1950-1990 By Irving Howe 490 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $34.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Dallas Ends Slump With Lakers

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: Paul Shyre Memorial
description: A memorial program for Paul Shyre, a playwright, director and actor who specialized in the works of Sean O'Casey, will be held at 2 P.M. Monday, the first anniversary of his death, at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street. It will be open to the public. Mr. Shyre died in Manhattan at the age of 63.

title: Miss Pirie Weds Thomas Harbeck
description: Virginia Nash Pirie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Pirie Jr. of Allendale, N.J., and Thomas Page Harbeck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene O. Harbeck Jr. of Grand Haven, Mich., were married yesterday by the Rev. Armen Hanjian at the First United Methodist Church in Montclair, N.J.

title: Pakistan Has Differences of Clans, Not Castes; Election in Shakargarh
description: To the Editor:

title: Bias Issue May Force Shift of 11 PGA Events
description: The PGA Tour could be forced to shift as many as 11 of its tournaments next year because of the refusal of private all-white clubs to comply with professional golf's new antidiscrimination policy, a tour official said yesterday.

title: Victorious India Leader Urges Austerity
description: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar tonight comfortably won a parliamentary vote of confidence in his six-day-old minority Government after a bitter eight-hour debate, and then called for austerity and greater economic self-reliance.

title: Derek Walcott to Read
description: The poet and teacher Derek Walcott will read from "Omeros," his new epic poem, at 6:30 P.M. Monday at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center. The poem was published last month by Farrar, Straus & Giroux . Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 239-6200.

title: 340 Held in Abortion Protests
description: About 340 protesters were arrested today at demonstrations outside abortion clinics, the police said. The protests, organized by the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, snarled morning traffic around two clinics near the downtown area. The police had to requisition several buses to take away the protesters, who were arrested for blocking entrances to the clinics.

title: Import Fall Narrows Trade Gap
description: Although the nation's bill for imported oil rose to the highest level in nine years, the American trade deficit narrowed slightly in September, the first full month after Iraq invaded Kuwait, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: William Herndon, 54, A Director and Actor
description: William E. Herndon, a director and actor on stage and television, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 54 years old. He died of AIDS, a spokesman for the family said.

title: Network Demands U.S. Return Data on Noriega
description: The Cable News Network today demanded that Federal officials return materials pertaining to the network's inquiry into the Government's case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Let Water From Faucets Run Until Cold to Get the Lead Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Pitfalls of an Anchorman
description: Two situations appalled me when I sat in the anchor chair. For one, there were those who would come up to me on the street and say:

title: Remainder Trusts For Charity Gifts
description: A STRADIVARIUS violin is to be auctioned Wednesday at Christie's in London, and if more than a few prayers are already being said about it, well, this is no ordinary auction. The proceeds are to serve two purposes: provide retirement funds for a New York businessman who bought it 35 years ago and make money available for social and human services through the UJA-Federation.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: U.S. Doubts That Kremlin Seeks Delay in U.N. Effort
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other American officials expressed doubt today that the Soviet Union wanted a fresh political initiative in the Persian Gulf before the United Nations authorized a military offensive against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Carter Urges Patience in Gulf
description: Former President Jimmy Carter praised President Bush's initial handling of the Persian Gulf crisis today, but urged him to show patience and avoid sacrificing American lives in a desert war. In a question-and-answer period with high school students, Mr. Carter said he rejected the arguments that jobs and oil were sufficient reasons to go to war. "I don't believe that those are the kinds of reasons for us to sacrifice human life in the desert of Saudi Arabia and Iraq," he said, and he urged Mr Bush to "wait it out and not launch a war." Mr. Carter was attending a conference at Hofstra University on his four-year Administration.

title: Palestinians' Support for Iraq Tempered by Kuwait Horrors
description: Thousands of Palestinians have fled Kuwait in the wake of the Iraqi invasion, and their stories of brutality have weakened Palestinian support for Saddam Hussein and produced a change in the political mood in Jordan.

title: INSIDE
description: Home, Sweet Niche?

title: Offering No Apologies, Cranston Faces Judges
description: Frail and drawn, Senator Alan Cranston entered the majestic Senate hearing room this afternoon, made his way to the desk reserved for him, sat down and faced six fellow Senators who will be both his judge and jury.

title: Agents Explain Why C.I.A. Planned for a Resistance in Europe
description: Retired and still active intelligence officers here sought today to place in perspective the "stay behind" program of armed resistance groups organized 40 years ago by the Central Intelligence Agency in Western Europe to fight on if the Soviet Union invaded and occupied their countries.

title: Shigeo Shingo, 81, Productivity Expert For Japan Industry
description: Shigeo Shingo, an industrial-management specialist who helped the Toyota Motor Company and other industrial concerns improve their production methods, died of cancer on Wednesday in Tokyo. He was 81 years old.

title: Leary Reported Close to Signing With Yanks
description: Faced with potentially devastating pitching problems, the Yankees were on the verge of reaching an agreement with Tim Leary on a new contract, one of the pitcher's friends said yesterday.

title: Emotions High During Seminar On Daily News
description: Three weeks after a bitter strike began at The Daily News, a top management spokesman sallied out yesterday for his first head-to-head, out-in-the-open debate with some of the strikers.

title: Dawkins Has Surgery
description: Johnny Dawkins, the injured point guard for the Philadelphia 76ers, underwent reconstruction surgery on his right knee yesterday, and the 76ers signed the free agent Jim Farmer, bringing the team's roster to 11 players.

title: Canucks Top Islanders, 3-2
description: Dave Capuano scored the game-winner in the second period and the goaltender Kirk McLean made the lead stand up in the third, leading the Vancouver Canucks to a 3-2 victory over the Islanders tonight.

title: PRAGUE TO APPEAL FOR AID FROM U.S.
description: As flags went up and a workman on Wenceslas Square painted over graffiti saying "Yankees, Get Out of Saudi Arabia," Czechoslovakia prepared today to mark the anniversary of the revolution that toppled Communism by presenting President Bush with an appeal for economic aid.

title: I.B.F. Sanctions Fight
description: The heavyweight title fight between Evander Holyfield and George Foreman on April 19 in Atlantic City will be sanctioned by the International Boxing Federation, on the condition that the winner must fight the top-ranked Mike Tyson or whoever is the No. 1 contender at the time by next Oct. 25.

title: Polish Leader Warns Rival on Unrest
description: With transit strikes under way in two cities and coal miners threatening to walk off their jobs, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has warned his chief rival in the Polish presidential elections, Lech Walesa, the Solidarity chairman, against seeking political advantage from the sudden surge in labor unrest.

title: Inconsistent Actions Seen in Case Of Boy Said to Be Victim of Abuse
description: New York City's welfare agency, acting in the case of an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy who was a suspected victim of child abuse, took two critical steps in opposite directions in November 1989, an official familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: Hers; Do as She Said, Not as She Did
description: THE FIRST TIME I heard the question it surprised me. The second and third time, I was uneasy, but after that, when it was asked wherever I spoke, no matter who the audience, I was deeply troubled.

title: On Staten I., New Use For Gracious Landmark
description: For almost 150 years, the winds from the Kill van Kull must have evoked memories of the violent seas for thousands of homeless sailors who took shelter at Sailors Snug Harbor, a self-contained community for retired seamen on Staten Island.

title: 'Not the Sort of Blokes I'd Have Chosen as Mates'
description: STONE ALONE The Story of a Rock 'n' Roll Band. By Bill Wyman with Ray Coleman. Illustrated. 594 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF PORGY AND BESS: The Story of an American Classic. By Hollis Alpert. (Knopf, $35.) "Porgy and Bess" was the result of a uniquely American ethnic mix: music by the son of a Russian-Jewish immigrant, George Gershwin; story by a white Southern aristocrat, DuBose Heyward; direction by an Armenian refugee, Rouben Mamoulian; and a story about the descendants of African slaves. As Hollis Alpert recounts in "The Life and Times of Porgy and Bess," Gershwin made a deliberate attempt to marry elements of jazz and blues to traditional European opera. The black performers in the 1935 production, most of them classically trained singers with advanced degrees, felt little kinship with the characters they portrayed. Some critics made fun of the opera's stylistic pretensions; Virgil Thompson called it "crooked folklore and halfway opera." Its racial attitudes and strange hybrid form -- something between a Broadway musical and grand opera -- would continue to attract criticism, but subsequent productions have validated the opera's stature. In this engrossing cultural history, illustrated by rarely-seen photos, Mr. Alpert takes us behind the curtain to an elegant evening at Gershwin's, on a tour of Charleston, S.C.'s slums to find the original Catfish Row, and through the exciting auditions and laborious rearrangement of scenes necessitated by each new production. Bringing to life the genius of a unique collaboration, Mr. Alpert, a film critic whose previous books include a biography of the Barrymores, invites us to witness the birth and development of an indigenous musical art.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Shankar and Glass: 'Passages' Ravi Shankar and Philip Glass. Private Music 2074-2-P; CD only.

title: Coaches Like Irish
description: IT has been ranked No. 1 by the nation's football coaches, so it should come as no surprise that Notre Dame dominates an all-America team selected by the 3,000 members of the American Football Coaches Association. A total of four Fighting Irish have been named to the team: Todd Lyght, a defensive back; Chris Zorich, a nose guard; Mike Stonebreaker, a linebacker, and Raghib (Rocket) Ismail, the wide receiver. Notre Dame's Orange Bowl opponent, Colorado, which has been ranked No. 2 in the United Press International coaches' poll, came in second with three selections: Joe Garten, an offensive guard; Alfred Williams, a defensive end, and Eric Bieniemy, the tailback. (AP)

title: New Obscenity Trial Is Denied
description: A record store owner convicted of obscenity for selling an album with sexually explicit lyrics by the rap group 2 Live Crew lost his bid for a new trial Friday. A jury convicted the owner, Charles Freeman, on Oct. 3 for selling the album "As Nasty as They Wanna Be." Mr. Freeman's lawyer, Bruce Rogow, argued Friday that he should be granted another trial because the judge had given the jury instructions that both defense lawyers and prosecutors had not agreed to. Mr. Rogow said he would appeal.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BIG TIME. By Phil Berger. (Dryad Press/Jefferson Street Press/Taylor Publishing, $15.95.) In the early 1950's, college basketball was shaken by a point-shaving scandal. One of the most talented players of the era was Columbia University's Jack Molinas, a brilliant man compelled to live life on the edge. Drafted by the Fort Wayne Pistons of the National Basketball Association, he played in only 29 games before being banished from the league for placing bets on his own team. Several years later, after becoming a lawyer, he was convicted for his role in another college point-fixing scheme. After his release from prison, Molinas drifted into some shady deals and was eventually shot to death as he and a girlfriend sunbathed in his backyard in the Hollywood Hills. It is upon the life of Jack Molinas that the sportswriter Phil Berger has based his latest novel. Jake Cardoza is a kid from the Bronx who uses his brains as well as his enormous athletic ability to hoist himself out of the slums. Unfortunately, he's got the obligatory tragic flaw: a need to circumvent the rules. While others get caught in a college point-shaving conspiracy of which he is a part, Cardoza lucks out and winds up in the N.B.A., playing for a fictional team called the Rockbridge Stars. Naturally, character equaling destiny, Cardoza soon succumbs to his baser instincts, and therein lies this tale. Mr. Berger, who reports on boxing for The New York Times, knows his subject well and goes to great lengths to give the reader a sense of his story's time and place. Sometimes, however, he tries too hard; the early parts of the novel, for example, are overloaded with brand names and landmarks, an excess of detail that becomes wearisome, even irritating. In addition, Mr. Berger has set a difficult task for himself by trying to weave a fictional story that's more interesting than the real one on which it is based. Although he makes a valiant effort, in the end he isn't quite up to it. Instead, "Big Time" serves to whet the appetite for a book on the genuine article, rather than a pale imitation.

title: Date Rape And a List At Brown
description: At the beginning of the school year, the Brown University library became a repository for information of a most unusual kind: on its bathroom walls women made a list of the male students who the women said had raped them.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Buying a Lot as a Trading-Up Strategy
description: ONE of the biggest fears people have in today's market is not being able to sell their house before closing on the one they have agreed to buy.

title: Q and A
description: M.C.I. Rent Increase Question: What are the sorts of major capital improvement expenses for which a rent-stabilized tenant can be charged? Would pointing, for example -- which it seems to me is maintenance rather than an improvement -- qualify? What about new plumbing or the cost of a lobby renovation? . . . Mary Watson, Manhattan Answer: It would depend on the extent of the work. According to the New York City Rent Stabilization Code, most work must be a new installation and not the repair of old equipment. New plumbing would qualify.

title: Strangers in a Strange Town
description: I'M a good traveler, not a great one -- say a 6 on a scale of 10. I pore over histories and guidebooks before taking a trip; pack sensibly and lightly; make a point of ordering the local specialties once there; try to actually see things, not photograph them, and know enough to select the proper vantage point -- be it cafe, park or fountain -- and, rather than chasing it, let a place come to me . Against that, I have the typical American's clumsiness with languages; am fussy about the hardness of hotel beds, and helpless in computing time zones, airline schedules and exchange rates.

title: When Businesses Decide to Flee
description: In a Forum article, "A Company Gives Up on New York" (Nov. 4), Stuart Meyers, a partner in a small family-owned business, wrote that after 20 years, he was moving his business out of New York. An unusually large number of letters were received in response.

title: The Executive Computer; More and More Portables, With More and More Power
description: THE personal computer industry is getting carried away these days, literally and figuratively. The flurry of new portable machines fall into two broad categories: smaller and more powerful, or larger and more exotic, and scores of them were on display last week at the annual Comdex/Fall computer trade show here. Manufacturers clearly expect portables to become standard equipment in businesses in the years ahead and many types of portables have emerged:

title: St. Petersburg
description: Long one of the country's most popular retirement spots, St. Petersburg, Fla., is attracting younger residents as it rides a wave of growth. Parks -- green year round -- flank the downtown, and the mild winter weather invigorates walkers and joggers. The older neighborhoods still sleep peacefully in the shade of towering oaks, but a crop of new towers has risen.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: SOUNDINGS;
The Checkered Life Of 'Sebastian'
description: "Sebastian" was the first of Gian Carlo Menotti's three ballet scores. Commissioned in 1944 for his short-lived Ballet International by the Chilean-born impresario the Marquis de Cuevas, "Sebastian" has had a checkered life on the stage. Over the years it has enlisted the interest of several distinguished choreographers, Agnes de Mille and John Butler among them. But as a ballet, "Sebastian" has pretty well fallen out of the repertory. Mr. Menotti's score, however, contains some of his loveliest music, including a Barcarolle that serves as a sort of idee fixe throughout.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: My wife and I have been to Switzerland some 10 times in recent years. Like most visitors, we agree that the country's hospitality and efficiency is legendary. However, this summer in Zermatt we saw another side of Switzerland.

title: Giants to Face Run-and-Shoot
description: The Detroit Lions present unique challenges for the Giants Sunday. The Lions do not have the grinding defense of the Philadelphia Eagles, whom the Giants will play the following Sunday, or the offensive finesse of the unbeaten San Francisco 49ers, whom the Giants will meet eight days later.

title: TALKING: Water; Improving Quality in A Building
description: CONSULTING engineers are finding that a growing number of high-rise New York City cooperatives and condominiums are failing to conduct the annual water tower inspections mandated by the city's Health Code -- an oversight that can prove hazardous in the long run, they say.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I propose carrying out an urgent, fundamental reorganization of executive power in the center by subordinating it to the President, directly to the President." -- President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ 1:6. ]

title: Nursing Home Chain Is Guilty
description: Beverly Enterprises Inc., the nation's largest chain of nursing homes, has been found guilty of unfair labor practices, and organized labor hailed the ruling as a major victory that could affect other big corporations.

title: Yonkers Moving Ahead On Its Waterfront Park
description: WITH financing secured for a long-awaited waterfront park and public boat-launching site, city officials here have declared the beginning of a turnaround for the city's rundown Hudson River waterfront.

title: L.I.R.R. Planning To Drop 60 Trains
description: THE Long Island Rail Road, beset by a budget gap of $27 million and a shrinking ridership attributed to "the unexpected depth of the recent downturn in our region's economy," is planning to cancel 60 trains a day and close Pennsylvania Station and the Flatbush Avenue terminal in Brooklyn from 1:30 A.M. to 4:30 A.M.

title: Hammer and Ice, Rappers Who Rule Pop
description: For at least four years now, rap has been proclaimed part of the mainstream, as singles and albums by Run-D.M.C., L.L. Cool J., the Beastie Boys and more recent hopefuls have pushed their way up the pop charts. But when Vanilla Ice bumped M. C. Hammer from the top of Billboard's pop album chart two weeks ago, it marked rap's biggest triumph yet.

title: Happiness Can't Be Pursued in Isolation
description: To the Editor:

title: Canucks Rely on Goalies
description: The Vancouver Canucks, hoping to ride consistent goaltending out of last place in the Smythe Division and into the Stanley Cup playoffs this season, got a strong effort from Kirk McLean on Friday night against the Islanders. McLean made two game-saving blocks in the third period in leading the Canucks to a 3-2 victory.

title: Leave It To Germans
description: To the Editor: Matthew Gurewitsch's article "Can a Woman Do a Man's Job in 'Winterreise'?" [ Oct. 28 ] missed the point about "Winterreise" and lieder singing. The winter's journey in Schubert's 24 songs is a dark journey of the soul. Anyone, man or woman, who has ever felt the gloom of Schubert's protagonist can easily relate to the despair of "Winterreise."

title: 'South Africa Now' Ponders Its Uncertain Future
description: Even for Danny Schechter, the whirlwind executive producer of "South Africa Now," it had been an unusually hectic week.

title: Heck's Angels
description: Fonda: "If God did not exist it would be necessary to invent him." Hopper: "That's a humdinger." -- "Easy Rider"

title: State Investigating Stony Brook Flood
description: IS a flood that turned a section of Route 25A in Stony Brook into a raging river, that caused cars to bang into one another, that tore up lawns and driveways and sent at least one person to the hospital the result of an "act of God" or of negligence?

title: For Dick Hyman, 88 Keys to Stardom
description: E VEN with all the other things Dick Hyman does these days -- composing movie scores, orchestral suites and concertos or running the 92d Street 'Y's Jazz in July Festival, to name just a few -- he still considers himself a "piano player."

title: Me, My Selves and I
description: YOU DON'T LOVE YOURSELF By Nathalie Sarraute. Translated by Barbara Wright in consultation with the author. 233 pp. New York: George Braziller. $17.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Agassi and Edberg Advance: After Andre Agassi lost a third-set tie breaker to Stefan Edberg in Frankfurt on Wednesday night, he said, "The next time I play Stefan I would -- as I'm sure he would -- go to the casino and put money on myself." As it happens, the rematch will be in Frankfurt today, when Edberg and Agassi will play for the Association of Tennis Professionals Tour World Championship. In the semifinals yesterday, Agassi beat Boris Becker, 6-2, 6-4, and Edberg defeated Ivan Lendl, 6-4, 6-2. Agassi, who has been polishing his serve ever since Pete Sampras taught him a lesson in the final of the United States Open in September, was master of today's match from start to finish. He wavered only momentarily, late in the second set, when Becker survived three match points. Becker saved the first one at 3-5, 30-40, and eventually won the game. He saved two more when Agassi was serving at 5-4, 40-15 and 40-30. At deuce, Becker's attempted drop volley failed to clear the net, and this time Agassi made good with a forehand winner. The Edberg-Lendl match was equally one-sided. After sealing the first set, Edberg immediately broke Lendl's serve in the first game of the second set. Golf U.S. Extends Lead: Beth Daniel and Betsy King defeated the European pair of Laura Davies and Alison Nicholas yesterday as the United States team extended its lead to 6-2 after two days in the Solheim Cup competition in Orlando, Fla. The American team, made up of the top players from the L.P.G.A. tour, needs two victories and a tie in the eight singles matches today to win the woman's inaugural equivalent of the Ryder Cup. The United States team won three of four matches at the Lake Nona Club after Daniel and King defeated Davies and Nicholas, 4 and 3, by making five birdies on the first six holes on the back nine. (AP) Mize Leads by Three Strokes: A controversial ruling gave the defending champion, Larry Mize, a three-shot lead yesterday after three rounds of the Dunlop Phoenix tournament in Miyazaki, Japan. Mize finished at 203 after a third-round 69, but he saw his lead rise from one shot to three when Larry Nelson fell out of second place after losing a 40-minute argument with rules officials over what he believed to be an imbedded ball. Nelson dropped back into third at 207 and left Naomichi Ozaki of Japan at 206 after a five-under-par 67. (AP) Soccer UConn and North Carolina in Final: Connecticut tied the game on a goal by Britton Arico with five seconds to go in regulation time, then won on penalty kicks, 4-3, in overtime yesterday, upsetting top-ranked Santa Clara, 2-1, in the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. women's Division I tournament in Chapel Hill, N.C. The loss was the first this season for Santa Clara, which won 18 times and tied once. In the final today, Connecticut (15-7-1) will face North Carolina at home. The sophomore strikers Rita Tower and Kristine Lilly scored second-half goals as the top-seeded Tar Heels (19-1-1) beat Colorado College, 2-1, in the other semifinal. The Tar Heels extended their home winning streak to 51 games. They will be seeking their ninth title in the last 10 years. Rutgers Tops Adelphi: Steve Rammel, Dave Mueller and Maurice Mazzocchi scored on penalty kicks during overtime and Rutgers eliminated Adelphi, 3-2, in the East Regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. Division I men's tournament yesterday in Piscataway, N.J. Rutgers (18-2-2) will next meet the winner of today's game between between Dartmouth and Columbia. Rutgers lost a 2-0 lead. Jeff Carstens got the first goal at 18:22 when his 65-yard shot bounced over the head of the Adelphi goalie, Chris Lowe. Mueller made it 2-0 at 25:05, knocking in a pass by Alexi Lalas. Peter Thompson headed in a pass from Yossi Cohen a minute later and Adelphi (14-6-1) tied the score at 42:08 when Chris Beach of Rutgers scored into his own goal while trying to clear the ball. (AP) Bowling Special Victory for Johnson: Jimmy Johnson won his first Professional Bowlers Association title yesterday with a 243-227 victory over Robert Lawrence in the stepladder finals of the Brunswick Memorial World Open in Chicago. The victory was special for Johnson in that his father, the P.B.A. Hall of Famer Don Johnson, won the first two Brunswick Memorial World Opens in 1972 and 1973. (AP)

title: Steady On For the Pound
Norrington Conducts
description: Roger Norrington is to conduct the London Classical Players in Beethoven's "Egmont" Overture and Fourth Symphony, and Schubert's Fourth Symphony at Avery Fisher Hall at 3 P.M. today. Tickets are $15 to $30. Information: 874-6770.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Allamuchy 189,000 Bountiful Drive 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; fireplace, pool, backyard; taxes $2,957. Jackson 131,900 East Burke Tavern Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old raised ranch; eat-in-kitchen, 2-acres, fireplace; taxes $2,700. Lakewood 86,900 1301 Paris Court 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 6-year-old townhouse; c/a, w/w carpeting, monthly maintenance $85; taxes $1,800. Oakland 165,000 73 Lakeshore Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; in-ground pool, lakefront property, fireplace; taxes $3,774. Waldwick 172,000 24 Grand Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; h/w floors, oversize garage, new furnace; taxes $2,792. Wyckoff 440,000 547 Chestnut Street 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; fireplace, deck, library, wine cellar; taxes $6,030. OTHER AREAS Westbrook, Conn. 137,000 28 Maple Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old raised ranch; deck off kitchen, office, on cul-de-sac, 0.67 acre; taxes $1,328. Bronxville, N.Y. 835,000 34 Ridgecroft Road 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 55-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, pantry, screened porch; taxes $12,130. Seaford, L.I. 225,000 4040 Meadow Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split level; new kitchen, den, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $5,000.

title: THE FRENCH AND MICKEY ROURKE
description: As one who hitchhiked through France a few years back, I find there is nothing quite so refreshing as a good read of an all-out "French bashing," particularly when the subject is relatively harmless, like French taste in American film ("Can 50 Million Frenchmen Be Wrong?" by Alessandra Stanley, Oct. 21).

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Compost. Compost. Compost. Pile everything -- leaves, frosted annuals, perennial tops, the final grass clippings, kitchen peelings, but do not include bones, animal fats or chicken skins because they attract rodents. Hardy Fuchsia

title: NOVELS YOU CAN SINK YOUR TEETH INTO
description: It is reassuring to learn from Susan Ferraro that the author Anne Rice -- whose literary preferences run to vampirism, "enthusiastic hard-core pornography," sadomasochism and necrophilia -- "radiates vulnerability," is afraid of the dark and avoids the slightest hint of decolletage. One shudders to think of the depths of gaudy depravity to which Rice might sink if not restrained by innate primness and delicacy. LOUIS JAY HERMAN New York, N.Y.

title: Anatomies of a Murderer
description: STALIN IN POWER The Revolution From Above, 1928-1941. By Robert C. Tucker. Illustrated. 707 pp New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95. STALIN The Glasnost Revelations. By Walter Laqueur. 382 pp. New York: A Robert Stewart Book/ Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95. STALIN'S WAR AGAINST THE JEWS The Doctors' Plot and the Soviet Solution. By Louis Rapoport. Illustrated. 318 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.95.

title: Amid Honors, Lots of Fun
description: The centennial of President Dwight D. Eisenhower's birth was celebrated Thursday at the Women's National Republican Club with a Patriots' Ball in the club's ballroom. Anne Eisenhower, a granddaughter of the President, accepted an award for James D. Robinson 3d, chairman of the Eisenhower Centennial Foundation.

title: Campus Life: Smith; Parking Fines Help to Swell Scholarship Fund
description: Parking is proving profitable for Smith College's scholarship fund. Fines from campus parking tickets alone added $38,000 to the college's financial-aid program last year, according to Charles Johnson, the college's acting treasurer. It was the largest amount contributed since the college starting adding the fines to the scholarship fund three years ago, he said.

title: The Plight Of the Session Player
description: Mark Murphy's new album was just about finished, and Larry Fallon, a New York-based producer-arranger, had booked a studio to sweeten four of the jazz singer's tracks with incidental music. Strings, horns and voices were once used to enhance records, but on this day Mr. Fallon hired only one musician, Jon Cobert, a freelance keyboardist.

title: Football Dreams
description: THE BEST THERE EVER WAS

title: At the Hartford Stage, 'Marvin's Room'
description: ASK Scott McPherson why people laugh during his play "Marvin's Room," which concerns illness -- lingering and terminal, physical and mental -- as well as such incidental details as drowning, child abuse, arson and overall desperation, and he briskly answers, "Why not?"

title: Helth Plan for Poor: Varied Assessments
description: MOTHERS with young children crowded the lobby of the Middlesex County Board of Social Services here on a recent Friday, waiting to find out why their welfare checks or food stamps were late.
