It presented a perfect opportunity for Connie Mills, a recruiter for the Garden State Health Plan, a state-run health maintenance organization for low-income families. Again and again, she introduced herself and touted the main selling point of Garden State: a personal family doctor.

title: Tracey Roberts Weds Paul J. Haigney
description: Tracey Elizabeth Roberts, a daughter of Joanne Van Wart Roberts of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and John A. Roberts Jr. of New York, was married yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough, N.Y., to Paul Joseph Haigney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Haigney of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Hillary R. Bercovici performed the ceremony.

title: NOVELS YOU CAN SINK YOUR TEETH INTO
description: Ferraro says Rice's characters are "compulsive sinners, filled with self-loathing." I disagree. Rather, they are explorers filled with questions of identity. What are we? What elements define us: where or when we live? our blood? race? gender? what or whom we eat? Given the choice, would we choose differently? Would we choose to be mortal? Would we choose to be powerless? EMILY ROSENTHAL New York, N.Y.

title: A Novelist Finds The Bare Bones Of a Play
description: ADAPTING FICTION FOR THE stage is an extremely difficult task, though it's hard to say why. The written word and the spoken word are both words -- aren't they?

title: Woman Is Sentenced to Death in Poisoning
description: A woman suspected of at least three slayings was sentenced to death Friday for killing a former boyfriend by spoon-feeding him arsenic-laced food while he lay in a hospital bed four years ago.

title: Campus Life: Bryn Mawr;   New-Age 'Hamlet': Mobile Audience and a 1964 Ford
description: A moving production of Shakespeare's "Hamlet" was offered last week by the Bryn Mawr and Hayerford Colleges' theater department. Only it was the audience that was doing the moving.

title: State View on Breast Cancer Upsets Patients
description: PEOPLE with breast cancer and their support groups might have been expected to be relieved when the state's top official epidemiologist said contaminated wells and hazardous-waste sites were not linked to the incidence of the disease on Long Island.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Midwest; Strong Second Half Saves the Wolverines
description: Elvis Grbac threw three touchdown passes today as Michigan beat Minnesota, 35-18, in a Big Ten Conference game. Michigan (7-3 over all and 5-2 in the Big Ten) overcame a 10-7 halftime deficit with two touchdowns in the third quarter. Minnesota (5-5, 4-3) gave up two interceptions, both of which led to touchdowns.

title: Gettysburg: The Battle Still Beckons
description: MANY of the soldiers who survived the Battle of Gettysburg considered that experience the biggest event in their lives. They never tired of trooping back to the Pennsylvania town in later years for reunions. Modern Americans have likewise sensed the magnitude of what took place at Gettysburg on July 1 to 3, 1863, and maintained a steady stream of visitors. As a consequence, tourism has been a significant element of the town's life for more than a century.

title: Van Dyck: 350 Years Of Playing Second Fiddle
description: It's tough to feel pity for Anthony Van Dyck, an artist gifted by the age of 14 with skills that few painters develop in a lifetime. By his early 20's he had launched himself on a career that was to bring major commissions from some of the grandest of the European aristocracy and royalty, above all the king of England, Charles I, an avid collector and no slouch at separating artistic winners from losers.

title: Students Must Bear Weight of Education
description: THE trend in dealing with current abuses or potential problems in intercollegiate athletics is to pass legislation, and establish a rule or regulation to prevent the wicked from doing wrong. In this time when everyone from the National Collegiate Athletic Association to the United States Congress is attempting to legislate morality on the college campus, we must recognize that the essential issue is one of responsibility.

title: Review/Music; New Early-Music Ensemble
description: Like an engine-cleaning lubricant, the music of Vivaldi presumably oils musicians' gears and soothes their grating souls. It is hard to think why otherwise an all-star early-music group like the Ensemble les Nations, which made its New York debut early Tuesday evening at the Frick Collection, would devote an entire program to eight concertos and trio sonatas by that composer. Even with some subtly varied selections and playing that at times rose to distinction, the concert bogged down in bright, chirpy sameness.

title: Police in Middle, on Overtime, in the News Strike
description: Among the many points of contention in the 25-day-old strike by Daily News workers is the proper role of the New York City Police Department and the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins. Management and labor at the paper agree that the city should preserve safety, but their ideas of what that means diverge.

title: POSTINGS: $7.5 Million :Project; Facelift for G.M.
description: One of Manhattan's most prominent office structures, the General Motors Building at 767 Fifth Avenue, is undergoing a major facelift. The entire facade of the building, which takes up the block bounded by Fifth and Madison Avenues and 58th and 59th Streets, will have its windows recaulked and about 400 of the 43,000 marble slabs that sheath its exterior replaced.

title: Gordievsky's People
description: KGB The Inside Story of Its Foreign Operations From Lenin to Gorbachev. By Christopher Andrew and Oleg Gordievsky. Illustrated. 776 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $29.95.

title: Shrinking Returns For Bush's Journeys?
description: SOMETIMES, President Bush's cadence seems a bit off.

title: Violent Desires
description: NEAR CHANGES By Mona Van Duyn. 69 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. V. And Other Poems. By Tony Harrison. 86 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95. THE WANT BONE By Robert Pinsky. 70 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $17.95.

title: Insurers Press Use of Cheaper Drugs
description: Health insurers, which used to pay for prescription drugs with little attention to price, are increasingly influencing Americans' choice of medicines. Trying to curb drug costs, the fastest-growing expense in many health plans, they are offering financial incentives to people who select a lower-price version of a medicine when a choice is available.

title:
National Notebook: Cumberland, Me.;
A Town Center For Crossroads
description: A PUBLIC PLANNER, a landscape architect and a developer want to create what this bedroom community of 6,800 residents a dozen miles north of Portland, Maine's largest city, never had before -- a town center.

title: Corrections
description: A short pop review on Oct. 21 about a recording by the group INXS misstated the number of members in the band and the number of albums it has released. INXS is a six-member group and has released seven albums.

title: England
description: To the Editor: "London's Literary Village" (Travel, Sept. 30) informs the traveler about many homes of literary stars, but does not mention one of the most interesting small museums in the area of Hampstead.

title: Ridley Scott Tries to Make It Personal
description: The temperature is edging into the 90's at the Vagabond Inn, a dreary ill-kempt sandstone motel where the poolside room truly stretches the concept. Inside the room, whose designer must have been mired in a turquoise period, the actress Susan Sarandon has collapsed on the floor in tears. The air is stale and stagnant, an oppressive blend of heat and cigarette smoke. An already impatient Geena Davis snaps, yelling sharply at Ms. Sarandon to pull herself together.

title: Review/Theater; Nostalgic Yiddish Musical
description: It speaks Yiddish only, but the Folksbiene Theater is the oldest continuing theatrical company in New York, in any language. The Folksbiene, even when it does comedy, as in its new 75th-anniversary production, a musical called "Father's Inheritance," has always been serious about its undertakings; after all, its first production, in 1915, was a Yiddish version of Ibsen's "Enemy of the People."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-23

title: Style Makers;   Pearl Johnson and Howard Hines, Musical Sign Interpreters
description: When Pearl Johnson and Howard Hines make theatrical appearances, they often unintentionally upstage the actors or musicians. They have even managed to divert the audience's attention from so compelling a speaker as Nelson Mandela. All this by just waving their fingers, plus some expressive body language.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MICKEY'S MILESTONE

title:
The Executive Life;
With This Headhunter, $10K Defines a Spouse
description: "A LOT of executives don't have time for a personal life," said Robert M. Davis, an executive recruiter in Philadelphia. "Executives are also picky about relationships. They want people from the same background as themselves."

title: The World; At the Businesses Owned by Beijing, The Ink Is Red
description: A UNIVERSAL joke in socialist countries is that employment in state-owned companies is a matter of make-believe: "We pretend to work, and they pretend to pay us." In China, this game is carried to extremes. Employees in state-owned companies receive only about $30 a month, and some quip that they don't even deserve that much, what with late arrivals, tea breaks, lunch breaks and early departures.

title: SoHo on the Danube: An Artist's Village
description: IN Hungary, SoHo is west of the Danube. It is the small town of Szentendre, less than an hour from Budapest by ferry, train or taxi. Its meandering cobblestone streets and steep alleyways lead to over a dozen museums and galleries revealing the scope of 20th-century Hungarian art.

title: Review/Music; Finnish Baritone in Debut
description: Jaakko Kortekangas, the 29-year-old Finnish baritone who sang his first New York recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday, finds himself in the enviable position of having half-grown talents and plenty of time left in which to develop them.

title: Talene L. Arslanyan and Richard Rosen Are Wed
description: Talene Lee Arslanyan, a daughter of Lucy and Vahram Arslanyan of New York, was married last evening in Huntington, L.I., to Richard Scott Rosen, a son of Rhoda and Seymour Rosen of Little Neck, Queens. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Karnig Halajian of the Armenian Apostolic Church of America officiated at the Huntingtown Towne House.

title: The '91 Budget's Impact on Homeowners
description: THE nation's 1991 deficit-reduction package will make real estate a slightly less attractive tax shelter for the most affluent families while continuing incentives for low-income housing, according to accountants and tax experts.

title: Birds Behind Bars (and Some Are Real)
description: IN the last 15 years, the painter Hunt Slonem has had no fewer than 54 shows. The galleries range from one in Madras, at Grindley's, a bank founded by the British raj, perhaps the East India Company itself, to several in Manhattan.

title: A Nuclear Repository Or a Possible Disaster
description: After a decades-long, multi-billion dollar search the Government has chosen Yucca Mountain in Nevada as a possible repository for the nation's most lethal nuclear refuse.

title: Ideas & Trends; California Tried Democracy, And Look What's Happened Now
description: HERE in the land of new beginnings, what might be called the end of politics has begun.

title: Correction
description: The Dining Out column on Oct. 14 about the Nantucket Cafe in New Canaan misstated the price range of dinner entrees. It is $13.95 to $19.95. The error was reported to The Times soon after the column was published, but the correction was delayed through an editing error.

title: Mark Berlinsky to Wed Tracy M. Stolls in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Stolls of Bethpage, L.I., have made known May wedding plans for their daughter, Tracy Marlene Stolls, and Mark Jonathan Berlinsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Berlinsky of East Windsor, N.J.

title: On the Street; A Jacket Designed To Adapt
description: When it comes to clothes, the Italians have a lot of good ideas. One of the latest is a soft, roomy, quilted outerwear jacket that is ideal for these late fall days that can't quite decide whether to be cold or mild. With its corduroy collar, large patch pockets and snap-button front, the knuckle-length jacket is neither too dressy nor too sporty, and its boxy shape allows it to fit comfortably over a suit jacket. The most popular version is cotton poplin over a thin layer of insulated quilting (the jacket is also available in wool and suede). Its light weight makes it a boon for travelers. In fact, many of those seen wearing it along Fifth Avenue this week were tourists or businessmen from Italy. One of them reported that the jacket, which comes in olive, khaki and navy blue, has become something of a status symbol in his country. Very soon it may be a fad here.

title: Off to Good Start, Ewing Is Aiming Higher
description: WHEN the Knicks' locker-room door opened after the game on Thursday night in Portland, Ore., Patrick Ewing braced himself for the inevitable group of reporters waiting. He had ice bags on both knees, a few scars on his body, but fewer concerns about the Knicks on his mind.

title: Reviews/Music; Gospel's March To Ecstasy
description: "Black Gospel Styles" at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday night wandered along amiably until the arrival of the McCollough Sons of Thunder Brass Band, the final act. Made up of 15 trombones, a trumpet, a tuba and three percussionists, the group, based on 125th Street, had one thing in mind: to get ecstasy rolling in the aisles.

title: THE FRENCH AND MICKEY ROURKE
description: The French are right about Michael Cimino's epic, "Heaven's Gate." That film was never given a chance by American audiences or critics (it required patience and a willingness to follow it on its own terms).

title: Autobahn Alert
description: To the Editor: I thought I'd pass along a word of warning to travelers on German autobahns. My wife and I were en route to France on the Munich-Stuttgart Autobahn, when we were pulled over by a police officer on a motorcycle. He informed us that we were speeding. When I mentioned the number of other cars doing at least twice our speed, he threatened to have us put in jail. He demanded 75 marks (about $48); I said I had no marks. He said dollars or any European currency would suffice. Saying we only had traveler's checks didn't help. He took my passport and told me to follow him to a bank about five miles off the autobahn, where he and the bank teller had a grand time recounting what appeared to be his latest conquest. The policeman took the 75 marks. No ticket, no receipt.

title: Knicks Are Quick In Dismantling 76ers
description: The new unselfish Knicks, born on the West Coast trip where they posted a 3-1 record, opened a four-game homestand by overwhelming the Philadelphia 76ers, the defending Atlantic Division champion, 106-79, last night.

title: A Novel Fund-Raising Concept
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gulf Isn't the Only Crisis
description: Since Aug. 2, our attention to events beyond our borders has been confined largely to the Iraqi aggression in the Persian Gulf. In recent days, our preoccupation with Iraq has been magnified by the debate that was triggered by President Bush's announcement of new U.S. military deployments to the region.

title: Miss Macaulay Wed at Columbia
description: Morenike Abiodun Macaulay, the daughter of Josephine C. Macaulay of New York and the late Milton A. Macaulay, was married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University to Lenel Hickson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hickson of Washington. The Rev. Lewis Anthony, a minister of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, performed the ceremony.

title:
National Notebook: Delray Beach, Fla.;
Rebuilding Downtown
description: THREE years after a local hair stylist rallied his neighbors with a vision of a thriving arts community in what was then a decaying downtown neighborhood, this Atlantic coast city about 50 miles north of Miami is benefiting from both public and private investment.

title: Offshoot of the Bolshoi To Dance 'Nutcracker'
description: The Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company will perform "The Nutcracker" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Dec. 19 to 30. The engagement marks the New York debut of the new company, which was formed this year by Yuri Grigorovich, director of the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow. It includes dancers from the senior troupe and young dancers from the Bolshoi Academy and other leading Soviet ballet schools.

title: S. & L. Crisis Muddies Market Outlook
description: THE fallout of the savings and loan bailout, only beginning to be felt in the housing markets of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, will become more evident next year as Federal regulators hasten their efforts to sell single-family homes, co-ops and condominiums that have been seized from failed lending institutions.

title: Trying to 'Close the Loop' on Recycling
description: ANDREW N. BENSON looked into his backyard a year ago and saw the future. Lurking in the malodorous contents of his trash cans were, he believed, the makings of products that would be useful to people and kind to the environment.

title: Elway to Help Reeves
description: THE team is 3-6 and the quarterback has publicly expressed his displeasure with the coach's offense. So now John Elway will get a chance to share the blame; he will help Coach Dan Reeves develop the Denver Broncos' game plan.

title: 'The Trump Castle,' a Novel
description: Pocket Books is gambling an estimated $3 million or so on two novels that it will publish with Ivana Trump's name on them as author. -- The New York Times, Oct. 15, "Who are you?" asked K.; and disdainfully -- whether contemptuous of K. or of her own answer was not clear -- she replied: "A girl from the Castle." -- "The Castle" by Franz Kafka Chapter One

title: Homeless Man Killed by Gang Is Remembered
description: At a rousing gospel memorial service held yesterday in a parking lot on Wards Island, a homeless man who was killed in a violent Halloween rampage was remembered as a loving person who struggled with alcoholism and drug addiction.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Just about a year ago, I stripped a number of layers of paint off the paneled front door of my house. The wood looked so handsome, however, that I decided to repaint only the exterior of the door, leaving the inside natural and simply wiping it down with lemon oil. Last winter, the door warped severely. It straightened in the summer, and I gave it two coats of clear varnish on the inside to seal the wood. Will this help to solve the warping?

title: Topics of the Times; A Voice From the Wilderness
description: For several years a New Yorker employed by a big company has been aware that her office telephone number is similar to that of a law firm, city agency or charitable institution. One call in five is from someone who says "I want the lawyer." The lawyer is never named.

title: AN AGE-OLD QUESTION
description: I offer this alternative model of female aging to Susan Jacoby (Hers: "An Age-Old Question," Oct. 21).

title: The Fish of His Dreams
description: MY dream of many years, to catch a big striped bass on a fly in the surf, wasn't even on the agenda when we headed for East Hampton, L.I. Jim Clark, a local teacher, outdoorsman and builder of large and intricate doll houses, had invited me on his 23-foot Mako for an excursion to some of the more productive tidal rips between Three Mile Harbor and Montauk. But a relentless and disheartening northeast wind of near gale force sent us to the South Beaches, where the high dunes gave us a protected area for fly casting.

title: Against Zionism
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Nov. 3 MANHATTAN Chelsea 312,000 121 West 17th Street 1,400-sq.-ft. open loft co-op; part-time doorman, elevator, 11 windows, oak-strip floors; maintenance $654, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Herbert H. Kleigerman Associates/ Corcoran Group) Greenwich Village 256,350 14 Horatio Street (Van Gogh) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 950-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, terrace, roof garden; maintenance $1,024, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Halstead Property Co.) TriBeCa 417,000 16 Hudson Street 1,975-sq.-ft. open loft co-op; 2 baths; 11-ft. ceilings, new windows, track lighting, remodeled kitchen and baths; maintenance $947, 65% tax-deductible (Broker: Joffee LaSalle/J.I. Sopher Co.) Upper East Side 1.65 million 156 East 62d Street 5-bedroom, 5 1/2-bath, single-family, 5-story brownstone; dining room, 2 fireplaces, library, central air-conditioning, artist studio, original moldings and details, wine cellar, south garden; 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $17,550 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Upper East Side 550,000 1000 Park Avenue (83d St.) 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, maid's room; maintenance $1,700, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: David Day Realty) BRONX Clason Point 200,000 475 Commonwealth Avenue 2-family, semi-attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining room, eat-in kitchen in each unit; hospitality suite in finished basement; 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,500 (Broker: ERA/Marland Real Estate) Riverdale 107,000 3215 Netherland Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; large living room; maintenance $543, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) BROOKLYN Brooklyn Heights 260,000 62 Montague Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. co-op in a renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, fireplace, view of the Manhattan skyline; maintenance $759, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Montague Realty) Ditmas Park 295,000 744 Rugby Road 7-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, detached, frame house; dining room, parquet floors, stained-glass windows, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,800 (Broker: Jacob Gold Realty) Park Slope 770,000 47 Montgomery Place 4-bedroom, 6-bath, 5-story, single-family house; dining room, elevator, 6 fireplaces, billiard room, central air-conditioning, stained-glass windows, oak floors, 25- by 89-ft. lot; taxes $3,600 (Broker: F.J. Kazeroid Realty Group) QUEENS Forest Hills Gardens 470,000 47 Markwood Road 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, brick house; dining room, fireplace, solarium, 1-car garage, 60- by 60-ft. lot; taxes $2,100 (Broker: Madeleine Realty) Kew Gardens 600,000 115-18 Mayfair Road 6-bedroom, 5-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, breakfast room, study, central air-conditioning, 2 fireplaces, wine cellar, 60- by 200-ft. lot; taxes $3,335 (Broker: Century 21/F.H. Realty) STATEN ISLAND Lower Todt Hill 210,000 44 Ocean Terrace 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, fireplace, 1-car garage, 42- by 107-ft. lot; taxes $2,092 (Broker: Salmon Real Estate) West Brighton 330,000 21 St. Austin's Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, library, spiral staircase, rear deck, 1-car garage, 100- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,600 (Broker: Otto Vitale Real Estate/Rand Properties)

title: Headliners; Having a Seat
description: For some Federal judicial nominees there might as well be a sign posted: 100 Senators -- No Waiting. One such is Dennis Shedd, whose nomination for a Federal District Court seat in South Carolina was rushed through in the final days before Congress adjourned despite Mr. Shedd's relative lack of trial experience and over the objections of some liberal lobbyists. In one of his cases Mr. Shedd defended a South Carolina county government in a voting rights suit brought by, and eventually settled in favor of, a civil rights group. His confirmation in Washington, a process that can take months, took barely a week. Mr. Shedd had no comment on the matter, but it clearly helped that he happened to be a former longtime aide to Senator Strom Thurmond, the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee. A member of the committee staff said it was evident that Mr. Shedd would have been confirmed easily in February and that "it was a courtesy to Mr. Thurmond to act on it now."

title: Darmakusuma Ie, Ophthalmologist, Weds Ms. Greenberg, a Social Worker
description: Elizabeth Rachel Greenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua F. Greenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Dr. Darmakusuma Ie, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Njoek San Ie of Plantation, Fla. Justice Martin H. Rettinger of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill.

title: A Turnaround for Dartmouth
description: Princeton outgained Dartmouth by 138 yards to 18 in passing yardage today, but the Big Green thoroughly outplayed the Tigers in posting a 23-6 victory to gain a share of the Ivy League championship with Cornell.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on page 33 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the public television series "South Africa Now" reports that WGBH, the public station in Boston, recently announced plans to drop the program. On Thursday, after the section went to press, the station reversed its decision. The series will resume on its UHF channel, WGBX, (Channel 44), starting tonight at 11.

title: Carol Goldstein Is Wed To Robert Alan Raskin
description: Carol Sue Goldstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goldstein of North Miami Beach, Fla., and Robert Alan Raskin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Raskin of Huntington, L.I., were married last evening at Temple Beth Shalom in Hollywood, Fla. Rabbi Morton Malavsky officiated.

title: 29 Fraternities Are Subpoenaed in Hazing Inquiry
description: A Travis County grand jury has issued subpoenas to 29 fraternities at the University of Texas to obtain names, photographs and other information about every member and every new pledge after a succession of hazing incidents, assaults and other crimes were reported in recent months.

title: Review/Music; Brubaker Piano Recital
description: One of the most appealing attributes of Bruce Brubaker's piano playing on Monday evening was his ability to create an impression of extreme clarity, even when the music's chromaticism or his own penchant for heavy pedaling should logically have made for a cloudier sound.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WESTPORT;
Customers and Complaints Mingle on Trendy Main Street
description: WILLIAM CRIBARI sipped coffee in the Westport Pizzeria, stared out onto Main Street and reminisced about a town that no longer existed. The 70-year-old special officer for the Westport police said his was a Main Street that had a huge fountain in the center; Papa George's Diner, where he could order a thick hamburger; Bill's Smoke Shop for a good cigar. From his boyhood, he said, Main Street was the place where a small-town allegiance was forged.

title: Government to Assist Soldiers' Overseas Offspring
description: Tentatively settling a two-year-old lawsuit, the Government has agreed to help the overseas offspring of American soldiers get in touch with their natural fathers.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Just about a year ago, I stripped a number of layers of paint off the paneled front door of my house. The wood looked so handsome, however, that I decided to repaint only the exterior of the door, leaving the inside natural and simply wiping it down with lemon oil. Last winter, the door warped severely. It straightened in the summer, and I gave it two coats of clear varnish on the inside to seal the wood. Will this help to solve the warping?

title: Lori Kopf Weds David E. MacWilliam
description: Lori Kopf and David Edwin MacWilliam were married yesterday at Christ Lutheran Church in New York by the Rev. Robert Wurdeman. Mrs. MacWilliam is the daughter of Ruth Kopf of Westerleigh, S.I., and the late Phil Kopf. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin MacWilliam of Deltona, Fla.

title: Credit Card Calls From Pay Phones
description: In response to the recent article "State Looking at Pay Phone Charges": Every working day, I make at least one or two credit card calls from pay phones that are or appear to be New Jersey Bell phones. In addition to the caveats given, I offer the following:

title: Breaking Away From Tradition
description: GEORGE MIKAN chuckled when asked recently what would have happened to a 6-foot-10-inch player of his day who launched a set shot during a game or, worse yet, attempted to break a press or create his own shot by dribbling the ball.

title: Kim Leinwand, Student, to Wed
description: Kim Hayley Leinwand and Dr. Steven Robert Erle plan to marry in December.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
An Excuse to Stare
description: "The camera was the armor I needed, it shielded my timidity, gave me an excuse to stare. . . . Everywhere I go I carry these lead weights, my cameras. Maybe I'd float without anchors," writes Sylvia Plachy in her introduction to a collection of her photographs, SYLVIA PLACHY'S UNGUIDED TOUR (Aperture, $39.95). Ms. Plachy, a longtime staff photographer at The Village Voice, at her best displays wit, irony, innocence and just the right amount of gravity -- for example, her shots of polar bears diving in a New York City zoo, or of an elderly couple, looking forever young, blowing soap bubbles in the back seat of a car. Her fine portraits include a shot of a debauched-looking Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the film director; another conveying the mischief and magic of the singer Tom Waits, and a touching photograph of the great photographer Andre Kertesz. There are many images of Hungary, Ms. Plachy's homeland; perhaps the most resonant depicts two soldiers dancing in the street. And three photographs -- of a statue in Montparnasse Cemetery, of the dancer Mary Overlie and of a naked child playing in a Nicaraguan courtyard -- form a strikingly beautiful meditation on the human figure. "When you are smuggled out of a Stalinist country in the bottom of a farm cart, covered with corn, at age thirteen, you have the sense that the worst has already happened," Guy Trebay, a senior editor at The Voice, writes in an afterword. "The important thing is to get the shot." This book is evidence that Sylvia Plachy is an indefatigable, gifted and compassionate chronicler.

title: Children's Books: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Learning The Trials Of Disabled
description: MUNICIPAL officials and merchants in Paterson recently abandoned their offices and stores to partake in some childlike activity: a Saturday afternoon scavenger hunt.

title: World Markets; Gold: No Longer the Sure Thing
description: THE dollar is falling. American banks are in trouble. In the Persian Gulf, a war seems as likely as a debilitating standoff. And gold, the usually perfect play in such circumstances, is going nowhere.

title: Topics of the Times; Sweeping Change
description: This weekend marks the first Big Sweep, a volunteer street and sidewalk cleaning program sponsored by New York Pride and a host of other civic organizations. The sponsors are asking owners and occupants of New York buildings to take responsibility for cleaning sidewalks and streets in front of the premises in which they live and work. And citizens with energy to spare are encouraged to clean eight hitherto neglected target areas whose locations can be learned by phoning (212) 967-7433.

title: Wall Street; One Muni Fund's Dismal Days
description: SOME mutual funds are born troubled. Others become troubled through their own efforts. And still others have trouble thrust upon them. But the best explanation for the mess brewing at the New York Muni Fund, with $230 million in assets, would seem to be "all of the above."

title: A Thanksgiving Celebration Of the Communal Spirit
description: THE new sanctuary of the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church here will be the setting Thursday for an ecumenical service and the community is invited. The Rev. Robert S. MacLennan, senior minister of the church, promises a "very simple public Thanksgiving for all Americans of all types."

title: Ms. Briggs Weds Donald Kitchen
description: Susan Curtis Briggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Briggs of Naples, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rochester to Donald Montgomery Kitchen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Kitchen Jr. of Pittsford, N.Y. The Rev. Robert M. Wainwright performed the ceremony.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Just about a year ago, I stripped a number of layers of paint off the paneled front door of my house. The wood looked so handsome, however, that I decided to repaint only the exterior of the door, leaving the inside natural and simply wiping it down with lemon oil. Last winter, the door warped severely. It straightened in the summer, and I gave it two coats of clear varnish on the inside to seal the wood. Will this help to solve the warping?

title: Twomey Opposed On Shoreham Plan
description: This is in answer to and in opposition to the "production" by Thomas A. Twomey Jr., "Start Converting Shoreham to Gas" [ Oct. 21 ] .

title:
DINING OUT;
Familiar Italian Fare in Mamaroneck
description: WE remember Enzo's in its early days. Then it was one of the new wave Italian restaurants, offering mostly hearty, thoughtful Italian dishes several notches above the mushy spaghetti with tomato sauce and everything else in the style parmigiana that most pasta parlors dished up. With its interesting pasta and chicken dishes in particular -- full of spark and spontaneity -- the kitchen at Enzo's promised exciting renditions that have not quite been realized.

title: Seattle Rock: Out of the Woods And Into the Wild
description: This fall, the record industry went in search of the Seattle sound and returned with four rock bands whose only common trait seems to be inordinately long hair. The Screaming Trees' "Something About Today" is third-generation acid rock, while the Posies' "Dear 23" revels in gushy, exuberant pop that recalls the early-70's heyday of the Raspberries and Badfinger. In roof-raising contrast, Mother Love Bone's "Apple" and Alice in Chains' "Facelift" offer pulverizing hard rock in all its grating glory.

title: Campus Life: Catholic U.; Dissenting Voice On Abortion Is Rejected
description: The student judiciary at the Catholic University of America last week struck down a resolution passed by the student government recognizing a campus organization that wants to discuss abortion as an option for women.

title: Stamps
description: By contracting out the production of more and more stamps, the United States Postal Service has generated subtle varieties that can be spotted even by non-hobbyists who care nothing about perforations or printing papers.

title: Toy Banks Tally the Thrift of an Another Time
description: TOY banks, which flourished in the United States from 1850 to the late 1930's, encouraged children to practice the virtue of thrift. Examples of the banks, including those that dazzle the eye with their mechanical feats, are on display through Jan. 6 in "The Fine Art of Penny Pinching" at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

title: Delta Queen
description: To The Editor: I would like to complain about the Delta Queen on the Mississippi. A friend and I went on a seven-day cruise from New Orleans and back to New Orleans. We did not take the least expensive accommodations but one that had two twin beds on the Sun Deck for which we paid $1,730 each. That is better than $225 a day.

title: Katherine Mackie To Marry in April
description: The engagement of Katherine Anne Mackie to Andrew Joseph O'Conor Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Conor of Ottawa, Ill., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Mackie of Irvington, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart on Nov. 4 headed "Wall Street, Tokyo," with an article about American securities firms in Japan, mislabeled figures for the flow of long-term capital from Japan. The figures were worldwide, not just for the United States.

title: WEST IS REBUKED BY JORDANIAN KING
description: King Hussein opened the Jordanian Parliament today with a largely bleak assessment of Jordan's prospects in the wake of the Persian Gulf crisis and attacked what he called the "blatant and shameless" hypocrisy of nations involved in the military buildup in Saudi Arabia.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE KATONAH MUSEUM OF ART;
A New Building, All Its Own, To Match New Needs
description: EDWARD LARRABEE BARNES, architect of the new Katonah Museum of Art, is modest about his latest achievement:

title: Surprises in Store As Jets Face Colts
description: Whatever happened to that bag of tricks Bruce Coslet used with so much success as the offensive coordinator at Cincinnati while making the Bengals one of the National Football League's top offensive units?

title: Headliners; Raining on Charade
description: Marcel Marceau would have loved it. The producer of the album that rocketed the rock duo Milli Vanilli to stardom last year disclosed last week that the two sang nary a note on the record or in the concert appearances that followed. The two, Rob Pilatus (right) and Fab Morvan, were just mouthing the words to the hit songs that helped win them a "Best New Artist" Grammy award last year for their 7-million-selling debut album, "Girl You Know It's True," said their producer, Frank Farian. Mr. Farian said he hired the the long-haired pair simply to lip-sync and dance in front of the band. Arista Records, which distributed the album, was never told, he said. The producer refused to reveal who the real singers were. Rob and Fab, as they are known, said Mr. Farian had refused to let them do their own singing and that the whole affair left them distraught. But Arista was unruffled. Said a spokesman: "Embarrassing? I don't mean the end justifies the means, but we sold 7 million albums."

title: Gothic That's Positively Exuberant
description: The gothic revival style in 19th-century Britain transformed parlors and the halls of Parliament with furnishings of far more fantasy, exuberant imagery and aristocratic presence than their counterparts in France and the United States. As shown in "Memories and Visions: Historic Revivals and Modernism" at Didier Aaron, 32 East 67th Street, through Dec. 1, the British interpretations of medieval trefoils, crockets, tracery, spirals, pinnacles, rosettes and linenfold are more vigorous and varied than those produced on the Continent and in America.

title: Business Diary/November 11-16
description: COMPANIES A New Claim on Drexel

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ALL-FAITHS THANKSGIVING

title: On Iraq's Other Front
description: THE DUST-SWIRLED TOWN OF SILOPI LIES along a stretch of blacktop that Turks call the Silk Road. It isn't quite as glamorous perhaps as the ancient Silk Road that linked China to the West, but it carries the same whispers of prosperity and hopes of lasting security.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Time to Toot Tubas

title: Inspiration for Thanksgiving's Cooks
description: ALONG with bags of cranberries, jugs of cider and apples for pie, the arrival of the holiday season also brings dozens of new cookbooks. Some of this year's offerings are filled with inspiration for Thanksgiving.

title: What Gorbachev's Union Treaty Means
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; Suburban Sprawl Also Applies To the Circulation Of Newspapers
description: WHILE a strike continues to obscure the fate of The Daily News, New York City's other newspapers reported some circulation gains at their rival's expense. But such gains came against a decades-long backdrop of changes in circulation patterns that have seen suburban papers gaining readers while the total number of papers sold in New York City has dropped sharply. Overall newspaper circulation in the city has been in decline since the end of World War II, a trend that reflects the exodus to suburbia, the strengths of local newspapers and changes in the newspaper business nationally.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 4 about C. S. Lewis and the play "Shadowlands" referred incorrectly to a line from Lewis's poem "A Confession." It was inspired by T. S. Eliot's "Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock," not "The Waste Land."

title: POSTINGS: Martinique Proposal; Out of Oblivion
description: In the 1980's, there were few hotels as uninviting as the Martinique, at Broadway and 32d Street. It had sunk from turn-of-the-century grandeur into a notorious symbol of the plight of homeless families, hundreds of whom lived under its great mansard roof. The last residents moved out in 1988.

title: David King Weds Miss Kriegman
description: Michelle Robin Kriegman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar M. Kriegman of Wayne, N.J., was married last evening to David Andrew King, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Joseph King of Randwick, New South Wales, Australia. Rabbi Judith Lewis officiated at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: East; Syracuse Beats a Sloppy W. Virginia
description: Martin Graves threw for one second-quarter touchdown and ran for another as Syracuse erupted for 24 points in the period en route to a 31-7 victory over mistake-prone West Virginia today. The victory kept alive Syracuse's bid for a trip to the Eagle Aloha Bowl. The Orangemen are 6-3-2 with a game remaining at Miami, Fla.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Cumberland, Me.;
A Town Center For Crossroads
description: A PUBLIC PLANNER, a landscape architect and a developer want to create what this bedroom community of 6,800 residents a dozen miles north of Portland, Maine's largest city, never had before -- a town center.

title: Miss Whitehead To Wed in Winter
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Marc Whitehead of Wayzata, Minn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Kimberly Sandford Whitehead to John Sedberry Puckett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Puckett 3d of Signal Mountain, Tenn. A February wedding is planned.

title: Bridge
description: The Ogust-Schenken Pairs, which preserves the memory of two New York stars of yesteryear, attracted a star-studded field of 28 pairs at Manhattan's Cavendish Club a week ago. There were 13 players who will be involved in playoffs next May to determine the American representation in the 1991 World Championships in Japan and seven others who have had major successes in the past three years, but none of them finished at the top.

title: Kevin Krier Wed To Arie Federici
description: Arie Catherine Federici, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Federici of Essex Fells, N.J., was married yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York to Kevin John Krier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Krier of Dublin, Ohio. Msgr. Franklyn M. Casale, the Vicar General of the Archdiocese of Newark, officiated.

title: Margot Metz Is to Marry
description: June wedding plans for Margot Metz and Richard Thomas Klingman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Klingman of Smithtown, L.I., have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Metz of Manuels, Newfoundland. Ms. Metz and the prospective bridegroom, 24 years old, are 1988 graduates of Bucknell University. She is an employment recruiter for the United States Trust Company in New York. Her fiance is a government bond trader at Union Bank of Switzerland Securities in New York.

title: India Gets $450 Million Loan for Gulf Hardship
description: The International Monetary Fund has agreed to loan India $400 million to $450 million to address an economic crisis caused by rising oil prices and shortages after the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait, a top Indian finance official said today.

title: Against Zionism
description: To the Editor:

title: Affirmative Action?
description: To the Editor: Donal Henahan wishes to bring affirmative action to the high-stakes job of conducting our symphony orchestras [ "America Still Shuns Americans," Nov. 4 ] . He would have us believe that the country of someone's birth -- in this case the United States -- should be a criterion when appointing a music director to lead the strings and winds of New York, Chicago or Philadelphia. Shouldn't the criterion be talent and ability, however, rather than something as extraneous as place of birth? Factors like race and nationality are totally irrelevant to the matter of excellence in music. HAROLD BELL Williamstown, Mass.

title: Democratic Leaders To Vote On Oldi
description: COUNTY Democratic leaders will be making an important and, for some, difficult decision Wednesday: whether to retain Marion B. Oldi as the Democratic Commissioner on the Board of Elections for what would likely be a final two-year term or replace her with Lloyd King Jr., her deputy.

title: Mutual Funds; John Templeton's Faith and Patience
description: THERE are certain words that crop up in discussions with money managers and John Marks Templeton knows them all. But in his 50 years of money management, he has been just as likely to weave God and patience into a paragraph as yield and return. In today's market, there's more of a connection than usual.

title: The Mayor Referees Football And Politics
description: IF John C. Daniels had been invited to officiate at a major college football game last Jan. 1, he would have had to decline. Mr. Daniels had spent three previous New Year's Days working at big games, including the 1989 Sugar Bowl. But on the first day of 1990, he had another important engagement, his inauguration as Mayor of New Haven.

title: Camera
description: A friend recently returned from a photography safari in Africa and last week brought out her album to show me the color pictures she and her husband had taken. Zebras, lions, elephants, rhinoceroses -- I was amazed at the number and variety of wild species that had willingly sat still for their portraits.

title: Review/Theater; Anthropomorphic Relationships Down on the Farm
description: Strange things are happening on the Malvetz family farm in Sturgeon Bay, Wis. "The Mud Angel" is a play knee-deep in symbolism and sexuality, as Darrah Cloud studies the interwoven relationships among a mother, her three children and a horse named Shadow. In this bizarre middle-American Gothic tale, the horse has all the best lines.

title: Stan Z. Burns, 63, Broadcaster at WINS
description: Stan Z. Burns, a broadcaster who played a major role in the development of the all-news radio station WINS, died on Friday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SOVIETS ADOPT EMERGENCY PLAN TO CENTER POWER IN GORBACHEV AND LEADERS OF THE REPUBLICS
description: Warning that the country was sliding toward chaos, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today announced the creation of a new emergency power structure in which he will govern along with leaders of the republics.

title: Crossing the Bridges With the Newmans
description: THEIRS IS THE MOST FAMOUS marriage in filmdom and perhaps in all of America, a durable union that is still going strong after more than 30 years and numerous collaborations on the screen. No wonder, then, that a Sunday afternoon in November finds Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward together at a rented Malibu beach house with their daughters and other guests, Mr. Newman shucking ears of corn for the visitors as Ms. Woodward converses quietly with them on a deck overlooking the Pacific Ocean.

title: Review/Music; The McGarrigle Sisters' Homey Way With a Song
description: Kate and Anna McGarrigle's first album since 1983, "Heartbeats Accelerating" (Private Music), often orchestrates their songs with synthesizers. But befitting the most un-careerist of songwriters, they played at Tramps on Thursday night with low-tech equipment: button accordion, banjo, harmonica, mandolin, piano, guitars and fiddle (although Joel Zifkin's fiddle and Jason Lang's electric guitar did plug in). As they performed new songs, they reaffirmed their connections to old-timey sources; the McGarrigles are still closer to hymns, parlor songs and modal French-Canadian folk tunes than to current pop.

title: Three-Headed Recorders Show Off Their Charms
description: Put a new count on the old adage: Three heads are better than two. That, at any rate, applies to tape recorders, where three-headed models are gaining prominence.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MODEL RAILROADS

title: Fighting for Their Lives
description: IMAGINE A WOMAN And Other Tales. By Richard Selzer. 229 pp. New York: Random House.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q&A;: PETER MARCELLE;
From Rocky Point to Owning a Manhattan Art Gallery
description: GALLERY openings in Manhattan are not rare, but it is unusual for a gallery to be devoted exclusively to the works of one artist. An exception occurred last week, when the Marcelle Fine Art Gallery on Madison Avenue opened with a benefit reception featuring the art, and presence, of Andrew Wyeth.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AQUABOOGIE: A Novel in Stories. By Susan Straight. (Milkweed, Paper, $9.95.) In the community of Rio Seco, Calif. -- where the ambitions of young people fade into the blankness of drugs and murderous Los Angeles street gangs, where the older generation that came from the Deep South laughs knowingly at its children's attempts to get out -- defiance is clung to like a life raft. The junk collectors, nursing-home cooks, beauticians and gardeners who live here are white America's black laborers, people who may never have visited Hollywood or the beach but stick it out because California is home. For Shawan, the young protagonist in the last story of this remarkable collection, being able to turn on and off the music on her portable radio becomes the one control she has over her life. Her best friend has been senselessly murdered by the gangs, and her hope, not to mention the money she has saved from her job as a telephone operator, has dwindled as she tries to meet the needs of her pregnant sister. "I ain't nobody's 'mine,' " she says, rebuffing an amorous pursuer. Guided by the fine hand of Susan Straight, Shawan and the other survivors of this harsh yet durable landscape recount their personal trials over the period of several months. These characters include not only "old timeys" like Red Man, who is so absorbed in earning his backbreaking living that he can't envision a better way for his family, but also the second generation, young men like Nacho who, worn down by white harassment elsewhere, is pulled irresistibly back to Rio Seco to take up the same work his father did. "Aquaboogie," which won this year's Milkweed National Fiction Prize, is a love story in fragments, a tale of an unrelenting struggle to preserve tenderness for friends and loved ones against the brutalities of the outside world, a book by a writer whose love for her characters infuses her work with the dignity and urgency they so clearly deserve.

title: Arms Pact to Codify Europe's New Power Balance
description: In an important postscript to the end of the cold war, the Soviet Union is to renounce its traditional huge superiority in conventional arms in Europe when a far-reaching East-West disarmament treaty is signed at the opening of a 34-nation European-security summit meeting here on Monday.

title: Pinning All The Blame On Drexel
description: THE demonization of Mike Milken is proceeding apace. Now, the Government says he was a significant villain in the savings and loan debacle. Mr. Milken will be punished for other crimes, but the latest claims appear to be highly exaggerated, at best.

title: After 6th Period, It's TV as an Art
description: FOR 36 students at Herricks High School in New Hyde Park, academics end every school day after the sixth period. It is then that they change into a uniform of shorts, sneakers and their trademark T-shirts and spend the remainder of the afternoon at STAC.

title: Negotiating an Iraqi Withdrawal Beats War; Chamberlain Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi General Says a U.S. Attack Is Doomed to Fail
description: A top Iraqi general said today that the American-led military force in the gulf would face "uncalculated developments" if it launched an attack to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait -- developments that would doom the attack to failure.

title: Czech Party's Property Is Transferred to State
description: Communist legislators stalked out of Parliament on Friday night as a bill turning party property over to the state was overwhelmingly approved, the Czechoslovak press reported today.

title: Tough Decision
description: To the Editor: In response to the question "Has La Mama lost her nerve? Is age . . . making her soft [ "At La Mama, the Avant-Garde Buttons Up," Oct. 28 ] : No, dear. I did not, as Catherine Texier writes, "quietly" sign the pledge and accept the checks. I was front and center at the National Endowment for the Arts rally in Union Square in Manhattan. If Ms. Texier is concerned, as I am, about the very survival of the N.E.A., she should avail herself of such opportunities as these demonstrations, rather than use working theater people to make her own personal points in print. During these 29 years of producing more theater annually than any other theater in the world, most of it at the cutting edge of culture, there have been a lot of tough decisions to make, and this was one of them.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FLEETWOOD: My Life and Adventures in Fleetwood Mac. By Mick Fleetwood with Stephen Davis. (Morrow, $17.95.) The party was over for Mick Fleetwood. "It was June 1984," he writes, "and I had just been forced to file for bankruptcy. The newspapers were saying that I had lost eight million dollars and that much of it had gone up my nose. . . . My band, Fleetwood Mac, once one of the biggest groups in the world, hadn't played together in two years." In "Fleetwood," a blithe, slapdash memoir written with Stephen Davis, the author of "Hammer of the Gods," Mr. Fleetwood makes the rock musician's life seem cliched and ho-hum: he needed to play music, he made too much money, he took too many drugs. Fleetwood Mac, begun in England in the summer of 1967, has undergone several incarnations over the last two decades in both its music and its personnel. However, the most significant change came in 1975, when Mr. Fleetwood hired the singer-songwriters Stevie Nicks and Lindsey Buckingham. This edition of the band -- "more powerful than ever," Mr. Fleetwood writes -- would produce a string of best-selling albums. The downside was that the band began to abuse cocaine. "Until then, Fleetwood Mac hadn't had much experience with this Andean rocket fuel," he writes. "Now we discovered that a toot now and then relieved the boredom of long hours in the studio with little nourishment." Mr. Fleetwood, the band's manager as well as its drummer, says he felt compelled to get the other members to carry on with their work. After he recouped his financial losses in 1985, Mr. Fleetwood and the band gave it one more go, and in 1987 they released one last hit album before Mr. Buckingham left. Mr. Fleetwood has since recast the band yet again and looks forward to more life on the road. "I'll keep playing forever," he writes. "I'm going to be an eighty-year-old rocker, and they'll have to take me out and shoot me to get me to stop."

title: Deborah C. Asher, Engineer, Is Wed
description: Deborah Caren Asher, an engineer, and Scott Alan Anderson, a candidate for a doctorate in civil engineering, were married yesterday at the Rittenhouse in Philadelphia by Judge Edward R. Becker of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Mrs. Anderson is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard B. Asher of Rydal, Pa. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore I. Anderson of Lexington, Mass.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the artist Anthony Van Dyck misstates his nationality in one paragraph. As noted elsewhere in the article, he was Flemish, not Dutch.

title: Paper Pact in San Francisco
description: A tentative settlement was reached today to avert a strike at the San Francisco Bay area's three largest newspapers, a management negotiator said. Management accepted a union proposal at 10 A.M. after considering it during a short break in negotiations that went through the night, said Richard Jordan, chief negotiator for the San Francisco Newspaper Agency. Unions representing 4,500 employees at The San Francisco Examiner, The San Francisco Chronicle and The San Jose Mercury News had threatened to strike at 5 P.M. on Friday.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Major Complex For Riverside
description: CONSTRUCTION has begun on the Strip, Down by the Riverside, a complex that will include a 420-foot-long floating platform and have commercial, entertainment and residential facilities. The 38-acre, 10-block site, now a commuter parking lot, is on the Allegheny River just north of downtown.

title: The World; Thatcherism's Impact Is Secure, Thatcher's Future May Not Be
description: CAN Thatcherism survive Margaret Thatcher? The question is in the air today as the Prime Minister, who has led Britain for 11 1/2 years, flies to Paris for a three-day summit conference. There is a chance -- probably slim -- that she may no longer be Prime Minister when the meeting ends on Wednesday.

title: Devils Top Flyers As Terreri Shines
description: Inspired by Chris Terreri's save on a penalty shot in the first period and buoyed by strong defense from the entire team in the third period, the Devils defeated the Flyers, 3-2, today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Side Dishes Can Make Meal a Success
description: LIKE a gorgeous Miss America contestant, Dar Tiffany wants to be taken seriously in the talent division. For a steakhouse, that means recognition for its red meat. Instead, this strikingly beautiful and visually impressive Greenvale restaurant takes first place in the swimsuit division.

title: Why Louisville Accepted the Fiesta Bowl Bid
description: THE University of Louisville made a decision to go to the Fiesta Bowl knowing full well it would be controversial.

title: Iraq Could Have Atomic Arsenal by 2000, Intelligence Experts Say
description: Iraq has acquired a nuclear weapons capacity that could enable it to begin manufacturing and using a small but devastating stock of nuclear missiles, shells and bombs within 10 years, American, British and Israeli intelligence experts have concluded.

title: Pierre Braunberger, 85, French Film Producer
description: Pierre Braunberger, who produced the first films of Jean Renoir and Luis Bunuel during a 67-year career in cinema, died on Friday, his family said today. He was 85 years old.

title: Campus Life: Connecticut; Signs of Concern: Ecology Library And Recycling
description: Environmental awareness is a part of life on campus here, from the cafeteria to student dormitories to classrooms.

title: Chess
description: There is along-standing belief that the larger the chess pool, the greater the chances of turning out top players or perhaps even a world champion. Still, the converse does not follow, at least not in the context of women.

title: Norwalk's Marching Band Is California Bound
description: UNDER four street lights and a nearly full moon, the 192 members of the Norwalk High School Marching Band were refining their Z-pull, worm and blind-backup-build formations in a parking lot. Their parents watched, cheered, shivered and poured refreshments for the five-minute break, as they do three nights a week and all day on Saturdays.

title: Unions Canvass Queens for News Cancellations
description: In a show of support for striking Daily News workers, members of 25 unions canvassed neighborhoods in Queens yesterday to ask the newspaper's subscribers to cancel home delivery.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lee, Mass.;
1885 School Is Now an Inn
description: A FORMER Roman Catholic elementary school building in this Berkshire Mountain community has been moved and converted into the Chambery Inn, whose guest suites incorporate the blackboards and chalk trays of the onetime classrooms.

title: Negotiating an Iraqi Withdrawal Beats War; Mirage of Consensus
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK GAINS TOP EAGLE HABITAT
description: New York State has acquired one of the most important bald eagle habitats in the eastern United States -- in Rockland and Sullivan Counties, only 80 miles northwest of New York City.

title: INCEST AND THE LAW
description: Mithers states in the article that "since incest often occurs in the home, plaintiffs have sought to collect damage awards from the defendant's homeowners' insurance policy."

title: A TIMELY TEA
description: As someone who has lived on both sides of the Atlantic (and enjoys teatime every day), I felt that what Liz Logan said in her article, "A Timely Tea" (Food, Oct. 28), needs amending slightly. To wit:

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: PAUL KELLEHER;
Deciding Which Students Go Where
description: IT was not too long ago that schools in the county and across the nation were being closed, sold, sometimes even converted into condominiums. Baby boomers were just not having enough children to fill the classrooms.

title:
FOCUS: North Philadelphia;
A Neighborhood Struggles for a Revival
description: SOME months before Mayor W. Wilson Goode released his 1986 "North Philadelphia Plan: A Guide to Revitalization," he got into his limousine to ride a dozen blocks north of City Hall to a ribbon-cutting.

title: INCEST AND THE LAW
description: Carol Lynn Mithers's article "Incest and the Law" (Oct. 21) was moving and healing for me, a survivor of childhood incest. Legal recourse is not possible in my case (my father has been dead for 15 years), but the knowledge that others have this option is strengthening to me. As your author concludes: "The symbolic importance is profound. Lawsuits make public the fact that incest happens, that it is wrong and that it should be punished."

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: South; Virginia Upset by Maryland, 35-30
description: Tony Thompson ran for 106 yards and scored the clinching touchdown on a 1-yard run as Tennessee gained the inside track to the Sugar Bowl with a 22-13 Southeastern Conference victory over Mississippi today.

title: SOVIET UNION
description: To the Editor: After reading "Marlboro Man in Moscow" by William E. Geist (Travel, Sept. 30), I would like to share my cigarette experience while in Russia. I too was advised to bring Marlboros, cosmetics, pens, etc., but decided to bring a generic brand of cigarettes, and plain cash (U.S.) for tips. One evening, while our group was attending an opera, everyone's luggage was pilfered of Marlboro cartons. Not ours. The generic brand was our salvation. As for tips, I found dollar bills gladly accepted. Regina Blay Old Bridge, N.J.

title: 'Roar of Greasepaint,' A Musical Curiosity
description: SIR, who stands for the Establishment, or the power elite, and Cocky (for Cockney, the underdog or Everyman) are playing the Game of -- what else? -- Life.

title: A Lifelong Search For 'Prose Painting'
description: Throughout much of his long lifetime (1908-87) the English painter and teacher William Coldstream was a key figure in the British art world, nationwide. As chairman from 1958 to 1971 of the National Advisory Council on Art Education, he did as much as anyone to reshape the patterns of British art schools. Even where his friends and former pupils diverged from his own practice as a painter, they too made themselves felt in the art life of Britain.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: TOURS OF THE BLACK CLOCK, by Steve Erickson. (Avon, $8.95.) After wiping out his family, a Pennsylvania boy named Banning Jainlight flees to Vienna, where he changes the course of history by writing pornographic fantasies for Hitler. In this novel, "everything is strange and, at the same time, recognizable," Kathy Acker said here last year. " 'Tours of the Black Clock' is, above all, a gorgeous argument against a culture of absolutes and for a way of life based on questioning."

title: 'Anchors'
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: East Islip 113,000 101 Meroke Lane 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 38-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car detached garage; taxes $3,000. Farmingdale 170,000 17 Cheryl Lane North 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level; dining room, den, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,500.
