Jackson, N.J. 131,900 East Burke Tavern Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old raised ranch; eat-in-kitchen, 2-acres, fireplace; taxes $2,700.

title: Barbara Kay Morrow Wed To Jeffrey Matthew Bayone
description: Barbara Kay Morrow, the daughter of Col. Robert Warren Morrow, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Morrow of Lawson, Mo., was married last evening at the Beekman Tower in New York to Jeffrey Matthew Bayone a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Bayone of Forest Hills, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Judge Robert L. Carter of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Publish Or Perish
description: There were so many opportunities to reject Bret Easton Ellis's novel "American Psycho."

title: Headliners; Twice-Sold Tale
description: Many a novelist would not mind the sort of rejection that Bret Easton Ellis got from Simon & Schuster last week. The company, which had paid for and edited Mr. Ellis's third novel, "American Psycho," and was preparing to ship it to bookstores next month, abruptly decided not to publish it. Richard E. Snyder, the chairman of Simon & Schuster, said the reason he had overruled his top editors was "a matter of taste." Two magazines recently offered pre-publication criticism of the book, in which a serial killer's mutilations of women are graphically described. Mr. Ellis accused Simon & Schuster of censorship and said he probably would never publish with the company again. But if his sensibilities were offended, his finances were not. He got to keep the $300,000 Simon & Schuster had paid him and his agent said other companies immediately lined up to bid for the book. By week's end, Vintage Books had acquired it for an undisclosed price.

title: Reviving Nuclear Power From Its Coma
description: Nuclear power has been comatose in the United States for more than a decade. The last nuclear plant order was placed in 1978, the year before the accident at Three Mile Island terrified the public and sent chills up the spines of utility executives who suddenly realized how easily a multibillion-dollar plant might be wiped out.

title: An Option of Cultures: China, Sicily or Mexico
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. The Golden Unicorn

title: Onerous Choices In Health Care
description: Sister Margaret Straney, president of Cathedral Healthcare Systems, states that the focus of health care must be shifted from acute care and its associated technology to prevention ("A New Vision in Health Care," Opinion page, Oct. 7), and that such a shift will save millions of dollars by preventing larger problems and bigger payments down the road.

title: Children's Books
description: PEOPLE OF THE BREAKING DAY Written and illustrated by Marcia Sewall. 48 pp. New York: Atheneum.

title: NOVELS YOU CAN SINK YOUR TEETH INTO
description: From the day I made my acquaintance with "The Vampire Lestat," I have been fascinated by Rice's voice.

title: The World; The Struggle to Make A Monarchy Fit In Modern-Day Japan
description: DOZENS of courtiers in multilayered robes carrying banners, swords and arrow-filled quivers made the enthronement of Emperor Akihito of Japan last week seem like a ceremony from a forgotten world. Indeed, many of the trappings of acsension for the oldest monarchy on earth dated from more than a thousand years ago. But the installation of Japan's 125th emperor was also a completely contemporary event that looked both forward and backward -- a subtle and revealing effort to reconcile Japan's heritage with the image of the nation it wishes to be.

title: French Said to Spy on U.S. Computer Companies
description: A senior official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today confirmed reports that France's intelligence service recently sought to spy on American industrial targets, but added that he knows of no current French espionage in the United States.

title: Johnson Faults Met Officials
description: The week after Darryl Strawberry took his $20.25 million hike, Davey Johnson peered across the four seasons that transformed the Mets and agreed that his championship team had not made the orderly transition charted for the 1990's but had been dismantled. And, he believes, for no good reason.

title: On Q
description: INSIDE THE RECORDING BOOTH at A&M Studios, Quincy Jones stands behind a mike, headphones on, listening.

title: Gorbachev's Five Years: Era of Tumult and Change
description: March 1985: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is named to succeed the late Konstantin U. Chernenko as Soviet leader and outlines an urgent agenda to improve the economy.

title: Nets Reach Futility Mark for Losses
description: The Nets unintentionally played themselves into the record books tonight when their streak of futility on the road reached 32 games after a 111-99 loss to the Milwaukee Bucks at the Bradley Center.

title: Negotiating an Iraqi Withdrawal Beats War; Vietnam Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Waiting for Jimmy
description: THE SUMMER OF THE PAYMASTER By Alfred Nielsen.379 pp. New York:W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title:
GARDENING;
Durable Plants for Impossible Places
description: The best place to use an indoor plant for decorative purposes is usually the worst place to grow it: the dimmest, shadowy corner. My ideal plant must be able to endure these conditions as well as tolerate an irregular watering schedule. And most important, it should be attractive.

title: Whither China? Back to the Era of 'Comrade'
description: Fighting the linguistic fashion of the last decade, China's hard-line rulers are dusting off the revolutionary expression "comrade" and encouraging its use instead of more bourgeois salutations.

title: In Brooklyn, Party Leader Sees New Era
description: Unlike many of his predecessors, the new Brooklyn Democratic leader, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., doesn't like to be called "boss." He prefers "coordinator slash mediator."

title: Suburbs Asked to Share Housing Burden
description: A BRIDGEPORT Alderman's suggestion that neighboring communities accept some low-cost housing has found little favor among the wealthy suburbs that surround to the state's largest city. The Alderman, Bradford Hubler, a Republican from the city's Black Rock neighborhood who is serving his first term, has proposed that $6.4 million in Federal housing funds earmarked for Bridgeport be diverted to build low-income housing in Fairfield County suburbs where, he said, "restrictive zoning by default prohibits the poor from living."

title: Cuomo Seeks Big Cuts; 10,000 May Be Laid Off
description: Warning that New York State faced "no other choice," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed layoffs of up to 10,000 state workers and other actions that would ultimately reduce the state government's work force by about 18,000 jobs, or 10 percent.

title: POSTINGS: M.I.T. Master's Class; Graduates Abroad
description: Tough times and diminished real estate opportunities in this country have prompted more than a few American developers to look overseas for new projects. Now, following on the heels of some industry veterans, a group of future real estate entreprenuers will head for Europe.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
All in the Family for Arizona
description: WHEN the University of Arizona basketball team arrives tomorrow to prepare to play in the semifinals of the Dodge NIT in Madison Square Garden, it will bring with it the expectations of one of the top three teams in the nation, and the closeness of a family.

title: Ireland
description: To the Editor: We just returned from Ireland where the dollar was $1.80 to the Irish pound. With this in mind I was delighted to see an ad for Cashback in the Aer Lingus magazine on the flight over. The ad said, "When shopping in Ireland for gift items and clothing, etc., you pay a sales tax (called VAT). The good news is that you can collect special Cashback vouchers, which will allow you to reclaim this tax in cash, before you return home."

title: Building a House on One's Own, From Scratch
description: DESPITE the slowdown in real estate sales, it took Michael Morris and his wife, Karen, only a month to find a buyer for their 100-year-old house in Ossining.

title: Bobby Lewis to Lecture On Changes in Acting
description: Changes in the acting profession over the last 40 years will be discussed in a four-part lecture series led by Bobby Lewis, beginning tonight at 7:30 at the Double Image Theater, 15 Vandam Street.

title: Correction
description: An art review on Nov. 4 about exhibitions in Morristown misstated the location and hours for a show of Thomas Nast drawings. Today is its last day at the Macculloch Hall Historical Museum, and it is open from 2 to 4:30 P.M.

title: Woodwinds From Solo To Ensembles
description: THERE is a lot of woodwind music to be heard this week, starting tomorrow at 8 P.M., when the Festival Winds visit the University of Connecticut's Jorgensen Auditorium in Storrs. Organized in 1947 as the New Art Wind Quintet, the ensemble changed its name a dozen years later to emphasize the fact that their performances range from solo pieces through works scored for large ensembles. Tomorrow's contingent is a quartet -- Paul Dunkel, Melvin Kaplan, Allen Blustine and Marc Goldberg, respectively playing flute, oboe, clarinet and bass. The program lists works of Debussy, Vivaldi, Telemann and Berger. For information, call 486-4226.

title: Headliners; Leaving Early
description: Ever since he helped expose corruption, nepotism and other improprieties by members of New York City's Community School Board 27, the district superintendent, Coleman Genn, has been running the system while keeping one eye over his shoulder. Last week he said that lingering ill will toward him and anxiety over the possibility that someone might seek revenge were getting to be too much. Mr. Genn said he would retire in January even though two and one-half years remain on his contract. As a result of Mr. Genn's testimony last year, the board was suspended and 50 paraprofessionals, one principal and one assistant principal were dismissed. And now someone has been spreading false rumors about him, he said. All in all, he added, "I'm tense and worried that I've made a lot of enemies, that people whose toes have been stepped on will come at me in one way or another." But at least one member of the suspended board praised him. Said Thomas A. Gebert, "What Genn did was unbelievably courageous."

title: SETI, PHONE HOME
description: I can accept the overwhelming curiosity that drives the SETI program, but has it not occurred to anyone that if these possible worlds are billions of light years away, then any intelligence we might receive will be billions of years old. Our own experience tells us that civilizations rise and fall in less time than it takes to bat a cosmic eyelid. MICHELE ROOT-BERNSTEIN East Lansing, Mich.

title: A Teacher's 2d Vocation: Sheepherding
description: KATE TREADWELL-HILL likes to be called a shepherd. Not only is sheepherding one of the oldest professions in the world, she said, but also it doesn't sound like bureaucracy.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. SUSAN ARLEN;
Helping a Patient's Loved Ones to Cope
description: WHEN someone is stricken with a serious chronic illness or crippled in an accident, there can often be two patients, says Dr. Susan Arlen, who practices rehabilitation medicine and psychotherapy here.

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
For Beecham, the Present Was a Time for the Past, Too
description: "Oh, Sir Thomas," gaffed a society lady on being introduced to Sir Thomas Beecham's 15-year-old boy, "I'd absolutely no idea that you had a son!" "An early work, madame, I assure you," replied the nonchalant baronet, as he momentarily cast his mind back to the early years of his marriage to Miss Utica Welles of New York City. She had come to London with her parents to wed the young and potentially wealthy scion of the Lancashire family that manufactured Beecham's Pills. But since a rift had occurred between Beecham and his father, the newlyweds -- much under the influence of the other in-laws too -- found it difficult to settle down.

title: Ms. Romash Wed To J. A. O'Hara 3d
description: Marla E. Romash, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Romash of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to James A. O'Hara 3d, a son of Catherine O'Hara of Nashville and the late Mr. O'Hara. The Rev. William McConville, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Seymour Rosen performed the ceremony at Evviva, a historic house in Narberth, Pa.

title: Campus Life: Clark; Professor Resists Request to Teach Pluralistic Views
description: An effort to encourage Clark University faculty members to include the views of minorities and women in their courses has prompted a debate here, with some professors saying that such efforts limit academic freedom and reduce faculty control of course material.

title: Slow Readers Get Help in First Grade
description: A NEW reading program that gives intensive, individual teaching to first graders who are the slowest readers in their classes is being introduced in a growing number of school districts in the Westchester region. Educators believe that the program, while expensive because of one-on-one teaching, is cost-effective in the long run because it can prevent a pattern of failure and years of remedial reading later.

title: Jill Brenner Wed to Jonathan Deutsch
description: Jill Alison Brenner, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard W. Brenner of New Vernon, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Jonathan Stephen Deutsch, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic H. Deutsch of Tenafly, N.J., and New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: An Oil Policy That Can Keep the Peace
description: THE Persian Gulf crisis has once again shown the underlying volatility of the international oil market and the world's economic dependence on gulf oil. While the restoration of Kuwait is the moral imperative, the international community should at the same time look ahead to formulate policies to support stable oil supplies and prices.

title: Blacks and the Election: What Was the Message?
description: In an election that played out in a welter of mixed signals, few signals were so mixed as those coming from black Americans on Nov. 6.

title: Cornell Gains Share of Ivy Title
description: Maligned early in the season after surrendering 115 points in the first three games, the Cornell defense came up big when it counted, stopping a driving Penn offense late in the fourth quarter today and handing the Big Red its second Ivy League co-championship in three seasons.

title: Yale Trounces Harvard
description: Yale polished the silver anniversary year of its coach, Carm Cozza, today with a complete victory over Harvard, the opponent that has given Cozza's teams so much trouble over the last quarter century.

title: Men's Style; BE A SPORT
description: AS CANDID AND UNSTUDIED AS THE hound at his side, the man in the photograph could be an icon for the 1990's. His seemingly easy demeanor and straight-shooting look speak volumes; his tweed cap and rubber Wellies say the rest.

title: All About/Breakfast Cereal; The Snap Has Turned to Slog
description: THE breakfast cereal industry is entering a midlife crisis, pursuing an aging market with time-worn products. Look at Tony the Tiger, of Frosted Flakes fame. In his latest commercials, the cartoon character beloved to generations of children shoos the kids out to school. Then he sits down to breakfast with Mom and Dad, assuring them, "It's O.K. to be a kid again."

title: Bush's War Powers
description: "You can't have 435 Commanders in Chief," President Bush said the other day. "I've read the Constitution. [ Congress has ] the right to declare war and I have the right, as Commander in Chief, to fulfill my responsibilities . . . " Of course you can't, and of course he does.

title:
ART;
Use of Materials Can Act as Theme
description: LATELY it has been experiments with new combinations of materials that seem to intrigue, motivate and energize artists and their work. Two current Long Island exhibitions are good examples of the trend.

title: What's Wrong With the Siege?
description: How badly has Iraq been hurt by near-total siege that the United Nations imposed in August? The only available information is anecdotal, and it suggests that Iraq has been hurt by a lack of vital spare parts. And yet President Bush is suddenly determined to build up U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia massively, in the implicit belief that the embargo isn't biting hard enough to evict Iraqi occupiers from Kuwait.

title: 'Batman' Detective Sentenced in Fraud Case
description: A former undercover New York City police officer known as Batman for his anti-crime exploits, was sentenced to four years in prison on Friday for defrauding several insurance companies of hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RELATIVE DISTANCES. By Victoria Jenkins. (Peregrine Smith/Gibbs Smith, $15.95.) Lost in urban and suburban anomie, many readers might find it hard to imagine a contemporary setting for good old-fashioned tragedy. But Victoria Jenkins has found such a place in the isolated new West, on the cattle ranches of Wyoming. Thirty-five-year-old Myra Wells, ambitious to recapture the sense of possibilities she recalls from her youth, sets the plot's dominoes in motion by returning to the region where she grew up and married early. There her cousin and first love, Arlen Dyer, has patched together a large ranch, with debts to match. Her son, Tom, whom she left behind long ago, and Arlen's son, Neal, work together as Arlen's ranch hands. As winter slowly yields to spring and summer, Myra turns not to Arlen but to Neal for solace and new life. And in the process, Arlen's need to dominate his son clashes with Neal's need for freedom, with grim results. Although its plot hinges on a parent in love with a child's best friend, "Relative Distances" feels considerably less manipulative than it sounds. This is largely due to Ms. Jenkins's careful, attentive prose, which is grounded in everyday details yet portrays the characters' hopes and memories with sympathy and even lyricism. It's sometimes hard to understand why these people are so obsessed with one another; Myra, in particular, hardly seems as distant and unattainable as both Arlen and Neal think she is. But if these particular fixations aren't convincing to the reader, the characters' fateful submissions to them are. These people might not talk a lot, but they sure do feel. And they still know how to shoot straight.

title: She Was Good, All Right, but Good Enough?
description: The very name of it signifies danger: "Jeopardy!"

title: Fashion; JACKET MAGIC
description: Its pretty Well known that a jacket is the linchpin of a woman's daytime wardrobe. It's the piece of clothing that creates a stylish look by pulling together disparate elements -- skirts, pants, sweaters, T-shirts and blouses old or new. One great jacket can shape up a combination of these into a snazzy-looking outfit. This fall, the jacket's legerdemain is extending to the evening hours as well.

title: Headliners; The Ethics of Withholding Medical Information
description: IN the competitive and creative enterprise of science, a researcher's worth is often measured by the number of papers published and the frequency with which they are cited. In fact, a theory or experimental result can hardly be said to exist until it appears in a refereed journal, for which papers are reviewed by a group of the author's peers.

title: Candyce F. Homan Wed To Peter David Chimera
description: Candyce Fluehr Homan, a daughter of Marion J. Fluehr of Lower Gwynedd, Pa., and Robert E. Homan of Indian Mills, N.J., was married last evening to Peter David Chimera, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Chimera of Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Anne Ritchings performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church Whitemarsh in Fort Washington, Pa.

title: High School Students Found Recycling Clubs
description: THE "Reefers" are raising money for reusable plates.

title: Another Enigma in Postwar Beirut: 'Useless' Ex-Militiamen
description: Kamal Kadi, a Druse militiaman, terrorized a neighborhood of 5,000 residents in Muslim West Beirut for the last 10 years.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Offensive on Ethics Turns Defensive
description: Supremely confident that he would be cleared in the influence-peddling inquiry that has captivated Capitol Hill, Senator John McCain marched straight from the Ethics Committee's hearing room on Friday to appear on a viewer call-in program on the cable channel C-Span.

title: Tape Recorder vs. Court Reporter
description: A STATE Supreme Court committee's search for the most efficient way to insure accurate records of court proceedings has intensified a debate over the use of tape recorders in the state's trial courts.

title: Ballet Lovers, Pack Your Luggage
description: New York City: Dance Capital of the world. That has been the phrase bandied about by critics at home and abroad for the last 25 years, and until very recently, it has usefully described the locus of international dance activity. Foreign companies felt compelled, as a matter of course, to appear regularly in what is, by consensus, also America's cultural hub. Such seasons were essentially more glamorous versions of home-grown creativity in New York City itself -- from George Balanchine and Martha Graham to the novice giving a first concert in a downtown church or loft.

title: Hurricanes in the Hunt After a Rout of B.C.
description: When the Miami Hurricanes trotted off the Orange Bowl grass at halftime today with a measly 14-12 lead over Boston College, the 50,943 fans here were muttering and murmuring, obviously spoiled by an offense that entered averaging 37 points and 510.3 yards a game.

title: Chickamauga's Costly Victory
description: A BATTLEFIELD, like a cemetery, harbors ghosts. One enters a field where great loss of life once took place. Perhaps even more than in a cemetery, one feels the presence of spirits here because this is where soldiers fought and died. The Battle of Chickamauga, which took place Sept. 19 and 20, 1863, roughly eight miles below Chattanooga, was one of the bloodiest engagements of the Civil War. There were 2,268 Confederate soldiers killed, and 1,656 from the Union. (The total of dead, wounded and missing at Chickamauga came to around 34,000, enough to populate a fair-sized town.) Tactically, it was a Southern victory, but in the costly victory (and in not pursuing their enemy when they had him whipped) the death knell of the Southern Rebellion was sounded. As Gen. D. H. Hill of the Confederacy said afterward: "It seems to me that the elan of the Southern soldier was never seen after Chickamauga; the brilliant dash which had distinguished him was gone forever. He fought stoutly to the last, but after Chickamauga, with the sullenness of despair, and without the enthusiasm of hope. That 'barren victory' sealed the fate of the Southern Confederacy."

title: NOVELS YOU CAN SINK YOUR TEETH INTO
description: Anne Rice's vampire chronicles represent a tasty new style of writing: Melvillian philosophical pondering wedded to a bloodthirsty pop genre ("Novels You Can Sink Your Teeth Into," by Susan Ferraro, Oct. 14).

title: New York Council Presses Alternative-Fuel Plan
description: The New York City Council is moving toward passage of a bill that would put as many as 1,500 city-owned alternative-fuel vehicles on the street in the next three years.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THERE is a big, long ridge that lies in the northwestern part of New Jersey, running from the peak to the brim of the "milkman's cap." The "milkman" (for those who never enjoyed the benefits of Mr. Miller's fifth-grade class) refers to the entire state.

title: England
description: To the Editor: Anne Wilson's piece on Hampstead brought back memories. Several years ago, a friend drove me back to Frognal and, driving past a tall 18th-century house, said, "My family lived there for several years after we escaped from Poland in 1939." Her father, a painter whose work hangs in the Tate, moved there because Hampstead welcomed refugees from the continent. Another famous refugee, Charles de Gaulle, was often seen walking in Frognal Lane during World War II.

title: Data Update
Rentals Abroad
description: To the Editor: Several months ago in response to listings in the Travel section, I contacted Four Star Living of New York to arrange a villa in Acapulco for my party of 12 beginning on a specific date for a specific duration of time.

title: 'Anchors'
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard Lesson
description: AS a 6-foot-5-inch, 300-pound nose tackle, Joe Phillips was the anchor of the San Diego Charger defensive line, the team's strongest player and a man not to be messed with. No wonder he developed a sense of invincibiliy.

title: Opponents Of Mail Site Undecided On Next Step
description: IN the wake of the Postal Service's decision to build a $100 million regional mail center on a 23-acre site at the County Airport, local government officials and environmental groups are reviewing the post office's latest environmental study to decide whether to continue their fight against the project.

title: Anne Flocco Marries William Thrush
description: Anne Robin Flocco and William Lake Thrush were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Christopher A. Brown and the Rev. Bruce Shipman officiated. The bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Flocco of Franklin Lakes, N.J. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Thrush of Dorset, Vt.

title: Troops in Germany Pack Up Kit Bags and Tanks
description: Tens of thousands of American soldiers in Germany are packing their gear and bidding their families farewell as they prepare to board planes for Saudi Arabia.

title: Houston Law
description: TRIAL By Clifford Irving. 329 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: Q and A
description: Visiting House of Commons

title: Food; Prosciutto's Promise
description: Now that the initial euphoria over the arrival of Italian prosciutto has subsided, the question remains: What to do with it?

title: Campus Life: Stetson; A Peaceful Way Of Easing Control By the Baptists
description: Stetson University moved last week to distance itself a bit from control by the Baptist church, but it stopped short of efforts undertaken in recent months by Furman University in South Carolina and Baylor University in Texas.

title: AN AGE-OLD QUESTION
description: Having made a careful, conscious decision to be a Shameless Old Hussy (and thanks for providing a good descriptive title), I can assure you that the ridicule of teen-agers is completely irrelevant. They are much too young to have formed any useful judgment about being old. Anyway, I suspect that teen-agers are too self-absorbed to notice me at all. MARY FRANCES READY New Orleans

title: No Headline
description: WHEN County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke asked the County Board of Legislators for guidelines on drawing up his second $1 billion budget, this one for 1991, one of their suggestions was "to keep the increase under double digits," he said.

title: Excerpts From Gorbachev's Speech Proposing a Revamped Government
description: Following are excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech today to the Supreme Soviet proposing a new structure for the Soviet Government, as translated by The Associated Press:

title:
State View on Breast Cancer Upsets Patients;
Breast Cancer Reports Rise
description: BETWEEN 1978 and 1987, there were an average 89 breast cancer cases per 100,000 women in the state. Suffolk County averaged 97 cases and Nassau 103 for every 100,000 women.

title:
Style Makers;
Sheldon Keller and Howard Albrecht, Gag Writers
description: Ever wonder how your favorite morning disk jockeys come up with so many quips and groaners every day? Their repertoire of jokes may well have originated in the minds of two self-described "over-the-hill" Hollywood comedy writers.

title: Unique Sounds Emerge From Farm in Litchfield
description: FROM the street, Paul Winter's farm in rural Litchfield offers no hint that it houses a company that creates innovative jazz recordings. A dirt driveway curves past a rambling, white-clapboard farmhouse to a small barn. Several hundred feet away is a much larger barn, once used for a dairy herd, and beyond it stands a modest cottage.

title: Catherine Kress and Edward McGettigan Jr. Wed
description: Catherine Mary Kress, the daughter of Patricia M. Kress of Wilton, Conn., and Donald G. Kress of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward Thomas McGettigan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McGettigan of Wilton and Del Ray Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Raymond P. Kress, the bride's uncle, and the Rev. JoAnn Munro, both Episcopal priests, and the Rev. Donald Driscoll, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Dinkins Braces for Even Greater Losses
description: Although Cuomo administration officials pledged yesterday to work with New York City to minimize the impact of a proposed $100 million cut in state aid, Mayor David N. Dinkins said he feared even greater cuts -- and their toll on city services.

title: Excellence in the Art of Traveling
description: THE LONG LOST JOURNEY By Jennifer Potter. Illustrated. 176 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. $16.95.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Is there anyone who goes to a charity benefit because of the decor, the dinner, the dancing or the entertainment? It's possible. The world is full of strange creatures.

title:
ART;
The Stories That Surfaces Can Tell
description: AT the Wunsch Arts Center's Sabbeth Art Gallery in Glen Cove, "Energized Surfaces" focuses on five artists for whom the external "skin" of their work is an integral ingredient in their imagery.

title: Tourism Industry Now No. 1 on Island
description: FOR the first time in Long Island history, tourism is the leading industry, in both revenue and employment, and there is growing recognition that the need to promote tourism is greater than ever.

title: Nice Gift
description: THE problem with track at the University of Oregon has been that the runners sometimes run too fast. That's because of the strong northerly winds swirling round the Eugene campus, which have invalidated various American and world records clocked at Hayward Field.

title: The Slip 'Twixt the Met's Pit and Its Stage
description: Half a loaf, provided it is well baked, is better than none. With that yeasty qualification in mind, it is easily possible to imagine that James Levine's regime as artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera will be viewed with reasonable kindness by history. His success in transforming the Met orchestra into a world-class ensemble, documented last week in these pages by Will Crutchfield, will weigh heavily on the scales. Still, there is that other half loaf to be considered, too: Mr. Levine's indifferent success, to put it as mildly as possible, at controlling the total artistic product that appears on the stage night after night.

title: Despite Debt and Apathetic Youth, Little Russia Still Lives
description: AT Bab's Gift Shop, where a visitor can buy Soviet-made chocolates, amber necklaces and painted wooden eggs, the aging Russian emigres were talking of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Twomey Opposed on Shoreham Plan
description: Mr. Twomey's article is illustrative of the shallowness of much of what passes as debate on the Shoreham issue.

title: Topics of the Times; Oils From Troubled Waters
description: The ill wind of the savings and loan crisis has blown a rare treasure ashore in New York. The treasure, enough to fill several galleries, consists of rare oil paintings and other works of art collected over many years by the Seamen's Bank for Savings.

title: Sabatini Stuns Graf, 6-4, 6-4
description: Gabriela Sabatini raised her fist and her game and caused Steffi Graf such consternation that the defending champion let her racquet slip from her grasp even before the Argentine, who seems finally to have transformed herself into Graf's archrival as well as her contemporary, had finished off the West German, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in their riveting semifinal of the $3 million Virginia Slims Championships.

title: Review/Theater; Neil Simon's Touch, in a First Effort
description: The American Jewish Theater has opened its new season with the first in what will be a decade-long retrospective of the plays of Neil Simon, who is still writing and may need more than 10 years of catching up before the final look-back is in order. The first in this series is "I Ought to Be in Pictures," a play that might well be classified by Simon historians as one of the minor works.

title: INCEST AND THE LAW
description: Men as survivors of childhood incest and sexual abuse are all but ignored in your article.

title: Carrie P. Berger Weds Richard N. Rosenthal
description: Carrie Phyllis Berger, a daughter of M. Howard J. Berger of New York and the late Roberta Berger, was married last evening to Dr. Richard Nelson Rosenthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Rosenthal of New York. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik performed the ceremony at the Mark Hotel in New York.

title: A January Bridal For Hope Worley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Worley Jr. of Riverside, Conn., have announced that their daughter, Hope Elizabeth Worley, and Curtis William Hillegas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hillegas of Limerick, Pa., are to be married in January.

title: Hofstra Finally Wins in Playoff
description: Finally playing like a Division I school in a Division III playoff, Hofstra University trounced Cortland State, 35-9, today and achieved the first post-season victory in the school's history.

title: Hilary Colgate Weds Mark McInerney
description: Hilary Kirtland Colgate and Mark Jeffrey McInerney were married yesterday at St. James's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Seymour Flinn. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Howard H. Leach of San Francisco and John K. Colgate Jr. of Mill Neck, L.I. Her husband is a son of John B. McInerney of Pittsfield, Mass., and the late Marilyn McInerney.

title: Decoding Ads for Special Fares
description: SPLASHED in huge type in newspaper advertisements across the country, Trans World Airlines beckoned consumers last year with what appeared to be a great bargain: "London + Hotel + Car = $298." But, alas, T.W.A.'s arithmetic was suspect. The hotel, it turned out, was miles from London and "free" only after paying for several nights; surcharges on the flight were not included. In fact, when all the additional charges were tallied, the price for the vacation ranged from $792 to $1,418.

title: Leary Will Return to the Yankees
description: Tim Leary and the Yankees, whose contract talks stalled late last season, essentially reached agreement this weekend on a three-year deal for just under $6 million.

title: Inside Jobs
description: THE TABOO SCARF And Other Tales.By George Weinberg.324 pp. New York:St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

title: Cruises
description: To the Editor: On Aug. 13 my husband, myself and my 12-year-old son disembarked from the Star/Ship Oceanic after a three-night cruise to Nassau and Salt Cay. At the point of disembarkation, my camera was missing, my husband was drenched in maple syrup, my son's head had been scalded with burning butter, and I was in a near state of frenzy because we had been detained over three hours from the scheduled time of disembarkation.

title: Disabled Sailors Find Confidence Afloat
description: WHEN Richard Fucci injured his spinal cord 13 years ago, his choices for recreation were limited to wheelchair races and basketball games. Now Mr. Fucci heads the Sail Connecticut Access Program, which he says is the only group in the state that introduces the exhilaration of sailing to people with disabilities.

title: 3 African Nations Reported To Back Baker on U.N. Vote
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d apparently won the support of three African countries today for a United Nations resolution backing the use of armed force in the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Review/Music; The Lark, a New Quartet, Arrives With a New Work
description: The Lark Quartet arrived at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening trailing accolades. One of the more recent was the 1990 Chamber Music Award of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation, which presented the concert and commissioned a work for the occasion, Aaron Jay Kernis's String Quartet ("musica celestis").

title: All Roads Lead to Disney World, Slowly
description: FOR the week between Christmas and New Year's, it seems that all roads lead to Disney World: The week is one of the two busiest in the year for what has become the premier tourist attraction in the United States. While Disney does not release annual attendance figures, stock analysts and others put the number at 30 million to 35 million, or 673,000 a week. But Christmas week and spring vacation week are well above average. This year, officials at Disney World expect the crush to begin on Dec. 22 and be at its most intense from Dec. 26 to Jan. 4 or 5.

title: The Love for Cars: A Quarter-Century of Best Sellers
description: THE BEST-SELLING car today is a lot different from what it was 25 years ago. In the affluent and resource-abundant 1960's, an occasional Ford won out, but for the most part Americans saw the U.S.A. in a full-size Chevrolet. And No. 1, selling well over a million models, was a massive beast, stretching to 18 feet and more and weighing a couple of tons. To move all this metal took a powerful V-8 engine, which was mounted in the front to drive the rear wheels -- an arrangement that required a large hump in the passenger compartment to accommodate the drive shaft.

title: Tech Notes; When Even a Mouse Is Too Big
description: MANY personal computers and software programs require the use of a pointing device to move the cursor -- a "mouse." But a mouse needs a tabletop to navigate on, and most substitutes, like trackballs, are bulky. For the new generation of very small portable computers, or "notebooks," a better solution was needed. Home Row Inc.'s answer is to turn the "J" key into a pointing device, activated by pressing the computer's control key. In effect, the key becomes a miniature joystick that can move in any direction. The cursor's speed is determined by how hard the key is pressed. The left hand can press the F, D, and S keys to give the commands on the traditional mouse buttons. Home Row, based in Clackamas, Oreg., has licensed its technology to a number of computer makers. The first products are due this year.

title: Campus Life: Bates; A school Rejects Requiring Tests For Applicants
description: Six years after having made the Scholastic Aptitude Test optional for admission,t he bates College faculty voted last week to make all standardized-test results optional for applicants.

title: Bush Gives Czechs a Copy of Liberty Bell
description: President Bush rang a replica of the Liberty Bell in the Czechoslovak capital today to mark the first anniversary of this country's democratic revolution, and he evoked the memory of Czechoslovakia's subjugation by Hitler to appeal for support in his fight against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Smart Coverups For Festive Hosts
description: The cook -- man or woman -- who is usually content to improvise an apron out of a dish towel often wants a coverup with a festive touch for holiday entertaining.

title: Irving Janis Dies at 72; Coined 'Group Think'
description: Irving L. Janis, a retired Yale University psychology professor whose research on decision-making, stress and attitude changes spanned more than four decades, died on Thursday at his home in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 72 years old.

title: Coach Is Gone but Impact Is Felt
description: Just before halftime of Friday night's game in New Jersey between Randolph and Livingston, Gerrick Wilson, a wide receiver for Randolph, was trying to catch up with a pass that seemed hopelessly out of his reach.

title: Directors' New Obsession, in 30 Seconds
description: CLOSE-UP: THE SCULPTURED faces of a woman and a man. The woman is young, fresh faced, the man darker with shifting eyes. As the two move together to kiss, we hear soft strings; the narrator intones, "At his lips' touch she blossomed for him like a flower and the incarnation was complete."

title: Worlds Apart
description: THE ROAD WE ARE ON NOW," our guide Nikolai announces dryly to the busload of American writers and their spouses, "was once called the Boulevard of the Enthusiasts." It picked up that name in the 19th century when political prisoners were herded along it in chains for the long walk to Siberia. Fortunately, we're now headed in the opposite direction, back to Moscow and the seedy comforts of the Hotel Ukraine, after our day trip to the ancient city of Suzdal and its innumerable wooden churches.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Just about a year ago, I stripped a number of layers of paint off the paneled front door of my house. The wood looked so handsome, however, that I decided to repaint only the exterior of the door, leaving the inside natural and simply wiping it down with lemon oil. Last winter, the door warped severely. It straightened in the summer, and I gave it two coats of clear varnish on the inside to seal the wood. Will this help to solve the warping?

title: Holiday Glamour That's Comfortable, Too
description: It starts this week: the entertaining-for-the-holidays season. Whether you invite guests to dinner or go to a party at a friend's, the occasion calls for wearing something special.

title: The Inventor Vanishes
description: THE MISSING REEL The Untold Story ofthe Lost Inventor of Motion Pictures.By Christopher Rawlence.Illustrated. 306 pp. New York:Atheneum. $19.95.

title: Gail Dratch Wed to David Michaels
description: Gail Deborah Dratch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Dratch of Chevy Chase, Md., was married last evening to Dr. David Morris Michaels, the son of Ruth Gruber of New York, and the late Philip H. Michaels. Rabbi Tzvi H. Porath performed the ceremony at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington.

title: A Mountain of Trouble
description: YUCCA MOUNTAIN IS A BARREN, flat-topped ridge rising out of the Nevada desert. Located 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, it stands amid a desolate expanse that is broken every so often by a Joshua tree or yucca plant. The mountain rises some 1,500 feet and runs six miles or so. Within two decades it could hold the most dangerous nuclear facility in the world.

title: London Museums Offer Gift Choices
description: EVEN in the most exotically and comprehensively stocked cathedral to consumerism, you might have difficulty finding, under one roof, a copy of a book entitled "Anatomical Drawings of Biting Flies," a toy Muttaburrasaurus and a stuffed woolly mammoth handcrafted in the Channel Islands. Or, under another single roof , a copy of the Rosetta Stone, black tights with hand-painted Greek symbols and silver earrings after designs by the great Scottish architect and artist, Charles Rennie Mackintosh. Such, however, are the wondrous inventories of London's museum shops -- a boon to visitors in search of holiday gifts.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Hudson Tubes Powerhouse; A Majestic, Aging Giant
description: THERE is an inherent dilemma in the appreciation of historic buildings. Is what we value the pristine, original structure, as the designer conceived it? Or is our principal interest the structure as it has aged, even if it is far from its original state?

title: Congress Asks What It Should Do In the Gulf, and How
description: CONGRESS, or at least enough of it to form the sort of critical mass that attracts media attention, reappeared briefly here last week and found itself engaged in a confusing, ad-hoc debate on American policy in the Persian Gulf.

title: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: Gaining Some Vital Time; Gorbachev Takes Charge to Win Respite From Talk of Coup and Investor's Fears
description: For the first time in many months, Mikhail S. Gorbachev seemed today to have regained his footing on the slippery terrain of Soviet domestic politics.

title: Mary Anne Slattery Weds William Kleen
description: Mary Anne Slattery was married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I., to William Paul Kleen. The Rev. Donald T. Bennett officiated. Mrs. Kleen is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Slattery of Garden City. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Kleen of Gilmore City, Iowa.

title: Anne C. Mitchell To Wed in Spring
description: The engagement of Anne Camille Mitchell to Alexander F. Vitale, a son of the late Judge and Mrs. Alexander Vitale of Woodbury, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. F. N. Mitchell of Bristol, Va. An April wedding is planned.

title: The Region; The Schoolteacher as Budgetary Sacrificial Lamb
description: NEW YORK CITY'S schools are fabled as hideaways for idlers and political hacks. But when Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and the Board of Education were recently forced to come up with plans for saving $90 million, the jobs of more than 4,000 teachers were targeted first for layoffs.

title: A Setback for Polystyrene
description: MANUFACTURERS of polystyrene, the lightweight plastic packaging material, have been struggling for two years to improve their environmental image by establishing a recycling program. But all of their efforts may have been undone by the decision earlier this month by the McDonald's Corporation to switch from plastic foam to paper packaging for its hamburgers.

title: Suddenly, the Specter of Capitalism Is Haunting Intourist
description: INTOURIST, the vast Soviet agency that has monopolized foreign tourism for decades, is packing for a new destination: the world of competition.

title: FAMOUS BY DESIGN
description: ALBRECHT DURER A Biography. By Jane Campbell Hutchison. Illustrated. 247 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $24.95.

title: The Partners' Revolt at Peat Marwick
description: IN THE END, it was the suit that gave him away, a hand-tailored symbol of how far Larry D. Horner had fallen.

title: Decades After Helping Jews Escape, a Psychologist Gains Honor as a Hero
description: To the troubled G.I.'s he counseled in Munich, to the bureaucrats he battled in the District of Columbia welfare department, to the students he taught at George Washington University, William R. Perl was a psychologist with a German accent and an impish if irascible temperament.

title: 2 Camps in the Search for U.N. Refugee Chief
description: A disagreement between the Bush Administration and the Secretary General over who should take charge of helping the world's 15 million refugees is growing more complex as both sides organize separate searches to find the ideal candidate.

title: Campus Life: Rice; Sending Students In Liberal Arts To Medical School
description: In an attempt to prove that the pen is as mighty as the scalpel, and at least as useful in a doctor's life, Rice University and Baylor College of Medicine have begun a program intended to channel liberal arts majors into medicine.

title: Scissors and Shears From Backyard Trash
description: A year ago, Andrew N. Benson looked into his backyard in Purdys, N.Y., and saw the future. Lurking in the malodorous contents of his trash cans were, he believed, the makings of products that would be useful to people and kind to the environment.

title: Retired Nurse Is Bludgeoned to Death in Brooklyn
description: An 83-year-old retired nurse was bludgeoned to death with a bowling trophy in her Brooklyn apartment early yesterday, and the police were searching for a neighbor seen running from the apartment.

title: Yaphank Mall Is Pushed Despite Suits
description: A DEVELOPER who proposes to build a vast commercial and residential complex on top of Long Island's largest supply of pure ground water will proceed with the first part of the enormous project despite legal challenges from environmental groups, the builder said last week.

title: Greed Killed Go for Wand
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Peru Suggests U.S. Rethink Eradication in Land Where Coca Is Still King
description: Slipping his pistol into a desk drawer, Uchiza's Mayor smoothed his shirt and posed proudly by the city seal formally adopted here last month.

title: For Kean, Drew Has Become a Laboratory for His Ideas
description: TEN months after leaving public office, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean says he is thriving in his new role as Drew University's 10th president. A bicycle has replaced the state car and driver, and Cabinet meetings have given way to faculty meetings, but his new position is allowing him to pursue the some of the education reform issues that meant so much to him as Governor.

title: All the Wrong Moves on the Deficit
description: THE agreement on the budget deficit is doomed to failure. All that time and effort were spent debating the wrong problem. The budget deficit is not the cause of our ailing economy, it is a symptom. By focusing on the deficit, our leaders found political accommodation but they did not begin to address the economy's actual short- or long-term problems, let alone solve them. In fact, the budget agreement could actually make our economic situation worse.

title: Review/Music; Soprano to Center Stage
description: Dawn Kotoski, a soprano from Baltimore who studied at the Manhattan School of Music, opened the 30th annual Young Concert Artists series at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday evening. Miss Kotoski was making her New York debut, as a winner of the 1990 Young Concert Artist International Auditions. But she is not entirely unknown to New York audiences. Since 1987, she has been heard in small roles at the Metropolitan Opera and in concert performances.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Long Island City
description: ANN LEGGETT, an artist who has lived in Long Island City since 1979, calls it "big sky country." Ms. Leggett, who uses the first floor of her two-story home on Jackson Avenue as a studio, says "there's plenty of space and the low-level buildings let in lots of sunlight."

title: About Cars; A New Look (Sort of) for Chrysler's Van
description: LEE IACOCCA has done some neat things.

title: A Mystery to Himself
description: THE FACE OF A STRANGER By Anne Perry.328 pp. New York:Fawcett Columbine. $17.95.

title: President's Proclamation
description: Following is the text of President Bush's Thanksgiving Day proclamation: THE WHITE HOUSE *3*By the President of the United States of America A PROCLAMATION

title: Clare Cushman To Wed in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul Cushman Jr. of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Clare Hepburn Cushman, to Amedee Stephane Prouvost, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Amedee Prouvost of Paris. A May wedding is planned.

title: Linda Gatchell, Writer, to Wed
description: The engagement of Linda Gatchell to Tim Holiner has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Frieman of La Jolla, Calif. Mr. Holiner is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Holiner of Brooklyn. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Campus Life: Mills; Still for Women Only, With New Curriculum
description: A half-year after Mills College reversed its decision to admit men for the first time in its 138-year history, faculty members have begun a plan to revitalize the liberal-arts curriculum and thus make ends meet by attracting 225 more female students in the next five years.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Los Angeles; Garment Area Strains Seams
description: THIS city's garment district is outgrowing its historic downtown core, in large part because of Asian manufacturers who are opening new factories to be closer to their retail customers in the United States.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Mt. Arlington Condos Buck Slow Market
description: THOUGH residential construction is slowing in most of New Jersey, in the Morris County community of Mount Arlington a developer is moving ahead with a 591-unit condominium complex. It is set on 100 acres of hilly woodlands in the far southeastern corner of the town.

title: East Hampton Looks Again at Its Stringent Zoning Code
description: IN East Hampton in the early 80's town planners were on the spot. The Republican-controlled government sought to shift the control of subdivisions, environmental reviews, zoning variances and other actions to other departments.

title: Elaine Mack Wed To S. B. Timbers
description: Elaine Charbonneau Mack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Mack of Winnetka, Ill., was married there yesterday to Stephen Bryan Timbers, a son of Mrs. Wesley W. Fink of Englewood, Colo., and the late James George Timbers. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Ventura at SS. Faith, Hope and Charity Roman Catholic Church.

title: J. D. Mandt Weds Pamela Townsend
description: Pamela Townsend, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Peter Townsend of Dallas, was married yesterday to Joseph Daniel Mandt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Mandt of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. N. Paul Vogen performed the ceremony at the South Miami Lutheran Church in Miami.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Wall Street column last week, about the post-election outlook for municipal bond issues, misstated the percentage of such issues approved on the Nov. 6 ballot across the country. It was 41 percent; 59 was the percentage of those rejected.

title: Georgia on Her Mind
description: LOVINGLY, GEORGIA: The Complete Correspondence of Georgia O'Keeffe & Anita Pollitzer. Edited by Clive Giboire. (Touchstone, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $14.95.) "Lovingly Georgia" is more than the complete correspondence between Georgia O'Keeffe and Anita Pollitzer, a friend and fellow artist with whom O'Keeffe exchanged letters for 53 years. It is also the story of a friendship broken after years of affinity and trust. O'Keeffe and Pollitzer met at Columbia University in 1914. Over the next several years, as O'Keeffe took teaching jobs in Virginia, South Carolina and Texas, the two corresponded almost weekly. Lonely and at times depressed, O'Keeffe found in Pollitzer's exuberant letters a link to the world she had left behind. Pollitzer sent books, photographs, art supplies and the latest avant-garde magazines, shared her thoughts on writers and critics, and described plays, art exhibits and lectures she had seen. O'Keeffe was equally expressive, though her letters spoke not of social events or of art ideas but of the huge Texas sky or a lightning storm at night on the prairie. She wrote of her daily schedule, of being lost in her work, unsure of her sanity. In Pollitzer she found not only a sympathetic ear but also an ardent supporter, critic and agent. O'Keeffe periodically sent Pollitzer rolls of drawings, to which she responded with unabashed enthusiasm. "It screams like a maniac & runs around like a dog chasing his tail," she exclaimed of one picture. "They've gotten past the personal stage into the big sort of emotions that are common to big people," she wrote of other works. Both women thought that the most important place to show art was at Alfred Stieglitz' gallery. Without telling her friend, Pollitzer took O'Keeffe's drawings to Stieglitz, whose now legendary response, "Finally a woman on paper," would change O'Keeffe's life. Stieglitz showed O'Keeffe's work and later married her. In 1950, with O'Keeffe's approval, Pollitzer began work on a biography. As the last of the letters in "Lovingly, Georgia" shows, the project came to a bad end after 18 years. (The book, edited by Clive Giboire -- who is also the editor of this volume -- was posthumously published in 1988 as "A Woman on Paper: Georgia O'Keeffe.") "I cannot approve it . . . in any way," wrote O'Keeffe. "It is a very sentimental way you like to imagine me," she observed. "It reads as if we . . . didn't understand one another at all." Yet to judge from the depth and candor of these fascinating letters, O'Keeffe's disavowal seems not only cruel but a denial of the rapport these two women so obviously shared.

title: Rangers Get Proof Miller Can Deliver
description: The puck slid from the Rangers' end of the ice toward the boards behind the Minnesota net. Two North Stars skated for it, casually.

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth; Research Program Hopes to Inspire Women Scientists
description: In an effort toencourage more women to enter the sciences rather than the liberal arts, Dartmouth College has begun a pilot program aimed at providing women students with internships with researchers.

title: Managing; Rankings by the Rank and File
description: TEENA OSGOOD, a second vice president at the Massachussetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, routinely got high marks in coaching and development from her superiors. Then Mass Mutual asked her subordinates to rate her. To everyone's shock -- including hers -- she came out low.

title: New Season of Recitals Opens in Pleasantville
description: A GROUP of music lovers founded the Pleasantville Chamber Music Society 14 years ago with the goal of attracting fine performing artists to their community. But unlike almost all similar presenting organizations in the county, it determined that the concerts should be open to the public without charge.

title:
MUSIC;
Putting Sacred Music Back in the Cathedral
description: JOHN D. NOWIK believes in returning sacred music to the churches and cathedrals for which it was originally composed. Mr. Nowik, who is the organist and choirmaster for the Cathedral of St. Francis of Assisi in Metuchen, is responsible for creating and administering a series of concerts at the cathedral.

title: Gambling Drops in State But Lottery Grows
description: CARL BUSH says he used to come to his favorite Off-Track Betting office in Bridgeport every day. But the 63-year-old retiree says he has cut down on his gambling. Because of the weakened economy, Mr. Bush, like other longtime gamblers, says he does not have as much money to wager.

title: C.I.A. Disciplines Workers Over Rare Stamps
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has closed a four-year-old case by dismissing four employees and disciplining five others who, after discovering that the agency had unknowingly bought 95 valuable stamps for routine use on mail, sold most of them to a stamp dealer.

title: SOVIET UNION
description: To the Editor: The elements and instruments of repression are still very much in place in the land of glasnost and perestroika, as we experienced on a recent trip to the Soviet Union, under the auspices of the World Affairs Council. After a briefing at the U.S. Embassy, we were "invited," i.e., forcefully detained by the police, while shopping on Arbat Street, after purchasing a Russian doll with dollars, as everyone else seemed to be doing.

title: Review/Dance; Stage Potatoes in 'Peeler'
description: Each of the four choreographers who presented works on Thursday night at the Dia Center for the Arts in SoHo created strong images. But not all were able to develop their imagery effectively in this program, which was part of the Salon Project, a choreographers' showcase series coordinated by Susan Osberg and Joan Duddy.

title: Miss Stone Is Engaged To Jonathan Hochwald
description: Dr. and Mrs. Phillip A. Stone of Longmeadow, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Meredith Stone to Jonathan Kirp Evert Hochwald, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald I. Hochwald of Bedford Hills, N.Y. A March wedding is planned.

title: Miss Lebenthal To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. James A. Lebenthal of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Lebenthal to Jeremy Diamond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Diamond of Bowie, Md. A March wedding is planned.

title: Mastering the Soldering Technique
description: SOLDERING is a way of joining pieces of metal, especially sheet metal, plumbing and electrical wiring, by using heat and an additional metallic compound called solder.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Fairfield's Back in the Relocation Game
description: WHILE New York City fights to retain companies considering moves to the suburbs, southwestern Fairfield County, where so many New York companies resettled more than a decade ago, is experiencing a surge of newcomers. This time, they are smaller companies and divisions of the large ones, rather than huge corporations.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: West/Southwest; Longhorns Overpower the Frogs
description: Peter Gardere tied a school record by throwing four touchdown passes, three to the Cash twins, Keith and Kerry, as Texas stayed on course to the Cotton Bowl by beating Texas Christian, 38-10, today.

title: Thailand Tells U.N. to Stop Aiding Burmese
description: The Interior Ministry has threatened to expel United Nations or other refugee officials who assist Burmese dissidents living in Thailand, newspapers reported today.

title: Laura Godman Has Wedding
description: Laura Marie Godman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Godman of New York, was married last evening to Barry Howard Woolfson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin G. Woolfson of Baltimore. Cantor Richard Botton performed the ceremony at the Parker Meridien in New York.

title: Outspoken Ex-Drug Chief Selected to Lead the G.O.P.
description: In a surprising move that was intended to invigorate the demoralized Republican National Committee, President Bush has chosen William J. Bennett, the departing Federal drug policy chief, to be the new party chairman, Administration officials said tonight.

title: SOVIET UNION
description: To the Editor: A friend sent me a copy of the fine article you did about Tbilisi, in Soviet Georgia ("The Treasures of Tbilisi" Travel, Sept. 30). I have had considerable contact with that part of the world and am glad when others are able to share the excitement and pleasure of visiting there.

title: A Low-Fat Alternative
description: This menu represents a breakthrough in low-fat cooking. For several years, I have recommended beating nonfat yogurt with light ricotta cheese as a substitute for heavy cream. However, the curds and whey separated when the mixture was heated. If you wanted to mix the ricotta and yogurt with ingredients that were cooking, you had to remove the other ingredients from the heat first.

title: Canada
description: To the Editor: After traveling for a month around the Maritime Provinces, I was eager to read the articles on Canada's Atlantic Provinces (Travel, Sept. 2). I was surprised to see that there was no mention of the west coast of Newfoundland, which is the more highly visited and more scenic area of the province. (Newfoundlanders themselves say that). The scenery in Gros Morne National Park is comparable to that of Norway, and Lanse aux Meadows at the northern tip of Newfoundland is believed by some to have been the landing point of the Vikings in America.

title: In North Philadelphia, a Struggle for a Revival
description: Some months before Mayor W. Wilson Goode released his 1986 "North Philadelphia Plan: A Guide to Revitalization," he got into his limousine to ride a dozen blocks north of City Hall to a ribbon-cutting.

title: Style Makers; Olivier Echaudemaison, Makeup Artist
description: He has scrubbed, powdered and painted the faces of Princess Caroline, Audrey Hepburn and Sophia Loren, as well as Hubert de Givenchy's models.

title: Black Agents at Firearms Bureau Charge Hiring and Promotion Bias
description: Black agents at the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms have filed a lawsuit charging the agency with discriminating in its hiring, promotion and evaluation of blacks.

title: Climbing a St. Kitts Volcano
description: COLUMBUS called it St. Christopher. The English came there so often they called it St. Kitts. Before them all, the Carib Indians called it Liamuiga -- the fertile land. Mount Liamuiga, a volcano that tops out at nearly 3,800 feet, dominates the Kittitian landscape. It is also known as Mount Misery, a well-deserved appellation, as anyone who has climbed it can attest.

title: Why Breaking Up Is So Very Hard to Do
description: HAVE YOU NOTICED THAT THE tear-jerker rarely gets its due?

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Garment District; The Days of the De Rigeur Address Are Done With
description: ALTHOUGH it rises and falls on the ephemeral, the garment industry has been remarkably resistant to changes in real-estate fashion. A description of 1400 Broadway as "headquarters for many of the leaders in the dress business," which sounds contemporary, was written in 1932.

description: Marcelle Langan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Langan of Setauket, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul Joseph DiFalco, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic J. DiFalco of Commack, L.I. description: Lalyn Read Ottley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Ottley of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married there yesterday to Norman Martin Kenyon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George N. Kenyon Jr. of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Seymour St. John performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Robert Langdon Little; New Child Welfare Chief
description: Robert L. Little, the new head of New York's troubled Child Welfare Administration, is by most accounts a cerebral, unassuming and deft administrator. There is also the inner man less neatly discerned: the former foster child and the quixotic college student, anchored by the streetwise tutelage of Malcolm X, his older brother.

title: Teen-Ager Slain in Harlem After Jostling a Youth
description: A 16-year-old youth was shot to death and his friend was wounded late Friday night in Harlem after they accidently jostled another youth on the street, the police said yesterday.

title:
Your Own Account;
The Discounters' Advantage
description: A BEAR MARKET and a recession shouldn't drive you to drop your investment program. But they could encourage restructering a portfolio, and certainly encourage an attitude of thrift. With that in mind, a discount broker may be the answer.

title: Gregory J. Ressa Is Married to Margo J. Avallone

Ressa, both of Sands Point, L.I. The Rev. Matthew Pravitz performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Crestwood.

title: Mary Eaton Crown Plans March Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. E. Crown of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced March wedding plans for their daughter Mary Eaton Crown and William Russell Corson Ellis, a son of Anne Haskell Ellis of Middletown, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late John C. Ellis.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE. By Jean M. Auel (Crown, $24.95.) Prehistory buffs may be the only readers who'll have fun with Jean M. Auel's latest epic, "The Plains of Passage." In this fourth installment of the Earth's Children series, the adventure begun in "The Clan of the Cave Bear" continues, with Ayla of the Mamutoi and Jondalar of the Zelandonii undertaking a long and tortuous journey on horseback across the wind-swept grasslands of Ice Age Europe in search of Jondalar's kin. Will the two travelers ever reach the camp of the Zelandonii and, if they do, will Jondalar's fellow clansmen recognize him after so long an absence? These questions haunt Jondalar and Ayla throughout the novel, but a more pressing challenge is posed by the natural world that surrounds them, which sets a host of dangers in their path. Although Ms. Auel's descriptions of this world are fairly uninspired, the steamy love scenes between Ayla and Jondalar afford some compensation. Yet these interludes are few and far between, and it's unlikely that all but the most devoted readers will follow them to the book's end. Prehistory buffs with any savvy will also find Ms. Auel's feminist portrayal of the blond, blue-eyed Ayla somewhat hard to swallow. Here is a multilingual woman who, among other talents, is clever enough to invent a contraceptive, in an era when human reproductive capabilities were apparently still a mystery to mankind. Such skills may enhance Ayla's status in the novel -- but among readers they're apt to raise a few eyebrows.

title: Roommates
description: To the Editor:

title: Game Goes To Yale
description: IN what they've called The Game since the days it was, the Yales beat the Harvards, 34-19, yesterday, but the victory in Cambridge was not enough to give the Elis a share of the Ivy League title with Cornell and Dartmouth or to have much of an impact on big-time college football.

title: Ideas & Trends; America's Battle Over How to Remember Its Forgotten War
description: THE Korean War holds an uneasy place in history, squeezed between World War II and Vietnam -- America at its zenith and nadir. The war's legacy is similarly hazy. Was it a victory or a defeat, a heroic stand against Communism or a tragic stalemate? Was the United States a champion of freedom or an interloper pursuing its own cold war games?

title: Jane Mailman Is Married
description: Jane Elizabeth Mailman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd S. Mailman of Baltimore, was married there last evening to Louis Joshua Sosland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil N. Sosland of Mission Hills, Kan. Rabbis Mark Loeb, Alan Cohen and David Bockman officiated at Beth El Congregation. Mrs. Sosland, a graduate of McGill University, received a master's in developmental psychology from the University of Kansas, where she is a candidate for a Ph.D. The bridegroom, a graduate of Harvard University, is an editor of markets for Milling and Baking News in Kansas City, Kan.

title: Taste and Smell Shape A Center's Research
description: EVERY year, more than 150 people, some from as far away as South America and Europe, travel to the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington, hoping to regain their senses of taste and smell.

title: Symbols of America on the Streets of Prague
description: It seemed somehow appropriate that as Vaclav Havel received and welcomed the first American President to visit Czechoslovakia, the Czechoslovaks should hold, wave and drape themselves in American flags, youngsters should hawk Czech translations of the United States Constitution, and a popular independent weekly should cover its front page with the words "We The People" in their distinctive calligraphy.

title: Investing Can Be a Day Job
description: To the Editor:

title: College Football; Penn St. Shocks Notre Dame
description: There were oranges in the end zone.

title: The Blood Bath on His Doorstep
description: ALMOST A REVOLUTION By Shen Tong with Marianne Yen. Illustrated. 342 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: Jennifer O'Reilly Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Jennifer Leigh O'Reilly and Bruce Garner Wilson Jr., the son of Mary W. Wilson of Norwalk, Conn., and Mr. Wilson of Darien, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Leigh T. Ryan of Norwalk, Conn., and Edward F. O'Reilly of Westport, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title: Is There a Klepto in the Stacks?
description: THE New York Public Library, true to the spirit of a knowledge-propagating institution, irrepressibly provides all sorts of facts about itself. Speaking about the Central Research Library on Fifth Avenue at 42d Street, staffers reel off statistics on the number of visitors (1.3 million a year) and the length of the book stacks (88 miles). They'll tell you how many inquiries come to the library's Telephone Reference Service (235,404 this year) and even some of the most common questions people ask: What is the word for fear of the number 13? ("Triskaidekaphobia.") And is the country of Rwanda for sale? (No.) But ask one certain question and the first reaction comes from another great library tradition: Shhhhhhhhh!

title: Sentence for Killing Newborn: Jail Term, Then Birth Control
description: A 17-year-old Florida girl who admitted smothering her newborn daughter in the bathroom of a Jacksonville hospital in April has been sentenced to two years in prison and required to use birth control for 10 years after her release from jail.

title: Cruises
description: To the Editor: My wife and I booked a cruise on the Nordic Prince to sail to Bermuda and Nassau. We booked through White Travel Service in West Hartford, Conn. Because of health problems, I notified White and Royal Caribbean Cruises that we were canceling our booking. Our notice was given by certified mail 37 days before the cruise was to commence.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales

Old Lyme, Conn. 225,000 9 Springfield Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, new year-round beach cottage; within beach assocation, enclosed porch, furnished; taxes $1,227. Westbrook, Conn. 137,000 28 Maple Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old raised ranch; deck off kitchen, office, on cul-de-sac, 0.67 acre; taxes $1,328. Bronxville, N.Y. 835,000 34 Ridgecroft Road 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 55-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, pantry, screened porch; taxes $12,130. North Salem, N.Y. 370,000 Dingle Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 64-year-old farmhouse; fireplace, covered porch, terraces, studio, 4.9 acres; taxes $7,001. Pleasantville, N.Y. 275,000 105 Charlmont Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; family room, office, screened porch, brick patio, log cabin playhouse; taxes $5,917. OTHER AREAS Seaford, L.I. 225,000 4040 Meadow Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split level; new kitchen, den, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $5,000. Allamuchy, N.J. 189,000 Bountiful Drive 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; fireplace, pool, backyard; taxes $2,957. Jackson, N.J. 131,900 East Burke Tavern Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old raised ranch; eat-in-kitchen, 2-acres, fireplace; taxes $2,700.

title: Review/Music; 'Falstaff' Opens Carnegie Opera Series
description: By the time Carnegie Hall's "Opera in Concert" series, a major element of its season-long centennial celebration, got off the ground on Thursday evening, with the Minnesota Orchestra's "Falstaff," conducted by Edo de Waart, the event had come to seem anticlimactic.

title: SETI, PHONE HOME
description: If the SETI project, described by Howard Blum in his article, "SETI, Phone Home" (Oct. 21), picks up any signals at all, they most likely will be "I Love Lucy" reruns from Rupert Murdoch's satellite network.

title: Review/Music; Torch Songs With 'Twin Peaks' Overtones
description: Like almost everything else connected with the television series "Twin Peaks," its wafting, saccharine background music composed by Angelo Badalamenti has an air of deadpan parody about it. Taking the elementary melodic style of early 1960's rock-and-roll ballads, Mr. Badalamenti has softened its edges to create a surrealistic elevator music with quasi-symphonic textures that border on kitsch. And in Julee Cruise, the angelic-voiced soprano who sings occasionally on the series, he and David Lynch, the director and lyricist, have found a vocalist whose affectless delivery recalls early rock-and-roll singers at the same time that her tonal purity evokes loftier genres.

title: A Sidewalk Guide to Watching The Parade on Thanksgiving Day
description: Watching the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade on television is like watching the videotape version of "Ben Hur": everything seems slightly diminished and secondhand.

title: The Ex-Im Bank Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Business Diary column last Sunday misstated the size of Darryl Strawberry's five-year contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers. It is $20.25 million, not $23.5 million.

title: Siobhan Irene Scalia Marries Michael W. Carroll
description: Siobhan Irene Scalia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. Scalia of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael William Carroll, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Carroll of Medfield, Mass. Msgr. Joseph F. Colligan performed the ceremony at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, L.I.

title: Food Store In Jersey: Low Prices And More
description: It's midafternoon, and as usual, Corrado's is thronged with customers. In front of the deli counter, two women chat in Italian as they wait to buy sausage. A woman in a diaphanous pink sari plies the spice aisle. In the produce section, a young Chinese man examines huge papery heads of garlic. Above it all, the P.A. crackles: "Angel! Angel, up front! Angel!"

title: Janice Lieberman Married in Jersey
description: Janice Lynn Lieberman, a daughter of Joan Miller of Hillsdale, N.J., and Saul M. Lieberman of Hackensack, N.J., was married last evening to David Evan Berliner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Berliner of Florham Park, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Barry Hewitt Greene and Cantor Norman Summers at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Klingler Passes For 11 Touchdowns
description: David Klingler threw a National Collegiate Athletic Association record 11 touchdown passes today and tied the record of 47 scoring passes in a season as he led Houston (9-1) to an 84-21 victory over Eastern Washington.

title:
DINING OUT;
Menu Like a Gastronomic Map of China
description: IT is often with mixed feelings that one hears of a restaurant's expanding, for while it is heartening that business is good, there is concern that the quality may decline.

title: Where's the Rest of Him?
description: AN AMERICAN LIFE By Ronald Reagan. Illustrated. 748 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: GOBBLERS ON PARADE

description: HISTORY OF AIDS Emergence and Origin of a Modern Pandemic. By Mirko D. Grmek. Translated by Russell C. Maulitz and Jacalyn Duffin. 279 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $29.95.

title:
DANCE;
Growing Too Tall for 'Nutcracker'?
description: "NUTCRACKER" mania, a seasonal madness that strikes dancing schools between Halloween and New Year's Day and threatens countless families of balletic Soldiers, Angels and Bonbons, broke out last week in full force. From the first day of auditions until the last spun-sugar tutus are packed away, more than 500 performing children around the state will help create the enchanting spell of some version of "The Nutcracker."

title: Pate
description: To the Editor: Will someone please explain how my bringing home a can of French pate to my housebound mother will endanger the health of American animals? Is it that she might give a bit of it to her cat? Or does it threaten the cows grazing on the outskirts of town? Please answer quickly as I'm going back to France for more pate soon. G. VANDENBROECK South Otselic, N.Y. Dr. John H. Blackwell, senior staff microbiologist, Import-Export Products, United States Department of Agriculture, replies: The problem is that animals may be infected with diseases from abroad if the pate was not cooked at a high enough temperature to inactivate disease agents and the can and some of the contents is thrown into the garbage and then gets into the animal food supply. Properly cooked pate, called shelf stable, is allowed into the United States. A traveler may obtain a courtesy permit for its import by writing to the United States Department of Agriculture, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Veterinary Services, Import-Export Products, 6505 Belcrest Road, Hyattsville, Md. 20782.

title: How Sex Killed Frank Wedekind
