description: DIARY OF AN EROTIC LIFE By Frank Wedekind. Edited by Gerhard Hay. Translated by W. E. Yuill. Illustrated. 283 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Basil Blackwell. $24.95.

title: Taking a Hammer To a Faberge Egg
description: To the Editor: The issue of benefiting AIDS charities aside, as I read Stephen Holden's essay about Cole Porter among the rockers [ "Why Cole Porter Prevails -- Be It Pop, Rock or Even Rap," Oct. 21 ] , words like vandalism and desecration came to mind. But neither serves any purpose. The story of how a group of thoroughly inappropriate individuals has gone to Cole Porter's oeuvre as if with a hammer to a Faberge egg under the impression its contents would make a good omelet has to be read in its entirety to be believed. The cliche about spinning in one's grave cannot be resisted in this case. Cole Porter, like most other composers and lyric writers, didn't take kindly to tampering, and he once made his objections very clear in a telegram to Frank Sinatra concerning the latter's rendition of "The Lady Is a Tramp." How quaint Mr. Sinatra's substitution of "broads" for "girls" appears after one has read Mr. Holden's article. Beyond this, Mr. Holden should read the lyrics to "I Get a Kick Out of You" again. It doesn't contain "erotic excitement as the ultimate pleasure" in any greater degree than that found in any one of hundreds of other songs by other composers, an enormous percentage of which were melodically and lyrically dazzling, charming, witty and enchanting -- and certainly doesn't come even close to where the Gershwin-DeSylva "Do It Again" takes things. "I Get a Kick Out of You" never gets into bed, and talks of being "out on a quiet spree" and "fighting vainly the old ennui" and of the adored object providing that "kick" merely by "standing there." Anarchy, to use Mr. Holden's word, was the last thing an elitist like Cole Porter would idealize. It is equally nonsensical to attribute "spoon-moon-June romanticism" in a "prudish age" to such as the Gershwins or Rodgers and Hart. As to the issue of prudishness in general, we are really talking about the failure of a good many people to distinguish between prudishness and what is merely a matter of good taste and true sophistication. ELLIOT WEST Fairlee, Vt. The writer is a novelist.

title: Collectors of Classic Jigsaw Puzzles Love to Pick Up the Pieces
description: IN 1908, jigsaw puzzles were advertised as "all the rage of Newport." Now the puzzles are much the rage in Connecticut. Craftsmen are cutting them from wood, manufacturers are stamping them out of cardboard and at least one collector is saving the puzzles that were such a hit with the smart set in Rhode Island.

title: Irma Kanter Marries Warren Nimetz
description: Irma Jean Kanter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Kanter of Clifton, N.J., was married last evening to Warren Jay Nimetz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Nimetz of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Joseph Herman and Cantor William C. Lieberman performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J.

title: Review/Music; Piano and Cello en Famille
description: The pianist Oxana Yablonskaya has been heard regularly as a soloist in New York since 1977, when she emigrated from the Soviet Union. Her son, Dmitri Yablonsky, a cellist, emigrated with her and completed his studies at the Juilliard School and the Curtis Institute.

title: Debutant's Halo Wins by 2 Lengths In Aqueduct Upset
description: Debutant's Halo came from just off the pace and scored an upset victory yesterday in the $116,600 Grade II Demoiselle Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Aqueduct. The winner, who has done most of her racing at Philadelphia Park and has a reputation for bad behavior, paid $28.80 for $2 to win in her second stakes victory.

title: WOMAN IN THE NEWS: Joan B. Campbell; 'Seasoned Ecumenist' Takes Charge
description: Until she was 40 years old, the Rev. Joan Brown Campbell was a full-time mother, wife, housekeeper and community volunteer.

title: Emma Rymer Is to Be Wed To T. William Roberts 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. William W. Rymer of Providence, R.I., have announced that their daughter Emma Harrison Rymer will be married in May to T. William Roberts 3d, a son of Mr. Roberts Jr. of Villanova, Pa., and the late Frances Kellett Roberts.

title: R. J. Santilli Weds Ann Laupheimer
description: Ann Blair Laupheimer, a daughter of Mrs. William E. Zabel of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and John D. Laupheimer of London, was married yesterday to Robert John Santilli, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Santilli of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. The Rev. Mary Moore Gaines officiated at Christ Episcopal Church in Philadelphia.

title: In Landscapes, Nature Is Rendered With Unnatural Coldness
description: IN the Joseloff Gallery at the University of Hartford, Neil Welliver's show of Maine landscapes begins with a row of canvases each two feet square and painted freely in colors that are quite lush. A century or more ago, these studies would have qualified as preliminaries for the "machines" that make up the rest of the display, although only one of them is repeated.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Janice Weinberg;
Job-Hunting Skills for Tough Times
description: FINDING a job, or changing careers, is usually challenging, but especially so during the kind of slowdown that Connecticut is now experiencing. In her book "How To Win the Job You Really Want," published last year, Janice Weinberg, a career consultant, includes a section on "Looking for a Job During a Recession."

title: Technology; A Thirsty California Is Trying Desalination
description: FACING a possible fifth year of sustained drought, communities along the California coast are looking to desalinated ocean or bay water as a way to quench their thirst and water their lawns.

title: Beth Margel Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence N. Margel of Villanova, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Beth Sharon Margel and David Raymond Dahle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Dahle of Cincinnati. An April wedding is planned. Miss Margel, 25 years old, and her fiance, 26, are graduates of Duke University. She is an employee-benefits consultant with Noble Lowndes, management consultants in Philadelphia. The prospective bridegroom is an insurance broker in Stamford, Conn., with Johnson & Higgins.

title: Drugs in Europe: Signs of a Spreading Plague
description: The 14-hour days spent treating heroin addicts at a clinic in Warsaw leave Helena Baran exhausted. But after spending 10 hours here, listening to grim predictions about crack in Europe, she was alarmed.

title: AN AGE-OLD QUESTION
description: In her article, Jacoby describes a friend, who, at the age of 50, has gone on a liquid diet and reduced her weight to under 100 pounds. Jacoby breezily dismisses this, saying the woman is "searching for a suitable style in which to grow old." In so doing, she implies that self-destructive behavior is par for the course, just another step in a woman's search for identity. LIZA KLEINMAN Middletown, Conn.

title: A Medieval Overlook in Umbria
description: THOUGH it is not specially designated as a scenic route, one of the most beautiful roads in Italy -- its official number is 448 -- winds from Orvieto to Todi, through the varied striking landscape of the upper Tiber Valley. Sometimes the river is hidden, sometimes it winds far below; at one point it broadens into a lake. And all around there are the green hills, the deep valleys that are typical of the region.

title: Budget Agreement Seen as Likely to Help the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Problems With Computer Delay Installation of New Weather Radar
description: Computer problems have caused delays in production of an advanced weather radar system meant to spot tornadoes before they strike and improve all types of forecasting.

title: Nigeria Is Spared the Worst of AIDS, but Experts Wonder for How Long
description: After a long delay that may have lulled Nigerians into a false sense of security, AIDS has begun to creep into the population, especially among prostitutes, prompting warnings that the disease may soon reach the epidemic levels reported elsewhere in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Dr. Ellis Weds Dr. Manuel Ramirez 3d
description: Dr. Mercedes Adelia Ellis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Byron A. Ellis of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Dr. Manuel Leonel Ramirez 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ramirez Jr. of Corpus Christi, Tex. The Rev. Eugene J. Stoklie performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Mary Queen of Heaven.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE DWARFS. By Harold Pinter. (Grove Weidenfeld, $17.95.) It comes as little surprise to discover that Harold Pinter's only novel is composed almost entirely of dialogue. "The Dwarfs" was completed in the early 1950's, before Mr. Pinter wrote any of his plays, before he established himself as one of the most influential voices of his generation. The delayed appearance of "The Dwarfs" is certainly a literary event. Nevertheless, it's easy to see why the novel has taken over 30 years to arrive, and why Mr. Pinter himself told The Paris Review in 1967 that it was "not good enough to be published, really." While some of the original material has evidently been cut and rearranged, what remains can be ferociously vague at times and woefully sophomoric at others. To be sure, a calculated ambiguity combined with a wealth of non sequiturs and a dearth of action emerge as powerful aspects of Mr. Pinter's theater of menace, and scholars will enjoy finding signs of his later work in this preliminary exercise. But such techniques do not make for a compelling novel. (Nor did they succeed, as Mr. Pinter also once acknowledged, when he based a play on "The Dwarfs" in 1960.) The story, if it can be called that, hovers around four characters. Pete, the catalyst, is a reluctant moralist given to internal musings a la Joyce and Beckett. He apparently works in some kind of an office, perhaps involved with "literary research." Though we learn that Virginia is a teacher, that Mark is an actor and a Lothario, and that Len works in an industrial setting, such information is outside Mr. Pinter's existential concerns. In its relentlessly dialectical unfolding, "The Dwarfs" aims to capture nothing less than "this whole bloody racket" called life. As the novel progresses, Mr. Pinter's characters might be accused of simply evaporating -- if they'd ever come into focus in the first place. Throughout, they remain blurry figures, four characters in search of the playwright Mr. Pinter would become, and in need of actors to embody the inflated ideas they represent.

title: Prisoner Sues Over Forced Psychiatric Exam
description: On July 29, 1978, two young Columbia University medical students went for a walk on a heavily wooded 184-acre estate in northern Connecticut that belonged to the uncle of one of them. The next day, Steven M. Asherman, then 28 years old, emerged from the woods and said that he had become separated from Michael Aranow, then 27, after they had been met by some "tough-looking men."

title: The World; Recovering Marcos Assets Proves Trying For Aquino
description: NEARLY five years after former Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos fled the country carrying with him crates of jewels, gold and pesos, the Philippine Government has recovered relatively little of what officials in Manila say was $5 billion to $10 billion in money and assets pillaged from the country he ruled for two decades.

title: Social Events
description: Party and Movie Premiere

title: TOURISM IN ISRAEL TAKES SHARP DROP
description: For the first two months of the Persian Gulf crisis, Israeli tourism officials appeared on television and were quoted in newspapers almost every day calmly reassuring everyone that tensions in the Middle East had no impact on the tourist industry.

title: Beethoven Programs
description: The pianist Gilbert Kalish and Joel Krosnick, the cellist of the Juilliard String Quartet, are to play Beethoven's complete works for cello and piano in two concerts today at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater of Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street. The first program, at 3 P.M., includes the First, Third and Fourth Sonatas and the variations on a theme from Handel's "Judas Maccabaeus." The second program, at 7:30 P.M., includes the Second and Fifth Sonatas and the two sets of variations on themes from Mozart's "Magic Flute." Tickets are $12 for both performances. Information: 307-7171.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Oct. 28 about the 1989 murder of a 14-year-old girl and its effect on a Stony Brook neighborhood located the girl's mother, Bonnie Manners, incorrectly. She was at the left. The woman in the center was Victoria Tinyes.

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Chief to G.O.P. Post

title: Pushing the Pen
description: MRS. HUMPHRY WARD Eminent Victorian,Pre-eminent Edwardian.By John Sutherland.Illustrated. 432 pp. New York:Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: Surprising the Sociologist
description: BRAVE NEW FAMILIES Stories of Domestic Upheaval in Late Twentieth Century America. By Judith Stacey. 328 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: Dr. Joanna Rumerman To Wed Dr. C. S. Fuchs
description: Dr. Joanna Rumerman and Dr. Charles Stewart Fuchs plan to marry in March. The prospective bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Rumerman of Belmont, Mass. Dr. Fuchs is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Fuchs of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
How to Spoil the Grandchildren
description: MY grandparents were about 125 years old, white-haired haggard people who talked only about rheumatism, their bodily functions and what time was lunch. My grandmother wore a bun, black oxfords and had an extensive clothing selection: one Swirl housedress and 175 aprons.

title: Pianists in Search Of a Mozartean Sound and Style
description: Collectors who frequent New York's out-of-print record shops will be familiar with a quaint habit of olden days, when new classical LP's were regularly reviewed in a number of excellent publications. Some consumers cut out the reviews from whichever magazines they followed and taped them to the jacket of the record in question (or, less damagingly but with greater risk of loss, slipped them inside). I enjoy finding old albums thus adorned; it's like finding an old score with a concert or opera program tucked in -- a tangible trace of the history that attaches to the object.

title: Fair Play for Disaffected Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Diane Shapiro Is Married
description: Diane Sue Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Shapiro of Pepper Pike, Ohio, was married last evening to Mark S. Richer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Richer of Wantagh, L.I. Rabbi Benjamin Kamin officiated at the Shaker Heights Country Club in Shaker Heights, Ohio. Mrs. Richer, 31 years old, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received a law degree from Georgetown University. She is an associate in the Washington law firm of Shaw, Pittman, Potts & Trowbridge. The bridegroom, 35, graduated from the Rochester Institute of Technology. He is the director of engineering for the Public Broadcasting Service in Alexandria, Va. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: COURT GETS PLEAS ON NORIEGA TAPES
description: Asserting that "the First Amendment is part of the rule of law, not above it," the Justice Department today urged the Supreme Court to permit a lower court's order barring the broadcast of tapes of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's conversations with his defense team to remain in effect temporarily.

title: Mandela's Group Begins a Recruiting Drive
description: A middle-aged white couple recently walked into the old Arthur Murray dance studio for a rehearsal and found the last waltz saved for the African National Congress.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Hong Kong Tourism Recovering

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Shipwrecked Boxers A. J. Liebling's matchless boxing pieces combine a fan's absorption in the sport with a writer's eye for detail. This is from "A Neutral Corner: Boxing Essays" (North Point).

title:
ART;
Two Campus Galleries in New Rochelle
description: BECAUSE the College of New Rochelle now has three art galleries, with some others promised on the campus, one could in theory spend a whole enriching Sunday afternoon here. The venerable Castle Gallery is now between shows, but the nearby College Center Exhibition Hall, a well-lighted space even if not as grand as its name implies, and the ample white room that is the Gill Library Exhibit Hall, contain work of a high level.

title: A Mexican Menu That Turns Up the Heat
description: WHEN Azteca's opened in New Haven early in 1986, it served the usual Tex-Mex fare with a few tentative renderings of Southwestern dishes. Through the years, the chef and co-owner, Lynne DeLeo, has expanded her repertoire and pushed up the spice thermometer. In the process, a restaurant rated Good now merits Excellent. The basic menu has not changed much, amply showcasing the expected Tex-Mex favorites. But what gives Azteca's its pizazz is the pink list of six special entrees and three appetizers. The first-time diner will best experience Azteca's inventiveness by concentrating on the specials, for they are where the chef's creativity really radiates.

title: A Passionate Slice of America's Past
description: ARGUMENTS over school curriculums, fundamentalist religions, the breakdown of moral and family values, states' rights and the separation of church and state are all topics that could have come from last week's newspapers. Or, for that matter, from any week's headlines and editorials.

title: 2 Parties Optimistic On '91 Suffolk Vote
description: SUFFOLK County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, a Democrat, and Assemblyman John C. Cochrane, the Suffolk Republican leader, looked at the gubernatorial election returns and saw them as good omens -- but for different reasons.

title: Wall Street; A Little Rain From the Accounting Standards Board
description: THE market took a swipe at Circuit City Stores after the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets corporate bookkeeping rules, issued a new guideline on Nov. 6 that will slow the pace at which companies can recognize revenues from the sale of extended service contracts.

title: Arizona Fallout
description: IT may be too early to tell if the decision of Arizona voters to reject an official Martin Luther King Jr. holiday will have an adverse impact on the recruitment of college athletes, but nobody in the state's athletic system seems to think it will help.

title: 'Recycled Solutions' At Rutgers
description: Before reading "Rutgers Confronts a Crossroads" (Sept. 30), I noticed an advertisement in the Sept. 12 issue of the Chronicle of Higher Education. Rutgers wanted to hire a director of media and external relations who would "initiate and continue programs for national publicity and exposure." He or she would be involved "in planning activities which advance the university's mission and goals at the central administration levels."

title: Updating a Tree Ordinance: Property Rights vs. Public Good
description: TREES, said Margaret M. Slavin, the Dobbs Ferry Village Administrator, are like motherhood and apple pie: they represent basic American values and everyone loves them.

title: Donna Bukinik Is a Bride
description: Donna Lynn Bukinik, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel G. Bukinik of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Cristian Joel Delmonico, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Delmonico of Syracuse. Rabbi Charles Davidson and the Rev. Francis Maione, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y. Mrs. Delmonico, 26 years old, graduated from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Her husband, 25, graduated from LeMoyne College. They are market research analysts at the Pyramid Companies, a shopping center developer in Syracuse.

title: POSTINGS: West Side Story; Landmark Seminar
description: The residential boom that has swept the Upper West Side over the last few decades has now been matched by a broad movement toward extensive landmarking in the old neighborhood, but with a twist: The designations of buildings and entire districts in the area has proceeded with so little opposition from residents and owners that Community Board 7 and a local preservation group with the emphatic name of Landmarks West! have teamed up to hold a seminar tomorrow that will explain what landmarking is all about. Their goal is to head off problems among owners, builders and restorers before they arise.

title: Data Bank/November 18, 1990
Bears Leave Lions In the Ivy Cellar
description: While his former team was defending its top ranking in the East in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III playoffs yesterday on Long Island, Mickey Kwiatkow- ski's new team, Brown, was battling Columbia in upper Manhattan for a more dubious honor: the chance to escape the Ivy League cellar in the final game of the season.

title: Wanted: A Kindler, Gentler Germany
description: THE world needs a stable, civil united Germany and the Federal elections on December 2 may tell the world if it will get one. But already Chancellor Helmut Kohl's main challenger, Oskar Lafontaine of the German Social Democrats, has said that if he wins, he will reduce immigration and asylum rights. Granted, a united Germany can only handle so many new arrivals added to the 16 million poor eastern Germans now folded into the West. But as the rise in racial attacks, Jewish cemetary desecrations and neo-Nazi activity attests, unification has already made some people more aware of themselves as Germans and less tolerant of those who are not. Government policies restricting rights for foreigners will reinforce this view. Chancellor Kohl and his party, the Christian Democratic Union, is in favor of restricting immigration except to foreigners of German ancestry.

title: Can Bliss Survive the Fadeout?
description: WHEN JAMES SPADER stalks into a restaurant at the end of "White Palace," he has the determination of Prince Charming searching through the kingdom for Cinderella's tiny foot, or at least Richard Gere carrying Debra Winger out of that factory in "An Officer and a Gentleman." He is a 27-year-old advertising executive bound to win back his 43-year-old-waitress lover. (Yes, she looks like Susan Sarandon, but that's a little fact we're meant to ignore.)

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Most Big Books drone on and on, smearing formulaic characters, plots and dialogue over the pages. UNDER SIEGE by Stephen Coonts (Pocket Books, $19.95) is a step above that. His characters do tend to be stereotypes, but Mr. Coonts knows how to write and build suspense. "Under Siege" is on the best-seller list, and deserves to be. Here is escape reading at its best.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 18, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 DAWN, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.95.) A series of horrors besets a Virginia schoolgirl. 2 5 DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) Unexpected crises wreck a man's safe world. 3 4 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) A former Federal prosecutor reluctantly defends his daughter-in-law. 4 8 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 5 4 THE CAPTIVE, by Victoria Holt. (Fawcett, $5.95.) A 19th-century woman's adventures. 6 3 SORCERESS OF DARSHIVA, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $5.95.) The fourth volume in "The Malloreon," a fantasy series. 7 1 THE GREAT AND SECRET SHOW, by Clive Barker. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) The mail he reads in a dead-letter office engages a man in a cosmic struggle both barbaric and baroque. 8 2 EXILES, by Howard Weinstein. (Pocket, $4.50.) A new "Star Trek" novel. 9 8 POSTCARDS FROM THE EDGE, by Carrie Fisher. (Pocket, $4.95.) A starlet's encounters with drugs and her quest for the right man. 10 * 2 DEFCON ONE, by Joe Weber. (Jove, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative is trapped in the Kremlin as glasnost fails and the Soviets plan a first strike. 11 * 7 THE SECRET DIARY OF LAURA PALMER, as seen by Jennifer Lynch. (Pocket, $8.95.) The journal of a "Twin Peaks" television character. 12 8 OLDEST LIVING CONFEDERATE WIDOW TELLS ALL, by Allan Gurganus. (Ivy, $6.95.) A 99-year-old woman reflects on her past. 13 7 THE MINOTAUR, by Stephen Coonts. (Dell, $5.95.) The hunt for a mole in the Pentagon. 14 7 CALIFORNIA GOLD, by John Jakes. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A young man makes his fortune. 15 51 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $5.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis. 16 * 25 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Ivy, $5.95.) Chinese-American women and their mothers. 17 * 19 SO WORTHY MY LOVE, by Kathleen E. Woodiwiss. (Avon, $5.95.) The abduction of a woman leads to romance in Elizabethan England. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 52 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 369 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 3 8 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $8.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's, as witnessed by a young bond trader. 4 3 HIGH TREASON, by Robert J. Groden and Harrison Edward Livingstone. (Berkley, $6.50.) Evidence to suggest that the assassination of John F. Kennedy resulted from a massive conspiracy. 5 24 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $9.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 6 * 14 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict over the past decade. 7 * 1 HENRY AND JUNE, by Anais Nin. (Harvest/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $8.95.) A young woman's sexual awakening in Paris, as recorded in her diary. 8 10 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) A historian recalls her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. 9 1 MY TURN, by Nancy Reagan with William Novak. (Dell, $5.95.) The memoirs of the former First Lady. 10 * 10 AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN, by Tracy Kidder. (Avon, $9.95.) A year in the life of a fifth-grade teacher in Holyoke, Mass. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 8 THE AUTHORITATIVE CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons. 2 2 WIENER DOG ART, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $7.95.) "Far Side" cartoons. 3 4 THE "LATE NIGHT WITH DAVID LETTERMAN" BOOK OF TOP TEN LISTS, by David Letterman, Steve O'Donnell, et al. (Pocket, $8.95.) Humor. 4 115 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperSanFrancisco, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people. 5 4 THE OLD FARMER'S ALMANAC 1991. (Yankee Publishing, $2.95.) The 199th annual edition. 6 * 4 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Works in Progress; A View From The Bridge
description: Having looked Abraham Lincoln in the eye (left), Tim Vogt reports that the President's gaze is steady. And though Lincoln's visage has weathered - "There's a crack across the bridge of the nose," Vogt says - he's in pretty good shape overall, and so are his three companions on Mount Rushmore. (Washington, Jefferson and Theodore Roosevelt, if you've forgotten).

title: Sweet Corn Has a Bountiful History
description: A CLUSTER of ornamental corn hung by the door meant a bountiful harvest. At least it did in Colonial days. More recently, a cluster of ornamental corn hung on or near the front door has become a decorative tradition much the same as lights strung on trees and shrubs at Christmas time.

title: The World; To Serve Its New Politics, Poland Re-Invents the TV Ad
description: NONE of the candidates speak in sound bites. Nobody has climbed atop a tank, and space-age graphics seem light years away. But as Poland prepares to hold its first free presidential elections since 1922, its voters are being electronically courted as never before.

title: Rose Deserves to Be on the Hall of Fame Ballot
description: BASEBALL'S Hall of Fame is trying to pick Pete Rose off its 1992 ballot with what amounts to a hidden-ball trick. But if the Hall of Fame succeeds, it will have spurned the wishes of the late Bart Giamatti, the commissioner who suspended Rose, that the defrocked Cincinnati Reds' manager be voted upon like any other eligible candidate.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AVA: My Story. By Ava Gardner. (Bantam, $19.95.) As this highly readable, sardonic memoir makes clear, Ava Gardner did nothing by half. If she drank, it was all night and the whole bottle; if she swore, it was a good long stream of obscenities; if she loved, it was not wisely but too well. If she got mad, well, watch out for the bric-a-brac; Gardner once beaned a persistent but never-to-be-satisfied suitor, Howard Hughes, with a heavy bronze ball. Born in a tiny dot of a North Carolina town, the would-be secretary wound up in Hollywood "green as a spring tobacco leaf" when someone from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer spotted her picture in the window of a photography studio. Gardner had little confidence in her intellect and even less in her talent. "I was never an actress -- none of us kids at Metro were," she says. "We were just good to look at." As for stardom, "it gave me everything I never wanted." Gardner doesn't hold much back. "Ava: My Story," which was compiled from tape recordings made before her death in January 1990, describes her drunken and amatory excesses, her abortions, the battering she took at the hands of George C. Scott, the failures of her three marriages -- and the failures of her husbands. Artie Shaw had "a penchant for self-improvement --

title: Review/Music; Part 1 of a Centenary Retrospective
description: Nobly ambitious if perhaps insufficiently daunted by economic realities and millenarian gloom, Town Hall has begun a 10-year project in which it hopes to survey the cultural achievements of this century. Entitled "Century of Change," the series offers programs and symposiums devoted to all the arts, a decade each year.

title: Sunrise, Sunset
description: Can a 55-year-old actor do better than a 31-year-old actor in one of the juiciest musical comedy roles, especially when both actors are the same person? The role is Tevye, the dairyman hero of "Fiddler on the Roof," and why the question arises at all is because the show has returned to Broadway, where it opens tonight at the Gershwin Theater.

title: On Language; (HED) Folo My Lede (UNHED)
description: "IN THE OLD DAYS," wrote Herb Caen, the San Francisco columnist, "we pounded out the copy with two fingers and hollered 'Boy!' to rush this hot stuff to the composing room. Today you yell 'Boy!' and a girl arrives along with a member of the union grievance committee."

title: Kristin R. Takala To Wed in March
description: March wedding plans for Kristin Richards Takala and Robert Wucker Tishman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tishman of Hollywood, Fla., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph J. Takala of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Susan Jacobson Wed in Virginia
description: Susan Ruth Jacobson, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Marc Jacobson of Norfolk, Va., was married there last evening to Gordon James Coburn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Coburn of Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Rabbi Stuart G. Altshuler officiated at Temple Israel.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY Greyhound Lines is due to submit its bankruptcy reorganization plan in a Dallas court. * The Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills. * Deadline for refiling of dismissed charges against Charles Keating in Los Angeles. TUESDAY: Commerce Department reports housing starts for October. * Union contracts with the United States Postal Service expire. * Philip Morris stands trail in Richmond for alleged violations of the state's new anti-smoking law at a gift shop in its tobacco plant. WEDNESDAY: Scheduled sentencing of Michael Milken by Federal Judge Kimba Wood. THURSDAY: Thanksgiving. FRIDAY: Financial markets open as usual, with few traders likely to participate.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Anheuser-Busch's Bud Bowl May Get a New Contestant
description: WITH the football season more than half over, talk is turning to Super Bowl Sunday and the rivalry between those two powers, Bud and Bud Light.

title: Seles Outlasts Sabatini
description: Over the last few months, Gabriela Sabatini, once as reticent on the court as she is off it, has developed a rebel yell, a venomous glare at the net and a mercenary's appetite for a good fight. Monica Seles, by contrast, has always possessed a signature screech, a menacing squint and an overdose of competitive instincts.

title: Reviews/Music; A Caveman's Sensibility, a Modern Orchestra
description: The American Composers Orchestra has always tried to point up the stylistic variety in contemporary American music, but it has rarely pulled together a more disparate set of works than the three that Paul Lustig Dunkel conducted at Carnegie Hall on the afternoon of Nov. 11.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * General Electric Capital Corp. is offering $250 million in 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 100 through Kidder, Peabody & Co. The notes are rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corp. COMMON STOCK * Chiquita Brands International Inc., Cincinnati, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 2.6 million common shares, of which 1.17 million will be offered in the United States market, through Lehman Brothers. RATINGS * Central Illinois Light Co.'s first mortgage bond and secured pollution control bond rating has been lowered to Aa-2, from Aa-1, by Moody's. The company is based in Peoria, Ill. * Hawaiian Electric Co.'s senior secured debt rating has been lowered to A-, from A, by S.&P. The company is based in Honolulu. * Midlantic Corp.'s rating and that of its affiliates, Midlantic Banks Inc. and Midlantic Funding Corp., are under review with negative implications by S.&P. The corporation is based in Edison, N.J. * Philadelphia's water and sewer revenue bond rating has been lowered to B, from Baa, by Moody's, which also lowered the airport revenue bond rating to Ba, from Baa. * USF&G Corp.'s debt rating has been lowered to A-3, from A-2, by Moody's, and its commercial paper rating to Prime-2, from Prime-1. The insurance holding company is based in Baltimore.

title: President's Post Filled In Corning Revamping
description: Roger G. Ackerman, who has been with Corning Inc. for 28 years, has been named president and chief operating officer as part of a broad reorganization of the management of the company, which is best known for its glass and ceramic products.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Housing Starts...Oct. Wednesday None Thursday None Friday None

title: Faltering Laventhol Is Reportedly Closing
description: The roughly 350 partners of Laventhol & Horwath voted over the weekend at a hastily arranged emergency meeting to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and disband the firm, former Laventhol partners said last night.

title: Min Xiao Marries Michael C. Morris
description: Min Xiao, a daughter of Zhen Dong Xiao and Dr. Mei Qing Zhou of Shanghai, and Michael Charles Morris, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Morris of New York, were married yesterday in New York. Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: TV's Venturesome Programmers Find It's Lonely Out Front
description: After years of trying to stem the tide of fleeing viewers by taking defensive action with their programs, the broadcast networks shifted this fall from rear guard to avant-garde, rallying behind a banner of innovation and experimentation.

title: 2 Arrested in Slaying of 2 Security Guards
description: Two men were arrested yesterday and charged in the killing of two plainclothes security guards at a Queens housing complex last week, the police said.

title: Lien-Sheng Yang, Professor, 76
description: Lien-Sheng Yang, a professor emeritus at Harvard University whose extensive research on Chinese history and Sinology spanned nearly four decades, died on Friday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 76 years old.

title: Challenged Over Europe, Thatcher Refuses to Budge
description: Although fighting for her political life, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said in interviews published today that she would not soften her opposition to a single European currency and central bank and that she might put the matter directly to voters in a national referendum.

title: Coach's Call Works for Devils
description: A bus ride down the New Jersey Turnpike to Philadelphia can apparently inspire a coach to make the right decision on his starting goaltender.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HAROLD C. SCHONBERG and PAUL HUME often disagreed about music, but they have one thing in common: They will celebrate their 75th birthdays together at a symposium at the Juilliard School on Nov. 30 and Dec. 1, sponsored by the Music Critics Association, Lincoln Center and Juilliard.There will be discussions among critics, including the honorees, about the past, present and future of arts coverage in the press. Those are open to the public.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Nov. 5 headed "More of Less From Local TV Stations" reported innovations in news coverage of political campaigns around the country, and criticisms of the coverage.

title: Review/Chamber; A Musical Conversation With the Orford Quartet
description: The economics of the music business have gone a long way toward distorting perhaps its purest medium, the string quartet. Top-of-the-line ensembles command fees that only large audiences can pay for. Old repertory calculated to small rooms finds itself out of place; new repertory abandons intimacy and subtlety in search of big effects.

title: Canada Weighs Aid to U.S.S.R.
description: Canada is examining how it can offer better credit to the Soviet Union to enable Moscow to import grain and other goods now in short supply, Foreign Minister Joe Clark of Canada said Saturday.

title: Despite Order, U.S. Stalls Aid to Poor Children
description: Nine months after the Supreme Court ordered the Social Security Administration to stop denying benefits to poor children with severe physical and mental disabilities, hundreds of thousands of children have yet to receive assistance.

title: Yes, Defend the Schools, but Credibly
description: Strongly and stubbornly, Joseph Fernandez, New York City's Schools Chancellor, has been pursuing a passionate crusade to protect schools from drastic budget cuts. Mayor David Dinkins's latest demands could mean substantial teacher layoffs, and Gov. Mario Cuomo's new plan to close the state's huge budget deficit would cut $75 million from state aid to city schools.

title: Fighting the Iraqis: Four Scenarios, All Disputed
description: As more than 150,000 American reinforcements head for the Persian Gulf region to give the United States what President Bush calls an "offensive military option," the question of how to wage war against Iraq is emerging as a contentious issue.

title: Do Justice to Savings and Loan Speculators
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury to Sell 3-Month and 6-Month Bills
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to today's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Fragrance Marketing Group, Chaska, Minn., a unit of Tsumura International New York, to Hakuhodo, New York, for its new product line, with undisclosed billings.* Golden Grain Co., San Leandro, Calif., a subsidiary of Quaker Oats Co., Chicago, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, for a new food product. Billings have not been decided. The agency handles several other Golden Grain products.* Yves Saint Laurent Parfums Co., Paris, to Partners & Shevack, New York, for the French fragrance company's $5 million United States media buying account.

title: INSIDE
description: Bar on Telecasts By CNN Stays in Force A judge's order barring the Cable News Network from televising recorded conversations between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his lawyers was left in place by the Supreme Court. The vote was 7 to 2, with Justices Thurgood Marshall and Sandra Day O'Connor dissenting. Page A14. Gloomy Real Estate Outlook Prices of commercial property, which are already slumping, are likely to drop sharply in the next two to three years, experts say. Page D1. Losses at Freedom Bank Several charities with more than one account at Freedom National may lose hundreds of thousands of dollars under Federal rules. Page B1.

title: Maria Chiarizia Marries Daniel Levine
description: Maria Ann Chiarizia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Chiarizia Sr. of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel Mark Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Levine of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel and the Rev. James Gardner, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Orienta Beach Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Trading Halted in Italy
description: A strike by floor traders protesting a proposed capital gains tax halted stock trading Friday in Italy. Picket lines formed outside the Milan exchange, Italy's largest, and trading was also blocked in Rome and the other small stock exchanges in the country. The union said the strike will continue until at least Wednesday, when a committee of Parliament has agreed to hear the strikers' grievances.

title: R. L. Rabe Dies at 62, An Expert on Hostages
description: Robert L. Rabe, 62, a retired assistant chief of the Washington police and an authority on dealing with hostage takers and other terrorists, died Thursday at his home in Derwood, Md.

title: GORBACHEV IS FIRM ON GULF SOLUTION
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that he was "convinced" that the Persian Gulf crisis could be settled without war, and added that unspecified "new ideas" were being explored to find a diplomatic solution.

title: Question Box
description: Ahead of Notre Dame Q. Are there any college football teams with a winning record against Notre Dame?

title: Jets' Late Letdown Leads to 17-14 Loss
description: After the Jets' dismal no-touchdown performance against the Miami Dolphins last week, capping a three-game stretch in which the team had just 570 yards of total offense, Coach Bruce Coslet promised that some changes would be made against the Colts this week. "I can't tell you exactly what I'm going to do," he said. "Just wait and see."

title: Diane Frances Lewis Marries Mark Neil Wladis
description: Diane Frances Lewis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Lewis of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Neil Wladis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Wladis of Fayetteville, N.Y. Rabbis Charles A. Kroloff and Pinchas M. Teitz performed the ceremony at the Hilton in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Agassi Wins Title By Beating Edberg
description: Andre Agassi got the biggest victory of his career tonight, , beating Stefan Edberg for the 1900 ATP Tour championship.

title: Tackling the Slopes With Technology
description: NEW technology in the design and construction of skis over the last year has set the industry abuzz.

title: Outdoors: Fond and Fun Tale of Fishing
description: THE butt section of one of my fly rods is plastered with the tiny scales of snapper blues that will remain there for a season or two, reminding me of a fishing adventure with two of my grandsons, Morgan and Jesse Child.

title: Poles Seek to Reverse Output Drop
description: Poland's trailblazing economic program to replace Communism with capitalism has slashed inflation, stabilized the nation's currency and made food lines a thing of the past. But the program now faces one of its biggest tests: reversing the huge drop in economic output that Poland has suffered.

title: 2 Southern Schools Get $38 Million Donations
description: A retired insurance executive's estate donated $38.9 million each to Samford University here, and Asbury Theological Seminary in Wilmore, Ky.

title: But Meir Kahane's Message Refuses to Die; Not Herzl's Zionism
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 18: MONDAY Baxter Intl Inc Crane Co First Intst Bancorp Genuine Parts Co Hormel Geo A & Co PHH Corp TUESDAY BRE Pptys Inc Briggs & Stratton Corp Collins Foods Intl Consolidated Rail Corp HARSCO Corp Hughes Supply Inc Ohio Edison Co Public SVC Enterprise Grp Utd Telecommun Inc(MO) Wells Fargo & Co WEDNESDAY Baltimore Bancorp Bowater Inc City Natl (Beverly Hills) Crystal Brands Inc Fleet/Norstar Finl Group Florida East Coast Inds Inc Marsh & McLennan Cos Inc Northrop Corp FRIDAY Pacific Telesis Group

title: A Theme Song for the Baltics: March of the Customs Posts
description: "On what authority are you stopping me?" the Latvian motorist asked the new Estonian border guard who flagged him down on the road, exemplifying in a simple confrontation the ultimate questions haunting the Soviet Union.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the selection of William J. Bennett to be chairman of the Republican National Committee misattributed a quotation in some copies to Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat. It was Mr. Bennett who called Mr. Rangel a "gasbag," not the other way around. An article about Mr. Bennett appears today on page A16.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
As America Ages, It Walks More, Too
description: THE shift of the dominant population group from 18 to 34 to ages 35 to 55 has dramatically changed the reasons why Americans exercise as well as how they how they exercise.

title: Censure Vote May Topple Government in France
description: France's Socialist Prime Minister, Michel Rocard, today faces the most serious political challenge since he took office 30 months ago -- a censure vote in the National Assembly in which conservatives and Communists are expected to combine against him.

title: Books of The Times; The Group That Thought Theater Could Be Life
description: Real Life Drama The Group Theater and America, 1931-1940 By Wendy Smith Illustrated. 482 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Behind the Bennett Selection: Bush Wants a Battler
description: The choice of William J. Bennett as Republican national chairman grew out of President Bush's judgment that the party needed a lightning rod rather than a low-key strategist to rescue it after months of turmoil, Administration officials said today.

title: Giants Stay Perfect
description: The Giants routed the Detroit Lions, 20-0, today and ran their record to 10-0. They shot down the Lions' run-and-shoot offense with an unusual 2-4-5 defense, and even Bill Parcells, the Giants' cautious coach, was impressed.

title: Good Way to Start For Cornell Coach
description: For Jim Hofher, it was not a bad season. At age 33, in his first head- coaching job and at his alma mater, Cornell, he turned out a championship team.

title: 'MacNeil/Lehrer' Adds Reports From Time
description: Moving to expand its news coverage but not its staff, "The MacNeil/ Lehrer Newshour" will begin presenting occasional reports by correspondents from Time magazine.

title: Designing the New Europe: Plenty to Argue About
description: The leaders of the United States, the Soviet Union and more than 30 other European countries began arriving here today for an extraordinary summit meeting to celebrate the end of the division of Europe and to design ways of guaranteeing peace and democracy on a continent twice ravaged by world war in this century.

title: Emigre From Canada Running Well in Poland
description: A wealthy Polish-born emigre businessman from Canada has suddenly emerged as a dark-horse candidate in the Polish presidential election campaign.

title: Offense Is Off, But Bills Win, 14-0
description: The Buffalo Bills, who entered the game with a league-high 274 points, were limited to Thurman Thomas's two rushing touchdowns in a 14-0 victory over the New England Patriots today.

title: Charities Face Large Losses In Failed Bank
description: Charitable organizations that maintained more than one account in the failed Freedom National Bank stand to lose hundreds of thousands of dollars that they had thought was protected by Federal deposit insurance.

title: Agreement and Discord on Cuomo Cuts
description: New York State's top lawmakers today endorsed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's call to solve the state's $1 billion budget problem without new taxes, borrowing or fiscal legerdemain.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "With the anti-tax climate out there, it's going to make it all the more interesting to watch how the new governors deal with problems in most states. When they realize how bad the fiscal condition of their state is, they will have to call on all their creative powers to balance budgets without tax increases or significant cutbacks, never mind any tax decreases." -- Marcia A. Howard, research director for the National Association of State Budget Officers. [ A1:2. ]

title: But Meir Kahane's Message Refuses to Die; Source of 'Never Again'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Cabaret; Insights Into Neglected Songs of the 1930's
description: Sandra King, an English cabaret singer who made a strong impression in this country five years ago when a concert she gave in Washington was recorded, is making her third appearance in New York since then in a pair of two-night stands -- last Tuesday and Wednesday, and tomorrow and Wednesday -- at Dannys' (346 West 46th Street).

title: MARIJUANA FARMS GO BELOW GROUND
description: Police officers in Southern California have discovered two elaborate underground marijuana farms, which the authorities said were capable of producing $250 million worth of marijuana a year.

title: A Yugoslav Republic Holds a Contested Election
description: Voters in the central Yugoslav republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina cast ballots today in the first multiparty parliamentary elections here in more than half a century.

title: Praise for Gorbachev
description: The Soviet press praised President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reorganization of the Government as a turning point toward ending the Kremlin's paralysis. The move appeared to be a concession to Boris N. Yeltsin, the leader of the Russian republic, but he remained silent.

title: Kindly Reflections on the Carter Era
description: If events wrought havoc with Jimmy Carter's Administration at the time, history has been decidedly good to America's 39th President.

title: Gorgeous Frankensteins
description: The revelation last week that two Grammy Award-winning singers were actually fronts for a third voice(s) was greeted with too much shock. The pair, who call themselves Milli Vanilli, didn't sing a note of the hit record that won them a Grammy last year. And when they performed it "live" they lip-synced to recorded music, miming a voice that belonged to another human.

title: Maryliz Geffert, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Mary Elizabeth Anne Geffert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Geffert of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Frank Todd Herdman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen J. Herdman of Livonia, Mich. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harris Riordan-Hendlin, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Hackensack Golf Club in Emerson, N.J.

title: Dartmouth Gains in Soccer
description: Frazer Leversedge knocked home a rebound with 12 seconds left today to lift Dartmouth to a 2-1 victory over Columbia, sending the Big Green into the regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's soccer tournament. Dartmouth will travel to New Brunswick, N.J., to face Rutgers next weekend.

title: Real Estate Woes Seen Worsening
description: The slump in commercial real estate is almost certain to get worse before it gets better, real estate executives, bankers and other business people say.

title: Finding of Plane Wreckage Ends Mystery About Missing Executive
description: Blan Stewart, a 47-year-old insurance executive, disappeared two years ago, and prosecutors suspected he had faked his death to avoid a theft indictment and to collect $4 million in insurance money. They were wrong.

title: MCA Goes Calling on Capitol Hill
description: MCA Inc., the parent company of Universal Studios and MCA Records, has enlisted some of Washington's heavy hitters to promote its possible sale to the Matsushita Electric Company, Japan's largest electronics company.

title: 2 Soldiers and 2 Civilians Arrested In Theft of Huge Weapons Cache
description: An Army sergeant and three other men have been arrested in the theft of a huge cache of military weapons and explosives, Federal and local officials said Saturday.

title: Leland Goodrich, 91, Scholar and Consultant
description: Leland M. Goodrich, a Columbia University professor emeritus and a United Nations scholar, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: U.S. Says It Has Broken Drug Ring That Buried Cash in Puerto Rico
description: The Federal authorities say they have broken a cocaine-smuggling ring whose leader buried $43 million on a farm in Puerto Rico.

title: Which Industries Should New York Help?
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: A New Twist To Untwist
description: A golf club manufacturer in Freeport, L.I., has developed a new line of woods that eschew the traditional curved club head for one with its back cut out. The line, Cavity Back Woods, is designed to twist less in hitting than conventional woods. Nassau Investment Casting Company introduced the woods last spring. The Cavity Back Woods were used on the Senior PGA Tour this year. Bill Forbes, a technical adviser for the United States Golf Association, said the manufacturer has not asked the association to approve the new design. "I doubt we would disapprove it," said Forbes, noting that its shape does not appear to violate tournament rules. The difference in weighting between a regular wood and one with the C-section in the back removed is likely to be minimal, he said.

title: Manerplaw Journal; In Burmese Jungle, Rebel Fortress Awaits Attack
description: The Karen, one of the largest of the dozen ethnic minorities of Myanmar, have been digging bunkers into the steep, forested, malarial hills that protect Manerplaw, the headquarters camp for insurgents fighting the Burmese military Government.

title: Cuomo Seeks To Overhaul Election Law
description: Calling it an issue of even greater long-term concern than balancing the state budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has said that he will make the overhaul of the state's voting system a legislative priority next year by linking it to the reapportionment of legislative and congressional districts.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Y.& R. Lays Off 30 Employees
description: Young & Rubicam has laid off about 30 employees at its New York office, a spokeswoman said on Friday.

title: The Disappearing Labor Shortage
description: REMEMBER the days, only a year ago, when the fast-food restaurants couldn't find enough counter help? Outfits like McDonald's and Wendy's even recruited teen-agers in city neighborhoods and bused them to suburban restaurants. Help-wanted signs appeared in many windows, and the scramble for entry-level workers in the fast-food industry became the most popular evidence that the nation suffered from a shortage of young workers.

title: French Look to Florida Festival To Help Regain Movie Market
description: The second annual French Film Festival took place here over the last five days, bringing a sprinkling of stars and would-be stars, senior French Government officials, American buyers and 21 new French movies whose producers were hoping for an American sale.

title: Profits Down At Hewlett
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company Friday reported declining earnings for the quarter and year that ended on Oct. 31. Revenues and orders increased for the period, but operating expenses and the cost of goods that were sold grew more rapidly.

title: Many Houses Find Images Are Blurred
description: WHEN the chairman of Simon & Schuster denied last week that the house had bowed to the dictates of its corporate owner by canceling a novel with scenes of uncommon violence, he touched on issues that book publishers rarely address any more -- issues of taste, values and standards.

title: Further Slips in Rates Predicted
description: Credit market analysts say they think the steep slide in interest rates in the last six weeks is probably over. In the next breath, however, they say they expect further declines before the year's end.

title: Black Media Giant's Fire Still Burns
description: John H. Johnson, the owner of Ebony and Jet magazines and one of the richest black men in America, is not altogether happy that 12 percent of his readers are white. "That is more than I would like to have," he said. "I want to be king of the black hill, not the mixed hill."

title: Reviews/Music; 1931 Copland Piano Work In Orchestral Transcription
description: Orchestra transcriptions of piano pieces have a way of devouring their originals. Ravel made ensemble versions from most of his keyboard music, yet in them he does not so much enhance a smaller original as create something wholly new. Thus "Le Tombeau de Couperin" makes dry and austere tributes to the harpsichord into little carnivals of whimsy. The notes are the same (though sections are left out), but the tone and aim are changed.

title: Study Attacks Women's Roles in TV
description: Network television continues to give women fewer leading roles, both on and off screen, than it gives men, says a study released this week that analyzed on-screen portrayals and employment behind the camera during the 1989-90 television season.

title: Dolphins Complete Defensive Renewal
description: JEFF CROSS lounged poolside on Friday afternoon at the Miami Dolphins' practice facility at St. Thomas University here. The Dolphins had nearly completed a focused week of preparation for a Monday night of madness in Joe Robbie Stadium against the dangerous Los Angeles Raiders. Now it was time for music, laughter and reflection.

title: Manager Quits At First Boston
description: Joining the stream of executives departing CS First Boston, Pen King, the national sales manager for the fixed-income department, resigned Friday.

title: Esther R. Boylan, Teacher, Marries
description: Esther Robin Boylan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward S. Boylan of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Myles C. Wolfson, the son of Renee Wolfson of Brooklyn and Nathan Wolfson of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Shmuel Boylan, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Atrium Plaza in Spring Valley, N.Y.

title: J. S. Vogel, Lawyer, and Carol Greitzer, New York City Councilwoman, Marry
description: Carol Greitzer, a member of the New York City Council, and Joshua S. Vogel, a lawyer, were married yesterday in New York. Rabbi Deborah Hirsch performed the ceremony at the restaurant Positano.

title: Firefighter Is Hit by Stolen Car in Brooklyn
description: A New York City firefighter was struck and injured last night by a stolen car while he was on duty in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Sabbath Observance, in Many Forms
description: There is an ancient Jewish belief that if all Jews observe two Sabbaths in a row, the Messiah will have no choice but to come and immediately redeem the world.

title: In New Jersey, a Fear of the Bad Old Days
description: From the gilded casinos of Atlantic City to tiny villages reminiscent of old New England, New Jerseyans are expressing confusion and rage about their Governor, the economy and the future of a state that until recently seemed full of optimism.

title: Diane Hoey Weds Craig Rothenberg
description: Diane Margaret Hoey and Craig Alan Rothenberg, who are publicrelations executives in New York, were married yesterday in Walnut Creek, Calif. The Rev. John Hester, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Charles Familant performed the ceremony at the Boundary Oak Country Club.

title: Neither an Alligator Nor a Crocodile
description: To the Editor: "Sao Paolo Journal: The Pollution Is Horror Enough. Now Alligators" (Nov. 5) reports the "invasion" of areas of Brazil by "alligators."

title: Two Crewmen From Trawler Are Held After a Disturbance
description: Two crewmen from a trawler were being held by the Federal authorities today on assault charges after a shipboard disturbance over unpaid wages.

title: Bridge
description: The international bridge community now has to mourn a death in bridge literature, but the deceased is not a writer. It is the annual series of world championship books (1953-1989) produced by the American Contract Bridge League. Future books will be prepared in England by the World Bridge Federation, and it is to be hoped that the quality will continue on a comparably high level.

title: Simms Finds Time For Pass of the Day
description: The defense usually gives the offense 3 1/2 to 4 seconds to get a pass off in the National Football League: the snap, the quarterback searching for a receiver, the throw.

title: A.T.& T.'s Rivals Find Out Just How Big a Giant Can Be
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has finally learned to throw its weight around effectively, battering the sales and stocks of United Telecom and MCI.

title: The Security Conference: What It Is, What It Has Accomplished
description: ORIGIN Discussions about an East-West security conference go back to Soviet proposals made to Austria in the spring of 1968. Negotiations on membership, including United States and Canadian participation, produced agreement to hold a preparatory conference in Helsinki in January 1973. The Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, commonly known as C.S.C.E., formally began on July 3, 1973, in Helsinki with a meeting of 35 foreign ministers and a proposal by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, for a new charter of relations among all European states and an East-West meeting by the end of that year to end what remained of the cold war. On Aug. 1, 1975, 35 heads of states and representatives of powers, principalities and the Vatican held such a conference in Helsinki and signed a Final Act that has since become known as the Helsinki Accords. THE HELSINKI ACCORDS The final declaration included pledges on the inviolability of frontiers, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and freer and wider dissemination of information, as well as a vow to "respect each other's right freely to choose and develop its political, social and economic and cultural systems." The members agreed on notification of military maneuvers of more than 25,000 troops within about 150 miles of any border. MEMBERS Austria Belgium Britain Bulgaria Canada Cyprus Czechoslolvakie Denmark Finland France Germany* Greece Hungary Iceland Ireland Italy Liechtenstein Luxembourg Malta Monaco The Netherlands Norway Poland Portugal Romania San Marino Spain Sweden Switzerland Turkey Soviet Union United States The Vatican Yugoslavia *East and West Germany were original members. OTHER ACCOMPLISHMENTS Treaty on reducing conventional forces in Europe, which will be signed in Paris on Monday. Negotiations on this treaty, involving the then 23 members of NATO and the Warsaw Pact began in Vienna in April 1989, superseding fruitless talks that the two blocs began in January 1973. "Helsinki Groups" set up in the Soviet Union and other Easters European countries to press Communist governments to fulfill their human rights pledges. These organizations, like Charter 77 in Czechoslovakie, became rallying points for the political opposition and formed the core of the democratic movements that are now in power in Eastern Europe. Agreements on movement of people and ideas. In Madrid in 1983, detailed agreements were signed by conference members. Other arms agreements: Members agreed to the principle of on-site inspection and other "confidence-building measures" in Stockholm in 1986. Agreement on the right to peaceful assembly: Agreement was reached in Copenhagen in June. Other rights in the agreement included freedom of associates and demonstration, the right to own and enjoy property, the right to effective remedies against violations of human rights and condemnation of anti-Semitism. GOALS FOR THE FUTURE A small secretariat. The site is likely to be Prague. A conflict-prevention center in Vienna. Annual meetings of the foreign ministers of the 34 members, and meetings every two years of their heads of state.

title: Time to Go
description: Two great bugaboos have sapped Britain's strength since World War II. One was the fear of encrusted trade unions, the belief that there was no way to break their strangling grip on industry. The other was the fear of losing "sovereignty" to the European Community.

title: Iraqi Leader Talks of Freeing Hostages by Spring
description: President Saddam Hussein will release all Western hostages held in Iraq by late March "unless something would take place that mars the atmosphere of peace," the official Iraqi press agency announced today.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL GOLDEN STATE (NBA) -- Placed Mitch Richmond, guard, on the injured list. Signed Bart Kofoed, guard. HOCKEY PHILADELPHIA (NHL) -- Suspended Kerry Huffman, defenseman, indefinitely without pay, for leaving the team without permission.

title: Montana and 49ers Roll Along
description: In the final minutes, Joe Montana was standing on the sideline and watching the day move along like everyone else. Another Sunday had come and gone, and the San Francisco 49ers were still unbeaten, still unharried and still moving closer to their Monday night meeting with the Giants.

title: Primeval Hollywood
description: To Hollywood, the biblical deserts are in California and biblical times were well within this century. Now there's also a Hollywood version of archeology.

title: A Child's Death Prompts Questions Of How Efforts Failed to Save Him
description: Like many others before him, Yaakov Riegler was known to child welfare officials long before he was beaten unconscious in September, his skull fractured and one leg twisted so viciously that it broke.

title: America's Children, Still at Risk
description: Many major social problems are linked to family disintegration. While the Government cannot replace stable two-parent families, it can reinforce them.

title: Stefanie Beth Bank Weds Evan Barnett Bower
description: Stefanie Beth Bank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Bank of New York, was married yesterday to Evan Barnett Bower, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Bower of Muttontown, L.I. Rabbi Jack Bemporad performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Mrs. Bower and her husband, both 24 years old, are 1988 graduates of Syracuse University. She is the showroom manager in New York of Krystal K. International, a clothing manufacturer in City of Industry, Calif. The bridegroom is a vice president at Bower and Glickman, insurance brokers in Syosset, L.I.

title: Dr. Robert Hofstadter Dies at 75; Won Nobel Prize in Physics in '61
description: Dr. Robert Hofstadter, a Nobel laureate in physics in 1961 for pioneering research into the heart of the nuclear particles that form the basic building blocks of the universe, died Saturday at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The family that plays together stays together? The Olivier family will work together for the first time when they open later this month in J. B. Priestley's "Time and the Conways" at the Old Vic in London.

title: Soviet Press Hails Shifting of Powers
description: The Soviet press praised President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposed reorganization of the Government today as a turning point, although one newspaper asked why he had not done it sooner.

title: Despite 2 Upsets, Bowls Won't Shift
description: Sam Jankovich, the athletic director at the University of Miami, was on the telephone again this morning in an unsuccessful attempt to rearrange the lineup of bowl-game matchups on New Year's Day.

title: Johnson Gets Back in the Running
description: FROM a distance, he looks untouched and unchanged from the images burned into worldwide consciousness two years ago. The muscled arms, thighs and calves, a stunning blur of power and grace: none of it has betrayed him. Now as then, Ben Johnson fairly screams down the track, as if never quite touching it, as if once again the world's fastest human.

title: Dairy Queen Bracing for a Battle
description: Dairy Queen, whose Dillybar and Peanut Buster Parfait frozen desserts and Brazier Burgers have become staples of small-town America, is about to learn if it can withstand an onslaught from the Big Mac.

title: Herbert B. Maw, 97, Former Utah Governor
description: Herbert B. Maw, who served two terms as Governor of Utah in the 1940's, died Saturday. He was 97 years old.

title: Not Oil Nor Jobs
description: Soon after America stepped up to its responsibility in the Persian Gulf, Senator Bob Dole -- ever the cynic, and a prime appeaser of Saddam Hussein -- spelled out the motive he saw behind our action: "O-I-L."

title: Review/Theater; 'Fiddler' Returns, With a Heritage of Its Own
description: In the 26 years since it was first produced on Broadway, "Fiddler on the Roof" has become a universally cherished folk musical. With countless versions performed throughout the world, it is part of our musical heritage, just as the Sholom Aleichem stories on which the show is based derive from an earlier European literary heritage. As the revival that opened last night at the Gershwin Theater proves, "Fiddler on the Roof" has not lost an ounce of its charm or its emotional power.

title: Gail Garramone Marries M. G. Morris
description: Gail Garramone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Garramone of Haworth, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Gregory Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Morris of Stamford, Conn. Judge Larry Hauser of Connecticut Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Chieftains estate in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Tough Times Cut Opportunities for Minority Journalists
description: Reduced advertising and tight economic conditions at most newspapers appear to be hurting the industrywide effort to increase diversity in the nation's newsrooms.

title: Ban on Noriega Tape Telecast Continues
description: The Supreme Court, by a 7-to-2 vote, refused today to lift a Federal district judge's order that temporarily bars the Cable News Network from televising taped telephone conversations between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his legal defense team.

title: Promotion At The Times
description: William L. Pollak has been promoted to senior vice president for circulation at The New York Times.

title: Will Europe Spell Peace C.S.C.E.?
description: American and European hopes for a stable post-cold war order are riding on the 34-nation summit conference that opens today in Paris. It could be another Congress of Vienna, which ended the Napoleonic era in 1815 and ushered in nearly a half-century of peace in Europe. Or it could be another Paris Peace Conference, which concluded World War I in 1919 but produced an uneasy truce that lasted a scant 20 years.

title: Cuomo's Fiscal Shift
description: The harsh budget-cutting plan proposed on Saturday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo represents a drastic policy shift for his administration, which is being guided by a grim new set of economic and political concerns.

title: S.& L. Tries Recasting Self as Victim
description: The $4.5 billion claim filed last week against Drexel Burnham Lambert by the Columbia Savings and Loan Association provides the first look at Drexel's purported manipulation of the securities markets through the eyes of one of its biggest "junk bond" customers and adds new allegations against the failed firm.

title: But Meir Kahane's Message Refuses to Die; His Truest Disciple
description: To the Editor:

title: As Connecticut Budget Picture Darkens, Weicker Faces Grim Tax Choice
description: Throughout his campaign for governor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. sidestepped questions on whether he would raise sales taxes or propose a state income tax to close Connecticut's budget gap.

title: Lynn Brenman Is Wed To Stephen Donheiser
description: Lynn S. Brenman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Brenman of Orlando, Fla., was married yesterday to Stephen Donheiser, the son of Sally S. Donheiser of New York and the late Dr. Emanuel Donheiser. Rabbi Ammiel Hirsch officiated at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Florida's Defeated Governor May Become Drug War Chief
description: President Bush has tentatively decided to name Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida, who was defeated earlier this month in his re-election bid, as the nation's new drug policy adviser, White House officials said today.

title: Again, Clubs for Poets to Read and Rage
description: In the 1970's, the Nuyorican Poets' Cafe, a hole in the wall on the Lower East Side, served a select few: angry young Puerto Rican poets who met to show off their wares and tears in a neighborhood more popular to drug dealers than artists.

title: Can Nets Win On This Trip?
description: The Nets made two West Coast trips last season and returned home each time with the same number of victories they would have had if they hadn't gone. Zero.

title: Head of Hogan Systems Named Equimark Chief
description: Gary W. Fiedler has been named chairman and chief executive of the Equimark Corporation, the Pittsburgh-based bank holding company.

title: In Los Angeles, Hispanic Candidates Get Chance at Spotlight
description: Filling a political void that goes back for more than a century, Hispanic candidates are jostling one another in a campaign to represent a newly redrawn district for the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a superconducting transistor built at Sandia National Laboratories in New Mexico misstated the properties of copper and oxygen. They do not become superconductive -- losing resistance to all electrical current -- at temperatures above minus 320 degrees Fahrenheit; scientists have discovered such chemicals, but they are compounds based on copper and oxygen.

title: Bush, in Germany, Finds Kohl Cool to Gulf Policy, Stressing Talks Instead
description: As President Bush paid a brief visit to Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl offered only lukewarm support today for Mr. Bush's Persian Gulf strategy and referred repeatedly to the idea of conducting negotiations with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: But Meir Kahane's Message Refuses to Die; In a Line of Martyrs
description: To the Editor:

title: Youths Criticize Media On Coverage of Children
description: Citing headline words like "wolf pack," "hoodlums" and "thugs," about 1,000 young people berated a panel of newspaper and television representatives on Saturday for what the youths said was negative coverage of children.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants' New War Cry: 11 and 0
description: EARLY every Monday morning, the phone in Bill Parcells's office at Giants Stadium rings continually. Some of the coach's calls are from former Giant players who want to talk to him about the team's progress through this undefeated season. Not long ago the phone rang and Parcells immediately recognized the voice as that of Phil McConkey.

title: More Painful Cuts for New York City
description: The Cuomo administration's proposed $100 million cut in state aid to New York City would strike hardest at schools, health services and social programs and, coming atop the city's own retrenchments, could force painful new cuts in essential services, city officials said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Signature, Memphis, a printing company, named Thomas P. Nelson senior vice president of corporate planning and development. * Cosmair Inc., New York, a cosmetic holding company, appointed Jean-Pierre Jabart vice president and general manager of its Biotherm division, replacing Margaret M. Sharkey, who was named deputy general manager and senior vice president in charge of marketing in its Lancome division. * Republic Health Corp., Dallas, named H. Neil Campbell vice president, finance, replacing Craig R. Clark, who becomes vice president and chief accounting officer. * Timberland Co., Hampton, N.H., manufacturer of footwear and outdoor gear, appointed Ron Tise vice president of retail. * Universal Foods Corp., Milwaukee, producers of yeast products, named Jacqueline M. Beuadry vice president of human resources, John T. Pool president of the frozen foods division and Mark W. Hayden vice president of sales in the frozen foods division. * Warrantech Corp., Stamford, Conn., sellers of service contracts covering consumer electronics, appointed Richard Rodriguez vice president of operations and Steven M. Thomas vice president of sales in its consumer product services unit. * Weigh-Tronik Inc., Fairmont, Ill., manufacturers of industrial electronic scales, named Salvatore Vinciguerra president and chief executive, succeeding Richard Bradley, who retired. * West Point-Pepperell Inc., West Point, Ga., a subsidiary of Farley Inc., Chicago, that manufactures bed linens, appointed Edgar E. Davis president and chief operating officer.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;
People
description: * William E. Stein, corporate president and chief operating officer of Campbell-Mithun-Esty, has resigned.* McCann-Erickson has made three international appointments. Jerry Cammisa has been named creative director of television at McCann-Erickson, Germany. Edward Pollack and Peter Whitelam have joined McCann-Erickson Hakuhodo, Tokyo, as creative directors.* Fran Nemeth has been named vice president of HDM, Los Angeles.* William F. Donnelly has been appointed vice president of client services at Crispin & Partners Advertising, Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Japan Loans to Soviets
description: Five Japanese commercial banks have lent the Soviet Union $400 million to buy steel pipes and pay for goods imported from Japan, the economic newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported last week. Nihon Keizai said the loans were extended to the Soviet Government-owned Soviet Bank of Foreign Economic Affairs but did not identify the Japanese banks.

title: Britain Still Needs the Iron Lady
