description: Politics is very much a matter of signals, and there is little doubt what signal the Conservative Party would be sending if it got rid of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Saddam Hussein has already indicated what the message would be: Britain is losing heart for the battle.

title: In Cuba, Swapping Bulls for Tractors?
description: Fidel Castro, who has condemned multilateral pressures on Iraq from Cuba's seat on the U.N. Security Council, would have the world believe that his regime faces similar threats: an expanding economic blockade and even a possible U.S. invasion, with the complicity of his late East European allies and perhaps the silent support of the Soviet Union.

title: Linda Goldstein, A Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Linda Ceilia Goldstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Goldstein of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Guy Steel Manuel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andre A. Manuel of Paris. Rabbi Miriam Shapero officiated at the Estherwood mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: But Meir Kahane's Message Refuses to Die; Mourning for Years
description: To the Editor:

title: E. H. Woodburn, 78; Sold Gardening Books
description: Elisabeth H. Woodburn, one of the country's best-known dealers in rare books on horticulture, died yesterday at her home in Hopewell, N.J. She was 78 years old.

title: Metro Matters; Is Panel Set Up To Curb Bias Itself Unlawful?
description: While a special panel reshapes voting districts in New York City, with the mission of electing more black, Hispanic and Asian candidates to the expanded City Council, an even more fundamental campaign is being waged between the lines.

title: But Meir Kahane's Message Refuses to Die
description: To the Editor:

title: Denouncing Torture Does Some Good
description: Hardly anybody was paying attention, but just before adjourning, the Senate gave its advice and consent to the United Nations Convention Against Torture. As with the recently ratified Genocide Convention, this could not happen without a flurry over real or imagined injury to United States sovereignty, but by finally approving it, the Senate did credit to America's honor.

title: Chronicle
description: Honors for 10 human-rights monitors For the Oliviers, a family theater project A music symposium and a joint 75th birthday celebration.

title: Eagles Rally to Edge Falcons
description: Roger Ruzek's 46-yard field goal today with 1 minute 45 seconds remaining and Randall Cunningham's three touchdown passes gave the Philadelphia Eagles a 24-23 victory over the Atlanta Falcons.

title: To Victors Go the Trials After Races Against Taxes
description: In his campaign for governor, John Engler told voters what they apparently wanted to hear.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;
Magazine Ad Revenues Down 2.5% in October
description: More dismal news for publishers: Total magazine ad revenues for October were down 2.5 percent from October 1989, and ad pages were down 6 percent in the period, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.

title: Review/Dance; In Motion, Ambivalence About a Flag
description: Members of Codanceco ran frantically back and forth on Friday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater in Ann Carlson's "Flag."

title: U.S. Export Ban Hurting Makers Of New Devices to Code Messages
description: Advances in technology have created coding devices small enough to be placed on computer chips, allowing even desktop computers to code and decode material at a relatively small cost. And there is a growing appetite for such equipment among many companies and government agencies in the United States and abroad.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Earnhardt Wins Title: Dale Earnhardt wrapped up his fourth Winston Cup championship with a workmanlike third-place finish yesterday in the season-ending Atlanta Journal 500 in Hampton, Ga. Morgan Shepherd won the race, his first victory since March 1986. The 38-year-old Earnhardt, who stayed near the front and led several times, joined the seven-time Nascar champion Richard Petty as the only drivers who have won more than three titles. Earnhardt came into the 500-mile, 328-lap event at Atlanta Motor Speedway leading Mark Martin by just 6 points and needing to keep his Chevrolet Lumina ahead of Martin's Ford Thunderbird to wrap up the $1 million championship. (AP) GOLF Bradley Leads U.S.: Pat Bradley made seven birdies in her first 11 holes yesterday as the United States routed a European all-star team to win the first Solheim Cup, the women's version of the Ryder Cup. Bradley beat Trish Johnson of England, 8 and 7, to help the eight-woman Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour squad to an 11 1/2-4 1/2 victory over the team from the European Tour Women's Professional Golf Association. The Americans, who led by 6-2 after the foursomes on Friday and Saturday, won five of yesterday's eight head-to-head matches and halved another at the Lake Nona Golf Club in Orlando, Fla. (AP) SOCCER U.S. in Scoreless Tie: One year after the United States beat Trinidad and Tobago to qualify for the World Cup finals, the teams met again yesterday in Port of Spain, Trinidad, and played a scoreless tie in an exhibition match. While an overflow crowd of 35,000 crammed National Stadium on Nov. 19, 1989, just 12,000 attended yesterday's game. (AP) RUGBY New York Defeats Moscow: The New York City Rugby All-Stars beat the Moscow All-Stars yesterday, 17-16, at Gaelic Park in the Bronx. Dare Studevant, a 26-year-old computer technician from White Plains, crossed the goal line three times, including once after an 80-yard run, to pace the New Yorkers. Horse Racing Colonial Waters Wins: Colonial Waters earned the first victory of her illness-shortened season in the $174,000 Ladies Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct. The 5-year-old mare, with Jose Santos up, took the lead entering the far turn and held off Buy the Firm by 2 1/4 lengths. Jessi Jessi was a head back in third. Colonial Waters, trained by Leroy Jolley, ran the 1 1/4 miles in 2:05.89 and paid $3.40 for $2 to win. The daughter of Pleasant Colony had previously managed only five races since undergoing intestinal surgery in the spring. COLLEGE SOCCER Tar Heel Women Triumph: The University of North Carolina won the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I women's championship yesterday with a 6-0 rout of Connecticut in Chapel Hill, N.C. Winning its 52d consecutive home game, North Carolina claimed its fifth straight N.C.A.A. championship. The Tar Heels have won eight of the nine N.C.A.A. titles and own a 26-1 tournament record. Six different players scored for North Carolina, which finished the season with a 20-1-1 record. Connecticut finished at 15-8-1. One of the Huskies' victories this season ended the Tar Heels' 103-match unbeaten streak.

title: The Legacy of Helsinki
description: Fifteen years ago last August, the leaders of the 35 members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, meeting in Helsinki, signed a document called a Final Act that recognized the inviolability of the boundaries forcibly redrawn in World War II.

title: A New Deal for Editors: Writers Hire Their Own
description: Ovid Demaris has written several best sellers, but when he finished an early draft of his new nonfiction book about a Las Vegas con man, he picked up the telephone and called the doctor -- Renni Browne, a "book doctor" equipped with a blue pencil and the ability to diagnose weaknesses in manuscripts.

title: Angry Crowd of 70,000 Tells Bulgarian Government to Step Down
description: About 70,000 angry protesters rallied in a central square here today to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov and his Government.

title: Moscow Holds Off On Backing Move For Use Of Force
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met for two hours on Sunday night and early this morning with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, but Mr. Shevardnadze said afterward that Moscow had not yet reached a final decision to support a United Nations resolution that would authorize the use of military force in the Persian Gulf.

title: Barney Frank Is Stricken
description: Representative Barney Frank suffered a mild heart attack while exercising at a health club Saturday night. The 50-year-old Massachusetts Democrat checked himself into Beth Israel Hospital here and was resting comfortably in the intensive care unit today, hospital officials said.

title: Lincoln Center Presents Its New Wing
description: With trumpets, speeches and a mocha-cake model of its newest wing, Lincoln Center officially opened its nearly completed 29-story Samuel B. and David Rose Building yesterday.

title: Children Evacuated at School
description: Some 60 children were evacuated from an elementary school today after complaining of headaches and nausea apparently caused by leaking carbon monoxide, the authorities said. Some children lost consciousness but were revived outside the school, said a spokesman for the Butler County Sheriff's Department. The students were taken to nearby hospitals to be examined.

title: Family Business: Trying to Gain a Brother's Freedom
description: Moments before the Iraqi jetliner touched down at Saddam International Airport this afternoon, Bill Stevenson turned to a fellow passenger and explained that he simply could not be concerned for now about the larger issues of international law and national sovereignty, and of the new American role in the Persian Gulf.

title: Synetic Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leary Stays in Yanks' Fold
description: The Yankees made it official yesterday when they announced that Tim Leary was returning, having agreed to a free-agent contract that could keep him in New York for the next five years and is worth almost $6 million. But it did not necessarily signal their unabashed entry into the pool of available free agents this winter.

title: Flexwatt Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chrysler Wants to Go Nonstop
description: Handcuffed by a lack of money for plant expansion, the Chrysler Corporation is trying to become the first auto maker to squeeze extra production from a United States assembly plant by operating it nearly nonstop.

title: First Chicago Stake By Crown Family
description: The family of the late billionare Henry Crown disclosed that it had acquired a 5.5 percent stake in the First Chicago Corporation, the commercial bank based in Chicago. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Crown family said the shares had been purchased for investment purposes.

title: Harbor Barge Said to Hold Tainted Oil
description: Federal environmental regulators said yesterday that a barge owned by a New York family that operates companies accused of polluting New York Harbor holds as much as 50,000 gallons of oil contaminated by a toxic substance, polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's.

title: Bush Vetos Sanctions On Chemical Weapons
description: President Bush has employed a pocket veto to kill legislation that would have imposed mandatory penalties on nations and companies that promoted the spread of chemical or biological and weapons to developing nations like Iraq.

title: What Is the Need for NATO Now? Where Do East Bloc Nations Fit In?
description: The signing of an East-West treaty today eliminating the Soviet Union's once-intimidating superiority in nonnuclear weapons in Europe may well be one of the final political acts of the Warsaw Pact. As a military alliance, it is already dead.

title: 'Bettelheim Became the Very Evil He Loathed'
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial Takes Hard Look at a Personal-Injury Law Firm
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have said from the beginning that the criminal trial of a prominent lawyer and some of his colleagues on charges of wholesale corruption would provide an unsavory glimpse behind the curtains of a large personal-injury law firm.

title: Dotronix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Homeless Woman Arrested In Death of Her Infant Son
description: A 21-year-old homeless mother, apparently angered by the incessant crying of her 3-week-old son, killed him Sunday by shaking him, causing internal bleeding, the police said.

Critic's Notebook; Senators and Their TV Awareness
description: Several players in the current hearings of the Senate Ethics Committee have noted that there are television cameras in the committee room, and viewers of C-Span and CNN may be noticing the effects of that awareness on the five Senators under investigation.

Maurice N. Richlin, A Screenwriter, 70
description: Maurice N. Richlin, an Oscar-winning screenwriter of "Pillow Talk" who helped create the clumsy Inspector Clouseau in "The Pink Panther," died Tuesday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center. He was 70 years old.

title: Alta Gold Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INSIDE
description: Vanishing Louisiana Habitat Wetlands are sinking into the Gulf of Mexico at an alarmingly rapid rate. Scientists are struggling to save the habitat, which is vital to fish and birds. Science Times, page C1. Milli Vanilli Loses Grammy The pop music group was stripped of the Grammy Award for the hit album it did not sing. Page C15.

title: New Stouffer Foods Chief Has a Background in Wine
description: The Stouffer Foods Corporation, the nation's leading producer of frozen prepared foods, has named E. Michael Moone president and chief executive. He replaces David H. Jennings, who will become chairman.

title: Hologic Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New York City Sells Notes but Pays Higher Interest
description: New York City, entering the credit markets for the first time since the emergence of significant budget problems last month, sold $1.3 billion in short-term notes yesterday, amid a strong demand from investors, city officials said.

title: Americans More Wary of Gulf Policy, Poll Finds
description: Americans are increasingly worried that President Bush, who has been trying to intimidate President Saddam Hussein of Iraq with hostile words and larger troop levels, has been too quick to commit American military forces to the Persian Gulf and has not been working hard enough on a diplomatic solution, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Bridge
description: After a weekend of struggle in Manhattan, six pairs emerged from the area final of the Grand National Pairs and qualified for national playoffs in Atlantic City in March.

title: Dionics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nortankers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ideas for Making Ocean Trap Carbon Dioxide Arouse Hope and Fear
description: SCIENTISTS worried about heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere are devising elaborate schemes for removing one of them, carbon dioxide.

title: Giants-49er Match To Air in Britain
description: The Monday night game on Dec. 3 between the Giants and the San Francisco 49ers will be televised in Britain, starting at 2 A.M. Tuesday.

title: By Design; Dressed-Up Legs
description: The top half may cost a fortune, but the bottom is probably dirt cheap. That's the differential in the newest way to dress for evening. You start out with a gala jacket that can range in price from the thousands to the low hundreds of dollars. Then you put the jacket over a pair of svelte leggings or tights. The top price for most of these will be under $100, and you'll find them at the hosiery counter.

description: At a time when virtually all of Wall Street is decidedly gloomy, William B. Summers Jr., the newly elected chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, has the air of a man who is decidedly upbeat.

title: Chess
description: For the first time since 1949, a non-Soviet woman will be the challenger for the Women's World Championship. The candidates' tournament ended in October in Borzhomi, U.S.S.R., in a tie for first place between Xie Jun of China and Alisa Maric of Yugoslavia, who each scored 4 1/2-2 1/2 in the eight-player round-robin competition.

title: People
description: * Louise Pollock has been appointed senior vice president and associate director of the New York office of Ketchum Public Relations.

title: Police Searching For Bank Official
description: Bank examiners investigating a possible $13 million embezzlement at a bank closed by the state studied the institution's records today, while police searched for its missing president. A handful of angry depositors showed up at the Heritage Loan and Investment Company demanding their money but were turned away by state police. Dozens more called, seeking reassurance that their money was safe.

title: Results Plus
description: CROSS-COUNTRY O'Sullivan Beats Favor for Title

title: Marines on the Edge Are Trained, Ready And Mostly Young
description: With occasional talk of death, grimly realistic chemical warfare drills and the explosion of 81-millimeter mortars being zeroed in, the Second Battalion of the Seventh Marines is palpably preparing for war in its third month here in the Saudi desert.

title: New Jersey Votes to Repeal Truck Sales Tax
description: In a day of parliamentary disorder, the Legislature returned here today for its first session since Election Day and voted to repeal a tax on the sales of heavy trucks, a response to the fervent anti-tax sentiments expressed Nov. 6 by New Jersey voters.

title: Oil Company Campaigns Attracting Some Criticism
description: OIL companies like Texaco Inc. and the Amoco Corporation are running advertising urging consumers to conserve oil, but some marketing and oil industry executives said these campaigns were not likely to create much good will for their sponsors.

Chicopee Journal; Once Again, an Air Base Is a Magnet for Protest
description: At the rear gate of Westover Air Force Base here, Alice Swift quietly made her way through a six-man police guard this morning to take her place amid a ragtag band of 85 Quakers, students and Buddhists, who were beating peace drums and chanting anti-war slogans.

description: The general counsel for Cable News Network said today he was confident that the judge in the case of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega would allow the network to televise taped conversations between the general and his legal team.

description: The company said pre-tax profits were $ 70,300 in the latest quarter, but that net income was again affected negatively by alternate minimum tax calculations.

title: Dow Gains 15.10 Points on Light Volume
description: The stock market managed a gain yesterday even though bond prices came under pressure and the price of oil resumed its climb. The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 61.64 points last week, added 15.10 points, to 2,565.35.

title: In Louisiana, a Critical Wetland Habitat Founders
description: SHEA PENLAND, associate director of the Louisiana Geological Survey, eased a 22-foot skiff out of its slip in this small settlement deep in the bayous of Terrebonne Parish. He nudged the throttle forward and the boat picked up speed, clearing the harbor and skimming over the light chop of Terrebonne Bay toward the barrier islands that protect the estuary and its fragile marsh from the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Boy at Center of Suit For a Marrow Donor Is Dead of Leukemia
description: Jean-Pierre Bosze, a 13-year-old leukemia victim whose father waged an unsuccessful legal battle for a potentially life-saving bone marrow transplant, died today, a spokesman said. He lived in Hoffman Estates, a Chicago suburb.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. is offering $300.1 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit securities through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The offering is backed by 15-year Freddie Mac gold participation certificates, with a coupon of 9 1/2 percent. * MCI Communications Corp., Washington, has filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of about $750 million in subordinated medium-term notes through Merrill Lynch & Co. The offering would be due from nine months to 30 years from the date of issue. Combined with proceeds from an earlier registration, the total value of the offering would be $910 million. * New York State Electric and Gas Co., Ithaca, N.Y., will redeem on Dec. 24 all $75 million outstanding of its first mortgage bonds, 12 1/8 percent series, due 2015. * Philip Morris Cos., New York, is offering $250 million in notes, due in 1994, through Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes, expected to yield 8.80 percent, have an 8 3/4 coupon rate and were priced at 99.825 to yield 96 basis points more than comparable Treasury securities. Noncallable for life, the issue is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's. * Westwood One Inc., Los Angeles, is offering to exchange its 9 percent convertible senior subordinated debentures, due in 2002, for its 6 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2011. Ratings * Glendale Federal Bank's long-term deposit and senior debt ratings have been lowered to Ba-2, from Ba-1, and the subordinated debt rating has been lowered to B-2, from Ba-3, by Moody's. The rating agency also lowered the subordinated debt of GlenFed Inc., the parent of the Glendale, Calif., savings and loan association, to B-3 from B-1.

title: Ontario's New Premier a Surprise to Business
description: The gibes about the People's Republic of Ontario, which greeted the surprise election of a left-wing government in Canada's richest and most populous province in September, are heard less often these days around Toronto's financial district.

title: Yeltsin Rejects Gorbachev's Reorganization Plan
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, today rejected President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for overhauling governmental powers but invited a compromise conditioned on the Kremlin's recognition of the republics' full sovereignty.

title: USR Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dancing Fast Enough in Moscow?
description: Mikhail Gorbachev has pulled off another feat of political judo. Beset by challenges from left and right, he has responded with a sweeping government reorganization that would strengthen his own authority while offering a larger role to the restless Soviet republics.

title: 16 Chinese Gang Members Held in Queens
description: Six leaders of the Green Dragons, a Chinese gang, were arrested yesterday in Queens and charged with violations of a Federal anti-racketeering act, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: National Parties of the Right Take Lead in Yugoslav Voting
description: Nationalist political parties appeared today to have won a sweeping victory over the ruling Communists in parliamentary elections held Sunday in the central Yugoslav Republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina.

Greyhound Financial Plan Filed
description: Nearly six months after the only nationwide passenger-bus system entered Federal bankruptcy protection during a bitter drivers' strike, Greyhound Lines Inc. filed a financial reorganization plan today that calls for the company to repay much of what it owes its largest creditors.

title: Price of Gasoline Drops
description: Gasoline at the pump fell nearly a penny a gallon in the last two weeks, dropping to an average of just under $1.46 a gallon, a national survey found. "This is the first significant change in the downward direction since the invasion of Kuwait," said Trilby Lundberg, an oil analyst whose biweekly Lundberg Survey of 13,500 stations was released on Sunday. The average for all grades of gasoline was $1.4598 a gallon, a drop of 0.94 cent since the survey of Nov. 2. Gasoline has gone up about 28 cents a gallon since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, according to the survey.

title: Man Charged in Boy's Death
description: An Atlantic City man was charged today with aggravated manslaughter in the death of a 3-year-old boy who died from a violent shaking. The man, Dallas Pressley, 26 years old, had already been charged with aggravated assault, child abuse and endangering the welfare of the boy, Steven Weaver. The added charge came after the boy died on Saturday, said the Atlantic County Prosecutor, Jeffrey Blitz. Investigators said the boy was injured while his mother, Stephanie Brown, was shopping on Thursday. Mr. Pressley was Ms. Brown's boyfriend and was living with her, investigators said.

title: Keating Fraud Counts Are Refiled
description: The Los Angeles County District Attorney's office today amended fraud charges against Charles H. Keating Jr. and three other former executives of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, making changes in language that prosecutors said should satisfy the concerns of a state judge.

title: Investor to Limit Stake in Henley
description: Libra Invest and Trade Ltd., a Swiss investment firm controlled by the Lebanese investor Toufic Aboukhater, has agreed not to raise its stake in the Henley Group Inc. above 30 percent. Mr. Aboukhater, an associate of Henley's chairman, Michael Dingman, controls 24.8 percent of Henley's shares. He had been seeking Federal antitrust clearance to buy up to 49.9 percent of Henley, a health and scientific, aerospace and specialty materials concern based in Hampton, N.H.

title: David C. Levy Named Corcoran Head
description: David C. Levy, chancellor of the New School for Social Research in New York City, was named today the director and president of the Corcoran Gallery of Art here. The gallery also issued a statement pledging its support for "freedom of speech, thought, inquiry and artistic expression."

title: Superintendent Picked for Statue of Liberty
description: The National Park Service has appointed a new superintendent for the Statue of Liberty National Monument, which includes Ellis Island. She is M. Ann Belkov, who has been the superintendent of the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve in the New Orleans area since 1988.

title: 3 Are Acquitted of Charges In Purported Stock Scheme
description: A former executive of Bear, Stearns & Company and two other men were acquitted yesterday on charges of conspiracy, perjury and obstruction of justice that were brought after a seven-year investigation into practices in the stock-lending business.

title: Star Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Georges Kaplan, 92, Furrier Who Owned Salon on 5th Avenue
description: Georges Kaplan, a master furrier who had a salon on Fifth Avenue for more than 20 years, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92 years old.

title: At the Summit, a Glance Homeward
description: The public statements and bold smiles of the leaders gathered for the summit of 34 nations were generally as glittering as the city that provided the backdrop. But many a participant might have been distracted by private thoughts on a more pedestrian level, given the problems waiting at home.

title: David Lloyd Kreeger Dead at 81; Insurance Official and Arts Patron
description: David Lloyd Kreeger, retired chairman of Geico, the Government Employees Insurance Company, and an art collector and philanthropist, died on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 81 years old.

title: George Bush, Meet Woodrow Wilson
description: In May 1915, a year after World War I began, Woodrow Wilson called for establishment of a League of Nations, which, through collective means, would prevent future world wars from breaking out. His proposal -- partly embodied in the feeble post-World War I League and then after World War II in the U.N. -- never achieved the kind of collective security he hoped for.

description: A survey of banks has found increased credit restraint, with a large majority tightening standards for commercial real estate loans, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Heavy Winds Delay Shuttle

title: Coach of Giants Sees Beyond the X's and O's
description: With the New York Giants off to a 10-0 start as they await a game Sunday against the Eagles in Philadelphia, they have the opportunity to become one of the National Football League's memorable teams. But they already reflect the importance of the player-coach relationship, which transcends sports.

title: Review/Music; Robert Shaw and Students In 'A German Requiem'
description: Seldom does Carnegie Hall offer a musical event in the form of a final exam, but Sunday afternoon's performance of "A German Requiem" by Brahms was roughly that: the proof of what a gathering of choral directors, orchestra conductors, music administrators and singers had learned under Robert Shaw during five days of seminars and rehearsals.

title: Miss Rudkin Wed to Stephen Gotwald
description: Margaret Mercedes Rudkin, the daughter of Dorothy S. Rudkin of Lake Worth, Fla., and Henry A. Rudkin Jr. of Jackson Hole, Wyo., was married yesterday in Sarasota, Fla., to Stephen McClain Gotwald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Etter Small Gotwald Jr. of York, Pa. The Rev. Donald Jackson of the Unity Church in Sarasota performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother Dorothy Bostwick Campbell.

A traditional symbol of spring, along with fitted navy coats and flower hats, the neat navy suit has given way this season to more exuberant expressions of clothes for the start of warm-weather dressing.

title: Traders in Milan Striking Over Capital Gains Tax Plan
description: For the last two business days, no trading has been conducted on the Milan Stock Exchange because of a strike by floor traders protesting a proposed new capital gains tax and the pace of market-reform plans winding slowly through the Italian Parliament.

title: Split Into 3 Units Set By Santa Fe Pacific
description: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it would split into three independent units as of Dec. 4 in an effort to enhance the company's value for stockholders.

title: Raiders Run Dolphins Right Into The Ground
description: The Raiders strutted into Joe Robbie Stadium here tonight with a two-game losing streak and with a running game that had fizzled. The Dolphins were the new big, bad bullies on the American Conference block and this Monday night showdown was supposed to be a national showing for their peers and doubters, a put-up and shut-up affair specially made for those persistent doubters.

Greene & Company, a New York broker-dealer with a 10.5 percent stake in Shared Medical Systems Corporation, said the company should consider a tender offer, merger or asset sale to increase its stock price. Shared Medical, based in Malvern, Pa., supplies software to hospitals and physicians. In a filing with the Securities and ExchangeCommission, Greene said that Shared Medical's stock was significantly undervalued.

title: The Disgrace: Not Just Noriega's
description: For Manuel Noriega it has been a long, fast fall. A year ago he was a pampered Panamanian dictator, a strongman who stole his country's election, roughed up his opponents and declared Panama at war with the United States. Now he is a Federal prisoner awaiting trial on charges of drug dealing and money laundering, so strapped he may require an appointed lawyer. He is, he says, "at the mercy of a totally unfair and unjust system" of American justice.

title: Man Perishes in Fiery Suicide Outside the Capitol
description: An unidentified man set himself afire and burned to death on the west side of the Capitol today, leaving no immediate clues to the reason for his suicide.

title: Partial Settlement In Chevron Case

Corporation reached a partial settlement with pensioners of the Gulf Corporation in a class-action suit, agreeing to pay benefits and claims of about $25 million to terminated employees. Chevron agreed to vest the pension benefits of all employees dismissed by Gulf between Jan. 1, 1984, and June 30, 1986. Chevron acquired Gulf in 1984.

description: Allegations that researchers at Texas A&M University spiked water with tritium to fake cold nuclear fusion are apparently unfounded, an internal panel said.

title: Young Trumpeters Blow the Clouds Away for Jazz
description: They came flocking to the Louis Armstrong Trumpet Competition in all shapes, colors and sizes. There were big guys wearing ill-fitting suits, small guys looking more like accountants than potential geniuses. But when they took out their trumpets, the workaday facades fell away, leaving a string of enormously talented young trumpeters who set out to blow down the walls of the Baird Auditorium at the Smithsonian Institution.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, said its Bank of America unit had agreed to acquire the deposits and some of the assets of the Los Angeles-based Southwest Federal Savings Association from the Resolution Trust Corporation. Bank of America said it would acquire about $616 million in deposits and about $350 million in residential mortgage and consumer loans. * Blockbuster Entertainment Corp., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said it would buy Erols Inc., a videocassette rental and sales chain, for about $40 million in cash. * Canadian Pacific Hotels Corp., a unit of Canadian Pacific Ltd., Montreal, a holding company, said it had bought Methotels Inc., Phoenix, an operator of hotels, from Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., for an undisclosed amount. * Consolidated National Corp., Washington, an insurance holding company with a 22.5 percent stake in First Executive Corp., Los Angeles, a holding company, said its talks on ways to help reorganize First Executive were at a standstill. * B. F. Goodrich Co., Akron, Ohio, a maker of plastics and specialty chemicals, said it would form a joint venture with Norsk Hydro A.S., Oslo, a maker of fertilizers and oil and gas products, to provide specialized compounds to the European market. * Heritage Media Corp., Dallas, a television and radio company, said that it had completed the acquisition of Pop Radio Corp., an in-store radio network, and added that it would incorporate Pop Radio into its wholly owned subsidiary Actmedia, an in-store marketing company. Terms were not disclosed. * Liberty Financial Services Inc., Boston, a financial services company, formed a new unit called Liberty Distributors, Inc. through the combination of its existing units Pamco Group, Encino, Calif., a marketer of annuities and mutual funds through banks, and Liberty Securities Corp., Boston. * Trinova Corp., Maumee, Ohio, a supplier of power and motion control products, said its Vickers Inc. subsidiary, Troy, Mich., a maker of hydraulic equipment, had sold the businesses of its Statesville, N.C., and Hof, Germany operations to subsidiaries of Garphyttan Industrier A.B., Norsburg, Sweden, for undisclosed terms. * Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Co., Danbury, Conn., purchased the Triton surfactant and alkylphenol business unit from Rohm & Haas Co., Philadelphia, a maker of chemicals and plastics, for an undisclosed amount. * Varian Associates, Palo Alto, Calif., a maker of electron tubes and devices, said it would sell several of its non-core operations to DKP Electronics Inc., a privte company, for undisclosed terms.

title: The Man Who Would Be Thatcher
description: Legend has it that Michael Heseltine, while a student at Oxford University, plotted his career and set as his goal becoming Prime Minister at age 55.

title: Key Rates
Georgia Tech Holds Its No. 1 Ranking, With Reservations
description: Largely because it is the nation's only undefeated major college football team, Georgia Tech remained on top of The New York Times's computer ranking yesterday. The Yellow Jackets, who as champions of the Atlantic Coast Conference will play in the Florida Citrus Bowl against Nebraska on Jan. 1, need a victory over Georgia on Dec. 1 to complete a regular schedule sullied only by a midseason 13-13 tie at North Carolina. Georgia Tech has won nine other games and has been rated No. 1 by The Times's computer four times in the last eight weeks.

title: New Rift in U.S.-Japan Jet Project
description: A year after plans to co-develop an advanced fighter aircraft led to the most bruising confrontation between Japan and the United States in years, the military project has caused new discord. Both countries now blame the other for delays, huge cost overruns and technical problems that are engulfing the effort.

description: Federal officials said today that they had no intention of blocking research on a controversial abortion drug that is being studied as a possible weapon against some cancers -- even for abortion research.

title: Alcohol and Ice
description: Alcohols, like the ones found in antifreeze, usually inhibit the formation of ice by permeating water. Now scientists have found that certain types of alcohols have the opposite effect, encouraging ice formation.

title: Death of a Homeless Man: From Ivy League to Streets
description: Thomas Ebbers had all the advantages. He was financially independent, graduated from an Ivy League college and had a bright future in the 1970's. But when he died at age 47 two months ago, stabbed to death in a park on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, Mr. Ebbers owned only the clothes on his back -- he died a homeless New Yorker who had just begun to climb back from alcoholism and despair.

title: Inquiry Into Zia Crash Reopened by Pakistan

title: A Standout in a Crowded Field

One that stood out from the crowd, however, was the AST Premium Exec from AST Research Inc. of Irvine, Calif.

title: Motorola Shift On Technology
description: Motorola Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed with Qualcomm Inc. to jointly test and develop cellular telephones and other products using so- called code division multiple access technology. The technology involves encoding each cellular phone's signal with a different code, and could allow a twentyfold increase in the capacity of cellular networks.

description: The four basketball coaches sat side by side at the head table. Among them, they had seven Final Four appearances, more than 1,000 career victories, and a stack of conference championships.

title: Andrew Gerzel, Restaurateur, 81
description: Andrew Gerzel, a restaurateur who for the last 25 years managed Sweet's, the 148-year-old seafood restaurant on Fulton and South Streets in lower Manhattan, died on Sunday at the City Hospital Center in Elmurst, Queens. He was 81 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 24 about Arab- Jewish violence in Israel misstated the number of Jews killed last year when a Palestinian steered a bus off a cliff. It was 16, not 13.

title: New Pictures From Space Show Giant Storm on Saturn
description: A storm recently observed on Saturn has grown into one of the largest atmospheric features in the solar system and is now racing around the planet at 1,000 miles an hour, scientists reported today.

title: 20 Die in Rebel Assaults in El Salvador
description: Hundreds of rebels attacked more than a dozen military positions in El Salvador today. At least 20 people were killed and 46 were wounded, the army said.

title: Brady Warns Regulators About Credit
description: Reflecting the growing view in the Bush Administration that unnecessarily tight credit is contributing to softness in the economy, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged bankers and Government regulators last night to take steps to make loans more readily available.

title: Milken's Morals, and Ours
description: The perversity of the public prosecution of Michael Milken was that it ignored what troubled people most. Probably, there is someone out there who turns purple at the mere thought of a man violating a half dozen of the more technical rules in our stock markets (as Mr. Milken did); there is probably someone who believes jaywalkers deserve the death penalty.

title: Postal Contract Talks Fail
description: Negotiators for the United States Postal Service its 660,000 unionized workers failed to settle differences on wages and job security by a midnight deadline Tuesday, sending the dispute into lengthy binding arbitration, which could take three months. No disruption in mail service was expected because Federal law prohibits strikes by postal workers. The unions demanded 8 percent pay increases the first year and 7 percent in each of the next two years. The Postal Service had offered lump sum payments of $950 over two years and pay incentives of up to $1,100 a year.

title: Bernard Diamond, 77, A Psychiatry Professor
description: Dr. Bernard L. Diamond, a professor emeritus of law and psychiatry at the University of California at Berkeley, died on Sunday at the Marin General Hospital in California. He was 77 years old and lived in Ross, Calif.

title: International Mobile Machines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ohrid Journal; Pharoahs in Their Past? So the Yugoslavs Say
description: Few Yugoslavs would argue that what this country, with its many contentious nationalities, needs is yet another group of people who consider themselves different from their neighbors. But that is just what is surfacing in the ethnically mixed republic of Macedonia, where a growing number of residents are claiming descent from ancient migrants from the land of the Pharaohs.

title: Harvest Moon Over Hawaii
description: WITH the brilliant pink sunset as a backdrop and the aroma of roast pig perfuming the air, Keali'i Reichel approaches the microphone and begins a melodic Hawaiian chant.

title: Reviews/Television; Weather: Engine of History, Then Force for Global Unity
description: For the first hour of tonight's two-hour PBS special, "After the Warming," James Burke bustles through several thousand years in a summer suit, explaining how every momentous occurrence, from the development of writing to the rise and fall of the Roman Empire, to the discovery of America by the Vikings, to the Industrial Revolution was caused by the weather. It's quite a performance, a touch monomaniacal no doubt, but easily as plausible an explanation of history as other such grand theories as Marxism or millennialism. This quick course in climatism can be audited at 9 on Channels 13 and 49.

title: Ford Unit Sells Notes Due in '94
description: The Associates Corporation of America, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, is offering $300 million in notes due 1994 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Anticipating Jitters, Not Jingling
description: Store executives across the nation, anticipating a disappointing Christmas season beginning Friday, have already cut back on merchandise and held big sales. But a few, seeing a glimmer of hope in their early November sales, say the situation is so uncertain that results could end up being much better than predicted.

title: Afghan Chief Said to Meet Exiles in Geneva for Talks
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan, on a surprise visit that stirred rumors of a new peace initiative, met today with several Afghan exiles, his spokesman said.

title: Lee Castle, Trumpeter And Band Leader, 75
description: Lee Castle, a trumpeter who led the Jimmy Dorsey Orchestra, died on Friday at Hollywood (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Elmsford, N.Y.

title: CHRONICLE

Circuit Court Judge Donald M. Haddock said Robert Lujan was "an unreasonable danger" to the community.

description: William C. Steere Jr., a sales and marketing executive who has worked for Pfizer Inc. ever since graduating from Stanford University as a biology major in 1959, will be the next president of the $6 billion diversified health-care company. He succeeds Gerald D. Laubach, who is retiring as president on Feb. 1.

Properties and N.F.L. Films.

The company's name has been changed to Whitehall Capital Inc. * Chevron Chemical Co., a subsidiary of Chevron Corp., San Francisco, said it was seeking offers for its fertilizer business. * Crawford & Co., Atlanta, a claims adjusting firm, has acquired Graham Miller Group, London, a loss-adjusting organization, for undisclosed terms. * Domtar Inc., Montreal, a paper products and chemicals company, will cut about 300 jobs as part of a restructuring. * E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Wilmington, Del., predicted earnings growth for 1990 because of the strong performance of its European and petroleum operations. * General Dynamics Corp., St. Louis, the military contractor, said its Atlas IIAS launch vehicle would be used to launch two American Telephone and Telegraph Co. Telestar 4 communications satellites. * General Motors of Canada Ltd. said it would extend its regular Christmas shutdown at two Ontario plants. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, the aircraft company, said it had talks with Malaysia Airlines on a possible sale of MD-11 aircraft. * Montedison S.p.A., the Italian chemicals and pharmaceuticals company, purchased an undisclosed stake in ACX S.A. of France, a supplier of industrial components. * Raytheon Co., Lexington, Mass., a technology and services company, said it had been awarded a $635.4 million contract for the Army's Patriot missile system.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Donald Trump's debts, and another on Monday about troubles in the real estate industry, referred incorrectly to a default on a mortgage loan for the Presidential Plaza apartments, part of the Newport complex in Jersey City. Although members of the LeFrak family have an interest in the companies that own the development, neither the Lefrak Organization nor any member of the family defaulted. Other parts of the Newport project have not defaulted, and Lefrak says its financial condition is good.

title: COOKS ON THE MAP - This Month: Susan McGowan, Deerfield, Mass.;   Giving Thanks With Porridge and Oysters
description: WESTERN Massachusetts is New England as it wants to be, small villages clustered around green and tree-shaded commons, white steeples, handsome old brick and wood frame houses and distinguished preparatory schools.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Kings Finally Get a Victory Sacramento became the last National Basketball Association team to win a game this season as Duane Causwell converted a 3-point play with 38 seconds left last night, lifting the Kings to an 87-82 victory over the Washington Bullets, who got 45 points from Bernard King. The Kings (1-7), who had lost 13 straight dating back to last season, squandered a 17-point lead, then scored 10 of the game's final 12 points to win at the Capital Centre for the first time since November 1983. With Washington holding an 80-77 lead, Wayman Tisdale made a 3-point play to tie the score. Two free throws by Antoine Carr gave Sacramento the lead but King tied the score again with a 20-foot jumper. Causwell then hit a short jumper in the lane while being fouled by Charles Jones. He made the free throw and the Bullets (2-7) did not score again. (AP) Pistons 106, Heat 90: John Salley scored 24 points and the visiting Pistons held Miami without a field goal over 9 minutes 19 seconds of the second half. Mark Aguirre added 22 points and Isiah Thomas had 13 points and 14 assists. The Heat shot only 37.8 percent (31 of 82), including 5 for 23 in the third quarter. Miami trailed, 55-45, when Glen Rice, who scored 19 points, hit a 22-foot jumper with 6:58 left in the third quarter. But the Heat didn't get another basket until Kevin Edwards scored 2:21 into the fourth period. By then, the Pistons led, 77-58, and the margin never went below 16. (AP) Hornets 128, Hawks 121: J. R. Reid led seven Charlotte players in double figures with 23 points as the Hornets, playing at home, handed the Atlanta Hawks their fifth straight loss. Charlotte is 6-6. Last season, it took 19 games before the Hornets had 6 victories. Two free throws by Johnny Newman gave the Hornets their biggest lead, 87-61, with 8:38 to play in the third quarter. Dominique Wilkins scored a game-high 27 points for Atlanta. (AP) Timberwolves 92, Mavericks 91: Tyrone Corbin's tip-in of his own missed shot with three-tenths of a second left in overtime gave Minnesota the victory on Dallas's home court. Brad Davis made one of two free throws with 9.1 seconds remaining to give Dallas a 91-90 advantage. Corbin then missed a shot in the lane and Felton Spencer missed a tip-in before Corbin guided home the winning basket. Tony Campbell scored 28 points and Sam Mitchell 26 as the Timberwolves ended a three-game losing streak. Rolando Blackman led Dallas with 32 points and Derek Harper had 17. (AP) N.H.L. Blues Snap Back Against Jets Gino Cavallini scored the tie-breaking goal with 5:47 left in the third period as the Blues defeated the Winnipeg Jets, 4-2, last night in St. Louis for their seventh victory in eight games. Cavallini took a pass from Jeff Brown and beat Rich Tabaracci with a slap shot from just above the left face-off dot. The Blues avenged a 4-3 loss at Winnipeg on Sunday. In that game, the Jets came from two goals down in the third period to snap St. Louis's winning streak at six games, one short of the team record. (AP)

title: Real Estate; How Deal On Barneys Came About
description: THE deal to bring Barneys, the specialty store, to an office building at 60th Street and Madison Avenue owned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will convert the building into a two-unit commercial condominium.

title: New Trial Ordered For Murder Suspect
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court has thrown out a murder conviction and ordered a new trial for William Outlaw, whom the police have accused of running a violent drug ring in New Haven.

title: Roseburg Closing 3 Lumber Mills
description: Roseburg Forest Products is closing three mills and laying off 700 people for at least a month because of the sluggish market for lumber and plywood.

title: Nets Set Record For Losses On Road
description: The Nets suffered a National Basketball Association record 33d consecutive road loss tonight as Sedale Threatt and Xavier McDaniel keyed a 23-9 spurt to start the third quarter and power the Seattle SuperSonics to a 105-88 victory.

title: Prices Rise as Commodities Fall
description: Another big drop in the price of basic commodities gave impetus to the credit markets yesterday. Prices of Treasury securities rose, and interest rates fell in generally thin trading.

title: BURMA SENTENCES 2 FROM OPPOSITION
description: The military rulers of Myanmar, also called Burma, have sentenced two opposition leaders to 10 years in prison, their toughest move yet against the party that won the nation's general election in May, a politician said today.

title: Giving Aluminum Cans More Muscle
description: The aluminum can has almost replaced the steel can for carbonated beverages. Now aluminum companies, helped by innovations just coming into wide use, are taking on the market for cans containing noncarbonated beverages and foods.

title: Dow Tumbles 35.15, Ending Rally in Stocks
description: Boeing led blue-chip stocks sharply downward yesterday in moderate pre-holiday trading, ending the market's rally. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 35.15 points, to 2,530.20.

description: The Spiritual Life of Children By Robert Coles Illustrated. 358 pages. A Peter Davison Book/ Houghton Mifflin . $22.95.

title: Righetti Talks Move to Other Teams
description: The Yankees continued their off-season pursuit of Dave Righetti yesterday, but the attorney who represents the free-agent relief pitcher said he had begun talks with other teams and hoped to have Righetti signed to a contract in the next month.

title: Hudson Tolls Need $1 Rise, Officials Say
description: Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday that they would seek to raise tolls on the agency's bridges and tunnels by a dollar and the fare on PATH trains by 25 cents.

description: Every time the Knicks and the Houston Rockets play, the spotlight seems to wind up on the matchup of Patrick Ewing and Akeem Olajuwon, the National Basketball Association's most dominant centers.

description: The leaders of seven South Asian countries are to begin a meeting here on Wednesday, at a time of more widespread internal turmoil and greater uncertainty about the region's place in the world than those countries have known in decades.

description: It's a safe bet that a good many offices have some sort of gambling pool based on National Football League or college games. Indeed, the practice is so prevalent and generally considered so innocuous that supervisors who don't actually participate themselves often look the other way when their employees are making their weekly picks.

The order is worth $1.15 billion, the Boeing Company, based in Seattle, said. Gulf Air will use the planes, which will have engines from the General Electric Company, to extend service, including new flights to Singapore and Australia. 11-20-90 1953

And only in the movies could it be put in jeopardy by the adults' worries that their picture-perfect life is not sufficiently conventional for a 5-year-old girl.
