description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has fined the wife of Genentech Inc.'s president and chief executive $162,400 in settlement of her role in an insider trading violation.

title: Worthy Enters Plea
description: James Worthy, the Los Angeles Lakers' second-leading scorer over the last five seasons, pleaded not guilty yesterday in a Houston court to two counts of soliciting prostitution.

title: An Unbeaten Season Possible, Says Shula
description: Don Shula, who knows about undefeated seasons, believes that the Giants or the 49ers can finish the season unbeaten. But that doesn't mean he's happy about it.

title: Bush's Midterm Crisis
description: President Bush's eight-day trip abroad was not planned, so far as is known, as an escape from the troubles that suddenly plague him at home. But he could hardly be blamed if he's enjoying a week of freedom from the nightly news and the daily headlines. First, it was the budget fiasco and the perception of the President as unable either to make up his mind or bring his party along in whatever direction he was going. This after his campaign pledge never, never to raise taxes earned him a steep drop in the polls and the prestigious 1990 Doublespeak Award from the National Council of English Teachers.

title: Mortgage Woes Rise At Citicorp
description: Delinquent mortgages at Citicorp, the nation's largest home lender, increased substantially in the quarter ended Sept. 30, with much of the rise coming from the economically depressed Northeast.

title: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Off in Week
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mostly lower for the week ended yesterday. The easing by the Federal Reserve Board last week has not yet had an appreciable effect on bank deposit rates. It will take time to work its way through the banking system especially during the holiday period.

title: Thanksgiving Tomorrow
description: NEW YORK

title: CHRONICLE
description: It has been 35 years since he played in the Hoosier Little League in Huntington, Ind., but Vice President DAN QUAYLE has finally made it to the Little League Hall of Excellence in Williamsport, Pa. Mr. Quayle has already donated his baseball glove to the Little League. He will be inducted in a ceremony in Washington on Dec. 6, said David Beckwith, a spokesman for Mr. Quayle.

title: Virginia Governor Pressures Military School
description: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder said today that the state's military college should be open to women. It was the first time he had taken a position on the issue since the Federal Government sued over the school's all-male admissions policy in March.

title: Thatcher Vows to Continue Fight To Keep Conservative Leadership
description: Battered but unbowed, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain vowed tonight to continue battling the challenge to her leadership of the bitterly divided Conservative Party majority in Parliament in a second ballot next Tuesday.

title: India Assails Bhopal Pact
description: The Indian Government demanded today that a $470 million settlement between an earlier administration and the Union Carbide Corporation to compensate victims of the 1984 Bhopal disaster be overturned.

title: Company Indicted in Theft of Tenants' Money
description: A once prominent Queens real-estate company and its president were indicted yesterday on charges of embezzling $300,000 from almost 70 cooperative apartment buildings the company managed.

title: Hockey: Notebook; Loss to Referee and Tie With Yale
description: The college hockey season has already has its first officiating controversy about goals, one that counted and one that did not.

title: Acuson Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: The company said share data is adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a stock dividend on Aug. 10.

title: VMS Hotel Investment Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Britain Clears Pub Merger
description: British regulators today approved a merger involving 7,000 pubs owned by Elders IXL Ltd. of Australia and Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Devils Rally, but Kings Regroup and Win
description: Tomas Sandstrom scored the first three goals and set up the game-winner by John Tonelli with 4 minutes 33 seconds to play tonight as the Los Angeles Kings lost a 4-0 lead, then held on to beat the New Jersey Devils, 5-4.

title: DEALS
description: PRO BASKETBALL DENVER (NBA) -- Activated Jerome Lane, forward, from the injured list. Placed Marcus Liberty, forward, on the injured list. Waived Corey Gaines, guard.

title: People
description: * Michael D. Drexler has been appointed worldwide media director at Bozell, New York. * Susan Graham has been named vice president at J. Walter Thompson, Chicago.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dime Savings Bank of New York, New York, named C. David Bushley senior vice president and general manager of mortgage banking. * First International Bank, Chula Vista, Calif., appointed Suzanne Baril vice president and manager of its Bankcard department. * First Western Bancorp Inc., New Castle, Pa., named Thomas O'Shane president and chief executive, replacing John Sant, who is retiring. * Jefferson Bancorp Inc., Miami Beach, named Beverly J. Davis vice president of human resources. * K-Tron International Inc., Pitman, N.J., a manufacturer of digital measurement products, appointed Marcel O. Rohr president and chief operating officer. The company treasurer, Ronald G. Larson, added the titles of senior vice president and chief financial officer. * M/A-Com Inc., Burlington, Mass., a producer of electronic components, named Dr. John M. Herman 3d vice president and general manager of its semiconductor division. * Omega Hydrocarbons Ltd., Calgary, Alberta, named Thomas J. Hall chairman and chief executive. His son, Dennis Hall, replaces him as president. * Technology Applications Inc., Alexandria, Va., a professional and technical services company, promoted Lee Cooper to vice president of its applied sciences division. * Vical Inc., San Diego, a biopharmaceutical company, appointed Dr. Dannie H. King executive vice president and chief technical officer. * Wisconsin Toy Co., New York, a subsidiary of Value Merchants Inc., Milwaukee, named Alan Chaikin president and chief operating officer.

title: Book Notes
description: King's Speech Sources In April, The Free Press will publish "Voice of Deliverance: The Language of Martin Luther King Jr. and Its Sources," by Keith D. Miller. The book will examine the sources used in many of Dr. King's speeches and essays.

title: Market Place; Zenith's Strategy Pressed for Time
description: IT has a grand name, a promising technology but a depressing record of losses. Now, with its stock in the pits and a possible takeover battle on the horizon, the Zenith Electronics Corporation may be running out of time to carry off a strategy to become a technology pioneer.

title: A Japanophile and His Wine
description: SCOTT LATHAM is a man with a vision. An unabashed Japanophile and an aficionado of wine, he has looked to the future and is convinced that a new libation is about to seize the imagination of thirsty New Yorkers.

title: Bowl Games Could Pick Milli Vanilli
description: At least once per annum, usually on the second or third day of the new year, the lords of college football are herewith advised how to run their business.

title: Bush to Visit Moscow
description: The White House said tonight that President Bush hoped to visit Moscow early next year, perhaps in January, if a treaty cutting long-range nuclear arms is completed. But it denied reports that a firm date had been set for the summit meeting.

title: 76ers Sign Turner
description: In an effort to bolster a backcourt disrupted by a season-ending injury to Johnny Dawkins, the Philadelphia 76ers signed the guard Andre Turner to a one-year contract yesterday.

title: Atico Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 391,000, or 7 cents a share.c-Net lossd-Included an extraordinary reversal of tax-loss carryforward of $ 243,000.Year-ago quarter and 9 months losses from continuing operations of $ 37,152,000 and $ 37,109,000, respectively, included pretax restructuring charges of $ 35,301,000.

title: Lechters Inc. reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 27
The Pop Life
description: McFerrin and Voicestra Many of the songs on Bobby McFerrin's new album, "Medicine Music" (EMI), were inspired by what the virtuoso vocalist, composer and performance artist described in a recent interview as "an ancestral calling."

title: Players and Pop Stars: More Millions for Both
description: In the big leagues of sports and pop music, the big names are earning bigger and bigger bucks.

title: VMS Mortgage Investment Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Film; Seeking Truths in Northern Ireland
description: As the camera sweeps over gorgeous green hills, it settles on the cramped, urban cluster of Belfast. There, at an exuberant loyalist parade, an I.R.A. sympathizer surreptitiously passes a tape to an American human-rights activist; the transaction turns out to be a death warrant. "Hidden Agenda," the English director Ken Loach's lucid political thriller about Northern Ireland in the 1980's, is bracketed by such contrasts.

title: F.D.A.'s Tests on Milk Are Called Inadequate
description: Tests by the Food and Drug Administration have failed to determine to what extent drugs given to cows contaminate the nation's milk supply, the General Accounting Office said in a report released today.

title: Bill Would Give Unwed Couples Equal Benefits
description: Unmarried domestic partners would be protected against discrimination and would be able to document their relationship officially under a bill that went before the New York City Council yesterday.

title: Los Angeles Journal; An Amusement Ride? No, a Commuter Train
description: The verdict among the Sunday riders of Los Angeles's brand new experiment in commuter rail transport: better than the Magic Mountain amusement park.

title: Lawmaker Is Candidate for Labor Secretary
description: President Bush is considering Representative Lynn Martin of Illinois to succeed the departing Labor Secretary, Elizabeth Dole, an Administration official said today.

title: Panel Hears of Senators' Antagonism
description: An aide to Senator John McCain testified today that she had warned him that his Arizona colleague, Senator Dennis DeConcini, was trying to pressure him into improper negotiations with Federal regulators on behalf of a savings and loan executive in March 1987.

title: Durrell Gave Landlords a Good Name
description: To the Editor:

title: To Quiet Its Own Critics, China Aims at Japan
description: Perhaps getting tired of criticizing only the United States, China's official press has found a new target: Japan.

title: Ivax Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. AND SOVIETS URGE MORE STEPS BY U.N. IN GULF
description: The United States and the Soviet Union said tonight that further United Nations action would be needed to get Iraq out of Kuwait, but they apparently failed again to reach an agreement on what concrete steps the Security Council should take to achieve that aim.

title: One Empire to Go
description: The original purpose of the 1975 Helsinki conference was to substitute for a World War II German peace treaty, impossible to sign because of two Germanys. So the Soviets settled for a document guaranteeing the postwar borders and, in effect, recognizing two German states.

title: Cincinnati Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Who Makes What in the Major Leagues
description: Contract information was obtained from management and player sources.

title: Advanced Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ekco Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 3.6 million restructuring charge. The company noted that last year's 9-month revenues included $ 10 million from product lines which were sold or liquidated during 1989.

title: VMS Mortgage Investors L.P. II reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeShare earnings are in units.

title: Concord Fabrics Inc. reports earnings for Year to Sept 2
Look to Dirty Needles as African AIDS Source; The TB Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian TV Job Cuts
description: The troubled Australian television network Channel Seven announced on Monday that it would cut 100 jobs and freeze executive salaries for two years. The dismissals occurred at the network's stations in Sydney, Melbourne, Perth and Brisbane. They are Channel Seven's first large-scale cutbacks since receivers were appointed a year ago for Qintex Australia Ltd., the operator of Channel Seven.

title: Gregg to Step Down As Coach at S.M.U.
description: Forrest Gregg said last night that he would step down as Southern Methodist coach after the season finale against Arkansas Saturday but that he would remain the school's athletic director.

title: Greece to Investigate Plan for Guerrilla War
description: Greece's conservative Government has ordered an investigation into a 1955 agreement between the C.I.A. and the Greek military for the establishment of a guerrilla network to fight invading Warsaw Pact forces in the event of a war.

title: Livery-Cab Drivers Slow Traffic to a Walk
description: With horns honking and protest banners flapping from their radio antennas, hundreds of angry livery-cab drivers all but sealed off the Brooklyn Bridge and the Queens-Midtown Tunnel in the morning rush yesterday and slowed traffic on other major highways to somewhere between the pace of a glacier and a snail.

title: 9 1/2% Notes Sold By ICI Financial
description: The ICI Financial Corporation, a unit of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., is offering $300 million in notes due 2000 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Review/Opera; Piano and Some Staging For Contemporary Works
description: The Center for Contemporary Opera, an eight-year-old organization that specializes in chamber operas with English librettos, has just started a workshop program in which it is presenting new works with piano accompaniment and rudimentary staging. The first offering in the series was presented on Sunday afternoon at the Turtle Bay Music School and was a pairing of one-act works with contemporary political themes.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Our common future may be darkened by the sinister clouds of the resurging conflicts of bygone days unless the split into a rich and a poor Europe, an 'A' class and a 'B' class Europe, is overcome." -- Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland. [ A1:4. ]

title: Valdice Prison Blues a Bit Happier Now
description: In a concrete workshop hall in the maximum-security prison here, inmates in blue cotton prison pants and jackets recently cheered enthusiastically as a leading Czech country-western singer performed such favorites as the Czech-language version of Johnny Cash's "Folsom Prison Blues."

title: S.E.C. Suit on Manipulation
description: Federal securities regulators sued nine people and a North Providence, R.I., brokerage firm today, accusing them of a huge manipulation of seven penny stocks over a two-year period.

title: U.S. Banknote Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 7,081,000, or $ 1.16 a share, and an extraordinary loss of $ 440,000.c-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $ 98,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 256,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9 months also included an extraordinary loss of $ 626,000.Income from discontinued operations represented the net gain of $ 7.1 million on the sale of a subsidiary.The extraordinary losses represented deferred debt costs expensed in connection with the refinance and restructure of the company's senior indebtedness.Figures for 1990 periods included preferred stock dividends.The latest quarter and 9-month results reflected the acquisition of International Banknote Co.

title: Keithley Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gottschalks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Net loss

title: Bridge
description: The youngest player in the Grand National Pairs final that was played Sunday in Manhattan came within a whisker of qualifying for the national playoffs. Andrew Moss, a 17-year-old senior at Columbia Preparatory School, led after the first qualifying session, playing with his older brother, Brad. In the second session they fell to fourth, just short of the crucial third position, which would have allowed them to advance.

title: Thanksgiving in the Gulf
description: Turkey dinner for 200,000. That's what the Pentagon has planned on Thanksgiving Day for the United States forces stationed in the Persian Gulf region.

title: U.S. Accuses a TV Station of Sex Discrimination
description: Saying it wants to "send a message" to the nation's television industry, the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has accused a Baltimore television station of discriminating against an anchorwoman in pay and working conditions because of her sex.

title: VMS Short Term Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Peter A. Pender, 54, Leading Bridge Player
description: Peter A. Pender, one of the world's leading bridge players, died Sunday night in San Francisco. He was 54 years old.

title: Holders in Suit Against MCI
description: Nine shareholders of the MCI Communications Corporation announced yesterday that they had filed a class-action suit against the company and three of its executives in Federal District Court in Washington.

title: Washington to New York on 4.3 Gallons
description: Some drivers are not willing to trade size and smooth ride for fuel economy, but for those who are, no car sold in the United States gets better gasoline mileage than the Geo Metro. On a recent drive from Washington to New York, the car, made in Japan by the Suzuki Motor Company and sold by the General Motors Corporation, consumed 4.3 gallons, which comes to 58 miles a gallon.

title: Cutting the Computer Wire Snarl
description: Swarming under floors, above ceilings and through elevator shafts of virtually every modern office building are hundreds and thousands of wires and cables. Forming bunches as thick as a fat man's waist near the center of each floor, they fan out across offices to telephones, answering machines, lamps and computers.

title: Allen Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 8,855,000, or $ 1.08 a share.

title: Mercury Air Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Katharine F. Schwab, Navy Officer, 92
description: Katharine Fisher Schwab, one of the first women to become an officer in the Navy at the outset of World War II, died on Monday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. She was 92 years old and lived in Danbury.

title: Theodore A. Kelly, Judge, 70
description: Theodore A. Kelly, a senior justice of the New York State Supreme Court, died yesterday at Nyack Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Pearl River, N.Y.

title: Objectivity Up in Smoke
description: "We were concerned about the appearance of conflict of interest," a spokesman for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said about the agency's recently appointed 16-member scientific panel on smoking. It's hard to tell that from the makeup of the panel.

title: Jackson Said to Be Near a Deal That Is as Big as His Hits
description: The pop star Michael Jackson is in the final stages of a renegotiation of his contract with CBS Records that will guarantee the singer, already the highest-paid performer in the record business, the most lucrative deal in pop music history, say record industry executives, lawyers and managers.

title: Augat Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Henderson Selected Most Valuable Player
description: Rickey Henderson, who said that by his own recollection, there were at least three other times he should have won the award, was voted the most valuable player in the American League today.

title: Atlanta Sets a Curfew for Youths, Prompting Concern on Race Bias
description: A curfew for teen-agers went into effect here Monday night, with some residents hoping it would reduce drug-related violence and others charging that it is singling out poor black children and their parents.

title: New Jersey Sued Over Financing Of Health Care
description: The New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. and New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield have filed suit seeking an immediate end to the system of financing hospital care for the poor through a hidden tax on hospital bills paid by patients and insurers.

title: THATCHER UNABLE TO ELIMINATE FOE IN PARTY ELECTION
description: Suffering her biggest setback in 11 1/2 years as Britain's leader, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher failed today to knock her rival, Michael Heseltine, out of the contest for the leadership of the ruling Conservative Party.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Engineer Is Selected For Top Post at Hercules
description: Thomas L. Gossage, a chemical engineer who joined Hercules Inc. two years ago to run the company's core specialty chemicals business, will become its chairman and chief executive on Jan. 1, the company said. He replaces David S. Hollingsworth, 62 years old, who announced in July that he would retire at the end of the year.

title: Ralph Brown Dead; Tap Dancer Was 76
description: Ralph Brown, a tap dancer on Broadway and in films, died Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Class Sends Message To Harvard Law School
description: In a small basement classroom at Harvard Law School, 22 students gather week after week for a class no one was expected to take.

title: Dayton Hudson Net Down
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation said today that its earnings fell 9.4 percent in the third quarter, partly because of costs associated with its acquisition of Marshall Field & Company.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: SHRIMP and prawns are particularly well suited to quick deep frying and, done properly, the results are addictively good.

title: Economic Scene; Let Them Eat Bread
description: ITEM: In yet another bid to prevent the Soviet Union from disintegrating in its winter of discontent, Mikhail Gorbachev reorganizes his Government and hints that full-blown rationing will be needed to feed the nation.

title: Mauna Loa Macadamia Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cult of the Last Czar Takes Root in Russia
description: Seventy-two years after the Bolshevik secret police here slaughtered the last Russian monarch, his wife, son, four daughters, family doctor and three servants, Czar Nicholas II is rallying the kind of popular following that eluded him in life.

title: Review/Theater; Still Nasty After All These Years
description: Watching Jules Feiffer's "Carnal Knowledge" in its long delayed New York theatrical premiere at the Kaufman Theater, one reaches the conclusion that with work and revisions this might be the basis for a provocative film. The odd thing is that the film, which preceded the play's production by 19 years, uses a script that is nearly identical to that of the play. The difference is that of direction, performance and perception.

title: First Essex Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: CHRONICLE
description: YEHUDI MENUHIN was on stage yesterday afternoon at the University of Toronto. Although he played not a note, the 800 people who filled Walter Hall seemed delighted nevertheless.

title: Eastern Leaders at Summit Warn Against New Divisions in Europe
description: Eastern European leaders at the 34-nation summit meeting here warned today of a threat to stability if the ideological separation of Europe is replaced by an economic and social divide.

title: Carving the Breast Before You Cook It
description: LIKE most Americans, I feel it is not Thanksgiving without a large roast turkey, and I usually serve roast turkey on Christmas as well. But my consumption of turkey is not limited to holiday periods, nor is it confined to roast turkey.

title: Baghdad to Free Germans To Try to Split Gulf Alliance
description: The Iraqi Government announced today that it would free all German hostages, acknowledging that the move was meant to divide the international coalition against Baghdad and prevent military action in the Persian Gulf.

title: JMB Realty Slowing Pace of Development
description: The JMB Realty Corporation, a leading real estate manager, confirmed rumors today that the privately held firm had decided to slow its pace of acquiring and developing shopping centers and office buildings.

title: Global Natural Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IGI Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rabbi M. H. Lewittes, Educator, 79, Is Dead
description: Rabbi Mordecai Henry Lewittes, an educator, author and head of the Fire Island Synagogue, died on Saturday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Suspect Is Indicted In Kahane Killing
description: El Sayyid A. No sair, who is accused of killing Rabbi Meir Kahane, has been indicted on second-degree murder charges, the Manhattan District Attorney's office announced yesterday.

title: A Correction: Recipe for Tamale Pie Baked in a Casserole
description: AN article in The Living Section on Nov. 14 about potluck dishes for Thanksgiving gave incomplete cooking instructions for tamale pie. The ground beef listed among the ingredients should have been added in Step 4. Here is the corrected recipe. Tamale Pie (Adapted from Amy Graf, of Good and Plenty to Go) Total time: 2 hours 1 pound plus 1 tablespoon unsalted butter 4 17-ounce cans corn niblets, drained if necessary 1/2 cup flour 1 1/2 cups cornmeal 3 cups whole milk 3 eggs 3/4 cup minced onion 1 medium-size red bell pepper, cored, seeded and chopped 1 tablespoon corn oil 1 1/2 pounds ground beef 1 cup crushed tomatoes 1 16-ounce can pinto beans, drained 1/2 teaspoon Tabasco sauce 1/4 teaspoon cumin 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper 1 teaspoon oregano 1 1/2 teaspoons salt.

title: Clemens Receives Penalties For Run-In
description: Roger Clemens, the Red Sox pitcher ejected from the fourth game of the American League Championship Series on Oct. 10 after a verbal run-in with Umpire Terry Cooney, was fined $10,000 yesterday and suspended for Boston's first five games of the 1991 season because of the incident.

title: Intera Information Tech.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Paul Harris Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Net income

title: Central Louisiana Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cooking Turkey: Everybody Does It A Different Way
description: IT'S the annual showdown: you versus the turkey. With the turkey trussed and the oven lighted, it hardly seems fair. But the outcome may still be in doubt.

title: Brooklyn Woman and Boyfriend Charged in Sex Abuse of 4 Sisters
description: A Brooklyn woman and her boyfriend were charged yesterday with sexually abusing four sisters placed in her care by city child welfare officials, the police said.

title: Merger of Law Shows Seen
description: Time Warner Inc. and the Cablevision Systems Corporation are preparing to merge their planned cable channels dealing with the legal profession, people close to both companies said yesterday,

title: U.S. May Allow Dump for Shoreham Parts
description: Signalling a possible change in policy, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission staff said today that it was leaning toward allowing the Long Island Lighting Company to ship contaminated fuel supports from the Shoreham nuclear power plant to a low-level radioactive waste dump in South Carolina.

title: Millicom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Arab Nations to Ease Stand on Israel
description: Arab countries have said they are ready to end the efforts they have made since 1982 to expel Israel from the United Nations. But in return, they want the General Assembly to declare that Israel's delegation does not represent territories occupied after the 1967 war.

title: Seeking a Franchise
description: Bart Fisher, an attorney for a newly formed investment group, said yesterday that his organization was bidding for a National League expansion franchise for the Washington area and would deliver a deposit and paperwork to league officials early next week.

title: Field of 162 in Majors' $1 Million Lineup
description: More than one-fifth of major league players earned $1 million or more this year, a salary survey determined yesterday.

title: Review/Theater; An Accident Upstages the Show And an Actor Is the Beneficiary
description: Had the actor Philip Casnoff not been beaned by a falling slab of scenery at a press preview last week, "Shogun: The Musical" might have been best remembered as the first Broadway musical extravaganza to beguile an audience with a song about a dildo. But Mr. Casnoff's accident and his speedy recovery upstaged all else in the show -- and justly so. Mr. Casnoff is something. "Shogun," with or without sexual toys, is something else.

title: Bulgaria's Former Leader to Face Charges
description: The former Communist leader, Todor Zhivkov, will face trial on charges of misappropriation of funds and abuse of power, Bulgaria's prosecutor general announced today.

title: Adobe Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossc-Included a tax loss of $ 569,000 in the quarter and a tax credit of $ 390,000, or 1 cent a share, in the 9 months.

title: What to Make of King Plagiarism Charge

title: The Honesty Gap on Medigap: Closed
description: More than 20 million elderly Americans buy medical insurance to pay bills that Medicare doesn't cover. "Medigap" it's called, and it's wise protection against catastrophic illness that can bankrupt even wealthy families. In fact, Medigap is such a good idea that many families are talked into buying two, three or more different policies.

title: Look to Dirty Needles as African AIDS Source; An Uneasy Profession
description: To the Editor:

title: Riverside Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company said its net income for third quarter and nine months 1990 was negatively affected by higher loss ratios in all insurance programs, especially in the new mobile home and homeowners programs.In addition, the company said it recorded charges of $ 2,273,000 in the third quarter of 1990 from decline in value of its investment in Fairfield Communities Inc. and its investment in the Atlantic Group Inc., Fairfield's largest shareholder.

title: Review/Film; The Quarry: Humans
description: Anyone who hoped to create the most mindless, mean-spirited action film of the holiday season will be sobered by the arrival of "Predator 2," an unbeatable contender on both scores. No one else need notice.

title: Home Building Plummets; Level Is Lowest Since 1982
description: Home building plunged by 6 percent in October, the Commerce Department said today, extending the longest construction slide on record and sinking housing starts to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession.

title: Meghan Robinson, Actress, Dies at 35
description: Meghan Robinson, an actress, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 35 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Car in Kidnapping Recovered
description: A bank executive's gray Mercedes-Benz, in which he was kidnapped and held briefly on Monday before making his escape, was found by the authorities in downtown Minneapolis today. But the Federal Bureau of Investigation said it still did not know who was responsible for the abduction of John F. Grundhofer, chief executive of First Bank System, the second-largest bank in Minnesota, or the motive for it.

title: Central Vermont Public Svc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a one-time net gain of $ 1.3 million from an investment tax credit related to a generation plant.c-Included a net writeoff of investment in Champlain Pipeline of $ 1.8 million.

title: Ismail Doubtful
description: Notre Dame, deposed from the No. 1 ranking in the news-agency polls after its loss to Penn State last Saturday, will probably have to play Southern California this Saturday without its top offensive threat, Raghib (Rocket) Ismail.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group reports earnings for 12mos Oct 31
2 New York Prosecutors Nominated to Bench
description: Two prosecutors in New York City have been nominated for Federal judgeships, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato announced yesterday.

title: WPP Is Getting a Taste of Tough Times
description: MARTIN SORRELL, the highly regarded chief executive of the WPP Group, is getting a taste of what it is like to be one of the beleaguered Saatchi brothers, Charles and Maurice, his one-time mentors at Saatchi & Saatchi, with whom he is now competing.

title: Co-Steel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: William Kemsley, 82, Labor Administrator
description: William Kemsley Sr., a labor relations specialist, died Monday at Medical Center Hospital of Vermont in Burlington. He was 82 years old and lived in Burlington.

title: Cominco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: It Gets Worse; Next Year Is Real Test For Cuomo the Manager
description: In presenting his latest plan to close the state's budget gap, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo seemed to be trying to re-establish himself as a sound manager after almost three years of fiscal disarray. He proposed $1 billion worth of spending cuts, and the plan included none of the gimmicks his administration has often used in the past to avoid painful decisions.

title: Southern Co. reports earnings for 12mos Oct 31
description: b-Included a $ 218 million write-off by Georgia Power.

title: Police Find Body After Stopping Van
description: Two men were arrested and charged with second-degree murder yesterday after the state police stopped them for speeding and found a body in the back of their van.

title: Sol Bergstein, Accountant, 78
description: Sol Bergstein, a certified public accountant in Manhattan for 50 years, died on Saturday at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in the Bronx. He was 78 years old and lived in Floral Park, L.I.

title: Marathon Oil
description: The Marathon Oil Company announced it was dissolving the Marathon Petroleum Company, one of its wholly owned subsidiaries. Marathon Oil, whose parent is the Pittsburgh-based USX Corporation, said it would absorb the assets and activities of Marathon Petroleum. J. Louis Frank, Marathon Petroleum's president, was named executive vice president of Marathon Oil.

title: Sun Li-jen, 91, War Hero in Burma Fighting, Dies
description: Gen. Sun Li-jen, a Nationalist Chinese war hero who was accused of trying to topple President Chiang Kai-shek, died Monday of pneumonia and sepsis, hospital officials said. He was 91.

title: Milli Vanilli Explains Its Lip-Synching
description: Rob Pilatus and Fab Morvan, who have given up their Grammy Award and their group's name, Milli Vanilli, said today that they were poor and hungry when seduced by an unscrupulous producer who later coerced them to keep their lip-synching secret.

title: Review/Film; An Animated 'Nutcracker'
description: Though "The Nutcracker" seems like a foolproof Christmas story, there has to be some reason to justify doing it again. It might be lovelier than ever or just plain goofy, but it has to offer something fresh if it hopes to survive the cutthroat holiday competition. The new, animated "Nutcracker Prince" brings together Tchaikovsky's music, E. T. A. Hoffman's story and a few glib modern touches to create a muddled and bland version, which isn't the kind of difference it needs.

title: INSIDE
description: Florida Shuttle Landing Bad weather forced a quick change in the landing site for the space shuttle Atlantis, diverting it from California to a landing in Florida. Page A18. Why the Traffic Stopped A livery-cab drivers' protest turned New York City into a sea of seething motorists as morning rush-hour traffic ground nearly to a halt. Page B1. Carve a Turkey? Me? Carving is a man's art, right? But when it comes to wielding the knife, young men today are a lost generation. The Living Section, page C1.

title: Net at Caesars Is Off by 20%
description: Caesars World Inc. said today that its fiscal first-quarter income fell 20 percent, partly because of sluggish activity in the company's Atlantic City casinos.

title: Defense Foiled In Alibi Effort At Jogger Trial
description: A defense move to provide an alibi for a defendant in the second Central Park jogger trial backfired yesterday when a witness testified that she saw the youth enter the park shortly before the jogger was raped and beaten.

title: Lotus Continues Suit on Software
description: The Lotus Development Corporation went to trial against Mosaic Software, a small company accused of imitating Lotus's 1-2-3 business spreadsheet program.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SHALOM LEAF and Janis Leventhal of Manhattan like to listen at Upper West Side playgrounds in order to keep up with the names of the new generation. In alphabetical order, their latest list:

title: VMS Mortgage Investors L.P. III reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeShare earnings are in units.

title: U.S. Troops and Saudis: A Silent Clash of Cultures
description: As the military deployment here lengthens and President Bush arrives to celebrate Thanksgiving, the cultural gap dividing American troops from their Saudi hosts appears to be widening, leaving each staring at the other across a chasm neither can easily bridge.

title: Continental Bank Cut
description: The Continental Bank Corporation's short- and long-term debt ratings were reduced because of the risk of loss the company faces from loans for commercial real estate and highly indebted corporations, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday. The Chicago-based banking company's senior debt was reduced to Baa-3, from Baa-2, and the commercial paper was cut to Prime 3, from Prime 2. Long-term deposits of a year or more of Continental Bank were cut to Baa-1, from A-3.

title: Cullen/Frost Bankers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Mary K. Landers, 85, Former Math Professor
description: Mary Kenny Landers, professor emeritus of mathematics at Hunter College, died on Sunday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. She was 85 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: VMS Mortgage Investors L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeShare earnings are in units.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Official Says U.S. Ignores Syrian Terror
description: A former high-ranking Central Intelligence Agency official asserted today that the Government had applied a double standard to Middle Eastern sponsors of terrorism, berating Iraq and Iran while overlooking "really horrible" acts by a current ally against Iraq, the Government of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.

title: Methode Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CNN Gives Up Noriega Tapes To Federal Court in Florida
description: The Cable News Network today surrendered to the Federal courts tape recordings of telephone conversations between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his legal team.

title: Victim of Fiery Suicide at Capitol Is Identified as Vietnam Immigrant
description: The man who set himself afire and burned to death outside the Capitol in Washington on Monday was identified by friends today as Nguyen Kim Bang, a Vietnamese immigrant from San Jose, Calif.

title: CBS to Cut Stations' Fees 20% on Jan. 1
description: CBS will cut program payments to its affiliated stations by 20 percent, the network said yesterday, saving about $30 million a year.

title: Debentures Priced By Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, a publicly traded and federally chartered company that provides a continous flow of funds to mortgage lenders, priced $500 million in three-year debentures yesterday through its regular 25-member debenture dealer group.

title: About Education
description: The school reform movement is in trouble. There is growing concern that public expectations and political promises will not be met in the 1990's.

title: Silence by the Police On Slaying's Cruelty Outrages Bostonians
description: Three weeks ago, when the body of a slain woman was found in a park here, the police seemed to treat the case as routine. They called no special attention to it -- just another killing in a city that has seen 128 of them this year.

title: PHH Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,223,000 and $ 2,579,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Dollar General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Mets Offer to Coleman
description: Vince Coleman's agent said yesterday the Mets had made the base-stealing outfielder an "attractive" proposal, one that "reflects their seriousness."

title: Ousted Teamster Aide Assails Union Leader
description: A top aide to the teamsters' retiring president, William McCarthy, says he was dismissed because he had decided to run for president of the union rather than to support Mr. McCarthy's choice for a successor.

title: Chrysler's New Effort For Involving Readers
description: Advertisers are not always satisfied with consumers simply seeing their ads; sometimes, they demand that they participate in them. It can sometimes be an event as surprising as opening a page and listening to a product that sings. Otherwise, it is more mundane -- there is a tab to pull or a surface to scratch.

title: Farm & Home Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 31,500,000 loss on sale of investments, loans, mortgage backed securities and mortgage servicing rights.c-Net lossLatest 9 months' results included a $ 4,035,000 preferred stock dividend.

title: Wine Talk
description: THESE are dark days in the wine and spirits business. Whether it is government officials searching desperately for new taxes or public-interest groups concerned about drunken driving and alcohol-related health problems, it seems that everyone is ready and eager to take a shot at the people who make and sell liquor and wine.

title: Choosing $90 Million in School Cuts: Layoffs or Attrition, It's Class Chaos
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins and Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez now agree that the school system must cut $90 million by June 30.

title: A School in Minnesota Doesn't Have a Principal
description: What was once the principal's office has a conference table in it now. The name plate on the door is covered with a slash of masking tape with the word "SHARE" scrawled across it.

title: Healthco International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 3,340,000 for costs in connection with a proxy challenge for the quarter and 9 months.c-Net income

title: MEI Diversified reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 1,086,000 in the second quarter from proceeds from sale of company's candy and snack group.Results for 1990 included acquisitions of new dimensions in medicine and MEI-Regis Salon Corp. from their July 1 and Aug. 30 respective dates of acquisition.

title: Mitsubishi in Deal On Carbide Unit
description: The Mitsubishi Corporation agreed to buy a 50 percent interest in the UCAR Carbon Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Union Carbide Corporation. The Japanese company said that it would pay about $230 million for the stake and that Union Carbide, based in Danbury, Conn., would retain ownership of the other 50 percent of UCAR.

title: Topics of The Times; Uncivil Disobedience
description: The livery drivers who disrupted New York City's main roads and bridges during rush hour yesterday certainly got plenty of attention. But if they were hoping to enlist public support, they'd best find another strategy. Their tactics amounted to a form of urban guerrilla warfare that hurt thousands of people who were simply going about their business. No city can tolerate, nor any dispute justify, such behavior.

title: Markets Closed
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. Banks, government offices and most businesses will also be closed.

title: British Steel Sets Deal in Alabama
description: British Steel P.L.C. said it had agreed to buy the 90.4 percent of the Tuscaloosa Steel Corporation that it did not own from the Alabama-based company's other shareholders. British Steel refused to disclose the price.

title: Leaders of New Jersey Tax Rebellion Take Aim at Legislature
description: Two weeks after New Jersey voters almost unseated Senator Bill Bradley and frightened several Democratic Congressmen in a flush of anti-tax fervor, the leaders of a citizen group that helped nurture that anger are savoring their success and planning their next campaign.

title: Parent & Child
description: FOR many new parents, the question is not whether to return to work, but when. The decision is often mainly a matter of family finance, but it also requires steps to assure a smooth transition for everyone -- steps that go beyond taking children's ages into account when timing a return to work or choosing the right kind of day care.

title: A Growing Foster-Care Program Is Fraught With Ills
description: Five years after a quiet and uncertain start, New York City's program to pay grandmothers, aunts and other relatives to take in and care for abused or neglected children in their families is bidding to become the dominant form of foster care here.

title: Postal Workers' Contract Talks Break Down
description: A dispute over wages and job security for 660,000 unionized Postal Service workers was sent into binding arbitration today after negotiators failed to reach agreement on a new contract by the midnight deadline and called off further talks.

title: Review/Music; Roberta Peters, in Recital, Celebrates 40 Years of Song
description: On Nov. 17, 1950, the 20-year-old Roberta Peters made her Metropolitan Opera debut, which also happened to be her first public performance. To celebrate the 40th anniversary of the occasion, she appeared Monday night in a Carnegie Hall recital.

title: Judge With a Reputation For Innovative Rulings
description: The Federal judge who sentenced Michael R. Milken yesterday to 10 years in prison has a reputation for bold and sometimes imaginative decisions and apparently did not feel unusual pressure in sentencing one of the best-known financiers of the 1980's.

title: Santa Fe Is Selling Track in Southwest
description: The Santa Fe Railway Company reached an agreement to sell 730 miles of track in the Southwest to the privately held Orient Railcorp. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: F.D.I.C. Limit on Insurance
description: The Treasury Department is considering restricting each American to three federally insured accounts in banks, savings institutions or credit unions -- no matter how little money is in each.

title: Randi Schoenberger Weds John Lewis 3d
description: Randi Schoenberger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schoenberger of New York, was married last evening to John W. Lewis 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Lewis Jr. of Atlanta. Cantor Mark Lipson performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Currents; A Cloning Of Shops In Museums
description: BOTH the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art have recently opened new gift shops in Manhattan. Each store reflects, in miniature, the architecture of the parent museum.

title: Home Improvement
description: BANISTERS are built as mucfh for the safety of stair climbers as they are for decoration. The sophisticated carpentry that is often used in banisters sometimes complicates repairing them when they are broken.

title: Emigre Is 2d in Poland Poll
description: An emigre who has emerged as a strong dark-horse presidential candidate moved into second place today in a public opinion poll, behind Lech Walesa but ahead of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki.

title: Ask Computer Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
How to Make the Welfare System Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Text of Bush's Message
description: Following is the text of President Bush's message to American troops broadcast today over armed forces radio:

title: Census Bureau Cries a Million After Furious Push by Detroit
description: The Census Bureau has raised the estimated population of Detroit over one million, acknowledging that volunteers scouring the city for people missed by the bureau's counters had helped push the city over the mark needed to retain Federal and state dollars.

title: Worthy on Record
description: The name of James Worthy, the forward for the Los Angeles Lakers, appears on the log of an escort service in Portland, Ore., according to the police in that city. Worthy, the most valuable player in the National Basketball Asosociation playoffs in 1988, pleaded not guilty on Tuesday in Houston to charges that he solicited prostitution from two undercover police officers. He was said to have called an escort service that was being monitored by the police and was arrested last week before a game with the Houston Rockets. He faces trial on Jan. 28.

title: Lisbon Paper to Close
description: The Lisbon evening newspaper Diario de Lisboa will close at the end of November after 69 years of publication, the editor said today. The daily is the latest victim of a Portuguese press industry crisis in which eight leading daily and weekly papers closed in two years. The newspaper's chief editor, Antonio Ruella Ramos, said the last issue would be published Nov. 30, after negotiations with the Projornal media group failed to find a formula to save the paper.

title: Women Nowadays Take Pregnancy in Stride; Postmenopausal Puzzle
description: To the Editor:

title: The Breakdown of 'Junk'
description: Michael R. Milken was sentenced to 10 years in prison not for his role in a "decade of greed," but for crimes that were aimed at enriching himself and his clients, Federal Judge Kimba M. Wood said yesterday.

title: Metro Matters; A Shelter The Neighbors Can Live With
description: Even before Nimby (Not in my back yard) there was Lulu (Locally undesirable land use). Together they begat Basta.

title: Damson Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossShare earnings represent class B units.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $150 million in 8.23 percent notes due 1995 at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are noncallable for two years. * Tech Data Corp., Clearwater, Fla., said it had established a $55 million revolving line of credit with a group of banks led by NCNB National Bank, Charlotte, N.C., and including Barnett Banks, Jacksonville, Fla.; National Bank of Detroit and Royal Bank of Canada, Montreal. Common Stock * Atlanta Gas Light Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for one million common shares through Merrill Lynch & Co. * Conagra Inc., Omaha, is offering four million common shares at $33.25 a share through Lehman Brothers. * Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Newark, has filed for five million common shares, including 500,000 warrants, through Merrill Lynch & Co. Ratings * HomeFed Bank's subordinated debt rating has been lowered to B+, from BB+, and its commercial paper rating to B, from A-3, by S.& P. The bank is based in San Diego and is a unit of the HomeFed Corp. * Memorex Telex Corp.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to B-, from B+, and its subordinated debt to CCC, from B-, by S.&P. The company is based in Tulsa, Okla.

title: D. J. Sanchini, 63; Headed Atomic Plant
description: Dominick J. Sanchini, who managed the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant for the Rockwell International Corporation in the contractor's final four years there, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 63 years old.

title: Currents; Water At a Wave Of the Hand
description: WAVE your hand in front of the Thermatronic system, and water will run hot, warm or cold. You can also preset the device to make the water run for any length of time.

title: Price Rift Narrowing In MCA Deal
description: A disagreement between the Matsushita Electrical Industrial Company and MCA Inc. over what the giant Japanese company would pay for the owner of Universal Pictures eased yesterday.

title: Some '90 Thank You Notes
description: On too many other days, the schemers and the scoundrels of sports are in the headlines. But on Thanksgiving Day, it's appropriate to remember some of the good people who just by being themselves make sports' little corner of the world a better place to be:

title: Deprenyl Research reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock dividend paid in August.The latest 9-month share earnings does not include 18 cents a share credited to contributed surplus (10 cents in the second quarter and 8 cents in the third quarter) resulting from the sale of Deprenyl shares held by its Shulman Diversified Ltd. unit.Year-ago 9-month share earnings included a non-recurring after-tax gain of 42 cents from the sale of shares in Somerset Pharmaceuticals Inc.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Jobless Data Push Up U.S. Issues
description: An unexpectedly large rise in initial unemployment benefit claims, a number that suggested employment conditions deteriorated further in November and might set the stage for easier credit, helped push up prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Notebook; Dartmouth Atop Standing for Ivy All-Star Team
description: Dartmouth, which shared the Ivy League championship with Cornell, was first when it came to the post-season honors.

title: Improvisations; Photos That Tease Viewers
description: HANG a photo on the wall and people might take a glimpse. Place it casually on a picture rail, in a basket or on a postcard rack and people are likely to pick it up and give it scrutiny.

title: Paderewski's Remains to Return to Poland
description: The remains of Ignace Jan Paderewski, the pianist, composer and first Prime Minister of Poland, are to be returned from the United States to Poland for a state burial, highlighted by a gala "Paderewski Freedom Concert," a half-century after he died in New York City.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Up 7.9 % on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Nov. 15 increased by 62.6 million, to a record level. The new total is 7.9 percent above the previous record, which was set a month earlier.

title: Bonanza for Browning, Boddicker and Jackson
description: Baseball's free-agent market proved to be a bountiful place for pitchers yesterday as Tom Browning and Mike Boddicker signed contracts that propelled them into the club of players with $3-million-a-year average annual income. Those two signings, coupled with the deal struck between Danny Jackson and the Chicago Cubs, brought the spending output for the day on three pitchers to $32 million.

title: R.V. Simkus Wed To Abigail Ratner
description: Abigail Taxin Ratner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Ratner of Wyncote, Pa., was married last evening at the Hyatt Regency in Princeton, N.J., to Richard Victor Simkus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Algimantas Simkus of Mahwah, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Federal Judge J. William Ditter Jr. of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

title: Many Toys Violating Standards, Report Says
description: A consumer group said today that toys posing dangers for young children were still being sold this Christmas season in disregard of voluntary industry standards and Federal regulations.

title: Hallwood Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossc-Net incomeThe company said the net loss for 1990 included about $ 1.2 million of non-cash charges for the amortization of a deferred asset related to the guarantee of a subsidiary's debt, which expired in the second quarter.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Crown President Likes Lure of Gold Mining
description: The lure of gold exploration today is the same as it was 140 years ago, says Christopher E. Herald, the geologist who is the new president of the Crown Resources Corporation, a gold exploration company based in Denver that prospects in the West and Canada.

title: Excerpts From Judge Wood's Explanation of the Milken Sentencing
description: Following are excerpts from comments by Judge Kimba M. Wood yesterday about her sentencing of Michael R. Milken in Federal District Court in Manhattan:

title: Books of The Times; Pursuing the Pheasant: Philosophy and Practice
description: Pheasants of the Mind By Datus C. Proper Illustrated. 154 pages. Prentice Hall Press. $18.95.

title: Reading Gorby's Mind
description: That sneaky Mitterrand tried to slip the Baltic states into the C.S.C.E. meeting in Paris as guests, and the Danes and the Icelanders supported him, but I put a stop to that. I told him he could have the Baltics or the Soviet Union in the room, not both. So the French called the Baltic leaders out of the room on a ruse and then locked them out.

title: United's Boeing Jet
description: United Airlines has taken delivery of the first of four Boeing 737-500's it expects to use on routes into and out of its hubs in Denver and San Francisco. The 737-500 is a slightly shortened version of the Boeing 737-300 and seats 108 passengers. The carrier said that by the end of the year, its operating fleet would reach an all-time high of 462 planes. United has 556 new aircraft on order and option, including a $22 billion order for Boeing 747-400's and Boeing 777's announced last month.

title: Afghan's President Meets Rebels
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan said today that he had met here with Afghan guerrilla leaders and that the talks opened the way to peace in his country after 12 years of civil war.

title: Where to Find It; Books Whose Covers Are the Story
description: EVERY day Philip Bradburn, managing director of the Manor Bindery, makes books no one will ever read. Fashioned from leather, wood and gold, his books are are judged solely by their covers. In short, they are fakes.

title: Control Data Deal With CSK of Japan
description: The Control Data Corporation will sell Micrognosis, which devises computer systems for the financial industry, to the CSK Corporation, Japan's largest independent computer services company, the companies said. No terms were disclosed.

title: You Call This Giving Thanks? No Thanks
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Nowadays Take Pregnancy in Stride
description: To the Editor:

title: Guinness to Buy Largest Brewer in Spain
description: Guinness P.L.C. announced plans today to buy the largest brewer in the fast-growing Spanish market for $1.02 billion. Analysts said the deal reflected the growing interest of multinational beverage companies in regional European brewers.

title: Seeking a Way to Collect Livery-Tax Millions
description: A Brooklyn police officer who noticed that few livery cars displayed a required $400 tax stamp on their windshields did some research about a year ago and discovered that New York City was losing millions of dollars in unpaid taxes.

title: Army is Moving to Halt Retirements
description: Senior Defense Department has given the military services authority to halt retirements and indefinitely extend all periods of enlistment to avoid depleting their ranks as the United States builds up its troops in the Persian Gulf region, officials said tonight.

title: The Vigil in Foley Square for the Magic Number
description: It took 27 minutes for the judge to finally speak the magic number -- and seconds for Michael R. Milken to absorb the shock.

title: Currents; Where Art Is Blowin' In the Wind
description: IN the depths of the subway station beneath Herald Square, "Radiant Site," a golden wall, is being born. Michele Oka Doner, a Manhattan artist, has set her workers to covering the wall with 11,000 gold glazed tiles.

title: 34 LEADERS ADOPT PACT PROCLAIMING A UNITED EUROPE
description: The leaders of 34 European and North American states, great and small, rich and not so rich, today proclaimed the end of the "era of confrontation and division" that followed World War II.

title: Currents; A Quarter Of a Watch, Full Price
description: ALFRED Brodmann, a product designer, does not make round watches with 12 numbers. Instead, his newest wristwatch, Segments, tells the time with only a quarter of a watch.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "When a man of your power in the financial world, at the head of the most important department of one of the most important investment banking houses in this country, repeatedly conspires to violate, and violates, securities and tax laws in order to achieve more power and wealth for himself and his wealthy clients, and commits financial crimes that are particularly hard to detect, a significant prison term is required in order to deter others." -- Judge Kimba M. Wood, sentencing Michael R. Milken to 10 years in prison. [ A1:6. ]

title: Shop, Save Money, Waste Time via PC
description: I AM sitting at my computer, taking a multiple-choice quiz about garlic. "For centuries," reads the question, "the Chinese have used garlic cloves as: a) a substitute for pearl onions in their Gibsons; b) little surprise gifts left in the holes of good friends' bowling balls; c) toggle buttons."

title: Defendant's Mother Ejected For Outburst at Jogger Trial
description: The second Central Park jogger trial was thrown into an uproar yesterday when the mother of a defendant was ejected from the courtroom and her testimony as a defense witness was stricken after she repeatedly shouted at the prosecutor, accusing her of lying.

title: Review/Music; A Pianist and Math Student Makes His New York Debut
description: Christopher Taylor's program biography lists him as a mathematics student at Harvard. But he is also a formidable enough pianist to have won first prize at this year's University of Maryland International William Kapell Competition. He made his New York debut under the competition's auspices at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening.

title: MCI Pulls Account From Wells, Rich
description: The MCI Communications Corporation pulled its $50 million account from Wells, Rich, Greene yesterday and gave it to Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer, a small New York agency.

title: U.S. MAY SUMMON THE U.N. COUNCIL
description: The United States is considering calling a meeting of the Security Council at the foreign ministers' level next week, probably on Thursday, to consider further steps in the Persian Gulf crisis, Council members said today.

title: How to Make the Welfare System Better
description: To the Editor:

title: S&F Famous Brands Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 110,000, or 5 cents a share, resulting from insurance proceeds for the retail value of inventory damaged during Hurricane Hugo.

title: Words of Wisdom for Parcells
description: Grandma Gripaldi is writing letters again to Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants.

title: Oil Sheiks Will Fight To the Last American
description: To the Editor:

title: Eldon A. Grimm, 78, A Securities Analyst
description: Eldon A. Grimm, a securities analyst, financial writer and money manager, died on Monday at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: 10-Year Extension
description: Spike Dykes, the Texas Tech football coach, who suffered his worst season this year at 4-7, was given a 10-year contract extension yesterday.

title: Bankruptcy Filing by Laventhol
description: Attributing its problems to a litigious society, changes in the tax law, a soft economy and negative publicity, Laventhol & Horwath, once the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm, filed for protection from creditors yesterday in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Stunning Justice in the Milken Case
description: For the crimes he admitted and for abusing his conspicuous position of public power, Michael Milken has been sentenced to 10 years in prison. He will get his wish to perform community service -- but only after doing hard prison time, when he serves an added three years on probation.

title: Gemco National reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 750,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Women Nowadays Take Pregnancy in Stride; Male Disadvantages
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Muna Tseng Explores Mysteries
description: Muna Tseng is a dancer with an unusual blend of delicacy and strength. There is a moment in her recent "Earth Mysteries," performed on Sunday night at the 14th Street Dance Center, that epitomizes her style. In the solo, set to mysterious yet earthy music composed and performed by Mieczyslaw Litwinski, Miss Tseng dances within a circle formed by three abstract but suggestive sculptures by Tobi Kahn. She approaches one of the sculptures, in that telling moment, and kicks at it through a pile of leaves that surrounds its base. That little kick is strong and deftly aimed, yet as dry and fragile-seeming as the leaves themselves.

title: Jawad F. George, 40, Spokesman for Arabs
description: Jawad F. George, executive director of the National Association of Arab Americans, died yesterday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 40 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Mountain Medical reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: University Trustees to Meet After Furor Over a Payout
description: Widespread opposition to a $1 million settlement offered to American University's former president to sever his ties to the school has prompted the trustees to schedule a special meeting next month to discuss the offer.

title: Sharon Steel Plan Approved
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today approved a plan to spin off the steel division of the financially ailing Sharon Steel Corporation to a New York merchant bank and sell its brass, railroad and mining interests to unsecured creditors.

title: Review/Theater; Wrestling for a Soul Deep in the Inner City
description: Early in Charles Smith's despairing drama "Jelly Belly," the title character, a drug dealer who has returned to his old stomping grounds after serving a six-month prison term for murder, describes his vision of a world in which people are either shepherds, sheep or lamb chops.

title: Ellis Suspended
description: Dale Ellis, the Seattle SuperSonics guard, was suspended yesterday without pay for five days, the team announced.

title: American Power Conversion reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Following are excerpts from the Charter of Paris for a New Europe, which was signed today at the conclusion of the summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe:
