BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Crown President Likes Lure of Gold Mining
description: The lure of gold exploration today is the same as it was 140 years ago, says Christopher E. Herald, the geologist who is the new president of the Crown Resources Corporation, a gold exploration company based in Denver that prospects in the West and Canada.

title: Treasury Agency Settles Bias Suit
description: Black workers at the Treasury Department agency that produces dollars, stamps and Government securities will be given more opportunity for advancement under a court settlement that also provides for $1.4 million in back pay.

title: The Maligned Flat Foot: Some See an Advantage
description: Ballet masters shun dancers with low arches and in slang "flat-footed" is synonymous with clumsy. In World War II, the military turned down thousands of recruits because they had flat feet.

title: Women Nowadays Take Pregnancy in Stride; Surrogate Exploitation
description: To the Editor:

title: Novelist With Copy Doctor on Call
description: Diane Johnson had professional help with her latest novel, "Health and Happiness," a widely praised tale about a hospital, its staff and its patients in which the moral quandaries of professionals who routinely exercise the most far-reaching powers are vividly presented.

title: Officials Leave Retail Group
description: Fifteen top executives and specialists of the National Retail Federation, the country's largest retail trade association, have chosen to take early retirement and most will not be replaced, the federation said yesterday in New York.

title: Review/Music; Latin Rhythms on Piano From Jose Caceres
description: For a composer, an inherited popular culture can serve either as a starting point or as quicksand underfoot. At Jose Caceres's concert at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday night, called "The Piano in Latin America," popular culture did a little of each.

title: Talking Deals; How Trump Got A Second Chance
description: TALK about the art of the deal.

title: Review/Music; Slovak Players in Works From Home
description: When Bohdan Warchal and his excellent Slovak Chamber Orchestra performed four years ago at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, they were taken to task by one reviewer for unadventurous programming, specifically their failure to play indigenous or contemporary music. They returned to the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the museum on Saturday evening with both, offering Dvorak's String Serenade and Ilja Zeljenka's "Musica Slovaca."

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Mahorn Lifts Sixers Rick Mahorn tapped in a missed shot with four-tenths of a second left, giving the Philadelphia 76ers a 101-99 victory over the Sacramento Kings last night at the Spectrum in Philadelphia. A follow shot by Ralph Sampson of the Kings with 10 seconds remaining had tied the score, 99-99. Charles Barkley then missed on a short attempt, and Mahorn, who scored 9 points in the fourth quarter, tipped in the winning basket. (AP) Celtics 108, Rockets 95: Kevin McHale scored 16 of his game-high 32 points in the second period as Boston won its fourth straight game. Larry Bird had 18 points, 15 rebounds and 8 assists, and Robert Parish had 18 points and 11 rebounds. ws(AP) SOCCER U.S. Held Scoreless The United States national team and the Soviet Union played a scoreless tie yesterday in the second game of the Carib-BWIA Triangular Series at Port-of-Spain, Trinidad. The Americans were 0-4 in previous matches with the Soviets. The United States tied Trinidad, 0-0, on Sunday and wound up the round-robin competition with 2 points. The Soviets outshot the United States, 10-4. (AP) N.H.L. Flyers Repel Penguins Pelle Eklund scored twice as the Philadelphia Flyers got five consecutive goals and held on to beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 5-4, last night in Pittsburgh. Eklund's goals came in the third period as the Flyers handed the Penguins their second loss in the last six games. (AP)

title: Westinghouse Plans to Cut Staff
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, plans to reduce the work force in its energy services division. A Westinghouse spokeswoman, Mimi Limbach, said most of the reductions would be in management. No numbers were disclosed.

title: Currents; Behold the Vase, Wrapped in Glory
description: MOST people wrap gifts. Emilio Robba, a French floral designer, wraps vases. At his first store in the United States, which opened last week in Manhattan, he wraps terra-cotta vases in burgundy velvet, blue-and-gray cotton ikat (a tie-dyed cloth) or flower-sprigged chintz. The fabric is swagged, twisted and ruched, or pleated.

title: Panel Questions a Basis for Accrediting Colleges
description: A Federal panel has recommended that the Secretary of Education delay reauthorizing one of the nation's college accrediting organizations, pending a review of the organization's new emphasis on "cultural diversity" as a criterion for evaluating colleges and universities.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After 13 years, the National Executive Service Corps, which matches the expertise of retired senior executives with the needs of cultural, charitable, health-care and educational institutions, has its first top executive. ARTHUR M. McCULLY , 58 years old, who retired this year as the manager of product administration for I.B.M. Latin America, has been named president and managing director.

title: U.S. Jury Faults Mobil Dismissal Of an Employee
description: A Federal jury in Newark found yesterday that Mobil Chemical Company wrongfully dismissed one of its top environmental officials after he refused to perform acts that would have violated Federal and state environmental laws.

title: Review/Theater; World of Adventure in a Monologue
description: One of the two strands of the playwright John O'Keefe's vivid, chargingly energetic performance monologue "Vid," at Performance Space 122, is his description of being both the player and the protagonist of his own video game.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chrysler Corp., Highland Park, Mich., said it would close its Jeep plant in Toledo, Ohio, for a week beginning on Monday because of slow sales. About 4,700 employees will be affected. * Crane Co., New York, said it had decided not to spin off its military business to shareholders. * Dun & Bradstreet Corp., New York, a business information company, said its board had authorized the intermittent repurchase of up to 3.2 million common shares for employee stock options and employee compensation plans. * Elsevier N.V., a Dutch publisher, has sold its remaining 28 percent stake in another Dutch publisher, Kluwer N.V., to Goldman, Sachs & Co., New York. Terms were not disclosed. * Envirodyne Industries, Oak Brook, Ill., a plastics company, said it would sell certain production equipment to its Viskase Corp. unit for $170 million and then lease it back. * First Western Bancorp Inc., New Castle, Pa., a bank holding company, said its stockholders had approved an agreement to acquire First Federal of Western Pennsylvania, Sharon, Pa., a savings institution, for $21.6 million. * JTN Acquisition Corp., New York, has extended until Dec. 20 its $18-a-share offer for up to 6.1 million shares of Justin Industries, Fort Worth, a maker of brick and concrete products. As of last Tuesday, when the offer was to have expired, JTN had received more than 1.9 million shares. JTN, a new company, is headed by Perry H. Sutherland of Sutherland Lumber, Kansas City, Mo., and Barry S. Rosenstein, the New York investor. * Liposome Co., Princeton, N.J., said it had licensed to Pfizer Inc. its worldwide rights to TLC D-99, an anti-cancer drug Liposome expects to be on the market by 1994. No other terms were disclosed. * Manpower P.L.C., London, an employment agency, said it had ended discussions on selling certain units to Brooks Opportunities Ltd. * One Liberty Properties Inc., New York, a real estate investment trust, said it would sell its 40 Firestone retail outlets in 17 states for $26.3 million. The buyer was not disclosed. * Pier 1 Imports Inc., Fort Worth, a home-furnishings retailer, has completed its acquisition of Sunbelt Nursery Group Inc., Fort Worth, for $12 a share.Bridgestone+(Firestone)

title: Gentex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
War-Bruised Iraqi City Arms Again
description: Just two years after this weary, tortured city was reduced to near-rubble, Basra must prepare to fight again.

title: The Glass Half Empty
description: My daughter is 2 years old today. She is something like me, only better. Or at least that is what I like to think. If personalities had colors, hers would be red.

title: Review/Rock; Audiences Are Really Lifted When Jane's Addiction Plays
description: The ticket-taker at the Ritz on Tuesday night was saying "No slamming tonight," to no avail. When Jane's Addiction started playing, members of the audience began heaving across the floor and lifting fans up on their shoulders toward the stage, where bouncers repelled them.

title: Milken: Pathfinder for the 'Junk Bond' Era
description: PERSONAL

title: CHRONICLE
description: At $3.25 million, the modernistic seven-bedroom house on four acres off a quiet cul-de-sac in Saddle River, N.J., languished. The property still didn't move when the price dropped to $2.9 million. But $2.4 million hit the mark on Tuesday, as IWAO USHIJIMA , a Tokyo businessman, bought the house from former President RICHARD M. NIXON without a mortgage.

title: A Restraint on Bush
description: The failure of the United States and the Soviet Union to agree on if and when to use military force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait has undercut the Bush Administration's Persian Gulf strategy, at least temporarily,

title: Weakness in German Strength
description: West German managers, the people who head international giants like Daimler-Benz and Bayer, have been enormously successful over the last four decades. They have created Europe's most powerful economy and become the world's leading exporters through the diligence, craftsmanship and meticulous organization that are national hallmarks.

title: 37 Die in Thailand Plane Crash
description: A plane carrying at least 37 people to a southern resort island crashed in heavy rain today, and the police said all aboard were killed.

title: For Holiday, Abundance of Losers
description: Turkey and football.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 524 money market mutual funds increased by $6.36 billion, to $423.52 billion, for the week that ended yesterday, the Investment Company Institute said. The weekly increase was the fourth largest ever. The assets of the 160 institutional funds increased by $3.74 billion, to $107.24 billion. The assets of the 260 general-purpose funds were up by $1.3 billion, to $149.99 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.32 billion, to $166.29 billion, the institute said.

title: Plea by Igwebuike
description: Donald Igwebuike, the place-kicker for the Minnesota Vikings, yesterday pleaded not guilty during an arraignment in Federal court in Tampa, Fla., to charges that he helped finance an attempt to smuggle $1 million worth of heroin from Nigeria.(AP)

title: U.S. to Track Cancer Cases
description: The American Cancer Society, working with the American College of Surgeons' Commission on Cancer, has started an information system to track and compare information on the treatment of cancer from hospitals around the country.

title: Big Break Reported in Bombing Case As Suspect's Wife Aids Prosecutors
description: The estranged wife of the man charged in last year's mail bombing deaths of a Federal judge and a civil rights lawyer is cooperating with prosecutors, and her help has led to another arrest, Federal investigators working for the prosecution say.

title: Calendar: Making Holiday Wreaths
description: Holiday Under Glass

title: Christian Militia Prepares for East Beirut Pullout
description: Thousands of Christian militiamen prepared to pull out of their strongholds in East Beirut today in a move that would make the Lebanese capital free of militias for the first time since the civil war broke out 15 years ago.

title: President and the G.I.'s: He Will Get Respect
description: President Bush's Thanksgiving visit here, along with military exercises and steps in Middle East diplomacy, form part of what is shaping up as a major effort to show American resolve in the Persian Gulf.

title: Letter: On Israel; A Better Way to Quell the Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Republic Waste reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,732,000, or 76 cents a share, and $ 2,401,000, or 65 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Ratings Cut For News Corp.
description: The rating of debt securities issued by the News Corporation Ltd. has been lowered, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. The rating change affects about $1.7 billion (United States) in securities issued by the Australian media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch.

title: After Arrest, a Fatal Crash
description: A Massachusetts man charged with speeding died a half hour after being released from custody when a car driven by his brother careened off the Merritt Parkway, the state police said today. The victim, Sun Jae Kim, 23 years old, of Cambridge, Mass., was arrested in North Haven, the state police said. He posted $300 bond at 11:43 P.M. Tuesday and headed south on the parkway, with his brother, Sun H. Kim, driving. Just 33 minutes later, Sun H. Kim lost control and the car flipped down an embankment. Sun Jae Kim was pronounced dead at Norwalk Hospital. His brother, 21, was treated and released.

title: Dividend Slashed At Fleet-Norstar
description: Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc., considered to be one of New England's strongest banking companies slashed its dividend by almost 43 percent. Fleet declared a quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share, down from 35 cents, payable on Jan. 1 to stockholders of record on Dec. 15. Analysts had expected some sort of cut.

title: Nuveen Offering Shares in 2 Funds
description: To raise $400 million in capital for two new closed-end funds, John Nuveen & Company is making initial public offerings of common stock for the Nuveen New York Investment Quality Municipal Fund Inc. and the Nuveen California Investment Quality Municipal Fund Inc.

title: Knicks Aren't Looking Very Good
description: Good teams in the National Basketball Association are supposed to win at home and play with consistency, not lose big leads.

title: Anderson About to Join Big Names He Nears 10,000 Yards
description: In the 70-year history of the National Football League, only seven backs have rushed for 10,000 yards. On Sunday, when the Giants (10-0) play the Eagles (6-4) in Philadelphia, Ottis Anderson of the Giants will need 62 yards to join them.

title: Review/Music; Not the Day It Was Supposed to Be
description: For many in New York, Sunday may have seemed to be Robert Shaw Day, with the conductor performing Brahms's "German Requiem" in the afternoon at Carnegie Hall to conclude his choral workshop of last week. But officially in Manhattan, it was Mid-America Productions Day, as Ruth W. Messinger, Manhattan Borough President, proclaimed in the evening from the Carnegie stage, citing the opportunities the company has created for young American and foreign groups to perform in the venerable hall.

title: Personal Health
description: After running the New York City Marathon, an estimated 5,000 runners, or 20 percent of participants, experienced blood in their urine, a phenomenon that at any given time occurs in about one in seven adults, athletic or otherwise.

title: Washington Talk; Private War Within Public Hearings
description: They are Senate col leagues from Ari zona. They say "hello" when passing each other in the hallway. But they rarely smile at each other anymore. Indeed, they barely hide their mutual dislike.

title: Digital Equipment To Close Operation
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said it would close a plant in Phoenix and eliminate more than 400 jobs, which might require the first layoffs in company history. Digital, which has been slashing its payroll for months because of a slump in computer sales, said it would try to find other slots in the company for some workers. The company also plans to offer a financial package similar to a severance program it has used to encourage workers to voluntarily leave their jobs.

title: Chinese Atom-Arms Spying in U.S. Reported
description: Chinese intelligence agents succeeded in stealing nuclear-weapons secrets from the Government's Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in the 1980's, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation later conducted a long espionage inquiry into the theft, American intelligence experts said today.

title: Army to Extend Enlistments
description: The Pentagon has decided to give the Army the authority to halt retirements and indefinitely extend enlistments in the gulf crisis. Page A20.

title: Article 666890 -- No Title
description: A 270-year-old violin by Antonio Stradivari called the Red Mendelssohn was sold yesterday at Christie's in London for $1.7 million, a record at auction for a musical instrument. The instrument is named after the members of the Berlin banking family who were descendants of the composer Felix Mendelssohn and who owned the violin from the late 19th century until the 1950's.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Aeromexico, a subsidairy of Aerovias de Mexico C.V., Mexico City, appointed Guillermo Heredia president. * Discover Re Managers, Farmington, Conn., a reinsurance group, appointed Albert Collings executive vice president and chief financial officer; Gregory Berg executive vice president; Rhonda Miller a vice president, and Robert Schultz assistant vice president for underwriting and marketing. * Federal National Mortgage Association, Washington, known as Fannie Mae, named Martin D. Levine and Thomas W. White senior vice presidents. Appointed vice presidents were Violetta Kapsalis, Donna M. Callejon, Deborah L. Cohen, Bess Donaldson, Jane Orahood, Julie St. John, Daniel C. Smith and Paul R. Vergets. * Oracle Corp., Redwood Shores, Calif., a subsidiary of Oracle Systems Corp., Belmont, Calif., a software company, appointed Terence J. Garnett vice president of corporate marketing. * Sotheby's Inc., New York, a unit of Sotheby's Holdings Inc., Bloomfield Hills, Mich., the auction and realty concern, named Diana D. Brooks president and chief executive. * Three-Five Systems Inc., Phoenix, a maker of optical displays and keyboards, named James F. Bowser senior vice president for sales and marketing, and Frank A. Polimene vice president of operations.

title: Thackery Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,191,000, and gain from disposal of discontinued operations of $ 6,595,000, or $ 1.29 a share.

title: Despite State Vote, One Arizona County Will Honor Dr. King
description: Reacting to a statewide vote against a holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., one Arizona county has decided to give its workers a paid holiday commemorating him.

title: Matsushita Set to Acquire Advanced Chip Plant in U.S.
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation has signed a letter of intent to sell an advanced computer chip manufacturing plant in Puyallup, Wash., to the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, one of Japan's largest electronics concerns.

title: Honeywell Realigns Top-Level Managers
description: Streamlining its operations, Honeywell Inc. this week appointed three top executives to vice presidential posts just a step below the company's chairman and chief executive, James J. Renier.

title: Judge Approves New Picket Site At News Plant
description: Brushing aside the New York City Police Department's objections, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that the police must allow striking Daily News workers to expand their picket lines at the newspaper's main printing plant in Brooklyn.

title: Earth Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Walton Returns as a Steeler
description: There was no bitterness, no rancor, no remorse in the voice of Pittsburgh's offensive coordinator, Joe Walton. He was speaking over the telephone today from Pittsburgh about returning to Giants Stadium on Sunday for the first time since he was dismissed as the Jets' head coach the day after last Christmas.

title: Cavalier Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Neediest Cases Drive Begins Its 79th Year
description: Drugs. Homelessness. AIDS.

title: Rangers Let a Victory Slip Away
description: Two goals 18 seconds apart in the waning moments of regulation time earned the Sabres a 5-5 tie tonight with the Rangers, who absorbed tremendous pressure in the third period and in the scoreless overtime.

title: Lyme Disease Shows Latent Effects
description: Some victims of Lyme disease may suffer memory loss, mood changes, tingling sensations, shooting pains and other signs of nerve damage that strike years after the initial tick bite and that may not disappear with antibiotic therapy, scientists announced today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a shooting at a dance club referred incorrectly to Paul Friedman, an officer of the company that owns the club. He is not an executive of Monaghan Management, which has offices in the building at 285 Broadway where the club is situated.

title: Soviet-Italy Phone Deal
description: Italtel S.p.A., an Italian telecommunications equipment maker, signed a joint venture accord on Tuesday with a Soviet company to produce digital phone exchanges. Telezaria, as the joint venture is named, is 60 percent owned by the Soviet company Krasnaja Zarja and 40 percent by the Italian partner. Once it runs at full capacity, Telezaria expects to supply 25 percent of the Soviet telecommunications market, which plans to have 100 million telephone lines installed by the year 2000, according to a statement released in Milan. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company owns 20 percent of Italtel.

title: Review/Theater; 'Grotesque Love Songs,' Family Tale
description: Don Nigro's "Grotesque Love Songs," at the WPA Theater, belongs to a tradition of Middle American drama that has been so overworked it is a stiff challenge for any playwright to pump new life into it. A family that seems as normal as blueberry pie goes through a fit of soul-searching in which skeletons tumble out of closets until a new equilibrium is reached.

title: Gorbachev Critics Step Up Their Attacks
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's critics stepped up their complaints about his domestic performance today as he returned home from another summit meeting abroad.

title: Cardinals Sign Manley To Bolster Pass Rush
description: The Phoenix Cardinals, who rank 23d in the league in sacks, picked Dexter Manley from the waiver wire yesterday, two days after the former Pro Bowl player was reinstated to the National Football League.

title: A Late Rally Pushes Dow Up by 9.16
description: After falling for much of the day, stocks rallied before yesterday's closing in thin trading. At that point some traders had already left to start the Thanksgiving holiday.

title: Harcor Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a writedown of $ 153,000 for the quarter and 9 months.c-Net lossThe latest periods give effect to the consolidation of a minority-controlled subsidiary at Sept. 30.

title: Critic's Notebook; Films That Live on the Border Between Fantasy and Reality
description: You never know what words will turn an object of affection into a subject of romance. In "Tune In Tomorrow," Barbara Hershey is a glamorous 36-year-old who challenges her 21-year-old nephew-by-marriage with this unseductive line: "I'm almost old enough to be your mother, you know?" Keanu Reeves flashes a hopelessly enamored smile and leaps right back with the answer that wins her heart: "Then I've almost got an Oedipus complex." It's not "Romeo and Juliet," but it's got a spark all its own.

title: Key Rates
CHRONICLE
description: CHUCK BERRY was ecstatic after a child-abuse charge against him was dropped and felony drug charges reduced yesterday in Missouri. Under a plea bargain, the 63-year-old singer agreed to serve two years of unsupervised probation on a misdeameanor charge of possession of marijuana. Prosecutors said the child-abuse case was not strong enough to try.

title: INSIDE
description: Thatcher Is Home for Battle Despite growing confidence in the camp of her challenger for the party leadership, the Prime Minister said: "I fight on. I fight to win." Page A3. More Trouble for Gorbachev Criticism of President Gorbachev mounted in the Soviet Union, with Boris N. Yeltsin suggesting a referendum on the leader's powers. Page A3. Public Hearing, Private War Arizona's two Senators were never close. Now, under pressure of an ethics inquiry, they are baring dislike. Washington Talk, page A24. A Patriot's Return The remains of Ignace Jan Paderewski, pianist and first Prime Minister of Poland, will be returned to Poland from the United States. Page C15.

title: Alexander S. Gross, Editor, 76
description: Alexander S. Gross, a retired makeup editor at The New York Times and a former assistant news editor at The New York Herald Tribune, died on Tuesday at Jamaica Hospital in Queens. He was 76 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Police Say Abuse Suspect Took Girls Out of School to Have Sex
description: A Brooklyn man who is charged with sexually abusing four young sisters adopted by his girlfriend signed two of them out of school at least 22 times this year to have sex with them, the police said yesterday.

title: A Seventh Encephalitis Death
description: A seventh death has been linked to the outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis that has spread across much of Florida since mid-August. The state's Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services today identified the latest victim of the outbreak as a Hillsborough County man who died Nov. 7. A total of 128 confirmed cases of the mosquito-borne disease have been reported across the state.

title: Ex-Ohio Congressman's Conviction Upheld
description: The Ohio Supreme Court today upheld the conviction of former Representative Donald E. Lukens for contributing to the unruliness of a minor. The charge stemmed from his having had sexual relations with a teen-age girl in 1988 in his Columbus apartment.

title: Thanksgiving Day
description: NEW YORK Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 77th Street and Central Park West; then heads to Columbus Circle and down Broadway to 34th Street. Government Offices: Federal, State and Municipal closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday parking rules. Sanitation: No pickups or street cleaning. Schools: Closed today. Closed tomorrow in New York City, with option to close elsewhere. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Holiday schedule for buses, subways, L.I.R.R., and Metro-North. NEW JERSEY Government Offices: Federal, state, and municipal closed. State offices closed tomorrow. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Option to close tomorrow. Tranportation: N.J. Transit on weekend schedule. CONNECTICUT Government Offices: Federal, state, and municipal closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed today and tomorrow. Transportation: Holiday schedule for the Metro-North New Haven line.

title: Bensonhurst Witness Challenged on Use of Drugs
description: A prosecution witness in the Bensonhurst murder case testified yesterday at the trial of two defendants that she had seen them with a gun shortly after the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins.

title: Bangor Hydro-Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Indians' New Harvest
description: The only news to travel from Indian country to the major media in 1990 has been news of disaster: a violent standoff between Mohawks and Government officials in Quebec; fatal gun battles over casino gambling at the St. Regis reservation in New York State; the ignoble fall of Peter MacDonald from the helm of the Navajo Nation. America has been saturated with images of incompetent Indian leadership and harebrained business schemes. As much as Native Americans seek understanding, this has been a year when many would just as soon the press had ignored them.

title: Dissident in Filing On ASK Computer
description: James P. Lennane, a dissident shareholder of ASK Computer Systems Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he was reviewing his options after losing a proxy battle with the company and that he might seek control of the software concern, based in Los Altos, Calif. Mr. Lennane said he controlled 1.4 million ASK Computer shares, or 7.45 percent of those outstanding.

title: Milken Gets 10 Years for Wall St. Crimes
description: Michael R. Milken, the once-powerful financier who came to symbolize a decade of excess, was sentenced to 10 years in prison yesterday for violating Federal securities laws and committing other crimes.

title: Effort to Mobilize Parents Starts Anew
description: Two years ago Dr. T. Berry Brazelton and some friends who share his concern for children decided it was time to mobilize the nation's parents to fight for family issues in Washington. So they announced the creation of a new group to represent the voices of mothers and fathers. They gave the organization a name that summed up their philosophy: Parent Action.

title: Hiring-Bias Lawsuit Settled by State Farm
description: A Federal judge has approved the settlement of a class-action lawsuit that accused State Farm Insurance Companies of discriminating against minorities and women in its Texas region.

title: No Santas, No Snowmen, Just a Howl
description: THE traditional images of holiday cards -- Santa Claus, giddy children in sleighs and plump snowmen -- are being joined this year by a Weimaraner.

title: Phil Landrum, 83, Former Lawmaker From Georgia, Dies
description: Phil M. Landrum, a Georgian who served in Congress for a quarter-century and helped write landmark legislation intended to curb union corruption, died Monday at Pickens General Hospital in Jasper, Ga. He was 83 years old and lived in Jasper.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-23

title: Back Home, Thatcher Vows to Fight
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher returned early from the European security conference in Paris today and vowed, "I fight on, I fight to win," despite growing confidence in the camp of her challenger Michael Heseltine that he would oust her from the Conservative Party leadership next week.

title: Far West Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Growing Number of Parents Are Opting to Teach at Home
description: When Michael Polino's playmates trudge off to school, the 7-year-old stays at home, where the dining room table becomes his desk and his parents double as his teachers.

title: 'Riverhead Sniper' Gets 42 Years to Life
description: A self-styled commando known as the Riverhead Sniper was sentenced today to 42 years to life in prison for a 1988 spree in which one man was killed and three others were wounded.

title: Texaco Unit Prices $200 Million Issue
description: Texaco Capital Inc. yesterday priced $200 million in notes due in 1997 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Signal Leaves, Manilla Turkey
description: Along with traditional warmth, the man realized, Thanksgiving brings an inexorable chill. If it's Thanksgiving, it's already too late to do Christmas shopping with any kind of calm, care or comfort. Starting tomorrow, the stores will contain too many customers, too few clerks and too many items suddenly out of stock. But this year the man felt no chill, for this is the year he learned to look at the catalogues.

title: Deals
description: Baseball DETROIT (AL) -- Signed Rob Deer, outfielder, to a three-year contract. KANSAS CITY (AL) -- Signed Mike Boddicker, pitcher, to a three-year contract. CHICAGO (NL) -- Signed Danny Jackson, pitcher, to a four-year contract. CINCINNATI (NL) -- Agreed to terms with Tom Browning, pitcher, on a four-year contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) -- Named Jeff Podobnik director of Florida baseball operations. ST. LOUIS (NL) -- Purchased the contracts of Mark Clark and John Ericks, pitchers, from Savannah of the South Atlantic League; Luis Alicea, Bien Figueroa, Mike Ross, Joey Fernandez and Stan Royer, infielders, and Lonnie Maclin, outfielder, from Huntsville of the Southern League.

title: Nets Drop 34th Straight on the Road
description: The Nets' road woes continued tonight when they surrendered a late fourth-quarter lead and lost to the Los Angeles Clippers, 99-90.

title: Czechoslovak Church's Quandary: Married Priests
description: Czechoslovakia's Roman Catholic Church is urging priests who were secretly ordained in the years when religion was repressed, among them married men and fathers, to come forward to have their status reviewed by church authorities.

title: Hard Times In Albany Dim Smile of Speaker
description: Among the many sure indications of New York State's slide into economic turmoil is the subdued look on the face of Mel Miller, the normally exuberant Speaker of the New York State Assembly, a man known for addressing just about everyone he comes across in the Capitol as "Darling."

title: Novelist With Copy Doctor on Call
description: Diane Johnson had professional help with her latest novel, "Health and Happiness," a widely praised tale about a hospital, its staff and its patients in which the moral quandaries of professionals who routinely exercise the most far-reaching powers are vividly presented.

title: Review/Dance; Many Casts In Joffrey's 'Nutcracker'
description: The Joffrey Ballet's production of "The Nutcracker" will be packed with myriad detail and cast changes during a season that runs through Dec. 2. A performance not to be missed is one that features Jodie Gates as a Sugar Plum Fairy of vivid and exquisitely classical style.

title: G.M. Recalls Cars for Defective Brake Light Switch
description: The General Motors Corporation is recalling more than half a million of its 1989 and 1990 midsize cars to correct a defective switch for brake lights that could lead to rear-end collisions.

title: Dresden Journal; First the Allies. Then the Communists. And Now?
description: Ulrich Aust's love affair with the Royal Palace in his hometown began in the 1960's. That is when he and other students sneaked out into the night to work hurried repairs on the charred and hollow ruin that was left after British and American bombers gutted the city, a jewel of European Baroque, in a hail of fire in the waning months of World War II.

title: Fund Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed in the week ended yesterday.

title: Mary Kirk Jazz Pianist, 90
description: Mary Kirk, a jazz pianist, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90 years old.

title: CSC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the murder trial of a winery worker in California referred incorrectly to court proceedings in the case. The jury recommended that the defendant, Ramon Salcido, be sentenced todeath in the slayings of his wife, two of their children and four other people; it did not sentence Mr. Salcido to death. Juries in California murder cases advise the judge whether they believe a defendant should be executed or be sentenced to life in prison without parole. The judge will formally sentence Mr. Salcido on Dec. 17.

title: Vessels To Lift Or Simply To Look At
description: SEVENTY clay, glass and metal drinking vessels that incorporate numerous technical and sculptural innovations are on view in the exhibition "Vessels: From Use to Symbol" at the American Craft Museum.

title: Review/Dance; City Ballet's Tribute to Tchaikovsky
description: Tchaikovsky, the best composer in 19th-century ballet, was born 150 years ago, and this anniversary was marked, belatedly but aptly, with a tribute as the New York City Ballet opened its fall-winter season on Tuesday night.

title: The Bee or the Butterfly?
description: One clear result of the confused elections was the strong mandate given a somewhat offbeat political constituency: monarch butterflies. At a time when environmental bond proposals were being knocked down all over the country, residents of the Monterey Peninsula in California voted overwhelmingly, 61 to 21 percent, to spend more than $1 million on a refuge for the monarch, which likes to winter there. This should certainly sway Congress, which now has before it the matter of naming a national insect.

title: Bush, on Saudi Visit to Troops, Sees U.N. Acting on Iraq in Week
description: The United States, the Soviet Union and France called separately today for new steps soon by the United Nations Security Council to bring about Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. But American officials said that there was still no consensus on the exact shape of a new resolution.

title: Statue in Met Show Said to Be Stolen
description: The Turkish Government has hired a New York City law firm to investigate allegations that half of an ancient sculpture, now on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was smuggled out of Turkey. The marble piece, said to be the top half of a statue of Herakles, or Hercules, dating to A.D. 170, is in the show "Glories of the Past," a selection from the antiquities collection of Leon Levy and Shelby White.

description: The college basketball season has just begun but Arkansas and Arizona have flexed their muscles and have justified preseason predictions as two of the nation's top five teams.

title: Bridge

He will be remembered as a role model who showed that AIDS need not be a barrier to a full and rewarding life.

title: Dinkins Aide Robbed; 2 Youths Are Seized

And every three years they put on a show to display what they have made: microcosms of villages, houses and shops filled with tiny people, animals, furniture, rugs and clothing.

title: Review/Rock; Harmonies of Middle Ages Used by Dead Can Dance
description: Dead Can Dance's show on Tuesday night at Symphony Space had less to do with rock than any rock concert I've seen in years. While all sorts of popular music sought its roots during the 1980's, Dead Can Dance went back further than most -- to the music of the Middle Ages, before Western tonality was established. Somber and stark, sometimes dissonant in terms of classical harmony, the music is close to European and Balkan folk dances, traditional ballads, Gregorian chants and medieval motets and chansons, and a long way from current pop. For Dead Can Dance, the composer Guilliame Machaut (c. 1300-1377) means more than Madonna.

title: Man Screaming to Satan Held in Mother's Killing
description: A 23-year-old Queens man screaming "Don't worry, I won't die, Satan," stabbed his mother to death and wounded his father with a kitchen knife at a Thanksgiving Day gathering yesterday, the police and neighbors said.

Those performing include Dean Spencer, Rory Block, the Short Sisters, John Calvi, Guy Davis, Beth Shepard, George Ward, Judy and Kate Seeger and Tony Seeger, the ethnomusicologist and head of Folkways Records. The concert is a benefit for the scholarship fund of the Killooleet summer camp in Hancock, Vt. Tickets are available at the door for $15 ($10 for students and the elderly). Information: (203) 354-5728.

description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's remarks yesterday at a Marine outpost in northeastern Saudi Arabia, as provided by the Federal News Service, a Washington-based transcription agency. You know, Thanksgiving is the oldest, some, some might say the most American of holidays, dating back to our very origins as a people. And it's a day, I think we would all agree, separate and apart from others. It's a day of peace, it's a day of thanks, a day to remember what we stand for, and what it means to be an American, and why our forebears sacrificed so much to cross an ocean and build a great land.

description: The Waterboys, a pop quartet from Ireland led by the singer and songwriter Mike Scott, is an unusually versatile folk-rock band that makes a point of changing styles at the drop of a hat. Since the band released its first album seven years ago, it has moved away from uptempo folk-rock with a post-punk edge toward songs with more traditional Irish flavor. But on Monday evening at the Beacon Theater, where the Waterboys opened a two-evening engagement, the band shifted among half a dozen different styles, often with a jump-cut abruptness.

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Tub of Their Own
description: The first tenants of the Edgecomb, a turn-of-the-century mansion in New York's Washington Heights, were surely a family and most likely prosperous. (There are several maid-sized bedrooms on the top floor.) But as the neighborhood fell, so did the house. It became, until a few years ago, a brothel. Now the Edgecomb is a home again, to people who have gone for a long time without aspects of home that most Americans take for granted. Their own tubs and toilets and sinks. Their own refrigerators. Their own beds. A roof over their heads

title: Sounds Around Town
description: The Joe Beck Trio Joe Beck Trio, Zanzibar and Grill, 550 Third Avenue, south of 37th Street, in Manhattan (212-779-0606). The guitarist Joe Beck has straddled the worlds of jazz and rock much of the time since he shot to attention in the 1960's after performing with Charles Lloyd, Gary McFarland, Chico Hamilton and Gil Evans. In the early 70's, he played with the cross-over groups Weather Report and Blood, Sweat and Tears. He later became a dairy farmer and reduced music to a sideline, but since returning to music full time six years ago, he has devoted himself to straight jazz. He took on a new stance in 1984 with an album by an acoustic trio featuring Jay Leonhart on bass and Grady Tate on drums. He is now leading another acoustic trio, in which Lonnie Smith plays organ and Matt Keeler the drums, every Sunday at Zanzibar. Shows are at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. There is a $7 music charge with a one-entree minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar. Kellaway and Leonhart

The program includes Martinu's Three Madrigals, the Brahms Clarinet Trio (Op. 114), Debussy's "Danses Sacrees et Profanes" and Bloch's Piano Quartet No. 1. The performers are to include Hae-Young Ham, Sharon Yamada, Vladimir Tsypin and Allan Schiller, violinists; Dorian Rence, Irene Breslaw and Dawn Riggs, violists; Alan Stepansky and Nancy Donaruma, cellists; Harriet Wingreen and Dmitry Rachmanov, pianists; Peter Simenauer, clarinetist; Sarah Bullen, harpist, and Michele Saxon, bassist. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 362-8719.

title: Economic Scene; Trying to Soothe Scared Bankers
description: ADDRESSING the New York chapter of the Arthritis Foundation this week, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged bankers to keep lending to their good customers. He is afraid the bankers may be spooked into creating a credit crunch by their fears of an economic slump and their worries about meeting tougher regulatory standards. To ease the latter worry, Mr. Brady told regulators not to use "unrealistically negative scenarios in evaluating loans."

title: Review/ Art; Tiny Units Make Playful Wholes in Italian's Work
description: Despite hundreds of illuminating exhibitions, books and magazine articles, postwar European art still harbors many artists who deserve wider recognition in this country. One of them is the Italian Alighiero e Boetti, currently the subject of an exhibition at the Salvatore Ala Gallery in SoHo. Mr. Boetti is not entirely unknown in this country. His work has been included in one group exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art and another at P.S. 1 in Queens, and he has had four one-man gallery shows in New York City since 1975. But the Ala Gallery's charming if somewhat piecemeal exhibition, which includes 18 works dating from 1965 to 1989, is his largest and most impressive showing yet. It conveys much of the freshness of a new discovery.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 15 about Malcolm Muggeridge, a British journalist and social critic, misstated the title of one of his books. It is "Jesus Rediscovered." The obituary also omitted the title of his last book, about his conversion to Catholicism in 1982. It is "Conversion: A Spiritual Journey."

At the Movies
description: On to 'Barcelona'

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING 5,000th Winner for Day Pat Day rode his 5,000th career winner yesterday, taking the feature race at Churchill Downs to become the 12th jockey to reach the milestone. The victory came in the Falls City Handicap, a race for 3-year-olds at nine furlongs. Day was aboard Screen Prospect, who paid $5.80 for $2 to win. (AP) Sports View Wins: Sports View held off a late drive by the favorite, I'm Sky High, and won the Queens County Handicap by a head yesterday at Aqueduct. Killer Diller and Lost Opportunity finished in a dead heat for third. The winner, carrying Craig Perret, covered the mile and three-sixteenths in 1:57 and paid $9.80 for $2 to win. (AP) TENNIS Leach and Pugh Upset Scott Davis and David Pate upset their fellow Americans Rick Leach and Jim Pugh, 7-6, 3-6, 6-4, yesterday to move toward a semifinal spot in the A.T.P. World Doubles round-robin tournament at Sanctuary Cove, Australia. In other matches, Emilio Sanchez and Sergio Casal of Spain beat Gary Muller and Neil Broad of South Africa, 6-7, 6-3, 7-6, and the top-seeded Pieter Aldrich and Danie Visser of South Africa were upset by Jakob Hlasek and Guy Forget, 6-3, 7-5. (AP) GOLF A Double-Eagle Sandy Armour scored a double-eagle on the par-5 ninth hole yesterday on his way to a seven-under-par 64 and the first-round lead in the Australian PGA tournament in Sydney. Armour holed his second shot on the ninth on the par-71 Riverside Oaks course and wound up with a one-stroke lead over Wayne Grady and Brett Ogle. (AP) Nelson in Front by Two: Larry Nelson shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take a two-stroke lead after the first round of the Casio World Open in Kaimoncho, Japan. Four golfers were tied for second. (AP) English Team Ahead: The English golfers Mark James and Richard Boxall faltered slightly yesterday but maintained their lead halfway through the World Cup of Golf at Orlando, Fla. James shot a one-under-par 71 and Boxall carded a 69 for a 276 total, one stroke ahead of Spain and two better than the United States in the two-man team competition. (AP) BOXING Daniels Keeps Title Robert Daniels, the World Boxing Association cruiserweight champion, retained his crown yesterday by fighting to a draw with the former champion Taoufik Belbouli at the Madrid Sports Palace. Belbouli dominated the middle rounds of the 12-round fight, but Daniels rallied in the last two to keep his title. Two of the judges scored the fight even; the third gave the fight to Daniels by a single point. A W.B.A. fight supervisor, Carlos Chaves of Venezuela, ruled the bout a draw. (AP)

Tickets are $22. Information: (212) 874-6770.

Free Meal, Then Illness
description: A free Thanksgiving lunch for the homeless sent more than two dozen people to hospitals with food poisoning on Wednesday. Officials said the meal of turkey sandwiches and turkey soup had been donated by a church and served to about 300 people at a downtown soup kitchen called the Austin Baptist Chapel. Sally Muir, an emergency services spokeswoman, said 28 people had been taken to three hospitals by 6 P.M. Health officials said people with food poisoning usually recover quickly, but many of those who became ill were in poor health to begin with.

title:
Developing Staten Island;
After Delays, Hillside Homes Are Near
description: Some of the finest views from Staten Island are afforded by sites on Ward Hill -- elevation 202 feet -- the northernmost of the five hills that form a serpentine ridge down the center of the island.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Shopper's Lunch My first independent dining experience occurred when I was 10 years old. My mother gave me 50 cents, and I took the bus from our home 20 blocks south to downtown Columbus, Ohio, and had lunch in the tea room of Lazarus, the department store. I remember the meal in exquisite detail: a dainty plate of chicken dressing with giblet gravy accompanied by a glass of milk. It was perfect. Even today, slabs of perfect foie gras and glasses of 1921 Chateau d'Yquem don't always surpass the memory I reserve for that first taste of self-determination. And I may still have a bias in favor of department-store dining. I love the Cafe SFA that opened last week on the eighth floor of Sak's Fifth Avenue.

title: Critic's Choice
description: Karen Akers, a cabaret artist who has never been known for her warmth and spontaneity, has made a significant breakthrough in her new cabaret act at the Ballroom in Manhattan. Performing a program that features three songs from the Richard Maltby-David Shire revue "Closer Than Ever" and two Stephen Sondheim numbers from the movie "Dick Tracy," the singer is far more communicative than she used to be. The show's high points include a superbly dramatized reading of Maltby and Shire's "Life Story" that has surprising flashes of humor, and renditions of "Sooner or Later" and "More," from "Dick Tracy," in which Ms. Akers becomes a sultry pop-jazz vamp. Among other welcome resurrections are Craig Carnelia's "Picture in the Hall" from the play "Three Postcards," and "Blame It On the Summer Night," the strongest ballad from the ill-fated Broadway musical "Rags."

title: Maryland Coach to Stay
description: There's nothing like giving a coach a little incentive, his job, for example, to spur his team to unaccustomed heights. That seems to be the case, anyway, with Joe Krivak, the Maryland football coach. After three consecutive losing seasons, Krivak knew his job was on the line when the Terrapins went into their final game with a 5-5 record and little chance of avoiding a 5-6 farewell finish. Then came the stunning 35-30 upset victory over highly ranked Virginia that gave Maryland a winning 6-5 record, and instead of "Goodbye, coach," it was "Hello, new contract. Krivak, who learned of the decision Wednesday morning, got a bonus of sorts later that day, a surprise bid to play Louisiana Tech in the Independence Bowl in Shreveport Dec. 15. (AP)

title: Review/ Jazz; The Kansas City Sound By Queen Bey, a Singer
description: Kansas City, Mo., once a fertile source of jazz musicians like Charlie Parker and singers like Big Joe Turner, has become a jazz backwater in recent years. But there are performers who still work in the old traditions. A singer who calls herself Queen Bey and the violinist Claude (Fiddler) Williams bring a slight whiff of the old Kansas City to the show that opened on Tuesday at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street) and will continue through Dec. 8.

title: L.S.U. Narrows Field
description: Only four candidates from an original list of 40 remain in strong contention to replace Mike Archer as football coach at Louisiana State, the Times-Picayune of Baton Rouge, La., reported yesterday. The four are Dick Sheridan of North Carolina State, Bobby Ross of third-ranked Georgia Tech, Curley Hallman of Southern Mississippi and the former Pittsburgh coach, Mike Gottfried. (AP)

title: A Surer Way to Control Crime
description: Here's a statistic to shock, and shame, New Yorkers: Nearly one-fourth of black men aged 20 to 29 in the state are under some sort of correctional supervision. The study that produced this figure calls vaguely for broad reform of social injustices that push young blacks into the criminal justice system. But a much more specific response is possible, and needed: vastly expand drug treatment.

title: Review/Cabaret; Swing vs. Broadway: Dueling Tunes
description: Early in "Daugherty and Field Off Broadway," the New York cabaret team's theatrical debut at the Double Image Theater, Bill Daugherty, the duo's junior member, lead singer and cut-up, cheekily declares his preference for swing tunes over Broadway melodies. The announcement elicits huffs of indignation from Robin Field, the team's pianist, arranger and writer of its special material. Before long, the two are engaged in a spirited vocal duel in which Mr. Daugherty performs his favorite swing tunes while Mr. Field wraps them harmonically in choice Broadway melodies.

title: European Inquiry Is Ordered For Anti-Communist Groups
description: The European Parliament called today for an investigation into the activities of secret anti-Communist organizations that were set up in the 1950's to counter a possible Soviet invasion of Western Europe.

title: Tom Otterness's Wicked World of Human and Beastly Folly
description: With his commission for the north park of Battery Park City, Tom Otterness has reached a new plateau. The opportunity to make sculptures for children and adults to live with in a public space has helped him focus the playful, sinister and allegorical impulses of his work. It has also enabled him to give his tiny Jiminy Cricket-like people and his menagerie of exotic or mundane animals a narrative and a home. His bronze sculptures at the Brooke Alexander Gallery in SoHo are like a fable about desire, curiosity and folly.

title: Pop/Jazz; Heart Throbs Offer Guitars, Pithiness And Fatalism
description: Love, dreams, a touch of apocalypse, a profusion of guitars: those are the underpinnings of the Heart Throbs, a British band that is to perform tonight at Maxwell's in Hoboken, N.J., as part of its first United States tour. They carry the clear, level-headed voice of Rose Carlotti, the Heart Throbs' co-founder and lyricist, in pop songs that have classic proportions and a modern sense of disquiet. "Tossed Away," the opening song on "Cleopatra Grip" (Elektra), the Heart Throbs' debut album, describes nuclear Armageddon with calm fatalism: "Atoms kiss and we blow them away/the planet sighs and we make our mistake."

title: Review/Music; Dutoit Offers Stravinsky and Debussy
description: In recent years, Charles Dutoit has presided over some of New York's most elegant and refined orchestral concerts, whether he was conducting his own Montreal Symphony, the New York Philharmonic, the Philadelphia Orchestra or some other ensemble. The current Philharmonic subscription series at Avery Fisher Hall might seem stocked with his specialties. But it cannot be said that Wednesday evening's opening concert was very successful.

title: Study Says Deposit Law Would Cut Pollution
description: Levying a deposit on beverage cans and bottles would reduce pollution and conserve energy, says a Government report that could improve prospects for passage of a national deposit law.

description: Charles Palmer, the executive chef and part owner of Aureole in on the East Side of Manhattan, wanted to have more than one restaurant. A keen observer of the dining scene and a fine cook, he understands what many have learned the hard way: with few exceptions, being a chef and owner of a multi-star restaurant and being a multi-restaurant mogul are mutually exclusive.

Miss Isbin is also to play Bach's Lute Suite No. 2 (B.W.V. 997), Walton's Five Bagatelles (1972), Brouwer's "Espiral Eterna" and works by Rodrigo, Barrios and Lauro. Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: As Economy Slows, Malls Brace for a Blue Christmas
description: Christmas has already come to the mall. But along with the gaudy white tulle trees, the enormous ornaments bobbing from the ceiling and Santa Claus and his sneaker-wearing elves, there is anxiety here. You can see it among the merchants, many presiding over shops with few or no customers on the Monday before Thanksgiving. And you can see it among the shoppers, many who shop without buying.

title: CHRONICLE

title: Second Earthquake in 2 Days Strikes in Aleutian Islands
description: For the second time in two days, an earthquake struck Wednesday in a remote area of Alaska near the Aleutian Islands. No injuries or damage were reported, officials said.

title: TV Weekend; From Mellow to Motown in 3 Shows
description: In one guise or another, pop music will be having a heavy play on television this weekend. Among the more prominent highlights: tonight's "Great Performances" presentation (at 9 P.M. on Channel 13) of "Harry Connick Jr. and His Orchestra: Swinging Out With Harry" and, at 10 P.M., Arts & Entertainment's "Inside Track With Graham Nash." Then on Sunday (9 P.M. on CBS ), there's "Motown 30: What's Goin' On." That covers a lot of stylistic territory.

title: Corrections

It was music director. The obituary also misstated the year of the founding of the Washington Opera. It was 1956.

title: A Thanksgiving Feast, Under the Highway

But at noon he was too busy to ponder it. Company was coming for dinner, and he was behind schedule building an oven.

title: See? New York's Not a Parade of Horrors
description: Watch New York from a step back, Ginny Pope had been telling herself for two days. Better yet, two steps back. Don't get too close to the people in rags and the hustlers and all those others crowded onto the sidewalks. So she watched New York from ferries and tour buses. She thought she was keeping her distance.

title: Reviews/Art;   Eric Fischl Mixes India's Exotic and Mundane Sides
description: Eric Fischl's latest paintings are at once his most ambiguous and his most resolved. They may also be among his best. Their subject is India, or more precisely the artist's relationship to the India that he encountered on a visit there, and that seems to have confounded and seduced him. It is a place where the mundane and the exotic mix uneasily, where a visitor never loses sight of the distance between cultural insider and outsider.

title: Pay Phone Surcharge at Issue
description: A surcharge on calls made from pay telephones may be banned under a proposal before New Jersey State regulators. The state Board of Public Utilities on Wednesday considered eliminating the extra charges, which can add up to $1.50 a call, The Record of Hackensack reported. The money goes to the businesses where the pay phones are installed.

Auctions
description: The downward spiral of art prices continued this week at the November auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York, with the action, or absence of it, witnessed by hundreds of spectators. At the sales of tribal art and Impressionist, postwar and modern prints, the prices paid were mostly at the low end or below the house estimates, and about 25 percent or more of what was offered did not sell. The only auctions that attracted spirited bidding were the sales of Latin American and pre-Columbian art, although even at these sessions many works found no buyers.

title: Worker Killed in Laundry
description: A commercial laundry worker was killed when he was apparently knocked into a huge dryer by 100 pounds of wet clothing. The worker, Alfredo Castro, 31 years old, was preparing to clean the dryer Wednesday night when a pile of wet laundry came down a shuttle belt and somehow knocked him inside the machine, the police said.

Two years after the death of its founder and namesake in 1988, the company was facing an accumulated deficit of $1.8 million. Its board was racked by dissent. And when its artistic director, Gerald Arpino, resigned last May, taking his ballets with him, it seemed like the coup de grace.

title: Fear Abates Among Chinese But Few Find Cause for Hope

But neither a warm kang nor a down jacket can dispel the political and economic winter that has lasted nearly 18 months and shows little sign of easing.

title: Edwin Gary, Optician, 71
description: Edwin Gary, an optician who was director of special services for Sola/ Barnes-Hind, a contact lens company in Phoenix, died Tuesday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 71 years old.

title: 2 Cross-Country Streaks on the Line
description: Pat Porter of Alamosa, Colo., and Lynn Jennings of Newmarket, N.H., will attempt to extend streaks today at The Athletics Congress national cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Porter has won eight consecutive individual men's titles and Jennings has won three straight in the women's division and four over all.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Baybanks Inc., Boston, a bank holding company, said its Baybank Norfolk and Baybank Southeast N.A. units had merged to become Baybank South, which will have headquarters in Dedham, Mass. * Bombardier Inc., Montreal, a maker of engines and transportation equipment and machinery, said it was waiting for a final decision from Amtrak on an order for about 80 passenger cars worth about $190 million. Amtrak said a decision would be made at its board meeting next week. * CSA Management Ltd., Toronto, an investment manager, and Goldcorp Investments Ltd., Toronto, a gold and mining investment company, said they had acquired the assets of Abermin Corp., a mining company, from Deloitte & Touche Inc., which is the trustee in bankruptcy for Abermin. Terms were not disclosed. * Diasonics Inc., San Francisco, a maker of medical diagnostic imaging systems, said Sonotron Holding A.G., its European distribution subsidiary, had acquired Vingmed Sound A.S., a Norwegian subsidiary of Interspec Inc., Ambler, Pa., a maker of medical ultrasound systems. The purchase price is $17 million plus the assumption of up to $5.25 million in bank debt. * Hart Technologies, Pleasant Grove, Utah, a maker of high-precision instruments, said it would acquire Lifschultz Fast Freight, New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Best Matchup May Be in Division III
description: The last of 92,516 tickets for the Notre Dame-Southern California game at the Los Angeles Coliseum was sold in mid-August. At Trenton State, the message has been going out just this holiday week that there will be a game at Lions Stadium today.

Penney or any of hundreds of thousands of other retailers, you may not have to provide a credit card as identification. The reason? But that was all right for Nathaniel Brown, who at 80 years old still goes out picking oysters and who could use a little more time to get going himself.

But dancers also need strong, reasonably sophisticated choreography that makes the most of their gifts and is sensitive to their liabilities. And choreography was the weakest element in a program of nine pieces presented by the company in "A Sign of the Times" on Nov. 16 at the Triplex Theater.

The agency deals mainly with the city's most vulnerable children -- foster children who, more often than not, are victims of abuse and neglect. This daunting task now falls to Robert Little, a veteran social worker who takes the helm next month.

description: The former major league catcher Bo Diaz was killed today when he was crushed by a satellite dish on the roof of his home here, city officials said.

title: Trefoil Warning On Child World
description: Trefoil Capital Investors L.P., an investment group affiliated with Roy Disney's Shamrock Holdings, said it believes the conditions of its acquisition of an 82 percent stake in Child World Inc., the No. 2 United States retailer, will not be satisfied. The stake is now held by the CNC Holding Corporation. Trefoil said it had advised CNC that if that agreement fell through it would also terminate its plan to buy the remaining 18 percent interest in Child World that is in public hands.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Down in Slow Day
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities declined moderately in thin trading yesterday, largely in reaction to another sharp rise in crude oil prices, to $31.90 a barrel. But the shorter Treasury maturities, which are less influenced by inflation fears and pressures, were basically unchanged.

title: A Toast to Helsinki
description: Fifteen years ago the leaders of 35 nations met in neutral Finland to sign what became known as the Helsinki Accords. These agreements eventually led to this week's great Paris summit meeting and its champagne toasts to the demise of the cold war. Yet another toast is in order: to the much-abused promoters of the original Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, whose work at Helsinki initially drew skepticism, even derision.

title: Cranberry Crop Down
description: The crop of fresh cranberries has dropped 30 percent this year in Massachusetts compared with last year's harvest. The shortage was caused by inclement weather. The December 1989 deep freeze damaged some vines, and an 8-inch, bog-flooding rainfall on Cape Cod and adjacent areas in late July was devastating, leading to rot. Massachusetts is traditionally the nation's biggest cranberry grower, accounting for half the United States crop, but Wisconsin might take over the top spot this year once this year's figures are in.

title: Review/Art; Surrealism's Roots in Its Time
description: No modern art movement has been more trivialized than Surrealism. "Surreal" has long been a commonplace word used to describe experiences in which reality has something of the character of dream. The slickness and buffoonery of Salvador Dali, the most popular Surrealist, has encouraged the belief that Surrealism was mainly about posturing and surprise. When Surrealism has influenced recent art, it has been largely as a style, or as an esthetic, of metamorphosis, incongruity and deformation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS South African Pair Upset Fourth-seeded Grant Connell and Glenn Michibata of Canada upset top-seeded Pieter Aldrich and Danie Visser of South Africa, 6-2, 7-6, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the world doubles championship in Sanctuary Cove, Australia. Connell and Michibata clinched a spot in the final four of the tournament with a 2-1 round-robin record. They will play Emilio Sanchez and Sergio Casal of Spain today in a three-of-five-set semifinal. Sanchez and Casal beat the previously unbeaten Scott Davis and David Pate of the United States, 6-3, 7-6, and also posted a 2-1 round-robin record and won their group. Davis and Pate, seeded second, advanced to the semifinals despite the loss with a 2-1 round-robin record. They will play Guy Forget of France and Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, who improved their record to 3-0 with a 6-2, 7-6 victory over Darren Cahill and Mark Kratzmann of Australia. (AP) HOCKEY Red Wing Rookie Scores 4 Goals Johan Garpenlo scored four goals last night and Tim Cheveldae stopped a penalty shot as the Detroit Red Wings beat the Boston Bruins, 5-3, in Detroit. Garpenlo, a rookie who joined the Red Wings in the off season after four years in Sweden, snapped a 2-2 tie 5 minutes 36 seconds into the second period when he converted Marc Habscheid's rebound. That gave him his first N.H.L. hat trick, and 28 seconds later he got his fourth goal of the game. (AP) Leach Gets 2 Goals in 10 Seconds: Steve Leach scored twice in 10 seconds as the Washington Capitals tallied three goals in 21 seconds of the first period in a 7-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in Landover, Md. Leach entered the Washington record book by breaking the mark of two goals in 11 seconds, set by Dennis Maruk in 1982. The three goals in 21 seconds set a club record and was just one second short of the National Hockey League mark for the fastest three goals, held by the Boston Bruins, who did it in 1971. The Capitals held a 5-1 lead after the opening period, then coasted to their third consecutive victory. (AP) Whalers 4, Bruins 2: Ron Francis and Pat Verbeek of Hartford took advantage of overlapping five-minute penalties in the third period to score two goals apiece and lead the Whalers to victory in Boston. Cam Neely was hit with a five-minute match penalty for high-sticking the Whalers' Randy Lavouceur at 5:34, and John Carter drew a five-minute major for slashing Ulf Samuelsson at 7:28 to set up Hartford's decisive power-play situation. (AP) Flyers 4, Maple Leafs 1: Scott Mellanby's power-play goal early in the third period snapped a 1-1 tie and sparked the Flyers in Philadelphia. Toronto lost a fourth consecutive game and remained without a victory in 10 road games this season. (AP) Sabres 3, Oilers 2: In Buffalo, Benoit Hogue scored 34 seconds into overtime for the victory. Hogue moved in from the point, took a pass from Rick Vaive and fired a low shot between the legs of the Oiler goaltender, Bill Ranford. (AP) North Stars 6, Canucks 4: Brian Bellows broke out of a slump with three goals as Minnesota, playing at home, ended a streak without a victory at six games. (AP)

title: Guidepost; Figuring What C.D.'s Pay
description: The advertised yield on bank certificates of deposit with maturities of less than one year is often stated in terms that assume the investment will remain on deposit for a full year. But that is not much help if you want to calculate the amount of interest paid just for the period the money will be in the bank. When you want to know how much money your investment will yield at maturity, here is a simple five-step formula to help you figure the interest that short-term certificates will pay. This example uses a typical three-month rate of 7 percent, yielding 7.25 percent if the money were to remain on deposit for 12 months. Step 1: Subtract the interest rate from the yield: 7 - 7.25 = 0.25 Step 2: Divide by 12 the number of months the certificate will be on deposit: 3 / 12 = 0.25 Step 3: Multiply the answers from Step 1 and Step 2 by each other: 0.25 x 0.25 = 0.0625 Step 4: Add the answer from Step 3 to the interest rate: 0.0625 + 7 = 7.0625 Step 5: Multiply the answers from Step 4 and Step 2 by eachother: 7.0625 x 0.25 = 1.76. This means that the interest rate for three months is 1.76 percent, paying $17.60 on an investment of $1,000. Source: Steven J. Braitman, Consumer Banking Group, Chemical Bank
