description: Christmas tree rustlers are at it again in national forests in southern California, rangers say. Poachers have been taking trees without permits at Los Padres, Angeles and San Bernardino national forests, National Forest Service officials said, adding that tree theft was especially serious in Southern California forests because the relatively few evergreens were already fighting disease, insects and smog.

title: Power Halt Cuts Trading Of Stocks
description: An electrical failure at the New York Stock Exchange halted trading for more than an hour and a half yesterday, making a traditionally slow post-holiday session even slower.

title: BUSH SAYS SYRIA SUPPORTS THE USE OF FORCE ON IRAQ
description: Declaring that he is "tired of the status quo," President Bush said today that he was close to an accord on a United Nations resolution on using force against Iraq. He moved to tighten his coalition by meeting with President Hafez al-Assad and setting aside suspicions about Syrian links to terrorism.

title: Review/Music; Rhythms of the Philippines In a Percussion Ensemble
description: For all the headway world music has made in recent years, many exotic national forms and regional variants have scarcely been heard in New York City. One form that has not been offered plentifully is the kulintang music of the Philippines, or, more specifically, of the country's Mindanao region. On Wednesday evening, the Karadya'an Ensemble presented traditional Filipino instrumental and dance pieces at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Networked Picture Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Staar Surgical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossShare earnings for the latest 9 months included a gain of 31 cents a share on tax-loss carryforward.

title: Collins Foods International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 14
Jamesway Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 859,000 for estimated costs of closing two stores in the fourth quarter of 1990.c-Net income

title: Curtiss-Wright Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 13,860,000 for the estimated cost of an environmental cleanup at its Wood Ridge, N.J., property.c-Net incomed-After income of $ 1,237,000, or 25 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago results were restated.

title: Richardson Staying Put
description: He won't be returning to the National Basketball Association, but his little flirtation with the Philadelphia 76ers seems to have paid off for Micheal Ray Richardson. The former Knicks and Nets star, who has been playing in Italy since 1988, when the N.B.A. lifted a ban imposed after his third bout with cocaine in 1986, said the other day that the 76ers had offered him a guaranteed two-year contract at $800,000 a year. He said he would accept the offer unless it was matched by his Italian team, Knorr Bologna, which has been paying him $550,000 a season.

title: Deficit Up In October
description: The Federal Government opened the 1991 fiscal year with a $31.5 billion deficit in October, the Treasury Department said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two members of the teen-age singing group Menudo were dismissed from it yesterday after being arrested at Miami International Airport and charged with possession of marijuana. SERGIO GONZALEZ , 18, and RUBEN GOMEZ 16, were charged Thursday after a United States Customs Service dog smelled marijuana. Customs agents took small amounts of the drug from the youths, said Lieut. James Kaelin of the Metro-Dade police.

title: With a New Computer Program
description: You've done your homework, shopped around and found a new computer program at an attractive price. Now comes the real work: culling the parts of the program you truly need from a manual that is 500 to 1,000 pages long.

title: Buffton Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossThe latest quarter also included a gain on the reversal of a $ 1 million charge accrued for clean-up costs which was charged to operations in the fourth quarter ended Sept. 30, 1989.

title: Army Copter Crashes Into Oklahoma Lake
description: An Army Reserves helicopter on a night training mission crashed into Lake Ellsworth and five crew members were pulled to safety on a fishing boat. A sixth was missing, the authorities said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SARA L. ENGELHARDT will be the new president of the Foundation Center, which provides information on foundations and corporate philanthropy. She will succeed THOMAS R. BUCKMAN , 67 years old, who is stepping down in June after 20 years as the center's president. Ms. Englehardt, its executive vice president,used to be corporate secretary of the Carnegie Corporation of New York.

title: Kleinman Still Suing
description: Although the Yankees executive Leonard Kleinman has been cleared by Commissioner Fay Vincent of any wrongdoing in George Steinbrenner's payment to Howard Spira, he intends to continue a $22 million lawsuit against the commissioner, Kleinman's lawyer, Dominic F. Amorosa, said yesterday.

title: Dow Drops by 12.13; Week's Loss Is 23.02
description: In a post-Thanksgiving Day session marked by a morning power interruption, trading on the New York Stock Exchange fell yesterday to its lowest point since the day after Christmas in 1986.

title: Women's Push Into Work Force Seems to Have Reached Plateau
description: Although women seem as committed as ever to holding jobs, they are no longer piling into the labor force as rapidly as they did in the 1970's and 1980's.

title: Culp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Some Doubt Milken Can Aid in Prosecutions of Others
description: Will Michael R. Milken's cooperation prove helpful to the Government in bringing new criminal cases out of its investigations of wrongdoing on Wall Street?

title: Miami Suspends One of Its Fullbacks
description: Leonard Conley, one of four rotating Miami fullbacks who have helped the Hurricanes achieve a 7-2 record and high national rankings this season, has been suspended from the team for unspecified rules violations and will miss tonight's game against Syracuse, Miami's last home game of the season.

title: Ivaco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $ 27.5 million from the sale of the Niagara Lockport operations.Results are in Canadian funds.Both year-ago periods' sales were restated to reflect the sale of the Niagara Lockport operations.

title: Correction
description: Excerpts yesterday from remarks in Parliament during an appearance by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher misidentified one speaker. He was Paddy Ashdown, a Liberal Democrat, not Joe Ashton of the Labor Party.

title: U.S. Asks Allies to Help Move Troops to Gulf
description: The United States today appealed to European allies in Brussels for planes and ships to carry reinforcements to the Persian Gulf, American officials said.

title: Embolden Hussein's Opponents
description: The Bush Administration has met reluctance from its partners in the Persian Gulf crisis for the new United Nations resolution it wants explicitly authorizing the use of force against Iraq. It isn't clear whether President Bush has decided there will have to be a war, or believes a resolution, plus massive American reinforcements, will finally persuade Saddam Hussein to turn tail.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The New York Association of Black Journalists is giving its Lifetime Achievement award to CAROL JENKINS , a news anchor and reporter on WNBC-TV who has received recognition, including an Emmy, for excellent television reporting. She will receive the award on Dec. 7 at the organization's annual scholarship dinner. The association also gives college scholarships and cash awards to the winners of a high school essay contest.

title: Thatcherism: Viable Still?; 'Caring Government' Seems at Odds With It
description: With Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's decision to step down after 11 1/2 years as Britain's leader, a logical question to ask is whether Thatcherism is likely to outlast Mrs. Thatcher.

title: Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Commerce Clearing House reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $ 1.1 million on the sale of an equity investment.

title: Throngs Brighten Retailers' Day
description: Dispelling, if only temporarily, widespread forecasts of a gloomy Christmas for retailers, the 1990 holiday shopping season began in earnest yesterday, with stores around the country reporting throngs of shoppers streaming through the aisles.

title: James River Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Results are on a pro forma basis reflecting the restructuring plan announced by the company in August 1990.

title: Francis Kemp Is Dead; Bank Leader Was 50
description: Francis Kemp, president of the NCNB Corporation, one of the nation's largest bank holding companies, died yesterday at his home in Dallas at the age of 50.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FREDERICK A. O. SCHWARZ JR. , the former chairman of the New York City Charter Revision Commission and a former corporation counsel, is being honored by the Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic group that acts as a watchdog on government. He is to be given its Civic Leadership award at the group's annual dinner on Tuesday. Mr. Schwarz is now a partner in the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore.

title: Ventura Entertainment Group Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company said about half the losses of the latest quarter are attributed to the startup of Ventura Music Group.

title: Hughes Supply reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included after-tax gain from the sale of manufactureing operations of $ 617,000, ore 15 cents a share.

title: Van Kampen Merritt Intermediate Term High Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The fund began operation on Jan. 26, 1989.

title: Fate of Domestic Policy Lies in a Battle of Aides
description: In an Administration in which collegiality has gone the way of the "no new taxes" pledge, the latest internecine struggle is between Richard G. Darman, the pragmatic budget director, and a group of young White House conservatives who are trying to revive the late-60's idea of putting power in the hands of the poor.

title: 11-0? Eagles Say No Way Giants Are Facing A Surging Team
description: THE Giants (10-0) are unbeaten. They have a huge division lead over the Eagles (6-4). They can clinch the division title today, five weeks before the regular season ends, by beating the Eagles in Philadelphia.

title: Demystifying Stanford's Stats
description: To the Editor:

title: When Country Music Moves to the Suburbs
description: The southern twang is back in country music. So is the honeyed sob and the catch in the throat, the plink of a mandolin, the woozy swoop of pedal steel guitar. Young, smiling men in cowboy hats (like Clint Black, Garth Brooks, Dwight Yoakam, Randy Travis, Alan Jackson) and women vying to be the next Patsy Cline (K. D. Lang, Reba McIntyre, Patty Loveless, Kelly Willis, Suzy Boguss) talk up their rural roots as they reign over the country charts.

title: All About/Movie Theaters; The Crunch Comes to Cinemas
description: WHEN movie ticket sales peaked seven years ago, the theater chains continued to expand. They added 4,000 screens, for a 1989 total of nearly 23,000. Only now are they retrenching, trying to sell their theaters as well as their tickets.

title: Louis Clapes, 73, Dies; Ex-Mayor of Stamford
description: Louis Clapes, who served four consecutive terms as Mayor of Stamford, Conn., died on Tuesday at St. Joseph Medical Center in Stamford. He was 73 years old and a lifelong Stamford resident.

title: Some Facts and Figures In the Leagues' Dispute
description: The Professional Baseball Agreement requires that each major league team field at least one team at three minor league levels: Triple A, Double A and Class A. The contract is due to expire Jan. 11.

title: Producers Carsey and Werner: What Have They Done for Us Lately?
description: PEERING THROUGH A KITCHEN WINDOW, Jonathan Winters sights Bigfoot on the front lawn and describes his vision to a guileless child at a nearby table. The comedian's eyebrows rise and fall, calisthenic chevrons, as the moment spins off in the kind of improvisation that has undone camera operators and audiences since his first appearances on television more than 35 years ago.

title: Eastern Europe
description: To the Editor: Now that the summer mobs have departed from Eastern Europe, the time is right to visit its long-hidden treasures.

title: Keeping the Camcorder on a Steady Course
description: IT'S GETTING TO BE PEAK season for camcorders. Family get-togethers during the holidays account for much of the annual footage shot by video amateurs. So this is a good time to recall the cardinal rule of videography: Keep steady.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Executive Computer column on Nov. 11 misstated the affiliation of Jonathan L. Yarmis, a computer industry analyst. He is with the Gartner Group of Stamford, Conn.

title: Berr-REEP! Electronic Dartboards Are Enticing Millions of New Players
description: "When you hit the bull's-eye it goes 'Beep' -- no, it's a little deeper, more like 'Berr-REEP,"' said Marcio Bonilla of Arachnid Inc., describing his company's electronic darts machine.

title: Sports People; 'Fite, Bite, Scratch'
description: CLOSE encounters don't scare the Winnipeg Blue Bombers. In fact, Trevor Kennerd said the Canadian Football League Eastern champions enjoy an old-fashioned nailbiter.

title: Where Music's Boundaries Are Growing
description: MANY people may wonder what the clink of a Coca-Cola bottle against a fire extinguisher has to do with music.

title: The World; Mexico's Salinas Rains on His Own Parade
description: AFTER two years of growth in Mexico, a country once seen as an archetype of Third World mismanagement, few analysts still doubt that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is serious about economic reform.

title: Preventing AIDS Through Training
description: The articles on AIDS and women were particularly effective in highlighting that the AIDS crisis is not limited to homosexuals or ghetto populations and the fact that women are clearly at high risk. The need for prevention has to be emphasized and the efforts to reach the suburban middle-class population are appreciated.

title: Bucks Undo Knicks
description: The Knicks played poorly again yesterday. They lost at home again, their fourth defeat in their six games at the Garden this season.

title: Soothing to the Sensibility as Well as to the Palate
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Le Regence

title: Frances Lukens To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Lukens of Chevy Chase, Md., and Greensboro, Vt., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Frances Day Lukens and Jeffrey W. Bennett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donaldson K. Bennett of Winnetka, Ill.

title: The Only Giant Without Blinkers
description: FOR several weeks, it's as if the undefeated Giants were wearing blinkers. The coaches and players have professed not to be looking ahead to their Dec. 3 game with the 49ers. But when the undefeated 49ers try to extend their winning streak to a record 19 games today against the Los Angeles Rams in San Francisco, the Giants' pro personnel director, Tim Rooney, will be looking ahead. Tomorrow morning he will walk into Coach Bill Parcells's office with a 55-page scouting report.

title: Cathy Rigby's 'Peter Pan': 'Real Wish Fulfillment'
description: FOR Broadway-bound shows, the historic Shubert Theater in New Haven once represented the big stop before the big time. If only for the next two weeks, theater lovers can imagine the rebirth of that aspect of a golden age. And what more fitting show to fire one's fancy than the one about youth recaptured in Never-Never Land?

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Sanchez and Casal Win: Emilio Sanchez and Sergio Casal of Spain outlasted the Canadians Grant Connell and Glenn Michibata in a five-set marathon yesterday to advance to the championship match of the Association of Tennis Professionals World Doubles finals in Sanctuary Cove, Australia. The Spanish team squandered 2 match points in the fourth set before winning, 6-4, 6-7, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3, in 3 hours 38 minutes. They will meet either the Americans Scott Davis and David Pate or Guy Forget of France and Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland today in the final. Those two teams had split their first four sets when the match was halted by darkness. The match will resume this morning. (AP) Golf Ogle Leads in Australia: Brett Ogle of Australia shot a two-under-par 69 yesterday to take a three-shot lead after three rounds of the $385,000 Australian PGA championship in Sydney. Ogle's closest challenger is an American, Lee Carter, who shot a course-record-tying 64 on the par-71, 6,979-yard layout for a 54-hole total of 207. Another American, Sandy Armour, the first-round leader who faded with a 73 on Friday, fell apart in the third round, soaring to a nine-over 80 that left him at 217, 13 shots off the pace.(AP) Reid Leads in Japan: Mike Reid of the United States took a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the World Open in Kaimoncho, Japan, yesterday by shooting a seven-under-par 65, his best round this year. Reid, who started the round three shots off the pace, has a 54-hole score of 204. Seve Ballesteros of Spain and Ryoken Kawagishi of Japan were tied for second. Ballesteros shot a 68 and Kawagishi had a 66. (AP) Germany Captures World Cup: Bernhard Langer shot a three-under-par 69 and Torsten Giedeon had a 72 yesterday to lift Germany to its first title in the World Cup of Golf in Orlando, Fla. The Germans finished at 20-under-par 556, three shots better than second-place England and Ireland. David Feherty shot a final-round 63, the best score of the tournament, as he and Ronan Rafferty gave Ireland its best World Cup finish since 1958. Payne Stewart of the United States won the International Trophy and $75,000 for the best individual score. He shot a final-round 66 for a 271 total, 17 under par, but his partner, Jodie Mudd, struggled to a 77-291 as they finished fifth in the 32-team competition. (AP) Bowling Roll-Off in World Cup: Tom Hahl of Finland defeated Adam Apo of Honolulu, 48-39, in the first two-frame roll-off ever in the Bowling World Cup yesterday in Pattaya, Thailand, and won the men's title in the amateur tournament. Hahl rallied to tie Apo, 190-190, setting up the roll-off. Linda Graham of Des Moines won the women's title, beating Marie Holmqvist of Sweden, 225-176, by throwing strikes on her final seven rolls.(AP) Bohn Wins in Milwaukee: Parker Bohn 3d of Freehold, N.J., won his fifth Professional Bowlers Association title yesterday by beating Kelly Coffman of Topeka, Kan., 213-200, in the final of the American Bowling Congress Fall Classic in Milwaukee. Coffman moved into the title match by defeating Marshall Holman of Medford, Ore., 208-186. (AP) Boxing W.B.C. Middleweight Title for Jackson: Julian Jackson, an American from the Virgin Islands, knocked out Herol Graham of Britain in the fourth round last night to win the vacant World Boxing Council middleweight championship in Benalmadena, Spain. Graham, the British middleweight champion, dominated the first three rounds, but in the fourth Jackson suddenly delivered a short right hand that sent Graham to the canvas. Graham was counted out by Referee Joe Cortez of the United States. Jackson's victory gave him the W.B.C. middleweight crown, vacant since Sugar Ray Leonard retired earlier this year. He also holds the World Boxing Association light middleweight crown. Jackson scored his 34th straight knockout in raising his career record to 42-1, with 39 knockouts. The 31-year-old Graham took his third defeat against 43 victories. (AP)

title: Diana S. LeDoux Marries
description: Diana Steen LeDoux, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Steen of Vicksburg, Miss., was married yesterday to Niles Alexander Jaeger, the son of Henry Jaeger of Rhinebeck, N.Y., and Claire Picken Jaeger of New York. The Rev. Gerald Gallagher officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Rhinebeck. Mrs. Jaeger, 40 years old, is a graduate of Louisiana State University, from which she also received a master's degree in English. She is a marketing director for Home Box Office in New York. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Jaeger, 38, graduated from the Collegiate School and Bard College. He is a television producer.

title: 49ers Wary of Rams, History Considered
description: IN the days that passed between their last victory and their next game, there was no confusion among the San Francisco 49ers. At least, it seemed so.

title: A Sampling of Festive Sites for a Holiday Brunch
description: DESPITE daily countdowns, the coming holidays always seem to catch most of us by surprise as we shop and plan get-togethers and prepare festive foods for family and friends. Hosts finding time in short supply and money in much the same condition might consider swapping dinner out for a gala brunch. At this moment, the area's restaurants are draping ropes of evergreens, tying bows and stringing lights, creating a mood as festive at brunch as at dinner.

title:
TELEVISION;
Youth Will Be Served by Great Performances
description: Great Performances, public broadcasting's long-running and high-aiming performing arts program, is going after some missing persons. Those are adult viewers below 50, underrepresented in the PBS audience compared to the commercial networks' demographics.

title: Getting Off the Reservation
description: THE INDIAN LAWYER By James Welch. 349 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company.

title: 5 Killed, 17 Hurt as a Truck Slams Into Stopped Traffic
description: A big-rig truck careened into stopped traffic on Interstate 215 about 65 miles east of Los Angeles on Friday, causing a nine-car chain collision in which five people were killed and 17 injured.

title: Q and A
description: Leak in Storage Space Question: For over 20 years I have rented storage space in a Manhattan commercial building. On a recent visit to it I discovered an overhead pipe leaking on my property. The water had accumulated on the floor and damaged valuable items. I advised the owner-manager by certified letter asking him to correct the problem and advise me of the name of his insurance company. To date, the owner has not responded. Before initiating a suit, what other options are there? . . . Anthony Brook, Ascutney, Vt. Answer: Probably none. According to Edward I. Schiff, a partner in the law firm of Edwards & Angell of Manhattan who specializes in real estate matters, there are no administrative agencies that have jurisdiction over this situation. Unless you can persuade the landlord to take immediate action to repair the pipe and reimburse you for the damage, the only way to recover your loss is through a suit.

title: U.S. IS SCRUTINIZING IMMIGRATION FRAUD
description: The Government says it is cracking down on entrepreneurs who are charging illegal immigrants thousands of dollars to help them apply for legal status, then mishandling their applications.

title:
THEATER;
The Critic Tastes Comeuppance
description: Like many playwrights, Michael Weller has received his share of poor notices, most recently for the short-lived "Spoils of War," his 1988 play that won favorable reviews Off Broadway but fell short when it moved to Broadway later that season. In his new play, "Lake No Bottom" the tables are turned: a critic is under attack after a lifetime of doling it out.

title: In Beirut Milestone, the Last Militia Starts Pullout
description: In what was seen here as a turning point in efforts to end 15 years of civil war, members of a holdout Christian militia began withrawing today from strongholds in East Beirut as units of the reunified national army stood by to move into the vacated areas.

title: Argentine Union Leader Blunt About Payoffs
description: A labor leader's recent public admission that he saw nothing wrong with taking his cut from business deals has caused embarrassment even in this country where payoffs and other corruption are considered common practice.

title: The Questions Continue
description: It's hard to imagine that there was an American household this Thanksgiving that did not have, at its holiday table, a liberal helping of war talk laced with confusion, skepticism and doubt.

title: A Group For Adult Adoptees
description: CHARLENE KALBFELL was 32 years old when her ailing mother confessed the secret she had concealed all her daughter's life.

title: No Cause for Angst
description: To the Editor:

title: College Football Lacks Honor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Smoking Boat
description: BLUE THUNDER How the Mafia Owned and Finally Murdered Cigarette Boat King Donald Aronow. By Thomas Burdick and Charlene Mitchell. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster.

title: Sports of the Times; The Surfer Who Pardoned the Shark
description: IT was an accident. The shark was not cruising in three feet of water just waiting for James Cornnell to fall off his surfboard.

title: Headliners; Weighing Anchors
description: How does the principle of equal pay for equal work apply to the most visible, and highly paid, members of the television news business? Rudy Miller figures to find out. The Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed suit on Ms. Miller's behalf last week, arguing that WBAL-TV in Baltimore treated her unfairly when she was an anchor there, paying her less than male anchors and dismissing her last year when she insisted on equal pay. The commission chairman said that the panel intended to "send a message" to biased broadcasters. A WBAL executive argued that Ms. Miller was paid less than two male anchors -- she got $141,000, they got more than $170,000 -- for the same reason that some athletes and entertainers earn less than others. "Like ball players, actors and many other job categories, performance and productivity are the important determining factors in compensation," he said, "and at WBAL-TV, so are the principles of fairness and equality."

title: The Documentary Hits Its Stride on PBS
description: Week after week, season after season, public television comes across with a remarkable assortment of documentaries that dig into America's past and present and sometimes its future. This is a particularly strong season for "Frontline," "Nova" and "The American Experience," three series based on respect for both their subjects and their viewers. Their success stands in contrast to the failure of the networks in recent years to do very much of what television can do so well -- but then success and failure are measured by different criteria in the commercial operations.

title: Miss Berdy Weds Steven J. Sperber
description: Karen Ann Berdy, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Berdy of River Edge, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Steven Jay Sperber, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Sperber of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Andrea Gouze performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: 'I Was 17, Poor and Joined the Marines'
description: To the Editor:

title: John Sayles Finds His 'City of Hope' in Cincinnati
description: John Sayles looks at the punched-out brick buildings on the reeling edge of this city's downtown, and he sees New Jersey in 1990.

title: Correction
description: A map of Dresden on Nov. 4 located the Zwinger Palace incorrectly. It is just south of the Semper Opera House, off the Postplatz, and not on the Elbe River.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Fine-Tuning a Plan for the 21st Century
description: NEW JERSEY took an innovative step in 1985 when it began crafting a coordinated-growth plan to accommodate what was expected to be 1.2 million more residents and more than 700,000 new jobs by the year 2010.

title: Oren Aviv Is Wed To Katie Locke
description: Katie Locke, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Locke of New York City and Waccabuc, N.Y., was married last evening in New York to Oren Aviv, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Aviv of New York. Rabbi Dr. Louis Gerstein officiated at A Perfect Space in the American Thread Building in New York.

title: Rocky Pt. Weighs Route 25A Plans
description: AS the State Transportation Department develops plans to widen 6.6 miles of Route 25A from Miller Place to Shoreham, residents of Rocky Point are being asked to choose between preserving their business district or environmentally protected lands.

title: Canadian Choreographers Are Upwardly Mobile
description: The Bible and the ancient Greeks made especially strong use of the idea of a body falling through space. It is an image that has great mythic connotations. The legend of Icarus, who flew too close to the sun on waxed wings and fell to his death, remains a supreme metaphor for humanity's overreaching ambition or, in another interpretation, man's striving toward the seemingly impossible, even the ideal.

title: Can an Eastern Company Survive in a Western World?
description: A YEAR ago, Dieter Walter was the No. 2 executive at the giant Robotron computer and electronics company, which had 67,000 employees.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Menu That's Melting-Pot American
description: THE Rocky Hill Inn seems to be the largest building in the Somerset County hamlet for which it is named, but it is neither the oldest building nor the most famous in the immediate area. A little farther along Route 518 is Rockingham, the house in which George Washington wrote his farewell address to the Army.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 25, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 6 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe in the Ice Age. 2 2 3 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man she brings back to life after he drowns. 3 4 11 FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) The destiny of an American woman is haunted by a vengeful Greek tycoon. 7 7 2 THE RUBY KNIGHT, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) The second volume in "The Elenium," a series about magic and adventure in a fantasy land. 8 11 6 UNDER SIEGE, by Stephen Coonts. (Pocket, $19.95.) The rivalry of two men who want to become consul of the Roman Republic in 110 B.C. 10 10 6 BUFFALO GIRLS, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The end of the old Wild West, seen through the lives of Calamity Jane and two mountain men. 11 * 8 24 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An attorney tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death. 12 13 40 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 13 1 THE SHEPHERD, by Joseph F. Girzone. (Macmillan, $15.95.) A Roman Catholic bishop undertakes to reform his church and its relationship with all faiths. 14 * 14 10 THE GENERAL IN HIS LABYRINTH, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $19.95.) The last, sad retrospective days of Simon Bolivar. 15 12 7 RABBIT AT REST, by John Updike. (Knopf, $21.95.) The fourth and final novel about Harry (Rabbit) Angstrom. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 7 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 2 8 2 A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) AND BEAR IN MIND

title: Planned Parenthood Uses Counseling Grant
description: Women's health-care issues are often disregarded by health and scientific professionals, the media and the community at large. HIV-AIDS is no exception. It was therefore encouraging to see "For Women, Growing Risks From AIDS" (Oct. 21) address the issue of women and AIDS. We are, however, concerned that important information was not included.

title: Cold, Fragile, Invisible
description: Economists argue: Will there be a recession? Are we in one already? But there are many for whom the debate is irrelevant, even frivolous. They are the poor, the fragile elderly, the homeless, the children of poverty. They need not consult economic indicators; they have been suffering the pain of recession -- no, of depression -- for a long time.

title: Tech Notes; Animation From Unusual Linkages
description: SCIENTISTS at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory have married a Cray X-MP supercomputer, a Macintosh personal computer and a videotape recorder to produce animated color images of scientific experiments from numerical data. Still images taken from the Macintosh can be printed on conventional printers, either color or black and white. The animated images are produced with a commercially available program called Macro Mind Director. One test took readings from pressure sensors attached to a plastic sheet and converted them into color video images, showing what happens as the plastic issubjected to stress. The new technique can also show heat passing through metal in a simulated welding session.

title: 'Final Analysis'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lorraine Ciampa To Wed in April
description: The engagement of Lorraine Charlotte Ciampa to Patrick Enz Downey, a son of Sheila E. Downey of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., and the late John V. Downey, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Dominick A. Ciampa of Manhasset, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HUNGER BANQUET Some of the guests attending a banquet at Wainwright House this evening will feast on hors d'oeuvres, prime ribs of beef, salad, wine, dessert and coffee. Their tables will be set appropriately with linen, china, glassware and cutlery.

title: Health Care At Home Goes High Tech
description: ERIN MCCRANN spent the first six months of her life in a hospital. Born with Wernig Hoffman, a muscular disease for which there is no known cure, Erin requires 24-hour nursing care, has to be tube fed, and needs a ventilator and various medications.

title:
National Notebook: Plantation, Fla.;
I-595 Spurring Office Growth
description: SOME of South Florida's steadiest commercial development, spurred in part by a new east-west interstate highway, is taking place in central Broward County halfway between Fort Lauderdale and the Everglades.

title: THE RUSSIAN CHARACTER
description: No doubt about it, Russians have pilfered from the state for years. Blat (connections) is a way of life. As it is in the United States. Even in the Green Mountains where neighbor trusts neighbor and you can leave your key in your car, innkeepers, to keep their licenses, give inspectors whatever they want. And is not the world's biggest and most destructive influence peddling -- the savings and loan robbery -- done under Federal regulation with Government connivance?

title: ANTI-DRUG EFFORT DRAGS OUTSIDE U.S.
description: Nearly two years after President Bush declared his war on drugs, Administration officials say they have made little progress toward blocking narcotics trafficking from Latin America into the United States.

title: Anthropology in Bumper Stickers
description: IF it is true that one man's junk is another man's treasure, then Dr. Richard Blake is by his own acknowledgment a wealthy man. In the last six years, Dr. Blake, an assistant professor of social work at Seton Hall University, has amassed thousands of what he terms state-issued ephemeras, or "disposable stuff," many of which bear the "New Jersey and You -- Perfect Together" slogan.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Granite Springs, N.Y. 315,000 74 Raemont Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 25-year-old ranch; formal dining room, den, family room, stone fireplace, pool, 1 acre; taxes $7,750. Katonah, N.Y. 375,000 124 Mekeel Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 57-year-old Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, greenhouse, eat-in kitchen, patio, 9.3 acres; taxes $6,848. Rye Brook, N.Y. 415,000 208 Country Ridge Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; brick fireplace, deck, den, sunken living room, 2-car garage; taxes $5,517. Bridgeport, Conn. 134,000 84 Harlem Avenue. 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; enclosed front porch, new furnace, large yard; taxes $2,406. Darien, Conn. 399,000 15 Blueberry Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; professional landscaping, rear deck, 1.7 acres; taxes $4,360. Greenwich, Conn. 1.5 million 19 Indian Chase Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 60-year-old waterfront colonial; dock, terrace, stucco facade, 1 acre; taxes $4,374. OTHER AREAS Kings Park, L.I. 155,000 24 Alder Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; basement, attic, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,300. Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. 685,000 3 North Court 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 17-year-old contemporary; new kitchen, Florida room, fireplace, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $7,600. Freehold, N.J. 163,900 27 Meadowbrook Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; 2 fireplaces, 1-car garage, patio, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,349.

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: NONFICTION
description: NORDI'S GIFT. By Clyde Rice. (Breitenbush Books, $21.95.) Is man meant to spend life with only one mate? Can a literate person satisfy his intellect through the exhilaration of outdoor physical labor? Clyde Rice tussles with these questions throughout "Nordi's Gift," the sequel to his first volume of autobiography, "A Heaven in the Eye." In this volume, the author, now 87 years old, recounts his experiences from 1934 to 1955, and his vivacious writing conveys the passion and immediacy of his younger years. Mr. Rice revels in jobs that demand muscle -- he chopped and sold cordwood, repaired ships, built a boat and fished for tuna, opened a lumber mill. The book's most enthralling passages are devoted to the author's family. His strong voice and remarkable memory combine to produce finely wrought portraits of his wife, Nordi, and her niece, Virginia, with whom Mr. Rice fell in love. Readers may wonder about and even condemn some of the author's decisions. He divorced Nordi to marry Virginia; Nordi later lived with the new couple. (If that sounds strange, imagine working on and off, as Mr. Rice did, for a stepmother who despises you and a father easily swayed by his spouse.) As a social history of the American Northwest (Mr. Rice is a native of Oregon), "Nordi's Gift" makes for engrossing reading -- with one caveat. Adept with an ax, Mr. Rice cuts trees more easily than he cuts through prose. Too many technical descriptions of logging and shipbuilding impede his story. Yet Clyde Rice is good company and has written an inspiring book about a thoughtfully considered life.

title: A Defense of Doctors In Treating AIDS
description: In a very informative article on the AIDS challenge in the suburbs [ "The Challenge AIDS Presents in the Suburbs," Nov. 4 ] , the limitations of space severely curtailed the elaborate commentary I provided on physicians' responsibility and involvement with AIDS in Westchester County.

title: Streetscapes: The Croton Gatehouse; Worthy Interests Clash on 113th St.
description: IS there room only for the elegant, the fancy, the important on our list of landmarks? Or should it also include the humble, the picturesque, the simply curious?

title: In Havana, Where They Really Dance To the Music
description: La Tropical is the only dance hall in Havana that's open regularly. It's a big, open-air beer garden that has seen decades of service. The legendary singer Benny More used to play here, and the dance band Conjunto Casino has been here plenty. On this night, as Conjunto Casino finishes its set, the club is jumping, packed with maybe 1,500 people.

title: Russia, in Its Own Voice
description: For decades Soviet diplomats objected when their country was called "Russia," which is only one, even if the largest, of the 15 republics of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Today those times are remembered in the Kremlin with nostalgia.

title: Trapped In Germany
description: To the Editor: Donal Henahan's article about the lack of American conductors at the helm of our major orchestras [ "America Still Shuns Americans," Nov. 4 ] could have been more useful had it been more in depth. (It might, for instance, have pointed out that there is one all-powerful agent representing almost all the conductors who are considered for high posts.) Its most regrettable lack, however, was an apparent failure to understand exactly what is at stake. We are not speaking of mere performers to fill the job of conductor. These major orchestra posts require a music director. Those who hold such positions make repertory decisions that constitute a virtual death grip on orchestral music in the United States.

title: Tort Storyteller
description: JEFFREY ARCHER DOESN'T SO MUCH walk into a room as bound in. Boyish, good-looking, impeccably dressed in a Jaeger suit and fitter than any 50-year-old has a right to be, he sweeps into the living room of his London penthouse, with its wraparound view of the River Thames and the Houses of Parliament, shakes hands with a vigor that suggests he has just stepped out of a very large battery charger and plunks himself comfortably, but restlessly, on one of the room's many plush sofas. Even in repose he gives the impression of an engine with the idle set a little too high.

title: Once Divided by War, Now United by Tourism
description: Twenty years ago they could have been mortal enemies. Today, Hamdi Saad El-Din, Egypt's tourism director, and Raphael Farber, his Israeli counterpart, practically walk arm-in-arm as they rave about each other's country.

title:
The Executive Life;
The Enduring Charm Of the Drexel Mystique
description: "OH my God!" squealed a woman in her 30's, waiting to get inside a crowded Mexican restaurant called Tequila Willie's near Wall Street. "I can't believe it's you!" she said, turning to embrace the briefcase-carrying woman who had just joined her at the door. "I haven't seen you for so long. Did you end up somewhere?"

title: The Editorial Notebook; Legal Crack? No Sale
description: Crack created a crisis of criminal justice -- and revived support for legalizing drugs. Aren't the violence and other public costs of keeping drugs illegal even worse than the harm caused by the drugs themselves?

title: Foucault
description: To the Editor: Although William Weaver had to travel to Paris to see Foucault's pendulum, in connection with his research involving Umberto Eco's novel of the same name ("Tracking Down Foucault's Pendulum," Travel, Sept. 23), anyone else interested in viewing the pendulum that proves the earth rotates can do so right here in New York.

title: The Breakfast Egg
description: I HEAR VOICES. By Paul Ableman. (McPherson, Cloth, $18; Paper, $10.) Paul Ableman, an esteemed British playwright and critic, originally published this arresting and brilliant travesty 30 years ago. His first novel (Mr. Ableman has published four more since), "I Hear Voices" originally appeared on the list of the Olympia Press, the Paris house that first brought out "Lolita" and "Naked Lunch." It may be read as one long wake-up call -- the protagonist never entirely makes it out of bed. The delivery of his breakfast egg is a recurrent set piece, and would be a symbol in a less explosive exercise. But Mr. Ableman must constantly break his eggs, fragment his abbreviated roundabout world. His unnamed narrator -- who, one quickly suspects, is a schizophrenic -- tumbles through a series of encounters that flare with offhand intensity, including a number of party scenes that seem startlingly canny about social give and take, despite their strangeness. Along the way, poetic tangents fly off in every direction: "There were far reports and others that leapt from brain to brain so that the sunset was pricked with doubt and signaled a spectrum of confused acknowledgement." Is this in fact the mind of a madman? There are scenes that suggest psychiatric counseling, but whatever grasp on reality they might offer is laughingly undone by the narrator's phantoms and leitmotifs. Mr. Ableman's best effect is a breathtaking precision about states of mind, played off against a hilarious vagueness about physical reality. His unchaptered slice of dream (occasionally reminiscent of Donald Barthelme) is another example of the wild freedoms embraced by European fiction since 1945, freedoms still only fitfully understood on this side of the Atlantic.

title: NOT EXACTLY THE BEST MAN
description: While I am not sure it is always necessary for one to attend an ex's wedding, it is essential that divorced parents be able to share in the important events in a child's life: a birthday, a graduation, a wedding.

title: Jodi Morgan, an Accountant, Is Married on L.I.
description: Jodi Beth Morgan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Morgan of Old Bethpage, L.I., was married last evening to Allan Jonathan Pantuck, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Pantuck of Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Julius Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Woodcrest Country Club in Muttontown, L.I.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: ST. PETER'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH;
Keeping Up by Reaching Out
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, St. Peter's Episcopal Church on Division Street here was drawing 1,000 people to Sunday services. By the 1980's, that number had dwindled to 50. Now, the pendulum is swinging back and attendance is on the rise again -- several hundred parishioners have been showing up each Sunday -- and the church is expanding in other ways.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: A letter of praise for the Italian State Railway system and the courteous, economical transport it provided on a recent trip to northern Italy. Like the vast majority of its passengers, we bought second-class tickets (only in Milan did the line to buy them resemble Grand Central's). Trains were comfortable and clean, ran frequently and, with one exception, on time. Best of all, the rail network made every town on our itinerary accessible.

title: Manhattan Beach
description: To the Editor

title: Ideas & Trends: Leftovers; Musings on Cold Turkey
description: THE weekend after Thanksgiving is one that finds the American home deep in the leftovers that are a challenge to the hands that rule the kitchen. The turkey often gains flavor on the second day, certainly when, with the help of barley and vegetables, it is transformed into turkey soup, or, in a lighter vein, into turkey salad and, not at the top of every gourmet's list, turkey croquettes. It is also, perhaps, a time for musing about leftovers of other kinds.

title: Bulgarian Premier's Backers and Foes Clash
description: About 30,000 demonstrators rallied to back Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov today, one day after he narrowly survived a no-confidence vote. Opponents of his Socialist Government blocked a main boulevard in protest.

title: John Ruskin
description: To the Editor: In the article "London's Literary Village" (Travel, Sept. 30), Anne Wilson refers to "the socialist writer John Ruskin." Ruskin may have been the greatest English language art critic in history, but he was certainly no socialist. In his book "Fors Clavigera," he wrote, "I will tell you plainly, I am, and my father was before me, a Tory of the old school." JOHN W. OSBORNE West Orange, N.J.

title: The Nation; The Noriega Tapes In the Court's Court
description: THE audio tapes that Cable News Network has, supposedly showing that the Government recorded telephone conversations between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and members of his defense team, are said to be so scratchy that it is hard to make out much of the conversation.

title: A New Geography For the Coal Industry
description: THE rumble of change is being heard in the coal fields of America.

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: FICTION
description: THE WOMAN WHO READ NOVELS AND PEACETIME. By Constance Urdang. (Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.) Constance Urdang, the author of five previous novellas as well as five books of verse, clearly displays a poet's sensitivity and depth of feeling in these two wonderfully crafted novellas. Leaning stylistically toward the experimental (though not tilting as far as the avant-garde), Ms. Urdang's crisp, angular prose explores the complexities of both loneliness and intimate relationships. "The Woman Who Read Novels," which is set in New York City, wanders between the past and present experiences of an elderly woman named Ruby, whose broken engagement to her cousin, Leo, has shadowed her life since she was barely past her teens. Alive with sadness, this novella depicts the chilling figure of a soul isolated and in despair. In contrast, the second novella -- titled, somewhat ironically, "Peacetime" -- presents the stories of several baby boomers who, while nostalgic for the 1960's and their idealized days as student activists, find their present-day marriages and close friendships enveloped in a fog of incompetence, violence and dread. Whereas "The Woman Who Read Novels" ends on a clearly pessimistic note, the very sense of failure felt by the characters in "Peacetime," their struggle to make satisfying contact with others, propel them forward in a heroic attempt to find, and define, the meaning of their lives.

title: At Second-Run Theaters, Moviegoers Applaud the Prices
description: THE Forest Theater in West Haven is a real family business. Patrons at the movie house buy their tickets from Irene Terrazano, who sits in a tiny booth beneath the marquee, tearing tickets from a large roll. Mrs. Terrazano's husband, Tony, stands in the lobby, smiling as he takes tickets. The couple's son, Frederick, and their grandson, Richard Mallette Jr., are behind the refeshments counter, selling popcorn and candy at bargain prices.

title: Close to the Wild in Senegal
description: HEADING east into Africa's interior, away from the beach resorts on Senegal's Atlantic coastline, the villages become fewer and farther apart and the potholes ever wider, until at times there is more pothole than paved road. Small boys fill the craters with gravel, hoping for coins from grateful motorists in return.

title: 2 Benefits, n Opening And a Gala
description: The New York City Ballet opened its 93d season Tuesday with a program dedicated to Tchaikovsky on the occasion of the composer's 150th birthday.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Making Little Estates Out of the Big Ones
description: WITH economic conditions making it more difficult for the owners of large estates in Westchester or their heirs to keep their properties intact, they are increasingly selling them for subdivision.

title: The Asbestos Mess
description: DR. IRVING J. SELIKOFF is short, he is round, he is old. Normally these attributes combine unpreposessingly in one man, but not in Irving Selikoff. He has the aura of a savant of the previous century, someone who might have been sculptured by Rodin. There is the cane, for one thing, and the fluent French, when that's necessary, and, at the core, the sheer dignifying weight of accomplishment.

title: Ideas & Trends; Art Invents A Jarring New World From Technology
description: SIX years ago, a young and unknown science-fiction writer captured a cult following with his first novel, "Neuromancer." The writer, William Gibson, struck a chord with his vision of a dark, computerized future filled with ultrafast data networks and populated by technologically adept, low-life hustlers living in an urban dystopia called The Sprawl.

title: Campus Life: Connecticut College; Cheaters to Lose Privileges Linked To Honor Code
description: Students at Connecticut College do not encounter professors during exam week. Under the student honor code, exams are self-scheduled and unproctored, a privilege that some students and faculty members have sought to take away from students who have been determined to be cheating.

title: Managing Your House Plant's Environment
description: Keeping a house plant looking good year after year takes certain management skills. You don't need to treat it to a power lunch with a heavy dose of fertilizer or leaf shine for success. Instead, says John Peterson, professor of horticulture at Ohio State University, you need to find the right balance of culture and climate.

title: Ann Newman Marries Paul Chelminski
description: Ann Elizabeth Newman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Newman of Pensacola, Fla., was married yesterday to Paul Roman Chelminski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Chelminski of East Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John W. Melton, a grandfather of the bride, and the Rev. Victor Wilson performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Pensacola.

title: Ms. Hickey Weds Dr. James Wallis
description: Kathleen Ann Hickey, a daughter of Blanche Hickey of Newport News, Va., and Robert J. Hickey of Fairfax, Va., was married yesterday to Dr. James Burton Wallis, a son of Dr. Lila A. Wallis and Dr. Benedict L. Wallis of New York. Msgr. James Wilders performed the ceremony at the Shrine of Elizabeth Ann Seton in New York.

title: Maral J. Poladian Is Wed to Dr. Mark A. Ayanian
description: Maral J. Poladian, the daughter of Araxie Poladian of Belmont, Mass., and the late Joseph Poladian, was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Armen Ayanian, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Zaven S. Ayanian of Matawan, N.J. The Rev. Mampre Kouzouian performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Armenian Apostolic Church in Cambridge, Mass.

title: A New Obstacle Stalls Action on Jay Site
description: THE decadelong dispute over the future of the Jay property in Rye took an unexpected twist earlier this month, when the Westchester County Attorney blocked the condemnation process set in motion two months ago by the Board of Legislators. This week, a state official will visit the county to try to resolve the problem, which she calls "a technical misunderstanding."

title: Government Protects Everyone but Its Own From Polygraphs
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Heads to Cotton Bowl
description: Butch Hadnot's 19-yard touchdown run and Michael Pollak's three field goals rallied Texas to a 23-13 victory over Baylor today, clinching the first Southwest Conference title for the Longhorns in seven years.

title: Karen Dickstein To Wed in 1991
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Dickstein of Muttontown, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Sue Dickstein, to James Lewis Frank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen H. Frank of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I. A February wedding is planned.

title: Social Events
description: Skating for Art

title: Sports People; Unser Jr. Honored
description: HIS father won it in 1970 and his uncle Bobby won it in 1974, so what could be more natural than having Al Unser Jr. be named the 1990 Driver of the Year in a vote by a national panel of 10 motor sports writers and broadcasters. Unser, who won his first CART PPG Cup Indy-car championship this season, drew five first-place votes and beat beat out four-time stock car champion Dale Earnhardt. The 28-year-old Unser won six of 16 races in 1990, including a CART record four in a row. (AP)

title:
Northeast Notebook: Chesterfield, N.H.;
Developers Vie For Area Mall
description: TWO developers are in a race for approval to build a regional shopping mall in southeastern New Hampshire, near the state's border with Vermont and Massachusetts.

title: Charter Boats
description: To the Editor: Simon Elegant, writing about Langkawi ("Changing Malaysian Isle," Travel, Sept. 16), says that Pelangi Cruises, whom we represent in the United States, charters their boats "at exorbitant prices." I can quite understand that reaction from one unaccustomed to yacht charter rates. However, I would like to say that the 40-foot yacht which charters in Malaysia for $3,180 compares not unfavorably with the same yacht which charters in Yugoslavia for $3,045, in Martinique for $2,850 and with the 39-foot yacht which charters in Thailand for $2,950 and the 38-foot yacht in St. Martin for $3,059 and the Virgin Islands for $2,912. EVELYN B. GRESSER Le Boat Inc. Maywood, N.J.

title:
World Markets;
The Dollar in Germany's Future
description: DURING the rush to unity that culminated with the creation of a single German state on Oct. 3, the dollar's steady slide to one record low after another was largely ignored by the nation's eight stock exchanges. Investors and stock experts were focused on the potential for profits in building the Eastern Europe of the future, rather than on problems stemming from currency rate fluctuations of the moment.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Calling All Ducks

title: Rona Gluck Is Married To Philip William Kirsh
description: Rona Gluck, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Gluck of New York, was married last evening to Philip William Kirsh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Kirsh of Johannesburg. Rabbi David B. Kahane performed the ceremony in New York at the Pierre.

title: Sports People; Wilson Activated
description: THE Minnesota Vikings activated the quarterback Wade Wilson yesterday, but Rich Gannon was expected to start today against the Chicago Bears. Wilson injured his thumb in a 19-16 loss at Chicago on Sept. 23 and hasn't dressed for a game since then. Before the injury, Wilson had thrown for seven touchdowns in three games as Minnesota's starter.

title: Margaret Lyons, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Margaret Mary Lyons, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. John L. Lyons of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Steven Allen Kessler, the son of Loretta Kessler of Queens and Charles Kessler of Roslyn, L.I. The Rev. James Devlin, a Roman Catholic priest, and Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Experimenting at Harvard
description: ON a crisp fall day recently, the 80 students in an accounting class at the Harvard Business School listened intently as Mary Barth, an assistant professor, described how bonds are classified on a company's balance sheet. The students nodded their understanding. Except for one, Alexei Maximov, who frowned and whispered a question in heavily accented English to his neighbor. He was completely lost.

title: Business Diary/November 18-23
description: COMPANIES Milken's Exile From the World That Milken Built He spent tens of millions on his defense, and his lawyers were the very best. But on Wednesday, Michael R. Milken, the most powerful financier of his time, was sentenced to 10 years in prison, to be followed by 3 years of community service. It was the toughest sentence by far for anyone caught in Wall Street's recent scandals, from a judge familiar with the financial community's ways. Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood gave up a lucrative partnership in a New York law firm, specializing in antitrust law, for the relatively modest pay of the bench. She offered Mr. Milken the prospect of a milder sentence if he helped prosecutors snare others, but he is banned from the securities industry for life. Some mourn Mr. Milken's exile, saying that the collapse of the "junk bond" market since he left Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. proves how indispensable he is. But how much are those bonds truly worth if their value depends on the fate of one firm and one man? Accountants Go Under Laventhol & Horwath ultimately couldn't even balance its own books. The nation's seventh-largest accounting firm asked for bankruptcy protection from creditors on Wednesday -- apparently the largest such filing by a professional services firm. The firm had a negative net worth of $6.9 million as of Oct. 13. It also faces lawsuits seeking nearly $2 billion over its handling of such clients as the P.T.L. ministry and its favorable feasibility studies for real estate projects that would have needed divine intervention to succeed. Those trying to collect from Laventhol at this point might do just as well directing their prayers to Jim and Tammy. Bad Mortgages at Citicorp How can a bank lose by pumping out plenty of mortgages when the housing market is strong? As long as borrowers provide a fat down payment, why bother pawing through piles of their financial records? Citicorp's latest experience is providing some answers. The company said mortgages delinquent 90 days or more or in foreclosure have risen from 3 to 3.6 percent of dollar volume during the third quarter. Falling home prices, especially in the Northeast, are partly to blame, but Arthur P. Soter, a banking analyst at Morgan Stanley, also points to relaxed lending criteria. The surprise is that it happened at Citicorp, the nation's largest home lender. "This is not some mad dash for growth by an inexperienced, wet-behind-the-ears player," Mr. Soter said. Citicorp has decided to take more care in verifying applicants' income and down-payment sources. But more loans might go sour. As Mr. Soter said, "Problems related to real estate tend to have a fairly long tail." Move Over, Wayne Gretzky The sports world's probable greatest money-earner was laid to rest in an oak coffin a week ago at age 29 in Canada, where he was bred. Northern Dancer's achievements only began with his victories in the 1964 Kentucky Derby -- a track record -- and the Preakness. At stud, he enriched his thoroughbred breed with foals, including 123 stakes winners, that won more than $26 million. His descendants included more than 1,000 stakes winners. Bidding by European breeders and Arab sheiks for his royal bloodline pushed prices for his yearlings past $10 million, and his stud fee to $1 million. "He was a national hero in Canada, along with Wayne Gretzky," the hockey star, said Bernard McCormack, general manager of Winfields Farm near Toronto, where Northern Dancer rests. Wait 'til all the athletes concerned that their multimillion-dollar salaries are lower than someone else's hear about all this. Buyout Funds Reborn Merger mania still lives. Forstmann Little & Company and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company are having some initial success in raising new buyout funds of $1 billion to $2 billion. CBS Plot Thickens Maybe CBS should consult a script doctor to straighten out its tortured plot. The network is in the awkward position of telling affiliates about its weaknesses and advertisers about its strengths. CBS executives said last week that they expect a loss this quarter, and they asked affiliated stations to swallow a 20 percent, $30 million cut in payments to carry CBS shows. Instead of planning the usual three-day bash for affiliates in Los Angeles next year, with parties, invitations to spouses and walk-ons by network stars, CBS will hold a sober day-and-a-half meeting in New York in June just for station managers. Laurence A. Tisch, president of CBS, said increased competition for viewers and advertisers is "changing the fundamental economics of network television." CBS is boasting to advertisers, meanwhile, that it will remain the best way to reach a huge audience, with spots on "60 Minutes" likely to have as many viewers as a blanket campaign on cable networks. Air Fare Bonanza The airlines might fill up their seats with two-fers, but barely have money to go on with the show. In a frenzy to retain market shares, the nation's airlines are offering free companion tickets, most until Feb. 28. "The industry is going to lose a fortune," said Helane Becker, an analyst at Shearson Lehman. With the high cost of fuel, she added, "A couple of airline companies are going to have great difficulty surviving." Buy now, she said, because the deals are unlikely to last into March. THE ECONOMY

title: THE RUSSIAN CHARACTER
description: The notion of a "national character" is particularly undependable in the case of a large country that is composed of numerous ethnic groups -- Byelorussians, Georgians, Armenians, et al. -- with diverse characteristics. This is so despite Government policy to homogenize the population and to eradicate such ethnic differences.

title: Century-Old Store Wraps Its Wares In Lots of Tradition
description: THE Christmas-shopping season is gathering steam at the Howland-Hughes department store, but no closed-circuit televisions blare the praises of the latest in jeans; no glittery, floor-to-ceiling displays of wrapped boxes crowd the floor, and no slinky saleswomen are positioned by the escalators to spritz shoppers with the season's designer fragrance.

title: Vegetables and Chicken
description: The seasonings on the chicken meld perfectly with the seasonings of the colorful corn and red pepper. The vegetables are heated, not just to defrost the corn, but to blend and intensify the flavors.

title: L.I.R.R. Cuts Are a Signal Of Downturn
description: A PROPOSAL by the Long Island Rail Road to reduce service 9 percent because of declining ridership and slumping subsidies resounded across the Island last week as if a conductor were announcing the arrival at a new and troubling destination.

title: B.Y.U. Passer Sets Record
description: Ty Detmer threw for 560 yards and five touchdowns and set an National Collegiate Athletic Association season record for passing yardage today as Brigham Young rolled past Utah State, 45-10.

title: FLORIO UPSETTING CONSERVATIONISTS
description: When Gov. Jim Florio came into office with a strong environmental record in Congress, New Jersey environmentalists saw him as a savior. But in less than a year they have grown disillusioned, worrying that the Governor may be too accommodating to industry and developers.

title: Postings: Cobble Hill Condos; A New Mews
description: The Dutch settlers of Manhattan called it Ponkiesberg and 18th-century Colonials saw it as Cobbleshill. Both were looking at the conical hill across the East River in Brooklyn. In the 1950's, long after the hill was quarried out and carted away to fill in the dips in Atlantic Avenue, the pre-Revolutionary name was revived as Cobble Hill to lend a historic association to a neighborhood that had recently been discovered by brownstone buyers.

title: Programs Are Aiding Employees Hurt on Job
description: ON a typical workday, a baker at Entenmann's Bakery Inc. in Bay Shore, Chris Alliegro, whips up 7 to 12 huge kettles of glaze. He pours and mixes 500 pounds of sugar and 130 pounds of hot syrup for each batch.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: CROW AND WEASEL. By Barry Lopez. Illustrated by Tom Pohrt. North Point. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up) In this allegorical novella, two young men, Crow and Weasel, whose costumes appear to be from the northern Plains, set off on a voyage of self-discovery. The handsome large format suits the stately prose and, as Weasel concludes, "seeing different ways of life, has made me wonder."

title: Judge Overturns Law on a Bail Requirement
description: A justice in State Supreme Court in the Bronx has invalidated a statute that requires defendants using real estate for bail purposes to prove that their property is worth at least double the amount of the bail.

title: Headliners; Campus Martial
description: After his long public battle with Catholic University in Washington, the Rev. Charles E. Curran thought he would find some peace and quiet when he accepted an invitation to teach religion at Auburn University in Alabama. Then the university president, James A. Martin, pulled the chair from under him. Disregarding a faculty committee's overwhelming recommendation that Father Curran be given a permanent professorship, Mr. Martin has refused to grant him tenure and, so far, has also refused to say why. Now the Auburn faculty senate has demanded that Mr. Martin reverse his decision or explain it. If he does not respond by Dec. 7, he could face a formal censure. Father Curran, who accepted a one-year appointment at Auburn, has stayed out of the fight. The theologian, who left Catholic University in 1986 after the school barred him from teaching theology because of his criticism of the Vatican, said that one of the attractions of Auburn was that "it was quiet and I could get some work done."

title: A Vote for the Ex-Im Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: Coslet Confronts Familiar Foe
description: Have you noticed that the Jets are doing better this season against teams from the American Football Conference Central Division than they are in their own A.F.C. East?

title: Scott Serels Wed To Rose A. Masri
description: Rose Allyson Masri, a daughter of Dorothy Cohn of Eastchester, N.Y., and Norman Masri of Weehawken, N.J., was married last evening to Scott Reed Serels, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Serels of Englewood, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Mark Wiener at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye, N.Y.

title: Nature's Vigilantes
description: ECO-WARRIORS: Understanding the Radical Environmental Movement. By Rik Scarce. (Noble Press, Paper, $11.95.) The direct-action wing of the environmental movement has garnered both widespread praise and opprobrium. An overwhelming groundswell of support transformed Greenpeace from a daring but ragtag band of eco-guerrillas into the largest environmental organization in the world in barely over a decade. Yet last spring's bombing incident in Oakland, Calif., involving two organizers of the group Earth First! exposed an underlying bias in the news media. Despite strong evidence to the contrary, many reporters unquestioningly accepted police and Federal Bureau of Investigation charges that the two activists had themselves planted the device. In "Eco-Warriors" the journalist Rik Scarce examines the controversial world of radical environmentalism, providing a sympathetic and fascinating look inside the hearts and minds of those who would meld Gandhi with King Ludd. Much of the book is devoted to Earth First!, the best known of the dozen or so direct-action groups now operating around the world. Mr. Scarce charts the rise of the group, from its founding in 1980 by a quintet of wilderness advocates fed up with Secretary of the Interior James Watt's prodevelopment "sagebrush rebellion" and the increasing bureaucratization of the country's leading conservation groups. The author also details the arguments over tactics, strategies and goals that have begun to splinter the group, arguments reminiscent of those that divided the New Left. In addition, the blow-by-blow accounts of assorted acts of sabotage in defense of the environment by the Sea Shepherds and animal liberationists make intriguing, if sometimes disturbing, reading. Mr. Scarce occasionally weakens his superb reporting with superficial analysis, but on the whole this is a fine account for anyone looking for insight into the global environmental movement.

title: Faldo Takes 4 Skins And Wins $70,000
description: There are those who contend that the bulldozer-formed knolls and rolls of PGA West Stadium Course give it a Scottish flavor, and indeed, it was shades of St. Andrews today as Nick Faldo made the biggest shots on the first nine holes of the $450,000 Skins Game.

title: No Victory For Shopkeepers
description: To the Editor: In Paul Goldberger's engaging article "In Beverly Hills, a Theme Park for Rich Adults" [ Nov. 11 ] , he properly states that a hotel had been planned for the intersection of Rodeo Drive and Wilshire Boulevard, "until community protests led the City of Beverly Hills to rule out tall buildings on this site." That's true as far as it goes.

description: THE SPIRITUAL LIFE OF CHILDREN By Robert Coles. Illustrated. 358 pp. Boston: A Peter Davison Book/Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.

title: Headliners; The Pay for Hits, All Kinds, Goes Up
description: FINANCIAL institutions are failing and bread lines are lengthening, but as usual there is no recession among the purveyors of diversion. Jack Nicholson reportedly got $10 million for joking around in "Batman," Buster Douglas got $24 million for the seven minutes it took him to lose the heavyweight championship, and Bill Cosby, with an income estimated at around $100 million a year, could double the gross national product of many a small country simply by moving there.

description: To the Editor:

description: An early morning fire turned a commercial stables into a ruin, killing more than 50 show and race horses here today.

title: Pediatricians Focusing On Rare Genetic Illness
description: WHEN Harris Laish's dysautnomia was diagnosed, doctors told his parents that he would not live past the age of 5 1/2. But in January, Harris, who lives in Syosset, will celebrate his 17th birthday.

title: Postings: Advice for Directors; Co-op Seminar
description: At a time when boards of directors of New York City cooperatives and condominiums must learn to live with new laws and financial requirements, help is available at the 34th annual seminar of the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives, a nonprofit group that advises co-ops and condos across the city. The seminar will be held from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. next Sunday at Queens College in Flushing.
