description: International 3-21

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: Read With Me

title: The Action Is Not at the Table
description: SYMPOSIUM By Muriel Spark. 192 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: The Huntington's Triple Treasures
description: CRITICS groaned when Henry Huntington moved his library of rare books from New York to his ranch in San Marino, California, in 1920. Obviously, they said, people who understood such works lived on the East Coast.

title: Mets-Yanks Fans And Strawberry
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenwich Antiques Show: 'New Spirit of the 90's'
description: ANTIQUARIUS, the annual Christmas Antiques Show, opens with a preview cocktail party at the Greenwich Civic Center in Old Greenwich on Thursday, signaling the close of the town's 350th anniversary celebration.

title: Amy H. Amelkin Wed To Kenneth G. Cramer
description: Amy Heather Amelkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Amelkin of Huntington, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Kenneth Gordon Cramer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Cramer of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and Gates Mills, Ohio. Rabbi Barton Shallot performed the ceremony at the Breakers hotel in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Hope in Hell's Classroom
description: COMING INTO NORTH PHILADELPHIA, I CAN SEE TRASH and blight everywhere. A few of the blocks are attractive, with little row houses painted in bright colors; but many of the old storefronts and apartment buildings are burned out, boarded up. Some doors are covered not with boards but with steel plates. The sidewalks are eerily silent, except for one corner near the Blaine elementary school, where four or five young black men stand watching the street. One of them is bouncing a basketball.

title: Irish Wait to Escape Emigre Shadow
description: A furtive existence, life in the shadow of the law, is about to end for thousands of Irish immigrants who have been living in this country without visas or legal documentation.

title: Lizzie Eldredge Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. LeRoy Lincoln Eldredge Jr. of Hingham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Elizabeth Atwood Eldredge, the senior resident in neurosurgery at the Children's Hospital and Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, to George L. Alexakos, a corporate manager at Citibank in San Juan, P.R. A May wedding is planned.

title: Nadina S. Simon To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Nadina Suzanne Simon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Simon of Yonkers, N.Y., to Ethan Van Vorst Sewell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius V. V. Sewell 3d of New York and Williamstown, Mass., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. A June wedding is planned.

title: Future of Big Computing a Victory for Lilliputians
description: The long-running debate about how best to make computers thousands of times more powerful than they are today appears to be ending in a stunning consensus. The nation's leading computer designers have agreed that a technology considered the underdog as recently as two years ago has the most potential for the next generation of the world's fastest computers, called supercomputers.

title: Fashion Bargains for the Battle on AIDS
description: With more than 100 fashion designers putting on a clothing sale this week to help AIDS charities, consumers are about to be treated to the largest sample sale ever. Are you ready?

title: The World; What Will It Take to Make Saddam Hussein Nervous?
description: AFTER more than three months and a commitment of almost 400,000 American soldiers, the Bush Administration and its Arab allies still wonder how to get Saddam Hussein's undivided attention.

title: The Winners Are Those Who Didn't Play
description: IN the late 1980's, the takeover game often seemed like the only game on Wall Street. Those who wouldn't play were dismissed as irrelevant. Now, it appears, the only survivors after this recession may be those who by luck or brains managed to stay on the sidelines. The rules have changed.

title: National Notebook: Galveston, Tex.; Picking Up The Strand
description: FOR 14 years, George Mitchell and his wife, Cynthia, have tried doggedly to revitalize the Strand, a 17-block historic district on the National Register of Historic Places adjacent to Galveston's downtown. They have spent more than $40 million buying and restoring 16 buildings and soon will start on a $6.3 million hotel, restaurant and retail development overlooking the harbor a block away.

title: Fashion; THE GREAT AMERICAN COCKTAIL
description: START WITH SEVERAL JIGGERS OF NOSTALGIA: 1960's is this season's favorite vintage. Throw in a dash of inspiration from other designers. Chanel and Armani are the recommended brands, though Lacroix, Azzedine, Courreges and Montana are also popular. Don't forget a soupcon of saleability. Top it off with some sprinkles of originality (optional). Shake well and serve neat. That's the great American fashion cocktail for spring 1991.

title: Boston Plans a New Arena
description: City officials say the are willing to forgive $9 million in taxes and issue $125 million in bonds to help finance a new Boston Garden.

title: Surprises and Contrasts in Hicksville
description: HICKSVILLE'S Eye of the Tiger is a new Chinese restaurant with clashing contrasts. First, there is surprise and excitement; then, there is the ordinary and pedestrian.

title: Kathryn Young, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Kathryn Rachel Young was married last evening to Dr. Steven David Spandorfer at the Helmsley Palace in New York. Cantor Annie Bornstein performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners; Now Appearing
description: After months of touch-and-go teetering, the Joffrey Ballet seems to be back on its feet. With the death of the company's founder and namesake, Robert Joffrey, in 1988, it fell to the founding artistic director, Gerald Arpino, to choreograph account books and performance bookings in addition to ballets. Growing friction with a restive faction of the Joffrey board climaxed earlier this year, when Mr. Arpino threw up his hands and walked away from the company, taking his ballets with him. Then many of the board members resigned, as did the company's executive director, and it was disclosed that the Joffrey was in deep financial difficulty. Since then, Mr. Arpino has come back and, with the help of a corporate consultant, has made substantial progress in straightening out the company's finances. And bookings are accumulating for performances celebrating the company's 35th anniversary next year. "I've devoted practically all my time to making the company fiscally stable," Mr. Arpino said. "I'd done it on a smaller scale, but never on such a creative scale."

title: Fires Hit Colorado and Montana; Arson Suspected as Homes Burn
description: A fast-moving fire northwest of Boulder destroyed 14 structures, including houses and garages, early today in what the authorities suspect was arson. Scores of residents were evacuated.

title: The Middle Of the World
description: YEARS after Mark Twain described the Equator as looking "like a blue ribbon stretched across the ocean," gullible seafarers scanned the horizon, hoping to see for themselves. But the Equator, that imaginary 24,000-mile-long circle around the earth, is clearly visible 15 miles north of Quito, Ecuador, where it takes the form of a four-inch-wide strip of stones through the center of a stone walkway, marking the division between the Northern and Southern hemispheres.

title: Campus Life: Iowa; Suits and Debate Follow Display Of Cartoon Poster
description: So far, the poster of the cartoon character Bart Simpson that was hung in the student union has touched off one lawsuit, one complaint each to the campus Human Rights Committee and the Iowa City Human Rights Commission, and the resignations of two University of Iowa human-rights officials, while prompting debate on homophobia and free speech. The poster was up only six days.

title: The Executive Computer; Provocative Diskette Technologies
description: NEW generations of high-capacity diskette drives are on the horizon, including optical diskettes, magnetic floppy disks and hybrids called "floptical drives.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: JOHN R. HOWARD;
Beyond the Simple Answers to Crime
description: WASHINGTON has far more policemen per capita than does New York City, yet the district's crime rate is higher than New York's. The United States has more people in jail than any other Western democracy, yet this country's incidence of violent crime is higher than their rates.

title: Training to Crew on the QE2: It's Not All Sun and Beaches
description: The crew members of the cruise ship the Queen Elizabeth 2, no strangers to the back alleys and bazaars of Lisbon, Bangkok and Gibraltar, have added a new port of call: the Vanderbilt Y.M.C.A. at 224 East 47th Street.

title: GOVERNMENT AIMS AT A HEART TEST TO TRIM EXPENSES
description: Since the early 1900's, physicians have relied on a brief test called an electrocardiogram to measure the heart's impulses and alert them to signs of problems. And insurers and patients have usually paid whatever the doctor charged for the test.

title: Technology; The Superplastic, Rare-Metal Legacy of Stealth
description: UNTIL now, the Pentagon has kept secret most of the design and manufacturing breakthroughs that were used to build the radar-evading Stealth, or B-2, bomber. But in one of the clearest views yet permitted, a result of a series of interviews, it has become evident how several of the long-range bomber's metallic parts, including engine covers and other heat-resistant parts, were formed from titanium and aluminum alloy molds.

title: INSIDE
description: Burmese Junta's Tight Grip Despite liberalization around the world, the Burmese military maintains its tight hold on power. Page 20. British Opposition's Woe Prime Minister Thatcher's resignation has left Britain's opposition Labor Party in a quandary. Page 3. News Strike Hits Home Like others striking The Daily News, Ruben Vazquez is scrimping and expects a frugal Christmas. Page 36.

title: Giants Don't See Beyond A Tough Eagles Rivalry
description: THE big game for the Giants may be the potential summit meeting Dec. 3 with the also-unbeaten 49ers in San Francisco. Even so, the clash with the Eagles in Philadelphia today must be regarded as the big game before the big game.

title: Focus: Western North Carolina; Homes Bloom in Piney Mountain Country
description: GROWING up on a farm in the western North Carolina mountain community of Whittier (pop. 1,000), Bill Gibson often felt isolated from the world and considered it a treat to meet someone new. Now, Mr. Gibson, who is 42 years old, feels fortunate to see someone he knows.

title: Linda Movish Married To Benjamin A. Zurier
description: Linda T. Movish, a daughter of Arline T. Movish of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Edward Movish, was married last evening to Benjamin A. Zurier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin L. Zurier of Providence, R.I. Rabbi Leslie Y. Gutterman performed the ceremony at the Inn at Longshore in Westport, Conn.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Flaky Croissants: Finding Paris's Best
description: THERE are many criteria for judging a good croissant, and no place better than Paris to put croissants to the test. For regularly, right around dawn, every pastry shop and bakery in the city stacks croissants on shelves and in a window or two. Early morning pedestrians run in and, rarely waiting to bite into the buttery, flaky pastry, brush off the subsequent shower of crumbs as they continue on their way. Or, they slip into a cafe and pluck a croissant from a laden basket to dip into dark espresso.

title: The World; Assad of Syria, The Smoother Of Two Evils
description: NAME an Arab president whose name is virtually synonymous with ruthless tyranny; whose rule, carried out by a small circle of hometown cronies and family members, is based on fear backed up by seemingly ubiquitous secret police and torture; who has not hesitated to kill tens of thousands of his own citizens; who harbors terrorists, and who, after long coveting a weaker neighbor, recently sent his troops rampaging through that country's national palace.

title:
DANCE;
New Work Bespeaks Company's Status
description: IN high-top leather sneakers and street clothes, Alfred Gallman projects the image of a social worker in a pickup basketball game. Even in rehearsing his company of talented and attractive dancers, Gallman's Newark Dance Theater, this choreographer-director camouflages his creative forces by maintaining a low-key, casual demeanor.

title: For a Nickel, You Get History
description: The residents of Westchester may be shocked to learn that they are getting something for a nickel these days. And yet, that nickel could soon be eliminated or cut to a few cents [ "Budget Plan Links Cuts to Fate of Sales Tax," Nov. 18 ] .

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.; A Professor Is Given a Coveted Appointment: to the Rank of Student
description: John L. Wyatt never liked taking timed exams when he was an undergraduate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Now, more than two decades after earning a degree in electrical engineering and computer science, Mr. Wyatt is a tenured professor in the department at M.I.T.

title: Campus Life: Colorado;   Students Reject Ban on the Sale of Coors Beer
description: Students at the University of Colorado have soundly defeated a proposal to ban the sale of Coors beer on campus.

title: Once Again, A MAN WITH A MISSION
description: ON A STILL SUMMER NIGHT, LONG AFTER HE had gone to bed, Jonas Salk awoke with a start and began another session of what he calls his night writing. Sitting in his house, high atop the cliffs of La Jolla, Calif., he picked up paper and pen. Then, still in a twilight state of half sleep, half consciousness, he began taking dictation, transcribing what he believes are messages from another realm.

title: Wall Street; Is Tyco's Chief Loosening His Grip?
description: WALL STREET has long had one word of advice for Benson A. Selzer, the chairman of Tyco Toys Inc.: quit.

title: Postings: Takashimaya Building; Return to Fifth
description: In the heart of Fifth Avenue's fanciest retail strip, a wrecking crew is demolishing two vacant two-story buildings to make room for a new 20-story retail and office tower for Takashimaya Company of Tokyo. The structure will go up on the east side of the avenue between 54th and 55th Streets, where a Chandlers shoe store and Wempe Jewelers once stood. The Takashimaya building's neighbors will be Elizabeth Arden and Bijan, an exclusive men's store where clothing is sold by appointment.

title: A Gay Film Maker Bares His Soul
description: MARC HUESTIS is a film maker who only makes movies that "speak to me, come from my heart, my community" and are about "things I know, can relate to, am familiar with."

title: Two Musicians Who Defy the Boundaries of Jazz
description: Though it would be hard to tell judging from today's jazz recordings, it was only five years ago that a big discussion swirled among younger members of the jazz community about revitalizing the music. Deemed irrelevant in the hands of the 1960's avant-gardists, or stale in the hands of be-boppers, jazz's resuscitation was in order.

title: Art Under Attack: Who Dares Say That It's No Good?
description: One consequence of the uproar over art labeled obscene, blasphemous or otherwise offensive is that the careers of the creative artists whose work is at issue have been given a rocket-powered boost. This was surely not intended by those who have taken the artists and the National Endowment for the Arts to task, but it should not have surprised them. In today's culture, notoriety often equals fame, and fame passes for success.

title: ADDICTS STEALING DIAPERS TO RESELL
description: Drug addicts trying to scrape up quick cash in this struggling mill city are turning to the theft of disposable diapers, baby formula and Tylenol, the police report. There is a ready market for the merchandise.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Salisbury
description: A SENSE of preservation prevails in the well-tended woodlands, homes and horse and dairy farms of the five villages of Salisbury, Lime Rock, Lakeville, Amesville and Taconic that make up the 65-square-mile Town of Salisbury in the northwest corner of Connecticut.

title: Elusive Handshake
description: To the Editor: A friend from America sent me John Rockwell's article about Leopold Stokowski [ "Beneath Faded Glamour, a Real Maestro," Sept. 30 ] , brought about by a new showing of the redone "Fantasia." Many years ago I went to see it with Stokowski and his children. Chris was then very little and sitting on my knee. Suddenly he yelled, "Look, that's my Dada shaking hands with Mickey Mouse." He wanted to go "backstage" and meet the mouse, and was led from the Little Carnegie picture house, tears streaming down his face. WENDY HANSON Arezzo, Italy The writer was Leopold Stokowski's personal assistant for three years.

title: Discovering Alternatives to Chemicals
description: TIME was when gardeners would see a bug and run for the spray can. Never mind what kind of bug or why it was there, they just got rid of it.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Keep up with the season and finish outdoor chores. Compost any leaves still on the ground. Check over the house plant collection to be sure no outside pests have come indoors for the cold months.

title: The 'Super' Concept
description: Now that the Soviet Union has been deflated, and may even be breaking up, does the world still need the U.S. as a remaining superpower?

title: 9th in Row for Penn State
description: Critics may say that the polls are confusing and the bowl matchups are inconclusive in determining who's No. 1. But the competitive essence of college football remains healthy as was proven again today when Penn State narrowly defeated Pitt, 22-17, in the regular-season finale for both teams.

title: Corrections
description: The Video column on page 22 of the Arts and Leisure section today misstates the telephone number of Cinema Products Corporation, a LosAngeles electronics manufacturer, in some copies. The correct number is (800) 955-5025.

title: Seasoned in Vietnam, 'Harlem Hell Fighters' Report to the Gulf
description: They are members of the 369th Transportation Battalion of the New York National Guard, but their nom de guerre, earned in combat during World War I, is the "Harlem Hell Fighters."

title: After Bad Years, Baymen See Upturn
description: LONG ISLAND baymen expect next year's harvest of bay scallops to equal the records set in the early 1980's, when brown tide was unknown and bay life was in bloom.

title: Probe's Venus Mission Interrupted by an Error
description: Engineers corrected a ground control computer error that had halted the Magellan spacecraft's mapping of Venus, space agency officials said today.

title: Drivers
description: To the Editor: A. Z. Livolsi's observations of American drivers (Letters on Travel , Sept. 23), with which I sadly concur, brought to mind several illuminating experiences I had in driving from Rome to Florence last year.

title: Poles Voting for a President Who Can Face Up to the Ordeals
description: There is wide agreement here that the winner on Sunday in Poland's first direct presidential elections will immediately face difficult political and social choices in the struggle to rebuild the devastated economy.

title: CRIME
description: Dark and moody and full of its own melancholy street music, GROOTKA (Foul Play/Countryman, $19.95) is a great introduction to Jon A. Jackson's police procedurals featuring his scrappy Detroit bulldog, Detective Sgt. Fang Mulheisen. "He had a predilection for obscure, nondescript neighborhoods, forgotten places," the author says of Fang's deep but unsentimental affection for his city. "It seemed the right place to find a corpse."

title:
FILM;
Silent Movies Speak Eloquently Of Social Issues
description: I was long puzzled as to why there were no muckrakers in the early days of movies. I have been a fervent propagandist for the silent film since I was a boy, showing them on my home-movie projector in the 50's. Many were entertaining; some were moving; a few were works of art. But, until recently, I believed that hardly any dealt with the social problems of their time.

title: Carrie Maynard Wed in Florida
description: Carrie Frances Maynard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Buckley A. Maynard of Glen Rock, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Francis Nichols Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nichols of Windermere, Fla. The Rev. Robert Gray performed the ceremony at the Winter Park (Fla.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Food; It Takes a Thief
description: SOME PEOPLE, WHEN THEY GO TO A RESTAURANT, steal the silver, the linen and even the china. Years ago, restaurant keepers placed individual pepper mills on their tables, and diners made off with them by the thousands. Which is why today pepper is ground by the waiter from a mill so large that only a professional can steal it -- and then only from a distracted waiter. As for me, I prefer to leave the silver alone and help myself to the recipes.

title: 'Final Analysis'
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Men Rob Bus After Driver Waited For Them to Arrive
description: Would the bus driver please wait for his friends, the young man asked. The bus driver said she would. It only took a moment for them to arrive -- and a few minutes more to rob the driver and about 20 passengers at gunpoint, the police said last night.

title: Tanii-san Goes Fishing in Hollywood
description: A FEW weeks ago, Akio Tanii, president of the world's biggest consumer electronics manufacturer, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, invited his nemesis over for dinner. It was Norio Ohga, president of the Sony Corporation. No one will say much about what they talked about, but history may record it as Japan's back-to-the-future rendition of the days when Louis B. Mayer dined with Samuel Goldwyn.

title: Role for Workers in Plant Safety Debated
description: A BILL that would give residents and plant workers a role in reducing and eliminating industrial hazards faces stiff opposition from a coalition of business groups.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Fortunately there's no uncertainty in most cases, but when the question does pop up it can be one of the trickiest of life's minor situations. When is it proper to use a first name, especially when addressing an older person? And for that matter should it ever be done without first being suggested by the other person, especially if older?

title: Commercial Property: 450 Lexington Avenue; Up From the Depths: A Neo-Neo-Classical Tower
description: "GEE, when are you going to get going?" As senior vice president of the Hines Interests development concern, David T. Lawrence endured that question for more than a year after construction had actually begun on the new 40-story office tower at Lexington Avenue and 45th Street.

title: Review/Dance; An Italian Souvenir Is Revived
description: After a subdued opening earlier in the week, the New York City Ballet hit its stride on Friday night at the New York State Theater with a fabulously projected performance of "Who Cares?" -- or, George Gershwin as viewed by George Balanchine.

title: Style Makers; Craig Miller and Richard Zeichik, Fund-Raisers
description: When they first met in 1984, Craig Miller and Richard Zeichik were involved in, among other issues, Southern California's nuclear-freeze movement and arms reduction. Later that year, their prime concern became AIDS; since then they have raised almost $27 million in the battle against the disease.

title: South Asian Leaders Call for Effort Against Drugs
description: Leaders of seven South Asian nations have concluded a three-day summit meeting in the Indian Ocean nation of the Maldives with a call for greater cooperation in combating the narcotics trade and drug abuse in the region.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: STRING BASS CONCERT

title: Deals
description: Football

title: Seaport Getting New Art Collection
description: The first public showing of valuable maritime art, ship models and other marine artifacts in a collection that was threatened with dispersion or removal from New York City is planned for the spring by the South Street Seaport Museum, which is negotiating its purchase from a Federal agency.

title: THE GUIDE
description: POETRY AND HEALING

title: THE RUSSIAN CHARACTER
description: Smith wrote of lazy workers, but he did not report that 90 percent of the women in the Soviet Union work full time, building roads, etc. He wrote of long food lines but did not say that it is mostly women who wait on those lines.

title: Dissent by Burmese Only Brings More Repression
description: Their heads shaved and bowed and their hands tied to a thick rope, about a dozen barefoot young men walked sullenly into the shabby, cavernous township jail.

title: Headliners; Back to Basics
description: Someone in Washington seems to figure that hard-core spying in the 90's is a job for an old-fashioned cloak-and-dagger kind of guy. The new head of the Central Intelligence Agency's operations directorate -- the department where the actual spies work -- is Thomas Alan Twetten, whose 28 years in the C.I.A. have been spent mostly under cover in the Middle East and Africa. Some in the intelligence community were surprised, viewing Mr. Twetten as a throwback to the freewheeling days when the agency blithely manipulated governments and plotted assassinations. He declines to be photographed and even some close relatives had no idea what he did until Bob Woodward, the Washington Post reporter, mentioned him in his 1987 C.I.A. expose, "Veil." Mr. Twetten is generally praised for his handling of tricky assignments in the past, but some former C.I.A. officials hint that they will be keeping a wary eye on him. For his part, Mr. Twetten says simply that espionage is no longer "a gentleman's game."

title: East Europe Rethinks Music, Too
description: Dennis Russell Davies, the chief conductor of the American Composers Orchestra, Brooklyn Philharmonic and Brooklyn Academy of Music (among other titles) has a remarkable record of championing important new scores to the communities in which he appears.

title: Fred Shero, 65; Coached Flyers to Stanley Cup
description: Fred Shero, who coached the Philadelphia Flyers to two Stanley Cup championships in the mid-1970's and then brought the Rangers to the brink of victory in 1979, the first of his two seasons in New York, died yesterday at Cooper Hospital in Camden, N.J.

title: Amy Jo Zeidman, Lawyer, Engaged
description: The engagement of Amy Jo Zeidman to Dr. Jay Bruce Horowitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Horowitz of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Saul I. Zeidman of Boynton Beach, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title: Flooding Forces Evacuations in Northwest
description: Crews searched for scarce sandbags and emergency shelters reopened today as rivers widened by heavy rains drove nearly 2,000 people from their homes in the second wave of floods this season.

title: Archie Brown, 79, Union Leader In Landmark Case on Communists
description: Archie Brown, the West Coast longshoremen's union leader who won the 1965 Supreme Court decision upholding the right of Communists to serve as union officials, died Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 79 years old.

title: Postings: Chinatown's Wall St.; New Bank Tower
description: The 15-story Glory China Tower, now under construction at 11 East Broadway, on the corner of Catherine Street, is at least eight months away from completion, but its development would seem to further the case for East Broadway as Chinatown's Wall Street.

title: Among Skulls And Tigers, a Yeti Shows Its Face
description: Do masks conceal or reveal? Are carved wood and papier-mache faces depicting three-eyed eagles, snarling tigers, grinning skulls and a hairy yeti the ultimate in fantasy or reality? Or all of the above?

title: THE RUSSIAN CHARACTER
description: As an American, Russian-speaking, Russia-watcher for about 20 years now, I regret to say that Hedrick Smith's observations in his article "The Russian Character" (Oct. 28) are right on target. I'm glad someone had the courage to chuck the platitudes and talk straight about these wonderful people who are just as flawed as we are. GARY K. BARKER Louisville, Ky.

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: NONFICTION
description: "LIFE IS PAINFUL, NASTY & SHORT . . . IN MY CASE IT HAS ONLY BEEN PAINFUL & NASTY." Djuna Barnes, 1978-1981: An Informal Memoir. By Hank O'Neal. (Paragon House, $19.95.) This odd little memoir of Djuna Barnes (1892-1982) has its curiosities and its charms. At once admiring of and admonitory toward its subject, the book serves as a loopy chronicle of the three-year friendship that developed between the aging, infirm and still piously eccentric poet and novelist and Hank O'Neal, a record producer and writer, who got to know Barnes after being asked to look in on her by their mutual friend, the photographer Berenice Abbott. Mr. O'Neal met Barnes late in 1978; by then the creator of the highly stylized novel "Nightwood" had been in virtual hiding in a one-room Greenwich Village apartment for nearly 40 years. Mr. O'Neal served as confidant, accountant, literary executor and errand boy to "an extraordinarily bright woman who lived in a time warp." Barnes, nearly 90, told him: "Don't think for a minute this is the real Djuna Barnes. The real Djuna Barnes is dead." What emerges from " 'Life Is Painful, Nasty & Short . . . In My Case It Has Only Been Painful & Nasty' " is a portrait of the writer in her final decline: proud, bowed and -- as Mr. O'Neal and others before him who had befriended her were forced to conclude -- insufferable.

title: Robyn Einbinder and Jeffrey Koeppel Are to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Einbinder of Jericho, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Robyn Einbinder to Jeffrey Koeppel, a son of Dr. Edward Koeppel of Jericho and Alida Koeppel of Roslyn, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: R. A. Yaffa Jr. to Wed Miss Goldwasser
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dan L. Goldwasser of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter, Lauren Audrey Goldwasser, and Richard Alan Yaffa Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Yaffa of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Gorbachev's Plan for a New Union: A Central Government Still in Charge
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented the nation with a new focus for its growing power struggle today, publishing his blueprint for a politically redesigned Soviet Union that promises greater sovereignty to the restive republics, but no guaranteed shrinkage of the powers of the central Government.

title: Spanish Food Finds a Sunny Norwalk Niche
description: FOR an authentic touch of Spain, one can drop in at Meson Galicia in Norwalk, one of relatively few Spanish restaurants in the Northeast. There is authenticity in abundance -- in atmosphere, service, menu and, most important, in the food itself.

title: Eurail
description: To the Editor: Before going on a lengthy trip to Europe this past summer, I had nightmares about how I would handle my luggage. I am not young, and I was traveling alone.

title: Susan Haley Wed To Robert Keyes
description: Susan Smith Haley, the daughter of Mrs. William Headley Garthwaite Smith of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Smith, was married yesterday to Robert William Keyes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Keyes of Painter, Va. The Rev. James T. McGuire performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: Taking Out Iraq's Nukes
description: The prospect of Saddam Hussein brandishing an arsenal of nuclear weapons is the nightmare of all who oppose him. Just imagine if his invasion of Kuwait had been backed by a nuclear punch that could decimate the forces now massed against him and devastate Israel, among other countries.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Many Avoiding Rome's New Air Terminal ROME

title: Airline Tickets
description: To the Editor: Travelers should be aware of airlines that offer complimentary tickets if you give up your confirmed seat on an overbooked flight. I recently had an experience with Continental Airlines, which exchanged two tickets for my one confirmed seat for a Newark-to-Tampa flight. Only after I received the tickets did I notice that the complimentary tickets are standby coach tickets. These may be converted to a confirmed reservation subject to seat availability, if reservations are made within seven days of your departure.

title: Mom And Pop Story
description: SEXUAL INTERCOURSE By Rose Boyt. 181 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: About Men; Father Time
description: IN EARLY AUGUST 1947, my father turned 40 years old; I was 0. Actually I was about a month old, and being a slow child it had not yet occurred to me what being 40 years younger than my father might mean. When I got to be 10, he would be 50. There were four other children, three older brothers and an older sister, and so, at 1 month, I was probably busy listening to their advice on the one hand and defending myself on the other.

title:
FORUM;
A Saudi Explanation of Oil Pricing
description: On October 31, Murray Adelman, professor of economics emeritus at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology and a specialist on the economics of oil, submitted written testimony to the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs on oil price volatility.

title: Wave Swamps a Craft Trying to Set a Record
description: Two sailors were defeated by mountainous waves off the tip of South America in their quest to break a 136-year-old sailing record, a spokeswoman here said.

title: 36,000 U.S. Workers Displaced
description: The manufacture of Japanese cars in the United States cost Americans 36,000 jobs in 1988 and 1989, the General Accounting Office says.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page contents listing in the Travel section today carries an incorrect page number in some copies for an essay about a guidebook writer's travels in Turkey. It is on page 29.

title: Codes for TV Listings
description: Users of the Television section in The New York Times will find a change in the program listings starting today. Code numbers follow many entries, for use with a device that simplifies videocassette recording.

title: Yonkers Initiates New Legal Action In Housing Case
description: TWICE in recent weeks, Judge Leonard B. Sand has asked the parties to a proposed contract for construction of desegregated housing in Yonkers to meet in his Federal District Court chambers in Manhattan. He called them in to give him reports on the final negotiations over a document that would enable the court-ordered construction to begin.

title: Diving in Truk
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from two weeks of diving in Micronesia, one week of which was spent in Truk, I enjoyed the excellent and insightful article on "Wreck Diving Beneath Truk's Blue Lagoon," (Travel, Sept. 16).

title: Asians at U.N. Reluctant to Criticize Burmese for Rights Violations
description: A Swedish-led campaign at this year's General Assembly to censure the military Government of Myanmar for contempt of its citizens' basic human rights has run into strong opposition from other Asian countries, diplomats at the United Nations say.

title: Crewman in Crash Is Found
description: Army divers today recovered the body of a civilian flight instructor who had been missing since a military helicopter crashed into a lake during a night-training exercise on Thursay, the authorities said. The body of Phillip E. Walker, 54 years old, of Sheridan, Ark., was found shortly after the wreckage was raised from Lake Ellsworth, a spokesman said. Five other crew members, identified as Army reservists, were not seriously injured. They were rescued by residents along the lakeshore, north of Fort Sill. The Army said the crash was under investigation.

title: Coins
description: Christie's will auction a collection of world bank notes and artwork from the archives of the American Bank Note Company later this week. And what a strange collection it is. There are notes from Canada and Bolivia, from the Belgian Congo and Martinique. The American Bank Note Company was one of the largest printers of paper currency in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, so the variety of nations represented is not so surprising as are some of the notes' designs.

title: Mary Higgins to Wed Matthew Dunne
description: Mr. and Mrs. William W. Higgins of Greenwich, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Mary Hatheway Higgins and Matthew William Dunne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Lee Dunne of Hudson, Ohio.

title: Lean Times for Daily News Strikers
description: For Ruben Vazquez, the hardest thing about being on strike against The Daily News is hearing the playful squeals of his youngest granddaughter, Ivana.

title: Book on Sea Cliff: Imaginary Mayhem
description: HAVING forsaken the life of a high-powered Manhattan marketing executive for full-time motherhood in the Long Island town of Sea Cliff, Jessica McAllister, the heroine of Cynthia Blair's novel "Close to Home" (Ballantine, $4.95) finds herself in an unexpected state of non-ecstasy.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Bethlehem, Pa.;
Lehigh Joins Loan Pool
description: LEHIGH UNIVERSITY is contributing at least $1 million to a loan pool to help development on the South Side, whose economy has been hard hit by migration to the suburbs and by layoffs at the neighboring Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant.

title: Church's School Plan Draws Protest
description: A PLAN by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport to operate and finance a regional system of elementary schools has drawn criticism from Bridgeport parishoners, because the city would be the only community isolated as a district by itself.

title: Aleutian Caves Focus Of UConn Research
description: THE chance finding of a burial cave in the windswept Aleutian Islands, off the Alaskan coast, has opened another window on the people whose ancestors were among North America's first settlers. The cave has special interest to a University of Connecticut researcher and his associates, who have long studied the Aleut people, and to the Aleuts themselves, who want to preserve their heritage.

title: Dr. Mary May Wed to A. A. Fairchok
description: Dr. Mary Patricia May, a daughter of Dr. William E. and Dr. Patricia A. May of Kensington, Md., was married yesterday to Andrew Arthur Fairchok, a son of Barbara Best of Salt Point, N.Y., and Andrew Fairchok of Kingston, N.Y. Msgr. Leo J. Coady and the Rev. John F. Harvey officiated at Holy Redeemer Roman Catholic Church in Kensington.

title: Transplant Pioneer Plans to Quit Surgery
description: Dr. Thomas Starzl, who in 1967 was the lead surgeon in the world's first successful liver transplant and who subsequently trained most of the nation's doctors now qualified to perform the operation, says he plans to quit surgery and concentrate on research.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Newsletter Centers on Women
description: A LACK of information and opportunity or the inability to find out where to learn skills are some of the things that may keep women from enjoying the outdoors.

title: Mimi Carter Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. W. Carter of Somers, Conn., and Greensboro, Vt., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Mary Elizabeth Carter and John Denton Haley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Duane F. Haley of Bloomfield, Conn. Miss Carter, who is known as Mimi, is a graduate of St. Lawrence University. She is a watercolor artist in Cambridge, Mass. Mr. Haley is a graduate of Catholic University. He is an architect with Benjamin Thompson & Associates in Cambridge.

title:
ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Tripping the Light Fantastic Is No Picnic
description: By this standard, the soul of New York is raffishly ad hoc: there seems to be no overall policy on design of the streetscape. Miraculously, in spite of neglect, the streets continue to work; laid out intelligently long ago, they foster transportation, circulation and people watching. At a time when many American cities are desperately trying to coax a little street life into their downtowns and waterfronts, New York fortunately possesses a sound, popular walking environment. The problem is that the city has been steadily ceding its pedestrian heritage to the visions of traffic engineers. Roadways have been gradually widened and sidewalks narrowed. If one had to name the key element dominating New York's street design in the last 40 years, it would be the convenience of motorists.

title: Gained In Translation
description: To the Editor: To know that Hollywood's war on Indians is coming to an end [ "Hollywood's War on Indians Draws to a Close," Oct. 7 ] is of some comfort. But the Indians won some skirmishes in that war that should be noted for the record.

title: Wall Street; At Last, the Game May Be Up for Nintendo
description: FOR five years now, Nintendo has been the Grinch that stole Christmas from American toy makers. This year, roughly 20 cents of every retail dollar Americans spend on toys and video games -- $3.5 billion of the $17.4 billion total -- will go for products from the Nintendo Company, the Tokyo parent, according to Sean McGowan, an analyst with Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company.

title: Scary Monsters and Super Freaks
description: THE LOOK OF HORROR: Scary Moments From Scary Movies. By Jonathan Sternfield. (Courage Books/Running Press, $14.98.) Covering a genre of movies that runs from "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari" to "Little Shop of Horrors," "The Look of Horror" is a compressed history that is long on images and short on words, a well-illustrated, smartly written recap of some of the more frightening moments in movie history -- and the faces that make those moments memorable. This is a fan's book and never pretends to be a groundbreaking study of horror films. No long-winded theories or footnotes about What It All Means, just page after page of the bright, fantastic visions from the classics we know so well (and some we may have forgotten). Jonathan Sternfield, a freelance writer and photographer, breaks his study into different sections, covering aliens, creatures, ghosts and the demons among us -- the bad seeds, the ordinary people who can be the most terrifying monsters around. The author wisely keeps his opinions short, crisp and to the point. His text amounts to plot summaries and critical commentaries on the quality of the films. What animates this book are the photos of these scary monsters and super freaks. Mr. Sternfield has some interesting inclusions: in a book rife with werewolves, blobs and tarantulas the size of 747's, for example, he has included "Fatal Attraction" as a horror film for a new generation. We cover the gamut here, from monsters alien and otherwise to seemingly innocent demonic devices (the car in John Carpenter's "Christine," the red-headed doll in "Child's Play"). Mr. Sternfield delivers what he promises and does it in a loose, readable style. And the coffeetable format makes it effective; the pictures are large and lurid -- the better to frighten you with, my dear.

title: Iowa Falls, But Gains Rose Bowl
description: Keswic Joiner caught a 28-yard touchdown pass and recovered a blocked punt for another score in Minnesota's 31-24 upset of Iowa, which backed into the Rose Bowl when Michigan beat Ohio State earlier today.

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: FICTION
description: FALL QUARTER. By Weldon Kees. Edited by James Reidel. (Story Line Press, $18.95.) Written in 1941, this only surviving novel by the gifted poet, short-story writer and painter Weldon Kees, who disappeared mysteriously in 1955 at the age of 41, has finally been rescued from oblivion. Rejected as unsuitable for wartime publication, the book pillories the vapidity of 1930's small-town mid-America. Part academic farce, part sardonic social criticism, it details the initiation of prim, ambitious William Clay, age 25, newly a Master of Arts in English literature, into the sorry ways of college teaching. In a deadpan ironic tone, Kees sets Clay up for a collision with rude reality. An expert on the vowel sounds in the poetry of Richard Crashaw, Clay anticipates the good life of the mind. His foolish dreams collapse in this often funny, sometimes preposterous work. Using screwball-comedy techniques, Kees assembles grotesques to shatter Clay's illusions. He teaches composition to students with "the vacant faces of those who know nothing and want to know nothing." His colleagues are mediocre bores, diligent pedants and wizened eccentrics. The department live wire (soon dismissed) has survived two years by swigging whisky, the "life giver" for many of the drab town's stupefied inhabitants. Corruption abounds. The costly defective floors in Needham Hall (purchased from a trustee) smell as though "something had died in the place." The failing grade of a lazy dolt (a trustee's son) is changed. Clay, smitten, pursues the local femme fatale, a giddy radio chanteuse, and the ludicrous chase to bed her and wed her provides the book its plot. Merciless, labored at times, "Fall Quarter" surrealistically evokes the nightmare of disappointed lives. It could have been written yesterday, alas.

title: Are We Doomed?
description: THE CHANGING ATMOSPHERE A Global Challenge. By John Firor. 145 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.

title: An Exhibition, Like a Pudding, Requires a Theme
description: Like certain chiantis, many Italian exhibitions do not travel well: they must be experienced on the spot. Even when the subject is one of the towering giants of Western art, the opportunity of viewing a wide selection of objects in the city in which they were created holds the promise of unique rewards. Unfortunately, these do not always materialize.

title: Onerous Choices in Health Care
description: Sister Margaret Straney, president of Cathedral Healthcare Systems, states that the focus of health care must be shifted from acute care and its associated technology to prevention ("A New Vision in Heath Care," Opinion Page, Oct. 7), and that such a shift will save millions of dollars by preventing larger problems with bigger payments down the road.

title: I Just Flew Into New York and . . .
description: This is my first time back in New York since last year when I came to celebrate 20 years of "Monty Python" and 15 years of "Saturday Night Live," which they celebrated oddly enough after 14 years.

title: U.S. Tries to Sway Colombia And Malaysia on Using Force
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d failed today to gain immediate support from Colombia and Malaysia for a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force to drive Iraqi troops from Kuwait.

title: Damage Wreaked By Bows and Arrows
description: As a North Haven resident, I was stunned by the biased reporting in your newspaper in "North Haven Keeps Ban on Deer Kill" (Nov. 4). By presenting mainly the point of view of the Department of Environmental Conservation, which favors the antiquated method of slaughtering animals to reduce their populations, you did our community a disservice.

title:
ART;
The Peril of Stifling Creative Impulses
description: THE premise that underlies "White Sale: Revolution Denied," the multipart installation in the Amelie A. Wallace Gallery of the State University of New York at Old Westbury, is both highly topical and a longstanding concern of Western art.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Building New Houses Closer to the Hubs
description: NEXT month, Peter and Debra Savage will move into their first home, a two-bedroom town house in an Islip development called Hansen's Landing. One of the attractions, and a major reason for buying their $129,990 house, Mr. Savage said, is the "super convenient location."

title: A Business Seminar On Investment in Israel
description: DESPITE the heightened tensions in the Middle East, business opportunities for American companies trading with Israel appear strong, said speakers at a recent trade seminar here for county business people.

title: Eurail
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from Europe, I find it necessary to warn other travelers about the dangers of traveling by train. Since two friends and I were hosteling through Europe, we purchased Eurail passes. We found traveling by train both economical and convenient, until we took a night train from Geneva to Nice. Sometime during the night, someone came into the cabin and took our bags without awakening us. In the morning, upon discovery of the theft, we sought help from the conductors on the train, as well as the police in Nice; neither was very helpful. In the police station we came across 10 other people who had a similar experience on the train.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold 163,900 27 Meadowbrook Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; 2 fireplaces, 1-car garage, patio, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,349. Howell 156,000 9 Mystic Cove 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old ranch; family room, 1-car garage, fireplace; taxes $3,447. Mahwah 224,000 49 Brookwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old contemporary; patio, fenced-in yard, brick fireplace; taxes $3,475. Ramsey 278,000 14 Brookfield Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; finished recreation room, fireplace, enclosed porch; taxes $5,070. Randolph 238,000 10 Woodlawn Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; h/w floors, brick fireplace, arched doorways; taxes $3,652. Roxbury 142,000 45 Condict Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old contemporary; w/b stove, professionally landscaped, full basement; taxes $2,657. OTHER AREAS Bridgeport, Conn. 134,000 84 Harlem Avenue. 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; enclosed front porch, new furnace, large yard; taxes $2,406. Katonah, N.Y. 375,000 124 Mekeel Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 57-year-old Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, greenhouse, eat-in kitchen, patio, 9.3 acres; taxes $6,848. Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. 685,000 3 North Court 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 17-year-old contemporary; new kitchen, Florida room, fireplace, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $7,600.

title: Ethiopian Combatants Agree to Open Port to Food
description: The Ethiopian Government and the Eritrean rebels opposing it have reached a tentative agreement to open the rebel-held Red Sea port of Massawa to relief vessels, United Nations and State Department officials say.

title: Sherrie Edelman Weds Steven Natko
description: Sherrie Lynne Edelman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Edelman of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., was married last evening to Steven Paul Natko, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Natko of West Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi David H. Wice performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia.

title: Off-Limits Rule for Soviets
description: The inability of an America's Cup yacht-racing team from the Soviet Union to bypass naval security precautions in San Diego Bay has led crew members to postpone their travel plans to the United States. The group had expected to arrive in San Diego Tuesday for the start of training for the 1992 cup matches.

title: Dirty Business
description: GLOBAL DUMPING GROUND The International Traffic in Hazardous Waste. By the Center for Investigative Reporting and Bill Moyers. Illustrated. 152 pp. Washington: Seven Locks Press. Paper, $11.95.

title: Still Gonzo After All These Years
description: SONGS OF THE DOOMED More Notes on the Death of the American Dream. Gonzo Papers: Volume Three. By Hunter S. Thompson. 315 pp. New York: Summit Books. $21.95.

title: New Gutter Brings His Own Patent
description: TO build a better rain and leaf gutter has not exactly been David P. Gottlieb's lifetime ambition, but to invent something -- anything -- and receive a patent for it has been.

title: Redmen Roll in Opener Over Monmouth
description: St. John's opened a new basketball season with an old formula on Friday night: play a weak opponent, win easily and look very good doing it.

title: Holiday Gifts And Gadgets For the Road
description: SHOPPING time again. Here is a selection of travel gifts, mostly small ones for people on your list who need gadgets. Perhaps need is not the word, but here they are.

title: Keeping Up With Suffolk's Last Welcome Wagon Lady
description: WITH a bright red blouse draping her shoulders and a basket filled with goodies hanging over her arm, Barbara Lambert looked like Little Red Riding Hood. But it was not to grandmother's house she was going.

title: An Elegance That Hasn't Faded
description: This is the season of tradition, and nowhere is it reflected with more dignity than by the women of a certain age who grace Madison and Fifth Avenues on their holiday shopping tours, often with a grandchild. Theirs is a formality securely fastened in time, untouched by the whims of fashion. Its hallmarks are unmistakable: the well-tailored suits that echo the style of the 50's, the sensible shoes, the gloves and handbags over the arm, the hats cocked at a dashing angle. Then there is the carriage, ramrod straight, and the grooming, impeccable. That adds up to elegance at any age, any place.

title: His Music Never Lied
description: THE NEW SHOSTAKOVICH By Ian MacDonald. Illustrated. 339 pp. Boston: Northeastern University Press.

title: Hard Work Can't Stop Hard Times
description: Donald and Mary Dalton followed all the rules and held fast to the American dream. They worked five days a week, saved their money and reared five children. Someday, they hoped and believed, they would retire to a lake in Minnesota.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 25, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 DAWN, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.95.) A series of horrors besets a Virginia schoolgirl. 2 6 DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe, predictable world a man has built for himself and his family. 3 5 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Philip Friedman. (Ivy, $5.95.) A former prosecutor defends his daughter-in-law, charged with murdering his son. 4 9 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 5 5 THE CAPTIVE, by Victoria Holt. (Fawcett, $5.95.) A 19th-century woman's adventures while a hostage of North African pirates. 6 2 THE GREAT AND SECRET SHOW, by Clive Barker. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) Kennedy resulted from a massive conspiracy. 4 9 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $8.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's. 5 11 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.)
