"Far Side" cartoons. 3 5 THE "LATE NIGHT WITH DAVID LETTERMAN" BOOK OF TOP TEN LISTS, by David Letterman, Steve O'Donnell, et al. (Pocket, $8.95.) Humor. 4 116 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperSanFrancisco, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people. 5 5 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Immigrant Act Aids Filipino Veterans
description: Thousands of Filipino veterans, who served in the United States military in the Far East during World War II, hope that after 45 years of waiting a new law will finally give them recognition.

title: Presenting America's Heroes to Children
description: WHEN did it all begin, Jean Fritz's love affair with American heroes of the 18th century?

title: Witchcraft Held As Nothing to Fear
description: THE white two-family house on a quiet suburban street here looks like any other. But neighbors of Deborah Lipp and Isaac Bonewits might be surprised to learn that the couple who live inside have a shrine to the Goddess of Witchcraft in their living room and cast spells.

title: Q and A
description: Visiting the Aleutians

title: Lori Krivins Is Married
description: Lori Beth Krivins, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Krivins of Interlaken, N.J., was married last evening at Temple Beth Torah in Ocean, N.J., to Marc Jeremy Comer, a son of Dr. Nathan L. Comer of Penn Valley, Pa., and the late Rita Ellis Comer. Rabbi Jacob Friedman officiated.

title: China to Be Host Of Bowling Event
description: China will get its first major tournament when the Bowling World Cup is held in Beijing Nov. 2-12 next year.

title: End of Road for the Trabant
description: The fume-spewing little car that carried many East Germans to new lives in the West will soon chug off into automotive oblivion. The last Trabant will be built sometime next year, after about 10,000 cars are delivered to Poland under an agreement with the former East German Govewrnment, the German Economic Ministry said in a statement on Friday.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MOMMY DOESN'T KNOW MY NAME

title: The Region; Albany Looks Longingly at Land It Can't Pay For
description: QUIETLY but arduously, New York State has been negotiating over the last few years to buy some of the most spectacular plots of privately held land in the state. Among these are Sterling Forest, an 18,000-acre parcel in Orange County that is the largest stretch of woodlands left in the New York City metropolitan area, and the Whitney Property, 51,000 acres of wilderness that includes one of the largest undeveloped lakes in the Adirondacks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We never meant to quit our jobs. They quit on us." -- Donald Dalton of Waterloo, Iowa. [ 1:5. ]

title: The Met Stakes Its Claim In the Rossini Renaissance
description: In a revival long overdue, Gioachino Rossini's "Semiramide," his Babylonian tale of love, murder, and incest, will return to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday. Although the opera has been revived successfully in theaters throughout Europe and the United States (including Chicago and San Francisco), this will be the first New York staging since it appeared at the Met in the 1890's, with Nellie Melba (of peach Melba fame) in the title role.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The paint on our clapboard house begins to peel shortly after being applied, despite careful preparation of the clapboard surfaces each time. Since most of the peeling is on the north side of the house, I assume that humidity is the chief cause. Might venting of the wall spaces be the way to go, or is this likely to greatly reduce the efficiency of the insulation and thus waste too much energy?

title: Dr. Judy Fried Wed to Jonathan Siegel
description: Dr. Judy Jill Fried, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curt Fried of Ardsley, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Jonathan Andrew Siegel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Siegel of Woodbridge, Conn. Cantor Martin Goldstein performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Retired Greyhounds Learning To Be Pets
description: WHEN greyhounds named Deirdre and Chloe first came to live with the Schweitzer family in Bloomfield last year, the success of the arrangement was in doubt. Dierdre was a gracious addition to the household, but Chloe had the manners one might expect from a creature that had been trained to wear a muzzle and chase a lure around a dirt track in front of hundreds of screaming people.

title: Sad Tales of the Sagging Co-op Market
description: THERE are about 14,000 co-ops and condos for sale in Manhattan, 4,000 more than a year ago, and behind most of them there is a story about frazzled owners who wish they had managed to sell out a few years ago, before the sun went down on apartment values.

title: 'Final Analysis'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Slave Fortresses of Ghana
description: A FEW centuries ago the African slave trade thrived at the European-built castles and forts clustered on Ghana's southern coast. Today the fortresses reveal some of the horrors of West Africa's past.

title: The New Order; Peace Isn't So Simple as the End of Cold War
description: WHEN revolutions or wars turn things upside down, the politicians, craving stability, always start trying to institutionalize the new world order. After Napoleon came the Holy Alliance, after World War I the League of Nations, after World War II the United Nations. So last week, 34 countries -- the United States, Canada and all the European states except Albania -- had a go, around a hexagonal table in Paris, at inventing something to replace the cold war and its institutions.

title: On Screen, a Well-Traveled Road
description: Roads and movies seem to have been born for each other. Roads are made for travel. And movies aren't called motion pictures for nothing.

title: THE RUSSIAN CHARACTER
description: Smith's article reminded me of stories I heard in June while running a seminar on American literature in "occupied" Estonia. My students, middle-aged teachers of high-school English, were excited about Estonian moves for independence; and while they were worried about repercussions from Moscow and a skidding economy, they often seemed more concerned about the lasting effects of decades of Russian control. A whole generation has been infected by what one teacher called the "Russian disease." She spoke of her two teen-age sons who are rebelling at the idea of attending the university: "Why? So we can end up like you? And wait 10 years for an apartment?" One of them wants to be a doorman at a restaurant, where he'll get big tips and the chance to purchase booze and meat that he can use to get his name moved up on lists for apartments, and the like. The other, for similar reasons, wants to drive a van or cab.

title: Managing; Sheepskins With a Corporate Twist
description: JAMES W. STERNITZKY, now a nuclear technical review engineer at the Wisconsin Public Service Corporation, took science courses at work in order to get promoted. When he discovered he could apply 33 credits from them toward a nuclear science degree from the University of Maryland, it was an unexpected bonus. "I had figured it would take seven years to get my degree, and it only took five," he said.

title: Australia
description: To the Editor: "Australia's Sunshine State" by Janette Turner Hospital (Travel, Sept. 30) could be more appropriately subtitled, "Queensland runs the gamut: beach and desert, jungle, cay -- and the world's highest incidence of melanoma skin cancer. Two out of every three people who live in Australia will require treatment for at least one type of skin cancer in their lifetime (See "Skin Cancer in Australia," by Robin Marks; Skin Cancer Foundation Journal, 8:9, 1989).

title: Talking: Energy Use; Steps To Lower Fuel Bills
description: THE specter of going through the winter with sky-high heating and utility bills is a powerful reminder of the need to revive some of the energy-saving measures that lapsed into disuse after fuel prices dropped in the late 70's. The measures are also worth considering because they could help make a home easier to sell.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 18 about Long Island City misstated the date Queens became part of New York City. It was 1898. The article also misspelled Manducati, the name of a restaurant. And the Court Square library is a branch of the Queens Borough Public Library, not of the New York Public Library.

title: Jennings Coasts; Porter Fails
description: While Lynn Jennings easily captured her fourth straight women's title, Robert Kempainen prevented Pat Porter from extending a string of eight consecutive victories by winning the men's division yesterday at The Athletics Congress national cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Coach Is Feeling Pressure To Repeat Dream Season
description: WHEN Jim Calhoun was named the men's basketball coach at the University of Connecticut in 1986, one of his goals was to make the team a consistent winner with a national reputation.

title: Chess
description: It used to be that women players were belittled in every which way: They could not calculate combinations; their positional judgment was shallow; they lacked the determination to struggle hard over the board or to give opening preparation the arduous work it needs in the milieu of tournament play.

title: Style Makers; Horace Solomon, Art-Video Producer
description: Horace Solomon scoffs at doomsayers who assert that New York City is no longer the center of the art world. "Everything of significance eventually shows here and sooner rather than later," said the 60-year-old art-video producer, and then he pounded the table. "This is the place!"

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Robert H. Soldwedel;
Increasing the State's Trout Population
description: AS the supervising fisheries biologist for the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife, Robert H. Soldwedel oversees the state effort to increase the trout population in New Jersey.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE>
description: Feeding Celebration's Fire

title: On the CD Horizon, Untapped Resources
description: Compact-disk players do their task both effortlessly and invisibly. From the best of the little plastic doughnuts they decode sounds of crystalline clarity and enormous dynamic range, without background hiss or scratchiness. They can skip around, start, stop, pause and perform assorted other tricks at the wave of a remote control from the listening chair, some of them unimaginable with LP records and cassettes, or at best matters of hit-and-miss and hunt-and-peck.

title: Regional Approach To Services Reconsidered
description: IN a recent speech at the New Jersey State League of Municipalities convention in Atlantic City, Gov. Jim Florio, as a way of countering the state's mounting fiscal crisis, exhorted municipal officials to take a new look at an old idea: regionalization of municipal services.

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: NONFICTION
description: A DARLING OF THE TWENTIES. By Madge Bellamy. (Vestal, Paper, $19.95.) Although her name is now generally unknown, Madge Bellamy was a star of the silent screen. While most of her 57 movies may have been mediocre, and many remain hard to locate or lost forever, a handful possess cult interest, such as "Lorna Doone" or "The Iron Horse," which was directed by John Ford. (At the height of her popularity, fans could purchase a "Lorna Doone" cape and a Madge Bellamy cap.) Though she tried to shed an ingenue image and to negotiate the transition into talking pictures, Bellamy never really accomplished either. In her lavishly illustrated memoir, "A Darling of the Twenties," completed before her death in January (when she was probably 90 years old), Bellamy wants desperately to understand and explain what she calls her "Cinderella story in reverse." But in trying to account for a crucial moment when she turned down the lead in "The Trial of Mary Dugan," Bellamy exclaims, "Why did I do this? A thousand sleepless nights haven't solved the puzzle for me." In one embarrassing passage after the other, Bellamy betrays the naivete that apparently retarded both her career and her personal development. She says more than once, "I wish that I had gone to a psychiatrist, but I never did." Bellamy lived out most of the second half of her pathetic life "in abject poverty" with her "stage and screen identity undisclosed," and she last captured headlines for a few days in 1943, when she took a gun to a longtime companion, the lumber magnate A. Stanwood Murphy, after he abruptly married another woman. As the film historian Kevin Brownlow writes in his introduction, this poignant autobiography is "the dramatic and touching case history" of one of Hollywood's "victims." Whatever else it has to tell us about the shabby methods of the silent film industry, it inadvertently demonstrates that the firmament is fickle and that some stars are a lot less immortal than they may at first appear.

title: Unusual Accord Opens the Way for a Gold Mine
description: Here on a scarred mountainside near the Nevada border, the environmental movement and its archenemy the mining industry have clashed, talked and finally decided that they can live with each other.

title: Kids Happily Horn In On the Grown-Ups' Act
description: Santa's movie elves have been working overtime this season, turning out whatever children's films the traffic will bear. It is worth remembering -- certainly those elves remember -- that a well-made, cleverly targeted children's film can not only influence its young viewers' thinking but also become a significant part of the gross national product. ("The Little Mermaid," last year's animated holiday triumph, has meant combined domestic film grosses, video sales and tie-in merchandising approaching the $350 million mark, not to mention an entire generation on a first-name basis with Sebastian the Crab.)

title: What We Fear Least Kills Most
description: TECHNOLOGICAL RISK By H. W. Lewis. 353 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $22.95.

title: Sports People; Narrowing Down
description: THE task of replacing Mike Archer as Louisiana State's head football coach is proving more difficult than first believed.

title: Carolie Wildrick and Carlton W. Johnson Marry
description: Carolie Adele Wildrick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Donald Wildrick of Chatham, N.J., and East - Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Carlton William Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Johnson of Chatham. The Rev. Kenyon J. Wildrick, an uncle of the bride, assisted by the Rev. Kenyon Tucker, the uncle of the bridegroom, officiated at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title:
Your Own Account;
Decision Time for Benefits
description: IN the last few years, changes in employee benefit plans have shifted more of the cost to employees -- and more of the burden for figuring out how to use them. To wring the most value from your plan next year, you've got to make some decisions by Jan. 1.

title:
ART;
A Colorful Realism in Puerto Rican Prints
description: ON a November day when the wind puts up a fight as one walks to the Newark Public Libary, the bright bursts of color in the exhibition inside can compensate for the hardship. The exhibition is "A Unique Visual Expression: The Poster and Print Art of Puerto Rico" in the library's Third Floor Gallery.

title: New Star for G.O.P. Is Conservative and Black
description: During campaign stops at supermarkets and shopping centers, Gary A. Franks often found that passers-by, particularly in wealthy Fairfield County towns like Wilton and Ridgefield, would offer only the slightest of smiles or the limpest of handshakes, blithely dismissing him as just another liberal black Democrat running for office.

title: Debra Olarsch and Paul Denson Marry
description: Debra Marcie Olarsch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert I. Olarsch of Springfield, N.J., was married last evening to Paul Winfield Denson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Bruce Denson of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. Rabbi Perry Raphael Rank performed the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.

title: 'Sex, Love and Passion' in Office Lobby
description: HERE it comes again, the flap over what it is or is not suitable work to show in an art gallery. This time, the scene is Stamford and the setting is 1 Landmark Square, the downtown building that stands like a giant clothes peg.

title: Kohl Is Savoring 'This Happy Hour'
description: Mr. Kohl's political future seemed uncertain as recently as a year ago, but now he is heavily favored to win re-election as Chancellor on Dec. 2. It will be the first free election in all of Germany since 1932.

title: Free Agency Won't Set Players Free
description: THE United States Supreme Court will determine soon whether it is going to decide the case of Powell v. National Football League. This is the most important sports-law decision in several years. At issue is whether the N.F.L.'s free-agency system violates antitrust law. The litigation is an outgrowth of the defeat of the players' union in the 1987 strike. The plaintiff, Marvin Powell, a former offensive lineman for the New York Jets and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, was the president of the N.F.L. Players Association at the time the suit was filed in October 1987.

title: 'We Saved Some Land. We Had Some Fun.'
description: GOOD DIRT Confessions of a Conservationist. By David E. Morine. 195 pp. Chester, Conn.: The Globe Pequot Press. $19.95.

title: Minors and Majors Are Ready to Split
description: "Bye-bye, minor leagues."

title:
DINING OUT;
A Colonial Setting in Yorktown Heights
description: BECAUSE new management took charge of Pratt's Inn earlier this year, this restaurant is in a transitional phase, with all the accompanying ups and downs (sometimes occurring simultaneously).

title: THE RUSSIAN CHARACTER
description: Smith's article was excellent. His wheelbarrow anecdote seems to be an oft-used story. I heard it years ago in a United States setting to explain the initiative and ingenuity of American workers.

title: High Court to Hear Case on Obesity
description: All Sharon Russell ever wanted to be was a nurse, but her weight nearly got in the way.

title: Julia Coyle to Wed Peter H. Atkins
description: June wedding plans for Julia Andrews Coyle and Peter Herrick Atkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald R. Atkins of Bedford, N.Y., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Coyle of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Data Bank/November 25, 1990
Campus Life: Hampshire College; Students' Fears Prompt New Steps On Campus Safety
description: Weeks of rumors of campus rapes, the appearance of a Peeping Tom, complaints from female students of harassment by male security guards and a Halloween prank in which a male student brandished a hatchet have prompted hundreds of students at Hampshire College to demand better campus security. Last week, the college administration agreed to many of their demands.

title: 'I Was 17, Poor and Joined the Marines'; Call It R.O.T.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Racing; Indy Aims for Manhattan Site
description: The organizers of the Meadowlands Indy-car race, who want to move their event to Manhattan, have proposed a 1.3-mile temporary street circuit along the Hudson River that would isolate only one group of office buildings.

title: From Carnegie Hall, Pianist Coming to SUNY
description: WHEN Arturo Toscanini conducted Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" for the first and only time in his career (in 1942), his soloist was a 27-year old staff pianist at NBC. In the years since, Earl Wild has won worldwide renown for his virtuoso performances, his dozens of superb recordings, his many fascinating keyboard transcriptions and his sensitive work as a teacher.

title: Soccer Body Opposes Mexico
description: The governing body of soccer in North and Central America and the Caribbean said it would oppose Mexico's attempt to participate in next summer's South American championship.

title: Brilliant Stars in Bad Plays
description: THE HOUSE OF BARRYMORE By Margot Peters. Illustrated. 642 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: The Dodge Stealth Roars Into View
description: FOR a long time now, there have been stories and murmurs regarding a couple of pulse-quickening prospects from Chrysler Corporation.

title: Development Rights, Affordable Housing
description: The article "State Program Keeps 'Em Down on the Farm" (Oct. 28) underestimates the significant economic and social costs of the state program of buying development rights from farmers. Obviously, for the state to pay $8,000 to 9,000 an acre for such rights appears a bit frivolous during a time of economic and budget crisis.

title: Songs With a Cult Following
description: REMEMBER "The Yearling"? Not the novel by Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings (Pulitzer Prize, 1939).

title: Campus Life: Illinois; Squash Perfume Lures Beetles To Their Deaths
description: Two University of Illinois re searchers have developed a pest-control method based on "squash perfume" that they say is 99 percent effective against beetles attracted to it and is environmentally safe to boot.

title: Kristin Egan and Tyson Reed to Wed
description: The engagement of Kristin Ann Egan to Tyson Carter Reed, a son of Mrs. Harold Williams of Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Richard C. Reed of Hanover, N.H., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William P. Egan of Natick, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: Land Mine Kills 5 Policemen And 5 Hindus Die in Punjab
description: A land mine thought to have been planted by Sikh extremists exploded today under a police jeep in the state of Punjab, killing five policemen, a district official said.

title: Kathy Mahler Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Mahler of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathy M. Mahler, to Ian Kansky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Kansky of New City, N.Y. An April wedding is planned. Miss Mahler and Mr. Kansky are 24 years old and graduates of the State University at Albany. She is a marketing specialist at Merrill Lynch & Company and Mr. Kansky is an office manager at the brokerage house of R. J. Kross Associates, both in New York.

title: Data Update
Homeless in Berkeley Could Get Campsites
description: Homeless people in Berkeley could soon have the chance to pitch tents on an undetermined number of vacant lots, which would be turned into urban campsites.

title: The Yen Goes a Bit Soft
Now Lyons: 64 Squares in Search of a Master
description: It was in Lyons this time, but to the clannish world of chess the scene was as familiar as the 64 squares that rule their lives.

title: Chicago Journal; Seeking New Harmony, But Finding a Racial Rift
description: It was a Chicago writer, Finley Peter Dunne, who coined the expression, "All politics is local." In recent years, it might be said of Chicago, "All local politics is racial."

title: Campus Life: Michigan; An Elusive Pet Turns a Dormitory Upside Down
description: Dog, a four-foot python that pulled a sneaky escape act from Aaron Hammer's room in the University of Michigan's Couzens residence hall, was finally spotted last Monday in a storage room, hiding between fireplace logs, after a two-and-a-half-week search that turned the building upside down.

title: Fire Companies Offer Novel Benefits To Lure More Volunteers
description: FIREFIGHTING in Connecticut remains largely the work of volunteers whose boots wait by the door until the siren wails. But changes in the way people live are compelling fire companies to redefine the volunteer service.

title: Here Today, But Tomorrow?
description: For a few select videos these days -- some of them big new films and others specialized titles with wide appeal -- one way to grab attention is to get scarce. Studio strategy is to offer the releases to distributors and retailers for limited periods, then cut off orders; in stores cutoff titles often do their runs in limited numbers before staging official withdrawals from the shelves. In the trade the term is moratorium; the object, of course, is to drive up immediate demand.

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: FICTION
description: AFTER THE BOMBS. By Arturo Arias. Translated by Asa Zatz. (Curbstone, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $10.95.) True to its title, the Guatemalan writer Arturo Arias's horrific, satirical first novel tells the story of a boy's youth in Guatemala City in the aftermath of the American-backed 1954 coup that toppled the civilian Government and initiated a series of repressive military regimes. Maximo Sanchez grows up in a climate of ignorance, knowing nothing of his "disappeared" father or of a peaceful life. "After the Bombs" describes the reigns of terror of corrupt generals and the constant fear experienced by a corrupted, intimidated populace. Torture is endemic and arbitrary, brazenly conducted in public. Executions are treated like sporting events. Books and writing are illegal, illiteracy is encouraged and school is usually called off, although students continue to be promoted. In depicting this scenario, Mr. Arias creates vivid, cartoonlike scenes that have the horror of nightmares. In a work filled with symbolism, his characters are caricatures and grotesques; his staccato, truncated style, ably rendered in Asa Zatz' translation, conveys immediacy as well as brutality. Mr. Arias, who is primarily known to American readers as the co-author of the film script for "El Norte," has produced a powerfully disturbing work. In the novel, Americans are not only the agents of doom, the men who dropped the bombs on innocent civilians; they themselves also emerge, as the plot twists into the future, as both victims and saviors.

title: Opponents Remain Wary as Pipeline Construction Approaches
description: AFTER a four-year fight, backers of the newly approved $600 million natural-gas pipeline from Canada to Long Island say that they are hoping to begin construction in Connecticut in the early spring.

title: Iraq Tries to Offset U.S. Weapons With Low-Technology Strategies
description: Iraqi military commanders are taking steps to offset the technological superiority that will be the United States' major military advantage in any Persian Gulf conflict, American defense and intelligence specialists say.

title: Celery Root: Out of the Bistro and Into the Kitchen
description: CELERY root is a gnarled monster of vegetable, but it conceals a tender heart. Its flesh is pale ivory in color and delicate in flavor. This vegetable, a cousin of common celery, is cultivated for its root rather than its stalk.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: PATRICIA GRIFFIN and her two children started this year living in a single room at the Carlton, one of Newark's biggest welfare hotels. They had spent a dreary Christmas there. They had marked a bleak New Year's there. They worried they might be in that room for a long time.

title: Camera
description: It's the time of year for lists: shopping lists, gift lists, wish lists, maybe-next-year lists. If your lists include a camera or two, chances are you'll need some way of sorting through the myriad models available today.

title: The Real Reason
description: To the Editor: The article bemoaning the lack of American conductors leading the American "big five" orchestras (a term as outmoded and provincial as the idea that an American must lead one of these orchestras) raises a question.

title: What Started at Blood River
description: THE MIRROR AT MIDNIGHT A South African Journey. By Adam Hochschild. 309 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95. FIGHTING YEARS Black Resistance and the Struggle for a New South Africa. By Steven Mufson. Illustrated. 360 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $24.95.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Sharon, Mass.;
Toll Takeover Progressing
description: TOLL BROTHERS of Philadelphia has taken over the building of a 212-home complex here from Skanco Sharon-Foxboro Development, a subsidiary of a Swedish developer, and the first six houses are under construction. They are to be ready for occupancy in January.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MOMMY DOESN'T KNOW MY NAME By Suzanne Williams. Illustrated by Andrew Shachat. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: Marcy Lefkowitz, Producer, Is Wed
description: Marcy Rachel Lefkovitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudy Lefkovitz of Plainview, L.I., and Steven Howard Saltzman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Saltzman of New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Leonard Gordon, a brother-in-law of the bride, officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: 'Final Analysis'
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy   George Johnson
description: BATTLE FOR JUSTICE: How the Bork Nomination Shook America, by Ethan Bronner. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) When Robert Bork was nominated for a seat on the United States Supreme Court, he and his conservative allies considered him a sure thing. In documenting what went wrong, Ethan Bronner has written a book whose strength "is in the personal details of the story, expertly elicited and sympathetically conveyed," Garry Wills said in The Book Review last year.

title: Woodard Hits Six 3-Pointers As Villanova Defeats L.S.U.
description: All Greg Woodard of Villanova needed was some encouragement.

title: 'Final Analysis'
description: To the Editor:

title: Perspectives: Multifamily Workouts; The Listing Ship of Overfinanced Rentals
description: IN moderate-income neighborhoods of New York City, the late 80's were a time of feverish property buying by a handful of owners. Prices were paid by some on the basis of heady expectations of what rents might be expected in the short term for upgraded buildings, and how successfully they might be converted to co-ops.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'AFRICA OYE!'

title: Miss Pomerantz to Wed Kevin Davis
description: February wedding plans for Susan Meredith Pomerantz and Kevin Roger Davis have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Sandford Furman of Tenafly, N.J., and John J. Pomerantz of New York. Mr. Davis is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Davis of London.

title: The Droll European Ad
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Hospital Receives $25 Million Gift
description: The Starr Foundation of New York is giving $25 million to begin a 10-year modernization program at New York Hospital. The philanthropy's gift will enable the medical center to begin work immediately on a new 12-story wing to be built over the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, housing 600 beds and operating rooms.

title: Moira O'Hanlon Wed in Armonk
description: Moira Catherine O'Hanlon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. O'Hanlon of Armonk, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William Edward Bubeck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Bubeck of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Thomas J. Tolentino performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: If It's Broke, Why Not Fix It?
description: REMAKING SOCIETY Pathways to a Green Future. By Murray Bookchin. 222 pp. Boston: South End Press. Cloth, $25. Paper, $10.

title: Ideas & Trends; For Immigrants, Tough Customers
description: JOHN EDWARDS sometimes hears from angry customers who come into his clothing shop in Chicago's mostly black Roseland neighborhood, bringing their complaints about the Korean merchants whose stores are up and down 113th Street.

title: Wine; ORIGINAL ZIN
description: In London some years back, the writer Hugh Johnson and a few of his friends decided to form a club for fans of American wines. They called it the Zinfandel Club.

title: Riding the Mali Express to Dakar
description: IN parts of the world where you know neither the language nor the local procedures, things appear to happen magically. A visa stamped at a border, a passenger arriving at a destination, the mere existence of a printed schedule -- it can all seem quite marvelous. This is especially true in West Africa, where much is chaotic, and time has little meaning.

title: The Getty's Grand Collection
description: IN his heyday in the 1940's, the oil billionaire J. Paul Getty liked nothing better than to retreat to his 65-acre citrus ranch in the Santa Monica Mountains overlooking Los Angeles and the Pacific Ocean, there to contemplate the landscape and the collection of art he had built up over the years. But it was only after he left the United States in 1951 to spend the rest of his life in Europe that he conceived of a museum on those grounds that would, as he put it in his private diaries, compare to Hadrian's Villa in Tivoli, Italy, or Hearst's castle at San Simeon, Calif., and stand as "my Taj Mahal."

title: And the Bettors Say . . .
description: At the I. Morris Ltd. betting shop in this city's Holland Park section, Michael Heseltine is known as "the Assassin" for knocking off Margaret Thatcher as Britain's Prime Minister.

title: England
description: To the Editor: At the Shap Wells Hotel dining room (in Shap, in the Lake District of England) you must interpret the small print on the menu. If you order from the a la carte menu you will be surcharged $23 for the fixed-price dinner. Since my wife and I did not read the small print we were charged an extra $46. I made a vociferous protest but to no avail. Luckily I paid with my Visa card, and after three weeks of negotiating the charge was dropped. RAY FINKELSTEIN Great Neck, L.I. S. W. Simpson of the Shap Wells Hotel replies: Mr. and Mrs. Finkelstein stayed with us for two nights. They had dinner in our restaurant one night and ordered alternative dishes from our a la carte menu. The charges on this menu are in addition to the fixed-price menu charge. Their extra charges were $20. The total charge for the dinner was $66. We make no attempt to hide the extra charge; it is clearly printed at the top of the a la carte menu. We have not made any reduction to their bill, so any refund that has been made must have come from the credit card company.

title: NOT EXACTLY THE BEST MAN
description: I sympathize with Garfinkel's frustration at not being able to come up with the nomenclature for his ex-wife's new husband. After rejecting such terms as "former husband's current wife" and "first husband's second wife," I coined a term that was immediately understandable to almost everyone: "wife-in-law." SANDY WAGNER Fairfax, Va.

title: A Provocative Look at Collaborations
description: AFTER they had co-founded the exhibition service Independent Curators Incorporated, Susan Sollins remained its director and Nina Castelli Sundell departed, to become, eventually, head of the Lehman College Art Gallery and, more recently, an independent curator on her own. Now, the two have come together again, their purpose to celebrate the organization's 15th anniversary. And what better way to do this than with a show about collaborating artists?

title: 11-0? Eagles Say No Way Eagles' Runners Are Ready to Adjust
description: WHEN Heath Sherman was an undergraduate and running back at Texas A&I, he discovered that studying psychology was as interesting as studying game film or memorizing a playbook. The Philadelphia Eagles made him their sixth-round draft choice in 1989, and immediately upon his arrival with the team, he found that his new teammates and his new locker room offered an unusual case study.

title: Running Hard to Stay in Place
description: ARAFAT In the Eyes of the Beholder. By Janet Wallach and John Wallach. Illustrated. 465 pp. New York: A Lyle Stuart Book/Carol Publishing Group. $19.95.

title: Bridge
description: A dozen players from the New York metropolitan area were happy a week ago, in spite of a small silver cloud in the lining. They had qualified for the national playoffs in the North American Pair Championships, with an expenses-paid trip to the Spring Nationals. But as this tournament, next March, is in Atlantic City, the amount of traveling silver they will receive from the American Contract Bridge League will be trivial. They would have preferred a free trip to San Francisco, where the Fall Nationals are now in progress.

title: NOT EXACTLY THE BEST MAN
description: I read with interest Perry Garfinkel's About Men article, "Not Exactly the Best Man" (Oct. 14), as I, too, am a member of a blended family. In my case, my husband and I have a son, Stevie, and we share parenting of my husband's two daughters, Liz and Sarah, with his former wife. Our son, now 8, has been visiting with his sisters and their mother, Maureen, at least weekly since he was a baby. When still quite small, he noticed that my relationship with Liz and Sarah had a name ("stepmother"); apparently surmising that it was a reciprocal arrangement, he began to call Maureen the same thing. Adults do a double take when Stevie reports spending the night or going boating with his "stepmother," but since there is no other name for his close relationship with my husband's former wife, we have kept it as the best alternative. For Stevie, "stepmother" has no pejorative connotation. MELANIE MOREL SULLIVAN New Orleans

title: Tea Factories Shut After Threats by Militants
description: Indian tea producers, panicked by threats by an extremist movement in the tea-growing northeastern state of Assam, have closed several factories and tea gardens and have evacuated dozens of managers.

title: Botanical Garden Prepares for Centennial
description: THE New York Botanical Garden is just four miles south of the Westchester County line, about a 20-minute drive down the Bronx River Parkway from White Plains. This is nothing new, but under its current president, Gregory R. Long, the garden has had a change in attitude.

title: Anne K. Albright Is Wed in Capital
description: Anne Korbel Albright, a daughter of Madeleine Korbel Albright and Joseph Medill Patterson Albright, both of Washington, was married yesterday to Geoffrey Roland Watson, a son of Elizabeth Robinson Watson of New York and Vals-les-Bains, France, and Edward J. Watson of Bar Harbor, Me. The Rev. William Billow, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Washington Cathedral.

title:
IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: FICTION;
Women and Other Foreigners
description: LOOKING FOR HOME: Women Writing About Exile. Edited by Deborah Keenan and Roseann Lloyd. (Milkweed Editions, Paper, $11.95.) Women have often used the metaphor of exile to describe their position at the margins of our culture. Those wishing to enter the American mainstream frequently feel divided between traditionally female values and the male-defined values of the marketplace; they struggle to shape the culture they enter, rather than be shaped by it. Given this context, we can doubly welcome the publication of "Looking for Home: Women Writing About Exile," an anthology of poetry written by women of diverse backgrounds, all with different definitions of alienation. Some of the poems describe the experience of learning a new language; some present women who want to hoard the words of their native tongue, to keep them safe, as Meredith Stricker writes, "against the enemy's decoding." There are poems about migration, the pulls of conflicting allegiances, the weight of history and the search for a unified self. Others tell stories of economic deprivation, chemical dependency and illness, of life as a lesbian in a culture hostile to sexual nonconformity. The collection includes work by poets as familiar as Sharon Olds and Denise Levertov, as well as poems by unknown writers. Its principle of organization remains somewhat obscure -- it is divided into seven sections with elusive quotations as titles, and even within one section two poems from one writer may or may not be placed together. Yet the anthology richly communicates both the singularity and the universality of women's deepest concerns. The poems that the editors, Deborah Keenan and Roseann Lloyd, have chosen may be more or less sophisticated in their technique, but they rarely strike a false note, and in most of them one hears language freighted with experience, the real voices of real women.

title: News Is Silent on Cuomo's Offer to Mediate
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo again offered to intervene as a mediator in the strike at The Daily News, and was again rebuffed by the paper's management, he said yesterday.

title: Gas Pipeline Leak Closes Part of Arthur Kill
description: The Coast Guard closed a section of the Arthur Kill for three hours yesterday morning after natural gas erupted from a pipeline there, sending a column of water 15 feet into the air, a Coast Guard official said.

title: Rags to Wretches
description: THE FASHION CYCLE A Behind-the-Scenes Look at a Year With Bill Blass, Liz Claiborne, Donna Karan, Arnold Scaasi, and Adrienne Vittadini. By Irene Daria. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: The 'Arch Henchman'
description: THE TRIAL OF IVAN THE TERRIBLE State of Israel vs. John Demjanjuk. By Tom Teicholz. Illustrated. 354 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $22.95.

title: Japanese Believed Near Purchase Of the Owner of Universal Studios
description: MCA Inc., one of the nation's largest entertainment companies, and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan are expected to announce as early as today that Matsushita is acquiring MCA.

title: Humor Carries Serious Message on AIDS
description: A GROUP of 150 middle school students gathered recently at the First Congregational Church in Madison for a performance of an unusual road show. The youngsters, from shoreline towns from Guilford to Essex, gave their rapt attention to a powerful performance that dealt with the facts and fallacies about AIDS.

title: Parents Can Still Help the Hyperactive Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Travels With My Editor
description: DEPARTURE Day Minus One: Tomorrow I am going to fly from San Juan, P.R., to Istanbul. That a flight can link these two cities seems exceptionally improbable. I am writing the chapter on the western coast of Turkey for a guidebook. This is an area that I have let my editor think that I know with an intimacy perhaps greater than I actually possess. Furthermore, I have reason to suspect that much of my time in Turkey was spent before the editor was born. (In a recent telephone conversation, she had characterized another contributor as "remarkably active" for a man of 50; I am 48.) Toward dawn, I awaken my husband.

title: Anatole Broyard, 1920-90
description: Anatole Broyard, who was a daily book reviewer at The New York Times for nearly 15 years and an editor of The Book Review for three years, died on Oct. 11 at the age of 70. The critic Alfred Kazin delivered the following remarks at a memorial service on Oct. 29 in Southport, Conn.

title: Bettina Palatine Rice Is Wed to James Hackett
description: Bettina Palatine Rice, a daughter of Irene P. Rice of Southbury, Conn., and Alan B. Rice of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to James Hackett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Hackett of Edgewood, R.I. The Rev. Roger Gagne performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Edgewood.

title:
IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: NONFICTION;
Lords of the Rings
description: For many people, including too many historians of popular culture, the modern American circus means Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey and little else. STEP RIGHT UP! The Adventure of Circus in America (Betterway Publications, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $19.95) goes a long way toward correcting that misconception. It celebrates the renaissance of the circus during the last decade and lovingly salutes the tenacious entrepreneurs who have held on through adversity over generations. Tent shows take center ring here and names like Circus Vargas, Clyde Beatty-Cole Brothers, Carson & Barnes, Franzen Brothers and Kelly-Miller are spotlighted, as well as such new wave productions as the Pickle Family Circus, the Big Apple Circus and Canada's Cirque du Soleil. The authors, LaVahn G. Hoh, a professor of drama at the University of Virginia, and William H. Rough, an independent scholar, are circus buffs who relish the details of how the shows move from town to town, how the performers and crews get fed and the minutiae of circus finance. Many of the more than 300 illustrations are unusual for a circus book -- details of decaying circus wagons or close-ups of the bale ring used to hoist a tent. This is an intimate and folksy book: managers and roustabouts are called by their first names and readers are made privy to their various physical ailments and financial reversals. "Step Right Up!" is also the first general study of the circus to examine in any detail the history of black and female performers. Unfortunately, the authors' style undermines the book. Early on they state, "We are not historians," and their writing confirms this. The tortured prose, erratic footnoting, absurd generalizations ("No one played music in colonial America"; "the total collapse of known civilization at the end of the Roman Empire") and especially the silly pop psychology that substitutes for cogent analysis cry out for excision at every turn. Nonetheless, the authors' unabashed love of the circus is contagious and the glimpses behind the scenes will delight circus enthusiasts.

title: Fine Season for Viewing 42 Outdoor Sculptures
description: In the crisp air of fall, the sculptures that surround the headquarters of Pepsico seem to dominate the landscape. The foliage has retreated, ceding the broad lawns of this corporate center to monumental artwork. It is both soothing and disturbing.

title: Mutual Funds; The Hot New Global Income Funds
description: WHEN it comes to mutual fund marketing, only three things matter: yield, yield and yield. So that's what folks think about when they dream up new fund products, and they've hit the jackpot with short-term global income funds.

title: The Region; In Successes and Failures, A Glimpse of the Future?
description: TO regional planners and ecologists, Long Island has become both a leading example of the pressures of development and a laboratory for efforts to improve the quality of the environment. Its strategies for conserving water and electricity have met with some success, but problems caused by garbage and traffic congestion have proved much more troublesome. In the long run, Long Island's experience may serve as a guide for other areas of the country that are grappling with the same issues.

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: FICTION
description: SEPTUAGENARIAN STEW: Stories & Poems. By Charles Bukowski. (Black Sparrow Press, Cloth, $25; Paper, $14.) Charles Bukowski loves to present himself as a crusty arrogant old man, proud of his years spent as a heavy-drinking bum, living the low life and thumbing his nose at the literary world and bourgeois society in general. In this regard, he shares company with William Burroughs, but while Mr. Burroughs specializes in weirdly vivid imagery and nearly hysterical satire, Mr. Bukowski's prose reflects bemused wonder at life's ongoing and all too familiar atrocities. In "Septuagenarian Stew," his subjects are nearly always the same: drinking and womanizing; hanging out in bars, at the racetrack, in low-rent neighborhoods and low-down apartments; once in a while being recognized as the great writer fallen on hard times. Elsewhere, however, Mr. Bukowski's authorial persona, having come into some money from an indulgent publisher, rather relishes the good life he has so long eschewed. Aside from the rather harrowing story "Son of Satan," in which a group of young toughs nearly succeeds in murdering a friend, most of the stories in this collection never get off the ground. Mr. Bukowski doesn't empathize with others -- especially not with women -- and the further characters stray from his own likeness, the flatter they become. His loosely constructed poems range from narratives forced into staggered lines to spare meditations leavened by a knowing wit. At best Mr. Bukowski comes across as a benign, somewhat bewildered spirit capable of surprising insights, at worst as a lazy writer unwilling to push his language to produce something extraordinary.

title: Polished Surfaces and Difficult Pastorals
description: THE REST OF THE WAY By J. D. McClatchy. 81 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. HOUSE OF LIGHT By Mary Oliver. 80 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $14.95. NEW POEMS: 1980-88 By John Haines. 93 pp. Brownsville, Ore.: Story Line Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Janet Blume and Allan Bower to Wed
description: The engagement of Dr. Janet A. Blume to Dr. Allan Francis Bower, a son of Dr. Yvette Bower and Dr. Edward Bower of Cambridge, England, has been announced by her parents, Dr. Sheila B. Blume and Dr. Martin Blume of Sayville, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: With Thatcher Gone, Labor Party Loses Lead in Polls
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's resignation has stunned the opposition Labor Party, erasing its lead in public opinion polls and leaving it with few clearly perceived policy differences with the governing Conservatives.

title: But Would Drexel Have Done the Deal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Sunday about Stan Z. Burns, a broadcaster at radio station WINS, omitted the cause of death. He died of cancer, family members said.

title: Past Catches Up With Convict, Who Faces a Stiffer Sentence
description: A man who was imprisoned for nearly five years under a false name was finally tripped up and correctly identified, and now faces a stiffer sentence because of a criminal background that the authorities could not previously link to him.

title: IN SHORT/SMALL PRESSES: FICTION
description: RUNAWAY. By Mary Clearman Blew. (James R. Hepworth/Confluence Press, Lewis-Clark State College, Lewiston, Idaho 83501-2698, Paper, $8.95.) At the funeral supper after her father's death, a woman is caught and held by the prints and paintings of Western life on the dining-room walls around her. "Specific and faithful," these images of last stands and cattle roundups seem to her "a celebration of the least detail of a twilight world." Mary Clearman Blew, who grew up on a Montana ranch, certainly knows this world, which is evoked with great immediacy in her second collection of short stories. In "Runaway," Ms. Blew makes readers privy to the clanking, dusty, bloody, reeking reality of home on the range. Oddly enough, although her stories with male narrators are particularly powerful, Ms. Blew is less convincing in her attempts to portray women who may bear some resemblance to herself -- women who have broken from the ranching culture to pursue a life of the mind. In stories like "College Bound 1957" and "Granddaughters," the point of view is uneven, the author's voice intrusive. And yet, at her best, Ms. Blew can write of other women with great force. In "Bare Trees," for example, a tragic, immensely fat girl welcomes death with open arms. Elsewhere, a tomboy and her cousin strip a Hutterite girl of her heavy clothing while outside their fathers shear the fleece from bewildered sheep. And, in the title story, the destiny of a failed nun and a feisty bay mare link in a wild, breakaway ride. Some of Ms. Blew's stories draw characters from a single family, and the mysterious death of a Scottish sheepherder also haunts several tales. Here, as we hunker on our heels by the campfire, the storyteller's voice drops low and an older world comes vividly back to life.

title: 'Final Analysis'
description: To the Editor:

title: HUSSEIN PROMISING TO FREE 11 BRITONS
description: In a gesture that Western diplomats said was a cynical effort to entice more foreigners to visit Iraq and become "human shields," President Saddam Hussein announced tonight that he would free 11 Britons whose wives and children had traveled to Iraq to rescue them.

title: THE RUSSIAN CHARACTER
description: If Hedrick Smith is interested in the Russian character, he might study Russians who came to the United States as young men and women after World War II. Enough time has elapsed to form conclusions. He will find that Russians who live in a free society, under a rational government, like to get ahead and succeed -- and they work hard at it.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Another 48 Hours 1990. Paramount. $91.95. Laser disk, $24.98. 1 hour, 38 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Sports People; Little Big Shots
description: HE was listed near the bottom of the roster of the team his family's newspaper sponsored 35 years ago and there are no statistics available on how he did at bat or afield, but Vice President Dan Quayle will become the third inductee to the Little League Hall of Excellence, joining the former major league pitcher, Tom Seaver, and the basketball star-turned-United States Senator, Bill Bradley.

title:
ENVIRONMENTAL BOOKS;

Grass Routes
description: GREENWAYS FOR AMERICA. By Charles E. Little. (Johns Hopkins University, $22.95.) Our system of land use may have lost much of its legitimacy and the planning profession may have few new ideas to offer, but Charles E. Little sees greenways as a grass-roots source of positive change. Greenways are protected natural areas; most are used for recreation such as hiking or biking, although some are designed primarily to protect environmental resources. Central to the greenway concept is the idea of linkage: creating connections among recreational resources, natural resources and communities. Mr. Little, whose previous books include "Challenge of the Land" and "Green Fields Forever," sees such networks as providing the framework for regional planning. "Greenways for America" makes clear that greenways have provided recreation, environmental enhancement, economic stimulus and civic pride in widely varied situations. Mr. Little concludes that to make a greenway is to make a community. The projects that the author visited are located across the country, from the San Juan Islands in Washington to the Hudson River Valley, and are "as rich and diverse as human ingenuity and topographic opportunity could make them." Mr. Little is an enthusiastic journalist with both an eye and an ear for local history and politics. With a few colorful strokes he brings to life the unconventional people he met along the way. His text ranges from the history of the greenway concept to an examination of the types of greenways he identified. During his greenway reconnaissance, Mr. Little found the tenacity and ingenuity that we want to believe continue to define the American character. And he provides many practical ideas for people who would follow suit.

title: Iowa Loses And Wins
description: MINNESOTA brought home the bacon by beating Iowa, 31-24, but the Hawkeyes bagged the big one, anyway. They backed into the Big Ten Conference championship and a trip to Pasadena to play Washington in the Rose Bowl when Michigan knocked off Ohio State, 16-13. Minnesota's victory brought it Floyd of Rosedale, a bronze pig that has gone to the winner of the Iowa-Minnesota game since 1935, when the original, live, Floyd, was put up for grabs.

title: The World; East Europe's Women Struggle With New Rules, and Old Ones
description: A CZECH journalist, asked recently to examine the puzzling absence of women from public life in Eastern Europe's new democracies, offered a simple explanation. "Maids," she said, and she was only half joking. "The day we have someone to help us will be the day we have the time and energy to get into politics."

title: A Dangerous Species
description: CONDUCT UNBECOMING The Rise and Ruin of Finley, Kumble.By Steven J. Kumble and Kevin J. Lahart.Illustrated. 312 pp. New York:Carroll & Graf. $19.95.

title: Free Agency Won't Set Players Free
description: THE United States Supreme Court will determine soon whether it is going to decide the case of Powell v. National Football League. This is the most important sports-law decision in several years. At issue is whether the N.F.L.'s free-agency system violates antitrust law. The litigation is an outgrowth of the defeat of the players' union in the 1987 strike. The plaintiff, Marvin Powell, a former offensive lineman for the New York Jets and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, was the president of the N.F.L. Players Association at the time the suit was filed in October 1987.

title: Park Debate Continues
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Solo Engagements For Young Artists
description: YOUNG artists are in the solo spotlight at three symphonic concerts this week, starting on Friday evening at 8, when Leila Josefowicz makes her debut with Thomas Crawford and the Fairfield Orchestra. The violinist will play a Heifetz favorite, the E Minor Concerto by the Russian composer Jules Conus. Also on the program at the Norwalk Concert Hall are Delius's "Walk to the Paradise Garden," the world premiere of David Leisner's "Dances in the Madhouse" and Brahms's Fourth Symphony. For tickets, call 255-1160.

title: On Language; The Mood of 'Tude
description: To most of us, an attitude is something a person has: a cheerful frame of mind or a negative outlook. The word is neutral, requiring some modifier to tell us what kind of attitude we're talking about.

title: Golf World Cup Is Set for Rome
description: Next year's World Cup of Golf will be played at the Italian Golf Federation's course in Rome, officials announced today.

title: Lauren Osborne, Editor, to Marry
description: Lauren Melanie Osborne, an editor at the Harvard University Press in Cambridge, Mass., and Robert Charles Lieberman, a candidate for a Ph.D. in political science at Harvard, plan to marry in June.

title: Islanders a Match for Rangers
description: Although the Rangers and the Islanders have met only twice this season, their encounters have evoked memories of the days they were both highly competitive, a contrast with their current positions at opposite ends of the standing.

title: Teams Go to School at N.I.T.
description: For the four college basketball teams that made it to Madison Square Garden this week, the Dodge National Invitation Tournament offered valuable lessons.

title: Chess Match Resumes With Tricks and Traps
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov adjourned Game 13 of the World Championship Chess Match in Lyons, France, last night in a tricky, trappy rook-and-pawn ending. Karpov wrote his 42d move and sealed it in the referee's offical envelope until 5 this afternoon when the game is to resume. Pending the outcome of this game, the match is tied at 6-6.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The paint on our clapboard house begins to peel shortly after being applied, despite careful preparation of the clapboard surfaces each time. Since most of the peeling is on the north side of the house, I assume that humidity is the chief cause. Might venting of the wall spaces be the way to go, or is this likely to greatly reduce the efficiency of the insulation and thus waste too much energy?

title:
MUSIC;
Professional Concerts Arranged by Volunteers
description: WITH determination inspired by a passion for having culture in their own communities, the volunteer administrators of Atlantic City Community Concerts operate the organization with a brand of perseverance that might well run a major corporation. Although there's not a professional administrator in the group, the association presents concerts four times a year that could be the product of any full-time professional concert presenter.

title: Spectacle - but With a Ninja Twist
description: At the outset of "Shogun," the sumptuous musical that has been wrested -- and I do mean wrested -- from James Clavell's sprawling novel about feudal Japan, a crackle of lightning dances across the black lacquered screen that serves as a curtain at the Marquis Theater.

title: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund Begins Its 79th Annual Appeal
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begins its 79th annual appeal today in the midst of economic hard times, making the needs of the poor all the greater but contributions all the harder to raise.

title: Proper Way to Hang Mirrors
description: MIRRORS, especially large ones, can be tricky to hang. Because they are heavy and fragile, caution is needed when handling them, and wall fasteners must be installed carefully.

title: Army Leaving Hockey League
description: The Army hockey team will take on Division I independent status beginning with the 1991-92 season, the school announced on Friday.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Existing home sales for October. TUESDAY: Balance of payments for the third quarter. * Conference Board releases its consumer confidence index for November. * Former chairman of Ashland Oil to be sentenced in New York for conspiracy and wire fraud. * Auto sales for mid-November. WEDNESDAY: Appeals court hearing in New York for Leona Helmsley.* Durable goods orders for October. * Corporate profits and revised gross national product for the third quarter. * The Treasury auctions five-year notes. THURSDAY: Personal income and consumption expenditures for October. * The Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills. FRIDAY: Index of leading economic indicators for October. * December heating oil and gasoline contracts expire.

title: 'Songs of the Doomed'
description: SAIGON, May 1975. The city is about to fall to the National Liberation Front. The last American reporters left in the besieged capital are calculating when to fly out before the honorable desire to stay to the bloody end becomes merely suicidal. Meanwhile, Hunter S. Thompson has just flown in to the encircled city with $30,000 in cash taped to his body (don't ask). Only to learn he has been fired by Rolling Stone (some bitter dispute with its publisher, Jann Wenner, over a book advance) and both his medical insurance and his Telex card link to the outside world have been canceled by the magazine.

title: Hofstra Remains Unbeaten
description: Bring on the Warriors of Lycoming. That was the message today from Hofstra's unbeaten team, which advanced to the semifinals of the Division III tournament with a 38-3 victory over Trenton State.

title: 'Final Analysis'
description: To the Editor:

title: So You Think It's Easy to Hang a Picture?
description: As the Guggenheim Museum tinkers with an expansion plan -- most recently proposing changes to the facade of a new wing that is already under construction -- it is understandable if passers-by along Fifth Avenue seem fretful. Will Frank Lloyd Wright's structure give the impression of spiraling upward or downward when the results of the renovation are revealed next fall? Troublesome though it was to organize exhibitions in such an idiosyncratic space, and much as the museum needs room in which to display its extensive collection, the central court and curved walls of the Guggenheim have a grandeur and vigor that can make even minor works look significant.

title: Road Skid Ends For Nets at Last
description: The Nets ended their 34-game losing streak on the road, an National Basketball Association record, as Mookie Blaylock's baseline jumper with less than one second remaining beat the Phoenix Suns, 116-114, on Friday night.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: DR. DWIGHT T. JANERICH;
Hazards of Second-Hand Tobacco Smoke
description: MANY health-conscious Americans have stopped smoking in light of the evidence linking tobacco smoke to lung cancer and heart disease, but close to one-third of the adult population in the United States is still addicted to cigarette smoking. The American Cancer Society predicts that in 1990, 157,000 new cases of lung cancer will be diagnosed, and 142,000 Americans will die of the disease.

title: Coach's Bold Step Deserves Praise
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Psychobabble of the Doppelgangers
description: DREAM OF THE WOLF By Scott Bradfield. 240 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title:
MOUNT LAUREL JOURNAL;
At Pie Shop, Everyone Pitches In to Meet Holiday Demand
description: EACH year at Thanksgiving, custom blends tastefully with convenience in the four ovens that line the back wall of Godfrey's Farm Market on Route 38.

title: 'Peter Pan' Stops By On Way to Broadway
description: For Broadway-bound shows, the historic Shubert Theater in New Haven once represented the big stop before the big time. If only for the next two weeks, theater lovers can imagine the rebirth of that aspect of a golden age. And what more fitting show to fire one's fancy than the one about youth recaptured in Never-Never Land?

title: Mild Seasons And Low Taxes Bolster Market
description: Growing up on a farm in this western North Carolina mountain community (pop. 1,000) Bill Gibson often felt isolated from the world and considered it a treat to meet someone new. Now, Mr. Gibson, who is 42 years old, feels fortunate to see someone he knows.

title: If Black Gets $3 Million, Gooden Will Get . . .
description: AT one session during the general managers' meetings in Arizona earlier this month, two outside experts spoke on the art of contract negotiations. As part of their presentation, they offered a critique of a videotaped negotiating session.

title: AGAIN IN CAPITAL, A HOMICIDE RECORD
description: Although the percentage of killings related to drugs is down sharply, the District of Columbia has set a homicide record for the third consecutive year.

title: Can the Sanctions Work?  Many Aides Are Doubtful
description: But they added that despite these successes, the sanctions would not significantly hamper Iraq's military for at least six months. President Saddam Hussein, they say, has managed to protect vital civilian and military industries and services by manipulating his state-planned economy to shuffle resources. What Hussein Is Doing

title:
FORUM;
Untangle the State Regulatory Web
description: ACROSS Europe, lines of commerce will soon run virtually unbroken by national or continental boundaries, creating the largest and freest market in the world. After years of breast-beating, American companies may soon be stepping onto that near-mythical "level playing field." At long last, the rest of the world has begun to embrace our concept of unrestricted trade. The whole world, that is, except the United States.

title: A. S. Trefts Jr. Weds Victoria Leonhart
description: Victoria Andrea Leonhart, a daughter of former Ambassador and Mrs. William Leonhart of Washington, was married yesterday to Albert Sharpe Trefts Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Trefts of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Chautauqua, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Laird Jones performed the ceremony at the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church in Washington.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The paint on our clapboard house begins to peel shortly after being applied, despite careful preparation of the clapboard surfaces each time. Since most of the peeling is on the north side of the house, I assume that humidity is the chief cause. Might venting of the wall spaces be the way to go, or is this likely to greatly reduce the efficiency of the insulation and thus waste too much energy?

title: Hockey Puck Built for Speed
description: A former professional hockey player for the Montreal Canadiens, Mickey Keating of St. Paul, has developed a new puck that is designed to keep its momentum longer than standard pucks.

title: Defense and Patience Lift Orangemen
description: Some good defense early and patient offense late on Saturday night gave Syracuse a berth in the championship game of the Maui Invitational.

title: Review/Music; New Works for Quartet by Composers of 6 Nations
description: In its recordings, particularly 1987's "White Man Sleeps" and this year's "Black Angels," the Kronos Quartet has taken entirely unrelated works and made them into components in a cycle. The group has not always achieved that illusion of cohesiveness in its concerts. But it did so on Saturday evening, in the first of the three programs it is playing at Alice Tully Hall this season.

title: Winnipeg Wins Grey Cup
description: The Winnipeg Blue Bombers dominated the Canadian Football League championship game today, trouncing the favored Edmonton Eskimos, 50-11, in the 78th Grey Cup.

title: Dolphins (9-2) Gain on Bills
description: Dan Marino threw touchdown passes on Miami's first two possessions and reached 30,000 career passing yards faster than anyone in league history as the Miami Dolphins defeated the Cleveland Browns, 30-13, today.

title: David S. Lee Wed To Cathy A. Pohl
description: Cathy Anne Pohl, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pohl of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Stephen Lee, a son of Elaine L. Lee of Scarsdale and the late Edward Lee. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Richard Morell Wed To Susan Zuckerman
description: Susan Meredith Zuckerman, the daughter of Sol Zuckerman of the Bronx and the late Gwen Zuckerman, was married yesterday to Richard Charles Morell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Morell of Port St. Lucie, Fla. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel and Justice Nicholas Figueroa, of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated at the Union League Club in New York.

title: Helping Mend Broken Lives With Gifts to Neediest Cases
description: Her business-school classroom is only a few subway stops from the shelters where she used to spend her nights.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANTHONY HOPKINS has pulled out of a film based on "A Murder of Quality," by JOHN LE CARRE . Although Mr. Hopkins had agreed to play George Smiley, he did not like the script, which had been rewritten by Mr. le Carre.

title: Connecticut Water Service Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Century Medicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 185,512, or 4 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $ 107,591, or 3 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: Europe 1992 Changes Worry Caribbean Banana Farmers
description: Banana farmers in the Caribbean are worried about the economic changes in Europe, which they fear could kill their industry.

title: Bridge
description: Some internationally known stars on Saturday night captured the first major titles to be decided at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here.

title: Strange Wins Skins Playoff and $220,000
description: In the supposedly relaxed atmosphere of the Skins Game, Curtis Strange rediscovered both the fire in his belly and a hot putter today to dominate Greg Norman, Nick Faldo and Jack Nicklaus with some dramatic golf at the punishing Stadium Course at PGA West.

title: Review/Music; 'Judas Maccabaeus' Led by Gerard Schwarz at Y
description: The conductor Gerard Schwarz seems to be waging a quiet campaign to convince New Yorkers that the Handel oratorio most singularly appropriate to this season is not "Messiah," whose text points toward Easter more than Christmas, but "Judas Maccabaeus," which relates the story of Hanukkah. (Handel's own practice resolves nothing; he conducted "Messiah" only in March and April, "Maccabaeus" in February, March and April.)

title: Punk Rock and Military Jobs Lead to Mattel Video Games
description: William Novak, a top video game designer for Mattel Inc., is probably one of the few employees working for a $1 billion corporation with a resume that boasts of founding two punk rock record labels.
