title: AW Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRONICLE
description: Former Justice WILLIAM J. BRENNAN JR. will be the first McKay Distinguished Fellow at the New York University School of Law. Mr. Brennan, 84 years old, will be in residence one week each semester beginning next spring. He will visit classes, take part in seminars and preside at the finals of the moot court competition.

title: John Adams Life Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: U.S.to Auction Bills and Notes This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week includes today's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed tomorrow by an auction of two-year notes and Wednesday by an auction of five-year notes.

title: Ccair Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Circle Express Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company did not report share earnings results.Revenues represent operating revenues.

title: Survey Finds Most Clients Dissatisfied With Agencies
description: WHAT do clients think of their agencies? Anxious industry executives want to know -- especially during tough economic times when skittish advertisers are more likely to go looking for a new agency as a cure for sickly sales.

title: Micronetics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hawkins Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossYear-ago results are pro forma; the company was formed in December 1989, after limited partners in oil and gas drilling partnerships approved the exchange of Partnership United for common stock. The pro forma results reported for 1989 reflect the financial consolidation of separate business entities, each with its own restrictions and objectives.

title: Mirabella vs. Lear's: Stylish Fight
description: "The thing about age is that it's a phony issue," says Grace Mirabella, the founder of Mirabella magazine, enunciating the word "age" with elegant disdain. "Mirabella is more about a sensibility than an age."

title: New Telescope to Enable Mapping Of More Than a Million Galaxies
description: A project to map 100 times as much of the universe as ever mapped before, pinpointing in three dimension more than one million galaxies, was announced yesterday by astronomers from the University of Chicago, Princeton University and the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton.

title: Akorn Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Beard Oil Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company said that current results were severely impacted as a result of $ 2.84 million of dry hole cost attributable to the Sturgeon No. 1 Wildcat well in the Cook inlet of Alaska which was plugged and abandoned in October. Also, third quarter and year-to-date results were affected by the negative interest spread, amounting to $ 2 million for the quarter and $ 5.27 million for the 9 months, resulting from the $ 60 million shared appreciation debenture financing completed by the company in October 1989.

title: Books of The Times; Retracing the Tire Prints on a Philosophical Journey
description: Guidebook to 'Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance' By Ronald L. DiSanto and Thomas J. Steele 407 pages. William Morrow & Company. Cloth, $22.95; paper, $12.95.

title: Inflation Fear Is Said To Subside
description: Many credit market analysts say inflationary pressures have begun to ease significantly, even though oil prices remain substantially above the levels before Iraq invaded Kuwait and could go higher still if war erupts in the Persian Gulf.

title: Critic's Notebook; When What You Hear Isn't What's Onstage
description: At the MTV Video Awards two months ago, Rob Pilatus and Fab Morvan, better known as Milli Vanilli, declared themselves to be more talented than Bob Dylan and Paul McCartney. Mr. Dylan, when asked to comment on this assertion, asked a question of his own: "Who is Milli Vanilli?"

title: Middle-Class Blacks Try to Grip A Ladder While Lending a Hand
description: Joyce Ford, the daughter of laborers, fled the hand-to-mouth world of Washington's black housing projects and now has amenities of the middle class: a good job in the Government, an office across the street from the White House, a merit raise and an American Express card. But she still has the bone-deep worries of the poor.

title: Lawrence Jarvie, 84, Retired Educator, Dies
description: Dr. Lawrence L. Jarvie, an educator who helped to lead the postwar expansion of New York State's community colleges and served as a president of the Fashion Institute of Technology, died on Thursday at the Largo Medical Center in Florida. He was 84 years old and lived in Belleair, Fla.

title: Affluent Urged to Buy Now to Avoid Tax
description: Retailers are urging affluent consumers to buy expensive cars, boats, jewelry and furs before the new Federal "luxury tax" takes effect on Jan. 1. And many consumers appear to be accepting the advice, with some retailers of luxury goods reporting a surge in sales.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Better Tennis From the Easy Chair
description: THE Davis Cup final on ESPN this weekend all but wraps up the season's important tennis telecasts (the International Tennis Federation's Grand Slam Cup is scheduled for later in December). So it may be time to use the television to improve your own game.

title: Hong Kong Economy
description: The Hong Kong Government Friday revised the growth forecast for this British colony's gross domestic product in 1990 to 2.3 percent from 2.5 percent predicted in August. It also revised the inflation rate to 9.7 percent from 9.5 percent. The Government's chief economist, K. Y. Tang, said the colony's economy could have been hit harder by the slowdown in domestic exports to the United States, Britain and Japan if not for continued strong growth in re-exports, which involve goods assembled in Hong Kong of components made elsewhere.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Money Manager Guided By Father's Philosophy
description: Alan I. Greene, the managing partner of David J. Greene & Company, is concerned that the public will get the wrong idea from his firm's recent suggestion to a company it has invested in, the Shared Medical Systems Corporation, that a merger with a larger company be considered.

title: Ex-Wife of Stan Getz Testing a Divorce Law
description: Monica Getz's marriage to a famous jazz musician lives on, at least along the paneled walls of Shadowbrook, the mansion here where she makes her home, high above the Hudson. Above the staircase is a portrait of her with her former husband, the saxophonist Stan Getz, and their children. Nearby in the library is a snapshot taken in the halcyon days of their courtship.

title: Review/Ballet; Typical Hidden Depths In a Balanchine Work
description: More than even other Russian-born choreographers in the West, George Balanchine favored the composers of his native country. Not only did he repeatedly return to some -- especially Tchaikovsky -- but he also often used the same score more than once.

title: Compudyne Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $ 5,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and a loss of $ 114,000 for 9 months, both from discontinued operations.c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 277,000 and $ 273,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Metro Matters; Westway's Ghost Pays Off, Proving Skeptics Wrong
description: If the road to hell is paved with good intentions, just imagine where Manhattan's West Side Highway would lead.

title: Kimberly S. Grayson Wed to Robert Rizzuto
description: Kimberly S. Grayson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Grayson of Westport, Conn., and Robert P. Rizzuto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rizzuto of Old Brookville, L.I., were married yesterday at the Radisson Hotel in Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Robert Orkand officiated.

title: Energy Conversion Devices Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago revenues included gain of $ 2.3 million from sale of stock.

title: Useless?
description: "Mosses are biological widgets, useless inventions of a creator inordinately fond of the color green," says the plant ecologist Peter Dunwiddie. "They don't taste good, grow tall, supply valuable medicinal substances, or rally causes . . . as do, for example, the limpid eyes of a baby harp seal." So why does the Massachusetts Audubon Society's Mr. Dunwiddie spend hours "peering through a microscope at minute features of cell walls and leaf tips"?

title: Baker Is Right About 'Jobs' . . .
description: Secretary of State James Baker has introduced a curious new rationale for our changing Persian Gulf policies: jobs. "An economic recession worldwide, caused by the control by one nation -- one dictator if you will -- of the West's economic lifeline will result in the loss of jobs for American citizens," the Secretary tells us.

title: Market Place; An Ailing Buyout Tries a Buyback
description: WHEN Supermarkets General went private in 1987, in a deal completed just before the stock market crash, the company's expectations were for steady growth that would provide more than enough cash to meet its debt payments.

title: Johnson Worldwide Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 94,000 for the quarter and $ 34,000 for the year.

title: Aero Systems Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Acton Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 471,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 8,557,000, or $ 3.26 a share, for the 9 months.The losses for the latest quarter were primarily the result of the general decline in real estate markets, which necessitated writedowns totaling $ 4,297,000 of the carrying value of real estate held for development and sale, combined with a writedown of $ 1,500,000 to reflect what the company believed to be other than temporary declines in the value of its fixed maturity portfolio.

title: Academy Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $ 516,000 for the quarter and $ 1,677,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months.c-Net incomed-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 261,000 and $ 873,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.The company said the latest quarter was adversely affected by a charge to operations of $ 1.7 million from write-down of the carrying value of an investment in real estate in Valley Forge, Pa.The company also said results for the quarter included a charge to operations of about $ 350,000, representing start-up expenses associated with a joint venture formed to market and service personal lines property adn casualty products to the company's military market. It said the venture is now operational in eight states and expects to be in 20 states by year-end.

title: A Year Later, Youth Is Held In a Bronx Elevator Killing
description: A year to the day after a 37-year-old jazz saxophonist was shot to death in a Bronx elevator on Thanksgiving morning, the police arrested a 16-year-old youth who they said had killed the man for "staring him down" over a petty argument.

title: Cranston Acted Properly in Keating Case
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Taiwan Aims for High-Tech Niches
description: In the glass and steel buildings beyond the green lawns of this science park, Taiwan is trying to stage a new industrial revolution.

title: Rutgers Gains Semifinal
description: Quietly and methodically in recent years, Rutgers has been building a powerhouse soccer team, bringing the school the national recognition it has sought in football and basketball. This afternoon, the Rutgers team added to its stature by beating Dartmouth, 1-0, to reach the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I tournament for the second consecutive year.

title: The Year They Closed the Stock Market
description: The stock market reminds me of the old joke about the weather: Everybody complains, but nobody does anything about it. The securities markets are notoriously unreliable at predicting economic trends and even at assessing the real economic value of securities. Yet the markets keep getting busier.

title: Brady (W.H.) Co. (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
10 Die in Three Clashes Along Israel's Borders
description: Four Israelis were killed and more than two dozen wounded today when an Egyptian border policeman crept across the frontier, stationed himself in a ditch beside a highway and then opened fire on passing vehicles.

title: Possibility of War Sinks In As Iraqi Reserves Are Called
description: The notifications have already begun, and Khalil al-Said, a 27-year-old cloth merchant in the city's grand bazaar, said that he has many friends among the 150,000 Iraqi Army reservists who are being told this week to abandon their jobs and report for duty in occupied Kuwait.

title: Ares-Serono SA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said data per share are based on 209,468 Bearer shares and 835,330 registered shares (total equivalent number of Bearer shares 543,600).

title: Islanders Lose, 4-1, As Peeters Stars
description: Pete Peeters started the season as third in command among Flyer goaltenders, but he has carried his team in its last 11 games with inspiring performances, including one tonight that helped Philadelphia beat the Islanders, 4-1, at the Spectrum.

title: Contenders Line Up in Droves
description: Never before have there been so many contenders -- at least a dozen -- for college football's national championship, a crown always more ethereal than substantial, as the regular season comes to an end.

title: Direct-Mail Plan Upsets Newspapers
description: The newspaper industry is up in arms about a proposal by the United States Postal Service to create a new third-class mail category that could potentially cost newspapers millions of dollars in lost business.

title: Not Even Santa Is Off Limits in War of Words at News
description: The bitter labor war between The Daily News and its nine striking unions has been fought primarily in the streets, around the city's newsstands. But there has been another side to the five-week struggle, bloodless but equally ferocious: the fight for public sympathy, spearheaded on each side by a corps of professional public relations specialists.

title: Sudan Again Bombs Civilians in Rebel Areas
description: In a sortie over this rebel-held town on Nov. 13, a Sudanese Government plane dropped half a dozen bombs, killing 12 people and wounding more than 20 others.

title: Ira Glackens Dead; Biographer of Artists And a Diva Was 83
description: Ira Glackens, a writer who was the son of the realist painter William Glackens, died on Friday at his home in Shepherdstown, W.Va. He was 83 years old.

title: Eagles Slam Giants' Express
description: The Giants' unbeaten season is over. The Eagles beat the Giants soundly today, 31-13, with big plays from Randall Cunningham on offense and a relentless pass rush on defense.

description: A Pittsburgh- based drug maker has accused the American Cyanamid Company of violating a marketing agreement on a drug used to treat high blood pressure.

ON YOUR OWN;
Fitting a Bicycle Like a Fancy Outfit
description: WOULD you spend $500 or $1,000 on a suit or a dress that doesn't fit? So why would you do that when buying a bicycle? Jack Harrier has taken the inexact science of fitting a rider to a bicycle and tried to bring it to levels of comfort and efficiency never reached before.

title: Megamation Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Dance; When Taking All the Time In the World
description: Yasuko Anzai brought a remarkable stage presence to the two solos she danced on Saturday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. She knew how to command attention and magnetize her audience in these works she choreographed in collaboration with Toshiyuki Shikyo. But before the evening was over, she revealed that stage presence is not enough to make a performance satisfying.

title: Bush Visit to Highlight Caracas Chief's Role
description: If there is a world leader who works the international telephone operators harder than President Bush, it is President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela.

title: Florio Is Moving Quicker on Shift In Car Insurance
description: A sweeping overhaul of the automobile insurance system in New Jersey, including lower premiums for good drivers and more choices for consumers, will take effect several months earlier than expected under a series of executive orders to be signed in Trenton today by Gov. Jim Florio.

description: b-Net incomeThe company said a primary reason for the losses was a nonrecurring adjustment in estimated premiums due as of Sept. 30, 1990.Revenue represents gross revenues.

title: Negotiations Continue on Matsushita's Proposed Acquisition of MCA
description: Talks continued last night on the proposed acquisition of MCA Inc. by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Corporation, and a person involved in the negotiations said no substantive issues remained to be settled.

title: Outdoors: With Deer, Focus Is Crucial
description: ALTHOUGH there is a plethora of books devoted to the art of successful whitetail-deer hunting, none of them, to my knowledge, caution against succumbing to the trait that has bedeviled my own endeavors in the activity.

description: b-Included $ 26,598,000 of revenue from the sale of a portion of the company's Woodland Hills Property and a pretax gain of $ 24,602,000.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Money Manager Guided By Father's Philosophy
description: Alan I. Greene, the managing partner of David J. Greene & Company, is concerned that the public will get the wrong idea from his firm's recent suggestion to a company it has invested in, the Shared Medical Systems Corporation, that a merger with a larger company be considered.

title: JAPAN WEIGHS AID TO NORTH KOREANS
description: Nearly a half century after the end of its brutal subjugation of the Korean Peninsula, Japan is starting to think about possible reparations for North Korea but finding the decision-making difficult because of Koreans' extreme wariness of Japanese motives.

title: In U.S., Walesa Wins Easily
description: Lech Walesa, apparently more popular in North America than at home, easily won a majority of the absentee votes in the Polish presidential election that were cast in the United States and Canada, according to tallies by Polish officials and the national radio and television network.

title: Guadalupe Journal; Under the Dunes, a City by DeMille
description: A phar aoh's nose has been unearthed in the dunes here.

title: Traffic in Fake Documents Is Blamed For New Rise in Illegal Immigration
description: Four years after a new immigration law brought about a steady decline in the number of illegal aliens caught crossing the southern border, the number has turned sharply upward as illegal aliens and those who help smuggle them have widely circumvented the law with counterfeit documents.

title: Nets Find Touch After 34-Game Skid
description: After months of embarrassment, the Nets were able to walk proudly through Newark Airport yesterday afternoon as they returned home. After a record-breaking 34-game losing streak on the road, the team had ended a five-game West Coast trip with successive victories against two strong teams, the Phoenix Suns and the Golden State Warriors.

title: Ms. Frank Weds Marc I. Schwarz
description: Melissa Carol Frank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Frank of Oceanside, L.I., was married yesterday at the Oceanside Jewish Center to Marc Ira Schwarz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Schwarz of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Ephraim Rubinger and Cantor Erno Grosz officiated.

title: Democracy in the Way?
description: As President Bush intensifies the threat of war on Iraq, we are hearing complaints that criticism of that policy spoils its chance of success. Saddam Hussein would take the threat more seriously, that is, if Americans would silently support it.

description: Acknowledging that homeless people rummaging through garbage has become a permanent urban problem, many New York City residents are finding ways to make the best of a bad situation.

Cuomo on Iraq
description: Like a journalistic Javert, I have been tracking Gov. Mario Cuomo for months to get his position on countering the threat of Saddam Hussein. He has ducked.

Syria and British Meet In Effort to Revive Ties
description: Four years after they broke off diplomatic relations over the issue of terrorism, Syria and Britain held talks in Damascus today in an effort to resume them.

title: Maura Freyer and Adam Ruskin Marry
description: Maura Freyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl J. Freyer of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Adam Jay Ruskin, the son of Evelyn Ruskin Gordon of Philadelphia and David B. Ruskin of Anchorage. Rabbi Shmuel Goldin performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Renault-Volvo Czech Car Plan
description: Renault and Volvo A.B. offered to invest about $2.6 billion in Skoda, the Czechoslovak car maker, Renault said Saturday.

title: Arafat Stresses Linkage in Settling Gulf Crisis
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, has said he strongly supports President Saddam Hussein's assertions that a withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait must be tied to an overall settlement of conflicts in the region, including the 40-year-old Palestinian-Israeli conflict.

title: Bears, Raiders, Bengals Tumble
description: The Minnesota Vikings sacked the Bears' quarterback, Jim Harbaugh, seven times and held the National Football League's leading rushing attack to 107 yards today en route to a 41-13 victory over Chicago.

title: Iraq Frees Germans; Italians May Be Next
description: The Iraqi Government released about 100 German hostages today and indicated that it was prepared to free dozens of Italians a day after Italy donated nearly 25 tons of medical supplies.

title: Diagnostic-Retrieval Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Forget and Hlasek Win: When Guy Forget of France and Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland arrived in Australia to compete in the Association of Tennis Professionals World Doubles final in Sanctuary Cove, their hairstyles were the topic of conversation. By the time the $1 million tournament ended yesterday, the talk had switched to their tennis. Forget and Hlasek celebrated their first year as a partnership by collecting $305,000 in prize money and bonuses. The pair, both of whom shaved their heads before the tournament, beat Emilio Sanchez and Sergio Casal of Spain, 6-4, 7-6, 5-7, 6-4, yesterday in a 2-hour-52-minute final. They played the match only 90 minutes after completing a five-set semifinal victory over the No. 2-seeded Americans Scott Davis and David Pate that had been halted by darkness Saturday night tied at two sets. (AP) Golf Reid Wins Casio Open: Mike Reid shot a two-under-par 70 yesterday for a two-stroke victory in the $923,000 Casio World Open tournament in Kaimoncho, Japan. Reid finished at 14-under 274 over the 7,014-yard, par-72 Kaimon course of the Ibusuki Golf Club. (AP) Ogle Takes Australian P.G.A.: Brett Ogle of Australia shot a two-under-par 69 yesterday and won the $385,000 Australian P.G.A. Championship by five strokes. Ogle was the only player to have four sub-par rounds over the par-71, 6,979-yard Riverside Oaks course in Sydney. He finished at 11-under 273. (AP) Horse Racing Jack Betta Be Rite Wins: Star Track Farms' Jack Betta Be Rite, the favorite, came from just off the pace and won the $87,300 Schenectady Handicap for 3-year-old fillies yesterday at Aqueduct by two lengths.

title: Humiliation Is Life For 'L.A. Law' Actor
description: So a couple of weeks ago on "L.A. Law," Douglas Brackman Jr. draws a cigar from his breast pocket as he enters a stall in the men's room at McKenzie, Brackman and two seconds later, boom! By the next scene, Douglas has become the target of his colleagues' obvious jokes.

title: Cincinnati Offers a Humane Model of Toilets for the Homeless; Incentive Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Some in the Military Are Now Resisting Combat
description: The volunteer army gave many young people job skills, but the prospect of war in the Middle East has given some of them second thoughts, and dozens -- the numbers are disputed -- have tried to avoid their obligation by declaring themselves conscientious objectors.

title: A Low-Key Return for Walton
description: Dressed in Steelers' black, Joe Walton insisted on a low profile today.

description: b-Net income

title: California, the Congressional Giant, Has the Numbers but Not the Solidarity
description: If numbers were all that mattered, the most powerful delegation in the House of Representatives would be California's.

title: Business and the Law; Prepackaging A Bankruptcy
description: AS more overleveraged companies admit that they cannot make the interest payments on high-yield securities they issued in the 1980's, they face the prospect of long, bitter and costly bankruptcy proceedings. Some troubled corporations are trying to cut both the time and the expense of bankruptcy reorganization by taking an approach known as the prepackaged bankruptcy.

title: Cross & Trecker reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 21,272,000 related to restructuring costs. Results in fiscal 1990 do not include operations of three companies that have been sold as part of the restructuring program. These units contributed $ 63.5 million to revenues in the 1989 year and had an operating loss of $ 3.1 million.

title: Seeing the World Through the Eyes of 7-Year-Olds
description: Michael Apted, the English film maker who documented the lives of 14 children in his highly praised series "7 Up" more than a quarter of a century ago, was resting in a second-grader's chair, looking bemused. A brand new "7 Up" was revving up around him, as a crew of seven film makers toiled under the direction of Phil Joanou. They were adjusting lights and loading the camera in Room 308 at Public School 97 on East Houston Street in Manhattan, as everyone waited for the first 7-year-old to arrive.

title: INSIDE
description: Unbeaten No More The Giants and the San Francisco 49ers lost for the first time, dimming the spotlight on their meeting next week. Three other division leaders, the Bears, the Bengals and the Raiders, also lost. SportsMonday, page C1. Despair on Soviet Pollution In one polluted Soviet city, people who want a clean environment are not celebrating the new freedoms. The system is expected to leave regulation up to the powerless city. Page A8. Flow of Aliens Rises Anew Illegal crossings of the border with Mexico have turned upward, raising questions about the effectiveness of the 1986 immigration law. Page A14. Gentle Giant in Congress The California House delegation, 45 strong and growing, could be the most powerful, but ideolgical and regional divisions dilute its clout. Page A17. Merger Talks Continue Negotiations continued last night about the proposed acquisition of MCA Inc. by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Corporation. Page D2.

title: U.S. Is Reported To Win Support For Use Of Force
description: Bush Administration officials and foreign diplomats said today that the United States has mustered enough support in the United Nations Security Council to gain approval of a resolution that would authorize the use of military force against Iraq if it did not withdraw its forces from Kuwait by the end of January.

title: Pontoon Bridge Sinks in Flooding As Seattle Is Battered by Storms
description: Huge concrete chunks of a closed floating highway bridge that links Seattle to its eastern suburbs sank this morning after the pontoons that kept the structure afloat filled with water in stormy weather.

title: Family Feared Death in Battle, But Marine Dies on Queens Road
description: Lance Cpl. Reynaldo Martindale's family feared that the young marine would be sent to Saudi Arabia and possible death. Instead he died on a Queens highway early yesterday when a hit-and-run driver struck him and a friend after they stopped to help a stranded motorist.

title: CNN Misjudged Duty On Noriega Tapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Walesa Takes Wide Lead in Presidential Voting
description: Lech Walesa, the electrician who ran the anti-Communist Solidarity labor movement for a decade, took a wide lead today in Poland's presidential election but failed to win enough votes to avoid a runoff, according to early returns.

description: b-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,226,700, or 98 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 2,274,800, or $ 1.00 a share, for the 9 months.

title: President Robinson
description: When Mary Robinson announced her candidacy for the presidency of Ireland in May, bookmakers rated her chances as 100 to 1. No woman had served in the office, much less a socialist known for opposing censorship and favoring an end to Ireland's constitutional prohibition of divorce. So guess who has now been elected by Parliament?

title: Kuwaiti Resistance Gunmen Said to Shoot Iraqi Governor
description: Kuwaiti gunmen have wounded an Iraqi official who served briefly as governor of the occupied emirate, a spokesman for the exiled Kuwaiti Government said today, citing recently arriving Kuwaitis as the sources of his report.

title: In Polluted Russian City, a New Fear
description: A theater director seeking a stage set of hell could hardly do better than the industrial park that crowds the northern edge of this Russian city.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Indiana Jones's whip has been donated by HARRISON FORD to the Institute of Archaeology in London. It will be auctioned Dec. 20 by Christie's to raise money for a new conservation center at the institute. Between adventures in his three films, Mr. Ford's character taught archeaology.

title: Question Box
description: Heisman to No Glory

description: The company said the decrease in revenue is primarily due to the closing of two land sales during the prior year's quarter. Also, revenues from residential property sales in Florida decreased $ 5,019,000 as a result of the company's withdrawal from the Florida market.

title: Steelers Trounce Jets, 24-7
description: There are some funny bounces in football and in life and the ones here today bounced in favor of Pittsburgh as the Steelers beat the Jets, 24-7, in Joe Walton's first return to Giants Stadium since he was dismissed last December as the Jets' coach.

title: A.W. Perigard Is Dead; Data Executive Was 52
description: A. W. Perigard, a telecommunications executive, died Wednesday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 52 years old.

title: 2 Held in Bias Attack on Pakistani in Subway
description: A Pakistani man was assaulted by a marine and a companion on a Brooklyn-bound subway train early Saturday, the transit police reported, listing the incident as a bias attack.

Walter Thompson, Chicago. * John Parlato and Walt Hampton Jr. have been named senior vice presidents and creative directors at W. B. Doner & Company. * Timothy Scott has been promoted to a management representative at DDB Needham, Chicago. * Thomas W. Eley has been named vice president of business development for the Gannett Outdoor Group, New York. * Mitchell Hershey joined Wexler, McCarron & Roth Advertising, Pompano Beach, Fla., as a senior vice president of marketing and business development.

title: POLISH STRONGMAN HAUNTS CAMPAIGN
description: Poles gathered in this historic village today to vote for President, and many of them said they longed for a strong, even stern, leader who could bring an end to the turbulent times in this newly democratic country.

title: American Woodmark reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Cape Canaveral's Need to Renovate
description: In the shadow of the latest Delta rocket awaiting liftoff here, an obsolete computer reads data the old-fashioned way, from a paper tape punched with holes. When the computer needs spare parts, engineers here must sometimes rummage for them in electronics surplus stores in Orlando.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 17 about reports that China had stolen American nuclear-weapons secrets misidentified the Senate panel that held hearings in 1988 on security lapses at nuclear weapons laboratories. It was the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, not the Foreign Relations Committee.

title: U.S. Aides Press Iraqi Nuclear Threat
description: The Bush Administration today stepped up its effort to raise American concern about Iraq's ability to develop nuclear weapons, saying Baghdad might be able to produce a crude nuclear device within a year.

title: Genex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mexicans Hopeful as They Await Bush Today
description: Seeking to capitalize on the warmest official American-Mexican relations in recent memory, Mexican authorities prepared for the arrival of President Bush here on Monday for a two-day state visit that is expected to focus largely on trade issues.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants Lose Their Poise, Too
description: THROUGH their history, the Giants have had some vicious rivalries, beginning with the Washington Redskins in the 30's, then the Cleveland Browns in the 50's, the Redskins again in the 70's and the 80's. But now the Philadelphia Eagles soar alone as the team the Giants love to hate more than any other. And the Eagles were soaring higher than ever as the winner of four of the last five games with the Giants after yesterday's 31-13 victory at Veterans Stadium.

title: Boxer's Appeal for Hostages
description: Muhammad Ali, on a visit to Baghdad, pressed today for the release of some of the hundreds of Americans held in Iraq. Officials said a meeting between Mr. Ali, former heavyweight champion of the world, and President Saddam Hussein was postponed, and no new date was announced.

title: Review/Music; Harry Connick Jr., On Piano, Drums, Etc.
description: In Harry Connick Jr.'s superb new show at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, this 23-year-old musical Wunderkind from New Orleans does the work of several entertainers. Over the course of the two-hour two-act evening, Mr. Connick plays the piano, sings, leads his own 16-piece big band, jokes with the audience, dances, plays a little bass and drums and models his Alexander Julian wardrobe.

title: Bumbling 49ers See Streak End at 18
description: This afternoon was supposed to be a kind of dress rehearsal for the San Francisco 49ers, a prelude to a night next week that could have -- perhaps should have -- matched two unbeaten teams in a game of Super Bowl proportions.

title: Miscellany
description: * Lewis, Gilman & Kynett and Gray & Rogers, advertising agency subsidiaries of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, have merged to become FCB/LGK, Philadelphia.

title: Campbell Soup Co. Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The company said the sales decline reflects the sale of two mushroom farms and the gattuso pasta and sauce business. Excluding the businesses sold, sales were flat in the latest quarter.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ninja Turtles Save the Day For CBS Children's Lineup
description: The heroes in a half shell have conquered Saturday morning, and CBS is reaping the benefits of turtle power.

title: The Bloody Mullahs of Iran
description: A world preoccupied with Iraq has taken too little note of relentless repression in neighboring Iran. This is now partly remedied by a United Nations report corroborating charges of cruel and inhuman punishment inflicted by Teheran's mullahs. It makes gloomy reading: executions by sword, amputations and whippings are routine. Fear is pervasive. Religious minorities are deprived of rudimentary rights. Iranian death squads are accused of killing an exiled opponent.

title: Machine Tool Orders Rose 1.9% Last Month
description: Machine tool orders increased nearly 1.9 percent in October from the September level, the industry's trade association reported in its monthly survey. Some analysts said the increase indicated that the nation's economic slowdown had not yet prompted manufacturers in the United States to sharply reduce spending for new equipment.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; Books Go East and, Maybe, Profits Go West
description: FARRAR, STRAUS & GIROUX has long published books by authors from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. But with censorship and other barriers to book publishing toppling in the region, the house recently added what are known as subagents in Berlin and Belgrave, Yugoslavia.

title: India's Hindus Try to Right a 400-Year Wrong; Structural Reforms

title: Actors Talk About Theater
description: Stockard Channing and F. Murray Abraham will take part in a discussion about the theater this evening at 6 at the New School, 66 West 12th Street in Manhattan. David Black, an actor and director and author of "The Actor's Audition," will be the host. Admission: $15. Information: (212) 741-5690.

Schlegel president of the Grumman LLV unit, which makes a delivery truck called the long-life vehicle that is being built for the Postal Service. He succeeds Robert H. Howell vice president of corporate services. * MCI Communications Corp., Washington, appointed Anthony D. Martin vice president of systems engineering support and operations. * Viacom Inc., New York, appointed Robert Meyers vice president of planning and development in its network group operations unit.

title: Former Bonn Chief Forecasts His Party Will Lose Election
description: Former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is under heavy fire from his Social Democratic party after he predicted in a newspaper interview that the party's candidate in national elections next month, Oskar Lafontaine, would lose, adding, "He deserves it, too."

description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 639,000,000 and $ 709,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which included a charge of $ 599 million reflecting the estimated loss attributable to the proposed sale of Home Insurance Co. to TVH Acquisition Corp.c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $ 30,000,000, or 88 cents a share, for the quarter, and $ 108,000,000, or $ 3.16 a share, for the 9 months.The company said the provision for loan losses for the third quarter was $ 35 million, reflecting a continuing decline in the overall economy, particularly in commercial real estate.

title: Call of Gulf Duty Echoes In a Home in Brooklyn
description: Catherine Sbordone spent yesterday running around her cozy home in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn collecting items she usually takes for granted: a nail clipper, sunscreen, toothpicks, safety pins and a deck of cards.

title: Fire Delays Flights in Denver
description: Two storage tanks containing nearly a million gallons of jet fuel caught fire today near Stapleton International Airport, triggering efforts to keep the blaze from spreading to other tanks. The blaze apparently was caused by a broken valve for one of the 400,000-gallon tanks; the heat from the fire ignited the second. United Airlines reported delays of as long as four hours for departing flights.

title: Acmat Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Struggling Czech Retailer Delivers the Goods
description: A full year after the democratic revolution in Czechoslovakia, this country's leading department store is still struggling almost daily to stock Western products eagerly sought by shoppers.

title: Competent to Die?
description: To the Editor:

title: Barry Blau & Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Major Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: "I know that when I get paid on the first of the month, I'm going to get a call. It's expected that I have it and that I'm going to give it. I feel I'm working for the whole extended family. It's not a question of if they're going to need it. I know they're going to need it." -- Donald Sheppard of Houston. [ B7:1. ]

title: Eagles' Formations in Step
description: Seventeen times against the Giants' rugged defense today, the Eagles faced third-down situations that meant maintaining drives or settling for less than a touchdown. It did not matter whether the yardage needed was long or short or whether the ball was in Philadelphia territory or on the Giants turf. The Eagles often aligned in the perfect formation for each test. The perfect play was often called.

title: Ulster County Warns Albany of a Tax Revolt
description: In bucolic Ulster County, some 90 miles north of New York City, there are rumblings of a tax revolt. The stirrings began three weeks ago, when the county unveiled its proposed 1991 budget -- and a proposed county property-tax rise of 82 percent.

title: In Thatcher's Constituency, a Sense of Betrayal; in Labor Areas, Utter Relief
description: In Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's North London constituency of Finchley, the roof fell in today on the local Conservative Party headquarters.

title: Medical Sterilization reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Queens Man Dies in Stabbing; 3 Are Held
description: A 24-year-old Queens man was stabbed to death early yesterday in a dispute outside a restaurant. One man reportedly involved in the dispute was charged with murder and two others with assault, the police said.

title: A Better Way to Protect Deposits
description: The recent collapse of Freedom National Bank in Harlem demolished a proud symbol of black-owned neighborhood enterprise. It also focused attention on Federal deposit insurance, since several charitable organizations stand to lose hundreds of thousands in accounts they mistakenly thought were insured.

title: Identix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
General Devices Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on purchase of debentures of $ 239,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 1,000,858, or 27 cents a share, gain on sale of discontinued operations for the 9 months, and 9-month also included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 197,071, which reflects the sale of part of the company's engineering service business.c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $ 208,874 and $ 362,456, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which reflects the sale of part of the company's engineering service business, and 9-month also included an extraordinary gain on sale of discontinued operations of $ 270,798, or 8 cents a share.

title: FT Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 2,285,000 and $ 5,652,000, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-After income from discontinued operations of $ 3,305,000, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 2,499,000, or 24 cents a share, for the 9 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * National Gypsum Co., Dallas, which filed on Oct. 28 for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, said it had received approval from the Federal Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of Texas to use the full $105 million available to the company under a debtor-in-possession line of credit established with the General Electric Capital Corp. * Sears Receivable Financing Group Inc., a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Co., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $500 million in credit-account pass-through certifictes through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., also a Sears unit. * Southern Electric Generating Co., Birmingham, Ala., which is owned by the Alabama Power Co. and Georgia Power Co., has filed for $24.5 million in pollution control revenue refunding bonds. * Tandy Corp., Fort Worth, manufacturer of consumer electronic goods and personal computers, has filed for up to $500 million in debt securities to be issued from time to time. Rating * New Haven's general obligation bond rating has been lowered to BBB-, from A-, by Standard & Poor's.

title: Intrex Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Intrex said the latest quarter and 9 months included other real estate owned expenses and writedowns of $ 908,000 and $ 1,869,000, respectively. The amount of the writedowns and expenses in the year-earlier quarter and 9 months totaled $ 13,000.

title: Budd Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an amount equal to 85 cents a share arising from the the receipt of price adjustments retroactive to the prior year, and from the sale of a warehouse surplus to the company's requirements.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hewlett-Packard reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Vukovich Is Killed In Race Warmup
description: Bill Vukovich III, a third-generation race car driver and rookie of the year in the 1988 Indianapolis 500, died today after his car slammed into a wall during practice laps at Mesa Marin Speedway.

title: Eleanor Dillon Weds Daniel Petigrow
description: Eleanor Ann Dillon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin P. Dillon of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Daniel Petigrow, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Petigrow of Stony Brook, L.I. Rabbi Moshe Edelman and Cantor Jacob Merlis performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation.

title: Allcity Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Another Berlin Airlift?
description: In the summer of 1948, in the coldest moments of the cold war, Moscow imposed a blockade on West Berlin. An American airlift kept the city alive. Then, in 1953, West Berlin began stockpiling emergency supplies of food and other essentials as a hedge against another siege. Since then, 300,000 metric tons have been piled up in 280 warehouses around the city.

title: Donaldson Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Male Journal; 1,190 Islands in Danger: Sea Could Drown Them
description: Even before the first hint of dawn outlines the offshore islands rimmed with white sand, the chugging motors of dhoni boats have announced a new day to this town.

title: Avoiding Snares, Karpov and Kasparov Draw a Tricky 13th Game
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov evidently decided that they had run out of tricks to spring on each other and agreed to a draw in Game 13 of the World Championship Chess Match in Lyons, France yesterday morning without resuming play. They are still tied, at 6 1/2-6 1/2.

title: Star With Big Ego Need Not Apply
description: IN Hollywood, an actor who plays character roles is usually either too old or too inexperienced or too limited in talent and popularity to merit top billing. Few aspire to the category, but many settle for it.

title: In India, Death and Democracy
description: The events in India seem to become more and more like a lurid hallucination: terrorist attacks in the states of Punjab and Assam, caste riots in New Delhi, shootings and arrests in Kashmir, hundreds of thousands of Hindus marching upon a 16th century mosque in Ayodhya.

title: Less Visible but Heavier Burdens As AIDS Attacks People Over 50
description: Hidden for years by secrecy, shame and in some cases the assumption that their symptoms were simply those of aging, a growing number of older people are emerging as victims of AIDS.

title: Etz Lavud Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossResults have been converted into U.S. dollars from new Israeli shekels a the rate of exchange as of Sept. 30, 1990.

title: L.S.U. to Make Decision
description: The Southern Mississippi coach, Curley Hallman, began two days of meetings with officials at Louisiana State University yesterday in anticipation of succeeding Mike Archer as the head coach. Archer resigned amid reports he was about to be dismissed after four years in the post. Hallman will need approval by the L.S.U. Board of Supervisors, but board members said they would endorse him. (AP)

title: Thomas B. Haire, Publishing Executive, 77
description: Thomas B. Haire, retired president of the Haire Publishing Company, died yesterday at his home in Little Compton, R.I.. He was 77 years old,

title: FIRE IS CONTAINED AT DENVER AIRPORT
description: Fed by more than two million gallons of jet fuel, a fire near Stapleton Airport raged for a second day today, sending thick, oily plumes visible for 50 miles around into the sky. But by afternoon, firefighters said they were getting the blaze under control, and air traffic returned to normal after a day of disruption for thousands of travelers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "A lot of people feel betrayed. They feel the leaders of Solidarity created economic disaster." -- Stanislaw Tyminski, the Polish emigre who finished second in the Presidential election. [ A14:6. ]

title: Kiley Resigns After 7 Years as Chairman of the M.T.A.
description: Robert R. Kiley, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, who oversaw a vast program to rebuild New York City's subways, bus lines and commuter railroads, resigned yesterday after seven years with the agency.

title: New Nixon Museum Can't Deny Tape Access
description: To the Editor: It is misleading to imply, as a Nov. 9 report does, that the recently established library of Richard M. Nixon in Los Angeles could deny the public access to the "Nixon tapes."

title: By Design; Sparkle for the Ears
description: Last year the earring of the evening was a dingle dangle. If it was so long that the bottom brushed the shoulder, all the better. But now earrings are going in another direction.

title: Bid by Chase To Sell Unit
description: Reacting to reports that the Chase Manhattan Corporation is offering its investment advisory unit for sale, analysts said yesterday that the operation was undoubtedly among the banking company's businesses that could be sold as it tried to cut costs and improve its financial condition.

title: Bills Follow The Leaders By Losing
description: Lorenzo White baffled Buffalo with his career-best rushing and receiving game and Warren Moon threw two touchdown passes tonight, carrying the Houston Oilers to a 27-24 victory over the Bills and creating a three-way, first-place tie in the American Football Conference's Central Division.

title: Dow Edges Up by 5.94 Points, to 2533.17
description: The stock market, following the bond market's lead, reversed its early losses around noon yesterday and closed higher.

title: Two Goals by Sheppard Keeps Ranger on Streak
description: For Madison Square Garden, which is in the process of spending hundreds of millions of dollars in renovation costs, Ray Sheppard qualified as a distinctly minor restoration project. The right wing, after all, cost the Rangers and thus their corporate parent next to nothing, acquired for a nominal fee from the Sabres last July.

title: On Morning After, a Wake-Up Call for 10-1 Rivals; Giants Are Dwelling Only on What's Next
description: This morning, Coach Bill Parcells started preparing for the Giants' big game next Monday night against the 49ers in San Francisco. And even though the Giants took a 31-13 beating Sunday from the Eagles in Philadelphia, for their first loss of the season, Parcells was not in mourning.

title: The G(reedy) O(ld) P(arty)
description: William Bennett is the first Republican National Committee chairman in memory, maybe the first ever, who is an intellectual. His stock in trade is not cronyism, not the glad hand, certainly not the politician's ready smile. Rather, his credentials are training in history, logic and philosophy, along with fearlessness about new ideas and debating them. It was these credentials that first put him on the map.

title: PATTERNS
description: Appeals for Giving

title: The Scorpion, Bizarre And Nasty, Recruits New Admirers
description: TO the ancient Chinese, snakes embodied both good and evil, but scorpions symbolized pure wickedness. To the Persians, scorpions were the devil's minions, sent to destroy all life by attacking the testicles of the sacred bull whose blood should have fertilized the universe.

title: People
description: * Christine Stroebel has been appointed vice president and media director of Kobs & Draft Advertising, Chicago. * Jim Weller has been named a partner at Kollewe & O'Sullivan Advertising, Los Angeles. * William M. Abrams has been appointed vice president of marketing and development for daytime programs at ABC Entertainment, New York.

title: Ivory Coast's Ruling Party Wins a Huge Majority in Open Election
description: President Felix Houphouet-Boigny's party won an overwhelming majority in Parliament in multiparty elections that ended 30 years of unchallenged one-party rule, the Government said today.

title: Solar System Lineup Will Bring High Tides
description: NO matter what happens in southeastern Missouri, where a prediction of an earthquake on Dec. 3 has caused widespread anxiety, forecasters are certain of one thing: there will be unusually high and low tides along the world's coasts for four days and nights, from Dec. 1 through Dec. 4.

title: Railways in Eastern Germany Crippled by Strike
description: Tens of thousands of railway workers went on strike in eastern Germany today, crippling passenger and freight lines in an effort to press the Government in Bonn to raise wages and guarantee jobs.

title: Critic's Notebook; Waging a Ratings War: 'Cosby' vs. 'Simpsons'
description: Hey, what's going on here? Terrible Bart Simpson, patron saint of underachievers, is turning out to be surprisingly sweet under that bratty veneer. And on "The Cosby Show," the Huxtables are dipping their very proper middle-class toes into the world of urban rap. Yo, viewers, chill out! This is television entertainment and, depending on which way the ratings happen to be blowing, anything can happen.

title: Top Delaware Court Rules In Rift at Kirby Foundation
description: The Delaware Supreme Court has affirmed a lower court ruling that defended the right of Fred M. Kirby 2d to oust his three siblings from the board of the F. M. Kirby Foundation Inc., his family's charitable foundation, and secretly replace them with his wife and children.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the public relations people representing The Daily News and its striking unions referred incorrectly to John Scanlon. Mr. Scanlon, a consultant to the newspaper's management, represented CBS News when the network was sued for libel by Gen. William C. Westmoreland; he did not work for the general.

title: Bush, in Mexican Visit, Radiates Amity
description: Forgoing complex trade talks for cowboy boots and box seats at a rodeo, President Bush came to call on President Carlos Salinas de Gortari today in a visit intended to jump-start Mexican-American relations with a show of unabashed political friendship.

title: Bridge
description: One of the world's strongest bridge teams took a commanding lead in the Open Board-a-Match Teams here Sunday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Massachusetts Dismisses 4 For Sexual Abuse in Hospital
description: The Massachusetts Department of Mental Health has dismissed four workers, accusing them of sexually abusing five female patients at a state hospital.

title: Shipment of New Chip Has Begun at Motorola
description: After months of delays caused by production problems, Motorola Inc. said yesterday that it had begun volume shipments of its most advanced microprocessor, the 68040.

title: Poland Votes Its Impatience
description: The first-round results of Poland's presidential election may advance political pluralism. They also reflect explosive social discontent. The winner of next month's runoff will face mounting public impatience for a better life. That's reason enough for America and Western Europe to accelerate existing programs to help Poles and other East Europeans make the transition from Communism. Otherwise, last year's democratic euphoria could become next year's angry disillusionment.

title: Samuel Noah Kramer, 93, Dies; Was Leading Authority on Sumer
description: Samuel Noah Kramer, one of the foremost authorities on the ancient Sumerian language and literature, died yesterday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 93 years old.

title: Oil Prices Rise $1.05, To $32.95
description: Crude oil prices rose yesterday for the third straight trading day. Traders and analysts attributed the gain to the belief that the United Nations Security Council might authorize the use of force against Iraq.

title: The DOCTOR'S WORLD; Iron in Diet Is Poison for a Million Americans
description: IN the comics, Popeye the Sailor gulped spinach for the iron that made him invincible, popularizing the belief that eating lots of iron-rich food builds muscles.

title: Transit Chief Resigns
description: Robert R. Kiley, who helped overhaul New York's transit system, resigned as head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Page B1.

title: Report Links Neil Bush To Securities Law Case
description: President Bush's son Neil served on the board of an affiliate of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association that helped a Denver home builder evade securities laws, according to Federal documents quoted by The Denver Post.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HAROLD BROWN raced through Columbia College in two and a half years, graduated at the top of his class and earned a doctorate from Columbia University when he was 21. Today the college is giving him its highest honor, the Alexander Hamilton Medal, at a dinner in Low Library.

title: Port Authority Should Take Over Port of New York Fireboats
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq's Atomic Red Herring
description: The Iraqi bomb is a red herring. President Bush's Thanksgiving Day invocation of an imminent Iraqi nuclear threat to justify war in the Persian Gulf misreads history. Expert estimates put Iraqi acquisition of a limited nuclear arsenal at least 10 years away.

title: Bradford Clark, 83, Public Works Chief For Wagner in 60's
description: Bradford Norman Clark, an engineer who was New York City's public works commissioner from 1963 to 1966, died Nov. 19 at his home in Old Greenwich, Conn. He was 83 years old.

title: Bible and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Cancer Therapy Works, but Do Insurance Rules?
description: A year ago, James Kustka's legs had swollen so from lymphoma that he had trouble walking. "Fluids were collecting, collecting, collecting. I gained 16 pounds of fluid." Tremendous amounts of cancer in his pelvis lymph glands pressed on the veins that drain the legs. His doctor, Arthur Berken, a cancer specialist, was out of ideas. Traditional chemotherapy no longer worked. "Continuing like this, he'd been better off dead," said the doctor.

title: 30 Runners Disqualified
description: The New York Road Runners Club says that 30 runners of the 23,774 finishers in the New York City Marathon have been disqualified for various infractions, among them 64-year-old Jim McNearny of Melbourne, Fla., the first finisher in the men's 60 to 69 age group. The club said that McNearny was not recorded at video checkpoints set up along the route.

title: Brazil Candidates Backed by President Lose
description: Candidates supported by President Fernando Collor de Mello have been shut out in gubernatorial elections in Brazil's largest and most powerful states.

title: Review of Matsushita Debt Rating
description: The rating of about $2.4 billion in senior debt issued by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Matsushita Electric Trading Finance N.V., the Panasonic Capital Corporation, and Panasonic Finance (Netherlands) B.V. is under review for a possible downgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday. The agency said Mastushita senior debt was currently rated Aaa.

title: New Prospects for Gene-Altered Fish Raise Hope and Alarm
description: WITH quickening speed, scientists are genetically engineering new strains of fish, producing faster-growing, larger strains but raising concerns about whether Government regulation will move fast enough to head off potential environmental problems.

title: THATCHER BACKING HER FINANCE CHIEF
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher wants the Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, to win the vote to succeed her as leader of the Conservative Party in balloting Tuesday, one of her closest aides said today.

title: Out of Personal Calamity, A Tale of Trials Overcome
description: When Natalie Kusz was 7 years old, growing up in near poverty with her family in the dark, forbidding cold of the Alaska countryside, she was savagely attacked and mutilated by a starving sled dog one day as she was returning home from school.

title: Rifle Maker Plans to Reopen
description: The U.S. Repeating Arms Company, which recently closed its operations because of money problems, has worked out financing that will allow it to resume production of its Winchester rifles, the company said last week.

title: Yangon Journal; Temple Rises Grandly; Will the Strongman Fall?
description: The nation is watching as construction workers put the finishing touches on this city's grandest temple, with its golden stupa that swells into the sky, for in whispers and prayers people are saying that it could spell the end for the most controversial man in this country: their leader.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GRACE JACKSON walked to the altar last weekend in Kingston, Jamaica, when she married HUGH SMALL , the nation's Minister of Industry, Commerce and Production. In the 1988 Olympics, Ms. Jackson won a silver medal in the 200-meter dash, coming in second to FLORENCE GRIFFITH JOYNER.

title: USF&G's Chairman Had Same Job at Heller
description: Norman P. Blake Jr. was appointed chairman and chief executive yesterday by the USF&G Corporation, the troubled insurance and financial services company.

title: Toyota Plant Is Expected For Kentucky
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation is expected to end months of speculation on Tuesday by announcing that it will build another automobile assembly plant near its existing factory in Georgetown, Ky.

title: Review/Television; Recalling the Iran-Contra Affair
description: Given the daily headlines from the Persian Gulf, the Iran-contra affair may seem like yesterday's news, yet "High Crimes and Misdemeanors" digs into an eminently current issue: the tension between the President and Congress over the conduct of foreign affairs. In tonight's 90-minute offering from "Frontline," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, Bill Moyers offers a cautionary account of the Reagan Administration's covert effort to channel the proceeds of weapons sales to Iran to anti-Sandinista forces in Nicaragua.

title: New Ways to Play Games With Windows
description: IF you have friends or relatives who use the Microsoft Corporation's new Windows 3.0 on their computers, you can give them packages of fun for the holidays. Games are a much safer bet than expensive major applications that might not be what they want.

title: Bond Prices Rebound Strongly
description: Treasury bond prices rose in a strong turnaround yesterday as dealers shrugged off worries about heightened tensions in the Middle East and rising oil prices and bought securities.

title: Ideology Said to Split Book-Award Jurors
description: In a climate of unusual divisiveness, jurors will convene today to choose the winners of two of America's most prestigious book prizes, the National Book Awards for fiction and nonfiction.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Thrifty Names President Of Its Drugstore Chain
description: The Thrifty Corporation said yesterday that it had named Eve A. Rich president of Thrifty Drug Stores, the company's Southern California drugstore chain.

title: Chess Coverage
description: During the championship match between Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov, the Chess column will not appear on Tuesdays. Coverage of the 14th game of the championship appears today on page B2.

title: Defendant in Jogger Trial Bolts From Stand in Rage
description: Kharey Wise, a defendant in the second Central Park jogger trial, exploded in rage on the witness stand yesterday and jumped down after repudiating his written and videotaped confession to his part in the rape and beating of a woman who was jogging across the nothern end of the park.

title: Assad and Bush
description: On the plane from Zurich to Tel Aviv, passengers stare at a newspaper photograph that tells an astonishing story: how swiftly and dangerously history can repeat itself.

title: Ascii Purchases 5% Informix Stake
description: The Informix Corporation, a software company based in Menlo Park, Calif., said the Ascii Corporation of Tokyo had purchased 5 percent of Informix's common stock at $10 a share, or about $6.7 million. Ascii distributes Informix's data base management and spreadsheet software in Japan.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Hear Appeal In Retirement Age Case
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states can set mandatory retirement ages for state judges.

title: U.S. Arts Chief Overturns an Approval
description: An experimental artist whose project was approved for a grant by a peer panel of the National Endowment for the Arts, and then upheld by the advisory National Council on the Arts at its August meeting, has been notified that the agency's chairman, John E. Frohnmayer, has rejected the recommendation.

title: Ex-President of American U. Wants to Teach
description: The former president of the American University, who resigned last spring after admitting he made obscene telephone calls, said today that he wants to return to teaching at the school. He indicated he would decline a $1 million offer from the school to buy out his tenure.

title: Iran, Gulf States in Deal
description: Iran has agreed to buy petroleum products directly from several Persian Gulf states, the National Iranian Oil Company said today. The company, which imports about 200,000 barrels a day of gas oil and kerosene, will buy those products from refineries in Bahrain, Qatar and Abu Dhabi, which is part of the United Arab Emirates. Many Persian Gulf states had banned the sale of oil products to Iran because of their support for Iraq in its 1980-88 war with Iran. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has reversed that situation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about animal rights advocates and their confrontations with hunters referred incorrectly to hunting regulations in California. For two years there has been a moratorium on bow hunting of black bears; bow hunting in general has not been outlawed.

title: Draft of the U.N. Resolution
description: Following is the text of a draft United Nations resolution on the use of force, as agreed on today by the five permanent members of the Security Council: THE SECURITY COUNCIL, RECALLING AND REAFFIRMING its resolutions 660 (1990), 661 (1990), 662 (1990), 664 (1990), 665 (1990), 666 (1990), 667 (1990), 669 (1990), 670 (1990), 674 (1990). NOTING that, despite all efforts by the United Nations, Iraq refuses to comply with its obligation to implement Resolution 660 (1990) and subsequent resolutions, in flagrant contempt of the Council, MINDFUL of its duties and responsibilities under the Charter of the United Nations for the maintenance and preservation of international peace and security, DETERMINED to secure full compliance with its decisions, ACTING under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,

title: How to Let Arab States Work It Out With Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: New Clues On Rise Of a Swath Of Granite
description: GEOLOGISTS studying the Appalachian Mountains suggest that radioactive heat led to the formation of the broad swath of granite that passes through southern Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts and Connecticut.

title: The New Force in Poland Is Candidate 'From Mars'
description: Before he scored his remarkable showing, coming in second to Lech Walesa in the first round of Poland's presidential election, Stanislaw Tyminski's only political success was his election five months ago as leader of Canada's tiny Libertarian Party.

title: Hills Appoints Two at the Top
description: Hills Department Stores, a large discount chain, yesterday named two men to replace its chairman, president and chief executive.

title: Books of The Times; A Woman Who Portrayed Adultery and Paid for It
description: Kate Chopin By Emily Toth 528 pages. William Morrow & Company. $27.95.

title: With Righetti Unsigned, Yanks Buy Some Insurance for Bullpen
description: With George Steinbrenner as the head recruiter, the Yankees have executed some stunning signings of free agents over the years. Steinbrenner has been banished from that role, but yesterday the Yankees pulled off another stunning signing. They gave Steve Farr, a free-agent relief pitcher, $6.3 million for three years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The sculptures of LOUISE BOURGEOIS have been traveling around Europe this year while she has been collecting honors in the United States. The latest is an Award for Distinction, to be given by the Sculpture Center in New York on Dec. 3.

title: They Lost, but They Also Clinched
description: Although the Giants may have lost to the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday, the National Football League concluded yesterday that the Giants have become the first team to clinch at least a wild-card berth in the playoffs.

title: Too Much Milken Moralizing
description: In sentencing Michael Milken to 10 years for violating Federal securities law, Judge Kimba Wood denied she was rendering a "verdict on a decade of greed." But others blame Mr. Milken for the financial excesses of the 1980's. Junk bonds, they say, bankrupted profitable companies, decimated savings and loan institutions and brought the economy to the edge of financial chaos.

title: Holyfield Protesting W.B.C. Rule in Court
description: Evander Holyfield, the heavyweight champion, will ask for a preliminary injunction today forbidding the World Boxing Council from stripping him of his crown when he defends it against the former champion George Foreman on April 19.

title: Timing for Bias
description: People are more likely to make biased judgments when they are least alert, according to two studies reported in a recent issue of the journal Psychologial Science.

title: A Most Painful Answer
description: The news that the Baseball Hall of Fame was reviewing its traditional way of voting for membership into its pantheon has the aspect of a lynch party. And the one whose unsaintly neck is in question is Peter Edward Rose, formerly No. 14 of the Cincinnati Reds, and now No. 01832061 of the Marion (Ill.) Federal Prison Camp.

title: Review/Ballet; The Tin Soldier, in Love Yet Again
description: The curtain rose on a parlor with a lighted Christmas tree on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater. No, the New York City Ballet was not presenting a sneak preview of "The Nutcracker." This tree was part of the set that David Mitchell designed for "The Steadfast Tin Soldier," George Balanchine's bittersweet comic pas de deux to music of Bizet.

title: Herbert Berghof Memorial
description: A memorial program for Herbert Berghof, the actor, director and acting teacher, is to be held at 11:30 A.M. Sunday at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street. Speakers at the program, which will be open to the public, are to include Vincent Canby, chief film critic of The New York Times; the playwright Horton Foote, and the actors Charles Nelson Reilly and Fritz Weaver. Mr. Berghof died on Nov. 5 at the age of 81.

title: Youths Lacking Special Skills Find Jobs Leading Nowhere
description: A decade or two ago, young Americans fresh out of high school could find a job in construction or sales, in a factory or an office, and make a good career of it. They could wait for raises to come along, buy a car, buy a house and take a trip once in a while.

title: Barge Owner Gets Probation for Sludge Dumping
description: Evelyn Berman Frank, the aggressive 75-year-old head of barge and ship-tank cleaning companies that are reeling under government pressure for pollutin New York Harbor, was sentenced yesterday to five years of probation for her role in illegal sewage sludge dumping.

title: G.M. Unit in Spain
description: The General Motors Corporation's Hughes Aircraft subsidiary has set up a company in Spain to supply the expanding commercial and industrial markets for electronic components in Europe. Hughes said that the move would be accompanied by expanded marketing efforts in Europe and that other new factories were being considered. Hughes Microelectronics Europa Espana S.A. will be built on nine acres of land in a new industrial park in Malaga, a seaport. By 1994, it will employ 400 workers.

title: Early-Morning Fire Destroys A Synagogue on Long Island
description: A fire early today destroyed a wooden building housing the Sinai Reform Temple, the Fire Department said.

title: Mansur T. Aftab, 65, Entrepreneur, Is Dead
description: Mansur T. Aftab, an entrepreneur who owned decorating companies in New York, New Jersey and Florida, died Friday night when the small plane he was flying crashed as he approached Atlantic City International Airport. He was 65 years old and lived in Hollywood, Fla.

title: Q&A
description: Vitamin Loss Q. How much of food's vitamins and minerals is lost in cooking?

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE-- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M. Security Ccouncil Meets at 10 A.M.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-17

title: Chess Game Adjourned As Wild Play Sputters
description: A wild chess slugfest last night between Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov in Game 14 of the World Championship Match in Lyons, France, sputtered out into an even position after 40 moves. The game was adjourned when the champion wrote down his 41st move and it was stored in the referee's envelope until play resumes this afternoon at 5.

title: The Ghost of Letelier
description: A long shadow is still cast by the 1976 murder in Washington of Orlando Letelier, former Ambassador of the leftist Allende regime in Chile. His car exploded, killing Mr. Letelier and an American friend, Ronni Moffitt. The crime was plotted by an American gun-for-hire, Michael Townley, who recruited help from the violent Cuban Nationalist Movement. The prime instigator was the Chilean dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet, anxious to silence an exiled opponent.

title: Sallie Mae Sets Note Offering
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $150 million in notes due Dec. 18, 1995, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Bluff in Dominica Yields Columbus's First Colony
description: ON a low limestone bluff lapped by turquoise waters, archeologists are scraping away five centuries of decay and covering loam to get at the ruins of the first known European colony established in the Americas, the place Christopher Columbus in 1494 described as a "well-situated rock" and, with extravagant hopes, christened La Isabela.

title: Food Shortages Cause Desperation in Moscow
description: Martina Bogdanova, manager of Food Store No. 19 in the Sverdlovsk District, shrugged her big shoulders as she tried to explain why all but one of the 16 refrigerator cases in her store were empty.

title: Iraq's Aim: High Toll for G.I.'s
description: The Iraqi Government has stepped up its efforts to raise the cost in casualties of any attack on its armed forces, United States military and intelligence specialists say.

title: Beeper Stops Attacker's Bullet
description: A beeper at a man's waist deflected a bullet fired while he defended his girlfriend from a gunman, the police said. They said the gunman grabbed the woman in an underground garage. The boyfriend then entered the garage and the gunman let her go. The boyfriend grabbed for the gun and it went off, firing the shot that was deflected by the beeper, and another shot, which hit the gunman. The dead man was identified as Vernon Justice, 23 years old, of Inglewood.

title: Homeless Man Charged In Attack on Publisher
description: A 35-year-old homeless man was charged yesterday in the stabbing of the publisher of the Zagat New York City Restaurant Review in a Manhattan movie theater earlier this month.

title: Teacher and Novelists Win Literary Prizes
description: A high school English teacher, novelists from Portugal and India and a French philosopher were among the winners of prestigious literary prizes awarded today.

title: Navistar Expands Mexico Truck Pact
description: The Navistar International Corporation said it had more than tripled its stake in Mexico's largest truck builder, Dina Camiones, to 17 percent, and agreed to supply Dina with as many as 5,000 diesel engines annually. The supply agreement "stabilizes the current production levels" at Navistar's Melrose Park engine plant outside Chicago, but it does not guarantee against layoffs, a spokesman, William H. Greenhill, said.

title: Problem for Richardson
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, who last week rejected an offer by the Philadelphia 76ers in order to stay with the Italian club Knorr Bologna, may face disciplinary action after an on-the-court brawl that was broken up by riot police. The 35-year-old former N.B.A. All-Star was identified in initial referee reports as one of the instigators in the fight in the last two minutes of the game Sunday between Ranger Varese and Knorr in Varese. In all, 17 players and team officials were expelled.(AP)

title: Fear Enters Israeli City After a Terrorist Attack
description: In some ways, this city has been an optimist's vision of Israel's future in the midst of its present: a growing Jewish community, sharing quiet borders with Jordan and Egypt, untroubled by political strife or nationalist bloodshed.

title: Bird Helps Celtics To Win 7th in Row
description: Larry Bird led a balanced Boston attack with 21 points, 14 rebounds and 11 assists tonight as the Celtics coasted to their seventh straight victory, a 118-101 decision over the Miami Heat.

title: Air France Account To TBWA Advertising
description: TBWA Advertising has created advertising for French water and cheese, and now it will try to sell French airline services to American consumers. The agency's New York office has won the $5 million account for Air France.

title: Law Professors Demand War-Making Limits
description: A group of 11 of the country's most prominent law professors across a wide ideological range filed a brief today urging a Federal judge to rule that President Bush may not go to war against Iraq unless he receives the explicit permission of Congress.

title: Takeover May Benefit the TV Networks
description: Alfred C.
