Sikes, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that the Matsushita Electric Industrial Corporation's acquisition of MCA Inc. could give a boost to efforts by the television networks to be granted more freedom to own the shows they broadcast and perhaps to own film studios as well.

title: Electrifying Teacher
description: THE Miracle Piano Teaching System, which combines a 49-key electronic piano keyboard and special software for the Nintendo Entertainment System computer, is the first Nintendo product we have seen that has the potential to capture the imagination of parents and teachers, as well as young people.

title: Commercial Credit
description: The Commercial Credit Corporation, a subsidiary of Primerica Holdings Inc., yesterday priced $150 million in notes due in Dec. 1, 1992, through Morgan Stanley & Company. Underwriters said the 8.875 percent notes were priced at 100, or about 137.5 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The noncallable notes are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Security Pacific To Redeem Stock
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, among the largest bank holding companies in the United States, yesterday announced plans to redeem $225 million of its total $525 million in outstanding auction-rate preferred stock.

title: Senators' Keating Ties Assailed by Ex-Official
description: The former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board admonished five Senators today, saying they should have had the sense to steer clear of Charles H. Keating Jr. when he sought their help in fending off Federal banking regulators.

title: 2 Young Designers Decorate Their Clothes With Wit
description: Minimalism has high visibility as a trend in fashion in the hands of such designers as Calvin Klein and Michael Kors. But an alternate direction is springing up. Instead of paring down their clothes, some designers are decorating them. Surfaces are embellished with prints, embroideries and beading. Shapes mimic flowers, a roll of banknotes or elaborate maharani clothes. Some styles are cut to entertain as well as to cover the body.

title: Nets Wield New Sort Of Streak
description: When the Nets played the 76ers three weeks ago, they should have been able to savor their effort. For 47 minutes and 58 seconds on what became a very strange evening in Phiadelphia, they did.

title: Twins and Abuse
description: When twins are abused, one, rather than both, tends to be the victim, a national survey of child abuse in Japan has found.

title: Police Rebut Daily News On Violence
description: Senior New York City police officials yesterday rebutted accusations by The Daily News that the newspaper's nine striking unions were engaged in a criminal conspiracy to disrupt circulation through violence and intimidation.

title: At 11-0, Trail Blazers Aiming Next for Suns
description: The National Basketball Association season began with most coaches echoing the sentiments of Chuck Daly of the Detroit Pistons that at least eight teams had a legitimate shot at winning the title.

title: Guerrillas in Colombia Kidnap 3 American Engineers at Oilfield
description: Leftist guerrillas kidnapped three American and two Colombian engineers at an oilfield in the northeast of the country over the weekend, the Government-run oil company, Ecopetrol, said today.

title: Talking Business with Ammerman of Mattel; Optimistic View Of Toy Industry
description: John W. Ammerman has been chairman and chief executive of Mattel Inc. for nearly four years after serving seven years as head of the company's international operations. He is given credit by analysts with turning around the company's once-flagging fortunes, largely by reinvigorating sales of Mattel's existing products, including the Barbie doll, one of the most successful toy lines of all time.

title: Kaiser Aluminum In Public Offering
description: The Kaiser Aluminum Corporation, one of the world's leading producers of aluminum, has filed an initial public offering of six million common shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Houston-based company, formerly known as Kaisertech Ltd., was acquired by Maxxam Inc. in the fall of 1988 for $850 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Banco Hispano Americano, Madrid, and Rockefeller & Co., the Rockefeller family investment arm, have formed a new investment company in Spain called Corporacion Borealis S.A. * Boise Cascade Corp., Boise, Idaho, said it expected only to break even in the final three months of 1990. Officials at the wood products company said expansion costs, higher interest rates and a weakening market for paper, pulp and corrugated containers would reduce Boise Cascade's profitability. * B. Manischewitz Co., Jersey City, N.J. has had about 77 percent of its common stock purchased by a unit of Kohlberg & Company, a private merchant banking concern. The unit, the Mano Acquisition Corporation, had purchased 40,603 shares of Manischewitz as of last Wednesday. Mano said it had also received guarantees for an additional 2,372 shares, representing another 4 percent of the shares of the kosher food company. Mano offered $800 a share for Manischewitz's 53,072 shares outstanding, in a deal valued at up to $42.5 million. * Philips N.V., Eindhoven, the Netherlands, said its Philips Display Components Co. unit, has postponed plans for a $116 million picture tube plant in Saline, Mich., citing a sluggish American economy. * Sprouse-Reitz Stores Inc., Portland, Ore., an operator of variety stores, said it would be acquired for $16 a share, or $22.9 million, by a concern formed by Transaction Financial Corp., First San Francisco Holdings Ltd. and individual investors. * Ube Industries, Ube City, Japan, a Japanese maker of chemicals, cement and machinery, established a joint venture in Britain with the Marubeni Corp., Osaka, Japan, to provide plastic composites to European auto makers and producers of office automation equipment. The joint venture, to be called European Technological Composites Ltd., is capitalized at $:2 million, equal to about $3.9 million, with Ube Industries holding a 70 percent stake.

title: Legacy of Anti-Tax Fervor: Taxes, But With a Purpose
description: The growing backlash against state and local tax increases has created an imaginative patchwork of thousands of special-purpose taxes as elected officials aim revenue proposals toward specific programs, frequently requiring selected groups of taxpayers to pay for them.

title: Drenttel Doyle Has Success As the All-Purpose Agency
description: DRENTTEL DOYLE PARTNERS, a small New York advertising and design firm, has won the $5 million account for Ellen Tracy's new line of clothing, and the agency's advertising expertise was only part of why it got the job.

title: N.F.L.'s 11th Week Brings a Not-So-Subtle Change in Fortunes
description: For the front-runners and the playoff contenders and pretenders alike, week 11 offered a painful and yet joyous reminder that the National Football League regular season includes 16 games. Fast starts can fizzle into murky dreams. Darkness at the beginning of the tunnel can, after all, lead to light.

title: Ban on Tobacco Ads Is Urged
description: Community and hospital groups urged a ban on tobacco advertising on city and transit agency property today, saying the rate of respiratory illness among low-income residents is startlingly high. The community group, called the Uptown Coalition for Tobacco Control and Public Health, and the Delaware Valley Hospital Council said they would testify Wednesday before the City Council, which is considering an ordinance to limit billboard advertising of tobacco products.

title: S.&P. Lifts Rating on Paper And Jet Lessor's Senior Debt
description: The rating of $1.4 billion in senior debt and commercial paper issued by the International Lease Finance Corporation has been raised, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: Move Reflects a Belief In Role of Sheer Size
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company's acquisition of MCA Inc. is the latest in a series of transactions that have transformed Hollywood, and it almost certainly will not be the last.

title: BULGARIANS STRIKE TO OUST LEADERS
description: Tens of thousands of workers walked off their jobs today in response to a call by the leader of an independent trade union for a general strike to force the resignation of the Socialist Government.

title: Death and a Leather Coat: Family Mourns Slain Man
description: Annette Richardson has spent much of the last two days trying to get her mother, Lula, to put aside her pain and grief for just a moment and to eat something, anything.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Japanese advances in portable computers misstated the affiliation of the Zenith Data Systems Corporation. It is owned by Groupe Bull of France, no longer by the Zenith Electronics Corporation.

title: Key Rates
CHRONICLE
description: Long the interpreter of glasnost in his role as spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, GENNADI I. GERASIMOV has been named the Soviet Ambassador to Portugal. A wisecracking, Westernized former journalist, Mr. Gerasimov disarmed Americans with humor and candor. When trying to explain the Soviet attitude toward the emerging capitalist economies of Hungary and Poland, he invented "the Sinatra doctrine," saying that those nations were doing it their way.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JERRY HALL and MICK JAGGER have finally done it. They got married last Wednesday in Bali, 12 years and two children after they became an item. The wedding took place at the end of a six-week vacation in Asia, said a spokeswoman for Rogers & Cowan, a public-relations firm.

title: Bulldogs' Coach Quits
description: Rockey Felker, under fire for Mississippi State's poor record in the Southeastern Conference, resigned yesterday. The Bulldogs were 21-34 in Felker's five seasons, but only 5-28 in conference play. Mississippi State, which won its only S.E.C. title in 1941, was 5-6 this past season and 1-6 in the conference -- the same marks as in 1989. Felker's contract had a year to go. (AP)

title: Connecticut Rescinds Eviction of a Squatter
description: The state will not evict an elderly woman from her beach shanty in Milford, Attorney General Clarine Nardi Riddle said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Supreme Court Will Decide On Judge Retirement Rules The Supreme Court agreed to hear a case challenging state rules that require judges to retire at the age of 70. A decision by the Justices four of whom are themselves over 70, will resolve conflicting rulings by Federal appellate courts. Page B8. Thatcher's Choice As Britain's Conservatives prepared to select a leader, an aide said Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher wanted John Major, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, to succeed her. Page A7. Empty Stores in Moscow Muscovites are desperately hoarding goods as shortages in state shops approach what many see as the worst level since World War II. Page A14. Stormy Daily News Hearing As The Daily News lost another major advertiser, Alexander's, police officials said they saw no sign of a union conspiracy to hurt The News through violence. Pages B1 and B5. Columbus's Colony The site of Christopher Columbus's settlement La Isabela is emerging in an archeological dig in the Dominican Republic. Science Times, page C1.

title: Thailand Is the Capital of Pirated Tapes
description: A stroll in any direction from any Bangkok hotel brings one face to face with the souk-like world of commercial piracy: cheap copies of Benetton, Lacoste and Polo shirts, of Rolex and Cartier watches, of Lee and Levi's blue jeans, computer software, prescription drugs and, most especially, thousands upon thousands of videotapes and pop, rock and jazz cassettes.

title: A Peruvian Is Laying Out Another Path
description: Hernando de Soto was irritated when a journalist credited him with secret authorship of Peru's new anti-drug policy.

title: Careers; Repair Jobs Are Going High Tech
description: AS computers, robots and other high-technology equipment play a bigger part in daily life, jobs in high-technology services are becoming one of the fastest-growing employment areas, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Arizona Continues On Its Winning Way
description: With a smothering defense and balanced shooting led by Deron Johnson, a reserve who scored 14 points, Arizona defeated Western Illinois, 90-51, tonight.

title: The Gecko Hid Behind the Refrigerator
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank Coss, Executive, 63
description: Frank Coss, a former executive vice president of the Deutsch, Shea & Evans advertising agency, died last Wednesday in Oxford, England. He was 63 years old and had lived in Weston, Conn., for many years before retiring in 1984.

title: Baghdad Is Raising the Stakes
description: Iraq is taking steps to insure that any attack on its troops would entail heavy casualties among American-led forces, experts say. Page A16.

title: Jane Pauley Program Set for January
description: Jane Pauley will return to NBC 's prime-time schedule in January when her news-magazine program "Real Life," which was seen over the summer, is broadcast at 8 P.M. on Sundays. The program will be paired with another series produced by NBC News, "Expose," a program based on the investigative reports of the reporting-producing team of Brian Ross and Ira Silverman. Tom Brokaw will be the anchor "Expose" and may contribute occasional reports.

title: Homosexuals' Suit Seeks Marriage License
description: A homosexual couple sued the District of Columbia today, contending that it had discriminated against them by refusing to approve their request for a marriage license.

title: Louis Clapes, 73, Dies; Ex-Mayor of Stamford
description: Louis Clapes, who served four consecutive terms as mayor of Stamford, Conn., died last Tuesday at St. Joseph Medical Center in Stamford. He was 73 years old and a lifelong Stamford resident.

title: The Framers, on War Powers
description: President Bush promised to appoint judges who would interpret the Constitution strictly. He has lectured us about remaining faithful to the intentions of the Framers. How then can he argue that he has the power to start a war in the Persian Gulf without the express consent of Congress?

title: Floods in Northwest Recede But Leave Questions
description: There is a saying, popular in the Northwest in these environmentally conscious times, that everyone lives downstream from someone else. After the second major flood in two weeks in river basins west of the Cascade Mountains, some waterlogged residents are pointing fingers upstream, toward developers and timber companies.

title: Huge Rebuilding Effort Awaits Kiley's Successor
description: Robert R. Kiley's successor as head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will inherit a network of rail and bus lines and bridges and tunnels on which more than $16 billion has been or will be spent in one of the most expensive rebuilding efforts ever undertaken in the New York region.

title: Early Contributions Kick Off Drive for the Neediest Cases
description: Attached to the $20 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was a brief note: "Please list as anonymous. Do not waste time and postage on acknowledgments."

title: Heinz's Focus On the Family
description: The H. J. Heinz Company is spending more than $10 million in sponsorship to build on the image of ketchup and gravy as being as American as baseball and apple pie. The company is sponsoring "Family Works!" -- a nationally syndicated series of television programs that will focus on family issues.

title: 1918 Gift Yields Home for Elderly Retarded
description: A $2,200 gift by a poet 72 years ago has swelled nearly a hundredfold and will be used to establish a group home for elderly retarded people.

title: Bill Vukovich 3d, 27, Driver of Racing Cars
description: Bill Vukovich 3d, a third-generation race car driver whose grandfather was killed while leading the Indianapolis 500 in 1955, died Sunday after a crash at Mesa Marin Speedway. He was 27 years old.

title: PREMIER IN POLAND RESIGNS AS VOTERS PREFER NEWCOMER
description: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki resigned tonight along with his Government after he was eliminated from Poland's presidential race by an emigre businessman from Canada who was a political unknown just a month ago.

title: Elizabeth Rusciano Wed in Palm Beach
description: Elizabeth Anne Rusciano, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Rusciano of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to William Margrabe, the son of Mary Margrabe of Frederick, Md., and the late Carl W. H. Margrabe. The Rev. David Johnson, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Palm Beach home of the bride's parents.

title: J. C. Satterthwaite, A Director General Of Foreign Service
description: Joseph C. Satterthwaite, a former Assistant Secretary of State who also served as Director General of the Foreign Service, died on Nov. 19 at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 90 years old.

title: Texas Takes A Turn
description: The season is almost over, but no clearly superior college football team has emerged from the pack, a fact reflected in the juggling of the ratings and polls announced yesterday.

title: Ludwig von Moos, Former Swiss President, 80
description: Ludwig von Moos, a former President who also served as Vice President and Justice Minister, died today. He was 80 years old.

title: New Suffolk Budget Angers Chief
description: The Suffolk County Legislature today enacted a $1.3 billion 1991 budget that freezes property taxes, as the County Executive, Patrick G. Halpin, proposed, but severely embarrassed him by abolishing a number of his programs.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Enserch Exploration Inc., an affiliate of Enserch Corp., Dallas, a diversified energy, engineering and construction concern, appointed Gary J. Junco president and chief operating officer, succeeding Robert G. Fowler. * First Interstate Ban of California, Los Angeles, named Diane C. Siegel and Peter K. Ulyatt senior vice presidents. * Lands' End Inc., Dodgeville, Wis., an apparel manufacturer, appointed Thomas L. Ditty vice president of inventory management. * Landmark Bank for Savings, Whitman, Mass., promoted Kenneth A. Peterson to president and chief executive, replacing Roy C. Ekengren, who had been chief executive on an interim basis. * Lawrence Group Inc., Schenectady, N.Y., named Bruce Saxon Wise executive vice president, secretary and treasurer, and Joseph K. Ram senior vice president of United Republic Reinsurance Co., Houston, a subsidiary of the Lawrence Insurance Group Inc. division in Albany. * Micropigmentation Devices Inc.., Edison, N.J., sellers and distributors of cosmetic surgical equipment, named Joseph M. Cooperstein president and chief executive. * Right Associates, Philadelphia, an outplacement counseling service for executives, appointed Peter J. Doris executive vice president for its Canadian region and North American business development division.

title: Hawaiian Group May Buy Ameron
description: A Hawaiian investment group said it was considering the purchase of Ameron Inc., a Monterey Park, Calif., construction products manufacturer. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the investment group said that it had talked with third parties about financing an acquisition but that no agreements had been reached.

title: Alexander's Joins Large Retailers That Won't Advertise in The News
description: Alexander's, one of the largest advertisers in the strike-crippled Daily News, said yesterday that it had stopped advertising in the paper, and another chain, Abraham & Straus, confirmed reports that it had pulled out too.

title: U.N. DRAFT OFFERS ONE 'FINAL' CHANCE FOR IRAQI PULLOUT
description: The draft text of a United Nations Security Council resolution allows Iraq "one final opportunity" to pull its troops out of Kuwait by mid-January or face the possibility of a military conflict with the United States and other forces now in the Persian Gulf area, diplomats here said today.

title: Jets' Quarterback Picture Cloudy
description: Ken O'Brien's status as the starting quarterback for the Jets was in limbo today after he was benched in the fourth quarter of Sunday's 24-7 loss to Pittsburgh and replaced by Tony Eason.

title: F.D.A. Ruling Sought For Engineered Crops
description: Concerned about the public's acceptance of the use of genetic engineering in producing fresh and processed foods, a California company today became the first in the agricultural biotechnology industry to ask the Food and Drug Administration to study the safety of a new tomato and two other gene-altered crops.

title: Market Place; Pricing a Station In Biggest Market
description: JUST what is a television station worth in the New York market? That question will soon be answered, as investors get a chance to buy the first "pure play" available. WWOR-TV is being spun off from MCA Inc. as part of its deal to be acquired by Matsushita.

title: California Democrats Criticize Chief
description: After a two-year grace period, California Democrats have started telling Jerry Brown jokes again. Republicans, of course, never stopped.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Donald Ulrich, an Air Force physicist, misstated the hometown of a daughter, Carolyn Ulrich. She lives in Amherst, Mass., not Alexandria, Va.

title: New York Transit, Back on Track
description: In his seven years as chairman of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Robert Kiley has presided over the comeback of the city's mass transit system. What was once a frustrating and grim test of endurance -- riding the buses, subways and commuter trains of New York -- is now reasonably efficient. His achievement deserves New York's gratitude.

title: Oregon Lottery Hits a Snag
description: The Oregon Lottery's basketball betting game is a financial flop that should be discontinued, the state Lottery Commission said today.

title: At Baghdad's Bazaar, Everyone Wants Hostages
description: It has come to resemble a bazaar, this pleading and wheedling and haggling for the release of a hostage.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Thrifty Names President Of Its Drugstore Chain
description: The Thrifty Corporation said yesterday that it had named Eve A. Rich president of Thrifty Drug Stores, the company's Southern California drugstore chain.

title: Freer World Trade Falls Victim to Its Own Success
description: In seven rounds of global trade talks over four decades, tariff rates have been slashed by more than 75 percent. As imports became so much cheaper, trade across frontiers surged, and workers the world over produced a staggering amount of wealth.

title: Corrections
description: The Guide column of the Westchester Weekly on Sunday misstated the date of the "Survival Tactics IV" conference, sponsored by the United Way of Westchester and Putnam to help nonprofit organizations seek corporate support. It will be held at the Marriott Hotel in Tarrytown on Thursday, not Saturday. The registration number is (914) 997-6763.

title: Saudis in Korea Oil Venture
description: The state-owned Saudi Arabian Oil Company today announced an agreement in principle to set up a joint oil refining company in South Korea with the Ssangyong Oil Refining Company, the official Saudi press agency reported.

title: In Manhattan, Vacant Stores Are a Sign of Hard Times
description: There are signs of economic distress all over Manhattan these days, and many of them say "Space Available" or "Store for Rent."

title: U.S. Aide Sees 'Step Forward' In Cambodian Peace Process
description: A senior United States Government official said today that the latest round of international talks on a Cambodian peace plan had produced "an important step forward in the process of a political settlement" in Cambodia.

title: Liberian Factions Gather to Start Peace Talks
description: The leaders of Liberia's main political factions gathered here today in preparation for long-planned peace talks.

title: Judge in Noriega Case Says Image of Trial Worries Him
description: The Federal judge who will preside over the trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega delivered an unusually pointed commentary on the case today, saying he was deeply concerned about the image of the case but "bound and determined that this defendant is going to get a fair trial."

title: Two Eagles Rookies Are Rising to Challenge
description: With Mike Quick limping and Cris Carter falling out of favor in Buddy Ryan's all-or-nothing approach in loyalty to his players, Ryan hit the 1990 draft bent on gaining speedy wide receivers to complement Randall Cunningham, Keith Byars and Keith Jackson.

title: BAN IS LEFT INTACT ON SUBWAY BEGGING
description: The Supreme Court today let stand a ban on begging in the New York City subway system, refusing to hear an appeal by lawyers for a group of homeless people who argued that asking others for money was a form of free speech the Government could not prohibit.

title: Fiction Pays for Putnam Publishing Unit
description: When MCA Inc. bought G. P. Putnam's Sons in 1975, the house was publishing more than 225 hardcover titles a year. Today, Putnam publishes only 70 to 80 books a year, but its revenues are eight times as high.

title: MD-11 Deliveries Set by McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it would deliver on Thursday its first MD-11 jetliner to Finnair, the national airline of Finland. The delivery will mark the end of the development and testing phase of the MD-11 program, which has cost the company $3.3 billion, and the beginning of full-scale production and delivery.

title: Jon Epstein TV Producer, 62
description: Jon Epstein, producer of the television mini-series "Rich Man, Poor Man" and executive producer of the "Columbo" series, died of leukemia on Saturday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center here. He was 62 years old.

title: Knicks Aim to Build Defense and Consistency
description: Consistency is a trademark of good teams. Lately, the Knicks have not been very consistent, nor have they been very good.

title: Review/Music; Two Points of View on the Baroque
description: Two period-instrument bands -- the Artek Ensemble and Musica Antiqua Koln -- set out to make distinct historical points at their concerts on Sunday. Although the performances were not related, taken together they proved an interesting overview of the musical ferment of the 18th century and of the way the complexities of Baroque style were supplanted by the simpler elegance of Classical forms.

title: Indonesia Government Bans a Times Reporter
description: A reporter for The New York Times has been banned from Indonesia for an article he wrote about President Suharto, according to the Indonesian Information Minister, Harmoko. The International Herald Tribune, in which the article was reprinted Nov. 12, is no longer being distributed in Indonesia as a result.

title: Rebel Economists Add Ecological Cost To Price of Progress
description: COULD biologists, ecologists and other natural scientists have more to say about the economics of the environment than economists themselves?

title: A Japanese Developer Is Bankrupt
description: In what could prove one of the largest bankruptcies in postwar Japan, the Kyowa Company, a construction concern that became caught up in the real estate and golf course development craze, filed in court today for the equivalent of bankruptcy petition.

title: How to Let Arab States Work It Out With Iraq; A Reasonable Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: On Morning After, a Wake-Up Call for 10-1 Rivals; 49ers Are Lamenting End of Their Streak
description: The day after wasn't much better than the night before. Even though the sun rose quickly in the morning sky, it still didn't wash away the memory of a stormy Sunday for the San Francisco 49ers.

title: George Nichols 3d, Producer, 70, Dies
description: George Nichols 3d, a theatrical producer and a member of the board of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, died on Thursday at his home in Watch Hill, R.I. He was 70 years old and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Politics and Multinational Movies
description: When he announced Japan's largest purchase yet in the United States, the president of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company appeared to fuel the political concerns surrounding the deal with a surprise omission: He refused to say that the Japanese consumer electronics giant would not interfere with the content of MCA's movies, records or books.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE DEAL FOR MCA

title: Home-Computer Network Criticized for Limiting Users
description: The Prodigy Services Company, an in-home shopping and information service for personal-computer users, has issued guidelines restricting its electronic mail service.

title: The Gecko Hid Behind the Refrigerator; Owner's Obligation
description: To the Editor:

title: Czech Communists Gain Seats in Local Elections
description: Czechoslovak voters sent a warning today to Civic Forum, President Vaclav Havel's political movement, by giving an unexpected salute to the Communist Party in this country's first free municipal elections in 52 years.

title: THE DEAL FOR MCA;
description: MCA Inc., one of the nation's largest entertainment companies, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company. The deal, valued at $6.13 billion plus stock in a television station, will be the largest purchase ever of an American company by a Japanese company.

title: Dedication to Entertainment Has Been Profitable at MCA
description: No Hollywood studio has adhered as closely as MCA Inc. to the theme that "there is no business like show business."

title: Kremlin Insists That Iraqis Let Russians Leave
description: The Soviet Union demanded today that Iraq release more than 3,000 Soviet citizens stranded there, charging for the first time that Baghdad was preventing them from leaving.

title: Much Envy on Wall St. On Fees in MCA's Sale
description: After years of watching the flow of big-money deals evaporate, Wall Street's investment bankers and lawyers looked on yesterday's announced $6.13 billion acquisition of MCA by Matsushita Electric Industrial with envy.

title: William H. Lewis Jr., Internist, Is Dead at 88
description: Dr. William H. Lewis Jr., a former New York internist who played a role in the early years of nuclear medicine, died on Saturday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 88 years old and had lived in Washington for the last two years.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS BUSH TO PUT OFF MILITARY ACTION
description: With the United Nations Security Council due to approve a resolution later this week authorizing the use of military force against Iraq any time after Jan. 15, Senate Democrats urged the Bush Administration today to delay taking military action and give economic sanctions more time to work.

title: Sears Issue Backed By Credit Cards
description: A $500 million issue of pass-through certificates backed by Sears, Roebuck credit cards was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: Thatcher Loyalist Chosen as Successor; Finance Official Beats 2 Rivals in Tory Vote
description: John Major was selected as the next Prime Minister of Britain tonight after his two rivals in the Conservative Party leadership contest withdrew and conceded that he could best unite their divided ranks before the next elections.

title: The 'Start' Treaty: A New Urgency
description: If we are worried about the fate of nuclear weapons in a disintegrating Soviet Union, there is one concrete step that we can take: complete the Start treaty.

title: Pressure to Help an S. & L. Is Recalled
description: A former chief regulator for the nation's savings and loan industry recounted in dramatic detail for the Senate Ethics Committee today how he had been summoned to a meeting in Senator Dennis DeConcini's office and had found himself surrounded by four influential Senators seeking help for a savings and loan executive, Charles H. Keating Jr.

title: After Decades of Rises, Rents Sag in Much of New York City
description: For the first time since the Great Depression, apartment rents are dropping in much of New York City.

title: A Little Lamb in Midtown
description: Recently a pedestrian waiting to cross 43d Street at Eighth Avenue was startled to see, waiting on the opposite corner, a lamb. No, it wasn't an uncoiffed poodle or a rare breed of terrier. It was a lamb -- white as snow, a face as innocent as a baby's. It had a pink ribbon around its neck, and was being led by a quite blase-looking young man.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Kurt Weill's Theater Music
description: The Music Today ensemble, under the direction of Robert Kapilow, is to present a program called "I Am an American: The American Theater Music of Kurt Weill" at 8 P.M. on Dec. 5 at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. It is to feature excerpts from "Huck Finn," "Lost in the Stars," "Street Scene" and other shows written by Weill from 1936 to 1950. Joining the group is to be the soprano Angelina Reaux. Tickets are $15 and are available at the box office. Information: 362-8719.

title: Coleman Does It All: 28 Points, 23 Rebounds
description: There was such a focus this month on Nets' streaks that the latest version might be difficult to believe. It shouldn't be.

title: Blazers Lose to Suns And Streak Ends at 11
description: Tom Chambers scored 28 points and Eddie Johnson had 21 of his 25 in the second period tonight as the Phoenix Suns built and lost an 18-point halftime lead before ending the previously unbeaten Portland Trail Blazers' 11-game winning streak, 123-109.

title: Moves Urged In Trade Talks
description: The head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said today that after four years of hard bargaining, the talks were in a crisis, and he urged ministers who will meet at the final session in Brussels next week to reach early compromises.

title: Trusts for the Disabled Gaining Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Speech Not Issue In Misogynist Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Stock Certificates: Outmoded Now?
description: MUCH of Wall Street doesn't like the idea, but share certificates are here to stay. The big question appears to be whether it will be the brokerage houses, or those individual investors who demand physical certificates, that pay the costs of an increasingly inefficient system.

title: McKinney Retires From Race Competition
description: Tamara McKinney, whose 18 victories in World Cup Alpine competition are the most by an American, announced her retirement from competitive racing yesterday. McKinney, who is 28 years old and has been a member of the United States Ski Team for 13 years, will become an official spokeswoman for Jimmie Heuga's Mazda Ski Express, a charity ski series that raises money to help fight multiple sclerosis.

title: Books of The Times; Wastepaper Love Story Amid the Cellar's Secrets
description: Too Loud a Solitude By Bohumil Hrabal Translated by Michael Henry Heim. 98 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich . $16.95.

title: Earning Success
description: To The Living Section:

title: Bulgarian Communist Stalwart Says He'd Do It All Differently
description: Todor Zhivkov, Bulgaria's deposed Communist dictator, long regarded as the East bloc leader most subservient to Moscow, looked back on his long political career during an interview here on Monday and said it was all a big mistake.

title: Chocolate Cakes Worthy of the Calories
description: CHOCOLATE cakes, unlike Western sunsets or Cezannes, are not all worthy of superlatives. But those that are, often discovered after determined searching and indulgent tasting, become the chocolate lover's culinary bench marks.

title: Central City Chorus To Offer a Rare Cantata
description: The Central City Chorus is to present Ralph Vaughan Williams's rarely heard Christmas cantata "Hodie" at 7 P.M. on Dec. 16 at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street. The program also includes Vaughan Williams's "Fantasia on Christmas Carols."

title: Witness Contradicts Herself in Bensonhurst Case
description: A prosecution witness in the Bensonhurst murder case stumbled often in her testimony yesterday, contradicting much of her previous testimony about the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins.

title: Book Notes
description: Novel of the Great War

title: INSIDE
description: Behind Telescope's Flaw

title: Soviet Envoy Says U.S. Accepts Jan. 15 Deadline
description: The United Nations Security Council will set Jan. 15 as the date for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw his forces from Kuwait or risk having them forcibly ejected by the armies of the United States and its allies, a senior Soviet official said tonight.

title: Francis T. Offer, 69, Ex-Iona College Dean
description: Francis T. Offer, a member of the Congregation of Christian Brothers for more than 50 years and a former dean of admissions at Iona College, died on Sunday at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 69 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: We Can't Afford More Delay on Hudson River Waterfront Park; 'Why I Voted "No" '
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; Giving Up a Child and Being Given Up
description: The joys, pains and perplexities of adoption are the subjects of tonight's strong edition of "48 Hours," at 8 on CBS . "Family Secrets" focuses on four cases: a young New Yorker who is trying to track down what the program calls his "birth mother" (the term "real mother," with all that it connotes, is scrupulously avoided); another man, who appears at the home of the Michigan couple who gave him up for adoption 20 years earlier, only to be rejected again; an 18-year-old who is reunited with her biological mother, who was 15 when she gave birth, and an unmarried couple who give up their newborn baby to another young couple they have helped to choose.

title: Review/Music; A Master of His Style at 75
description: The generation of pianistsraised in the Romantic virtuoso tradition has been dwindling for decades, and in the last 13 months it has lost two of its standard-bearers, Vladimir Horowitz and Jorge Bolet. One of the few surviving masters of the style, Earl Wild, celebrated his 75th birthday on Monday with a recital at Carnegie Hall.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about four days of unusually high and low tides beginning on Saturday misidentified a contributing condition. It is a full moon, not a new moon.

title: Life's Savory Moments
description: To The Living Section:

title: Short Sales Outstanding Post Increase of 3.6% on Nasdaq
description: In a short sale, an investor, believing that a stock's price will decline, sells borrowed stock in anticipation of buying back an equal number of shares later at a lower price, thereby making a profit. Views of Analysts Differ

title: Sheriff Forced to Move Out of Backup Jail
description: The Hampden County sheriff, who seized a National Guard armory nine months ago after running out of cell space, said today that a lack of money is forcing him to withdraw.

title: Nomura to Take Over Office Space of Merrill
description: The American division of the Nomura Securities Company, the huge Japanese brokerage, announced yesterday that it had agreed to take over a large amount of office space at the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan being leased by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Airlift to Gulf: Homework and Pencils
description: Next to the Iraqi Army, perhaps the biggest enemy facing American troops in the Persian Gulf is boredom.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Currents column of The Home Section on Oct. 18, with a report about hand-painted signs by Shoo Hale, was published in error. The sign shown was not painted by Ms. Hale. She wrote to The Times about the error in mid-October; this correction has been delayed by an editing error.

title: Suit Faults Exemption on Services For Catholic AIDS Nursing Homes
description: Three advocacy groups for people with AIDS are challenging a New York State decision to exempt Catholic-operated AIDS nursing homes from requirements that patients receive condoms, safe-sex counseling, and abortion services.

title: Dow Rises 10.64; O-T-C Issues in Big Gains
description: Blue-chip stocks edged higher yesterday, but smaller over-the-counter issues scored stronger gains.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE holiday season always makes me nostalgic for the foods associated with my native Burgundy. Chicken, inexpensive and versatile, was a staple that my mother prepared in countless ways.

title: Surgeon Is Sentenced to Jail In the Theft of 70 Rare Coins
description: A California surgeon was sentenced to six months in jail and fined $1 million after his plea of guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to charges that he stole an estimated $1 million in rare coins, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday.

title: The League Serves Notice
description: Lisa Olson wanted to be a byline, not a household name. When she left law school after a year, her parents were not amused. They wanted their daughter to have a profession, not a "sports beat" with a newspaper.

title: Mandela Meets de Klerk; No Sign of Accord
description: Nelson Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk met here today to try to resolve differences that have stalled proposed negotiations between the African National Congress and the South African Government.

title: Sandwiches: Anything Goes
description: "ONCE, when I was mad at my brothers, I mixed lard with peanut butter, raw egg and sugar, spread it on white bread and gave it to them," said Benita Rodney, a 38-year-old private secretary who lives in Washington. "And don't you know, they ate it."

title: 14 African Leaders Press Liberian on Cease-Fire
description: Fourteen African heads of state pressed the rebel leader Charles Taylor tonight to agree to a cease-fire in an effort to end Liberia's 11-month-old civil war.

title: New 'S' and Old 'U' in U.S.S.R.
description: If Mikhail Gorbachev has his way, the post-Socialist Soviet Union will remain the U.S.S.R. By making it the Union of Sovereign Soviet Republics, he hopes to keep it from degenerating into disunion. Depending on what he means by the word sovereign, it's an outcome Americans can welcome. As the Bush Administration recognizes, the U.S. is better off helping a pluralist Soviet Union than encouraging many separate Soviet states.

title: Cutbacks Set By Aer Lingus
description: Aer Lingus, fighting rising fuel costs and weakening traffic demands, said yesterday that it would defer the start of Los Angeles-Ireland passenger service until at least 1992 and take other cost-cutting measures, including suspending Los Angeles-Ireland freight service.

title: Newspaper Ad Official
description: Alfred Eisenpreis, senior vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau and a former economic development commissioner of the City of New York, said yesterday that he will retire from the advertising bureau on Jan. 31, 1991, but will remain a consultant to the organization. A widely known adviser on retailing and advertising, the 66-year old Mr. Eisenpreis served as corporate marketing vice president for Allied Stores from 1970 until 1974, when he became the city's economic development chief. He joined the advertising bureau in 1976.

title: Bank Yields Are Lower For 3d Week
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts for the week ended yesterday were lower for the third consecutive week.

title: F.B.I. Accused Of Keeping Files On Foundation
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit yesterday charging that the Federal Bureau of Investigation illegally kept files on the J. Roderick MacArthur Foundation and its president, Lance Lindblom.

title: Harvard Will Pay More To Cambridge in Accord
description: Breaking fresh ground in town-gown relations, Harvard University has entered into a 10-year agreement with the city of Cambridge that will substantially increase the university's payments to the city in lieu of taxes and will calculate a portion of those payments at current tax rates.

title: Rangers Sign Patrick Through 1993
description: The Rangers, who weeks ago agreed to terms in principle with James Patrick, officially announced yesterday that they had signed the gifted defenseman to a new contract.

title: Chemical Plants Buy Up Neighbors for Safety Zone
description: Prodded by lawsuits over pollution and damage claims from a number of explosions, several of the nation's largest oil and chemical companies are spending millions of dollars to create safety zones by buying up the homes around their plants.

title: Almost Forgotten Skills
description: To The Living Section:

title: Washington Talk; Bush and the Economy: Any Cure for the Jitters?
description: To Presidents, the economy hardly ever looks good. Recession seems to be looming or, if not, inflation is threatening, or the markets are down, or productivity is lagging, or something else is wrong that the voters might hold them responsible for. By the middle of their term, the economist Herbert Stein has observed, Presidents come "face to face with the dreadful prospect" that unless they change course, they might enter their re-election campaign "with an economy in misery."

title: Reviews/Music; Manhattan Philharmonic in a Choral Near-Marathon
description: To get to Carnegie Hall, performers have to practice -- these days, often quickly. Peter Tiboris's Manhattan Philharmonic, the orchestral arm of Mid-America Productions, which specializes in massing choruses for monster concerts, opened its eighth season on Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with a typically ambitious program: Mozart's "Coronation" Mass (K. 317), David Willcocks's "Ceremony of Psalms" and Liszt's "Faust Symphony."

title: WINE TALK
description: NOTHING is more frustrating than trying to make sense of the stock of the average wine shop, especially since the most familiar names are too often found on the most expensive bottles.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SALMAN RUSHDIE, a frequent critic of MARGARET THATCHER, emerged from hiding on Monday to appear on "The Late Show," a late-night arts program on BBC, to discuss the British Prime Minister's resignation and the current political situation. In the course of the program, Mr. Rushdie revealed that he was talking to Muslim leaders, although he did not disclose any details.

title: Daniel O'Sullivan, 61; Led Insurance Concern
description: Daniel E. O'Sullivan, an insurance industry executive, died on Sunday at Fairfax Hospital in Fairfax, Va. He was 61 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Messier Paces Oiler Victory Mark Messier had four assists, and Martin Gelinas and Craig Simpson scored 1 minute 43 seconds apart as the visiting Edmonton Oilers got five consecutive goals in a 7-3 victory last night over the Pittsburgh Penguins. Gelinas scored his sixth goal at 4:03 of the second period, taking Ken Linseman's pass and beating Pittsburgh's Frank Pietrangelo from 10 feet to tie the game at 3-3. Simpson scored his 11th after taking a behind-the-back pass from Messier.(AP) Red Wings 4, Kings 3: Bob Probert's seventh goal, with 2:05 remaining, gave Detroit the home-ice victory, its third consecutive triumph. Jimmy Carson skated behind the Kings' net and flipped a perfect pass to Probert, who tapped it past the Los Angeles goalie, Daniel Berthiaume. It was only the second defeat for Berthiaume (9-2-0), who started the season with five consecutive victories and went into the game with a 2.58 goals-against average. (AP)

title: 5 Israeli Soldiers Killed in a Guerrilla Clash in Southern Lebanon
description: Five Israeli soldiers were killed and a sixth was wounded early this morning during a firefight with Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon.

title: Key Rates
Falk's Career Strategy: Who Needs a Strategy?
description: 'Falk -- he's in this movie, he's in that movie," Peter Falk was saying in his patented growly shorthand. "He plays a soap-opera guy. Plays Columbo. Plays this. Plays that. Where is the consistency here?"

title: Panel on Space Telescope Cites Flaws in Management
description: The serious defect in the main mirror of the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope went undetected because of flawed management procedures at the space agency and the contractor, a Federal study panel said today.

title: Leonard Bout Near
description: Officials of Madison Square Garden Boxing have called a news conference for tomorrow, when they will announce that the Garden will stage Sugar Ray Leonard's next fight on Feb. 9, a challenge of Terry Norris' World Boxing Council junior middleweight title. The bout will be televised by Showtime, the cable network.

title: New Top Posts Filled By AMEV Holdings
description: Allen R. Freedman, who built a group of insurance companies in the United States for Dutch investors, has been named chairman and chief executive of AMEV Holdings, the American unit that he created.

title: Economic Scene; George Bush's Secret Weapon
description: WAS it Willie Horton, or the L-word, or the "read my lips" ploy that sunk Michael Dukakis's bid for the Presidency in 1988? None of the above, argues Ray C. Fair, an economist at Yale University who moonlights as a political prognosticator. Mr. Fair, who has just updated his remarkably accurate statistical model for explaining Presidential election results to include the Bush-Dukakis contest, suggests that nothing much can change the predisposition of voters to elect Republicans (especially incumbent Republicans) except parlous economic times.

title: Toyota Confirms Doubling Of Kentucky Plant Capacity
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation's plan to double its car-making capacity in Georgetown, Ky., officially announced today, will create one of the largest automotive complexes in North America. The expansion will give Toyota the ability to build 400,000 Camry models a year and challenge the Honda Accord and Ford Taurus as the most popular cars in the United States.

title: Carolina Plant to Encase Atomic Wastes in Glass
description: In a milestone on the road to cleaning up the residue of 40 years of atomic bomb making, the Department of Energy dedicated a $1.3 billion plant today to deal with its most hazardous wastes: millions of gallons of highly radioactive sludges and liquids in decaying steel tanks.

title: Barrier to Sale of Coliseum Is Removed by Appeals Court
description: The New York State Court of Appeals yesterday removed one of the last legal barriers to development of a huge commercial project on the site of the New York Coliseum.

title: The Pop Life
description: Of Steve Winwood

title: Having Helped a Friend, Bush Leaves Mexico
description: It ended today with the requisite joint statements of Mexican-American solidarity on everything from drugs to the Persian Gulf. But the 28-hour visit to northern Mexico by President Bush seemed primarily a demonstration of the lengths to which he will go to indulge his favorite pastime, high-level diplomacy, and reward a political ally.

title: Wells Fargo Shuts Offices
description: Wells Fargo & Company, which relied heavily on lending for real estate and highly indebted companies to become one of the country's most profitable banks in the 1980's, is closing seven loan production offices in California and other parts of the country.

title: Procter & Gamble Sells Debentures
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is selling $1 billion in 9.36 percent guaranteed employee stock ownership plan debentures that are due in 2021, through Merrill Lynch & Company as sole manager for the offering.

title: Madonna Video Goes Too Far for MTV
description: Madonna, who has made several controversial music-videos since becoming a star six years ago, has finally made one that MTV refuses to broadcast.

title: Teen-Ager Is the Winner Of the Rostropovich Contest
description: Wendy Warner, an 18-year-old from Evanston, Ill., won the top prize in the fourth international Rostropovich Cello Competition here on Saturday. She performed the Prokofiev Symphony-Concerto for Cello and Orchestra (Op. 125), with the Orchestra of Bordeaux-Aquitaine.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: BRIEFS
description: * Businessland Inc., San Jose, Calif., said it had signed a contract with the Eastman Kodak Co. to design and install an automated purchasing system. * Chrysler Corp., Detroit, said it would offer $500 rebates on its 1991 mini-vans through Dec. 31. * Daltex Medical Sciences Inc., Fairfield, N.J., a maker of medical devices and scientific products, said its proposed acquisition of Safeskin Corp., a maker of surgical gloves, had been delayed. * Digital Microwave Corp., San Jose, Calif., said it had agreed to develop advanced microwave radio products with the American Telephone and Telegraph Co. * Guinness P.L.C., the British brewer, said a subsidiary had reached an agreement to acquire 67.5 percent of Asbach & Company, a German distiller. * Hollywood Park Operating Co., Inglewood, Calif., said its board had recommended selling the Hollywood Park race track. * Marriott Corp., Bethesda, Md., the hotel chain, has sold its Amsterdam hotel to Goteborgs Betonbyggen A.B., a Swedish company, for $57 million. Marriott will manage the hotel. * Montedison S.p.A., Milan, Italy, the chemicals and pharmaceuticals concern, said it was creating a new holding company, Montecatini S.p.A., to oversee its chemicals, pharmaceuticals and energy businesses.A.T.&T.

title: Alaska Oil Cleanup Is Put at 85%
description: About 85 percent of the shoreline fouled in the Exxon Valdez oil spill has been sufficiently cleaned, Alaska's spill coordinator said Monday as the state released the cleanup plan for 1991.

title: Knicks Suffer Third Straight Defeat at the Garden
description: Before last night's game, the Knicks were already concerned about their recent performances.

title: Bill on Lip-Synching Is Proposed in Boston
description: Two state lawmakers have filed a bill to prevent singing groups like the pop duo Milli Vanilli from lip-synching in concert in Massachusetts without announcing that they are doing it.

title: Philanthropist's Memorials
description: Memorial services for Marion Rosenwald Ascoli, a philanthropist who was head of the Citizens Committee for Children of New York, will be held on Sunday and Monday. There will be a service at 4 P.M. on Sunday at the Teatown Lake Reservation in Ossining, N.Y., noting Mrs. Ascoli's gift of 150 acres of her estate in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., to the reservation, a conservancy group. The second service, at 4:30 P.M. on Monday, will be at the New-York Historical Society, 77th Street and Central Park West. Mrs. Ascoli died on Oct. 1 at the age of 88.

title: Witness Against Milken Settles S.E.C. Charges
description: A former money manager who was an important Government witness against Michael R. Milken yesterday settled charges of insider trading, market manipulation and other illegal acts with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Trade Deficit Much Wider in 3d Quarter
description: The United States trade deficit, aggravated by rising oil prices and a drop in farm exports, swelled to $29.75 billion from July through September, the worst quarterly imbalance in a year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Patriots and 3 Players Fined in Olson Incident
description: Paul Tagliabue, commissioner of the National Football League, yesterday fined Zeke Mowatt of the New England Patriots $12,500, two other players $5,000 each and the team $50,000 for a locker-room incident that the league found to have included conduct degrading to a female reporter.

title: Paternity Test at Issue in New Jersey Sex-Assault Case
description: A sophisticated genetics test that has proven increasingly useful in paternity cases over the last decade is creating problems in criminal assault trials, where genetics experts must talk of probabilities in an arena where "beyond a reasonable doubt" is the standard.

title: Myricks Ban Dropped
description: The Athletic Congress yesterday announced that it was dropping a lifetime ban against Larry Myricks for testing positive for drugs and making the two-time world indoor long-jump champion eligible to compete again on April 13, 1991. At its annual convention in Seattle, the executive committee on Monday accepted the recommendation of a reinstatement panel to commute Myricks's suspension.

title: Citing Violence, Bangladesh Declares State of Emergency
description: The Government declared a state of emergency today after weeks of violence by opposition forces demanding that President H. M. Ershad resign.

title: A Chestnut Baedeker and a Hint to Make the Peeling Easier
description: THE song about chestnuts roasting on an open fire may be American, but the nuts have long been imported. American chestnuts were all but wiped out by a blight early in this century. Yet if several entrepreneurs have their way, there may again be chestnuts grown in America to roast on the fire, sell on the streets and perhaps even turn into marrons glaces, the French confection that requires 12 steps to produce.

title: Ludwig J. Cibelli; Obstetrician, 82
description: Ludwig J. Cibelli, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist, died on Monday at Nassau County Medical Center. He was 82 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: Bicknell Dropped by Boston College
description: Jack Bicknell, who coached Boston College to four bowl games in his first six seasons but had losing records in his last four, was dismissed today after 10 years as head football coach.

title: Garbage Collectors Threaten a Strike in New York
description: Private sanitation workers who pick up about 40 percent of New York City's garbage from 250,000 businesses may strike next week if a new contract is not reached with the garbage-hauling industry.

title: Owner Strangles Daily News
description: To understand the real issue behind The Daily News strike, New Yorkers must realize that the bitter struggle being waged in the streets, in news columns and on the airwaves is not primarily between union employees and management.

title: Court Gives Eastern Air $135 Million
description: A Bankruptcy Court judge yesterday allowed Eastern Airlines to draw up to $135 million in escrow funds to help assure that the airline can keep operating through early next year.

title: Is Dancing Kosher? Jews Struggle to Define Orthodoxy
description: The waters of the Hudson River gently lapped at the bow of the cruise ship sailing under the flag of the Glatt Yacht as it slowly pulled from the noisy shoreline of Manhattan. A couple celebrating a special anniversary got up to dance as the pianist played Billy Joel's "Just the Way You Are."

title: People
description: * William P. Daily, a senior vice president at Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, Chicago, will join the Quaker Oats Company as director of sports marketing. * Jimmy E. Manis, vice president and general manager of the Pittsburgh Press Company, and Dennis Stoakes, vice president and director of media for North America for Hiram Walker-Allied Vintners, Toronto, were named directors of the board for the Audit Bureau of Circulation.

title: Dispute With Minors Remains Unresolved
description: The status of the negotiations between the major leagues and the minor leagues remained unclear after yesterday's attempt to reach an agreement that would preserve their 87-year association.

title: The Bane of Nations
description: The new partition threatening Europe is not just between rich and poor, comfortable and desperate. It is also between countries that have learned to pool some sovereignty, for mutual benefit, and those determined to assert sovereign separatism.

title: Zoning Law Ruling to Delay 6 Large Real-Estate Projects
description: In a court decision that is certain to delay some of New York's largest real-estate projects, including Donald J. Trump's plans for a phalanx of office and apartment towers along the Hudson River, a New York State Supreme Court judge on Monday struck down a city zoning law provision that was enacted in February.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: The Best of Organic

title: The World vs. the Slorc
description: Despite democracy's global advance, a murderous military tyranny still dominates Myanmar, formerly called Burma. The regime, known by the acronym Slorc, has for more than two years used terror tactics to thwart a brave democracy movement. Slorc leaders have ordered the massacre of thousands of peaceful demonstrators, intimidated Buddhist monasteries, defied the overwhelming verdict of free elections and sought to eliminate the leadership of the main democratic party.

title: Bronx Youth Is Not Indicted In a Slaying
description: A grand jury yesterday voted not to indict a young Bronx man who hunted down a man he believed had mugged and molested his mother and then stabbed him to death during a struggle.

title: California Utilities Merger Opposed
description: A Federal regulator today recommended against the proposed merger of two large California utilities, Southern California Edison and San Diego Gas and Electric.

title: New Delhi Orders Direct Rule For 3d Violence-Ridden State
description: The Indian Government placed the northeastern state of Assam under direct rule from New Delhi late Tuesday, the Government said today, citing what it called the state's failure to curb an insurgency.

title: Denver Fuel Tank Fire Is Extinguished at Last
description: A huge fire that burned unchecked for two days near Stapleton International Airport was extinguished today with help from specialists flown in from Texas.

title: John Pollard, 67, Dies; A Family Court Judge
description: John F. Pollard, a lawyer, a retired police lieutenant and a former judge in Family Court in the Bronx, died on Monday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Darling Is Wondering What's Next
description: Are the Mets planning to sever one more link to their past by trading Ron Darling, who became the senior member of the team when Darryl Strawberry decamped to Los Angeles three weeks ago?

title: Soviet Union Buys U.S. Flour
description: The Soviet Union today made its first purchase of American flour under the United States Government's export subsidy program.

title: Nguyen Van Tam, Vietnamese Statesman, 97
description: Nguyen Van Tam, who served as Prime Minister to Emperor Bao Dai of Vietnam from 1952 to 1953, died on Friday, his family said on Monday. He was 97 years old.

title: Shop? Many Say, Only if I Must
description: "SHOP till you drop" may have been the mind-set for the 1980's. But these days, a new phenomenon is emerging: the shopping dropout.

title: We Can't Afford More Delay on Hudson River Waterfront Park;   'Why I Voted "No" '
description: To the Editor:

title: Chip Company Is Established
description: A new computer chip company has been formed with the backing of Apple Computer Inc., VLSI Technology Inc., Acorn Computers of Britain and the Sanyo Electric Company of Japan.

title: Bettina Warburg Grimson; Psychiatrist, 90
description: Bettina Warburg Grimson, a retired psychiatrist, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90 years old.

title: Honeywell Executive Joining LTV Aerospace
description: The LTV Corporation, the steelmaker and military contractor, has named a Honeywell aerospace executive, Richard J. Boyle, to be president and chief executive of its LTV Aerospace and Defense Company.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "Our job now I think is quite clear. We're going to unite. We're going to unite totally and absolutely, and we're going to win the next general election." -- John Major, the new British Conservative leader and next Prime Minister. [ A1:6. ] "John Major is the no-change, no-majority Prime Minister, and he has none of the policies our country needs for the future. Let's have a general election without delay." -- Neil Kinnock, the Labor Party leader. [ A13:1. ]

title: Macy's Loss Said to Reach $66 Million
description: R. H. Macy & Company has told creditors and credit agencies that it had a loss of $66 million in its latest quarter -- a bigger loss than creditors expected and double its $33.1 million loss in the quarter last year, according to a number of creditors and credit agencies.

title: Philip A. Fulvi; Professor, 58
description: Philip A. Fulvi, a professor of foreign languages at Pace University, died on Sunday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ex-Shell Holders To Get $30 Million
description: A Delaware judge awarded 20,000 former stockholders of the Shell Oil Company an additional $2 a share for 15 million shares they relinquished in a 1985 merger. Judge Maurice A. Hartnett 3d ruled Shell owed the former stockholders the $30 million for failing to fully disclose its oil and gas reserves.

title: A Show of the Artists In The Nation Magazine
description: "Artists of The Nation," a free exhibition of artwork that appeared in The Nation magazine from the 1920's to the present, will be on view through Jan. 26 at Columbia University, the Wallach Art Gallery, Schermerhorn Hall, Broadway and West 116th Street. Among the artists represented in the show, which commemorates the 125th anniversary of the magazine, are Edward Sorel, Ed Koren, David Levine, Ben Shahn, David Low, Marshall Arisman, Seymour Chwast and Horacio Fidel Cardo.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
We're Feeling the Draft
description: Why, as we seem to be moving closer to war in the Middle East, am I fixated not on today's news, but on a deed done in March 1984 that has no obvious connection to today's crises?

title: Soviet Union on Its Way to a Market Economy; Help Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawrence G. Hines; Economics Professor. 75
description: Lawrence G. Hines, professor of economics emeritus at Dartmouth College, died Saturday at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H. He was 75 years old and lived in Hanover.

title: 3d Fiber-Optic System Installed in Manhattan
description: A Chicago company has completed lower Manhattan's third fiber-optic telephone system, part of a national binge of construction of urban systems that bypass the local telephone companies.

title: Vehicle Sales Up 12.6% in Midmonth
description: Propelled by rebates, sales of vehicles made in the United States rose by 12.6 percent in mid-November, compared with sluggish demand in the period last year.

title: Reshaping a Real Estate Dynasty
description: The Reichmann family of Canada built a fortune by attacking while others were in retreat. They bought office towers in New York at distressed prices in the mid-1970's when the city was on the brink of bankruptcy and developers were running for cover. In the early 1980's, in the midst of a deep real estate slump, they risked billions of dollars building the vast World Financial Center in downtown Manhattan. Both bets paid off handsomely.

title: New York Court Limits Grounds For Prosecuting a Top Legislator
description: In a decision that gives the Legislature broad authority to regulate its own affairs, the state's highest court ruled today that the minority leader of the State Senate, Manfred Ohrenstein, could not be prosecuted for assigning legislative employees to perform purely political tasks.

title: National Book Awards To 'Middle Passage' And 'House of Morgan'
description: Charles Johnson won the National Book Award for fiction last night for "The Middle Passage" (Atheneum), his novel about the voyage of a freed slave. The award for nonfiction went to Ron Chernow for "The House of Morgan: An American Banking Dynasty and the Rise of Modern Finance" ( Atlantic Monthly Press ), a study of the role of the Morgan family in the evolution of modern banking.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the sale of MCA Inc. to the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company misidentified an MCA company that is to be sold off within a year. It is the Yosemite Park and Curry Company.

title: New York Joins Suit for Baby Formula Royalties
description: In a legal action that lawyers said was the first of its kind by a state, the New York Attorney General's office said yesterday that it had joined patent lawsuits seeking royalties from the makers of infant formulas.

title: Without Resuming Play, Chess Contenders Agree to a Draw
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov settled for a draw yesterday without resuming play in Game 14 of the World Championship Chess Match. The contest is tied at 7-7.

title: New World for Junior Achievement
description: Having settled on the product their company would sell -- a singing mug -- the teen-agers in the applied economics class at Prospect Heights High School in Brooklyn turned to the question of how much it should cost.

title: Iraq Asserts It 'Will Never Succumb'
description: Iraq's Foreign Minister today dismissed the importance of a proposed United Nations resolution that would authorize the use of force to oust Iraqi forces from Kuwait, saying that his country "will never succumb to pressure."

title: EATING WELL
description: IF preliminary findings presented at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association in Dallas two weeks ago hold up, beta carotene may be the next nutrient in the public spotlight.

title: Allan Shaw; Advertising Executive, 63
description: Allan Shaw, president of Shaw & Todd Inc., a Manhattan advertising agency, died on Saturday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 63 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Treasury Security Prices Ease
description: Prices of Treasury securities eased slightly and interest rates inched up a bit in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers concentrated on an auction of $12.3 billion worth of new two-year Treasury notes.

title: Soviet Army Told to Use Force To Defend Itself in the Republics
description: The Soviet Defense Minister announced tonight in a televised address that the armed forces had been instructed to use force to defend military installations, monuments and servicemen against threats in rebellious republics.

title: L.C. Jones, 82, Dies; A Writer and Expert On Folklore in U.S.
description: Louis C. Jones, a specialist in American folk culture who was director of the New York State Historical Association for a quarter century, died on Sunday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 82 years old.

title: Ship With Mysterious Cargo Boarded by U.S. in Red Sea
description: A German-flagged ship loaded with two heavy boxes that could not be opened was diverted from its destination by a guided missile cruiser patrolling the Red Sea, the Pentagon said today.

title: NORTH PROSECUTOR IS SET BACK AGAIN
description: A Federal appeals court dealt another setback to the prosecution of Oliver L. North today when it refused to reconsider a decision setting aside his three felony convictions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GERALD ARPINO , the artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet, will represent the company today when the City Center's restored mezzanine lobby is dedicated in the name of the late Robert Joffrey. Mr. Joffrey, who began choreographing ballets in 1957 for New York City Opera when its home was City Center, made the theater his New York base when he founded the Joffrey Ballet in 1966. Mr. Joffrey died in 1988.

title: Nairobi Journal; On KTN, Mr. Big Man Is Often Not in the Picture
description: For television viewers in sub-Saharan Africa, the diet of nightly news is predictable: the head of state, often referred to in common parlance as the Big Man, is always featured as subject of the first, often endless and always adoring news item. No matter how trivial the occasion, "Mr. Big Man (fill in leader's name) said today" is the common opening.

title: Will Poles Scuttle Economic Plan?
description: Poland's program for creating a capitalist system, the most ambitious escape from Communist economics undertaken anywhere in Eastern Europe, has been called into question by the repudiation of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in Sunday's presidential elections.

title: Ultrasound Enters New Frontiers
description: Advances in ultrasound have opened windows on the human body in the last few years, allowing physicians to view internal organs safely and easily. New products just appearing on the market are taking this medical imaging technology into previously inaccessible areas of the body.

title: Same Song, Softer Voice on a European Currency
description: John Major has made it clear that he does not like, any more than Margaret Thatcher, the idea of a single currency and central bank for the European Community.

title: Resales Low For Homes
description: Fading consumer confidence continued to take its toll on sales of existing homes in October, pushing them down 4.7 percent, to their lowest level in nearly six years, a real estate trade group said today.

title: Psychiatrist for Dodgers
description: For the first time in a sometimes bizarre history that began in Brooklyn and shifted to Los Angeles 32 years ago, the Dodgers have hired a team psychiatrist to aid player performance, both on and off the field.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a New York State legislative hearing on the Daily News strike referred incorrectly to Jeremy Travis. He is Deputy Police Commissioner for legal matters.

title: Kohl's Campaign Foe: Standard-Bearer Who Leaves Party and People Cold
description: The campaign posters show Oskar Lafontaine, the Social Democratic standard-bearer in the German election, with a gentle smile and a white shirt. The slogan is "The New Way."

title: Soviet Union on Its Way to a Market Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Chevron to Produce Coastal Crude
description: Despite an unresolved conflict with environmentalists, the Chevron Corporation said today that it would begin producing oil from a large reserve off the central California coast. The oilfield has become a symbol of the clash between the nation's increased need for domestic sources of energy in the wake of the Persian Gulf crisis and concerns about spills and other pollution from the drilling and transportation of oil.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: John Major; A Tory of Humble Origins
description: One measure of the depth of class division in Britain may be the fixation on the "classless society" that John Major, the son of a onetime circus performer and the man who will become Prime Minister on Wednesday, wants to bring about.

title: YUGOSLAVIA SEEN BREAKING UP SOON
description: United States intelligence is predicting that federated Yugoslavia will break apart, most probably in the next 18 months, and that civil war in that multinational Balkan country is highly likely.

title: 10 Computer Makers Agree To Offer Multimedia PC's
description: Led by the Tandy Corporation, 10 personal computer manufacturers said today that they would begin delivering personal computers specially configured to run multimedia programs.

title: The Line Forms
description: If one swallow doesn't make a summer nor one snowflake a winter, then perhaps it is premature to announce that New York has taken on a new civility. Still, consider the evidence. New Yorkers are, observably, standing patiently in line.

title: Equitable Life Denies Rumors
description: Rumors that the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States had missed a debt payment and was near insolvency swept through financial markets yesterday despite strenuous denials by the company.

title: Defendant Told Of Jogger Rape, Detective Says
description: A detective testified yesterday that Kharey Wise, a defendant in the second Central Park jogger trial, had told him that he saw another defendant, Steven Lopez, raise a brick to smash the woman because Mr. Lopez "got sick of looking at her face" while raping her.

title: Fighting AIDS With VCR's
description: Some advertisers are finding that the only way to disseminate a candid message about AIDS is through the VCR. That's what AIDS Project Los Angeles, is trying to do with a public service campaign. The spot, produced pro bono by Hisk productions, shows a half- dressed couple in an intimate embrace. The man and woman then decide not to have sexual relations until they buy a condom.

title: Shutdown Is Expected At Spicer & Oppenheim
description: Current and former partners of Spicer & Oppenheim, the troubled accounting firm, said yesterday that they expected the firm to announce as soon as today that it would dissolve on Friday and that it had reached an accord with major creditors to avoid bankruptcy.

title: Busiest Day For A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that Monday was its busiest day ever for long-distance calls. Americans made 148.4 million calls on A.T.&T.'s network, 3.7 million more than on Oct. 18, 1989, the day after the San Francisco earthquake, said Herb Linnen, a company spokesman.

title: Miscellany
description: * Leo Burnett International has acquired an equity interest in the Portuguese agency Cineponto Publicidade e Marketing to assume responsibility for the agency's key clients in Portugal. * Wahlstrom & Company, Stamford, Conn., a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding, received the 1990 Creative Media Award for Yellow Pages for its client, Chrysler First. * ActMedia, an in-store marketing unit of the Heritage Media Corporation, Norwalk, Conn., has acquired Toronto-based Something Else Marketing Ltd., and has invested in Supermarket Visions Ltd., a British company.

title: Manville Seeking Court Ruling
description: The Manville Corporation asked the Federal courts to reaffirm that victims of asbestos-related diseases are barred from suing the company. A hearing was set for Jan. 2 on the motion by Manville, once the world's largest asbestos producer.

title: Joseph W. Cullen, 53, A Cancer Researcher
description: Joseph W. Cullen, director of a Denver-based cancer research center, died Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital in San Francisco. He was 53 years old and lived in Engelwood, Colo.

title:
Real Estate;
Cautious Builders Wait For Leases
description: IN a sign of the sluggish local commercial real estate market, a property management and development concern here did not begin construction on a suburban office building until it had obtained leasing commitments for almost half of the space.

title: Neely Suspended
description: Cam Neely of the Boston Bruins yesterday became the sixth player in the National Hockey League this season to be suspended for on-ice violence.

title: Bridge
description: There was a tie in one major event at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Monday night and a surprise in another.

title: 750,000 Condoms Are Recalled
description: The New York City Department of Health has recalled 750,000 condoms distributed through social service groups because some of the condoms may be faulty, health officials announced yesterday.

title: L.P.G.A. Set to Name Commissioner
