description: Charles Mechem, a retired Cincinnati broadcasting executive, will be named today as the new commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, sources close to the organization confirmed yesterday.

title: Guggenheim Withdraws Design Change
description: Facing heated opposition from neighborhood groups and others, the Guggenheim Museum has notified the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission that it is withdrawing its proposal to change the window treatment in its controversial 10-story annex, now under construction.

title: Devils Get Ysebaert
description: The Devils made a move yesterday to bolster their defense by trading the center Paul Ysebaert to the Detroit Red Wings for a veteran defenseman, Lee Norwood, and undisclosed future considerations. The 30-year-old Norwood played in 21 games for the Red Wings this season, collecting three goals and seven assists. But the Devils were primarily attracted by his plus-seven defensive rating.

title: Carrier's Pilots Confidently Face War
description: The F-18 Hornet fighters catapulted off the Midway's deck in a scream of engines and a shimmering pall of jet exhaust.

title: About New York; Global Company Recalls Its Roots In Old Brooklyn
description: Last August, a rock flew through a window in the office of Thomas J. Kline Jr.

title: Mrs. Thatcher's Lengthened Shadow
description: Margaret Thatcher may be finished. But the selection of John Major to succeed her as Prime Minister suggests that Thatcherism is not. Mr. Major was her chosen heir. Of humble origins, he epitomizes her spirit of enterprise and individualism. And he was judged the most reliable custodian of her social and economic policies.

title: W. Barron Rockwell; Banker, 84
description: W, Barron Rockwell, a retired investment banker, died on Friday at the Rochester (Minn.) Methodist Hospital. He was 84 years old and had lived for the last 15 years in Denver and Estes Park, Colo., where he moved from Manhattan.

title: Cineplex Reaches New Debt Accord
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation reached an agreement with its banks that allows the movie theater chain to defer principal payments until mid-1992. The preliminary four-year agreement also allows the company to keep assets that were to be sold under a previous agreement.

title: Chinese Official Is Invited to Washington in Response to Gulf Stance
description: The Bush Administration announced today that China's Foreign Minister had been invited for talks in Washington on Friday, in what appears to be compensation to Beijing for not blocking the American-sponsored United Nations resolution authorizing force against Iraq.

title: For Faithful in Small Church, A Jarring Charge of Homicide
description: By most accounts, Anneta Williamson is a conscientious mother, much like the other women in her church near here.

title: Dr. Ernest Duncan, 74, Mathematics Professor
description: Dr. Ernest R. Duncan, professor emeritus of mathematics at Rutgers University and the author of several mathematics textbooks, died on Sunday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in New Jersey. He was 74 years old and lived in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: Corrections
description: The Guide column of the Westchester Weekly on Sunday misstated the location for a film-lecture series called "Art, Ethics and Society." It begins at 8 P.M. on Saturday at the Chappaqua Library Theater, not the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts. The column also misidentified the husband of Barbara Dana, the program's first speaker. He is Alan Arkin, not Alan Alda.

title: Using Mist to Induce Plants to Produce
description: Scientists have tinkered for years with keeping plants alive outside the soil by bathing them in a nutrient-rich mist, a technology known as aeroponics. Now, one modest business and one potentially big one may be emerging from the work of Pamela Weathers, a biotechnology professor at the Worcester Polytechnic Institute, and Kenneth Giles, the former head of her department.

title: Brooklyn Woman Is Indicted In Killing of 8-Year-Old Son
description: Shulamis Riegler, a Brooklyn woman accused of killing her 8-year-old son, was indicted on a murder charge yesterday and bail was set at $250,000.

title: 49ers Focus on Finding Way to Stop Simms
description: Even from so far away, Phil Simms has left an impression on the San Francisco 49ers. Although they have yet to see him up close, it is clear to hear the players speak that Simms -- not so much the running game or the impressive and imposing defense -- is the heart of the Giants.

title: Mob Looks at Recycling and Sees Green
description: Changing with the times, some garbage haulers and processors with longtime links to organized crime are recasting themselves as recycling outfits, more sensitive and attuned to the environment.

title: Inspectors Say Iraq's Nuclear Fuel Wasn't Used for a Weapon
description: Iraq's small stock of highly enriched reactor fuel has not been diverted to build a nuclear weapon, the International Atomic Energy Agency reported yesterday. The announcement, which followed a technical examination of the Iraqi uranium by expert inspectors, seemed likely to quash speculation that Baghdad might have built a nuclear explosive device using the reactor fuel.

title: Reader's Digest Promotes Books With TV 'Bookends'
description: THE Reader's Digest Association will begin its first television advertising in 15 years for its popular series of condensed books with an innovative commercial that combines public service announcements with pitches for the book club.

title: Review/Theater; Finding Proper Targets For Missionary Zeal
description: It is always something of a surprise to rediscover how timely Shaw's early plays remain. And few are more germane to the social problems of the 1990's than "Major Barbara," Shaw's witty and wise discourse on politics, arms, greed, poverty and other crimes that is being given a mostly worthwhile revival at the Pearl Theater Company.

title: College Cost Forecast Upsets Schools Chief
description: Upset by predictions that four years of college may soon cost several hundred thousand dollars, Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos today called on colleges and universities to make tough choices to cut costs.

title: Predicting the Winners After the MCA Sale
description: The admiration and envy now being expressed in executive suites and studio commissaries here after the sale on Monday of MCA to the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan are tempered by uncertainty about who stands to gain most from the transaction, the biggest in Hollywood history.

title: Finding Some Shortcomings, Panel Calls for Major CHanges at Howard
description: Howard University in Washington, D.C., has begun an intensive and painful self-examination that is uncovering numerous academic shortcomings and raising the possibility that the nation's most influential black university will undergo substantial changes, like eliminating several colleges and tightening admissions standards.

title: Conviction Appealed In Wisconsin Sex Case
description: A man convicted of sexually assaulting a woman with 46 personalities requested a new trial on Monday because prosecutors failed to disclose that the woman was having a sexual relationship with a principal witness.

title: Trusts for the Disabled Gaining Support; Service Census
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Links Estrogen to Cancer, but Risk Is Slight
description: The largest study of its kind ever conducted has found that women who take estrogen after menopause run an increased risk of developing breast cancer.

title: Chase Manhattan Sells Tokyo Office
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said it had signed an agreement to sell one of its offices in Tokyo for an after-tax profit of $43 million. Chase did not identify the buyer. The sale is part of Chase's effort to strengthen its financial condition by selling some of its less crucial businesses and assets and by cutting costs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JANET JACKSON walked off with eight Billboard Music Awards on Monday night, including one for top pop album, "Janet Jackson's Rhythm Nation 1814," on A&M Records. Ms. Jackson, the 24-year-old sister of MICHAEL JACKSON , also won for No. 1 Hot 100 Singles Artist.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Finding a Need on Staten Island, Too
description: Sophie E. Matthews, a 72-year-old Staten Island native, gets a little testy when she hears people say that there's no such thing as poverty in New York's least populated borough.

title: Rutgers Starts Season By Upending Missouri
description: Keith Hughes scored 11 of his 20 points in the final three and a half minutes tonight as Rutgers opened its season with a 68-60 upset of Missouri.

title: Bulent Arel, 71, A Composer Known For Electronic Music
description: Bulent Arel, a composer and teacher best known for his electronic music, died on Saturday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived in East Setauket, L.I.

title: The Horse Before The Cart
description: Here are three reports from the American Dream:

title: Islanders Unraveled By Flyer Power Plays
description: The Islanders paid dearly for Ken Baumgartner's pugnacity tonight. After Baumgartner, the team leader in penalty minutes, drew a five-minute major for fighting early in the second period, the Philadelphia Flyers scored the first three goals of the game during his absence and went on to a 5-1 victory at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article in Science Times yesterday about ecological economists omitted several words in a sentence about their impact. The affected sentence, the first in the sixth paragraph, should have read, "But succeed or fail, they will almost certainly forceeconomists to face up to the issue that traditional analysis tends to undervalue environmental resources."

title: Giants-49ers Encounter Imperfect but Still Special
description: The Giants and the 49ers still meet next Monday night, still the teams with the National Football League's best records, still a symbol of East versus West, of grit versus flash.

title: Pay Abuses in Border Garment Shops
description: On the last Friday in May, Amelia Lambarena reported, as usual, to her job at Diana's Fashions workshop here. But on that day she did not sew a single stitch. The doors were locked, all the machinery had been removed in the night, and there was no sign of the owner, who owed her $700 in back pay.

title: We Can't Afford More Delay on Hudson River Waterfront Park
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Nutrition: Protein On the Side
description: FIFTEEN years ago reducing regimes like the grapefruit diet, the Stillman diet, and "five pounds in five days of chicken" were detailed in the pages of women's magazines, promising a quick fix for everything from thunder thighs to those embarrassingly protruding tummies.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blount Inc., Montgomery, Ala., a construction company, said that as previously announced, R. William Van Sant had succeeded Winton M. Blount as chief executive. Mr. Blount will continue as chairman. * Businessland Inc., San Jose, Calif., a microcomputer distributor, appointed three vice presidents: Leslie McNeill, for strategic planning; Thomas F. Pelandini, for communications, and Robert W. Wilkins, for distribution operations. * Estee Lauder U.S.A., a unit of Estee Lauder Cos., New York, appointed Muriel Gonzalez senior vice president in charge of marketing. * Guy F. Atkinson Co. of California, South San Francisco, a construction and exploration concern, promoted Christine V. Braunlich to vice president and treasurer, and Larry L. Magelitz to corporate vice president of accounting. * Imcera Group Inc., Northbrook, Ill., producers of human and animal health care products and chemicals, named Beverley L. Hayes vice president of human resources, replacing John M. Stapleton, who resigned. * Kohler Mix Specialties, White Bear Lake, Minn., a subsidiary of Michael Foods Inc., Minneapolis, that produces pasteurized milk, promoted Craig V. Miller to vice president of administration. * Monarch Co., Atlanta, a soft drink franchise company, appointed John L. Dupuis president of its Dad's root beer division. * Princeton Diagnostic Laboratories of America Inc., South Plainfield, N.J., named Susie Lucas McClellan vice president of sales and marketing.

title: Arab Countries in the Middle: Leverage With the Adversaries Is Growing
description: The Arab countries that have expressed opposition to the United States military presence in the Persian Gulf as well as Iraq's invasion of Kuwait are likely to play an enhanced diplomatic role in the weeks ahead as Washington and its allies in the gulf crisis edge closer to war with Iraq, Arab officials and Western diplomats in the Middle East and North Africa say.

title: White Sox Want Welch
description: The White Sox will offer a three-year contract to Bob Welch, the American League Cy Young Award winner, the Chicago general manager, Ron Schueler, said yesterday.

title: 'Middle Passage' and 'Morgan' Win
description: Charles Johnson won the National Book Award for fiction on Tuesday night for "The Middle Passage" (Atheneum), his novel about the voyage of a freed slave. The award for nonfiction went to Ron Chernow for "The House of Morgan: An American Banking Dynasty and the Rise of Modern Finance" ( Atlantic Monthly Press ), a study of the role of the Morgan family in the evolution of modern banking.

title: Maxwell House
description: Despite a sluggish economy, Maxwell House plans to begin work on a $30 million expansion of its plant here by February, the plant's manager, James Reese, said. The expansion will allow the company to hire 40 new workers next summer, Mr. Reese said. Maxwell House now has about 360 employees. Maxwell House's parent company, General Foods U.S.A., has said it will keep the Jacksonville plant open and close its operation in Hoboken, N.J.

title: Trump Hires Leasing Agent
description: With nearly 200,000 square feet of retail space in New York City either vacant or with leases expiring, the Trump Organization has named the Edward S. Gordon Company as the exclusive leasing agent for those properties.

title: Court Beats Celtics, Hawks
description: The game between the Boston Celtics and the Atlanta Hawks was called early in the second period tonight because of a slippery court at Boston Garden.

title: Topics of The Times; Touched by AIDS
description: On Saturday, arts institutions and AIDS organizations nationwide will work together to celebrate the lives of lost friends and colleagues, and provide all Americans with AIDS information. The memorials will take various forms. New York's tribute seems especially fitting. From 7:45 to 8 P.M., the lights that illuminate the great monuments of the Manhattan skyline, like the Empire State Building and Chrysler Building, will be turned off.

title: Market Place; Investors Seeking Safety in Foods
description: AS economists argue over whether the nation is in a recession or about to enter one, more investors are seeking safety. Regardless of the state of the economy, they reason, people still eat every day. As a result, the normally stodgy food sector of the market has again become attractive.

title: Leonard Rosenfeld, 77, A Public Health Expert
description: Dr. Leonard Sidney Rosenfeld, an expert on public health and a retired professor of health administration, died Monday at North Carolina University Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 77 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: Gingerly, Albany Studies SUNY Tuition Rise
description: Legislative leaders said today that they would consider authorizing tuition increases of as much as $300 a year, or more than 20 percent, at the State University of New York when they reconvene in special session here next month.

title: Knicks Drop Fourth Straight
description: What the Knicks did tonight would be good enough to beat most teams. It was not good enough to beat the Detroit Pistons.

title: Papal Official Regrets 'Wound' to U.S. Prelate
description: The papal official who barred a Vatican-affiliated faculty at a Swiss university from granting an honorary degree to Milwaukee's Archbishop as a result of a statement he had made about abortion has expressed regret over his action.

title: Thunder in Orlando
description: The first entry into the National Football League's new World League of American Football will be called the Orlando Thunder, the league announced yesterday.

title: G.N.P. Up By 1.7% in 3d Quarter
description: The Commerce Department reported today that the economy expanded at a 1.7 percent rate in the third quarter, a tenth of percentage point less than previously estimated. But private analysts said the figure masked the progressive economic contraction that started in the late summer.

title: 11 Bronx Stores Raided as Sheriff Continues Effort to Collect Fines
description: New York City's sheriff and 25 deputies raided 11 stores in the Fordham Road business district in the Bronx yesterday, shutting one and taking money from cash registers to collect on unpaid summonses for littering.

title: Israeli Cabinet Approves Increase In Taxes to Help Soviet Immigrants
description: The Israeli Cabinet approved stiff tax increases early today for all Israelis to help pay for the resettlement of Soviet Jews, who are now arriving at a rate of almost 1,500 every day.

title: Shifts in Deposit Insurance Weighed
description: The Bush Administration is exploring a wide array of ways to alter the Federal program that insures bank deposits, including basing the premiums paid by banks to the insurance program upon their financial health, Treasury officials and senior regulators said today.

title: U.S. Seems Baffled by Soviets' Disarray
description: With the Soviet Union under increasing domestic stress, Bush Administration officials say they are baffled about how to respond and increasingly worried that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will have to use military force to maintain control.

title: Metro Matters; Test for Dinkins: Can He Deliver On Police Plan?
description: When Mayor David N. Dinkins unveiled his ambitious public safety proposal two months ago, some cynical New Yorkers cavalierly dismissed it as a sham. Did they goof?

title:
Currents;
With the Bent of a Boomerang
description: THE curves of Australia's famous throwing stick provided furniture of the 1950's and 1960's with its futuristic panache. But while the boomerang became a well-known design motif, Australian design objects got much less exposure.

title: When the Need to Help Won't Take Early Retirement
description: GEORGE KREIDLER, 71 years old, drives a Chevy Cavalier with "A Touch of Class" on his license plate. "You have to have verve," he said.

title: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were mixed for the second consecutive week ended yesterday.

title: Senators' Lawyers Assail Accuser in Ethics Case
description: Lawyers for Senators facing an ethics inquiry into their ties to a savings and loan operator today sought to turn attention away from the lawmakers, questioning the competence of their leading accuser, Edwin J. Gray, a former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: INSIDE
description: Ban on Noriega Tapes Lifted

title: Catalogue Sales Lag
description: The pace of Christmas catalogue sales is even slower than that of retail sales in stores because catalogue companies are hampered by prices set many months ago, Rosalind Wells, chief economist of the National Retail Federation, said yesterday at a news briefing in New York.

title: Banks Rush to Sell Assets by End of Year
description: Department stores are not alone in having end-of-the-year holiday sales.

title: Bush May Ask Session Of Congress on Gulf
description: President Bush is considering calling Congress back into session next month to consider the use of force in the Persian Gulf, senior Senate Republicans said.

title: Equity in Scheduling Is Army's Next Mission
description: Hockey players are at West Point to become professional Army officers rather than professional athletes and none come from Canada.

title: To Keep the Flame Alive
description: MENORAHS come in a wide array of modern and traditional styles for Hanukkah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, which begins at sundown on Dec. 11.

title: Review/Theater; 'Fever,' From Shawn: A One-Man Attack On the Privileged
description: "This is a piece I've been doing mostly in people's apartments since January," says the actor and playwright Wallace Shawn by way of introducing "The Fever," the one-hour-45-minute monologue he is now reciting at the Public Theater. But which people, which apartments and, for that matter, which January?

title: Teaching Role for Rose
description: Pete Rose, a first-rate student of hitting as a player, will become a teacher's aide in the Cincinnati public school system when he gets out of prison in January.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALAIN DELON sold 32 paintings from his art collection Sunday for $7 million. The French actor said he sold them to finance his half of yet another painting, Modigliani's "La Belle Epiciere," which he bought for $11.5 million in March with FRANCIS BOUYGUES, a French construction magnate.

title: In Boston, A Slaying Reawakens Gang Fears
description: They called themselves the Pistons, hoping a name and a black baseball cap would bring them gang status on the narrow streets of the Franklin Field housing project in Dorchester, one of Boston's toughest areas.

title: Evading Sack, O'Brien Keeps Job
description: His starting job as the Jets' quarterback in jeopardy after he was benched Sunday in the loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers, Ken O'Brien was given a vote of confidence today when Coach Bruce Coslet said he would start Sunday against the Chargers in San Diego.

title: AFTER SCARE, SUIT BY APPLE FARMERS
description: A group of apple growers filed a lawsuit today against the CBS and its news program "60 Minutes" and an environmental group, seeking compensation for declining sales during a scare over the growth chemical Alar.

title: People
description: * Marianne Caponnetto has been appointed to the new position of director of corporate marketing for Dow Jones & Company. * Dean Bastian has been named vice president at J. Walter Thompson, Chicago.

title: Howard Beach Prosecution Ends in Negotiated Sentence
description: Four years of prosecution in the Howard Beach racial-attack case came to an end yesterday as three defendants agreed not to appeal their riot convictions in return for sentences of probation, community service and no jail time.

title: Spira Faces New Round On Ties With Steinbrenner
description: Howard Spira, the Bronx man indicted on charges of threatening George Steinbrenner and trying to extort money from him, faces the possibility of a superseding indictment when he appears in Federal Court tomorrow, a man involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Miscellany
description: * Rowland Worldwide Inc., the public relations subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., has acquired all of its associate company, L'Agence Groupe 7, Paris, for undisclosed terms. The firm will now be known as the Rowland Company Groupe 7.

title: Bulgaria's Tottering Government Appears Ready to Resign
description: Bulgaria's Prime Minister appeared today to be close to acceding to increasing popular clamor for the resignation of his Government.

title: The Front Writer
description: It seems the right time to admit that I do not really write this column.

title: Bridge
description: Two players who have a good claim to be considered the best women's partnership in the world led a strong field into the semifinal stage of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship here today. Lynn Deas of Newport News, Va., and Beth Palmer of Silver Spring, Md., who have won two world titles and been in close contention for several others, headed the qualifying stage on Tuesday.

title: F.D.A. Is Ordered to Release Data On the Safety of Breast Implants
description: A Federal judge has ordered the Food and Drug Administration to release more safety data on silicon breast implants, a move a consumer group said today will allow patients more access to information about the safety and effectiveness of drugs and medical devices.

title: Miriam M. Comer, Volunteer, 86
description: Miriam M. Comer, a founder of two community agencies in Great Neck, L.I., died on Monday at a nursing home there. She was 86 years old.

title: N.C.A.A. Suggests Basketball Sites
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's basketball committee announced today the sites it will recommend to the N.C.A.A. executive committee for first-round and regional games of the 1994 tournament.

title: Dow Drops 8.66, but the Broader Market Edges Upward
description: Stocks weakened yesterday with the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks off 8.66, to 2,535.15, but the broader market narrowly outperformed the blue chips, as 843 stocks advanced and 664 fell.

title: Review/Music; Grace Bumbry, in Concert, Celebrates a 30th Anniversary
description: Grace Bumbry's international career began with her 1960 debut at the Paris Opera, and on Tuesday evening she celebrated the 30th anniversary of that event with a concert of arias at Carnegie Hall. The concert was also a benefit for the American Guild of Musical Artists Emergency Relief Fund. The guild gave Miss Bumbry its Lawrence Tibbett award and established a scholarship fund in her name this year.

title: 8th Straight Draw in Chess Contest
description: A tranquil positional battle in Game 15 of the World Championship Chess Match saw Gary Kasparov, the champion, and Anatoly Karpov, the challenger, agree to a draw last night after 33 moves. It was the eighth straight draw, and brought the score to 7 1/2-7 1/2.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Nordiques End Slide Joe Sakic scored twice, Jamie Baker knocked in a goal with his skate, Tony McKegney's goal caromed off his head and Ron Tugnutt stopped 40 shots as the Quebec Nordiques ended a 17-game streak without a victory by defeating the Whalers, 4-3, at Hartford last night.

title: Rockers That Please The Eye and the Spine
description: Some of the families visiting students at Dartmouth College find Leo Flynn's oddly shaped birch and mahogany Womb Rocker irresistible. The large and enclosing structure by the Louisiana craftsman is one of 35 finely carved, rolled and ribbed rocking chairs on view at the Rubens & Locke gallery and store, two blocks from campus.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
S.E.C. Picks New Chief For Investment Division
description: Marianne K. Smythe, who has been serving as the chief of staff to the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was appointed yesterday to head the agency's investment management division.

title: Why Some Republicans Lament Chief's Absence
description: National party chairmen rarely emerge as dominant figures in modern American politics. Not many people outside of party circles talk about the Fahrenkopf Years or the Manatt Era. But Lee Atwater, the chairman of the Republican National Committee and manager of President Bush's 1988 campaign, has not been the average party chairman.

title: Martin Marietta's Big U.S. Contract
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said it had awarded a $525.9 million contract to the Martin Marietta Corporation. In the next 30 months, the company will replace all of the department's mainframe computers, work station computers and the equipment that ties desktop computers together to form local networks. Martin Marietta will also consolidate the department's automated data-processing operations in Lanham, Md., and create a national data communications network linking the department's 81 offices.

title: Personal Health
description: While city streets are rife with hazards for the elderly -- from uneven sidewalks to drivers who race through intersections and muggers who prey on the frail and weak -- most older people eel safe in their own homes.

title: DEALS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Sanitation Workers Do A Vital, Respectable Job
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE EXPECTANCY FOR BLACKS IN U.S. SHOWS SHARP DROP
description: Life expectancy for black people in the United States has dropped substantially, continuing a four-year decline, Federal health experts said today.

title: Don't Call Hmong Refugees Primitive
description: To the Editor:

title: Tired Nets Can't Keep It Going
description: It was fun while it lasted.

title: Governor Backs Plan To Protect Florida Keys
description: Gov. Bob Martinez has endorsed a plan to protect the Florida Keys by creating a marine preserve that would be paid for in part by $5 fees on snorkeling and diving.

title: L.P.G.A. Post Is Filled
description: As expected, Charles S. Mechem Jr., a retired Cincinnati television executive, was named yesterday as the fourth commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association. Mechem, 60 years old, replaces William Blue, who was dismissed Aug. 21 after serving less than two years of a five-year term. (AP)

title: Changes Don't Improve College Entrance Test; Successful Predictor
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Official Leaves in Doubt How He Will Vote on Iraq at U.N.
description: China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, suggested today that he would not vote in favor of a United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq.

title: Many Small Clothiers Are Closing
description: Bloomingdale's and Macy's are not the only retailers to have had problems recently. Take Harold's..

title: Germans Mobilize to Feed Russians
description: The German Government and an array of private businesses and charities are starting an emergency program of food aid for the Soviet Union.

title: Talking Deals; Breaking Logjam On California Oil
description: WITH a decade of mounting animosity and suspicions still frustrating the search for compromise, it is still an unfinished deal. But a proposal by Energy Department officials to end the regulatory opposition to the Chevron Corporation by citizen groups and local government agencies in California seems certain to get the first barrels of oil pumped from the Point Arguello field by next summer.

title: American Express Comes to Dresden
description: The American Express Company opened its first travel bureau in what was formerly East Germany. The company said it had found a good location for its new office in Dresden, 120 miles south of Berlin. But an American Express executive said real estate problems after the merger of the formerly Communist East Germany with West Germany had blocked its plans to open bureaus in eastern Berlin and Leipzig.

title: Philip Morris's Ratings Raised
description: Citing the Philip Morris Companies' ability to maintain interest and principal payments while expanding operations internally and through acquisition, Moody's Investors Service yesterday raised the company's senior debt rating to A-2, from A-3, and commercial paper rating to Prime-1, from Prime-2.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Decline
description: Problems in the interbank market, where banks borrow and lend to each other, and an auction of new five-year Treasury notes helped to push prices down yesterday on outstanding Treasury issues.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * California Commerce Bank, Los Angeles, a subsidiary of Banco Nacional de Mexico, Mexico City, appointed Jule Vargas senior vice president in charge of its retail banking division. * Figgie International Inc., Willoughby, Ohio, producers of fire protection products, named Joseph J. Skadra senior vice president of finance and controller. * Invacare Corp., Elyria, Ohio, a wheelchair manufacturer, promoted Hymie H. Pogir to vice president of marketing and rehabilitation products. * Loral Corp., New York, a producer of military computers, appointed Richard W. Koepke group vice president of four divisions of its newly formed products group. * MCI Communications Corp., Washington, appointed Edward G. Freitag vice president and assistant general counsel. * Maxtor Corp., San Jose, Calif., a maker of computer disk drives, named Mark Fischer-Colbrie to the new position of vice president of finance. * Mutual Life Insurance Co. of New York, known as MONY, promoted K. Rone Baldwin to senior vice president of corporate development and appointed Richard Daddario to chief financial officer. * NBI Inc., Boulder, Colo., word processing software manufacturers, appointed Gary R. Ensminger vice president of systems integration.

title: Judge Lifts Ban on Noriega Tapes; CNN Doesn't Plan to Play Them
description: A Federal district judge today lifted his ban that had prohibited Cable News Network from playing copies of tape-recorded conversations between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his legal team.

title: Rare Plants Free for Asking
description: SEVERAL new plants set out in my garden in mid-October seem at first glance to have little in common, except that they are small as yet, with their growth to maturity some years away.

title: Temperatures Hit 70's, but Winter Hovers
description: Balmy weather shattered records across New York State yesterday, leaving one last bit of warmth before winter sets in.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Alan Greenspan said the nation's economy is shrinking, making him the first top Government official to speak of a contraction. He told Congress economic activity has been contracting since last month, largely because of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. [ Page A1. ]

title: Merrill Lynch Moving To Trim Its Expenses
description: Reacting to the worsening market environment, Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage house, has taken a number of cost-cutting moves, including a hiring freeze and a freeze on salary increases based on merit.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-21

title: Decision Likely Today on U.N.L.V.
description: Officials at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas say the National Collegiate Athletic Association will announce Thursday whether it will modify its ban on post-season play for the defending national basketball champions.

title: Key Rates
Drug Use by Prominent Athletes Reported
description: A large number of internationally prominent athletes, including many from what was once East Germany, were identified in published reports yesterday as having used performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Mets to Be Bullish in Bare Market
description: The Mets yesterday unveiled their strategy for life without Darryl Strawberry, and it included shopping for four new players in the trade or free-agent markets and signing longterm contracts with three senior players to forestall any more defections of major talent.

title: Major, Aiming for Unity, Selects Cabinet
description: John Major succeeded Margaret Thatcher as Prime Minister of Britain today, rearranging the Cabinet and pledging to build on her achievements, but abandoning his mentor's strident style.

title: New York Offers Plan to Reduce Haulers' Rates
description: In a move that could cut the cost of doing business in New York, the city proposed yesterday that the rate that private garbage haulers charge commercial customers be reduced.

title: Hong Kong Rejects Effort to Loosen Election Laws
description: The legislature today rejected a bid to make Hong Kong's election laws more liberal, and some lawmakers said the move would make it easier for China to break a promise of self-rule for the territory.

title: William Boyle Jr., 67, A Developer, Is Dead
description: William A. Boyle Jr., a New Jersey real-estate developer, died on Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 67 years old and lived in Summit.

title: Debtor Is Said To Hide Assets
description: A former developer who said he was penniless after defaulting on $106 million in loans from the Silverado Savings and Loan Association hid more than $6 million in property under his wife's name, a lawsuit contends.

title: What Recession? It's a Depression
description: What's all this debate about whether a recession is coming or whether one has already begun? Don't worry. It's not a recession. It's a depression.

title: Mae D. Silbergeld, 66, Space Work Manager
description: Mae D. Silbergeld, a technical manager for contractors in the space program, died last Thursday at Bethesda Naval Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived in Garrett Park, Md.

title: How to Judge the Keating Five
description: Each Senator in the Keating Five investigation seeks moral distance from the others but all claim the same thing -- that nothing wrong happened. There was nothing wrong, they tell the Senate Ethics Committee, with those famous 1987 meetings of four or five Senators with Federal savings and loan regulators who had been summoned to justify their dealings with Charles Keating, the politically powerful financier.

title: 2d Jury Indicts Teaneck Officer In Youth's Death
description: A state grand jury today indicted a Teaneck police officer for manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a 16-year-old in Teaneck on April 10.

title: Iraq Says U.N. Backing for Use of Force Is 'No Concern to Us'
description: Iraq lashed out at the United States today for sponsoring a resolution in the United Nations Security Council to allow the use of military force to oust Iraqi forces from Kuwait, and said it would ignore any deadline set in the resolution.

title: Fiat, Seeing Recovery, To Build 2 New Plants
description: Looking ahead to a recovery in world markets in 1993 and beyond, the Italian automotive giant, Fiat S.p.A., said today that it would build two production plants in southern Italy.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Sports People column in some editions yesterday about a trade by the New Jersey Devils described it incorrectly. Paul Ysebart was traded to the Detroit Red Wings, not obtained by the Devils.

title: Options Seem to Be Growing Grimmer for Daily News
description: After a week in which The Daily News lost many of its major advertisers, the options available to the newspaper's management appear to be shifting in ways that bode ill for the paper's future.

title: CAUTIOUS WELCOME IN WESTERN EUROPE
description: Western Europe today cautiously welcomed John Major's election as Britain's Prime Minister, unsure if he will soften Margaret Thatcher's opposition to faster European integration, but confident at least that he will bring a less confrontational style to the councils of Europe.

title: When Historic Church Becomes a Home
description: WHEN Eitan Dor and his wife, Joanne Klein, pulled into the driveway of the stately Victorian church in the Dutchess County hamlet of Clinton Corners, they knew they had found their weekend home.

title: Act-Up Disrupts Yale Speech By Federal Health Secretary
description: A speech today by the Federal Secretary of Health and Human Services, Louis W. Sullivan, was interrupted more than 150 times by members of an AIDS advocacy group.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about vehicle sales in the United States in mid-November misstated the overall increase. Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks from Nov. 11 to 20 rose 14.7 percent, not 12.6 percent, over last year's.

title: Barkley, Hawkins Pace 76er Victory
description: Charles Barkley scored 33 points and Hersey Hawkins added 25 as the Philadelphia 76ers defeated Indiana, 116-106, tonight to keep the Pacers without a victory in seven road games.

title: On Public Television, No Fireworks Is Just Fine
description: When Robert MacNeil and Jim Lehrer look back over their years together in broadcast journalism -- as they will on Monday night at 8 P.M. on most Public Broadcasting Service stations -- they will probably note that they are about the only thing unchanged in daily television news in the 15 years since they teamed up for "The Robert MacNeil Report."

title: Parent & Child
description: MOST parents would agree that it is generally better to reward children for doing what you want than to punish them for avoiding tasks like finishing their homework or cleaning the cat's litter box.

title: What a Stroke of . . . Um, Ingenuity, Anyhow
description: The man who bills himself as the Thomas Edison of Japan has been in New York all week, presiding over something called the World Genius Convention. He promised a three-day showcase of the newest and neatest brainstorms, a chance for inventors to rub elbows with other inventors -- including, of course, the man who bills himself as the Thomas Edison of Japan, a man who even invented his own name.

title:
Currents;
Think of It: Parking. On the Street.
description: ANYONE taking a car into Manhattan knows that the true challenge is not navigating it, but parking it. Your Move Neighborhood Parking Maps decode the mysteries.

title: Graduate Schools Fill With Foreigners
description: Long considered a safe harbor for scholars from abroad, American universities are being flooded by waves of foreign graduate students who are changing the face of higher education and exposing in many ways the nation's declining ability to produce its own researchers, scientists and academicians.

title: Streak Ends as Rangers Come Up Flat
description: The effort was without desire or discipline. The result left no satisfaction or solace. And so the Garden, save for a macabre minority awaiting fights or meaningless goals, was without fans when the final buzzer blared last night, washing over an embarrassed outfit of Rangers who had made no real noise themselves.

title: Home Improvement
description: SLIDING doors save space and offer design possibilities different from those of swinging doors, but they often need adjustment to operate smoothly.

title: Panel to Separate Nynex Inquiries
description: The New York State Public Service Commission has ordered that its investigation of possible improprieties in the Nynex Corporation's purchasing practices be separated from the commission's review of a request by Nynex's main subsidiary, the New York Telephone Company, for a $832 million rate increase.

title: A Curtain-Raiser Now, a Grand Reopening Later
description: With cries of "To New York!" about 200 actors, playwrights, directors, arts patrons and politicians raised glasses of champagne yesterday afternoon at ceremonies to begin a $4.3 million renovation for the Theater for the New City complex on First Avenue, at 10th Street.

title: Once Again: What's the Rush?
description: Even as the U.N. Security Council prepares to demand, with new militance, that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait, a previous question reverberates -- as it has since Nov. 8, when President Bush abruptly changed his policy.

title: As Folksy Replaces Trendy, Wigwag Magazine Thrives
description: TRENDY, caustic magazines like Spy and Details that chronicle and criticize the lives of powerful, or often merely glamorous, people were the rage in the late 1980's -- but now it is hip to be square.

title: Absenteeism and Accidents In Workplace Tied to Drugs
description: People who were found in pre-employment tests to have used marijuana or cocaine had higher rates of work-related accidents and absenteeism than others, researchers said today. But the problems were not as great as some earlier estimates.

title: Mercedes-Benz To Raise Output
description: Mercedes-Benz A.G. said it wanted to increase production of commercial vehicles next year. The company, a unit of the German industrial giant Daimler-Benz A.G. said it wanted to step up worldwide production by 3.7 percent, to 270,000 units, in 1991.

title: Ernst Behrendt, Editor, 80
description: Ernst Behrendt, an editor who specialized in writing about automobile safety, died on Tuesday at the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Mathilde Ferro, 84, A TV Writer, Is Dead
description: Mathilde Ferro, a writer of television plays and serials including "The Guiding Light," "Leave It to Beaver" and "Dr. Kildare," died on Monday at the Thousand Oaks (Calif.) Health Center. She was 84 years old and lived in Thousand Oaks.

title: Events: Holiday Sales, Fairs and Bazaars
description: Holiday sales and fairs abound this month, offering everything from jewelry to world's fair memorabilia. Here are some of them. Greenery Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street; (212) 757-0915.

title: Proposal Would Tie Welfare To Vaccinations of Children
description: Alarmed at recent outbreaks of measles and other childhood diseases, Bush Administration officials want to require children to be fully immunized as a condition of receiving welfare or Medicaid.

title: U.S. Wine Exports Up
description: United States wine exports are booming and Japan is the best customer, the Agriculture Department said in the December issue of Agexporter, an official monthly publication. In the first six months of this year, wine exports topped $51 million, up 19 percent over the period last year. Japanese wine drinkers took one bottle out of every four. Since 1985, American wine sales have more than quadrupled.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Monday referred incorrectly to the status of the Supermarkets General Corporation's bank loan agreements. The company says it will be in violation of its bank loan agreements when it files financial reports for its current fiscal year, which ends on Feb. 2, but it is not in violation now. The article also misstated the 1987 value of a group of securities issued as part of a leveraged buyout. It was $34.66, not $45.26. The price being offered by the company for those securities now, $19.41, is 44 percent below that figure, not 57 percent.

title: Reservations On Upswing At Eastern
description: Martin R. Shugrue, the trustee of Eastern Airlines, buoyantly told a news conference yesterday morning that bookings at Eastern reservation centers were 15 percent higher than had been expected, now that the carrier had beaten back the pressure to liquidate and the bankruptcy judge had given it $120 million with no strings attached.

title: Liberian Factions Agree to a Cease-Fire
description: Leaders of Liberia's main warring factions agreed here today to an immediate cease-fire in their yearlong civil war.

title: Architects Show How to Set a Grand Table
description: NINE years ago Nan Swid and Addie Powell went into business "to design functional, mass-produced objects for the home by well-known architects," in Mrs. Powell's words. Now, after proving that a pitcher designed by Richard Meier can be a suitable vehicle for Kool-Aid, the two women are about to introduce the Architects' Collection, a limited-edition series of household items that happen to cost $5,000 to $35,000.

title: Sanitation Workers Do A Vital, Respectable Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Army Fights Rebels in Assam
description: Indian Army troops began a crackdown today against an insurgency in the northeastern state of Assam. In Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar's first decisive political strike in 18 days of office, he ousted the state's government, which is led by a regional party accused of aiding the rebels.

title: Scrimping and Saving Add To the Neediest Cases Fund
description: A quarter picked up from a puddle in the street, some spare change from a cup of coffee, the receipts from aluminum cans turned in at a supermarket.

title: U.S. Joins Suit That Charges Teledyne Inflated Contracts
description: The Justice Department said today that it had joined a whistleblower in accusing Teledyne Inc. of overcharging the Pentagon, possibly by hundreds of millions of dollars, on contracts for military electronics.

title: Top Executive to Quit At Young & Rubicam
description: Arthur Klein, executive vice president and managing director of joint ventures at Young & Rubicam, New York, will resign at the end of the year to pursue other interests. He intends to continue as a consultant.

title: Buffett Move on Housing
description: Warren E. Buffett, one of the nation's most acclaimed investors, announced yesterday that his investment holding company, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., was adding low-income housing to a portfolio that includes large hodldings in Capital Cities/ABC, the Washington Post Company, Coca-Cola and Wells Fargo & Company.

title: Farm Credit Issue's Top Rate Is 8.875%
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday announced the interest rates on a five-part offering of systemwide securities totaling $2.98 billion through the corporation and various securities dealers and dealer banks.

title: Grain and Soybeans Rise On Hints of Soviet Buying
description: Grain and soybean futures prices rose today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid speculation that the Soviet Union would use money borrowed from Saudi Arabia to buy United States grain.

title:
Currents;
The Spare And Dense On Display
description: ITALIAN architects often contrast the sparest of lines with the densest of textures. Of the postwar generation, Franco Albini (1905-1977) was one of the most accomplished. His talents can be glimpsed in an exhibition of photographs, drawings and furniture at the National Institute for Architectural Education (30 West 22d Street) through Dec. 28.

title: Windfalls for English Furniture Makers
description: It's an ill wind that blows nobody any good, and a novel exhibition at London's Kew Gardens sets out to prove that point.

title: Nebraska Upsets Mich. St. On 3-Pointer With :02 Left
description: Beau Reid hit a 23-foot shot with 2 seconds remaining, giving Nebraska a 71-69 upset of Michigan State tonight.

title: University Status at Risk Because of Trustees
description: The University of the District of Columbia, shut down earlier this year by student protests, has been notified that its accreditation is at risk because of activities of its trustees.

title: Review/Dance; In Ballet Hispanico's Work, New Twist on an Old Style
description: The art of narrative dance is not dead or even moribund, at least as far as Ballet Hispanico is concerned. The company opened a two-week, 20th-anniversary season on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) with a program of three dances whose vibrant storytelling made for an evening of good old-fashioned entertainment. Not that anything about it seemed dated.

title: Books of The Times; Gifts for Reading, Not Just Giving
description: "Books Do Furnish a Room," Anthony Powell titled one of the later volumes of his fictional epic, "Dance to the Music of Time." He meant the verb "to furnish" in the sense of "to equip," but with the books for Christmas giving that came in this year, one could build chairs, couches, tables, cabinets, and even bookshelves, not to mention a coffee table or two. The most appealing of these gift books are described below, ranged approximately by price. There are more entries than usual this year, because the books as a group seemed to set a higher standard.

title: Oryx Oilfield Stake to ARCO
description: The Oryx Energy Company today sold its interest in a central California oilfield to ARCO for $642 million.

title: Keeping Commodities Exchanges in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: GREENSPAN SAYS NATION'S ECONOMY IS IN A DOWNTURN
description: Alan Greenspan, the Government's most influential economic policy maker, today became the first top official to say publicly that the nation's economy is actually shrinking.

title: Changes Don't Improve College Entrance Test; Poor Predictor
description: To the Editor:

title:
Currents;
Rooms That Would Fit in a Corner
description: BECAUSE of the economy, thinking small seems to be the prevailing mood. So 20 interior designers have created miniature rooms that will go on exhibit Monday at Christie's, to be auctioned on Dec. 9 to benefit the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club. The participants include Mario Buatta, Georgina Fairholme, Noel Jeffrey, Tom O'Toole and Michael de Santis.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROB PILATUS of Milli Vanilli was arrested Tuesday at his home in West Los Angeles for investigation of charges of sexual battery. A woman has charged that he touched her intimately against her will. The woman's name was not made public. The District Attorney's office will decide whether to try the charges in court. Detective Steven Osti said that Mr. Pilatus was freed after posting $10,000 bail.

title: Memories (of Prime Ministers) Are Made of This
description: Margaret Thatcher is no longer Prime Minister, but her value as a collectible is just beginning.

title: Changes Don't Improve College Entrance Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Winners and Losers in Trade Talks
description: American companies are not sitting idly by as the United States negotiating team prepares to leave for the global trade talks to be held in Brussels next week. Convinced that the stakes are large, many companies are lobbying hard.

title: Ballet Theater Threatened
description: American Ballet Theater's board of directors voted yesterday to authorize its executive committee to ratify any agreement reached in negotiations with the company's dancers by Tuesday, when the dancers are to return to work from a seasonal break. The committee was also authorized to disband the company if no agreement is reached.

title: A Return for Forte
description: Chet Forte, winner of 10 Emmy Awards before leaving ABC in 1987, will return to television as director of ESPN's telecast of the Breeders' Crown of harness racing in Pompano Beach, Fla., Friday night.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "If in fact the sanctions will work in 12 to 18 months instead of six months, the trade-off of avoiding war with its attendant sacrifices and uncertainties would, in my view, be worth it." -- Adm. William J. Crowe, former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. [ A1:1. ] "By the time it is evident that sanctions alone cannot succeed, a credible military option will probably no longer exist." -- Henry A. Kissinger, former Secretary of State. [ A14:4. ]

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column on Nov. 20, about anti-abortion protests outside a medical clinic in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., misidentified a group that has rallied in support of the clinic. The group, known as WHAM, is Women's Health Action and Mobilization, not Women Against Men.

title: Review/Folk; Chanteys And Chants Of the South
description: Ten men in dark suits, most of them wearing hats, sat in a semicircle onstage at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday night, singing in sumptuous gospel harmony and regularly leaning forward to pull in an imaginary fish net. It was the New York City debut of the Menhaden Chanteymen from Beaufort, N.C., members of the last generation to pull in by hand nets holding thousands of menhaden. Since the 1960's, the oily fish, used in fertilizer and cat food, has been harvested with power winches, but the songs that rallied the fishermen's strength have survived. They were the rarest music in Tuesday's concert, a Folk Masters program that also included Delta blues from Mississippi and Mardi Gras Indian songs from New Orleans.

title: To Many Britons, Major Is Unknown
description: If Government leaders around the world are not too sure who John Major, Britain's new Prime Minister, is, they shouldn't feel too bad. A lot of people in Lambeth, the working-class borough in south London where he grew up and began his political career, aren't too sure either.

title: Dinkins Issues Harsh Warning On Cuts in Aid
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins told Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday that the state's proposed budget cuts would cost New York City about $185 million in its current fiscal year, or nearly twice what Mr. Cuomo estimated when he announced the cutbacks in state aid two weeks ago.

title: Feng Youlan, Chinese Philosopher With Links to West, Is Dead at 94
description: Feng Youlan, China's leading contemporary philosopher, died on Monday, the New China News Agency said today. He was 94 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MERYL STREEP and DONALD GUMMER are expecting a baby next summer. It will be the fourth child for the actress and her husband, who is a sculptor. They have a boy and two girls aged 11, 7 and 4.

title: Food Donors' Squabbles Imperil Aid to Sudan
description: As famine threatens to engulf the Sudan and Western donors try to persuade its Government that food aid is needed, fierce squabbling over where and how food should be delivered has erupted among the donors.

title: Accounts
description: * Recreational Equipment Inc., Kent, Wash., to Ketchum Directory Advertising, San Francisco, for its national Yellow Pages account. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Richard S. Jessup, Accountant, 83
description: Richard Stotesbury Jessup, a certified public accountant and a tax specialist, died on Sunday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Review/Dance; At Next Wave Series, Moving and Moving Hard
description: The image of the long-distance runner, alone while watched by a crowd, has been turned, especially by films, into a metaphor for social conflict.

title: Pathe Owner And MCA
description: Before MCA Inc. agreed to accept the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company's $6.13 billion offer, MCA's chairman, Lew Wasserman, received a letter from Giancarlo Parretti, who offered to top the Japanese bid.

title: Review/Television; A Lesbian Comes of Age, And Not in an Easy Way
description: Being shown on the Arts & Entertainment Network tonight at 9, the BBC's "Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit" is prefaced with a "Parental Discretion Is Advised" warning. There is a bit of nudity in this "coming of age" film, but the real reason for the nervousness is probably the fact the very special girl coming of age turns out to be a lesbian. Television, especially American television, tends to be notoriously silly when dealing with lesbianism. "Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit" is anything but silly. It's a fresh, challenging and memorable little movie. Parental -- and all other -- attention is advised.

title: Airport to Charge for Parking
description: A new $2 million parking lot will be built at the Stewart International Airport next year, bringing an end to free parking there, state transportation officials said. Parking fees would probably average $5 to $6 a day, said Russell Vachon, director of aviation at the State Department of Transportation. He said rates would be determined in the contract with the developer, APCOA Inc. of Cleveland.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a study of estrogen and breast cancer omitted the name of the medical journal that reported the research. It is The Journal of the American Medical Association. The article also misidentified a cancer researcher at Harvard Medical School. He is Dr. I. Craig Henderson. Because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to an epidemiologist at the National Cancer Institute. The epidemiologist is a woman, Dr. Louise Brinton.

title: Calendar: Tours, Trees And Christmas Trinkets
description: An Architect's Architect 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; (212) 996-1100.

title: Hospital Sets Policy on Pregnant Patients' Rights
description: In an unusual out-of-court settlement announced here today, George Washington University Medical Center has developed a policy to insure that ethically difficult decisions on how to treat severely ill pregnant women and their fetuses will be made by the woman, her family and her doctors and not by the courts.

title: Subaru to Cut Jobs Amid Sales Slump
description: Subaru of America Inc. will trim its work force by as much as 10 percent to cut costs and restore profitability. Some employees have been notified in recent weeks that they would be let go effective Dec. 28, and other reductions will be made in the next few months, a company spokesman, Richard Marshall, said.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

S.E.C. Picks New Chief For Investment Division
description: Marianne K. Smythe, who has been serving as the chief of staff to the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was appointed yesterday to head the agency's investment management division.

title: Defense Calls Jogger Case a Racist Witch Hunt
description: Defense lawyers in the Central Park jogger trial argued yesterday that the two defendants were victims of a police witch hunt driven by racism and spurred by a public clamor for quick arrests in the attack on a woman they called a member of the city's elite.

title: HOMETOWN CHEERS A POPULAR GERMAN
description: If all politics is local, then for Hans-Dietrich Genscher the year's wrenching events that toppled Communism in eastern Europe and wrought German unity probably began somewhere out on the edge of Halle, his grimy hometown in eastern Germany.

title: Argentina and Brazil Renounce Atomic Weapons
description: Moving to soften a long dispute with the United States just days ahead of a visit to this area by President Bush, the Presidents of Brazil and Argentina formally renounced the manufacture of nuclear weapons today at a meeting on their border.

title: Saudi King, Hardening His Stand, Dismisses Any Dealing With Iraq
description: On the eve of a United Nations vote on military action against Iraq, the King of Saudi Arabia appears to be taking his toughest stand yet against the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, warning that if he does not withdraw from Kuwait, it will "be a tragedy for Iraq."

title: If a Bumbershoot Goes Handle Up
description: FOR Gilbert Center, the manager of the Uncle Sam Umbrella Shop, bad weather means brisk business.

title: Bigger Loss Seen at Macy
description: R. H. Macy & Company has told creditors and credit agencies that it had a loss of $66 million in its latest quarter -- a bigger loss than creditors expected and double its $33.1 million loss in the quarter last year, a number of creditors and represenatives of credit agencies said Tuesday.

title: 2 Dead as Typhoon Hits Micronesia Homes
description: A typhoon with winds of 125 miles per hour raked Micronesia today, killing two men and leaving more than 1,000 people homeless, officials said.

title: Lord Pearce, Head Of Rhodesia Inquiry, Dies in Britain at 89
description: Lord Pearce, chairman of a Government panel in 1972 that rejected a proposed settlement in Rhodesia on the ground that most blacks opposed it, died Monday, newspapers reported today. He was 89 years old.

title: Entrepreneurs Sought For Clock Setting
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW LEADER TAKES SINGAPORE'S HELM
description: In a brief, rather solemn ceremony, Goh Chok Tong became Singapore's second Prime Minister tonight, taking over from Lee Kuan Yew, the world's longest-serving Prime Minister, who has run Singapore for the last 31 years.

title: Track Group Acts On King Holiday
description: The Athletics Congress voted today to withhold T.A.C. national championship meets from any state that did not recognize the birthday of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as a legal holiday.

title: Topics of The Times; Balanced Judgment
description: A New York woman who has them calls flat feet the "tyranny of the arches." She still cringes at the memory of monthly childhood visits to a chiropodist, the primitive X-rays and the clunky shoes with uncomfortable steel inserts that didn't correct.

title: Giants Have More Worries Than Just The 49ers
description: As the Giants started preparations today for Monday night's still-big game against the 49ers in San Francisco, there seemed to be cracks in the wall. All was not right with Mark Bavaro, Lawrence Taylor and Carl Banks, three of the Giants' Pro Bowl veterans.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Senators EDWARD M. KENNEDY and ORRIN G. HATCH are among those to be honored tomorrow night for their work in fighting AIDS.

title: Gerber Products Fills Two Corporate Posts
description: The Gerber Products Company named a new vice chairman and executive vice president yesterday as it completed management changes that began in January when its chairman and chief executive left the company.

title: Hanover Deal For Deposits Of Goldome
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 13 branches in the New York City area and about $1.6 billion of deposits from Goldome F.S.B., a Buffalo savings bank.

title: Heineken to Cut Work Force by 250
description: The Heineken brewing company said it would slash its Dutch operation by 250 jobs because of slow sales and the Netherlands' growing taste for specialty beers. The reduction by attrition, early retirement programs and internal transfers will bring Heineken N.V.'s work force down to 3,550 from 3,800, the company said. No dismissals will be forced, the company said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Diversified Energies Inc., Minneapolis, and Arkla Inc., Shreveport, La., a natural gas company, said their boards had approved Diversified's merger into Arkla. * EG& G Inc., Wellesley, Mass., a scientific and technical products company, has acquired the electro-optics business of General Electric Co.'s GE Canada Inc. unit. No terms were disclosed. * Hyundai, Seoul, South Korea, said it would invest in Siberia and build a car plant in China. * ISK Enterprises Inc., a maker of agricultural chemicals, has acquired SDS Enterprises Inc., a technology and chemicals company, from Fermenta A.B., Stockholm. The price was $300 million. * Lomas Financial Corp., Dallas, has completed the sale of its life insurance group to an affiliate of Conseco Inc., Carmel, Ind. The price was $140 million in cash plus $25 million in junior debt securities. * Mitsubishi Corp., Tokyo, and Chrysler Canada Ltd. will begin a 50-50 venture by the end of the year in Toronto to produce parts for Chrysler's new model, the LH car. * Reliance Group Holdings Inc. said it intended to buy up to two million common shares of Frank B. Hall Co. from time to time. Reliance owns 22.3 million of the estimated 36.6 million shares outstanding. * Unisys Corp., Blue Bell, Pa., said its military systems unit and Energetics Satellite Corp. would build and operate a satellite system. Unisys said the venture's revenues could exceed $250 million over 10 years.

title: Topics of The Times; Giving Warmth
description: Every so often, a good idea actually works. And every so often a good idea gets better. Both statements apply to a volunteer program in New York City to recycle coats. Last year, its first, the coat drive collected 10,000 used but wearable overcoats, jackets and parkas for adults and children. This year the drive's sponsors -- New York Cares and the J. M. Kaplan Fund -- are hoping to double that by setting up central collection centers.

title: Farm Export Drop Seen
description: The value of United States agricultural exports is expected to drop 4 percent this fiscal year to $38.5 billion, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday. The value of such exports rose to a nine-year high of more than $40.1 billion in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.

title: Cuomo to Forgo Inaugural Ball, Citing Expense
description: Dismissing a ceremony as expensive and a celebration as inappropriate, Mario M. Cuomo said today that his inauguration to a third term as New York's governor would be a strictly private affair.

title: Burke Fails to Make the Big Saves
description: Sean Burke continues to experience a nightmare whenever he steps onto the ice at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: The Humor of Gorbachev
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told reporters a joke about the faltering Soviet economy on Tuesday, after an all-day session of the Parliament of the Russian republic.

title: Ismail of Irish Winner In Walter Camp Vote
description: Raghib Ismail, the all-purpose junior at Notre Dame they call the Rocket for reasons air-grabbing rival tacklers have been learning about all season, was named the Walter Camp Player of the Year yesterday.

title: DDB to Work On McDonald's
description: The McDonald's Corporation, has returned to DDB Needham with part of its reported $300 million account, giving the agency a reported $55 million chunk of the business that had been handled by Leo Burnett. The agency handled McDonald's entire account until 1981, and it will rejoin the fast-food chain with various promotional work aimed at young audiences.

title: Aquatic Pest Turns Up Early in Hudson
description: The zebra mussel, an aquatic pest that fouls the intake pipes of power plants, has been found in the Hudson River for the first time, scientists who have been tracking its spread eastward from the Great Lakes said yesterday.

title: Dinosaur Displays Closing for Renovation
description: The American Museum of Natural History, which houses the largest collection of fossils in the world, has begun closing down its immensely popular dinosaur exhibitions as it initiates a five-year renovation project, the institution's most ambitious such remodeling since it was founded in 1869.

title: New U.S. Ambassador Reopens Embassy in a More Secure Lebanon
description: In a sign of improved security conditions in Lebanon, the new United States Ambassador, Ryan Crocker, arrived here today to reopen the embassy, closed for more than a year.

title: Britain and Syria Restore Ties After 4-Year Break
description: Britain and Syria today restored diplomatic relations, which were severed four years ago when Britain accused Syria of sponsoring terrorism, the two Governments announced.

title: Wound-Healing Elixirs Spur Debate
description: Esther Seabrook emerged from her doctor's appointment for the treatment of a longstanding sore on her shin carrying a rumpled paper bag containing an ordinary blue thermos. The thermos contained a thin clear potion of powerful wound-healing chemicals, platelet-derived growth factors, distilled from her own blood.

title:
Currents;
As Snug as a Morris Chair on a Rug
description: WILLIAM MORRIS, the 19th-century designer, social reformer and poet, is often remembered for the plain and sturdy recliner called the Morris chair. Yet Morris, Marshall, Faulkner & Company, the firm that Morris founded in 1861, turned out stained glass, metalwork, wallpaper, chintzes and other furnishings that now seem particularly exotic for their color and detail.

title: The Saddam Bomb (3)
description: Four weeks ago, when so-called experts were confident that Saddam Hussein would not have a complete nuclear weapons system for at least 5 to 10 years, I presumed in this space to task our intelligence agency with a much more specific mission: Find out how soon Iraq would be able detonate a simple, "dirty" device.

title: Wladyslaw Rubin, 73, Polish-Born Cardinal
description: Wladyslaw Cardinal Rubin, a Polish-born prelate who headed the Congregation for Eastern Churches of the Vatican, died today, church officials said. He was 73 years old.

title: 2 Ex-Military Chiefs Urge Bush to Delay Gulf War
description: Two former Chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff urged the Bush Administration today to postpone military action against Iraq and to give economic sanctions a year or more to work.

title: Researchers Gain in Mapping How AIDS Virus Enters Cells
description: Scientists have taken an important step forward in mapping the contours of the critical gateway through which the AIDS virus gains entry into human white blood cells.

title: Barbara Bush to Miss Tour
description: A "low-grade sinus infection" will prevent Barbara Bush from accompanying President Bush on his tour across South America next week, the White House said today. Instead, his daughter, Dorothy LeBlond, will make the trip on Dec. 2-8 to Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela. Mrs. Bush, 65 years old, spent much of the last 12 days with her husband in Mexico, Europe and the Middle East. Anna Perez, the First Lady's press secretary, said Mrs. Bush had been unable to shake the infection, which has bothered her for two to three weeks.

title: Douglas's Outlook for New Plane
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation reiterated today that it does not expect a significant loss on its contract to develop the Air Force's new C-17 transport plane, despite a new Air Force study that said the company could suffer cost overruns of $600 million.

title: Bush May Recall Congress To Consider Force in Gulf
description: President Bush is considering calling Congress back into session in December to consider the use of force in the Persian Gulf, two senior Senate Republicans said today.

title: Review/Jazz; Building on Basie's Legacy
description: The orchestra that Count Basie led in the late 1930's -- the band with which he established his place in jazz -- was loaded with musicians who played with such distinctive individuality that their solos were immediately recognizable. They ranged from Basie's spare piano style to Jo Jones's subtle and motivating drumming, and they included the tenor saxophonists Lester Young, Herschel Evans and Evans's successor, Buddy Tate, as well as the trumpeters Buck Clayton and Harry (Sweets) Edison.

title: Iran-Contra Prosecutor Is Sued by a Publisher
description: Penguin USA filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday against Lawrence E. Walsh, the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case, and the office of the independent counsel, seeking a permanent injunction to bar them from censoring a book by a former staff member about the investigation of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and his trial.

title: Daughter Succeeds Father As Head of In-Flight Phone
description: Sandra K. Goeken has been named chairman and chief executive of the In-Flight Phone Corporation, succeeding her father, John D. Goeken, in a move that the Goekens hope will be a temporary one.

title: Baker and Shevardnadze Plan Talks in Houston
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, announced today that they would hold a ministerial meeting on Dec. 10 and 11 in Houston, Mr. Baker's hometown, apparently to pave the way for a summit meeting in Moscow this winter.

title: Lilco Wins 3.6% Increase, But Must Also Pay Refund
description: State utility regulators approved a 3.6 percent increase in electricity rates for the Long Island Lighting Company today, but residential bills will not increase nearly that much.

title: Farebersviller Journal; Minaret Is Silent, but Has Much to Say to France
description: This is a tale of a minaret, two imams and a symbolic franc, of a fanciful architect and a rough stretch of coal country, of France and Islam and a little faith.

title: Legislators Feel Relief After Decision by Court
description: A State Court of Appeals decision to toss out hundreds of felony charges against the State Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, left legislators breathing a collective sigh of relief today. It also left a legal debate on what has long been one of the grayest ethical questions facing the Legislature -- whether legislative employees paid by the public can be assigned to work on political campaigns.

title: Gretzky's Skills Inspire Sandstrom
description: A few years ago, "Hockey Night in Canada," the National Hockey League broadcast across Canada, showed a musical-video spoof of the "Twelve Days of Christmas."

title: Home Equity Loans Back $500 Million Bank Offering
description: A $500 million issue of securities backed by home equity loans from the Shawmut National Corporation was priced yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After a 10-week trial in which she listened to daily testimony that her husband had been unfaithful to her, EFFI BARRY , the wife of the Mayor of Washington, has left MARION S. BARRY JR. She and their son, Christopher, 10 years old, have moved from their Washington home to an apartment, a spokesman for the Mayor said yesterday.

title: ISRAEL RESOLUTION LOOMS AT THE U.N.
description: The United States representative at the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, said today that at least 13 of the 15 members of the Security Council favor a vote to authorize force against Iraq on Thursday before the Council considers another resolution critical of Israel's treatment of Palestinians living in the occupied territories.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Florida's Department of Tranportation has postponed to January 1991 the negotiated sale of turnpike revenue bonds that had been scheduled for the week of Dec. 3. Moody's Investors Service reports that various sources in the state have said that the newly elected Governor, Lawton Chiles, will review the turnpike projects and determine budget implications, if any. * GTE Hawaiian Telephone Co. is offering $75 million in 9 percent first mortgage bonds, due 2000, at 98.647 to yield 9.21 percent through Kidder, Peabody & Co. Noncallable for five years, the bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. * Student Loan Marketing Association is offering $200 million in floating-rate notes due 1992, priced to yield about 55-hundredths of a percentage point more than the three-month Treasury bill through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The rate is adjusted weekly, and interest is paid quarterly. RATINGS * North American Philips Corp.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to A-3, from A-2, and commercial paper rating to Prime-2, from Prime-1 by Moody's. The diversified manufacturer of electronic goods is based in New York City and is a subsidiary of Philips N.V. of the Netherlands.

title: Craig Can't Outrun Critics
description: Roger Craig headed off in one direction and then another. Nothing worked. His moves simply weren't enough to avoid the afternoon rush of reporters.

title: Giants Still Resent 49er 'Cheap Shot'
description: On the Giants-49ers marquee, the game's the thing. Monday night's matchup is naturally the primary plot. Each team trying for an 11-1 record. Each team trying to gain the home-field advantage during the National Conference playoffs leading to Super Bowl XXV. Each team trying to avert a two-game losing streak that would shake its confidence.

title: Our Pain, Their Gain
description: Even though President Bush expects to obtain an additional resolution from the United Nations Security Council threatening Iraq with military action, he is today no closer to convincing the American people of the wisdom of the Administration's policies in the Persian Gulf.

title: New Status Is Sought For S.& L.'s
description: Federal regulators proposed today that savings and loan institutions be permitted to convert to state-chartered savings banks.

title: Local Setback for Michigan Law on Hate Crimes
description: A Michigan state law that makes it a crime to harass or harm people because of their race or ethnic origin has been declared unconstitutional by a municipal court judge, ruling in a trial involving a white man accused of setting fire to the house of a black couple.

title: Review/Film; A Writer Who Really Suffers
description: "MISERY," Stephen King's overweight suspense novel, may be paper-thin, but embedded within it, if only dimly seen like a watermark, there is a very funny idea:

title: Job Applicant's Lot Isn't Happy Either
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Press Book Fair
