description: The art of small-press publishing is to be demonstrated this weekend at the annual Small Press Book Fair at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street. Printing processes, from hand-printing presses to computerized techniques, are to be discussed at the fair, which is to feature nearly 200 publishers. There will also be readings, hundreds of books and magazines on sale and an exhibition of Walt Whitman memorabilia. Whitman himself set part of his "Leaves of Grass" poetry collection by hand in a small Brooklyn printing shop. Hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow and 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is free. Information: (212) 764-7021.

title: Dollar Rises Against Yen And Mark
description: The dollar surged yesterday, jumping more than 2 percent against the Japanese yen and more than 1 percent against the German mark.

title: Western Union Debt Offer
description: The Western Union Corporation offered holders of its "junk bonds" 50 cents on the dollar today to avoid a cash crisis and possible bankruptcy.

title: 12 Charged With International Theft Conspiracy
description: Twelve men from several countries were charged yesterday with participating in an international conspiracy to distribute more than $550 million worth of securities stolen from two financial institutions.

title: U.N.L.V. Allowed To Defend Title
description: Lifting a ban imposed in July, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has decided to allow Nevada-Las Vegas to defend its 1990 national basketball championship in the 1991 college basketball tournament, but only after the university and its head basketball coach, Jerry Tarkanian, agreed to accept even stiffer penalties next season.

title: Negotiators Closing In On Majors-Minors Deal
description: Earlier this week, the chief negotiator for baseball's minor leagues suggested that major league owners might be more receptive to an agreement on a new player-development contract than their negotiators were. Now, however, it appears that the minor league owners are the ones who could determine whether the two sides will have an agreement by the middle of next week.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Madison Avenue will be closed Sunday from 62d to 72d Street from noon to 5 P.M. for the Christmas for Children Fund Street Fair.

title: PAKISTANI OFFERS ATOM ISSUE TALKS
description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said today that he was ready to open talks with Washington on Pakistan's nuclear program, the central issue in what officials here call Pakistan's most serious crisis in relations with the United States in more than three decades.

title: Fringe Politics Eclipsed As Bonn Looks to Unity
description: On the fringes of German politics, the first election of a reunified Germany on Sunday is looming as a dark day.

title: House Leaders Tell President Not to Call Special Iraq Session
description: As the United Nations Security Council gave its approval today to the use of military force against Iraq, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the House told President Bush they could not guarantee strong bipartisan support for a similar resolution in Congress.

title: New U.S. Envoy in Lebanon Calls Hostage Issue Priority
description: Ryan Crocker, the new United States Ambassador to Lebanon, submitted his credentials to President Elias Hrawi today and announced that as he begins his diplomatic mission, he will give priority to winning freedom for six Americans held captive in this country.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sun Ra Benefit

title: S.E.C. Chief Aide to Leave
description: Edmund Coulson said yesterday that he would resign as chief accountant for the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington shortly after the first of the year to become a partner in the New York office of Ernst & Young, a leading accounting firm. A search is under way for his successor, as well as for the deputy's job, which is also vacant.

title: Suit by News Calls Unions Conspirators
description: The Daily News filed a new lawsuit yesterday in its fight with its striking unions, charging in Federal court that union leaders, workers and their advisers were engaged in a violent conspiracy to harm the newspaper.

title: Mistrial Declared in Louisiana Faith Healing Case
description: A mistrial was declared today by a State judge in the case of a woman charged with negligent homicide after her 5-year- old son died of leukemia last year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on Saturday about elections in Czechoslovakia misstated figures for the races being contested by the Communist Party and Civic Forum. The Communists contested 5,749, or 74 percent, of all races, not 74 races; and Civic Forum had candidates in 73 percent of the races, not 73 races.

title: De Larrocha in Mozart
description: The pianist Alicia de Larrocha is to be the soloist with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra in Mozart's Concerto No. 27 in B flat (K. 595) at Carnegie Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. The program also includes Haydn's Symphony No. 44 in E minor, Kodaly's "Hungarian Rondo" and Martin's Etudes for String Orchestra. Tickets are $10 to $25. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Super 8 Motels Are To Be Sold
description: Super 8 Enterprises Inc., a privately held South Dakota company that owns the Super 8 Motels franchise system, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the business to a group of Hong Kong investors for an undisclosed price.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Consolidated Natural Gas Co., Pittsburgh, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $200 million in 25-year convertible subordinated debentures through First Boston Corp. * Potlatch Corp., San Francisco, has filed for a $250 million shelf offering of debt securities. * Republic New York Corp. is offering $100 million in 9 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 2000 at a price of 100 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Noncallable through maturity, the notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P. * Utilicorp United Inc., Kansas City, Mo., is offering $250 million in debt securities equally divided between five-year and 30-year securities through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities. An issue due in 1995 is priced to yield 9.30 percent and an issue due in 2020 is priced to yield 10.60 percent. Both issues are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB- by S.&P. * Walt Disney Co. has filed for a $1 billion shelf offering of debt securities. Common Stock * American Adjustable Rate Term Trust Inc., Minneapolis, has filed for two million common shares through Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. Ratings * Transco Energy Co.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to BBB, from A-, and preferred stock rating to BBB-, from BBB+, by S.&P. The company is based in Houston. * USG Corp.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to Caa, from B-2, by Moody's, which also lowered the senior debt of USG's United States Gypsum Company subsidiary to Caa, from B-3. USG Corp. is based in Chicago.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Israeli budget misstated the figure for planned spending for immigration-related programs. It is $6.5 billion, not $6.5 million.

title: Rams Stun Pirates On 3-Pointer at End
description: Last year at this time, Fordham went to New Jersey to play heavily favored Seton Hall at Walsh Gymnasium. The Rams upset Seton Hall by 65-60, but some of the players thought the victory was hollow.

title: New Drug to Treat Sleeping Sickness With Few Side Effects Is Announced
description: The first new treatment for African sleeping sickness in 40 years, a drug that researchers say cures the disease with few toxic side effects, was announced today by the World Health Organization and the Marion Merrell Dow Company, the drug's maker.

title: At Year-end, Warning of Rise in Car Crime
description: One in every 42 registered automobiles in the nation was stolen or looted last year, and these crimes continue to rise sharply in many cities, as wailing auto alarms attest. December, going by experience, may be the year's peak month for vehicle crime as thieves do their own kind of holiday shopping.

title: Henry M. Caudill, Who Described Appalachia's Poverty, Dies at 68
description: Harry M. Caudill, a Kentucky lawyer, professor and author whose eloquent description of life in poverty-ridden Appalachia inspired Federal relief efforts beginning in the 1960's, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound yesterday at the Appalachian Regional Hospital in Whitesburg, Ky. He was 68 years old.

title: Challenge for Hofstra On Road to the Final
description: "Look out for the quarterback. He's tough. And don't think you're going to go up and down the field against their defense. It's tough."

title: What Shakespeare Knew About Baseball
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about gang violence in Boston misstated the city's record for homicides in a year. It was 135, registered in 1973; this year's total, through Wednesday, was 133.

title: McDonald's Hurt By Price Report
description: Stock of the McDonald's Corporation dropped $1.125 a share, to 28, on the New York Stock Exchange after an analyst said the fast-food chain was considering permanent price cuts on most basic menu items. But Jack M. Greenberg, McDonald's chief financial officer, disputed the report. He said the company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., was testing "a variety of value strategies" in local markets but had not settled on a systemwide plan.

title: The Police Plan, Snagged
description: New York City's plan to hire more police and expand other crime control programs has bogged down in a dispute between Mayor Dinkins and City Council Speaker Peter Vallone. The need for agreement is urgent if the city is to make a persuasive case for the approvals it needs from Albany in the deteriorating fiscal climate.

title: Teaneck Reacts To Indictment Of Policeman
description: The manslaughter indictment handed up on Wednesday against a police officer who fatally shot a teen-ager in the back after a foot chase last April startled some residents here and left others yearning for a trial and more details.

title: Composer Firmly on the Side of All Genres
description: Rhys Chatham, who will be performing a new score called "The Heart Cries With Many Voices," for a blend of rock instruments, brass and early-music singers tonight and tomorrow night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is only 38 years old. One says "only" because that would still count as young for most classical composers, which is what Mr. Chatham was trained, and now once again considers himself, to be.

title: Review/Ballet; A Mozartian Mixture Of Sacred and Secular
description: The New York City Ballet was in splendid form on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Prison for Patz Case Suspect
description: The main suspect in the disappearance of 6-year-old Etan Patz in Manhattan in 1979 was sentenced today to 10 to 20 years in prison for sexually molesting a boy in a northwest Pennsylvania campground. The suspect, Jose A. Ramos, 47, formerly of Coconut Grove, Fla., pleaded guilty on Oct. 19 to involuntary deviate sexual intercourse. Etan Patz has not been seen since he left his Prince Steet home in SoHo for school on May 25, 1979. Mr. Ramos was a boyfriend of a woman who had baby-sat for Etan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Whalers Beat Penguins Ron Francis scored the tie-breaking goal with 1 minute 20 seconds left in regulation time as the Hartford Whalers beat the slumping Penguins, 6-4, last night in Pittsburgh. The Penguins have lost five of their last six games. (AP) Bruins 4, Oilers 2: In Boston, Chris Nilan and Don Sweeney scored goals late in the second period and the Bruins held on. The Bruins improved their regular-season record over the Oilers at home to 6-0-1 since 1986. (AP) Blues 4, Kings 4: Wayne Gretzky's power-play goal with 3:27 remaining in the third period completed Los Angeles's comeback from a four-goal third-period deficit. The goal was the 16th of the season for Gretzky. (AP) Red Wings 5, Blackhawks 1: In Chicago, Glen Hanlon, the Detroit goalie, won for the first time since Feb. 2 and Joe Kocur converted his first penalty shot. (AP) N.B.A. Nuggets on a Roll Orlando Woolridge scored 32 points last night as the Denver Nuggets won a second consecutive game for first time this season, beating the Sacramento Kings by 136-128 in Denver. The victory was Denver's third in 14 games. Sacramento is 1-12. (AP) Suns 128, SuperSonics 110: Phoenix made all 23 of its free throws in a one-sided first half. The Suns led by 65-47 at halftime and by 96-77 entering the last quarter. (AP) Trail Blazers 107, Timberwolves 92: Clyde Drexler scored 21 points and Terry Porter added 20 as Portland, playing at home, built a 20-point halftime lead and coasted to victory over Minnesota. (AP)

title: Bush Signs 5-Year Farm Bill That Limits Crop Subsidies
description: President Bush signed a five-year, $170 billion farm bill Wednesday that will curb Federal crop subsidies and prod farmers to protect the environment. The measure also renews for five years the food stamp program that helps feed the nation's poor.

title: Those Big Bad Niners Have Giants Upset
description: Erik Howard, the Giants' nose tackle, says he is looking forward to Monday night's game against the 49ers in San Francisco. But he says he hopes the 49ers will refrain from the chop blocks and the cut blocks that are so dangerous to defensive players. He also says he hopes the officials will call penalties rather than turn their backs.

title: TV Weekend; James Garner as a Curmudgeon Pulled Back Into Life
description: James Garner is an old-fashioned actor. Like Gary Cooper and James Stewart, he conveys the impression that he is always playing himself with uncommonly easy grace. As it happens, Mr. Garner has done most of his best work in television. In recent years, the mature actor has excelled in such "Hallmark Hall of Fame" presentations as "Promise" and "My Name Is Bill W." Now, on Sunday at 9 P.M. on NBC , he's back in still another "Hallmark" production, "Decoration Day," and, by golly, he's doing it again, imbuing what could have been a fairly pedestrian role with remarkable weight and insight.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Amid lawsuits questioning his right to bequeath his art collection, DR. ARMAND HAMMERopened his new museum in Los Angeles on Wednesday. The 92-year-old industrialist will follow up that event with his bar mitzvah on Dec. 11, the first night of Hanukkah.

title: A Tough Sell for 'Made in Japan'
description: For years, American makers of supercomputers have complained that the Japanese Government has refused to buy any American-made versions of the world's fastest problem-solvers. Now it is the Japanese who are complaining.

title: Our Towns; Words to Beguile Lonely Children From Their Grief
description: Once a week for an hour, Grace Zambelli, a counselor at The Hospice Inc. here, meets with five boys and girls, ages 9 to 12, whose mother or father recently died. Her job is to help children understand death. This week's topic was, "Death, Facts Versus Fantasies."

title: Leonard to Fight At the Garden
description: Sugar Ray Leonard is coming to Madison Square Garden.

title: Hobart Hires Maxwell
description: Bill Maxwell, who has spent the last 10 years as quarterback coach and assistant head coach at Syracuse, was selected yesterday as the new football coach at Hobart College, a Division III school.

title: D.E. Rubin Wed To Miss Salzberg
description: Susan Hope Salzberg, the daughter of Helen M. Salzberg of New York and the late Henry H. Salzberg, was married yesterday to David Eric Rubin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Rubin of New Rochelle, N.Y. Cantor Richard Botton performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Recovery Plan for an S.& L.
description: Great American Bank, a financially troubled savings and loan company based in San Diego, said today that Federal regulators had approved a sweeping recovery plan that includes the previously announced sale of Great American's branches in California to the Wells Fargo Bank.

title: U.S. Sued Over Drug to Increase Milk Output
description: A public interest group sued the Department of Agriculture today, charging that it had helped begin a million-dollar public relations campaign for an experimental drug whose safety was still being investigated by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Purdue Coach Resigns
description: Fred Akers, the Purdue football coach who did not have a winning season in four years with the Boilermakers, resigned yesterday.

title: Bulgarian Premier Quits After 2 Weeks of Protests
description: Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov, a Socialist who was a Politburo member in the Communist Party that governed here for 45 years, resigned tonight after two weeks of loud but peaceful street protests and a four-day strike that paralyzed much of the country.

title: U.S. Backs World Bank Environment Unit
description: Industrial and developing countries agreed in Paris this week to establish a new fund within the World Bank devoted to protecting the global environment.

title: War And the President
description: Can President Bush take the country into war in the Persian Gulf without the approval of Congress? The question is heading toward decisive tests, legal and political. The answer could have profound consequences for our constitutional system and our internal peace.

title: Robert Hearin, 73, Mississippi Millionaire
description: Robert Hearin, a millionaire businessman whose wife was kidnapped from their home two years ago and was never found, died of a heart attack at Mississippi Baptist Medical Center on Wednesday after collapsing at his office. He was 73 years old.

title: Turnout Appears Low in Egyptian Election Boycotted by Opposition
description: In low numbers that showed apathy and cynicism, Egyptians voted today in a general election boycotted by opposition groups seeking to deny President Hosni Mubarak's assertion that he is moving his land toward real democracy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GEN. COLIN L. POWELL has agreed to be the honorary grand marshal for the annual King Week parade on Jan. 21 in the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s hometown, Atlanta. But the REV. JOSEPH LOWERY, the president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, criticized the King Center's decision to invite a military leader, saying it conflicted with Dr. King's teachings of nonviolence.

title: When Lawmakers Pad Their Payrolls
description: Is it illegal for legislators to use taxpayer funds to hire full-time campaign workers? Not according to New York State's highest court, the Court of Appeals. In a ruling this week that sends the wrong signal to politicians, it threw out the payroll padding charges that form the core of the case against Manfred Ohrenstein, the State Senate minority leader. If that doesn't endorse, it at least tolerates activities most ordinary citizens would consider theft of public funds.

title: Tariff Placed on Aspartame
description: The European Community imposed anti-dumping duties today on imports of the artificial sweetner aspartame from the United States and Japan.

title: Yankees and Righetti Years Apart in Talks
description: Dave Righetti, who has spent his entire major league career in pinstripes while accumulating more saves than any other pitcher in Yankee history, may not be with the team next season.

title: Major Plans to See Bush in December
description: John Major, making his first appearance as Britain's Prime Minister in the House of Commons today, said he hoped to confer with President Bush on the Persian Gulf crisis in Washington before Christmas.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "We must put the choice to Saddam Hussein in unmistakable terms." -- Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. [ A10:2. ] "If war breaks out, we will fight in a way that will make all Arabs and Muslims proud." -- President Saddam Hussein. [ A1:4. ]

title: Yale Scares Connecticut
description: In the kind of game that the 45-second shot clock supposedly eliminated, the University of Connecticut Huskies were pushed to the limit tonight in a come-from-behind 49-48 victory over Yale.

title: Black-Owned Media Fear Being Cut First
description: ADVERTISERS feeling the chill wind of a recession are quick to rethink where they are placing their ads, and black-owned media are worried that they will be the first to be frozen out.

title: Participating In the Day Without Art
description: A Day Without Art to dramatize the impact of AIDS on the arts world will be observed this weekend with a number of activities sponsored by cultural institutions. Here is a sampling of events in Manhattan. Today

title: INSIDE
description: High-Tech Role Reversal

title: Group Agrees To Buy Expos
description: A group of Canadian investors agreed in principle tonight to buy the Montreal Expos from Charles Bronfman.

title:
Affordable Housing;
New Jersey Builders Try Pennsylvania
description: The willingness of New Jersey residents to commute a little longer to work in exchange for attractive, relatively inexpensive housing prompted two developers to begin construction of 117 single-family homes in Bethlehem Township, Pa., one of the fastest-growing communities in Pennsylvania's Northampton County.

title: Florida's Indoor Beach
description: What with all the theme parks like Disneyland and Baseball City and Alligatorland and what not, it is not surprising that in St. Petersburg they have built themselves an indoor beach.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;
description: Jose Uribe, the San Francisco Giants' shortstop, was free on bail yesterday after he was charged with assaulting two women with a baseball bat, Santo Domingo newspapers said. Uribe was released after posting $26,000 bail, the newspapers reported.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bank of New York Co. will close the Chicago and Atlanta corporate-lending offices it acquired when it bought Irving Trust Co. two years ago. * Lockheed Corp., Calabasas, Calif., called a plan by Harold C. Simmons to acquire the company for $40 a share not feasible. It said the plan could involve $2 billion in new and refinanced debt, doubling the company's debt-to-capital ratio to almost 70 percent. The board is to consider the plan on Monday. * First Boston Corp., New York, an investment company, formed First Cellular Acquisition Corp. to invest in rural cellular telephone networks. * Louisiana-Pacific Corp., Portland, Ore., a forest-products company, will curtail production because of a slump in the housing market. * M/A-COM Inc., Burlington, Mass., an electronics concern, purchased Light Control Systems Inc., Tyngsboro, Mass., a fiber-optics company. * Pattison Partners Inc., a New York-based real estate firm, has an arrangement with Debenham Tewson & Chinnocks, a British real estate firm, under which Debenham's American operations will become a part of Pattison and both firms will have a minority investment in each other. * W. H. Smith Group P.L.C. bought 49 record stores in Pennsylvania from Wall to Wall Sound and Video Inc., Cinnaminson, N.J., for $23 million. * Stage II Apparel Corp., New York, a maker of men's and boy's wear, will not declare a quarterly dividend. Last quarter, its dividend was 3 cents. * USAir Group, Arlington, Va., agreed to coordinate connections between trans-Pacific flights of Japan's All Nippon Airways and USAir flights in the U.S.

title: Watson Quits Club
description: Tom Watson resigned from the Kansas City Country Club after Henry Bloch, chairman and co-founder of H&R Bloch Inc., was reportedly denied admission to the club because he is Jewish, it was reported yesterday.

title: Dolphins to Test Balance In Meeting With Redskins
description: When Dan Marino threw 29 times for 245 yards and 2 touchdowns in Miami's 30-13 victory over Cleveland on Sunday, it reminded him of his first seven years in the league when the Dolphins passed first and answered questions later about their often inept running game.

title: Judge Drops Some Charges In Racial Case
description: The judge in the Bensonhurst racial-slaying case dismissed the most serious murder charge against one defendant yesterday and said that the prosecution's evidence was so weak he would throw out any murder or manslaughter convictions against two of the three young men on trial.

title: People
description: * Michael Pollock has joined D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, as senior vice president and associate creative director. * Ari Schwartz and James Peace have been appointed vice presidents at Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York. * Tom Quaglino has been named a art director and Stu Krull a copywriter at Pedone & Partners, New York. * Jan H. H. Meyer has been named international publishing director for Financial World magazine.

title: NBC Wins Close Race In Prime-Time Ratings
description: NBC won an increasingly tight contest this month between the three major broadcast networks for leadership in prime time. But it led ABC and CBS by just one-tenth of a ratings point, underscoring the inability of all three networks to stem audience attrition and develop new hit programs this season.

title: Bush And Shamir
description: On Dec. 11, President Bush and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir will have an opportunity they rarely get and even more rarely use -- to work together to do themselves and their countries some real good.

title: Guatemalan Military Makes Elections a Hoax
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: Could two adjoining dining rooms in the same restaurant be under different management? Patrons banished to the back room at tres chic, tres French Le Comptoir must walk through the front dining room and up a few steps to reach it. Once they have crossed that great divide, they might as well be in a restaurant on the other side of town.

title: Researchers Find Genetic Defect That Plays Role in Some Cancers
description: Researchers have discovered an inborn genetic defect that strongly predisposes people to at least seven malignancies, including breast cancer.

title: Solidarity, Shaken by Dark Horse, Is Closing Ranks Behind Walesa
description: Staggered by the electoral appeal of Stanislaw Tyminski and uncertain what it portends for the Dec. 9 presidential elections, the leaders of the deeply divided Solidarity movement are closing ranks behind the candidacy of Lech Walesa.

title: A Trendmeister for Law Firms Finds His Counsel is Highly Coveted as Times Turn Tough
description: On the afternoon of Oct. 17, 1989, Bradford Hildebrandt sat in a San Francisco law office, preaching his message of the coming shakeout in the legal industry. And sure enough, the earth shook.

title: Burt Bleeds Niner Gold Instead of Giant Blue
description: The memories have been coming back all week. Jim Burt may have pushed them away long ago -- moved them somewhere into his distant past -- but they're back again.

title: MAI Systems' Chief Resigns
description: The MAI Systems Corporation, the computer company controlled by the investor Bennett S. LeBow, said today that William Weksel, the chairman and chief executive, has resigned "to pursue other business interests." Mr LeBow will replace Mr. Weksel as chairman and chief executive.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Assures New Life and Home for Child
description: This year, before Anna Valentine died of AIDS, Rosa Cruz swore that she would take care of her friend's 10-year-old daughter. By the end of September, only a few days after the funeral, it appeared that the promise might be hard to keep.

title: At the Movies
description: Still Plotting at 91

title: Dorsha Hayes, 93, Dancer and Writer
description: Dorsha Hayes, a dancer and writer, died Tuesday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. She was 93 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Theater; Weller Takes a Stab At the Pastoral Form
description: I didn't realize I had been missing Marsha Mason until I saw her -- radiant, good-humored, emotionally and sexually voluptuous -- in Michael Weller's "Lake No Bottom," the new play at the Second Stage. The actress one fondly remembers from the films "Cinderella Liberty" and "The Goodbye Girl," a two-fisted comedienne with a desperately vulnerable undertow, has returned to the stage with her gifts intact and matured. It seems a waste that Ms. Mason reaches Mr. Weller one play too late. The racy, hard-nosed, flamboyantly neurotic mother played so brilliantly by Kate Nelligan in the author's "Spoils of War" would be a great role for this star as well.

title: New Talks At Ballet Theater
description: Contract negotiations between American Ballet Theater and its 84 dancers resumed yesterday with a new sense of urgency after a three-week recess. On Wednesday, the board of the financially pressed company voted to authorize its executive committee to close "operations of American Ballet Theater in the event that the A.B.T. cannot be operated in a fiscally responsible manner." The board stipulated that an agreement must be reached by Tuesday, when the dancers are scheduled to return to work after a seasonal break. The vote, by 18 of the board's 34 members, was unanimous.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Los Angeles District Attorney's office has refused to file charges against ROB PILATUS of the Milli Vanilli pop duo, who was arrested on Tuesday for investigation of sexual battery. "There's not enough evidence to file a complaint," a spokesman for IRA REINER, the District Attorney, said yesterday. The police said that a 25-year-old woman, whom they would not name, had filed a crime report. Mr. Pilatus was arrested and freed after posting $10,000 bail.

title: Trying to Hold Down the Garbage Pile
description: Ruth Stumacher was minding her own business, doing her weekly shopping at the Gristede's here when she was caught red-handed.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Sardi's

title: Coke and Nestle Plan Coffee and Tea Drinks
description: Nestle S.A., the world's largest food and coffee company, and the Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink company, said yesterday that they were negotiating a joint venture to make and market coffee and tea drinks under the Nestle Nescafe and Nestea brand names.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Fiscal Crisis Could Handcuff Wilson in California
description: With the state's deficit expected to rise into the billions of dollars next year, California's incoming Governor, Pete Wilson, will take office in January facing a fiscal crisis that could severely restrict his adminstration's programs.

title: Auctions
description: Einstein and Freud on War>

title: Clash of Free Trade and National Interest
description: Free trade is wonderful, most nations agree -- except for those instances where it impinges on some powerful national interest.

title: Dow Falls 16.34, to 2,518.81, in Slow Trading
description: Grumbling by traders over interest rates and news reports that led to renewed war jitters sent stocks down yesterday for the second straight session.

title: A Super-Bowl Sample Sale for a Good Cause
description: Today Seventh Avenue is offering merchandise to the public wholesale, and the retailers don't even mind. Seventh on Sale, a three-day shopping marathon to fight AIDS, opens to the public at noon, after a year of concerted effort that has galvanized the fashion industry.

title: Corn and Soybeans Soar On Signs of Soviet Interest
description: Corn and soybean futures prices surged today on the Chicago Board of Trade on new signs of Soviet buying interest, but wheat futures fell to new 13-year lows under the weight of abundant world supplies.

title: 50 Reported Dead in Bangladesh Demanding the President's Ouster
description: Gunfire crackled through Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, today as police officers battled protesters demanding the ouster of President H. M. Ershad and an end to emergency rule there, witnesses said.

title: I Was Totaled By the Bureaucracy
description: I own a motorcycle -- a three button, Brooks Brothers, wing-tip shoes kind of motorcycle -- and until a month ago it was still shiny, scratchless and dentless, after a year of avoiding potholes. That's when it was stolen from its legal parking space on East 69th Street. I called the the 19th Precinct.

title: China's Babies: Better 'Elegant' Than 'Red'
description: While there are no free elections in China to use in judging the popular mood, one gauge of the people's sentiment is the names bestowed upon children.

title: India Announces Its Success In an Antitank Missile Test
description: India announced today that is had successfully tested the latest in its series of missiles, a short- range antitank weapon.

title: GORBACHEV TAKES BLAME FOR CRISIS
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev pronounced himself and other Communists "guilty before the working class" today in a discussion of responsibility for the country's economic crisis and political paralysis.

title: Paine Webber Is Said to Plan More Layoffs
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. plans to cut as much as 9 percent of its investment banking staff next week, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: Guatemalan Military Makes Elections a Hoax; Voice of the People
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit on Redistricting Panel Could Doom Voting Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Carpenter Union Chief Faces Charges That He Took Bribes
description: Paschal McGuinness, the president of the largest carpenters' union in the New York City area, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges of accepting more than $66,000 in bribes from contractors.

title: For Children
description: Big Apple Circus Damrosch ParkLincoln Center212-874-6770 (Centercharge)212-307-7171 (Ticketmaster)Recommended ages: Toddlers and upThrough January 7

title: German Rail Workers to End Strike
description: Striking rail workers in eastern Germany agreed to return to work today, after the Government agreed to consider their demands for higher pay and job security.

title: F.D.I.C. to Pay 50 on $1 for Large Deposits at Freedom Bank
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation decided today to give 50 cents on the uninsured dollar to Freedom National Bank depositors who had accounts of more than $100,000.

title: With Art and Without, a Day for Calling Attention to the AIDS Crisis
description: With performances and exhibitions, shrouds and silence, arts groups around the country plan to call attention to the AIDS crisis tomorrow in the second annual Day Without Art. At the end of the day of "action and mourning," much of Manhattan's skyline is to dim for 15 minutes to dramatize the city's losses from AIDS.

title: San Francisco Journal; When Skies Are Blue, So Are the Forecasters
description: After four years of drought, with the state's reservoirs as dry as mud flats, weather forecasters here are swamped with angry calls and letters every time they say it's a beautiful day because the sun is bright and the sky is blue.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Cabaret Duo

title: Phillip Morris's $400 Million Notes
description: The Philip Morris Companies Inc. is offering $400 million in fixed-rate notes due in 1997 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Upshaw Sings Schubert
description: The soprano Dawn Upshaw is to be the soloist with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in Schubert's "Shepherd on the Rock" and selections from Schumann's "Myrthen" on Sunday at 5 P.M. The program also includes the Brahms Clarinet Sonata in F minor (Op. 120, No. 1) and the Mendelssohn Piano Trio in D minor (Op. 49). Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Scientists Genetically Alter Rats to Mimic Arthritis in Humans
description: Researchers in Texas said today that they had developed the first animal model that mimics a family of human arthritic diseases. They said the work had confirmed a long-held suspicion that a protein found in most patients appeared to be a major factor in causing the disorders.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 526 money market mutual funds increased by $198.0 million, to $423.76 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 160 institutional funds increased by $216.6 million, to $107.45 billion. The assets of the 262 general-purpose funds were down by $105.8 million, to $149.92 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds increased by $87.2 million, to $166.38 billion, the institute said.

title: S.&P. Is Reviewing Rating On Macy's $2.5 Billion Debt
description: The speculative-grade rating of subordinated debt issued by R. H. Macy & Company is under review with the possibility of a further downgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: 3 Fiscal Monitors Press New York City on Budget
description: New York City's three official fiscal monitors said in separate reports yesterday that the city's current budget remained, at best, precariously balanced and that the Dinkins administration must take even more aggressive steps to confront much deeper troubles next year.

title: A Savings Examiner Recalls Senators' 'Full Court Press'
description: Five Senators under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee engaged in a "full court press" against Federal officials examining a troubled California savings and loan institution, one of the regulators told the panel today.

title: Prosecutor Recalls Violence in Park
description: The prosecutor in the second Central Park jogger trial recalled for the jury yesterday the night of April 19, 1989, when she said about 30 youths "exploded in one giant outburst of violence" that reached a grisly fever pitch with the gang rape and beating of a 30-year-old woman who was jogging in the park.

title: The Stale Rules That Stifle TV
description: The sale this week of MCA to the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan means that foreigners now control four of the seven largest Hollywood studios. That's no threat to American pride or the content of movies but it constitutes an indictment of the way Washington stifles competition in the entertainment industry.

title: Dr. Carl Levenson, 85, Rehabilitation Expert
description: Dr. Carl Levenson, a physician who specialized in rehabilitation, died Tuesday at his home in Wyncote, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title: Accounts
description: * New Life Treatment Centers Inc., Laguna Beach, Calif., to AC&R Advertising, New York, with billings around $2 million. * US Entertainment Magazine, New York, to Goldsmith/Jeffrey, New York, with a budget of $1 million. * Lehman Brothers, New York, to Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, New York, on an undisclosed fee-by-fee basis.

title: Consumers Said to Retrench As October Spending Stalls
description: Consumer spending, the driving force behind eight years of economic expansion, did not budge in October, the Government said today. Analysts viewed the report as further evidence of a recession.

title: CNN Showed Courage in Airing Tapes
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Keeping Big East Tourney
description: The Big East will continue to play its championship tournament at Madison Square Garden through 1996 under an agreement announced today.

title: South African Blacks Meet to End Strife
description: Leaders representing most of the spectrum of black politics in South Africa met today under the auspices of the Anglican Archbishop, Desmond M. Tutu, to try to promote mutual tolerance and end the factional violence afflicting black South Africans.

title: Study Faults Atlanta's System of Defending Poor
description: At a time when jails and courtrooms across the nation are jammed, providing adequate counsel for suspects who cannot afford a lawyer is a common problem. But experts here and elsewhere say Atlanta's courtrooms are confronting a situation so dire that it raises questions about the system's ability to provide even the most basic legal representation for the poor.

title: Stake in Microtest Is Bought by Intel
description: The Intel Corporation said it had purchased a minority interest in Microtest Inc., a Phoenix-based maker of diagnostic equipment for local-area networks that link computers. Microtest is closely held, and terms of the deal were not disclosed. Intel licensed technology from Microtest last year for use in Intel's recently introduced Netport local area network, or L.A.N., print server, a specialized computer for sharing printers on a network.

title: Dr. Luis A. Amill, 92, Retired Internist, Dies
description: Luis A. Amill, a retired specialist in internal medicine, died yesterday at Ocean County Medical Center in Point Pleasant, N.J. He was 92 years old and lived in Sea Girt, N.J.

title: Quayle Says Delaying War Would Increase Risks
description: Vice President Dan Quayle sought today to counter Democratic lawmakers who have urged a delay in any military action against Iraq, saying that putting off war would enable Iraqi forces to tighten their grip on Kuwait and might eventually lead to greater American military casualties.

title: Car-Racing Dreams Fulfilled
description: ON an island where the possession of a driver's license can sometimes carry a social stigma, it might come as a surprise that there is a place where you can race around in circles as fast and as long as you want and never have to worry about a summons or a cocktail-party slight.

title: The Phantom Lynch Mob
description: I'm getting tired of being part of a lynch mob. I didn't ask to be in it in the first place.

title: Review/Music; Of South Africa and Strife
description: The show on Tuesday night at the Knitting Factory, part of the Jive S.A. Festival of South African music, dance and poetry, had a nice relaxed feel to it. The music, by two groups, Sechaba Khoi Khoi and Mahube, was unpolished, but the audience, partly made up of both black and white South African expatriates, didn't seem to mind.

title: Court Says Prosecutor Need Not Have License
description: The New York State Court of Appeals, in a 5-to-2 ruling, upheld two convictions yesterday in cases that had been presented to a grand jury by an assistant district attorney who was not licensed to practic law.

title: Penalty for Holding-Cell Delays: $150 to Some New York Inmates
description: Frustrated by New York City's chronic violation of court-imposed limits on overcrowding in its jails, a Federal judge said this week that he would order the city to pay $150 to each prisoner held for more than a day in holding cells under improper living conditions.

title: It's Still Wiser to Jaw Than to War
description: The Security Council has "resolved" that Saddam Hussein should get his armies out of Kuwait by mid-January or risk war if he refuses, but there is little rejoicing in Washington over this surrender-or-fight ultimatum. For this resolution doesn't prove the U.N.'s determination to fight but merely authorizes the U.S. to do most of the fighting. It's sort of a Good Housekeeping seal of approval for war, a reassurance to President Bush that if he insists on fighting, they'll hold his coat.

title: G.M. CUTS OUTPUT IN THE LATEST SIGN OF ECONOMIC SLUMP
description: The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest industrial company, said today that it was sharply cutting back its production for the rest of the year because of the weakening American economy.

title: Hard Data Lacking on Iraqi Nuclear Threat
description: The recent flurry of seemingly conflicting statements by American officials about when Iraq might develop nuclear weapons is partly owing to a shortage of solid intelligence and definitive assessments on the issue, Government experts on the topic say.

title: Review/Film; Of Newlyweds And Their Life Under Scrutiny
description: In William Klein's 1976 satire "The Model Couple," two guileless and gullible French newlyweds are recruited for an experiment of national importance. With televised fanfare and an overabundance of scientific zeal, Jean-Michel (Andre Dussollier) and Claudine (Anemone) are installed in an antiseptic "happiness capsule," an apartment in which every aspect of their lives can be monitored.

title: Reviews/Art; Echoes of 60's and 70's Among the Young and Little Known
description: At any given moment in New York's galleries, there is work by young, relatively unknown artists waiting to be discovered. But this weekend, such art is unusually abundant in SoHo. While the quality is uneven, the work still indicates the esthetic inclinations of artists who have exhibited only a little or, in some cases, never before.

title: Independent Watchdog Takes Post at C.I.A.
description: A former undercover officer in the Central Intelligence Agency began work today as the C.I.A.'s first independent inspector general, ending a long and bitter dispute between Congress and Bush Adminstration over the need for outside monitoring of the espionage department.

title: Ford-Volkswagen Plan for Portugal
description: The Ford Motor Company and Volkswagen A.G. are negotiating to jointly produce a new multipurpose vehicle in Portugal, the president of Ford of Europe said. Lindsey Halstead said a final decision on the $2.5 billion project depended on continuing economic feasibility studies by the car makers, as well as support from the European Community.

title: Roger C. Harvey, 61; Produced Commercials
description: Roger C. Harvey, an advertising executive and producer of television commercials, including the Timex "takes a licking and keeps on ticking" ads, died on Sunday in Plantation, Fla., where he lived. He was 61 years old.

title: Burton Goldberg, 62, Computer Consultant
description: Burton S. Goldberg, a computer-information technolgy consultant and a retired executive of I.B.M., died on Sunday while swimming at the White Plains Y.M.C.A. He was 62 years old and lived in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Israeli Linked to Drug Traffickers Convicted of Illegal Arms Exports
description: An Israeli Army reserve officer accused by Colombia of arming and training drug traffickers was convicted today by an Israeli court of illegally exporting weapons and his military expertise.

title: Schools Chief Strips a Board Of Some Power
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday stripped a Queens school board of the power to appoint principals and assistant principals after it refused to obey his rules on how to select them.

title: Bridge
description: Two Chicago experts led into the final two sessions of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today, and there was a cosmopolitan flavor about their pursuers.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Hare's 'Racing Demon'

title: Drug Office Would Have New Voice Under Florida's Low-Key Governor
description: As the Governor of Florida, Bob Martinez doubled the state's prison cells, stiffened penalties for drug dealers and advocated wider use of American military forces in operations against drug activities abroad.

title: Guatemalan Military Makes Elections a Hoax; An Everyday Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Prosecutors Win Who-Indicts-Gotti Fight
description: Resolving a jurisdictional dispute, the Justice Department has authorized Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn to seek an indictment of John Gotti next month on charges that he is the boss of America's most powerful Mafia group, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Will U.N. Action Make a War Likely Or Add to Diplomatic Maneuvering?
description: The decision by the Security Council setting a time after which force could be used against Iraq has had the effect of igniting a fuse under the Persian Gulf crisis. By making Jan. 15 the date by which Iraqi troops must get out of Kuwait or face military action, the Security Council, at the urging of the United States, has made it much more difficult for the gulf crisis to continue without resolution indefinitely.

title: Call of the Wild, Where Spaces Aren't for Parking
description: A FEW weeks ago when a news-magazine poll found that a very large percentage of New Yorkers would rather be somewhere else, a Midwestern friend suggested that the real news story existed elsewhere, too. How does the rest of the country feel, he wondered, about the prospect of several million New Yorkers suddenly descending on them?

title: Galileo Spacecraft Heads to Earth For Gravity Assist Toward Jupiter
description: An interplanetary spacecraft is headed for Earth.

title: Market Place; Investors Flocking to Stock Funds
description: This year is shaping up as the worst one in a decade for the stock market, but mutual fund investors have responded by buying shares in stock funds at a record pace.

title: An Outsider Is Named To Top Steelcase Posts
description: Steelcase Inc., the big maker of office furniture, has reached out of its industry for a new president and chief executive, naming Jerry K. Myers to the positions.

title: Hollinger in a Premier
description: The oboist Heinz Hollinger is to be the soloist with the Zurich Tonhalle Orchestrea in the New York City premiere of Bernd Alois Zimmermann's Concerto for Oboe and Orchestra at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8. The program, to be conducted by Matthias Bamert, also includes Ravel's "Tombeau de Couperin," Haydn's Symphony No. 82 in C and Mozart's Violin Concerto in A (K.219). Bettina Boller is to be the soloist in the Mozart. Tickets are $10 to $23. Information: (212) 247-7800

title: Economic Scene; Protecting Banks In a Severe Slump
description: IN his meeting with bankers in Washington yesterday, President Bush sought to reinforce the message they have been getting from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan: that the Government is well aware of its responsibility not only to protect the safety and soundness of commercial banks but also to insure their economic viability.

title: Another Injury Jolts Jets' Starting Offensive Line
description: Murphy's Law continued its rampage through the Jets' offensive line as one more thing went wrong: Brett Miller, the starting right tackle, turned up lame after pulling his left hamstring in Wednesday's practice.

title: Investing in Idealism
description: President Bush last week signed a modest new law that can greatly enhance volunteerism and community service. The National and Community Service Act of 1990, while spending very little money, will establish a host of badly needed volunteer efforts around the nation.

title: New Chief at Reuters To Take Over March 1
description: One of Peter Job's earliest assignments at Reuters Holdings P.L.C. was reporting about food shortages that had brought India to the verge of famine in the 1960's. Now, it appears, he will again be dealing with lean times when he succeeds Glen Renfrew, 62 years old, on March 1 as managing director and chief executive of the news and financial information concern.

title: U.N. GIVES IRAQ UNTIL JAN. 15 TO RETREAT OR FACE FORCE; HUSSEIN SAYS HE WILL FIGHT
description: The United Nations Security Council voted 12 to 2 with 1 abstention today to authorize the United States and its allies to expel Iraq from Kuwait by force if President Saddam Hussein does not withdraw his forces by Jan. 15.

title: Governador Valadares Journal; You Might Say, This Is the Town Uncle Sam Built
description: In the vast, arid interior of Minas Gerais State rises a tidy, thriving city that residents call "Brazil's best American town."

title: New Spira Indictment Adds Charges of Threats
description: Howard Spira, who in March was indicted on charges of attempted extortion of George Steinbrenner and making threats against Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield, was indicted again yesterday, this time on 11 counts, including at least 3 new ones.

title: North Point to Stop Publishing New Books
description: North Point Press, a well-regarded independent house, yesterday became the latest casualty of the hard times in book publishing when it said it would stop publishing new titles after its spring 1991 list. It will, however, continue to publish books on its backlist.

title: John Powers Madigan, Executive, 82
description: John Powers Madigan, a former vice president of the General Reinsurance Corporation, died on Wednesday at his home on Plantation Key, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Excerpts From U.S., Kuwaiti, Iraqi and Chinese Remarks on the Resolution
description: Following are excerpts from statements by officials of the United States, Kuwait, Iraq and China at a meeting of the Security Council today. Remarks by the Kuwaiti, Iraqi and Chinese representatives were transcribed as they were read by United Nations translators. James A. Baker 3d: Secretary of State

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Motorola Inc. referred incorrectly to the company's history as a maker of chips based on a simplified design known as reduced instruction set computing. Motorola does make RISC chips and has done so since 1988.

title: Defiant Iraqi President Declares He Is Ready for War Against U.S.
description: In a defiant speech delivered hours before the United Nations Security Council approved a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq, President Saddam Hussein said Thursday that his nation was ready for war against American-led troops in the Persian Gulf.

title: Cranston Says He Was 'Unwise' In Dealings With Head of S.& L.
description: Senator Alan Cranston conceded to the Senate Ethics Committee in a deposition made public today that his involvement with Charles H. Keating Jr. was "politically stupid and unwise," though he insisted he did nothing improper in exchange for contributions from the savings and loan executive.

title: Text of U.N. Resolution on Using Force in the Gulf
description: Following is the text of Resolution 678, which was approved today by the Security Council: THE SECURITY COUNCIL,

title: Australians Pull a Surprise Move at Davis Cup
description: The draw for the 1990 Davis Cup final, which will be contested by the United States and Australia this weekend on clay inside the imposing Suncoast Dome, was conducted outdoors in the midday heat this afternoon and offered up one blistering surprise:

title: Once Again Bush Says Economy Will Improve
description: After meeting with his economic advisers, President Bush reiterated his confidence today that the nation's economy would improve soon.

title: The Times Seeks A Labor Accord For a New Plant
description: With construction virtually complete at The New York Times's new color printing and distribution plant in Edison, N.J., the paper says it is poised to begin serious negotiations with the seven unions whose members will operate the highly automated equipment.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of California, Los Angeles, appointed Adriana M. Boeka senior vice president and regional manager of its office in Beverly Hills, Calif. * Davox Corp., Billerica, Mass., which produces computer-aided communication systems, named Lawrence Doherty vice president of finance and chief financial officer. * Electronic Data Systems Corp., Dallas, a unit of General Motors Corp., Detroit, appointed Joseph M. Grant vice president and chief financial officer. * International Business Machines Corp., Armonk, N.Y., named Pierre Hessler and W. Wilson Lowery Jr. vice presidents. * Norfolk Southern Corp., Norfolk, Va., a transportation holding company, named Joseph R. Neikirk vice chairman. Robert E. L. deButts and David R. Goode were appointed executive vice presidents. Henry C. Wolf succeeds Mr. Goode as vice president. * Novadyne Computer Systems Inc., Santa Ana, Calif., appointed Robert A. Garbutt vice president of sales and marketing. * PLM International Inc., San Francisco, a leasing and management concern for transportation equipment, named Laurence W. Berger senior vice president for its Transportation Equipment Corp. unit. * Quaker Chemical Corp., Conshohocken, Pa., appointed Clifford E. Montgomery vice president of human resources.

title: Treasuries Off in a Hectic Session
description: Rumors of shooting in the Middle East, later denied, pushed down the prices of Treasury securities during a hectic session yesterday, one in which dealers had to cope with disparate pieces of information.

title: Matsushita Shifts Stance On MCA
description: Attempting to quell political concerns surrounding its acquisition of MCA Inc., one of the largest entertainment companies in the United States, the president of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said this morning that the giant consumer electronics manufacturer "has no intention of becoming involved in decisions regarding the subject or content of creative products at MCA."

title: Evarts Ziegler Dies; Literary Agent, 74
description: Evarts Ziegler, a Hollywood literary agent, died Saturday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: Electronic Bond Auction Founders
description: An effort to distribute a new corporate bond issue through an innovative electronic auction foundered earlier this week, when the U S West Financial Corporation chose to sell its bonds through Merrill Lynch & Company rather than Capitalink, a New York company that has been promoting the electronic system.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: Books of The Times; At Dinner, There's Malice on the Menu
description: Symposium By Muriel Spark 192 pages. Houghton Mifflin . $18.95

title: Washington at Work; An Architect of the Reagan Vision Plunges Into Inquiry on Race and I.Q.
description: One thing Charles Murray knows how to do is generate controversy. In 1984, his book "Losing Ground" argued that social programs did more harm than good and proposed, as "a thought experiment," that the country simply abolish them.

title: CNN Showed Courage in Airing Tapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Choice
description: Ralph Kirshbaum, a cellist from Texas who has lived in London for 21 years, has overcome his instrument's limited repertory largely by making connections with composers and performing new music. English music, not surprisingly, has been a particular specialty: Mr. Kirshbaum has given the premieres of Peter Maxwell Davies's concerto "Strathclyde" and Sir Michael Tippett's Triple Concerto for Violin, Viola and Cello. And his discography, which also leans toward 20th-century works, includes fine accounts of the Barber and Walton concertos.

title: Using Porsche As a Yardstick
description: If you want to tell everyone around how great you are, compare yourself to a Porsche.

title: Child World Deal Ended by Trefoil
description: Trefoil Capital Investors L.P., the investment partnership affiliated with Roy Disney's Shamrock Holdings, confirmed that its deal to acquire Child World Inc. had collapsed. Child World, the nation's second-largest toy chain behind Toys "R" Us, has been experiencing financial difficulties. There were several conditions attached to the deal, including provisions that Trefoil be able to raise $230 million in working capital and that Child World's business remain stable.

title: Seattle Commuters Hostage to Wind
description: The fate of about 100,000 commuters in Seattle is blowing in the wind, and has been since the weekend, when two floating bridges connecting the city's downtown area to the eastern suburbs were disabled.

title: Developer Pleads Guilty
description: The General Development Corporation, once Florida's largest builder of planned communities, pleaded guilty today and received five years' probation for defrauding buyers on overpriced homes. After the proceeding, Federal prosecutors said an indictment naming four more defendants and nearly 50 additional mail-fraud counts was likely next week. The developer sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after the original indictment was issued in March. Under the plea agreement, General Development admitted to conspiring to defraud people who bought 1,500 homes for a total of $100 million from July 1985 to July 1986.

title: Review/Art; In an Archaic Manner, With Modern Overtones
description: Those who believe that contemporary art has lost both its sense of direction and its mind may be thinking among other things, of the work of David McDermott and Peter McGough. Messrs. McDermott and McGough, as they are billed in their current exhibition at Sperone Westwater Gallery, are New York artists in their 30's, but they present themselves as turn-of-the-century esthetes, complete with turned-up collars, Edwardian vests and top hats.

title: Sex Bias Found in Awarding of Partnerships at Law Firm
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that a prominent Philadelphia law firm was guilty of sex discrimination against an associate when it refused to make her a partner. The judge said the firm had applied tougher standards to women seeking partnerships than to men.

title: Key Rates
CHRONICLE
description: Pratt Institute is inaugurating its new president, DR. WARREN F. ILCHMAN, and honoring six men for excellence in design tonight at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center. Dr. Ilchman, 56, was previously the executive vice president of the State University of New York at Albany. He succeeds RICHARDSON PRATT JR., 68, a great-grandson of Charles Pratt, the founder of the Brooklyn design school. Mr. Pratt is retiring.

title: John S. Linakis Dies; Real-Estate Broker, 73
description: John S. Linakis, a real-estate and insurance broker in Jamaica, Queens, drowned on Wednesday in Highland Beach, Fla., said his wife, Yorka S. Linakis, a State Supreme Court justice in Queens. Mr. Linakis was 73 years old and had homes in Jamaica and Highland Beach.

title: G.E. Capital's $250 Million Notes
description: A $250 million offering by the General Electric Capital Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Reviews/Art; Maria Nordman's Exhibition of Permanent Transience
description: The work of Maria Nordman is an endless process of finding and losing oneself. Her magical installation at the Dia Center for the Arts is public and private, meditative and restless. Everything in it has the feeling of transience, of suitcases always packed, of portable floors and walls that can be carted here and there and be erected and disassembled overnight. But the installation is also still and silent, and the objects within it seem as inevitable as those in a Chardin or Morandi painting.
